headline: Vows: Marie-Claude and Robert
text: Marie-Claude Wrenn and Robert Myers, friends who met decades ago, married others and later lost touch.

headline: Does It Play in Punjab?
text: Writer David Rohde and photographer Tomas Munita report from rural Pakistan, where President Pervez Musharraf claims to be widely supported.

headline: Don Rickles
text: A look back.

headline: Bloggingheads: Camp David's Echo
text:
Former Israeli negotiator Daniel Levy (l), and former Bush speechwriter David Frum (r), debate whether the failed Camp David talks help or hurt prospects for post-Annapolis peace talks.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Clinton: ‘Everything Stopped’
text: With the hostage situation over, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton appeared obviously relieved but poised and delivered a brief statement before flying to New Hampshire to be with her shaken campaign workers.

headline: Viva Knievel, the Final Chapter
text: “When you die,” Evel Knievel told me in a 1998 interview, “I think your spirit goes on.”

headline: Welcome Back!
text: Welcome back to the Reading Room. Last month, an all-star group of commentators made their way through Tolstoy’s “War and Peace.” This month, another distinguished crew (see their bios on the right) will spend two weeks tackling “The Education of Henry Adams,” an American classic published 100 years ago this year. Well, sort of: The memoir, which covers the years from Adams’s birth in 1838 to the death of Adams’s great friend the statesman John Hay in 1905, was printed in a luxurious private edition in 1907 and circulated to 100 or so friends — including then-president Theodore Roosevelt — who were invited to return it with comments and corrections in the extra-wide margins. (Only three complied.) The book was republished for a general audience in 1918, the year of Adams’s death. An unsigned review in the New York Times Book Review called it “a book every American should read.” It won the Pulitzer Prize.

headline: The Church of Coltrane
text: A San Francisco church believes that the music of jazz legend John Coltrane is divine.

headline: Evel Knievel, 69, Daredevil on a Motorcycle, Dies
text: Evel Knievel, the hard-living, death-defying adventurer who went from stealing motorcycles to riding them in a series of spectacular airborne stunts in the 1960s and ’70s that brought him worldwide fame as the quintessential daredevil performer, died yesterday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 69.

headline: What’s Left When the Surge Is Over
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Cellular Sea Change
text: These are interesting times in the world of mobile technology. Pressures of all kinds — consumer demand, regulation, lawsuits, technological advancements — are driving American cellular service providers in surprising and welcome new directions.

headline: Primary-Care Shortage
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Sound of Movement That’s in the Moment
text: Silence is one of the greatest pleasures of dance. No campaign sound bites, no Britney bulletins, just profound messages communicated by powerfully articulate bodies. But disappointment was in store for those who attended the first performance of the Movement Research Fall Festival, devoted to improvisational dance, on Thursday at the Danspace Project.

headline: Short Seller Sinks Teeth Into Insurer
text: “I’m going to try to give shorter answers,” said William Ackman, with an awkward smile.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Going Back to High School

headline: Astor Son Withheld Valid Passport, Prosecutors Say
text: At Anthony D. Marshall’s arraignment on Tuesday, he turned over his passport. An expired passport.

headline: Pope Stresses Hope in Latest Teaching
text: VATICAN CITY, Nov. 30 — Atheism may be “understandable” when mankind is confronted with evil and suffering, Pope Benedict XVI wrote in his second encyclical, issued on Friday. But the attempt to banish God, he wrote, “has led to the greatest forms of cruelty and violations of justice,” whether through Marxist revolution or the science that produced the atomic bomb.

headline: European Satellite Project
text: The European Union salvaged its most prominent investment project, agreeing to divert 2.4 billion euros ($3.5 billion) of public money to bail out its struggling satellite navigation project, Galileo. Intended to rival the Global Positioning System developed by the United States, Galileo has struggled with money difficulties and lengthy delays after a consortium that was supposed to get the satellite network off the ground failed to agree on financial terms. The deal was reached after a round of horse-trading among national governments fighting over the economic spoils. Late Thursday, Spain sought to block the deal because it was not granted a ground station as part of the network. Madrid finally agreed to the financing plan Friday after indications that the status of the station in Spain might be upgraded.

headline: Peace Conference at Navy Limits Pranks
text: In Annapolis, Md., what is good for peace in the Middle East may be bad for the Naval Academy’s fighting spirit.

headline: American Skier, Inspired by Movie, Is Second in Downhill
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Nov. 30 — Most of the downhillers on the United States ski team are devoted to the 1969 film “Downhill Racer,” which starred Robert Redford as a stubborn and raffish young American trying to break into a sport dominated by Europeans.

headline: When Football Moves to the Head of the Class
text: Three of the country’s most talented and successful college quarterbacks — Dennis Dixon of Oregon, Colt Brennan of Hawaii and Matt Ryan of Boston College — are spending more time in the film room this season than in the classroom.

headline: Standoff Ends Peacefully at a Clinton Field Office
text: ROCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 30 — A man who claimed to have a bomb walked into Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign field office here Friday and took three campaign workers hostage for hours before surrendering to the police.

headline: Awaiting a Glimpse of Their ‘Gossip Girl’ Kin
text: You could tell the tribes apart by variations in dress: the tartan kilts and pleated skirts of Nightingale-Bamford, Sacred Heart and Spence; running shoes on the girls who had made their way over from Chapin and Hewitt; leggings and anoraks for students at Dalton, with its relaxed dress code.

headline: Soprano Backs Out of Met’s ‘Norma’
text: The soprano Renée Fleming has decided that “Norma” is not in her future.

headline: Motorola Replaces Chief With an Insider
text: Motorola said yesterday that its chief executive, Edward J. Zander, was stepping down, a development applauded by the dissident shareholder Carl C. Icahn, who said the company should use the opportunity to split into four parts.

headline: Head of Oil Spill Cleanup Is Retiring
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  A target of criticism for leading the flawed response to an accident and oil spill in San Francisco Bay this month, the Coast Guard captain in charge of the initial cleanup has announced his retirement.

headline: Cervantes Prize Winner Is Announced
text: Juan Gelman, below, an Argentine poet who was forced into political exile during Argentina’s “Dirty War” and wrote about his experiences as a political activist, has been awarded the annual Cervantes Prize, the top literary award in the Spanish-speaking world, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gelman, 77, has published more than 20 books of poetry. In the 1976-83 campaign that Argentina’s military regime waged against leftists, Mr. Gelman’s son and daughter-in-law were among thousands who vanished. The prize, 90,450 euros (about $133,000), will be presented on April 23.

headline: Iraq Seeks to Execute 3 Former Officials
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 30 — The political battle over a death sentence for Iraq’s former defense minister flared again on Friday, with Iraqi government officials saying they had demanded that the Americans hand him over for execution.

headline: Tug of War: Rationality vs. Regret
text: ASIDE from having opposable thumbs, what makes us human surely includes our sense of humor, the awareness of our own mortality  and, I would argue, the ability to want what we can’t afford.

headline: As Talks With Europe End, Iran Gives No Sign of Concession on Nuclear Program
text: LONDON, Nov. 30  Negotiators for Iran and the European Union held a new round of talks on Iran’s uranium-enrichment program on Friday, but the meeting ended with indications that the Iranians had offered no new concessions to ease Western concerns that Iran plans to develop nuclear weapons.

headline: Hey, Brother, Can You Spare a Spectacular? 75 and Still Kicking
text: Nothing says Great Depression like the tap tap tap of dancing shoes and a long, spangled kick line.

headline: Labor Pacts in Detroit Didn’t Ease Stocks’ Slide
text: DETROIT, Nov. 30 — Detroit auto companies have long expected a quid pro quo from Wall Street when it came to their dealings with the United Automobile Workers union.

headline: Traveling With Troopers Has a Price in Privacy Lost
text: In January 2000, an odd little dispute spilled into sight. Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband had just bought a house in Westchester so she could run for the United States Senate. During the campaign, she was protected by Secret Service agents, just as all members of a president’s immediate family would be, whatever their pursuits. And of course, the Senate campaign often brought Mrs. Clinton to New York City.

headline: Rookie Plays a Good Game Instead of Talking One
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 30  David Harris does not look like a rookie, with muscles rippling off his 6-foot-2, 243-pound frame. And David Harris does not play like a rookie, accumulating tackles like a veteran Pro Bowler.

headline: Survivor Keeps CBS on Top
text: With the November sweeps period over, the reruns have returned, and several broadcast networks saw steep declines in the ratings on Thursday. CBS managed to remain No. 1 over all, thanks to “Survivor: China,” one of the few nonrepeats among the usual top-rated shows on Thursday. The 8 p.m. reality competition delivered 13.7 million viewers, Nielsen estimated, easily surpassing its rivals in its time slot, Fox’s “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” (9 million), a rerun of ABC’s “Ugly Betty” (6.5 million) and NBC’s “My Name is Earl” (6.6 million) followed by “30 Rock” (5.8 million). At 9, opposite repeats of CBS’s “CSI” (12.3 million), ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” (9 million) and NBC’s “Office” (6 million), Fox’s “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” (8.6 million) remained mired in fourth among adults 18 to 49. Fox finished third for the night in that demographic, behind CBS and NBC and ahead of ABC.

headline: Shanghai Tycoon Falls From Grace
text: BEIJING, Nov. 30 — He once was one of China’s richest and most politically connected businessmen, a real estate tycoon who had started out selling noodles. But on Friday, Zhou Zhengyi was sentenced to 16 years in prison, the latest powerful Shanghai figure to fall from grace.

headline: Putin’s Last Realm to Conquer: Russian Culture
text: MOSCOW — The fight is long over here for authority over the security services, the oil business, mass media and pretty much all the levers of government. Vladimir Putin’s Kremlin, notwithstanding some recent anti-government protests, has won those wars, hands down, and promises to consolidate its position in parliamentary elections. But now there is concern that the Kremlin is setting its sights on Russian culture.

headline: Paging Dr. Freud
text: To the Editor:

headline: Neither Sprain Nor Snow Will Keep Ward Off Field
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 30 — Let it rain, Derrick Ward said. Let it snow, too, and let the cold winds blow along the shore of Lake Michigan on Sunday when the Giants visit the Chicago Bears at Soldier Field.

headline: Lawyer Says Pakistan Heading Toward ‘Rigged’ Vote
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 30 — A corporate lawyer dressed in a pinstriped suit, Munawar Akhtar, 71, clutched a poster of a defiant colleague held in solitary confinement for three weeks, and marched Friday to the house of the dismissed chief justice of the Supreme Court.

headline: Deceptive Defense Fools Declarer to Stop an Overtrick
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 — At the Fall North American Championships here on Thursday night, the winners of the Blue Ribbon Pairs were Steve Landen of Ellicott City, Md., and Pratap Rajadhyaksha of Sarasota, Fla. They finished less than half a board ahead of Alejandro Bianchedi and Ernesto Muzzio from Argentina, with Marcelo Branco from Brazil and Diego Brenner, a Brazilian now living in Spain, third.

headline: Gospel Truth
text: Houston

headline: Philippine Authorities Hunt for Revolt Leaders
text: MANILA, Nov. 30 — The Philippine authorities searched today for some of the military officers who took over a luxury Manila hotel on Thursday in an attempt to stage a revolt against the government of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

headline: Russians Fall, Mostly, Into Step
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 30  Several years into an economic boom that has roused national pride at home and a more aggressive stance abroad, Russians will vote in a parliamentary election on Sunday that has been overshadowed by questions about the future role of President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: A Bid to Ease Credit in Europe
text: The European Central Bank said that it would extend a lending deadline in December to help the banking system through a period of unusually tight credit at the end of the year. The action represents a renewed effort by the bank to calm a lending system that had showed signs of returning to normal recently but now appears nearly as nervous as during the summer days when the global credit turmoil began.

headline: Food Safety
text: To the Editor:

headline: Calling All Volunteers (the Baby Boomer Kind)
text: To the Editor:

headline: That Same Old Beat, With Brand-New Choices
text: Darmstadt: Classics of the Avant-Garde, a series of monthly concerts at Galapagos in Brooklyn, celebrates its anniversaries by rounding up as many Downtown musicians as it can fit on a stage and performing Terry Riley’s 1964 Minimalist classic, “In C.” The series’s third annual reading, on Thursday evening, redefined the work as a cross between a late-1960s psychedelic freakout and a more up-to-date extended dance track, complete with an insistently pounding beat. It was the most vital, audacious and energizing performance of the score I’ve ever heard.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A dance review on Thursday about the Ballet Hispanico’s “Palladium Nights,” at the Joyce Theater, misidentified the choreographer. While Tina Ramirez conceived the production and is the company’s artistic director, Willie Rosario is the choreographer.

headline: Mormons and the Bible, Every Word
text: One moment that drew particular attention at Wednesday night’s Republican presidential debate was a video questioner’s asking whether the candidates believed every word of the Bible.

headline: Jangly Idiosyncrasies With Institutional Support
text: It’s tempting to view the career trajectory of the saxophonist Rob Reddy as indicative of a broader shift. He belongs to the constellation of avant-garde musicians who spent the 1990s working in close orbit to the Knitting Factory. More recently, faced with leaner options, he has grown increasingly independent even while courting institutional support.

headline: Dozens Hurt in Train Crash in Chicago
text: CHICAGO, Nov. 30  An Amtrak train slammed into the back of a freight train on the city’s South Side on Friday, sending about 70 people to the hospital, 8 with serious or critical injuries, the authorities said.

headline: Come Back to Bollywood
text: Denver’s an odd place for a Bollywood goddess, but that’s where Madhuri Dixit, India’s biggest female star of the 1990s, has been leading a Clark Kent-type life, married and raising children. Ms. Dixit has been gone from the screen for five years, long enough for a new crop of stars to emerge and for “Aaja Nachle,” her modest new film, to be a comeback vehicle.

headline: As Always, an Unequal Pie
text: THE distribution of wealth lies at the heart of political economics. Nations and empires have risen and fallen, and millions have died, as a result of humanity’s struggle to decide how (or whether) to divide wealth.

headline: Why I Parted Ways With Chávez
text: Caracas, Venezuela

headline: Lawyer Charged in Astor Case Has Been a Beneficiary in Clients’ Wills
text: Ever since the family battle broke out over Brooke Astor’s care and fortune, most of the attention has focused on her only son, Anthony D. Marshall, 83, who served as the steward of his mother’s finances for more than a quarter-century. But indicted this week along with Mr. Marshall was a lawyer with a troubled legal career who has faced disciplinary action in at least two states.

headline: This Situation Calls for Divorce, Sooner the Better
text: It’s sad to think, we’re not going to make it

headline: In Settlement, Charity Will Split Its Assets
text: The Internal Revenue Service issued a ruling on Friday that clears the way for the settlement of a long-running dispute between Tennessee and Mississippi over a private foundation.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Nigeria Turns From Harsher Side of Islamic Law
text: KANO, Nigeria  Just last year, the morality police roamed these streets in dusky blue uniforms and black berets, brandishing cudgels at prayer shirkers and dragging fornicators into Islamic courts to face sentences like death by public stoning.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,871 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: I.Q. Debate Adds a Chapter Online
text: Ever since the Nobel prize winner James D. Watson asserted six weeks ago that Africans have innately lower intelligence, fervid debates about race, genes and I.Q. have sprung up on the Web, in publications and in conference rooms.

headline: A Surgeon Opens Up, and Not With a Scalpel
text: DOCTORS are sometimes viewed as an arrogant bunch, and no doctors more so than surgeons — which is perhaps not surprising considering that the decisions they make every day are literally life and death. But Dr. Thomas R. Russell, the executive director of the American College of Surgeons, hardly fits that stereotype.

headline: Rudy’s Security Blanket
text: Rudy Giuliani has been having a bad week. Or, as he might put it, suffering persecutions never seen upon this planet since Mel Gibson was tortured on the rack, castrated, disemboweled and beheaded in “Braveheart.”

headline: No Escape From Reality, Even for Magical Horses
text: A theatergoer’s heart could be forgiven for sinking upon learning that the production she was scheduled to see at Theater for the New City was a riff on Dante called “The Divine Reality Comedy” and featured a “Born to Buy” critique set in “Paradise.” But that heart lifted upon hearing that Peter Schumann’s ragtag collective, the Bread and Puppet Theater, was the company undertaking said riff.

headline: The Power of Arts Education
text: To the Editor:

headline: Endangered Species
text: In early June, the Audubon Society released a report chronicling the disturbing decline of some of America’s most common bird species. This week, it issued a grim sequel: a survey that highlights the status of the species in most serious trouble, those at or near the verge of extinction.

headline: Motivating the Motivator
text: IT’S an old joke. A visitor is being shown around the office and asks, “How many people work here?”

headline: Calls in Sudan for Execution of British Teacher
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 30 — Hundreds of demonstrators in Khartoum, Sudan’s capital, poured into the streets on Friday demanding the execution of a British teacher who was convicted of insulting Islam because her class of 7-year-olds named a teddy bear Muhammad.

headline: Family Bonds That Hurt Also Heal
text: If Mignon Taylor had her way, she would open a craft shop and tearoom for the young people of Spanish Harlem, where she grew up.

headline: Russia Suspends NATO Arms Pact
text: President Vladimir V. Putin signed a law suspending Russia’s participation in a NATO treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe, intensifying pressure on NATO to make concessions, European diplomats said. Mr. Putin’s action, just before national elections, moved Russia a step closer to carrying out its threat to stop abiding by the accord on Dec. 12. American and Russian arms-control experts said they would step up negotiations. Russia contends that the enlargement of NATO to include Romania, Bulgaria and the Baltic states has given it too much muscle near Russia’s borders.

headline: Basque Militant Group Kills Spanish Guardsman
text: MADRID, Dec. 1 — One Spanish civil guardsman was killed and another seriously wounded in southern France today, the Spanish authorities said, accusing the Basque militant group ETA of its first slaying in almost a year.

headline: Mets Trade Milledge and Fill Two Holes
text: Two years ago, Lastings Milledge was mentioned prominently as part of trade discussions for the Boston slugger Manny Ramírez. Last year, the Mets dangled him in a package for a front-line pitcher. It was almost a foregone conclusion that they would eventually trade Milledge, which they did yesterday to the Washington Nationals, but on the surface the return was hardly as alluring as it once could have been.

headline: Recalling Days of Anti-Semitism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Down but Not Really Out
text: In the loopy medical thriller “Awake,” Hayden Christensen plays Clayton Beresford Jr., a wealthy young man who suffers a condition called anesthesia awareness during a heart transplant. Conscious but immobile, he gives us a voice-over play-by-play of the proceedings, and if you are one of those who viewed his portrayal of Anakin Skywalker as the ne plus ultra of lifelessness, prepare to be proven wrong.

headline: Counted Out, Knicks Show Their Resolve
text: In a development that can only make sense at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks closed out their best seven-day stretch of the season last night. They will understand if no one applauds the achievement — or even remembers it.

headline: Akons Day in Court
text: Charges have been filed against the platinum-selling singer Akon, below, who picked up a 15-year-old fan and threw him off the stage and into the crowd, where he landed on another concertgoer during a June 3 performance in Fishkill, N.Y., The Poughkeepsie Journal reported. Abby Rosa, the woman who was hit by the falling boy, suffered a concussion. An investigation led to the charges, which were announced by the town’s police on Thursday. Akon is scheduled to appear in court Monday morning to face a misdemeanor charge of endangering the welfare of a minor and a charge of second-degree harassment. During a concert in April in Trinidad, Akon invited a girl onstage and simulated having sex with her. When it was later discovered that she was 14, he apologized. Akon’s latest album, “Konvicted,” has sold more than a million copies in the United States.

headline: Charge the Rent, but Only if You Don’t Need To
text: SEVERAL credit card companies have introduced programs over the last year allowing homeowners and renters to pay their monthly housing bills with a credit card. For the cash savvy, the program is a potential windfall, allowing users to rack up rewards points that qualify them for free trips and other perks.

headline: Jurors Ordered to Hearing on Bias Remarks
text: BOSTON, Nov. 30  A Superior Court judge has ordered a jury that convicted a black man of the rape and murder of a white fashion writer in 2002 on Cape Cod back to court for a rare public hearing to consider whether racial bias influenced the verdict.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article in some copies yesterday about Dallas’s 37-27 victory over Green Bay misstated the Cowboys’ status for the N.F.L. playoffs and the number of field goals by their kicker, Nick Folk. Dallas has clinched a playoff berth; it does not need New Orleans and Arizona to lose tomorrow. And Folk kicked three field goals, not four.

headline: None Survive Turkish Plane Crash
text: ISTANBUL, Nov. 30 — A Turkish passenger jet crashed in the mountains of western Turkey early Friday, killing all 57 people on board, including several prominent nuclear physicists on their way to a conference, Turkish authorities said.

headline: Strike Prompts Layoffs at NBC
text: NBC yesterday laid off the nonwriting staff members of its two late-night entertainment shows, the “Tonight Show With Jay Leno” and “Late Night with Conan O’Brien,” because of the strike by Hollywood scriptwriters.

headline: Sunday Religion, Inspired by Saturday Nights
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Venezuela: Chávez Ready to Rule Until 2050
text: Wrapping up his campaign for changes to the Constitution before tens of thousands of supporters in Caracas, President Hugo Chávez delivered a speech threatening the moneyed elite, investors from Spain, foreign correspondents, the United States and “pitiyanquis,” a term loosely translated as “Yankee lovers.” He also ordered soldiers to occupy oil installations ahead of the referendum tomorrow, threatening to cut off oil exports to the United States in the event of American interference. “Who votes yes is for Chávez,” he said. “Who votes no is voting for George W. Bush.” Mr. Chávez devoted almost none of his speech to the 69 amendments in the vote, which would centralize power in the president’s hands and abolish his term limits. He said he could see himself ruling until 2050, when he would turn 96. The tensions led the United States to break its silence. “We are concerned that people would not be able to have the free and fair elections that they deserve,” said Dana Perino, the White House spokeswoman.

headline: Your College Application: The Real You?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Sponsor for Tanglewood
text: The Boston Symphony Orchestra said yesterday that Bank of America would make a seven-figure donation over five years to its Tanglewood summer music festival, starting next year. The parties declined to give a precise dollar figure. The festival also announced next summer’s offerings. Highlights include a two-part concert performance of Berlioz’s opera “Les Troyens” by the Boston Symphony; performances of Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin”; “Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny,” by Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht; and the festival’s student orchestra.

headline: Israeli Rocket Kills 5 in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 — Five members of the Hamas armed wing were killed early today by an Israeli rocket strike inside southern Gaza, near the village of Abassan. An additional eight gunmen were wounded, one critically, according to the Health Ministry in Gaza, as the airstrikes were followed up by helicopter gunship attacks.

headline: A Urinetown Suit Is Settled
text: A suit filed last year by members of the creative team behind the 2002 Broadway production of “Urinetown! The Musical,” which argued that a production of the show in Chicago copied their work without permission, was settled on Thursday. In the settlement, those involved with the Chicago production acknowledged that it contained “original and creative works” from the Broadway production and agreed to pay an undisclosed sum. The eyebrow-raising part of the lawsuit was the charge that Chicago copied the stage direction of the 2002 New York production. Some design elements and choreography are protected under copyright law, but there has not been a conclusive ruling on whether a director’s work is protected. John Rando, the director of the Broadway production, applied for copyright protection for his work but was turned down, and the Department of Justice intervened in the case, saying that the federal copyright office had acted properly in rejecting Mr. Rando’s plea. A separate, similar lawsuit involving a dinner theater production of “Urinetown” in Akron, Ohio, is still pending.

headline: U.S. Urges Freezing Some Rates on Loans
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Treasury Department is leaning on mortgage lenders to temporarily freeze the interest rates on subprime loans for homeowners threatened with foreclosure, but the scope of any relief will depend on crucial details.

headline: Andrew Foldi, Opera Singer and Educator, Dies at 81
text: Andrew Foldi, a bass who sang character roles for decades at the Chicago Lyric Opera, the Metropolitan Opera and other houses and later directed the Chicago Lyric Opera Center for young artists, died on Nov. 21 in Federal Way, Wash. He was 81.

headline: Iran Offers No Concessions in Nuclear Talks
text: LONDON, Nov. 30 — Negotiators for Iran and the European Union held a new round of talks today on Iran’s uranium enrichment program, but the meeting ended with indications that the Iranians had offered no new concessions to ease Western concerns that Iran plans to develop nuclear weapons.

headline: Rambo and the G.O.P.
text: I don’t know if children should be allowed to watch the Republican presidential debates.

headline: Thompson Bid, Criticized as Sleepy, Is at the Least Unconventional
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 29  Fred D. Thompson promised even before formally announcing his candidacy for president that he would not run a customary campaign. He was not kidding.

headline: Google to Join Spectrum Auction
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  Seeking to shake up the wireless industry, Google said Friday that it was preparing to take part in the federal government’s auction of radio frequencies that could be used to deliver the next generation of Internet and mobile phone services to consumers.

headline: Message Sent in Sentencing of Two Vick Co-Defendants
text: In sentencing two of Michael Vick’s co-defendants yesterday to longer prison terms than the government had recommended, United States District Court Judge Henry E. Hudson demonstrated an independence that could hurt Vick’s chance of gaining a reduced sentence, legal experts said.

headline: Wall St. Sees Silver Lining in Economy
text: As Wall Street rallied this week, it seemed that investors were taking comfort in the notion that the economy had become so imperiled by the crumbling housing market that it was forcing the government to finally mount an aggressive rescue effort.

headline: Corzine’s Slow Pace on Plan for Toll Roads Benefits Its Foes
text: One top New Jersey official says tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike are bound to triple. Another warns commuters to expect a 50 percent increase. Still others tell drivers to brace for a higher gasoline tax as well as a toll rise.

headline: Defense Ends Its Arguments in Terrorism Trial in Miami
text: MIAMI, Nov. 30  The lawyers representing seven men standing trial here on charges of planning to wage an armed insurrection against the government wrapped up their closing arguments on Friday and sought to portray their clients as young, misguided indigents rather than, as the government contends, homegrown terrorists eager to do Al Qaeda’s bidding.

headline: Proof That Overscheduled Modern Life Isn’t Fit for a Dog
text: EARLY one recent Saturday morning, Steffi woke me with another uninvited lick on the lips. I rolled over, but it was no use. She pawed across the pillows, licking my neck. My wife, Alison, was still fast asleep. I noticed that our 10-year-old son, Harrison, had wandered in from his room during the night. Steffi noticed the same thing, and promptly assaulted him with her tongue.

headline: City Urged to Rethink Rail Access to West Side
text: The city should rethink its development plans for the Hudson Yards area west of Midtown, Senator Charles E. Schumer said in a sharply worded letter to the city yesterday. He said that hundreds of millions of dollars budgeted for that work should be put instead into an extension of the No. 7 subway line, including a new station at 10th Avenue.

headline: Strike Halts Trains, Planes and Buses in Italy
text: ROME, Nov. 30 — Italy struggled through a transportation meltdown today, a reminder of the disruptions to daily life that crop up regularly in this beautiful nation and that can make getting about decidedly unpleasant.

headline: Estimates May Have Overstated Job Growth
text: The American economy appears to have created far fewer jobs this spring than has been reported so far, a new government report indicated yesterday. That could provide further impetus for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates when it meets Dec. 11.

headline: Lawmakers Set Deal on Raising Fuel Efficiency
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 — Congressional negotiators reached a deal late Friday on energy legislation that would force American automakers to improve the fuel efficiency of their cars and light trucks by 40 percent by 2020.

headline: Chad: Rebels Declare War on France
text: One of the biggest rebel groups, United Forces for Democracy and Development, declared war on France, saying the former colonial power was working to help prop up Chad’s president, Idriss Déby. A European Union force intended to protect displaced Chadians and refugees from neighboring Darfur is to begin deploying in January; about half the troops will come from France. Nicholas Sarkozy, the French president, brushed aside the threat and said plans for the force would continue.

headline: Israeli Court Upholds Gaza Fuel Cuts
text: Israel’s Supreme Court ruled that the government could continue cutting fuel supplies to the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip, which it has done since Oct. 28. But it ordered a delay on plans to cut electricity to give the government more time to respond to the groups challenging the plan.

headline: Roddick and Blake Give U.S. 2-0 Lead
text: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 30  Unadulterated tennis joy has been hard to generate for America’s finest men’s players in the age of Roger Federer, but there have been no Federer sightings at this Davis Cup final on a quick and friendly home court. And on Friday, with a sellout crowd of 12,000 providing the upbeat soundtrack, Andy Roddick and James Blake earned the emotional highs they have been seeking by staying faithful to their country’s tennis team.

headline: Italy: Strike Halts Trains, Planes and Buses
text: Italy struggled through a transportation meltdown as train workers across the country went on strike, buses and ferries halted service, and hundreds of flights were canceled. Even cable cars shut down. The unions want more government investment in transportation. “Nightmare,” said Emma Everitt, who arrived in Rome in the morning from Britain for a weekend visit.

headline: Saudi Rape Case Spurs Calls for Reform
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 30  The case of a 20-year-old woman who was sentenced to be lashed after pressing charges against seven men who raped her and a male companion has provoked a rare and angry public debate in Saudi Arabia, leading to renewed calls for reform of the Saudi judicial system.

headline: It’s December, and America Is Not in a Buying Mood
text: AMERICANS have grown much more pessimistic about both their own future and that of the economy, according to surveys being released just as the holiday shopping season gets going.

headline: Review by NASA Clears Shuttle for Launching
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The space shuttle Atlantis is to launch on schedule Thursday for a mission to the International Space Station after being cleared by a review of all elements of the flight, NASA managers said Friday.

headline: A Rising Number of Birds at Risk
text: Relentless sprawl, invasive species and global warming are threatening an increasing number of bird species in the United States, pushing a quarter of them  including dozens in New York and New Jersey  toward extinction, according to a new study by the National Audubon Society and the American Bird Conservancy.

headline: A Fuller Picture: U.S. Looks to Iraqi Data
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 30 — As the United States military begins to remove troops from Iraq, it plans to draw increasingly on Iraqi government data to gauge the level of violence and ultimately the effectiveness of the American strategy to stabilize the country.

headline: Roger B. Smith, 82, Ex-Chief of G.M., Dies
text: Roger B. Smith, the General Motors executive who tried to modernize the American automotive giant during the 1980s but instead became associated with its decline, died Thursday in suburban Detroit. He was 82.

headline: Uneven Day Caps a Solid Week
text: Stocks soared early yesterday but gradually gave up most of their gains as some negative news tempered the expectations of investors.

headline: Both Sides in Writers’ Strike See New-Media Future at Stake
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 — The nearly month-old strike by screenwriters has entered a new and perhaps uglier phase, revealing the conflict for what it has been all along: not so much a tiff over industry economics as a struggle for power over Hollywood’s perceived digital future.

headline: Nebraska Close to New Coach
text: Bo Pelini, the defensive coordinator at Louisiana State, is expected to be named the head coach at Nebraska, two sources with direct knowledge of the situation said last night. Pelini served as the defensive coordinator at Nebraska in 2003 and was the interim coach in the Cornhuskers’ Alamo Bowl victory against Michigan State that season after Frank Solich was fired. After leaving Nebraska, Pelini was co-defensive coordinator at Oklahoma. The hiring is expected to become official after L.S.U. plays Tennessee in the Southeastern Conference title game today.

headline: Turn Off the TV, and Get the Kids to Read
text: To the Editor:

headline: Top Ranks of Women on Wall Street are Shrinking
text: In 1982, John J. Mack, now the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, interviewed a fresh-faced Harvard Business School graduate named Zoe Cruz for an associate position in the firm’s bond trading business.

headline: Advisers Say F.D.A.'s Flaws Put Lives at Risk
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 — The nation’s food supply is at risk, its drugs are potentially dangerous and its citizens’ lives are at stake because the Food and Drug Administration is desperately short of money and poorly organized, according to an alarming report by agency advisers.

headline: Samsung Division Is Raided; Executives Are Questioned
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 30 — Prosecutors raided Samsung Securities, a financial arm of Samsung, on Friday, searching for evidence of a slush fund as they expanded the investigation into a corruption scandal.

headline: Return of a Long-Dormant Island of Grace
text: Stand at the center of the 1887 Eldridge Street Synagogue, whose main sanctuary reopens tomorrow after a restoration that took 20 years and cost $20 million, and gaze upward, past the chandeliers with their curled vintage glass, toward the 70-foot-high vaulted ceiling, painted with gilded stars.

headline: At Citigroup, a Favorite Emerges for the Top Job
text: Citigroup, the financial giant, is closing in on a chief executive and the board appears to be leaning toward an insider, according to people briefed on the situation.

headline: U.S. Pulls U.N. Resolution Disliked by Israel
text: In a diplomatically embarrassing about-face, the United States withdrew a draft United Nations Security Council resolution endorsing the agreement reached this week in Annapolis, Md., on starting Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations, a day after it was introduced and had attracted widespread support from the Council’s 15 members, including Qatar, the Council’s Arab representative. Israel said it had not been consulted on the language of the measure, and diplomats said that Israel objected to direct involvement in the peace process of the United Nations, where Israel is often pilloried. “We feel that the appreciation of Annapolis has other means of being expressed than in a resolution,” said Daniel Carmon, Israel’s deputy ambassador. Alejandro D. Wolff, an American envoy, said, “The focus, we’ve all realized again, should be placed and remain on Annapolis.”

headline: Poor Non-Urban Districts Await Corzine’s Revised School Aid Plan
text: The century-old building that houses Columbus Elementary School in Carteret, N.J., has become so crowded that art and music classes must share the same space. There is no high-tech language lab, so a Spanish teacher carries materials from classroom to classroom on a rolling cart.

headline: Twins Insist on Hughes for Santana
text: The Yankees’ chance of dealing for Johan Santana depends on their willingness to include Phil Hughes in a trade offer. After weeks of resisting the idea, the Yankees may be changing their stance.

headline: Saying No to Chávez
text: Since he took office eight years ago, Venezuela’s president, Hugo Chávez, has grabbed more and more power, exploiting his nation’s oil wealth to buy up popular support. Now there are hopeful signs that his plan to become president for life may be too blatant for the electorate to swallow.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Roger Smith, Former G.M. Chief, Dies
text: Roger B. Smith, the General Motors executive who tried to modernize the American automotive giant during the 1980s but instead became a scapegoat for its decline, died Thursday in suburban Detroit. He was 82.

headline: Witness Names to Be Withheld From Detainee
text: Defense lawyers preparing for the war crimes trial of a 21-year-old Guantánamo detainee have been ordered by a military judge not to tell their client  or anyone else  the identity of witnesses against him, newly released documents show.

headline: Run on Montana Fund
text: Montana school districts, cities and counties withdrew $247 million from the state’s $2.4 billion investment fund over the past three days after officials said the rating on one of the pool’s holdings was lowered to default. The fund, managed by the Montana Board of Investments, holds $90 million in Axon Financial, a structured investment vehicle, or SIV, that was cut to “D” by Standard & Poor’s amid the collapse of the subprime mortgage market.

headline: An Upbeat Moment for a Downtrodden Area
text: The inaugural festivities of the new New Museum of Contemporary Art kick off today at noon and continue for a celebratory 30 admission-free hours. Just east and south of the museum’s Bowery site, some two dozen galleries, many of them recent arrivals, are open for business.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A brief art review in Weekend yesterday about an exhibition at the Deitch Projects gallery, in Soho, misspelled the artist’s given name. She is Mariko Mori, not Moriko.

headline: Army Pays $725 in Set-Aside World War II Case
text: SEATTLE, Nov. 30 — A month after the Army said it made a mistake when it court-martialed Samuel Snow and 27 other black soldiers in World War II, the Pentagon has cut Mr. Snow a check for back pay, money withheld while he served a year in prison on a rioting conviction.

headline: Plucked From a Prep Powerhouse
text: SOUTHLAKE, Tex., Nov. 29 — For decades, the University of Missouri was a football backwater, a remote stop for powers like Texas and Oklahoma to romp through on the way to their seemingly annual glories.

headline: Is It Healthy? Food Rating Systems Battle It Out
text: At the grocery store, shoppers confront a dizzying array of labels promoting whole grains, reduced fat, antioxidants or vitamins. Some foods are said to be “Smart Choices,” while others are a “Sensible Solution.”

headline: Four Are Arrested in Killing of Redskins’ Taylor
text: The Miami-Dade Police Department arrested four people yesterday in connection with the murder of Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor.

headline: When Expectations and Exuberance Are Both Running High
text: In the archive of the New York Philharmonic are three batons that belonged to Leonard Bernstein, who was very picky about his batons. These treasured artifacts are rarely lent to visiting conductors.

headline: Progress Seen in Talks on Antiquities
text: ROME, Nov. 30 — After years of tough talk and high-profile court cases to force the return of archaeological artifacts, Italian cultural officials and American museum directors this week seemed intent on charting a new course.

headline: Evan Jenkins, 72, Retired Editor at The Times, Dies
text: Evan Jenkins, a retired editor at The New York Times who was an authority on the linguistic bugbears — “gantlet” versus “gauntlet,” “flaunt” versus “flout” — that keep reporters, editors and many others awake at night, died yesterday at his home in Huntington, N.Y. He was 72.

headline: The Girl Scout Effect
text: To the Editor:

headline: Colombia Seizes Videos of Hostages
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 30 — Colombia’s government said Friday that its army had captured three guerrillas carrying videos, photographs and letters containing proof that more than 15 captives, including three American military contractors and Ingrid Betancourt, a former presidential candidate, were still alive recently.

headline: Sonatas From a Work in Progress Called Beethoven
text: Beethoven visited the violin and piano format 10 times: often in the early years, sparingly later on. People will know best the “Kreutzer” Sonata, sitting somewhere in the middle of the list and owing its fame as much to Tolstoy’s long short story as to its own considerable qualities.

headline: On the Auction Block
text: Documents including a top- secret German manuscript instrumental in the development of modern rockets and a copy of the Declaration of Independence, as well as early sketches by Charles M. Schulz and Theodor Geisel (better known as Dr. Seuss), will be on display beginning today in a preview of a books and manuscripts auction beginning Tuesday at Bonhams New York, Madison Avenue at 57th Street.

headline: Corrections
text: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday about Children’s Book Day at the Brooklyn Historical Society, using information provided by the society, misstated the day. It is today, not tomorrow. (Go to Article)

headline: A Pygmy Traveler Gives Voice to a Marginalized People
text: LYNCHBURG, Va.

headline: Behind the Stem Cell Breakthrough
text: The stunning announcement by Japanese and American research teams that they have obtained highly promising stem cells without having to destroy an embryo could help free scientists from shackles that have long hobbled their efforts. It is especially important for a critical field of research that is far behind where it could have been if the Bush administration and Congressional conservatives had not thrown up so many roadblocks.

headline: Radio’s Newest Strategy: Play a Hit, Again and Again
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30  For the millions of Americans who listened to Top 40 radio last week, it was almost impossible to miss “Apologize,” the string-tinged elegy performed by the modern rock band OneRepublic and remixed by the eclectic producer Timbaland.

headline: Exporting a Sport to China: How Do You Say Zamboni in Mandarin?
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 28 — Shortly before the Islanders played Ottawa on Wednesday, two broadcasters took their seats in the second row of the press box at Nassau Coliseum, near the Fox Sports Net team of Howie Rose and Billy Jaffe.

headline: Leadership Seems to Be Lacking From the Knicks’ Top Performers
text: As a marquee game turned into a nationally televised nightmare Thursday night, as the scoring deficit doubled from 10 points to 20, then from 25 to 50, the Knicks stared blankly around the TD Banknorth Garden  toward one another and past one another. If anyone had an inspiring phrase for his teammates, it either went unheard or unheeded.

headline: Mothers Scrimp as States Take Child Support
text: MILWAUKEE — The collection of child support from absent fathers is failing to help many of the poorest families, in part because the government uses fathers’ payments largely to recoup welfare costs rather than passing on the money to mothers and children.

headline: Firm Employing Bruno Handles Unions’ Money
text: ALBANY, Nov. 30 — An investment firm that employs New York’s Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, is managing tens of millions of dollars from New York labor unions, according to state ethics records and tax documents.

headline: Morrissey to Sue a Music Magazine
text: Morrissey, below, the former lead singer of the Smiths, is suing the music magazine NME for defamation after it ran a cover this week with the headline “Bigmouth Strikes Again” and a quote attributed to the singer: “The gates of England are flooded. The country’s been thrown away.” The magazine quoted Morrissey as saying that an immigration rate higher than that of other European countries had caused Britain to lose its identity, Reuters and the BBC reported. The singer said the interview was distorted and demanded an apology but did not get one, his representatives said, leading them to release a statement saying, “Our lawyers are therefore in the process of issuing legal proceedings for defamation against the NME and its editor, Conor McNicholas.”

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Rudy’s Security Blanket
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Dec. 1 column.

headline: Axles of Evel
text: Evel Knievel died on Friday, days after settling a lawsuit in which he alleged Kanye West stole his daredevil image in a music video. So the “College Dropout” has learned a lesson. When the rapper ages into his astronaut diaper years, he’d better not try the same stunt with Evel’s last ride:

headline: The grim truth
text: That’s the title of an article in National Review. What they mean, of course, is the grim possibility of a Democratic sweep next year. (Hat tip to Daily Kos.)

headline: The myth of low population density
text: Whenever I write about America’s lag in telecommunications — how we’re falling behind other countries both in wired and wireless networks — some people point out that we have much lower population density than Europe or Japan.

headline: Death In Moscow: A Cemetery Tour
text: By Sophia Kishkovsky

headline: The Rorschach doctrine
text: Right now, economic statistics are telling mutually contradictory stories. Gross Domestic Product, the usual measure of economic growth, surged in the summer; Gross Domestic Income, which should basically be an alternative measure of the same thing, was sluggish. Estimates of payroll employment grew fairly fast; other data related to employment did not.

headline: An arsonist and a fireman combined
text: Alan Greenspan.

headline: Romney Begins Taking Aim at Huckabee
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa—If there was any doubt that Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign was seriously concerned about the threat posed to them by Mike Huckabee in Iowa, Mr. Romney’s latest campaign swing through the state surely erased that.

headline: A plan called hope
text: Oy – I somehow missed the fact that the proposal to help subprime borrowers avoid foreclosure is called the Hope Now Alliance.

text: Whew. Friday was an unusually tense one in New Hampshire as a hostage standoff played out at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign office in Rochester. We live blogged the events yesterday, and more information has since emerged about suspect, Leeland Eisenberg, and the candidate’s actions during the “hostage situation.” From The Washington Post:

headline: Democrats Strip Michigan of Delegates
text: In a widely expected move, the Democratic National Committee voted this morning to strip Michigan of all its 156 delegates to the national nominating convention next year. The state is breaking the party’s rules by holding its primary on Jan. 15. Only Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina and Nevada are allowed to hold contests prior to Feb. 5.

headline: Strike News: Lay-Offs At ‘The Tonight Show’
text: As expected, NBC Universal laid off the non-writing staff of the “Tonight Show with Jay Leno” and “Late Night with Conan O’Brien” on Friday.

headline: Telemundo Dips Into Late-Night Talk
text: Telemundo, the Spanish-language network owned by NBC Universal, introduced a new late-night talk show on Thursday. (Telemundo’s writing staffs aren’t members of the writers guild, and thus they’re not on strike.)

headline: Greetings From Icy Iowa
text: DES MOINES — It took a while, but winter has finally arrived in Des Moines. And it is, on this icy Saturday morning a month before the Iowa caucuses, causing all kinds of headaches for the presidential campaigns.

headline: Trump Trauma
text: These are tumultuous times for flamboyant developer Donald Trump.

headline: The Times Drops the Puck
text: Stick taped? Helmet buckled? Good, let’s dump the puck in the corner and get this blog rolling.

text: Anyone interested in why I’m so obsessed with the balance of environment and human development, my thoughts on problems with media coverage of climate, and the genesis of Dot Earth might enjoy the interview below, filmed by Brook Silva-Braga for his new Web TV effort The Interviewpoint.

headline: 'Well-Adjusted'
text: When I first started reading about adoption, I kept coming across the words "well-adjusted adoptee." In 1970s the thinking was that adoptees should be content with their present lives and not think about their adoptions. I read studies on the Internet in the 1990s and it seemed little had changed. Questions beyond childhood curiosity and looking anything other than "happy" would get you labeled as having psychological problems or "issues."   Technically, I was a "functioning" adult — a stay-at-home-mom who cooked, cleaned, took care of her children like most of my friends. I wasn't prone to depression though there were times when I would go deep into thought. I laughed and cried, felt joy and anger like most people I knew. The difference was that I had a dirty little secret. I was actually thinking about my adoption and its effects on me.   When people asked why I was digging into my past, my typical reply was that I needed to know the truth to pass on to my children. But there was more to it than that. Answering the questions of why, who, when, where and how might also lead to some understanding of myself. My experiences as an adoptee didn't have everything to do with shaping me as a person, but how much it did was something I'd never considered before.   There were moments in childhood that turned my mind to questioning. As a young girl, I found my green card in my mother's purse. When I was 10, the arrival of another Vietnamese adoptee redirected my perspective from that of the adopted child to that of a Vietnamese adoptee. Then there was Binh, who'd I had come across on the Internet. Binh was Vietnamese and lived in England. Our contact was the first positive experience I'd had with another person from Vietnam.  We didn't talk about adoption or even Vietnam, but shared an interest in movies and anime. It's sad, but our online exchanges were the first real interaction on any "normal" level I'd had with another Vietnamese person. He was almost half my age but thoughtful and compassionate beyond his years. Often our discussions would center on how we felt about the world and our lives in it. This set into motion a process of reexamination. How had I gotten where I was and why? My inner eye eventually turned to my adoption.   Struggling to put my life back into the context of adoption was infuriating and deeply isolating at first. Part of the loneliness was self-inflicted; I felt many wouldn't have understood why I couldn't just "move on." The one family member to whom I disclosed my need to re-examine my adoption felt I'd lost my mind and even gave that impression to others. He suggested counseling. I felt insulted. What I needed wasn't therapy, it was understanding. I hadn't lost my mind; I was going through a process of reclaiming it. For the greater part of my life, I'd simply accepted what I'd been told.   To me, the suggestion of therapy meant I was "maladjusted" and needed to be readjusted — but to what? Adoption itself wasn't viewed as "normal." How do you assign a norm to an unusual situation? As more adult adoptees have grown into adulthood and spoken out about their experiences, changes in the way society perceives adoption are slowly being made.   Today, it's more acceptable for adoptees to question, to seek answers and even mourn their losses as some of us often do. As long as we eventually come to some sense of "peace" and go about our daily lives, all is well. It isn't until some of us become critical that we are confronted by a revised version of "maladjusted." This new term implies the same thing as the old but with a twist. We've come to be known as "the bitter, angry adoptees."   When I first began writing critically about my adoption on my blog, I was surprised by this and even more so to learn I'd been smacked with the same label. While there were a few readers who tried to understand without judgment, there were still those who couldn't get past their misperceptions. People online who didn't even know me gave me well-intentioned advice on how to resolve my "anger issues." Others suggested therapy and still others told me to "grow up." It was still the same attitude, but the language had changed.  I would get e-mails from adoptive parents who would often argue that "things are so much better for adoptees now." But are they? I felt the statement was dismissive and showed a lack of understanding. The labeling itself seemed a sign that some things were not better. Why did it seem anger was not an acceptable emotion for an adoptee to feel?  Many adoptees have valid reasons for being angry. Should someone else decide that those reasons are not valid? Who defines socially acceptable norms? Based on what? I feel these are questions that should be asked. And I think that the answers are at the heart of the "bitter adoptee" label.   Just like many in the adoptee community, I'm not willing to settle for "better." To stop thinking about it now would mean settling into complacency. I know all too well what happens when the mind stops thinking critically. The pressure to conform to someone else's expectations can be overwhelming. In my desire to appear "well-adjusted." I resorted to denial and suppression. I became a chronic people-pleaser as result of my attempts to blend into my surroundings.  It would be a lie for me to say I'm not still angry. I am, but people often misunderstand what I am angry about. I came to terms long ago with the fact that I'm adopted. I've even begun to come to terms with many of my negative experiences that involved racism, isolation and even deception. Much of my anger comes from people labeling me with dehumanizing, dismissive and misleading terms. It also comes from frustration about the condescending attitudes we often face when we speak out. Sometimes it's simply conviction and determination.  There is a difference between anger and all-encompassing, blind rage. I write about painful, anger-inducing experiences because I wasn't allowed to explore them before. Writing publicly about them also contributes to the understanding of the complexities of adoption. As a society, I think we still have an overly simplistic view of adoption. While current studies may scratch the surface by studying the different aspects of adoption, the "either/or" idea is still prevalent. Adoption is either good or bad. Either you're for it or against it. The adoptee is either well-adjusted or maladjusted.  I think the reactions of some adoptive parents are sometimes rooted in fear that their children might turn out to be one of the "the bad ones." I believe most adoptive parents genuinely love their children. They don't want them to be miserable, but that fear is often based on that same all or nothing misconception. Just as adoption itself can't be painted over with a broad brush, neither can adoptees — as a community or as individuals. We also can be paradoxical in nature. I am thankful for what I have but I still mourn what I've lost. I can acknowledge my anger but still think past it to laugh and enjoy life.   Many of the adoptees I know who were initially labeled as "bitter" or "angry" have gone on to do some pretty incredible things. Some have become accomplished writers and artists, formed organizations, become socially and politically aware and active. Some have even entered the field of adoption as professionals. No longer content to adapt and conform, many adoptees are now working toward social change. The "angry, bitter ones" are just a part of a greater whole existing as productive members of that community.  For many like me, critiques on adoption are not just about our own experiences. It just began there. Our eyes have turned toward the next generation, to first mothers and beyond. It doesn't stop at our front door as we've begun to delve into subjects like adoption ethics, racism, civil rights, economics and politics. Angry? Yes, some of us are but sometimes that's a necessary element. History is full of examples. Should we dismiss the Boston Tea Party as a mere temper tantrum? Why are some adoptees getting a bad rap from some adoptive parents? I think it's because adoptees are still thought of as "the lucky ones," the ones who were "saved." What do we have to complain about?   Of course, I can only speak for myself. There will be adoptees out there whose experiences and opinions differ. "We" only refers to those with whom I share certain commonalities, nothing more. Yes, "we" have made progress, but many feel we still have a long way to go. Building our communities and support systems was just the beginning and it seems we're in it for the long haul.

text: When I first started reading about adoption, I kept coming across the words “well-adjusted adoptee.” In 1970s the thinking was that adoptees should be content with their present lives and not think about their adoptions. I read studies on the Internet in the 1990s and it seemed little had changed. Questions beyond childhood curiosity and looking anything other than “happy” would get you labeled as having psychological problems or “issues.”

headline: Rangers’ Defensive Dilemma
text: With the Rangers’ seemingly high-powered offense struggling to score goals this season, and their defensemen scoring more than their usual share of goals, the Rangers’ defense has gotten little critical scrutiny so far this season.

headline: Krugman’s version of his appearance is disputed
text: I say I’m 6’4″, and thin as a rail. But this version is disputed by Republicans and even some Democrats, who say I’m 5’7″ and could stand to lose a few pounds.

headline: Stealing Water to Survive
text: Abbas Wadi Kadhim provides for his family by washing cars in Baghdad using city water from a broken pipe.

headline: Housing Anxiety in New Orleans
text: A housing crisis in New Orleans fuels anxiety and homelessness years after Katrina.

headline: Armed With Faith
text: In Trenton, churches are trying to connect with youth before the gangs do.

headline: I Love Center Ice
text: After working most of the past 30 years on the night desks of newspapers, drinking foul cold coffee and eating bad takeout at my desk (actually, the takeout available around The Times could be awesome), I finally have the opportunity to partake of the magic that is N.H.L. Center Ice. It’s got to be one of the greatest bargains in civilization. (At $149 for the season and approximately 40 games a week for 26 weeks, it comes to 14 cents a game.)

headline: They’re Head Over Heels
text: This pair just flipped for each other:

headline: Personnel File: The Raiders’ Fargas Is Ready to Ramble
text: The only thing that has slowed Justin Fargas since he became the Oakland Raiders’ starting running back has been the defense of the Minnesota Vikings, which held him to 60 yards rushing. Fargas’s opponent today, the Denver Broncos, should not be nearly as challenging.

headline: A Science Challenge for G.O.P. Candidates
text: Some of the Republican presidential candidates have dismissed medical marijuana as unnecessary or “too dangerous.” Now they’re being offered $10,000 to come up with the scientific evidence.

headline: Miles Tries to Clear the Air
text: ATLANTA, Dec. 1 — Les Miles barged in front of a microphone Saturday for an impromptu news conference, saying he was the Louisiana State coach and intended to be the L.S.U. coach, in response to a report that he had agreed to become the coach at Michigan.

headline: Q&A With the Moscow Bureau
text: In the wake of December’s parliamentary election in Russia, two foreign correspondents based in Moscow for The Times, Clifford J. Levy and Andrew Kramer, took turns answering questions from readers on the meaning of the vote and the country’s political future. The forum is now closed for questions.

headline: Mock and Load! It’s Joke-Huntin’ Season.
text: Striking comedy writers have put down their pens, but it’s still a target-rich environment out there. Send your jokes via the comment link below. Here’s some fresh reader comedy:

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Masterpiece Home Theater
text: Don’t worry. I won’t get the “Water Lilies.” Although, to be honest, I’d consider it, if the image weren’t still so scented with memories of Muzak and fluoride treatments. It’s not a painting’s fault when dentists like it. And maybe those tranquil Giverny colors are just what I need this winter on my monocle-size screen when I’m alone, peering importantly at my BlackBerry for its little blinky company and moral support. headline: Welcome Back to Morgantown, Center of the Universe
text: MORGANTOWN, W. Va. — Just pulled into town for the second straight week, and needless to say there’s a tangible difference here in the atmosphere. Along with playing for a spot in the national title game, West Virginia is also playing its arch rival, Pittsburgh.

headline: Spinning With the Spin
text: ATLANTA – The L.S.U. fans do not know whom to believe. Is Les Miles leaving or staying?

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Dec. 2
text: Some of the most passion-inducing figures in contemporary politics are booked on this Sunday’s talk shows.

headline: Ending Famine in Malawi
text: The secret of Malawi's success in ending famine is heavy subsidies for fertilizer, farmers say.

headline: Clinton Is Pressed to Help Immigrants — Fast
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton got a reminder in Iowa today of just how divisive the issue of immigration is –- on both sides of the ideological spectrum. She drew a lusty chorus of boos from advocates of laws permitting illegal immigrants to become citizens as she spoke at the Heartland Forum, a Democratic presidential forum organized by a collection of community groups here.

headline: Live from San Antonio: The Big 12 Championship Game
text: SAN ANTONIO — With less than 40 minutes to kickoff of the Big 12 championship game here at the Alamodome between No. 1 Missouri and No. 9 Oklahoma, fans are beginning to slowly trickle to their seats.

headline: Pryor Knowledge
text: MORGANTOWN, W. Va. — For West Virginia, the most important fan among the 60,000 in attendance tonight will be Terrelle Pryor, a Pennsylvania high school quarterback. He’s the consensus No. 1 player in the country and seemingly an ideal fit for the Mountaineers’ spread offense. Pryor is most often compared to the former Texas quarterback Vince Young and has narrowed the list of universities recruiting him to Ohio State, West Virginia, Florida, Penn State and Tennessee.

headline: Big Moment for Big East
text: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — With West Virginia on the cusp of a spot in the national title game, Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese welcomed the opportunity to reminisce about some dark days for the league. Tranghese recalled that four years ago this weekend, Syracuse beat Boston College to put Pittsburgh in the Fiesta Bowl. (The Panthers were blown out by Urban Meyer’s undefeated Utah team.) That moment capped a miserable season for the league, which had lost Virginia Tech and Miami to the A.C.C. and was slated to lose B.C. the next year.

headline: Did You Write Off the Devils?
text: Just over two weeks ago, the Devils’ season appeared to be unraveling.

headline: A Scary Business
text: SAN ANTONIO — While the former Colorado coach Gary Barnett has expressed interest in the open Southern Methodist job, he doesn’t believe that sentiment is mutual.

headline: Rangers Catching a Wave
text: When the Rangers were struggling to score earlier this season, losing mind-boggling games by scores of 1-0 or 2-1, their opponents were all too happy to pounce on their weakness.

headline: The World’s Top 10 Clubs
text: We’ll be posting our World Club rankings periodically over the course of the season, a look at how the leading teams in the eight best pro hockey leagues across the planet would rate against one another. Theoretically, of course.

headline: Jobs Picture May Not Be So Grim
text: CONSUMER spending seems to be flattening out and home building appears to be in free fall, but most companies have shown little inclination to cut back on hiring. That picture may become clearer this week when employment conditions are announced for November.

headline: S.E.C. Sends Investors to the Children’s Table
text: TALK about a one-two punch.

headline: Death in the Family
text: "This will be my last campaign,” Booth Gardner said. “This will be the biggest fight of my career.” He walked along the lane between the beach of driftwood and his compound of houses. The driftwood clotted the shore; it was the end of summer now, and the cove was still, but in winter massive branches and trunks churn up out of the water of Puget Sound. Bone-white roots clawed at the air on this late afternoon; Gardner’s grandchildren climbed across them. His walk was a vigorous lurch. One foot twisted inward, one knee buckled. His torso keeled slightly with each step. He has Parkinson’s. He was governor of Washington State for two terms in the 1980s and ’90s. He is 71, and his last campaign is driven by his desire to kill himself. “I can’t see where anybody benefits by my hanging around,” he told me, while his blond grandchildren, sticks prodding, explored the water’s edge.

headline: A Place to Call Home: Something’s Got to Give
text: A long-simmering crisis in housing has led the counties of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Orange, Putnam, Rockland and Dutchess to unite behind legislation encouraging municipalities to build more housing that regular people can afford. It is called the Downstate Suburban Workforce Housing for Economic Sustainability Act. It is a solid attempt to confront a chronic suburban problem and deserves wholehearted support in Albany.

headline: Masterpiece Basement
text: If you happened to be in Tehran between 1977 and 1979, you might have seen the incredible collection of 19th- and 20th-century Western masterpieces on display at the Iranian capital’s newly inaugurated Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art. Only a handful of Westerners have seen it since, making a trip to the museum’s basement one of the art world’s most prized — and fraught — pilgrimages.

headline: Books of Style
text: THE GREAT FUNK

headline: Book Soup
text: On a late October evening, despie the haze and lingering smoke caused by the California wildfires — only the “H” and “D” of the Hollywood sign are visible — the Taschens’ living room still gives way to spectacular views. Lauren and Benedikt Taschen enjoy their perch in John Lautner’s Chemosphere house, a space-age showpiece from the 1960 that has been referred to as a flying saucer, a “Jetson” treehouse and, according to the 1961 Encyclopedia Britannica, “the most modern house in the world.” Benedikt, who over the past 27 years has turned what was a small comic-book shop into an international art publishing empire, bought the house above Mulholland Drive in 1997.

headline: Martha Sutphen, Richard Stock
text: Martha Rusk Sutphen and Dr. Richard J. Stock were married on Tuesday in New York. Judge Robert W. Sweet of the United States District Court in New York officiated in the bride’s apartment.

headline: Can Residents Agree to Lower the Heat Setting?
Gimme Shelter
text: How can you not be intrigued by a history of hotels in America that begins with a trenchant discussion of Immanuel Kant? “The father of the modern philosophy of international law and human rights,” as he is described, published “Toward Perpetual Peace” in 1795. He “proposed that international conflict could be ended only under ‘conditions of universal hospitality,’ in which ... ‘a right to visit’” belonged to all people.

headline: A Shoe Box Full of Sandwiches
text: Firehouse Deli falls somewhere on the scale between grab-and-go food shops that are little more than convenience stores and the kind of full-service delicatessens that offer just about everything.

headline: The Oprah Party Wants You
text: BACK in 1992, the Bush White House deemed Oprah Winfrey’s daytime talk show insufficiently serious for the incumbent president to visit. But in the intervening years, Ms. Winfrey’s couch, along with the easy chairs on other chat shows, became so attractive to candidates that the political world is now wondering whether Ms. Winfrey might actually hold the Democratic nomination in her hands.

headline: ‘Heil Hitler! Love, Bobo’
text: In this age of blogs and celebutantes, the aristocratic, letter-writing Mitfords may seem snobbish, quaint, even kitschy. But to dismiss them as dusty relics would be to miss out on a great deal of eccentric charm, wit and historical resonance. Those features are drolly captured in a 1933 letter from the 13-year-old Debo — later Deborah, Duchess of Devonshire — to Diana, who would soon become Lady Mosley (wife of Oswald), thanking her for the gift of a heavenly evening bag. “Thank you SO much for the HEVERN eveninger,” she wrote in Mitford family shorthand. “I even forgive you being a fascist.”

headline: Insider Art
text: Among contemporary art collectors — a world in which more is more these days — having your own private, architect-designed art gallery isn’t new. But hiding it in the side of a mountain is.

headline: Unholy Production With a Fairy-Tale Ending
text: PHILIP PULLMAN’S novel “The Golden Compass,” the basis for the new movie of the same name, is set in a parallel universe that runs on something called anbaric power instead of electricity, and where people travel in hot-air balloons and enormous, slow-moving zeppelins. Landing the movie in theaters, where it will open Friday, was not unlike inflating and then piloting one of these exotic, cumbersome airships.

headline: The Texas Tate
text: The British artist Tracey Emin asks me if I can stay on the line as she finds her lip gloss and makes herself comfortable on the bed in her suite at the Ritz-Carlton in Dallas. “I’ve shown in New York and now I’ve shown in Dallas, and that’s it,” she says, sounding incredulous about her United States presence. “This is after 15 years of being an artist!” It may be Emin’s first trip to Dallas, but it will not be her last: two of her biggest fans — the former director of a cheerleading supply company and his boyfriend — have just opened a foundation for contemporary British art in the city’s Uptown neighborhood.

headline: Hester Is Giving Bears and Fans Happy Returns
text: In Chicago, at least, kickoffs and punts are no longer viewed as a mundane transition from one football possession to the next.

headline: Dark One-Liners Shine a Light on the Mood of Serbs
text: BELGRADE, Serbia — “Why shouldn’t we be proud of our past, when each new day is worse than the previous one?” asks Aleksandar Cotric, a dissident-turned-politician, whose dark one-liners were once scrawled on banners during the demonstrations that helped overthrow the Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic in 2000.

headline: Change at Quarterback Gives the Browns Reason to Hope, for a Change
text: BEREA, Ohio, Nov. 28  It is not easy work dragging the Cleveland Browns back to respectability, which explains why the first-year offensive coordinator Rob Chudzinski skulks the hallways of the training complex with puffy eyes and dark circles, appearing as if he had just gone 15 rounds with a film machine.

headline: To Run for President

headline: Going Green, Luxuriously
text: IF the ski industry has a buzzword this season, it's “green.” Yes, all those snowmaking guns and high-speed lifts soak up untold amounts of energy, but thanks to eco-friendly capital improvements, skiers can schuss down the mountain this winter with a somewhat clearer conscience. Snow guns are using oil-free air compressors, mountaintop restaurants are being powered by solar panels, and carbon offsets can be purchased as part of your lift ticket. Ignore the S.U.V.'s crammed in the parking lot, and skiing might also seem like a sustainable sport.

headline: An Early Haven for Artists
text: Q I grew up in an unusual building, the Vermeer Studios, two side-by-side structures on 66th Street east of Park Avenue. We had 19th-century landscapes in our apartment, and I remember my father going next door to visit A. Conger Goodyear, who collected modern art, and coming back and saying “You can’t believe what that man has on his walls!” What can you tell me about the Vermeer? ... Eleanor Graves, Manhattan

headline: Map Quest
text: Maps make us incoherent. They replace speech and transcend description. They leave us awestruck and dumbstruck because they seem shamingly concise and often stunningly beautiful. The difference between maps and other data-conveying graphics is that maps exist to represent spatial relationships — direction, sequence and distance. And space is hard to describe in words.

headline: The People We Have Been Waiting For
text: It was 60 degrees on Thursday in Washington, well above normal, and as I slipped away for some pre-Christmas golf, I found myself thinking about a wickedly funny story that The Onion, the satirical newspaper, ran the other day: “Fall Canceled after 3 Billion Seasons”:

headline: Treating What Ails
text: BOTH my father and grandfather were doctors. I studied pre-med as an undergrad, but I found I had an extreme distaste for organic chemistry. It made me face myself in the mirror. I liked business, so I got my master’s degree in health care administration at Duke University.

headline: I Am America. (And So?)
text: From   Rudy Giuliani’s making “12 Commitments to America” to  John Edwards’s taking a “Road Trip for One America,” our latest crop of campaigners for the presidency seem to take for granted that the word “America” has a special resonance, that it defines something meaningful. But what, exactly, is it? America doesn’t take its name from an ethnicity nor from a clear demographic, whereas the French, say, owe “France” to their Frankish forebears. Despite the frequency of its use, “America” is actually somewhat difficult to define, particularly if we acknowledge that many people living on our planet who are neither residents nor citizens of these United States see themselves as Americans.

headline: Shana Warshawsky, Arye Dworken
text: Shana Beth Warshawsky, the daughter of Julie Warshawsky and Robert Warshawsky of Howell, N.J., was married on Thursday evening to Arye Dworken, the son of Susan H. Dworken of Teaneck, N.J., and the late Rabbi Steven M. Dworken. Rabbi Shmuel Silber officiated at the Puck Building in Manhattan.
