headline: Got a Hold on Me
text: The Beatles’ Second Album” (the book) is not going to work unless readers can find the equal of “The Beatles’ Second Album” (the album) in their own lives. But that’s fine by Dave Marsh. True, the 1964 record is among the first he goes to for “refuge and reassurance” when “the scent of freedom that leaped out at me from rock ’n’ roll” has faded like the smoke from yesterday’s joss stick. It’s not his only sanctuary in dull times, however, because “anyone who tells you there is a single greatest rock ’n’ roll record either doesn’t know enough to make the claim or doesn’t love rock ’n’ roll enough to be worth listening to.” My pick would be “Here’s Little Richard,” which appeared seven years earlier, though I, too, concede that a couple of decent albums have appeared since.

headline: No Gloating as Navy Beats Army for the Sixth Straight Time
text: BALTIMORE, Dec. 1  Their cleats clicking on the concrete floor, Army and Navy football players streamed side-by-side to the locker rooms after Navy’s 38-3 victory Saturday. Navy linebacker Irv Spencer paused to wish the Black Knights the best.

headline: Skis, Boots and Poles, Driven to Your Place
text: Let’s face it: skiing means standing in line. Lines at the lift. Lines at the shuttle. And, of course, lines for rental equipment. A new company, Door 2 Door by Christy Sports (866-323-7547; www.d2dskis.com), hopes to take away the tedium of standing in the rentals line by offering its full-service ski shop on wheels inside your chalet, condo or hotel suite. You tell Door 2 Door when and where you’d like the service (they are available round the clock), and trained employees will arrive for the fitting, armed with size and equipment information sent to them in advance. Items like jackets and gloves are also available for purchase and, on request, for rental. The Door 2 Door service is offered at 14 Western mountain resorts, including Jackson Hole, Park City, Sun Valley and Aspen. Rental packages of skis, boots and poles are $25 to $50 a day, including delivery.

headline: When Opportunity Came Crawling
text: WHEN I said I was going to become an exterminator, everybody laughed at me. They thought I was nuts. It was 1987, the year of the crash. I worked on Wall Street in commodities and I could see the writing on the wall. People were being laid off. My wife was pregnant, and I told her I had to find something else to do. One day an exterminator came to our condo on Staten Island and sprayed for two minutes and charged $25. I said, “Wow.”

headline: Now Wearing |Next-Gen Fendi
text: The Fendi clan has a new rising star, and it’s not a fur-covered tote. Delfina Delettrez, the 20-year-old daughter of the designer Silvia Fendi, is crafting jewelry laden with skulls, spiders and other creepy-crawlies. “I have a phobia of insects, and this is the only way I can touch them,” explains Delletrez, whose fans include Asia Argento and the family pal Karl Lagerfeld. She plans to open a boutique near Rome’s Piazza Navona around Christmas and is confident that the baubles — which mix materials like wood, leather and bone with Massa-Carrara marble, diamonds and sapphires — will be worn by her friends and by more traditional customers. “The minimum price is 300 euros,” she says, “and the maximum — well, it’s not very elegant to say.”

headline: Rethinking Plastic Bags
text: Two southern New Jersey assemblymen are proposing a partial ban on plastic bags. Though the proposal is controversial, banning plastic bags would be a relatively effortless way to protect the environment, save energy and reduce a danger to wildlife as well as dogs and other pets. It would also make New Jersey a lot prettier by cutting down on the number of ugly bags that get stuck in trees, on telephone polls and in storm drains.

headline: Images of an Island Emerging From Chains
text: The Yale Center for British Art’s fine exhibition “Art and Emancipation in Jamaica: Isaac Mendes Belisario and His Worlds” traces the history of Jamaica from the beginning of British rule in 1655 to the abolition of slavery on the island in the 1830s.

headline: Bibliogifts
text: Black is the new black. Walking briskly down Madison Avenue in New York, I passed the window of the designer DKNY, but the display therein slowed my gait to a lugubrious plod. All the mannequins in the windows were clothed in funereal chic — outfits suitable for matronly morticians at an undertaker’s convention.

text: FOR decades now, as a writer, economist and scold, I have been receiving letters from thoughtful readers. Many of them have warned me about the dangers of a secret government running the world, organized by the Trilateral Commission, or the Ford Foundation, or the Big Oil companies or, of course, world Jewry.

headline: Film on Mexico’s Disputed ’06 Election Stirs Emotions
text: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 — A documentary about last year’s disputed presidential election has drawn big crowds and generated controversy here, after its director, Luis Mandoki, waged a long battle to find a distributor willing to take on a politically charged film.

headline: Not Pretty
text: In “History of Beauty,” Umberto Eco explored the ways in which notions of attractiveness shift from culture to culture and era to era. With ON UGLINESS (Rizzoli, $45), a collection of images and written excerpts from ancient times to the present, all woven together with a provocative commentary and translated by Alastair McEwen, he asks: Is repulsiveness, too, in the eye of the beholder? And what do we learn about that beholder when we delve into his aversions? Selecting stark visual images of gore, deformity, moral turpitude and malice, and quotations from sources ranging from Plato to radical feminists, Eco unfurls a taxonomy of ugliness. As gross-out contests go, it’s both absorbing and highbrow.

headline: L.S.U. Ignores the Talk and Captures a Title
text: ATLANTA, Dec. 1 — The confetti rained down on the Georgia Dome carpet, Les Miles looked perfectly happy as the Louisiana State football coach, and his team looked just as satisfied with the championship of the Southeastern Conference. A season-long chase for the national title appeared to fall short and talk swirled of Miles’s possibly leaving for Michigan.

headline: Louder Life, Thicker Windows
text: BLAME the extra sirens, cars or just people, but many New York streets are noisier than they’ve been in decades, according to experts.

headline: Meteorologists Shape Fashion Trends
text: In the capricious world of fashion, where hemlines, fabrics and colors fall in and out of favor with breathtaking speed, designers and retailers have always relied on one constant — the orderly changing of the seasons.

headline: Now Filling | Art Pools
text: The Swiss artist Sylvie Fleury is making a splash with her customized natatoriums. At the Austrian home of the art dealer Thaddaeus Ropac, she used steel cutouts to spell “Be Amazing” on the pool’s floor; the edges are ribboned with words borrowed from a Prada cosmetics pamphlet. “It lists all the functions that the cosmetics are meant to perform,” Fleury says: “Revive, shield, hydrate, exfoliate.” Fleury, who says she is more interested in what makes us consume than in what we consume, plans to etch another pool in St.-Tropez with the name of Estée Lauder’s Pleasures fragrance. She’s also creating a soundtrack for it, mixing electro and bubbling sounds: “I think it’s so nice to hear music underwater.”

headline: Performance Upstart
text: With Damien Hirst reportedly selling a $100-million diamond-encrusted skull and Louis Vuitton emblazoning bags with Richard Prince images, it’s encouraging to watch the rising career of an artist like Mika Tajima. The New York-based Tajima incorporates many disciplines — performance, architecture, graphic design, sculpture, even fashion — into her art, making for esoteric work that isn’t necessarily an easy sell to the new breed of hedge-fund collectors. Yet to curators and critics, Tajima is onto something.

headline: Six Chairs, Less Waiting at Winter Park Resort
text: Winter Park Resort in Colorado is set to open the Panoramic Express, which will be the highest six-person high-speed lift in North America. Leitner Poma designed the mechanism, the towers of which were flown in to the resort by helicopter about two months ago.

headline: Tight Weave
text: Visitors to the Baroque tapestry show at the Met might not blink at the sight of Kehinde Wiley’s new creation. Like the artist’s oil paintings and marble busts, Wiley’s eight-by-six-foot hanging, woven in Belgium, mingles art history (a composition borrowed from François Boucher’s “Fêtes Italiennes” and botanical tracery from the “Besler Florilegium”) with urban swagger (the models were culled from the streets of Harlem). The unusual medium is as canny as it is curious. “It’s borrowing from some of the tenets of modern art,” Wiley says. “It has to be indecipherable to be worthy of our praise.” $15,000, produced in a limited edition of 48 for Cerealart. Go to www.cerealart.com.

headline: You Bring Leo, I’ll Bring Diddy
text: BEYOND a teak doorway on an unremarkable stretch of far West 17th Street, a hallway is faintly aglow. Carved into its black ceiling and walls are lines of nearly indecipherable script, each word painted with gold leaf, forming an excerpt from Darwin’s “Origin of Species.” At the hallway’s end, curvy leather banquettes outline a fanciful room where light fixtures fashioned from recycled bicycle tires evoke wizard’s caps, walls are upholstered in ostrich leather and mirrored open-air decks beckon from behind a fireplace.

headline: Navigating a Life From East to West
text: “I’M not very smart at business,” Tomoko Matsuyama said. “And I don’t know the U.S. market.” Ms. Matsuyama, a trim woman in a russet-colored sweater, tossed off the self-deprecating comments during a tour of her newly renovated town house on 152nd Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue.

headline: Signs of Recovery in a ‘Riot Corridor’
text: Washington

headline: Comics
text: Cartooning is always subjective, so when you look at political comics, it’s useful to think about where their arguments can lie — not just in their words but in the implications of their visual style. If you were to read only Andrew Helfer’s text for RONALD REAGAN: A Graphic Biography (Hill & Wang, $16.95), for instance, it would seem to be a straightforward chronological trot through Reagan’s life story, with particular attention paid to the showmanship of his public persona and his weakness for self-serving fabrications. Most of the book’s spin, though, is actually in its artwork, by Steve Buccellato and Joe Staton. After an opening montage of notable moments from Reagan’s public life, which might as well have been sketched from publicity photos, “Ronald Reagan” becomes a catalog of the sorts of visual rhetoric cartoonists can pull off: nearly every panel incorporates some kind of broad caricature or symbolic distortion, usually at Reagan’s expense. On a single page, we see a smiling Reagan hobnobbing with three other Screen Actors Guild board members while Jane Wyman checks her watch; then Reagan and Wyman sweating, smiling and pushing away enormous tough guys with shirts labeled “Union”; then a quizzical Reagan (with a question mark over his head) watching a man with a fez and a hammer-and-sickle jacket whispering in someone’s ear; and finally the editorial-cartoon shorthand of an eagle and a bear standing on a broken swastika and scowling at each other.

headline: Correction: Language as Sculpture, Words as Clay
text: An article on Oct. 21 about the artist Lawrence Weiner misstated the duration that manhole covers he created with the assistance of the Public Art Fund were to remain in 19 locations below Union Square. The manhole covers are to remain there indefinitely; they were not removed several months after their installation in 2000. The article also gave an erroneous description of Mr. Weiner’s personal copy of the Public Art Fund manhole cover in front of the Whitney Museum. That manhole cover is nonfunctional; it did not replace a working manhole cover. This correction was delayed because a reader’s query went astray at The Times.

headline: A Rocker Who Rocks to His Own Beat (and CD)
text: JERSEY CITY

headline: Season of the Kitsch
text: Who says I’ve never darkened the door of a museum? Though I may have a reputation for avoiding virgins and haystacks like the plague and I hit the Aleve when confronted with rusted metal arcs and sliced cows, I have been in what feels like hundreds of museum gift shops, most of which do not even require that you pay admission to enter. Why even as I write this, I am sipping my instant coffee from a café au lait cup decorated with the winsome French cartoon character Bécassine purchased in the boutique next to Paris’s almost impossible to find Musée de la Poupée.

headline: A Fine Blend of Places to Sip
text: THE choices read like chapters in a children’s book: Margaret’s Hope, Empress of Japan, Sweet Endings. At the Greenport Tea Company, you can even act like a kid in a candy store, lifting the lids on glass jars to inhale the aroma of these exotic-sounding teas.

headline: A Decade of Patterns and Promise
text: It is hard to argue with the broad aims of Pattern and Decoration, an American art movement from the mid-1970s to the mid-1980s. The artists associated with the movement wanted to reassert the primacy of aesthetic concerns in art, to make art that was beautiful and that didn’t require any sort of theoretical framework for understanding.

headline: Buildings’ Boards: Who’s in Control?
text: ONE of the most contentious issues in co-ops and condominiums relates to sponsor control of the building.

headline: Deadbeat Water Users
text: New Yorkers are spoiled when it comes to drinking water. The taste is good, the quality is high and the cost is reasonable, less than residents pay in other large cities, including Boston and Philadelphia.

headline: Learning How Local Local Food Can Be
text: Bedford Hills

headline: A Light Unto Nations
text: Marcus Tremonto is an artist, a sometime furniture designer, an architecture enthusiast and, as his latest series of electroluminescent Perspex works so aptly illuminates, a self-described “tech geek.” About 16 of these objects — including hanging light pieces, tabletop sculptures and paintings — will be on display (and also for sale) at Phillips de Pury & Company’s Chelsea gallery from Dec. 7 to 29. But are they art? Design? Design/art? Don’t expect Tremonto to shed any light. While he readily accepts comparisons of pieces like “Bahaus” (above) to chandeliers, Tremonto’s sci-fi versions are ultimately still lifes. “You aren’t exactly going to read by them,” he says.

headline: I’m Dreaming of an Eco-Christmas
text: “O Christmas Tree, O Christmas Tree, Your branches green delight us.” And, we might add, so do your energy-saving L.E.D.’s.

headline: ‘One Little Village,’ but Top-Notch Ballet
text: MYSTIC BALLET will open its season on Dec. 8 with “Fire and Ice”: Sergei Vanaev’s “Sonata,” set to Beethoven’s “Pathétique” Sonata, and the United States premiere of his forceful re-interpretation of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring.”

headline: He’s a Model? Consider the Odds
text: EVERY weekday evening, Simon Rogers rides the uptown No. 1 train from his job in the garment district to his home on the Upper West Side. He usually sits near the door for a good view of people climbing aboard, but on this day Mr. Rogers was seated near the center of the car because the train was crowded. Almost automatically, he began evaluating his fellow passengers, and his eyes found an older man in a newsboy cap and glasses.

headline: A Sinner’s Tale
text: Q: Your novel “Atonement” — the story of Briony Tallis, a novelist who tells a lie in her girlhood and hurts her older sister in a way for which she can never atone — has been made into a film, and I was surprised to see that you are the executive producer. Most novelists run from film, afraid that the care they lavished on their prose will be squandered. I know. Well, it will be squandered whether they run or not.

headline: Brut Force
text: Here’s a revolutionary idea to usher in the holidays: peace on earth, goodwill toward men. Trite and treacly, you snort? Evidently not. The new millennium seems dark and vengeful, sunk in a mire of militant theology and fundamentalist agitprop. Let’s toast humanism and prudence. Rashly optimistic, you say? Sticks and stones, I say. The Sipper is stepping up to the mike alongside Elvis Costello to pose the musical question: what’s so funny ’bout peace, love and understanding? And she’s anointing this radical vision with the most revered of holiday symbols, Champagne. Quickly, though, before it all vanishes in an Armageddon of supply and demand, karma and dogma.

headline: Now Booking | the Bunny Pages
text: Nina Garcia, the TV style pundit and fashion director of Elle, describes Star Von Bunny as having “the cutest tail in the business.” The makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury gushes over her perfect pink lips. And she’s known to strike a pose with Jean Paul Gaultier. But Star Von Bunny is not a supermodel or starlet. She’s a stuffed rabbit who is also the protagonist of “Star Von Bunny: A Model Tale” (HarperEntertainment), by Kym Canter, the creative director for the (ahem) furrier J. Mendel. In Von Bunny’s quest to become a model, she dispenses diet tips (“Always eat dessert”), takes yoga lessons with Christy Turlington and even has a go-see with Carine Roitfeld at French Vogue — complete with a knockoff of an Olivier Theyskens dress made for her 14.5-inch waist. Think of it as a “Pat the Bunny” for adults who have never grown up.

headline: Coltrane Slept Here
text: DIX HILLS

headline: Just Where Is Home for the Holidays? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nancy Knox and James Talcott
text: Nancy Stanton Knox and Dr. James Austin Talcott were married yesterday by the Rev. Michael L. Lindvall, a Presbyterian minister, at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York.

headline: What’s an Art Adviser, and Why Do I Need One?
text: The private consultant ELIZABETH FIORE explains.

headline: Californian Takes World Title at Children’s Event in Turkey
text: Play chess, visit exotic places, make new friends, maybe become a world champion.

headline: Making a Scene!
text: One season it was a fractured collage of New York City; the next, rolling hills with a river made from 600,000 pieces of candy, a homage to the late conceptual artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres. Then came a neoclassical villa plucked from Bernardo Bertolucci’s movie “The Conformist”; and last season, a giant video installation with models trooping down the runway in sync to a film by the artist Charles Atlas that showed them doing so in lingerie.

headline: Immigration Contractor Trims Wages
text: Workers who help process millions of visa and citizenship applications for a federal immigration agency are getting pay reductions just as the agency is facing an enormous surge in those applications.

headline: Huckabee’s Stature Rises, Mobilizing Tax Critics
text: As Mike Huckabee rises in the Republican presidential polls, fiscal conservatives have been raising alarms about a series of tax increases he oversaw while governor of Arkansas — new taxes on gasoline, nursing home beds and even pet groomers.

headline: If Bacchus Drank Cola
text: THE Calimocho served at Pamplona, the recently revamped Spanish restaurant on East 28th Street formerly known as Ureña, is not made in the traditional way. That is to say, it isn’t mixed in a plastic shopping bag.

headline: A New Kind of Diva
text: Anna Netrebko is a gifted opera singer who at 36 has already mastered many of the roles — Mimi, Violetta, Lucia, Manon — that used to go to the queenly, temperamental sopranos of the old school, with their furs, their atomizers, their entourages. She is also a media-savvy entertainer from the new school, with the knockout looks, the fans, the celebrity of a pop star. Her “Traviata” at Salzburg two years ago was such a hot ticket that scalpers were reportedly charging $7,000 a seat, and her records regularly top the charts in Europe. In the summer of 2006 she was part of a concert in Berlin that filled a stadium.

headline: You’ve Got Mail
text: EVERY year around this time, as the catalogs and holiday greetings flood my mailbox, I am reminded of New York City’s defunct 27-mile pneumatic tube system. This underground network fueled by pressurized air carried first-class mail in two-foot-long canisters from Manhattan’s General Post Office to postal branches around the city.

headline: Scrooge Relents. Joy Prevails. Again.
text: PRINCETON

headline: Ready for Download: CTS 2.0
text: A SCENE in the 2005 action film, “Mr. and Mrs. Smith,” shows Mr. Smith (Brad Pitt), a professional assassin, racing home in his black Cadillac CTS-V. He skids around a corner, and in the next shot suddenly he is in a Lincoln Town Car instead of the Cadillac.

headline: Datebook
text: BRUSSELS

headline: Swept Away
text: OF all the cities in the world, New York is among the most cosmopolitan. It is almost as though different parts of the world had been stolen and pieced together to form a singular city. Nearly every ethnicity has its own territory within New York’s boundaries. Stores, restaurants, even entire families seem to have been removed from their homelands and shipped to this city in the same way a part of a liver is transplanted into a foreign body so as to eventually become its own organ.

headline: Hope for Helping Hands Fuels a Rally
text: Stocks rallied last week on hopes that both the Federal Reserve and the United States Treasury would take action to bolster the market.

headline: 4 Rowers to Take on 12 in Trans-Atlantic Race
text: SHELTER ISLAND

headline: Maid Marion
text: In “La Vie en Rose,” you play Edith Piaf from age 17 to her death at 47. Piaf was a brilliant singer, but she was also a drug addict with a deeply dramatic personality. Was it challenging to play a woman who was so extreme in her emotions?

headline: Cheap and Cheerful
text: Style Map | Buenos Aires: The 11-hour flight to Buenos Aires is richly rewarded with warm weather (our winter is their summer), great shopping and a still-kicking dollar. The Palermo Hollywood district is a welcome antidote to the already overrun Palermo Soho across the tracks — a quieter place to stumble across young designer boutiques, underground restaurants and an easy-to-navigate flea market. Happy hunting. [?][?][?]CHRISTINE MUHLKE

headline: Caroline Charlston, Christopher West
text: Caroline Leigh Charlston, a daughter of Mary Ann and Harry G. Charlston of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married last evening to Christopher Stephen West, a son of Judy and Stephen O. West of Atlanta. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

headline: The Classless Utopia of Reality TV
text: IT is sometimes hard to detect much difference between artfully edited reality shows like “The Hills” on MTV and scripted dramas like “Gossip Girl” on CW and the recently canceled Fox series “The OC.”

headline: Pop-Culture Exile: It’s a Family Thing
text: MY daughter, Gillian, wants a cellphone, a pack of chocolate Bubblicious, Webkinz trading cards, an iPod Mini skin and a pair of Ugg boots.

headline: Venezuela Votes on Whether to Give Chávez More Power
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 2 — Voters went to polling stations throughout Venezuela on today to cast ballots on a referendum over constitutional changes that would significantly enhance the power of President Hugo Chávez.

headline: From the Heights of $100 Oil, Most Stocks Look Vulnerable
text: THE recent spike in oil prices is probably a passing mania, many investment strategists say. But they warn that if oil remains near record levels next year, it would hurt most domestic stocks, with the notable exception of energy companies.

headline: Toddy Time
text: Hot toddies may be for thermoses, but not the Colts Neck Toddy from the Bar Room at the Modern. It’s really a spiked herbal tea: verbena leaves are steeped in hot water and honey, then mixed with spirits. (Other herbs, like rosemary or sage, can be substituted.) “You can use just about anything to make the hot water more interesting,” says Ehren Ashkenazi of the Modern. Be artful, in other words, and improvise.

headline: In Panama, a Home in the Mountains
text: ALTOS DE CERRO AZUL, Panama

headline: Someday We’ll Sing, ‘Take the G Train’ (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Two to Try With Latkes
text: The cheery spirit of Hanukkah, which begins Tuesday, is captured in Carmel’s fizzy 2006 Young Moscato from Israel ($7.99) and the light 2005 Rashi Malvasia ($9.99) from Puglia, Italy. Both are kosher.

headline: O Brother, Where Art Thou?
text: Customarily in presidential races, Americans seek a patriarchal figure, a strong parent to protect the house from invaders and financial turbulence.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Mother Knows Best

headline: Lawyers Compete, Except in Bonuses
text: BONUSES on Wall Street are going to be bad this year, except if you work at Goldman Sachs. Or, oddly enough, if you’re an associate at a white-shoe law firm. (Granted, the scale of banking bonuses is in a rarefied class of its very own, even when compared with law firms, but bear with me).

headline: Service Bulletin: Fix Your Car
text: KIAS that won’t start in the morning and high-revving Hondas are among the problems found in recent technical service bulletins.

headline: Cover Less to Cover More
text: THE governor of New York has been touting his “patient-centered approach to health care policy,” claiming that it is “driven by the needs and demands of New Yorkers.” That sounds nice, but the plan is actually centered on more government control of the health insurance market and higher taxes — not exactly a new approach here.

headline: On Long Island, Off the Streets and Onto the Court
text: WYANDANCH

headline: Stephan Balint, 64, a Founder of the Squat Theater, Dies
text: Stephan Balint, the underground Hungarian writer, actor and director who gained fame in New York with the above-ground Squat Theater in the late 1970s and ’80s, died on Oct. 11 in Budapest. He was 64.

headline: Me Bid
text: My husband is not the kind of man targeted by the Neiman Marcus catalog. He is not a Man Who Has Everything. He doesn’t have enough socks, shoes or underwear. He shuns all things new. I wouldn’t dare buy him a personal G.P.S. device for Christmas. Ah, but a 19th-century fishmonger’s sign? An Albertus Seba illustration of a possum and snake locked in battle? That’s another matter. The man is to antiques what women are to shoes: a little goofy.

headline: When the Future Looked Brave and New
text: Aldous Huxley began his literary career on the edge of Bloomsbury and ended it in Beverly Hills, the prophet of a dystopian future and advocate of LSD. Huxley was so preoccupied by the dangers threatening civilization that he could not rouse himself to defend it. The reader of this engrossing collection of letters, many previously unpublished, is dismayed to find him refusing to sign a declaration against Hitler — never mind fight — a few weeks after the outbreak of war, because “I do not feel that politics ... are my affair,” except “such politics as are dictated by the need to ‘make the world safe for mystical experience.’ ” Support from Bloomsbury old boys was not lacking: “Have you yet read [Bertrand] Russell’s new book, ‘Which Way to Peace’?” he asked a correspondent in 1936, as the Nazis prepared to trample over Europe. “It is a most admirably lucid argument leading by remorseless logic to the complete pacifist position.”

headline: Buyer Beware in Seeking Lower Energy Costs
text: WITH winter setting in and heating fuel prices nearing record levels, Westchester residents may be thinking about taking advantage of Con Edison’s Power Your Way program, which allows them to buy gas or electricity from a source other than Con Ed.

headline: The Discreet Charm of the Gauloisie
text: REALITY is — like life, or art or dinner — as real as you make it. This concept is not terribly popular right now in the art world, where reality seems to equal the price your work brought at Sotheby’s. And art that does not have a tangible value is just too abstract.

headline: Caught Up in a Storm, With His Eyes Wide Open
text: PASCAGOULA, Miss.

headline: Death to Capital Punishment
text: Montclair

headline: Corrections
text: The list of 100 Notable Books of 2007 in the Book Review today misspells the surname of the author of the novel “Let the Northern Lights Erase Your Name.” She is Vendela Vida, not Veda. (The same error appeared in the Editors’ Choice column on Jan. 7.)

headline: Putting a Price on a Wrongful Conviction
text: WILLIAM GREGORY and David Pope were both convicted of rape. Mr. Gregory served seven years in a Kentucky prison and Mr. Pope was imprisoned by Texas for 15 years before being released because of new DNA evidence.

headline: Yoko Mizumoto and Daniel Fleisher
text: Yoko Mizumoto, the daughter of Yuko Mizumoto and Toshihiro Mizumoto of Nara, Japan, was married on Monday to Daniel Aaron Fleisher, a son of Dr. Jan E. Paradise and Dr. Gary R. Fleisher of Newton, Mass. Ralph A. Antonacci, a justice of the peace in Stamford, Conn., officiated at the Stamford Government Center.

headline: Pakistan’s Slow-Motion Emergency
text: Karachi, Pakistan

headline: The World as an Imperfect Globe
text: NEARLY a quarter century ago, Theodore Levitt, the Harvard business professor, heralded a global convergence of consumer tastes. The global corporation, he proclaimed, “sells the same things in the same way everywhere.” In 2005, Thomas L. Friedman, The New York Times columnist, sounded a similar trumpet about the effects of technology, inaugurating his world-is-flat franchise.

headline: To Play Football at Fairfield Prep (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Can a Co-op Demand Health Insurance Proof?
text: Q My co-op board has begun to request proof of health insurance of applicants. There are no specific requirements as to an amount, just “proof of insurance.” The requirement is not included in the application package, but it is requested after the application has been submitted.

headline: Caitlin Wight, Timothy Fitzsimmons
text: Caitlin McDermott Wight, a daughter of Deborah McDermott Wight and William Needles Wight of New York, was married last evening to Timothy James Fitzsimmons, the son of Mary Elizabeth Fitzsimmons and James Edward Fitzsimmons of Whippany, N.J. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. James’ Episcopal Church in New York, with the Rev. Luke Travers, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: Late Encounter With a Bluefin
text: The fish lay on a table. The crowd at the barriers stood six deep. They held up cellphones and cameras to take its picture.

headline: Housing Crisis? Try Mobile McMansions
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: What You Get for ... $6 Million
text: Naples, Fla.

headline: End of an Era for Family Mansion
text: WHEN she died last year at 103, Aimee de Heeren — of New York; Palm Beach, Fla.; Paris; and Biarritz, France — became one more lost link to an earlier age of social grace and high society.

headline: Pins and Needles
text: HELEN UFFNER, the owner of a theatrical costume company, has a vast inventory of vintage items dating from the 1970s back to the 1860s, among them 8,300 dresses, 3,200 women’s hats and 800 cartons of accessories. Items from her collection have made cameo appearances in movies like “Capote,” in television shows like “Saturday Night Live” and in countless Broadway plays.

headline: Beyond Basel
text: An international guide to the best of the winter and spring art offerings.

headline: Teachable Moments: Tell Me More, Indeed! (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toy Stories
text: The All-I’ll-Ever-Want Christmas Doll” is a rich portrait of a poor black family in the midst of the Depression. Written by Patricia C. McKissack, the winner of numerous awards, and illustrated by the equally renowned Jerry Pinkney, it has the look, sound and feel of a classic. McKissack’s direct and unfettered language partners beautifully with the vivid tones of Pinkney’s pencil-and-watercolor illustrations. Inspired by a true story, “The All-I’ll-Ever-Want Christmas Doll” is an evocative book with a universal message.

headline: Between Buyers and Sellers, a Stalemate
text: BRUCE EPSTEIN has spent the last four months looking for co-ops on the Upper West Side, and he thought he had a pretty good grip on how much they were going for. When he decided to offer slightly less than the $1.15 million asking price for a two-bedroom in a walk-up building that required renovations, he thought he was being reasonable. But the seller said he shouldn’t even bother to make an offer if he wouldn’t pay the asking price.

headline: Twisting and Chatting the Ailey Way
text: DANCES have traditionally been handed down from performer to performer, even since the invention of dance notation. But how do dancers learn about the mysterious culture of performing? Some of that can be soaked up in the daily work, but there is nothing quite like a lazily extended, spontaneous conversation with a veteran choreographer, dancer or company director.

headline: One Is No Longer the Loneliest Number
text: SURE, traveling alone can be an extremely freeing experience, with no one else to slow you down or bicker with over which sights to see along the way. But it can also be a drag. When you’re hauling your bags around on your own, or when the only other single on your hiking tour is the guide or after your third sunset dinner on the hotel’s veranda — alone — traveling by yourself can lose its allure.

headline: Immigrants in New York Better Off, Study Finds
text: Foreign-born New Yorkers are better educated, more likely to have health insurance and less likely to have entered the country illegally compared with immigrants in the rest of the country, according to a new analysis.

headline: Inside the List
text: ‘NOW THAT YOU ASK’: Denis Johnson’s novel “Tree of Smoke” saw an uptick in sales after winning the National Book Award, but not enough of one (yet) to put it back on the fiction list. It rests currently at No. 29 on the extended list. Johnson, famously, does not give many interviews, and when he does he is pretty laconic. Here’s a sample of a Q. and A. with him that’s posted on the National Book Awards Web site:

headline: How the Filibuster Became the Rule
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Montreal: Opus Hotel
text: THE BASICS

headline: Books, Boots and a Big Sky
text: BOZEMAN, an old Montana cowboy town known for long views and a vast sky, is in the throes of development, with big-box stores expanding around its perimeter. But business owners in the city's downtown are steadfastly trying to maintain the history of the area and the character of their shops.

headline: One Piece or Two?
text: It’s that time of year: sand, sea, salt air — and scene, if that’s what floats your boat. Want a beach vacation with billionaires or bohos? Margaritas or mint tea? Here, the ins and outs The bohemian’s Baja, where a rollicking beach and colorful town square trump the megaresorts lining the rest of the Pacific Coast.

headline: Ending Famine, Simply by Ignoring the Experts
text: LILONGWE, Malawi — Malawi hovered for years at the brink of famine. After a disastrous corn harvest in 2005, almost five million of its 13 million people needed emergency food aid.

headline: Shaking Up Branford
text: Here is a disturbing national statistic: In general, about 80 percent of 80-year-olds vote, but only about 20 percent of 20-year-olds vote. While young people still go to the polls in significant numbers, it’s little wonder that the needs of the YouTube generation are not at the top of the average politician’s priority list.

headline: The Stowaway on Schindler’s List
text: MIMI REINHARD, 92, sat very straight on the edge of a sofa, her lipstick freshly applied, her neck garlanded with pearls. Though the furniture was mostly gone from her apartment on West 72nd Street and the carpets were rolled up, an air of the Viennese drawing room hovered about her.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Smoke This Book
text: If the mark of a classic is that every time you read it you discover something new, then the 1972 paperback of A. E. Van Vogt’s science-fiction novel “Quest for the Future” just might be a classic. Those who read the book when it was first published in hardcover in 1970 certainly won’t recognize this passage from Chapter 15: “A large gleaming machine with an opening at one end was wheeled in, and once again the cycle ran its Micronite Filter. Mild, Smooth Taste. For All the Right Reasons. Kent. America’s Quality Cigarette. King Size or Deluxe 100s.”

headline: Israeli Forces Kill 6 in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 — Five members of the Hamas armed wing were killed Saturday by an Israeli rocket strike in southern Gaza, near the village of Abassan. An additional eight gunmen were wounded, one critically, according to the Health Ministry in Gaza, when helicopter gunship attacks followed the airstrikes.

headline: Letters: The Ethicist
text: The incomplete grade given by the professor, referred to in the Ethicist’s update, solves nothing (Nov. 18). The student who copied a paper from the Internet simply writes another paper, and except for possible penalties for lateness, apparently walks away as if the plagiarism never occurred.

headline: Where Living in Fear Starts at the Top
text: For more than a year, fearing assassination, the prime minister has lived in his office in the ornate government building, surrounded by concentric circles of barbed wire, soldiers and armored vehicles that separate him from antigovernment demonstrators. Some 40 members of Parliament from the razor-thin majority are holed up in the luxurious, gaudy Phoenicia Hotel a few blocks away, behind three tiers of metal detectors, internal security police and drawn curtains. The two majority leaders are in fortress-like family palaces, one high in the mountains, the other with surrounding city streets sealed off for blocks.

headline: For Suns’ Hill, Quality Time, but Precious Little Quiet Time
text: PHOENIX, Nov. 29 — It was a rare day off from basketball, but there was no rest for Suns forward Grant Hill. On a recent Saturday morning, Hill had seen his mother off to the airport and visited the barbershop. Now he was seated at the kitchen table, thumbing through the latest issue of Vanity Fair while cradling his crying 3-month-old daughter, Lael, in his lap.

headline: Peace? Sure, I’ll See What I Can Do
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: A Couple Find Their Dream in the Field
text: Old Bethpage

headline: Fact and Fiction on the Campaign Trail
text: LAST Monday’s Times reported that Rudolph Giuliani had accused Mitt Romney of having a bad record on crime while governor of Massachusetts.

headline: Art Attack
text: When the subprime actress Jamie-Lynn Sigler helmed an off-schedule event during last year’s Art Basel Miami Beach, two things became clear even to the uninitiated: Mischa Barton must have been busy, and the art world had degenerated into one long, ridiculously oversubscribed party.

headline: He Writes About What He Knows
text: Art doesn’t just imitate life in David Henry Hwang’s play “Yellow Face.” It clones it.

headline: Now Wearing | the Other Chloë
text: For her new line, Chloë Sevigny for Opening Ceremony, sold at the eponymous downtown boutique and other hip spots, the actress drew upon her “completely awkward and dorky” junior-high years. “I wanted this collection to embody that spirit of being young,” she says. This meant cropped blazers, Liberty-print grunge dresses, even a motorcycle cap made from recycled cassette tapes. “My friend told me that the whole collection was a pretty accurate self-portrait,” she says. “I wasn’t sure if he meant it as an insult or a compliment.”

headline: Curry Seems to Lose His Touch Just as the Knicks Find Theirs
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 1  Even Eddy Curry could not resist poking fun at himself during the last three games.

headline: Just How Effective Is Stop and Frisk? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prices Nice as the Food
text: The Upper West Side has long been accused of having a scarcity of good restaurants, but these places in the West 70s are not only good but also affordable.

headline: Twins Look for Yanks to Up Ante for Santana
text: The Yankees insist they have gone as far as they are willing to go in their trade offer for Johan Santana, the ace left-hander of the Minnesota Twins. Their chances of getting him depend on whether the Twins insist on receiving another top prospect in the deal.

headline: Lots of Little Screens: TV Is Changing Shape
text: INEXPENSIVE broadband access has done far more for online video than enable the success of services like YouTube and iTunes. By unchaining video watchers from their TV sets, it has opened the floodgates to a generation of TV producers for whom the Internet is their native medium.

headline: To Be Safe, Call the Bride by Her First Name
text: WHEN Jill Van Camp decided to play catcher in a softball game on the September morning of her wedding, her mother worried that the bride might lose a tooth. Ms. Van Camp, 31, was more concerned about losing her good name. Literally.

headline: In Patchogue, a Novel Cure for Old Muck
text: PATCHOGUE

headline: Art Basel 911
text: Noel Lanzas is a full-time concierge at the Ritz-Carlton South Beach and a Surrealist painter in his free time. This month, he’ll merge both as the hotel’s Art Basel Miami Beach Ambassador. As an on-call guide, he will shepherd fragile art-world newbies during the four-day event. He can tap into the hotel’s network of art consultants, create a fair-hopping schedule for seasoned collectors, get V.I.P. party invitations and advise on shipping options for those who score.

headline: Mud, Sweat, Jeers. But a Free Tree!
text: Sharon

headline: Homicide in New York: When the Victims Are Women
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: The Sleep-Industrial Complex
text: Did Thomas Edison’s invention of the electric light wreak havoc on heliocentric sleep behavior, or did our society always cut sleep short? Jon Mooallem (Nov. 18) rightly turns to anthropologists to answer this fascinating question. But the question remains, where do we go from here?

headline: Mad
text: If you grew up with the cartoons of Don Martin, which were a fixture of Mad magazine from 1956 through 1988, there’s a danger in revisiting them: once you’ve become a sophisticated-type person — that is, one who has finally grasped that “thwap” and “thoipoing” aren’t real words — does Martin’s world, in which there are a thousand variations on the squirting-flower gag, and where human beings sport snappy-looking but physiologically untenable hinged feet, still look weird? Or is it really nothing more than comfort food for nostalgic baby boomers who can’t let go of that figurative (or perhaps literal) stack of old Mads stashed under the bed?

headline: Nonstop Theft and Bribery Stagger Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 1 — Jobless men pay $500 bribes to join the police. Families build houses illegally on government land, carwashes steal water from public pipes, and nearly everything the government buys or sells can now be found on the black market.

headline: The Hang Man
text: When a fashion designer’s work is called arty, it’s usually a polite way of saying that the clothes are interesting but unwearable. Christian Lacroix, who during his 20 years as a couturier has whipped up many a masterpiece, makes no pretensions toward being an artist. He has, however, long harbored the fantasy of being a museum curator. With the opening of “Christian Lacroix: Histoires de Mode” at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris, he finally gets his shot. Selecting some 500 garments from the museum’s vast archive, combined with 80 couture pieces of his own design, Lacroix has revised fashion history in his own checked, polka-dotted, striped and quilted image, exuberantly mixing up styles and periods — much like he does in his own collections — with the flair of a true postmodernist.

headline: Smile, Make Eye Contact and Don’t Burp
text: NEW CANAAN, Conn.

headline: Note to City Dwellers: Steals Available Here
text: MORE than a neighborhood, Flatbush often refers to a sprawling community in central Brooklyn comprising multiple smaller ones.

headline: Andrea Carbone, Charles Dufresne Jr.
text: Andrea Lisa Carbone, the daughter of Phyllis A. Carbone of Lynbrook, N.Y., and the late Dr. Richard R. Carbone, was married yesterday to Charles Harry Dufresne Jr., the son of Jean M. Dufresne and Mr. Dufresne Sr. of Suffield, Conn. Thomas Costello, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph’s Roman Catholic Church in Hewlett, N.Y.

headline: Adding Notes to a Folklorist’s Tunes
text: NASHVILLE

headline: Turkey Says It Attacked Kurdish Fighters in Iraq
text: ISTANBUL, Dec. 1  The Turkish military said Saturday that it had inflicted “significant losses” on a group of Kurdish guerrillas in Iraq, though it offered no evidence for its claim.

headline: Sooners Awaken and End Tigers’ Dream
text: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 1 — After No. 9 Oklahoma’s 38-17 victory against top-ranked Missouri to win the Big 12 championship Saturday night, Sooners Coach Bob Stoops was quick to campaign for his team to play in the Bowl Championship Series title game.

headline: Kill the Cat That Kills the Bird?
text: Last summer, even as he talked about facing jail time, Jim Stevenson couldn’t stop looking for birds. “There’s a couple yellow-crowned night herons,” he said, pointing out his living-room window. “They roost in that chinaberry tree.” He rested his eyes on the blue-gray birds. “Anyway, the cops pulled me over and searched my van and found the gun, and —”

headline: The Raiders’ Fargas Is Ready to Ramble
text: The only thing that has slowed Justin Fargas  since he became the Oakland Raiders’ starting running back has been the defense of the Minnesota Vikings, which held him to 60 yards rushing. Fargas’s opponent today, the Denver Broncos, should not be nearly as challenging.

headline: It’s Only a Game, Right?
text: A few weeks ago, two ill-matched high school football teams played a game so lopsided that the score was 51 to 0 before the end of the first half. This created a problem. Piling up a lead of more than 50 points can get a coach suspended under the rules of the Connecticut Interscholastic Athletic Conference. The coach therefore directed one of his players to field a kick and run the wrong way into his own end zone, intentionally causing a safety and making the score 51 to 2.

headline: Effort to Limit Junk Food in Schools Faces Hurdles
text: Federal lawmakers are considering the broadest effort ever to limit what children eat: a national ban on selling candy, sugary soda and salty, fatty food in school snack bars, vending machines and à la carte cafeteria lines.

headline: Second Thoughts and Profits
text: PIER LUIGI LORO PIANA, an Italian businessman, yachtsman and scion of a family known for its cashmere and luxury goods business, was caught up in the excitement last year over the conversion of the Plaza Hotel into luxury condominiums. In May 2006, he signed a contract for a $5.8 million one-bedroom on the 14th floor with views of Central Park.

headline: Heard Near the Gowanus: Calls for Room Service
text: AS recently as 16 months ago, there were, not surprisingly, zero hotels amid the myriad auto body shops that dot Fourth Avenue and the surrounding Gowanus area. Now there are three, and plans for a fourth, an 18,000-square-foot structure at President Street and Third Avenue.

headline: Precious Metals
text: Sometime around 1960, the sculptor Alexander Calder was visiting Jean Lipman, the editor of Art in America, when he noticed one of her keepsakes, a triangular stone. “Grandpa asked her if he could have it,” says his grandson, Alexander S. C. Rower, who directs the Calder Foundation. Taken aback, Lipman assented reluctantly, figuring her rock was gone for good. But soon after, he surprised her by returning it, transmuted into the “jewel” of a brass and silver wire brooch. Such deviltry was totally in character, Rower says: “You could always count on the guy to do something surprising.’

headline: The Sputnik Effect
text: On the evening of Oct. 4, 1957, while millions of Americans settled into their sofas for the premiere of “Leave It to Beaver,” Soviet engineers thousands of miles away were celebrating a different sort of debut. Earlier in the day, they had successfully launched the world’s first artificial satellite — the antenna-strewn orb known as Sputnik — from a test center deep in the rugged Kazakh desert.

headline: Here’s the Show, the Works Are Elsewhere
text: Los Angeles

headline: Middle East Peace Through Anxiety
text: Annapolis, Md.

headline: The Shock of the Hue
text: When Grace Coddington, Vogue’s creative director, turned up at the Paris collections in a green dress this autumn, it might have seemed no cause for comment — except perhaps from the French, who think green is unlucky.

headline: Food History
text: If the past is a foreign country, do they eat things differently there? Not as differently as you’d think, to judge from the new anthology FOOD: The History of Taste (University of California, $39.95), a weirdly fascinating survey of dietary habits stretching from prehistoric barbecues right up to the “molecular” menu at El Bulli. Consider the Pueblo II civilization, an advanced agricultural community that lived in the American Southwest a thousand years ago. These days it’s fashionable to blame the farm bill for the gross amount of corn that Americans eat — but as it turns out, even without federal subsidies or Orville Redenbacher to influence them, the Pueblo II couldn’t get enough of the stuff either.

headline: Letters
text: Corrupt Practices Act Is Hardly Obscure

headline: Following a Kindly Light, and Casting One
text: POMONA, N.Y.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE MISSION SONG, by John le Carré. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.99.) This novel’s hero, Bruno Salvador, a k a Salvo, is one of le Carré’s outsiders, the son of an Irish Catholic missionary and a Congolese village woman. Now an interpreter living in London, Salvo is asked by British intelligence to translate at a secret meeting of Congolese officials and a mysterious syndicate of business and political interests bent on subverting Congo’s approaching elections. As he examines Salvo’s response through the lens of his past and of his affair with a Congolese nurse, le Carré remains preoccupied with “how individuals, as they are forced to define their moral commitment, must attempt to defy the overwhelming political pressures around them,” our reviewer, Neil Gordon, wrote.

headline: Pout and Shout
text: ALL is not well in MileyWorld.

headline: An Armory, and a Siege by Rebels Who Live Nearby
text: THE Seventh Regiment Armory, the massive, crenellated red-brick building that occupies a full square block on the Upper East Side, spent much of the 1990s falling apart. “When we took it over,” said Rebecca Robertson, president of the Seventh Regiment Armory Conservancy, “it had rats, it had lead contamination, there was litter everywhere.”

headline: He Has Leverage
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

headline: Rangers Start Fast and Add to Ottawa’s Woes
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 1  Before Saturday’s game between the Ottawa Senators and the Rangers, fans of the Senators tried to manufacture enthusiasm. They warmed themselves on a brutally cold day by cheering their struggling team, which entered the day on a five-game losing streak.

headline: Judging Eminent Domain
text: THE recent $12.4 million jury verdict against the Town of Branford for eminent-domain abuse signals the public’s heightened sensitivity to the issue, said lawyers for both sides in the case.

headline: Visuals
text: War is hell! Yet in James Aulich’s WAR POSTERS: Weapons of Mass Communication (Thames & Hudson, $40), a lush catalog for a current exhibition at the Imperial War Museum in London, many of the posters produced in favor of armed conflict and in opposition to it during the 20th and early 21st centuries are so exquisitely conceived and rendered that they can be appreciated as art, not mere propaganda.

headline: Fuel Bill Shows House Speaker’s Muscle
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 — The question has hung over Nancy Pelosi since she became speaker of the House: could she handle the powerful Democratic committee chairmen who stuck it out 12 years in the minority for the chance to wield authority once their party won control?

headline: Few Priests? Papal Visit Seen as Help
text: YONKERS

headline: Correction: Amid Affluence, the Hidden Homeless
text: An article and an accompanying picture caption last Sunday about homelessness on Long Island misstated the location of a National Wholesale Liquidators store at whose loading dock homeless people sometimes congregate. It is in the Village of West Hempstead, not Hempstead.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: FILM

headline: Where to Eat Before Hibernating
text: EVERY year about this time, I suffer the same disappointment. It’s called winter, and somehow it always comes as a surprise.

headline: Is Bulgaria Really Skiing’s Next Hot Spot?
text: THE morning sky outside my window was gray with rain — the last thing I wanted to see at Bansko, the biggest ski resort in Bulgaria. A dispiriting mist hid the half-built hotels and condos that lay beyond the ugly Glazne River, and the Pirin Mountains were all but invisible. The town had been warm and wet the past two days, and conditions up on the slopes below the roughly 9,000-foot Todorka peak hadn't been much better. I closed the curtains with a sigh and gave myself the day off.

headline: Benefits of Immigration
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: A Chicken Coop, but No Tigers
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the film director Ang Lee misidentified the man standing beside Sihung Lung on the set of “Pushing Hands.” It was Chung Zen Chang, a tai chi instructor, not Mr. Lee.

headline: Party Politics
text: By 2003, at the age of 33, the Alabama-born writer Michael Knight had written, and seen published, two collections of stories and a short novel. It was a promising start. Knight’s understated prose presented a quietly volatile world of tight Southern communities and families, a world defined by festering resentments, fumbling relationships, affairs, divorces, sudden furies. For all its dark insight into human entanglements, Knight’s fiction also contained surprising jolts of humor.

headline: Tangled Up in Blue
text: LIKE nearly everyone in one corner of Ozone Park, Queens, Mary Ann Simulinas can tell you stories about the elusive inhabitant of the silvery blue house that sits opposite a cemetery on the corner of 107th Avenue and 84th Street.

headline: Danielle Axelrod, James Magid
text: Danielle Sara Axelrod, a daughter of Margaret Golieb Axelrod and Jay G. Axelrod of New York, was married last evening to James Arthur Magid, the son of Caryn Magid and James I. Magid of New York. Rabbi Jonathan Stein officiated with Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman at the Pierre in New York.

headline: A Student Editor Finds Himself at the Center of the News
text: SOME day, Jason Braff, now a junior at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, could join Tom Brokaw, Ted Koppel, Peter Jennings and Leslie Stahl as a recipient of the college’s Fred Friendly Award — named for the former CBS News president and bestowed for showing courage in preserving free speech. But for now, Mr. Braff, in his first year as editor of the student newspaper, The Chronicle, is in a battle with the administration over what he and others say is his right, and that of the paper’s, to criticize the university.

headline: Paraplegic Actor Sings for Stem Cell Research
text: MITCH LONGLEY, an actor on the NBC series “Las Vegas,” remembers that day in Rowayton 24 years ago when hundreds of friends, relatives and well-wishers from the community gave him a surprise 18th birthday party and presented him a Buick, wrapped in a bow, that he could drive on his own, with his hands.

headline: New Rallying Cry: Save the Small Airports
text: NOT long ago, many of New Jersey’s small airports were endangered because of opposition from local communities and pressure from developers interested in converting the land to more profitable use, like condos or shopping malls. These general-aviation airports, which cater to private pilots, flight schools and other nonairline operations, were closing at the rate of one a year, falling to 43 today from a high of around 100 after World War II.

headline: The Road to Funny
text: In his often engaging new memoir, “Born Standing Up,” Steve Martin recalls an encounter in 1967, at a nightclub in Aspen, with his first serious heckler. “See if you think this is funny,” the man said, throwing a glass of red wine at him. The incident feels especially shocking because by this point in the book, almost halfway through, the reader is so sympathetic to Martin — the guy slaved for years analyzing comedians on television, studying them in clubs, torturing himself to deliver something radically new, all the while waiting for even the tiniest recognition — that you take the heckler’s assault personally.

headline: Colts Are Hobbled but Remain Potent
text: Contrary to popular belief, the Indianapolis Colts’ season did not end with a loss to New England. In fact, if not for a late rally by Tom Brady that day and a missed field goal late in a loss at San Diego a week later, the Colts (9-2)  not the Patriots  would be 11-0.

headline: Raise a Glass to the Father of Energy Drinks
text: It was never about winning or losing with Dr. J. Robert Cade. From our first telephone conversation 41 years ago, it was always about helping others and solving problems, like the dozens of young football players across the country who were dehydrating and having strokes during practices and games.

headline: Snow Men
text: Why can’t the snowman get any respect? By Bob Eckstein’s count, of the approximately 500 books with the word “snowman” in the title, 488 are either for children or about drug dealers. Of the some eight million pieces of art on record at the Royal Library in The Hague, only two contain images of a snowman. Consumer capitalism has pressed the snowman into service as a pitchman for everything from anti-dandruff shampoo to laxatives to tampons. Feminist professors have publicly denounced him as a fat white male who lolls on the lawn “while the woman of the house is inside toiling.” In Switzerland, there is even a national holiday dedicated to blowing him up.

headline: The Jaws That Bite
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hollywood Chronicle
text: HOLLYWOOD’S CENSOR Joseph I. Breen and the Production Code Administration. By Thomas Doherty. (Columbia University, $29.50.)

headline: Connecticut’s Interstate of Confusion
text: Norwalk

headline: For East End, an Ideal Year
text: East End producers are virtually ecstatic about this year’s vintage. “If someone asked us to describe what would be the ideal growing season on the North Fork, we would have to describe 2007,” Charles Massoud, an owner of Paumanok Vineyards in Aquebogue, said in an e-mail message. Roman Roth, winemaker at the Wölffer Estate in Sagaponack on the South Fork, wrote: “The 2007 vintage is turning out to be spectacular. It is a rare combination when high quality is also met by high yields and healthy clean fruit.”

headline: Statistics Pinpoint Problems in Paterson Schools
text: PATERSON, N.J. — Assistant school superintendents here are routinely summoned to a 10 a.m. Thursday meeting where they must answer for missing test scores, overdue building repairs and other lapses, which are presented in painful detail on PowerPoint slides. Excuses are not an option.

headline: Bitter Pill
text: Harold Schechter seems an average sort. He teaches American literature at Queens College in New York City. His author’s bio mentions a home in Brooklyn and a wife. His face, which stares out from the photo on his Web site, radiates middle-aged respectability. Beneath this placid exterior, however, thuds a dark and savage heart.

headline: The Brando of Ballet
text: The Nureyev family of the small industrial town of Ufa in the Soviet republic of Bashkiria was so poor that at the age of 5 little Rudik had no shoes. He was carried to school by his mother on her back. He was called a “beggar” by the other children. One day he fainted from hunger. Fifty-two years later, at a packed auction at Christie’s in New York, a single pair of Rudolf Nureyev’s used ballet slippers sold for more than $9,000. John Dryden called dancing “the poetry of the foot,” and rarely before had a pair of feet so defined, and symbolized, this poetry. Every male ballet dancer for the past five decades has been dancing in the space, the vast terra infirma, charted by Nureyev’s well-worn shoes.

headline: Is There a Bespoke Framer?
text: The framer Richard Ziello has a knack for complementing a canvas, from Motherwell to Matisse. (One collector calls him a “rogue aesthetician.”) Ziello will measure your art at home and then return to his Long Island studio to fabricate welded aluminum, wood and gold-leaf frames with molding of his own design. “We can adjust the style and molding to fit the proportions of the picture, and the art never leaves the owner’s hands,” he says. His couture approach stems from his trade as a sculptor (see his work at the Tribes Gallery through Dec. 7). Too busy with commissions from Ameringer Yohe Fine Art, the estate of Hans Hofmann and others, Ziello neglects his own art. “I’m like the shoemaker who couldn’t afford his own shoes.” E-mail rickybonzai@aol.com.

headline: Neue Galleries
text: Berlin’s reputation as the next art capital was sealed this fall with the arrival of several new spaces, all outposts of established European galleries. Haunch of Venison (also of London and Zurich) opened a more than 5,000-square-foot branch in Mitte in September with a splashy concert by the fictional ’70s band Lustfaust. Meanwhile, in Kreuzberg, Konrad Fischer Galerie (Düsseldorf) and Jablonka Galerie (Cologne) have joined Buchmann Galerie and Julius Werner Berlin (above) in the area around Checkpoint Charlie.

headline: Manhattan Turns to New Jersey to Fulfill Its Need for Electricity
text: Manhattan already orders out to New Jersey for much of what it needs, from food to furniture to gasoline. Soon the list of imports from across the Hudson River may include electricity.

headline: Anna Kneitel, Michael Gross
text: Anna Weber Kneitel, the daughter of M. Diane Weber and Dr. Alan Kneitel of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Michael Benjamin Gross, a son of Judith and David Gross of Sudbury, Mass. Rabbi Jay B. Heyman officiated at the Golden Gate Club in the Presidio in San Francisco.

headline: Sand, Sea and Space to Roam on Horseback
text: BRIGANTINE BEACH

headline: Defeating Hunger and Homelessness, Step by Step
text: Three and a half years after he was evicted, David Joseph still remembers the shock of coming home to a chain on his apartment door in the Bronx. He was 18. He had never lived on his own before.

headline: In Preservation, Room for Growth
text: CHESTERFIELD

headline: NFL Matchup
text: LIONS at VIKINGS

headline: Simon Says
text: Any cookbook that has a chapter devoted entirely to cream is a book I can’t do without. Add a chapter on custard, another on chocolate, and I’ll order it from England for a small fortune in postage. No wonder, then, that I now have not one but two copies of Simon Hopkinson’s “Roast Chicken and Other Stories” on my kitchen counter — the U.K. edition, already dog-eared and grease-and-gravy-stained, and an arguably more pristine copy of the new American edition, which came out in September. “Roast Chicken” is one of those rare cookbooks that, once opened, becomes indispensable — perhaps because it takes so many of the dishes you thought you had already mastered and, quite simply, does them that much better. Foodies know it as the winner of the 1995 Glenfiddich award for best food book, and publishers know it as the book that trumped Harry Potter on Amazon.com’s British best-seller list. The British magazine Waitrose Food Illustrated named it the most useful cookbook ever, but here I must disagree. “Roast Chicken and Other Stories ” is far too idiosyncratic to be labeled “useful.” Rather, it is deliciously random and highly opinionated.

headline: Silly Putting
text: The Heat and the Dolphins had better make way for Miami’s new sporting obsession: miniature golf. Back 9, a new course where every hole is designed by a local artist, began as an installation on the Albion hotel roof during last December’s Art Basel Miami Beach. The owner, Peter Rozek, 29, cobbled it together, calling in a few favors from creative friends like Cristina Lei Rodriguez, Hernan Bas and Daniel Arsham. Rozek’s folly is now a campy landmark inside a garden center on the mainland. Art fans play spot-the-masterwork — Ali Prosch’s black arbor is a current standout — while sipping a free rum cocktail. The best day to play is the last Saturday of the month, when an over-the-hill hole is retired and its replacement makes its debut at a dance party. 7244 Biscayne Boulevard; (305) 984-3231; www.uppereastsidegarden.com.

headline: Marie-Claude Wrenn, Robert Myers
text: Marie-Claude Palmieri Wrenn and Robert Anthony Myers were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Family.

headline: Amy Bielefeld, Stephen ten Broeke
text: Amy Bielefeld, a daughter of Elizabeth and William Bielefeld of Dongan Hills, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Stephen ten Broeke, the son of Phyllis and John ten Broeke of Centerville, Mass. Michael Gleason, a Roman Catholic deacon and an uncle of the bride, will officiate at Our Lady of the Rosary in Manhattan. The Rev. Peter Meehan, a Roman Catholic priest, will also participate.

headline: Masterpiece Home Theater
text: Don’t worry. I won’t get the “Water Lilies.” Although, to be honest, I’d consider it, if the image weren’t still so scented with memories of Muzak and fluoride treatments. It’s not a painting’s fault when dentists like it. And maybe those tranquil Giverny colors are just what I need this winter on my monocle-size screen when I’m alone, peering importantly at my BlackBerry for its little blinky company and moral support.

headline: Art Fair Field Guide
text: Identifying Basel Miami’s Indigenous Species.

headline: Stefanie Schuman, Rory Weiner
text: Dr. Stefanie Gail Schuman and Dr. Rory Brett Weiner were married last evening by Rabbi Harry K. Danziger at Temple Israel in Memphis.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You’
text: A review on Nov. 11 about “Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You,” by Peter Cameron, omitted the Farrar, Straus & Giroux imprint that published the book. It is Frances Foster Books.

headline: Spanish Policeman Is Killed in Attack in France
text: MADRID, Dec. 1  A Spanish policeman was shot dead in southern France on Saturday by members of the Basque militant group ETA, Spanish authorities said. Another policeman was seriously wounded in the attack.

headline: Save the Date
text: There’s something a little bit infectious about the Dolphin Studio’s calendar ($50), silk-screened by the ceramic artist John Ffrench and his wife, Primm, who have been making these folksy, colorful prints from their home studio in Stockbridge, Mass., for 37 years. All of the family members, including their grandchildren, have been contributing artwork since they were old enough to hold a brush. “I don’t think we’ve ever said, ‘Oh, no, that won’t do,’ ” Ffrench says. Production grows each year (they’re up to 1,500), since nearly every calendar giftee becomes a gifter. Here’s an example: this writer gave one to Daily Candy’s Crystal Meers; Aimee Acord (the sister of the cinematographer Lance), who saw it at Meers’s house, gave one to the designer Jane Mayle — who then produced sweaters bearing interpretations of the designs for Barneys Co-op. “The images were so strong graphically and so very charming that it was hard not to do something with them,” Mayle says. “Looking at my calendar on the wall every day just seemed a little small and selfish.” The family now has a Web site. “I’m the computer person, and I’m a little wobbly,” Primm says. Welcome to 2008. Go to www.thedolphinstudio.com or call (413) 298-3735.

headline: The Day’s Best
text: Kevin Smith had 284 yards and 4 touchdowns as Central Florida beat Tulsa, 44-25, to win the Conference USA championship. Smith, a junior, is the nation’s leading rusher with 2,448 yards.

headline: Strange Pairing on Hall Ballot
text: Having Marvin Miller and Bowie Kuhn on the same Hall of Fame ballot is like having Alex Rodriguez and Carl Pavano on the same players ballot. Yet there they are, Miller and Kuhn, together as candidates on the executives ballot of the newly constituted election format for the Hall of Fame.

headline: Once Upon a Time in China
text: Here’s a lesson in the graceful acceptance of defeat. In 1298, the Genoese navy bested the Venetian fleet at the Battle of Curzola. Unable to live with the disgrace, one Venetian commander, Andrea Dandolo, killed himself by beating his head against his ship’s mast. Another Venetian leader, Marco Polo, surrendered calmly, was taken prisoner and spent a few years writing his memoirs in comfortable captivity. Dandolo’s fame died on the deck; Polo’s will outlive our grandchildren. Few famous names have as much vagueness attached to their exploits, though. Marco Polo opened Asia to European trade, so we’re told, but we generally don’t know much else. Laurence Bergreen remedies that by bolstering Polo’s reputation and arguing for his historical importance in a book as enthralling as a rollicking travel journal. Bergreen, who has written biographies of Louis Armstrong, James Agee and Irving Berlin, turned his attention to ancient explorers with “Over the Edge of the World,” which tracked Ferdinand Magellan’s circumnavigation of the globe. I was a fan of that book, but “Marco Polo” far outshines it, and not surprisingly. Marco Polo, unlike Magellan, left his biographers a masterpiece of a memoir to work with.

headline: Giving You Christmas When You Want It
text: “IS it that time already?” “Every year it gets earlier!” “Please! No tinsel! Not before December!” These are just some of the comments I overheard recently as passers-by saw me and my colleagues installing the holiday windows at the emporium of style and fashion where we work.

headline: Weather
text: Having spent a lot of time fleeing the hazards of erupting skies, slate-gray funnel clouds and flash floods while filming in remote locations (not to mention my twister-fearing Illinois youth), I have always been curious about someone who runs right at them, camera in hand.

headline: Naama Ashkenazi, David Bloom
text: Naama Ashkenazi and David Andrew Bloom were married last evening. Rabbi David Adelson officiated at Loft Eleven, an event space in New York.

headline: Marriage, by God or Government?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Savoir Fair
text: As the public face of Art Basel, the world’s biggest trade fair for modern and contemporary art, Samuel Keller is a moving target — at once an organizer, strategist, friend, flack, booster, bouncer, Old World roué and entirely social animal. One minute he’ll be touring a biennial in Shanghai and the next will find him in Los Angeles, co-sponsoring a dinner for art dealers and collectors with Michael and Eva Chow. Twenty-four hours later, he’ll arrive in New York to table-hop at the Four Seasons after the opening of the Richard Prince retrospective at the Guggenheim.

headline: Letters
text: Recycle the Holly

headline: Now Sketching | James Jean’s Prada Prints
text: If next season brings more ethereal changelings than can be counted in “The Faerie Queene,” blame Miuccia Prada. For her enchanting spring collection, the allusive Prada collaborated with the Los Angeles-based illustrator James Jean to create the woodland backdrop for the show, as well as the wallpaper for the Prada Epicenter stores in New York and Los Angeles. Versions of the prints then appeared in a fairyland’s worth of diaphanous fabrics printed with wood nymphs and flowers. For more examples of his work, go to www.jamesjean.com.

headline: India
text: Flipping through INDIA SUBLIME: Princely Palace Hotels of Rajasthan (Rizzoli, $65), it’s easy to see why the post-backpack foreign set — not to mention India’s own increasingly affluent traveling class — has made this northwestern province a necessary pit stop on the country’s tourist itinerary. Not that any of the establishments in Melba Levick’s elegant photographs could remotely be described as a pit. These ancestral properties, converted into luxurious heritage hotels, cater to all manner of aristo fantasies: drifting off to sleep in a giant silver bed, lulled by the sound of your own personal indoor fountain; contemplating the desert horizon from your pillared marble pleasure pavilion in the middle of your vast green lawn, sprouted from imported Kenyan seeds planted in two million donkey loads of dirt; admiring thousands of reflections of your very own self in the glass mosaic ceiling of a maharaja suite, an experience the book’s writers, Mitchell Shelby Crites and Ameeta Nanji, liken to “being inside a huge glittering kaleidoscope.”

headline: Rock Portraits
text: One of the most striking pictures in ROCK AND ROLL (Abrams, $50), a collection by the music photographer Lynn Goldsmith, captures the symbiotic ties between fans and bands. It is 1978 in Anaheim, Calif., and Mick Jagger is alone on a stadium stage littered with fans’ shoes. He has a towel draped over his shoulder, but the audience is clearly not through with him yet. He’s looking away from the masses with a dark but unreadable expression on his face: maybe it’s exhaustion, or failure, or contempt. Or maybe he’d just been hit in the face with a flip-flop.

headline: Telluride, Colo.: Honga’s Lotus Petal
text: Sushi restaurants in the Rocky Mountains are a little like Mexican joints in Minnesota: something about them just seems wrong.

headline: Correction: Beckoned by Bivalves
text: An article on Nov. 18 about a culinary pilgrimage to Prince Edward Island for its shellfish referred incompletely to air service from the United States to the province. Although there are no direct flights in winter, there are direct flights in the summer from Detroit on Northwest and from Boston on Delta.

headline: San Francisco Fleet Is All Biodiesel
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30  Claiming it now has the largest green fleet in the nation, the city of San Francisco this week completed a yearlong project to convert its entire array of diesel vehicles  from ambulances to street sweepers  to biodiesel, a clean-burning and renewable fuel that holds promise for helping to reduce greenhouse gases.

headline: Editor’s Cut
text: Ahh, the lure of the madman — the harrowed, sinewy figure with glowing eyes who approaches out of the shadows, burning to communicate his incommunicable truth. Think of Jack Nicholson in “The Shining” with his wild stare and lurking ax: “Heeeeeere’s Johnny!” When such a person nears, do you step back? Do you linger, frozen in terror, compelled by his mesmeric gaze? Or do you, like Vikar, the “cinéautistic” protagonist of Steve Erickson’s latest novel, “Zeroville,” regard him quizzically, without fear, thinking only, “I don’t understand comedies”?

headline: Campaign for Sale
text: The sticker price for next year’s presidential and Congressional elections is rocketing toward $5 billion, shocking even political professionals who figure the ante in the opening Iowa round may cost out at $300 per caucusgoer. When you consider that the votes taken at those caucuses actually have no direct effect on who is nominated by either party, the cost should be ludicrous by the laws of economics, never mind politics.

headline: Brooklyn, the Acropolis
text: Brooklyn, the Acropolis

headline: Art vs. Life
text: Why Pay Six Figures for a Photo?

headline: 400 Umbrellas That Spell ‘Park Slope’
text: THE line that snaked back from the cash registers at Tarzian Hardware on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope on a rainy Monday afternoon moved briskly enough, so most customers probably missed the plastic garbage can next to the counter by the front door. It wasn’t raining very hard, either, or else they might have paid more attention to the contents of the can: a little yellow foldable umbrella, free for the taking.

headline: A Righteous Recipe for Longevity
text: With bullets whizzing over his head in the Battle of the Bulge, Daniel Bukantz dug his foxhole and hunkered down because, as he freely admits, “I was scared.”

headline: The Dealers Show Their Cards
text: The dealers’ recent vote to unionize at Foxwoods Resort Casino is potentially momentous for Connecticut. Dealers number 3,000 out of more than 10,000 employees at the casino, which the Mashantucket Pequot tribe opened in 1992. The casino, along with the nearby Mohegan Sun, run by the Mohegan tribe, are among the largest in the world. Although the two tribes employ more than 20,000 workers, none are unionized.

headline: Stories Conflict, but Miles Says He’ll Stay at L.S.U.
text: ATLANTA, Dec. 1  Les Miles barged in front of a microphone Saturday for an impromptu news conference, saying he was the Louisiana State coach and would be the L.S.U. coach, in response to a report that he had agreed to become the coach at Michigan.

headline: The Kids Are All Right
text: To the Editor:

headline: Political Cartoons
text: Tom Lehrer once remarked that “political satire became obsolete” when Henry Kissinger won the Nobel Peace Prize. He didn’t know the half of it; in 2004, a little more than 30 years later, the Medal of Freedom, America’s highest civilian honor, was awarded to the major architects of the Iraq disaster, George Tenet, Tommy Franks and L. Paul Bremer. Yet far from being obsolete, political satire thrives, especially late nights on Comedy Central.

headline: A Theatrical Work to Do Good Works
text: JOEL EHRLICH hated to admit it, but the Broadway stagehands’ strike may have worked to his advantage.

headline: Jana Chapman Christopher Gates
text: Jana Michelle Chapman, the daughter of Karen Chapman and Jeff M. Chapman of Turlock, Calif., was married yesterday to Christopher Stanley Gates, a son of Sandy Gates and John V. Gates of New Providence, N.J. The Rev. Mark Robinson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Manhattan Penthouse, an event space in New York.

headline: Travel
text: "Whereas the term adventurer suggests a passion for new frontiers,” Alexandra Lapierre observes in the coffee-table book she’s written with Christel Mouchard, WOMEN TRAVELERS: A Century of Trailblazing Adventures, 1850-1950 (Flammarion, $45), the term adventuress “connotes ambitiousness, intrigue, mercenary sex.” But the authors of six recent travel books — all men — suggest otherwise.
