These writers and their books traffic in ambitiousness, intrigue and mercenary sex. Could they be adventuresses too?

headline: Robo Love
text: A few months ago I wrote a magazine article about scientists who are building robots capable of a rudimentary form of sociability. As part of my research, I spent a few days at the humanoid robotics laboratory at M.I.T. And I admit: I developed a little crush on one of the robots. The object of my affection was Domo, a man-size machine with a buff torso and big blue eyes, a cross between He-Man and the Chrysler Building; when it gripped my hand in its strong rubbery pincers I felt a kind of thrill. So I was primed for the basic premise of David Levy’s provocative new book, “Love and Sex With Robots”: that there will soon come a day when people fall in love with robots and want them for companions, friends, love objects and possibly even partners for sex and marriage.

headline: NFL Matchup
text: BENGALS at STEELERS

headline: Correction: A Time to Rethink AIDS’s Grip
text: An article last week about the future of the AIDS epidemic misidentified the antibiotics that kill Yersinia pestis, the microbe that was one of the causes of the Black Death. Streptomycin, doxycycline and chloramphenicol are generally used against the bacterium, not penicillin. The article also misstated the percentage of AIDS sufferers in low- and middle-income countries who receive antiretroviral drugs. It is estimated that close to a third or more of those who need the drugs get them; not one-tenth.

headline: Though Caucuses Loom, Democrats Tone It Down
text: DES MOINES, Dec. 1 — Markedly shifting their tone of recent weeks, the Democratic presidential candidates had a largely friendly exchange Saturday night at a debate devoted to black and Hispanic interests, though they expressed some differences over Cuba, drug sentencing and health care.

headline: You’re on the List
text: If you’re an art-world heavy, only an original work can truly express season’s greetings. It’s a tradition that started with Robert Indiana’s iconic “Love” sculpture, originally designed in 1965 as a holiday card for the Museum of Modern Art. If you’re not on Peter Norton’s list, however, try to get on these.

headline: Dusting Off the Shelves of Hellenic Kitchen
text: IN the 1940s and ’50s, the streets of Hell’s Kitchen were sprinkled with Greek businesses, so much so that the neighborhood’s newsstands carried no fewer than three Greek-American dailies. Today, about all that remains of Manhattan’s Hellenic outpost is a spanakopita bakery, a restaurant, a grocery and a little collection of Greek books and artifacts in a dusty antique store at Ninth Avenue and West 43rd Street.

headline: The Oligarchettes
text: The last Venice Biennale had its fair share of fabulous parties: the Gucci shindig at the Palazzo Grassi, the Scissor Sisters concert at the Lido, François Pinault’s private dinner for Madonna, Elton et al. on San Giorgio Maggiore. But there was one especially lavish bash at the Hotel Cipriani that boasted not only the crooning of Paolo Conte, Italy’s Perry Como, but also a flashbulb-popping cameo from the noted art lover Naomi Campbell. It was thrown by the Moscow collector Stella Kesaeva to spotlight her foundation’s show, “Ruin Russia.” But Kesaeva threw a fit before she threw her caviar-accented party, more a face-saving gesture designed to be a spoiler as much as a stand-alone good time.

headline: Food of Lands Touched by the Mediterranean
text: OF several dishes that stand out at Tapastre (pronounced tapestry), two are stellar.

headline: Resorts Prepare for a Future Without Skis
text: THE sun was glaring down on the Swiss Alps. Bronzed 30-somethings in designer sunglasses and tight T-shirts were draped over extra-large lounge chairs that lined the deck. Euro-pop music played from multiple speakers as fetching young waiters served expensive bottles of Champagne and cheese plates. It might have been August at a Nikki Beach Club — except for the splotches of snow, mountain vistas and overworked snow machines.

headline: The Originals
text: Provocateurs at heart, the artists featured here are no less stimulating when it comes to style. For some, the way they dress cannot be separated from their work; for others, it’s an independent vehicle for expression, one piece in a larger project of reflecting and interpreting the world around them. Untouched by stylists and fashion freebies, these Originals know only one way to get dressed: their own.

headline: Now, a Nordic Trail the Length of Vermont
text: The Catamount Trail (www.catamounttrail.org), a 300-mile cross-country ski trail that traverses the length of Vermont — from the Massachusetts to the Canadian border — is now complete. In October, volunteers cleared and marked its final four and a half miles, in the Green Mountain National Forest, which makes up 80 miles of the trail. A combination of backcountry and groomed cross-country trails, snowmobile paths and old logging roads, the trail is divided into 31 sections, each of which can be skied separately and each of which has its own volunteer trail chief. It crosses both public land (about 135 miles) and private land, through arrangements with more than 200 landowners, many of whom have agreed to conservation easements that have permanently protected their portions of the trail.

headline: Youngest McEnroe Sets Quieter Tone for Davis Cup
text: Portland, Ore.

headline: For the 2008 Race, Google Is a Crucial Constituency
text: LAST century, General Motors assembly plants were a regular stop on the itineraries of presidential candidates. This election cycle, Google headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., has become a favorite destination.

headline: To Reduce the Sewage in the Gowanus Canal (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Croatian Shellfish
text: To the Editor: Regarding Frank Bruni’s article “Beckoned by Bivalves” (Nov. 18), about his pilgrimage to Prince Edward Island for oysters and mussels:

headline: An Imperfect Solution
text: IT was Jon Werberg’s long commute that made him and his girlfriend, Helene Mattera, impatient to leave their apartment in Pelham Bay, the Bronx.

headline: Art-Book Smarts
text: In their previous incarnation as Coromandel Express, the Parisian publishers Alexis Fabry and Olivier Andreotti put the edge back in the illustrated book. Beginning in 1996, their limited-edition tomes became a sort of passage obligé for artists, writers and designers. Vik Muniz, the Bouroullec brothers, William Klein and Martin Amis all obliged, and the Paris concept store Colette devoted windows to their works not once but twice.

headline: Art by Writers
text: Imagine a favorite work of literature. Now imagine it unpinned from words. What is left? Anything? To what extent do works of art arise from the particular mediums of which they are composed, and to what extent are they molded from the primordial, formless soup of inspiration? Could a sonnet be a ballet? Could a novel find life as a melody, or a collage? These are some of the existential questions implicitly raised by Donald Friedman’s book THE WRITER’S BRUSH: Paintings, Drawings, and Sculpture by Writers (Mid-List Press, $40).

headline: Correction: On the Tequila Trail in the Place Where It’s Made
text: A picture on Nov. 18 with the Comings & Goings column was published in error. The photograph accompanying a report on a package offered by the Presidente InterContinental Hotel Guadalajara in Mexico was of the Casa Herradura, a distillery near Guadalajara; it was not of Mundo Cuervo, another distillery, which is included in the hotel’s tour package.

headline: The Seer
text: When it came to building her personal collection, the legendary art dealer Ileana Sonnabend said she relied on a time-tested method. “For years, after a show, I’d buy what nobody else wanted,” she once told an interviewer. “They were always the most difficult pieces, but in the end they became the strongest.”

headline: Tahira Williams and James Copland IV
text: Tahira Aisha Williams and James Reuben Copland IV were married yesterday at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Paul T. Rock, an associate pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Made in Japan
text: The artist Takashi Murakami is about much more than Louis Vuitton bags. This month, he is exporting his six-year-old art fair, Geisai, from Tokyo to Miami. Fresh on the heels of his Los Angeles museum show, Murakami is sponsoring and underwriting a satellite outpost inside the Pulse fair showcasing a clutch of gallery-less artists you won’t see at Art Basel Miami Beach. He is tweaking the free-for-all flea market setup of the Tokyo fair: instead of 1,000 or so ad hoc participants selling work, Geisai Miami will have 20 jury-selected artists culled from thousands of online applicants who hope to become the next Shiro-A, a group that made its debut at Geisai No. 7 in 2005, then quickly bagged a spot at the Venice Biennale. “I’d like Geisai to be an opportunity for artists who are rather on the shy, quirky, geeky side,” he said through a translator. “It’s an opportunity to pick up artists who aren’t marketable.” No doubt Marc Jacobs will be prowling the aisles. Dec. 5 to 9; go to www.geisai.us.

headline: The Good Fight
text: Trenton

headline: Yahoo Betrays Free Speech
text: For a company that ostensibly believes in the Internet’s liberating power, Yahoo has a gallingly backward understanding of the value of free expression.

headline: Two Workers Found Dead Inside Empty Chemical Vat
text: LINDEN, N.J., Dec. 1 — Two workers were found dead Saturday afternoon in an empty 20,000-gallon chemical vat at an industrial dry cleaning plant here, the Linden police said.

headline: Fitting End to a Tumultuous Season
text: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 1 —West Virginia Coach Rich Rodriguez stood before reporters Saturday night with a dazed look and cracked voice.

headline: Study Puts Price Tag on Delays at Airports
text: The growing number of delayed flights at Kennedy International Airport and the region’s other major airports has cost passengers nearly $200 million in lost productivity this year, according to a report to be released today by the New York City comptroller’s office.

headline: In a Progressive State, a City Where Gay Life Hangs by a Thread
text: NEWARK, Nov. 30 — To live in Newark often means grappling with unrelenting poverty, the anesthetizing lure of drugs, murderous gangs, a lack of decent jobs.

headline: My Sorority Pledge? I Swore Off Sisterhood
text: MY life’s greatest sorrow stems from my inability to feel close to other women. At 41, I’ve cautiously cultivated a few cherished female friendships. But generally I feel a kind of skittish distrust and discomfort when dealing with most women, particularly women in packs.

headline: Letters: The Stomach-Surgery Conundrum
text: In their excellent article about bariatric surgery, Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt (Freakonomics, Nov. 18) mention that the procedure “often produces complications — physiological ones, to be sure, but also perhaps psychological ones.” As a psychiatrist, I have no doubt that a morbidly obese patient without other medical cause for obesity (i.e., thyroid disease) already has a severe psychiatric problem. Without treating the compulsion that underlies such behavior, it is no wonder that patients who have surgery but no psychiatric treatment may develop “new” psychiatric symptoms, like gambling, compulsive shopping and alcoholism.

headline: Stephanie Stegich, Adam Treanor
text: Stephanie Anne Stegich was married yesterday to Adam Jude Treanor. The Rev. Thomason Newcomb, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y.

headline: Talks Fail to Find Unity in Belgium
text: BRUSSELS, Dec. 1 (Reuters) — Belgium plunged deeper into political uncertainty on Saturday when the would-be prime minister, Yves Leterme, abandoned his efforts to form a four-party center-right government after the collapse of marathon talks.

headline: Romney’s Words Testify to Threat From Huckabee
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 1 — If there was any doubt that Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign was seriously concerned about the threat posed to them by Mike Huckabee in Iowa, Mr. Romney’s latest campaign swing through the state erased that.

headline: Ashcan School
text: Of the countless attempts by visual artists to catch New York City on the fly, few have been as loving or warmly vibrant as those of the painter John Sloan. A native Pennsylvanian, Sloan (1871-1951) relocated from Philadelphia to New York in 1904, and in the next 15 years he took the sidewalks of his adopted city as his muse. A tireless walker, he did not paint outdoors but stored impressions in his mind to recreate later in the studio. He was particularly attracted to the area he had settled in, Chelsea, by Sixth Avenue and West 23rd Street, then a rather honky-tonk stretch with dance halls, movie houses and burlesque stages, which, he wrote, “had a Coney Island quality in 1907.”

headline: The Dollar Is Falling, and That’s Good News
text: ANXIETY about the dollar continues to spread. The falling greenback is often seen as a sign of an impending recession or the fall of the United States from global leadership. A low dollar simply looks bad. We are, after all, used to judging ourselves against others — comparing our salaries with the earnings of our peers, and our homes with those of our neighbors. We’re used to thinking it is a big advantage to stand at the top of a numerical list.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Page 32 of The Times Magazine today, about the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko, misstates the date of a concert she performed at Carnegie Hall. It was in May 2007, not June. (Go to Article)

headline: Shades of Capote
text: Truman Capote ended as he began, writing sketches and mood pieces, but the later versions were a little skimpier and less promising than the earlier ones. That’s the sad conclusion to be drawn from “Portraits and Observations,” a collection of some 42 pieces spanning his career. The first, a remarkably stylish and assured autobiographical sketch about living in New Orleans, was written in 1946, when Capote was in his early 20s, working on his own after a brief stint as an editorial assistant at The New Yorker. (“What is that?” Harold Ross is reported to have said on first glimpsing the magazine’s new hire, and he fired him not long after.) Capote was working on the last piece in the collection, a recollection of meeting Willa Cather back in the early ’40s, on the day before he died, in August 1984.

headline: Is Hello Kitty Turning Feral?
text: HER image can be found on everything from sandwich makers to Swarovski crystal-encrusted laptops.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘For Love of Politics’
text: A picture caption on Nov. 18 with a review of “For Love of Politics,” a book about Bill and Hillary Clinton by Sally Bedell Smith, misstated the location where the couple were shown, based on erroneous information from the photo agency. The picture, taken by Robert McNeely, was made in the Capitol building, not the White House.

headline: Camera Ready
text: Leica’s the first real relationship I’ve ever had with a camera. I’d always hated Leica men: I thought of them as really macho men who went to India and poor places in the world and thought they knew them without spending any time there. But my close friend Peter Hujar used one. (He used to tell me that if he didn’t like the lens, he would take it back to the store and try them until he liked one.) So I got my first Leica in 1990. Since then, I’ve dropped them, I’ve broken them, I’ve had them stolen on the subway, I’ve lost them in taxis. When I was working on the Mira Nair film “Monsoon Wedding,” I fell almost 10 feet into an empty pool. As I was falling, I hallucinated that the Leica was my baby. I held it against my chest and landed with all my weight on my wrist and broke it into a million pieces. But I saved my Leica. Over the years, I’ve learned that the lens is a very subjective relationship. The reason I use a Leica is because it actually has a subtext. It depends on what you’re photographing, but the lens shows you not just the surface: the levels underneath are revealed. Somebody told me once how optically this was possible. I just thought it was magic.

headline: 36 Hours in Park City, Utah
text: IF you haven't visited Park City in several years, brace yourself for discombobulation. Sure, Main Street hasn't gone anywhere, and it's still achingly picturesque under a confectioner's sifting of Utah's famously light snow. That is, when it's not jammed with smoking S.U.V.'s. In the last few years, thanks to several factors — the 2002 Winter Olympics, the Sundance Film Festival, a growing realization among wealthy skiing baby boomers that this former silver-mining town is “in Utah but not of Utah” — the area is booming so fast as to be nearly unrecognizable. The negatives to this classic New West story include traffic and unbridled second-home development across the mountainsides. But the upside is an infusion of ambitious new hoteliers and chefs in Park City proper, injecting new life and urban sophistication into the city of 7,400 people.

headline: Coming Up Roses (and Weeds)
text: Couldn’t dance. Couldn’t, for all practical purposes, act. Couldn’t sing with the kind of nuance we expect of singers today. Was only moderately good-looking early, and later became a bit of a fright. No wonder it takes two biographies to try to put across why Ethel Merman was one of the biggest and most enduring stars Broadway has ever known.

headline: A Family That Plays Together, and a Jazz Legend
text: 3 Cohens

headline: Gonzo
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giants at Bears
text: Eli Manning vs. Rex Grossman

headline: The Whole Story
text: Is your grasp of the Aurignacians’ artistic accomplishments not quite what it used to be? Worried that conversation at the office party will turn (yet again!) to the banganga spiritual mediators of the Congo and their anthropomorphic nkisi nkondi figures? Fear not. 30,000 Years of Art’ (Phaidon) covers world art history from 28,000 B.C. to today. A thousand works of art — including painting, sculpture, textiles, masks, ceramics and jewelry — are featured on 1,064 pages, putting you on par with even the most assiduous culture vulture. Even if art is not your thing, the tome could come in handy: weighing in at 13 pounds, it readily doubles as an erudite doorstop.

headline: Putin’s Party Wins in Russia, but Leadership Is Still Clouded
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 2  President Vladimir V. Putin’s party secured a landslide in parliamentary elections on Sunday after a campaign in which the Kremlin persistently hobbled the opposition. Yet while the results represent a triumph for Mr. Putin, they also usher in a new era of political instability for Russia.

headline: Let There Be Art
text: The earliest artworks originated in the service of a ritual — first the magical, then the religious kind,” the philosopher Walter Benjamin wrote in the 1930s. Western culture changed, as Benjamin put it, when “the secular cult of beauty” developed during the Renaissance. Once liberated from its religious function, art gradually became its own theology — “a negative theology in the form of the idea of ‘pure’ art,” Benjamin believed.

headline: Solid Gold
text: All that glitters for the holidays.

headline: A Fine Line
text: If all you knew of Kenneth Paul Block were his society portraits and fashion drawings, you’d think he’d spent his life clinking martinis with Gloria Vanderbilt and wheedling previews out of Yves Saint Laurent. If all you knew were the ascot he knots inside the turned-up collar of a black cotton shirt and the retired cigarette holder and opera cape, you’d think he was too fastidious for words (which he is). But that picture of Block — the last in the line of great fashion illustrators; Eric, René Bouët-Willaumez and René Bouché are the others — would not be complete.

headline: New Tradition: Eat the Turkey, Then Go Online
text: Black Friday (the day after Thanksgiving) and Cyber Monday (the Monday after Thanksgiving) get all the publicity as busy holiday shopping days. But when it comes to online retail traffic, Thanksgiving itself outperforms both days — and has been the busiest day of the entire holiday season for the last four years, according to Hitwise, an online research firm.

headline: A Sip for Après-Whatever
text: WE don't do winter sports all that well in Manhattan. Though skating is free in Bryant Park and comes with cool views in Central Park, and diehard snow fiends find ways to cross-country ski, play hockey and snowshoe, few visitors to New York arrive with such sporty ends in mind.

headline: Cooking
text: Why are British cookbooks, circa 2007, so much better than American ones? By “better” I don’t mean that they are larger or more comprehensive, that you would necessarily give them to a new bride and groom, or that they are in possession of lustier photographs or crisper layouts or even bolder or more exacting recipes.

headline: More Talk of Sharing Services
text: FROM 1995 to 2005, total property taxes in Westchester increased by 67 percent while the county’s population grew by less than 5 percent. Numbers like that have led the Tax Foundation, an organization based in Washington that favors lower taxes, to rank Westchester as one of the top three counties with the highest tax burdens in the country.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘The Pleasures of the Damned’
text: Because of an editing error, a review last Sunday about “The Pleasures of the Damned,” a poetry collection by Charles Bukowski, misspelled the second word of a Latin phrase meaning “we were smoke.” It is fuimus fumus, not flumus. (The phrase, a version of a tomb motto, is quoted from Thomas Wolfe’s “Look Homeward, Angel,” where it is used to suggest life’s transitory nature.)

headline: Grand New Party
text: Holiday party” — two words that signal the beginning of a zombielike progression of eggnog and enforced cheer. But perhaps miracles are still possible, as evidenced by the fact that a handful of culinary artists are redefining what it means to eat and to socialize, and not necessarily in that order.

headline: Now Serving | Tokyo Treats
text: Get your sugar high with an artsy pedigree. The Omotesando Hills shopping complex in Tokyo is home to S and O (for Sweets and Objects), a gallery and store devoted to artists’ confections. There are Gumi Girls by Yoshitomo Nara and pumpkin cookies by Yayoi Kusama, who also makes heart-shaped candy dishes filled with marble chocolate. Suck on Fuku Fuku, Ai Yamaguchi’s gumdrop balls, each with an adorable image of a sweetie pie. And who could be so sour as to not enjoy Ban Chinatsu’s ceramic elephant full of maple syrup? Get a peek online at www.macmuseumshop.com.

headline: Sex, Science and Savings
text: President Bush’s veto of Congress’s main social spending bill has Democratic leaders looking for places to make trims to satisfy the president’s sudden zeal for fiscal discipline. A small, but sensible, place to begin would be to eliminate the bill’s $28 million increase for one of Mr. Bush’s signature boondoggles — abstinence-only sex education.

headline: Nia VonHockman and Christopher Chase
text: Nia Alexandra VonHockman was married yesterday morning to Christopher Raymond Chase at the Church of the Magdalene in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Dietz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Revised Lineup Helps Nets Snap Home Skid
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 1  The Nets have a bad habit they cannot seem to break. They fall behind, then must try to climb back into the game. This time, they got away with it.

headline: In the Spotlight, Ready for Its Close-Up
text: THERE was a time when being told that I would be spending New Year’s Eve in Des Moines would have, well, sobered me up in a New York minute.

headline: When Bucs Went 0 for the Season
text: Toward the end of the 1976 season, as it became clear the Tampa Bay Buccaneers would not win a single football game, home fans held signs that read, “Go for 0!” Johnny Carson routinely roasted the expansion Bucs on “The Tonight Show.” Some even started calling the team the Yuckaneers.

headline: L.A.C.M.A. is More
text: When you combine the talent and ambition of an inventive museum director like Michael Govan, a visionary architect like Renzo Piano and a Medici-like board of trustees (including the power philanthropist Eli Broad), you’re guaranteed a blockbuster show. “Transformation” is the continuing expansion and renovation of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (L.A.C.M.A.). The first part of the three-phase project opens this February. Visitors will pass through Chris Burden’s “Urban Light” installation en route to the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum, which contains works from Broad’s vast personal collection. From here they can take in historical works by Thomas Eakins and Jacques-Louis David and a cache of ancient art. For a glimpse of even older artifacts, museumgoers can check out the neighboring La Brea Tar Pits.

headline: Only Downtrend at Pump: Independent Stations
text: WHEN Bill Hands bought an unbranded gasoline station in Orient on the North Fork 21 years ago, it had three pumps — one for regular, one for premium and one for diesel. It still does.

headline: Good News for All the Hockey Pucks
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Down South, Singing the Indie Blues
text: WHAT she’d really like, said the film producer Maggie Renzi, is “a big check and a lot of help.” So far, getting the help hasn’t been a problem. The big check, however, may depend on how well she and her longtime companion, the director John Sayles, can counter all the changes in the independent film business, effect a few of their own and reinvigorate an audience that most movie distributors write off as AARP, if not R.I.P.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Barack Obama?
text: JUST 24 hours after Hillary Clinton mowed down a skeptical Katie Couric with her certitude that she would win the Democratic nomination — “It will be me!” — her husband showed exactly how she could lose it.

headline: Undervalued, Overlooked, but Far From Forgotten
text: For most baseball fans, the Hall of Fame debate season runs about a month, from the mailing of the ballots in late November to the announcement of the inductees on Jan. 8. But for me and about 54 other aficionados of the sport’s history, scrutinizing the records of the game’s great and good has been a nonstop affair for five years.

headline: 15 Going on 50
text: It is, I guess, one of the burdens of growing older that you walk around wishing you could talk to people who are gone. Something arises to make you miss the one person who would get the joke, give sage advice or sympathize, but death has thwarted the conversation. These days, if new books are any indication, it seems that we’re missing Andy Warhol. Even — or particularly — those of us who never knew Warhol in life.

headline: A Cloudy Forecast for Commercial Market
text: MANY commercial real estate players may be ready to turn the page on 2007, in light of the continuing credit crisis and weakening economy. But they may not see a major turnaround throughout most of the country during the new year, according to one year-end industry report.

headline: The Full Picture
text: When collecting art, There’s more than meets the eye. Or is there? Art investment has its own set of rules, but it all comes back to what you love (and want). Learn the ways of the trade, from buying to restoring. Here, a guide to getting the good stuff.

headline: Much More Than a Roof Overhead
text: GARDEN CITY

headline: The People We Have Been Waiting For
text: It was 60 degrees on Thursday in Washington, well above normal, and as I slipped away for some pre-Christmas golf, I found myself thinking about a wickedly funny story that The Onion, the satirical newspaper, ran the other day: “Fall Canceled after 3 Billion Seasons”:

headline: Hobbies Are Rich in Psychic Rewards
text: Q. Between work and family, you have little time or energy left for hobbies, like crafts, painting or music. Without them, though, life feels mundane. What can you do about it?

headline: Special Packages Whittle Away at Cost of Trips
text: SKI season has barely begun, but now is the time to scope out deals and cost-saving packages. This year, you’ll find a number of ways to skim dollars off the ever-growing expense of a ski holiday. Online travel agencies like Travelocity frequently tout packages that combine air, accommodations and ski tickets. Ski.com is a place to check for a constantly changing array of packages, and sites for specific ski areas often post special offerings. Here are some current deals at resorts in North America to get your ski trip search started.

headline: A Place to Call Home: Preserving Middle-Class New Yorkers
text: Anybody who has tried to rent an apartment in New York City knows how expensive they are. At the same time, most pay packets in the city are not much thicker than they were a few years ago, unless you work and thrive on Wall Street. Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Deborah VanAmerongen, the commissioner of the state’s housing agency, eased the burden a little last week when they made it harder for the owners of apartments built under the state’s subsidized Mitchell-Lama program to evict their middle-class tenants.

headline: Friending, Ancient or Otherwise
text: THE growing popularity of social networking sites like Facebook, MySpace and Second Life has thrust many of us into a new world where we make “friends” with people we barely know, scrawl messages on each other’s walls and project our identities using totem-like visual symbols.

headline: Masterpiece Planner
text: Never miss a moment on the global art calendar with the Mrs. John L. Strong Collector’s Diary and Directory. Hotel, restaurant, art transport and even gifting tips are included. $495; www.mrsstrong.com.

headline: One Stop for Homey or Haute
text: If making dinner has become a chore — or you simply don’t have time for it — then Annie’s Gourmet Kitchen in Westfield, which opened in June, can be a useful stop. Supper is served in three ways: you can take home heat-and-serve entrees, buy frozen meals or, for the ambitious, even assemble dinner in Annie’s on-site kitchen from already-prepped ingredients.

headline: Few Moved the Scenery, or Even Chewed It
text: NORMALLY, a theater critic would not review a show that has already closed. But I’ll have to make an exception for “The Great Broadway Stagehands Strike of ’07.” After all, you can’t properly assess the merits and flaws of a drama before the curtain has come down. (Well, not latterly; in days of yore, when critics attended opening night, they occasionally had to skip the last moments of shows to meet their deadlines.)

headline: Waiting for the Other Leaf to Drop
text: MAPLEWOOD, N.J.

headline: If the Shoe Fits, Wear It. If Not, Design One That Does.
text: EVEN for the most dedicated shopper, finding just the right pair of shoes can be elusive. A store-to-store search — whether on the Web or at the mall — can take hours. Shoppers may think they’ve found the perfect pair, only to be stymied by a problem with fit, style or color.

headline: Boy Killed in a Park in Brooklyn
text: A 14-year-old boy who was fatally stabbed in a Brooklyn park on Friday had been trying to rob an acquaintance of the youth who stabbed him, the police said yesterday.

headline: Christine Bader, Adrian Chitty
text: Christine Harriet Bader and Adrian James Chitty were married last evening in New York. The Rev. David Lowry, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony at the Prince George Ballroom.

headline: Screen Goddess
text: You have been working a lot: in the next few months, you are starring in the historical drama “The Other Boleyn Girl” and in “My Blueberry Nights,” which is a road-trip movie directed by Wong Kar-Wai. It was busy last year. I just had my dream job: for the Discovery Channel, I went into the jungle in Rwanda with the mountain gorillas. My mom came, too — I saw a whole new side of her. The silverback gorillas are massive — 400 pounds — and they have 98 percent of the same DNA as humans, and it shows. They can be a little soap opera-ish in their behavior. The baby gorillas would start crawling toward our cameras. They thought the cameras were other monkeys.

headline: Life of Michael

But take another look (it’s easy to find on YouTube) and pay particular attention to Cleese’s interaction with the meek young man in search of a government grant whose walk, alas, is not particularly silly. It’s the heart of the routine, and it’s a perfect example of Michael Palin at his most endearingly Palinesque.

headline: The Decade That Won’t Die
text: There are three kinds of revisionism. Marshaling cunning arguments to prove that James Polk is a vastly underrated president is tendentious but doable. Trying to convince skeptics that James Carter is a vastly underrated president is willfully contrary. Contending that James Buchanan is a vastly underrated president is flat-out nuts. But of the three, arguing that Buchanan should be up there on Mount Rushmore is by far the most fun, because if you’re going to be a revisionist, you might as well swing for the fences.

headline: The Greeks
text: The 21 archaeologists who have contributed essays to GREAT MOMENTS IN GREEK ARCHAEOLOGY (J. Paul Getty Museum, $75) would have us know that their calling is much more than the unearthing of beautiful objects for the delight of public display. But the photographers and designers who have assembled this opulent large-format volume — to say nothing of the artistic genius of the ancient Greeks themselves — threaten to undermine this crucial scientific point at nearly every turn. For a generous share of the hundreds of color photographs that overflow its pages exhibit uncontested masterpieces of Greek art in all their glory. Some, just to scratch the lustrous surface, are as familiar as the bronze charioteer from Delphi or the Victory of Samothrace, which now stands atop the Daru staircase in the Louvre. Other objects amid the profusion of wall paintings, sculptures, vases, mosaics, furniture and metalworks on display here are less instantly recognizable but scarcely less breathtaking. These ancient treasures, together with historic photographs of the major excavations, aerial panoramas of splendid sites, old watercolors and lithographs, and 19th-century architectural renderings, are enough to leave a deep impression on anyone with a drop of philhellenic blood.

headline: Fashion
text: Let’s start, fashion lovers, with a quiz. When you hear the word “bar,” your first thought is of: (a) Leonardo DiCaprio’s supermodel girlfriend, Bar Refaeli; (b) that place you stumble into when you’ve been wearing your teetering Yves Saint Laurent platforms for too long and only alcohol will dull the pain; or (c) the wasp-waisted skirt-suit that, in 1947, formed part of Christian Dior’s trailblazing “New Look” in women’s clothing. Obviously, there is a time and place for both (a) and (b). But those who answered (c) score bonus points for knowing that with confections like the “Bar” suit, Dior helped make high fashion what it is today: at once a bonanza of glossy worldwide press coverage and an artful, gloriously improbable celebration of the female form.

headline: Poetry of Protest
text: In my native Iran, choosing the wrong heroes can have frightening consequences. I chose my first hero (not counting my adored father) a decade ago when I was a university student in Tehran, studying Spanish. My teacher put before us a book of verse by the poet Federico García Lorca, who was killed by nationalist soldiers at the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War. Even reading his poems of dire prediction, I was thrilled by his bravery, facing life and its torments with no balm other than words. I remember the experience of reading one of his poems, “The Weeping.” A sympathy for my fellow men and women, no more than a seed before I read it, grew shoots above the soil by the time I finished.

headline: Here We Go Again

For the past six weeks, I’ve stared at my computer screen and tried to come up with new words to describe this season. I’ve used surreal, topsy turvy, volatile, dizzying, inexplicable, unpredictable, engaging and maddening. And those are just off the top of my head. I’m sick of going to the thesaurus, convinced that a new word will magically appear — just as a new improbable scenario seemed to appear every week.

headline: Gilbert and George | Dynamic Duo
text: Their his-and-his bespoke suits have made them two of the most recognizable peacocks in the art world. But unlike their perfectly tailored demeanor, the work of the London artists Gilbert and George is a messier affair. Often the stars of their own pieces, the pair have explored taboo subject matter like bodily fluids and skinhead subcultures in their photography and performance art. (An image from their 2005 series ‘‘Ginkgo Pictures’’ shows them morphing into a sort of two-headed monster.) A retrospective of their work was shown this year at the Tate Modern and is making its way to the Brooklyn Museum in October 2008. Much like their sartorial habits, their work appears timeless.

headline: Slater Bradley | Culture Vulture
text: As a child growing up in San Francisco, the multimedia artist Slater Bradley was obsessed with whom he wanted to be. ‘‘I think it’s something we all do when we’re really young,’’ he says. This search for identity still lingers in his work. ‘‘Doppelgänger Trilogy,’’ his 2004 lo-fi video series, showed his ‘‘veritable double,’’ Benjamin Brock, dressed as cultural icons from Bradley’s youth like Kurt Cobain and Michael Jackson. ‘‘I think the ‘Doppelgänger’ piece was practically begging for YouTube to exist,’’ Bradley says. He is now interested in moving toward sculpture but is aware that his alter ego won’t stop haunting him anytime soon: ‘‘I have had about 29 solo shows, but people mostly know me by that piece.’’

headline: Grayson Perry | Subversive
text: It’s not news that Grayson Perry loves to wear a frock. ‘‘I’m a transvestite,’’ says Perry, who won the Turner Prize in 2003. ‘‘It comes with the territory.’’ But don’t expect this self-described ‘‘art tranny’’ to be impressed by designer labels. He prefers to have his wardrobe custom-made. (For a summer course he taught at Central St. Martins, the students had five weeks to make him an outfit; he bought the ones he liked the best.) Perry, whose work ranges from ceramics to graphic novels, is currently designing a fabric for the English company Liberty; curating a show for the Arts Council England, ‘‘Unpopular Culture’’; and crafting a medal for the British Museum that he promises will be anything but noble. Despite his own penchant for baby-doll dresses and ruffled socks, he says: ‘‘I am terribly sick of the infantilization of everyday life. Whatever happened to things being subversive, slow and complex?’’
