headline: A ‘Normal’ Family
text: It happened again — this time before Halloween — as we reached the cashier’s station at The Party Store.

headline: A ‘Normal’ Family
text: It happened again — this time before Halloween — as we reached the cashier's station at The Party Store.  The clerk, who must have been about 18, took a long look at my daughters.  "Are they yours?" she asked.  "Yes," I said tersely, hoping my tone would dissuade further inquiry.  It didn't.  "Are they adopted?" she asked.  Now I was ready to give her a blast, a lecture about manners and boundaries.  "Yes, they are — "  But the young woman cut me off, interrupting with a perky, "I'm adopted, too!"  Oh. Um, never mind.  In the last year or so, I've noticed that I have these kinds of conversations more and more. People who once would have intruded with a boorish question seem to have been replaced by others who want to share their own abiding connection to adoption. They were adopted themselves. Or they're in the process of adopting — a "waiting family." Or their grown son or daughter is on his or her way back from overseas, about to make them a grandparent.  In fact it seems to me — dare I say it? — that adoption is becoming normal. Or least more normalized. Sure, it's taken 60-some years. But attitudes are changing. And that's not my imagination.  Ten years ago, 58 percent of Americans had a family member or close friend who had adopted a child, were adopted themselves, or had placed a child for adoption, according to a national survey by the Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute in New York. By 2002, that figure had risen to 63 percent. It's surely higher now.  The same studies found that the percentage of Americans who have seriously considered adopting a child rose from 36 percent to 39 percent — a 3 percent increase that's statistically insignificant, but which the institute believes may mark the start of a permanent change in the way people think about how to build their families.  Adoption is routinely in the news these days, and not just because Brangelina and Madonna have new children. The coverage reflects the sheer number of people who are adopting, particularly from overseas, and the way in which each individual adoption radiates outward, from nuclear family to extended family to friends and co-workers. In the last 15 years, nearly 62,000 children have arrived from China alone. Another 76,000 have come from Russia and Guatemala. Today more are coming from African nations like Ethiopia.  Most of those families couldn't hide their adoptions if they wanted to — and they don't. That's a big change from the 1950s and 1960s, when adoption was a secret so shameful it had to be kept even from the child.  When that clerk spoke up at The Party Store, my daughters paid no attention. Sure, Jin Yu, 7, was busy admiring her High School Musical cheerleader costume. Zhao Gu, 4, had her arms wrapped around her Dorothy of Oz dress, perhaps contemplating the most efficient means to dispose of unwanted witches. But it was more than that. Both of them know adoption as a common word in their household and a routine fact of their lives.  Four adopted children live on our street. Jin Yu's best friend is adopted. So is a boy in her first-grade class. And a teacher at her school. None see it as extraordinary. Which is not to say things are perfect.  Adoptive Families magazine recently carried the story of a Florida woman who was asked to prove that she was her daughter's mother before hospital personnel would treat the child. It's impossible to conceive of a biological parent being asked to verify the same relationship. And every adoptive parent I know has endured frustrations like my own: The woman who approaches our group at a restaurant, demanding to know who among our girls are the "real" children. The relative who laments that I never had "children of my own," oblivious to the little girls beside me. The strangers who feel free to ask why my wife and I adopted and how much it cost — as if the doctors and nurses who deliver babies work for free.  I wonder how these folks would feel if I turned the tables, if I were to tap them on the shoulder while they and their child waited in line for a movie or a seat at a restaurant. "Hey, was your daughter born by in-vitro? She looks in-vitro to me. Am I right or am I right?"  Last summer we were on vacation in Germany when Jin Yu tugged on my arm.  "Dad," she said, "those boys keep pointing at me. Why are they pointing at me?"  I knew why. But I didn't want to say. Because I hated that the rudeness of strangers should compel me to explain to my daughter — again — that some people see our family as different. So I didn't respond at first, and in that moment's pause Jin Yu answered her own question with the very words her father should have offered:  "It's not polite to point," she said.  No, it's not.  It's encounters like that one that make me brace for wounding questions — more and more to find that I needn't have worried. Not long ago, I was leading Zhao Gu along a beach at the Jersey shore.  "Excuse me," a woman said from her seat on a towel, "is your daughter from China?"  "Yes, she is," I said — and kept walking.  But in a moment the woman was on her feet, trying to catch up with me in the sand.  "We're a waiting family!" she called.  Oh. Why didn't you say so?

headline: Edwards Wins a Key Iowa Backer
text: DES MOINES – John Edwards is set to collect a key Iowa endorsement tomorrow from one of the state’s Democratic members of Congress, a coveted prize that each of Mr. Edwards’ rivals have been aggressively courting.

headline: Brett Hull, General Manager
text: I spoke last week with Brett Hull for a Sunday Shootout story. He sounded like he was having the time of his life (who wouldn’t want to be an N.H.L. general manager?) but was learning along the way. He stressed that Les Jackson, the longtime front-office man and his co-general manager, was running the show.

headline: Bali Begins
text: For 15 years, the great climate-treaty traveling road show has wandered the world. Thousands of participants have taken over a sprawling convention center and galaxy of hotels once or twice a year for talks aimed, in theory, at achieving a goal agreed to by all the world’s nations in Rio de Janeiro in 1992 — avoiding “dangerous” human interference with the climate system. (Among the many things no one ever settled on, through all the talks since then, is a definition of the word “dangerous.”)

headline: The Giants, Half Full of Playoff Hopes and Scenarios
text: The N.F.L. season is three-quarters finished, and the Giants’ proverbial glass is half full. It seems a nice time to consider the various playoff scenarios that would greet them in January, should things stay pretty much the way they are now.

headline: The Limits of 21st-Century Revolution
text: CARACAS, Venezuela

headline: Congress, Returning From Break, Has Much Work to Finish Before the Next One
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — With Congress returning to the capital, President Bush and Democratic lawmakers renewed their war of words today and seemed as far apart as ever on Iraq war funding, tax increases, wiretap authorization and other issues.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,481,319.86

headline: After Six Decades, a Jane Bowles Puppet Play Takes Flight
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 30 — Bill T. Jones’s new “Quarreling Pair” may surprise those familiar with his work over the last 20 years. There are no overarching social themes or emotions. The tone is relaxed and instinctual. Based on a short play by Jane Bowles, “A Quarreling Pair” does not look at our time or the cultural history that shaped it. Instead, Mr. Jones and his scenic designer, Bjorn G. Amelan, delve into the central relationship and tone of this odd little four-page puppet play and then move through it, as through a magic mirror, into a complex, dreamlike world in which their imaginations run playfully, riotously wild.

headline: David Oppenheim, 85, Dean of N.Y.U. Arts, Is Dead
text: David Oppenheim, a clarinetist at Tanglewood and a producer of classical music records and television documentaries who became the main architect of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, died in New York on Nov. 14. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Ralph Beard, a Star Tarnished by Point Shaving, Is Dead at 79
text: Ralph Beard, who propelled the University of Kentucky to two consecutive N.C.A.A. basketball championships in the late 1940s, and starred in the N.B.A. before his career was shattered by involvement in a widespread collegiate point-shaving scandal, died Thursday in Louisville, Ky. He was 79.

headline: Facebook Founder Finds He Wants Some Privacy
text: Social networking Web sites can seem dedicated to the idea that nobody’s personal life is worth keeping private, but when it comes to Mark Zuckerberg — the founder of Facebook, one of the largest networks — Facebook disagrees.

headline: ‘Kite Runner’ Boys Are Sent to United Arab Emirates
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 — The “Kite Runner” boys are safely out of Kabul. After months of worrying and diplomatic wrangling from half a world away, the movie studio that is releasing the tale of childhood betrayal, ethnic tension and sexual predation in Afghanistan has whisked to safety four young actors. They were feared to be vulnerable to reprisal because of the film’s depiction of a culturally inflammatory rape scene.

headline: As Underdogs, the Jets Overwhelm the Winless Dolphins
text: MIAMI, Dec. 2 — The Jets spent last week pretending, at least publicly, that being considered the underdog against a winless team did not bother them. Privately, many of them were seething. On the eve of one of the least-anticipated matchups of the season, the subject came up in team meetings, in the locker room and in hotel rooms.

headline: Conferences Consider Change to B.C.S.
text: Mike Slive, the coordinator of the Bowl Championship Series, likes to refer to the skepticism surrounding the B.C.S. as the “annual nervousness.” Mike Tranghese, the commissioner of the Big East Conference, is not quite as diplomatic, calling the annual specter of controversy in college football “debilitating and wearing.”

headline: Three Men Shot
text: A man was killed and two were wounded in a shooting in St. Albans early yesterday, the police said. The men were shot shortly before 5 a.m. at Baisley and Merrick Boulevards, the police said. The officers who responded to a call of gunshots fired found one man, David Alston, 22, dead at the scene. Mr. Alston, of 118th Avenue in Jamaica, was shot once in the head, the police said. The wounded men were Jonathan Stephens, 24, who was shot twice in the back, and Devon Robinson, 21, who was shot in the stomach, the police said. Both men live in Jamaica, according to the police. Mr. Stephens was in stable condition at Mary Immaculate Hospital, and Mr. Robinson was at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. Ronald Alston, 50, an uncle of the dead man, said the family had no details on what led to the shooting. “We want to pray for the killers, and we hope they find the strength to turn themselves in,” he said. “Not only did they take a life, they destroyed a family.”

headline: Lessons From Rosie, Revisited
text: Say what you will about Judith Regan — most people have — she knows her way around a rip-roaring read. The complaint in her $100 million civil suit against the News Corporation, with its riveting passages about corporate connivance, public malfeasance and ill-fated romance, is as much a page-turner as any of the dozens of salacious best sellers she produced at ReganBooks, her imprint at HarperCollins before she was fired at the end of last year.

headline: White House Reaction to Iran Report
text: Here is the text of a statement issued today by Stephen Hadley, President Bush’s national security adviser, concerning the new National Intelligence Estimate on Iran’s nuclear weapons program. The intelligence estimate says that, contrary to previous assessments, Iran halted the program in 2003 in response to international pressure and has probably not restarted it since then, though it has the capacity to do so.

headline: Moving Between Cool Style and Broadway-Flash Pizazz
text: The Alvin Ailey season’s first three performances were completely different in repertory, except that all three ended with Ailey’s 1960 classic, “Revelations.” There was no doubt that the audience was happy about that. People don’t applaud just what happens in this piece; they applaud some of it before it even starts to happen. The beginning of a new section or the first glimpse of a particular dancer can be cause for whoops and screams. I prefer it when its spirituals are sung live, as at Wednesday’s opening-night gala at City Center, but performances on Thursday and Friday, when taped music was used, won even more hollers from the crowd.

headline: F.D.A. Cites Risks in a Genentech Cancer Drug
text: Genentech’s drug Avastin did not help women with breast cancer live meaningfully longer, and it caused significant side effects, including a few deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said today in a review of the drug.

headline: Showing Character After a Shaky Start
text: Chicago

headline: NASA Site Seeks to Draw the MySpace Crowd
text: Cool nebula LOL ; - ).

headline: Better Savings Plans
text: Take two savers, one at Company A and one at Company B. They each have $20,000 in the same investments in their respective 401(k) plans, which they leave untouched for 30 years, earning 7 percent. But the employee at Company A ends up with $132,000 and the employee at Company B ends up with $99,600.

headline: European Academy Honors Romanian Film
text: The 1,800-member European Film Academy, in 20th anniversary ceremonies in Berlin on Saturday, awarded its prize for the year’s best film to “4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days,” which captured the Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival in May, Reuters reported. The film, by Cristian Mungiu, above, of Romania, who also won the prize for best director, tells of two student friends who are ruthlessly exploited when one seeks an illegal abortion. The accolade for best actress went to Helen Mirren for her Oscar-winning performance in “The Queen,” and the prize for best actor was awarded to Sasson Gabai of Israel for “The Band’s Visit,” a comedy about a small Egyptian police band that finds itself in Israel as part of an awkward goodwill exchange. The People’s Choice Award was won by the Italian director Giuseppe Tornatore for “La Sconosciuta” (“The Unknown”).

headline: Detroit Automakers Report Mixed Sales
text: DETROIT, Dec. 3  The Ford Motor Company today snapped a streak of 12 consecutive declines in monthly United States sales, selling 692 more vehicles in November than it did in the month a year earlier.

headline: ‘Jingle Bells’ in Dog Barks? No, Thanks
text: America’s least-loved Christmas song is a Danish recording of “Jingle Bells,” performed in dog barks. The song — which enjoyed brief success in the United States in 1955 and 1970 — took last place in a test of 579 Christmas recordings, performed by Edison Media Research. Edison played the songs for a national sample of 200 women aged 30 to 49, recruited via e-mail, who said that they either liked or loved Christmas music.

headline: Secretary Gates Visits Base in Djibouti
text: CAMP LEMONIER, Djibouti, Monday, Dec. 3 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived in the Horn of Africa today to inspect one of the most unusual missions in the American military, one that has not captured or killed a single terrorist or foreign fighter, yet is viewed by Pentagon officials as a model military deployment.

headline: Brad Pitt Commissions Designs for New Orleans
text: Thom Mayne of Morphosis in Los Angeles designed a house that would float if the city floods. James Timberlake of KieranTimberlake Associates in Philadelphia created a house with native vines climbing up the side walls to provide shade and coolness. Steven B. Bingler of Concordia in New Orleans envisioned a house with wide front steps ideal for a traditional crawfish boil.

headline: Witness Confesses in 1990 Killing, but Prosecutors Keep Pursuing Suspect
text: It was salsa night at the Palladium, a popular East Village nightclub, in the early morning after Thanksgiving 1990, when shots rang out on the street outside, killing one bouncer and wounding another.

headline: With One Month to Go, the Battle Lines Are Drawn
text: DES MOINES, Dec. 3 — There has probably never been a presidential campaign quite as challenging to track as the 2008 race, given the sheer number of candidates and the shifting calendar of nominating contests. But with less than a month to go before the voting starts, it’s becoming clear that Iowa has become the prime battleground for Democrats, while New Hampshire has become the main stage for Republicans.

headline: Vivendi to Acquire Activision
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 — Vivendi said Sunday that it planned to acquire a controlling stake in Activision in a deal that creates a rival to Electronic Arts as the world’s largest independent video game publisher.

headline: A Kyrgyz Reporter Is Killed, and Suspicions Fall on Uzbekistan’s Government
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan — In his short career as a journalist in this Silk Road city in Kyrgyzstan’s south, Alisher Saipov gained a reputation for being driven, thorough, impassioned, brave and insatiably curious — though sometimes arrogant and abrasive. Above all, he was known for being outspoken.

headline: Innovating Our Way to Financial Crisis
text: The financial crisis that began late last summer, then took a brief vacation in September and October, is back with a vengeance.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a proposal to limit the types of food and beverages for sale at schools was imprecise in some editions about the extent of the proposal. It covers food served on special à la carte lines, in vending machines and in snack bars. It would not cover standard school cafeteria food, which must meet Department of Agriculture nutritional standards.

headline: Grandmother Puts the Children First
text: When Julia Santos moved to New York from Puerto Rico in 2003, things were looking up. Her fiancé made a good living as a mechanic. She saw her three grandchildren regularly. And after 11 years in separate cities, she and her daughter, Alaeida Cruz, were both in New York.

headline: Carefully Plotted Course Propels Gun Case to Top
text: Robert A. Levy, a rich libertarian lawyer who has never owned a gun, helped create and single-handedly financed the case that may finally resolve the meaning of the Second Amendment.

headline: Venezuela Hands Narrow Defeat to Chávez Plan
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Monday, Dec. 3 — Voters in this country narrowly defeated a proposed overhaul to the constitution in a contentious referendum over granting President Hugo Chávez sweeping new powers, the Election Commission announced early Monday.

headline: Addenda
text: Miscellany

headline: Mayor Backs Judges’ Raises
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday in his radio address that he supported a proposal to increase the salaries of New York State judges. The Legislature is expected to consider the increase in a special session this month. The judges last received a raise in 1999. Mr. Bloomberg called an increase “long overdue,” according to a transcript provided by his office. “Judges work for the public full time, all year round,” he said. “For that, they deserve not only our respect but also fair and just compensation.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mozart Manuscript Put Up for Auction
text: A single manuscript sheet from one of Mozart’s greatest works, found in a private collection in England, is to be sold at auction tomorrow at Sotheby’s in London. The sheet covers the cadenza for the first movement of the Sinfonia Concertante in E flat for Violin, Viola and Orchestra, a 1779 masterwork that lifted the composer into the ranks of the great at the age of 23, The Times of London reported. The sheet is one of only two surviving leaves from the original score. On its reverse side it also carries, in Mozart’s hand, the parts for two horns for two unidentified pieces. Simon Maguire, the senior specialist in Sotheby’s music department, said: “What makes the survival of this sheet particularly noteworthy is the fact that cadenzas are perhaps the least likely part of any musical piece ever to be written down. Cadenzas were usually improvised, so there was no need for written guidance from composers. In this instance, because the concerto is a work for two instruments, Mozart worked it out in advance and wrote it out separately to avoid the two instruments improvising independently and clashing.” The sheet is expected to sell for more than the estimate of $205,000.

headline: An Antifashion Classic Returns
text: WITH their chunky rubber soles and sturdy leather uppers, Dr. Martens are just the thing to be wearing if you happen to step in something unpleasant, which is exactly what the company itself did this spring.

headline: Page From Romance by Napoleon Is Sold
text: A single, messily handwritten page from a short unpublished 1795 novel based on the author’s brief romance with the sister of his brother’s wife sold yesterday for $35,400 at auction at Fontainebleau, outside Paris, The Associated Press reported. The author of the work, “Clisson and Eugénie,” was Napoleon Bonaparte, who wrote it when he was a 26-year-old general. The 22-page novel was never published in Napoleon’s lifetime, and the page, thanks to Napoleon’s sloppy penmanship, was long believed to be from a text about a historical figure named Clissot. The Osenat auction house did not disclose the identity of the buyer of the page, which came from the private collection of a French family.

headline: U.S. to Call Buffett in Gen Re Trial
text: Federal prosecutors intend to call Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, to testify about five former senior insurance executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its financial statements through $500 million in phony transactions, according to court papers filed today.

headline: The Power and Tumult of Mahler’s Second
text: NEWARK, Nov. 30 — “If you have not experienced this work before, I envy you,” Kelly Hall-Tompkins, a violinist with the New Jersey Symphony, said from the stage before the orchestra performed Mahler’s Symphony No. 2 (“Resurrection”) on Friday night at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here.

headline: Exciting Davis Cup Win for Those Who Saw It
text: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 2  The new Davis Cup champions from the United States played meaningless tennis Sunday against the Russians and recovered from what sounded like a memorable victory party with a full dance floor and rapidly emptying glasses.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Mortgage Relief Impact May Be Limited
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — The Bush administration’s effort to help at least some people in danger of defaulting on their subprime mortgages could affect only a small share of those who took out such loans during the final two years of the housing bubble, industry analysts said today.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: BUYING THE AIRWAVES Applications are due today from companies that want to bid on a valuable chunk of wireless spectrum that could be used to offer broadband data service. Google said on Friday that it was planning to bid. The Federal Communications Commission will not reveal information about the bids until mid-December.

headline: The Comic Book Is Back, in Luxe Coffee-Table Form
text: Two years ago, David Gabriel, a senior vice president at Marvel Comics, publisher of Spider-Man and the X-Men, was sitting in the company’s Fifth Avenue offices with a few colleagues trying to come up with a product tie-in for the Fantastic Four film to be released that summer — “something to get the extreme collector excited,” he said.

headline: Brooks Benefit Shows in Los Angeles Sell Out
text: Less than an hour was all it took to sell the 85,677 tickets for the five concerts that Garth Brooks is giving to raise money for victims of the recent wildfires in the Los Angeles area, The Associated Press reported. Proceeds of the concerts next month at Staples Center in Los Angeles will also provide equipment for fire departments around California. Tickets were about $45 each.

headline: Marbury’s Father Dies After Knicks-Suns Game
text: One of the most difficult periods of Stephon Marbury’s life took a painful turn last night when his father, Don, died after attending the Knicks’ game at Madison Square Garden, the team spokesman Jonathan Supranowitz confirmed.

headline: Class-Action Leftovers: How to Dispense the Money
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lester Ziffren, 101, First to Report Start of Spanish Civil War, Dies
text: Lester Ziffren, a foreign correspondent for United Press in the 1930s whose coded message from Madrid signaled to the world the start of the Spanish Civil War, died at his home in Manhattan on Nov. 12. He was 101.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Karim Abay, advertising director at Nylon magazine, New York, was promoted to associate publisher, a new post. Nylon is published by Nylon Holding.

headline: Off-Target Pitch Leaves Saints Scrambling for Playoff Spot
text: A botched trick play might have cost the New Orleans Saints their season.

headline: Climate Talks Take on Added Urgency After Report
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 2 — Thousands of government officials, industry lobbyists, environmental campaigners and observers are arriving on the Indonesian island of Bali for two weeks of talks starting Monday that are aimed at breathing new life into the troubled 15-year-old global climate treaty.

headline: Redskins’ Draining Week Ends in Emotional Defeat
text: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 2 — After a late field goal sent the Washington Redskins to another loss Sunday, cornerback Fred Smoot lay face down on the sodden turf for long enough that his teammates hovered over him, wondering if he was injured.

headline: Spam’s End? Maybe, if Time Allows
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Twenty-five years ago Steven T. Kirsch built a better mouse. Now he believes he has found a way to create a better trap  for spam, not mice  if he has enough time to finish his project.

headline: A Chastened Imus Returns to Radio
text: Nearly eight months after he was fired for making a racially and sexually disparaging remark about the Rutgers women’s basketball team, Don Imus went back on the radio at 6 a.m. today and vowed he would not say anything like that again.

headline: U.S. Says Iran Ended Atomic Arms Work
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — A new assessment by American intelligence agencies concludes that Iran halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003 and that the program remains frozen, contradicting judgment two years ago that Tehran was working relentlessly toward building a nuclear bomb.

headline: Teaching an Old Greyhound New Tricks
text: A venerable bus line that once asked travelers to “leave the driving to us” is leaving nothing to chance in a campaign to promote an ambitious makeover.

headline: Isle of Wight Festival Showcases Sex Pistols
text: The Sex Pistols and the Police will headline the Isle of Wight music festival next year, the BBC reported. At the event, from June 13 to 15, the Sex Pistols will appear on the second night, and the Police will be the prime attraction on closing night. Tickets go on sale on Dec. 10.

headline: New Orleans Hurt by Acute Rental Shortage
text: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 — Inside trailer No. 27 here at the A. L. Davis Playground, where the government set up a camp last year for displaced residents of Hurricane Katrina, Tracy Bernard’s meager possessions are all packed up, even though she has nowhere to go.

headline: Lesser Lights Get Chance to Shine for Boras
text: It is a winter meetings tradition, like the eager job-seekers, the Christmas tree in the lobby or Tommy Lasorda backslapping old pals. At some point each day, the agent Scott Boras will march from one elevator to another, carrying a well-worn leather briefcase stuffed with information on his free agents. Reporters will crowd around him, and executives will notice him.

headline: Official Leaves Post as Texas Prepares to Debate Science Education Standards
text: HOUSTON, Dec. 2 — After 27 years as a science teacher and 9 years as the Texas Education Agency’s director of science, Christine Castillo Comer said she did not think she had to remain “neutral” about teaching the theory of evolution.

headline: Repentance as the Key to Open Pearly Gates
text: Lumped by history with Schumann’s other large-scale vocal works, “Das Paradies und die Peri” has suffered guilt by association. “Genoveva,” his only finished opera, demonstrates a great man’s stubborn ineptitude in theatrical matters. “Scenes From Goethe’s ‘Faust’” sets out to be an opera, then loses heart and retreats into a kind of oratorio. Beautiful music in both cases is squandered on unsustainable formats.

headline: A.P. to Reorganize Work and Accent Multimedia
text: After a decade of watching newspapers and rival wire services shrink, The Associated Press, the 161-year-old news cooperative, is refitting itself to handle the 24-hour news cycle it helped create.

headline: California Taking Aim at Uninsured on the Roads
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 — The California insurance commissioner filed a proposed ballot initiative last month that aims to increase penalties for driving without car insurance in the state, which ranks only 49th in the nation in insured motorists.

headline: The Climate in Bali and Washington
text: So far, this has been an encouraging year for people who care about global warming. Governors have signed regional agreements to cap greenhouse gas emissions. The federal courts are pressing Washington to take action. Venture capitalists have poured money into cleaner fuels. Polls show rising public concern.

headline: Leno to Pay Salaries of Staff Members
text: Jay Leno, the host of “The Tonight Show,” joined his NBC colleague, Conan O’Brien, in assuring the nonwriting staff of his show that he would pay their salaries for this week. The staff was laid off last week by NBC because the shows have been out of production since the strike by the Writers Guild of America.

headline: Southern California Ports Move to Curb Emissions From Shipping Industry
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 — The breeze coming off the Pacific ought to clean up the smoggy interior of Southern California. But it does just the opposite, picking up tons of shoreline air pollution from the tens of thousands of diesel engines on trucks and ships at the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach.

headline: Romney Plans to Address Concerns About His Faith
text: Mitt Romney will address head-on suspicions about his Mormon faith in a speech he plans to deliver Thursday in Texas, not far from where John F. Kennedy delivered an address nearly 50 years ago that many credit with defusing concerns about his Catholic faith in his election.

headline: Russian Firm Buys LiveJournal
text: The owner of LiveJournal, a blogging and social-networking site, agreed yesterday to sell the company to SUP, a Russian online media company, in the latest example of deal-making in the social-networking sector.

headline: U.S. Urges Iraq to Take Advantage of Lull
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 2 — Deputy Secretary of State John D. Negroponte, in Baghdad after a week of meetings with Iraqi provincial leaders, said Sunday that lawmakers must take advantage of the decline in daily violence in recent months to pass crucial legislation and improve basic government services.

headline: For Miami, Losses and Anger Mount
text: MIAMI, Dec. 2  There was a mixture of anger and frustration in the Miami Dolphins’ locker room Sunday as they moved one step closer to N.F.L. infamy. Losing to the division-rival Jets would sting badly under normal circumstances. Getting routed at home in a game that could have broken their season-long losing streak left the Dolphins in uncharted emotional territory.

headline: Ukraine Blast Kills 4 Miners
text: DONETSK, Ukraine, Dec. 2 (Reuters)  An explosion on Sunday killed four men in the same mine in eastern Ukraine hit by the country’s worst mining accident last month.

headline: A Single Trick Can Make All the Difference
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 — The premier event at the Fall North American Championships here, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, were to be decided late Sunday, with 14 teams (up from the traditional 10) competing over two sessions.

headline: Seven Held Hostage in Robbery, Police Say
text: Two armed robbers burst into a New Jersey home last night and tied up seven occupants, including a 2-month-old infant, according to one victim and the police.

headline: New Orleans Didn’t Meet the Test for a Debate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kings 107, Rockets 99
text: SACRAMENTO, Dec. 2 (AP)  Kevin Martin praised his former coach Rick Adelman before Saturday night’s game, then went out and helped spoil Adelman’s return to Sacramento.

headline: Help for the Homeless, and Hope for an Addict
text: The idea was born more than a month ago in front of a White Castle near a busy intersection in Downtown Brooklyn. It was a cold day, and Felix Middleton encountered a homeless woman sitting in front of the fast food restaurant. He wanted to help.

headline: Ward Runs and Runs and Then Limps Off
text: CHICAGO, Dec. 2 — The cliché insists that all athletes put their pants on the same way, one leg at a time, but it was not as easy as that for Giants running back Derrick Ward on Sunday after the best performance of his career in a 21-16 victory against the Bears.

headline: An End to the Free Ride on Trains in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 — It may be hard to fathom for subway riders in cities like New York, Chicago and Boston, but the transit system in Los Angeles has no turnstiles, gates or other barriers where tickets are collected or checked.

headline: Moses Weinstein, 95, Legislator and Judge, Dies
text: Moses M. Weinstein, a Queens Democrat who served in the State Assembly, with stints as majority leader and acting speaker in the 1960s, and nearly two decades as a trial and appellate judge of the State Supreme Court, died on Friday at Memorial Hospital in Pembroke Pines, Fla., where he lived. He was 95.

headline: Top Editor and Two Colleagues to Leave Media Blog Gawker
text: When half of a media outlet’s editorial staff decides to jump ship, chances are it will be reported first on the media gossip blog Gawker — even, it turns out, when those departures are from Gawker itself.

headline: Air America to Test Its Fan Base and Its Sea Legs
text: In the current political climate, it seems that no news item is too small to be lampooned in the blogosphere by the guys across the aisle.

headline: ‘Enchanted’ Remains Most Charming
text: The revisionist Disney fairy tale “Enchanted” continued to work its magic, taking first place for a second consecutive weekend at the North American box office with a gross of $17 million, according to estimates by the tracking company Media by Numbers. Second place went for a second straight weekend to “This Christmas” (distributed by Sony/Screen Gems), a family tale with Delroy Lindo and Chris Brown that took in $8.4 million. “Beowulf” (Paramount), at No. 3, gathered $7.8 million. The weekend’s sole newcomer to finish in the Top 5 was the medical thriller “Awake” (MGM). Starring Hayden Christensen as a heart transplant patient, it finished in fourth place with $6 million. Fifth place went to “Hitman,” the gory video game adaptation from Fox, which grossed $5.8 million.

headline: At Wikipedia, Illustrators May Be Paid
text: The foundation that runs Wikipedia has finally agreed to pay contributors to the online encyclopedia a modest fee for their work. But it won’t pay the thousands of people who participate in creating the wiki pages — just artists who create “key illustrations” for the site.

headline: Hoop Dreams and Ice Fishing in a Small Town
text: “Nimrod Nation,” an eight-part documentary with its second evening on the Sundance Channel tonight, is yet another reminder that if you are not watching “Friday Night Lights,” you should be. The new series takes its inspiration so closely from the NBC drama (and the Buzz Bissinger book on which it is based) that it almost seems to be rampaging on intellectual property. The goal is exactly the same, to portray life in a hardscrabble place that finds redemptive value in its obsessive relationship to high school sports.

headline: Truckers in Maine, Feeling High Costs of Diesel Fuel, Urge State to Intervene
text: DAMARISCOTTA, Me., Dec. 1  Truckers across Maine are mobilizing against the rising price of diesel fuel, lobbying politicians to provide relief from high costs they say are crippling their businesses and causing some to stop driving.

headline: A Bag Problem Blossoms
text: Now that the leaves have finally fallen, a new decoration becomes more visible on the nation’s many deciduous trees: those plastic bags that float high into tree limbs and flutter noisily with each autumn breeze. Despite this unappealing vision, a ban of all plastic bags would be hard to champion, although the earth would be a greener and healthier place without them. What this unsightly airborne litter does offer is an opportunity for industry and consumers to think a lot harder about how much such convenience is costing the planet.

headline: Stabbing Leaves Woman Dead and Four Children Wounded
text: SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 2 — A 48-year-old man stabbed his companion and four of their children from previous relationships on Saturday night, killing the woman and injuring one child critically, officials and neighbors said Sunday.

headline: Ad for New Train Service Strains European Taste
text: LONDON, Dec. 2 — An advertisement in Belgium promoting the newly accelerated Euro- star trains recently caused a rare sense-of-humor failure in Britain.

headline: Back in Times Square, Toshiba Stands Tall
text: An advertiser that stuck with Times Square during bad times is returning to take advantage of better times.

headline: Small Merchants Gain Large Presence on Web
text: MOM-AND-POP retailers have helplessly stood by over the last decade as big-box merchants steamrolled over them. Online, though, small merchants are not going down without a fight.

headline: New CDs
text: WYCLEF JEAN “Carnival Vol. II: Memoirs of an Immigrant” (Columbia)

headline: Suspected of Fixing, Davydenko Is Also in Need of Repair
text: Portland, Ore.

headline: The Day’s Best
text: Lofa Tatupu had three interceptions to lead the Seahawks past the Eagles, 28-24. He returned the first two inside the Eagles’ 20, and made the third at the Seattle 4 in the final minute.

headline: Climate Talks Take on Added Urgency After Report
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 2 — Thousands of government officials, industry lobbyists, environmental campaigners and observers are arriving on the Indonesian island of Bali for two weeks of talks starting Monday that are aimed at breathing new life into the troubled 15-year-old global climate treaty.

headline: From Stand in Long Island Slavery Case, a Snapshot of a Hidden U.S. Problem
text: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y., Nov. 30  The two tiny Indonesian women know just a handful of English words. They know Windex. Fantastik (the cleanser, not the adjective). They know the words Master and Missus, which they were taught to use in addressing the Long Island couple they served as live-in help for five years in the sylvan North Shore hamlet of Muttontown.

headline: Albany Panel to Assess Health Risks of Mold
text: It has been described by state lawmakers as posing an “unacceptable risk to New York State’s health and environment.” It drove Bianca Jagger, the former wife of Mick Jagger, from her Park Avenue apartment in 2003. It forced hundreds of residents in Westbury, on Long Island, to begin fleeing their apartment complex last week.

headline: Effort to Combat Internet Piracy Gains Strength in France
text: LONDON, Dec. 2 — Before the French election last spring, the rock ’n’ roll musician Johnny Hallyday endorsed the man who went on to become president of France, Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: Love, War and Betrayal in Busy Lives of the Estranged
text: Just about everyone left living at the end of Shakespeare’s “Cymbeline” is onstage for the play’s crowded climax. And just about everyone has a surprise or two to disclose.

headline: For Justices, Another Day on Detainees
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 — Observers at the Supreme Court on Wednesday should probably be excused in advance for concluding that they have wandered into a time warp.

headline: OPEC’s Tough Call: Raise or Hold Oil Supply
text: After a year of dizzying gains for energy markets, a rapid fall in oil prices lately is posing a dilemma for OPEC, the oil-producing cartel.

headline: Japan Urges China to Let Yuan Rise More Quickly
text: The Japanese finance minister, Fukushiro Nukaga, urged Chinese leaders at a meeting in Beijing to allow their currency to appreciate at a faster pace, joining calls from governments in Europe and the United States.

headline: Latin Translation: A Vote for Latin
text: Primum, duces nostros linguam Latinam non iam studere triste non videtur.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Enchanted’ Remains Most Charming

headline: Bush and Democrats Renew War of Words
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — With Congress returning to the capital, President Bush and Democratic lawmakers renewed their war of words today and seemed as far apart as ever on Iraq war funding, tax increases, wiretap authorization and other issues.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report on Saturday in the World Briefing column on a decision by the Israeli Supreme Court about plans to cut the electricity supply to the Gaza Strip misstated the reason for the court ruling. It ordered the delay to enable the government to respond to groups challenging the plan, not to give the groups more time to provide additional details. (Go to Article)

headline: Lashing Justice
text: Muslims who wonder why non-Muslims are often baffled, angered, even frightened by some governments’ interpretation of Islamic law need only look to the cases of two women in Saudi Arabia and Sudan threatened with barbaric lashings.

headline: Hospice Care: When the Dying Live On
text: To the Editor:

headline: Woman Is Fatally Stabbed
text: A woman was stabbed to death and her grandson was wounded on Saturday in her house on Alexander Avenue, the Suffolk County Police said yesterday. The police were called to the house about 2 p.m. by the grandson, Matthew Watson, 20, who lived there, the police said. Mr. Watson, who had several stab wounds, told officers he had been attacked by an intruder, the police said. The police did not release the name and age of the woman who was found dead.

headline: Democracy Advocate Wins in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG, Monday, Dec. 3 — A victory on Sunday by a popular figurehead of the democracy movement in an election for a legislative seat here has given fresh momentum to demands for the early introduction of promised democratic reforms.

headline: Gala for a Beach Boy and a Motown Diva
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 — Diana Ross emerged from the housing projects of Detroit to become a globally recognized pop music sensation with an all-female Motown group and, later, a solo artist with 70 hit singles. Brian Wilson was the lead songwriter and co-founder of a Southern California band famed for its catchy surfer anthems.

headline: L.S.U. Is In, but Not Without Grumbling
text: When the participants in college football’s major games were announced last night, there were no surprises.

headline: Requiem for a Red Lobster: A Novel of Downsizing
text: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Nov. 28 — Stewart O’Nan sat down for lunch at a Red Lobster along a strip-malled highway here and wondered if the waitress would try to entice him into ordering not just one, but two drinks before his meal. She didn’t.

headline: Yanks Give Twins Deadline on Santana
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 2  The Yankees insist that they want an answer from the Minnesota Twins by Monday night or they will back out of trade talks for the ace left-hander Johan Santana. The Yankees have offered Phil Hughes, Melky Cabrera and a midlevel prospect, and they believe that should be enough.

headline: A Vote for Latin
text: London

headline: Dear Alfred, Gertie and Mummy-snooks: Love, Noelie
text: As a bright young thing — which, it could be argued, is what he remained until almost his dying day — Noël Coward wrote letters filled with effusive glee. As a 12-year-old he would send home “squillions of kisses to all.” A couple of years later he was addressing his mother as “Ducky old Diddleums” and accurately advising her, “You’ve got a fascinating youth for your son, my dear.”

headline: Officer Hurt on Expressway
text: A Nassau County police officer was injured yesterday when a car ran into his patrol car, which was parked along the Long Island Expressway, the police said. Officer Gennaro Ferraro was parked on the shoulder of the expressway in Plainview, near Exit 48, when the patrol car was struck from behind about 5:44 a.m., the police said. Officer Ferraro suffered head and back injuries, and the driver and passenger of the car that struck the police officer’s vehicle were also injured, the police said. All three were taken to Nassau University Medical Center, where Officer Ferraro was in intensive care. The driver, who was identified as Paul V. Reid, 27, of Brentwood, was charged with vehicular assault and driving while intoxicated, the police said.

headline: Popular Demand
text: According to M:Metrics, which tracks mobile use, a total of 14.3 million users ages 18 to 34 went online from their mobile devices in the three months ended in September, followed by 9.2 million users ages 35 to 54.

headline: Lonely No More, Huckabee Faces Hurdles
text: DES MOINES, Dec. 2 — Mike Huckabee spent the weekend in New Hampshire, where he saw something he had rarely seen in his two years as a Republican candidate for president: People. Lots of them. Living rooms and halls packed with voters, campaign aides, reporters and jostling television crews.

headline: Monday’s Matchup
text: Baltimore’s defense is ranked third against the run, but New England is most dangerous when Tom Brady is passing, and the Ravens have been much more pedestrian in that area. The Eagles were successful last week by being physical with Brady and his receivers; the Ravens have a reputation for playing the same way. It could be cold and windy at game time, so Willis McGahee could see extra carries. He has 910 yards this season, but he has never scored against the Patriots and has never played on a team that has defeated them. Losing Rosevelt Colvin for the season was the first serious injury for New England this year. Then again, the Ravens, who have lost five in a row and average 23.7 fewer points a game than the Patriots, may not be able to take advantage of his absence. ANDREW DAS

headline: NBC to Pay Outsiders for Blocks of Programs
text: NBC has made an ambitious deal, apparently the first of its kind, to buy a two-hour — or perhaps even three-hour — block of prime-time programming from outside producers, including Thom Beers, the creator of adventure documentary series like “Deadliest Catch” and “Ice Road Truckers.”

headline: Manning’s Turnaround Lifts Giants
text: CHICAGO, Dec. 2 — The Giants needed a comeback, and the ball was in the uneasy hands of the much-maligned quarterback Eli Manning. John Mara, the team’s president and co-owner, paced a hallway outside the press box. His view out the window was of dark Lake Michigan, not brightly lit Soldier Field.

headline: Trouble on a Vital Road in Afghanistan
text: SALAR, Afghanistan — The ruined Afghan police truck smoldered on the highway in the village bazaar, flames rising from its cargo bed. The village was silent. Its residents had hidden themselves before an American patrol arrived.

headline: Unearthing War’s Horrors Years Later in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 2 — Shortly after the outbreak of the Korean War in June 1950, Kim Man-sik, a military police sergeant, received an urgent radio message from the South Korean Army’s Counterintelligence Corps: Go to local police stations, take custody of scores of Communist suspects held there and execute them.

headline: Spooky Rock, Noise and No Apologies
text: Sunburned Hand of the Man is a nebulous band. It comes from Boston and New York and points in between. It has a revolving cast of musicians, depending on where it’s performing or what it’s doing. Its music is improvised rock, spooky and droney. Its singers utter unintelligible words. It draws no conclusions; it leaves some of the heavy lifting to you.

headline: Nevada Learns to Cash In on Sales of Federal Land
text: LAS VEGAS — When it opens in 2009, the Clark County Shooting Park will be something to behold, through a scope or otherwise: hundreds of acres devoted to all things gun and bow, complete with a rifle range, a skeet center and an R.V. “host area.”

headline: Two Brothers Are Shot, One of Them Fatally, Outside Bar Near Columbia Campus
text: Two brothers were shot, one fatally, in an argument with other men early yesterday outside a restaurant and bar near Columbia University as the wounded man tried to shield his younger brother from gunfire, the police and the men’s mother said.

headline: In Macho Argentina, a New Beacon for Gay Tourists
text: BUENOS AIRES — Home to the sexy tango and strapping meat-eaters, this South American capital has long been thought of as a bastion of macho attitudes. But a new hotel here is adding to the city’s growing image as a bastion of gay-friendliness.

headline: A Warning About East Coast Tsunamis
text: The risk is low. But the consequences could be high, with deadly waves striking the coastal communities of Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey and killing thousands of people.

headline: New U.N. Envoy in Iraq Sets Out Strategy to Revive Hopes Crushed in 2003 Attack
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 2 — The new United Nations special representative for Iraq has been here barely three weeks, but he says he is moving swiftly to reassert the organization’s involvement in a place from which it had largely retreated after its compound was bombed four years ago.

headline: Party’s Triumph Raises Question of Putin’s Plans
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 2 —With President Vladimir V. Putin’s opponents persistently hobbled by the Kremlin, his party swept Sunday to the kind of landslide long predicted for the parliamentary elections. Yet the results, while a triumph for Mr. Putin, also usher in a new era of political instability for Russia.

headline: Venezuelans Decide Whether to Give Chávez More Power
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 2 — Voters went to polling stations throughout Venezuela on Sunday to cast ballots on a referendum over constitutional changes that would significantly enhance the power of President Hugo Chávez.

headline: Puppets Are Rescued After a Seamy Spoof
text: Even though 23 years had passed since Rusty the Rooster and Jerome the Giraffe last appeared in a Canadian television production, the children of their creator, Bob Homme, were less than pleased. Last week, the family’s anger over the unauthorized use of the puppets, stars of “The Friendly Giant” children’s program, led to their removal from the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation’s museum along with dozens of other items from the show, which ran for 26 years on the network.

headline: Colts Add Distance and Subtract Some Stress
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 2 — The Indianapolis Colts all but wrapped up their fifth consecutive division title Sunday with a victory against the Jacksonville Jaguars. But they also won something nearly as valuable: time.

headline: Long Night for Swashbucklers in Uncharted Territory
text: It was a long Friday night at Terminal 5 at the first of two sold-out performances by Ween, the band from New Hope, Pa., that has turned two decades of long nights into one unexpectedly long — and fruitful — career. And this long night was ending with a long song, loudly sung by just about everyone in the building.

headline: Only a Month Left to Iowa
text: As the countdown to the Iowa caucuses hits the one-month point, an already long and intense campaign enters a new level of engagement as candidates on both sides of the ticket battle ferociously for undecided voters.

headline: Highway 1 in Afghanistan
text: Highway 1, the main route between Kabul and Kandahar, symbolizes both the ambitions and frustrations in Afghanistan six years after the Taliban were chased from power.

headline: Chavez Defeated
text: In a surprising victory, voters in Venezuela defeated a contentious referendum that would have given President Hugo Chavez sweeping new powers through a series of constitutional reforms.

headline: Vivendi to Acquire Activision
text: Vivendi said Sunday that it planned to acquire a controlling stake in Activision in a deal that creates a rival to Electronic Arts as the world’s largest independent video game publisher.

headline: Kent Roberts: I’d Rather Not Know
text: I always thought that someday everything would just make sense to me. It never happened. Should I have married my first-grade girlfriend? Should I not have? Ignorance is bliss.

headline: Lampert: From Sage to Upstart?
text: Billionaire investor Edward S. Lampert, long thought by many to have a midas touch when it came to bargain hunting, seems to have recast himself in the role of the underdog in the wake of Sears Holding‘s dismal third-quarter earnings report.

headline: AdBrite Reels In $23 Million
text: AdBrite, the advertising sales and services network founded by Phillip Kaplan, notorious bubble chronicler and founder of numerous popular personal Web sites, has landed $23 million in Series C funding.

headline: Roundup at the Crack of Yawn
text: Lasso your wit and tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions at right.

headline: PrivateBancorp Raids LaSalle Bankers
text: Chicago-based PrivateBancorp, which has already hired 34 high-level bankers from LaSalle Bank since Sept. 30, continues to win over LaSalle employees, even in other markets, according to The Chicago Tribune.

headline: Samsung Offices Raided Amid Bribery Probe
text: Prosecutors raided Samsung Securities, a financial arm of Samsung, on Friday, searching for evidence of a slush fund as they expanded the investigation into a corruption scandal.

headline: Nevada Learns to Cash in on Sales of Federal Land
text: Tens of thousands of acres of federal lands in the Las Vegas area have been sold under an unusual law pushed through Congress nearly a decade ago by the Nevada delegation. The sales have grossed nearly $3 billion and counting.

headline: Short Seller Sinks Teeth Into Insurer
text: William Ackman may be incapable of giving short answers, if his hourlong presentation at an investment conference last Wednesday is any sign. But the activist hedge fund manager is nothing if not persistent.

headline: European Central Bank Seeks to Ease Credit
text: The European Central Bank said that it would extend a lending deadline in December to help the banking system through a period of unusually tight credit at the end of the year, The New York Times reported. The action represents a renewed effort by the bank to calm a lending system that had showed signs of returning to normal recently but now appears nearly as nervous as during the summer days when the global credit turmoil began.

headline: U.S. May Scuttle Bain’s 3Com Deal, Report Says
text: U.S. intelligence agencies may scuttle Bain Capital‘s $2.2 billion cash buyout of 3Com, announced in September, because of concerns about the role of Chinese minority investor Huawei Technologies, The Washington Times reported.

headline: Deutsche Is Said to Reconsider Backing Northern Rock Bid
text: Deutsche Bank is threatening to abandon plans to back Virgin Group‘s bid for Northern Rock, according to the Sunday Telegraph newspaper.

headline: Consorte Media Gets $7 Million Round
text: Consorte Media, a Hispanic online media company, said Monday that it received $7 million in a round of venture investment led by Sutter Hill Ventures. The Series B round also included the Mayfield Fund, a return investor.

headline: FL Group Sheds Stake in AMR
text: FL Group, the Icelandic investment firm that had pressed American Airlines parent AMR to sell off assets, is now washing its hands of the company.

headline: Italy’s ENI Buys Burren Energy for $3.58 Billion
text: Italy’s Eni has agreed to buy oil explorer Burren Energy for 1.736 billion pounds ($3.58 billion), boosting the oil major’s operations in the Republic of Congo and giving it a toehold in Turkmenistan, where a new leadership is warming to foreign investment.

headline: Market Has Spoken on BHP Bid, Rio Chief Says
text: The market value of mining giant Rio Tinto continues to outstrip the multibillion dollar bid put forward by rival BHP Billiton, Rio’s Chief Executive Tom Albanese said Sunday.

headline: Hong Kong Billionaire to Pony Up for Facebook, Report Says
text: Li Ka-shing may have agreed to write a $60 million check to help Facebook founder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg build out his fast-growing social networking site, but a media company controlled by the Hong Kong billionaire denies that the money went through them.

headline: Behind Cruz’s Rise and Fall at Morgan Stanley
text: In 1982, John J. Mack, now the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, interviewed a fresh-faced Harvard Business School graduate named Zoe Cruz for an associate position in the firm’s bond trading business. With his support, she flew higher in the investment bank, rising to the level of co-president and Mr. Mack’s heir apparent.

headline: Eldercare, an Inevitable Work/Life Issue
text: If there is one issue that most of us will face, it is likely to be the need or desire to spend time with an aging relative or close friend. I have a 93-year-old grandmother who lives a remarkably independent life. She lives in and cares for her own home, prepares her own meals and does most of her own food shopping. Until two years ago, when she gracefully agreed not to use her car anymore, she also drove. What she wants and needs most is company, and she never fails to recognize how busy all of us “young people” around her are even as my mother, my two cousins and I do our best to visit each week. We are the lucky ones. My grandmother is relatively healthy and autonomous, and we are able to enjoy the time we spend with her. I also have a flexible working life, so if I visit her on a Tuesday, I can work on a Saturday to make up for it.

headline: In Equity Office Deal, a Trio of New Kids on the Block
text: When the Blackstone Group closed it $39 billion deal for Samuel Zell’sEquity Office Properties earlier this year, it was the largest leveraged buyout ever. But, says The Deal.com, that was only half the remarkable story.

headline: Nasdaq Opens Up in Beijing to Seek Mainland Offerings
text: Nasdaq, the No. 2 U.S. stock exchange, set up shop in Beijing on Monday as it looks to attract more Chinese firms to list on the exchange instead of alternatives such as Hong Kong.

headline: Broadview Seeks $287.5 Million I.P.O.
text: Broadview Networks, a venture capital-backed voice and data networking company, filed with regulators on Friday to raise about $287.5 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

headline: Tribune Deal Gets F.C.C. Nod
text: The Federal Communications Commission late Friday approved real estate magnate Samuel Zell’s $8.2 billion buyout of Tribune, with conditions, giving the company just enough time to close the deal by the end of the year as it had promised investors.

headline: The Early Word: Iowa Heat
text: While the temperature in Iowa may have dipped into the teens over the weekend, things are getting pretty hot between the Democratic rivals and in fact, between the Republican rivals, too.

headline: Panel Studies Growing Problem of ‘Toxic Mold’
text: The New York State Toxic Mold Task Force will hold its first meeting on Tuesday, in Latham, N.Y. The panel represents an attempt by health officials and medical experts to address what they describe as a growing but little-recognized mold problem that has damaged property and affected the health of tenants, homeowners and their children.

headline: Pandit Is Said to Emerge as Top Candidate for Citi
text: Citigroup is closing in on a chief executive and the board appears to be leaning toward an insider, The New York Times reported Saturday, citing people briefed on the situation. The inside candidate, Vikram S. Pandit, is a former Morgan Stanley investment banker who joined Citigroup seven months ago, these people said.

headline: SK Telecom Buys Hanaro fo $1.2 Billion
text: SK Telecom, South Korea’s largest cellular carrier, said Monday it has agreed to buy a controlling 38.89 percent stake in broadband and telephone service provider Hanarotelecom for 1.09 trillion won ($1.2 billion), equipping itself to challenge the country’s biggest fixed-line operator, KT, following deregulation next year that will allow telecom companies to offer bundled services.

headline: Swiss Life to Pay $1.64 Billion for Germany’s AWD
text: Swiss Life surprised investors on Monday with plans to buy AWD, the dynamic German financial advisory group, hard on the heels of big disposals in recent weeks.

headline: The Zeppelin Comes In for a Landing
text: Yesterday, the Bagger left his New Jersey redoubt for the wilds of New York City, trespagging on the Meadowlands along the way, always an exercise fraught with peril on a game day (the Jets beat the Fish 40-13). But we snuck by on Route 3 in the fourth quarter.

headline: Russian Firm Buys LiveJournal
text: The owner of LiveJournal, a blogging and social-networking site, agreed Sunday to sell the company to SUP, a Russian online media company, in the latest example of deal-making in the social-networking sector.

headline: Juno What?
text: The Bagger was talking with an experienced Oscar campaigner last night and they both agreed that “Juno” might be the year’s little movie that could. Not that it is favored to win all the marbles, but it will probably be in the mix, in part because an irresistible screenplay by newcomer Diablo Cody.

headline: Buffett Buys $2 Billion in TXU Bonds
text: Warren E. Buffett put $2 billion of Berkshire Hathaway‘s cash to work at the end of last week when the company purchased high-yielding bonds issued by Dallas-based power producer TXU Corp., according to Fortune.

headline: Thain Plans Cultural Changes at Merrill
text: John Thain, who begins his new job as Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive on Monday, told The Financial Times that he wants to remake Merrill’s management culture to look more like that of Goldman Sachs, where he once worked.

headline: Lawyers Compete, Except in Bonuses
text: In his weekly DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin takes a look at the somewhat strange tradition of top-tier law firms matching each other virtually dollar for dollar on new bonuses. The tradition, he says, is out of step with many other businesses such as investment banks — lawyers’ closest business cousins — which typically pay their people based on merit and the health of their own businesses, while still being competitive in a down year.

headline: [APPENDED] The United States and Liechtenstein — [NOT] Odd Pair Out
text: Now that Australia has ratified the Kyoto Protocol, that leaves the United States and Liechstenstein as the only industrialized countries not bound by the troubled pact, which took legal force in 2005 and has binding limits on greenhouse gases that expire in 2012.

headline: Don’t You Hate How Marc Jacobs Gets No Attention?
text: The Lagerfeld documentary is so last season. Now we’re fixated on Loic Prigent’s film, “Marc Jacobs & Louis Vuitton,” which recently came out on DVD in Paris and will be shown Stateside on the Sundance Channel at the end of January. The film was made after a year’s unfettered access to the designer and his work process (beaucoup de all-nighters, ponderous brain-storming sessions and Tiger’s Milk energy bars). Admittedly, the translation is a bit choppy and the point-of-view sometimes verges on wide-eyed, but there are some brilliant moments. We nearly broke our DVD player’s rewind button to get the following details on the ultimate fashion insider’s bag—the so-called “emergency bag” all models receive before the Louis Vuitton show in Paris. The Vuitton baggies are a million miles removed from the little ones we’re used to seeing backstage, and contain…

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

headline: The Hour Grows Late
text: Can you believe how late the big award movies are coming this year? Check the “Coming Soon” and “Just Arrived” ads and you’ll find “Sweeney Todd,” “The Kite Runner,” “There Will Be Blood,” “Juno,” “Atonement” and “The Great Debaters.” “Charlie Wilson’s War,” which was going to be one of the last, is moving up a few days, from Christmas day to Dec. 21, according to the Hollywood Reporter. Universal, which is putting out the movie, which stars Tom Hanks as a Congressman who turns a theater of combat into his own private Idaho, said “people are really enjoying the movie,” and there was “no reason ” not to take advantage of an earlier release slot. Yeah, that and the question of how in the world the members of the Academy are going to find a way to see all of those movies.

headline: You’re Gonna Get It
text: Those of you who have yet to take in the four-hour documentary Peter Bogdanovich conjured out of the career of Tom Petty can get a taste come the Super Bowl, Feb. 3, to see why the pride of Gainesville, Fla., is one of the South’s best storytellers since Faulkner.

headline: Edwards Ad Attacks Drug Companies, Lobbyists
text: Former Senator John Edwards began running a new television ad today in New Hampshire repeating his argument that he is the candidate wiling totake on lobbyists and powerful interests in Washington.

headline: U.S. to Call Buffett in Gen Re Trial
text: Federal prosecutors intend to call Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, to testify against five former senior insurance executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its financial statements through $500 million in phony transactions, according to court papers filed Monday.

headline: Randstad to Bid $5.2 Billion for Vedior
text: Dutch staffing company Randstad said Monday it will bid around $5.17 billion in cash and shares for Vedior in a management-backed takeover that would create the world’s second-largest employment agency.

headline: Agrium and UAP to Merge in $2.16 Billion Deal
text: Agrium, the third-largest fertilizer producer in Canada and the United States, agreed to buy UAP for about $2.16 billion to boost sales of crop products as demand rises.

headline: One for McCain
text: A conservative kiss to McCain: The editorial page of the Union Leader of Manchester, N.H., has endorsed John McCain for the Republican nomination for president. The editorial, written by Joseph W. McQuaid, the newspaper’s publisher, was published on the newspaper’s front page. It states:

headline: The U.S. Military’s Energy-Saving Efforts
text: Australia’s new prime minister waited hours after taking office before he signed the Kyoto Protocol, an international agreement that sets limits on greenhouse-gas emissions. The predictable reactions took only moments: spontaneous applause erupted at the international climate summit in Bali, and the United States was suddenly exposed as the only major industrialized nation refusing to join.

headline: The big scam
text: Brad DeLong has this line about the Bush administration — that it’s worse than you could have imagined, even when you take into account the fact that it’s worse than you could have imagined.

headline: Monday Kickoff: The Craziness Continues
text: With all that has happened this college football season, did we really think that finding two teams to play in the national title game would come without controversy? Mark Richt, Pete Carroll and several other coaches may not be happy to be on the outside looking in at the Louisiana State-Ohio State matchup, but John Romano of the St. Petersburg Times writes that it’s the perfect culmination to a dizzying season.

headline: The Battle Lines Are Drawn
text: In his Web column today, Adam Nagourney writes that “with less than a month to go before the voting starts, it’s becoming clear that Iowa has become the prime battle ground for Democrats, while New Hampshire has become the main stage for Republicans.”

headline: Inside the Pentagon Chief’s Jet
text: Editors’ Note: Thom Shanker, a Washington correspondent of The New York Times, is traveling with Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates during one of his many trips abroad.

headline: Euro Disney
text: The first time I visited Euro Disneyland outside Paris, for Euro Disney’s 2004 annual meeting held in March, I realized something was very different from the Disney parks I had known in the United States.

headline: The Learning Curve of a Freshman
text: We are smack in the middle of the B.C.S. controversy, but The Quad is also going to be a one-stop emporium for your college basketball needs. And one of our main contributors during the season will be Stephen Danley, who played forward at Penn before graduating last spring. He received a Marshall Scholarship to study at Oxford. Today, Stephen breaks down the shortcomings in the game of the Gonzaga freshman Austin Daye and the potential he has to become a special offensive player.

text: The media industry may be getting Guitar Hero envy.

headline: DVD Movies With an iTunes Copy: Worth More?
text: Richard Greenfield, the Pali Research analyst, writes this morning that he hears that the long standoff between Apple and Hollywood over movie downloads may be heading for a resolution. As of right now, Disney, of which Steve Jobs is a director and large shareholder, sells movies through the iTunes Store, and the other major studios don’t. The issue has been that the studios want to charge more money for downloads than Mr. Jobs thinks they are worth. The studios also worry about offending Wal-Mart and Target, which are by far their largest distributors. (The report is here, but requires registration to see.)

headline: Euro 2008 ‘Group of Death’
text: In case you were still dreaming of Lionel Messi’s crafty run down the left flank in Barcelona’s 1-1 derby draw with Espanyol and missed the Euro 2008 draw on ESPN2 at 6 a.m. Sunday, uefa.com re-creates it for you online.

headline: Crossing the Finish Line
text: The Bagger wasn’t the only gawker from the House of Many Doors at last night’s premiere of “The Golden Compass.” The Baguette, too, graced the proceedings and filed some gimlet-eyed observations.

headline: Leno Will Pay Non-Writing Staff
text: Days after being laid off by NBC, the non-writing staff of the “Tonight Show with Jay Leno” will be paid directly by Mr. Leno, the network confirmed on Sunday.

headline: A New Dose of Reality for NBC
text: Thom Beers has had an impressive track record on cable: “Monster Garage,” “Deadliest Catch” and “Ice Road Truckers,” produced by his company, Original Productions, have been bona fide hits for the Discovery Channel and the History Channel. Now he will try to transfer those talents to a broadcast network.

headline: Waterpiece by John Sturgeon
text: A video from the Getty's video archives, from 1977.

headline: Bloomberg’s ‘Munchkin’ Moment
text: Did Diane Sawyer really refer to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as a “munchkin” this morning on national television? Indeed she did.

headline: Monday Morning Motorsport
text: Formula One: Lewis Hamilton appeared on Top Gear in Britain on Sunday. The highlight of the 10-minute segment was the “Star in a Reasonably Priced Car” feature, in which celebrities lap the Top Gear track in a Suzuki Liana.

headline: Danny Brown’s Lost Initials
text: A while back on this blog we introduced you to the story of the chef-restaurateur Danny Brown and his contretemps with the chef-restaurateur Daniel Boulud. Mr. Brown e-mailed me early this morning to say that the battle had ended, and not in his favor.

headline: Raising a Glass to (Almost) Organic Wine
text: For years, the main color decision a wine drinker had to make was red or white. Now the question is whether the wine should also be green.

headline: The Johan Santana Meetings
text: The Johan Santana Meetings started in Nashville this morning to coincide with the official 2007 Baseball Winter Meetings. Santana, the superb Minnesota Twins pitcher, is expected to be traded and his immediate future will be the main focus here.

headline: Screen Test: Natalie Portman
text: The actress ('Star Wars,' 'Closer,' 'V for Vendetta') talks candidly about becoming a performer at a young age.

headline: Screen Test: Marion Cotillard
text: The Oscar-mentioned star of 'La Vie en Rose' discusses her film career and what it is like to die on screen.

headline: Preparing for Subprime Holiday Parties
text: After a year of layoffs and write-downs, it may be hard to summon much holiday cheer on Wall Street.

headline: A Collision of Excellence
text: Those of us who pulled up to the starting line with some reluctance this year — is it that time already? — have found some succor in the fact that this year’s crop of contenders has something for everyone and one thing in common: a high level of quality and execution. Writing in OscarWatch, Sasha Stone says that other than a paucity of great roles for women, the dark rooms have been full of so many splendors that it will be hard to know where to look. And she lays down some markers for Best Picture:

headline: And an Aria of Praise
text: Anne Thompson reports that the Internet people have spoken — mostly in whispers because they aren’t supposed to review the film — and “Sweeney Todd” apparently lives up to the hype. Experienced Oscar hand that she is, Ms. Thompson reminds that it’s never good to count your bloody chickens before they hatch, but suggests the Depp will get an actor nod, and that the film will get with enough other nominations — cinematography, production design, costumes — to turn Tim Burton’s movie into one of the bigger, more majestic contenders of the season.

headline: Brooks Brothers Migrates to the West
text: The new Brooks Brothers store on Broadway at 65th Street. (Photo: David W. Dunlap/The New York Times) Slide Show: Brooks Brothers on Broadway Even in an era of rampant brand extension, there is something incongruous about the sight of a Brooks Brothers store at Broadway and 65th Street, which was still “West Side Story” territory in the days when Brooks was outfitting John F. Kennedy in sack suits.  You could say, cynically, that this is merely a sign that the venerable clothier is now no more than a Banana Republic chain for the next-higher income bracket. Or you could say that Brooks Brothers is really returning to its roots, since it conducted business on Broadway from 1858 to 1915, moving steadily uptown all the while.  Lou Amendola, the chief merchandising officer for Brooks Brothers, can look at a map of Manhattan and see the 9,500-square-foot Lincoln Square branch, which formally opened today, as following naturally in a northwesterly migratory pattern going back to 1818 and the original store at Catharine and Cherry Streets.  Brooks Brothers’ first appearance on Broadway was at the corner of Grand Street. Abraham Lincoln shopped here. (What other customer would have needed an overcoat for his second inauguration with a quilted lining embellished by an embroidered eagle holding a “One Country, One Destiny” pennant in its beak?) The store then moved briefly to Union Square.  At 670 Broadway, on the corner of Bond Street, Brooks opened its next headquarters — a Victorian confection designed by George E. Harney. “Externally it is an ornament to the street,” The New York Times declared on April 11, 1874, “and its internal arrangements are of the most perfect kind.” The building is still an ornament in NoHo. Recent retail tenants have included the Top Tomato produce store and the Wet Seal clothing store.  Brooks moved up Broadway to 22nd Street in 1884. Here, it introduced Americans to the button-down polo collar shirt, the polo coat, the Shetland sweater and the silk Foulard necktie. Brooks moved to its current flagship, at Madison Avenue and 44th Street, in 1915. Though much altered, the 22nd Street building still stands. If you visit Domain Home Fashions today, you can still see the great cast-iron columns of the main selling floor, where men’s suits were once piled high. (That’s how they displayed them, in piles, turned inside out so customers could see the fine linings.)  Are there more neighborhood Brooks Brothers to come? “The potential is definitely there,” Mr. Amendola said through a spokesman. The challenge, he added, is finding the right space to accommodate a full range of the store’s offerings.  If the company is thinking about NoHo, it is worth noting that there is an 11,250-square-foot corner storefront now available. At 670 Broadway, on the corner of Bond Street.
