text: Even in an era of rampant brand extension, there is something incongruous about the sight of a Brooks Brothers store at Broadway and 65th Street, which was still “West Side Story” territory in the days when Brooks was outfitting John F. Kennedy in sack suits.You could say, cynically, that this is merely a sign that the venerable clothier is now no more than a Banana Republic chain for the next-higher income bracket. Or you could say that Brooks Brothers is really returning to its roots, since it conducted business on Broadway from 1858 to 1915, moving steadily uptown all the while.

headline: New Partners at Paul Weiss
text: Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, the New York law firm, said Monday it named five new partners effective Jan. 1.

headline: Council Speaker Supports Keeping Term Limits
text: Updated, 1:05 p.m. | As many had widely expected, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, says she will not support a referendum or bill to extend term limits for members of the City Council.

headline: Imus in the Heartland
text: Don Imus returned to radio on WABC-AM this morning ­ and to television, too, on RFD-TV, a cable channel primarily known for delivering farming reports and country music to rural America.

headline: Wolfowitz May Return as Arms Control Advisor
text: If you’ve never heard of the State Department’s International Security Advisory Board, it may be because the name recently changed. And if its former moniker — the Arms Control and Nonproliferation Advisory Board — still doesn’t ring a bell, you may recognize some of the current members, including former chiefs of the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Executive Who Moved ‘Dem Bums’ Out of Brooklyn Is Hall of Famer
text: The decision to add Walter F. O’Malley to the Baseball Hall of Fame is expected to draw predictable griping from ardent Brooklyn Dodgers fans who lament the team’s departure to Los Angeles in 1957 — even if they were not alive when it happened.

headline: Suicide Notes
text: If I had one of those private edition copies, I would have implored Henry Adams to fill in the most glaring gap in those crucial missing twenty years, 1872-92. After finishing a late, Sunday breakfast with his wife, Clover, he found her dead body on an upstairs rug. A strange smell — the potassium cyanide she used for her photographic work — confirmed the worst: suicide.

headline: Evel Knievel on Kierkegaard
text: Evel Knievel died late last week, a sad event that would seem to have essentially no impact on the world of books.

headline: Problems on the Clinton Press Plane
text: MASON CITY, Iowa – A bit of a harrowing moment here: Smoke began filling the cabin of the Gulfstream jet carrying the Clinton campaign press corps as it was landing here this morning, and the reporters and plane crew disembarked on the middle of the icy tarmac as an emergency response team arrived.

headline: Old Losers
text: Is Hillary Clinton too old to be president?; McCain’s loss column; Unworthy in the N.C.A.A.

headline: McCain and Dodd Welcome Imus Back
text: Don Imus returned to the radio this morning after nearly eight months in exile, and, as if no time had passed, two presidential candidates, John McCain and Christopher Dodd, traipsed right back behind him.

headline: Monday’s Links: Gruden Fired Up Despite Win
text: An ESPN report that Jeff Garcia, the Buccaneers quarterback, had a hairline fracture in his back had Tampa Bay coach Jon Gruden fired up, according to Tom Balog of the The Lakeland Ledger. If Gruden and Garcia are telling the truth, and Garcia’s back is not fractured, it would seem to raise questions about Chris Mortensen’s reporting. In happier news for the Bucs, Gruden’s decision to go for it on fourth down sealed the deal against the Saints.

headline: Latest Strike Casualty: Press Tour?
text: The biannual Television Critics Association press tour, a staple of the television beat for writers and critics, will likely not be held in January as originally scheduled.

headline: The Funny Side of Paralysis
text: “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” Julian Schnabel’s acclaimed adaptation of the late Jean-Dominique Bauby’s memoir of the same name, got its first American screening back in September, at the New York film Festival. The Baguette had the foresight to attend a Q&A with the director, where she learned that even Mr. Schnabel’s wife hadn’t wanted him to make a movie about a man who is entombed in his own body, able only to blink one eye.

headline: News Headlines
text: Articles from the world of real estate:

headline: Unequal Treatment at the State Department
text: Retirement ceremonies for career American diplomats tend to be predictable, decorous affairs reflecting the skills of envoys who have spent years perfecting the fine art of defending often indefensible Washington policies abroad. But when Michael Guest, a former ambassador to Romania, closed out his quarter-century career recently he did what few people do — displayed uncommon courage and threw a rhetorical hand-grenade into his own party.

headline: More Climate Fakery
text: In the timeless category of, “If it’s too good to be true, it probably isn’t,” a remarkably sophisticated, but fake, news release and Web link went out to the media this morning proclaiming that the Climate Action Partnership -– a who’s who of big corporations, from Alcan to Xerox — had pledged essentially to turn off their emissions in the next 50 years (a 90 percent cut by 2050). They also supposedly called for an immediate freeze on new construction of coal-burning power plants.

headline: Blank Checks Keep Getting Bigger
text: The private equity industry may be in hibernation, but another brand of buyout vehicle — known as the special-purpose acquisition company — is in overdrive.

headline: Here Comes the World Junior Championship
text: This is one of our favorite times of year because the World Junior Championship starts the end of the month (Dec. 26 through Jan. 5 in the Czech Republic this year). The W.J.C. is an amazing showcase for the next crop of stars. This is when images of the players themselves fuse onto the one-dimensional listings of the Central Scouting rankings of prospects.

headline: City Arms Police Recruits With iPods for Their Exams
text: The penetration of mandatory iPods in secondary and higher education has been growing. Duke University has issued the music players to incoming freshmen. The Brearley School, a private school for girls in Manhattan, has required iPods for homework and classroom assignments. And the school district in Union City, N.J., has issued 300 iPods to bilingual students with limited English skills to improve their English vocabulary and grammar.

headline: Another Dubious Fashion Alliance
text: The news announcing Victoria Beckham as the latest celebrity to flog the Marc Jacobs brand has us wondering what outfit she’ll be modeling for Juergen Teller’s lens. If you recall, the Spring/Summer 2008 collection was heavy on abstruse undies as outerwear, aggressive backward-is-the-new-forward pieces and neo-burlesque transparency — not exactly the unreflective lascivious gear Mrs. Becks usually wears. Until the photos are leaked, The Moment has worked up some composite shots of Posh in Marc Jacobs SS08…

headline: Big Boost in Energy Science and Technology Sought
text: [UPDATE, 6/6/08: The International Energy Agency has echoed the call from many climate and energy experts for big increases in energy research, development, and deployment of non-polluting technologies, saying that there is no way to curb greenhouse gases as human populations and economies swell in coming decades without an “energy revolution.” ]

headline: The Great Glass Ceiling at Opryland
text: The Opryland Hotel, site of the baseball winter meetings, has always reminded me of the movie “The Truman Show,” where Jim Carrey exists in a self-contained universe in which even the sky is not real. The hotel is vast, with ballrooms, restaurants and trees everywhere, rivers flowing beneath your feet, and the open areas covered by giant glass ceilings.

headline: The Video Lounge | The Neistat Brothers
‘Housewives’ Beat ‘Sunday Night Football’
text: Drawing 20.6 million viewers on Sunday, “Desperate Housewives” lifted ABC into first place for the night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The 9 p.m. drama delivered the largest audience of the night, easily outperforming NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” which averaged 13 million viewers.

headline: Making a List
text: I have the kind of insomnia where, even though I fall right to sleep at bedtime, I then wake up at 2 a.m., my mind racing with things I need to do. Last night at 2 a.m., I kept thinking about all the decisions that remain to be made. After tossing and turning for a while, I got up to make a to-do list for Florida:

headline: Two Choices for the Plus One
text: In the next few months, college football fans are going to be hearing a lot more about the “Plus One” system as an alternative for the college football postseason. In numerous conversations with college football power brokers over the past year, it’s become very clear that the Bowl Championship Series meetings this April in Miami will be a critical time to see whether or not the Plus One will be implemented in 2011. Mike Slive, the coordinator of the B.C.S., has nudged the issue to the forefront lately by asking the question: “Is two enough?” He means is having two teams with a shot at the national title enough anymore. Certainly a legitimate question this season.

headline: What Buffett’s TXU Play Doesn’t Mean
text: Don’t count on Warren E. Buffett’s purchase of TXU bonds from Goldman Sachs as a sign of confidence in the high-yield debt market. The Oracle of Omaha himself doesn’t see it that way.

headline: Hawaii’s Team Concept
text: Faithful readers of The Quad all know what Hawaii quarterback Colt Brennan thinks of his receivers, who are affectionately known as The Dread Heads. So after Hawaii completed its 12-0 season on Saturday, Brennan pulled aside Karl Benson, the commissioner of the Western Athletic Conference Commissioner, and asked if he could give one more shout out to his receivers and his offensive line.

headline: Comptroller’s Report Issues Warning About City’s Economy
text: The New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., warned today that the local economy is “at a turning point,” and predicted that the city could face a budget gap of more than $6 billion in the fiscal year that starts in July 2010 — the first year that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s successor will be in office.In a City Charter-mandated report on the city’s economy and finances, Mr. Thompson warned: “Turmoil in the nation’s housing and mortgage markets has reverberated through the financial sector, threatening to produce a marked slowdown in local economic activity. The principal threat to both the national and local economies is the unfolding subprime mortgage debacle and its collateral effects on credit markets. The resulting financial losses and layoffs are likely to fall disproportionately on New York firms and workers.”

headline: U.C.L.A. Fires Dorrell
text: U.C.L.A. fired Karl Dorrell today after the Bruins finished the regular season with a 6-6 record. The Bruins will face B.Y.U. in the Las Vegas Bowl on Dec. 22, though the university has not said who will be the coach of the team for that game. (Update: The defensive coordinator DeWayne Walker will coach the Bruins in their bowl game.)

headline: Final Fixes of Some Scripted Series
text: Four weeks after the writers’ strike commenced, networks are showing the last original episodes of several popular television series.

headline: The Making of an Audio Book
text: In all its glory.

headline: A Family Affair, Staal Style
text: As the oldest of the three Staal brothers playing in the N.H.L., Carolina forward Eric Staal has an interesting perspective on his brothers’ budding careers. And it gets even more interesting when he gets to play against them.

headline: Clinton Steps Up Attacks on Obama
text: MASON CITY, Iowa – Hillary Rodham Clinton’s spokesman may be crowing about a new Associated Press poll in Iowa that is somewhat better for her than Sunday’s Des Moines Register poll. But that doesn’t mean Mrs. Clinton is lightening up on her attacks on one rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Barack Obama.

headline: Testing Chimps' Memory
text: Young chimps can outperform some adult humans in a memory test.

headline: Heisman Watch: The Final Edition
text: Florida quarterback Tim Tebow: The vote will be close, but he becomes the first underclassman to win the award.

headline: Bruno Won’t Discuss His Other Job
text: The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the state’s top Republican, was asked by City Room this afternoon about his other salaried position — his job at a Connecticut-based investment company, the Winthrop Corporation, which was the subject of a Times article on Saturday. The question came at the end of a news conference on negotiations over the state’s expiring horse racing franchise.

headline: How Professional Is Your Doctor?
text: Nearly half of doctors in a recent survey admit to witnessing a serious medical error but not reporting it.

headline: The Details Behind Verizon’s Announcement
text: Everyone’s e-mailing me to ask what I think of Verizon’s announcement.

headline: An Ad for Ads
text: ‘‘Generation Y’’—once and for all — refers to Americans born between 1981 and 1995. (Hey, Wikipedia is looking for an expert on you all; enlist today!) It’s a dopey name, but with ‘‘Greatest’’ already taken, the rest of us are bound to be left with clunkers.

headline: What Gov. Spitzer Gets This Holiday: Lumps of Coal from Leading Magazines
text: New York’s Governor Eliot Spitzer has done something that nobody could have expected when he took office almost a year ago. He has made Albany and his stewardship of the state such big news that Vanity Fair and The New Yorker both have huge profiles on him in their big holiday issues that have just come out.

headline: A Place in Our Hearts for Pay Phones
text: The pay phone’s long goodbye paused for an especially poignant moment today, when AT&T stopped believing after 129 years:

headline: Pedestrians Struck as High Winds Buffet City
text: The National Weather Service has issued a wind advisory for the late afternoon and evening, warning of west winds between 23 and 28 miles per hour, with gusts as high as 45 m.p.h. There were reports of pedestrians struck by objects falling off Midtown buildings, including the new headquarters of The Times.There have been sustained winds from 25 to 35 m.p.h. throughout the five boroughs, with Kennedy International Airport reporting winds of up to 46 m.p.h. around 1 p.m. “We do have a wind advisory out until 7 a.m. tomorrow,” said Matthew Tauber, a meteorologist with the weather service. “We are looking at these winds continuing throughout tonight.”

headline: Why I get mad at Obama about Social Security
text: So I just spent a fairly unpleasant 15 minutes on right-wing talk radio. And the host said — this is rough, not a verified quote — “Look, everyone knows that Social Security is going bust, and we’d all be better off if we could put out money in 401(k)s. Even Barack Obama says so!”

headline: Merrill Appoints Chai as New Finance Chief
text: On his first full day as Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, John A. Thain has already poached someone from his old firm.

headline: Dating-Related Violence Rises Among Teenagers
text: Fighting decreased by 20 percent in New York City schools from 2003 to 2005, but dating-related violence is on the rise. The new report, “Teen Safety in New York City,” described trends in youth violence and showed an association between violence and other health risks — both for victims and for aggressors.

text: Let’s review:

headline: Romney Signals His Religion Speech
text: How will Mitt Romney handle the subject of his Mormon faith during a much-anticipated speech on Thursday? He gave some clues yesterday, dispelling notions that he would focus mainly on allaying any doubts about his Mormon faith.

headline: Romney’s J.F.K. Moment?
text: Mitt Romney has “an impossible balancing act to maintain” when he delivers a speech on his Mormon faith later this week, suggests conservative blogger Daniel Larison, a graduate student in Byzantine history at the University of Chicago. “Romney cannot keep evading the issue so long as he wishes to define his campaign and his ‘values’ in terms of being a ‘person of faith,’ ” Larison writes. He continues:
