text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: Opening Santa’s Mail (and Answering It)
text: Santa Claus has set up shop in the 10001 ZIP Code, though addressing an envelope to “Santa Claus New York,” “Santa’s Workshop, North Pole” or just plain “Santa” is enough to land a letter in the hands of Santa’s helpers.

headline: Short Squeeze?
text: For afficianados of NovaStar Financial, there is an eerie quiet. The bulls are loving it.

headline: The ‘Wimp’ Factor in Albany
text: The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, is not on good terms with the other two state leaders. That’s putting it mildly. This afternoon, he held a news conference to chastise Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver for stalling on an agreement over who will run the state’s three thoroughbred tracks when the New York Racing Association’s contract expires at the end of the year. Mr. Bruno is at a disadvantage in the talks, because Saratoga Race Course is in the heart of his district and thus the issue is a far higher priority for him than the other two men who run the state.

headline: Humans Test Their Memory
text: In some memory tests, humans perform worse than young chimps

headline: Thompson Tackles Immigration Query
text: Henry from Mississippi, a conference call participant, put Fred D. Thompson on the spot today when he asked about illegal immigrants, saying they are needed to fill labor shortages in the construction, farming and poultry industries.

headline: DARPA's Urban Challenge
text: Driverless vehicles make the rounds at the DARPA Urban Challenge. (Courtesy of DARPA)

headline: The Spectrum Auction Secrecy Begins
text: A veil of mystery is about to descend over the auction of the 700-megahertz band, a useful swath of the electromagnetic spectrum that is being freed up by the move to digital television.

headline: Adams’s Dark Matter
text: “The Education of Henry Adams” is not really an autobiography. As the author himself confesses several dozen pages from the end, it is the modern omega to the medieval alpha (his book “Mont-Saint-Michel and Chartres”) in his project to contrast long-ago cohesion with latter-day multiplicity. “The Education” is a treatise, an elegant, patrician apogee to the fine American tradition of cranks putting forth literary explanations for the whole universe, of which their own country is a strangely exceptional precinct. Adams’s “Dynamic Theory of History,” developed during a decade in which he was also playing with magnets and seeking revelation in the statistics of coal production, proceeds from a late-life awareness of himself a “a conscious ball of vibrating motions, traversed in every direction by infinite lines of rotation or vibration.” His discovery that, as of 1900, the world would “not be a unity but a multiple” freed him to write a memoir whose own ever-increasing entropy could be rationalized as a shape to suit the times.

headline: A Case of Political Counter-Programming
text: DES MOINES – When one politician launches an attack at another politician, particularly in the closing month of a bare-knuckle presidential campaign, the recipient of the strike frequently responds with swift aggression. The cable television networks count on it, right?

headline: Democracy Scorecard: Venezuela, Russia, Pakistan
text: Is democracy batting 1 for 3 in today’s rush of election news? Here’s a look at developments in Venezuela, Russia and Pakistan posted to NYTimes.com’s homepage today.

headline: Yahoo Shuffles Yet More Executives
text: After a 100-day strategic review of Yahoo, chief executive Jerry Yang declared that the company he co-founded in 1994 would focus on three things: become a starting point for the most consumers; become the must-buy for advertisers; and turn itself into a more open platform for publishers and developers.

headline: Romney, Politics and Religion
text: Dampening our expectations (and perhaps trying to lessen the hype), Republican candidate Mitt Romney today dismissed the notion that he would offer up later this week a speech on religion akin to that given by John F. Kennedy on Sept. 12, 1960.

headline: Oprah Overload Alert
text: There are no tickets left for Oprah Winfrey’s appearance in Columbia, S.C., on Sunday with Barack Obama. The event is to be held in the Colonial Center, the biggest arena in the state, seating 18,000 people.

headline: Bloggingheads: Stem-Cell Semantics
text: Science writer Carl Zimmer, left, and biologist Lee Silver on whether a recent breakthrough will really end the stem-cell controversy.

headline: China's Endangered Species
text: China's rapid economic expansion has jeopardized the nation's prized wildlife and biodiversity, such as the Yangtze turtle.

headline: When Dirt Is Just as Good
text: A thin layer of snow did not last long in Riverside Park, but that did not stop children from taking a slide on Dec. 2.

headline: Who’s Going to Win the Harlon Hill?
text: If you think the Heisman Trophy race is close, check out the battle for the Harlon Hill Trophy.

headline: 'A Look to the Future'
text: A conversation for the New York Times Building opening ceremony.

headline: Toronto Station Retracts Report on Avery
text: The Toronto radio reporter who caused a stir by claiming that Rangers forward Sean Avery had made derogatory comments about Maple Leafs forward Jason Blake’s recent cancer diagnosis before a game last month, retracted his report in a broadcast Monday.

headline: More Trump
text: A week after Aberdeen officials rejected his plan for a $2 billion golf course and resort project, Donald Trump is threatening to take his project and go home.

headline: Campus Voices: Granite State Impressions
text: Our band of undergraduate students at Harvard, under the umbrella of the Kennedy School’s Institute of Politics, is spending a lot of time in New Hampshire in the leadup to the state’s Jan. 8 primary. The students braved the chilly prelude to that Granite winter wonderland this past weekend, and filed these posts. (The snow is starting to fall in the Northeast and elsewhere, mind you.)

headline: Would You Let These Cars Take You for a Ride?
text: Now that I’ve hailed the coming age of self-driving cars in my Findings column, I’d like to hear what Lab readers think of this prospect. But before you weigh in — and tell me how naively optimistic I am — take a look at these videos of driverless cars.

headline: CBS Announces Revised Schedule, Including Winter Edition of ‘Big Brother’
text: On Monday, two broadcast networks, CBS and NBC, gave the clearest indication to date of how their programming schedules were being affected by the four-week writers’ strike. CBS said it would introduce several new reality shows and midseason replacements beginning in January, including the first winter season ever of the reality show “Big Brother.”

headline: The Lingering Cullen Debate
text: The Rangers did not need Carolina center Matt Cullen to show them how good an offensive player he can be, but that is just what happened in Monday night’s 4-0 loss to the Hurricanes. Cullen, whom the Rangers traded in the offseason for two players who may never play for them and a draft pick, had two assists, giving him 21 this season to go with six goals.

headline: Are Words Worthless in the Climate Fight?
text: In Science Times this week, I have a story examining the limits of language. Can scientists or anyone else find new words sufficiently potent to inspire action on long-term challenges, like shifting from unfettered use of coal and oil to limit the odds of climate surprises?

headline: Being Green: The Young Show the Way
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tiny, Ordinary Movements Polished by Self-Awareness
text: Apparently we are back in the 1960s, but in a 2007 kind of way. In three works presented on Saturday night in “Dance and Process,” a program at the Kitchen organized by Dean Moss, the choreographers largely espoused the ordinary movement and neutral presentation of odd activities first deployed by artists like Yvonne Rainer and Steve Paxton. But I suspect that the polished, almost glamorous patina of at least two of these pieces is a manifestation of a more self-conscious age.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Turner Prize Winner

headline: Clinton Aims for Anger Without Making People Mad
text: CLEAR LAKE, Iowa, Dec. 3 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton doesn’t sound angry or look angry or act angry. But if you transcribe her recent speeches in Iowa and reread them, they do seem angry — or, at least, more negative toward other Democrats than she has been since the 1992 presidential primary campaign of her husband.

headline: Cause and Effect: Images of Lung Damage From Secondhand Smoke
text: Researchers say that for the first time, they have been able to get an image of lungs apparently damaged by secondhand tobacco smoke.

headline: Chimps Exhibit Superior Memory, Outshining Humans
text: Spend even a little time around chimpanzees, and you begin to realize how intelligent they are. But can they outshine humans in brain power? Most humans would scoff at that.

headline: Britain: Muslims End Holocaust Day Boycott
text: The Muslim Council of Britain, the biggest Muslim umbrella group in the country, has voted to end its boycott of Holocaust Memorial Day, The Guardian reported. The organization’s central working committee voted 18 to 8 on Saturday to end the boycott, which began in 2001, and to send representatives to the next Holocaust Memorial Day commemoration, on Jan. 27, in Liverpool. The Guardian said that those who voted to attend said the boycott had allowed the council to be accused of anti-Semitism. Those who supported the boycott argued for a more inclusive title like Genocide Memorial Day that they said could give greater recognition to recent genocides like those in Rwanda and Bosnia. The newspaper said there were concerns that the vote might lead some of the 500 organizations in the council to leave.

headline: Akon Pleads Not Guilty in Fan-Tossing Case
text: The platinum-selling hip-hop star Akon, 34,  pleaded not guilty yesterday to criminal charges filed after he tossed a 15-year-old boy off the stage at a concert on June 3 at the minor league baseball stadium in Fishkill, N.Y., The Associated Press reported. Akon was released on his own recognizance after a brief appearance in court, where he was charged with misdemeanor endangering the welfare of a minor and second-degree harassment, a violation. He was accused after a fan, Abby Rosa, said she suffered a concussion when the boy thrown from the stage fell on her. Akon had no comment when he left the courthouse. His lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, said: “It was never Akon’s intention to violate the law. This unfortunate incident was a spontaneous reaction during a live concert that Akon deeply regrets.”

headline: Pressure on U.S.C., and Spotlight on Mayo
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 — Tim Floyd served as a technical adviser on “Glory Road,” the 2006 movie based on the story of Texas Western University and its colorblind men’s basketball coach, Don Haskins. That team traveled the still-segregated road to the 1966 N.C.A.A. tournament championship, using an all-black starting five to beat an all-white Kentucky team in the title game.

headline: Larry Wachtel, Market Analyst, Is Dead at 77
text: Larry Wachtel, a stock market analyst whose humor and trademark Brooklyn accent kept radio listeners attuned to the ups and downs of the markets for more than three decades in the New York area, died on Sunday in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 77 and lived in Yonkers.

headline: MySpace Hoax Draws No Charges
text: No criminal charges will be filed in the case of an Internet hoax that ended in a teenage girl’s suicide in a St. Louis suburb last year, the local prosecutor said yesterday.

headline: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Manhattan: Teachers Now Oppose Housing Plan
text: The United Federation of Teachers said yesterday that it would seek to withdraw from a $28 million effort to build 234 units of moderately priced housing for teachers because the city and the developer would not pledge to use union labor. Randi Weingarten, the union’s president, said she would ask the Teachers Retirement System to end its participation in the project. The city’s Housing Development Corporation and the developer, Atlantic Development Group, trying hold down costs, said they would not guarantee use of prevailing-wage workers.

headline: Democratic Presidential Debate on NPR
text: The following is a transcript of the 2008 Democratic primary presidential debate hosted by National Public Radio. The participating were Senator Joesph Biden, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Christopher Dodd, John Edwards, Mike Gravel, Representative Dennis Kucinich, and Senator Barack Obama. The transcript is provided by CQ Transcriptions. The audio of the entire debate can be downloaded at npr.org.

headline: F.D.A. Criticizes Avastin Use for Breast Cancer
text: Genentech’s drug Avastin did not help women with breast cancer live meaningfully longer, and it caused significant side effects, including a few deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday in a review of the drug.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sudan’s President Pardons British Teacher
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 3 — The British schoolteacher jailed in Sudan for allowing her 7-year-old pupils to name a class teddy bear Muhammad was pardoned Monday by the Sudanese president and left for England later in the evening.

headline: Florida: Sears Tower Case Goes to Jury
text: A jury began deliberations in the trial of seven Miami men accused of plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago and wage a religiously motivated war against the United States government. Prosecutors, drawing on evidence collected in an eight-month investigation, have said the men were trying to get financial support from Al Qaeda to conduct an armed jihad. But defense lawyers have insisted their clients were entrapped by undercover F.B.I. agents and played along to raise money to build a construction business and a local religious mission..

headline: Behavior: Even Babies May Be Good Judges of Character
text: Did that mean Square push that poor Circle down the hill? Yes — and Baby isn’t about to forget it, either.

headline: Stuck on Coal, and Stuck for Words in a High-Tech World
text: Human progress, Loren Eiseley wrote in 1954, has largely been a climb up “the heat ladder” from one energy source to the next. Each has been more convenient or potent or economical than the last. No one lugs firewood to warm a high-rise apartment building in Chicago.

headline: Omitting Miller Not Surprising, but Still Embarrassing
text: The National Baseball Hall of Fame has become a national joke. Its latest electoral contrivance elected three former executives to the Hall yesterday, none named Marvin Miller. Making the committee’s decision even worse, one of the three is named Bowie Kuhn.

headline: MySpace to Showcase Music and Sell Performance Videos
text: MySpace, the social networking site where people create home pages and embellish them as they would a dormitory room, plans today to start positioning itself as a top destination for buying exclusive musical performances.

headline: Peter Lieberson Songs Win an Award
text: A song cycle inspired by love for a wife doomed to an early death has won Peter Lieberson the University of Louisville’s $200,000 Grawemeyer Award for outstanding works in music composition. The work, “Neruda Songs,” based on five love poems by the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda and written for the mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, who died of cancer last year at 52, was chosen from among 140 entries from around the world. Mark Satterwhite, a University of Louisville music professor who directs the award program, said: “Each song represents a different stage of love, from first passion to the end of life. The piece has a beauty and surface simplicity but great emotional depth and intellectual rigor as well.” Before her death Ms. Hunt Lieberson performed the work with the organizations that commissioned it: the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Elizabeth Hardwick, Writer, Dies at 91
text: Elizabeth Hardwick, the critic, essayist, fiction writer and co-founder of The New York Review of Books, who went from being a studious Southern Belle to a glittering member of the New York City intellectual elite, died Sunday night in Manhattan. She was 91.

headline: Citing Past Troubles at Indian Point, State Urges Panel to Deny License Extension
text: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that the state had asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to deny an application to extend the license of the Indian Point nuclear reactors, citing “a long and troubling history of problems.”

headline: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Manhattan: Expansion of No. 7 Subway Line
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. Eliot Spitzer spoke yesterday at a ceremony in the Times Square subway station to mark the start of work on a westward extension of the No. 7 subway line. The extension is intended to spur development on the west edge of Midtown, using what Mr. Bloomberg called “the galvanizing power of the subway.” The 7 train now runs from Flushing, Queens, to Times Square. The extension will take the line west to 11th Avenue, then south to 34th Street, where a station will be built at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. At the ceremony, Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff defended a decision not to build a station at 41st Street and 10th Avenue, saying that development had already been progressing in that area without the impetus of the new subway. The project is due to be completed in 2013.

headline: W.T.O. Court Rejects Brazil’s Tire Ban
text: The World Trade Organization’s highest court, backing a European Union complaint, upheld a ruling finding that Brazil illegally bans imports of retread tires for vehicles. Appellate judges agreed with a June 12 decision that the restriction was unjustified because Brazil imports used tires for making retreads, so it would be unfair to prevent imports of the finished retread product. Europe said Brazil’s September 2000 ban unfairly denied it a market expected to import three million used tires by 2003. Brazil had argued that Europe was trying to export its pollution problem of old tires, which cannot be used for making retreads more than once, and would therefore become a waste problem at the end of their second life.

headline: Ceremonial Objects From West Africa With Blood in the Patina
text: Certain ceremonial objects from the Dogon and other cultures of West Africa are known for their dark patina. There is plenty of ethnological evidence that the thick coating on these wood sculptures, which are often in human or animal shapes, contains blood from animals sacrificed as part of the ceremonies. But the presence of blood had not been proved through chemical analysis.

headline: Beethoven’s Sonatas as a Series of Dialogues
text: The 92nd Street Y is smitten with the idea of Beethoven cycles this season. In September the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio played all the piano trios in chronological order in an all-day marathon. Now the violinist Christian Tetzlaff and the pianist Alexander Lonquich are playing the Sonatas for Violin and Piano. Mr. Tetzlaff and Mr. Lonquich are in less of a hurry: Having played the first four sonatas on Thursday, they picked up with the fifth — “Spring” Sonata — as well as the sixth and seventh on Sunday afternoon, and will play a concluding concert tonight.

headline: Desperate Housewives Outscores Football
text: Drawing 20.6 million viewers on Sunday, “Desperate Housewives” lifted ABC into first place for the night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The 9 p.m. drama delivered the largest audience of the night, easily outperforming NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” which averaged 13 million viewers. NBC finished third overall among adults 18 to 49, just behind Fox, which got a boost early in the evening from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage followed by its half-hour special, “Bowl Championship Series Selection Show,” at 8 (10.8 million). ABC’s “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” remained the 8 p.m. time slot leader with 14.5 million viewers, and ABC finished first in the 10 p.m. hour as well with “Brothers & Sisters” (12.7 million). CBS, which ranked second over all in total viewers ahead of Fox and NBC, finished fourth in the 18-to-49 set. Following “60 Minutes” at 7 (14 million) and “The Amazing Race” at 8 (11.2 million), CBS’s “Hallmark Hall of Fame” movie “Pictures of Hollis Woods” attracted 11.5 million viewers from 9 to 11.

headline: Jefferson DeBlanc, Honored World War II Fighter Pilot, Dies at 86
text: Jefferson J. DeBlanc, a World War II fighter pilot who was awarded the Medal of Honor for shooting down five Japanese planes on a single day while running out of fuel, died Nov. 22 in Lafayette, La. He was 86 and lived St. Martinville, La..

headline: Bright Prospects for a Comfortable Ride
text: Those plump Lincoln Town Cars that provide a ride as soft as a pillow are clogging city streets and airport access roads these days — a sign that the $2.4 billion chauffeured transportation business in the United States is doing well, particularly with corporate customers.

headline: Vulnerable Democrats See Fates Tied to Clinton
text: MANHATTAN, Kan. — Nancy Boyda, a Democrat who ran for Congress in this district last year, owed her upset victory partly to the popularity of the Democratic woman at the top of the ticket: Kathleen Sebelius, who won the governor’s seat. Now, with a tough re-election race at hand in 2008, Ms. Boyda faces the prospect that her electoral fate could be tied to another woman: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Health Insurance for All, Only if Everyone Pays?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Close to a Completed Club, the Mets Are Just Window Shopping for Now
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 3  Mets General Manager Omar Minaya sounded like a man who did not expect to make a major trade for a pitcher at the winter meetings. Perhaps he was purposely lowering expectations, or maybe he did not want to disclose much about negotiations. Still, he offered a revealing anecdote.

headline: For Democrats, a Strained Debate on Immigration
text: DES MOINES, Dec. 4  If there is one issue that has perplexed presidential candidates from both parties in Iowa this year, it is immigration. The Democratic presidential contenders were confronted with it an unusual way at a debate here this afternoon: Should an American citizen turn in someone they know to be an illegal immigrant?

headline: Bringing an Energy Bill Home
text: Congress is now within reach of a breakthrough energy bill that would reduce both America’s dependence on foreign oil and its emissions of the greenhouse gases that cause climate change. House passage later this week is virtually certain. Senate approval depends on whether the majority leader, Harry Reid, and the minority leader, Mitch McConnell, can corral a half-dozen votes among moderate Republicans to resist a threatened filibuster.

headline: A Farm Boy and a Mogul, and How They Changed the World
text: With billionaire parents now producing bar mitzvah celebrations and sweet-16 parties as if they were major motion pictures, it’s only a matter of time before this spare-no-expense approach is applied to their kids’ school projects. Imagine that Mr. Hedge Fund, with money to burn and many favors to call in, imports a crack combination of writer, director and actors to put across Junior’s oral report with envy-making, A-worthy flair.

headline: Justices Express Skepticism in a Discrimination Case
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Beneath the surface of a Supreme Court argument on Monday in a case of job-related age discrimination was a surprising question: has the Supreme Court drifted so far toward the employer’s side in job discrimination cases that it is now to the right of the Bush administration?

headline: Tired of Corruption but Afraid of the Crackdown
text: HWASUNG, South Korea, Dec. 3 — For Choi Hae-pyung, head of an electronics parts maker, running his business over the last year has been like steering a boat through a double storm: competition from China and the rising value of the Korean currency have squeezed his already thin profit.

headline: A Frustrating Season Turns Sorrowful for Marbury
text: The final minutes of the first half were winding down Sunday night, and Stephon Marbury had settled into a steady, peaceful rhythm. His shots were falling, the Knicks were rallying and Madison Square Garden was again echoing with cheers instead of boos.

headline: An Emotional Ceremony to Honor a Fierce Player
text: MIAMI, Dec. 3 — One week after the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor was shot and killed, about 3,000 people came to say goodbye to the man whose body now rested inside a mahogany-colored coffin.

headline: Ford and G.M. Plan to Trim 2008 Output
text: DETROIT, Dec. 3 — General Motors and Ford Motor Company, struggling to keep turnaround plans on track, both said Monday that they would cut production in the first quarter because of slowing sales.

headline: Rutgers Upends Another Top Team
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 3 — Rutgers was trailing an undefeated team by 5 points, and its leading rebounder and defensive stopper was on the bench with four fouls. It did not look good for the Scarlet Knights — that is, until Epiphanny Prince took over.

headline: A Lurid Aftermath to a Hedge Fund Manager’s Life
text: JUPITER, Fla. — A life of private jets and black-tie balls ended with Seth Tobias, a wealthy investment manager and a familiar presence on CNBC, floating face down in the swimming pool of his mansion here.

headline: One Last Ride to the Hubble
text: GREENBELT, Md. — It’s the last roundup for the People’s Telescope.

headline: Life Was Lost in Maelstrom of Suspicion
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — Friends of Charles D. Riechers, whose Air Force career took him from the back of a B-52 cockpit to the front of the service’s $30 billion procurement office, said something was telling in the fact that his suicide note to his boss was typed. They described it as an effort to set the record straight by a meticulous man who felt deeply misunderstood.

headline: Florida Is Advised on Saving a State Fund
text: BlackRock, the asset management firm hired to advise Florida on a state pool whose subprime-tainted holdings led to withdrawal of almost half its $27 billion assets, recommended yesterday that the remaining holdings be split into two entities to ensure the fund’s survival.

headline: Stayin’ Alive: An Era That Was Running on Empty
text: Hardly anyone has a good word to say about the 1970s, a decade associated with Nixon and Watergate and Vietnam, rising unemployment, growing gas shortages and soaring crime rates. On much of the cultural front, things were equally bleak: Rock ’n’ roll was giving way to disco and heavy metal; happy, psychedelic hippie clothes were being replaced by leisure suits and hot pants; the Beats and Black Mountain poets were losing ground to “Jonathan Livingston Seagull” and “Love Story.” It was a time when shag rugs and shag haircuts were shagadelic, a time when pet rocks, platform shoes and polyester were primo. Think of avocado-colored refrigerators, yellow smiley faces and silvery disco balls.

headline: A Bouncer Tells Jurors Assassins Framed Him
text: On trial for three killings connected to a strip parlor in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, a bouncer told jurors yesterday that he was being framed by a squad of police assassins acting on orders from a corrupt detective who was out to shake down the bouncer’s private security business while his martial arts students conducted countersurveillance black ops against the Police Department.

headline: Spice Girls Reunite
text: Singing, strutting, hugging and even pole-dancing to the delight of a screaming audience of more than 15,000, all five of the Spice Girls reunited in Vancouver, British Columbia, late Sunday in their first major appearance in about eight years, Agence France-Presse reported. The performers, now in their 30s and with a combined seven children, were embarking on a world tour. In their heyday the Spice Girls — Victoria Beckham (above, at right), Emma Bunton, Melanie Chisholm, Melanie Brown and Geri Halliwell (above, at left) — sold 55 million albums and had nine No. 1 singles in Britain.

headline: A Tale of Two Strongmen
text: Voters on Sunday gave a split decision to two of the world’s most prominent and problematic authoritarian leaders. Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, turned a parliamentary election into a referendum on himself and cynically manipulated a huge victory, undermining what was left of the independence of the Duma and Russian politics. In Venezuela, President Hugo Chávez’s latest and most outrageous power grab was rejected at the ballot box, offering hope that political competition there will now flourish.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $2,526,869.86

headline: In Iran, Group of ‘Mothers’ Criticizes Nuclear Policy
text: TEHRAN, Dec. 3 — More than 500 Iranian women calling themselves “mothers of peace” have signed a letter to senior officials expressing their fear that there will be a war over Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Quick Fixes to Bring Back Damaged Voices
text: When Ray Boyer woke up from neck surgery last year, he felt fine — except he couldn’t say so.

headline: Skeletal Remains Are Found in a Brooklyn Home
text: The police found the skeletal remains of a woman in a home in Brooklyn yesterday. How long ago she died was unknown, but neighbors said they had not seen her for about two years.

headline: Suicide and the Elderly (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pakistani Rivals Threaten Boycott of Elections
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 3 — Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif, the two former prime ministers who have long bitterly opposed each other, joined with an opposition alliance on Monday to denounce what they see as an unfair environment leading up to parliamentary elections planned for January.

headline: In Alaska’s Far North, Two Cultures Collide
text: BARROW, Alaska — Each summer and fall, the Inupiat, natives of Alaska’s arid north coast, take their sealskin boats and gun-fired harpoons and go whale hunting. Kills are celebrated throughout villages as whaling captains share their catch with relatives and neighbors. Muktuk, or raw whale skin and blubber, is a prized delicacy.

headline: Britain: Abdication Buick Fetches $205,429
text: King Edward VIII’s 1934 Buick, which he rode to Downing Street to announce his abdication from the British throne in 1936, sold for $205,429 at Bonhams auction house in London. Bonhams would not identify the buyer.

headline: U.S. Finds Iran Halted Its Nuclear Arms Effort in 2003
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — A new assessment by American intelligence agencies released Monday concludes that Iran halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003 and that the program remains frozen, contradicting a judgment two years ago that Tehran was working relentlessly toward building a nuclear bomb.

headline: Magazine Voices Doubt Over ‘Diary’ From Iraq
text: After months of accusations that reports written in The New Republic by “The Baghdad Diarist,” an American Army private, about the cruelty of ordinary soldiers in Iraq were false, the magazine says that as a result of its own investigation it can no longer stand by the articles.

headline: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Manhattan: Renovation at Washington Square Park
text: City officials said that yesterday’s decision by a justice in State Supreme Court in Manhattan has cleared the way for the renovation of Washington Square Park to begin. The work, including moving the park’s fountain and decreasing the size of the plaza, had been challenged by neighborhood and environmental groups. The city won two previous lawsuits, and yesterday’s decision, by Justice Joan A. Madden, found that the city had taken steps to ensure that the work would not significantly damage the environment, city officials said. The renovation is expected to begin by year’s end, city officials said. Daniel L. Alterman, a lawyer for the opponents of the renovation, said they were considering whether to appeal.

headline: Ratatouille Leads the Annie Race
text: “Ratatouille,” the tale of a rodent chef, amassed 13 nominations, including best feature, when the Annie Awards, honoring animation, were announced yesterday, The Associated Press reported. In the competition for best animated feature film it was joined by “Bee Movie,” “Surf’s Up,” “Persepolis” and “The Simpsons Movie.” The Annie Award winners in 25 film and television categories are to be announced in Los Angeles on Feb. 8. Since the category was added to the Oscars in 2001, the winner of the Annie for best picture has gone on to win the Academy Award for best animated feature every year but one. Last year the Annie Award-winning “Cars” lost to “Happy Feet.”

headline: Tenor Turns His Focus to the Art of the Song
text: Not that many years ago voice buffs in New York who admired the American tenor Matthew Polenzani had to content themselves with hearing him in winning performances of supporting roles at the Metropolitan Opera. For the role of David, for example, the young apprentice to the shoemaker Hans Sachs in Wagner’s “Meistersinger,” the boy-next-door wholesomeness and awkward earnestness of his portrayal, not to mention his handsome singing, were ideal; he was the best David of my experience.

headline: Trunk Line
text: Q. How keen is an elephant’s sense of smell, and where in the trunk is it handled?

headline: Driver Piles Up Wins and Miles
text: The only hard part, Tim Tetrick said, was all the time in his car, driving on the New Jersey and Pennsylvania turnpikes, Interstate 95 and Route 13 in Delaware. The rest was easy, or at least he made it look easy.

headline: Serving Life for Providing Car to Killers
text: CRAWFORDVILLE, Fla. — Early in the morning of March 10, 2003, after a raucous party that lasted into the small hours, a groggy and hungover 20-year-old named Ryan Holle lent his Chevrolet Metro to a friend. That decision, prosecutors later said, was tantamount to murder.

headline: Mood Problems Prevalent After Katrina, Survey Finds
text: The first study to rigorously assess the mental health fallout from Hurricane Katrina has confirmed what many researchers and Gulf Coast residents predicted: that mood problems after the storm occurred about as often as in any natural disaster ever studied, and that the delayed government response almost certainly made the problem worse.

headline: New Hampshire: Bail Set in Clinton Standoff
text: A man accused of taking hostages at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign office in Rochester was arraigned on six felony charges, including kidnapping and criminal threatening. The man, Leeland Eisenberg of Somersworth, was ordered held on $500,000 cash bail by a Rochester District Court judge. Mr. Eisenberg walked into the office Friday, claimed he had a bomb and took people hostage.

headline: Phoenix Mayor Shifts on Officers’ Asking for Immigration Status
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 — Under pressure from advocates for stricter immigration laws, the mayor of Phoenix said on Monday that he no longer backed a Police Department order barring officers from routinely asking the immigration status of people it arrested and announced a panel to study a policy change.

headline: Cecil Payne, Baritone Saxophonist Who Mastered Bebop, Dies
text: Cecil Payne, who in the 1940s was one of the first baritone saxophonists to master the intricacies of modern jazz and who for more than half a century was a leading exponent of his instrument, died last Tuesday  in Stratford, N.J. He was 84.

headline: The Dictatorship of Talent
text: Shanghai

headline: Robot Guitar Calls the Tune
text: The world’s first self-tuning guitar was introduced yesterday in London. The instrument, the Gibson Robot Guitar, above, automatically detects when a string has fallen out of pitch and corrects it, Agence France-Presse reported. Gibson, the Nashville-based manufacturer, promised that it would “change the guitar world forever” when it goes on sale worldwide on Friday. Using technology developed over 10 years the Robot will sell in Britain for $2,900.

headline: Putin Basks in Election Win Despite Broad Criticism
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 3 — President Vladimir V. Putin declared Monday that his party’s imposing victory in parliamentary elections was a “sign of trust” that had conferred new legitimacy on the government. But European monitors and opposition parties harshly criticized the balloting, saying it had been neither free nor fair.

headline: The Claim: Super Glue Can Heal Wounds
METRO BRIEFING | NEW JERSEY; Trenton: Anti-Death Penalty Bill Moves Forward
text: A bill that would abolish the death penalty in New Jersey easily passed the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee yesterday by an 8-to-4 vote. The next stop for the bill is the floor of the Senate, where the Senate president, Richard J. Codey, has said he would like to see the bill voted on before the end of the year. In the State Assembly, an identical bill is scheduled for a committee hearing on Monday. That bill is expected to pass the committee easily, and then go before the full Assembly by the end of the week.

headline: Late Gaffes by the Ravens Give Brady and Pats an Opening
text: BALTIMORE, Dec. 3 — Don Shula sat in the stands, a reminder of everything that was on the line for the New England Patriots, and perhaps he was the same sort of good luck charm for the Baltimore Ravens that other members of the 1972 Miami Dolphins had provided when their latter-day brethren stood in the way of the Chicago Bears’ perfect run 22 years ago.

headline: Bush Says Iran Still a Danger Despite Report on Weapons
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 — President Bush warned today that Iran remained a threat despite an intelligence assessment that it had halted a covert program to develop nuclear weapons four years ago, as the administration struggled to salvage a diplomatic process now in disarray.

headline: 2 Are Hurt in New York by Debris From Towers
text: Wind gusts knocked glass or debris from two skyscrapers in Midtown yesterday afternoon, including the new building that houses The New York Times. In each case, a pedestrian was reported to have been injured.

headline: Calculating Energy Bill’s Real Figures
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — Gas mileage would go up under the compromise reached by Congressional leaders last week, but not as high as the trumpeted numbers. And despite the tougher 35 m.p.g. standard, a growing population of drivers would push up total fuel use, as well as greenhouse gas emissions — but not as rapidly as would occur without the legislation.

headline: Forecasters Say Madison Avenue Will Escape a Recession, Just Barely
text: GROWTH in advertising spending in the United States is slowing considerably, according to several forecasters whose predictions are closely followed. But they believe the continuing strength of ad spending online — as well as the stimulative effects of the elections and the Summer Olympics — should keep the industry from suffering a recession in 2008.

headline: Diocese in Iowa Settles With Abuse Victims for $37 Million
text: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Davenport, Iowa, has reached a $37 million settlement to compensate victims of sexual abuse by clergy members and let the diocese emerge from bankruptcy, the two sides announced yesterday.

headline: China: Insurer Gets Approval for Offering
text: China Pacific Insurance Group, which is part-owned by the Carlyle Group and Prudential Financial, has received approval to sell a billion new shares in a Shanghai offering to bolster its finances and compete with domestic rivals. The listing committee of China’s securities watchdog agency approved the share sale yesterday, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said on its Web site. China Pacific also plans to sell as many as 900 million shares in a Hong Kong public offering “as soon as possible” after the mainland initial public offering. The two offerings are expected to raise as much as $6 billion.

headline: India Finds Mutated DNA Where Water Is Toxic
text: NEW DELHI, Dec. 3  Toxic chemicals in the water in Punjab, India’s grain belt, could be causing genetic mutations in the population, a recent study suggests.

headline: New Hall of Famer Stirs Both Sides in Brooklyn
text: Forgive? Perhaps not. Forget? Um, forget about it.

headline: A Visit With Mother Russia and Her Children
text: Every literate Russian can quote Pushkin and hum a tune from Glinka. No Russian orchestra on the road is likely to leave either man at home. Valery Gergiev and the Kirov Orchestra of St. Petersburg, in two Carnegie Hall concerts over the weekend and a third scheduled for tonight, have been happy once again to leave other people’s music to other people. Patrons could be assured that Borodin or Rimsky-Korsakov or something kindred was on the way. No one seemed disappointed.

headline: Pettitte to Return to the Yankees
text: NASHVILLE – The Yankees came to the winter meetings hoping to land a veteran left-handed starter for the top of their rotation. As the meetings began here on Monday morning, they got one. But it is not Johan Santana.

headline: Respect in a Box: Giving John Ford the Major American Artist Treatment
text: Film culture in this country has long been in need of a paradigm shift, a way of saving old films from the swamp of nostalgia and seeing them as vital cultural products rather than quaint artifacts of another age. People don’t read Faulkner’s “Light in August” to be reminded of their lost youth, but most studios continue to market their library titles (when they bother to market them at all) as so many trips down memory lane.

headline: Santana Deal Is Still Alive, but Window May be Closing
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 3 — The Yankees’ pursuit of Johan Santana showed a flicker of life early Tuesday morning when the Minnesota Twins backed off their demand that the right-hander Ian Kennedy be added to the Yankees’ trade offer.

headline: Ex-Ranger Shows Old Team What It Lost
text: Matt Cullen said he remembered all the good things about playing for the Rangers last season: the jazzed-up atmosphere at Madison Square Garden, the late-season push for the playoffs, scoring the game-winning and series-clinching goal against Atlanta in the first round.

headline: Russia: Phone Company Offers to Buy Rival
text: VimpelCom, Russia’s second-largest cellphone company, has offered to buy a rival, Golden Telecom, for about $4.2 billion to create Russia’s first integrated mobile and fixed-line provider. VimpelCom offered $105 a share for the Internet, voice and data provider, 3.5 percent higher than the closing price Friday, the companies said. They are “in discussions regarding the potential acquisition of all the outstanding common stock” of Golden Telecom, according to the statement. VimpelCom, which had more than 61 million subscribers at the end of October in Russia, Armenia, Kazakhstan, Ukraine, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Georgia, wants to branch out in more markets and into services like broadband. Golden Telecom said Nov. 8 it had 394,900 broadband subscribers in Russia.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about favorite gadgets of executives referred incorrectly to the video game Gran Turismo 5. It has not yet been released, and thus is not a best-selling game. The article also referred imprecisely to the game Halo 3. It is the first game in the Halo series designed for the Xbox 360; the earlier games, though playable on the Xbox 360, were designed for the original Xbox. The chip in the Xbox 360 also was misidentified. It has a Xenon chip, not a Cell processor. And the article also misstated the price of the Sony PlayStation 3. The PlayStation 3 starts at $399, not $299. (Go to Article)

headline: Inveterate Wanderer: An Intercontinental Salamander Family
text: The family of salamanders known as plethodontids are unusual in many ways. For one thing, they don’t have lungs. Instead, they get their oxygen through moistened skin.

headline: Tired of Corruption but Afraid of the Crackdown
text: HWASUNG, South Korea, Dec. 3 — For Choi Hae-pyung, head of an electronics parts maker, running his business over the last year has been like steering a boat through a double storm: competition from China and the rising value of the Korean currency have squeezed his already thin profit.

headline: Giuliani’s Firm Lobbied for Bill Considered Threat
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — Although Rudolph W. Giuliani is campaigning as President Bush’s staunch ally in the war on terror, his law office has lobbied Congress on behalf of legislation that the Bush administration calls a threat to antiterrorism efforts in the Horn of Africa.

headline: Role for Actors’ Equity at American Girl Place
text: Broadway isn’t the only place in town that can put on a theatrical labor dispute. On Saturday the adult actors and assistant stage managers who work at the theater in the American Girl Place store on Fifth Avenue at 49th Street voted, for the second time, to take on Actors’ Equity Association as their bargaining representative. The first election was held in November 2006 after a dramatic summer when 14 of the store’s 18 actors, who appear in shows including “Circle of Friends: An American Girl Musical” and “Bitty Bear’s Matinee: The Family Tree,” went on a two-day strike. Though the actors voted to join the union in last year’s election, American Girl Place charged that Equity had unfairly influenced the voting. Both sides agreed to hold the election again, and the actors voted 9 to 6 in favor of Equity.

headline: Council Plans Heftier Fines for Apartments Used as Hotels
text: Many New Yorkers complain that landlords are fleecing them with excessive rents.

headline: U.S. Team on Adu’s Mind, Even in Portugal
text: The education of an American soccer player, Freddy Adu, continues in Portugal.

headline: Bank of Canada Unexpectedly Cuts Key Rate
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 4  The Bank of Canada cut its key interest rate today by a quarter-point, to 4.25 percent, citing concerns about the global effect of the subprime loan crisis in the United States. While made for other reasons, the move may provide some relief for exporters that have been suffering from the recent sharp rise in the Canadian dollar.

headline: Cracking the Code to the Memory Vault
text: I bless the day 3M invented Post-It notes. I don’t think I could survive without them. They decorate my computer, reminding me how to do things like create a folder, undo an error or save an attachment without opening it. They adorn my refrigerator and kitchen cabinets to help me remember what to buy, what to order and when I have to be where.

headline: Joseph L. Henderson, 104; Expanded Jungian Methods
text: Joseph L. Henderson, a psychologist and author who was an early practitioner of methods developed by Carl Jung to explore cultural influences on the unconscious mind, died on Nov. 17 in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 104.

headline: In the Future, Smart People Will Let Cars Take Control
text: As the baby boomers cruise into their golden years, I have good news for them — and for everyone else in danger of being run over by these aging drivers. The boomers will not be driving like Mr. Magoo. An electronic chauffeur will conduct them on expressways, drop them at the mall entrance and then go park their cars.

headline: Promising Season Is Bouncing Away From Saints’ Bush
text: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 — Even a day later, the Saints could not turn away from televised replays of the trick play that seemed to startle no one but themselves. The result was a lost ball for Reggie Bush and perhaps a lost season.

headline: Bruno Won’t Talk About Role at Firm
text: ALBANY, Dec. 3  Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, declined on Monday to describe what he does for a Connecticut-based money management firm that has employed him for more than a decade.

headline: Imus Is Back, Chastened but Still Proudly Obnoxious
text: Nearly eight months after being fired for making a racially and sexually disparaging remark about the Rutgers women’s basketball team, Don Imus returned to the radio at 6 a.m. yesterday and vowed he would not say anything like it again.

headline: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Staten Island: Fire Marshal’s Death Ruled Homicide
text: The death of a 38-year-old city fire marshal who was discovered shot to death in his Staten Island home over the weekend was ruled a homicide yesterday, the authorities said. Detectives were investigating the killing last night, but had made no arrests, the police said. An autopsy showed that the victim, Douglas Mercereau, above, died of gunshot wounds to his head, said a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner’s office. Mr. Mercereau’s wife dialed 911 about 8:25 a.m. on Sunday, the police said, and emergency responders found Mr. Mercereau lying in bed in their home at 90 Tarrington Street. Mr. Mercereau, who joined the Fire Department more than 12 years ago, was promoted to supervising fire marshal last month, a Fire Department spokesman said.

headline: How Did a 2005 Estimate Go Awry?
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — In the summer of 2005, senior American intelligence officials began traveling the world with a secret slide show drawn from thousands of pages that they said were downloaded from a stolen Iranian laptop computer, trying to prove that Iran was lying when it said it had no interest in building a nuclear weapon.

headline: Back on Air, Imus Vows to Play Fair
text: Redemption was in the air yesterday. In the air and on the airwaves. There hadn’t been so much talk about redeeming since the heyday of S & H Green Stamps.

headline: Huckabee Repudiates Group’s Effort
text: Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate, distanced his campaign yesterday from an independent group’s efforts to promote his candidacy through calls to the homes of caucusgoers in Iowa and through mailings.

headline: ‘Suicidal Gestures’ at Guantánamo Disclosed
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba, Dec. 4  A detainee at the military detention camp here cut his throat with his own fingernail, causing substantial blood loss early last month, but was not at risk of death, military officials said today.

headline: German Bank Acts to Help Its Programs Tied to U.S. Mortgages
text: FRANKFURT, Dec. 3 — In an effort to limit fallout from the subprime lending crisis in the United States, the German bank WestLB said on Monday that it would guarantee full liquidity to several of its investment vehicles that had put money into asset-backed securities.

headline: Evolution and Texas
text: Is Texas about to become the next state to undermine the teaching of evolution? That is the scary implication of the abrupt ousting of Christine Comer, the state’s top expert on science education. Her transgression: forwarding an e-mail message about a talk by a distinguished professor who debunks “intelligent design” and creationism as legitimate alternatives to evolution in the science curriculum.

headline: Memo Pad
text: DELAYS UP, LOST BAGS DOWN The airline delay rate has averaged 23.95 percent of all domestic flights this year through October, the highest in the 12 years since consolidated data have been compiled by the Transportation Department’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics. Flight cancellations, at 2.13 percent, were the highest since 2001, when figures were affected by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But there was some good news in the data released yesterday. The rate of mishandled bags  bags that are delayed, damaged or lost by airlines  was 5.36 per 1,000 bags, down from 7.49 per 1,000 bags in the same period of 2006.

headline: In Victory, Giants Sample Their Playoff Future
text: The Giants would like to think that their come-from-behind victory over the Bears in Chicago will come to represent a turning point, when the growing doubts about a teetering team were finally tucked away.

headline: Congress Has a Way of Making Witnesses Speak: Its Own Jail
text: Congress and the White House appear to be headed for a constitutional showdown. The House of Representatives is poised to hold Joshua Bolten, the White House chief of staff, and Harriet Miers, a former White House counsel, in contempt for failing to comply with subpoenas in the United States attorneys scandal. If the Justice Department refuses to enforce the subpoenas, as seems likely, Congress will have to decide whether to do so. Washington lawyers are dusting off an old but apparently sturdy doctrine called “inherent contempt” that gives Congress the power to bring the recalcitrant witnesses in  by force, if necessary.

headline: Politically Charged Prints Cause Talking in the Library
text: Controversy has erupted from the sleepy third-floor hallway galleries at the New York Public Library, where a modest exhibition of contemporary prints called “Multiple Interpretations” is on view.

headline: The Birth of Creativity (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Map of Antarctica Brings Frozen Landscape Into Focus
text: A new map of Antarctica displayed last week at the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., combines 1,100 digital satellite images into a mosaic with the most geologically accurate, true-color, high-resolution views of the frozen continent now possible.

headline: Brazilians Giving Up Their American Dream
text: Like hundreds of thousands of middle-class Brazilians who moved to the United States over the last two decades, Jose Osvandir Borges and his wife, Elisabeth, came on tourist visas and stayed as illegal immigrants, putting down roots in ways they never expected.

headline: Unhappy? Self-Critical? Maybe You're Just a Perfectionist
text: Just about any sports movie, airport paperback or motivational tape delivers a few boilerplate rules for success. Believe in yourself. Don’t take no for an answer. Never quit. Don’t accept second best.

headline: Trend Shows Bye Week Benefits Jets’ Defense
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 3  Dissecting the Jets’ defense requires dividing the past two seasons into segments: before bye and after bye.

headline: Simulations of Ailing Artists’ Eyes Yield New Insights on Style
text: For Claude Monet, 1912-22 was a watershed decade. He was perhaps the most successful artist of his time, and his genius had already assured him a place in history.

headline: ON THE ROAD; Bunking Up, Business Class
text: HERE is another depressing trend. With overall costs for business travel expected to rise 6 to 8 percent next year, more companies appear to be saving on lodging by having employees share hotel rooms on business trips, according to Orbitz for Business.

headline: Getting Help When Fire Destroys Everything
text: The sound of a window bursting at 2 a.m. saved their lives.

headline: Paulson Sees Limited Aid in Rate Plan
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — The Bush administration’s effort to help borrowers in danger of defaulting on their subprime mortgages could help only a small number of those who took out such loans, industry analysts said Monday.

headline: Education for Smokers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Candidates Hold to Their Stances on Iran
text: MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 3 — The campaigns of the leading Democratic candidates seized Monday on an intelligence report showing that Iran had halted its development of nuclear weapons, saying the findings justified their more cautious approach to Tehran.

headline: Girls Make History by Sweeping Top Honors at a Science Contest
text: Girls won top honors for the first time in the Siemens Competition in Math, Science and Technology, one of the nation’s most coveted student science awards, which were announced yesterday at New York University.

headline: As Clock Ticks, Congress and White House Stand Firm
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — President Bush and Congressional Democrats were at a stalemate Monday over federal spending, taxes, domestic surveillance and the war in Iraq, and neither side made a move to negotiate, even though lawmakers have just a few weeks left to wrap up work for the year.

headline: Indian Bloom in a Borough Nighttown
text: To some people Queens Boulevard means the sprawling road in the New York City borough, and to plenty of us “Queens Boulevard” is the title of the arty black-and-white film that Vince on the HBO series “Entourage” took to Sundance. Charles Mee’s “Queens Boulevard (the Musical)” is positioned halfway between the two. Trying to reflect an ordinary multicultural world while adding vague artistic pretensions, the play doesn’t come through on either count.

headline: Manhattan: 3 Charged in Identity Theft Scheme
text: A man and two women were arrested last Tuesday at a Bank of America on 97th Street and Broadway as they tried to withdraw money by using stolen identification, a police source close to the investigation said yesterday. The three, Charles Belim, 51, Crystal Velasquez, 30, and Kimberly Tucker, 30, all of Manhattan, have been charged with forgery and identity theft, the police said. The women were charged with wearing wigs, scarves and makeup to mimic the photographs on driver’s licenses, the source said. Officers from the Manhattan North Grand Larceny Unit seized 11 stolen credit cards, three driver’s licenses, wigs and sunglasses, the police source said.

headline: Europeans See Murkier Case for Sanctions
text: PARIS, Dec. 3 — The Bush administration’s new intelligence assessment that Iran halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003 is likely to complicate efforts to impose new sanctions on Iran at the United Nations Security Council, European officials said Monday.

headline: Haydn, Fleet but Controlled, Debussy in Many Textures
text: When you hear the phrase “New York recital debut,” what usually comes to mind is a fresh-faced young aspirant hoping to make that first big splash. But sometimes a debut can be a long-overdue appearance by an established performer.

headline: A Growing Debate Over Folic Acid in Flour
text: Every year, an estimated 200,000 children around the world are born with crippling defects of the spinal column. Many are paralyzed or permanently impaired by spina bifida; some, with a condition called anencephaly (literally, “no brain”), survive in a vegetative state.

headline: As Scripted Shows Dry Up, Reality Sets In
text: As original episodes of scripted comedies and dramas dry up because of the Writers Guild of America strike, reality competitions and game shows are likely to reach record prominence on broadcast television in early 2008.

headline: Court Bars State Effort Using Faith in Prisons
text: A federal appeals panel ruled yesterday that a state-financed evangelical Christian program to help prisoners re-enter civilian life fostered religious indoctrination and violated the constitutional separation of church and state.

headline: Sloppy Police Lab Work Leads to Retesting
text: The New York Police Department has begun to test thousands of drug evidence samples, as a review by the state’s inspector general has found that sloppy work by analysts in the department’s crime laboratory could have skewed drug evidence used by prosecutors.

headline: Richard Nolte, Three-Week Ambassador During Six-Day War, Dies at 86
text: Richard Nolte, a Middle East expert whose tenure as American ambassador to Egypt lasted only three weeks in 1967 because of the turmoil of the Six-Day War and despite the fact that he sympathized with the Arab cause, died Nov. 22 at his home in Hanover, N.H. He was 86.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,873 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Asperger’s Syndrome Gets a Very Public Face
text: Heather Kuzmich has the neurological disorder known as Asperger’s syndrome. She is socially awkward, has trouble making eye contact and is sometimes the target of her roommates’ jokes.

headline: Buffett Is Named as a Witness in the Fraud Trial of 5 Insurance Executives
text: Federal prosecutors are expected to call Warren E. Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, to testify in the trial of five senior insurance executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its finances through $500 million in fraudulent transactions, according to court papers filed yesterday.

headline: J. Richard Steffy Is Dead at 83; Made Shipwreck Analysis Scientific
text: J. Richard Steffy, who made his living as an electrical contractor until he was 48, then cast security aside to pursue his passion, studying shipwrecks, and become a leading a expert in the field, died Thursday in Bryan, Tex. He was 83.

headline: Turn Back. Exit Village. Truck Shortcut Hitting Barrier.
text: WEDMORE, England, Nov. 28 — This little village would seem to be an obviously poor place through which to drive your average large truck. It is in an obscure, rural location. Its streets were built in the days of horses and carts. There is no room to pass and no room to maneuver.

headline: Taking Off in Blue Jeans and Landing in Armani
text: IN my job, you have to look good. Fortunately, being stylish, or at least trying to look stylish, is something that I’ve managed to work out, even at 30,000 feet.

headline: In Gesture, Israel Frees 429 Palestinians
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Dec. 3 — Israel on Monday released 429 Palestinian prisoners from Israeli jails as a gesture intended to bolster the political dialogue with Palestinian moderates, Israeli officials said.

headline: Safety: Used Regularly, Opioids May Not Affect Driving
text: Patients taking the powerful painkilling drugs known as opioids are often advised not to operate heavy machinery because of the sedating effects of the medication. But a new study finds that people who take opioids regularly for chronic pain drive as well as most others on the road.

headline: Unison Movement, and Unusual Uniforms
text: Esse Aficionado is led by three Purchase College graduates who are certainly — as the name suggests — passionate devotees of dance. Formed in 1999 by Veronica De La Rosa, Gina Graham and Maki Morinoue, the group didn’t stray far from its collegiate roots at the Joyce SoHo on Friday. For all the directors’ youthful exuberance, the dances suggested academic exercises brought to life with costumes and lights.

headline: Kuhn Is Elected to Hall, but Miller Is Not
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 3  Bowie Kuhn and Marvin Miller were adversaries during baseball’s labor battles from the late 1960s through the early 1980s, when Kuhn was the commissioner and Miller the executive director of the players union.

headline: Turner Prize Winner Is Announced
text: Mark Wallinger was named the winner yesterday of the Turner Prize, given annually to a British artist younger than 50 for an outstanding exhibition or other presentation of work in the 12 months preceding May 8, the BBC reported. The actor and director Dennis Hopper presented Mr. Wallinger, left, with the $50,000 award at the Tate Liverpool gallery, where the ceremony was held outside London for the first time since the prize was established in 1984. Mr. Wallinger was nominated for an exhibition at Tate Britain that featured banners and other material used by the peace protester Brian Haw during his six-year vigil outside the Houses of Parliament. Mr. Wallinger’s entry in the exhibition of nominees’ work in Liverpool was a video of himself dressed in a furry bear suit wandering as if in a daze around a modern art gallery in Berlin.

headline: Key Judgments From a National Intelligence Estimate on Iran’s Nuclear Activity
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  Following are key judgments from a November 2007 National Intelligence Estimate, “Iran: Nuclear Intentions and Capabilities,” as declassified and released Monday by the office of the director of national intelligence. The judgments include the following footnote:

headline: Aging: Researchers Identify Signs for Risk of a Broken Hip
text: For someone who is elderly, a broken hip can be the beginning of the end. With the loss of mobility that so often results, serious illness and death can follow.

headline: Now and Forever
text: Most of the time we pretend it’s not there: The staggering financial cost of the war in Iraq, which continues to soar, unchecked, like a rocket headed toward the moon and beyond.

headline: Seductive Voices
text: To the Editor:

headline: Venezuela Vote Sets Roadblocks on Chávez Path
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 3 — The surprising defeat of a referendum over the weekend to accelerate President Hugo Chávez’s socialist-inspired revolution has given new energy to his long-suffering opposition.

headline: Paul Brach, 83, Painter and Teacher, Is Dead
text: Paul Brach, a New York painter and teacher who became the first dean of the School of Art at the California Institute of the Arts and a mentor to some of the brightest stars of the art world of the 1980s, died on Nov. 16 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: Gravity May Eventually Triumph, but Not Without a Fight
text: At the start of Elizabeth Streb’s “Slam Show X,” which opened on Friday night at her cavernous workshop and performance space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the performers (“action engineers” in Strebspeak) clamber high up side walls, then fall, flat as pancakes and with a loud splat, onto mattresses below.

headline: Northwest Reeling From Storms
text: The Pacific northwest was reeling today from the effects of two winter storms whose high winds and heavy rains caused floods that blocked highways, cut power to thousands of homes and prompted the governors of Oregon and Washington to declare states of emergency. Four deaths were attributed to the bad weather.

headline: Belgian King Enters Dispute
text: BRUSSELS, Dec. 3  King Albert II of Belgium on Monday met twice with the country’s acting prime minister, asking him to take steps necessary to end the country’s political deadlock. The meetings came after talks on forming a government collapsed over the weekend, nearly six months after elections.

headline: Accounting Errors Cause Plunge in VeriFone Shares
text: VeriFone Holdings, the maker of electronic-payment equipment, lost nearly half its market value in New York trading yesterday after accounting errors erased four-fifths of pretax profit for the first nine months of 2007.

headline: Facing Tough Times, Spitzer Prepares for Budget Battle
text: Declining enrollment in Medicaid will produce the first drop in state spending on the program in almost a decade, Albany budget officials are estimating.

headline: Staten Island: Charges in Drag-Racing Death
text: Two drivers who the police said were drag-racing when they had an accident that killed a 17-year-old passenger in one of their cars in July were indicted yesterday on manslaughter charges. The drivers, Anthony Reis, 18, and Joseph Donovan, 17, were both driving more than 80 miles an hour on Veterans Road West at the south end of Staten Island on July 25 when Mr. Donovan’s car struck Mr. Reis’s, the Staten Island district attorney’s office said. The crash killed one of Mr. Donovan’s passengers, Michelle Arout, 17, and injured several others. Both men were charged with second-degree manslaughter, which carries a sentence of up to 15 years in prison.

headline: Red Crescent Says 25,000 Iraqi Refugees Have Returned
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 3 — At least 25,000 Iraqi refugees have returned to their beleaguered homeland from Syria since mid-September, according to preliminary estimates released Monday by the Iraqi Red Crescent. The figure represents a fraction of the estimated 1.5 million Iraqis who fled to Syria in recent years to escape the sectarian violence and ethnic cleansing in Iraq.

headline: A Walkway Paved With Pennies, for the Sake of Charity
text: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. — Here, beneath the blue suburban skies, Teddy Gross and James S. Polshek have been building their own Penny Lane.

headline: Morning TV Veers From News to Frills
text: In a world without men, the word metal is rarely heard, but there is a lot of talk about metallics.

headline: A Microscopic Insurgent
text: Washington

headline: U.S. Senses a Rise in Activity by Al Qaeda in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 3 — American military and intelligence officials are detecting early signs that Al Qaeda may be increasing its activities in Afghanistan, perhaps even seeking to return to its former base of operations, a senior Defense Department official said Monday.

headline: An Assessment Jars a Foreign Policy Debate About Iran
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 — Rarely, if ever, has a single intelligence report so completely, so suddenly, and so surprisingly altered a foreign policy debate here.

headline: Bart Scott Loses It
text: As far as late-game personal fouls go, Bart Scott’s meltdown after the Patriots took the lead Monday night didn’t have the lose-your-head stupidity of Dwayne Rudd’s helmet toss in the Browns’ opener in 2002, but answer this:

headline: 'Czech Vision'
text: Images from the show at the Howard Greenberg Gallery.

headline: Gagner Is No Kid in the Shootout
text: The Edmonton Oilers’ Sam Gagner, who turned 18 in August, may be the N.H.L.’s youngest player, but he’s old enough to school some of the league’s best goaltenders in the shootout.

headline: $700,000 Homes
text: Properties on the market in Vermont, Florida and Wyoming.

headline: The Birth of Television
text: Photos from the Broadway play "The Farnsworth Invention."

headline: Old Lady vs. Mercedes
text: It’s not the freshest video on YouTube, but youth isn’t everything:

headline: BlackRock Hired to Advise Ailing Florida Fund
text: BlackRock, the asset management firm hired to advise Florida on a state pool whose subprime-tainted holdings led to withdrawal of almost half its $27 billion assets, recommended Monday that the remaining holdings be split into two entities to ensure the fund’s survival.

headline: Bright Prospects for a Comfortable Ride
text: Those plump Lincoln Town Cars that provide a ride as soft as a pillow are clogging city streets and airport access roads these days – a sign that the $2.4 billion chauffeured transportation business in the United States is doing well, particularly with corporate customers.

headline: Gen Re Trial to Put Spotlight on Buffett, Greenberg
text: The trial of five senior insurance executives accused of helping the American International Group manipulate its finances through $500 million in fraudulent transactions could put the spotlight not only on Warren E. Buffett, but also A.I.G.’s chairman, Maurice R. Greenberg, who was forced out after nearly four decades, as well as several prominent Wall Street equity analysts.

headline: Overheard in New York
text: Snatches of city street conversation posted at Overheard in New York:

headline: Germany’s WestLB to Fully Back Its Conduits
text: In an effort to limit fallout from the subprime lending crisis in the United States, the German bank WestLB said on Monday that it would guarantee full liquidity to several of its investment vehicles that had put money into asset-backed securities.

headline: Tired of Corruption but Afraid of the Crackdown
text: South Koreans have grown tired of the corrupt ways of their big businesses. But because the economy depends so heavily on a handful of them, Koreans fear striking too hard a blow against them. That appears to be the case with the bribery scandal that has rocked manufacturing giant  Samsung.

headline: Transocean to Tap Public Markets for $6 Billion
text: Transocean, the world’s largest offshore oil and gas drilling contractor, on Monday said it plans to raise $8.5 billion by issuing debt in order to repay borrowings to pay shareholders in its recent purchase of GlobalSantaFe.

headline: ABN Bankers Said to Threaten Revolt Over Bonuses
text: After seven months of takeover warfare and the $99.1 billion it took to win ABN Amro, Royal Bank of Scotland may now have do battle with some of the Dutch lender’s bankers over loyalty bonuses.

headline: No Takeover Talks for News Corp. and LinkedIn, Report Says
text: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation is not holding takeover discussions with LinkedIn, a fast-growing online social network for professionals, according to Reuters.

headline: Delphi Moves to Extend Bankruptcy Saga
text: In the latest twist in Delphi‘s ongoing bankruptcy saga, the auto-parts supplier has sought a three-month extension of its right to control its bankruptcy reorganization, saying the credit crunch has made it difficult for the company to obtain Chapter 11 exit-financing.

headline: Canadian Income Trust Flies Off With Loyalty Management
text: Canadian loyalty-card operator Aeroplan Income Fund has agreed to pay the equivalent of $759 million to acquire Loyalty Management Group, which operates the Nectar loyalty program in Britain, from a group of investors.

headline: Baosteel Chief Said to Mull Rio Counter-Bid
text: Top China steelmaker Baosteel is weighing a bid to counter BHP Billiton‘s $125 billion takeover offer for Rio Tinto Group, Baosteel Chairman Xu Lejiang told a Chinese business newspaper.

headline: Unhappy Tesla Founder, or Impostor?
text: On Friday, Tesla Motors issued a statement on its Web site explaining that the Silicon Valley electric-car start-up’s founder and former chief executive, Martin Eberhard, “has transitioned from the board of directors and executive management of the company to the advisory board.”

headline: NBC Executive in Talks to Sell Firm to Elisabeth Murdoch, Reports Say
text: NBC Universal hired Ben Silverman in June to reverse the fading fortunes of its broadcast network. But the biggest winner so far seems to be the 37-year-old TV producer and the production company, Reveille, he is poised to sell for more than $100 million, according to press reports.

headline: NBC Universal Chief Says DreamWorks Deal Is Possible
text: NBC Universal would consider buying DreamWorks from Viacom if the movie studio was ever put up for sale, its top executive said on Monday.

headline: The Fast Life and Strange Death of a Hedge Fund Manager
text: A life of private jets and black-tie balls ended with Seth Tobias, a wealthy investment manager and a familiar presence on CNBC, floating face down in the swimming pool of his mansion in Jupiter, Florida.

headline: JPMorgan to Invest $200 Million in the Movies
text: JPMorgan Chase said Monday it will invest $200 million in film and entertainment projects to add to its entertainment advisory and banking operations. The New York investment bank said it will use subordinated debt for investments such as film and television financings, acquisitions and print and digital media start-ups.

headline: As Hong Kong Index Suffers, Aluminum Foil Maker Pulls I.P.O.
text: Xiashun Holdings, China’s largest maker of aluminum foil used for food and drink packages, canceled a 2.1 billion Hong Kong dollar ($270 million) Hong Kong stock sale after the city’s key index had its worst month since March 2004.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Sell Their Marble Bar to EFG
text: Five hedge fund managers at London’s Marble Bar Asset Management will share at least $400 million after agreeing to sell their five-year-old firm to EFG International, the Swiss bank.

headline: Providence Equity Continues March into Emerging Europe
text: Providence Equity Partners, the communications-focused buyout firm, has invested $200 million in a Ukrainian cable company in the country’s largest private equity transaction.

headline: Investors See End to Buyout Boom, Survey Says
text: How do limited partners feel about the recent shifts in the buyout landscape? More than a bit gloomy, according to a new survey by Coller Capital, which found that most institutional investors think the private equity boom is over, with North America likely to feel the pain most acutely.

headline: Lazard Hires Ex-I.M.F. Official for Investment Banking Role
text: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said on Tuesday that it has hired the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund as a senior managing director for its investment banking unit.

headline: Lehman to Buy Van der Moolen’s NYSE Assets
text: Lehman Brothers said Tuesday it would buy assets from Dutch specialist market maker Van der Moolen including its New York Stock Exchange portfolio.

headline: Travelport Said to Plan London Stock Offering
text: Travelport, the travel services company that Blackstone Group bought 16 months ago, has filed to list on the London Stock Exchange, Reuters reported, citing undisclosed sources. The offering could raise about $2 billion, Reuters said. A Travelport spokesman declined to comment.

headline: Dynamos and Virgins
text: The second round of the Reading Room, the Book Review’s series of conversations about great books, is up and running.

headline: A Few Helping Hands With Eldercare
text: After my post yesterday about the challenges of eldercare, I wanted to suggest Web sites that caregivers can use for information and support on a variety of issues. Not surprisingly, the people behind these resources have firsthand experience with eldercare — just another one of the ways people are shaping their careers based on their own life experiences.AGIS is an online eldercare site founded by Kevin Sypniewski, who has spent a lot of time thinking about caring for those who need extra care. His developmentally disabled brother, who died at 31, needed care throughout his life. His sister is a special education teacher, and his mother worked as a nurse in a special education school district. Mr. Sypniewski helped care for his mother, his stepfather, and most recently for his father, who all died of cancer. “My family was exposed to these issues through a train of close relatives needing care in the late 1990s and early 2000s,” he told me. “But it is something all baby boomers will be dealing with.”

headline: Togo’s Sandwich Chain Sold to Buyout Firm
text: Togo’s, the soup-and-sandwich chain created nearly four decades ago in downtown San Jose, Calif., is returning to its Bay Area roots. The 261-store chain was sold by Dunkin’ Brands on Monday to Mainsail Partners, a private equity firm based in San Francisco, The San Jose Mercury News reported Tuesday.

It seems too soon to tell, although indications are the report is likely to temper the broader debate over Iran. Still, the candidates and their campaigns are talking about it, especially around the framework of the Kyl-Lieberman measure, which Senator Hillary Clinton voted for and which her campaign advisers continued to defend yesterday.

The film’s opening had been delayed while Paramount tried to figure out how to make sure that the young men were not victims of reprisals in their native Afghanistan. The effort paid off, according to the Bagger’s colleague, David M.Halbfinger.

headline: Police Retesting Drug Samples Because of Sloppy Lab Work
text: In the five years since sloppy work in the Police Departent’s crime laboratory, the nation’s busiest, was identified in 2002, some of the evidence has been destroyed, making any new tests very difficult, according to a new review by the state inspector general. Legal experts said this could open the door to appeals by those who want to have their convictions overturned or their sentences shortened.
