headline: The great tuna race
text: This is apropos of nothing much, but in the course of textbook-related research I ran across a curious story. The United States has a “tariff-rate quota” (TRQ) on canned tuna: a certain amount is admitted under a low tariff rate, then a much higher rate is levied thereafter. Normally, the right to import stuff under the low rate is controlled by a set of licenses. But in the case of tuna, it’s first-com-first-served. And the result is the great tuna race:

Tom Maguire, who blogs at Just One Minute, has perhaps the most novel theory: it helps John McCain, Rudy Giuliani — and Hillary Clinton. Maguire writes:

headline: The ‘Draft Gore’ Movement, Sidelined
text: Al Gore is not running for president — not yet, anyway, his most ardent supporters would say –- but the campaign to draft him in New York lives, if only on life support, in an apartment on East 84th Street.Yes, the local “Draft Gore” campaign rests in several neat stacks of nomination petitions, on a campaign table next to “Gore for President” buttons, stickers and fliers. The table is in the modest, rent-stabilized apartment of Robert Plautz, 60, a tax lawyer and longtime Democratic activist. Mr. Plautz helped organize a last-ditch effort to put Mr. Gore on the Democratic primary ballot in New York State with a signature-gathering mission to persuade the former vice president to run again.

headline: TED spread
text: Ah — here’s a good chart of the spread between 3-month Libor and 3-month Treasury bills — what I was referring to in my last column. This spread is normally very small, but it has gaped wide as banks lose trust in each other. Notice the pattern: crisis of confidence in August, seeming recovery in Sept/Oct, but now we’re in big trouble again.

headline: Tuesday’s Links: Another Close Call for Patriots
text: For the second week in a row, the Patriots found their perfect record in jeopardy late in the fourth quarter, but they pulled out a 27-24 victory against the Ravens. (Here are the highlights if you didn’t stay up.) The Ravens certainly had the right personnel to follow up on the Eagles’ defensive strategy from last week, but who knew their offense would be able to help out, too? Willis McGahee, who said he was playing for his fellow Miami Hurricane Sean Taylor, kept Tom Brady off the field by grinding out 138 yards on 30 carries. It was only the third game this season the Patriots did not lead in time of possession. AOL FanHouse writes that the Ravens’ performance shows that the Steelers have a good chance against the Patriots next week because Pittsburgh can copy a lot of what Baltimore did.

headline: U.N. Inspectors Welcome a Truce on Iran Intelligence

headline: Disproving Search Results

It is as if we would not know it is their opinion without the ever-present reference to the self.

headline: Now It Can Be Told: Liz Taylor Causes Global Warming!
text: From CNET:As if the burden of divorce weren’t bad enough, people with failed marriages can be blamed for global warming, according to a study by Michigan State University. Divorced couples use up more space in their respective homes, which amounts to to 38 million more rooms worldwide to light, heat and cool, noted the report. And people who divorced used 73 billion kilowatt-hours more of electricity and 627 billion gallons of water than they would otherwise in 2005. Dissolving a marriage also means doubling possessions, from the lowly can opener to the SUV. The report, however, did not estimate how many more natural resources the children of shared-custody parents consume by getting birthday and holiday gifts twice. Nor did it count the greenhouse gases spent to shuttle kids between their pair of energy-hogging households. Read more here, here and here.

His strong play for the United States at last summer’s FIFA U-20 World Cup in Canada hastened his move to Europe. headline: Blood Ties and Acts of Love
text: As I look at my ever-growing and protruding belly, I find myself fascinated by the biological processes at play: sperm, egg, and a baby being made. I imagine that any woman experiencing this process for the first time would find it, as I do, an exciting but mystifying and often uncomfortable journey. In my own first three months I wondered, Why does anyone go through this?   As an adopted person my context for the way babies come into the world is through adoption, not birth. Of course I understand birth, but that is not the way I came into my family. I did not grow up knowing the people who gave birth to me. But I do not doubt the labor my adoptive parents went through to get me. It consisted of mounds of paperwork and home studies that stretched over two years. I thank God pregnancy is just 9 months.   In anticipating the birth of my child, I feel like an explorer getting ready to delve into a foreign land that is also somehow familiar. I did not grow up in the culture of blood; I grew up in the culture of adoption. The ties that bind me to my family are not based in biology. They are based in relationship.   But for the first time, I and my husband -– who happens to also be adopted from South Korea -– will, through our child, know what it is to be connected with someone who also shares our genes. And I must admit there is something delicious about finally being a part of the majority.   But it could get complicated. Like when we have to make a family tree. And have to explain how our little Korean child came from Irish, German, English and Italian ancestry. Although our child will look at our faces and will see familiar curves and lines, the extended family will not look as familiar. And so we will have to explain our adoption so our child can understand why grandma has blond hair and grandpa has blue eyes and we don't.   Part of the legacy we will also give our child is the loss of genetic ancestry. We will have to explain why mommy and daddy did not grow up with the parents who gave birth to them and why we got new families. And even though I have met my birth family, I do not know the family history. And knowing the history is not just knowing one's genes, it's knowing the stories going back generations.   Even though I hope to someday bring our child to Korea to meet extended biological kin, my husband and I cannot provide all of the skills needed to be effective in that culture. We don't speak Korean in the home; nor do we cook Korean food regularly. Although we have become very knowledgeable about Korean culture and have connections to the Korean-American community, I wonder about our ability to nurture our child's racial and cultural identity.   I am relieved, though, that my child will not have to answer the question "Why were you born?" the way I had to answer the question, "Why were you adopted?" I am glad that my child will not be told by well-meaning strangers he or she is "lucky" to have been born. And I certainly won't tell my child to be grateful because I brought them into the world. And if my child feels any gratitude toward me I hope it is because I earned it.   It will be important to remind ourselves that it is because of our own needs, not theirs, that we bring children into our lives to parent. Being able to have the gift of a child born to me allows me to reconnect to that which I had lost as a consequence of adoption. But I also know that to also have the gift of a child adopted by me would allow me to continue the culture I most understand -- the culture of adoption.   I anticipate that generations and generations after me will slowly erase my history. They will most likely forget that their great-great-great grandmother had to learn to be Korean. That she came to America at 3 and a half years old in a little red pant suit and vest, and white sweater trimmed in red. That she cried to return to her motherland. And that the mothershe loved had blond hair and the father she loved was an Irishman. Ultimately I want generations after me to know this about the culture of blood and the culture of adoption: That blood is thicker than water, but love can be thicker than blood.

headline: Blood Ties and Acts of Love

In my own first three months I wondered, Why does anyone go through this?

Population growth, aging and environmental pressures will transform these metropolises by 2050, according to a panel of experts who took up the issue of “sustainable cities” at a panel discussion.

headline: Cheap? Theater? London? Listen.
text: Going to the theater in London can be an expensive business. Prices in the West End for good seats range from 45 – 60 pounds. And if musicals aren’t your thing then choice is limited. However…if you are looking for good theater as well as good value, don’t despair. A number of what are known as “Off West End” houses consistently offer exciting work for less.

headline: O’Malley, Unforgiven
text: By Charles DeLaFuente

headline: Cypher Stent TV Spot
text: Johnson & Johnson starts to market its stents to consumers.

headline: A Year Later: Chat on AIM through GMail
text: Google’s $1 billion investment in AOL may not have been the most financially savvy move as an investment. (Most analysts think AOL is worth far less than the $20 billion value that Google put on it.) But Google did get some payoff today.

headline: Hacking Rings Take Advantage of Death in Boston
text: When friends and family of Ann Marie McNally search for the deceased woman’s name in Google, they come across several distasteful posts — all exemplary of the spam that some fear is taking over search engine results.

headline: Talking the Walk
The National Intelligence Estimate
text: The political landscape changes as it is learned that Iran's  nuclear weapons program has been inactive since 2003.

headline: Romney Fires Landscaping Company
text: Kevin Madden, Mitt Romney’s national press secretary, just sent out an e-mail announcing that the Massachusetts governor had fired Community Lawn Service after “learning that a company caring for the governor’s property was employing individuals who are not permitted to work in the United States.”

headline: Proudly Pandering in Iowa
text: Question: Is there any length candidates for president will NOT go in appealing – dare we say pandering – for the votes of Iowans in the Jan. 3 caucus?

headline: Giuliani Steps Back From Firm
text: Will Rudolph W. Giuliani’s decision to pull back from the direct management of his consulting and law firms insulate him from questions about the firms’ activities?

headline: The Edible Martini
text: Chef/mad scientist Dave Arnold of the French Culinary Institute has figured out how to vacuum infuse a martini inside a cucumber.

headline: A Rule That May Be Forced Out
text: The weekly wrap’s contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: Alison Smale, of the International Herald Tribune, discusses events in the world this week.

headline: The National Intelligence Estimate
text: The political landscape changes as it is learned that Iran's  nuclear weapons program has been inactive since 2003.

headline: Are the Patriots Weatherproof?
text: There are a lot of theories making the rounds about how the 5-7 Eagles and the 4-8 Ravens have managed to slow down the Patriots in the last two weeks. There is probably some legitimacy to all or most of them. But here’s the question that I think will ultimately determine whether New England finishes off its perfect season – or simply settles for winning the Super Bowl: Are the Patriots built to win in any weather element?

headline: China's Endangered Species
text: China's rapid economic expansion has jeopardized the nation's prized wildlife and biodiversity, such as the Yangtze turtle.

headline: Bill Clinton: Media Critic
text: Former President Bill Clinton is not happy with the way the news media are covering the presidential campaign, telling students at Keene State College in New Hampshire yesterday that too much focus is put on “pure politics” and not enough on the candidates’ experience.

headline: Niedermayer Time Again?
text: Bob McKenzie, the plugged-in TSN columnist, is reporting that Scott Niedermayer may be nearing the end of his Roger Clemens-style retirement. McKenzie says signs are that the Ducks are ready to make some trades to off-load enough salary to add Niedermayer and avoid bumping into the cap next season. Last month, the Ducks waived the backup goaltender Ilya Bryzgalov and replaced him with Jonas Hiller at a cost savings of more than $500,000. Reports from Anaheim are that Niedermayer has been skating and working out.

headline: Clinton on the Dynasty Question
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton thinks it was not a good idea for one Bush to follow another into the White House, but having one Clinton follow another is apparently a different matter.

headline: Mum’s the Word for Student Who Asked Clinton Question
text: GRINNELL, Iowa – Remember the story of the college sophomore who asked a planted question to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton?

headline: U.S. Team Named for World Juniors
text: USA Hockey named the 22 American under-20s who will wear the red, white and blue at the World Junior Championship in the Czech Republic Dec. 26 to Jan. 5.

headline: Gifts Ideas That Find Themselves
text: An array of G.P.S. devices for a diverse set of interests.

headline: Belize Realtors Ink Deal
text: In a big step forward for the Belize market, the Belize National Association of Realtors has signed a reciprocal agreement with the U.S.-based National Association of Realtors. The deal should help bring ethical guidelines and basic standards to agents in the Caribbean country.

headline: The High and Low Notes of Politics and Romance
text: It must be fun for the bass Samuel Ramey, whose specialties in the opera house are devils and villains, to imitate barnyard animals in a lighthearted work like “I Bought Me a Cat.”

headline: Comedian Says Minnesota Run Is a Serious One
text: ST. PAUL  Even as Al Franken stretches out his big doughy hand to another potential voter inside Nina’s Coffee Cafe on a recent morning, it is easy to forget that Mr. Franken, the former “Saturday Night Live” star, the satirist and author, the liberal radio host, is trying to be elected to the United States Senate.

headline: Forget the Carats. How Many Gigabytes?
text: WHEN flash drives came on the scene nearly eight years ago, they were given all kinds of nicknames: thumb drives, for their small shape and size; or key drives, for how they plugged into a computer’s U.S.B. slot.

headline: Medical Center to Support Tuition Fund in Pittsburgh
text: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 4  The University of Pittsburgh Medical Center will contribute up to $100 million to help pay college tuition for eligible high school seniors who graduate from the city’s public schools, medical center officials said Tuesday.

headline: Neighbors Reflect on a Death No One Noticed
text: For the last years of her life, Christina Copeman kept to herself.

headline: Drink and Be Merry: Wine Prices to Rise
text: THE signs, at best, have been wretched. The price of oil has shot up, and the dollar has plunged to new lows. For lovers of European wines in particular, it’s a recipe for skyrocketing prices.

headline: For Parents, a Service That Can Offer Peace of Mind
text: ED GRAY’S two teenage daughters wanted cellphones, but the answer was a firm parental no  until Mr. Gray learned about a service that changed his mind.

headline: Putting a Curious Eye on a High School Ranking System
text: That venerable sage, the funk musician Rick James, once said, “R&B stands for rhythm and business.” His aphorism is worth remembering while paging through this week’s issue of U.S. News & World Report, which includes the magazine’s first ranking of high schools.

headline: Snow in Midwest Snarls Travel
text: The Pacific Northwest is continuing today to cope with flooding from storms that lashed the coastal areas with high winds and rain, while the Midwest experienced snarled highway traffic and air travel delays as snow moved into the region.

headline: An Old Nut Receives a New Crack
text: Few artistic experiences are harder to bear than sendups that seem more dated than the traditional works they poke fun at. Watching mediocre ballet might be worse, however, and it is my grim duty to inform you that “Nutcracker: Rated R,” now running at Theater for the New City, gives ticket buyers a chance to decide for themselves.

headline: Teenager Had a Date to the Prom, but How to Pay for a Dress?
text: When Elton Rodriguez, then 14, finally found the courage to ask Kiara Nieves to the John Ericsson Junior High School prom in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, it was a week before the dance in June. Kiara’s enthusiastic “Yes!” came with a condition: He had to ask her mother, Alexa Pacheco, for permission.

headline: Senate Approves Peru Trade Deal
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  The Senate gave overwhelming final approval Tuesday to a trade agreement with Peru, as most Democrats joined nearly all Republicans in handing President Bush an unusual victory but leaving prospects unclear for other trade deals.

headline: O’Casey’s Musical Voice, Reflecting on His Dublin Life
text: If you listen very, very carefully to “I Knock at the Door” and “Pictures in the Hallway,” you can hear the lovely music of Sean O’Casey, one of the most tuneful writers in 20th-century theater. But the static from uneven performances makes it difficult.

headline: Russia: G.M. Seeks Automaker Stake
text: General Motors is pursuing a “significant” stake in Russia’s biggest automaker, OAO AvtoVAZ, as it seeks to expand outside North America, where sales and profit are stagnant. G.M. is “in the bidding process” for a portion of AvtoVAZ, a spokeswoman, Melisa Tezanos, said. She declined to say how much G.M. had offered or what percentage of the company G.M. was seeking. AvtoVAZ, based in Togliatti in central Russia, has said it wants a foreign partner to develop new vehicles.

headline: Some Things the Well-Dressed iPods and iPhones Will Be Wearing
text: MORE than 100 million iPods have been sold since they were introduced in 2001, and with all those players there have been thousands of accessories jostling for attention too. Shopping for them can take a little research.

headline: Qatar Group Steps Away From Omx
text: A suitor for the Nordic stock exchange operator OMX, the investment group Qatar Holding, has withdrawn its application to be considered a potential owner. The decision could clear the way for a joint $4.9 billion takeover bid for OMX by Borse Dubai and Nasdaq. The Qatar group owned under 10 percent of the shares in OMX and had applied for permission to buy up to 100 percent of the company, fueling speculation of a bidding contest.

headline: Guantánamo Prisoner Cuts His Throat With Fingernail
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba, Dec. 4  A prisoner at the detention camp here cut his throat with his own fingernail last month, causing a substantial loss of blood, but was never at risk of death, military officials said Tuesday.

headline: ‘Real Books’ Are Great, Except in Your Luggage
text: FOR someone who is both technologically adventurous and an avid reader, this may be the perfect holiday season.

headline: Florida: Padilla Sentencing Delayed
text: The sentencing hearing for the convicted terrorist Jose Padilla, which was scheduled to begin today, was postponed until next month by the judge presiding over the case, court officials said. Judge Marcia Cooke of Federal District Court in Miami had planned several days of hearings to determine what sentences to impose on Mr. Padilla, 37, and two foreign-born men, who were convicted Aug. 16 of terrorism conspiracy charges. But Judge Cooke had to reschedule the start of the hearing for Jan. 7 because her brother died unexpectedly yesterday, the officials said.

headline: The Top Games: Wars, Swords and Joan of Arc
text: THE heated competition between the Xbox 360, PlayStation 3 and Wii for home console dominance has yielded surprisingly few great games this year. Or perhaps I’m jaded: a lot of games that other critics are putting on their Top 10 lists  Halo 3, Metroid Prime 3: Corruption, Super Mario Galaxy, Mass Effect  would be on my list of most underwhelming. Have I played so many games over the years that almost nothing is good enough anymore? Maybe, but I can still name 10 of this year’s games that thrilled me to the core.

headline: Food Stuff
text: Now on Broadway, and Off: The Trufflettes

headline: Kidnappers in Iraq Release Video of Briton
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 4  The kidnappers of five Britons abducted in May from a Finance Ministry building in Baghdad released a video of one of them on Tuesday, threatening to kill him within 10 days unless Britain withdraws its troops from Iraq.

headline: Iran Hails U.S. Report That It Ended Bid for Nuclear Arms
text: TEHRAN, Dec. 4  Iran on Tuesday welcomed a major American intelligence report’s conclusion that it was not developing a clandestine nuclear weapons program.

headline: Recipe: Bulgur Pilaf With Chestnuts and Spicy Tangerine Brown Butter
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: Without a Writer, Is a Joke Still Funny?
text: The problem is not that Carson Daly defied the writers’ strike and resumed taping his late-night show on NBC. It’s that Monday night’s show might as well have been a rerun.

headline: Two Insurers Increase Bet on Medicare
Leader’s Illness Heightens Concern About Somali Stability
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 4  The president of Somalia was abruptly hospitalized on Tuesday in Kenya, adding worries to an already jittery and troubled nation.

headline: Israel Unconvinced Iran Has Dropped Nuclear Program
text: JERUSALEM, Dec. 4  Israel today took a darker view of Iran’s nuclear ambitions than the assessment released by United States intelligence agencies yesterday, saying it was convinced that Iran was pursuing nuclear weapons.

headline: Stalled Brooklyn Arts District Regains Momentum
text: For years, Harvey Lichtenstein, the impresario who turned the Brooklyn Academy of Music into an internationally known site for innovative productions, has dreamed of transforming the parking lots near BAM into a cultural district reminiscent of the Left Bank in Paris.

headline: A Winner in Cleveland Gets His Turn in New York
text: Piano competitions have snowballed to such an extent that like musicians, they need to fight to retain their competitive edge in a crowded field. According to program notes for the recital on Monday at Zankel Hall by Alexander Ghindin, winner of the 2007 Cleveland International Piano Competition, that event was one of “only 31” piano contests to have received a five-star rating out of the more than 400 surveyed in Piano Competitions Worldwide, a book published in 2003.

headline: A Razor-Sharp Focus Trumps Uncertainty
text: PORT SULPHUR, La., Dec. 4  The smell of gasoline fills the ruined gym each evening as a generator sputters to life. A string of bulbs provides thin lighting above the weight-lifting equipment that sits on a warped and abandoned basketball court. A makeshift dressing area for the South Plaquemines High football team spreads beneath one backboard, where floodwaters from Hurricane Katrina rose above the rim, 10 feet off the floor.

headline: Proliferation of High School Polls Spurs Subjective Debate
text: About 2,000 videotapes arrive in a post-office box in Kansas City, Mo., every fall, sent by coaches, sportswriters and parents from throughout the country. The people behind the return addresses are hoping to catch the attention of Jamie DeMoney, who issues one of several national rankings of high school football teams, a product that is partly arbitrary and largely popular.

headline: Love at First Sight, Transcending Nazi Internment
text: Jack Polak’s wife knew about his girlfriend, and his girlfriend knew about his wife. As he tells it, the two slept on beds “close enough” to see and hear each other.

headline: Cardinal Tells of Assault Over Sexual-Abuse Cases
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4  Cardinal Roger Mahony, the leader of the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, told fellow priests that he was assaulted last summer by a man who yelled angry statements about the sexual abuse of children by Roman Catholic priests.

headline: Signs of New Life in Wi-Fi Cameras
text: THE camera world has periodically heralded the Wi-Fi revolution. Soon, we were told, cameras would download images effortlessly and quickly without wires or even a computer.

headline: Inviting an Old Favorite to the Hanukkah Table
text: IT is probably impossible for many people to hear the word “babka” and not think of the “Seinfeld” episode in which Jerry and Elaine, desperate to bring a chocolate babka to a dinner party, angrily confront another customer at a bakery who gets the last one. They settle for cinnamon, even though Elaine calls it “a lesser babka.”

headline: Correction: Recipe: Back Forty
text: A recipe with the Pairings column last Wednesday for a Back Forty cocktail misstated the amount of orange bitters that should be used. It is three to five dashes, not three to five ounces.

headline: Edwards Takes Step Back as Two Others Slug It Out
text: DES MOINES, Dec. 4  As Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama exchanged frequent and increasingly personal jabs on the campaign trail this week, John Edwards found himself on the sidelines. And enjoying it.

headline: A Blue Blood New in Name Only
text: London

headline: Obama and Race: What Affects a Voter’s Choice?
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Old Smoothie Turns Up a New Idea
text: WHEN my children were little, I fell into the habit of peeling and freezing overripe bananas, then using them to whip up a morning shake with yogurt, milk and maple syrup.

headline: When It Looks at You, It’s Done
text: OF all the exquisite, sultan-worthy delicacies that were arrayed before me during a recent trip to Istanbul, the last one I would have expected to fall in love with was a humble bulgur pilaf.

headline: A Heart Stent Maker Decides the Way to the Patient Is Through the Patient
text: FOOTBALL fans who tuned in to watch the Dallas Cowboys crush the New York Jets on Thanksgiving Day saw at least one novel play: the first attempt by a medical device maker to market a heart stent directly to consumers.

headline: NFL Network Prolongs a Disconnect With Fans
text: The only way I could watch the NFL Network’s broadcast of the Green Bay-Dallas game last Thursday night was on NFL.com, which streamed parts of the game, but occupied users with extensive blather from a C-level, hyperbolic studio crew.

headline: Cabrera and Willis May Join Tigers in Eight-Player Trade
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 4  While most of the baseball world has been monitoring every detail of the Johan Santana sweepstakes, the Florida Marlins and the Detroit Tigers were operating in their own world as they worked to complete an eight-player trade.

headline: Supreme Court Hears Medical Device Case
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Whether a federal statute pre-empts state law is a familiar issue at the Supreme Court, one the justices will face multiple times during the current term alone.

headline: Canada Bank’s Rate Cut May Not Help Exporters
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 4  The unexpected decision by the Bank of Canada on Tuesday to cut its key interest rate by a quarter-point, to 4.25 percent, will probably do little to help exporters struggling to cope with a rising Canadian dollar, economists said.

headline: Newark: Two Charged in Bank Robbery
text: Two men have been arrested and charged with brandishing handguns during a bank robbery in Piscataway on Nov. 10 in which they took more than $93,000, according to complaints filed with the United States attorney’s office. One of the men, Ruben Rosado, pointed his pistol at bank employees and customers as they lay on the floor, while the other, Michael Green, vaulted over the tellers’ counter at Investors Savings Bank and dumped cash from the registers into a bag before the duo fled in a stolen car, the complaints charged. Mr. Green was arrested after a witness led the police to a barbershop in Perth Amboy, court papers said. Mr. Green identified his accomplice as Mr. Rosado, the papers said. He appeared in federal court on Monday and was being held without bail, said Michael Drewniak, a spokesman for the United States attorney in New Jersey. Mr. Green pleaded not guilty yesterday to one count of armed bank robbery and was being held pending a bail hearing, said his lawyer, Richard Verde.

headline: Recipe: Chocolate Almond Paste Filling With Rum-Soaked Raisins
text: Adapted from Mrs. London’s, Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

headline: Bomb Explodes in Pakistan, Killing Woman Carrying It
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Dec. 4  A woman who the police said was a suicide bomber was blown up in an explosion in a high security military cantonment here on Tuesday, police and security officials said.

headline: Officer Arraigned in Bronx Shooting
text: A New York City Police officer pleaded not guilty today to a charge of first degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of an unarmed building porter after a car accident in May, when the officer was off duty.

headline: Romario’s Defense
text: The Brazilian star Romario has attributed his failed drug test to a substance found in anti-balding medication. Romario, a 41-year-old striker who was FIFA’s player of the year in 1994, said yesterday that he tested positive for the banned substance finasteride in October. He said he had been using the drug, whose active ingredient is Propecia, to prevent hair loss.

headline: Crossing a Threshold on Energy Legislation
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  A moment that has been a generation in the making arrives here this week, with Congress poised to act on the first bill to increase vehicle fuel efficiency significantly since 1975 and on the first economywide bill to address global warming since scientists raised the alarm in the late 1980s.

headline: Activision’s Chief Looks for Gaming’s Next Moves
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4  Guitar Hero III, a video game sweeping the nation like a Top 40 tune, lets players strum along on a toy plastic guitar to rock songs played on a television screen. It is attracting a wide audience: children, teenagers, 40-somethings, even the elderly.

headline: Precursor of the Constitution Goes on Display in Queens
text: The Flushing Remonstrance made a rare visit yesterday to the old neighborhood.

headline: Curbing Junk Food
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gift Cards Go Philanthropic
text: THIS year, the use of gift cards, many of which are bought and redeemed online, has merged with another venerable holiday tradition: charitable donations made in the name of gift recipients.

headline: Top Officials Greet Gates in Kabul With Pleas
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 4  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates heard appeals on Tuesday from Afghanistan’s most senior government and military leaders for more money, weapons and security trainers as 2007 brought the greatest spike in insurgent violence since the Taliban and Al Qaeda were routed six years ago.

headline: Calendar
text: Fish From Sicily

headline: 37-Month Sentence for Priest Who Defrauded Parish
text: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4  Telling him, “Not even the collar can protect you from prison,” Judge Janet Bond Arterton ordered a 37-month sentence Tuesday for the Rev. Michael Jude Fay, the Roman Catholic priest who admitted pilfering $1.3 million from the church he had led in Darien.

headline: Freedom Just Ahead: The War Within the Civil War
text: The chaos of Civil War meant only one thing to America’s four million slaves: hope. With armies on the march, and the old social order crumbling, men like John Washington and Wallace Turnage seized the moment and made a break for freedom, issuing their own emancipation proclamations before the fact. They were “quiet heroes of a war within the war to destroy slavery,” as David W. Blight puts it in “A Slave No More.”

headline: Socializing in the Digital Age
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Japan, Rural Economies Wane as Cities Thrive
text: NOSHIRO, Japan  The only outward sign of conflict here is the red flags of protest, but this small logging city on Japan’s remote northern coast is seething.

headline: Is the Entree Heading for Extinction?
text: THE entree, long the undisputed centerpiece of an American restaurant meal, is dead.

headline: Ethanol Advocates Push for More in Regular Cars
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  With ethanol production threatening to grow faster than the existing fleet of cars and complex of service stations can absorb it, lobbyists opened a push today to fuel ordinary cars to run on blends of 20 percent to 30 percent ethanol, compared with 10 percent now.

headline: Teacher Tells of Time in Sudanese Jail Over Teddy Bear
text: LONDON, Dec. 4  Arriving back in Britain after more than a week in a Sudanese jail, the school teacher who allowed her seven-year-old students to name a class teddy bear Muhammad said today that she was "very upset to think that I may have caused offense to people.”

headline: Biking the Expressway? This Could Beat a Map
text: LIKE many vaguely serious cyclists, I view maps as one of the sport’s most important accessories. Part of it is self-preservation. One wrong turn on an exhausting ride that delays the trip home by an hour or two prompts anyone to study maps.

headline: Heavyweights at the Garden
text: Madison Square Garden announced that it would stage a heavyweight title fight Feb. 23 between Wladimir Klitschko of Ukraine and Sultan Ibragimov of Russia. The 31-year-old Klitschko (49-3, 44 knockouts) is recognized as champion by the International Boxing Federation and the International Boxing Organization. Ibragimov (22-0-1, 17 knockouts), 32, is the 2000 Olympic silver medalist and the champion of the World Boxing Organization. Their fight will unify three of the five heavyweight titles.

headline: Bush and Stem Cells
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Ballet Love Story Comes to an End on an Icy Road
text: As sure as the weather grows cold and the holidays approach, dancers from American Ballet Theater and other major companies fan out to regional theaters for performances of “The Nutcracker,” a fixture in the world of dance and the minds of young ballerinas.

headline: Shuttle to Put European Module in Space
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 4  The space shuttle Atlantis is poised for a Thursday launching to the International Space Station on an 11-day mission that will make the orbital outpost more international.

headline: The Thin Line Between Civilian and Military Nuclear Programs
text: For years, American intelligence agencies contended that Iran had a clandestine nuclear weapons program. But even as Tehran continues to enrich uranium, which could fuel a bomb, the agencies have reversed themselves, saying the Iranians halted their weapons program in 2003.

headline: Recipe: Cinnamon-Raisin Filling
text: Adapted from Katja Goldman

headline: Pimp C, Southern Hip-Hop Rapper, Dies at 33
text: Pimp C, the rapper who helped define Southern hip-hop with his group, UGK, was found dead in a hotel room in West Hollywood, Calif., yesterday morning. He was 33.

headline: Verizon Is Denied a Rate Request
text: Federal regulators yesterday denied a request by Verizon Communications to let it charge rival carriers higher rates to get access to lines in six East Coast markets.

headline: Navigators Everywhere, Especially on Holiday Gift Lists
text: JUDGING from the holiday-season popularity of G.P.S. navigators, there are few gestures more satisfying than telling the person you love, “You have no sense of direction, but don’t worry  modern technology can help.”

headline: Bush Insists Iran Remains a Threat Despite Arms Data
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  President Bush warned on Tuesday that Iran remained a threat despite an intelligence assessment that it had halted a covert program to develop nuclear weapons four years ago, as the administration struggled to save a diplomatic process now in disarray.

headline: Canada: Trading System Is Delayed
text: The Instinet unit of Nomura Holdings has delayed the start of its Canadian stock trading system until the middle of the first quarter to give investors time to adjust to new equity markets. Instinet said in June that it planned to bring its alternative trading system to Canada by the end of December. Instinet’s Chi-X Canada platform is one of at least three alternative trading systems being developed in Canada in the next year to compete with the TSX Group, owner of the Toronto Stock Exchange. Perimeter Financial plans to start its Omega ATS on Dec. 6 and Alpha Trading Systems, owned by a group led by six banks, plans to start its trading platform in late 2008.

headline: Plaza Hotels, Plain and Fancy, Spar on Name
text: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 4  One is to be a luxurious $5 billion complex that will evoke the cachet of its New York namesake in an increasingly posh part of the Strip. The other is a weathered 35-year-old joint in this city’s decaying downtown core with $39 rooms and a buffet that always costs $7.77.

headline: Businessman Details Payments to Former Canadian Premier
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 4  Karlheinz Schreiber, a former West German intelligence officer, lobbyist, arms dealer and political fund-raiser, used a parliamentary committee hearing Tuesday to both insult and support his onetime ally, former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about operational changes at The Associated Press referred imprecisely to job cuts at Reuters, one of its competitors. The London-based company cut 3,000 jobs companywide over a three-year period starting in 2003; the layoffs were not aimed at the news wire service, which is only part of Reuters’s operations. (The number of full-time journalists employed by Reuters has remained flat, at about 2,400, since 2000.) The article also referred imprecisely to revenue trends at Reuters. Since the annual loss that inspired the layoffs, revenue at both the overall company and in the media division, which includes the wire service, has grown; the revenue has not fallen “over the last decade.” (Go to Article)

headline: Curtains Rise Again
text: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Dec. 1  When the director Michael Moore moved to northern Michigan from New York City in 2002, the marquee of the State Theater on Front Street here had been dark since 1978. It was a sullen space in this Great Lake city’s central business district.

headline: Church Sues New York City Over Its Catering Permit
text: A lawsuit against New York City is the latest volley in a yearlong battle between a Christian Science church on Park Avenue and its well-to-do neighbors, who do not want the church building rented out for social events.

headline: Extension for Tommy Bowden
text: Clemson University gave Coach Tommy Bowden a contract extension after ESPN reported that Arkansas was focusing on Bowden to lead its program. Terms of the extension were not available, the team said in a news release. Bowden made $1.2 million this season. Bowden led Clemson to a 9-3 record and an appearance in the Chick-fil-A Bowl against Auburn on Dec. 31.

headline: Aide Arrested in Sex Sting
text: A former aide to Senator Maria Cantwell, Democrat of Washington, is in federal custody after being arrested on a charge of attempting to sexually exploit a minor. Hours after his arrest on Friday, the aide, James M. McHaney, 28, was dismissed from his job as a scheduler for Ms. Cantwell. The F.B.I. said in a charging document that Mr. McHaney tried to set up a meeting with an undercover witness posing online as a 13-year-old boy. Mr. McHaney was being held without bail pending a hearing today, said Channing Phillips, a spokesman for the United States attorney’s office for the District of Columbia.

headline: Mitt Romney Is No Jack Kennedy
text: INEVITABLY, Mitt Romney’s long-awaited speech on faith and religious freedom tomorrow at the George Bush Presidential Library at Texas A&M will be compared to John F. Kennedy’s 1960 speech to Protestant ministers in Houston, just 90 miles away. Like Kennedy, Mr. Romney faces questions about his religious beliefs and how they might affect his judgments as president. Also like Kennedy, Mr. Romney realizes  and polls demonstrate  that a sizable number of voters (again, mostly Southern white Protestants) oppose him because of his religion.

headline: A Haven Becomes a Dilemma
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 4  When the Lebanese police caught him in a routine sweep earlier this year, Jaffar Sadiq al-Lami, an illegal Iraqi immigrant, figured he would spend a month or two in jail and be released with a warning, like the previous two times he had been arrested.

headline: Wall Street Firms Subpoenaed in Subprime Inquiry
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has subpoenaed major Wall Street firms including Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank, seeking information about the business of packaging and selling subprime mortgages, according to people briefed on the subpoenas.

headline: From Ireland, Love Songs in the Key of Desperation
text: The title character in “Pumpgirl” is a butch gas station attendant, described by a local lout as a woman “who walks like John Wayne and looks like his horse.” The lout’s friend and Pumpgirl’s sometime lover is an amateur race car driver called Hammy, who proudly announces, “They don’t call me No Helmet for nothing.” One of the wonders of Abbie Spallen’s fiercely observed, unflinching play is that we can see how the utter lack of options  and imagination  in this Irish town could have driven Pumpgirl and Hammy into their affair, and Hammy’s wife, Sinead, to a one-night stand with a brute. Sometimes love is blind; sometimes it’s just this desperate.

headline: 2 Airlines to Cut Back Plans for Increases in Capacity
text: Delta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines will scale back seating-capacity plans for next year on mounting concern over high oil prices and a weakening United States economy.

headline: Europeans Toughen Line on the Dollar’s Weakness
text: PARIS, Dec. 4  European policy makers hardened their tone this week on the decline of the dollar, as economists trimmed their growth forecasts for the 13-nation euro area and major manufacturers like Airbus threatened to move factories overseas.

headline: Free Universal Music Downloads on New Nokia Phones
text: LONDON, Dec. 4  Nokia, the telecommunications company, and the Universal Music Group, the recording company, said on Tuesday that they would offer unlimited free downloads of Universal songs to buyers of certain Nokia phones as a way to promote cellphones as media devices and to develop new revenue for a music industry struggling with piracy.

headline: New Pact for Tuberville
text: Auburn Coach Tommy Tuberville reportedly agreed to a two-year contract extension yesterday that includes a $200,000 annual raise and ends speculation he might leave for another job.Tuberville told The Birmingham News and The Huntsville Times that he and Athletic Director Jay Jacobs reached an agreement that would run through the 2013 season. Tuberville, who had been mentioned as a candidate for the now-filled Texas A&M job and the Arkansas opening, will make $2.8 million next season, escalating to $3.8 million in the final year, the two newspapers reported.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Lou Dobbs Hears Radio Calling

headline: Fund Crisis in Florida Worrisome to States
text: Top Florida officials moved yesterday to stabilize an investment pool for local governments after a multibillion-dollar run prompted the state to temporarily suspend withdrawals by cities and school districts.

headline: White Helps the Devils Find the Right Edge
text: NEWARK, Dec. 4  Things are changing in the Devils’ world. They now practice at their new rink inside Prudential Center, next to cardboard boxes of nuts and bolts stacked on wooden pallets, and Colin White, their stoic defenseman, wears a face shield.

headline: New Post for Archie Manning
text: Archie Manning succeeded Ron Johnson yesterday as chairman of the National Football Foundation and College Football Hall of Fame. Manning, an All-America quarterback at Mississippi, was inducted into the Hall in 1989. He played 14 seasons in the N.F.L., and his sons Peyton and Eli are N.F.L. quarterbacks. Johnson, a running back, was inducted into the Hall in 1992. He played for Michigan and then seven seasons in the N.F.L.

headline: With New Data, U.S. Revises Its View of Iran
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  How could American intelligence agencies have overstated Iran’s intentions in 2005 so soon after being reprimanded for making similar errors involving Iraq?

headline: For Struggling Black College, Hopes of a Revival
text: MARSHALL, Tex.  When the light at University Avenue is green, drivers can pass Wiley College without a glance. There was a time, however, when this small black liberal arts college here caught the attention of a nation: in the 1930s, Wiley’s polished team of debaters amassed a series of victories over white competitors that stunned the Jim Crow South.

headline: Monitoring Agency Praises U.S. Report, but Keeps Wary Eye on Iran
text: PARIS, Dec. 4  The International Atomic Energy Agency on Tuesday publicly embraced the new American intelligence assessment stating that Iran had halted its nuclear weapons effort, but in truth the agency is taking a more cautious approach in drawing conclusions about Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: No Charges of Perjury for Ex-Aide
text: ALBANY, Dec. 4  The Albany County district attorney has decided not to bring a perjury case against a former top press assistant to Gov. Eliot Spitzer at this point, though he has not ruled out revisiting the case next year, according to several people involved in the case.

headline: Legal Challenge to Rowling
text: The publisher RDR Books picked up an ally yesterday in its legal battle against J. K. Rowling for the right to publish the “Harry Potter Lexicon,” a reference guide to the Harry Potter books and films. The Fair Use Project of Stanford Law School’s Center for Internet and Society said it had signed on as co-counsel to defend RDR. Ms. Rowling sued in October to block publication of the lexicon, saying plans for the book, a print counterpart of a fan Web site (hp-lexicon.org), would interfere with her own intention to compile a Harry Potter encyclopedia.

headline: Forget It, Jake, It’s Koreatown
text: “Undoing,” by the writer and director Chris Chan Lee, buries a potentially haunting pulp thriller beneath flashy tics.

headline: Afghan Bomber Hits NATO Convoy
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 4  A suicide car bomber crashed into a two-car NATO convoy on the Kabul airport road on Tuesday morning, wounding 22 Afghan civilians on their way to work.

headline: Where’s the Stick?
text: Two weeks ago, in a major policy shift, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. endorsed the notion that some at-risk mortgages should be modified en masse, rather than on a case-by-case basis. Common sense and the public interest drove the switch: With the subprime lending scandal portending up to 2 million foreclosures through 2008, too many troubled borrowers would be homeless before there was time to work out their loans individually, harming them and entire communities.

headline: Seven Days in December?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Take Me to Starbucks if You Can’t Amuse Me
text: IT was a normal trip home from Grandma’s Thanksgiving feast, except that we had Emily in the back seat complaining, in British English and Brazilian Portuguese, that “cucumber upsets my stomach.” She also kept asking if anyone spoke Afrikaans and telling us that she was terrified of spiders. No, Grandma did not serve English tea and finger sandwiches instead of turkey and stuffing. And no, Emily is not a gastrically challenged, bilingual, arachnophobic exchange student. Instead, our 9- and 11-year-olds were passing the time by building the silliest phrases they could find from the translation software loaded on our Garmin Nuvi G.P.S. unit and delivered by Emily, a synthesized voice. The unit’s Language Guide not only lets users translate a wide range of travel phrases  from transportation questions to accommodation issues  but it can amuse a carful of weary travelers.

headline: China’s Turtles, Emblems of a Crisis
text: CHANGSHA, China  Unnoticed and unappreciated for five decades, a large female turtle with a stained, leathery shell is now a precious commodity in this city’s decaying zoo. She is fed a special diet of raw meat. Her small pool has been encased with bulletproof glass. A surveillance camera monitors her movements. A guard is posted at night.

headline: Modernity Takes the Stage, Captured by Czech Cameras
text: “Czech Vision” at the Howard Greenberg Gallery pursues one of the many leads tossed out by “Foto: Modernity in Central Europe, 1918-1945,” the revelatory overview of interwar photography on view at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. The photographers working in Czechoslovakia are especially tantalizing at the museum. At Greenberg, with 63 early prints by 21 of them, they seem to form a nearly complete microcosm of modernity.

headline: Songs in the Street, Revolution in the Air
text: The tiny, tough, sneakily moving film “The Violin” wears its revolutionary romanticism on its sleeve, not far from its gun. Set amid the mountains of the southern Pacific Coast state of Guerrero, Mexico, home of both touristic pleasures and peasant revolt, it blends fablelike simplicity with documentary touches to tell the story of a near-primordial struggle between the haves and the have-nots. For the three generations of one indigenous family who travel to small, dusty towns, playing their music for coins, the struggle is written on their unsmiling faces and in their plaintive, haunting songs.

headline: Dell to Resume Stock Buyback
text: Dell Inc., the personal computer maker, said yesterday that it would resume its stock-buyback program with a $10 billion repurchase, the first since it restated four years of earnings.

headline: In a New Merger, Evidence of How Much the Gaming World Has Changed
text: As recently as three years ago, if you told a top game industry executive that your favorite genre was online PC games, you would almost invariably provoke a reaction akin to telling a television mogul that your favorite shows explain the migration patterns of obscure African fauna. In other words, you would get the verbal equivalent of a condescending pat on the head  “Oh, that’s nice”  while the executive looked around for someone with something more relevant to say.

headline: Justices Hear Arguments in Guantánamo Cases
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  A lawyer for six detainees held at the Guantánamo Bay naval base in Cuba and the chief lawyer for the Bush administration waged a spirited argument before the Supreme Court today on whether the detainees have adequate means to challenge their captivity.

headline: Gunman Kills 8 People, Then Himself at a Mall in Omaha
text: OMAHA, Dec. 5 — A gunman dressed in camouflage and wielding a rifle opened fire inside a mall crowded with holiday shoppers today, killing eight people and wounding five others, before turning the gun on himself. The shooter, who was identified by authorities as Robert A. Hawkins, 19, was described by friends and family members as a troubled, depressed person who had struggled to hold a job.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: NEW PLACES

headline: Recipe: Strawberry-Yogurt Smoothie
text: Time: 5 minutes

headline: South African Miners Strike for Better Safety Conditions
text: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 4  South Africa’s crucial mining sector was hit Tuesday by its biggest strike in two decades, as tens of thousands of workers stayed home to protest poor safety conditions that contribute to the high death rate among miners.

headline: Liquor Ads on TV
text: To the Editor:

headline: Strong Report on Jobs Lifts Stocks
text: Stocks rose sharply today, erasing two days of declines, after investors cheered a surprisingly strong report on employment. But the Federal Reserve may face a more complicated landscape as it considers whether to cut interest rates again next week.

headline: Lawsuit Winners Assured Payments Will Continue
text: As far as Eric Rabinowitz knew, there was no problem with the checks from an insurance company that he had been receiving since he was a teenager, for damage to his right eye. His limited vision prevented him from holding a regular job, and he depended on the insurance money to pay for his apartment and other expenses.

headline: Crises Dull That New Prime Minister Shine
text: LONDON, Dec. 4  When he took office last summer, Prime Minister Gordon Brown presented himself as the anti-Tony Blair: colorless but capable, dour but trustworthy. The idea was that he would be a burst of cool Scottish forthrightness after the murky spin and dissembling that had come to characterize perceptions of Mr. Blair’s played-out government.

headline: City Names Six Schools to Close After Poor Grades
text: In the first fallout from the Bloomberg administration’s controversial new school report cards, the city named six schools yesterday that will be shut down after earning D’s and F’s.

headline: That Sound Upstairs Is Jam Master Junior
text: AS disc jockeys have morphed from the anonymous spinners of old into stars in their own right, the ranks of aspiring turntablists have increased exponentially.

headline: One Eye on Opera, the Other on France
text: James Levine’s directorship in Boston has turned out to be a good thing for New Yorkers who admire his work outside the opera house. When the Metropolitan Opera was his main American podium, his symphonic appearances in New York were limited to his Carnegie Hall series with the Met Orchestra. Now he turns up regularly with the Boston Symphony as well, effectively doubling his appearances conducting nonoperatic work.

headline: President of Brazilian Senate Resigns Over Corruption Scandal
text: BRASÍLIA, Dec. 4  The president of Brazil’s senate, Renan Calheiros, resigned his leadership post to avoid being expelled from Congress by his fellow senators because of a lengthy corruption scandal.

headline: Junior Fear Abroad
text: Bologna, Italy

headline: Intercepting Iran’s Take on America
text: There are two intelligence analyses that are relevant to the balance of power between the U.S. and Iran  one is the latest U.S. assessment of Iran, which certainly gave a much more complex view of what is happening there. The other is the Iranian National Intelligence Estimate of America, which  my guess  would read something like this:

headline: Democrats Confront Immigration in Debate
text: DES MOINES, Dec. 4  If there is one issue that has challenged presidential candidates of both parties in Iowa this year, it is immigration, and the Democratic contenders were confronted with it again Tuesday, in a provocative way. Should American citizens, they were asked, turn in someone they know to be an illegal immigrant?

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Liquor of Legend Makes a Comeback
text: EARLIER this year, when Lance Winters heard that absinthe was being sold in the United States again for the first time since 1912, he shrugged it off. Then he reconsidered. He’d spent 11 years perfecting an absinthe at St. George Spirits, the distillery where he works in Alameda, Calif., and considered it one of the best things he’d ever made. Why not sell it?

headline: Off the Menu
text: Open Now

headline: Germany: Tempelhof Airport to Close Next Year
text: Tempelhof Airport in Berlin, known for one of the most important stories in aviation history, the Berlin Airlift of 1948 and 1949, will permanently close on Oct. 31, 2008, Germany’s top administrative court ruled, ending legal challenges by airlines to keep it open.

headline: Space Shuttle Widow Is Ready to Move on From Rituals of Loss
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 3  By now, nearly five years after her husband died when the space shuttle Columbia broke apart over Texas just 16 minutes before its scheduled landing at Cape Canaveral, the astronaut’s widow has a meticulous list of the things to pack for remembering him in public.

headline: Ex-I.M.F. Director Is Named Lazard Investment Executive
text: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said yesterday that it had hired the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund as a top executive for its investment banking unit.

headline: Good and Bad News About Iran
text: There is a lot of good news in the latest intelligence assessment about Iran. Tehran, we are now told, halted its secret nuclear weapons program in 2003, which means that President Bush has absolutely no excuse for going to war against Iran. We are also relieved that the intelligence community is now willing to question its own assumptions and challenge the White House’s fevered rhetoric. The president and his aides are apparently too worried about getting caught again shaving intelligence to stop that.

headline: Latin Lessons: O Tempora! O Mores!
text: To the Editor:

headline: Russell Crowe Takes Role Brad Pitt Left
text: Exit Brad Pitt. Enter Russell Crowe. Mr. Crowe, below, has agreed to star for Universal Studios as an investigative journalist looking into the murder of a lawmaker’s mistress in the film “State of Play,” Variety reported. Mr. Pitt abruptly bowed out of the production before Thanksgiving, when his representatives indicated that he was not happy with the script, a situation complicated by the writers’ strike. The decision by Mr. Crowe left “State of Play” on course to go before the cameras this year.

headline: California: Water Plan Is Revived
text: San Diego took another step toward a pilot project that would purify treated sewage to increase the supply of drinking water in a reservoir. The City Council voted 5 to 3 to override a veto by Mayor Jerry Sanders, who had rejected the plan as costly, unnecessary and unpopular with the public. The city’s Water Department will now write a plan for the project, which would make San Diego, confronting possible water shortages next year, one of the few places in the country that augments drinking water reservoirs with purified sewage.

headline: More Time Given to Art Sales Opponents
text: Opponents have won more time to bar the financially pinched Randolph College from selling four paintings from its collection of American art. The Virginia Supreme Court extended until Feb. 15 their deadline for raising $1 million to keep in place an injunction against the auction, The Associated Press reported. Monday had been the cutoff date for raising the money, and Anne Yastremski, executive director of Preserve Educational Choice, said that opponents raised slightly more than $500,000 from 650 donations. Brenda Edson, a spokeswoman for the college in Lynchburg, Va., said the extension was not meaningful. “We didn’t have immediate plans to sell the artwork before the circuit court makes the decision on the merits of the case,” she said. “That doesn’t mean the need to sell the artwork has gone away, but we’ve been concentrating on moving the college forward.” The school had expected to realize at least $32 million by selling four paintings last month to increase its endowment.

headline: Accord Tightens Control of Security Contractors in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top United States commander in Iraq, and Ryan C. Crocker, the American ambassador to Baghdad, have agreed on the details governing the operations of Blackwater and other private security contractors there, American officials said Tuesday.

headline: San Diego Takes Step to Merge Fire Services
text: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 4  A little more than a month after devastating wildfires swept through rural and suburban San Diego County, regional officials here have taken a step toward establishment of a consolidated countywide fire service.

headline: A Church Is Divided, and Headed for Court
text: SAVANNAH, Ga.  For 274 years, there has been one Christ Church here, and it is a congregation with a proud history.

headline: Never Mind the Wasteland. We’re Just Talking Vast.
text: AT 50, can you be thinner, sharper and more popular than you were at 40? When talking about the size of television sets, electronics manufacturers say the answer is yes.

headline: Elizabeth Hardwick, Critic, Novelist and Restless Woman of Letters, Dies at 91
text: Elizabeth Hardwick, who as a studious Kentucky belle set her ambitions on becoming a member of New York’s glittering intellectual elite and then achieved them, as a critic, essayist, fiction writer and a co-founder of The New York Review of Books, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 91.

headline: China: Vatican-Backed Bishop Installed
text: China ordained Joseph Gan Junqiu, a priest who has publicly declared his fidelity to Pope Benedict XVI, as a bishop of Guangzhou. The ordination, at the Sacred Heart Cathedral, occurred with the Vatican’s backing and was held under heavy security. Last week, another priest, Lu Shouwang, was ordained as a bishop in Hubei Province, also with the Vatican’s support. In Beijing, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said, “We hope the Vatican can proceed from the overall picture of beneficial relations.”

headline: Mama Doesn’t Feel Well, but Everyone Else Will Feel Much Worse
text: All happy families are alike, Tolstoy told us, and each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way. But I’d bet the farm that no family has ever been as unhappy in as many ways — and to such sensationally entertaining effect — as the Westons of “August: Osage County,” the new play by Tracy Letts that blazed open last night at the Imperial Theater.

headline: In Trial Run, City to Send Notification of Disasters
text: Julie Menin yesterday recalled the chaos in Lower Manhattan when the Deutsche Bank building began to burn on Aug. 18: Residents did not know whether to leave their apartments or stay inside, whether the air was safe to breathe or the fire was a result of another terror strike.

headline: Venezuela: Raid on Jewish Center Condemned
text: Jewish leaders here and abroad condemned a police raid over the weekend at a Jewish community center in Caracas. The raid by about two dozen armed security agents, ostensibly a search for weapons, was carried out at about 1 a.m. on Sunday, just hours before the referendum that day on proposed constitutional changes backed by President Hugo Chávez. It failed to uncover any weapons.

headline: Plan to Build Reactors Is Running Into Hurdles
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  For the first time in three decades, companies are getting ready to build nuclear reactors in the United States. They intend to do so under streamlined procedures meant to avoid the long delays and cost overruns that crippled the industry last time around.

headline: About a Boy, His Village and Time in the Spotlight
text: “I know I’m unique,” announces Billy, an opinionated 10th grader and the willing subject of Jennifer Venditti’s sly documentary, “Billy the Kid.” Delivered almost apologetically, the comment is without arrogance. But as one candid confession follows another, the camera’s role in their solicitation becomes difficult to overlook.

headline: Knicks Look for Next Option at Point Guard
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 4  Having moved from shock to shared grief to quiet resolve, the Knicks will resume their season Wednesday evening with a point guard yet to be named.

headline: U.S. Indictment for Fund-Raiser
text: Norman Hsu, the Democratic fund-raiser accused of bilking money from investors and putting pressure on some to contribute to campaigns, was indicted yesterday on mail and wire fraud charges and violating federal election law.

headline: From the Bronx to Iraq to a Return Home, Too Soon
text: All afternoon, leaning into the wind, they trudged down Castle Hill Avenue in the Bronx, dressed in funeral parlor clothes. A car rolled up, and an older woman slowly unfolded from the front passenger seat, bracing her fingertips against the door frame, then pulling herself out deliberately, waving off a hand extended from the sidewalk. A young woman carried an infant seat out of a minivan. Soldiers from an Army honor guard, perfectly creased and practiced at their duties, had been among the first to arrive.

headline: A Plan for the Presidio
text: A new museum proposed for the Presidio in San Francisco by Donald Fisher, who founded the clothing retailer the Gap with his wife, Doris, would be a two-story, 100,000-square-foot glassy structure, above, on the crest of the parade ground at the former military base and prison that became a national park in 1994. Resembling a stack of overlapping cubes, with white masonry walls broken by stretches of clear glass to reveal works by artists like Alexander Calder and Richard Serra, the proposed Contemporary Art Museum of the Presidio would also incorporate a network of terraces where sculptures could be exhibited, according to the Fishers. The planned building, designed by Richard Gluckman, faces competition from a proposal for a 48,000-square-foot History Center of the Golden Gate, exploring the culture of the American West. Directors of the Presidio Trust are expected to choose one of the museum proposals early next year.

headline: OPEC Keeps Production Levels Steady
text: OPEC said today that it was leaving its production levels unchanged for the moment, signaling that it was more concerned with slowing economic growth than with high oil prices.

headline: Russia: Two Groups Pull Out of Project
text: Tamir Fishman, an Israeli venture capital fund, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development pulled out of a Russian investment project after a Russian partner boasted in a newspaper interview that he had backing from the F.S.B., the successor agency to the K.G.B., to force business owners in Russia to sell to him at below market rates. The Tamir Fishman Russian venture fund was intended for investment in high-tech start-ups, and would have received matching funds from the Russian government. In an interview with Kommersant newspaper, Oleg Shvartsman, a minority owner of the fund’s management company, described using ties to the F.S.B. to force private Russian business owners to sell out to companies with ties to Kremlin and F.S.B. insiders and “members of their families.” The European development bank said it was withdrawing from the project to protect its reputation.

headline: NBC Leads Newscaster Horse Race by a Nose
text: “NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams” narrowly overtook “World News With Charles Gibson” on ABC to become the most-watched of the three network evening newscasts in November, a so-called sweeps month regarded by advertisers and the networks as a bellwether of the broadcasts’ fortunes.

headline: Italian Court Summons Top Toons
text: Mickey Mouse, raise your right paw and swear that you will tell.... In a counterfeiting case before an Italian court in Naples, summonses were issued for the Disney rodent, as well as Donald Duck; his longtime sweetie, Daisy; and Tweety Bird, the Looney Tunes avian, right. According to The Associated Press, all were called upon to appear on Friday to testify against an unidentified Chinese man accused of counterfeiting Disney and Warner Brothers products. Instead of naming the companies and their legal representatives, court clerks listed as witnesses the cartoons that decorated the toys and gadgets that the defendant was said to have reproduced, said Fiorenza Sorotto, vice president of Disney Company Italia. Court officials did not answer telephone calls yesterday. The characters were summoned under their respective Italian names: Topolino, Paperino, Paperina and Titti. Of her three clients, Ms. Sorotto said, “Unfortunately, they cannot show up, as they are residents of Disneyland.”

headline: Israel Insists That Iran Still Seeks a Bomb
text: JERUSALEM, Dec. 4  Israel said Tuesday that it remained convinced that Iran was pursuing nuclear weapons and that it had probably resumed the weapons program the Americans said was stopped in the fall of 2003.

headline: Supreme Court Reconsiders Pivotal Louisiana Case on Racial Selection of Juries
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  It is just over two years since the Supreme Court sent a death-row inmate’s case back to the Louisiana Supreme Court with instructions to consider whether the jury selection had been infected with racial bias.

headline: A G.P.S. Manufacturer With Precise Timing
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan

headline: Precipitation Across U.S. Intensifies Over 50 Years
text: Across the United States, the number of severe rainfalls and heavy snows has grown significantly in the last half-century, with the greatest increases in New England and the Middle Atlantic region, according to a report released yesterday.

headline: What You Get for ... $700,000
text: Stratton, Vt.

headline: A Perfect Race, With Help From Above
text: ALEX MROSZCZYK-MCDONALD, a medical student at the University of Vermont, is normally pretty good at math. But he found performing mental gymnastics difficult when he ended up at the 22-mile point of a marathon in Austin, Tex., earlier in the year.

headline: Ravens Say Late Calls Favored the Patriots
text: Controversy seems to follow the New England Patriots wherever they go, and their victory against the Baltimore Ravens on Monday night was no exception. A furor has ignited over the conduct of the officiating crew during the game-winning touchdown drive that saved the Patriots’ perfect season.

headline: Brazil: Arcelor Buys Brazilian Unit
text: ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, will spend up to $1.75 billion to buy the rest of its Brazilian specialty steel unit. The company also agreed to buy the British steel distributor NSD. Separately, ArcelorMittal said its chairman, Joseph Kinsch, 74, would step down in May to be succeeded by Lakshmi Mittal, who led Mittal when it made a bid to acquire Arcelor.

headline: Yankees Say They Are Out of Chase for Santana
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 4  The Yankees’ pursuit of Johan Santana is over, according to Hank Steinbrenner, the team’s senior vice president, after the Yankees and the Minnesota Twins failed to agree on a deal Tuesday.

headline: A Page of Mozart Sells for $228,000
text: One of only two surviving pages from Mozart’s draft for his Sinfonia Concertante sold yesterday for $228,000 at Sotheby’s in London, the BBC reported. Bought by London-based dealers on behalf of a private client, the 1779 manuscript, part of a private collection, had not been seen in public for decades and was unavailable for scholarly scrutiny.

headline: Lou Dobbs Hears Radio Calling
text: The way Lou Dobbs sees it, people shouldn’t need basic cable to hear him sound off at length on issues like immigration and free trade. Mr. Dobbs, right, said yesterday that he was creating a daily three-hour talk radio show that would run in the afternoons and conclude an hour before his nightly program on CNN, which begins at 7 p.m. on the East Coast. “My interest is in bringing a voice of reason, rather than the partisan and ideological poles that define talk radio right now,” he said in a telephone interview. Mr. Dobbs vowed that neither the right nor the left would be able to lay claim to him, with some conservatives who support his hard-line take against illegal immigrants breaking ranks with his opposition to free trade. “I consider both political parties to be tragic failures,” Mr. Dobbs said. United Stations Radio Networks, a private company that syndicates one-minute financial updates by Mr. Dobbs, is producing the program. Asked if any station had committed to carry it, a company spokeswoman said that it was only now starting its outreach.

headline: As U.S. Pop Wanes Abroad, Talent Scout Looks Wide
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4  Leslie Feist, a former punk rocker from Calgary, Alberta, now known professionally as the indie torch singer Feist, recorded her 2004 album, “Let It Die,” in Paris. But if listeners detect any hint of French flavoring, she insisted, it is entirely imaginary.

headline: No. 2 Memphis Shakes Off a Poor Night on Offense
text: Memphis’s win did not come easily, nor was it a thing of beauty. The Tigers did not play well and their two offensive stars struggled all game. Somehow, though, they got the job done.

headline: A Key Moment for Justice
text: The Supreme Court hears arguments today in a case that offers a chance to redress an enormous wrong done by President Bush and Congress when they denied justice to a group of prisoners. It is the latest phase of a battle over whether detainees held in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, have the right to bring a habeas corpus challenge to their confinement. The narrow legal issues have changed since the court considered the question last year, but the principle remains the same: The detainees have a right to have a court determine whether the government has a valid basis for imprisoning them.

headline: Taking Aim at Indian Point
text: In an extraordinary move, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Attorney General Andrew Cuomo have placed themselves at the head of the group of federal, state and local officials who believe that the Indian Point nuclear power plant is unsafe and poorly run and should be closed. They should be given a chance to make their case.

headline: Writers Find Haven on an Ivy Campus
text: PHILADELPHIA  College coaches have long scoured the country for supremely quick point guards who can transform a basketball team or fierce linebackers who can dominate a football game. Al Filreis is also perpetually on the lookout for talented high school students, although the ones he seeks do remarkable things with a pen or keyboard. He recruits writers.

headline: Federal Suit Is Seeking to Expedite Citizenship
text: A federal lawsuit was filed yesterday in California against immigration authorities, seeking to help legal immigrants whose petitions for citizenship have been held up by delays in background checks performed by the F.B.I.

headline: The Lounge That Ate a Restaurant
text: AFTER one meal that culminated in dishes of braised short ribs and cavatelli and another that involved duckling and red snapper, I was under the impression that I’d been eating dinner at Grayz.

headline: In Southern France, Renovating an Estate
text: UZES, France

headline: A Calmer Iraq: Fragile, and Possibly Fleeting
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 4  The reduced violence in Iraq in recent months stems from three significant developments, but the clock is running on all of them, Iraqi officials and analysts warn.

headline: Mets Remain Interested in Liván Hernández
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 4  Omar Minaya, the Mets’ general manager, said Tuesday that he planned to speak with the representative of Liván Hernández, a free-agent pitcher who played last season for Arizona.

headline: Police Officer Is Indicted in Shooting
text: A Bronx grand jury indicted an off-duty police officer on a first-degree manslaughter charge yesterday in the fatal shooting of an unarmed building porter after a car accident in May, according to a person with direct knowledge of the case.

headline: A Simple System, Superb at Math
text: IT may seem like a magical device, able to conjure its location from the ether. But at its heart, a G.P.S. unit is simply a radio receiver, picking up signals from satellites orbiting some 12,600 miles above earth.

headline: FDA Panel Votes Against Cancer Drug
text: A federal advisory committee voted Wednesday that Genentech’s drug Avastin should not be approved as a treatment for breast cancer. The drug is already on the market as a treatment for lung and colon cancer.

headline: Ham From Spain’s Prized Pigs Ready for Debut
text: THE first Ibérico hams from Spain are ready to be sold in the United States, having passed government inspections. They will make their American debut tomorrow afternoon at Jaleo, in Washington, where the chef José Andrés plans to slice and serve jamón Ibérico to the Spanish ambassador, among others.

headline: Seeking Mr. and Mrs. Right for a Baby on the Way
text: Juno MacGuff, the title character of Jason Reitman’s new film, is 16 and pregnant, but “Juno” could not be further from the kind of hand-wringing, moralizing melodrama that such a condition might suggest. Juno, played by the poised, frighteningly talented Ellen Page, is too odd and too smart to be either a case study or the object of leering disapproval. She assesses her problem, and weighs her response to it, with disconcerting sang-froid.

headline: Much of Suit Aimed at Indian Cigarette Sales Is Dismissed
text: A federal judge has dismissed all but one charge in a lawsuit, filed last year by a supermarket mogul who hopes to be the next mayor of New York City, that challenged two Long Island Indian tribes over their longstanding practice of selling tax-free cigarettes from reservation smoke shops.

headline: Mexico: Popular Musician Killed
text: Sergio Gómez, the lead singer of the popular Norteña group K-Paz de La Sierra, was found dead along a highway on Monday, a day after he was kidnapped in the southern state of Michoacán. At least 14 other Norteña musicians, some of whom compose and sing ballads not only about love and loss, but also about bandits and narcotics traffickers, have been killed in the last two years.

headline: Study Shows Why the Flu Likes Winter
text: Researchers in New York believe they have solved one of the great mysteries of the flu: Why does the infection spread primarily in the winter months?

headline: Starbucks Picks Memoir
text: Starbucks has announced that its next book selection is “Beautiful Boy: A Father’s Journey Through His Son’s Addiction” by David Sheff, a memoir of his son’s methamphetamine addiction. The book, being published by Houghton Mifflin, is scheduled to go on sale in more than 6,500 Starbucks-owned stores on Feb. 26. Mr. Sheff’s son, Nic Sheff, has also written a memoir, “Tweak: Growing Up on Methamphetamines,” which is being published in February by Ginee Seo Books, a Simon & Schuster imprint. Ken Lombard, president of Starbucks Entertainment, said Starbucks preferred the father’s book because of its unique parental perspective. This title is the fourth selected by Starbucks since it began its new book program last fall with “For One More Day” by Mitch Albom.

headline: Force-Out Rule May Get Flagged
text: The force-out rule is where football meets figure skating. Cue the fuzzy criteria. Cut to the controversy.

headline: There Are Ways to Help Lassie Come Home
text: WHO let the dogs out? And who is going to find them? Well, you can call off the hounds because a new breed of gadgets helps dog owners track their wayward pets.

headline: Romney Faces New Questions on Illegal Workers at Landscaping Firm
text: Mitt Romney, who has relentlessly wielded the issue of illegal immigration against his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination in the past few months, is facing an embarrassing new revelation that the landscaping company at his home in Massachusetts was found for a second time to be employing illegal immigrants.

headline: 76ers Fire Their General Manager
text: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP)  The Philadelphia 76ers fired their general manager and team president, Billy King, on Tuesday and replaced him with the Nets’ general manager, Ed Stefanski.

headline: Clinton Attack on Obama Overlooks Some Realities
