text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been attacking Senator Barack Obama’s health care plan, saying that while her proposal would provide universal coverage, his would leave out 15 million people.

headline: Finally, a System That Will Listen
text: PORTABLE satellite navigation units for cars are becoming more sophisticated as the technology moves beyond just navigation, putting more control in drivers’ hands.

headline: Something to Watch Over You
text: “WILL it find bathrooms?”

headline: $21 Million Separates Contract Proposals By Studios And Writers
text: The Associated Press reports: On Tuesday “bargaining resumed in Los Angeles after a four-day recess, with a relatively scant $21 million separating contract proposals by studios and striking Hollywood writers.

headline: World Cup: Five Quaterfinalists Determined, Three Matches Go to Tiebreakers
Comments on the New Assessment of Iran’s Nuclear Program
text: President Bush At a White House news conference Tuesday morning:

headline: $300 Digital Cameras: A Comparison Chart
The Hidden Half-Dozen
text: The six remaining regular-season N.F.L. games that will air exclusively on the NFL Network.

headline: Dan Blackburn, Beyond Hockey
text: Before Henrik Lundqvist there was Dan Blackburn, the first-round pick (10th over all) of the Rangers in 2001 who made the N.H.L. at 18. He recorded his first victory in Montreal, beating Jose Theodore and the Canadiens, 2-1, with his mother cheering him on. The future was dazzling. But after two seasons, it was all over. A freakish injury while weight training caused nerve damage in his left shoulder. By way of James Mirtle’s blog comes this story from Scott Cruickshank , of The Calgary Herald. Blackburn is managing just fine in his life after hockey.

headline: Still Suspicious?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: $300 Digital Cameras
text: David Pogue puts nine cameras to the test on a recent trip to Miami. The following slides highlight some of their hits and misses.

headline: Mosley sets the scene, discusses his hobby
text: As the World Motor Sport Forum opens in Monaco today, and the World Motor Sport Council prepares to judge the Renault spy scandal tomorrow, Max Mosley, the world’s motor sport leader, today made available through the FIA site an interview with himself that clearly attempts to prepare the world for tomorrow’s verdict.

headline: Hong Kong’s Jumbo Floating Restaurant
text: Boats heading to Jumbo. Photos by Joyce Hor-Chung Lau

headline: General Motors Wants Stake in Russia’s AvtoVaz
text: General Motors is bidding for a stake in Russia’s largest carmaker as part of an effort to expand its presence in that rapidly growing market, a G.M. spokesman confirmed Tuesday.

headline: Another Couple, Another Insider Trading Sentencing
text: In the latest case of pillow talk leading to a jail time, a former financial analyst at Morgan Stanley and her husband, a former hedge fund analyst at ING, were each sentenced yesterday to a year and half in prison for insider trading.

headline: Fannie Mae Seeks to Raise $7 Billion in Stock Sale
text: Like her brother Freddie Mac, Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance company, said Tuesday that it would sell $7 billion of preferred stock and cut its dividend 30 percent to shore up its capital base through 2008 as the housing slump worsens.

headline: MyStrands Adds $24 Million to Series B
text: MyStrands, social recommendation technology developer, has added $24 million to its Series B round that gives it $49 million in second-round financing.

headline: CrossLoop Lassos $3 Million
text: CrossLoop, a desktop sharing software developer, announced Tuesday that it raised $3 million in a first round of funding led by El Dorado Ventures.

headline: NexTone and Reef Point Dial Up Deal and Pull In Cash
text: NexTone Communications and Reef Point Systems, two well-funded, venture-backed telecommunications start-ups, have combined to form NextPoint Networks and have raised $20 million in new capital to advance converged opportunities in fixed-mobile and wireless interconnectivity products.

headline: Maxim and Former Chief Settle Backdating Charges
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil charges Tuesday against legendary Silicon Valley entrepreneur Jack Gifford and the former chief financial officer of Maxim Integrated Products, alleging they were responsible for routinely rigging stock options to make them more valuable for workers, new hires and directors.

headline: Pegasus Closes New $750 Million Fund
text: Pegasus Capital Advisors, the middle-market private equity firm, has closed its latest investment vehicle, capping the new fund at $750 million.

headline: How Green are Rental City Bikes?
text: By Simon Marks

headline: Has Cerberus Lost Its Nose for Bargains?
text: Cerberus Capital Management‘s recent decisions to walk away from a couple of traditional leveraged buyouts, namely its deal for H&R Block‘s mortgage arm Option One and United Rentals, has taken some of the shine off the distressed investors, Breakingviews says.

headline: Senate Delays F.C.C. Ownership Proposal
text: A Senate committee unanimously approved bipartisan legislation that would halt for at least six months a proposal to let companies own a newspaper and broadcast station in the same city.

headline: Shares Slip Further on Fear of Bank Debt
text: Investors have entered December, usually a winning month on Wall Street, cautiously. Fears of further weakness in the financial sector helped push the stock market down for a second day Tuesday.

headline: Is Malone Shopping for Diller’s Ticketmaster?
text: When Barry Diller announced that he planned to split his IAC/InterActiveCorp into five parts, speculation arose that the dealmaker may finally get closure with media mogul John C. Malone by swapping the Home Shopping Network for Liberty Media‘s 24 percent stake in IAC.

headline: Legg Mason’s Miller Offers Blueprint for Citi’s Next Chief
text: As reports surface that Vikrim S. Pandit is the top candidate to take the pole position at Citigroup, Bill Miller, the legendary Legg Mason Value Trust fund manager and Citigroup shareholder, has some ideas of his own for who should succeed Charles O. Prince III at the banking conglomerate.

headline: Newspaper Spin-Off Has Yet to Enchant Street
text: Belo chairman and chief executive Robert W. Decherd launched a campaign Tuesday to sell Wall Street on his plan to spin off the company’s newspapers – a sales pitch that was apparently met with skepticism.

headline: Rocky Road for I.P.O.’s in 2008?
text: As financial markets go, so go initial public offerings.

headline: Sirius Optimistic About XM Deal
text: Sirius Satellite Radio remains hopeful that it can close its acquisition of XM Satellite Radio by the end of the year, as the Department of Justice has “little left to do” to complete its review of the proposed transaction, Sirius Chief Financial Officer David Frear told investors on Tuesday.

headline: Judge Takes Milberg Weiss to Task Over Criminal Probe
text: Milberg Weiss can’t seem to shake the shadow of its criminal probe.

headline: Paul Hastings Names New Partners
text: Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, the Los Angeles law firm, said it elected 16 new partners, effective Feb. 1.

headline: Citi Sells 2 Buildings for $1.58 Billion
text: Citigroup has agreed to sell two downtown Manhattan office buildings to SL Green Realty for about $1.58 billion, the companies said.

headline: Banks Make Bets on Clean Energy
text: Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers are just some of the Wall Street firms that are actively investing in renewable energy sources these days.

headline: Fund Manager Said to Pay $46 Million for N.Y. Co-op
text: Real estate may be the source of Wall Street’s woes at the moment, but the top of the market appears to be humming right along.

headline: Standard Chartered SIV Sells Assets
text: Whistlejacket Capital, the structured investment vehicle managed by Standard Chartered, has sold assets to reduce the fund by 40 percent to $10.8 billion since August.

headline: Lehman Pays ‘Zero’ for Van der Moolen Assets
text: Lehman Brothers is getting into the floor specialist business at the New York Stock Exchange — at the attractive price of zero dollars.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Charged With Fraud
text: In a federal court action, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged that a Michigan hedge fund manager told investors that one of its funds had $2.1 million in assets, when the fund was down to only $200,000.

headline: Clear Channel Delays $20 Billion Buyout
text: Clear Channel Communications said Tuesday that it now expects to close its $20 billion buyout by Bain Capital Partners and Thomas H. Lee Partners in the beginning of 2008, rather than the end of this year.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Ready Sale of Spanish Unit
text: Morgan Stanley has put its private banking business in Spain up for sale with a price tag of up to 800 million euros ($1.2 billion), The Financial Times reported. The move is the latest sign that the investment bank is concentrating on super-wealthy clients.

headline: Cure for Meth Mouth?
text: There’s a joke in here somewhere. From the Associated Press:

headline: Ackermann Said to Reject Citi’s Top Spot
text: Josef Ackermann, chief executive of Deutsche Bank, has turned down an approach from Citigroup about taking the top spot at the troubled financial giant, The Financial Times reported citing an unnamed source.

headline: Wall St. Firms Said to Receive Subpoenas
text: Merrill Lynch, Bear Stearns and Deutsche Bank are among the Wall Street firms that have been sent subpoenas from the office of the New York state attorney general, which wants to know about how mortgages were sliced up and resold to investors, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: More of Your ‘Late Night’ Jokes
text: Can a late-night show without writers be funny? By crossing the picket line, Carson Daly seems to be demonstrating this week that the answer is no. Ah, who needs him anyhow? Here’s some more reader-generated comedy:

headline: “High Five,” the Sequel
text: “High Five Hollywood” builds on the popularity of a Funny or Die video featured here a few weeks back:

headline: Xstrata Bids $842 Million for Resource Pacific
text: Swiss mining group Xstrata on Wednesday made an $842 million cash bid for coal miner Resource Pacific, trumping an all-share offer by New Hope, as it seeks to grow in Australia’s booming resource sector.

headline: More Nelson
text: Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden, the director/writing pair that was very much in the mix last year with “Half Nelson,” may be back next year after signing a deal with HBO for their film “Sugar.”

headline: Amaranth Veterans Said to Lose 15% at New Fund
text: Does the specter of Amaranth Advisors still haunt its survivors?

headline: Ten Little Indians
text: Award’s Daily wrapped up a poll on the year’s best picture and the results are in:

headline: In Defense of the Entree
text: In an intriguing, illuminating article by my colleague Kim Severson in Wednesday’s Dining section, some very important chefs talk some very disturbing trash about the entree, which I would like to defend.

headline: ‘Bionic Woman’ Seems Dogged by Mortal Flaws
text: What went wrong for “Bionic Woman?”

headline: Beyond the Romance of Wine
text: As you might guess I spend a lot of time reading about wine. Books, periodicals, web sites, blogs, you name it, I’m often there. Today I want to focus on magazines, which if I’m not careful start proliferating around my apartment like tribbles.

headline: World Cup Update: Quarterfinalists Are Set; Kamsky Is One of Them
text: In the World Cup in Khanty-Mansiysk, three matches went to tiebreaker games today to decide the final three quarterfinalists. Dmitry Jakovenko of Russia, No. 19 in the world, upset Levon Aronian of Armenia, No. 9; Gata Kamsky of the United States, No. 17, also pulled an upset by beating Peter Svidler of Russia, No. 12; and Evgeny Alekseev of Russia, No. 14, held to form by taking care of Evgeny Bareev of Russia, No. 57, who was the lowest remaining player in the tournament. The results and the games can be found on the tournament’s Web site.

headline: A Copy Is Art. So What's the Original?
text: Images from the works of Richard Prince and Jim Krantz.

headline: American Prankster
text: Every once in a while, the guests lists get crossed and the Bagger ends up at an event where he manifestly does not belong. Last night, Yvonne and Barry Cohen hosted Brian Grazer and his girlfriend Chau-Giang Thi Nguyen at their soaring apartment in the skies above the East River. The event was held to raise money for a Steinway piano, which is to be donated to Ms. Thi Nguyen’s music school in her native Vietnam. The evening featured an exquisite piano performance by Ms. Thi Nguyen.

headline: Dying in Brooklyn, Alone and Unnoticed
text: On Monday, the police found the skeletal remains of Christina Copeman in her home in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. She had been dead for a year to 18 months, and was dressed to go out, in a coat and beret. “It seems impossible for a person to fall through the cracks like that, to die in her own home and go undiscovered. New York is a big city, but it is impersonal only at a distance,” Andy Newman writes. “People have neighbors. They have relatives. But Christina Copeman, who would be 70 if she were alive today, managed to slip away almost by sheer force of will.”

headline: The Early Word: Immigration and Iran
text: While some of the candidates are moving on to other issues today, with Barack Obama issuing a call for national service and Hillary Clinton addressing the mortgage crisis (and Mitt Romney preparing for his big speech on religion tomorrow), the fallout from debates over immigration and Iran continue to resonate in Iowa and around the country.

headline: Talk Off | Cologne
Nonpartisan AEI
text: I have a lot of problems with this Kit Seelye piece. It’s kind of weird that the usual “both sides may have a point” reporting gave way to a clear declaration that one side is right — precisely on an issue where many, many health experts believe that Obama is wrong, and that mandates are both feasible and essential. Much better coverage of the issue, I’m sorry to say, in the Murdoch news.

headline: A music box of a Paris shop
text: Tucked below the arcades of the Palais-Royal is a cramped little box of a shop that naturally sells just that: music boxes of warbling birds, waltzing women, polka dancing peasants.

headline: On Iran, a Hawk Says Talk
text: Robert Kagan, a hawk’s hawk who once wrote that “Americans are from Mars and Europeans are from Venus,” now thinks the United States should begin to open direct talks with Iran. He writes in his monthly Washington Post column:

headline: A Must-See Thursday Night
text: On Thursday night HBO is going to begin airing a documentary about Darfur, “Sand and Sorrow.” Most places would headline that it features narration from a big-time movie star, but here in “On the Ground,” we’re going to trumpet that Nick is in it. The folks behind the film are encouraging people to have house parties and to participate in a call-in after show. Nick will be on the call along with filmmaker Paul Freedman, Samantha Power and John Prendergast. The documentary premieres on Dec. 6 at 8 p.m. and will also show on Dec. 10 at 2:15 p.m. and 10:30 p.m.

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Rudolph Delson
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

headline: Art Murmur | First Look at A.B.M.B.
text: We’re not the only ones swooning over the prospect of Art Basel Miami Beach. A passenger had an apparent seizure on a Monday morning flight from New York carrying art-world heavy-hitters, including the artist Terence Koh, the gallerist Sara Meltzer, the power collector David Teiger, Blue Medium’s John Melick, and Paper magazine’s Kim Hastreiter. For the record, none of the healthcare professionals who came to the young man’s aid was dressed like a Richard Prince nurse.

headline: Who’s to Blame for Big Golden Parachutes?
text: Whenever a chief executive at a top firm loses his or her job because of poor performance, one question crops up right away: How big is the exit package? When the size of the chief’s golden parachute comes to light, it usually inspires a wave of criticism about the board of directors that seemed to sign the check.

headline: Canada’s Rendition of the Personal-Data Breach
text: The infamous data-security breach in Britain last month, where disks full of personal financial data on half the country’s households somehow got lost between offices, came down essentially to a “moment’s blunder” in the mailroom — an infuriating mistake that shook the government and prompted a resignation, but nonetheless a straightforward human error.

headline: For the Record
text: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column yesterday about the Grawemeyer Award for music composition, won by Peter Lieberson for the song cycle "Neruda Songs," misstated the given name of his wife, a mezzo-soprano who inspired the work and who died last year. She was Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, not Helen.

headline: Rome just got Better, or Easier at least
text: A service inaugurated in Rome this week allows you to reserve tickets via phone or online to some of Rome’s most popular monuments – including the Colosseum, the Borghese Museum, and the National Roman Museum. It also includes a number of theaters, although theater in any language other than Italian is a rarity here.

headline: You’re Lookin’ Swell, Dali
text: Random kudos from the Surrealist Compliment Generator:

headline: Wednesday Kickoff: Hello, Michigan? Anybody There?
text: So how did Les Miles get away from Michigan? Well, Jim Carty of the Ann Arbor News reports that Michigan Athletic Director Bill Martin never returned Miles’s phone calls (or, more specifically, those of Miles’s agent). With the Miles-to-Michigan deal falling through, Angelique S. Chengelis of the Detroit News reports that more than 500 e-mails have been sent by former players and alums to Martin and Michigan’s president, Mary Sue Coleman, pledging support for Miles.

headline: Santa Claus Is Still Fat
text: Holidays reflect people’s obsessions, so this year (kind of like last year) the jolly dude is taking a hit from the food police, including the Surgeon General and British shopping centers. Here’s a debate on Fox:

headline: For the Moment | Proenza Schouler’s Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough
text: (Greg Kadel)

headline: Adams’s Portrait of Democracy
text: Are we being too hard on Adams? A number of readers posting comments seem to think so. Who cares if Adams doesn’t say more about his brothers or his Harvard roommates, or anything at all about his wife’s suicide? It’s ungrateful and “unfair,” they suggest, to greet this “startlingly brilliant exercise of mind and style” with a cry for more color, more anecdotes, more tears, more dish.

headline: Ron MacLean, What’s Your Number?
text: Scoring is down. Scoring is up. Your left is my right, and everything looks wrong.

headline: As Tech Buying Slows, G.P.S. Stays the Course
text: I’ve learned long ago not to assume my taste in products is shared by many other people. But this year we are not alone. The top of the Hansell house holiday list was a Global Positioning System navigation gizmo for the minivan. (We had one too many misadventures on the way to birthday parties in New Jersey strip malls.)

headline: Viewers Turning To The Web For TV
text: The most popular Web source for full episodes of television shows is ABC.com, according to a study conducted by The Nielsen Company and released today.

headline: New Group Will Help Homeowners Avoid Foreclosure
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and leaders of the City Council announced this morning that New York City will invest $2.8 million to start a nonprofit organization that will be dedicated to helping homeowners avoid foreclosure — the city’s most tangible response so far to the crisis in subprime lending and the turmoil in the housing and mortgage markets.

headline: “Circumcision” or “Mutilation”? And Other Questions About a Rite in Africa
text: My post about a debate over a female initiation rite in Africa prompted lots of angry reactions, some quite thoughtful ones, much misinformation and one entirely reasonable request from Charles:

headline: Juno What Else?
text: The Bagger has been tagged out for excessively puffing “Juno,” probably because he is an unholy amalgam of fanboy/hack/journeyman who knows nothing of cinema, or movies for that matter.

headline: Waiting for the Slipper to Drop
text: This afternoon at 2 p.m., the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures will announce its selections for the year. People love to slag on their choices, in part because they need to make picks that deliver high star wattage for their event. The NBR has not been super predictive in the recent past, but in a year cluttered with excellence, any heat is good heat. Check back this afternoon for the results.

headline: Rolling Around on the Carpet
text: Alreet, the Bagger asked The Community — okay, the rugrats who lurk in Comments — to start showing some leg around their favorites for the year.

headline: The ‘Truth,’ Without Jokes?
text: Al Franken on one of the issues of the day:

headline: Are We In A Recession Yet?–At Least Some of Us May Be
text: Against a steady drumbeat of bad news from the housing and credit markets, many Americans are starting to wonder whether the economy is about to topple over into recession. Depending on where you live, it might already have.

headline: Zuckerberg Apologizes, Allows Facebook Users to Evade Beacon
text: Mark Zuckerberg has produced a symphony of contrition in a blog post today about Facebook’s Beacon feature, which initially sent information on users’ Web purchases to their friends unless they specifically blocked the disclosure of each purchase.

headline: Do New Roads Help or Hurt Global Warming?
text: If you read the column today, you know that France last month pledged an end to new highway construction. Environmentalists cheered the development, but they are watching the loopholes carefully. Even so, the tentative steps France is taking are in sharp contrast with developments elsewhere in the world. One of the biggest projects is the Asian Highway, a network of new and upgraded roads spanning 140,000 kilometers, or about 87,000 miles, and crisscrossing 32 countries from Southeast Asia to Central Asia.

headline: Giuliani Ad Focuses on Iran
text: Just two days after the release of a National Intelligence Report that has made Iran the flashpoint of debate in the presidential race, the Giuliani campaign is up with a new ad highlighting the Iran hostage crisis, and the need to “stand up” to “dictators” and “tyrants.”

headline: James Wolcott and the Exploding Scoreboard
text: James Wolcott, in this week’s New Republic, delivers a status report on the health of book reviews, and writes that, in the digital age, “book reviewing bears the social handicap of a dying trade, like typewriter repair or horseshoe mending.” It’s a piece worth reading – you can find it here.

headline: Looking for the Weaknesses in United Rental’s Lawsuit
text: United Rental‘s lawsuit against Cerberus Capital Management introduced a new phrase to legal neophytes watching the proceedings: “specific performance.” In its lawsuit, the rental equipment operator is demanding that Delaware’s court of chancery force Cerberus to complete the $4 billion buyout, arguing that the specific performance clause in the deal agreement mandates just that.

headline: A High Price for Healthy Food
text: Healthy eating really does cost more.

headline: Recipe: Fennel With Blue Cheese And Bread Crumbs
text: “Gratin” has come to mean a kind of macaroni-and-cheese affair, a gooey dish in which the main foodstuff — whether potatoes, noodles or vegetables — is dominated by a mass of white sauce, cheese and butter. But the word really refers to the crust that forms on the top and sides of a dish that has been browned under a fire. Although gooey, cheesy dishes can be enjoyable, you can make honest, simple, lean gratins with fewer ingredients to produce easy, interesting vegetable dishes.

headline: Two Managers and One Pitcher
text: Red Sox Manager Terry Francona sat in front of a row of black curtains, doing his best not to mention Johan Santana. A half hour later, Ron Gardenhire, the manager of the Twins, sat in front of a different set of black curtains and spoke openly about Santana.

headline: Moonves: There’s Something About Katie
text: In November the total audience for the “CBS Evening News with Katie Couric” “was down over a million (or 13.5 percent) when compared with the same month a year ago,” Jacques Steinberg notes in today’s Times.

headline: Basel Player | Dan Colen
text: Dan Colen (Hannah Liden)

headline: Ferrari Champions Team Up for Fiat Commercial
text: Michael Schumacher and Kimi Raikkonen appear together in this commercial for the Fiat Bravo T-Jet. We’ve seen this premise before. Stick two superstars together in a game of one-upmanship, add some trash talk, and watch the sparks fly. The classic example is Larry Bird and Michael Jordan playing horse for a Big Mac.

headline: Recipe: Pasta With Chestnuts and Mushrooms
text: Title: Pasta With Chestnuts And Mushrooms

headline: Apologies to Liechtenstein
text: I mistakenly lumped the United States and Liechtenstein as the last of the industrialized countries that have not ratified the Kyoto Protocol, now that Australia did so early this week under its new government.

headline: Applying a ‘Reality Test’ on Congestion Pricing
text: Remember congestion pricing? The New York City Traffic Congestion Mitigation Commission continues to evaluate Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan for charging traffic fees in much of Manhattan, even as several opponents of the plan have put forward alternatives that would not involve charging regular passenger vehicles.

headline: Papal Indulgences, Two Ways: Easy and Hard
text: According to the centuries-old rules of the Roman Catholic Church, sin-reduction is a two-step process. Guilt is absolved through confession and prayer, but punishment — on earth or in purgatory — can be avoided through indulgences, an ancient form of church-granted amnesty that critics deride as a shortcut to salvation.

headline: The Candidates’ Tough Stances, on TV
text: Forgive the 7-year-old son and 9-year-old daughter of Senator John Edwards of North Carolina if they’re not as hip as their schoolmates to the latest plotlines on “Hannah Montana’’ or “SpongeBob.’’ “Beyond UNC games,’’ Mr. Edwards wrote recently in response to a survey on children’s media, “watching television isn’t a favorite pastime in our house.’’

headline: Obama Issues Call for Public Service
text: MT. VERNON, Iowa – Senator Barack Obama implored young Americans “to step into the currents of history,” by not only supporting his presidential candidacy, but committing to form a new generation of public service.

headline: Stars Picket, And Shiver, As Strike Enters Second Month
text: The Writers Guild of America, East marked Tuesday’s one-month anniversary of their strike against the studios by returning to the Rockefeller Center plaza, the site of the first day of picketing.

headline: The Golden Age of Travel?
text: We can all fancy ourselves masters of our own domains these days; cyberspace allows us to draw up our own preferences, to cater to our niche interests, to create a community of people who are just like us. We have the whole world in our hands (in our laptops), we can swivel between hundreds of channels on our TV sets, our cell phones allow us to contact Cindy in Tibet.

headline: Flushing House Gave Rise to Religious Freedom
text: Growing up in Queens, I remember visiting the Bowne House as a child. Along with institutions like the Queens County Farm Museum and the Louis Armstrong House & Archives, Bowne House is a reminder of Queens’s rich — and often underappreciated — contributions to American history.

headline: Trump’s Golf Megaresort, Back From the Dead?
text: Never famous for taking no for an answer, Donald Trump has evidently decided to go over the heads of the municipal board that rejected his plans for a £1 billion ($2 billion)

headline: Continental’s Design Flaws
text: When I checked into the airport in White Plains, N.Y., last week, I went straight for the check-in kiosks, avoiding the long holiday lines. I noticed two strange things about Continental’s kiosks: two bad-software design issues in one.

headline: From Afghanistan to Iraq in a Jumpseat
text: Editors’ Note: Thom Shanker, a Washington correspondent of The New York Times, is traveling with Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates during one of his many trips abroad. Read all the dispatches here.

headline: Cat Fight
text: It seems that people, just like the deadlocked jury in the Texas case of Jim Stevenson, the cat-shooting bird lover, remain deeply divided over whether cats should be allowed to roam free outdoors. Scientists estimate that free-range cats, either pets or feral, kill tens of millions of birds each year (not to mention chipmunks, voles, the occasional rabbit and other critters).

headline: The National Board of Review Award Winners for 2007
text: The National Board of Review has announced its 2007 award winners. Here they are:

headline: If It’s Snowing Outside, Don’t Worry. It’s Normal.
text: The early December flurries on Sunday and today give rise to the question: Is it snowing earlier than usual this year? Well, not really, according to meteorologists at Pennsylvania State University. Todd Miner, a meteorologist at the university, which supplies the information for The Times’s daily weather reports, said the city is almost exactly on track for average snowfall this winter. So far in December, 1.4 inches have been recorded; November had 0.3 inch.

headline: The First of Many
text: The National Board of Review, which will be held on Jan. 15, is a lovely event, in part because everyone knows who already won. And that’s because they were announced today. Although the results aren’t terribly predictive in terms of the Oscars, it does get a witless monkey like the Bagger typing and speculating. So, without further ado, witless monkey speculation.

headline: Fox’s Fair and Balanced Ad Policy
text: Actor Danny Glover has filmed a TV ad asserting that the Bush Administration is destroying the Constitution through the use of torture, rendition, and other war-on-terror tactics. Mr. Glover urges viewers to “rescue the Constitution.”

headline: Lawmakers Propose Campaign Reform
text: Before the 2000 presidential election, just three candidates, all independently wealthy, had ever opted out of the public finance system for the primaries. Today, few presidential hopefuls opt in, instead preferring to amass their own financial war chests.

headline: A Visit with the Master
text: During my two decades as a Washington journalist, I often mused that the orgy of scandal and tainted money that made the capital such a feast for investigative reporters and spoofers (think “Thank You for Smoking”) had to rival that of the Gilded Age, which provided Adams so much rich material. I think there is no better piece of writing about Washington than Adams’s chapter on Grant. Like Adams, I found that some of the politicians and lobbyists I covered defied burlesque because “they were more grotesque than ridicule could make them,” and that senators (the esteemed Mr. Hart a notable exception!) were often comical in their egotism. Still, like Adams, I couldn’t help but love the place. As he writes, “one could not stay there a month without loving the shabby town.”

headline: If You Can’t Beat Them, Join Them
text: Did you ever get the feeling the Flyers are in the headlights right now?

headline: One Way to Pay The Mortgage
text: A survey of chief financial officers out today, from Duke University and CFO Magazine, asks an interesting question:

headline: ABC Slips Without ‘Dancing’
text: Nielsen’s ratings for Monday were delayed due to processing issues, but the final results show ABC slipping into third place now that its highly rated series “Dancing With the Stars” is finished.

headline: College Cup: All Hail the Underdog
text: In some ways, athletes and coaches are like junkies.

headline: Everybody Into the Pool
text: I can make all the lists I want, but when it comes to how our house is being constructed, my role is much more reactive than proactive. That’s because I’m not driving this project. Our builder John Agnelli is.

headline: A Dark-Horse Candidate for Citi’s Top Job?
text: Since last month, Citigroup has struggled to find a replacement for Charles O. Prince III, its recently resigned chief executive. It has looked inside the sprawling financial giant; it has examined the firm’s alumni (some of whom left the firm unwillingly); it has cast its eyes on the top executives of its rivals.

headline: Legal Help for Immigrants, Even Illegal Ones
text: The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced on Tuesday the creation of an Immigrant Affairs Program to encourage immigrants who are crime victims or are aware of illegal activity to come forward without fear of arrest and deportation.

headline: Change of Venue for Oprah-Obama Event
text: How big is Oprah in South Carolina?

headline: CDOs explained
text: From Felix Salmon — this is great.

headline: Ozzie Guillen’s Wish List
text: Ozzie Guillen, the manager of the White Sox, hoped to get Torii Hunter as his center fielder when Hunter left the Minnesota Twins as a free agent.

headline: Depression More Deadly for Diabetics
text: Treating some diabetic patients for depression may help prolong their lives, according to new research.

headline: Taking Liberties With Tchaikovsky
text: Perhaps you think of “The Nutcracker” as the perfect children’s entertainment? Irina Roizin, the founder of the Brighton Ballet Theater and School of Russian Ballet in Brooklyn, is not so sure.

headline: More ‘Saturday Night,’ None of it ‘Live’
text: NBC viewers can expect a double dose of “Saturday Night Live” encores this month.

text: Striking entertainment writers say piano-playing cats and other cute Web critters have joined their walkout in sympathy …

headline: Week of Record-Breaking Auctions
text: The week brought record-breaking bids in three categories at auction houses in Europe:

headline: Limits to inflation — you read it here first
text: The WSJ writes about the helium shortage — but I was all over it a while back.

headline: Famous in His Own Right
text: Josh Brolin has a famous stepmother — Barbra Streisand — and a famous wife — Diane Lane. More to the point, he also has a role in “American Gangster” and stars in “No Country for Old Men,” which just won National Board of Review awards for the year’s best film and best ensemble cast. At a screening last month, Mr. Brolin told the Baguette that the two films “just showed up on my doorstop”

headline: Thompson Picks Up Endorsement in S.C.
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — In a state where he appears locked in a three-way race, Fred D. Thompson’s campaign heralded his endorsement from a grass-roots anti-abortion group in South Carolina today.

headline: Iowa Senator Games the Caucuses
text: When it comes to the notoriously complex Iowa presidential caucuses, there are few people as qualified to read the political tea leaves as the state’s senior senator, Charles E. Grassley, a Republican now in his 32d year in Congress. And even though Mr. Grassley has decided — for the first time apparently — not to endorse anyone in the Republican caucuses, that didn’t stop him today from offering up his predictions: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois for the Democrats and former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts for the Republicans.

headline: The Truth on Oil and the Iran Vote
text: In the National Public Radio debate Tuesday of the Democratic presidential candidates, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware twice mentioned the rise in oil prices when speaking about Iran.

headline: Where Flamingos Fly
text: Featured at Art Basel Miami, the Art Video Lounge. (Courtesy of the artist, Galerie Michael Zink, München/ Berlin. Curated by Michael Darling.)

headline: What’s Boring Around 60th Street
text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: Are Hedge Funds Getting Unfairly Clipped?
text: With this week’s report that a hedge fund manager has set a new record for buying the most expensive co-op in New York, it is small wonder that people in that profession don’t get a lot of pity these days.

headline: Tesoro Adopted Poison Pill After Kerkorian Rejected a Deal
text: Independent western U.S. refiner Tesoro‘s board of directors adopted a poison pill after investor Kirk Kerkorian’s Trancida rejected a deal that would have limited Tracinda’s percentage of Tesoro’s shares, its chief executive, Bruce Smith, said on Wednesday.

headline: Are City Council Members Paid Enough?
text: New York City is one of the most expensive cities in the world and it is not uncommon for some of its residents to work more than one job to make ends meet – and for others to do it just to allow themselves some financial wiggle room.

headline: Barry Manilow and Penny Marshall
text: Barry Manilow and Penny Marshall sing the theme song, in a 1977 performance.

headline: Little Boat
text: Featured at Art Basel Miami, Art Video Lounge. (Courtesy of the artist and Tracey Lawrence Gallery, Vancouver. Curated by Michael Darling.)

headline: And Cuomo Said, Let There Be Light
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo today unveiled his long-awaited “Project Sunlight,” a new good-government tool that his office has been working on for the better part of the year.The project is a essentially a large database that knits together information on legislation, lobbyists, campaign donations, state contracts and charities in a single, very user-friendly Web site. Our first impression is that this will be an extraordinarily useful tool for examining the interplay between money, politics and power in New York.
Featured at Art Basel Miami, Art Video Lounge. (Courtesy of the artist and Jessica Bradley Art + Projects. Curated by Michael Darling.)

headline: Big and Noble, Loving and Murderous
text: At the New York premiere of “No Country for Old Men” — a big winner of the National Board of Review awards — the Baguette mentioned to Javier Bardem that Anthony Lane, reviewing the film in the New Yorker, wrote that he had the “biggest, noblest and most sculpted head of anyone in movies.”

headline: Never a Dull (Avery) Moment
text: Injured Rangers forward Sean Avery will not play when the Toronto Maple Leafs come to Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, which means: A) No worries about a brawl in warmups, B) Avery’s main agitation target, Darcy Tucker, should have a quieter night, C) earplugs will not be necessary for children sitting near the ice.

headline: Ackman Says Pershing Fund May Seek Listing
text: William A. Ackman is not afraid to make big bets and stick by them. For years, he has been wagering that bond insurer MBIA would implode. This summer, his $6 billion hedge-fund firm, Pershing Square Capital Management, plunked down $2 billion to buy a stake in Target.

headline: Why Wiseguys Like Cannoli
text: We’ve heard of Christmas trees made of potatos, chocolate and even butter cookies. But we weren’t quite sure why the publicists promoting the 10-foot-tall Christmas tree made of 3,000 cannolis that appeared on Mulberry Street described it as the “world’s largest cannoli Christmas tree.” Are there any others?

headline: Brian Burke Is About to Speak
text: The Ducks’ GM Brian Burke has scheduled a press conference before Anaheim’s home game against the Sabres tonight. Hmmm, wonder what that could be.

headline: Art Basel Miami | Artist Shorts
text: In conjunction with T’s art-themed holiday issue and our ongoing coverage of Art Basel Miami Beach, The Moment has curated short films by artists who will be showing at A.B.M.B.

headline: Videos That End When the Buzz Does
text: So, remember that surfing video that I wanted to play in an endless plasma loop, at fascist scale, in my dream of myself as a tan, bald studio-boss jerk who had a full-time employee to man my millions in high-def technology?

headline: The Height of Movie Hype, Starring bin Laden
text: The internet rumor mill won’t turn for just anything, and one of its latest products has several qualifications to its credit:

headline: Thomas H. Lee Partners Closes $8.1 Billion Fund
text: Thomas H. Lee Partners has closed its sixth and largest-ever fund at $8.1 billion, two people briefed on the firm’s plans told DealBook, amid the new credit landscape that is less hospitable to mega-deals like that for Clear Channel Communications.

text:
Journalist Glenn Kessler, left, and political scientist Daniel Drezner on the Bush administration's war for hearts and minds in the Muslim world.

headline: Huckabee
text: Some commenters wondered why I mentioned Wayne Dumond in a post about Huckabee.

headline: Schilling Joins McCain in New Hampshire
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Ted Williams and Iranian mullahs. Social Security and the possible trade of the left-handed ace Johan Santana. The spiraling cost of health care and Red Sox Manager Terry Francona’s “disgusting” habit of spitting.

headline: Slapping Down a Viral Smear
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign distanced itself today from an Iowa volunteer who forwarded an e-mail message falsely stating that Senator Barack Obama was Muslim and was running for president as a Manchurian candidate.

headline: No Time for Sleep or News
text: Maybe it isn’t so sweet to be this week’s news media sweetheart.

headline: Eastern Europe Embracing Golf
text: After years of banishment and disfavor, golf is rapidly taking root in Eastern Europe, according to the latest Golf Benchmark Study by KPMG, the consulting firm.

headline: Down Goes Huckabee
text: Mike Huckabee’s Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day: Which blogburst is worse for Huckabee, the newfound attention being paid to the case of Wayne Dumond –­ a convicted rapist who was freed during Huckabee’s tenure as Arkansas governor and who later was convicted of raping a Missouri woman –­ or the chatter over Huckabee’s admission, during an interview on Tuesday night, that he had yet to hear the news about the National Intelligence Estimate on Iran?

headline: The Comic Who Shook Italy
text: Stand-up comic turned blogger Beppe Grillo is building the first populist political movement seen in Italy for decades.

headline: Huckabee on Rapist and Murderer
text: This is an episode in the career of former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee that probably will not go away soon. It has all the markings of tabloidian detail that can haunt a candidate, a lawmaker, an elected official, who walks and stalks the halls of criminal justice, who has, as he has said, weighed decisions on whether to impose capital punishment, and has ordered death.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Born-Yesterday Candidates
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Dec. 6 column.

headline: Fans Have Spoken: Phil Hughes Stays With Yanks
text: The rule when following the Yankees is simple: They’re the Yankees, so anything is possible. But from all indications, the Yankees are out of the bidding for Johan Santana, and they seem happy to be forging ahead with their platoon of young pitchers intact.

headline: Rudolph Shows the Way for CBS
text: The Christmas classic “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer” led CBS to a Tuesday night victory in the ratings as the special delivered 14.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Old Havana Restored
text: Eusebio Leal Spengler, the official historian of Havana, has rebuilt and refurbished more than 300 landmark buildings in Old Havana.

headline: Getting a Taste of the Life of a Rock Star, Talent Not Required
text: Playing a sold-out gig in New York, my band attracted 2,000 new fans but earned only $15.

headline: Bristol-Myers to Cut 10% of Job Force
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb announced a major overhaul today that will eliminate about half of its 27 manufacturing sites worldwide and cut its work force of 43,000 employees by more than 10 percent, as the company adjusts to a business model that emphasizes specialty pharmaceuticals rather than big-market drugs.

headline: Patiently, Twins Size Up Santana Suitors
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 5  Johan Santana has not been told to begin shopping for a new place to live in Boston. That may never happen. Not in Boston, New York or anywhere. Santana is still a pitcher for the Minnesota Twins and is still the most-talked-about player available on the trade market.

headline: Ethanol Lobbyists Begin Drive to Use Richer Blend
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  With ethanol production threatening to grow faster than existing automobiles and service stations can absorb it, ethanol advocates began a push Wednesday to allow ordinary cars to run on blends of 20 or 30 percent ethanol, compared with 10 percent today.

headline: Iranian Leader Calls Report U.S. Confession of ‘Mistake’
text: TEHRAN, Dec. 5  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran said Wednesday that an American intelligence report’s conclusion that Iran was not currently developing a nuclear weapons program was a big victory for his country. He said the finding was a result of Iran’s resistance to international pressure over its nuclear program.

headline: Tiny Lioness Commands Many Millions
text: A 5,000-year-old Mesopotamian sculpture of a lioness standing only 3 1/4 inches high, above, sold at Sotheby’s in New York yesterday for $57.1 million, a record price for any sculpture at auction. Known as the Guennol Lioness, the limestone sculpture was part of a well-known collection formed by the New York collectors Alastair Bradley Martin and his wife, Edith Martin, and had been on loan to the Brooklyn Museum since 1948. Five bidders, three on telephones and two in the salesroom, competed for the work. The winner was standing in the back of the salesroom and said he was a British buyer who wished to remain anonymous.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Sensual Evolution
text: SHORTLY after 10 p.m. on Tuesday, while the designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana were holding court with Kate Hudson and Matthew McConaughey at a table on the rooftop of the Gramercy Park Hotel, the dermatologist Dr. Lisa Airan leaned over the model Jacquetta Wheeler at another table to say something to the socialite Lauren Davis, thereby inadvertently mooning the president’s daughter Barbara Bush, who was smoking a cigarette.

headline: Remember Toys?
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Chávez, Reflection and Anger After Defeat
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 5  President Hugo Chávez’s political movement, once considered largely above internal criticism here, is being consumed by recrimination and soul-searching after his proposal to transform Venezuela into a socialist state was rejected by voters over the weekend.

headline: 2009 Ski Guides
text: Updated: Winter 2008 - 2009

headline: Corrections
text: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the hedge fund manager William Ackman’s pursuit of MBIA Inc., a holding company whose main subsidiary is the nation’s largest bond insurer, misstated his forecast about the company’s financial health. Mr. Ackman predicted the company could be bankrupt by the second quarter of 2008, not by February. The article also referred incorrectly to the company’s liabilities. It has $80 million in annual debt service, not in corporate debt. (Go to Article)

headline: Medicare to Cut Payment for Two Promising Cancer Drugs
text: New Medicare rules for a small but promising class of cancer drugs may cause thousands of lymphoma patients to lose access to the treatment, which in some cases is the only therapy available to them.

headline: Charge That Tee on My Platinum
text: NEXT to the new Manhattan outlet of Billionaire Boys Club and Ice Cream is an antique store that is going out of business. “Lost our Lease!” and “Everything 60% Off!” is written in giant letters in almost every window.

headline: Elections Official Wants to Help Troops at War Vote
text: Phil V. Donahue, director of personnel at the New York City Board of Elections, is not a typical city bureaucrat. He has a wild mane of white hair and a long flowing beard, and rides his Harley-Davidson lowrider to work at the board’s downtown headquarters at 42 Broadway.

headline: A Roomful of Sound, Not Wires
text: WHEN Bradley Partridge bought a sleek flat-screen for the living room of his Atlanta home, he did not want the clutter of speakers hanging from the walls or the trouble of running wires around the room.

headline: Museum Leaders Named
text: Dorothy Kosinski, senior curator of painting and sculpture at the Dallas Museum of Art, has been appointed director of the Phillips Collection in Washington. In the spring she will succeed Jay Gates, whose retirement was announced in June. ... The former culture minister of Italy, Antonio Paolucci, an art historian and former superintendent of Florence’s museum system, has been named by Pope Benedict XVI to lead the Vatican museums, Agence France-Presse reported. He succeeds the archaeologist Francesco Buranelli, who will become inspector of the Pontifical Commission for Sacred Archaeology.

headline: Institute Named for ‘Sesame’ Creator
text: In their pioneering work with the preschool show “Sesame Street,” Joan Ganz Cooney and her colleagues created a much-copied model that made children’s television educational as well as entertaining. Today the program’s producer, Sesame Workshop, will unveil a nonprofit research and production institute named after Ms. Cooney that will try to inject educational standards into digital media for older children.

headline: Bush and Iran: A New Landscape
text: To the Editor:

headline: Suicide Blast Kills 13 in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 5  A suicide bomber smashed his car into a bus carrying Afghan Army personnel here in the capital early Wednesday, killing 13 people.

headline: Work With Me, Baby
text: FASHION is a stepchild, in photography no less than in other areas of the culture. The reach of the imagery it produces influences everything from trash television to presidential campaigns. Yet the slick work cranked out by the fashion machine is rarely taken seriously.

headline: Two More Schools to Close for Bad Performance
text: The Department of Education announced yesterday that it planned to close Far Rockaway High School in Queens and Public School 220 in the Bronx, weeks after both schools received poor marks under the city’s new school-grading system. P.S. 220, also known as the Mott Haven Village School, will shut its doors at the end of this school year, and Far Rockaway will stop accepting new students and be phased out over the next four years. The Mott Haven school has been plagued with problems for several years  in 2004, the city decided to restructure it by eliminating the middle school grades there. Both of the schools had already been on the state’s list of failing schools in danger of being shut down. Officials said they expect to announce within the next week up to 12 more schools to be closed.

headline: Tip of the Week: Managing Bookmarks and Passwords
text: If you use Firefox and want to keep your bookmarks, cookies and passwords the same across the different computers you use, there is a far easier way than periodically exporting and importing a file composed of your bookmarks. The free Google Browser Sync can keep all your machines up to date. You need a Google account or a Gmail address for it to work. Google has complete installation and setup instructions at www.google.com/tools/firefox/browsersync, along with a link to download the application.

headline: Battle Lines Drawn as Officer Is Arraigned in Killing
text: It took only about 10 minutes for Officer Rafael Lora of the New York City police to be arraigned yesterday on a charge that he illegally killed an unarmed man while investigating a car accident outside his home this spring.

headline: A Movie and Protesters Single Out Henry Kravis
text: Bells will be ringing, and carolers will be greeting the Upper East Side neighbors of Henry Kravis this morning.

headline: Justice Dept. Numbers Show Prison Trends
text: About one in every 31 adults in the United States was in prison, in jail or on supervised release at the end of last year, the Department of Justice reported yesterday.

headline: Evel Knievel Funeral set for Montana
text: Evel Knievel will go out in a burst of fireworks and a funeral officiated by the televangelist Robert H. Schuller at the Civic Center in Mr. Knievel’s hometown, Butte, Mont., The Associated Press reported. Family members said the fireworks on Sunday night would be followed by a public viewing and memorial service on Monday morning. “We’re throwing a funeral,” his son Kelly said. “It’s Evel Knievel.” After the service, Mr. Knievel’s body will be driven along Evel Knievel Way, a six-mile loop in Butte. A private burial is planned. Mr. Knievel was 69 when he died on Friday.

headline: B.C.S. = Bad. Choice. System.
text: After the season we just completed, only those people with a bcsfootball.org e-mail address can argue with a straight face that the postseason system in place for college football is even remotely acceptable. But let’s ignore the ridiculousness of trying to determine the two best teams for a moment; take a look at how the other B.C.S. games were chosen.

headline: Shares Rally on Surprisingly Strong Jobs Data
text: A promising employment report lifted stocks yesterday, with the main indexes erasing two days of declines on renewed optimism about the outlook for the economy. But the Federal Reserve may face a more complicated landscape as it considers its next move on interest rates.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill 3 Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM, Dec. 5  Israeli forces on Wednesday killed two members of Hamas and wounded four others as they prepared to fire a mortar into Israel, and killed at least one Palestinian security officer in Bethlehem after Israeli forces in civilian clothing were fired upon as they were attempted to carry out an arrest raid.

headline: An Expedition That Explores Freedom and Control
text: The kinetic, episodic music of the Dave Douglas Quintet has plenty of precedent in the broad expanse of post-bop. Increasingly, though, the group has been sending signals from its own coordinates. At the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night it brushed against facets of modal jazz, nascent fusion and polyphonic funk  on the surface an index of styles from the early 1970s  but the mood was neither allusive nor retro. Mr. Douglas, the trumpeter and composer, led what felt like an expedition.

headline: Marbury Thankful for Prayers and Support
text: Knicks guard Stephon Marbury was not with the team last night, remaining instead with his family to mourn the death of his father, Donald E. Marbury, who had a heart attack while watching his son play against Phoenix at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night.

headline: Updated Fire Code Is Offered to Mesh With Revised Building Rules
text: New York City fire officials have prepared a proposed updated fire code that reflects a number of recent emergencies in the first major revision of the document in nearly a century.

headline: House Panel Finds Conflicts in Executive Pay Consulting
text: Conflicts of interest are pervasive among executive compensation consultants, according to a Congressional investigation. Moreover, the inquiry found, consultants who do other work for companies while helping them devise executive pay recommended significantly higher pay packages than consultants who had no such additional relationships.

headline: Pushed Out of Baghdad, Insurgents Move North
text: MOSUL, Iraq, Dec. 5  Sunni insurgents pushed out of Baghdad and Anbar Provinces have migrated to this northern Iraqi city and have been trying to turn it into a major hub for their operations, according to American commanders.

headline: Revelation on Statement by Spitzer’s Ex-Aide Fuels Mistrust in Albany
text: ALBANY, Dec. 5  Senate Republicans charged on Wednesday that the Spitzer administration might have used a legal maneuver to make statements that top aides submitted to the attorney general’s office appear to be sworn affidavits when they were not.

headline: Super Favre
text: He’s 38 and graying, but that hasn’t stopped Brett Favre from having a resurgent season, playing his way into contention for the Most Valuable Player award. Besides Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, is there a quarterback in the N.F.L. whom you’d rather have leading your team in a big game? If so, whom?

headline: Don’t Dillydally, Darwin, It’s Survival of the Quickest
text: The origins of Darwin’s “Origin of Species” might not seem a promising subject for a stage play. But then who could have imagined that New York audiences would flock to a three-part epic about the history of Russian thought in the 19th century?

headline: Coles Is on a Mission to Be Ready for Sunday’s Game
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 5  On Nov. 4, Laveranues Coles was inactive against the Washington Redskins because of a concussion. The Jets lost.

headline: Crimes by Juveniles Rise, China Says
text: BEIJING, Dec. 5 (Agence France-Presse)  The number of juvenile criminals in China has more than doubled over the past decade, as broken homes and a decline in social values have spurred youth delinquency, according to an article in a state-run newspaper on Wednesday.

headline: Bhangra’s Ambassador, Keeping the Party Spinning
text: Most album-release parties don’t include a multicourse Indian dinner, served on tables set with linen and take-home centerpieces of cookies and betel-nut digestifs assembled partly by the musician herself. And most don’t involve shout-outs to Mom and Dad and aunties and uncles, let alone a moment when the whole family gets together on the club’s dance floor.

headline: Stamp to Honor Sinatra
text: Ol’ Blue Eyes will be traveling first class. Frank Sinatra (1915-98) will be commemorated with a first-class stamp to be issued in the spring by the United States Postal Service, The Associated Press reported. The plan was announced yesterday by Postmaster General John Potter, who called Sinatra an “extraordinary entertainer whose life and work left an indelible impression on American culture.” The image that will appear on the stamp is to be made public on Wednesday, Sinatra’s birthday, at a ceremony in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: C.I.A. Destroyed Tapes of Interrogations
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Central Intelligence Agency in 2005 destroyed at least two videotapes documenting the interrogation of two Al Qaeda operatives in the agency’s custody, a step it took in the midst of Congressional and legal scrutiny about the C.I.A’s secret detention program, according to current and former government officials.

headline: Rudolph Shows the Way for CBS
text: The Christmas classic “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer,” above, led CBS to a Tuesday night victory in the ratings as the special delivered 14.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although CBS remained No. 1 at 9 p.m. with a rerun of “NCIS” (11.6 million), at 10 the network fell to third place with “The Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show 2007” (7.4 million), which finished behind ABC’s “Boston Legal” (8.6 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (11.7 million). For the night, NBC tied CBS for first among adults 18 to 49, earning solid results in that demographic from “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10 (8.3 million). ABC finished fourth for the night behind Fox, which broadcast all repeats. On Monday, ABC slipped into third place since “Dancing With the Stars” ended. NBC led that night among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Queens: Two Killed in Highway Crash
text: Two teenagers died and three others were critically injured when their car struck a guard rail, became airborne for 100 feet and hit a concrete overpass pillar on a sharply curving exit ramp from the Van Wyck Expressway to the Nassau Expressway early yesterday, the police said. The car, a 2007 Dodge Charger, was being driven at a high rate of speed when the accident occurred at 12:45 a.m. near the northern border of Kennedy International Airport, investigators said. Two passengers, Devindra Harilall and Christopher Karan, both 18, were pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. Both lived in Ozone Park. A 17-year-old and two 19-year-olds, the other occupants of the car, were taken to the same hospital. The police declined to identify them, but said that they had life-threatening injuries.

headline: Union and Baseball Discuss Punishment in Drug Case
text: The possibility that players who received shipments of performance-enhancing substances will be disciplined by Major League Baseball moved forward yesterday when it was revealed that the commissioner’s office and players union officials were discussing a penalty for one of those players.

headline: A Guide to Clients
text: HOW is a stylist to gauge whether a client wants their cut with a side of gossip?

headline: Advisory Panel Rejects New Use for Cancer Drug
text: A federal advisory committee voted yesterday that Genentech’s drug Avastin should not be approved as a treatment for breast cancer.

headline: Recalling Iranian Hostage Crisis, Giuliani Invokes Reagan as a Model
Tebow May Break a Class Barrier
text: The finalists for the Heisman Trophy were announced yesterday, and the inclusion of the Florida sophomore quarterback Tim Tebow will be yet another opportunity to renew a very old argument. No freshman or sophomore has won the trophy, even though Heisman voters have been debating whether one should, with controversial results since the 1940s.

headline: Lottery Numbers
CIRCUITS: Headset Kills the Noise for Both Sides of the Conversation
text: It’s hard to use a mobile phone headset in noisy surroundings. Motorola’s new Bluetooth headset, the Motopure H12, uses noise-canceling technology to filter out background noise so the user can hear the person on the other end. It also works in the opposite direction, so the other caller does not hear all the background noise.

headline: Gunman at an Omaha Mall Kills 8 and Himself
text: OMAHA, Dec. 5  A gunman in camouflage and wielding a rifle opened fire on Wednesday in a department store at a mall here crowded with holiday shoppers, killing eight people and wounding five others, before turning the gun on himself.

headline: Pulpit Was the Springboard for Huckabee’s Rise
text: In August 1980, as the conservative Christian movement was first transforming American politics, Ronald Reagan stood before a Dallas stadium full of 15,000 foot-stomping, hand-clapping evangelicals and pledged his fealty to the Bible. “All the complex and horrendous questions confronting us at home and worldwide have their answer in that single book,” said Mr. Reagan, the Republican presidential nominee.

headline: A Memphis Freshman Needs No Orientation
text: In an instant six years ago, Reggie Rose realized his younger brother Derrick was not just another middle school basketball player.

headline: A Holiday Medley, Off Key
text: WHEN her sons were toddlers, Amy Manata, a Jewish woman with a Catholic husband, began conducting a silent war. In the months leading up to Hanukkah, she would ask the boys, now 4 and 6, which toys they wanted most, then bestow them at Hanukkah to ensure that it was a better holiday than Christmas.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Nov. 27 about a feud between two pioneering heart surgeons, Dr. Michael E. DeBakey and Dr. Denton A. Cooley, misstated the name of the medical school with which Dr. DeBakey has been affiliated. It is Baylor College of Medicine, not Baylor Medical College.

headline: Santana on Mets’ List, but So Far It’s All Talk
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 5  Early Wednesday, Mets Manager Willie Randolph baited the hook and cast the line. He spoke specifically of Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins, a left-handed starter and one of baseball’s best pitchers, who is on the trade market.

headline: A Tour of Russian Works, Led by the Locals
text: Valery Gergiev and his Kirov Orchestra, along with a planeload of choristers and soloists from the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, finished their short residency at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. Their three concerts, part of Mr. Gergiev’s Perspectives series, offered a selective tour of the Russian opera and ballet repertory. Mr. Gergiev is the go-to guy for this music today. He has drilled his orchestra to produce a tremendous range of both sound and expressivity, from exquisite beauty and polish to terrifying ferocity.

headline: Report Sees Danger in Delay on Kosovo
text: BELGRADE, Serbia, Thursday, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  The United Nations and European Union must guide Kosovo on a path to independence as soon as failed negotiations with Serbia officially end on Monday, an organization devoted to resolving conflicts said on Thursday.

headline: Latin May Die in Missouri
text: To the Editor:

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $2,569,692.73

headline: L.S.U.’S. Dorsey Wins Lombardi
text: Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey won the Lombardi Award as the nation’s top college lineman or linebacker last night, his third individual honor in three days.The 6-foot-2, 303-pound Dorsey won the Bronko Nagurski Award on Monday, given to the nation’s top defensive player. He was named the Southeastern Conference defensive player of the year earlier yesterday. Despite playing the last five games of the season with a sore right knee, Dorsey finished with 64 tackles, 6 sacks and 11 ½ tackles behind the line.

headline: Late-Night Hosts Calculate Their Losses
text: Few of the hosts of television’s late-night entertainment shows are turning up in their offices these days, because there’s nothing for them to do.

headline: Senate Passes Bill to Block Tax Increase
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 — Trying to find a way out of a sticky tax problem, the Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to prevent the alternative minimum tax from hitting millions of middle-class Americans without replacing the $50 billion that would be lost.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
text: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: Kings’ Riches in a Chelsea Domain
text: THERE are designers who proudly haunt thrift shops and tag sales, but Thomas Hays, an investment banker turned interior designer who has just redone a boutique hotel in Marrakesh, Morocco, is not one of them. High-toned antiques dealers and his own far-flung travels are the source of the treasures in his Chelsea penthouse, and if you’re curious about how much they put him back, Mr. Hays, a fellow who is clearly confident in his investment skills, doesn’t mind telling you.

headline: Retailers Post Gains, but They May Be Brief
text: Cold weather and deep discounts appear to have rescued retailers from what threatened to be a dreary November  but it may not be enough to save the entire holiday shopping season.

headline: Bristol-Myers to Eliminate 4,800 Jobs
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it would cut approximately 10 percent of its work force of 43,000 employees, continuing a year of pharmaceutical industry layoffs as drug makers adapt to a more competitive environment.

headline: An Effort to Tempt Macy’s From a Century-Old Home
text: Is New York ready for a Miracle on 33rd Street? The developers behind the long-gestating plan to rebuild Pennsylvania Station and redevelop the surrounding neighborhood are trying to lure Macy’s from its 105-year-old landmark building in Herald Square to a glass-enclosed mall that would sit inside the new train station, public officials and real estate executives said.

headline: Suppliers and Medicare
text: To the Editor:

headline: Under a New Watch, Miramax Still Homes in on Awards
text: The SoHo headquarters of Miramax, with its high ceilings, hardwood floors and a 15th-floor view of Midtown, is lovely, if unassuming. A satellite office of the previous, much larger Miramax, the place doesn’t exactly shout Hollywood, but rather whispers of the back-office functions it used to house.

headline: Management of Subways to Be Split
text: Since the subways were unified into one system decades ago, New Yorkers have come to think of them as part of a single, vast, often unwieldy whole.

headline: Lawyer Associated With Racing Association Is Subpoenaed
text: ALBANY, Dec. 5  A state investigations commission on Wednesday subpoenaed the lawyer who used to oversee New York’s horse racing association, as part of an inquiry that comes amid strained negotiations between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate over whether the association will continue to run the state’s thoroughbred franchise.

headline: Hey Spot, You’ve Got Mail
text: SOMETIMES I think Otto is a goat.

headline: For Now, Yanks Stick With Their Farm Plan
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 5  Hank Steinbrenner has not attended the winter meetings, but his voice is among the most powerful here. Absent from the Yankees’ media guide a year ago, he is now the final authority on matters related to the marquee team in the major leagues.

headline: Boy Scouts Lose Philadelphia Lease in Gay-Rights Fight
text: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4  For three years the Philadelphia council of the Boy Scouts of America held its ground. It resisted the city’s request to change its discriminatory policy toward gay people despite threats that if it did not do so, the city would evict the group from a municipal building where the Scouts have resided practically rent free since 1928.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Q. My rabbit’s foot fern has grown too large for its hanging pot. The rhizomes are draped all over the outside. How do I re-pot without destroying the plant? I live in zone 10 and the plant stays outdoors year round.

headline: Car Bombs Kill 22 as Gates Visits Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 5  Car bombs in Baghdad and three northern Iraqi cities killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 60 others on Wednesday, as Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived for an unannounced visit with senior Iraqi officials.

headline: Designer of the Year: (Name Here)
text: IF you are a designer, this is your year.

headline: A.M.D. Delays Energy-Efficient Chip Again
text: The energy-efficient chip that Advanced Micro Devices was counting to win customers away from Intel has been delayed again, the company said yesterday.

headline: NASA Delays Shuttle Launch
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 6  NASA officials delayed the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis for at least 24 hours today following problems with a pair of fuel sensors.

headline: A Watch Lets an Athlete Keep Track of a Workout and Control the Soundtrack
text: Athletes may have little control over things like the weather, the terrain, their energy levels. With the Timex iControl, they can at least control their music selection from their wrist.

headline: Police Shoot Woman After Chase in New Jersey
text: Patrol officers shot a woman after a car chase in New Jersey last night, the police said. She collided with a police car, kept on driving, spun out of control and tried to hit another squad car, they said.

headline: Gates Decides Against Marines’ Offer to Leave Iraq for Afghanistan
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 5  Senior Pentagon and military officials said Wednesday that Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates had decided against a proposal to shift Marine Corps forces from Iraq to take the lead in American operations in Afghanistan.

headline: Early Honors for No Country
text: The National Board of Review named “No Country for Old Men” its best picture yesterday as speculation season began shifting into the bestowing of actual awards. The board named Tim Burton best director for “Sweeney Todd.” In leading roles, George Clooney was cited for “Michael Clayton” and Julie Christie for “Away From Her.” Amy Ryan (“Gone Baby Gone”) and Casey Affleck (“The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford”) were honored for supporting roles, and Emile Hirsch (“Into the Wild”) and Ellen Page (“Juno”) were cited for breakthrough performances. “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly” was named best foreign film. The awards will be presented in a ceremony Jan. 15.

headline: A Rewoven Black Flag, Raised for a New Audience
text: The year’s oddest musical tribute belongs to Dirty Projectors, the Brooklyn band that brought its lapidary, wayward constructions to the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night. David Longstreth, the band’s leader, singer and guitarist, decided to reinvent from memory his favorite album as a teenager: Black Flag’s 1981 punk-rock manifesto, “Damaged.”

headline: I'm Not Really Running, I'm Not Really Running...
text: BILL MORGAN, an emeritus professor of kinesiology at the University of Wisconsin, likes to tell the story, which he swears is true, of an Ivy League pole vaulter who held the Division 1 record in the Eastern region.

headline: After Setbacks, Corzine Looks to Make Up for Lost Time
text: TRENTON, Dec. 5  Battered by a year of personal and political hardships, Gov. Jon S. Corzine is struggling to catch a second wind.

headline: Manhattan: New Steps in City’s Energy Plan
text: The city will start implementing 132 energy-conservation projects in the next several months  the first in a series of steps aimed at reducing city energy consumption and greenhouse gas emission by 30 percent by 2017, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The projects, at a cost of $67 million, include installing energy-saving light bulbs and lamps in schools, police precincts and other municipal buildings and at landmarks including City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge. The city will also upgrade the laundry system at Rikers Island to allow hot water to be filtered and reused, and will replace 200 of the most polluting vehicles in its 27,000-vehicle fleet with hybrid cars. Municipal government accounts for 6.5 percent of the city’s total energy usage and 10 percent of its peak electricity demand.

headline: E.P.A. Is Prodded to Require Cuts in Airliner Emissions
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Five states, New York City and several environmental groups filed petitions with the Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday in an effort to force cuts in emissions of heat-trapping gases from airliners, a rapidly growing source.

headline: Manhattan: Cyclist Killed in Accident
text: A bicyclist riding northbound on the Avenue of the Americas yesterday morning died after he struck an open car door, fell off his bicycle and landed in the street, where he was hit by a truck, the police said. The cyclist, David Smith, 63, of West Ninth Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. The accident happened shortly before 8:30 a.m. in front of 989 Avenue of the Americas, near 36th Street, the police said. Mr. Smith, who was riding in a designated bicycle lane, hit the car’s door after someone on the passenger side opened it into his path, the police said. It was unclear if he was wearing a helmet. The police issued two summonses to the car’s driver, Benjamin Siano, 52, of Staten Island, for parking at a fire hydrant and for blocking a bicycle lane. They also issued a summons to his passenger, Augustus Browne, 31, of Staten Island, for opening a door unsafely into traffic, the police said.

headline: The President’s Cynical Budget War
text: President Bush’s lame-duck attempt to repair the Republican Party’s threadbare fiscal reputation is an increasingly reckless game. In the latest exercise of irresponsibility for political gain, Mr. Bush reportedly wants to slash counterterrorism funding for front-line police and firefighters.

headline: Diner Opens in Catskills After a Hell’s Kitchen Worth of Trouble
text: LIBERTY, N.Y.

headline: Meat Processors Look for Ways to Keep Ground Beef Safe
text: LEXINGTON, Neb.  In the last decade, Tyson Fresh Meats has transformed its slaughterhouse here to combat a potentially deadly type of food poisoning, adding huge chambers to scald carcasses and wash them in acid, steam vacuums to suck away microbes and elaborate gear to test hundreds of meat samples a day.

headline: Bolivia to Vote on Leader’s Job
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 5 (Reuters)  President Evo Morales of Bolivia on Wednesday called for a nationwide referendum to decide whether he should stay in office as a way to resolve a deepening political crisis in the country.

headline: Victims Urge Cluster-Bomb Ban
text: VIENNA, Dec. 5 (AP)  Victims of cluster bombs, many of whom had lost limbs, on Wednesday urged participants at an international conference to ban the weapons.

headline: Post Office Drawback Cited in Dark Forecast for Netflix
text: When Netflix’s seven million subscribers send their DVDs back to one of the rental service’s 47 distribution centers, the discs do not represent many happy returns for the Postal Service.

headline: At Port Authority, Getting a Charge, at No Charge
text: The Port Authority Bus Terminal is all about lines. Lines of people waiting to buy tickets or waiting for their buses. Lines of buses waiting to leave or pull in. Then, there is another type of line  an electrical line.

headline: In Iran We Trust?
text: Washington

headline: Defense Challenges Status of Guantánamo Detainee
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba, Dec. 5  Challenging one of the central pillars of the Bush administration’s detention policies, lawyers for a detainee who is charged as Osama bin Laden’s driver argued here Wednesday that he should be treated as a prisoner of war and should not be tried by military commission.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,874 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: Baseball Suspends 2 Over Banned Substances
text: Major League Baseball announced today that two players linked to shipments of banned substances had been suspended for 15 days, a template that will likely be used after George J. Mitchell’s report on performance-enhancing drugs is released. Those findings might be released late next week.The players  Jay Gibbons of the Baltimore Orioles and Jose Guillen, who played for the Seattle Mariners last season and has now joined the Kansas City Royals  were both suspended at the start of next season.

headline: Reyes Is Back Home, and Not Going Anywhere
text: PALMAR ARRIBA, Dominican Republic, Dec. 4  Drive along the dusty, pothole-filled road, careful not to strike the roosters or stray dogs, until it dead-ends beside a stone staircase. Run up the steps, climb over the aqua-colored fence  or, for the less adventurous, slip through an open gate  and behold a field littered with avocado-size rocks and teeming with about 60 boys of all ages, many holding balls or gloves.
