headline: A Straight-Ahead Rock ’n’ Roll Juggernaut: Are Y’all Having Fun Yet?
text: He stood onstage, bald and be-sideburned, facing a couple of thousand fans who seemed more pleased than thrilled to be there. He sang, he grimaced, he strummed a guitar, he sang some more. He angled for more applause. He pointed to one section of the crowd and asked, “Y’all having fun?” Yeah, pretty much. To another section: “Y’all having fun?” Sure they were.

headline: A Tough Night for a Bernstein Baton
text: In the tradition-rich world of classical music, it was fitting that Gustavo Dudamel, the latest young lion of conducting, got to use one of Leonard Bernstein’s batons in leading the New York Philharmonic as a guest conductor this week. Too bad for the baton. It broke shortly before the end of Tuesday’s performance, said Barbara Haws, the orchestra’s historian. Ms. Haws, who had lent Mr. Dudamel the baton, right, said the broken tip was retrieved and two pieces were returned. She said she would reattach them. “It’s now taken on a new dimension, this little baton has,” she said.

headline: Germany: Berlin to Get Giant Ferris Wheel
text: Berlin officials broke ground this week for the construction of the Great Berlin Wheel, a 600-feet Ferris wheel that will top the London Eye by more than 160 feet to become the largest in Europe. It will be near the Berlin Zoo, on the western edge of Tiergarten Park. When it opens in about two years, it will have 36 air-conditioned cars, each capable of carrying 40 passengers. A ride around the wheel will take 35 minutes.

headline: 10 Charged With Smuggling $200 Million in Fake Goods
text: Federal officials announced the arrests yesterday of 10 people they said were members of an international smuggling gang that illegally shipped millions of dollars’ worth of counterfeit apparel into the New York region from factories in China, often in falsely labeled shipping containers.

headline: Knife at Taylor’s House Links Accused to Earlier Break In
text: MIAMI, Dec. 5  At least two of the four men charged with the murder of the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor were involved in a burglary of his Miami-area home eight days before his shooting death, a law enforcement official and a lawyer involved in the case said Wednesday.

headline: Born-Yesterday Candidates
text: The presidential campaign is sure getting hot. Mike Huckabee is inching ahead of Mitt Romney in Iowa, precipitating a fascinating national debate about whether Mormons or Baptists love Jesus more. Meanwhile, on the Democratic side, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama are engaged in a battle over who has wanted to be president longer — or rather, less long.

headline: A Coach’s Tough Start at Duke, With an Eye Toward the Finish
text: DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 5 — A shift in the hierarchy of women’s college basketball came suddenly and unexpectedly March 24, the day top-seeded Duke was stunned in the N.C.A.A. tournament by an upstart Rutgers team that was not supposed to sidetrack the Blue Devils’ ordained run to the national championship.

headline: Footnotes
text: The British government has granted $101 million toward a $435 million extension of the Tate Modern in London, the BBC reported. Designed by the Swiss architects Herzog & de Meuron, the 11-floor structure may open in time for the 2012 Olympics. ... Matthew Bucksbaum, a real estate magnate, and his wife, Kay, have donated $25 million to the Aspen Music Festival and School. The money will help establish a new 23-acre campus named after them, the festival said. It is the festival’s largest gift. ... Stephen Hough has been named the winner of the $50,000 Jean Gimbel Lane Prize in Piano Performance. The award, given every two years by the Northwestern University School of Music, was established in 2005. Mr. Hough was a recipient of a MacArthur Fellowship in 2001.

headline: CIRCUITS: A Fashion-Conscious Smartphone, Cloaked in a Mirror
text: Many cellphones feature high-resolution cameras, powerful processors and full keyboards. This one offers a screen that turns into a mirror, essentially making the pocket compact obsolete.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about an advisers’ report critical of the Food and Drug Administration misstated the date that the report was made public. It was posted on the agency’s Web site last Thursday, not on Friday.

headline: Apologetic, Facebook Changes Ad Program
text: Mark Zuckerberg, founder and chief executive of the social networking site Facebook, apologized to the site’s users yesterday about the way it introduced a controversial new advertising feature last month.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Building Sensors

headline: 8 Victims in Omaha Shooting Are Identified
text: Police Chief Thomas Warren of Omaha identified the eight people who were killed in a shooting spree at a shopping mall on Wednesday. They included five women and three men who ranged in age from 24 to 66 years old. Six of the victims were employees of the Von Maur department store and two were customers:

headline: Turning Kitchens Into Laboratories to Find Treats for the Allergy-Prone
text: Lori Sandler traces the start of her company to the day in 1999 that her son Benjamin celebrated his first birthday.

headline: As Death Hit His Family, Responsibilities Grew
text: When he is at church, Kenneth Williams fills his soul by singing gospel. When he is at home, dancing with his children, Kenyetta Kathleen Reaves, 16, and Lamont Ali Reaves, 17, and his brother, Russell, 37, lifts his spirits. Recently, at a friend’s house, he also discovered that rap could relieve his stress.

headline: Bush Announces Mortgage Agreement
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  President Bush announced an agreement with the mortgage industry today to freeze interest rates for up to five years for some of the two million homeowners who bought houses recently with subprime loans.

headline: Tracing Business Acumen to Dyslexia
text: It has long been known that dyslexics are drawn to running their own businesses, where they can get around their weaknesses in reading and writing and play on their strengths. But a new study of entrepreneurs in the United States suggests that dyslexia is much more common among small-business owners than even the experts had thought.

headline: Fordham Opens Its Gift: An Antiquities Museum
text: For some four decades, William D. Walsh browsed auction catalogs in search of the ancient artifacts that would gratify his passion for classical antiquity.

headline: Guide to Student Loans
text: A college education may be the most important investment in a child's life and has become one of the most costly, too. The publicly reported tuition charged by private colleges and universities for the 2007-2008 can reach $50,000 a year. The trends are alarming, too. And while tuition at public universities is generally lower, costs there have been growing even more steeply in recent years as government support has lagged.

headline: Has-Beens From Olympus Downgraded to Mortals
text: A tree meets a dog walker at the start of “Gods Behaving Badly,” Marie Phillips’s flossy, high-concept comic novel. “I’m Kate,” the tree says. “I work in mergers and acquisitions for Goldman Sachs.” And then: “Could you dial my boss’s number and hold the phone to my trunk?”

headline: Carlos Valdés, a Conga King of Jazz, Dies at 81
text: Carlos Valdés, better known as Patato, whose melodic conga playing made him a giant of Latin jazz in Cuba and then for more than half a century in America, died on Tuesday in Cleveland. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Smoothing Out Web Video
text: Q. How can I make streaming video from Web sites play more smoothly, without all the starting, stopping and stuttering?

headline: Knicks Persevere for Marbury
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 5  Misfortune of varying degrees forced the Knicks to revamp their starting lineup and their mind-set, and to push aside several days worth of tough emotions Wednesday. The evening ended with their first good feelings of the week.

headline: A Bundle of Joy Isn’t Enough?
text: WHEN Jena Slosberg of Bedford, N.H., gave birth in March, she endured a labor that lasted 17 hours. But her discomfort was ultimately worth it, quite apart from the arrival of her daughter, Marin. In the recovery room, her husband, Paul, presented her with a pair of diamond earrings.

headline: A Highly Visible Reminder of Your Houseplant’s Needs
text: This season, gifts are going green, so the Thirsty Light fits right in. Actually, this digital plant monitor, available from www.thirstylight.com, is colored green to blend in with your favorite houseplant’s leaves. If you neglect the plant, this $9.95 device berates you by blinking.

headline: Old Havana Gets a Lift, but Cubans Don’t Benefit
text: HAVANA  These days, when Eusebio Leal Spengler walks the streets of Old Havana, people treat him like a rock star. Ladies kiss him on the cheek and whisper that they love him. Children point at him.

headline: Britain Cuts Rates; European Bank Stands Pat
text: FRANKFURT, Dec. 6  The European Central Bank, caught between fears of rising inflation and subsiding economic growth, walked a middle ground today, leaving interest rates unchanged.

headline: Jefferson DeBlanc, Hero Pilot, Dies at 86
text: Jefferson J. DeBlanc, a World War II fighter pilot who was awarded the Medal of Honor for shooting down five Japanese planes on a single day while running out of fuel, died Nov. 22 in Lafayette, La. He was 86 and lived St. Martinville, La..

headline: Reactor Shutdown Causing Medical Isotope Shortage
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 5  Medical treatments are being delayed or deferred at hospitals worldwide because of the extended shutdown of a Canadian reactor.

headline: Bush Writes to North Korean Leader
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 — President Bush, directly engaging the man he publicly called a “tyrant” and privately called a “pygmy,” wrote a letter to the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il in which he held out the prospect of normalized relations with the United States if North Korea fully disclosed all nuclear programs and got rid of its nuclear weapons, administration officials said.

headline: Opposition Candidate Cleared in Time for Korean Vote
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 5  South Korean prosecutors cleared the main opposition party’s presidential candidate of stock manipulation charges on Wednesday, an outcome expected to increase his already high chances of restoring a conservative government to power.

headline: Greece and Macedonia to Restart Talks on Name
text: ATHENS, Dec. 5  Greece and Macedonia on Wednesday agreed to hold a new round of talks on a festering dispute over Macedonia’s name that threatens to undercut its chances of joining NATO.

headline: A Dead Man Has Some Explaining to Do
text: LONDON, Dec. 5  John Darwin was declared dead some four and a half years ago, so it was a surprise when he walked into a police station here on Saturday, claiming to have no idea what he had been doing all this time.

headline: Springtime, Wrapped and Beribboned
text: I SAY this every year, and I’ll say it again: Don’t give cute presents to your gardening friends. Avoid stones engraved with the words Love or Peace. Instead, think about what’s practical. A Shaker basket my sister, Martha, gave me is not only one of my favorites, but every time I carry it to the garden and fill it with cut flowers or fresh greens, I think of her.

headline: Pessimism Is Growing in Executive Suites
text: The chiefs are getting worried.

headline: Lenders Agree to Freeze Rates on Some Loans
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 — The Bush administration reached an agreement with the mortgage industry on Wednesday on a plan to freeze interest rates for up to five years for a portion of the two million homeowners who bought houses in the last few years with subprime loans.

headline: China Resisting Pressure on Product Safety
text: BEIJING, Dec. 6  After pressing China for a new effort to police the safety of its food and other exports, the Bush administration is finding Chinese leaders pushing back, with demands for American commitments to insure the safety of American food and goods, administration officials say.

headline: The Perks of a Faster Phone
text: Q. What is the advantage of a “3G” phone?

headline: Cecil Payne, Baritone Saxophonist, Dies at 84
text: Cecil Payne, who in the 1940s was one of the first baritone saxophonists to master the intricacies of modern jazz and who for more than half a century was a leading exponent of his instrument, died Nov. 27 in Stratford, N.J. He was 84.

headline: Official Urges Arrest of 2 Darfur Suspects
text: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 5  The lead prosecutor of the International Criminal Court urged the Security Council on Wednesday to put pressure on Sudan to arrest and surrender two men indicted by the tribunal last spring for war crimes in Darfur.

headline: Straight A’s, With a Burger as a Prize
text: FAST-FOOD chains often post nutritional report cards about their product ingredients on restaurant walls. Now one is using children’s report cards to help stimulate sales.

headline: A Souped-Up Wireless Connection for Faster Web Browsing
text: Most jaded Wi-Fi users have moved beyond being awestruck that wireless networking works at all and have started complaining about the times when it fails to deliver a dependable connection. HField technologies (www.hfield.com) is going after this problem with Wi-Fire, a $79 antenna that connects to a U.S.B. port on either a Mac or Windows computer (XP and Vista).

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: China Cracks Down on Food Safety Violators
text: SHANGHAI, Dec. 6  China said today that it had demolished the facilities of more than 2,800 rural food makers as part of its effort to crack down on shoddy, fake or substandard food, according to the official Xinhua news agency.

headline: Pakistan: Judges Involuntarily Retired
text: The government formally retired 37 judges who opposed President Pervez Musharraf’s imposition of emergency in the country last month and refused to take a new oath of allegiance to him. They were 24 High Court judges and 13 Supreme Court justices, including the ousted chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry. They will be denied pensions and other benefits, according to local reports. The forced retirements are expected to further shake up opposition parties, as well as rights groups that have been campaigning for an independent judiciary.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day last Thursday about the settlement of class-action lawsuits involving the Ford Explorer misstated the extent of the settlement. The agreement ends lawsuits brought by Explorer owners who said their vehicles had lost value because of the perceived hazard of rollovers. It does not end pending personal injury and wrongful death lawsuits stemming from Explorer rollovers.

headline: House Boosts Fuel Economy Standards
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The House, brushing aside a veto threat from the White House, today passed a package of energy measures that includes a 40 percent increase in fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the United States.

headline: Sleek Lines and Fat Cigars (if You Got ’Em)
text: Pedro Ruiz’s “Club Havana” has become a signature work for Ballet Hispanico, and on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater it was easy to see why. Hot and cool, the ballet takes Latin ballroom dances brought to the United States since the 1920s and artfully sews them together in choreography that could be performed only by classically trained dancers.

headline: In Sonata Finale, Tension Gives Way to Introspection
text: In the landmark 1971 book “The Classical Style,” Charles Rosen wrote that Beethoven’s “Kreutzer” Sonata (Op. 47) “has a first movement unequaled in formal clarity, grandeur and dramatic force by anything that Beethoven had yet written.”

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How do I replace the built-in metal hamper in my 1950s bathroom?

headline: Other Mind Games
text: “No matter how high you jump, how fast you run or swim, how powerfully you row, you can do better,” Gina Kolata writes today in The Times. “But sometimes your mind gets in the way.” Since most people can do better, no matter how good their performance, the challenge is to find a safe way to push a little harder.

headline: Everton Advances
text: Everton, Atletico Madrid, Villarreal, Hamburger SV and FC Basel won yesterday to advance to the UEFA Cup’s Round of 32. Everton became the first English club to advance past the group stage when Tim Cahill scored in the 85th minute for a 1-0 victory over Zenit St. Petersburg.

headline: Tax Stalemate Threatens Chaos as Filing Nears
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  President Bush and lawmakers of both parties are finally in full agreement on something. All proclaim that middle-class taxpayers should be spared a surprise bill in the coming months posed by the alternative minimum tax.

headline: ‘Noel’ Rings Up Sales
text: Josh Groban’s album “Noël” (Reprise) held onto the top spot on the Billboard 200 chart for a second consecutive week with sales of 539,000 copies, compared with the 405,000 it tallied last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. If Mr. Groban’s sales were increased by a recent appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” an appearance on “60 Minutes” may have helped elevate the Eagles’ “Long Road Out of Eden” to second place from fifth, with sales of 313,000 copies. The Alicia Keys album “As I Am” (J) slid into third place, with 257,000 copies sold, followed by the compilation “Now That’s What I Call Music” Vol. 26 (127,000 copies) and Garth Brooks’s “Ultimate Hits” (Pearl), with 112,000 copies sold.

headline: Coke Names an Insider as Its New Chief
text: For Coca-Cola’s heir apparent, the time has come.

headline: Robert O. Anderson, Oil Executive, Dies at 90
text: Robert O. Anderson, an oilman whose Stetson-size accomplishments included building Atlantic Richfield into an industry giant; discovering oil in Alaska; becoming America’s largest rancher, and giving generously to environmental causes, died on Sunday at his home in Roswell, N.M. He was 90.

headline: Teenage Birth Rate Rises for First Time Since ’91
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  The birth rate among teenagers 15 to 19 in the United States rose 3 percent in 2006, according to a report issued Wednesday, the first such increase since 1991. The finding surprised scholars and fueled a debate about whether the Bush administration’s abstinence-only sexual education efforts are working.

headline: Details in Military Notes Led to Shift on Iran, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  American intelligence agencies reversed their view about the status of Iran’s nuclear weapons program after they obtained notes last summer from the deliberations of Iranian military officials involved in the weapons development program, senior intelligence and government officials said on Wednesday.

headline: There’s Sunlight in Albany?
text: So seldom is there good news out of New York’s state capital that when something like the new Project Sunlight Web site emerges, the instinct is to wonder how soon before the forces of darkness will try to kill it. Until they do, the new site from Attorney General Andrew Cuomo’s office gives ordinary New Yorkers the ability to see information about their state that should have been easily accessible in the first place.

headline: Task Force on N.Y. Flight Delays Issues Report
text: Trying to head off threats by the federal government to reduce flights at the three New York airports, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, along with airline industry executives and local transportation officials, unveiled 100 recommendations today that are meant to unlock congestion at the airports and allow them to handle more traffic.

headline: Arrest in Nightclub Killing
text: A Brooklyn man has been arrested in connection with the killing of a nightclub patron in Manhattan two weeks ago, the police said yesterday. The man, Anthony Taylor, 26, of 141 East 21st Street, in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday in Atlanta and will be returned to New York, investigators said. The fatal attack, on Nov. 23, occurred about closing time at Duvet, a bar and club at 45 West 21st Street, in the Flatiron district. The victim, Shamel G. McKinney, 25, of Brooklyn, was stabbed once in the chest. A knife was recovered in a nearby trash bin, but investigators have not said whether it was the weapon used in the killing. They also have not commented on a motive.

headline: OPEC Finds Price Range to Live With
text: When oil prices were approaching the milestone of $100 a barrel a few weeks ago, OPEC, the global oil cartel, expanded production and sought to jawbone prices down. In January, when prices were near $50 and falling, OPEC cut supplies to stem the decline.

headline: Inter Milan and Ac Roma Win Easily
text: Inter Milan and AS Roma posted comfortable victories to extend their lead atop the Italian league. Inter beat Lazio, 3-0, with a penalty kick from Zlatan Ibrahimovic and goals from Maicon and David Suazo. The Brazilian midfielder Rodrigo Taddei scored twice as Roma beat Cagliari, 2-0.

headline: Knuckle Sandwich on a Baguette
text: TIME was, only wiseguys threatened to serve you up a colorful meal: a mitt blintz, a handburger, a filet-o-fist. And back then, women’s jewelry was finely wrought to telegraph femininity. Post-Xena, of course, the rules for jewels changed. Now rings with the structure (and punch) of brass knuckles are giving the old diamond solitaire a poke in the eye.

headline: 10-Trick Deal Yields an 11th for Champs
text: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, the premier event of the Fall North American Championships in San Francisco, ended Sunday in victory for Jimmy Cayne of New York; Michael Seamon of Hollywood, Fla.; and four Italians: Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace.

headline: Two Teams Have a Lot Hanging Over Their Heads
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Your Hairdressers Know, but They’re Not Talking
text: “I’M not in a position to give you advice on that,” Mario Russo will say when one of the clients at his hair salon in Boston complains about her children. Or if a client disparages her ex-husband, he’ll say, “That’s a matter that needs to be discussed with a different professional than myself.” Then he’ll ask what styling products she uses.

headline: Forest Loss in Sumatra Becomes a Global Issue
text: KUALA CENAKU, Indonesia, Dec. 1  Here on the island of Sumatra, about 1,200 miles from the global climate talks under way on Bali, are some of the world’s fastest-disappearing forests.

headline: Many Shades of Gray Encircle the Black-and-Blue Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 5  The list of injured players is growing as the season is shrinking, and part of the Giants’ game planning in the coming weeks will include finding a balance between chasing regular-season victories and getting the team healthier for the playoffs.

headline: French Star in Downhill Announces Retirement
text: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 5  Haunted by the memory of a violent accident in a race early last year, the 2006 Olympic men’s downhill champion, Antoine Dénériaz of France, announced his retirement from skiing Wednesday.

headline: Coming Over the Bighorn Mountains in a Saturday Storm
text: Bighorn Mountains, Wyo.

headline: If the Copy Is an Artwork, Then What’s the Original?
text: Since the late 1970s, when Richard Prince became known as a pioneer of appropriation art — photographing other photographs, usually from magazine ads, then enlarging and exhibiting them in galleries — the question has always hovered just outside the frames: What do the photographers who took the original pictures think of these pictures of their pictures, apotheosized into art but without their names anywhere in sight?

headline: Details of Omaha Shooting Emerge
text: OMAHA, Dec. 6 A video surveillance camera at the Westroads Mall here showed that Robert Hawkins entered the main entrance of the Von Maur department store Wednesday afternoon, looked around briefly and then left, before entering the store again six minutes later, carrying what was later learned to be a rifle.

headline: Senate Panel Passes Bill to Limit Greenhouse Gases
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  A Senate committee approved a broad bill on Wednesday night to address climate change, a major step toward passage of a measure that would for the first time slow and then reverse emissions of the gases that scientists blame for the warming of the planet.

headline: Spitzer Official Gets a New Post
text: ALBANY, Dec. 5  Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced on Wednesday that his top budget official would move to a key post overseeing New York’s myriad agencies and departments.

headline: Dreams (and Instruments) of a Visionary Tinkerer
text: Almost every composer is part inventor. But Harry Partch, the eclectic, visionary and self-taught California-born composer who died at 73 in 1974, was primarily an inventor, in the most creative sense of the term.

headline: Bears at Redskins
text: Bears at Redskins

headline: Democracy in the Americas
text: CARACAS, Venezuela

headline: Justices to Answer Detainee Rights Question
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  When it comes to the rights of the detainees at Guantánamo Bay, the Supreme Court, and not the president or Congress, will have the last word.

headline: Dangerous, Unfinished Business
text: During the 1990s, the Balkans were the scene of Europe’s deadliest wars and worst atrocities since World War II. More recently, the region has been relatively peaceful, but many of its problems have merely been kicked down the road. Now, one of the most dangerous is coming to a head, with a United Nations deadline on Monday for resolving Kosovo’s political status.

headline: Liking Clinton, but Acting Like Huckabee
text: TRENTON, Dec. 5  Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to go to Iowa on Thursday to campaign for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, but when it comes to governing he is actually following a path blazed by another presidential candidate who lived in the Arkansas governor’s mansion: former Gov. Mike Huckabee.

headline: Beethoven on a Budget
text: The music started in an adult education class not long after World War II, with veterans and survivors seeking to lose themselves in Mozart and Beethoven.

headline: Crucial Test for Romney in Speech on His Religion
text: Mitt Romney’s planned speech today at the George Bush Presidential Library in Texas to confront suspicions about his Mormon faith is being viewed as the biggest moment of his presidential campaign.

headline: Lifting More Than Weight
text: There may be good news for the indolent as well as the fit in the latest research on exercise and the brain. A new study from Yale University suggests that physical activity encourages the brain’s neural pathways to work more efficiently — benefits that one day may come from the contents of a bottle.

headline: Looking Beyond Megapixels
text: You may have your holiday traditions: caroling, stockings, candles, whatever. But here at The New York Times Institute of Gadgetology, we have a tradition of our own. Every December since 2001, we’ve asked: “How much digital camera can you get for $300?”

headline: Contests for Consumers to Create Ads ‘March’ On
text: The next commercial you see for the March of Dimes may have been created by a viewer rather than an advertising agency.

headline: Past, Present and Future Troubles?
text: Marc Crawford’s Los Angeles Kings are unwatchable, injuries are mounting and the goaltending situation remains lost in a black hole that was created back in the 1990s when Kelly Hrudey left Southern California after the 1995-96 season.

headline: Neediest Cases: A Life After Addiction
text: A former drug addict, Florent Mathurin scrambles to keep the life he built.

headline: Text: E-Mail From Dow Jones Chief Executive
text: The following is the text of an e-mail from Richard Zannino, chief executive of Dow Jones:

headline: The Woof-Wide Wrestling Federation?
text: Hmmm … a post-prison business opportunity for Michael Vick?From K9 Magazine in Britain:

headline: Young Sanjaya and Pals Go Caroling
What Did You Do in the War, Henry?
text: My third-floor study here in Washington looks out toward the old Naval Observatory a few blocks away. The Vice President currently lives inside the gates of the new Observatory — an 1890s improvement that took the astronomers to higher ground. This older one sprang from the vision of John Quincy Adams, who called for it in his 1825 State of the Union message. It wasn’t his fault that the choice of a site — a malarial patch of land so often fogged over that the astronomers couldn’t see anything — fell to one of his successors, John Tyler, more than fifteen years later.

headline: Mississippi Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
text: A lawyer has pleaded guilty to conspiracy to bribe a judge and is assisting federal prosecutors in a case involving one of the nation’s wealthiest trial lawyers, according to court documents.

headline: What the Gen Y Worker Wants
text: When I finished law school in the recession of 1991, jobs were scarce. I didn’t have a job upon graduation and that was fairly common. Young people entering the job market today face a far more welcoming workplace. And as increasing numbers of baby boomers retire, the newest members of the work force will have even more choices. This anticipated shortage of skilled labor has been called the “war for talent,” and even if there is some dispute as to its grounding in fact, employers are behaving as if it’s real. Last week one of the most e-mailed articles on The New York Times Web site was about a law firm employing a “happiness consultant” to make sure that everyone was feeling properly fulfilled. I expect to see more of this type of thing.

headline: Former Brocade Executive Convicted of Options Fraud
text: A federal jury on Wednesday convicted Stephanie Jensen, the former personnel director of Brocade Communications Systems, on charges of conspiracy and falsifying records.

headline: Air France Bids for Alitalia
text: Air France-KLM Group, the world’s biggest airline, said it will offer to buy Alitalia and revive the unprofitable carrier that the Italian government has been trying to sell for a year.

headline: V.C.s Inject CardioMEMs With $33 Million
text: Wireless heart monitor developer CardioMEMS raised $33 million in a Series E financing to expand sales of an approved product for aneurysm patients and complete regulatory development and launch sales of a product for the larger heart failure market.

headline: FilmBankers Raises $200 Million for Indie Movies
text: FilmBankers International of Beverly Hills, Calif., is raising a $200 million private equity fund to invest directly in U.S. independent films.

headline: Judge Approves Dana Bankrutpcy Financing
text: Dana‘s hopes of an early 2008 emergence from bankruptcy were boosted Wednesday when a New York judge approved the auto parts maker’s $2 billion exit financing package.

headline: TPG to Take $270 Milion Stake in Japan’s NIS, Report Says
text: TPG, the U.S. buyout fund, may announce its biggest Japan acquisition as early as this week, investing 30 billion yen ($270 million) in lender NIS Group, Bloomberg News said.

headline: NetSuite Eyes $114 Million I.P.O.
text: Most technology companies do not dare to go public in late December, when the market for initial public offerings is usually as chilly as the weather.

headline: DundeeWealth Shares Rise on Merger Speculation
text: DundeeWealth surged 6.7 percent on speculation that Bank of Nova Scotia may buy the Canadian money manager to expand its mutual-fund business.

headline: Investors Flock to China Shipping I.P.O., Report Says
text: China Shipping Container Lines, the second-largest in Asia, attracted 2.6 trillion yuan ($351 billion) worth of orders for a stock sale, 170 times the amount available, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Chrysler to Lose $1.6 Billion This Year, Reports Say
text: It looks like Cerberus Capital Management, which bought a $7.4 bilion controlling stake in Chrysler in August, won’t be able to able stop the the bleeding just yet at the ailing carmaker.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland to Take $3 Billion Write-down
text: The effects of the mortgage market meltdown were in stark relief Thursday when Royal Bank of Scotland, announcing a 1.5 billion pound ($3 billion) writedown, saw its shares rise as investors expressed relief that the bank’s situation wasn’t worse.

headline: A J.F.K. Comparison for Obama That Is Not a Compliment
text: With the new National Intelligence Estimate this week coming to the surprising conclusion that Iran dropped its efforts to make a nuclear weapon in 2003, Hillary Rodham Clinton turned to an old friend on Wednesday to help boost her foreign policy credentials.

headline: Baostell Chief Said to Deny Rio Tinto Counterbid
text: The chairman of Baosteel Group, China’s biggest steelmaker, has denied his company plans to lead a bid for mining giant Rio Tinto, saying the company lacks the resources to do so, reports said Thursday.

headline: V.C.s Go on $20 Million WildTangent
text: Casual games maker WildTangent on Wednesday said it raised $20 million in debt funding from Hercules Technology Growth Capital.

headline: Henry Kravis in Focus as Buyout Backlash Spreads
text: Bells will be ringing, and carolers will be greeting the Upper East Side neighbors of Henry Kravis this morning.

headline: Canada Pension Plan Alters Auckland Airport Deal
text: Canada Pension Plan Investment Board cut the debt portion of its NZ$1.8 billion ($1.4 billion) offer for 40 percent of Auckland International Airport to quell concern the deal would have tripled the airfield’s borrowings.

headline: More on mandates
text: Jon Gruber, one of the nation’s top health economists, on Kit Seelye and the mandate issue.

headline: Congressional Report Takes Aim at Pay Consultants
text: Conflicts of interest are pervasive among executive compensation consultants, according to a Congressional investigation. Moreover, the inquiry found, consultants who do other work for companies while helping them devise executive pay recommended significantly higher pay packages than consultants who had no such additional relationships.

headline: Pelikan Flies Off With $69 Million
text: Pelikan Technologies, which makes a device for electronically extracting blood samples for glucose monitoring in diabetics, raised $69 million in venture funding. Clarus Ventures was the lead investor in the round, which also included new investors Bio*One Capital and Global Life Science Ventures.

headline: Investors Sue Bear Stearns Over Failed Hedge Funds
text: The first of a new round of investor claims was filed against Bear Stearns on Wednesday for its role in managing two mortgage hedge funds that collapsed earlier this year, securities lawyers said.

headline: Lenders Agree to Freeze Rates on Some Loans
text: The Bush administration reached an agreement with the mortgage industry on Wednesday on a plan to freeze interest rates for up to five years for a portion of the two million homeowners who bought houses in the last few years with subprime loans.

headline: AQR Capital Said to Book Big Losses
text: AQR Capital Management, a hedge fund known for its quantitative trading strategies, continues to get clobbered as volatility whipsaws its computer-generated trading models, according to The New York Post.

headline: Has Paulson Dimmed the Goldman Glow?
text: Goldman Sachs, whose successful alums have been touted often of late, has little to crow about when it comes to Henry M. Paulson, Breakingviews argued in a commentary Wednesday.

headline: Wary of Risk, Bankers Sold Shaky Mortgage Debt
text: As the subprime loan crisis deepens, Wall Street firms are increasingly coming under scrutiny for their role in selling risky mortgage-related securities to investors.

headline: Excepts from Romney’s Religion Speech
text: Former Gov. Mitt Romney is set to give a much-anticipated speech on religion this morning. The Times’s Michael Luo reports from the scene in Texas that more than 100 journalists — from places as farflung as Japan — have registered to attend.

headline: Credit Turmoil Not Seen as Obstacle to Indian Deal Making
text: Armed with strong balance sheets, willing local lenders and unrelenting ambition, Indian companies are well positioned to navigate the credit crunch and maintain their global buying spree, but must be flexible on financing, Reuters reported.

headline: Photo Opportunity
text: Finally, a piece of photographic data that solves the question that people always ask on the day the National Board of Review makes its picks: Who are these guys, anyway? Here’s another tantalizing clue.

headline: No Country? No Contest.
text: The National Board of Review loves it. The Gurus of Gold over at Movie City News pick it. Even competitors swoon when they talk about “No Country for Old Men.”

headline: Calculating the CO2 Cost of Al Gore and Bali
text: A few days ago, I was sent Al Gore’s schedule for December. He (and his family and his aides) are flying first to Norway to pick up his Nobel Prize on the 10th, and then flying on to Bali for the climate conference there. OK, Al Gore is a real hero of the environmental movement, and has admirably helped galvanize the world to action.

headline: The Early Word: Romney’s Moment
text: Mitt Romney claims his speech today in College Station, Texas, will address the issue of “faith in America” as a whole, even though some evangelical voters were hoping that he would clarify some of the controversial tenets of his religion.

headline: Rear-End Feedback
text: Is it just the Bagger, or have movies seats become a little more uncomfortable? Perhaps the Bagger’s advancing years have left him less able to sit up for a few hours. Or maybe, probably, surely, the movies are just getting longer because of an absence of adult supervision.

headline: Art Murmur | Day One
text: Ralph Lauren must have been seeing red, white and blue over the desecrating of Old Glory here at Art Basel Miami Beach. The crossroads of anti-Americanism is C-13/C-16, where White Cube and Hauser & Wirth are kitty-corner to each other and both feature unabashed bashing of America… Talk of the fair is the arty Chinese convenience store, “ShanghART Supermarket,” by Xu Zhen. Among the shopping: Hans Ulrich Obrist and Beatrix Ruf …Anne McNally and Anh Duong were laughing at being punk’d by the fake ATM created by Elmgren & Dragset for the Massimo De Carlo booth. Not only did they try a withdrawal but they also fell for the doll in a basket meant to resemble an abandoned baby…

headline: Buyout Tax Increase Unlikely This Year
text: A proposed tax increase on private equity and hedge funds seems to be off the table this year, thanks in large part to intense lobbying by Wall Street firms and their managers.

headline: Miramax 2.0
text: The Weinstein boys, Harvey and Bob, may not be in the house, but the logo is the same and the presence of same in the Oscars race remains a big factor. The Bagger happened to read something about how Daniel Battsek, a quiet Brit and the anti-mogul, has teamed up with Scott Rudin, the producer behind “The Queen,” “No Country for Old Men” and a million other movies, to keep the awards machine stoked. If the National Board of Review’s taste in movies is at all predictive, should be a nice little year at the Disney division.

headline: Will Competition Improve Subway Performance?
text: New York City Transit is to announce an overhaul today of how the subway system is managed. As William Neuman reports, the changes will give individual subway lines a greater degree of autonomy by putting each one under the direction of a manager who will be responsible for almost everything that happens on the tracks, in the trains and in the stations. The goal is to have each subway line operate, in many ways, as a self-contained railroad. The 24 lines will compete against one another and be rated on service, cleanliness, on-time performance and other measures.

headline: “Policing the Halls”
Writers, Studios Make Nice In Public Statements
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Thursday Kickoff: Put Down That Sandwich!
text: It appears that things got a little ugly at Jimmy John’s Gourmet Sandwiches in Gainesville yesterday morning. The Tampa Tribune’s Andy Staples reports that Florida defensive end Jermaine Cunningham and two others were arrested after allegedly throwing food and empty soda cups at an employee of the sandwich shop after he asked Cunningham to pay for a $1 bag of chips.

headline: Now Opening | Milan’s Design Museum
How Does Goldman Do It?
text: Among Wall Street’s big investment banks, one has remained an object of fascination and more than a little envy of late. We speak, of course, of Goldman Sachs, which has managed to avoid the subprime-related write-downs that its brethren have been forced to take. The firm was not even among those subpoenaed by Andrew Cuomo, New York’s attorney general, for information related to its subprime-tied activities.

headline: Memo to Mitt
text: What should Romney say in his “J.F.K. speech” today in College Station, Texas, about his Mormon faith and the role of religion in public life? Jan Shipps, a professor emeritus of religious studies and history at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis, writes on the op-ed page of The Salt Lake Tribune, “The mystery of Mormonism is not the exemplary way Latter-day Saints live, but what they believe.” (The Tribune describes Shipps as “a well-known non-Mormon scholar on the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.”) She adds:

headline: A Change of Heart on Kim Jong Il?
text: It came as no surprise today when an American envoy’s latest visit ended with disagreements remaining — no one said that it would be easy to get North Korea to fulfill its nuclear disarmament promises. In fact a lot of people thought it was foolish to try.

headline: Climate Panel May Not Have Time to Celebrate
text: Yvo de Boer, the executive secretary managing the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, gave his latest update to the press today in Bali on negotiations over next steps under that faltering 1992 climate treaty. Some excerpts are here:

headline: Scent Notes | Eau du Soir by Sisley
text: To call Sisley a niche scent house is almost overstating it. A skincare brand, Sisley has only three perfumes, in limited distribution, and niche houses are usually associated with shock-the-bourgeoisie, Santiago-Calatrava-in-a-bottle olfactive modernity. Exhibit A: The “I’m so cool I can barely stand it” Hotel Costes scents.

headline: Kiefer Sutherland Begins Jail Term; Fox Says ’24’ Unaffected
text: Kiefer Sutherland, the star of the popular Fox counter-terrorism drama “24,” checked in to a California jail Wednesday evening, right after being sentenced to 48 days in jail for drunken driving.

headline: Who’s Afraid of MBIA?
text: William Ackman, who leads Pershing Square Capital, is probably quite pleased that the markets and credit rating agencies seem to be picking up on the potential troubles at MBIA, the largest bond insurer in the United States. He has been betting for years that the company would blow up.

headline: The Dr. Seuss Jumble: Naming Web Sites
text: Could it possibly be true? Has all wit and cleverness already dried up in the naming of Web sites, less than 15 years after the Internet was opened to the public?

headline: Game On
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Anatomy of an Undiscovered Death
text: Updated, 4:10 p.m. | The more you think about it, the more unlikely the undetected death of Christina Copeman comes to seem. A colleague said to me, “If you purposely set out to die in your house in New York City and not be found for two years, you couldn’t do it.”

text: The following is the text of Mitt Romney's speech on faith, as prepared for delivery:

headline: Doctoroff Is Leaving Bloomberg Administration
text: Updated, 1:22 p.m. | Daniel L. Doctoroff, New York City’s deputy mayor for economic development and one of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg‘s closest advisers since 2002, will leave the government at the end of this year, the mayor announced this morning at City Hall.

headline: Seussical-Sounding Web Site Names
text: Could it possibly be true? Has all wit and cleverness already dried up in the naming of Web sites, less than 15 years after the Internet was opened to the public?

headline: Answers from John MacKinnon
text: Today biodiversity expert John MacKinnon answers questions from readers prompted by part six of our series on China’s environment.

headline: Romney’s Speech on Faith
text: Republican Mitt Romney just finished his speech on the role of religion in America, saying that as president he would “serve no one religion, no one group, no one cause.” Mr. Romney’s speech lasted about 20 minutes and he used the word “Mormon” one time. (Interesting contrast: In his 1960 speech, John F, Kennedy said the word “Catholic” 20 times.)

headline: How to Celebrate Microwave Oven Day
text: “Happy Microwave Oven Day!” Slashfood informs us today. “Now, I’m not sure if this means this is the day to buy a microwave oven or cook something in a microwave oven.”

headline: Super Favre
text: He is 38 and graying, but that hasn’t stopped Brett Favre from having a remarkable, resurgent season, playing his way into contention for the Most Valuable Player award. Besides Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, is there a quarterback in the N.F.L. you’d rather have leading your team in a big game? If so, who?

headline: How to Boost Your Willpower
text: Every day, we are tested. Whether it’s a cookie tempting us from our diets or a warm bed coaxing us to sleep late, we are forced to decide between what we want to do and what we ought to do.

headline: ‘Bored … Tubby … Mild’
A Kiss Is Not Just a Kiss
text: The Film Experience does a deconstruction of some of the more torrid cinematic saliva exchanges. Fine for viewing at work, but your face might get a little warm while you’re staring at Naomi Watts getting busy with a friend in “Mullholland Drive.”

headline: Bar Charting the Blood
text: Vulture, New York magazine’s entertainment blog, lives up to its name with some serious research into the amount of spurting hemoglobin in “Sweeney Todd.” After some cross-analysis with “The Departed,” “Saw IV,” “Mortal Kombat” and the American Civil War. “Sweeney Todd” is just nosed out of first — probably something to do with Gettysburg.

headline: Back-From-the-Dead Tale Gets More Bizarre
text: UPDATED

headline: A Stem Cell Breakthrough — No Thanks to Mr. Bush
text: There was a lot of discussion last month about a scientific breakthrough that made stem cell research possible without running afoul of the Bush Administration’s restrictions on destroying embryos. Bizarrely, admirers of President Bush claimed that he deserved credit for stimulating the latest advance.

headline: The Education of Gary Hart
text: It is a dangerous thing to read Henry Adams’s “Education” before actually seeing and knowing Washington. It encourages predispositions, some fair and some unfair, and it threatens to warp objective reality and unobstructed insight.

headline: More ‘Late Night’ Jokes From Readers
text: Send in yours via the comment link below:

headline: B.C.S. = Bad. Choice. System.
text: “Imagine if other sports had such rampant disregard for their postseasons,” Will Leitch writes about the B.C.S. system in this week’s Play newsletter. “The Cubs would make the playoffs every year; the Packers would host a wild-card game even if they were 8-8; heck, the N.B.A. might even find a place for the Knicks. For all the talk of the B.C.S. being “impartial,” the selection process for the non-title game bowls is steeped in the same cronyism and back-scratching we’ve been mired in for years.”

headline: The Long and Short of 2008
text: We’d like to share with you a “Letter From Washington” column written by Adam Clymer, a longtime Washington correspondent for The Times who is now retired. It was published in the International Herald Tribune yesterday, and discusses, as its headline aptly sums up: “How a Long Campaign Robs Voters of Time.”

headline: For The First Time In Years, ‘Nightline’ Tops Leno and Letterman
text: For the first time since Hurricane Katrina overwhelmed the news airwaves two years ago — and, for that matter, for the first time since Ted Koppel retired from network television shortly thereafter — ABC’s “Nightline” drew more viewers in a week last week than the “Tonight Show with Jay Leno” and “Late Show with David Letterman” according to Nielsen estimates provided to a reporter this morning by ABC.

headline: Evercore Adds Veteran Banker in London
text: Anthony Fry, a longtime media banker in Europe, is setting up shop in Evercore Partners‘ rapidly expanding London office.

headline: World Club Top 10: Pride of the Bashkirs
text: Well, the first posting of our World Club Top 10 rankings generated a, ahem, lively exchange of reader comments. We’ll address some of those comments in this posting — but first, here are the new rankings, updated through Wednesday’s games. The Russian Superliga team from Bashkortostan, Salavat Yulaev Ufa, still lead the way (more on them below as well).

headline: Stumptown in SoMa? Only if There’s Room to Roast
text: The neighborhood on Broadway south of Macy’s may already be getting a new nickname, SoMa, but will New York coffee lovers soon call it Stumptown?There has been speculation that Stumptown Coffee Roasters, the chain of cafes and “roasteries” based in Portland, Ore., might be planning an outpost in the lobby of the Ace Hotel, a Portland transplant that is scheduled to open on 29th Street and Broadway in 2009.

headline: When the U.S. Military Crosses Paths With Iran

headline: A Fixture in Brooklyn Considers Staying Closer to Home
text: For the last 25 years, Assemblyman Dov Hikind has been a fixture in Albany and in state politics. And he has also been a fixture — really, something of a political don — in his district, which is anchored in Borough Park, Brooklyn. But Mr. Hikind recently indicated that he might be looking to reduce his commuting time, and he is giving consideration to running for the City Council seat currently held by Simcha Felder.

And in Canada, that means a closer look at Sidney Crosby, the young Penguins and the the team payroll, all in the context of what once was a young, dynamic team working to elevate the game: the Edmonton Oilers.

headline: Remembering Murray Klein, 84, Former Co-Owner of Zabar’s
text: Murray Klein, who swept floors and stocked the shelves for Louis Zabar before becoming the managing partner of Zabar’s and transforming it from a modest deli into a venerable food emporium, died today at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84. The cause was lung cancer, according to Roger Klein, his son.

headline: Thursday’s Links: A Steeler You’ve Never Heard of Guarantees a Victory
text: Is it me, or should it take someone with a little more stature than the second-year safety Anthony Smith to guarantee that the Steelers will beat the Patriots? It’s one thing when Joe Namath and Mark Messier do it, but Smith hasn’t even started every game this season.

headline: Entrepreneurial Journalism in the Facebook Age
text: Every now and then, I meet someone idealistic and perhaps foolish enough to want to embark on a career in journalism. Until recently, my advice was largely the same as anyone had given for many decades: Find a gig where you can write — a small town paper, freelancing for an alternative weekly, a business trade publication (my route). If you’re good, the story went, you would find you way to bigger publications and forge a career.

headline: A Record-Breaking ‘Monday Night Football’
text: ESPN had plenty to cheer about after the nail-biting win by the New England Patriots over the Baltimore Ravens on “Monday Night Football:” the telecast was the most-watched program in the history of cable television.

headline: From a Kid to a Captain
text: I go way back with Jamie Langenbrunner, who was named Wednesday as the Devils’ captain. I met him in October 1996, when he was in his first full season with the Dallas Stars and I was a reporter for the Dallas Morning News. He was 21, a skinny kid from Minnesota’s Iron Range, and I remember talking to him one day about how he hated to sit around in the afternoons at his apartment waiting for games to start. He just seemed so young, as if he should still be playing at Cloquet High School.

There was the official welcome party at the Delano Hotel and, of course, our own blowout — T Magazine Online’s launch at The Raleigh. Check out The Moment’s party video (in the right column) or click here.

text: Hello! The editors of The Moment have been hounding me for an email dispatch for the readers of The Moment so thought I’d drop you guys a quick line.

headline: ABC and NBC Take Wednesday Night
text: ABC led a close race for No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, with its 9 p.m. medical show, “Private Practice,” delivering 10.4 million viewers as well as the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC also led the 8 p.m. hour in that demographic with its holiday special “Santa Claus Is Comin’ to Town” (9.4 million).

headline: A Lost Fight Over Washington Square Park’s Renovation
text: It seems appropriate that the renovation of Washington Square Park would involve six years of planning, arguing and fighting. After all, a spot that has played host to marching suffragists, picketing workers and protesting beatniks should not ease into changes without a brickbat or two, even if they are only rhetorical. But after all the shouting, the city’s proposal to shift the park’s fountain into direct line with the Washington Square Arch, add more lawn and spruce up the statues and fixtures finally seems about to move forward. In a decision issued on Monday, a judge dismissed two remaining claims against the renovation plan. Filed on behalf of community activists, the lawsuits claimed that the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation plan would violate environmental rules and alter the nature of the park.

headline: The Carpetbagger
text: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) heads downtown for a low-key premiere of "Atonement," the new period epic from Focus Features.

headline: Deputy Mayor to Head to Bloomberg L.P.

headline: Transfusion, Anyone?
text: While the Bagger has been gassing on about the gallons of gore spilled in “Sweeney Todd,” and their possible effect on Academy voters, the Baguette actually went out and talked to people at the film’s New York premiere a couple of days ago.

headline: Top 10 (or 11) for the 2008 Draft
text: Wayne Gretzky told me recently that one of the first things he learned as a coach is that each year the scouts will say this year is a deep draft. Well, this year, he agrees, they happen to be right.

headline: The Blessed Second Life of Beliefnet
text: There are few Internet journeys as harrowing as that of Steve Waldman and Beliefnet, a Web site about religion and spirituality. Started in 1999, the company reorganized in a Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceeding in 2002. That wiped out the stock holdings of all of the investors and employees, including Mr. Waldman, the founder.

text: If any Iowa voters missed Senator Barack Obama’s speech at the Jefferson-Jackson dinner in Des Moines last month — widely seen as a turning point in his campaign –­ they can catch it on television.

headline: The Fourth Time, the Robber Looked Familar
text: X Dreams, an adult entertainment business in an industrial section of West Babylon, N.Y., has a lot of regular customers, who pay cash for lap dances, pornographic videos and admission to the erotic theater.

text: Add “Don’t Forget the Lyrics!” to the growing list of reality shows that may be benefiting from the writers’ strike.

headline: Art Basel Miami | Where to Go

headline: A Privy for the Privileged
text: Nature designed me for a big chair, one more than 31 inches from the chair in front of me. I’m pretty tall, perhaps more than adequately wide, and jumbo-footed. My feet, egads! The front-seat overhang of a taxi traps my foot every time. I thus prefer the bus or the subway. When I fly, I want my shoes parallel, north and south, not in an X shape. In addition, I dislike having to win an elbow rest through combat. Sounds like first class should suit me.

headline: Venezuelan Leader Climbing YouTube Again
text: The King of Spain achieved momentary Internet stardom when his tirade at President Hugo Chávez hit YouTube. During the clip, Mr. Chavez seemed to hold his fire, but he did anything but that in another one is climbing the video site’s charts today with 90,000 views so far.

headline: 2008 Grammy Nominations
text: A look at the nominees for the 50th Annual Grammy Awards.

headline: Road Trip, Part 12: Bringing It All Back Home
text: The long and winding road has finally brought the duo of Matt Meyers and Mike Ogle back to New York. These two have been on the road for three months for CSTV.com (with weekly dispatches for The Quad), checking out the wacky happenings on the college football landscape. Their final stop was the Big 12 title game in San Antonio, where they encountered some excited Missouri alums and a singing Lee Roy Selmon. It’s been quite a trek for these two and we’re glad they shared their adventures with The Quad.

headline: Art Basel Miami | The Novel Place to Stay
text: Scoring a room at the writer Brian Antoni‘s house is possibly the ultimate stay in town. Just ask the German painter Anselm Kiefer, who described Antoni’s hodgepodge of quirky objets trouvée mixed with pieces like a classical self-portrait bust by Antoni’s sister, Janine, as “the best art in America.” Not only is the house enlightening, but Antoni, whose book “South Beach: The Novel” is due out from Grove Atlantic in February, is just the kind of tour guide you want. His reserve of gossip from Miami days past is perfect breakfast fodder. Just ask regulars like Jeffrey Deitch, Ellen Barkin or Patrick McMullan (who, we hear, has been sporting a bed-head look at Antoni’s all week). Take that, Andre Balazs!

headline: Tallying Activists’ Victories in 2007
text: Shareholder activists have been unusually vocal this year. But that doesn’t mean they’ve been more successful, a new report by Thomson Financial finds.

headline: 'One Hour' From Rudolph W. Giuliani
text: First aired on Dec. 5, 2007.

headline: The Pleasures Beyond Frascati and Soave
text: Sometimes a journalist must take matters into his own hands. You want to make a point — you’re chomping at the bit. But you have nobody handy to play the foil. Hence the straw man argument.

headline: Fixing Guitar Hero III’s Mono Problem
text: Some players of Guitar Hero III, the video game where you strum on a toy guitar to tunes played on the TV, have been emitting a different kind of squealing feedback.

headline: Tierney on Fishing Less to Catch More (and Make More Money)
text: My colleague John Tierney has a fine post up this afternoon on a fresh study in the journal Science showing how fishing less can increase catches and profits for fishing fleets in the long run.

headline: Jozy Altidore: Eating, Sleeping, Training, Traveling
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his latest post, Altidore discusses training camp in California and the coming trip to China with the United States men’s Olympic team for games on Dec. 13 in Changsha and Dec. 16 in Guangzhou. The squad leaves Friday from Los Angeles, the start of a trip that is expected to take 20 hours, or more.

text: The galleries of 19th-century European painting and sculpture are a popular attraction at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

text: Mitt Romney's speech drew inevitable comparisons to another speech from a half-century earlier by John F. Kennedy.

headline: Art Basel Miami | Patriot Games
text: Richard Prince‘s mega-retrospective at the Guggenheim may be called “Spiritual America,” but the artist does not necessarily have God on his side. I mean, could it really be coincidental that just as the exhibition was coming together this summer, his Guggenheim-owned installation in upstate New York, “Second House,” was struck by lightning and burned to the ground? Meanwhile, here in Miami Beach, the intersection of Booth C-13 (White Cube Gallery) and Booth C-16 (Hauser & Wirth) at Art Basel marks an interesting nexus of un-American activity. On one corner, Christoph Buchel weighs in with “Training Ground for Training Ground for Democracy,” a raucous two-story kindergarten cum internment camp that is simultaneously a prequel and a riposte to the Swiss artist’s ill-fated Mass MoCA show. On the opposite corner, White Cube throws a double punch with Tracey Emin‘s tri-color neon wall sculpture “Red, White and [f-bomb deleted] Blue,” and Liza Lou‘s bewitching “Black Flag,” which gives new meaning to the words Star Spangled Banner.

headline: Sherpas Face an Uphill Battle in N.Y.C.
text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: No Church at Ground Zero, Yet Faith and Hope Persist
text: For the 91st year, members of the St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox parish in Lower Manhattan gathered on the day in the liturgical calendar that honors the namesake of their church. For the seventh year, they had no church in which to gather.

headline: Would You Like a $1 House?
text: Countrywide Financial is one of the downtrodden stocks that rallied today on the government’s plan to push creditors to give some subprime homeowners a break in order to let them keep their homes. Why is it good for a lender to be forced to make concessions to borrowers? Beats me. Perhaps the theory is that this will make investors in mortgage securities more willing to accept modifications that will keep borrowers in their homes (and keep servicing fees flowing to Countrywide).

headline: Express-ing Himself
text: John Edwards has christened his latest bus tour across Iowa on Monday the “Main Street Express.”

headline: Regrets Only
Top Aide to Schools Chancellor Steps Down
text: Kristen Kane, one of the most trusted advisers to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, stepped down today as the chief operating officer of the Department of Education. Ms. Kane’s departure represents a significant loss for the department; she was one of the officials hired by the chancellor and gained a reputation for being extremely hard working and an important behind-the-scenes organizer of the department.“Kristen’s contribution to our city and schools has been incalculable,” Mr. Klein said in a statement. “She helped to shape and manage virtually every significant initiative of recent years, and her skill and dedication made her a model of public service. I am deeply grateful to Kristen for her work and wish her the best.”

headline: How Would You Run These Subway Lines?
text: The decision to decentralize management of the subway system could significantly affect riders’ experiences of the New York City subways. As William Neuman reported, New York City Transit plans to appoint a general manager for each subway line. The new managers will be responsible for almost all day-to-day operations on the line — stations, tracks, train cars and announcements — in an effort to improve accountability and responsiveness to customer opinion.

headline: Tough Road for Jason Blake
text: Jason Blake has found himself in the middle of all kinds of unwelcome stories this season, his first with the Toronto Maple Leafs after signing there as a free agent. It was supposed to be a triumphant move for Blake, who spent most of seven years playing for the Islanders, where he scored a career-high 40 goals last season.

headline: New Year’s Programming Resolutions at NBC: More Reality
text: “Broadcast at least one reality show every weeknight” appears to be NBC’s New Year’s resolution.

headline: Obama’s Got Grammy Potential
text: While Barack Obama is battling Hillary Clinton in the Democratic race, he can enjoy a small victory from those who vote with ears more than hearts and minds: He is one of five contenders for the Grammy Award for Spoken Word, one of 110 categories this year.

headline: Awards Roundup
text: There was plenty of hardware handed out tonight (most of it down in Florida) to honor college football’s best. Florida’s Tim Tebow won the Davey O’Brien Award as the nation’s top quarterback and the Maxwell Award as the best player (according to the Maxwell Memorial Football Club). Arkansas’s Darren McFadden won the Walter Camp Award honoring the best player (given out by the Walter Camp Foundation) and the Doak Walker Award, given to the top running back. McFadden also won the Doak Walker last year. These awards will only serve to fuel the Heisman talk heading into this weekend. Meanwhile, Dan Connor won the Chuck Bednarik Award as the best defensive player, making it three consecutive years that a Penn State linebacker has won it (Paul Posluszny won the previous two). Here’s a full rundown of the awards:

text: Queens is New York's real United Nations, the one without stuffy diplomats and security checks.

text: For evidence of the role international buyers are playing in Miami’s troubled market, look no further than CIMA, the latest tower project on the Miami River from NEO, the local developer.

headline: It’s Busy at the Top in the Hawaii Luxury-Home Market
text: WHILE real estate transactions continue to slump in many places on the United States mainland, the strength of Hawaii’s international pull has propelled its luxury sales ahead of last year’s and has increased speculative development.

headline: A Devotion to Film Binds Two Loners
text: In “Man in the Chair” Christopher Plummer, an actor typecast nowadays as a suave, smiling cobra slithering through the corridors of power, sheds his scales to play a tippling old curmudgeon raging against the dying of the light. His fierce portrayal of Flash Madden, a long-retired Hollywood studio gaffer, is the knot that ties together this sentimental intergenerational drama.

headline: C.I.A. Destroyed 2 Tapes Showing Interrogations
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  The Central Intelligence Agency in 2005 destroyed at least two videotapes documenting the interrogation of two Qaeda operatives in the agency’s custody, a step it took in the midst of Congressional and legal scrutiny about its secret detention program, according to current and former government officials.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Holiday Sounds, Traditional and Otherwise
text: How should a musician celebrate Christmas? Plunge into the holiday bustle or reconnect to tradition; savor the comfort of familiarity or seek a new personal twist; pay attention to family, to faith or, perhaps, to food. All those choices are part of this year’s notable holiday albums, reviewed here by the music critics of The New York Times.

headline: Congressional Maneuvering Dooms Hate Crime Measure
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Congressional Democrats on Thursday dropped their effort to tie a Pentagon policy measure to an expanded definition of federal hate crimes covering sexual orientation, ending chances that the long-stalled hate crime measure would clear Congress this year.

headline: Moving on From City Hall, a High-Level Relationship That Was Built on Trust
text: Not until the penultimate sentence does the 21-paragraph City Hall news release announcing Daniel L. Doctoroff’s departure as deputy mayor mention his new job.

headline: Ex-I.R.S. Agent Says Tax Evasion by Real Estate Partners Is Huge
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Investors in real estate partnerships evade billions of dollars in federal taxes each year, even though detecting this type of cheating is easy, a former specialist in partnerships for the Internal Revenue Service said Thursday.

headline: Aspen Skiing Company
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Chief of Coke to Step Down After Steering Its Recovery
text: In the annals of Coca-Cola’s history, E. Neville Isdell may well be remembered as the man who stopped the bleeding and sutured the wounds.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Nov. 28 about a hearing on whether WWOR, a New Jersey-based TV station owned by Fox Television Stations, covers New Jersey sufficiently to merit renewal of its broadcast license referred incorrectly to a WWOR video camera that recorded the proceedings. Although there was a piece of masking tape on the camera, it was not in fact covering the letters NY. Fox says that the station’s cameras are labeled My9 and do not have the letters NY on them. (Fox uses “My9NY” as a slogan and as part of its Web site address.)

headline: Senate Backs Freeze on Tax Without Cost Offsets
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Trying to find a way out of a sticky tax problem, the Senate on Thursday voted overwhelmingly to prevent the alternative minimum tax from hitting millions of middle-class Americans without replacing the $50 billion that would be lost.

headline: Women on the Verge of a Fiery Afterlife
text: Beneath its theatrical little flourishes and a philosophy of East-West accommodation, “The Gate” is modest in both its materials and its ambitions. The fourth installment of Tan Dun’s Orchestral Theater series, “The Gate,” which opened on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, gathers three women from different cultures to tell their stories at the gates of hell.

headline: Duke Erases a Bitter Taste and Ends Skid
text: DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 6  About two minutes into the second half of one of the more frustrating performances of the season by the Rutgers women’s basketball team, Coach C. Vivian Stringer apparently had seen enough.

headline: Gates Leaves Iraq Encouraged
text: MANAMA, Bahrain, Dec. 6  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that security progress in Iraq was significant yet still fragile, an assessment echoed by the senior American commander in Baghdad, who strongly cautioned against a premature declaration of victory.

headline: The Essence of Mormonism
text: Joseph Smith founded Mormonism in the 19th century in upstate New York as a restoration of what he considered to be the true Christian church.

headline: Russian Court Orders Release of a Journalist, Group Says
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (AP)  A Russian court has ordered the release of a reporter committed to a psychiatric hospital for nine months after writing articles critical of the military campaign in Chechnya, Reporters Without Borders said Thursday.

headline: U.S. to Pressure China on Food and Product Safety at Coming Trade Talks
text: BEIJING, Dec. 6  When Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. started his “strategic economic dialogue” with China a year ago, he was seeking greater access for American goods and services and hoping to persuade the Chinese to let the value of their currency rise against the dollar.

headline:
Democrats Call for Inquiry in
Destruction of Tapes by C.I.A.
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Angry Democratic lawmakers called for investigations today into the Central Intelligence Agency’s destruction in 2005 of at least two videotapes documenting the interrogation of two Qaeda operatives in the agency’s custody.

headline: Medicare Cuts Payout on 2 Cancer Drugs
text: New Medicare rules for a small but promising class of cancer drugs may cause thousands of lymphoma patients to lose access to the treatment, which in some cases is the only therapy available to them.

headline: Automakers Change Course on Fuel Standards
text: DETROIT  Just six months ago, an auto industry trade group warned that consumers could be forced to buy vehicles they did not want if Congress went too far in raising fuel economy standards.

headline: Hunter Mountain
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Extension for Miles
text: Louisiana State Coach Les Miles has signed a contract extension that will keep him with the Tigers through 2012. The deal was approved yesterday by the L.S.U. board’s athletic committee, apparently ending any chance of Miles leaving for Michigan to replace Lloyd Carr, who retired last month.

headline: A Leading Asian Utility to Cut Carbon Emissions
text: HONG KONG, Dec. 6  CLP, one of Asia’s largest power utilities, plans to commit itself on Friday to sharply reducing its emissions of carbon dioxide.

headline: Faith vs. the Faithless
text: Jon Meacham is the editor of Newsweek and the author of “American Gospel,” which describes the history of religious liberty in the United States. Richard John Neuhaus is the editor in chief of First Things and the author of “The Naked Public Square,” which is about efforts to banish religion from public conversation.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 29 about the Nixon administration’s alarm over Israel’s nuclear weapons program described incorrectly the process that prompted the Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum to release previously classified documents. The release was the result of declassification requests by researchers at the National Security Archive of George Washington University and elsewhere; it was not because of a regulation requiring review and possible declassification of documents after 25 years.

headline: Scout Leader in California Accused of Abuse
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6  A scout leader who once sued the City of Berkeley for challenging a national Boy Scout ban on members who are gay or atheist has been arrested on felony charges that for at least five years he sexually abused young males in the troops he led.

headline: Feathers Are Shed in Logo
text: The College of William and Mary’s new logo sheds the two feathers that the N.C.A.A. deemed offensive to American Indians. The logo, revealed yesterday, updates the familiar W&M monogram and uses the school’s more traditional colors of green and gold instead of the more recent green and yellow. Last year, the N.C.A.A. ruled William and Mary could keep its Tribe nickname but could not display its athletic logo with feathers at N.C.A.A. championship events or play host to N.C.A.A. tournament games at which the logo would be shown.

headline: The Crisis of Faith
text: Mitt Romney obviously felt he had no choice but to give a speech yesterday on his Mormon faith. Even by the low standards of this campaign, it was a distressing moment and just what the nation’s founders wanted to head off with the immortal words of the First Amendment: A presidential candidate cowed into defending his way of worshiping God by a powerful minority determined to impose its religious tenets as a test for holding public office.

headline: The Hills Are Still Alive, Just Look Past the Strings
text: Perhaps you’ve suffered through the clip-clop-clunk of a mediocre marionette performance, one in which there is no effort to invest the wooden stars with flexibility or personality. At the remarkable “Sound of Music” created by the Salzburg Marionette Theater, you’ll know you’re seeing an entirely different level of artistry as soon as the curtain goes up. It’s the nun down on her hands and knees scrubbing the floor, with a very convincing floor-scrubbing motion, who tips you off.

headline: Despite Report, France and Germany Keep Pressure on Iran
text: PARIS, Dec. 6  The leaders of France and Germany said Thursday that Iran remained a danger and that other nations needed to keep up the pressure over its nuclear program despite a United States intelligence report’s conclusion that Tehran was no longer building a bomb.

headline: Under a Microscope, Bush and His Presidency
text: The story of how the Bush administration took the United States to war in Iraq is such a complicated tale with so many plots and subplots, so much misinformation and spin, so many missteps and outrageous misjudgments that reporters in countless newspaper and magazine articles, television documentaries and dozens of books have struggled to piece together the narrative. It is a continuing process, as more and more information comes to light and needs to be sifted and weighed and connected.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Brooklyn: Girl’s Death Ruled Homicide
text: The death of a 3-year-old girl late Wednesday in Bedford-Stuyvesant was ruled a homicide yesterday by the city medical examiner. Police investigators were questioning the girl’s parents, and her three siblings were placed with the Administration for Children’s Services. The police said they found the girl, identified as Tkai Marcelle, unconscious when they went to the family’s apartment late Wednesday in response to a 911 call. The girl was pronounced dead at Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn. An autopsy yesterday determined that the cause of death was multiple injuries from blunt impact.

headline: Eye Candy, Noses, Beauty and Ugliness, Illustrated
text: Just as there is more to art than pretty pictures, there is more to art books than gorgeous illustrations. When the art and architecture critics of The New York Times were asked to choose their favorite books of 2007, their selections included a collection of essays on the museum in the age of globalization, two pessimistic studies of the modern city, a volume of poetry and an anthology of ugliness. But rest assured: the list still includes plenty of provocative, powerful and just plain knockout pictures, from Rembrandt's soulful noses to Martín Ramírez's visionary paintings.

headline: Web Access and E-Mail on Flights
text: Passengers may soon hear a new in-flight announcement: “You can now log on.”

headline: With Miles Staying Put, Michigan Talks to Schiano
text: Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano interviewed for the coaching vacancy at Michigan on Wednesday, according to a person who was briefed on the meeting but was not authorized to speak about it. Schiano met with Bill Martin, the Michigan athletic director, in New York, but has not received a job offer.

headline: Unfinished Business Marks Winter Meetings
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 6  A blizzard of major league executives marched through the spacious Opryland Hotel, stopped in the packed lobby and then bolted for the airport. The winter meetings ended Thursday, but for most of these suitcase-toting officials there was still work to be done in molding their teams.

headline: French Leader Urges Guerrilla to Free Woman
text: PARIS, Dec. 6  It was an unusual message from a president to a guerrilla. But the televised appeal by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France to the Colombian rebel leader Manuel Marulanda to release a woman who has been held hostage for nearly six years was only the latest episode in a tale of human endurance.

headline: Big Foot Follies
text: There’s precious little to laugh at in “The Sasquatch Gang,” a sad attempt to board the loser-nerd comedy bandwagon. Boasting a writer and director, Tim Skousen, who was an assistant director on “Napoleon Dynamite,” the movie affirms its pedigree with a near-subliminal cameo by that film’s star, Jon Heder. As if the stoned line delivery and moronic behavior weren’t enough to give the game away.

headline: German Design for an Industrial Age
