text: Tomorrow Sotheby’s begins the presale view of the 114 lots in the Dec. 14 auction “Deutscher Werkbund to Bauhaus: An Important Collection of German Design,” devoted to industrial design by architects and craftsmen working in Germany from the late 1890s to the early 1930s.

headline: Plans for Le Massif: Fame and Fortune
text: DESPITE its spectacular setting high above the St. Lawrence River, Le Massif is a remote ski destination that has attracted little attention outside Quebec since it opened 25 years ago.

headline: Doll’s Village: Some See Restoration as Too Cutesy
text: AURORA, N.Y.  After a five-year makeover at the hands of the founder of the American Girl doll collection, this village of white clapboard and faded brick on Cayuga Lake practically glows, with freshly painted homes, refurbished inns and markets selling dried organic cranberries and cheese made from sheep’s milk.

headline: Philippine Court Convicts 14 in Kidnapping Case
text: MANILA, Dec. 6  A Philippine court on Thursday convicted 14 members of the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group in the 2001 kidnapping of 20 people off an island resort, including three Americans, two of whom were eventually killed.

headline: China Reports Progress in Food Safety
text: SHANGHAI, Dec. 6  China said on Thursday that it had demolished the facilities of more than 2,800 rural food makers as part of its effort to crack down on shoddy, fake or substandard food, according to the official Xinhua news agency.

headline: Personal Responsibility Underground
text: Veterans of many seasons navigating New York City’s intricate subway network had to smile at the latest idea for improving their daily commute. Howard Roberts Jr., president of New York City Transit, wants to decentralize and make the various lines  there are 23 or 24 depending on how you count  compete against each other like separate railroads.

headline: The Young Bob Dylan, Charismatic and Electric
text: These days, and not for the first time, it seems as if everyone wants to be Bob Dylan. There are the half-dozen impersonators in Todd Haynes’s “I’m Not There,” soon to be followed by John C. Reilly in a few scenes of “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story,” and behind them there are several generations of guitar strummers and harmonica blowers Dylanizing in the streets and subway tunnels of every major city in the world.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: U.S. Agency’s Slow Pace Endangers Foreign Aid
text: The Millennium Challenge Corporation, a federal agency set up almost four years ago to reinvent foreign aid, has taken far longer to help poor, well-governed countries than its supporters expected or its critics say is reasonable.

headline: Megan’s Parents Ask Trenton Not to Abolish Death Penalty
text: TRENTON, Dec. 6  Four days before the State Senate is to vote on a bill that would make New Jersey the first state in a generation to abolish the death penalty, the parents of the young girl whose rape and murder led to Megan’s Law urged legislators to oppose the measure.

headline: A Collector Gives the Gift of Modern Art
text: Until his death in March, Richard S. Zeisler kept such a low profile that few people in the art world beyond museum circles knew his name. A private investor who lived in Manhattan, he quietly amassed more than 110 works by 20th-century masters like Miró, Magritte, Max Beckmann and Francis Bacon.

headline: Romney Seeks to Defuse Concerns Over Mormon Faith
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 6  In a heavily anticipated speech addressing the religion issue that has dogged the campaign of Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate mentioned the word “Mormon” only once today in asking the nation not to reject his presidential candidacy based upon his faith.

headline: Crisscrossing the Stage, Highly Charged Moves From Familiar Pieces
text: How easily the memory plays tricks. Or does it? The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater made a nearly abstract piece of Talley Beatty’s classic “Road of the Phoebe Snow” on Wednesday night at City Center. And the company performed Ailey’s “River” as if it were anything but the sometimes pallid-seeming exercise in choreographing for a ballet troupe. Still, on Saturday afternoon Ailey’s “Night Creature” looked like its sly familiar self, even with Alicia J. Graf giving the work a slightly unfamiliar twist.

headline: Holding the Hungry Hostage
text: It is a travesty that the fates of some 35 million Americans who need food aid are tied to the farm bill, which comes up every five years. The House passed an inadequate version last summer, and the Senate has failed to advance its own. It is time to ask why feeding the hungry must include a trough for multibillion-dollar agribusiness.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $2,603,086.73

headline: An Imax and AMC Venture Will Expand 3-D Theaters
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6  Imax and AMC Entertainment are teaming up to open 100 Imax theaters, doubling the number of large-format 3-D outlets in the United States and adding momentum to Hollywood’s growing interest in the genre.

headline: Islam’s Silent Moderates
text: The woman and the man guilty of adultery or fornication, flog each of them with 100 stripes: Let no compassion move you in their case, in a matter prescribed by Allah, if you believe in Allah and the Last Day. (Koran 24:2)

headline: Smugglers Build an Underground World
text: TECATE, Calif., Dec. 6  The tunnel opening cut into the floor of a shipping container here drops three levels, each accessible by ladders, first a metal one and then two others fashioned from wood pallets. The tunnel stretches 1,300 feet to the south, crossing the Mexican border some 50 feet below ground and proceeding to a sky-blue office building in sight of the steel-plated border fence.

headline: Corrections
text: A sports article yesterday about the sluggish start of the Duke women’s basketball team under a new head coach, including a rare three-game losing streak, misstated the last time the Blue Devils lost four games in a row. It was 1994, not 1995.

headline: Murdoch Said to Have Plan for Shake-Up at Dow Jones
text: With a week to go before the News Corporation takes control of Dow Jones & Company, there are already management changes under way at the top of Dow Jones.

headline: From the Archives, Old Hits Dressed Up for the Season
text: Holidays are for memories, and for recording companies they’re also good reason to plunge into archives in order to rediscover and repackage hits, rarities, live recordings and thematic collections. Here the music critics of The New York Times review some of this year’s compilations and anthologies.

headline: Kidd Denounces Fuss Over a Sick Day and Says He Is Not Unhappy
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 6  About 30 reporters formed a semicircle in front of Jason Kidd at the Nets’ practice facility Thursday afternoon. Kidd surveyed the scene for several seconds and then raised an eyebrow.

headline: A-Rod’s Properties and Charity Suggest Some Stinginess
text: The veneer of Alex Rodriguez’s real estate empire of working-class housing is staged to disguise his inner Mr. Potter.

headline: Recorded on a Suspect’s Hidden MP3 Player, a Bronx Detective Faces 12 Perjury Charges
text: A veteran New York City police detective was arraigned on perjury charges in the Bronx yesterday after a suspect in an attempted murder case secretly recorded his interrogation with an MP3 player.

headline: With Family
text: “Dirty Laundry,” the second feature by the writer and director Maurice Jamal, is a back-to-your-roots film about a gay African-American named Sheldon (Rockmond Dunbar) who meets a young son (Aaron Grady Shaw) he didn’t know he had, and revisits his extended family in an intolerant Southern town he once fled in the name of self-respect.

headline: Bill Would Give Tax Break to Exonerated Prisoners
text: Seven months after his release from prison in 2001, after serving 15 years for a rape he did not commit, David Pope received $385,000 in compensation from the State of Texas and set out to rebuild his life: He rented an apartment, bought a car, helped his mother pay bills and traveled overseas for the first time.

headline: China Media Less Aggressive in Foreign Coverage
text: SHANGHAI  For the second time in as many months there was big trouble in an important allied country that sits on China’s borders, with huge crowds demonstrating, bombs exploding, opposition leaders being arrested and demonstrators killed.

headline: Murray Klein, Who Helped Build Zabar’s Into Food Destination, Dies at 84
text: Murray Klein, who helped transform Zabar’s from a typical Jewish delicatessen on the Upper West Side of Manhattan into a culinary and cultural landmark, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: The Staggering Cost of a Long War
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Video Posted Online Poses a Riddle for Police
text: The amateur video lasts just a few minutes. It shows a group of young people standing over a man seated in a New York subway car, taunting him, waving a plastic bottle in his face and eventually striking him with their hands as he cowers under their blows.

headline: Britain: Terror Detention Plan Draws Fire
text: The government again sought the power to jail terrorism suspects without charge for up to 42 days, and the proposal brought immediate pledges of defeat from opposition parties and outrage from civil rights groups. Home Secretary Jacqui Smith, left, said the existing 28-day limit did not give the authorities enough time to investigate terrorism cases, which can involve unraveling false identities, tracking evidence in multiple languages and deciphering links to international terrorist networks. She also said, “There is a serious and sustained threat from terrorism.” The proposed new limits must go through Parliament.

headline: A New Bush Tack on North Korea
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  President Bush, directly engaging the man he publicly called a “tyrant,” wrote a letter to North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-il, in which he held out the prospect of normalized relations with the United States if North Korea fully disclosed its nuclear programs and dismantled its nuclear reactor, administration officials said Thursday.

headline: Congress Drops Measure on Hate Crimes
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Congressional Democrats today dropped their effort to tie a Pentagon policy measure to an expanded definition of federal hate crimes covering sexual orientation, ending chances that the long-stalled hate crime measure would clear Congress this year.

headline: Panama: Move for Chinese in Schools
text: The National Assembly has taken a step toward making the teaching of Mandarin compulsory in all schools, the BBC reported. Supporters of the bill, which has received conditional approval in the first of three debates, say increasing the number of Chinese speakers would help increase Panama’s competitiveness in the world, the report said. It said the proposed legislation set out a time frame of 10 years for Mandarin to be taught in all schools. Chinese teachers would be allowed to immigrate to help train local teachers.

headline: With Bonds Set to Appear Today, Former Prosecutor Expects a Trial
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6  Kevin V. Ryan, the former United States attorney here who helped lead the investigation into steroids in sports, said he expected Barry Bonds to push his defense all the way to a trial, where he would face an array of former associates, ballplayers and medical experts.

headline: Passaic: Police Defend Shooting
text: The police said yesterday that they were justified in shooting 20 times at an unarmed woman who led them on a car chase through northern New Jersey. The woman, Michelle M. Moleti, 34, was at St. Joseph’s Regional Medical Center in Paterson, recovering from six gunshot wounds, said James Avigliano, the Passaic County prosecutor. He said officers fired at the woman when she tried to run them over. The officers who fired the shots were from Clifton, where the chase began, according to Clifton Detective Capt. Robert Rowan. Mr. Avigliano said charges would be filed against Ms. Moleti.

headline: The Props Can Burst, and That’s the Point
text: This much might be said for the “Gazillion Bubble Show”: It is unusual.

headline: 105 Killed in China Mine Explosion
text: SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 7  A gas explosion at a coal mine in northern China late Wednesday killed at least 105 people in one of the country’s worst mining accidents this year, the official Xinhua news agency said Friday.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: The Gospel of Judas: A Word From the Translators
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about health care proposals offered by some presidential candidates referred incorrectly to Massachusetts residents who might be exempt from the state’s mandated health insurance plan. The state has estimated that up to 20 percent of all uninsured residents could be exempt — not 20 percent of all residents. (The percentage of residents who have no insurance is estimated at between 6 and 10 percent.)

headline: Strike Costs Become Test for Hosts of Talk Shows
text: The strike by the Writers Guild has shut down television’s favorite late-night shows, leaving the hosts to spend their days calling their agents to check out the latest rumors  and calling their financial advisers to determine how much the strike is costing them.

headline: A Devil of a Christmas
text: Do you know how you behave when you’re drunk, I mean, really drunk? If the answer is yes, then you’ve never been that drunk, since the curse and kindness of vast quantities of alcohol is that they obliterate self-awareness.

headline: Searching for Clues to a Young Killer’s Motivation
text: OMAHA, Dec. 6  The authorities on Thursday scoured surveillance tapes and studied text messages, voice mail and letters that a gunman sent before he stepped from a third-floor elevator in a shopping mall here and killed eight people.

headline: Strangers in a Land That’s Not So Strange
text: Stranded in the Israeli desert, the eight Egyptian members of the Alexandria Ceremonial Police Orchestra look a bit like a joke in search of a punch line. If “The Band’s Visit” were any other kind of film — a little more pat, say, and rather less knowing — these eight souls might quickly transform into mere props in a small-scale sermon about Middle East man’s humanity to Middle East man, minus the politics of course.

headline: Obstacles to Changing Old Ways of Subways
text: The “Wet Paint” signs were still up yesterday at the 14th Street station of the Eighth Avenue subway line. Work crews had given the station’s orange columns a fresh coat, in time for subway honchos to hold a news conference there to announce an experiment in making the trains run on time.

headline: Stylish Surroundings Are Shattered by Killings
text: OMAHA, Dec. 6 — To many people who live around Omaha, the Von Maur department store is a special destination for shopping, a retailer and respite at once, offering serenity along with its upscale goods in the Westroads Mall, the largest and busiest in Nebraska.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in The Arts yesterday about the photographer Jim Krantz and his views on the use of some of his pictures made for Marlboro advertisements by the artist Richard Prince referred incorrectly to the copyrights for his pictures. While the copyrights for his Marlboro photographs are owned by Philip Morris, Mr. Krantz retains the copyrights to most of his work; his clients do not generally own the rights.

headline: As Knicks Comfort Teammate, They Grow Closer
text: On an icy December morning in Coney Island, in an old brick church, the Knicks stood shoulder to shoulder across the pulpit, a fractured team no more.

headline: Arapahoe Basin Ski Area
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Sunday about improvements in Malawi’s agricultural production, using erroneous information from a study by researchers at Imperial College London and Michigan State University, misstated the size of recent corn harvests. (Because of an editing error, the article also included the wrong figures.) The increase in production was in millions of metric tons, not billions. (Estimates show that corn production rose to 2.7 million metric tons in 2006 and 3.4 million in 2007 from 1.2 million in 2005.)

headline: Electoral Revision Misses June Ballot
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6  A Republican-sponsored ballot measure that would have changed the way the state apportions its 55 electoral votes will not be eligible for the June primary ballot, its sponsors said on Thursday, in spite of promises a few weeks ago that the initiative would get enough money and signatures to do so.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Nov. 28 about a hearing on whether WWOR, a New Jersey-based TV station owned by Fox Television Stations, covers New Jersey sufficiently to merit renewal of its broadcast license referred incorrectly to a WWOR video camera that recorded the proceedings. Although there was a piece of masking tape on the camera, it was not in fact covering the letters NY. Fox says that the station’s cameras are labeled My9 and do not have the letters NY on them. (Fox uses “My9NY” as a slogan and as partof its Web site address.) (Go to Article)

headline: Corrections
text: A music review in Weekend last Friday about the contemporary-classical ensemble Tactus, at the Manhattan School of Music, misstated the date of composition of a piece that was performed, Alban Berg’s Chamber Concerto for Violin, Piano and 13 Winds. It was completed in 1925, not 1935. (Go to Article)

headline: Port Authority and Airlines Offer Ways to Ease Delays at New York Airports
text: Trying to head off threats by the federal government to reduce flights at the three New York-area airports, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, along with airline industry executives and local transportation officials, unveiled 100 recommendations yesterday that are intended to unlock congestion and accommodate more traffic.

headline: Corzine Seeks End to Monitoring of N.J. Troopers
text: TRENTON, Dec. 7  Gov. Jon S. Corzine said Friday that he would ask the federal government to halt its oversight of the New Jersey State Police because of sufficient reforms made in the eight years since its troopers were found to be engaging in racial profiling at traffic stops.

headline: Under Early Quebec Snow, a Jewel for Skiers
text: IT was the day after Thanksgiving but it was no time for leftovers. There was fresh powder to be had, untracked remains of a 15-inch snowfall. The evergreens were heavy with snow, making a dash through the glades a challenge of both reflexes and planning. Brush against the wrong tree limb and a cascade of snow cloaked jacket, hat, gloves and goggles.

headline: Romney, Eye on Evangelicals, Defends His Faith
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 6  Mitt Romney asked the nation on Thursday not to reject his presidential candidacy because of his religion, assuring evangelical Christians and other religious voters that his values matched theirs in a speech that used the word “Mormon” only once.

headline: Employers Added 94,000 Jobs in November
text: The economy added 94,000 jobs last month, the Labor Department said today, a sign of resilience that may ease fears of a recession but open the door for more rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.

headline: Senate Blocks Energy Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Brushing aside a veto threat from the White House, the House passed a package of energy measures on Thursday that includes a 40 percent increase in fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the United States. But the measure stalled today in the Senate, as expected.

headline: Christmas in Times Square, With Buses in the Manger
text: What would Jesus say about “Black Nativity,” the Classical Theater of Harlem’s new variation on Langston Hughes’s malleable 20th-century retelling of the original Christmas story? With Christian and seasonal generosity, let’s begin by pointing out the unmistakable spirit of joy at the heart of this production, which takes the 1961 work that Hughes called a gospel song play and transplants it to Times Square in 1973, a change that allows Mary and Joseph to wander through the neighborhood at its seediest, taking shelter in the Port Authority Bus Terminal instead of a manger.

headline: Stiff Penalty Recommended
text: The Southeast Missouri State women’s basketball team should lose all 79 of its victories during the four-year tenure of the former coach B. J. Smith, an N.C.A.A. committee has ruled. The Committee on Infractions also decided that Southeast should have its 2006 N.C.A.A. tournament appearance taken away, according to a letter released yesterday. The university is appealing the ruling and has asked for a full hearing.

headline: 2 Players Suspended for Acquiring Steroids and HGH
text: Major League Baseball yesterday suspended two players linked to the acquisition of performance-enhancing drugs, perhaps creating a template for players who could be named by George J. Mitchell when he issues his report on the use of banned substances in baseball, likely by the end of next week.

headline: All the Makings of a Carnival, Except the Fun
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  As if there was any doubt that Congress was on the verge of devolving into a carnival atmosphere, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader, on Thursday proposed doing cartwheels down the center aisle of the Senate chamber to draw attention to Republican efforts to block legislation.

headline: Park City Mountain Resort
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Lies, Guilt, Stiff Upper Lips
text: Joe Wright’s “Atonement” begins in the endlessly photogenic, thematically pregnant interwar period. The setting is a rambling old British country estate where trim dinner jackets and shimmering silk dresses are worn; cigarettes are smoked with sharp inhalations that create perfect concavities of cheekbone; and the air is thick with class tension and sexual anxiety. Heavy clouds are gathering on the geopolitical horizon, which lends a special poignancy to the domestic comings and goings. This charged, hardly unfamiliar atmosphere provides, in the first section of the film, some decent, suspenseful fun, a rush of incident and implication. Boxy cars rolling up the drive; whispers of scandal and family secrets; coitus interruptus in the library, all set to the implacable rhythm of typewriter keys.

headline: Not Just a Summer Romance
text: SUE AND JOE CANALE’S new beach house in Ocean City, N.J., handsomely sided in gray shingles and just steps from the Boardwalk, rises four floors above sea level. The view, they say, is always changing. Sometimes, whitecaps churn. Sometimes, the ocean is a fuzzy pink blanket. Sometimes, lightning flashes above the sea and reflects on the water.

headline: A Former Soprano Makes Her Singing Debut
text: IT is Wednesday afternoon, but things are doornail dead in Aida Turturro’s empty dressing room at the Ambassador Theater, where she is, at a robust 45, one shaky week into her Broadway musical debut as the prison matron Mama Morton in “Chicago.”

headline: Crimes of the Naïve, Superficial Heart
text: Nothing in Paul Schrader’s film “The Walker” can quite match its delicious opening scene of sniping repartee over canasta among three Washington grandes dames and their pet gay playmate. Lynn (Kristin Scott Thomas), Natalie (Lauren Bacall) and Abigail (Lily Tomlin) constitute what may be the screen’s most formidable threesome of jaded, dirt-dishing socialites since “The Women.”

headline: Winning Over Portland With One of Its Own
text: When they knew each other in the San Francisco Bay Area, and later worked together at the N.B.A. office in New York, Mike Golub could not muster up the courage to ask Cheri White for a date. Last June, he did the next best thing. He recruited her to help the once-revered and recently reviled Trail Blazers win back the city of Portland.

headline: Lack of Donated Copters Harms Darfur Effort, U.N. Leader Says
text: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 6  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Thursday that the refusal of countries to donate helicopters for the joint African Union-United Nations peacekeeping force in Darfur was endangering the scheduled start of operations three weeks from now.

headline: Six to Enter Hall
text: Robert Byron, the first driver to win a Nascar points championship, is among a diverse group to be inducted into the International Motorsports Hall of Fame. The six-person class of 2008 also includes Art Arfons, Bill Jenkins, Frank Kurtis, Everett Owens and Ralph Seagraves.

headline: Corrections
text: A theater review on Nov. 13 about “The Runner Stumbles,” at the Beckett Theater, misspelled the surname of the composer of the play’s music. He is Joseph Trapanese, not Trapenese.

headline: A Volleyball Vision 14 Years in the Making at St. John’s
text: The St. John’s women’s volleyball team was losing more than a match in front of its home crowd last weekend. The Red Storm appeared to be squandering an opportunity to reach the Round of 16 in the 64-team N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time.

headline: The Dreams and Horrors of the Ties That Bind
text: The supple team of enchanters who inhabit “Au Revoir Parapluie,” James Thiérrée’s loving performance piece about the circus that is the human family, never reaches the end of its rope. In this artful and affecting hybrid of dance, slapstick, music and acrobatics, which runs through Dec. 16 at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, rope is an endlessly mutable medium, as fluid and surprising as life itself.

headline: STS-122: An Eclectic, Multinational Crew
text: The all-male crew for the current shuttle mission to the International Space Station is remarkably international in its composition  and has remarkably little experience in space. The mission commander, Cmdr. Stephen N. Frick of the Navy, has flown just once before, in 2002. Col. Rex J. Walheim also has just one mission under his belt  the same Atlantis mission in 2002 as Commander Frick. The other three Americans on board are rookies.

headline: A Career Circling Fame and the Drain
text: As much the chronicle of an era as of a band, “The Holy Modal Rounders ... Bound to Lose” casts an affectionate eye on the kind of hedonism no one is meant to survive.

headline: Postcard Perfection in the Cascades
text: DOWNTOWN Sisters, Ore., with its 1880s-style buildings, resembles the Old West. But most of its horses are embroidered on shirts, and if the goods sold behind its swinging doors are any indication, stagecoach stops once sold French pastries.

headline: Lund Triumphs Again
text: Zach Lund edged his fellow American Eric Bernotas to win the skeleton event on the first day of the Bobsleigh and Skeleton World Cup in Park City, Utah. Lund finished in 1 minute 38.41 seconds, beating Bernotas by .25 of a second. Lund has won the event in Park City two straight years. Michelle Kelly of Canada won the women’s event in 1:40.43.

headline: Corrections
text: An article yesterday about an attack by Israel on Hamas as the militant group prepared to fire a mortar shell into Israel included incorrect statistics from the Israeli military in some editions about the number of rockets and mortar shells fired into Israel by Hamas so far this year. The monthly average before June, when Hamas took over the Gaza Strip, was 108, not 48. The monthly average after June was 248, not 240. The article also described incompletely the attacks for the year to date. The total of more than 2,000 is for attacks with rockets and mortars, not just with rockets.

headline: Some Gains, but Stores Are Worried
text: Cold weather, deep discounts and a quirk in the calendar rescued retailers from what threatened to be a dreary November, but it might not be enough to save the holiday shopping season.

headline: Some Needing Mortgage Aid Won’t Get It
text: When Jirina Koy heard that President Bush was announcing a freeze yesterday on mortgage interest rates, the Stockton, Calif., homeowner felt a flicker of hope.

headline: Some Airlines to  Offer In-Flight Internet Service
text: Passengers may soon hear a new in-flight announcement: “You can now log on.”

headline: Amy Winehouse Draws 6 Grammy Nominations
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6  Amy Winehouse, the British soul singer whose battles with addiction have turned her into a tabloid regular, drew six Grammy nominations, including nods for the four marquee categories, today as the contenders for the 50th annual awards ceremony were announced.

headline: Mental Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Very Late Comeback
text: Part tribute, part musical mystery, “ ’Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris” shines an overdue spotlight on a great who got away.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A River Town That Grant Once Called Home
text: THE route to Galena, Ill., can twist through steep hills and ravines strewn with the bones of lead-mining boomtowns on shoulderless roads that change names at a whim — when they have names at all.

headline: Coke Promotes Itself in a New Virtual World
text: COCA-COLA lovers will have a new place to hang out starting today, and it is an island on the Internet that is shaped like a Coke bottle.

headline: Bigger Cars, Flip-Up Seats, Poetry: How Riders Would Run a Subway
text: The bubble. Doing something to keep the bubble from ruining people’s days would be the first thing on Melanie Muccio’s to-do list if she were in charge of the No. 7 line.

headline: Age of Splendor Expands
text: The galleries of 19th-century European painting and sculpture are the Metropolitan Museum’s most popular attraction. And after they were closed for renovation in August, some very sad scenes ensued. Tourists expecting Monets and Renoirs by the roomful left the museum distraught, hopes dashed. Met regulars who count on having certain things just so  Cézanne’s “Card Players” right there, in that gallery, on that wall, forever  wandered about in a daze, their coordinates thrown off.

headline: The Name Game
text: YOU’VE found the right area for your vacation home. You’ve finally found the right property and have gone through the purchase process. Your household is in agreement that the porch needs new screens and that the kitchen must be updated. One decision remains: Should you give your charming beach cottage, farmhouse or mountain chalet a name? Or, if it already has one, should you keep it?

headline: Giants Find 3rd Receiver to Be an Elusive Catch
text: David Tyree has been a Giants receiver for five years. He caught his first pass of 2007 against the Chicago Bears on Sunday, during the final drive of the season’s 12th game. He caught his second pass four plays later, helping the Giants toward a game-winning touchdown.

headline: Lawmakers Back Limits on Interrogation Tactics
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  In a sharp rebuke to White House counterterrorism policy, a Congressional conference committee has voted to outlaw the harsh interrogation techniques used by the Central Intelligence Agency against suspected high-level terrorists.

headline: Two More Schools to Close
text: The Department of Education said yesterday that it would close two elementary schools  Public School 156, the Benjamin Banneker School, in the Bronx, and Public School 304, Casimir Pulaski, in Brooklyn  after both received F’s on the school report cards released last month. The announcement brings to 10 the number of schools scheduled to close so far, with a handful of additional closing announcements expected by early next week. The schools will close at the end of the school year.

headline: Grammy Nominations Include Six for Winehouse
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 — Amy Winehouse, the British soul singer whose continued troubles with substance abuse have turned her into a tabloid regular, drew six Grammy nominations, including nods in the four premier categories, as the contenders for the 50th annual awards ceremony were announced here on Thursday.

headline: Getting Help for Bullpen Moves to Yankees’ Front Burner
text: NASHVILLE, Dec. 6  The Yankees left the winter meetings Thursday with one new relief pitcher and a lot of public optimism about their pitching prospects. But young starters need to be supported by strong relievers, and the Yankees’ bullpen is a free-for-all before closer Mariano Rivera.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,877 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Chamberlain Says Prospect of Starting or Pitching Relief is ‘Win-Win’
text: Pitcher Joba Chamberlain is reaping the rewards of his sensational first season with the Yankees. He is doing nothing, or almost nothing.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: When a Public Offering Goes Bad Down Under
text: The founder of the company took in more than half a billion dollars by selling most of his stock to the public. Three weeks later, the company fell apart.

headline: Uganda: Ebola Outbreak Kills Medics
text: Health workers are among the dead in an Ebola outbreak, spreading panic among doctors and nurses needed to help treat victims of the highly contagious disease, officials said. Experts say that the Ebola strain in the outbreak is a new one and that the typical Ebola symptoms were not always present, slowing diagnosis. Doctors and nurses did not know at first what they were facing, so they failed to protect themselves, according to Jane Alisemera, the lawmaker who represents Bundibugyo District, the center of the outbreak. “We are facing a crisis in health care here,” she said. According to the Ministry of Health’s latest figures, Bundibugyo has 93 suspected cases of Ebola virus, among them 22 deaths. Four health workers were among the dead. The outbreak began Aug. 20, but the disease was not confirmed as a new strain of Ebola until Nov. 29. Infection control doctors from the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently arrived to help local officials contain the outbreak.

headline: Another New York Attorney General Starts a Wall Street Crusade
text: IT’S beginning to feel a lot like Spitzer.

headline: Elevation of a Murdoch Son Suggests Plan of Succession
text: In the clearest sign yet of a succession plan at the News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch’s younger son, James, will step down as chief executive of British Sky Broadcasting to take on a broader role within his father’s media empire, executives said last night.

headline: No Penalty for Renault
text: Renault was not penalized despite being found guilty of having confidential information about its Formula One rival McLaren. In September, McLaren was fined $100 million for using confidential data from Ferrari. In the latest allegations in Formula One’s spy scandal, the World Motor Sport Council summoned Renault officials to face accusations that the team had unauthorized access to details on McLaren’s cars.

headline: Medicare Oxygen Benefit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Manhattan: Judge Awards Legal Fees
text: Ending a long fight over legal fees for administering a $1.25 billion settlement to Holocaust survivors, United States District Court Judge Frederic Block awarded $3,095,325 yesterday to a lawyer in the case, Burt Neuborne. He and other lawyers had worked pro bono in the 1990s litigating a suit against Swiss banks, accusing them of looting millions of dollars of Jewish assets. A judge placed Mr. Neuborne in charge of follow-up litigation. In 2005, Mr. Neuborne submitted the hours he worked in that phase for payment without setting a price. When two other lawyers in the case opposed any payment to him, Mr. Neuborne valued his services at $5.7 million but discounted the bill to $4.1 million. Later he withdrew the discount. A court magistrate recommended the final figure, Judge Block said.

headline: Philippine Court Convicts 14 in Kidnapping Case
text: MANILA, Dec. 6  A Philippine court convicted 14 members of the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group today in the 2001 kidnapping of 20 people off an island resort, including three Americans, two of whom were eventually killed.

headline: Shuttle Mission Is Delayed by Problems With Fuel Sensors
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 6  NASA officials delayed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis at least until Saturday after canceling Thursday’s attempt because of problems with a pair of fuel sensors.

headline: ‘Preppy Killer’ Companion Is Released From Jail to Get Drug Treatment
text: The companion of the convicted murderer Robert E. Chambers Jr. was released from jail to a drug treatment program yesterday, with a promise from prosecutors that if all went well, she would be spared additional jail time for her October arrest on drug charges.

headline: White Plains: Kerik Lawyer on Offense
text: The defense lawyer for Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, has accused federal prosecutors of trying to taint the jury pool in his case and said they “irreparably harmed” his ability to get a fair trial. The federal prosecutors, Perry A. Carbone and Elliott B. Jacobson, called the allegations by the lawyer, Kenneth M. Breen, “entirely baseless and unfounded.” The exchange came out in court papers filed by Mr. Breen on Wednesday. In the papers, he asked the judge in the case, Stephen C. Robinson of United States District Court, to order the prosecutors to give him more information so he could respond to the government’s request that Judge Robinson consider disqualifying him from the case. The prosecutors asked the judge to consider the move because they said Mr. Breen could be called as a witness to testify about what the government contends was obstruction by Mr. Kerik in an earlier state case. Judge Robinson ruled yesterday that Mr. Breen was not entitled to the additional information, but he has not ruled on whether to disqualify him.

headline: Heavenly Ski Resort
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Bless the Beasts and Children
text: A fantastic bestiary inhabits “The Golden Compass,” prowling and flapping and slithering and fluttering. The animals, most of which are called daemons and are manifestations of the human soul, hover at the side of their people and near the story’s edge, where their coos and barks mix with the ambient clatter and clang. Every so often, an animal leaps forward, its fur raised in alarm, its feathers fanned in flight. And because these are no ordinary animals, they also offer words of comfort, advice, warning. In this otherworldly realm, humans have no dominion over these creatures, yet they are not merely equals, either. They are one.

headline: Corrections
text: An article and a subheading in some editions on Monday about the retrial of David Lemus in connection with a 1990 homicide at the Palladium nightclub referred imprecisely to the prosecution’s case. The theory that there were three gunmen is not in fact a new one. The transcript of Mr. Lemus’s 1992 trial shows that the prosecution referred to a possible third gunman in closing arguments.

headline: Former Chief Will Forfeit $418 Million
text: In one of the largest corporate pay give-backs ever, William W. McGuire, the former chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, has agreed to forfeit at least $418 million to settle claims related to back-dated stock options.

headline: Help Buying Clothes for Her Children, After She Saved Herself
text: The scent of marijuana greeted visitors as they entered the hallway leading to Samonia Malloy’s apartment in a Brooklyn housing complex. That environment is not the most appropriate one for Ms. Malloy, 25, who recently graduated from a drug rehabilitation program, as she tries to stay drug-free and raise her children. But she is determined to persevere.

headline: Package Bomb Kills 1 in Paris
text: PARIS, Dec. 6  An explosion from a bomb in a package delivered to a law office in the heart of Paris killed one person and seriously wounded another on Thursday, the police said.

headline: Poll Finds Hispanics Returning to Earlier Preference for Democrats
text: Gains made by Republicans among Hispanic voters in the presidential elections of 2000 and 2004 have been erased over the past year, with Hispanics returning to earlier levels of strong preference for the Democratic Party, a survey released yesterday by the Pew Hispanic Center in Washington shows.

headline: Corrections
text: A sports article on Tuesday about the death of Donald Marbury Sr., the father of Knicks guard Stephon Marbury, misstated his age. He was 68, not 69. (An article in some copies yesterday about Marbury’s thanking his fans for their support repeated the error.)

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: From Jail to Dreamland, With Its Sadist in Briefs
text: By turns clever, impassioned, incoherent and silly, “Revolver,” the fourth film by the writer and director Guy Ritchie, is a macho parable of a fallen man striving for grace.

headline: Art in Review
text: PAUL MCCARTHY’S

headline: Murray Klein, Long the Public Face of Zabar’s, Dies at 84
text: Murray Klein, who helped transform Zabar’s from a typical Jewish delicatessen on the Upper West Side of Manhattan into a culinary and cultural landmark, died today in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Detainee’s Loyalty to bin Laden Is at Issue in Hearing
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba, Dec. 6  For several years, a slight Yemeni detainee with a wispy beard, Salim Ahmed Hamdan, has been at the center of legal battles challenging the Bush administration’s Guantánamo policies. He was a driver for Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan, and his lawyers have cast him as little more than a low-level employee, a simple man who was just trying to support his wife and daughters.

headline: In Mortgage Plan, Lenders Set Terms
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  At least one thing is clear about President Bush’s plan to help people trapped by the mortgage meltdown: it is an industry-led plan, not a government bailout.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Lundqvist Lets His Guard and Team Down
text: The bounces looked unusual all game to Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist. Shots were careening off his pads, directly to Toronto’s goal scorers. On top of his game until last weekend, Lundqvist watched everything turn on its head last night and then watched the third period from the bench, a baseball cap shading his sullen expression.

headline: Riverhead: Brothers Convicted
text: The third of three brothers was convicted yesterday of gang assault in the beating of a veteran city firefighter returning from a Sept. 11 memorial service last year. On Wednesday, Darrell and Darian Taylor, 26, who are twins, were found guilty of first-degree assault in the attack in Mastic Beach on Firefighter Richard Berkhout, a 13-year veteran. Yesterday, their half brother, Christopher Robinson, who was tried separately, was found guilty in Suffolk County Supreme Court. Firefighter Berkhout, 47, was walking with his wife in Mastic Beach on the evening of Sept. 11, 2006, and yelled to the men to slow their car. The men got out and beat him, prosecutors said.

headline: Many Children Struggling After '05 Storms
text: At least 46,600 children along the Gulf Coast are still struggling with mental health problems and other serious aftereffects of 2005 hurricanes, according to a new study by the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University and the Children’s Health Fund.

headline: International Law Matters
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shubert Considers a Deal to Sell Theaters’ Air Rights
text: Now that Broadway shows have gone on again, theater owners in Midtown Manhattan have turned their attention back to another way of making money: selling the rights to the air above their roofs.

headline: Forgotten Suitcases, Emotional Baggage
text: TO a child a forgotten trunk in an attic opens the door to a beguiling fantasy world where a castoff shawl can be transformed into a king’s robe, a superhero’s cape or a genie’s flying carpet.

headline: House Sets Higher Goal for Vehicle Fuel Efficiency
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Brushing aside a veto threat from the White House, the House passed a package of energy measures on Thursday that includes a 40 percent increase in fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks sold in the United States.

headline: Queens: Man Arrested in Killing
text: A 23-year-old man suspected in the 2004 shooting death of an off-duty correction officer has been arrested in Ecuador, where he was in a hospital being treated for a gunshot wound, the authorities said yesterday. The man, George Saravanos, who the police said would be brought back to New York today to face charges, is suspected in the killing of the correction officer, Richard Ross, who was shot in a botched robbery attempt outside a hotel in Flushing at 2:30 a.m. on Dec. 4, 2004. Investigators began to suspect Mr. Saravanos was hiding in Ecuador after they learned in 2005 that his father, Andonas Saravanos, was wiring money there. George Saravanos’s arrest by United States marshals in Ecuador was disclosed by the police in New York City.

headline: Cellphones Challenge Poll Sampling
text: With more American households giving up their old-fashioned land lines and using cellphones for all calls, public opinion researchers are facing a challenge of how to make sure they are getting representative samples when conducting polls.

headline: Vinokourov Is Sanctioned
text: Alexandre Vinokourov was barred from cycling for one year for doping. Vinokourov, from Kazakhstan, was barred by his country’s cycling federation, Vinokourov’s former Astana team said in a statement on its Web site. Vinokourov and his Astana teammates were forced out of this year’s Tour de France when he tested positive for a banned blood transfusion.

headline: Detained Pakistani Seeks to Revive Judiciary Cause
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Dec. 6  The leader of the lawyers’ movement here, worried that the cause of an independent judiciary is foundering as elections approach, has written to his colleagues from detention outlining a strategy to keep the flame alive.

headline: Man Convicted in Club Death Is Acquitted at Second Trial
text: A man who spent nearly 14 years behind bars for killing a bouncer at the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan was acquitted yesterday by a jury at a second trial, in a case in which he claimed that he and another man had been wrongly convicted while the real killers went free.

headline: Mets’ Prospects Maturing in the Dominican Republic
text: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 6  After being frisked by pistol-toting security guards, fans passing through the turnstiles at Estadio Quisqueya are greeted by vendors selling the essentials of any authentic baseball experience: empanadas, cold Presidente and breath mints.

headline: The Mandate Muddle
text: Imagine this: It’s the summer of 2009, and President Barack Obama is about to unveil his plan for universal health care. But his health policy experts have done the math, and they’ve concluded that the plan really needs to include a requirement that everyone have health insurance  a so-called mandate.

headline: Distorted, Distorting and All-Too Human
text: The newborn with the shuffling eyes and bulbous wet head lies on a table, cooing and cackling. Less a bundle of joy than an emblem of dread, the baby arrives in David Lynch’s first feature, “Eraserhead” (1977), like the misshapen question mark it vaguely resembles. Could it really be the spawn of Henry Spencer (Jack Nance), the sad-sack factoryworker with the finger-in-the-socket shock of hair? The baby, nominally the result of Henry’s liaison with Mary X (Charlotte Stewart), haunts this amazing, still mysterious work as a manifestation — and apparent consequence — of distorted, distorting all-too human desires.

headline: Europe Holds Key Rate Steady, but Britain Opts for a Cut
text: FRANKFURT, Dec. 6  The European Central Bank, caught between fears of rising inflation and subsiding economic growth, walked a middle ground on Thursday, leaving interest rates unchanged.

headline: Three Stars Embracing One Sun-Warped Vision
text: The problem with most all-star aggregations is a clash of competing egos or mismatched agendas. Not so with the trio appearing at the Blue Note this week. Composed of the guitarist Bill Frisell, the bassist Ron Carter and the drummer Paul Motian, this is an all-star group that inhabits an atmosphere of accord. Instead of sparks it emits a soft, warm glow.

headline: California: Cardinal Won’t File Attack Report
text: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles told the police that he was assaulted by a man who shouted angry statements about the scandal of sexual abuse by members of the clergy but does not plan to file a report. The archbishop, Cardinal Roger Mahony, first reported the attack to fellow priests at a gathering in October, but not the police. After new reports of the alleged attack came out this week, the police contacted him. A spokeswoman for the Los Angeles Police Department, Lt. Roger Mora, said Cardinal Mahoney told the police by telephone that he had been dressed in a sports shirt and slacks on an evening in July when a man walked toward him outside Our Lady of the Angels Cathedral downtown, asking in a threatening tone if he was the cardinal. Cardinal Mahony, 71, told the police that the man pushed him to the ground and kicked him before running away.

headline: City Keeping Water Rate From Rising
text: Water customers in New York City got a break yesterday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Christine Quinn, the City Council speaker, announced an agreement that would allow the city to forgo a midyear water rate increase that could have been as high as 18 percent.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Turner Watercolor Fetches Millions

headline: Seasonal Debate Rages Over Loveliest Branches
text: DALLAS, Ore.  A battle is being waged for the heart of the American Christmas tree customer, pitting the real evergreen against the once-lowly artificial tree.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Week in Review on Sunday about an increase in the Senate’s use of the filibuster referred incorrectly to the American Enterprise Institute, one of whose members commented on the filibuster. The institute is a conservative research group based in Washington; it is not a nonpartisan group. (The error was repeated on Wednesday in an article comparing the health care proposals of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.)

headline: Putting Off the Pain of Grief by Starting on a Journey
text: For most of its 85 minutes “Grace Is Gone,” a small, tender film about contemporary parenthood in wartime, carries off a delicate balancing act. How do you portray the tragic effects of the Iraq war on the home front without sounding shrilly partisan or evasively neutral? How do you avoid jingoism, cynicism or mawkishness?

headline: Deputy Mayor Leaving to Run Bloomberg L.P.
text: Daniel L. Doctoroff was to have been the Robert Moses of the Bloomberg era, a bold visionary who would guide a sweeping revitalization of New York and put to rest the notion that the age of building big had ended.

headline: Somerville: Coach Guilty of Sex Assault
text: Jurors in Somerset County yesterday convicted the former coach of a high school girls basketball team of sexually assaulting a player but acquitted her of the most serious charge, aggravated sexual assault. Pamela Balogh, the former coach at Immaculata High School in Somerville, was found guilty on four counts: aggravated criminal sexual contact, sexual assault, child endangerment and criminal sexual contact. Ms. Balogh faces up to 10 years in prison when she is sentenced. A sentencing date was not set. According to prosecutors, Ms. Balogh had a relationship with a student that went on for more than nine months, beginning in 2004 when the girl was 15. Ms. Balogh resigned in 2005.

headline: Passionate Punches
text: Not since his nice-guy turns in “Thelma & Louise” (1991) and “Free Willy” (1993) has Michael Madsen, ever the designated heavy, played someone as huggable as Sean Kelleher, the Irish ex-boxer and tragic hero of “Strength and Honor.”

headline: Theater Listings
text: 500 CLOWN “Think of Buster Keaton and Chaplin, not Bozo,” said Adrian Danzig, the producing artistic director of 500 Clown, describing the performance style of his Chicago-based company. “Clown is a totally dirty word — no one uses clown in their title,” he said. “It sets you up to defend that you’re not doing children’s work.”

headline: Chip Reese, High-Stakes Card Champion, Is Dead at 56
text: Chip Reese, whose mix of intellect, poise and nerve propelled him to renowned eminence among the minuscule club of humans who convene to wager millions on poker games, died Tuesday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 56.

headline: Does King Henrik Need a Break?
text: There are always a few games during the course of a season that need to get filed into the “Please Disregard, Move on to Next Game” folder. And make no mistake, the Rangers game last night against the Maple Leafs fits that description. Team wide, there were breakdowns or a lack of spark in virtually every area, and Toronto seemed to pounce on every opportunity.

headline: Developing Dialogue
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Tanker Spills Oil Off South Korea
text: SEOUL — A Hong Kong-registered oil tanker leaked 10,810 tons, or 66,000 barrels, of crude oil off South Korea's stormy west coast on Friday, in what was estimated to be the nation's largest maritime oil spill, officials said.

headline: Art Basel Miami
text: Serious art lovers can still find moments of transcendence at the contemporary art fair.

headline: Sabres Shellacked in L.A.
text: Playing in front of a goaltender making his N.H.L. debut, the Los Angeles Kings, challenged for offense since their big line went dry, erupted for an octet of goals in an 8-2 win over Buffalo. Mike Cammalleri opened the scoring, with his second in two games. Cammalleri had had the early goal-scoring lead in the N.H.L., but hit a drought and was switched off a line with Dustin Brown and Anze Kopitar. Now he appears to be back, and the line is coming back to life. Brown had two goals in the beat-down of Buffalo.

headline: Week 14 Fantasy Advice: Your Direct Pipeline
text: While I wish that all I did 24/7 was write about fantasy football, sadly, I have another real job (advertising creative director), one that, because they pay me actual American currency, often requires more attention than I’d like to give it. Translation: I’ve been living at work night and day this week and, therefore, am unable to give you good people a Week 14 Playoff start-bench edition.

headline: Delta Financial to File for Bankruptcy
text: The subprime mortgage lender Delta Financial said Thursday that it planned to file soon for bankruptcy protection, after losses mounted and an agreement to obtain financing fell apart.

headline: Florida Fund Reopens, and $1.1 Billion Is Withdrawn
text: Florida’s state-run investment pool reopened, and local governments quickly withdrew more than $1.1 billion. The pool was frozen last week amid a run that withdrew almost $10 billion because of worries about investments in mortgage-backed securities.

headline: Investors Groove on Music Start-Ups
text: While the music industry remains perpetually confused in trying to figure out the best ways to make money through digital offerings, there are plenty of entrepreneurs seeking success where the big players have failed, The Deal.com notes.

headline: Graphite Capital Takes Alexander Mann for $205 Million
text: Graphite Capital Management, a London-based private equity shop, announced the buyout Thursday of Advent International‘s outsourced recruitment services business, Alexander Mann Solutions, for 100 million pounds ($205 million).

headline: Regulators Approve Nokia’s Navteq Deal
text: The federal government Thursday approved Finnish cell-phone maker Nokia‘s $8.1 billion acquisition of Chicago-based digital mapmaker Navteq.

headline: Roche to Launch Proxy Battle in Bid to Win Ventana
text: Swiss drug firm Roche said Thursday that it will launch a proxy fight in its campaign to acquire the cancer test-kit maker Ventana Medical Systems.

headline: China Railway Makes Tracks in Hong Kong Debut
text: China Railway Group, the world’s third-biggest construction company, rose 27 percent in its Hong Kong debut as investors bet the country’s investment in transport systems will boost earnings.

headline: Ryanair Calls on EU to Block Air France Bid for Alitalia
text: Not everyone, it seems, is happy about the bidding war for Italian airline Alitalia.

headline: Cevian Capital, Backed By Icahn, Buys Stake in Munich Re
text: Cevian Capital, a Swedish investment fund backed by Carl C. Icahn, has bought a stake of nearly 3 percent in Munich Re, the reinsurer, making it the latest activist investor to target a German blue chip, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Ron Paul Plays to His Blimpy Base
text: The Politico reports on plans to

headline: Stereogum Investors Swap Stake for Slice of BuzzNet
text: The owners of hipster music Web site Stereogum, which include former AOL executive Robert Pittman, former MTV digital guru Jason Hirschhorn and founder Scott Lapatine, have signed a deal to flip their equity stakes in the company to BuzzNet.com, The New York Post reported.

headline: Emap Sells Consumer Unit for $2.3 Billion
text: Emap, the British publisher of Grazia and Heat magazines, agreed to sell its consumer magazine and radio units to Germany’s Heinrich Bauer Verlag for 1.14 billion pounds ($2.3 billion).

headline: Britain’s Chrysalis Goes on the Block
text: Chrysalis Group, a British independent music company long coveted by a number of the major labels including Warner Music Group, has officially put itself up for sale with the hopes of raising as much as $300 million, The New York Post reported.

headline: GroSolar Attracts $10 Million
text: Solar installation and distribution startup GroSolar announced Thursday that it secured $10 million in its second round of funding.

headline: In I.P.O., NetSuite Tries Google Approach
text: NetSuite‘s dreams of an initial public offering are coming to fruition-with a twist.

headline: The Inevitable Issue: Adams and Anti-Semitism
text: William H. Theodore has posted a thoughtful comment noting Adams’s anti-Semitism. Edmund Morris, who wrote the introduction to Modern Library edition of “The Education,” described Adams as being “paranoid about Jews,” and even his bosom friend, John Hay, once remarked that when Henry “saw Vesuvius reddening … [he] searched for a Jew stoking the fire.” Some of Adams’s letters have overtly anti-Jewish observations and descriptions.

headline: Hedge Funds Hit $4 Trillion Mark, Survey Says
text: Hedge fund asset levels jumped 11 percent in the six months from April to November, while the industry’s combined assets under administration have reached the $4 trillion milestone, according to a new survey.

headline: Ex-UnitedHealth C.E.O. to Settle Inquiry for $400 Million
text: In one of the largest corporate pay give-backs ever, William W. McGuire, the former chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, has agreed to forfeit at least $418 million to settle claims related to back-dated stock options.

headline: Genzyme Chief Tempers Sale Speculation
text: Genzyme‘s stock fell slightly Thursday after the biotech company’s chief executive, Henri Termeer, said he had no interest in selling the company, despite speculation that billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who owns stock in the company, could push it to find a buyer.

headline: Pandit Is Rising, but His Fund Isn’t, Report Says
text: Vikram Pandit’s star has been rising ever since he joined Citigroup in July. But Old Lane Partners, the hedge fund that he co-founded and that Citigroup bought earlier this year, hasn’t enjoyed the same kind of success, according to Dow Jones.

headline: Morgan Stanley Co-Presidents Disclose Ownership Stakes
text: Morgan Stanley‘s two new co-presidents, Walid Chammah and James Gorman, disclosed in regulatory filings that they own a combined total of more than $57 million worth of the investment bank’s shares.

headline: Buyout Fund-of-Funds Scales Back I.P.O.
text: The credit squeeze has forced HarbourVest, one of the biggest private equity fund of funds, to scale back its initial public offering of a new fund, which started trading on Thursday on NYSE Euronext in Amsterdam, The Financial Times reported.

headline: ‘Hey, Mom, I Got Straight Mickey D’s on My Report Card!’
text: From Consumerist.com:

headline: Another N.Y. Attorney General’s Wall Street Crusade
text: It’s beginning to feel a lot like Spitzer.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Plan Chinese Banking Joint Venture
text: Morgan Stanley plans an investment banking joint venture with China Fortune Securities, one of the country’s oldest brokers, to expand its business and win clients in the fastest-growing major capital market, Reuters reported Friday citing unnamed sources.

headline: Darth Vader blogging
text: Back when Hillary Clinton described Dick Cheney as Darth Vader, a number of people pointed out that this was an unfair comparison. For example, Darth Vader once served in the military.

headline: When a Public Offering Goes Bad Down Under
text: The founder of the company took in more than half a billion dollars by selling most of his stock to the public. Three weeks later, the company fell apart.

headline: Real Estate Partnerships Said to Evade Billions in Taxes
text: Investors in real estate partnerships evade billions of dollars in federal taxes each year, even though detecting this type of cheating is easy, a former specialist in partnerships for the Internal Revenue Service said Thursday.

headline: Perelman Seeks $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
text: MAFS Acquisition, a blank-check company led by billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman, filed with regulators to raise as much as $500 million to fund an acquisition.

headline: The Few, the Proud, the … Wild and Crazy Guys!
text: This is described on YouTube as a Ukrainian Army recruitment ad:

headline: A New Northern Rock Bid Emerges, as One Is Withdrawn
text: British investment group Olivant came forward with a detailed rescue offer for mortgage lender Northern Rock on Friday as J.C. Flowers, the American private equity firm, reportedly pulled out of the bidding process.

headline: Shake-Ups in Dow Jones and Its Soon-to-Be Owner
text: With a week to go before the News Corporation takes control of Dow Jones & Company, there are already management changes under way at the top of Dow Jones — and Rupert Murdoch’s empire itself.

headline: Carried-Interest Tax Provision Defeated
text: House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Charles Rangel agreed to drop a proposed tax increase on “carried interest,” a measure bitterly opposed by the private equity and hedge fund industries, from hotly disputed tax legislation. “Score one for the barbarians,” The New York Post wrote, noting the intense lobbying from the largest buyout firms that helped defeat the measure, at least for now.

headline: Macrovision to Buy Gemstar for $2.8 Billion
text: Digital security company Macrovision said on Friday it agreed to buy Gemstar-TV Guide in a cash-and-stock deal worth about $2.8 billion, a move that it says will help speed up the delivery of home entertainment services.

headline: Lewis Raises Stake in Bear Stearns
text: Bear Stearns said on Friday that shareholder Joseph Lewis raised his stake in the company to 8.01 percent.

headline: Friday’s Links: When Career Choices Create Angst, or Worse
text: In this week’s reading, I stumbled onto a few articles all having to do with the way our career choices can affect our well-being, physically, mentally and emotionally.

headline: Shaking Up the Bali Climate Conference, Literally
text: Whatever their brains may tell them, human hearts are strongly prone to read meaning and intention into what happens around them, and not be satisfied with “coincidence” as an explanation. It’s just natural to anthropomorphise.

headline: The Early Word: Reviews of Romney’s Speech
text: Mitt Romney’s religious speech is being dissected and reviewed, with some of his rivals weighing in on his decision to address how his religious beliefs would affect his presidency.

headline: Not-So-Buried Treasure
text: So there the Bagger was, surfing along in search of balls of lint he could leverage into blog items, when he checked in at Awards Daily. It listed some significant ommisions — “American Gangster,” “’Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead,” “Charlie Wilson’s War” — in the National Board of Review’s ten best list this year, before offering someone else’s smart, historical take on that organization’s picks.

headline: The Upside and Downside of Low-Energy Lighting
text: In a world where two billion people still squint by the light of a kerosene lamp (at best) at night, any kind of electrical illumination is a gift beyond measure. But as long as coal is a big source of electricity, finding efficient, cheap, usable alternatives to the incandescent bulb will be a vital enterprise, experts say.

headline: Best Songs to Write Bits To
text: The Bagger stole a couple of Daily Variety’s out of the shop to catch up on real, industrial-grade news and found himself in receipt of a bunch of music. There, salted amid the For Your Consideration ads and all sorts of people ankling hither and yon, were a bunch of CD’s. Just this week, the haul included “Le Fistin” from “Ratatouille,” the original score from “Eastern Promises,” and the score for “Atonement.”

headline: What Doctoroff’s Departure Means for the City
text: In a front-page article about Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff’s decision to leave the Bloomberg administration to run Bloomberg L.P., Diane Cardwell and Charles V. Bagli write that “much of his agenda remains unrealized, despite his many achievements” and that the announcement “could signal the twilight of an administration still bursting with grand visions but running out of time.” (See related blog post.)

headline: Third Act From the Shark
text: Those of you who have traveled lo these many miles with the Bagger know that when it comes to films, he is basically a homer, through and through. He loves them all, even when he doesn’t, in part because he understands just enough about the process to know that simply getting a film made is the equivalent of juggling chainsaws and new-born babies. The benefit of the doubt is always stipulated.

headline: Victims of the Omaha Shooting
A Bad Job Report
text: The employment report today is not impressive. But it almost certainly is overstated.

headline: What the Democrats Knew and When They Knew It
text: Writing at Balkinization, the group legal blog, Georgetown law professor Marty Lederman criticizes two Democrats in Congress who knew about the C.I.A.’s destruction of interrogation videotapes. “Jay Rockefeller claims that the Intel Committees were not ‘consulted’ on the use of the tapes ‘nor the decision to destroy the tapes.’ But he does not deny that he was informed of the agency’s intent to dispose of the tapes, and he acknowledges that he learned of the destruction one year ago, in November 2006,” Lederman writes. He continues:

headline: Berlin’s (cheap) wine bars
text: With the artists and other creative types that used to call Prenzlauer Berg home slowly getting priced out of the neighborhood, places like the Weinerei are welcome holdouts. A wine bar that’s based on the honor system, the Weinerei at Zionskirchplatz (map) has a charming, if naively misplaced, faith in mankind’s honesty. For the price of one euro, you “rent” yourself a glass and get to sample as many of the wines as you want. At the end of the night you throw some bills or coins into a big jar, the amount based on how much you think you spent.

headline: Grammy Nominations for ‘Idols’
text: The Fox competition “American Idol” proved its musical value again on Thursday, as three “Idol” alums picked up Grammy Award nominations.

headline: Wall Street at Play (for Charity)
text: On Wednesday night, it felt like a sizable portion of Wall Street had moved uptown.

headline: Schiano Staying at Rutgers
text: The Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano met with his team at 7 a.m. on Friday morning to inform them that he was not taking the head coaching position at the University of Michigan.

headline: Investors Give Gemstar Deal a Cold Shoulder
text: Judging by the two companies’ stock prices on Friday, it seems shareholders are tuning out Macrovision‘s $2.8 billion offer for Gemstar-TV Guide International.

headline: Getting Only Half the Story
text: On Oct. 12, retired Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, the former top military commander of American forces in Iraq, delivered a scathing denunciation of the Bush administration’s “incompetent” management of the war – and an equally blistering denunciation of the news media.

headline:
Stray Questions for:
Ted Conover
text: Ted Conover’s most recent book is “Newjack: Guarding Sing Sing.”

headline: Flag Wavers Target Thompson, Romney
text: Fred D. Thompson may not campaign very much, but when he does, he can expect a crowd in South Carolina: protesters who are angry over his disapproval of the public display of the Confederate flag.

headline: Mayor Prepares for Trip to China and Indonesia
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is about to travel to Asia for a series of meetings culminating in a speech next Friday before the United Nations Frameworks of Convention for Climate Change Conference in Bali, Indonesia. In his weekly radio call-in program this morning, the mayor said that he hoped to use the forum to draw attention to the pronounced health effects of global warming in big cities.According to an itinerary released by City Hall, Mayor Bloomberg is to spend two days in Beijing, one in Shanghai and two in Bali. On Monday, he will participate in the China-United States Innovation Conference in Beijing; meet with the United States ambassador, Clark T. Randt Jr., and Cheng Siwei, vice chairman of the National People’s Congress; and attend a dinner run by the Chinese People’s Institute of Foreign Affairs. On Tuesday, Mr. Bloomberg will speak at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in Beijing.

headline: Is Macrovision Bringing More Cops to Your Living Room?
text: Macrovision’s business is mainly about what you can’t watch and listen to. Its main products have been producing methods to prevent people from copying audio and video programs.

headline: Real Action on Climate Change
Art Murmur | Day Two at Art Basel Miami
text: Amy Sadao, the director of Visual AIDS, overheard telling Blue Medium’s John Melick that at this fair “Birds are the new skulls.”… The arty convenience store, “ShanghART Supermarket,” by Xu Zhen, has been busier than a Chinatown fishmonger’s. Among the shopping: Hans Ulrich Obrist and Beatrix Ruf… Inquiring minds want to know: where is Marianne Boesky?…Sheikh Majed Al-sabah dropped a pretty penny at Pulse for his new art gallery that opens in Dubai in March… Don’t you hate it when your ex-wife gets a better seat than you and your new missus do at a ritzy ‘do? Kai von Bismarck does, and made sure that everyone within earshot knew it as he stormed out of the Pucci dinner. Scandale!

headline: Wall Street’s New Status Symbol: the Spac
text: Thomas Hicks did it. Nelson Peltz is doing it. And on Friday, Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire financier whose firm owns Revlon, joined the parade.

headline: A Film With a Fresh Face and an Uptown Flair

I would end up being a few minutes late, though, because the address for the set, 210 Joralemon Street in Brooklyn, didn’t make sense.

headline: Worker Is Killed in Scaffold Collapse on Upper East Side
text: Updated, Dec. 9 | Two brothers who worked together as window-washers fell from the roof of a 45-story luxury apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan around 10:15 a.m. today when the scaffold they were standing upon gave way. One brother was killed immediately, and the other was in critical condition at the Weill Cornell Medical College of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, according to the Fire Department.

headline: How big a deal?
text: A first reaction to the Paulson subprime plan: in terms of the financial crisis, my back-of-the-envelope calculations suggest that it is, at best, a very minor help.

headline: Finally, A Buyer for Gemstar-TV Guide
text: “Digital security company Macrovision said on Friday it agreed to buy Gemstar-TV Guide in a cash-and-stock deal worth about $2.8 billion, a move that it says will help speed up the delivery of home entertainment services,” Dealbook reports.

headline: The Swells (Although Not Many) Love ‘Friday Night Lights’
text: The second season of “Friday Night Lights,” the critically acclaimed drama set on and off a Texas football field, has managed to attract no more than 7.5 million viewers a week.

headline: Stalling for Laughs
text: Defamer takes a measure of the stance of Brad Pitt vis à vis his toilet stall neighbor George Clooney and pronounces it both wide and deep. (Actually, it was Mr. Clooney sending love to Julia Roberts at her tribute from American Cinematheque, but why spoil the magic.)

headline: Apple: Rich With Cash and Possibilities
text: Apple‘s newest store — its second-largest in the United States — is opening Friday night in Manhattan’s trendy Meatpacking District, and Apple enthusiasts are already gawking at what Gothamist.com has dubbed “the shiny, new tech haven.” From the looks of the photos Gothamist posted after Thursday’s media sneak peak, showing a three-story, all-glass, spiral staircase, Apple spent a pretty penny on it.

headline: A List. A Party.
text: The Bagger went to the “Atonement” party, as the video attests. For a time, though, he thought he had stumbled backstage at a White Stripes show. As indieWIRE points out, Michael Stipe was there, as was Josh Groban . But then he saw Keira Knightley and he knew he was in his natural element.

headline: Bush’s Alternative Energy Flip-Flop
text: The White House has raised several objections to the breakthrough energy bill recently negotiated by House leaders. But there’s an interesting and ironic backstory to one of these complaints.

headline: Teen Angst?
text: A Veteran Oscar Campaigner told the Bagger that “Juno” will get no best pic love because the “Academy never goes for teen movies.” The Bagger didn’t see “Juno” as a teen flick, but then he is older than dirt. He found plenty to identify with, most especially the ferocious love Juno’s parents have for their little oddlet of a daughter. Variety’s Anne Thompson ain’t buying the too-teen-to-mean-much theory, either.

headline: Just in Case You Were Wondering What the Guys in the Tall Hats Thought of ‘Compass’
text: A blurb in an ad today for “The Golden Compass,” which has been the subject of some debate in Catholic communities because the book on which it is based takes a dim view of god, religion and ecclesiastical hierarchy.

headline: Friday Kickoff: Moving Edition
text: Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano met with his team at 7 a.m. on Friday and told them that he’s sticking around. That ended a flurry of speculation after news circulated on Thursday night that he had interviewed with Michigan on Wednesday in New York City.

headline: The Google Moon Race Is On
text: Well, maybe it’s not quite a race yet — that would require at least two racers. But less than three months after Google put up $30 million for the Google Lunar X Prize, the first contestant has signed up for the race to send a privately funded robot on the Moon.

headline: In India, More Cars, Going Faster
text: India’s auto market is growing fast, and drivers will soon be able to go faster, too. On Wednesday, the national government raised the speed limit on private cars to 100 kilometers an hour from 80 — roughly, to 60 miles an hour from 48. Commercial traffic and vehicles carrying eight or more passengers will be held to lower limits. The higher speed limits would not apply to city streets, but on the country’s growing highways.

headline: A Push to Make Public Housing ‘Green’
text: Former President Bill Clinton and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined the federal housing secretary this morning in the Bronx to announce a wide-ranging plan to help New York City’s public housing system — the nation’s largest, with 2,600 buildings and 408,000 residents — reduce emissions of the greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming. In what the officials called a “first-ever sustainability partnership,” the New York City Housing Authority will put into place an array of plans to make its properties more environmentally friendly by reducing energy use.

headline: Has Facebook Worn Out Its Welcome?
text: The Associated Press is reporting that Syria has blocked its citizens’ access to the popular Facebook social networking web site. No official reason has yet been given, but the A.P. report suggests that it may have to do with Damascus worrying that Israelis were using the site to somehow infiltrate Syrian social networks.

headline: When Residents Weigh In on Gentrification
text: Can New York be too successful? We blogged on that question last week, and heard from readers concerned about the balance between commercial growth and neighborhood stability.
