headline: The Worst C.E.O. of 2007?
text: It seems to be open season on Eddie Lampert. The hedge-fund firm he runs, ESL Investments, has already taken some big hits this year, and now Herb Greenberg, the MarketWatch columnist, has selected him for that dubious annual honor: “Worst C.E.O. of the Year.”

headline: The Rangers’ First-Line Issues
text: One of the quirkier twists for the Rangers this season has been the presence of Brandon Dubinsky as the first-line center between Jaromir Jagr and Martin Straka. The Rangers went out this offseason and spent $14 million on centers Chris Drury and Scott Gomez, only to have neither of them centering their top line and instead handing the job to a 20-year-old rookie.

headline: Poor, Poor Pitiful Me
text: I have every right to be cranky.

headline: Bali Update: Pushing for Action, Not Talk
text: The diplomats and officials gathered in Bali to shape talks leading to a new climate treaty are beginning to feel the heat. In public conference rooms and private hotel suites, they are (in theory at least) trying to prepare a two-year “road map” for updating the faltering 1992 Framework Convention on Climate Change, the world’s first experiment in common action to limit global warming.

headline: Not Feeling the Oprah Love
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — The coming Oprah phenomenon on behalf of Senator Barack Obama is already having a ripple effect on rival campaigns.

headline: Late-Night Hosts: ‘We’ll Be Right Back’?
text: At least six of the eight late-night television hosts who have stayed off the air during the writers’ strike are paying the salaries of their nonwriting staff members, Bill Carter notes in today’s Times. “The question the hosts are struggling with is how long they can continue to stay off the air and subsidize their staffs, and what happens when they decide they cannot do it any longer.”

headline: Romney Ad: So Not P.C.
text: Mitt Romney’s latest ad, “Not Politically Correct,” may have some people wondering if the TV spot is strategically correct because it outlines positions that may renew charges of flip-flopping.

headline: Holiday Decoration Robber Is Arrested on Long Island
text: If you’re decking the halls on Long Island this season, make sure those boughs of holly are chained down. A man walked around his neighborhood with a shopping cart and filled it with holiday decorations stolen from several neighbors in Brentwood, according to the Suffolk County Police who arrested the man, Pedro Fournier, this morning. Mr. Fournier, 47, of Brentwood, had holiday lights and ornaments including a snowman, reindeer and tree, said the police, who responded to a 911 call at 7:38 a.m. The neighbors identified the stolen property.

headline: Ask Hongyan He Oliver a Question
text: Welcome back to our expert roundtable discussion of China’s environmental crisis. text: I sat next to a guy on a plane recently who mentioned that he was about to launch a Web site called MyBadFlight.com.Lord, how I’ve waited for this moment.

text: Trucks are the mules of China's spectacularly expanding economy -- ubiquitous and essential, yet highly noxious.

headline: Late-Night Ratings Dip. Sleep Rises Moderately
text: As noted yesterday, more viewers watched ABC’s “Nightline” than NBC’s “The Tonight Show with Jay Leno” or CBS’s “The Late Show with David Letterman” last week, for the first time in years. A report from the media buying agency Magna Global this week shows that Mr. Leno and Mr. Letterman aren’t the only shows hurting because of the writers’ strike.

headline: Weiner’s Vision of Healthier Days Ahead
text: For public officials interested in running for mayor, there seems to be a ritual these days of presenting policy speeches at breakfasts run by the Association for a Better New York. And today, it was United States Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s turn.

text: Arraignments do not, by their nature, produce compelling television. There are no arguments and no testimony and no witnesses.

headline: Art Murmur | Update from Art Basel Miami
text: For the second year in a row, the pool at The Raleigh is proving too inviting to resist. At Jeffrey Deitch’s late-night party, there were so many skinny-dipping galleristas that the scene resembled a Spencer Tunick photo… Turns out the ripped-from-the-Colosseum Roman soldiers clanking around town are not here for a sword-and-sandals convention but to hype a freshman fair, Roma Contemporary, making its debut in February… It seems there’s safety in numbers at this year’s fair. More and more dealers are sharing spaces, forging “Survivor”-like alliances to avoid being voted off next year, when the fought-after spots are reassessed by the new regime. Mary Boone and Rafael Jablonka from Cologne have the smartest set-up: a room each to do with as they will and a third make-nice space for Eric Fischl, the one artist the two galleries share… Massive steroid-charged artwork is not limited to the main fair. It also gets a workout at Pulse, where there is a courtyard stocked with jacked-up sculptures by Jurgen Mayer, Chris Larson and the tattooist-cum-fine artist Duke Reilly. Reilly’s work is a replica of a revolutionary war submarine called the “Turtle,” which in truth looks more like an old whisky barrel. The larkish Reilly submerged his work in the Hudson River early this year and “attacked” the QM2, an offence which got him arrested (the $120,000 tag for the piece includes a video of his capture)… It’s not just the wholesale appropriation trend that is trying the patience of gallerists. As the circuit hits 23 fairs and counting, FedEx and other couriers cannot handle the volume of art that’s zipping round the world. Galleries will soon have to find alternative methods, with many acknowledging that delivery delays have been worse than ever. Some shipments failed to arrive. For the first day, Berlin’s Galerie Michael Schultz had to make do with a minimalist set up of two canvases (the rest of the booth showed up last night); while a Danish gallery canceled completely when they received word that its shipment wouldn’t make it in time. That was good news for on person at least: the booth-less Aussie art collective The Glue Society was promoted into the space to exhibit its waggish light boxes, which show satellite images of what appear to be ancient Biblical scenes. Divine intervention?

headline: For Most Hedge Funds, a Chilly November
text: In a year that has proved volatile for hedge fund returns, November appears to be one of the down months — except for one investment strategy.

Reilly and brought to you by Judd “Knocked Up” Apatow. You can dial in at MySpace.com, IGN.com, Rottentomatoes.com or walkhard-movie.com, but be prepared to pledge that you are 18 because the movie is rated “R”.

headline: Huckabee Releases Immigration Plan
text: In advance of a Spanish-language debate on Sunday, Mike Huckabee has released a plan for immigration enforcement and border security today. The former Arkansas governor pledges to complete the border fence by July 2010 and rules out a pathway to citizenship for people currently in the United States illegally without first returning their country of origin.

headline: Man Dies in Bronx After Being Pinned by Construction Equipment
text: A construction worker died this afternoon in the Bronx after his head got pinned between the side of a dump truck and the rear end of a backhoe around 12:45 p.m. today, according to city officials and a hospital spokesman.

headline: ‘Oh, Bring Back the Days of the Simple Autograph’
text: The actor/novelist/comic/poetry tutor Stephen Fry has a (crazily good) blog now, and he has posted about how the cell-phone camera has ruined the lit’rary reading.

text: The verdicts are in on Robert Greenwald’s new short film critiquing the head of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Art-Fair Survivor | David Amsden
Spring Break for City Opera?
text: Talk is swirling that New York City Opera may shut down for the 2008-9 season so its home, the New York State Theater, can undergo acoustical renovations and other fixes desired by Gerard Mortier, the incoming general manager. Further, Mr. Mortier is said to want to discard all the company’s older productions, clearing the decks for new ones. In truth, Mr. Mortier has long said the State Theater will have to close for a few months and has promised all new productions, at least for his first season in charge, 2009-10.

headline: Living in Tompkinsville, Staten Island
text: The Staten Island Railway station at Tompkinsville is one stop from the ferry.

headline: Stop-Time
text: Paper Cuts is on hiatus – out raking leaves – until Monday, December 17.

headline: Expert Help In A Disastrous Deal
text: A reader writes to complain that my column today did not give the underwriter of the Rams Home Loans offering the credit it deserved for bringing this deal to investors.

text: Several names are being floated at City Hall as possible successors to Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, who is leaving the government at the end of the year to become president of Bloomberg L.P.

headline: Video: Romney on the Trail
text: A day after his speech addressing concerns about his Mormon faith, Mitt Romney held a press conference in Des Moines. He received a variety of questions from the two dozen or so reporters in attendance. Some were about the speech but some of the most notable exchanges were over the immigration issue.

text: Would you pay kickbacks to a supposed hedge fund manager whose fund bought shares through an E*Trade account?

text: Ways to save and generate energy from The New York Times Magazine's Year in Ideas.

headline: Democrats More Likely to Get a Real, Live Caller
text: You’re inundated with calls from campaigns if you live in Iowa or New Hampshire right now. But if you’re a Democrat, it might be harder for you to hang up without feeling guilty. A new survey by the Pew Research Center and The Associated Press found that while the vast majority of likely voters in those states have received automated voice messages, or “robo-calls,” registered Democrats are significantly more likely to have received a campaign pitch from a real, live person.

headline: More on WD’s Hard Drive That Won’t Share Video
text: BoingBoing today posted about a networked hard drive from Western Digital that blocks access to music and video files. The blogosphere started a chorus of outrage. And I referred to it in a post about the dark side of Macrovision’s acquisition of Gemstar TV Guide.

headline: Francis Ford Coppola — Indie
text: “Winning an Oscar is not the end all, be all of life,” Francis Ford Coppola told the Baguette Wednesday night after the premiere of “Youth Without Youth,” his first new film in a decade. “The end all and be all of life is to follow your dreams.”

headline: UrbanEye: A Week of Broadway
text: As Broadway stagehands returned to work, the Great White Way saw a marathon week of openings.  Melena Ryzik of The Times reports.

headline: On Basketball: The Heels Have a Need for Speed
text: North Carolina is supremely talented. I found that out last season in Chapel Hill when the Tar Heels beat my tournament-bound Penn team by 38. They confirmed it again this season, coming into a sold-out Palestra earlier this week and beating Penn by 35.

headline: Radars Taken Out by Arctic Warming
text: The continuing warming and summertime retreats of sea ice around the North Pole are making life difficult for seal-hunting polar bears, eroding Inuit coastal villages and now, evidently, eroding Arctic defenses (although not weakening them, the Pentagon insists).

headline: Blogger Roundup: The C.I.A. Tape Affair
text: The New York Times’s report on the C.I.A.’s destruction of two videotapes showing interrogations has taken on a life of its own across the blogosphere, where writers raised new questions, recalled to old ones and cross-referenced each other to create a fascinating, complex stew of opinion and analysis.

text: In conjunction with T’s art-themed holiday issue and our ongoing coverage of Art Basel Miami Beach, The Moment has selected short films by artists who will be showing at A.B.M.B. It’s also become a pretty good indicator of Oscar buzz a few years down the line. David M. Halbfinger, the Bagger’s colleague on the West Coast, has the hot-off-the-press details of the 2007 version.

headline: Restructuring Shop to Acquire CompUSA
text: CompUSA, the electronics retailer that has struggled amid pressure from rivals like Best Buy and Wal-Mart, said Friday afternoon that it will be acquired by Gordon Brothers Group, an investment and advisory firm specializing in restructuring. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Dropping of Roses Marks Pearl Harbor Anniversary
text: Joseph S. Hydrusko was a 22-year-old Navy seaman, working on board a hospital ship, the U.S.S. Solace, at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, on Dec. 7, 1941. He was helping to paint the vessel when six planes flew overhead; he assumed they were American planes flying ahead of a carrier. Instead, the planes began to drop bombs. Hundreds of Japanese planes followed them. Mr. Hydrusko rowed over to save wounded and dying men from the U.S.S. Oklahoma, a battleship that was sunk that day.

headline: Update: Talk Off | Cologne
text: Earlier this week, in The Moment’s Talk Off column, Bruce Pask, the magazine’s Men’s Fashion Director, battled Alex Hawgood, a Features Associate, over the merits of men’s fragrances. Readers voted by leaving comments. The results are in: Alex, who argued the negative position, has won the Talk Off with approximately 80 percent of the votes. Men who prefer l’eau naturale can breathe easy.

headline: A Wing Suit Landing Quest
text: Wing suit flier Jeb Corliss is on a quest to land a wing suit without a parachute.

headline: Adams on Trial?
text: Things are heating up in the Reading Room. In his very witty post, Gary Hart wonders what benefit Adams might have derived from experiencing “the outer ring of fear and loathing known to conservatives as The Bureaucracy” — not to mention “two intense years in the closest thing to bloodless civilian warfare,” a presidential campaign. Senator Hart certainly knows whereof he speaks. But Adams, who grew up assuming he would be president someday, never entered electoral politics.

headline: US Trust TV Spot
text: A US Trust commercial centers on a vintage VW bus.

headline: Total Cereal TV Spot
text: An ad for General Mills' Total cereal is filled with  psychedelic imagery.

headline: Geico TV Spot
text: An ad for Geico salutes those who lived through the 1960s.

headline: A Mutual Disinterest for Michigan and Harbaugh
text: As Michigan’s coaching search continues to spiral, don’t expect the name Jim Harbaugh to come up. Harbaugh is a former Michigan quarterback and has had success both at San Diego and Stanford, where he beat both Southern California and California this season. He would certainly be a logical candidate for Michigan, as he’s both a graduate and his father, Jack, coached there.

headline: Facebook Members Sell Their Own Ads
text: More than 1,500 Facebook users have started placing advertisements on their own profile pages — despite the social networking site’s rule against such ads.

headline: Traffic Jam in the Sky
text: In case you haven’t noticed, flying has become more delay-prone than ever. So far, 2007 has been the most delay-plagued year since the government began keeping records, punctuated by a disastrous summer in which millions of people around the country were stranded. How we got to this point, and what can be done about it, aren’t always understood.

headline: Bloggingheads: Writers' Strike
text:
Mickey Kaus of Slate's Kausfiles, left, and Rob Long, a (conservative) comedy writer, debate the goals and tactics of the screenwriters' labor action.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: The Week That Was
text: Let’s talk about the week that was; bookended by its beginnings with the Clinton campaign cheekily trying to trace Barack Obama’s presidential ambitions back to kindergarten – (just joking!!) and by its end, anticipation of the upcoming Oprah-fest abutting a dueling late-entry by Bill Clinton. (At least in South Carolina.)

headline: Oy, Obama
text: I’ll just outsource this to Ezra Klein.

headline: Citi Is Close to Picking New C.E.O.
text: Citigroup is scheduled to hold its year-end board meetings early next week, where its directors could decide on a new chief executive, according to people briefed on the search process.

headline: The Oprah-Obama Tour
text: The highly anticipated combination of Oprah and Obama descends upon Des Moines Saturday, and there are still tickets available for the rally. And they are free.

headline: Vows: Amy and Brian
text: Amy Pamela Weil and Brian Raphael met on a blustery night in Central Park.

headline: Holtz Gets No Help From Dad
text: The name of East Carolina Coach Skip Holtz has come up in connection with the Arkansas job recently. But don’t expect his famous father, the former Notre Dame coach and current ESPN announcer Lou Holtz, to call in any favors. At least without prompting.

headline: Clinton Deploys Mom
text: DES MOINES – Tonight, Dorothy Rodham made her debut on the 2008 presidential campaign trail.

headline: Teenagers and Cars
text: Many states are trying to find ways to fight high fatality rates in car accidents that involve teenage drivers. What are your thoughts about teenage driving, driving laws and safety programs? Read the Article

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Everything’s Perfect, Except…
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Dec. 8 column.

headline: Joyful Noise and Charity to Celebrate the Season
text: HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 5  When Yo La Tengo plays covers of ’60s and ’70s rock songs, the members of the band almost take the meanness and grubbiness out of record fetishism: The way they feel about old or obscure or outer-edges rock ’n’ roll comes through with affection, generosity, positive energy, even safety. They are not testing you.

headline: China Directs Banks to Raise Reserves
text: SHANGHAI, Dec. 8  China said today that for the 10th time this year, it would order banks to raise the amount of cash they set aside, in order to curb inflation and prevent the economy from overheating.

headline: A Solemn Milestone
text: Manchester United will mark the 50th anniversary of the plane crash that wiped out its famed team with a Premier League match against Manchester City. United has been given special permission by the league and its sponsors to wear the team’s old-style plain red jerseys and baggy shorts for the Feb. 10 home matchEight players were among 23 people killed on Feb. 6, 1958, when a plane carrying United home from a match at Red Star Belgrade crashed in Munich after refueling.

headline: Looking Back to Eddie Bauer to Rescue Eddie Bauer
text: BEFORE McNeil S. Fiske Jr.  or Neil Fiske, as he prefers  was named to the top spot of the struggling retailer Eddie Bauer in June, he was better known as an author. His book “Trading Up” told the story of how America’s secretaries were rushing out to buy Godiva chocolates, seeking in other words, to own a piece of the luxury market at a (relatively) cheap price.

headline: Record-Holder Has Modest Expectations With Jets
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Dec. 7  The Jets signed David Ball to their practice squad last week and the Jerry Rice jokes followed, as if in Ball’s slipstream. Ball tries to be a good sport when he is teased about his historical connection to Rice. It is an icebreaker.

headline: Give Officials Access, Landowners on Border Are Told
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Federal officials are warning landowners along the southern border that they have to give the government access to their property as it considers where to build a fence intended to block illegal immigration.

headline: Everything’s Perfect, Except ...
text: The peak of my sympathy for Mitt Romney came when he was being battered on one side by Christian fundamentalists who think his faith is a cult and on the other by fellow Mormons, who were irate when he fudged the fact that they believe Jesus will return to earth and build a new Jerusalem in Jackson County, Mo.

headline: Macrovision Agrees to Buy Gemstar-TV Guide for $2.8 Billion in Stock and Cash
text: Macrovision, in an effort to position itself at the forefront of the digital platform business, has agreed to buy the television listings provider Gemstar-TV Guide International for $2.8 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Authoritarians in the Andes
text: Venezuelan voters’ stunning rejection of President Hugo Chávez’s power grab provided a welcome reminder that there is a limit to what citizens will hand over, even to a popular leader with gargantuan oil wealth to spread around. Unfortunately, Mr. Chávez’s authoritarianism is spreading in the Andes, where his allies, Presidents Evo Morales of Bolivia and Rafael Correa of Ecuador are also trying to pass constitutional amendments that would greatly consolidate their power.

headline: Democracy Is Alive and Well in Venezuela
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the C.I.A.’s destruction of two videotapes documenting the interrogations of agents of Al Qaeda rendered incorrectly a quotation from Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of intelligence, in which he explained to C.I.A. employees why he was informing them of the destruction. General Hayden said, “The press has learned that back in 2002, during the initial stage of our terrorist detention program, C.I.A. videotaped interrogations, and destroyed the tapes in 2005.” He did not say he was informing them “because” the press has learned about the episode. (Go to Article)

headline: A Challenge for Churches: Adulthood Takes Its Time
text: At some point during the 20th century, the United States invented adolescence. Where once there had merely been youth, there were now teenagers, with their own dress, music, magazines, books, economy, culture and expected patterns of behavior. It was enough to get organized religion, in the words of the bard, “all shook up.”

headline: Trump Irate Over Rules for Restaurant on Ocean
text: WANTAGH, N.Y., Dec. 6  Donald J. Trump exercises his usual restraint in describing Trump on the Ocean, the 100,000-square-foot restaurant and catering hall he is building at Jones Beach State Park. It exists at “the best corner of Jones Beach,” or, for the more citified, at the “57th and Fifth of Jones Beach.”

headline: Season Ends for St. John’s
text: The St. John’s women’s team dropped a five-game match against Southern California yesterday and was eliminated from the N.C.A.A. tournament in the Round of 16 in Gainesville, Fla.The defeat ended the best season in the 14-year history of the program. After losing the first two games, the 12th-seeded Red Storm (33-4) battled back behind the senior Hui Ping Huang, who had a match- and career-high 29 kills. Asia Kaczor led fifth-seeded U.S.C. (28-4) with 25 kills. U.S.C will next face Texas, which beat Florida in four games.

headline: Looking Back to Eddie Bauer to Rescue Eddie Bauer
text: BEFORE McNeil S. Fiske Jr.  or Neil Fiske, as he prefers  was named to the top spot of the struggling retailer Eddie Bauer in June, he was better known as an author. His book “Trading Up” told the story of how America’s secretaries were rushing out to buy Godiva chocolates, seeking in other words, to own a piece of the luxury market at a (relatively) cheap price.

headline: Franchione Buyout Approved
text: The Texas A&M regents approved a contract buyout yesterday for the former coach Dennis Franchione that is worth up to $4.4 million over three years. A spokesman for the athletic department said Franchione, who resigned Nov. 23, would be paid up to $1.7 million for each of the next two years. He would receive another $1 million in the third and final year of the agreement. Before he resigned, Franchione’s contract had five years remaining at $2 million a year.Franchione went 32-28 at A&M, far short of the expectations when he replaced R. C. Slocum in December 2002. Off the field, Franchione was reprimanded for selling inside information about the team to boosters.

headline: U.N. Report Finds 31 Killed in Myanmar Crackdown
text: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 7  At least 31 people were killed in Myanmar during the military government’s crackdown on protests this fall, and arrests of and nighttime raids on suspected demonstrators are continuing, a United Nations human rights expert who visited the country last month said on Friday.

headline: A Message to Borrowers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Union-Busting at the Hall of Fame
text: Vero Beach, Fla.

headline: A Tie for the Shootout Lead
text: Woody Austin and Mark Calcavecchia shot an eight-under 64 in modified alternate-shot play for a share of the first-round lead with Fred Funk and Jeff Sluman in the Merrill Lynch Shootout in Naples, Fla. The tournament host Greg Norman and Bubba Watson were a stroke back, and the defending champions Jerry Kelly and Rod Pampling opened with a 66 on the Norman-designed Tiburon Golf Club course.

headline: Success Without Ads
text: YONKERS  It makes no sense for publications to charge readers on the Web  at least, that’s the conventional wisdom. But conventional wisdom does not carry much weight at Consumer Reports, that detailed guide to buying everything from prescription drugs to pickup trucks.

headline: Alternate-Side Parking Regulations Suspended Saturday
text: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in New York City will be suspended today. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: 6 Arrested Over Plots to Pump Up Share Prices
text: What began with an undercover F.B.I. agent’s posing as a corrupt hedge fund manager led to the indictments of six people yesterday on charges of fraud in the shadowy world of penny stocks, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Do Something Decent, and Satan Gets Mad
text: It may seem odd that the composer of contemporary classics like “Time Cycle,” “Echoi” and “Baroque Variations” lists a children’s opera as one of his favorites among his own scores. But Lukas Foss has always had a soft spot for “Griffelkin,” his tale of a child devil who spends his 10th birthday walking among mortals and ends up banished from hell for the twin crimes of shedding a tear of compassion and doing a good deed. Granted, the deed is major: Seeing two children grieving over their mother’s death, he brings her back to life.

headline: Former Strip Club Bouncer Convicted of 2 Murders
text: A bouncer who studied sword fighting and ninjitsu, adopted a Japanese surname and urged himself to become a “monster in the most positive way” was convicted yesterday of two 2005 murders but acquitted of a third.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday, about a campaign for Dr. Martens boots, referred incorrectly to one designer’s use of the footwear and to the fashion show at which they were featured. While the designer Yohji Yamamoto used actual Dr. Martens shoes, the designer Chloé featured boots that were inspired by Dr. Martens; both showed their designs at the ready-to-wear show in Paris in February this year, not during New York Fashion Week in September. The article also misstated the headquarters of Dr. Martens’s advertising agency, Exposure Communications. It is based in New York, not London. (Its parent company, Exposure Promotions, is based in London, and the campaign was photographed there.)

headline: Rating Your Doctor, Fairly
text: The drive to give consumers more information about the quality of their doctors has gotten an important shove forward by New York’s attorney general, Andrew Cuomo. That could be good for patients in dozens of states across the country that are served by some of the major health insurance companies.

headline: Resisting Michigan, Schiano Is Staying Put
text: Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano has rejected overtures to become the next coach at Michigan, providing another public blow to that university’s search for a successor to Lloyd Carr.

headline: Father in Brooklyn Is Held in Beating Death of Girl, 3
text: A 33-year-old Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with killing his 3-year-old daughter, who died Wednesday night after being beaten and severely burned, officials said.

headline: Corrections
text: A Spare Times listing in Weekend yesterday about a winter festival at Riverside Church today misstated the church’s address. It is 490 Riverside Drive, not 91. (The entrance for today’s event is at 91 Claremont Avenue, between 120th and 122nd Streets.)

headline: Tanker Spills Oil Off South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 7  A Hong Kong-registered oil tanker leaked 10,810 tons, or 66,000 barrels, of crude oil off South Korea’s stormy west coast today, officials said, in what was estimated to be the nation’s largest maritime oil spill.

headline: The Roles Blur for the Mayor and the Mogul
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has frequently turned to Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff to handle city matters that the mayor should avoid, given his extensive business interests.

headline: Australia’s Oscars
text: A film about migrants in Australia has won that country’s top movie award, while Eric Bana and Joan Chen, above, won the top acting honors, Reuters reported. The Australian Film Institute Awards named “Romulus, My Father” as best film, and its star, Mr. Bana, as best lead actor. The film tells the story of a post-World War II migrant family in Australia. Ms. Chen won for her role in “The Home Song Stories,” in which she plays a former Shanghai singer struggling to survive in 1970s Australia with two young children.

headline: Talks on Kosovo Hit a Dead End, Rice Says
text: BRUSSELS, Dec. 7  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice affirmed Friday that international negotiations over the future of Kosovo had reached a dead end, even as its probable new prime minister said that Kosovo would not seek independence from Serbia until early next year.

headline: Ship’s Pilot Is Charged in Oil Spill
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  A California maritime agency has filed misconduct charges against the American captain at the helm of a Chinese container ship that hit the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge on Nov. 7, spilling 58,000 gallons of fuel and fouling 40 miles of shore.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Weekend yesterday about the Grammy nominations omitted part of the title of an album, by the Foo Fighters, that was nominated for the album of the year award. It is “Echoes, Silence, Patience & Grace,” not “Echoes, Patience & Grace.”

headline: Germany: Move to Ban Scientology
text: The interior ministers of the nation’s 16 states as well as the federal interior minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, “consider Scientology to be an organization that is not compatible with the Constitution” and will work to ban the organization, Berlin’s interior minister, Erhart Körting, told reporters after a meeting. They gave no specific examples, but the most recent annual report on extremism compiled by their agencies criticized the organization for disregarding “basic and human rights, such as the right to develop one’s personality and the right to be treated equally.” Officials estimate there are 6,000 members of the Los Angeles-based Church of Scientology in the country.

headline: More Schools Being Closed for Low Score
text: City education officials said yesterday that they planned to close three additional schools: Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn; the Bronx Coalition Community High School; and P.S. 183, the Daniel Chappie James Elementary School in Brooklyn. They join 10 others that the Department of Education has decided to close after they received poor marks on the new A-through-F report cards.

headline: Bigger Bear Sterns Stake
text: Joseph Lewis, a billionaire investor who bought 7 percent of the investment bank Bear Stearns three months ago, has increased his stake to 8 percent, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Your Team: Coming to More Cities Not Near You
text: Pittsburgh Penguins center Sidney Crosby, the N.H.L.’s unofficial torch-bearer, is expected to reach a milestone of sorts tomorrow in Vancouver. Crosby will have needed 189 games, but he will have finally played in all 30 N.H.L. cities.

headline: Pakistan: Gunmen Kill 3 in Bhutto Office
text: Gunmen attacked a party office of Benazir Bhutto, a major opposition leader, in southwestern Pakistan on Saturday, killing three of her supporters, the police said. The police were still trying to identify the assailants and their motive for the attack, in Naseerabad, about 150 miles east of Quetta. Violence has been common in past elections.

headline: Diversity on Cable TV
text: To the Editor:

headline: Offer for Northern Rock
text: The British investment group Olivant outlined details of its rescue offer for the mortgage lender Northern Rock as the American investment firm J. C. Flowers reportedly pulled out of the bidding process.

headline: NASA Delays Shuttle Launching Again
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 7  NASA officials on Friday again postponed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis as they continued to discuss how to deal with a fuel sensor problem.

headline: The Obituary Bach Wrote for Himself
text: More than 250 years after Bach’s “Art of Fugue” was posthumously printed, the work still poses questions that have only conditional answers. Was this unfinished collection of 20 increasingly complex fugues and canons meant to sum up a life’s work? Probably, given Bach’s failing eyesight during the 1740s.

headline: Tomorrow’s Oscar Hopefuls Today
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7  Two years ago a young executive at Leonardo DiCaprio’s production company, hungry for some good scripts to read over the holidays, asked 100 peers to send him their 10 favorite new screenplays that would not make it into theaters before the New Year. He whipped up a spreadsheet ranking the responses, titled it “The Black List," e-mailed it around and then watched it become a Hollywood phenomenon, the kind of underground document that writers with projects stuck in development pray will mention their script.

headline: Attacks in Iraq Kill 25 People
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 7  Twenty-five people were killed Friday in the tumultuous Iraqi province of Diyala, northeast of Baghdad, when a suicide attacker detonated a bomb near the headquarters of a local committee of former insurgents working with American forces and a car bomb exploded at a checkpoint in Baquba.

headline: A Place for the Erotic, Slid Within the Sacred
text: Christian tradition holds that the Song of Solomon in the Old Testament is an allegorical representation of God’s relationship with Israel as that of man and wife. That interpretation, as well as later efforts to find correspondences between the life of Jesus and older Scripture, allowed a Latin translation of an early passage from Solomon, “Nigra sum sed formosa” (“I am black but comely,” spoken by a sun-darkened woman) to be adopted into Roman Catholic services celebrating the Virgin Mary.

headline: Romney and the Religion Question
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Photos and Notes, New Details on Shootings
text: OMAHA, Dec. 7  The authorities on Friday released photographs taken from a store surveillance video and notes written by a gunman as they continued to piece together what led the man to kill eight people and himself in a mall rampage this week.

headline: Alinghi Proposes Changes to America’s Cup
text: With his plans for the next America’s Cup scuppered by a loss in court, Alinghi’s president, Ernesto Bertarelli, has expressed interest in making radical changes to the competition, the world’s oldest major sporting event.

headline: Giants’ Blackburn May Get Chance to Solve the Eagles
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 7  Chase Blackburn of the Giants certainly had more pressing things to do, but he could not help himself. Football and math are his two passions.

headline: The Body Image War, Battle of Britain Edition
text: If you followed the news closely this week, you know that the National Intelligence Estimate has determined that Iran’s nuclear threat is overblown, and you probably also know that Jennifer Love Hewitt is angry. When photographs of that actress during a beach holiday surfaced on the Internet recently, accompanied by ungenerous commentary about weight gain (“We know what you ate last summer”), Ms. Hewitt retaliated, writing on her blog that she was proud of her body and saddened that so many other women obviously didn’t like theirs. “A size 2,” she declared, “just isn’t fat!”

headline: Peter Davi, Renowned Surfer, Is Dead at 45
text: Peter Davi, a renowned big-wave surfer from Monterey, died Tuesday while riding giant waves at a spot he had helped pioneer off Pebble Beach, Calif. He was 45.

headline: New Jersey Suburbs Fear a Drop in Special Education Aid
text: New Jersey’s support of special education in the public schools has been so generous that parents from all over the country have moved to the state to take advantage of the programs and services it offers.

headline: Special Payout At UAL
text: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said it would pay shareholders $250 million, or $2.15 a share, in a special distribution. The payout will be made on Jan. 23 to shareholders as of Jan. 9, UAL said.

headline: On the Road Again, but to Where?
text: Many Americans harbor a mythical California of the mind: not the ephemeral Hollywood world of tabloid trash and tans, but an idea of open space and giant natural forms, of dust-wreathed taco stands and endless highways running along the Pacific.

headline: France: Suspect in Paris Office Bombing
text: The police were holding a 45-year-old architect as a suspect in the package bomb explosion at a Paris law office on Thursday, a judicial police official said. The official said the suspect had had a past romantic relationship with the head of the law firm that was the target of the bombing. An office secretary was killed. The former law firm of President Nicolas Sarkozy is in the same building, but officials said there was no suggestion of a link.

headline: Tuning In to a New Winter Sport: Extreme Decorating
text: The Vatican broadcasts a Christmas Mass for shut-ins; HGTV offers a tour of the nation’s most elaborately lighted and decorated houses.

headline: Karlheinz Stockhausen, Influential Composer, Dies at 79
text: Karlheinz Stockhausen, an original and influential German composer who began his career as an inventor of new musical systems and ended it making operas to express his spiritual vision of the cosmos, died on Wednesday at his home in Kuerten-Kettenberg, Germany. He was 79.

headline: Seymour Benzer, Geneticist, Is Dead at 86
text: Seymour Benzer, a geneticist who made scientific history by discovering that genes were structured like words and who went on to do pioneering work on the ties between genes and behavior, memory and longevity, died on Nov. 30 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Efforts to Harvest Ocean’s Energy Open New Debate Front
text: NEWPORT, Ore.  Chris Martinson and his fellow fishermen catch crab and shrimp in the same big swell that one day could generate an important part of the Northwest’s energy supply. Wave farms, harvested with high-tech buoys that are being tested here on the Oregon coast, would strain clean, renewable power from the surging sea.

headline: Defying Critics, Italy’s Leader Endures
text: ROME

headline: When Doris Lessing Meets Lady Mary Wortley Montagu
text: This past week, I’ve been reading two books side by side, coincidentally at first and then more and more intently. They are the letters of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, perhaps the most accomplished Englishwoman of the 18th century, and “Shikasta,” the first volume of Doris Lessing’s science fiction series called “Canopus in Argos: Archives.”

headline: Strings, Hip-Hop and Not a Little Randiness
text: Diane Coburn Bruning’s Chamber Dance Project clearly wants to bring ballet into the contemporary world. “No buns, no tights, no tutus,” John Wright, “a classically trained urban vocal artist” (as his program biography states), said in his semi-rapped, slightly squirm-inducing introduction to the company on Thursday night at the Ailey Citigroup Theater.

headline: Crossing a Continent by Water to Another City by the Bay
text: The tourist-laden ferries shuttling between Manhattan and the Statue of Liberty cover about three miles in the round trip. But one boat that may soon be plying that short circuit is traveling almost 8,000 miles to do so.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: A Nobelist’s Acceptance Speech

headline: Ventures In China
text: Credit Suisse has signed a memorandum of understanding to establish a strategic relationship with Founder Securities of China. The venture, which is subject to regulatory approval, expects to underwrite domestic initial public offerings of shares by local Chinese firms and to offer corporate advisory and research services. Morgan Stanley also has reportedly signed an agreement to set up an investment banking venture with China Fortune Securities of Shanghai. (REUTERS)

headline: NATO Seeks to Retake Taliban Haven
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Dec. 7  Residents fled their homes in southern Afghanistan on Friday as NATO forces mounted an offensive to retake the town of Musa Qala, which has been a haven for Taliban fighters since British forces abandoned it in October last year.

headline: In Denver, Former City Official’s Death Prompts Promise of a Lawsuit
text: DENVER, Dec. 7  As its city attorney, Larry Manzanares was one of Denver’s most prominent public officials, a rising star in Colorado’s legal community, when he resigned abruptly in February amid well-publicized accusations that he had stolen a state-owned laptop computer. The authorities later announced that pornographic files had been downloaded on and erased from the computer while it was in Mr. Manzanares’s possession.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of a theater review of “The Farnsworth Invention,” at the Music Box Theater, misidentified the actor standing at the left. He is Spencer Moses  not Kyle Fabel, another actor in the play.

headline: With a High-Powered Hand, Leap-Frogging to the Title
text: Over the final three days of the Fall North American Bridge Championships, which ended in San Francisco on Sunday, there was another major event apart from the Reisinger: the Keohane North American Swiss Teams. The winners were Larry Mori of Clearwater, Fla.; Kelley Hwang of New York; Rick Kaye of Bingham Farms, Mich.; Leonard (Bill) Melander Jr. of West Bloomfield, Mich.; and Kazuo Furuta and Hiroki Yokoi from Japan.

headline: Two Museums Go to Court Over the Right to Picassos
text: In a legal strategy that is spreading in the art world, the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation jointly asked a federal court yesterday to declare them the owners of two Picasso paintings that a claimant says were sold under duress in Nazi Germany.

headline: Amgen Shares Fall on Safety Concerns
text: Shares of Amgen had their biggest decline in seven months on Nasdaq yesterday after the company reported it might revise the safety information on its biggest product, the anemia drug Aranesp.

headline: Appalachian State Advances
text: Quarterback Armanti Edwards rushed for 313 yards and 4 touchdowns and threw for 182 yards and 3 more scores to help Appalachian State advance to the Football Championship Subdivision title game with a 55-35 victory over Richmond last night in Boone, N.C.Edwards dominated on the ground as the Mountaineers built a 21-point lead. After Richmond (12-3) rallied to tie the score, Edwards threw two passes for touchdowns in the final 10 minutes. His yards rushing were the most by a quarterback in the F.C.S.  formerly Division I-AA. Appalachian State (12-2) will play the winner of today’s Delaware-Southern Illinois game next Friday in Chattanooga, Tenn.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article in some editions on Tuesday about a charity project called the Penny Harvest Field, to be unveiled on Monday in Rockefeller Plaza, reversed the identities of the two leaders of the project. Teddy Gross, of the nonprofit education group Common Cents, was second from left, and James S. Polshek, an architect, was at the right.

headline: A Switch Is Flipped, and Justice Listens In
text: On Christmas Day 2005, Erik Crespo was given a small red MP3 player as a gift. That night, he got on an elevator in the Highbridge section of the Bronx and shot a man in the face.

headline: Analysts Cut Credit Firms
text: A Merrill Lynch analyst, Kenneth Bruce, cut American Express, Capital One Financial and Discover Financial Services to sell from neutral, predicting a deterioration in consumer spending.

headline: Credit Card Settlement
text: Some 30 million people across the nation are receiving notices that they may be eligible for $25 or more from the settlement of a class-action suit over foreign currency conversions on credit and debit cards.

headline: A Sneak Preview Online
text: The first 10 minutes of “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story,” a new comedy co-produced by Judd Apatow, will be available online this weekend on four popular Web sites: MySpace.com, IGN.com, Rottentomatoes.com and walkhard-movie.com. The footage went up yesterday afternoon. The preview coincides with the Cox Across America Tour, a seven-city concert series featuring the film’s star, John C. Reilly, as Dewey Cox, a hard-living musician. The film opens Dec. 21.

headline: Settlement for Torture of 4 Men by Police
text: CHICAGO, Dec. 7  The City of Chicago is preparing to pay nearly $20 million to four men who were once sent to death row after interrogations that they say amounted to torture by the Chicago police, the city’s law department said on Friday.

headline: Huckabee Immigration Plan Emphasizes Security
text: Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate, released a plan for tougher immigration enforcement and border security yesterday, pledging to complete a border fence between the United States and Mexico by July 2010 and ruling out a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants unless they returned first to their country of origin.

headline: Free Speech on the Web
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Votes of Women
text: To the Editor:

headline: Delicate Singing and a Cow Call, Too
text: In the decade since the Trio Mediaeval was formed in Oslo, it has built a reputation, in contemporary as well as ancient repertory, for impeccably refined vocalism.

headline: Spies Like You and Me
text: Let the witch hunt begin. Are you now or have you ever been an illegal immigrant?

headline: CBS Survives
text: CBS earned the most viewers in every hour of prime time on Thursday, but ABC ranked first among viewers 18 to 49. CBS kicked off with “Survivor: China,” which dominated the 8 p.m. hour with 14 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. At 9, CBS’s “CSI” delivered the night’s largest audience (18.3 million), but ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” (17.6 million) stayed No. 1 among the 18-to-49 set. ABC also led at 10 in that age group with Barbara Walters’s “10 Most Fascinating People of 2007” (11.7 million). CBS’s “Without a Trace” finished first in total viewers at 10 (12.7 million), while NBC’s “ER” drew 8.1 million. NBC ranked third and Fox fourth among viewers 18 to 49.

headline: Gold’s Quirk: It’s Volatile, but Holders Feel Secure
text: On Nov. 7, the market price of a troy ounce of gold bullion briefly touched $845.50, the top so far in gold’s current eight-year bull market and a 28-year high in New York trading. The news made headlines and became a hot topic on radio talk shows.

headline: WHAT’S OFFLINE; Growing Big, Staying Fresh
text: THE law of large numbers is frustrating for big companies.

headline: Slowing Job Growth Seen as Ominous Sign for Economy
text: The nation gained a modest 94,000 jobs in November, the Labor Department reported yesterday, pulling back considerably from the previous month in the clearest sign yet that the American economy was headed for a substantial slowdown.

headline: Construction Worker Dies in the Bronx
text: A worker was killed yesterday at a construction site in the Bronx after he was pinned between two pieces of heavy equipment and then fell into an eight-foot-deep hole, the authorities said.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,689,769.55

headline: Special Payout at UAL
text: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said it would pay shareholders $250 million, or $2.15 a share, in a special distribution. The payout will be made on Jan. 23 to shareholders as of Jan. 9, UAL said.

headline: Young Israelis Resist Challenges to Settlements
Facing Up to the Reality of Losing a Teenage Son
text: Wana Joseph sometimes looks toward the front door of her home in East New York, Brooklyn, as if waiting for her son Terrell Bradley to enter. She still expects to see his head peering into her room to check on her. And when she hears rap music, she can’t help thinking of the dances he taught her.

headline: With Heisman a Dream, Defenders Take Solace in the N.F.L.’s Embrace
text: On Monday, Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey won the Bronko Nagurski Award for the nation’s top defensive player. On Wednesday, he was named the Southeastern Conference’s defensive player of the year. Later that evening, he claimed the Lombardi Award as the top college lineman or linebacker, and on Thursday he was awarded the Outland Trophy as the country’s top interior lineman.

headline: Holiday TV Is Devoted to Lightness (and Yes, Lots of Lights)
text: Two American inventions, the holiday marketing season and the made-for-television movie, collide every December, scattering tears and tinsel across the weekends leading up to Christmas. There’s a five-film pile-up tonight and tomorrow night, which means that with judicious use of a DVR, you could spend 10 hours (minus commercials, about seven and a half) having your heart tugged and your tear ducts massaged. No sane person would do that, of course, which is where I come in.

headline: Americans Held in Iraq Draw Justices’ Attention
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Expanding its inquiry into the role of the courts at a time of armed conflict, the Supreme Court accepted two cases on Friday that test whether federal judges have the authority to prevent military officials in Iraq from turning United States citizens over to the Iraqis for criminal prosecution or punishment.

headline: Bonds Pleads Not Guilty to Federal Charges
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  Barry Bonds, baseball’s home run king and the most prominent target of a five-year federal investigation into performance-enhancing drugs in sports, stood in a hushed federal courtroom Friday morning with his hands clasped behind his back and pleaded not guilty to five felony charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.

headline: Kazakh Leader Suggests Way to End Oil Standoff
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Dec. 7  Kazakhstan wants to raise its stake or receive compensation for cost overruns and delays in the gigantic Kashagan offshore field, the largest oil find in more than three decades, the country’s president said on Friday.

headline: Britain to Take Back 3 From Guantánamo
text: LONDON, Dec. 7  Three former British residents detained at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, whose release had long been negotiated by the governments of Britain and the United States, are about to be freed, their lawyers said Friday.

headline: In Russia, Ford Hurt by Strike and Rising Pay
text: VSEVOLOZHSK, Russia, Dec. 7  A strike at the Ford Motor Company assembly line has slowed production and cost the company, the pioneer of foreign car manufacturing in Russia, millions of dollars in lost production. Workers walked off the job on Nov. 22 at the Ford plant in this outlying district of St. Petersburg.

headline: Warming and the Right
text: LAST June, Jim Manzi, a longtime software executive, laid out a case in The National Review for the need for conservatives to accept the “reality” of global warming (nationalreview.com). It is, he wrote, “no longer possible, scientifically or politically, to deny that human activities have very likely increased global temperatures; what remains in dispute is the precise magnitude of the human impact.”

headline: Canadian Retailer Bans Some Plastic Bottles
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 7  A line of water bottles that had become a symbol of environmental responsibility has been removed from the shelves of Canada’s leading outdoor gear retailer over concerns about a chemical used in its manufacture.

headline: Winners and Losers of the Week in Foreign Policy
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  For the Democratic presidential hopefuls on the campaign trail, this week has been like Christmas in, well, December, all gift-wrapped and delivered straight from Washington in the form of three foreign policy bombshells.

headline: Plea In Inside-Trading Case
text: Juan Renteria, a former worker at a Wisconsin plant that printed BusinessWeek magazine, pleaded guilty for his role in an insider trading scheme that netted more than $6.7 million.

headline: Stocks, Sure, but Trading Places Can Be Enriching, Too
text: I AM in my own little fantasy land right now.

headline: From ‘Troubled’ to ‘Killer,’ Despite Many Efforts
text: OMAHA, Dec. 7  “As the twig is bent, so grows the tree.” A sign bearing these severe but hopeful words marks the entrance to Cooper Village, a residential treatment facility for teenagers along the rural northern edge of Omaha.

headline: A Nobelists Acceptance Speech
text: In her acceptance speech for the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature, Doris Lessing lamented a “fragmenting culture” in which “it is common for young men and women who have had years of education to know nothing about the world, to have read nothing, knowing only some specialty or other, for instance computers.” Ms. Lessing, 88, was unable to attend the awards ceremony in Stockholm yesterday because of ill health. Her British editor, Nicholas Pearson, read her speech. Ms. Lessing, who grew up in Africa, wrote of poverty-stricken schools in Zimbabwe where students yearn for books, while students at a privileged London school that she once visited read little. She criticized the Internet for having “seduced a whole generation into its inanities” and ended with an anecdote about a pregnant mother of two “somewhere in southern Africa” who must travel to procure scant water for her family and yet craves a copy of “Anna Karenina.” Ms. Lessing concluded: “I think it is that girl and the women who were talking about books and an education when they had not eaten for three days, that may yet define us.”

headline: Buyer to Close CompUSA
text: CompUSA, the consumer-electronics retailer owned by the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim, said it was acquired by the restructuring firm Gordon Brothers Group, which plans to close or sell its 103 stores.

headline: Like Subprime Mortgages, Some Construction Loans Are Delinquent
text: BANKS across the United States, particularly the smaller ones, have become dependent on construction lending just as that area of the economy is weakening and the number of bad loans is growing.

headline: Two Window Washers Fall 47 Floors
text: Two brothers who worked together as window washers plunged 47 stories yesterday morning with their scaffold from the roof of an Upper East Side apartment building. One was killed, cut in half by a wooden fence in an alley below, and the other was gravely injured but somehow survived.

headline: Officials Defended; 4 Ravens Are Fined
text: The National Football League fined four Baltimore Ravens players yesterday for violating rules prohibiting verbal abuse of game officials during the Ravens’ loss to the Patriots on Monday night.

headline: New Details on Opera Renovation
text: Interviews with Gerard Mortier, the incoming general manager of the New York City Opera, and Susan L. Baker, its chairwoman, have yielded new details in response to reports that the opera may shut down for the 2008-9 season so its home, the New York State Theater, can undergo acoustical and other renovations. Mr. Mortier has long said that the State Theater will have to close for a few months and has promised all new productions for at least for the 2009-10 season, his first in charge. In an interview, he said it was “likely” that the theater would go dark for the spring of 2009, with work done in time for rehearsals to begin in August. However, he and Ms. Baker said that no decision on a closing had been made, and that none would be until after a board meeting on Wednesday. In response to reports that he wanted to discard all the company’s older productions, Mr. Mortier, reached by telephone in Luxembourg, said he would probably keep some of them, especially those of American works. He also mentioned Jonathan Miller’s “Rigoletto,” which he called “a famous production,” adding, “I don’t see why I should throw it away.” Final planning for the 2008-9 season has been held up, he said, by uncertainty over the theater’s fate.

headline: Months After Protests, Myanmar Junta in Control
text: BANGKOK, Dec. 7  The streets are quiet in Myanmar. The “destructive elements” are in jail. The international outcry has faded. The junta’s grip on power seems firm.

headline: Norval Morrisseau, Native Canadian Artist, Is Dead
text: Norval Morrisseau, also known as Copper Thunderbird, one of Canada’s most celebrated painters and an important influence in the development of North American indigenous art, died Tuesday in Toronto. He was thought to be 75, though his birth year has been listed as both 1931 and 1932.

headline: Alois Kracher Jr., Austrian Winemaker and Advocate, Is Dead at 48
text: Alois Kracher Jr., a visionary winemaker whose luscious sweet wines and forceful personality were instrumental in restoring the Austrian wine industry’s international reputation after a 1985 scandal, died Tuesday at his home in Illmitz, in the Burgenland region of Austria. He was 48.

headline: C.I.A. Was Urged to Keep Interrogation Videotapes
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  White House and Justice Department officials, along with senior members of Congress, advised the Central Intelligence Agency in 2003 against a plan to destroy hundreds of hours of videotapes showing the interrogations of two operatives of Al Qaeda, government officials said Friday.

headline: Playing With Momentum in a Range of Physical Tests
text: Jennifer Nugent and Paul Matteson formed their professional partnership in 2005 with the creation of Nugent & Matteson Dance. Both are also former members of David Dorfman Dance, where their personalities emerged: Ms. Nugent’s as the tough, no-nonsense woman, and Mr. Matteson’s as the probing, sensitive man. “Pieced Apart,” their new collection of four works being performed at Danspace Project, seems to be an attempt to move beyond the myths, real or imagined, but it doesn’t entirely succeed.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Opera in the Armory
text: “Die Soldaten,” an opera by the German composer Bernd Alois Zimmermann, was first performed in Germany in a former power plant. In July it will be presented in the Park Avenue Armory, in a joint production of the Lincoln Center Festival and the armory. This will be the North American premiere of a 2006 German production, featuring a 110-piece orchestra and a cast of 40 singers, actors and dancers. It will be staged in the armory’s vaulted former drill hall for five performances from July 5 to July 12. “Die Soldaten” was staged twice in the United States before this production; it had its premiere at the Cologne Opera in 1965. Tickets will become available in mid-March.

headline: Supreme Court to Review Courts’ Wartime Reach
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  The Supreme Court, expanding its inquiry into the role of federal courts at a time of armed conflict, today accepted two cases testing whether federal judges have authority to prevent military officials in Iraq from turning United States citizens over to the Iraqis for criminal prosecution or punishment.

headline: A Separate Union, of Athletes, for Athletes
text: The need for an association of professional athletes was never more apparent than in the aftermath of the murder of Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor.

headline: Trucks Power China’s Economy, at a Suffocating Cost
text: GUANGZHOU, China  Every night, columns of hulking blue and red freight trucks invade China’s major cities with a reverberating roar of engines and dark clouds of diesel exhaust so thick it dims headlights.

headline: Liberia: Ex-President Arrested
text: Gyude Bryant, left, a businessman who led the transitional government that operated from the exile of Charles Taylor in 2003 to the inauguration of Ellen Johnson Sirleaf last year, was arrested for violating conditions of his bail while on trial on charges of embezzling $1.3 million from the government. The arrest was ordered after Mr. Bryant failed to show up in court twice this week. He was taken to Monrovia’s central prison.

headline: Budget Makers Plan Tradeoff for War Funds
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  Congressional leaders are assembling a $500 billion package to try to resolve an impasse by providing President Bush with unfettered money for the Iraq war in exchange for new spending on popular domestic programs.

headline: Writers’ Talks Collapse Amid Acrimony
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7  Talks between Hollywood’s striking writers and producers collapsed amid acrimony on Friday night, even as the sides braced for the likely appearance of a third party  the Directors Guild of America, whose own contract is up next June.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the C.I.A.’s destruction of two videotapes documenting the interrogations of agents of Al Qaeda rendered incorrectly a quotation from Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of intelligence, in which he explained to C.I.A. employees why he was informing them of the destruction. General Hayden said, “The press has learned that back in 2002, during the initial stage of our terrorist detention program, C.I.A. videotaped interrogations, and destroyed the tapes in 2005.” He did not say he was informing them “because” the press has learned about the episode.

headline: Marbury Returns as Knicks Come Up Empty
text: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7  The Knicks’ game against the Philadelphia 76ers on Friday night began like any other for Stephon Marbury. Moments before tip-off, he bumped chests with Nate Robinson and shook hands with Mardy Collins. The whole time, he was smiling.

headline: Authorities Investigate a Watchdog of the Docks
text: The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, an agency created more than 50 years ago to root out corruption on the docks that was immortalized by Marlon Brando, is itself now at the center of a wide-ranging investigation.

headline: Harsh Treatment for Youthful Offenders
text: The Justice Department has the authority to sue juvenile detention systems that allow detainees to be abused or that fail to provide safe conditions. The department, which has invoked this authority many times in the past, should take a hard look at Texas’s notoriously troubled juvenile justice system.

headline: An Emerging Conductor in a Program of Re-emerging Works
text: During the Kurt Masur years, the New York Philharmonic was fairly criticized for not trying hard enough to bring young conductors to its podium. But under Lorin Maazel, the orchestra has done much better at showcasing today’s emerging maestros.

headline: Elite Lawyers Anchor the Defense
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  Barry Bonds has spent the last couple of weeks interviewing top defense lawyers in the Bay Area. By all accounts, he ended up with an all-star lineup.

headline: At Fairs by the Beach, the Sands of Creativity
text: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 7  Last week the art world descended on the New Museum of Contemporary Art’s new building on the Lower East Side, where the art was fragmentary, improvisational and defiantly down-to-earth. This week the same crowd has massed here in Miami Beach for the sixth installment of Art Basel Miami Beach, a fair that celebrates everything the New Museum has made an effort to avoid.

headline: Framework for Annapolis
text: To the Editor:

headline: Maybe a Way to Get Rich Off the Rich
text: WHEN times get tough, people with an abundance of disposable income are inclined to keep disposing of it while the rest of us are forced to keep our thinner wallets in our pockets.

headline: Candle Power
text: MY family came to America from Egypt in 1963. We arrived during Hanukkah, and I remember being unable to take my eyes off the electric menorahs glowing in the windows of houses in Brooklyn, where we set out to hunt for our first apartment.

headline: The Pursuit of Justice, or Money?
text: “If I don’t bring the lead paint industry to its knees in three years, I will give them my boat.”

headline: In Russia, Ford Hurt by Strike and Rising Pay
text: VSEVOLOZHSK, Russia, Dec. 7  A strike at the Ford Motor Company assembly line has slowed production and cost the company millions of dollars. Workers walked off the job on Nov. 22 at the Ford plant in this outlying district of St. Petersburg.

headline: At the Shore, Although the Water Is Shallower
text: Imagine how much sleep future musicologists will lose over Philip Glass. Throughout his career he has changed his scores to suit the circumstances, trimming them for recordings, for example, because he believes that nonvisual performances benefit from (relative) concision. The notion of an immutable, sacrosanct urtext  the very thing musicologists sift historical evidence hoping to establish  is entirely alien to him.

headline: Looking Back on the Year That Sums Up the ’60s
text: A theory on documentaries that strip-mine the 1960s: The less fresh insight the program has to offer, the earlier the Buffalo Springfield song “For What It’s Worth” will turn up on the soundtrack. Written by Stephen Stills, that astonishing song (“There’s something happening here/What it is ain’t exactly clear”) came to encapsulate ’60s turmoil so perfectly that resorting to it is a subconscious admission by a documentarian: “I have nothing to say that Stephen Stills didn’t say better in 2 minutes 41 seconds.”

headline: Kidd Is Slow to Start in Return, as Are the Nets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 7  Jason Kidd returned Friday night from, depending upon whom you believe, his bout with migraine headaches or his one-game protest, but he was of little help to the struggling Nets. With Kidd unable to get untracked until late in the fourth quarter, the Nets lost, 96-89, to the Houston Rockets.

headline: Under Fire, State Dept. Watchdog Quits
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)  Howard J. Krongard, the embattled State Department inspector general who has been accused of impeding a Justice Department investigation of Blackwater Worldwide and other inquiries, announced his resignation on Friday.

headline: Congress Looks Into Obstruction as Calls for Justice Inquiry Rise
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7  The Central Intelligence Agency faced the threat of obstruction-of-justice investigations on Friday from both the Justice Department and Congressional committees over the destruction of videotapes of interrogations of Qaeda operatives.

headline: Monitoring of Police Should End, Corzine Says
text: TRENTON, Dec. 7  Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Friday that he would ask the federal government to halt its oversight of the New Jersey State Police because of sufficient reforms made in the eight years since its troopers were found to be engaging in racial profiling at traffic stops.

headline: Britain: Light From Once-Dead Kayaker
text: The police continued to question John Darwin, the man who suddenly reappeared more than five years after he was thought to have drowned after a kayaking accident. He originally said he could not remember anything but is now “putting forward some sort of account,” a police official said. He is being held on suspicion of fraud. His wife, Anne, who moved to Panama six weeks ago and originally claimed to be surprised that her husband was not dead, has now admitted to several British tabloids that she had known for some time that he was alive. She is said to be on her way back to England, where she is likely to face arrest. The couple’s two sons said they had no idea of what their parents were apparently up to. “If the papers’ allegations of a confession from our mam are true, then we very much feel that we have been the victims of a large scam,” they said in a statement.

headline: Court Rules Against Same-Sex Divorce
text: BOSTON, Dec. 7  The Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled Friday that same-sex couples who marry in Massachusetts, the only state that allows same-sex marriage, may not divorce in Rhode Island.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 8
text: Here is a slide show of 11 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the first night of Hanukkah, Venezuelans voting in absentia and a 61-year love affair sparked in a concentration camp during World War II.

headline: Gates Says Iran Remains a Threat
text: MANAMA, Bahrain, Dec. 8  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Saturday that Iran is a grave threat to regional security even without nuclear weapons, and called on Tehran to account for American intelligence that describes its support for terrorism and instability around the world.

headline: Last Race of the Season
text: The Frank Viola Homing Pigeon Club of Coney Island holds its final race of the fall.

headline: Obama’s Musical Draw
text: The old Riviera theater in Chicago, usually a venue for bands that are too big for the small venues and too small for the big ones, hosted an improbable headliner Friday night. “BARACK OBAMA,” read the marquee, “CHANGE ROCKS.”

headline: Clinton and Her Mother
text: At an event in Des Moines, Dorothy Rodham, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's mother, made her debut on the 2008 presidential campaign trail.

headline: The Early Word: Tense Times for Huckabee and Romney
text: When Kate Phillips wrote about the rapist who murdered a woman after he was released on parole during Mike Huckabee’s tenure as govenror in Arkansas, she said, “We can guarantee you that this will not go away.” It hasn’t. Today, The Los Angeles Times’s Richard A. Serrano examines today whether “his deep Christian faith — what on the stump he says ‘defines me’ — colored his view of Wayne DuMond’s case.”

headline: 35 M.P.G., Until You Read the Fine Print
text: It is a bit disorienting to find environmentalists giddy green over something being done by Congress. But despite one annoying loophole, environmentalists seemed thrilled that the House of Representatives passed the Energy Independence and Security Act Thursday.

headline: Mel in Costa Rica
text: Actor/Director/Controversy Magnet Mel Gibson is reportedly focusing on Costa Rica for his future endeavors. According to the Associated Press, Gibson was inMel Gibson

headline: Art Murmur: Day Three at Art Basel Miami
text: Nadja Swarovski doesn’t bruise easily. She laughed when told that “Light Sock,” the new work for the Swarovski Crystal Palace created by Diller, Scofidio + Renfro, resembles a scrotum…Even among the slew of artists celebrating appropriation, Eric Doeringer stands out like a ham at Hanukkah. Doeringer, who used to sell his irreverent knock-offs on the Chelsea sidewalks, was the breakout star at Geisai—despite the fact that his new enabler, Takashi Murakami, once sent him a cease-and-desist letter…Pharrell Williams popped in to the pop-up tattoo parlor at Design Miami and offered to create a design, joining the likes of Vito Acconci, Yves Béhar and Tord Boontje…What is the fate of two large-scale pieces by the hotter-than-Hades L.A. artist Dave Muller? Sources at Barbara Gladstone and Blum & Poe, in whose booths Muller spent days painting a stop sign and disco ball directly onto the walls, said the ‘ideas’ have been sold, but once the fair is over, the actual works will most likely be destroyed. So much for ars longa.

headline: Writers’ Talks Collapse Amid Acrimony
text: “Talks between Hollywood’s striking writers and producers collapsed amid acrimony on Friday night,” Michael Cieply reports in today’s Times.

headline: Saturday Kickoff: It’s Heisman Time
text: How are we going to get through the first Saturday without college football games? Well, luckily for us, the Heisman Trophy will be handed out tonight. No matter which of the four finalists wins, there is likely to be some moaning and groaning. The arguments for and against all of them have been made, so we’ll start off with a little Heisman history lesson from the Kansas City Star’s Joe Posnanski.

headline: Clinton in Arkansas
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has long been the wary partner in the Clinton marriage, a trait that revealed itself early in her political life.

headline: Paul’s Supporters Take to the Air
text: Hot air will be infused into the presidential campaign early next week.

headline: Chelsea’s Iowa Debut
text: DES MOINES – With Oprah Winfrey headed here on Saturday to campaign for Senator Barack Obama, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton brought a surprise guest of her own: Chelsea Clinton.

headline: He’s Ba-aack
text: The Atlanta Thrashers scooped up 39-year-old Mark Recchi from re-entry waivers. They will split his $1.75 million salary with Pittsburgh for the balance of the season. He becomes a free agent after that.

headline: Bill Clinton’s South Carolina Pitch
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. _ While the presidential candidates are traipsing across Iowa today, South Carolina became the staging ground for a battle of their most prominent surrogates.

headline: Hydrogen Car Is Here, but Where’s the Hydrogen Economy?
text: In the Greentech column of this weekend’s Autos section in The New York Times, Norman Mayersohn has a nice overview of Honda’s new hydrogen-fueled FCX Clarity, a (very) limited-edition sedan powered by fuel cells that, Mayersohn writes, Honda will begin leasing to a handful of private customers next summer.

headline: Long-Term Care a Focus for Clinton
text: WINTERSET, Iowa – In a frigid airplane hangar here, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced her plan for tax breaks for long-term health care, pledging a $3,000 tax credit for caregiving and a long-term care insurance tax credit.

headline: Personnel File: Being Third Option Works for Crayton
text: There are few advantages to being a team’s third option in its passing attack, but for Dallas Cowboys wide receiver PATRICK CRAYTON, that does not mean that he does not get his chances to dance in the end zone.

headline: Week 14 In Preview: A Distant Chance of Finding a Weakness
text: The Patriots do so many things well that searching for a weakness can be as futile as guaranteeing a victory against them, which Steelers safety Anthony Smith did on Wednesday.

text: In her Web column today, Helene Cooper examines which presidential candidates benefit politically from three major developments in foreign policy over the past week and finds that Democrats come out on top. Go to column

headline: Oprah in Des Moines
text: DES MOINES – “Oh my goodness,” Oprah Winfrey said. “At last, I’m here.”

headline: Martial Cuisinarts: Will Chuck Norris Blend?
text: In his new campaign ad with Chuck Norris, Mike Huckabee says that when the celebrity tough guy does a pushup, the earth goes down. But will Chuck Norris blend?

headline: More ‘Late Night’ Comedy
text: Uh-oh: The writers’ strike talks aren’t going anywhere. Better keep your jokes coming (via the comment link below). Here are some fresh ones:

headline: Well, Shut My Mouth
Weekend Explorer: Upper East Side
text: John Strausbaugh explores a neighborhood that was never as exclusive as some  of its residents had hoped.

headline: The Islanders’ Special Coach
text: In a move that will be tough to top as the classiest of the season, Islanders Coach Ted Nolan invited Al Arbour back to try to reach 1,500 coaching victories. The Isles got Arbour his milestone. Roy MacGregor, the captivating columnist with The Globe and Mail, has a revealing and poignant profile of Nolan here. Nolan’s 10-year banishment from the N.H.L., is surely one of the league’s bigger embarrassments.

headline: It’s Official: Tebow Wins the Heisman
text: The waiting ended tonight when Florida quarterback Tim Tebow was announced as the winner of the Heisman Trophy. Tebow is the first sophomore to win the Heisman.

headline: On the Campaign Trail: Oprah & Obama
text: Des Moines, Iowa

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Dec. 9
text: After Mitt Romney’s major speech about faith in America, the other G.O.P. contenders have a chance to get some airtime on this Sunday’s shows.

headline: CBS Executive Roger M. King Dies at 63
text: “Roger M. King, the CBS and King World Productions executive who helped bring stars including Oprah Winfrey, Alex Trebek and ”Dr. Phil” McGraw to television, died Saturday of a stroke, a CBS spokesman said. He was 63,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: A Gordie Howe Hat Trick, Nashville Style
text: Jordin Tootoo, the 5-foot-9 battering ram for the Nashville Predators, recorded a Gordie Howe hat trick (goal, assist, fight) against Anaheim on Saturday. Tootoo scored the first goal of the game in the opening period, dropped the gloves with defenseman Joe DiPenta five minutes later and assisted on a Ryan Suter goal in the second period. The Predators beat the Ducks, 4-2.

headline: Grabbing an Opportunity With Both Gloves
text: Tommy Gainey vividly remembers what his days were like 10 years ago, when he made $8.75 an hour on an assembly line wrapping insulation around water heaters.

headline: Biodegradable Coffins
text: This July, when Jorgi Wu was laid to rest in central California, she became the first American to be buried in an Ecopod  a 100 percent biodegradable coffin made of recycled paper. The seedpod-shaped coffin is designed to be planted in the ground, dissolve and replenish the earth with its nutrient-rich contents. Who needs embalming, cement vaults or herbicide-based lawn care?

headline: A Very Old Zen Master and His Art of Tough Love
text: JEMEZ SPRINGS, N.M.  What would Buddha do?

headline: The Government and Our Health (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Moral Uncertainty Never Looked So Good
text: At the start of “Doubt,” Father Flynn, the earnest central figure in John Patrick Shanley’s play, begins a sermon by asking: “What do you do when you’re not sure?”

headline: In One Village, Making a Balanced Display for Two Celebrations
text: Briarcliff Manor

headline: Getting a Handle on Taxes
text: The cover article in this section last Sunday explored the many ways Westchester is grappling with its tax burden, which has been steadily encroaching on people’s bank accounts like some unstoppable mold from outer space. Property taxes here rose 67 percent from 1995 to 2005, giving Westchester at least the bronze medal among all United States counties in the high-tax Olympics.

headline: At Historic Synagogue, a Congregation at Last
text: Milford

headline: Letters: Rock of Ages, Ages of Rock
