text: Hanna Rosin’s article (Nov. 25) reveals much about the current state of “young earth” creation science.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE BEST INTENTIONS: Kofi Annan and the UN in the Era of American World Power, by James Traub. (Picador, $16.) In 2004, James Traub, a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine, scored the kind of coup journalists dream of: he persuaded Kofi Annan, then the secretary general of the United Nations, to give him unparalleled access. Traub wound up talking to Annan 18 times, as well as to his closest aides. The result is an incisive, meticulously researched study of the problems of collective action at the post-cold-war U.N. Although “this benevolent and somewhat cryptic sovereign,” as Traub calls him, had the best intentions, he was no match for the power politics and scheming he encountered. Our reviewer, Josef Joffe, called the book the “best” guide to the United Nations “in recent memory.”

headline: Next Violin, The
text: The music sounded glorious: like the rich, sweet notes of a lovely old violin or cello. Yet it came from five weirdly shaped wooden objects, which served as resonators for vibrations coming from an electric violin. It was the first performance, at the Serpentine Gallery in London this fall, of the prototype of an entirely new stringed instrument.

headline: Left-Hand-Turn Elimination
text: It seems that sitting in the left lane, engine idling, waiting for oncoming traffic to clear so you can make a left-hand turn, is minutely wasteful — of time and peace of mind, for sure, but also of gas and therefore money. Not a ton of gas and money if we’re talking about just you and your Windstar, say, but immensely wasteful if we’re talking about more than 95,000 big square brown trucks delivering packages every day. And this realization — that when you operate a gigantic fleet of vehicles, tiny improvements in the efficiency of each one will translate to huge savings overall — is what led U.P.S. to limit further the number of left-hand turns its drivers make.

headline: A War to End All Campaigns
text: Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Correction: In Colombia, a War Zone Reclaims Its Past
text: An article on Nov. 11 about Tayrona National Park in Colombia misstated the extent to which kidnappings have been reduced since the Colombian president, Álvaro Uribe, initiated his new security policy in late 2003. According to the Vice Presidency and Ministry of Defense of Colombia and the U.S. State Department, kidnappings have been reduced from about 2,000 in 2003 to 687 last year and 393 from January to September 2007. The number of kidnappings was not brought down from 3,000 in 2003 to 100 a year.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Mafia’
text: A review on Nov. 18 about “Mafia: The Government’s Secret File on Organized Crime,” by the United States Treasury Department, Bureau of Narcotics, misstated the surname of a Hemingway character whom the book called to the mind of the reviewer. It is Ole Andreson, not Anderson.

headline: A Mormon’s Ultimate Doorbell
text: IT is probably not to his advantage that Mitt Romney’s clean-scrubbed, youthful presence so readily reminds voters of those earnest Mormon missionaries knocking on their doors.

headline: Brothers Concerned About Scaffold, Relative Says
text: Two brothers who plunged 47 stories from a Manhattan building when their window-washing platform collapsed  killing one and gravely injuring the other  knew their scaffold had a mechanical problem before they ascended the tower, but were assured by a boss that it had been fixed, a family member said yesterday.

headline: Letters: High-Def at High Noon
text: Martin Scorsese is right: If you haven’t seen “The Searchers” in VistaVision on a giant screen, then you haven’t seen it at all (The Medium, Nov. 11). Ten years ago, while visiting Jackson Hole, Wyoming, my husband and I, with two friends, got to see the film in the town’s historic local theater. We knew this was a rare opportunity to step out of the West (as tourist resort) and see Ford’s film the way he intended. The brutal force of John Wayne’s performance, in bas-relief against Monument Valley, took my breath away.

headline: Fatalities in Connecticut Brought Restrictions
text: ON the afternoon her teenage son hit a patch of black ice and lost control of his car while on his way home from school, Connie Jascowski rushed to the scene. A passenger in her 16-year-old son’s car who was hurt had managed to ask a witness to call her.

headline: Letters
text: You’ve Got Humor

headline: The Suburban Life: Stuck in a Penn
text: We are well into mating-walrus season on the Long Island Rail Road, when herds of riders in bulky winter coats shuffle and snuffle and sometimes snap at one another as they jockey for space on station platforms and in train aisles.

headline: College Loans by States Face Fresh Scrutiny
text: DES MOINES  When Iowa set up a corporation to make student loans more available, it hoped to expand access to college. Now state officials are investigating whether the corporation’s aggressive practices to get business help explain why Iowa’s college graduates have the nation’s second-highest debt burden per student.

headline: Hong Kong Shows Examine Fashion and Jewelry Design
text: The Hong Kong Heritage Museum is offering a lesson in local fashion and jewelry design this year. Through March 31, “Fashion Attitude — Hong Kong Fashion Design” will feature the works of nine Hong Kong fashion designers, including Barney Chang, Lu Lu Cheung, Peter Lau, and Ika, whose work is pictured below. Starting May 18 and running through Jan. 5, 2009, is “Jewelry for Life — Meaning and Adornment.” This exhibition will explore the history of jewelry, specifically Hong Kong’s history in manufacturing jewelry for global export. Approximately six manufacturer brands and four designer brands will show representative works in the forms of photographs, sketches and film footage. Admission: 10 Hong Kong dollars, or about $1.25 at 7.9 Hong Kong dollars to $1. (www.heritagemuseum.gov.hk).

headline: Self-Righting Object, The
text: The Gomboc is a roundish piece of clear synthetic material with gently peaked, organic curves. It looks like a piece of modern art. But if you tip it over, something unusual happens: it rights itself.

headline: Up Front
text: In this issue we present our selection of the 10 Best Books of 2007, split evenly, once again, between fiction and nonfiction. We chose two novels in translation, “The Savage Detectives” and “Out Stealing Horses,” by justly admired foreign masters; two first novels, “Man Gone Down” — a paperback original — and “Then We Came to the End,” by gifted young Americans; and, in “Tree of Smoke,” a major work by a third American writing at the peak of his formidable powers.

headline: Clubs Bloom in the Desert
text: SIX years ago, Dion Mavath, an Australian D.J., flew to Dubai to take up residency at an upstart local nightclub. Dubai, a fledgling metropolis, was still mostly known as an airport hub and a shipping port, and the local night-life scene, he quickly found, was nearly as sterile and undistinguished as the flat Middle Eastern desert landscape.

headline: The New Needy, Outpacing Charity
text: Huntington Station

headline: Artistically, Light Years Ahead
text: THE way people talk about the art bubble, as some fragile thing about to pop, you would think it was made of money. But though there is plenty of green around, as this weekend’s enormous Art Basel Miami Beach juggernaut clearly proves, the artisphere is forged of sterner stuff than junk bonds. It is so much about connections  aesthetic, intellectual and, above all, social  that the real art bubble is more like a rarefied world under glass, where you can look at, buy, talk about and live with art, all while breathing some exclusive art fumes.

headline: John Strugnell, Scholar Undone by His Slur, Dies at 77
text: John Strugnell, a respected biblical scholar at Harvard whose tenure as the chief editor of the Dead Sea Scrolls ended in controversy over anti-Semitic remarks he made in an interview, died on Nov. 30 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 77 and lived in nearby Arlington.

headline: Don’t Rush to Install New Voting Machines (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Episcopal Diocese Votes to Secede
text: FRESNO, Calif., Dec. 8  The Diocese of San Joaquin voted on Saturday to cut ties with the Episcopal Church, the first time in the church’s history a diocese has done so over theological issues and the biggest leap so far by dissident Episcopalians hoping to form a rival national church in the United States.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘The Letters of Noël Coward’
text: A review on Nov. 25 about “The Letters of Noël Coward,” edited by Barry Day, misstated the British military branch that issued the serial number 338171 to Lawrence of Arabia, one of Coward’s correspondents, who liked to use it to preface his own letters. It was the Royal Air Force, not the army.

headline: Weapon-Proof School Gear
text: Mike Pelonzi and Joe Curran aren’t paranoid; they just have a few rules when it comes to their kids’ safety. No bike riding without a helmet. No boating without a life vest. And no going to school without a bulletproof backpack.

headline: Rome Tour Features Music and Architecture
text: Seven private performances of Roman music in seven historic sites is the focus of a special package called “Rome: A Festival of Music,” from Feb. 3 to 9. Sponsored by Martin Randall Travel (www.martinrandall.com), the package features performances by the Gabrieli Consort and Andreas Scholl, among others, in settings like the Santa Maria in Trastevere, below. The package includes six nights’ accommodation, three dinners with wine and a private visit to the Sistine Chapel. Prices start at £1,870, or $3,927 at $2.10 to the pound, excluding airfare.

headline: The New New Philosophy
text: Suppose the chairman of a company has to decide whether to adopt a new program. It would increase profits and help the environment too. “I don’t care at all about helping the environment,” the chairman says. “I just want to make as much profit as I can. Let’s start the new program.” Would you say that the chairman intended to help the environment?

headline: Cowboys at Lions
text: COWBOYS at LIONS

headline: Industrial Evolution
text: Every story has to begin somewhere. Do we think technological progress was responsible for the Industrial Revolution and the astonishing increase in living standards in some countries but not others since then? Fine, but what brought about the new technology? Maybe social and political institutions — democracy, tolerance, the rule of law — played a role in when and where living standards increased. But where did they come from?

headline: A Sitcom Battles Its Own Prehistory
text: IN a deceptively agreeable column published in The Oregonian on Oct. 29, the television critic Peter Ames Carlin interjected two revolutionary sentences  13 seditious words that might cause polite readers to question his judgment, if not his sanity.

headline: On the Crest of a Food Wave
text: LOU ELROSE, a retired police officer with a passion for barbecue, is suddenly a hot commodity.

headline: Wikiscanning
text: When Virgil Griffith, a 24-year-old hacker, heard reports that Congressional staff members had been caught altering Wikipedia for the benefit of their boss, he got to thinking of all the other kinds of spin occurring on the site. After all, the very elements that make Wikipedia popular — its egalitarian, participatory spirit, mutative nature and easy anonymity — make the online encyclopedia all too vulnerable to manipulation by unscrupulous contributors.

headline: A Microbrewery for Hydrogen
text: IN the standoff between hydrogen supply and hydrogen demand, neither side has blinked yet.

headline: Digital Search Parties
text: In early September, the aviator and adventurer Steve Fossett took off from a private airstrip in Nevada in a single-engine Bellanca Citabria Super Decathlon. When he failed to return in several hours as planned, a search team got together. Unfortunately, Fossett hadn’t filed a flight plan and no one knew where he was headed. The total search area  some 17,000 square miles  proved a daunting challenge for the rescuers. To help out, a digital search party was formed.

headline: G.M.’s Fuel-Cell Test: 100 Cars, No Charge
text: AS Honda prepares to lease a handful of fuel-cell cars to consumers, General Motors is offering its own hydrogen cars free.

headline: True Meaning of Christmas
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rubles Are a Girl’s Best Friend
text: MOSCOW

headline: Divorce and a Haircut, Two Bits
text: FOR the first time in 13 years, I was sitting in a barber’s chair. The barber, Mike  mid-50s, short, with a head of thinning, perfectly groomed hair  turned me to face the mirror and asked, “So, what are we going to do today?”

headline: An Old Master Still in Development
text: ELLIOTT CARTER, a celebrated figure on the international stage even before Georg Solti took his Variations for Orchestra to Europe with the Chicago Symphony in 1971, is the most respected and admired of American composers. Festivals devoted to his music have taken place in many cities, including London, Paris and Madrid.

headline: Specialty License Plate Sought for Anglers
text: FOR the proud angler for whom a bumper sticker just isn’t enough, two state senators have introduced legislation to create a license plate for motorists who put the “fish” in aficionado.

headline: Yes, Whoosh Our Mail, but Only if We Want It! (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Opening Young Eyes to a Prize: a Career in Medicine
text: Amanda Rowley, a soft-spoken 11-year-old from Harlem, already knows what she wants to be: a heart surgeon. She got the idea a few years ago from watching the doctors on her favorite cable television shows. She is often surprised when she meets people who do not take her seriously.

headline: China to Order Banks to Raise Cash Reserves
text: SHANGHAI, Dec. 8  China said today that for the 10th time this year, it would order banks to raise the amount of cash they set aside, in order to curb inflation and prevent the economy from overheating.

headline: Snuggle and Sip
text: THE honey-haired couple wasn’t up for group conversation. Seated at a communal farm table, they were content simply feeding each other forkfuls of gooey lasagna and occasionally cooing in one another’s ear. At Bacaro, a wine bar and osteria hidden in the deep recesses of East Chinatown, such behavior is encouraged.

headline: From Fuel to Fields
text: From Fuel to Fields

headline: Summer Dance Celebration to Have a 75th Anniversary
text: The American Dance Festival — an international celebration of modern dance — takes place every summer on the campus of Duke University in Durham, N.C. This year, from June 5 to July 19, it will have its 75th anniversary. The festival got its start in Vermont in the 1930s with the Bennington School of Dance, created by choreographers like Martha Graham and Doris Humphrey who wanted to develop a laboratory environment for their dancers. Now the festival brings together more than 400 students and 50 faculty members from all over the world, in addition to dozens of world-renowned dance companies. This year, the festival will feature multiple dance companies on the same bill, giving audiences the opportunity to see two or three different styles of dance on the same night. Confirmed American companies include Pilobolus, right, Shen Wei Dance Arts and Paul Taylor Dance Company. Other countries represented will include Japan, Turkey and the Netherlands (www.americandancefestival.org).

headline: The Fixer-Upper
text: A curious passage occurs in “My Father Is a Book,” Janna Malamud Smith’s tender, touching 2006 memoir of her father, Bernard Malamud. In the spring of 1978, when the novelist was in his mid-60s, he and his wife, Ann, had dinner with Philip Roth and Claire Bloom in the latter couple’s London apartment. In a letter to his daughter describing the visit, Malamud affectionately characterizes Claire Bloom — “absolutely unpretentious” — and then, in parentheses, adds this detail about greeting Roth: “We kissed on the lips when I came in. He couldn’t have done that two years ago.” Now wait a minute.

headline: Molly Hover, Mark McCooey
text: Margaret Biddle Hover and Mark Joseph McCooey were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall, a Presbyterian minister, officiated. The Rev. Paul E. Carrier, a Jesuit priest, also participated in the ceremony.

headline: Call Them ‘Dutch Fries’
text: At European Republic, a storefront cafe with European art posters on the walls and Middle Eastern tunes on the sound system, the French fries arrived by way of the Netherlands. Aziz Yosofi, the Afghan-born owner, learned how to make the hand-cut, twice-fried potatoes in Amsterdam before bringing them to Huntington seven years ago.

headline: This Time, Santa Has Been Too Naughty
text: Microsoft says its engineers have persuaded Santa Claus to stop talking dirty, but they still don’t trust the big guy to keep it clean when speaking with children, so he is no longer allowed on Windows Live Messenger.

headline: Letters: Mind of a Rock
text: Mind of a Rock

headline: No, We Don’t Want to Kiss and Make Up
text: IT’S the time of year for holiday soirees and warm family dinners  and thus for reflecting on “don’t invite ’ems,” which is what the gossip columnist Walter Winchell liked to call adversaries so fierce they cannot be seated at the same table.

headline: The Illustrated City, to Tie With a Bow
text: NEW YORK BOUND, that quirky city-themed bookstore in Rockefeller Center, has been closed for a decade. So we culled the shops at the Tenement Museum, New-York Historical Society, Museum of the City of New York and various shelves and catalogs for a few of the most recent, richly illustrated holiday gift books about New York. Here are seven we liked.

headline: After 2 Competitors Crash, Downhill Is Cut Short
text: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 8  Despite what many coaches and skiers described as less-than-ideal, and even unsafe, conditions, the women’s World Cup downhill race started at the appointed hour Saturday, a day after several feet of soft snow fell on the mountain here.

headline: New York: Drop the Tax That Keeps Us in Cars (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Louder Life, Thicker Windows
text: A picture caption with the Posting article last Sunday about noise-blocking windows misidentified the building shown. It is the J Condominium in Dumbo, Brooklyn  not 88 Leonard Street in TriBeCa, Manhattan.

headline: 26-Year-Old Man Is Killed in the Bronx
text: A 26-year-old man was fatally shot yesterday on a Bronx street by men who drove up in a car, pulled a handgun out of the trunk and shot him in the back, the police said.

headline: Excerpts From Interview With Kyozan Joshu Sasaki Roshi
text: Kyozan Joshu Sasaki Roshi, a 100-year-old Buddhist Zen master of the Rinzai school, does not often meet with the press. But during a visit in November, from his main California temple, to the fall training retreat at his Bodhi Manda Zen Center in Jemez Springs, N.M., Joshu Roshi  known to followers as Roshi, or “venerable teacher”  sat for interviews, through a Japanese interpreter, with Ralph Blumenthal of The New York Times. Following are excerpts of the interview, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: After Coming So Far, He Stands to Lose So Much
text: In the six years since he received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Florent Mathurin has scrambled and saved his way into a new life, which he suddenly seems in danger of losing.

headline: NATO and Afghan Forces Hem In Taliban Haven
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 8  The Afghan government called on Taliban fighters in the town of Musa Qala in southern Afghanistan to put down their weapons and give themselves up or face a heavy attack from Afghan and NATO forces hemming in the town on Saturday.

headline: Money for Something
text: San Francisco

headline: The Getty Gets Serious About Video
text: EARLY this year the artist Martin von Haselberg, better known as one-half of the Kipper Kids performance duo, made a pilgrimage to the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles to view a video he hadn’t seen since he created it in 1976. The institute had just rediscovered it in the Long Beach Museum of Art video archives, a trove of early work that the institute acquired in December 2005.

headline: Stocks Climb on Optimism for Lenders
text: The stock market rose again last week on hopes that the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates and that a government rescue plan for subprime mortgage borrowers would stabilize housing and bolster the earnings of lenders.

headline: A New Vote on Phones, This Time, by Students
text: Under the century-old mural “New York City Receiving the Tributes of the Nation,” which covers much of the ceiling of the City Council chambers, Michelle Jean Baptiste was busy ripping the tar out of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday.

headline: Marijuana Mansions
text: Marijuana growers have long faced a dilemma. If they grow pot outdoors, weather conditions are unpredictable, and plants can be spotted from the air or accidentally discovered. Yet if they set up an indoor operation in a sleepy town, their suspicious activity tends to draw attention. The new and counterintuitive solution of some growers in California is to move into a busy, upscale suburban neighborhood and establish a “marijuana mansion,” as the street-life magazine Don Diva recently termed it.

headline: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Open County Primaries
text: TRENTON

headline: Westchester Deaths in an Age Range Flat After State Law
text: When their son started driving, Martin and Renee Pisarz required him to work part time and help pay the cost of buying a car. The Pisarzes, of Scarsdale, said that they also felt that if their son, Stephen, rather than a friend, was behind the wheel, he would be in control.

headline: Youtube (Accidental) Audition, The
text: The idea of a star being born from Web video isn’t new. There was Lonelygirl15, for instance, the fictional teenager whose YouTube videos drew an international audience last year.

headline: Auctioning Off Nevada
text: As cornucopias go, it is hard to top what has been happening in Nevada. Local governments have been cashing in on the sale of federal lands to spare their taxpayers the tab for a raft of amenities that include parks and shooting ranges. That’s right: the federal government has auctioned off thousands of acres in the last decade under an unusual law that channels most of the proceeds into an account set aside for projects in Nevada.

headline: The Power Grid Game: Choose a Catastrophe
text: BUCHANAN, N.Y.

headline: Who Says You Can’t Leave Home? Armor for Sleep
text: SECAUCUS

headline: Oil Money Flows, and City Prospers
text: ON most Friday nights in Almaty, the Uzbek-themed night spot known as the Car Wash  an ornately decorated rooftop restaurant with enviable mountain views  is packed with well-heeled Kazakhs smoking water pipes, drinking, dancing and eating extravagantly. Sandwiched between a residential district scheduled for rapid development and Almaty’s business district, the Car Wash is not the only center of hyperactive nocturnal activity.

headline: All Brains Are the Same Color
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: Within a Family, the Strength to Be a Soloist
text: West Hartford

headline: Man Is Arrested After Woman, 23, Is Fatally Shot in Queens
text: A man was arrested in the fatal shooting of a 23-year-old woman on a Queens street early yesterday after they argued over a cellphone, the police said.

headline: Knot Physics
text: When Doug Smith pulls the power cord for his laptop out of his bag, he inevitably finds that  whoops!  it has somehow tangled itself into a dense knot. This is, of course, a common complaint of the high-tech age (and before, with other types of cord). Most of us simply shrug. But Smith is a physics professor at the University of California, San Diego, and he wanted to know precisely why the knots form in the first place.

headline: Hospitals, Health Care and Children (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: When the Price Isn’t Right
text: WHO among us could have imagined that the same forces of financial ambiguity could at once choke the real estate market, Wall Street, network television and Major League Baseball? Yet somehow a rippling crisis of belief in the traditional ways of valuing so many things, from mortgage-backed bonds to a joke written for Jon Stewart, simultaneously grips many areas of American commerce.

headline: Inside the List
text: BECK V. COOPER: Glenn Beck, the conservative CNN news personality, has the new No. 1 title on the nonfiction list: “An Inconvenient Book: Real Solutions for the World’s Biggest Problems.” To promote it, he appeared recently as a guest on his own show, where he faced off against Anderson Cooper, also of CNN, in what was a strangely gripping hour of television. Beck versus Cooper — the noisy populist versus the dapper mandarin — felt like a class war and a seriocomic switchblade match for the soul of CNN. Cooper kicked things off by introducing Beck half-jokingly as, among other things, a “cable news rodeo clown” and “man of mystery.” The first words out of Beck’s mouth were: “I am not afraid of you.” Things went downhill — or uphill, depending on your perspective — from there. The men kept smiling but tangled over issues like global warming and immigration. When Cooper said “most scientists say yes” while asking if man is to blame for climate change, Beck replied: “Ooh. Most scientists say yes. Wow. You got me there. That’s why you’re on ‘60 Minutes.’ ” Beck called Cooper “Mr. I-Hang-Out-in-Africa” and said, “So anyway, talk down to me some more.” Cooper asked: “If Iran is the head of the snake, who’s the tail?” Beck’s reply: “You.” Near the end of the program, Cooper asked: “How long does it take for you to spray on your hair? I’m just asking.” Who won this battle? I don’t know. But by the end, Cooper did ask, “How come I’m the only one sweating here?”

headline: Postnuptial Agreements
text: In February, the TV-talk-show psychologist Dr. Phil introduced his viewers to a new twist in domestic drama: a husband asking his wife to sign a postnuptial agreement. A postnup? Like a prenup, a postnup is a contract that divides a family’s assets between spouses — only this time it comes after the marriage vows have been spoken.

headline: NATO Says It’s Prepared to Keep Peace in Kosovo
text: SKENDERAJ, Kosovo, Dec. 5  NATO commanders in Kosovo say they are ready to shut down any violence in the wake of the province’s expected secession from Serbia. The scorched frescoes and shattered roof tiles at the Serbian Orthodox monastery of St. Joanikije testify to how difficult that task might be.

headline: Soviet Deadpan
text: Let us consider Daniil Kharms, the Russian writer often described as an absurdist, largely unpublished in his lifetime except for his children’s books, who starved to death in the psychiatric ward of a Soviet hospital during the siege of Leningrad, having been put there by the Stalinist government for, among other reasons, his general strangeness. Kharms gave flamboyant poetry readings from the top of an armoire, did performance art on the Nevsky Prospect — by, for example, lying down on it, sometimes dressed as Sherlock Holmes — and was a founder of the Union of Real Art, an avant-garde group also known as Oberiu. His brilliant, hilarious, violent little stories, written “for the drawer,” are now being discovered in the West through translations by Neil Cornwell (collected in “Incidences”) and by Matvei Yankelevich, whose anthology “Today I Wrote Nothing: The Selected Writings of Daniil Kharms” (Overlook, $29.95) has just been published.

headline: Hollywood Windfall? Take It to the Streets
text: “THE Last Man on Earth Is Not Alone,” proclaims the advertising for “I Am Legend,” the Will Smith apocalyptic thriller opening Friday.

headline: The 53 Places to Go in 2008
text: 1 LAOS

headline: That Crazy Old Dude Is Chasing Windmills Again
text: It should be the best of all possible times for “Man of La Mancha.” After all, this is a musical in which Don Quixote observes, “When life itself seems lunatic, who knows where madness lies?” All you need for a line like that to go over big is an audience convinced it is living in a crazy world.

headline: Being Third Option Works for Crayton
text: There are few advantages to being a team’s third option in its passing attack, but for Dallas Cowboys wide receiver PATRICK CRAYTON, that does not mean that he does not get his chances to dance in the end zone.

headline: The ‘R’ Word Doesn’t Have to Be So Scary
text: AS fears over the credit crisis and housing correction have mounted, a growing chorus of economists has been talking up the probability of a recession next year.

headline: Clinton Proudly Talks of Scars While Keeping Her Guard Up
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  In July 2000, Hillary Clinton stood on a stage at the University of Arkansas and struggled to keep her composure. Her voice was unusually soft that day, her words seemingly unfiltered.

headline: Court Intrigue for the King of Torts
text: Clarksdale, Miss.

headline: Rental Doubts
text: After I put a deposit on an apartment, I learned that housing groups labeled the owner ‘New York’s Most Abusive Landlord’ for using rough tactics like cutting off water and heat to get rid of rent-controlled tenants. I find these tactics immoral, but I wouldn’t face them: I’d be paying much more for a renovated apartment. Is it ethical to take the place?  SEBASTIAN, BROOKLYN

headline: Craigslist Vengeance
text: Your boss alerts security to not let you back into the building in your paint-ball gear after you’ve been fired. Your neighbor installs cameras after you threaten to “rain pain” on his garden gnomes. Your girlfriend dumps you for a hilarious and wealthy and wonderfully bone-structured guy and comes home with him after you’ve bribed the super and are preparing to sprinkle itching powder all over that lovely orange duvet cover, forcing you to hide in her closet and withstand a shockingly amorous night that makes your eyeballs bleed, even now. Hypotheticals, sure, but the point is how difficult it is to enact even the best-laid revenge plan.

headline: Cultures Meet at the Dinner Table
text: ON the top floor of Istanbul's Marmara Pera hotel, the restaurant Mikla serves a dish that, at first glance, may look like a simple upgrading of a Turkish standard: smoked lamb loin with a side of white-bean purée — tasty enough, to be sure, but perhaps nothing special.

headline: Jogging Politique
text: Nicolas Sarkozy, who was elected president of France in May, likes to make a political point of personifying the idea of vigor. Heckled from a balcony by a striking fisherman, he yelled back, “Come down and say that.” During the recent railway strike, he poked a shop steward in the chest. Addressing a cabinet member with the familiar tu, he nearly left the man, who was once prime minister, speechless. But none of these challenges to the status quo provoked anywhere near the apoplexy with which certain segments of French society have greeted another of the president’s habits, his daily jog in the park.

headline: Jane Rule, Canadian Novelist, Dies at 76
text: Jane Rule, a prominent Canadian writer whose first novel, “Desert of the Heart,” is considered a landmark work of lesbian fiction, died on Nov. 27 at her home on Galiano Island in British Columbia. She was 76.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Farther Shore’
text: A review on Nov. 25 about Matthew Eck’s “Farther Shore,” a novel set in Somalia, misstated the service affiliation of 18 United States military personnel who died trying to capture the warlord Mohammed Farrah Aidid in Mogadishu in 1993. They were Army Rangers and Delta Force commandos, not marines.

headline: Left Behind
text: Shorewood, Wis.

headline: Fish-Flavored Fish
text: As stocks of ocean-caught fish dwindle in the face of overfishing and environmental changes, farmed fish has flooded the market, helping to meet our growing appetite for seafood. But one sector of the seafood industry has remained elusive. Fast-food restaurants, which serve hundreds of millions of deep-fried-fish sandwiches every year, have always chosen wild species over farmed ones, because the flavor is better.

headline: Paying for a Peaceful End
text: Connecticut began the first hospice in the United States during the 1970s. By the early 1980s, hospice services were such crucial components of end-of-life care that the federal government included them in both Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly, and Medicaid, the program that provides health care to the poor. Yet Connecticut is one of only three states that has not gone along with the federal model of offering hospice care to the poor.

headline: Gathering the Old Guard
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: The Harvest Goes Into Overtime
text: BRYAN O’HARA snaps a perfect spinach leaf off one of his plants and pops it into his mouth. Pretty normal given that he grows loads of it on his one-plus-acre farm, Tobacco Road, in Lebanon, Conn. Not so normal given that it’s the middle of November.

headline: Where a Buck’s Still Worth a Buck
text: OVER the last five years, Argentina has been steadily recovering from its currency collapse in 2001. While the turnaround has yielded a bevy of new hotels and restaurants, the country is still surprisingly inexpensive for American visitors, with hotel rooms often half the price of their European counterparts, and steak dinners, even at high-end parrillas, rarely costing more than the equivalent of $25.

headline: How to Keep an Ex-Terrorist Talking
text: The informer was growing terrified about the prospect of testifying against Al Qaeda. Osama bin Laden, he feared, would get to him or his family. Allah, he suspected, was already punishing him; his father was sick and his infant child had died. “Anything I touch, I don’t feel happy,” he said.

headline: Air Your Clean Laundry to Fight Climate Change (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in the Travel section today about Moscow as a new luxury destination misstates the cost of creating Turandot, a lavish restaurant that opened last year. It was $50 million, not $50.

headline: Faces Decide Elections
text: Here’s something to keep in mind as election time approaches: Study the politicians. Not their dossiers or their domestic policies, but their faces. Because according to new research by Anthony Little, a psychologist at the University of Stirling in Scotland, faces may decide elections.

headline: New York’s Part-Time Legislators
text: New York lawmakers are apparently poised to raise their own salaries, possibly by more than 20 percent. If they do, the question is what we  the taxpayers  will get in return.

headline: Britannia Bites
text: In an effort to clarify and define the rights and obligations of British citizenship, Prime Minister Gordon Brown recently invited the British public to help its government develop “a statement of British values”: as a Scot at a time when Scots in England are not as popular as they used to be, reviving the waning idea of an inclusive British identity is useful to him. Many people misread his words and imagined Brown wanted to find values unique to Britain — “British values.” More careful readers noted that what he was looking for was a particularly British expression of the Enlightenment beliefs common to, say, France or the United States, whose catchy slogans (“liberty, equality, fraternity” and “land of the free”) he seemed to envy.

headline: Handshake Sex Appeal
text: Gordon Gallup, an evolutionary psychologist at the University of Albany, has a suggestion for women going on first dates: Bring a handgrip dynamometer. It’s a small, purse-size device they can use to measure their date’s grip strength. Why? Gallup’s new research suggests that handgrip strength in men is directly connected with reproductive fitness.

headline: Second-World Solidarity
text: “The first and second worlds are being reunited into something which has no name yet, nor a number,” wrote the sociologist Ralf Dahrendorf back in 1990. “Perhaps it will just be the world.” Or perhaps not! The United States, China and the European Union seem to be forming an irritable triplet: no one of them can dominate either of the other two. They may make common cause, but it is just as likely that they will compete for control. And the places where they will compete have been labeled, by the New America Foundation analyst Parag Khanna, the second world.

headline: Neurorealism
text: You’ve seen the headlines: This Is Your Brain on Politics. Or God. Or Super Bowl Ads. And they’re always accompanied by pictures of brains dotted with seemingly significant splotches of color. Now some scientists have seen enough. We’re like moths, they say, lured by the flickering lights of neuroimaging — and uncritically accepting of conclusions drawn from it.

headline: Oregon’s Favorite Sons Keep Their Rivalry Alive
text: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 7  The football rivalry between two boys born nine days apart in small Oregon towns began, strangely enough, on surfboards.

headline: Mugabe’s Presence Hijacks European-African Meeting
text: LISBON, Dec. 8  A summit meeting of leaders from Europe and Africa on Saturday was dominated by divisions between the two continents over trade and criticism from European leaders of human rights abuses in Zimbabwe.

headline: Making Peace With Pieces
text: Manama, Bahrain

headline: Pssst: Some Hope for Spycraft
text: INTELLIGENCE officers who smell flowers tend to look around for a funeral. Experience teaches them never to say that things can’t get worse.

headline: Town House Living: The Untold Story
text: TO space-starved, yard-craving, neighbor-cranky apartment dwellers, a single-family town house of their own can seem like the cure for what ails them, if only they could afford it. An entry-level fee of $4 million to $5 million in much of Manhattan buys a few thousand square feet, emancipation from co-op boards and foul-weather dog walking, and, for many families with children, a chance to experience a bit of suburbia without actually having to live there.

headline: Talking Terror: From bin Laden’s Employ to Witness Protection
text: The Witness

headline: Angela Lentini and Francisco Rivera
text: Angela Ann Lentini and Francisco Antonio Rivera were married on Thursday at the New York City Municipal Building by Blanca Martinez, a marriage officiant. On Friday, Joseph Lasket, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, led a nondenominational ceremony at Westbury Manor, an event space in Westbury, N.Y.

headline: Pixelated Stained Glass
text: In late August, at the unveiling of the massive, awe-inspiring stained-glass window designed by the artist Gerhard Richter for Cologne Cathedral in Germany, the city’s conservative archbishop, Cardinal Joachim Meisner, was notably absent. Though Meisner claimed a prior engagement, skeptics suspected otherwise. Meisner had insisted that only a figurative depiction of 20th-century Catholic martyrs could substitute for the original Gothic window, which was destroyed by Allied bombing during World War II and never suitably replaced. Richter, however, delivered something wholly unexpected: an abstract composition of 11,500 identically sized units — at 14.5 square inches each, they are frequently compared to pixels — in 72 colors, the arrangement of which was determined randomly by a computer program.

headline: The Golden Compass; the Naming Game; Philip Glass
text: ‘THE GOLDEN COMPASS’

headline: Fake Tilt-Shift Photography
text: Tilt-shift photography may be destined to become a visual cliché. But for the moment, this playful technique  which can make shots of cityscapes, train stations and loading docks appear to be photos of obsessively detailed scale models  is flourishing on photo-sharing sites like Flickr. This year it even inspired the sincerest form of flattery: fakery.

headline: Sometimes a Memory Is a Tree’s Best Fruit (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Leaving Brooklyn
text: IT was tough for Talima Davis, Brooklyn born and bred, to leave her beloved borough.

headline: Lots of Little Screens: TV Is Changing Shape
text: The Re:framing column last Sunday, about growth in online video programming, included an outdated reference to the status of the new online series “Quarterlife.” The series has been picked up by NBC; it has not merely been discussed as a possibility for network television.

headline: Go for the Tea, but Stay for Dessert
text: KATHLEEN Chilcott, the proprietor of Kathleen’s Tea Room, in Peekskill, opened her palm to reveal about a dozen brown-green-gray balls. “Aren’t these beautiful?” she asked. Called Jasmine Dragon Tears, the tiny orbs are placed in a glass cup set over a flame and when hot water is poured over them, they unfurl, revealing themselves to be tea leaves. The tea smells like honeysuckle but isn’t actually sweet.

headline: Cara Adelglass, David Berkowitz
text: Cara Alana Adelglass, the daughter of Buttons Adelglass and Dr. Jeffrey M. Adelglass of Dallas, was married yesterday to David Evan Berkowitz, a son of Judith E. Berkowitz and Dr. Daniel Berkowitz of New Rochelle, N.Y. Wayde T. Coleby, a civil marriage officer in the Turks and Caicos Islands, officiated at the Somerset on Grace Bay, a hotel in Providenciales, with Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman taking part.

headline: Heisman Is Awarded to a Sophomore
text: After becoming the first major college quarterback to reach 20 passing touchdowns and 20 rushing touchdowns in a season, Florida’s Tim Tebow became the first sophomore to win the Heisman Trophy last night.

headline: How to Solve a Subprime Mess? An Iowan Says, Let’s Caucus
text: A HALF-DOZEN years before subprime mortgages were on the national agenda, Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa, led teams of state officials from around the country in negotiating settlements totaling more than $800 million with two large home lenders that were accused of misleading and overcharging borrowers.

headline: Polite Company
text: There may not be a more sensible set of literary reviews published this year than those in “Bamboo,” the first collection of such pieces — plus art reviews, travel writing and other assorted articles — from the British novelist William Boyd. The author of nine novels, three story collections and many screenplays, Boyd is unfailingly judicious, whether praising the “potent manipulation of symbol” in Toni Morrison’s “Song of Solomon,” the “compelling dry-eyed poignancy” of Raymond Carver’s stories or the “curious blend of faux naïveté and profanity, of innocence and deep irony” in the writerly voice of Kurt Vonnegut.

headline: Lap-Dance Science
text: Despite media reports to the contrary, the University of New Mexico did not pay for Geoffrey Miller and Brent Jordan to get 5,300 lap dances in two months. In fact, Miller has never even been in a strip club. And frankly, they’re getting tired of everyone’s asking.

headline: Giants Overcome Sluggish Start to Hold Off Eagles
text: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9  On a frozen field under a pewter sky, there were few colorful plays to shake the tug-of-war tedium of short runs ending in gang tackles and short passes ending short of first downs.

headline: With Eye on Schools, Critics Assail Housing Proposals
text: IN January 2005, Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, announced a large new development in Yaphank. A 250-acre parcel of county land off the Long Island Expressway would become the site of a recreational area, an industrial complex and 1,000 housing units.

headline: If It’s Fresh and Local, Is It Always Greener?
text: I’VE been feeling pretty smug lately about zipping over to the farmers’ market or the local Whole Foods for some New York apples or New Jersey spinach and ferrying it home in my reusable grocery bags.

headline: Jeanne Conway and Douglas O’Connor
text: WHEN Gen. Douglas John O’Connor, 76, talks about being 17 and meeting Jeanne O’Brien, he often exclaims, “I remember it vividly!”

headline: Jordana Merlis and Jeff Jacobs
text: JORDANA JACOBS loads the dishwasher in a way that she believes is orderly and methodical, honed from her training as a lawyer, expert knitter and businesswoman.

headline: The Women Come and Go
text: Cees Nooteboom’s dreamy and self-conscious new novel, translated from the Dutch by Susan Massotty, begins on a small commuter airplane when the narrator spots a woman skimming and then setting aside a novel. Craning for a closer look, he remarks on the author’s boldness in writing such a slender volume with so many short chapters, providing “a new beginning each time, for which you ought to have a good reason.” When he can finally make out the title, he triumphantly announces that “it’s this book, a book out of which she is about to disappear, along with me.”

headline: Gunman Kills 2 at Missionary Center Near Denver
text: Two missionaries-in-training were killed early today and two more were wounded when a gunman burst into a residence hall at the Youth With a Mission center in the Denver suburb of Arvada, the police said.

headline: The Mystery of the Umbrellas
text: THE first time it happens, the neophyte will probably think it’s an aberration, maybe one oddball’s bizarre pathology. Then there will be another, and another, and it turns out everyone’s doing it. What a funny bunch, these New Yorkers.

headline: Iran Snub of Atomic Pacts Is Denied
text: TEHRAN, Dec. 7 A former nuclear negotiator for Iran dismissed reports that the country’s current negotiator had brushed off previous agreements with Europe over the Iranian nuclear program.

headline: Driving While Adolescent
text: New Milford

headline: It’s a Stretch: Small-Car Specialist Hits the Big Leagues
text: TALK about being in the right place at the right time. Suzuki, known for motorcycles and little cars with great mileage that the Japanese love, had a surge in auto sales in the United States last year.

headline: With Starters Benched, Rutgers Still Takes Care of Army
text: Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer demands maximum effort from her players. When she does not get it, there are consequences.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: 24/7 Alibi, The
text: Nine months after 9/11, Hasan Elahi, an art professor at Rutgers University, was detained at the Detroit airport after the F.B.I. received a bogus tip that he had stockpiled explosives in a storage locker. Six months of interrogations and nine polygraph tests later, the F.B.I. let him go. (The F.B.I. declined to comment.) But Elahi wasn’t ready to let go of the F.B.I. In a sly swipe at the surveillance system that botched his case, Elahi has self-consciously, if a bit ostentatiously, surrendered his privacy via a personal Web site. He has an alibi now — a perpetual one.

headline: City on a Hill
text: Garry Wills, one of America’s best journalists and historians of the last half-century, has always enjoyed taking familiar subjects and staring at them long and hard until they look strange and new. In “Head and Heart” he invites readers to reconsider American religious history, challenging the conventional wisdom on many issues while synthesizing much of the finest recent scholarship. It is an odd and quirky book, however, going into extremely fine detail in some areas, hurrying past others with a few casual remarks, and deviating in its last hundred pages into political polemic.

headline: When a Stabilized Unit Is Not the Sole Residence
text: Q In 1999, I leased a rent-stabilized apartment in a building owned by my employer. My employer was fully aware that I had a residence in another state and would be using the apartment about 10 days a month while on company business.

headline: Are Paper Bags Better Than Plastic? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Questions for Michael Eisner
text: Was it coincidence that led you to run an interview with Michael Eisner in the middle of a writers’ strike (Deborah Solomon, Nov. 18)? Let’s review. In the 1980s Eisner and his cronies, the “suits,” told the Hollywood creative community that its participation in revenue from a “new” medium, videotape, was to be minuscule until the medium demonstrated profitability, at which point all would be revisited. After 20 years the VHS tape and its muscular nephew, the DVD, have proved profitable indeed, providing the bulk of revenue for most movies and a tasty ancillary market for many TV shows. Need I point out that nothing was ever renegotiated?

headline: Abortion Complicates Congressional Debate Over Foreign Aid Bill
text: Anti-abortion Democrats in Congress this year joined abortion rights supporters to pass a foreign aid spending bill that they all said would reduce abortions in poor countries. It would allow the federal government to donate contraceptives to foreign groups that provide family planning services abroad, including those that offer abortions or favor making them legal.

headline: Sharper Claws for Recovering Executive Pay
text: INVESTORS everywhere should applaud the deal struck last week by the UnitedHealth Group to recover nearly $1 billion in pay from former executives involved in the company’s option backdating mess.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Comedy

headline: In Arrogant Defense of Torture
text: The White House is already complaining about reports that House and Senate conferees have come to an agreement on an intelligence measure mandating that all agencies, including the Central Intelligence Agency, comply with the Army Field Manual’s outlawing of torture. The manual properly reflects American law by explicitly proscribing the gamut of torture measures  including waterboarding  that have proved dear to the heart of administration zealots.

headline: Lightning Farms
text: The possibility of harnessing the spectacular power of lightning has captured the imagination for a long time — or at least since Doc Brown returned Marty McFly to 1985 at the moment that lightning struck Hill Valley’s clock tower in “Back to the Future.” This summer, a company named Alternate Energy Holdings set out to see if the energy in lightning could actually be harvested, and if so, whether full-scale lightning farms might one day become a meaningful source of electricity.

headline: 2 Electricity Suppliers Step Into State Market With Lower Rates
text: WHEN the state’s electricity market was deregulated in 2000, Richard and Kathleen McKee of Mansfield had high hopes that competitors would quickly appear offering cheaper rates.

headline: Show Us the Mortgage Relief
text: When he announced a new plan to try to stanch the foreclosure crisis, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson Jr. said that the officials, lenders and investors involved had been working toward it since August. That start date is a useful benchmark for measuring the plan’s inadequacy.

headline: God Effect, The
text: Some anthropologists argue that the idea of God first arose in larger societies, for the purpose of curbing selfishness and promoting cooperation. Outside a tightly knit group, the reasoning goes, nobody can keep an eye on everyone’s behavior, so these cultures invented a supernatural agent who could. But does thinking of an omniscient God actually promote altruism? The University of British Columbia psychologist Ara Norenzayan wanted to find out.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Inappropriate Comments

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Avoid Boring People’
text: A review on Nov. 25 about “Avoid Boring People,” a memoir by James D. Watson, misstated the subject of a 1953 article in the journal Nature, written by Watson and Francis Crick, that the reviewer once happened across at the University of New Mexico. It was about the structure of DNA; only in the last sentence is there any reference to DNA’s self-replicating potential.

headline: Bomber Kills 11 at Police Station in Northern Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 8  A suicide truck bomber killed 11 people in an attack on a police station in the northern Iraqi town of Baiji, Iraqi security forces said on Saturday.

headline: Posthumous E-Mail
text: A macabre niche in the online economy is now being filled by Web sites that allow users to send e-mail messages from beyond the grave. For a modest fee, sites like youdeparted.com, letterfrombeyond.com, mylastemail.com and postexpression.com will send e-mail with instructions to be followed in the event of your death. (A beneficiary notifies site administrators of your passing.)

headline: Lite-Brite Fashion
text: The term Lite-Brite fashion may call to mind cheap novelty gimmicks like the flashing T-shirts favored by club kids, not the handiwork of a respected high-end designer. But this year, Hussein Chalayan, the nutty professor of fashion, produced a handful of effulgent dresses and hats that were illuminating in more than the obvious, brighten-dark-corners sort of way. Using lasers and light-emitting diodes, or L.E.D.’s — the sort found in mobile phones — Chalayan played with the aesthetic and conceptual possibilities of light and once again upturned conventional notions about clothing and its material (in every sense of the word) limitations.

headline: Graffiti, Underground and Above
text: BEGINNING in the 1970s, city kids swept up in the new trend of scribbling graffiti on the outside of subway cars gathered on a bench in the 149th Street-Grand Concourse station in the Bronx to appraise each other’s work as trains rumbled by on the tracks. The site became known as the 149th Street Writers Bench, and it is legendary in graffiti lore.

headline: Again, Strahan Withholding the Retirement Plan
text: Michael Strahan sat in one of his many cars, this one the Bentley, with the engine running and the heater purring to combat the cold that swirled around Giants Stadium. It was a momentary cocoon from all the outside influences, and as Strahan chatted, he paused to ponder retirement, again.

headline: Letters: Where Boys Grow Up to Be Jihadis
text: Andrea Elliott’s article (Nov. 25) on why (and where) boys become jihadis provides an excellent, nuanced account of the conditions they grow up in. Nevertheless, the basic cause is still obscure. Her analysis reminds me of a phrase: “the revolution of rising expectations.”

headline: A License to Pursue the Inner Bond
text: “I can’t really remember what the first James Bond movie I saw was,” said the slim soft-spoken man on the sofa in a suite at the Waldorf Towers. In a slight German accent, he continued: “It must have been in the mid-’80s, because there was no television in my house, and I didn’t see many movies until then. Roger Moore was in it, I think.”

headline: Right to Medical Self-Defense, The
text: If laws banning the use of force are relaxed when an intruder crawls in your window and you’re home, shouldn’t stringent F.D.A. regulations bend when you’re backed into a dark corner by a terminal illness? That was the gist of an argument made by the U.C.L.A. law professor Eugene Volokh in the May issue of The Harvard Law Review. Citing the concept of “medical self-defense,” Volokh contended that a dying American should have the right to buy any drug that has passed the F.D.A.’s preliminary safety tests. Currently, the F.D.A. insists that most terminally ill patients await, like everyone else, full proof of a drug’s safety and efficacy.

headline: A Proposal to Require Flu Vaccines for Preschool
text: The New Jersey Public Health Council is expected to vote tomorrow on a rule that would require flu vaccines for any child entering day care or preschool. If it is approved, New Jersey would become the first state in the country to impose that mandate.

headline: Electric Hockey Skate, The
text: When Tory Weber, a hockey enthusiast from Calgary, went to fetch the paper one frigid day in 1985, the soles of his warm running shoes melted the ice on his steps, sending him tumbling backward. He wondered, “What if I could get this reduced-friction scenario going in the right direction?” Later, while working at a lumberyard, he began devoting free time to the idea of a heated ice-skate blade that would yield a better glide with less effort. The skate he devised finally goes on sale this month.

headline: County Food Banks See a Surge in Demand
text: AS the holiday hubbub mounts, Westchester food banks are reporting a surge in the number of residents seeking a decent meal.

headline: Braille Tattoo, The
text: In April, while taking a university course on “body technology,” a Czech art student named Klara Jirkova had a vision of a “touchable ‘tattoo’ for blind people.” According to her project paper, one way to do it would be to emboss the surface of your arm, say, with a word or message in Braille by having stainless-steel beads surgically implanted under your skin  thereby creating a body modification meant not just to decorate “but to be touched and read.”

headline: A Tip Sheet to Help the Odds of Landing a Job
text: What do you want to be when you grow up? If you’re not sure yet, you may want to check out a new list from the Bureau of Labor Statistics that projects the fastest-growing occupations from 2006 to 2016.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: PORTRAITS AND OBSERVATIONS: The Essays of Truman Capote. (Random House, $28.95.) This handsomely produced volume documents the early precociousness and a later sense of weariness and dwindled powers before and after “In Cold Blood.”

headline: It’s His World; She Was Just Filming It
text: JENNIFER VENDITTI met the subject of her documentary “Billy the Kid” in a high school cafeteria in rural Maine. Seated apart from all the other students, who were clustered into the usual cliques, was a wiry 15-year-old in shorts and an AC/DC T-shirt.

headline: When the Mentally Ill Leave Prison (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Radiohead Payment Model, The
text: It could be a Zen koan, or a fragment of a Fifth Dimension lyric: The value of music is what the listener will pay. But as of Oct. 10, it became a viable business model. That was the day Radiohead made its seventh studio album, “In Rainbows,” available for download online. Customers were invited to pay whatever they wished. Clicking on the question mark on the Radiohead site led to a screen that read, “It’s up to you.” Clicking on that led to another message: “No, really. It’s up to you.” According to early estimates, 1.2 million downloaded the record in the first two days, earning the band somewhere between $1 million and $5 million. Soon after, the withered husk of the recording industry gently commenced to collapse on itself.

headline: The Dutiful Daughter
text: As a young man, Harold Klein is so scrawny that a fellow passenger on the train taking him to medical school wonders if he’s old enough to be traveling alone. It is South Africa in 1938: a country with a color bar, but not yet caught in the steel cage of apartheid. Harold’s father, Joseph, is a Jewish shopkeeper in a town a few hundred miles from Cape Town, and the family’s position is equivocal: they’re neither Boer nor quite English. When Harold sees newspaper reports of an Afrikaner re-enactment of the Great Trek, the 19th-century wagon-train journey that colonized the Transvaal, his father reminds him, “It’s not our holiday.” In time, Harold will become a country practitioner; he will marry and have two children of his own, both of whom will move to the United States. He’ll have a long life, long enough to see his country change. And then he’ll die, of a uremia that sends him into a coma and puts “a yellow smell in the air.”

headline: Words of the World
text: No contemporary poet is famous, but some are less unfamous than others. That’s because the poetry world, like most areas of American life, has its own peculiar celebrity system — and if the rewards of that system rarely involve gift suites filled with swag from Jean Patou, they remain tempting enough to keep grown writers hustling. The problem is, poetic stardom is an unpredictable business. Good writing doesn’t guarantee a reputation; bad writing doesn’t guarantee oblivion; nor can grace, money or nimble careerism entirely explain why Poet X reads to overflowing auditoriums, whereas Poet Y reads to his cats. Maybe it’s simply the case that, as William Munny remarked in “Unforgiven,” “deserve’s got nothing to do with it.”

headline: The Audition That Left Them Speechless
text: GABOUREY SIDIBE, from Bedford-Stuyvesant and later Harlem, had seen bright lights and dressing rooms. She had been backstage at the Apollo. Her mother, Alice Tan Ridley, is a singer, and Gabbie, as people now call her, sometimes felt as if she and her brother had grown up behind the bar at the Cotton Club. She had done some singing, too, and had been in a few plays at Lehman College, where a friend was a theater major.

headline: He Was Nerdy, but He Made the Shows
text: THE scene should be familiar to anyone who has ever caught an installment of a certain television talent show. The performer, an unabashed geek, takes the stage. Ordinarily he might be belittled for his gawky dance moves or sequined shirts, but instead the audience roars and holds aloft placards with his name. Eager to please, the singer belts out love songs, building to emotive climaxes that leave the crowd screaming for more. The people don’t vote, but they’ve spoken.

headline: Postwar Crimes
text: The mystery story is among the most labile of forms, as writers as distant in time and temperament as Poe, Doyle and Christie have demonstrated. Reading some current examples of the genre, though, you’d never know that. While contemporary crime writers are capable of more than tossing new garnishes on the dish known as “noir,” too often the mystery today seems ossified, its authors still working changes on precendents well established in the middle of the last century by the good firm of Hammett, Chandler, MacDonald & Co.

headline: Heads Up! Holiday Project Alert!
text: I CAN see her from the window in my office, crawling around the giant evergreen in her living room. She’s not a big woman, so the process comes to resemble a holiday pas de deux, as the tree envelops her, then spins her loose for another string of bulbs. This ritual  my neighbor Anne wrapping each branch with twinkle lights  is the first sign that Christmas madness is really upon us.

headline: And Now, Your Honor, Exhibit 1: The Litter Box
text: AS a New Yorker who can claim true neighborhood longevity, Siiri Marvits can tell tales of pocket-change rents. For the two-room apartment on West 10th Street in Greenwich Village where she has lived since 1962, she initially paid $67 a month.

headline: Fatal Distraction
text: Invisible. Impassive. Impervious to the vagaries of the job. Whatever qualities you might expect to find in a spy, Miles Flint, the unlucky MI5 operative in Ian Rankin’s WATCHMAN (Little, Brown, $24.99), has them — and that suffering hothead Inspector John Rebus does not. Both characters were created more or less at the same time, some 20 years ago, but Rankin remained loyal to only one of them. While Rebus went on to become the conscience of an enduring series of police procedurals set in Edinburgh, the coolly analytical Flint was ditched after his first assignment.

headline: Crowdware
text: When Mark Zuckerberg announced in mid-May that his company, Facebook, would open its platform to outside developers, you could hear the tech industry’s continents begin to grind and shift. The era of crowdware, or user-generated software, had begun: now anyone could design a miniature application (or widget) for Facebook. The most popular is FunWall, which is like an electronic wall where your friends can put up videos, photos and rude comments. FunWall has about 3.5 million active users and was designed by Slide, a small California company that has seized the widget moment. Many Facebook applications, though, are created by individuals or groups of two or three people. RateBeer, designed by Jonathan Kelly (about to graduate from California Polytechnic next year), has acquired from Facebook members more than 400,000 ratings of 19,000 beers. And RateBeer’s page has an ad  for Zuckerberg gave developers the chance to make money too. A month after opening the platform, Facebook had more than 800 widgets; by mid-November, it offered nearly 8,000.

headline: Access to Tools
text: The Whole Earth Catalog, originally published in 1968, had one of the most arresting covers in 20th-century publishing: an image of the Earth as seen from space. The idea for the picture came to Stewart Brand, Whole Earth’s publisher, in 1966, when, in the throes of an acid trip, he thought, “Seeing an image of the earth from space would change a lot of things.” Brand positioned himself on the campus of the University of California, Berkeley, wearing a sandwich board and selling lapel buttons that asked, “Why haven’t we seen a photograph of the whole Earth yet?” He mailed the buttons to Congress, and legend has it his lobbying goaded NASA into releasing celestial pictures from an Apollo mission.

headline: ‘Cat Lady’ Conundrum, The
text: Here’s a little-known and slightly terrifying fact: According to estimates from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more than 60 million people in the United States are infected with a parasite that may migrate into their brains and alter their behavior in a way that  among other things  may leave them more likely to be eaten by cats. New research into this common parasite  Toxoplasma gondii  may offer clues to the phenomenon known to the unscientifically-minded as “crazy cat lady” syndrome.

headline: RAIDERS at PACKERS
text: RAIDERS at PACKERS

headline: Correction: Essay About Alexis Wright
text: An essay on Nov. 18 about the Aboriginal novelist Alexis Wright reversed the given name and surname of another Australian author who wrote about the country’s indigenous people. He was Xavier Herbert.

headline: Parole Case and  ’90s AIDS View Trail Huckabee
text: As new polls highlight Mike Huckabee’s ascent in the Republican presidential field, he is drawing new scrutiny of his record in Arkansas, particularly his actions in the release of a convicted rapist who went on to murder a woman and his response to a questionnaire in which he said people with AIDS should be quarantined.

headline: Janna Fishman, Michael Stern
text: Janna Kimberly Fishman, the daughter of Meredith Porte Fishman and Barry S. Fishman of Hollywood, Fla., was married last evening to Michael Lenard Stern, a son of Susan Kahn Stern and Jeffrey M. Stern of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Ralph P. Kingsley officiated at the Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables, Fla. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs also took part in the ceremony.

headline: A Sporting Chance
text: WHEN I was born, the nurse said to my mother, “Here is your blockbuster.” I weighed 8 pounds and was 21 inches long. The name Buster stuck.

headline: Ciara Burnham, Peter DeNunzio
text: Ciara Anne Burnham and Peter Dwight DeNunzio were married yesterday. The Rev. J. C. Austin officiated at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

headline: Eat Till You’re Beat
text: In the late 1800s, Ladies’ Mile was a retailing mecca. Today this historic district, centered on Broadway south of Madison Square, is attracting shoppers again and, with restaurants like these, luring diners.

headline: Trips to Help Shape the World
text: HAVING watched celebrities like Angelina Jolie and Bono give their time and money to Africa in recent years, families can now play a role in the global campaign to “make poverty history,” while also enjoying the beauty of the land — and maybe even a quick safari.

headline: Letters: The Bears Among Us
text: Thanks to Darcy Frey for his article on bears (Nov. 25). Wonderful, and keep up the good work.

headline: Hope Can Be Worse Than Hopelessness
text: People often display a remarkable ability to adapt to adversity, bouncing back to their usual levels of happiness despite extreme hardships. But people don’t always rebound, and scientists have long wondered what factors might account for the difference. In a talk at Harvard in September, a team of researchers suggested that one obstacle to emotional recovery, oddly enough, is hope  the belief that your current hardship is temporary.

headline: A New Push for Affordability
text: Hauppauge

headline: Big, Bistro Classics in a Welcoming Spot
text: PROSPECTIVE restaurateurs hoping for a long, successful career might take a page or two from George Korten’s book. Mr. Korten opened George Martin (recently renamed George Martin the Original) in 1989 in Rockville Centre, and it has since become a Long Island institution. (Martin was the first name of a former silent partner in the venture.)

headline: Lessons From the Pits of Travel and Investment
text: AS I went through my financial and travel records for 2007, I realized that  as usual  I had made a great many mistakes. I’d like to help you to avoid making the same mistakes, so here they are. They might be considered New Year’s resolutions. Or they might be called Lessons Learned.

headline: That Lopsided Game Can Result in Injuries (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mugged in Maplewood
text: Maplewood

headline: China Shrinks
text: Few people noticed, but China got smaller the other day. According to new estimates, the colossal Chinese economy that has been making marketers salivate and giving others an inferiority complex may be roughly 40 percent smaller than previously thought: worth $6 trillion rather than $10 trillion. That means it lost a chunk roughly the size of Japan’s output.

headline: Hidden Treasures of the Food Industry
text: NEW JERSEY’S warehouses and suburban office buildings, as drab-looking as they often are, can be home to gastronomic treasures. Hidden in these prosaic settings are factory and company stores that sell hand-rolled ciabatta bread, fresh pumpkin ravioli and perfectly spiced pastrami directly to the public.

headline: The Year of Dressing Dangerously
text: THE party took place on a recent Tuesday night at R Bar, a midsize nightspot in downtown Manhattan with comfortable banquettes, four stripper poles and large framed photos of scantily clad models on the crimson walls. The lounge is on an emerging stretch of the Bowery that looked very different 15 years ago. The people inside? Less so.

headline: The Best Way to Deflect an Asteroid
text: In 1908, an asteroid is thought to have entered the earth’s atmosphere and exploded over a Siberian forest, leveling some 800 square miles of trees in what is known as the Tunguska Event. If we knew today that another asteroid were on a path to intersect with our planet, what could we do?

headline: King of the Dunk
text: King of the Dunk

headline: Children of the Revolution
text: Pinochet’s Chile, Marcos’s Philippines, Amin’s Uganda, Pol Pot’s Cambodia — and these days, Mugabe’s Zimbabwe — each of these regimes has or had as a centrifugal force the strange appetites and personal bugaboos of its loony dictator. Which is why such governments tend to self-destruct in spectacular colors; sooner or later, the Kool-Aid of gluttony and hypocrisy poisons enough people and the show implodes.

headline: A Store’s Air-Conditioner Is on a Condo’s Roof
text: Q I own a condominium unit in a building in Queens, and I own the roof rights above it. I would like to build above my unit, and this is acceptable to the board and the city Buildings Department. However, there is a large air-conditioning unit on the roof that belongs to the store on the first floor, which is also a condo unit.

headline: Necessary Roughness
text: If you are a politician trying to change the ways of a state known for its fiscal imprudence and addiction to debt, there are two words you surely do not want attached to your name: luxury boxes. So it was wise of Gov. Jon Corzine to withdraw the state’s offer of a $30 million loan to Rutgers University to help pay for a renovation of the school’s football stadium in Piscataway. The $120 million project, designed to expand capacity from 41,500 to more than 53,000, would have included the high-end suites that are so popular with affluent sports fans these days.

headline: Steelers Hope to Add to Pressure on the Patriots
text: Pittsburgh Steelers linebacker James Harrison does not watch football, unless it is of the game-film variety, so his attention was otherwise occupied Monday night while the rest of the N.F.L. was riveted by the Patriots’ near-miss victory over the Ravens.

headline: Dubai Art Fair to Promote an East-West Dialogue
text: From March 19 to 22, Art Dubai (www.artdubai.ae), a contemporary art fair, will take place at the Madinat Jumeirah resort in Dubai. About 70 galleries will participate, including Kukje Gallery in Seoul, which will display works of the artist Hye Rim Lee, right.

headline: Mitt’s No J.F.K.
text: WASHINGTON

headline: A Shore Thing
text: Mashpee, Mass.

headline: Oprah Winfrey Hits Campaign Trail for Obama
text: DES MOINES, Dec. 8  When she begins a typical show, seldom does Oprah Winfrey question the power of her brand or wonder aloud about the influence that accompanies her golden seal of approval.

headline: Teenagers and Cars: A Deadly Mix
text: WESTON, Conn.

headline: A Stick Sculpture, and a Beauty
text: The hockey stick sculpture hovers above the cash register at NHL Powered by Reebok in Midtown Manhattan as if poised to unleash a blizzard of slap shots at unsuspecting shoppers. The three rings that contain 435 black sticks are brightened on the inside by illuminated plexiglass pucks and on the exterior by eight 50-inch flat-screen televisions that are always tuned to hockey games or highlights.

headline: A Knack for Being the Bad Boy
text: HBO has a way with profanity. Tony Soprano could sculpture swear upon swear into something approaching fine art. Expletives are a stock in trade of the cops and drug dealers on “The Wire.” And in the new series “Tell Me You Love Me” dirty words convey the sexual aggravation of forlorn lovers slogging through couples’ counseling.

headline: So That’s Why They Drink Coke on TV
text: ADVERTISING is often like a game of cat and mouse. Consumers try as hard as they can to run away from sales pitches and commercial jingles, so marketers continually seek new ways to hunt them down.

headline: Jessica Nelson and Frank Clark II
text: Jessica Lee Nelson and Frank Milton Clark II were married yesterday at St. Christopher’s Church in Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas. Archdeacon Keith N. Cartwright, an Anglican priest, officiated, and the Rev. Charles G. Adams, a Baptist minister, participated.

headline: A Crisis Sent Him Away; Another Drew Him Home
text: THERE is nothing froufrou or la-di-da about Kevin Sessums’s studio apartment in Chelsea. Impeccably and sparely furnished, it does not look like the home of a self-described “Mississippi Sissy,” which is the title of his memoir about becoming an orphan at 8 and growing up gay in the segregationist South during the Civil Rights era.

headline: Vegansexuality
text: Forget homo-, bi- or even metro-: the latest prefix in sexuality is vegan-, as in “vegansexual.” In a study released in May, Annie Potts, a researcher at the University of Canterbury and a director of the New Zealand Centre for Human-Animal Studies, surveyed 157 vegans and vegetarians (120 of them women) on the topic of cruelty-free living. The questions ranged from attitudes about eating meat to keeping pets to wearing possum fur to, yes, “cruelty-free sex” — that is, “rejecting meat eaters as intimate partners.”

headline: If It’s Fit to Blog, Is It Fit to Print?
text: ON Nov. 19, PublicAffairs Books, an independent publisher specializing in books about politics, posted its catalog of upcoming spring releases on the Internet. One of them was “What Happened: Inside the Bush White House and What’s Wrong with Washington,” by Scott McClellan, President Bush’s former press secretary.

headline: 36 Hours in Beijing
text: BEIJING can feel chaotic and sprawling, especially as it races to finish Olympic construction before the Games begin on Aug. 8. But there's an ancient order to the place, a cosmology, and you can follow it. The palaces and temples line up like stars on the city's south-north axis. The government chose to build the Olympic Stadium on the axis, too. All over town there are digital billboards with a countdown to the Games. Down to the second. But wait. Besides the cranes and compact cars and floating particulate matter, everything essential about the city — its tall vermilion walls, its septuagenarians flying kites on bridges, its pigeons — has been there all along.

headline: Appendix Rationale, The
text: For years, the appendix got no respect. Doctors regarded it as nothing but a source of trouble: It didn’t seem to do anything, and it sometimes got infected and required an emergency removal. Plus, nobody ever suffered from not having an appendix. So human biologists assumed that the tiny, worm-shaped organ is vestigial  a shrunken remainder of some organ our ancestors required. In a word: Useless.

headline: Living the Hydrogen Life
text: Los Angeles

headline: Smog-Eating Cement
text: This year a new weapon against smog was introduced in the United States: cement. Called TX Active, it was developed by the Italian company Italcementi. Enrico Borgarello, Italcementi’s head of research and development, says the product can literally “kill” pollution.

headline: Stacy Feinberg, Michael Brylawski
text: Stacy Ellen Feinberg, the daughter of Donna Feinberg and Barry H. Feinberg of Villanova, Pa., was married last evening to Michael Mills Brylawski, a son of Joan Busko of Durham, N.C., and the late Thomas Brylawski. Rabbi Max Hausen officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

headline: Hydrogen Car Is Here, a Bit Ahead of Its Time
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Gates Sees Iran as Still-Serious Threat
text: MANAMA, Bahrain, Dec. 8  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Saturday that Iran is a grave threat to regional security even without nuclear weapons, and called on Tehran to account for American intelligence that describes its support for terrorism and instability around the world.

headline: Your Child's Disorder May Be Yours, Too
text: BY age 2 it was clear that the boy had a sensibility all his own, affectionate and distant at the same time, often more focused on patterns and objects than the people around him.

headline: Mindful Exercise
text: Simply by telling 44 hotel maids that what they did each day involved some serious exercise, the Harvard psychologist Ellen Langer and Alia J. Crum, a student, were apparently able to lower the women’s blood pressure, shave pounds off their bodies and improve their body-fat and “waist to hip” ratios. Self-awareness, it seems, was the women’s elliptical trainer.

headline: Melissa Ciano, Gregory Ellis
text: Melissa Ciano and Gregory Scott Ellis are to be married today at Alger House, an event space in New York. The Rev. John Merz, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate.

headline: The Future? It’s Stewart Airport
