text: NOW that the Port Authority has assumed control of Stewart International Airport in New Windsor with plans to upgrade and expand it, real estate agents in Orange County are anticipating a rush of new development that they believe is sure to follow.

headline: Wave Energy
text: For decades, researchers have tried to tap the clean energy of ocean waves. Unfortunately, storms and seawater have wreaked havoc on their delicate turbines. But now there’s a solution on the horizon: buoys that generate energy with nothing more than a souped-up rubber band.

headline: To Delight of Duffers, a Round at the Open
text: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 7  Almost every golfer has dreamed of being in the United States Open. Some have nightmares about incredible shrinking fairways; others see themselves sinking the 5-foot putt that beats Tiger Woods.

headline: A Refuge From Sticker Shock
text: DURING the morning rush, commuters from the rest of Staten Island, bound for offices in Manhattan and elsewhere, exit the Staten Island Railway at Tompkinsville, a stop before the ferry terminal in St. George, and head out to the street in droves.

headline: Mob Jurisprudence
text: MOB JURISPRUDENCE When the New Zealand police force said they were open to suggestions about how to rewrite national policing laws, they meant it. In September, they posted the 1958 Police Act online and invited Kiwis and non-Kiwis alike to visit the site and type in their own revisions to the law — extending the concept of “Wiki”-style collaborative writing from encyclopedias to democracy.

headline: Letters: The Perils of Petrocracy
text: In her Nov. 4 article, Tina Rosenberg relies on what I consider to be highly partisan sources. The result is a misleading picture of Venezuela and its oil industry.

headline: Fresh Eyes on a Colorful Movement
text: There is something breezy about artwork purely in the service of an aesthetic agenda. This is what art historians like to box up as “art for art’s sake,” or art that is free of ideas or ideology and made purely to be admired. The notion is often associated with late-19th-century English art, in particular the work of James McNeill Whistler. It is art that does not have anything to say.

headline: Space Shuttle Scheduled to Lift Off Sunday
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 8  NASA will try to launch the space shuttle Atlantis on Sunday under restrictive rules to deal with problem fuel sensors and an unusually tight liftoff schedule.

headline: Back to the Days of Bowie and Iggy
text: HANSA STUDIOS, in Berlin, where David Bowie, Iggy Pop and Nina Hagen all recorded career-defining albums, looks out these days on a modern red-brick apartment complex behind the gleaming new Potsdamer Platz. But in the late 1970s, when Bowie and company were recording there, the landscape was bleakly romantic: a sandy wasteland marked only by the Berlin Wall, which inspired Mr. Bowie’s epochal song “Heroes.”

headline: The Sacred Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time to Deal with E-Waste
text: There’s no denying that America has become a throwaway society, where old acquisitions don’t need to show much wear and tear before being replaced. This is especially the case with electronic waste, the fastest growing piece of the nation’s municipal waste stream.

headline: Reshaping the Debate on Raising Taxes
text: POWERFUL anti-tax rhetoric has made legislators at every level of government afraid to talk publicly about a need to raise taxes. The constituents of the few who dare speak are typically bombarded with attack ads that go something like this: “It’s your money, but your esteemed senator thinks the bureaucrats in Washington know how to spend it more wisely than you do.”

headline: Name-Dropping Can Be Hurtful in Drug Inquiry
text: Barry Bonds was arraigned Friday, no thanks to Major League Baseball. And that’s fine. That’s what government is for  to look into shady dealings, perhaps overlooked by the private industries and unions that might benefit from them.

headline: Interstellar Ramadan
text: When Malaysia’s first astronaut, Sheikh Muszaphar Shukor, blasted off to the International Space Station in October, he faced an unusual challenge: observing Ramadan in outer space. In a month when Muslims traditionally fast all day and eat after sundown, how do you know what time it is on a vehicle that orbits Earth 16 times every 24 hours? How do you bow toward Mecca five times a day in zero gravity? To answer these questions and more, the Malaysian government assembled 150 clerics and scientists and produced a booklet, “Guidelines for Performing Islamic Rites at the International Space Station.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in the Travel section today about Moscow as a new luxury destination misstates the cost of creating Turandot, a lavish restaurant that opened last year. It was $50 million, not $50. (Go to Article)

headline: Zygotic Social Networking
text: If there’s any truth to the Spanish proverb “an ounce of blood is worth more than a pound of friendship,” then consider the potential of genetic social networking. In October, two companies started social-networking Web sites based not on friendship, business connections or dating desires but on cheek-swab DNA tests. Participants fill out their genetic profile and link up with strangers who share DNA markers. Users can upload baby pictures and home videos, compare family trees and e-mail distant cousins to find out what life is like in the old country.

headline: In Fort Greene, a Spanish Red
text: Gnarly Vines, a boutique that opened last month in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, emphasizes small-production wines. The owner is Brian Robinson, formerly a Christie’s wine specialist.

headline: Julan Sun and Thomas Filep
text: Julan Sun and Thomas John Filep were married on Thursday on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. The Rev. Robert Nelson, a Baptist minister, officiated at Wyndham Sugar Bay Resort and Spa in Charlotte Amalie.

headline: As Ice Recedes, Interest Surges
text: FOR those who find that Discovery Channel documentaries and Al Gore’s PowerPoint presentations don’t adequately capture the phenomenon of global warming, another option is now more readily available: pulling on a fur-lined parka and watching the ice melt in Greenland.

headline: Accentuating the Negative
text: THE eureka moment came for Dave Hruby as he lay awake in his tidy three-bedroom house wondering why, after 10 months on the market, the property had failed to draw a single offer.

headline: Two-Birds-With-One-Stone Resistance
text: To kill two birds with one stone — what could be better? Taking the train instead of driving a car, for example, gets you to where you’re going and lets you read the paper. But it turns out that if you have just one goal in mind, chances are you’ll actually be less inclined to take a path that also happens to serve other goals. Foolishly, you’ll resist the more advantageous approach.

headline: Katherine Schneider and William Petricone Jr.
text: Dr. Katherine A. Schneider and Dr. William R. Petricone Jr. were married last evening at their home in Wallingford, Conn. Judge Edward J. Dolan of the State Superior Court in Norwalk, Conn., officiated.

headline: VIKINGS at 49ERS
text: VIKINGS at 49ERS

headline: Oil-Rich Nations Use More Energy, Cutting Exports
text: The economies of many big oil-exporting countries are growing so fast that their need for energy within their borders is crimping how much they can sell abroad, adding new strains to the global oil market.

headline: Prison Poker
text: In April 2003 the Pentagon created decks of playing cards to be given to soldiers, all featuring wanted members of Saddam Hussein’s inner circle. When he heard this, Special Agent Tommy Ray, a state law officer in Polk County, Fla., got inspired. Two years later, he made his own deck of cards, each bearing information about a different local criminal case that had gone cold. He distributed the decks in the Polk County jail. His hunch was that prisoners would gossip about the cases during card games, and somehow clues or breaks would emerge and make their way to the authorities. The plan worked. Two months in, as a result of a tip from a card-playing informant, two men were charged with a 2004 murder in a case that had gone cold.

headline: One Borough, Many Flags
text: A LOT of foreign tourists — and that includes Europeans, Californians and Manhattanites — have had occasion to stick their toe into the borough of Queens. Perhaps it was a trip to the Museum of Modern Art, during its temporary relocation to Long Island City. Maybe a sari and samosa shopping trip to 74th Street in Jackson Heights. Or a pilgrimage to Sripraphai, the Thai restaurant in the Woodside section with legendary status among crowds that speak in phrases like “best fried watercress salad in the city.”

headline: Bloomberg Went Too Far in Gun Sting, Dealers Say
text: SMYRNA, Ga., Dec. 5  In Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s campaign to remove illegal guns from New York City’s streets, he sued 27 out-of-state gun dealerships last year over what he said were illegal sales. Most agreed to settle, while others chose to take their chances in court.

headline: On Long Island, Fatalities in an Age Range Are Flat After Law
text: CANDICE J. STARK still remembers the teenage driving program at Oceanside High School that she attended with her son almost a decade ago. A police officer and an auto insurance representative talked about the perils of young people behind the wheel. Then a mother stood up and told a heart-wrenching story about losing her child in an auto accident.

headline: Letters
text: The Mortgage Mess

headline: Cliché Crunch
text: “Don’t believe all the hype about the ‘credit crunch,’ ” wrote the admirable financial columnist Robert Samuelson last month in Newsweek and The Washington Post. I was glad to read that reassurance from the burning deck while all the rest were fleeing, because such a combination of alliteration and onomatopoeia that produced credit crunch has been enough to raise the ghost of Magnus Arbuthnot. That fictional “cliché expert” of Frank Sullivan’s in the 1930s purged platitudes and banished bromides from our language during the linguistic heyday of The New Yorker magazine: “My motives are ulterior, my circles are vicious, my retainers are faithful. My suspicions are sneaking, my glee is fiendish. . . .”

headline: Airborne Wind Turbines
text: Traditional wind turbines can be unreliable sources of energy because, well, the wind blows where it will. Not the case 1,000 feet up. “At a thousand feet, there is steady wind anywhere in the world,” says Mac Brown, chief operating officer of Ottawa-based Magenn Power.

headline: Indie-Rock Musicals
text: This year, a young corner of the theater world turned to musicals scored with indie rock  rock music that deliberately avoids the traditional pop-song structures, widely accessible themes and smooth production of classic radio fare. “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” written and directed by Alex Timbers, with music and lyrics by Michael Friedman, uses slightly sloppy emo guitar riffs and raw, punkish singing to convey the underdog mentality of the frontier populists who founded the Democratic Party and bled the Indians. “Caravan Man,” with book by Tommy Smith and music by Gabriel Kahane (who will perform in “Bloody Bloody”), went up in summer as a work in progress at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, where “Bloody Bloody” was workshopped last year, and tells the story of the prophet Muhammad through alt-country songs stylistically similar to the rough-edged ballads of Ryan Adams. Meanwhile, “Love Kills” draws on the hardcore fringe of emo to revisit the murderous Nebraska couple famously portrayed in the film “Badlands”; its book and music are by Kyle Jarrow, Timbers’s sometime writing partner.

headline: As Iraqis Vie for Kirkuk’s Oil, Kurds Are Pawns
text: KIRKUK, Iraq  Even by the skewed standards of a country where millions are homeless or in exile, the squalor of the Kirkuk soccer stadium is a startling sight.

headline: You Couldn’t Write This Stuff: TV Reality Sets In
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8  Each year television viewers emerge in January from the traditional December blizzard of holiday specials and college football bowl games seeking new comforts from their favorite comedies and dramas, shows like “Grey’s Anatomy,” “Two and a Half Men” and “House.”

headline: Comfort Food for the Soul
text: You needn’t have been raised on black-eyed peas and collard greens to find comfort at Miss Thelma’s Restaurant in downtown Bridgeport. All you need is an appreciation of good Southern cuisine. Among the dozen or so entrees on the menu are pork chops smothered in gravy ($9), crispy fried chicken ($8.50), fried or grilled whiting and fried or grilled catfish ($9.50 to 11.50), meatloaf ($8.25) and barbecued pork ribs ($10). The restaurant also offers occasional specials, like oxtails stewed with tomatoes, onions and carrots ($9.50); chicken and dumplings ($8.50); and turkey wings, served with corn bread stuffing ($8.50).

headline: REITs Are Down, but for How Long?
text: THE enduring rally in real estate investment trusts finally ended this year as turbulence in the credit markets rattled the confidence of commercial investors and effectively halted the frenetic pace of REIT privatizations.

headline: Tax Rebates Await N.Y. Homeowners
text: THE State of New York is fervently trying to give property owners some of their tax money back. But some owners may be leaving money on the table.

headline: A Show of Small Works, and a Group Sampler
The Hills Are Alive (Ditto a Career)
text: Three years ago the choreographer Doug Elkins was sitting in his apartment in Washington Heights with his 3-year-old son. His dance company of 15 years had disbanded, his marriage had recently ended, and he was suffering from a pervasive melancholy that made the idea of creating new work feel like a distant mirage. But his son wanted to watch “The Sound of Music,” and as Mr. Elkins dutifully sang along to “The Lonely Goatherd,” he had the germ of an idea.

headline: Andrew Imbrie, 86, Composer and Teacher, Is Dead
text: Andrew Imbrie, a prolific composer and influential teacher best known for his harmonically rugged but appealingly lyrical 1976 opera, “Angle of Repose,” and for a rich catalog of chamber, vocal and symphonic scores, died on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Consider the Lobster
text: To the Editor:

headline: Look Who’s Still Standing in Russia
text: MOSCOW

headline: Afterlife Hard for Once-Grand Church
text: Jersey City

headline: Glorious Nation of Uzbekistan
text: A diplomatic posting to Tashkent may not sound glamorous, but it has been an important assignment in recent years. Craig Murray, who served as British ambassador to Uzbekistan from 2002 to 2004, explains in “Dirty Diplomacy” how the country has played a crucial role in the war on terror. Thousands of American troops have been stationed at the Karshi Khanabad air base, known as K2, and in 2002 American officials approved $140 million in aid for Uzbekistan. Murray found himself caught between geopolitical considerations — the strategic partnership between Uzbekistan and the United States and Britain — and his concern for the people living under a despotic leader. In his memoir, he incorporates political argument as well as personal reflection.

headline: Rumors of This Play Were Not Exaggerated
text: SHELLEY FISHER FISHKIN opened a file drawer at the University of California’s Bancroft Library in Berkeley, where the largest collection of Mark Twain’s papers is archived. She was researching a project on racial themes in his work, and was not thrilled to find the drawer crammed with Twain plays she had not yet read and didn’t care to.

headline: The Star Treatment
text: FINE, I’LL GO ONLINE!

headline: What Did the Professor Say? Check Your iPod
text: STUDENTS staring at their iPod screens may be taking a break with a music video  or they may be reviewing a tough chemistry lecture.

headline: In Gaps at School, Weighing Family Life
text: THE federal No Child Left Behind law of 2002 rates schools based on how students perform on state standardized tests, and if too many children score poorly, the school is judged as failing.

headline: Veto of Spending Bill Is Threatened
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The White House budget director warned on Saturday that President Bush was prepared to veto a $500 billion spending package being assembled in Congress if Democrats pushed for too much additional money for domestic programs.

headline: From North and West, a Winning Menu
text: PALOMINO in Old Greenwich is the latest in a four-restaurant mini-empire begun by the chef Rafael Palomino in Port Chester. The other three have nuevo Latin American motifs  Sonora and Pacifico in Port Chester and Pacifico in New Haven.

headline: Teaching Teamwork, but With Real Money
text: TOM ROGERSON has seen his share of families bickering over money  often because they were utterly unprepared to handle it.

headline: Bumps on His Head, Stars in His Eyes
text: THE first blow felt as though an air-conditioner had fallen from a window and landed on my head. The repeated strikes that followed revealed a more brutal truth: I was being mugged.

headline: Cartagena Again Welcomes International Music Festival
text: The Cartagena International Festival of Music is the latest source of inspiration for Charles Wadsworth, founding director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and the organizer behind the Spoleto U.S.A. Festival’s chamber concert series in Charleston, S.C. From Jan. 5 to 12 the festival will take over the Colombian tourist destination, known for its colonial architecture and temperate Caribbean breezes. The festival, now in its second year, is scheduled to include performers like the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet, the flutist Paula Robison and the guitarist Romero Lubambo. More than 40 master classes will be offered. Venues include the Teatro Heredia, above, which was built in the 17th century, and the chapels of several historic churches and hotels. There will also be four open-air concerts in the Plaza San Pedro Claver. Packages, which include lodging and tickets to events, start at $2,690 for five nights (www.cartagenamusicfestival.com).

headline: Studs’s Place
text: Imagine it is closing time, but the wizened man in the bar’s back booth shows no intention of leaving; he still has things to say. With martini-fueled words that carry gin’s sting and pleasure, he conjures memories that

headline: Calendar of Events
text: FILM

headline: Meacham Hitches Wagon to Girardi
text: With two out in the eighth inning, Curt Wilkerson hit a ground ball in the hole between third base and shortstop. Bobby Meacham backhanded the ball, bobbled it, then bounced it past Ken Griffey at first as Pete O’Brien scored what minutes later became the winning run in a 7-6 Rangers victory over the Yankees.

headline: Paving Over History
text: Fishkill

headline: Growing Old Enough to Appreciate Youth
text: AN abiding delight of my college years, as I devoured Verdi opera after Verdi opera, was the thought that there was an entire repertory of such gems waiting to be discovered. I did not realize then that I was starting at the top, and that very few other operas, however much I admired them, would yield that sense of visceral rightness: a sense that they communicated something of what life was about.

headline: Escape From New York, Nev.
text: In his seventh novel, “The Swing Voter of Staten Island,” Arthur Nersesian reinvents New York City in Nevada in 1980. This is not “old New York,” which still exists. This is the “first designated Rescue City,” an urban doppelgänger, designed in the 1940s as a military training zone and now populated by one million poor New Yorkers, as well as conscientious objectors from the Vietnam War, refugees from hurricanes and earthquakes, 150,000 people with “questionable criminal or political backgrounds,” half a dozen terrorist cells, political parties that behave as violent gangs, and Abbie Hoffman, Allen Ginsberg, Woodward and Bernstein and Daniel Ellsberg.

headline: Correction: Language as Sculpture, Words as Clay
text: A picture of an installation at the Galleri Susanne Ottesen on Oct. 21 with an article about Lawrence Weiner carried an imprecise credit. The photograph was provided courtesy of the Whitney Museum of American Art; it was not taken by the Whitney. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Nov. 14; this correction was further delayed for research.

headline: Community Urinalysis
text: Everyone knows how a drug test works: You urinate into a cup and your employer (or prospective employer) has the sample tested to see if you’ve been using any illegal substances. This year, though, Jennifer Field, an environmental chemist at Oregon State University, experimented with an unusual variation on this process. She found out what illicit drugs the population of an entire city was ingesting.

headline: Stereo Sanctuaries
text: What exactly do men do in their tricked-out electronic hideaways? You know, when they’re “working.”

headline: Biofuel Race, The
text: For millennia, civilization’s main event, the harvest, has focused our attention upon the fruit of our agricultural efforts  the kernel, the grain, busheled and bagged. So it’s no surprise that the fledgling biofuel industry has been similarly focused: America’s favorite biofuels come mostly from corn and from soy. But when food crops are used as fuel, difficulties may follow. The vogue for corn ethanol has driven up the price of corn around the world, putting the poor in jeopardy. (An expert affiliated with the United Nations went so far as to label the production of biofuels derived from food stock “a crime against humanity.”) Corn ethanol is also astonishingly inefficient: because vast amounts of fossil fuels are required for its manufacture, every 1 unit of energy nets a mere 1.3 units of ethanol.

headline: The Business of Weather
text: To the Editor:

headline: Man Held by C.I.A. Says He Was Tortured
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The first of the so-called high-value Guantánamo detainees to have seen a lawyer claims he was subjected to “state-sanctioned torture” while in secret C.I.A. prisons, and he has asked for a court order barring the government from destroying evidence of his treatment.

headline: Starch Made Us Human
text: Traditionally, when scientists spared a thought for our hunting and gathering forebears, they focused on the hunters and the meat they brought in. But it may be that it was our ancestors’ less glamorous ability to gather, eat and digest roots, bulbs and tubers — the wild versions of what became carrots, onions and potatoes — that increased the size of our brains and made the hunt and the territorial expansion that came with it possible.

headline: The 7th Annual Year in Ideas
text: For the seventh consecutive December, the magazine looks back on the passing year through a special lens: ideas. Editors and writers trawl the oceans of ingenuity, hoping to snag in our nets the many curious, inspired, perplexing and sometimes outright illegal innovations of the past 12 months. Then we lay them out on the dock, flipping and flopping and gasping for air, and toss back all but those that are fresh enough for our particular cut of intellectual sushi. For better or worse, these are 70 of the ideas that helped make 2007 what it was. Enjoy.

headline: Mogul’s New Role: Novice Producer
text: IT was the kind of publicity event that most first-time filmmakers could only dream of. An invitation-only screening of the documentary “Nanking,” held in late October at the Tribeca Grand Hotel, conjured up an eclectic mix of attendees, including the “60 Minutes” correspondent Bob Simon, the real estate scion Ivanka Trump and the gossip columnist Cindy Adams, not to mention its official hostess, Wendi Murdoch, the wife of Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation.

headline: A Diva Cruises Again
text: As James McCourt’s 1975 novel “Mawrdew Czgowchwz” came to a close, its heroine sailed out of New York Harbor, bound for Ireland to star in a film about her rediscovered Irish patriot mother. It might be read as an ironic conclusion: “the diva of the moment” going Hollywood at the peak of her operatic career.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Sunday in T: Holiday magazine about collecting art misspelled the name and e-mail address of an art-advisory company. It is Tizianos, at Tizianosmodern@gmail.com, not Pizianos.

headline: Fewer Places to Nest
text: It is impossible to imagine Connecticut without the sweet song of birds. The state is so crisscrossed with lush hills and streams that most residents think of it as a good place to live  or nest.

headline: Two Projects Claim Street Savvy
text: JERSEY CITY

headline: Honeycomb Vase, The
text: How many workers does it take to make a vase? To devotees of the Arts and Crafts Movement, it’s one. But in the case of the Honeycomb Vase, it’s 40,000  because the “workers” who made it were bees toiling in their hive.

headline: Susan Williams-Ellis, 89, Designer of Popular Ceramic Tableware, Is Dead
text: Susan Williams-Ellis, the eccentric designer of Botanic Garden, the widely popular ceramic tableware that made its debut in 1972 died on Nov. 27 in Portmeirion Village in northern Wales, the Italianate dream world built by her father, Sir Clough Williams-Ellis. She was 89.

headline: Back From the Other Side, Courtside
text: Neal Hawks, a real estate developer in Dallas, put some of his property to good use last night.

headline: Pay What You Want for This Article
text: OXFORD, England

headline: When Development Threatens Our Water (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Height Tax, The
text: Should we tax tall workers at a higher rate than their shorter peers? The answer  yes  “follows inexorably” from reigning academic theories of taxation, argues Greg Mankiw, an economics professor at Harvard (and former chairman of President George W. Bush’s Council of Economic Advisers), in a working paper first circulated in April.

headline: Sharon Klein, Joel Barnett
text: Sharon Gail Klein and Joel Carlton Barnett were married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas performed the ceremony.

headline: Quitting Can Be Good for You
text: America is a success-minded nation. Perseverance is practically a national resource. Posters of mountain climbers that read “Winners Never Quit, and Quitters Never Win” might as well be state-mandated signage in grade-school classrooms. But new research suggests that success — or more specifically, the persistence required to achieve hard-to-reach goals — may not be worth it.

headline: Unadapted Theatrical Adaptation, The
text: Why are stage adaptations of great novels almost always so disappointing? The problem, according to one popular theory, is that in shrinking the text down to size, erasing scenes and conflating characters, versions of “Jane Eyre” or (God help us) “The Scarlet Pimpernel” sacrifice some of the classic book’s essential virtues: the language, the rhythm of the sentences, the distinctive poetry of the author. This year, John Collins, the cerebral leader of the experimental New York theater company Elevator Repair Service, offered a radical solution: adapt without adapting.

headline: Knicks Lose Another, but Thomas Wins Support From Dolan
text: Isiah Thomas began the night with a sweeping statement and, in keeping with his ever-sunny vision of the Knicks, it was unfailingly optimistic.

headline: Telltale Food Wrapping
text: The usual way to tell if raw meat has gone bad is to see if it has turned purple-gray and smells sour. Fortunately, a more exact method is on the horizon: a piece of paper that changes color on contact with bacteria and thus immediately signals whether your ground chuck is tartare worthy or will be dangerous if it’s not well done. The active ingredient in the paper is a special biological agent that can spot — and, in some cases, even block or destroy — pathogens present in food, water or air.

headline: Off the Political Wagon
text: Chillicothe, Ohio

headline: Pop Fecundity
text: Rihanna, the Top-40 dance diva, upheld one music-biz tradition last summer — that a ubiquitous hit single can be as . . . ubiquitous as ever — while bucking another: that you have to keep your fans hungry. That single, “Umbrella,” came from her third full-length album in two years. Contrast that with the more common trickle strategy, in force since the late ’70s, especially among rock’s dinosaurs: three years and counting since the last all-new U2 CD; the first Eagles album of all-new material in almost three decades.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,689,769.55

headline: A Pad for the Occasional Bachelor
text: WALKING the cobblestones downtown near Stone Street, it’s easy to think of oneself living in an entirely different city, living an entirely different life. How many New Yorkers have passed the old Delmonico’s restaurant lately? Or the brownstone facade of the four-square India House? Or the tiny pocket park  really more of an island  in front of what was once Lower Manhattan’s thriving Cotton Exchange, built in the heyday of the 1920s?

headline: Minimal Chair, The
text: The industrial designer Konstantin Grcic has created a dozen or so chairs, but he long resisted making a cantilever one. “I didn’t dare,” he says. “It’s a no-go area, because it’s the icon of modern furniture design.” It’s also a technical challenge: a cantilever chair has no back legs and so relies on the strength of its materials for support. The odds are low of striking the right balance of stability, lightness and beauty. But Grcic beat the odds, and in October he unveiled his MYTO chair.

headline: Look Homeward, Angels
text: JUST before midnight on Nov. 3, a white truck pulled up to the Frank Viola Homing Pigeon Club, on a dark and quiet stretch of Stillwell Avenue in Coney Island. The air was cold and smelled faintly of the sea. Two men hopped out of the truck. One opened its rear doors. The other approached a handful of older men who were standing in the street. “How many you got tonight?” the man asked.

headline: Jets vs. Browns
text: Jets’ receivers

headline: A Rec Room for Rallies, Fistfights and Rock
text: IT appears likely that Webster Hall, the funky rock music club at 125 East 11th Street, is going to be spiffed up with landmark status.

headline: Culinary Orientalism
text: Tell me what you eat,” wrote the 19th-century French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin, “and I shall tell you what you are.” In other words, an understanding of a community’s cuisine entails an understanding of the community itself. Of late, the cookbook industry seems to have made  perhaps unwittingly  a case that understanding Middle Eastern cuisine is the path to resolving the world’s geopolitical crises.

headline: Letters: The Fish
text: As soon as I read the first stanza, I knew I was in the territory of the whimsical, tender poet Billy Collins (Food, Nov. 25). Thank you for including this inspired gem of a poem as an introduction to your fish recipes. Though I may never try the recipes, I will never tire of revisiting Billy Collins in that Pittsburgh restaurant.

headline: Rock-Paper-Scissors Is Universal
text: The children’s game rock-paper-scissors has a simple yet elegant structure: rock beats scissors; scissors beats paper; paper beats rock. Of the three possible moves, each defeats one, only to be defeated by the other. It’s almost karmic. Indeed, it’s a kind of equilibrium that scientists now say may govern conflict throughout the universe.

headline: Shuttle Launch Is Delayed Again, Until 2008
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 9  NASA, stymied by balky fuel tank sensors, delayed the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis to until at least Jan. 2 to give engineers time to diagnose and fix the problem.

headline: When a Luxury Vacation Cultivates Philanthropy
text: DOING charity work while on vacation no longer has to mean backbreaking labor and dorm-like accommodations. A new kind of philanthropic travel lets wealthy vacationers do good works while still enjoying plush hotel suites and fine restaurants.

headline: Humor, With a Serious Edge After All
text: Unlike, say, going to a movie, viewing art requires effort, for most artists assiduously try to distinguish their work from amusement. Therein lies both its limitation and its appeal.

headline: Amy Weil and Brian Raphael
text: Amy Pamela Weil and Brian Lee Raphael were married last night by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York.

headline: H. Wiley Hitchcock, Who Edited Dictionary of Music, Dies at 84
text: H. Wiley Hitchcock, a leading scholar of American music and the founding director of the Institute for Studies in American Music at Brooklyn College, died Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Comedy

headline: The Girl Beneath the Gilding
text: ANDREA GEYER, a German-born artist, would later describe her first encounter with the famous statue as a moment of intimacy between two living beings. It was the spring of 2004, and Ms. Geyer was starting a residency in a studio on the 33rd floor of the Woolworth Building.

headline: Iconic-Performance-Network Player, The
text: A new kind of sports star emerged in the baseball playoffs in October. Only his debut wasn’t on the field — it was in the phrasing of an agent, Scott Boras. His client Alex Rodriguez was no longer a mere superstar. He was now, Boras said, an I.P.N., or Iconic-Performance-Network, player. The I and P parts of the equation were self-evident and beyond dispute. The N was the next level, however. It was Boras’s way of saying that A-Rod produced more than runs and victories; he was an all-star revenue producer for the New York Yankees.

headline: The Web Users’ Campaign
text: Before they chartered planes and opened teeming offices in Des Moines or Manchester, even before they announced their lofty ambitions to the world, the current field of presidential candidates set about absorbing the lessons of Howard Dean’s 2004 campaign. Dean lost, of course, and in a fairly ignominious way, but his campaign was the first to harness the fund-raising and organizing power of the Internet, and both parties’ 2008 hopefuls had visions of replicating his model  minus the meltdown. One of the first things they did was to sign on a new class of online organizers and fund-raisers. The Web was the new frontier of American politics, and the candidates intended to exploit it.

headline: Cardboard Bridge, The
text: When the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban was asked to build a footbridge over the Gardon River in the south of France, he designed one that was keenly sensitive to its surroundings. He constructed it from locally available materials and based its geometry on the nearby Pont du Gard, a historic Roman aqueduct. But instead of stones or concrete, Ban used a mixture of cardboard tubes, recycled labels and creative engineering.

headline: Students Abroad, Reflecting America
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Republicans Find Their Obama
text: COULD 2008 actually end up being a showdown between the author of “The Audacity of Hope” and the new Man from Hope, Ark.?

headline: Social Groups Uniting the Eco-Conscious
text: Huntington

headline: Wireless Energy
text: The M.I.T. physicist Marin Soljacic found inspiration for his latest invention in the dying batteries of his wife’s cellphone. Every morning around 2 her phone would beep loudly. “One night it occurred to me, wouldn’t it be great if this thing took care of its own charging?” he says.

headline: Catherine Lucey, Ryan Donnell
text: Catherine Ellen Lucey, a newspaper reporter, and Ryan Philips Donnell, a photojournalist, were married yesterday. The Rev. David Engo performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

headline: Reviewing a Co-op Board’s Power to Impose a Flip Tax
text: Q Does a co-op need approval from 100 percent of its shareholders to institute a flip tax?

headline: Murphy Balcony, The
text: Many a person living in a claustrophobic apartment has imagined a spacious veranda suddenly coming into his life. An Amsterdam-based architectural firm has now come up with something that makes good on that fantasy: a window frame that folds out into a balcony with the press of a button.

headline: Office-Chair Exercise (for Men and Women)
text: Perhaps you’re reading this from a desk chair. If you’re male, you’re most likely leaning back into your seat, a bit slumped. If you’re female, you’re probably perched on the front of the chair, leaning forward. Yes, men and women sit differently. And both sexes sit far too long. Now there’s a solution to both problems.

headline: Alzheimer’s Telephone Screening
text: This year, researchers completed work on a 50-question telephone quiz to help them identify Alzheimer’s patients long before they exhibit typical symptoms. Such a quiz may soon become part of regular medical care.

headline: The Fatalist
text: Malcolm Lowry wrote one great book; the rest was miscellany. Before we get to the (freshly collected) miscellany, a word about the one great book. Single-masterpiece authors tend to divide into two camps: the Eternals (Cervantes, Sterne, Melville), or the world-historical quacks who pack everything into a single, unyielding wallop; and the Eternal Adolescents (De Quincey, Kerouac, Exley), or burnout cases who pull it together to manufacture a cult classic. It was Lowry’s fate to fall right in between the two. Coming of age a half-generation after “Ulysses,” the British-born, Cambridge-educated Lowry wanted to produce not just a novel but a cosmos-surfing, cosmos-swallowing book of books. “Under the Volcano” takes place in a demi-Joycean 12 hours, on the feast of the Day of the Dead in Mexico, and took Lowry a Joycean 10 years to fully emit. No one would ever call it underdone. Following the last hours in the life of a British dipsomaniac, “Under the Volcano” embraces everything from Dante to Freud to the cabala. Here it shambles like Cervantes, there it rages like Ahab, and every page of it pulsates on Out of Body Auto-Reply, that style of pure Lowry that points at once backward, to all European literature, and forward, to the mother of all nervous breakdowns.

headline: Climate Conflicts
text: It took years for a consensus on the existence and causes of climate change to emerge. But it took no time at all, it seems, for leaders around the world to latch onto the notion that global warming will bring war. In the spring, a report by retired U.S. generals and admirals called on Washington to incorporate climate change, especially its destabilizing effect on weak states, into the United States’ national defense strategy. Soon after, United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon wrote in The Washington Post that the origin of the brutal fighting between herders and farmers in Darfur was an extended drought that was tied to the warming of the Indian Ocean  itself the product of new weather patterns driven by human activity. And then Al Gore won the Nobel Peace Prize in part for his climate-change documentary, “An Inconvenient Truth.” What does global warming have to do with peace? In the view of the Nobel panel, it “may induce large scale migration and lead to greater competition for the Earth’s resources ... [and] increased danger of violent conflicts and wars, within and between states.”

headline: Just a Girl From Halifax
text: WHILE many actresses fantasize about wearing Valentino or Zac Posen on the red carpet, Ellen Page has a completely different idea.

headline: A Little Bit Country, a Little Bit Everything Else
text: NOT content to be pigeonholed, the Haitian-born rapper and producer Wyclef Jean this month released his sixth studio album  “The Carnival II: Memoirs of an Immigrant” (Columbia)  which dabbles in rock, reggae and hip-hop. This time around he has enlisted a diverse group of collaborators, including Shakira, T. I., Paul Simon and Norah Jones. Mr. Jean, 37, first gained note (and a Grammy) as a member of the Fugees, and was ubiquitous on the airwaves last year in “Hips Don’t Lie,” his duet with Shakira. Early next year he’ll tour the United States, Europe and Africa. While in Paris he took a break from a recording session with the French rapper Diam’s to speak by phone with Winter Miller about what he’s listening to now. Here are excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Rockies Trade Infielder
text: The Colorado Rockies have traded infielder Jamey Carroll to the Cleveland Indians for a player to be named, the teams said in statements. Carroll, 33, hit .225 with two home runs and 22 R.B.I. over 108 games last season.

headline: A Field That Interprets the Language of Genes
text: A YOUNG woman finds that she has a defective gene that increases her chances of breast cancer. A man must decide whether to be tested for the gene that causes Huntington’s disease, a debilitating neurological disorder.

headline: China Link Suspected in Lab Hacking
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8  A cyber attack reported last week by one of the federal government’s nuclear weapons laboratories may have originated in China, according to a confidential memorandum distributed Wednesday to public and private security officials by the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: The Team That Put the Net in Orbit
text: Arlington, Va.

headline: New Breed of Hamptons Paint Slingers
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

headline: How Much of a Rate Cut?
text: PERSISTENT worries about the financial system have led many traders to stop questioning whether the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again this week and to ask instead how big the cut will be.

headline: Taylor’s Heart of Kindness Might Have Left Him Vulnerable
text: MIAMI, Dec. 6  When all was silent, after the gunshots and the commotion had subsided, Jackie Garcia let go of her 18-month-old daughter and crawled from under the bedcovers.

headline: White Noise
text: Earlier this year at Luc Salsedo, a charming little restaurant in the old city of Nice, our glasses of excellent Crozes-Hermitage 2004 were still about half full. Christine Salsedo, who owns the restaurant with her husband, Luc, the chef, suggested cheese. The selection included a St.-Marcellin, one of my favorites.

headline: Five Rounds, With Fat City Nowhere in Sight
text: MANDEVILLE, La.

headline: Ambiguity Promotes Liking
text: Is it true that familiarity breeds contempt? A psychology study published this year concludes that the answer is yes. It seems we are inclined to interpret ambiguous information about someone optimistically, assuming we will get along. We are usually let down, however, when we learn more.

headline: South Plaquemines Wins the Title
text: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 (AP)  Quarterback Ridge Turner passed for two touchdowns and ran for three more as South Plaquemines High School defeated West St. John, 48-8, on Saturday for the Louisiana Class 1A state title.

headline: Letters: Dr. Drug Rep
text: I found myself uncomfortable with Daniel Carlat’s justification for accepting the job with Wyeth (Nov. 25). Every physician in this country is familiar with the efforts of the pharmaceutical industry to influence our prescribing patterns. It starts with medical school, with attractive sales representatives (usually women) stationed outside of lecture halls and cafeterias (only recently have medical schools and hospitals restricted the access of these salespeople).

headline: Lisa Steinmeyer, Peter Feldman
text: Lisa Steinmeyer and Peter Feldman were married yesterday at their weekend home in Mount Tremper, N.Y. Robert D. Smiley, a Rose Ministries pastor, officiated.

headline: Inquiry Begins Into Destruction of Tapes
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  The Justice Department and the Central Intelligence Agency’s internal watchdog on Saturday began a joint preliminary inquiry into the spy agency’s destruction of hundreds of hours of videotapes showing interrogations of top operatives of Al Qaeda.

headline: The Legacy
text: You’ve just been named the next editor of Commentary, which became the voice of the neoconservative movement in the ’70s under the stewardship of your famous father, Norman. Did you always want to be the editor of Commentary? I never wanted to be editor of Commentary, at least not after the age of 7, when children seem to think, largely because of fairy tales, that they ascend to the position their parents hold upon their parents’ death.

headline: Emergency Décor
text: HomeHero

headline: A Collage of Colliding References
text: CHARLES MEE is an affable rebel. His colleagues praise this playwright for everything from his collaborative spirit to his knack for dinnertime conversation, and when it’s time for an interview, he and his wife, the actress Michi Barall, sometimes invite reporters to their home in Brooklyn as though they were welcoming old friends.

headline: Priorities for Kids: Two Contrasting Views (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Suing God
text: It sounds like a kooky law-school exercise. Your life has been upended by a horrible tragedy, one of those “acts of God” listed in the clause in your insurance policy denying coverage. Why can’t you take a higher power to court and make it pay through the nose? The hypothetical became real on Sept. 14 when State Senator Ernie Chambers sued God in Douglas County District Court in Omaha.

headline: Giants vs. Eagles
text: Osi Umenyiora vs. William Thomas

headline: From Russia With Luxe
text: PRINCE ALBERT of Monaco was still eagerly expected, but already a thick throng of Moscow's clubbing elite and dolled-up wannabes was trying to claw its way into the Dyagilev Project nightclub. Dressed as if fresh from a Dolce & Gabbana year-end sale, the crowd pushed, pleaded and shouted the name of the doorman — “Pasha! Spasiba, Pasha!” — in hopes of entering.

headline: Reversing Scoring Decline Is Not a Goal
text: One of the main topics of discussion at the recent N.H.L. board of governors meetings was the continued decline in scoring.

headline: New Jersey Governor Appointed Group to Study Issues of Teenage Driving
text: Cliffside Park

headline: Death of Checkers, The
text: Checkers has been around for more than 400 years, has been enjoyed by billions of players and has taught generations of young children the joy of strategy.

headline: A School Gets an F, and Parents Worry About What Comes Next
text: ON Wednesday, the after-school scene outside Public School 79 in Tremont in the Bronx looked utterly typical. Older students lobbed snowballs and chunks of ice at one another as younger ones, bundled in heavy coats and mittens, climbed aboard bright yellow school buses.

headline: A Distant Chance of Finding a Weakness
text: The Patriots do so many things well that searching for a weakness can be as futile as guaranteeing a victory against them, which Steelers safety Anthony Smith did on Wednesday.

headline: Meg Gibson, Keith Reddin
text: Meg Gibson and Keith Reddin were married in a civil ceremony Wednesday at Village Hall in Irvington N.Y. Judge Lawrence H. Ecker, the village justice, officiated.

headline: The Shock of the Old
text: Napoleon’s occupation of Egypt in 1798 was among history’s more memorable military fiascos. A side skirmish in his drawn-out colonial competition with the British, by any measure the invasion went badly. The British promptly sank much of the French fleet, stranding the forces. A march across the desert from Alexandria to Cairo without so much as canteens, as Nina Burleigh tells us in “Mirage: Napoleon’s Scientists and the Unveiling of Egypt,” left “untold hundreds” dead. A Muslim uprising at Cairo resulted in more deaths and, not insignificantly, the loss of any remnant of civility on the part of the French who, invading the Azhar mosque in an effort to crush an insurgency, desecrated the Koran and, as an Egyptian contemporary wrote, “soiled the mosque, blowing their spit in it ... and defecating in it.” And then there was the plague, which, together with dysentery and other diseases, may have killed as many as 10,000 of the French soldiers.

headline: A Hail of Bullets, a Heap of Uncertainty
text: AFTER almost every high-profile fatal shooting by the police, a flurry of questions follows hard on the hail of bullets. Premier among them is, Did they have to kill him?

headline: Between Buyers and Sellers, a Stalemate
text: An article last Sunday about the stalemate between potential buyers in Manhattan who want to negotiate on price and sellers who are unwilling to budge from the asking price misidentified a neighborhood in northern Manhattan where two elderly brothers begrudgingly lowered the price on an apartment on West 181st Street. It is Washington Heights, not Inwood.

headline: Larsen’s Feat Lives in Amateur Movies
text: On Oct. 8, 1956, Saul Terry took his 8-millimeter camera to Yankee Stadium, where he and his wife settled into seats in the right-field bleachers, which would cast occasional clouds of darkness onto his film.

headline: Famine’s Villains
text: The Great Irish Hunger spawned a long-distance exodus probably without parallel in the history of famines. The emigrants are usually reckoned among its victims, and rightly so. At the same time, emigration was the Great Hunger’s main lifeboat; without it many, many more would have died. Those who left forged better lives for themselves and relieved some of the pressure on those who remained. Emigration was a crude form of disaster relief.

headline: Elline Lipkin, Richard Horowitz
text: Elline Isabelle Lipkin, a daughter of Nicole and Dr. David Lipkin of Weston, Fla., was married last evening to Richard Steven Horowitz, a son of Lenore and Herbert E. Horowitz of Washington. Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Faster Games Mean Mistakes, as Svidler Finds at World Cup
text: Chess has sped up lately, often affecting a game’s outcome.

headline: Fungus Once Again Threatens French Cave Paintings
text: PARIS, Dec. 8  For the second time in a decade, fungus is threatening France’s most celebrated prehistoric paintings, the mysterious animal images that line the Lascaux cave in the Dordogne region of southwest France, scientists say.

headline: And for Sports, Kid, Put Down ‘Squash’
text: YOU’VE already enrolled your teenagers in advanced-placement Mandarin, retained a $9,000-a-year college admissions consultant to help refine their applications, and sent them off to Kyrgyzstan to dig irrigation ditches for the summer. Still, there’s no guarantee that they’ll get into an Ivy League university. What are you going to do?

headline: Edible Cocktail, The
text: Dave Arnold, the head of culinary technology at the French Culinary Institute in Manhattan, is by training not a chef but a sculptor. He worked with metals and machinery as an art student and once battled a fire-breathing dragon. (It was a modified air blower that spit flaming kerosene; he wore a welding jacket and carried a lance.)

headline: For Your Ears Only
text: LAST week, at the corner of Prince and Mulberry Streets in NoLIta, a scene was playing out that would have gladdened the heart of any advertising buyer. Pedestrians were turning and gawking at a six-story tenement emblazoned with a giant billboard for “Paranormal State,” a new television series about ghosts on A & E.

headline: Criminal Recycling
text: In October, according to a police report, Paul Zurschmit and Darrin Bolin sneaked onto the football field of Archbishop Hoban High School in Akron, Ohio, and stole several metal bleachers, which they cut into pieces and hauled to a scrap yard 100 miles away in West Virginia, receiving $600 for the aluminum. The two men, who were later arrested, are representative of a strategy favored by thieves this year: criminal recycling.

headline: Correction
text: The Field Notes column last Sunday, about complications that arise when couples select their legal surname after marriage, misstated the Web address of a company that offers women advice on changing their name. It is www.MissNowMrs.com, not www.Misstomrs.com.

headline: Letters: Sweeping the Clouds Away
text: I’m writing in response to Virginia Heffernan’s article, where I learned that DVDs of early “Sesame Street” episodes contain the warning: “intended for grown-ups” (The Medium, Nov. 18). If I hadn’t read it in The Times, I would have thought it was a joke.

headline: Electric Glide: Passing Pumps on a Scooter
text: Los Angeles

headline: Battlegrounds
text: With the Iowa caucuses less than a month away, the actual voting in the 2008 presidential campaign will soon begin. The Op-Ed page asked four writers from key states to contribute occasional dispatches about the race. Here are their first reports.

headline: Judging Eminent Domain
text: An article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday about a $12.4 million jury verdict against the Town of Branford, Conn., for eminent-domain abuse erroneously included a party among the clients of the lawyer Timothy S. Hollister. Mr. Hollister represented the development company, New England Estates, which planned a project on the land, but not the owners of the property. The owners, Frank Perrotti Jr. and Thomas Santa Barbara Jr., were represented by Steven Humphrey and Brian R. Smith of the firm of Robinson & Cole.

headline: Design Miami 2007
text: A visual tour to make you feel like you were part of the furniture at this design fair.

text: Film

headline: Giants Find Traction in Second Half
The masses visit Hong Kong’s marshes
text: [Addendum: The Mai Po reserves are temporarily closed. Please see the note at the bottom of this post for more information.]

headline: Crunch
text: Credit this very news organization with the coining of “credit crunch,” writes William Safire in his Sunday column.

text: "There was a time," she then said, "time out of mind."
