text: Miami Springs

headline: Missed Opportunities for Jets
Al Gore and the Internet
text: To this day people repeat the lie that Al Gore claimed to have invented the Internet. Chris Matthews did it just a couple of weeks ago.

headline: A Proxy War in Iowa
text: On the day Oprah Winfrey appeared with Senator Barack Obama, Chelsea Clinton joined her mother on the campaign trail for the first time.

headline: The Hunt
Huckabee in South Carolina
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Mike Huckabee, the newest sensation in the Republican presidential primary, waded into a jammed restaurant here Saturday morning and, despite stepped-up scrutiny of his record as governor of Arkansas, delivered a folksy, feel-good message that was greeted warmly.

headline: The National Parity League
text: As eight teams took to the ice Sunday, the N.H.L. standings were as congested as rush-hour traffic in the Lincoln Tunnel. The Red Wings and Senators (now that they’ve righted themselves after a seven-game losing streak) have gone off on their own orbits. But in the Eastern Conference, just six points separated 12th-place Tampa Bay from the second-place Carolina Hurricanes. In the West, No. 2 Vancouver was just five points ahead of No. 11 Chicago.

headline: The 10 Best Books of 2007
text: Fiction

headline: Sunday Kickoff: Tebow’s Legend Grows
text: The fact that Tim Tebow became the first sophomore to ever win the Heisman Trophy is fitting, writes Mike Bianchi of the Orlando Sentinel. After all, there are plenty of folks in Florida who believe Tebow just might be Superman.

headline: They like me! They really like me!
text: Here.

headline: Giuliani Will Not Sever Ties to His Firm
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, seeking to stem a spate of bad news in his bid for the Republican nomination, defended himself Sunday morning from a vast array of questions about his personal integrity, his judgment and possible conflicts of interest because of business ties, among other issues.

headline: Answers from Michael P. Walsh
text: Today we have answers to selected questions and comments prompted by the seventh part of our series on China’s environment from Michael P. Walsh, a mechanical engineer who has spent his entire career working on motor vehicle pollution control issues, in the United States and in other countries, including Brazil, Hong Kong, Mexico, Vietnam and China.

headline: N.H.L. Scoring: Way, Way Down
text: After a spike in 2005-6, the N.H.L.’s post-lockout season, leaguewide scoring is plummeting back down to pre-lockout levels. Although for some reason there seems to be uncertainty about whether scoring really is down, there is no mistaking what the figures say:

headline: Why Brundle?
text: It has taken me a while to put my thoughts together on this problem – which I think is of equal importance to the questions left hanging in the various spy scandals that I am also still trying to wrap my brain around – but I now know why it has taken so long to come to me:

headline: News Headlines
text: Stories from the world of real estate:

headline: Coles and Cotchery Active
text: As Kellen Clemens enters his sixth N.F.L. start, the Jets made somewhat of a surprise announcement on Sunday afternoon. Both of Clemens’s top receivers, Jerricho Cotchery and Laveranues Coles, are active for the Jets game against the Cleveland Browns.

headline: Integrity or Craft: The Leadership Question
text: Katie Couric is now asking the presidential candidates 10 questions designed (declares the CBS News Web site) to “go beyond politics and show what really makes them tick.”

headline: Oprahpalooza in South Carolina
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — It was a staggering sight. Upwards of 29,000 people at a political rally. And the Democratic primary in South Carolina is not until Jan. 26.

headline: Oprah Winfrey in South Carolina
text: The talk-show host campaigned for Barack Obama at the University of South Carolina's football stadium Dec. 9, 2007.

headline: Fun at the Fair
text: The hedonistic final stop on the art-fair circuit.

headline: Online, NYC Style
text: The New York Film Critics Online came, saw and awarded, with Paul Thomas Anderson picking up best director for “There Will Be Blood,” which shared best picture honors with “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” Daniel Day Lewis picked up best actor for his work in Mr. Anderson’s film, while Julie Christie, starring in “Away From Her,” won best actress.

headline: Another Coast Heard From
text: And the Winner Is has the 411 on the Los Angeles Film Critics Association awards, and boy or boy, do they love “There Will Be Blood.” Picture, director, actor, and design. Big love for a big picture. Marion Cotillard, from “La Vie en Rose,” won for best actress. And Amy Ryan got an interesting supporting actress citation, winning for her work in both “Gone Baby Gone” and “Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead.”

headline: “No Country” Hits Home in the District
text: The Coen brothers had a nice day inside the Beltway. “No Country for Old Men” won the best picture award from the Washington D.C. Area Film Critics, who also named them best director. This, according to And the Winner Is …, which also broke the news that George Clooney had picked up his first best actor nod of the season for his portrayal of a conflicted lawyer/fixer named Michael Clayton.

headline: Coens Not Full of Beans
text: The Boston Society of Film Critics joined their brethren down the coast in D.C. by deciding that “No Country for Old Men” was the feature film achievement of the year. Julian Schnabel won best director for “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.”

headline: A Fund-Raising Web Site Hopes to Branch Out
text: ActBlue, the Web site that helps anyone raise money for Democratic candidates, is asking the Federal Election Commission for permission to broaden its operations.

headline: A Mommy Who Keeps on Swinging
text: Amy Ryan is on a roll tonight for her memorable character in “Gone Baby Gone,” having won best supporting actress accolades from the Boston, Washington, and Los Angeles film critics. Last week, she received that honor from the National Board of Review.

headline: Debates: Not Just for Show
text: Are all the debates this campaign season helping voters decide which candidate to support? A recent poll suggests that they are.

headline: Another Notch for God’s Chosen
text: The Baguette tends to chatter a bit around movie people. No special reason — everyone has their way and that’s hers. Ethan Coen doesn’t do chatter. His idea of small talk is no talk. But the Baguette recently buttonholed him at the premiere of “No Country for Old Men,” which had a big day with the critic’s awards yesterday, and when it was mentioned that his movie was among the mentioned, he did have one thought: “It will be good for the Jews.”

headline: One on One With Gretzky
text: Wayne Gretzky was single-mindedly focused on becoming a great hockey player. Look at how that turned out.

headline: Debate Season Ending, at Least for Iowans
text: The Democratic and Republican presidential candidates are holding debates in Iowa this week.

headline: Rangers Find Their Cure: The Devils
text: Rangers Coach Tom Renney went into Sunday night’s game saying he thought a game against the Devils was just what the Rangers needed. It sounded a bit strange considering the Devils were on a nine-game winning streak, the Rangers were on a three-game slide and Devils goalie Martin Brodeur looks like his all-world self again.

headline: BioShock Thriller Wins Spike TV’s Award for Video Game of the Year
text: BioShock, the noir thriller from Take-Two Interactive, garnered the top prize at the 2007 Spike Video Game Awards presentation in Las Vegas on Friday.

headline: On West Village Streets, Tears for a Gay Activist
text: Friends and colleagues of Bob Kohler, a veteran gay rights activist who died at 81 on Wednesday, took to the streets of the West Village last evening, celebrating the life of the man they called a hero, a griot and a legend of the gay community.

headline: Triple Play
text: Jeffrey Richards is the lead producer of three plays on Broadway  the recently opened and raved-about “August: Osage County”; “The Homecoming,” now in previews; and “November,” which begins previews on Dec. 20. So why not take advantage of that? In a synergistic move rare on Broadway in recent years, the producers of the three plays have come up with what they call a commercial subscription series, in which a theatergoer can buy orchestra or front mezzanine tickets for all three plays for $199. Producers have tried commercial subscriptions on Broadway for years with varying success, going back to the heyday of the Theater Guild in the early and middle years of last century. The latest venture can be found at the straightforwardly named Web site 3greatplays.com.

headline: Manning Reaches Milestone as Colts Reach the Playoffs
text: Peyton Manning threw four touchdown passes, including the 300th of his career, and the Colts coasted past the Ravens, 44-20, after building a 30-point lead in the second quarter.

headline: Footnote
text: Symphony Space will celebrate its 30th anniversary on Jan. 10 with an evening featuring many of the artists, including Fritz Weaver, Marian Seldes, David Strathairn, Alec Baldwin, Frank McCourt  and Fionnula Flanagan, who have appeared there over the years. Information: symphonyspace.org or (212) 864-5400.

headline: Ex-President Stands Trial in Edgy Peru
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 9  The Supreme Court in Peru will start its trial of former President Alberto K. Fujimori on Monday, making him the country’s first former head of state to be tried on human rights violations, including murder and kidnapping.

headline: Mistakes Cloud Clemens’s Future as the Jets’ Starter
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 9  Another game, another loss, and the questions that haunt the Jets continue:

headline: Disability Cases Last Longer as Backlog Rises
text: RALEIGH, N.C.  Steadily lengthening delays in the resolution of Social Security disability claims have left hundreds of thousands of people in a kind of purgatory, now waiting as long as three years for a decision.

headline: Brooklyn: Hearing in Airport Plot Case
text: A hearing was scheduled today for three men held in Trinidad who have been ordered to be extradited to the United States to face terrorism charges related to what prosecutors said was a planned attack on Kennedy Airport. The men, Kareem Ibrahim, Abdul Kadir and Abdel Nur, were charged in the summer by the United States attorney in Brooklyn of conspiring with a former airport cargo worker to attack jet fuel storage tanks and fuel lines at Kennedy. On Aug. 6, officials in Trinidad approved their extradition. Lawyers for the three men have appealed that ruling and will challenge the extradition order in San Fernando, Trinidad. Their lawyers were expected to argue the extradition would be a breach of the men’s rights.

headline: Iranian Students Protest Jailings
text: TEHRAN, Dec. 9  Iranian students held a protest on Sunday at Tehran University to demand the release of fellow students who have been jailed in recent months.

headline: After Setback, Chávez Makes the Clocks Fall Behind
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 9  Venezuelans turned their clocks back half an hour on Sunday, putting them in the company of people in other nations that offset time in half-hour increments from Greenwich Mean Time, like Afghanistan, India, Iran and Myanmar.

headline: Alois Kracher, Austrian Winemaker and Advocate, Is Dead at 48
text: Alois Kracher Jr., a visionary winemaker whose luscious sweet wines and forceful personality were instrumental in restoring the Austrian wine industry’s international reputation after a scandal in 1985, died Tuesday at his home in Illmitz, in the Burgenland region of Austria. He was 48.

headline: Fuel Tank Issue Delays Shuttle Flight Until at Least January
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 9  NASA on Sunday delayed the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis until at least Jan. 2 to give engineers time to diagnose and fix its balky fuel tank sensors.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Nov. 15 about an auction of contemporary art at Sotheby’s misspelled the surname of the Manhattan collector who sold the Jeff Koons sculpture “Hanging Heart (Magenta/Gold).” He is Adam Lindemann, not Lindeman. (The error also appeared in articles on Nov. 4 and May 18 of this year, and on June 28, 2004.)

headline: Today’s Matchup
text: The Saints’ visions of a return to the N.F.C. title game seem like a distant memory after a season that has included a four-game winning streak and a four-game losing streak. The Saints’ latest loss is the all-purpose star Reggie Bush, who is out with a knee injury, but Drew Brees has enough options to cover for him. Three is the magic number for the Falcons, as in three wins, three years since their last playofff berth and three starting quarterbacks. Chris Redman will replace Joey Harrington, who has been benched  you guessed it  three times in 12 games. The good news? After tonight, only three games remain in the Falcons’ season. ANDREW DAS

headline: Rangers Put End to the Devils’ Winning Streak
text: It was clear the Rangers were ready for the kind of defense required for a game against the Devils when forward Martin Straka blocked three shots during a power play in the second period, two of them without a stick because the first block had shattered it.

headline: Republican Candidates Firm on Immigration
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9  In front of what will probably be their most pro-immigration audience, Republican candidates toned down their rhetoric but told Spanish-language television viewers in a debate on Sunday that they would take strong measures to close off the country’s borders to illegal immigration.

headline: Black Is Sentenced to 6 1/2 Years in Prison
text: CHICAGO, Dec. 10  Conrad M. Black, the flamboyant former press baron, will spend more than six years behind bars for fleecing shareholders of Hollinger International out of millions of dollars, a judge decided today.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Whole Lotta Love for Led Zeppelin Reunion

headline: Revisiting Violent Past on Eve of New Jersey Death Penalty Vote
text: TRENTON, Dec. 7  So remorseless was Ambrose A. Harris for raping and shooting a young Pennsylvania woman in the back of the head that he mockingly dabbed his eyes with a handkerchief as the victim’s father sobbed on the witness stand.

headline: The Rhythmically Ebbing and Flowing of the Subway Riders of New York
text: Is the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater setting a trend? Both of its premieres this season are light and relatively frivolous. Fredrick Earl Mosely took on legends of the American West in his new and atypical “Saddle Up!,” And Camille A. Brown celebrates the captive community of New York subway riders in her delicious “Groove to Nobody’s Business,” first performed by the Ailey company on Friday night at City Center.

headline: Bomb Kills an Iraqi Police Chief
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 9  Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain made an unannounced visit to southern Iraq on Sunday to address his nation’s troops as they prepared to hand over the region to Iraqi forces later this month.

headline: Gate D: More Fans, More Security, More Abuse
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 9  The gantlet of abuse continued during halftime of the Jets’ game against the Cleveland Browns on Sunday at Giants Stadium, with hundreds of men chanting obscenities at a handful of women in the crowd to expose their breasts. Only this time, there were more fans and more security personnel at Gate D, where the harassment occurred, than there were the last time the Jets played at home.

headline: Something Schumann, Something Old and Also New
text: Poor Schumann. Every time he touched an orchestra, people meddled. Conductors reorchestrated his symphonies posthumously. His wife, Clara, nagged him into turning a fantasy for piano and orchestra into the A minor piano concerto we know today. (Despite those who pine for the great man’s original thoughts, I think she was right.)

headline: Ion Fiscuteanu, a Star of Romanian Stage and Film, Dies at 70
text: Ion Fiscuteanu, a Romanian stage and film actor known to international audiences for his role in “The Death of Mr. Lazarescu,” died early Saturday in Bucharest. He was 70.

headline: Mayweather May Take Break
text: Floyd Mayweather Jr. is again saying that he will take an extended break from boxing, insisting he is “bored with the sport” after he stopped Ricky Hatton in the 10th round of their 147-pound title fight in Las Vegas on Saturday night. The end came after Mayweather landed a crushing left hook that dropped Hatton on his back. Hatton got up at the count of eight, but Mayweather (39-0) almost immediately put him on the ropes and landed another flurry of punches to the head.Hatton went down while the referee Joe Cortez moved in to stop the fight, and Hatton’s corner threw in the towel.“He was definitely the toughest competitor I’ve ever faced,” said Mayweather, who was ahead by 89-81 on two ringside scorecards and by 88-82 on the other when the fight was stopped.

headline: Looking to Make Phoenix Great
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Wayne Gretzky stood motionless at the far boards of the practice rink, a Phoenix Coyotes toque pulled low on his head, and studied his young players as they skated drills.

headline: Many Seeking Disability From Social Security Face Big Delays
text: RALEIGH, N.C.  Steadily lengthening delays in the resolution of Social Security disability claims have left hundreds of thousands of people in a kind of purgatory, now waiting as long as three years for a decision.

headline: Loving Counterpoint: Heartfelt Arias and Hearty Applause
text: Fans of Andrea Bocelli, the Italian tenor who sings both opera and crossover, must rank among the most devoted of any artist. Legions of them filled Madison Square Garden on Friday to hear him perform popular arias as well as songs from his latest recording.

headline: U.N. Fears Serbs Will Disrupt a Free Kosovo
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Dec. 9  As Kosovo moves closer to declaring its independence, fears are rising that Serbia and Serbs in Kosovo’s north could take steps to try to disrupt the province’s shaky economy and scare off countries ready to recognize it as a sovereign state.

headline: Looking Back on the Bonfire of the 1980s
text: Tom Wolfe’s novel “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” published 20 years ago, was a satire set in a city that seemed to be on a downward spiral: racial power struggles, an overwhelmed and unfair criminal justice system, greed, self-interest and a widening gap between rich and poor. In the era of Michael R. Milken, Tawana Brawley, the Howard Beach riots and Ed Koch, the book provoked excitement and anger.

headline: ‘Tristan’ Harmonies Trump La Scala’s Labor Discord
text: MILAN  The gaudiest event of the opera season in Europe, La Scala’s opener on Dec. 7 was a sublime new version of “Tristan und Isolde,” directed by Patrice Chéreau under the baton of the house’s new principal guest conductor, Daniel Barenboim.

headline: The ’60s as the Good Old Days
text: IF you remember the ’60s, as a popular saying goes, you probably weren’t there. No matter. Madison Avenue is taking you back with a skein of campaigns celebrating sights and sounds of the decade.

headline: Platinum-Points Title Winner Can Toast With His Own Wine
text: At the three North American Bridge Championships each year the premier events are called N.A.B.C.+, for which platinum master points are awarded. The winner of the most platinum points this year was Roy Welland of New York. He collected 736.80 points, 60.35 more than Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla. Welland played in eight events, gaining two firsts, one second and two thirds.

headline: One Pass Erases Two Dallas Mistakes
text: DETROIT, Dec. 9 (AP)  Tony Romo and Jason Witten put mistakes behind them quickly enough to give the Dallas Cowboys the N.F.C. East title.

headline: When Part-Time Work Isn’t Enough to Pay the Rent
text: Some days, Idelle Doulin feels as if she is on a treadmill. No matter how fast she runs, she cannot get ahead.

headline: Atheists Have Hope
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Blessed Second Life of Beliefnet
text: The Blessed Second Life of Beliefnet

headline: Web Retailers Get Into Employee Gifts
text: FOR years, employees have had to hide their online shopping habit. Now they can start coming out of the closet.

headline: Whole Lotta Love for Led Zeppelin Reunion
text: Fans in London yesterday wait to be the first in line for tonight’s Led Zepplein concert. More than a million applied to get into the one-off gig, Agence France-Presse reported, but only 20,000, chosen by secret ballot, have tickets to see Jimmy Page, Robert Plant and John Paul Jones perform together for the first time in 19 years.

headline: Obama’s American Idea
text: I asked Senator Barack Obama if he’s tough enough for a dangerous world. Sometimes the Democratic candidate treads so carefully, and looks so vulnerable to a gust of wind, that the question of whether his legal mind can get lethal arises.

headline: International Herald Tribune and Reuters in News Alliance
text: PARIS, Dec. 9  The International Herald Tribune is to announce plans on Monday to transform its financial section online and in print next month by forging an alliance with the news agency Reuters.

headline: Ohio State Men Advance
text: Ohio State scored four goals in a 12-minute span in the second half to defeat visiting Bradley, 4-0, and advance to the N.C.A.A. College Cup. UMass also reached the College Cup, the Final Four of men’s soccer, by defeating visiting Illinois-Chicago, 2-1.

headline: Tebow Reaches the Top, but He Can Still Climb
text: The most compelling argument against Tim Tebow’s winning the Heisman Trophy seemed to be that he was only a sophomore. Tebow, Florida’s quarterback, would have two more chances to win the award, the thinking went, while the Arkansas junior running back Darren McFadden, who had already finished second once before and was likely to leave for the N.F.L., would not.

headline: Led Zeppelin Finds Its Old Power
text: LONDON, Dec. 10  Some rock bands accelerate their tempos when they play their old songs decades after the fact. Playing fast is a kind of armor: a refutation of the plain fact of aging, all that unregainable enthusiasm and lost muscle mass, and a hard block against an old band’s lessened cultural importance.

headline: Spike Video Game Awards: The Winners
text: Here is a list of winners, with publishers and developers, at the 2007 Spike TV Video Game Awards presentation:

headline: Big Banks Scale Back Plan to Aid in Debt Crisis
text: Some of the country’s largest banks are scaling back a plan set in motion by the Treasury Department to shore up troubled investment vehicles and calm the debt markets.

headline: Showdown in Arizona, Where Mariachis and Minutemen Collide
text: PHOENIX  Want to see America unraveling? Come here, to Thomas Road and 35th Street, to M. D. Pruitt’s furniture store. Come on Saturday morning and stand near the eight delivery trucks barricading the parking lot, like the wall of an urban Alamo.

headline: With New Support, Thomas Stays Calm
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 9  The “Fire Isiah” chants Saturday night were as loud and intense as they had ever been, and for once, Coach Isiah Thomas could not feign obliviousness. Yes, he acknowledged, he heard the pounding chorus, even as Madison Square Garden attempted to muffle it with music and drumbeats pumped through the public-address system.

headline: U.S. Is No Haven, Canadian Judge Finds
text: Late last month, a federal judge in Canada ruled that the United States had violated international conventions on torture and the rights of refugees.

headline: Another Ugly Win, but Looks Don’t Matter
text: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9  On a frozen field under a pewter sky, there were few colorful plays to shake loose the tug-of-war tedium of short runs ending in gang tackles and short passes mostly ending shy of first downs.

headline: Peter Davi, 45, a Pioneer of Pushing Surfing’s Limits in Big Waves, Dies
text: Peter Davi, a renowned big-wave surfer from Monterey, Calif., died Tuesday while riding giant waves at a spot he had helped pioneer off Pebble Beach. He was 45.

headline: Canadian Exchanges Plan to Merge
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 10  After several false starts, the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Montreal Exchange announced a merger today valued at 1.31 billion Canadian dollars.

headline: Ray Charles Statue
text: A revolving, lighted bronze statue of Ray Charles was unveiled on Friday in Albany, Ga., in the middle of a $2 million downtown plaza that bears his name, The Associated Press reported. “I can’t tell you how overwhelming it is for me to experience the love that you have for my father,” Sheila Raye Charles told the hundreds of people who had gathered for the ceremony. Charles, who died in 2004, was born in Albany in 1930 and moved with his mother to Florida when he was young, but he often returned to visit family. His version of “Georgia on My Mind” was made the official state song in 1979.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about efforts to harvest energy from ocean waves omitted a reporting credit. Erik Olsen contributed reporting to the article. (Go to Article)

headline: Man Committed Both Colo. Shootings, Police Say
text: Forensic tests have shown that the same young man who shot and killed two people at an evangelical church in Colorado Springs on Sunday afternoon also killed two other people about 12 hours earlier at a missionary training center in the Denver suburb of Arvada, the police said this afternoon.

headline: New Jersey Keeps Its Execution Chamber ‘on Standby’
text: TRENTON, Dec. 7  Once a week, the execution chamber at the New Jersey State Prison is inspected, searched and cleaned.

headline: School Moves to Sell Its Middle-Class Housing
text: On June 6, Meryl Fenster, a retired public school teacher, arrived home to find a letter from her landlord taped to her front door. It said that her building  the last one on the Upper West Side to offer subsidized rental apartments under the state’s Mitchell-Lama program  was being sold to a private developer.

headline: Trade Deals Stymied at Lisbon Meeting
text: LISBON, Dec. 9  European and African leaders wound up a summit meeting on Sunday in open conflict over trade deals between the continents and over human rights violations in Zimbabwe, despite committing themselves to a new partnership of equals.

headline: Finding the Money to Move Out and Up
text: Whenever I write about successful career changers or those who fled corporate life to start businesses, readers write to me asking about the financial circumstances of the people I’ve profiled.

headline: Infected With Laughter, and Opinions
text: There is much research into how viewers form opinions of a movie or television show. But there has been less study of how people unconsciously influence one another. A paper recently published in the Journal of Consumer Research explores this territory.

headline: Court Restores Sentencing Powers of Federal Judges
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Supreme Court today restored federal judges to their traditional central role in criminal sentencing.

headline: Harvard Steps Up Financial Aid
text: BOSTON, Dec. 10  Harvard University announced today that it would significantly increase the financial aid it offers to nearly all middle-class and upper-middle-class students, expanding on efforts it made three years ago to make its campus affordable for low-income students.

headline: People and Accounts in Advertising
text: Accounts

headline: New CDs
text: BEANIE SIGEL “The Solution”  (Roc-A-Fella/Island Def Jam)

headline: Expansion of Javits Center May Shrink to a Renovation
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer declared in a speech eight months ago that he would build a “thoroughbred” of a convention center in New York City and scrap the $1.8 billion plan he had inherited to expand the black-glass Javits Convention Center on the West Side.

headline: How Dictionaries Define Publicity: The Word of the Year
text: When editors at the New Oxford American Dictionary recently announced that their word of the year was “locavore,” which means someone who eats locally grown food, they also became the very definition of publicity.

headline: Rule on Shots Forces Some Students Off Maine Campuses
text: PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 7  Hundreds of students at the University of Southern Maine have been barred from its campuses here and in nearby Gorham over mumps vaccinations.

headline: Ang Lee’s ‘Lust, Caution’ Wins Prizes in Taiwan
text: Taiwan’s native son Ang Lee, below, and his spy thriller “Lust, Caution” won seven prizes, including best film and best director, when the 44th Golden Horse Film Awards, regarded as the Chinese-language Oscars, were bestowed in Taipei on Saturday, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Lee won the Academy Award for best director for “Brokeback Mountain” in 2006. ... “L’Ennemi Intime,” the French director Florent Emilio Siri’s  account of the savagery of France’s war against National Liberation Front rebels in Algeria in the 1950s, won the Golden Pyramid for best film on Friday at the 31st Cairo International Film Festival, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Herodotus Now: ‘Omnivorous Curiosity’ and Double Vision
text: Egypt, Herodotus tells us in “The Histories,” is a land with “more marvels and monuments that defy description than any other.” Not only is the Nile unlike any other river in the world, overflowing its banks in summer not in the early spring, but Egypt’s inhabitants also have “manners and customs” that in most ways are “completely opposite to those of other peoples.” Women go to the marketplace to sell goods, while men stay home to weave cloth; men carry loads on their heads, while women bear them on their shoulders; and “women urinate standing up, men sitting down.”

headline: What to Do About Indian Point?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Abba Museum Planned
text: A museum dedicated to the Swedish disco group Abba is to open in Stockholm in June 2009, Agence France-Presse reported. The museum, a short walk from the city center in a waterfront heritage site that was once a customs hall, will fill three floors and more than 43,000 square feet. Initiators of the project said all four members of Abba  Bjorn Ulvaeus, Benny Andersson, Agnetha Faltskog and Anni-Frid Lyngstad  have given their backing to the museum and will provide clothing, instruments and music. Despite breaking up a quarter of a century ago, Abba still sells two million to three million albums a year.

headline: Jets Thicken Plot Against Browns, but the Ending Is the Same Old Story
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 9  Steady rain pelted the pockets of fans midway through the fourth quarter. Trailing by 17-6, in a drenched and almost empty stadium, the Jets needed a defensive stop. They needed to score at least 12 points. And they needed to recover an onside kick.

headline: ‘Emeralds,’ ‘Rubies’ and ‘Diamonds’ Reveal Facets of a Company’s Style
text: LONDON, Dec. 8  All leading stage performers seem to give off their own light; that’s why they’re called stars. But ballet dancers, catching it, refract it prismatically, like jewels. Hence the name of Balanchine’s triple bill, “Jewels,” new 40 years ago and sometimes billed as the world’s first plotless, or abstract, full-length ballet. Balanchine was notably wary of the star system, which emphasized who was dancing more than what was being danced, but he was perpetually fascinated by the connections among dancers, music and light.

headline: Flying Humans, Hoping to Land With No Chute
text: Jeb Corliss wants to fly  not the way the Wright brothers wanted to fly, but the way we do in our dreams. He wants to jump from a helicopter and land without using a parachute.

headline: G.O.P. Voters Are Uninspired by Candidates
text: Three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Republicans voters across the country appear uninspired by their field of presidential candidates, with a vast majority saying they have not made a final decision about who to support, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Campaign of ‘Note’ on Campus
text: College students may be the targets of more marketing efforts than any other group of consumers. That’s why one recent campaign aimed at them took a nontraditional approach with a pitch that at first glance seems to be personal, hand-written notes rather than advertising.

headline: Philharmonic Agrees to Play in North Korea
text: Adding a cultural wrinkle to the diplomatic engagement between the United States and North Korea, the New York Philharmonic plans to visit Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, in February, taking the legacy of Beethoven, Bach and Bernstein to one of the world’s most isolated nations.

headline: Yankees Find Bullpen Help, Landing Hawkins for a Year
text: The Yankees added a veteran to their young bullpen yesterday, agreeing to terms with the right-hander LaTroy Hawkins on a one-year contract worth about $3.75 million. Hawkins, who turns 35 this month, will take a physical this week to make the deal official.

headline: Giant Moon Wins at Aqueduct
text: Giant Moon held off Spanky Fischbein by one and three-quarter lengths to win the $78,950 Damon Runyon Stakes for New York-bred 2-year-olds at Aqueduct.The colt, trained by Rich Schosberg, remained unbeaten in three starts by pulling clear in the deep stretch. His time was 1 minute 46.07 seconds for a mile and a sixteenth.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: South Korea Cleans Up Big Oil Spill
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 9  Thousands of fishermen, soldiers and volunteers struggled on Sunday to clean up an oil spill that has caused an environmental disaster in South Korea. It has blackened once scenic beaches, coated birds and oysters in sludge and driven away tourists with its stomach-churning stench.

headline: Unlikely Ally Against Congo Republic Graft
text: BRAZZAVILLE, the Congo Republic  The main teaching hospital here is in such disrepair that many patients have to pay freelance porters for piggyback rides up and down the stairs to get X-rays. It costs $2 a flight, each way.

headline: A Starring Role for Drivers Who Drink
text: PHOENIX, Dec. 4  A conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol is something many people try to conceal, even from their families. But now the bleary-eyed, disheveled and generally miserable visages of convicted drunken drivers here, captured in their mug shots, are available to the entire world via a Web site.

headline: No Longer the City of ‘Bonfire’ in Flames
text: Twenty years ago, the acid-penned journalist Tom Wolfe unleashed his first novel, “The Bonfire of the Vanities.” Skewering everyone from self-absorbed Wall Street millionaires to hucksterish street politicians, the sprawling satire painted a picture of a New York declining inexorably into racial conflict, crime and greed.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Allison Price Arden, associate publisher at Advertising Age, New York, part of Crain Communications, was promoted to publisher, overseeing print, digital and event operations for Ad Age and a sibling Crain publication, Creativity. She succeeds Scott Donaton, who joined Time Inc., New York, part of Time Warner, as publisher at Entertainment Weekly magazine and its Web site, ew.com.

headline: As Orthodox Population Grows, So Do Tensions
text: LAKEWOOD, N.J.  A fault line runs through Dr. Martin Luther King Drive in Lakewood, dividing the black families that have lived here for years, many in run-down apartment complexes at one end of the street, from their new neighbors, the Orthodox Jewish families who mostly occupy a row of two-story houses on the other side.

headline: ‘Masterpiece Theater,’ Now in 3 Flavors: Classic, Mystery, Contemporary
text: Gillian Anderson, best known to American audiences as Agent Dana Scully of the F.B.I., from the Fox television show “The X-Files,” will be one of the new hosts of “Masterpiece Theater” on PBS when it begins its new season on Jan. 13, the program’s producers plan to announce today.

headline: Rookie Safeties Help Stop McNabb
text: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9  Craig Dahl had last started a game when he played for North Dakota State. But in the Giants’ locker room after the 16-13 defeat of the Eagles, the rookie sounded as if he had played  ho-hum  just another game.

headline: Patriots Send a Message by Spoiling a Guarantee
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 9  A few hours before the New England Patriots became only the fifth team in N.F.L. history to win its first 13 games, a plane trailing a banner flew over Gillette Stadium bearing a none-too-subtle message: Bonds  756*, Belichick  3 Super Bowl wins*.

headline: Yahoo to Start Internet Program for Technology Investors
text: Yahoo, which already owns one of the most successful financial sites on the Web, is putting the final touches on a new online program for technology investors that is scheduled to begin next month.

headline: The Eagles Are Undone by Mistakes at Key Moments
text: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9  The Giants were already scampering to a celebration near their bench late in the fourth quarter when Philadelphia receiver Jason Avant raised his arm to make a last-ditch appeal for an official  any official  to pull out his yellow flag and fling it.

headline: Obama Pins Hopes on Oprah Factor in South Carolina
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  If you check out Oprah Winfrey’s Web site today, there is no evidence that she was part of a gigantic political spectacle over the weekend as she barnstormed across Iowa, South Carolina and New Hampshire for Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Roger M. King, 63, TV Syndicator, Dies
text: Roger M. King, a television syndication executive who helped make national stars of talents like Oprah Winfrey, Alex Trebek and Dr. Phil McGraw, died on Saturday. He was 63.

headline: ’72 Dolphins Unbeaten, Unbowed, but Sweating
text: I reached Marlin Briscoe yesterday morning just as he was preparing to tee off on a golf course in Cypress, Calif. Golf is part of a Sunday ritual that ends with Briscoe settling down to watch football. This season the ritual includes watching a New England Patriots team that poses the greatest threat yet to a legacy Briscoe holds near and dear.

headline: The Bronx: 26 Injured in Fire
text: Twenty-six people were injured last night in a fire in an apartment building at 2334 Boston Road in the Bronxdale neighborhood, fire officials said. Most of the injuries were from smoke inhalation and were minor. But three people were seriously injured. One had a life-threatening heart attack, fire officials said. Of those affected, 14 were occupants, 11 were firefighters and one was an emergency medical technician. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

headline: Satellite TV on the Move, at Fox News
text: As the beginning of primary season approaches, Fox News Channel is introducing a pair of satellite reporting units capable of broadcasting live video while on the move. The vehicles, two retrofitted sport utilities, had an early debut on Nov. 30 during a hostage incident at Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign office in Rochester, N.H., and are already raising interest and questions about their potential influence on live television news reporting.

headline: Muckraking Pays, Just Not in Profit
text: Last Friday, the city of Chicago agreed to pay out $20 million to settle lawsuits filed by four former death-row inmates who said they had been tortured by police officers and subsequently wrongly convicted. The four men were among dozens of black men who said they were tortured, beaten with phone books and suffocated with plastic typewriter covers while in police custody in the 1970s and 1980s, according to special prosecutors.

headline: Western States Agree to Water-Sharing Pact
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Facing the worst drought in a century and the prospect that climate change could yield long-term changes on the Colorado River, the lifeline for several Western states, federal officials have reached a new pact with the states on how to allocate water if the river runs short.

headline: A Rube Takes on the City and Falls for a Woman
text: Jaradoa Theater is off to a promising if not very pithy start with “Serenade,” a new musical that is the company’s first full production. What the show lacks in plotting depth, which is a lot, it makes up for in sheer energy and a fearless mix of musical and choreographic styles.

headline: Lottery Numbers
‘Compass’ Can’t Cure What Ails Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Hollywood is counting on the impending arrival of a naughty chipmunk, a treasure hunter and Will Smith to reverse a lingering box office malaise that deepened over the weekend with disappointing sales for “The Golden Compass.”

headline: Canadian Is Convicted in 6 of a Suspected 50 Killings
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 9  After a 10-month trial marked by horrific and often grisly evidence, Robert William Pickton, a pig farmer, was convicted Sunday of second-degree murder in the deaths of six women.

headline: Opposition to Take Part in Pakistan Elections
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 9  The two main opposition parties led by Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif said they would participate in Jan. 8 parliamentary elections, despite deep misgivings about whether the vote could be free and fair.

headline: UBS Sells Stake After Write-Down
text: FRANKFURT, Dec. 10  UBS became the latest Western bank to seek a financial lifeline from the cash-rich East today, selling a stake of more than 10 percent to investors from Singapore and the Middle East as it wrote down $10 billion more in mortgage-related assets.

headline: Massapequa: Woman’s Body Identified
text: The body of a woman found floating in the Narrasketuck River on Saturday morning has been identified, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The Nassau County medical examiner identified the woman as Yvonne Boykin, 46, of Lake Street, Massapequa, the police said. The body was discovered by a dog walker about 11 a.m., and the cause of death remained under investigation yesterday evening. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Cop’s Wife Spiraling Out of Control in Chicago
text: A young man walks into a Chicago flower shop at the start of “Person of Interest,” a smart, propulsive, tightrope-walking mystery novel by Theresa Schwegel. His name is Niko Stavrakos. He’s confident and handsome. He says he’s buying roses for his mother.

headline: Delay, Obstruction and Darfur
text: The world’s leaders say they care desperately about Darfur’s suffering, until they get distracted. It took years of international hand-wringing before the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution to send in 26,000 peacekeepers to replace a current force of 7,000, to try to halt the killing. With the deployment now set for Jan. 1, major countries are ignoring the U.N.’s appeals for essential aircraft, and Sudan’s government  which unleashed the genocide  is again reneging on its promises to cooperate.

headline: Junking Fat Foods in Schools
text: As America’s youth have grown fatter and the number with adult diabetes continues to rise, there is one obvious way to help. Public schools should stop selling students so much unhealthy food. A worthy but imperfect amendment pending in Congress would help curb junk foods sold in too many of the nation’s schools.

headline: Paying for Free Web Information
text: NEWSPAPER publishers and other content producers have a complicated relationship with giant search engines like Google and Yahoo. They simultaneously try to curry favor with these sites, hiring people known as optimizers with magical incantations to make articles show up high on the results pages and drive traffic, all the while grumbling that maybe, perhaps, it isn’t fair for the search engines to make copies of their material  so that it can be searched or appear on aggregation sites like Google News  without compensation.

headline: Help Me Spy on Al Qaeda
text: Washington

headline: Henry Paulson’s Priorities
text: By Bush administration standards, Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, is a good guy. He isn’t conspicuously incompetent; and he isn’t trying to mislead us into war, justify torture or protect corrupt contractors.

headline: A Growing Source of Fear for Migrants in Malaysia
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  When his turn comes to stand watch, Kang Long posts himself at a window, peering into the dark streets outside the tiny apartment where his fellow migrant workers sleep 10 to a room.

headline: A Crime Buster, With His Eye on the Future
text: He was, to the popular eye, Eliot Ness reincarnated, an unsparing prosecutor for a crime-shadowed age. And when the United States attorney in Manhattan resigned in January 1989, he earned a tabloid salute:

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Wheelchair Van Drivers Strike at 4 Transportation Companies
text: Drivers went on strike today at four companies that provide van rides for up to 9,000 passengers a day across New York City.

headline: Slot Machines for the Young and Active
text: The venerable slot machine is undergoing a generational shift. For more than a century, since its invention by a German immigrant named Charles Fey in the 1890s, slot machines have required little more than cash, faith and an ability to pull a lever or push a button.

headline: TiVo Shifts to Help Companies It Once Threatened
text: TiVo may be getting a second chance by thinking outside the box that made it famous in the first place.

headline: Gene H. Golub, an Innovator in Early Computing, Dies at 75
text: Gene H. Golub, a computer scientist who developed early techniques for using computers to solve scientific and engineering problems, died on Nov. 16 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 75.

headline: Stagehands Vote to Ratify New Contract
text: Members of the stagehands’ union voted yesterday to ratify the agreement reached on Nov. 28 between union officials and the League of American Theaters and Producers. That agreement brought an end to a strike by the stagehands that left most of Broadway dark for 19 days. With the ratification vote, the terms of the new agreement will go into effect today.

headline: Arsenal Beaten for First Time
text: Arsenal lost its first game of the English Premier League season, falling at Middlesbrough, 2-1. Arsenal still has a one-point lead in the standings.Stewart Downing and Tuncay Sanli scored to give Middlesbrough its first win in any competition since Sept. 1. Tomas Rosicky scored in injury time for Arsenal.Arsenal leads the league with 37 points, followed by Manchester United with 36 and Chelsea with 34.

headline: Chocolate in Beta Testing, Offered by a Wired Founder
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- In a vast refurbished warehouse on one of this city’s historic pier, Louis Rossetto, the co-founder of Wired magazine, is at it again. Only this time, his project has nothing to do with media or high technology. It is hand-crafted chocolate.

headline: Deloitte Agrees to Pay $1 Million Fine
text: Deloitte & Touche, one of the Big Four accounting firms, agreed today to pay $1 million to settle accusations that it botched an audit of a pharmaceutical company by entrusting it to a partner it knew to be a poor auditor.

headline: Italian Villagers Sue Culture Ministers
text: The town of Monteleone di Spoleto, Italy, is suing three successive Italian culture ministers in its latest effort to recover a 2,600-year-old Etruscan chariot, above, from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Italian news agency Ansa reported. “The artifact is part of our town’s perpetual and inalienable heritage,” said the suit, filed in Monteleone courts against the incumbent minister, Francesco Rutelli, and his predecessors Rocco Buttiglione and Giuliano Urbani. The suit contends that the ministers did not do enough to secure the return of the chariot, which was discovered in Monteleone, in Umbria, in 1902 and sold to the Met the next year. Monteleone officials say it was illegally whisked out of the country. The Met says that because the chariot was bought more than a century ago, the statute of limitations has expired.

headline: 6 Characters in Search of a Dimension, in Different Operatic Tempos
text: Though Elliott Carter is an indisputably towering figure in contemporary music, few would have pegged him as a composer with a knack for opera. He attended operas for decades, but selectively. He did not pay heed to “La Bohème” until he was nearly 70 and left the show unimpressed.

headline: C.I.A. Official in Inquiry Called a ‘Hero’
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  At a conference in El Paso in mid-August, Representative Silvestre Reyes of Texas, the Democratic chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, heaped praise on a man whose exploits, he joked, had been the inspiration for the television show “24.”

headline: It’s Not Life on the Mississippi, Jean-François Honey
text: What might have been a wheeze turns out to be a giggle.

headline: Caving In on Hate Crimes
text: Congressional leaders, who have disappointed frequently this year, have done it again. This time, the House leadership has failed to find a way to get a bipartisan law against hate crimes passed and signed into law. Racial, religious, sexual and other minorities have waited long enough. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has to do more than just express her support for the bill; she must find a way to make it the law.

headline: In a Cast
text: Victoria Clark, who won a Tony Award in 2005 for best actress in a musical for her performance in “The Light in the Piazza,” will star when Encores! presents the Marc Blitzstein and Joseph Stein musical “Juno” for five performances from March 27 to 30 at City Center. ... David Hyde Pierce, who won the 2007 Tony Award for best actor in a musical for his performance as the theater-loving detective in “Curtains,” has extended his engagement in the show at the Al Hirschfeld Theater for six months, through Aug. 31.

headline: 2 Fatal Shootings at Colorado Religious Sites
text: A gunman and four people were killed and four others wounded yesterday in two apparently unprovoked shootings that unfolded about 12 hours and 70 miles apart at a missionary training center and a church in Colorado, law-enforcement authorities reported.

headline: Screenwriters Dig In for an Extended Brawl
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9  Eight months ago, in a contemplative moment, Patric M. Verrone, president of the Writers Guild of America West, sketched out what could have been a script for the collision that wrecked talks between Hollywood’s producers and striking writers on Friday.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: FED MEETING The chief news of the week will be the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday. A quarter-point interest rate decrease is expected, but there are calls for a half point.

headline: Monthly Fare for Transit to Rise 6.6% in Proposal
text: Subway and bus riders who use monthly unlimited-ride MetroCards would be hit the hardest under a revised proposal to increase transit fares, which is to be announced today by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: Richard Nolte, Diplomat Who Got Caught Up in Mideast War, Dies at 86
text: Richard Nolte, a Middle East expert whose three-week tenure as American ambassador to Egypt in 1967 ended when the country expelled him during the 1967 Middle East War, even though he had sympathized with the Arab cause, died Nov. 22 at his home in Hanover, N.H. He was 86.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $2,689,769.55

headline: Homemade YouTube Video Lands Singer in a Web Ad
text: If, as the song goes, video killed the radio star, then homemade YouTube heroes like Tay Zonday have put a hit out on traditional advertising.

headline: Nokia Pushes to Regain U.S. Sales in Spite of Apple and Google
text: ESPOO, Finland  When Google announced plans in October to revolutionize the software of cellular phones, few were more eager to hear the details than the industry veterans at Nokia. They still are.

headline: At a Theater
text: Ethan Coen, whose credits as a filmmaker range from “Blood Simple” and “Raising Arizona” to “O Brother, Where Art Thou?” and “No Country for Old Men,” will make his debut as a playwright when the Atlantic Theater Company presents the world premiere of his “Almost an Evening.” Directed by Neil Pepe as the first production of the Atlantic 2 season, the production will consist of three short plays. F. Murray Abraham, Jonathan Cake, Mark Linn-Baker and Mary McCann are among the cast. Previews begin on Jan. 9 ... The Public Theater’s world premiere presentation of the Richard Nelson history play “Conversations in Tusculum” will begin previews on Feb. 19 and run through March 23. Examining those entangled in Julius Caesar’s manipulations and power, it has a cast that includes Brian Dennehy, David Strathairn and Maria Tucci. ... Samuel Beckett’s “Endgame,” featuring John Turturro, has been added to the spring season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The one-act play will be presented at the Harvey Theater in 24 performances from April 25 through May 18. ... The run of “Cyrano de Bergerac” has been extended for two weeks, through Jan. 6, at the Richard Rodgers Theater.

headline: Austin and Calcavecchia Win
text: Woody Austin made a 35-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole to win the Merrill Lynch Shootout with his teammate Mark Calcavecchia in Naples, Fla. The two won by a shot over the tournament host, Greg Norman, and Bubba Watson.The putt gave the team a final-round nine-under-par 63 in the scramble format and a 29-under 187 total.Norman and Watson barely missed birdie tries from 25 feet after Austin made his putt. Norman’s ball ended up inches right of the hole, and Watson’s putt faded and broke in front of the hole to the left.Norman was trying to win for the first time since the 2001 Skins Game. Watson has not won as a professional.

headline: Ramapo: Chase Ends in Suspects’ Arrest
text: Four suspects were arrested yesterday after an early-morning robbery at an Applebee’s restaurant and a car chase that ended at the George Washington Bridge, the police said. Police officers began chasing the car after a robbery was reported at the restaurant, on Route 59 in Airmont, about 7:20 a.m., the Ramapo Police Department said. Officers from several departments joined the pursuit, which ended when the suspects’ car crashed into another car as it entered the upper deck of the bridge. One suspect was injured when he tried to escape by leaping to the bridge’s lower deck; a second was hit by a police car while trying to carjack another vehicle, the police said. Two other suspects were arrested in Fort Lee, N.J., one while hiding inside a trash bin, the police said. None of the suspects were identified yesterday evening.

headline: Nets Unable to Stop Washington’s Butler
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  Caron Butler scored 20 of his 28 points in the second half Sunday night, leading the Washington Wizards to a 104-89 victory over the Nets.

headline: South Korea's Blackened Beaches
text: Thousands of fishermen, soldiers and volunteers struggled on Sunday to clean up the worst oil spill in South Korea's history.

headline: The Gay ’80s, ’90s and ’00s
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Children Hurt in Pakistan Bombing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 10 — A suicide bomb attack on a military truck carrying schoolchildren outside a Pakistani Air Force base in northwestern Pakistan injured five children and two adults early today, military officials said. The attack came a day after a separate suicide bombing in northwestern Pakistan killed six civilians and one police officer.

headline: Bobby Orr, in the Nude
text: If you’re in Soho this week and feel like seeing larger-than-life nude portraits of Bobby Orr and Derek Sanderson, you can. Kurt Kauper’s realistic figurative paintings of the two Bruins icons of the early ’70s are on exhibit at the Deitch Projects gallery on Grand Street through Dec. 15, and they’re well worth the visit. But be forewarned: a couple of the paintings are full frontal nudes.

headline: In Detroit, Bad Timing for a Renaissance
text: Although there are signs of life in the nation's 11th-largest city, there has been no end to the job cuts at automakers.

headline: Why We Laugh
text: From an article Monday about a new study in the Journal of Consumer Research:

headline: Today’s Tech Tip
text: Hmmm — from a commercial we’ve seen somewhere? How to use your new mouse:

headline: Was It the Onion Dip?
text: From the Onion:

headline: Apple Titters
text: Monday’s tech news is that Nokia’s taking on Apple anew. Well, as many an iPod user can tell you, Apple ain’t perfect. Here’s a video compendium showing Steve Jobs not always on top of his game:

headline: ‘The New Word Is Has-Been’
text: Getcha fresh reader comedy here (send in yours via the comment link below):

headline: Hey, Everybody! It’s Chavez Time!
text: In Venezuela, that is:

headline: Shoot Us an E-Mail
text: Go ahead: be “un”-funny. Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions at right.

headline: UBS to Write Down $10 Billion as It Prepares Stake Sales
text: UBS said on Monday that it would write down its subprime mortgage investments by $10 billion but would replenish its capital by selling stakes worth 13 billion Swiss francs to the Singapore government and an unnamed Middle Eastern investor.

headline: Statements
text: Madison Square Garden's Statement

headline: Deadlines Loom Over Spending Bills
text: When it comes to the Congressional end game, one lawmaker’s compromise is another’s extortion.

headline: Blodget May Get a Job Picking Stocks for Yahoo
text: Henry Blodget, who was barred from the securities industry for the misdeeds he committed as a research analyst at Merrill Lynch, may be getting another shot at picking hot tech offerings for a big firm. But instead of using his experience to enrich an investment bank, this time Mr. Blodget would be working for Yahoo.

headline: Japan’s Eisai to Cough Up $3.9 Billion for MGI Pharma
text: A Japanese drugmaker, Eisai, said on Monday it would buy a biotech firm in the United States, MGI Pharma, for $3.9 billion to expand in the United States and strengthen its pipeline in cancer treatments.

headline: NeuroVasx Takes $8.5 Million in New Funding
text: A medical device developer, NeuroVasx, raised $8.5 million in follow-on investment from previous backers to support completion of regulatory trials and a commercial introduction of implant technology to treat strokes in patients with brain aneurysms.

headline: Conduit Capital Unloads Stake in Inelec
text: Conduit Capital Partners said Friday that it had sold its stake in Inelec, a portfolio of three hydroelectric power plants in Mexico, to a Dutch subsidiary of the Italian utility Enel in a deal valuing the facilities at $193 million, including debt.

headline: Gander Mountain Deals for Overton’s
text: Gander Mountain, an operator of outdoor sports supply stores, said it will acquire a boating gear retailer Overton’s for $70 million in cash.

headline: Investors Push Entropic Up 40% in Debut
text: Although weak demand forced Entropic Communications, a semiconductor company based in San Diego, to cut the size of its initial public offering, its stock rose 40 percent in its Nasdaq debut on Friday.

headline: Conrad Black to Be Sentenced
text: The former newspaper mogul Conrad Black, convicted of swindling shareholders in his Hollinger International media empire out of millions of dollars, is due to learn just how steep a price he must pay.

headline: U.S. Must Get Tougher on Deal Compliance, Lawyer Says
text: An antitrust lawyer and former Federal Trade Commission official said that the Department of Justice should get tougher if it wants more timely compliance with merger divestiture orders.

headline: Tribune Appeals F.C.C. Ruling on Divestitures
text: Tribune is asking a federal appeals court to strike down an order by the Federal Communications Commission that would eventually require the company to break up newspaper-TV station combinations it operates in four markets.

headline: Coty Buys Kelso’s Del Labs for $800 Million
text: Kelso & Company, a private equity firm, said it would sell Del Laboratories, which makes Sally Hansen nail care products, to the fragrance giant Coty in a deal valued at about $800 million, according to The Deal.com.

headline: V.C. Investments May Hit 6-Year High
text: Venture capital investments in the United States, Europe, China and Israel this year have passed the $30 billion mark and the industry is on course to post its highest investment total since 2001, according to a new report.

text: Societe Generale, the French bank, will bail out its structured investment vehicle by taking on $4.3 billion of assets to avoid a fire sale.

text: Barron’s apparently likes the looks of JPMorgan Chase‘s prospects. In a bullish feature on Chase, the nation’s third-largest bank, the publication noted that JPMorgan avoided most of the losses suffered by other investment banks and its growth could now “really accelerate.”

As William Neuman reports, under the new proposal, the weekly unlimited-ride MetroCard would increase to $25, from $24, a 4.2 percent increase. While he was debating whether to throw out the power cord for a cellphone he lost three years ago, the critics in New York (the online variety), Washington, Boston and Los Angeles were concerning themselves with more pressing matters — like whether the Coens or Paul Thomas Anderson had this year’s most riveting take on the consequences of greed.

Here, in The Moment’s The Style Equation column, we use a rudimentary calculation to reduce a new design object to the sum of its parts. This week, the new Prada clutch.

headline: Adams in the 21st Century
text: My erudite colleagues have disclosed certain Adamsian qualities that would greatly disturb a student of Adams and yet would be difficult to refute. He was a mid-19th-century equivalent of a Vietnam-era draft dodger, hiding behind his father’s diplomatic frock coat during a war whose outcome had to do with nothing less than the character and destiny of his nation. He all too casually adopted crude stereotypes, especially where Jews were concerned, and evidenced a detachment from the colossal moral issue of slavery unbecoming to an enlightened and perceptive mind. He occasionally revealed himself to be, or to seem to be, an elitist, self-absorbed twit callously indifferent to the cares and woes of lesser mortals. And his outlook on the phenomenon and intricate operation of democracy itself was languid, to say the least, as if previous Adamses had said all that needed to be said on the subject and anything that might follow was mere froth.

headline: Books: Seeing Yourself in Autism

headline: Screening Dreams
text: If you are someone who suspects that what is billed as “aviation security” is often more show than substance, you are not alone. In fact, you are part of what Nixon aides used to call the “silent majority.” The security bureaucracy seems to think that as long as it is seen as doing something, and so long as another terror attack does not occur, the public will at least feel secure enough not to insist that it do whatever needs to be done actually to make us secure.Any number of examples could be cited to support this proposition, but let’s focus first on the foiled plot in the summer of 2006 to blow up several jetliners over the United States with liquid explosives. Because no technology had been developed to detect or thwart liquid explosives, the Transportation Security Administration was forced to take, for a time, the draconian step of banning all liquids and gels. We were told at the time that even liquids and gels that are harmless in and of themselves could become incendiary when combined in sufficient quantity.

headline: She’s Been Baking!
text: I love the morning after a party and the girlfriends call to discuss the food, the conversation, the clothes and, of course, the men folk. I gave a little party on Saturday night — I’m sorry I didn’t invite y’all — and the guests trooped through the darkness and the muddy snow, with bottles of wine, cakes and a bunch of white roses. I had brought together two separate worlds, friends and cousins, city and country people, and everyone got along and stayed until midnight. I cooked a fresh ham (thanks to James Beard, the calmest and funniest of authorities, I think), and my brother sent scallops from Nantucket, which I turned into a kind of pie. We had a potato gratin and a tossed salad. I dug out my mother’s recipe for chocolate pot de crème, and I used her old “Good Housekeeping Picture Cookbook” for the coconut layered cake. I cooked a batch of the Swedish ginger cookies, the ones made with bacon fat. Freddy the Jack stayed close to the ham all night, and Toby the Lab gave every pair of gray flannels a nice comet of hair. It was fun, the girlfriends said, sounding almost surprised.

headline: Should You Change Your MetroCard Habits? Math Says, Stay the Course

Those MetroCard buyers might be wondering, “What should I do if the fare goes up?” Fortunately, there’s a simple answer. We did the math. text: Scores of workers from MTV Networks walked off the job Monday afternoon, filling the sidewalk outside the headquarters of its corporate parent, Viacom, to protest recent changes in benefits.

headline: Buying Time
text: Rich people are tired, stressed out and eager for anything that might save them a little “me” time, according to a new study by Barclays Wealth entitled Insights: The True Value of Wealth.

headline: Led Zeppelin Rocks Again
text: The British band turned back the clock nearly 20 years at a charity concert in London.

headline: Bubble denial
text: Barry Ritholtz has a nice graph of the housing price-to-rent ratio — more or less the equivalent of the PE ratio on stocks. It was the ratio I was looking at most back in 2005, when I started writing about the housing bubble — it didn’t take much to see that something was way out of whack.

headline: Cartesian Blogging, Part One
text: Primae Objectiones Et Responsio Auctoris Ad Primas Objectiones

headline: Japan: Prudential Acquires Firm
text: Prudential Financial, the life insurer, acquired Round Hill Capital Partners Kabushiki Kaisha, a Japanese real estate management firm. Round Hill, established in 2001, previously provided asset management services to Prudential Real Estate Investors, Prudential said. Round Hill has arranged 19 investments for Prudential real estate totaling $1.5 billion. Terms were not disclosed. Prudential is based in Newark, N.J.

headline: Nostrums: Tame a Child’s Cough With a Touch of Honey
text: A spoonful of honey might quiet a child’s cough more effectively and safely than the most common over-the-counter cough medicine.

headline: Libby Drops His Appeal in Leak Case
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  I. Lewis Libby Jr., Vice President Dick Cheney’s former chief of staff, announced Monday that he was dropping the appeal of his conviction for perjury and obstruction of justice in the C.I.A. leak case.

headline: A Tug of War Over a Declaration of Independence
text: BOSTON, Dec. 10  Unbeknownst to Anna Plumstead, her attic in Wiscasset, Me., held a treasure: one of the earliest copies of the Declaration of Independence, delivered to her town in 1776 as part of a campaign to spread its message through the original 13 colonies.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Friday with an article in some editions about Samonia Malloy, a recovering drug addict and single mother from Brooklyn who received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misidentified the child pictured with Ms. Malloy. He is Ervin Velez Jr., her 1-year-old son  not Masyah Malloy, her 9-year-old son.

headline: New DVDs
text: SUSANA

headline: A Gift That Gives Right Back? The Giving Itself
text: When my mom died a few years ago, my siblings and I were discussing the many ways life would be different without her. “No more presents,” my brother noted.

headline: In the Lab: Gene Study Helps Explain Link to Breast Cancer
text: More than 10 years ago, scientists discovered that mutations in a gene called BRCA1 lead to a particularly deadly type of breast cancer. Now an international group of researchers has found at least one reason why. BRCA1 inactivates a tumor suppressor gene known as PTEN.

headline: China Said to Block U.S. Films
text: SHANGHAI, Dec. 11  China has stopped granting permission for American films to be shown in its cinemas in an apparent trade dispute with the United States, according to several Hollywood executives and United States government officials.

headline: Washington Mutual Cutting Dividend and Jobs
text: Washington Mutual, one of the country’s largest lenders, said yesterday that it would exit the subprime lending business, cut its dividend and eliminate 3,150 jobs.

headline: A Post-Thatcher Crime Fighter in a Pre-Thatcher England
text: The return of “Life on Mars” for a second season on BBC America tonight seems as good a time as any to ask why time travel has become such a popular theme on television recently. Is it that we cannot get enough of the retro aesthetic these trips backward occasion? The flesh-tone nylons, the lima-bean-green telephones with cords and dials and earpieces like coasters? Or is that writers see in bygone naïveté as dependable an opportunity for comedy as they do in a 6-year-old spouting off about deflated global currencies?

headline: How to Defuse Iran
text: Washington

headline: New York Film Critics Pick Winners
text: The New York Film Critics Circle chose  Ethan and Joel Coen’s latter-day western “No Country for Old Men” yesterday as the year’s best film. The Coen brothers, above (Ethan is at left), were also honored for their direction and adaptation of this film of Cormac McCarthy’s novel of the same title. Javier Bardem, who plays a serial killer in the film, was designated best supporting actor. Honors for best actor went to Daniel Day-Lewis for his portrayal of an oil magnate in “There Will Be Blood,” adapted from the Upton Sinclair novel “Oil!” (“There Will Be Blood” was also named best picture by the Los Angeles Film Critics Association.) Julie Christie, who plays a woman with Alzheimer’s disease in “Away From Her,” was named best actress. Sarah Polley, that movie’s director, was honored for best first film. Amy Ryan was designated best supporting actress for her portrayal of the mother of a vanished child in Ben Affleck’s “Gone Baby Gone.” Already the winner of this year’s Oscar for best foreign-language film, “The Lives of Others,” from Germany, was named best foreign film; and “Persepolis” was chosen as best animated film. The New York Film Critics Circle, comprising 29 writers for New York publications, is also honoring Sidney Lumet for lifetime achievement.

headline: Segui Admits Steroid Use
text: The retired first baseman David Segui said yesterday that he used steroids and purchased shipments of the drug from the former Mets clubhouse attendant Kirk Radomski, The Baltimore Sun reported on its Web site last night.Segui also repeated his June 2006 admission to ESPN that he used human growth hormone with a prescription. He told The Sun that he refused to talk to George J. Mitchell, the former senator whose report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball is expected soon. Segui said he did not want to betray the trust of other players.“I have nothing to hide. I have no problem talking about what I have done,” said Segui, who spent eight of his 15 major league seasons with the Baltimore Orioles. “But I never want any other players to think I was out there talking about their business.”

headline: Boeing Says 787 to Meet Delayed Schedule
text: The Boeing Company said today that it was on track to deliver the first 787 Dreamliner at the end of next year after improving supply chain problems that had led to a six-month delay in its original production schedule.

headline: Destruction of C.I.A. Tapes Cleared by Lawyers
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Lawyers within the clandestine branch of the Central Intelligence Agency gave written approval in advance to the destruction in 2005 of hundreds of hours of videotapes documenting interrogations of two lieutenants from Al Qaeda, according to a former senior intelligence official with direct knowledge of the episode.

headline: Doping Experts Find Loopholes Beyond Baseball
text: Game days are a day of rest for the National Football League’s drug-testing program. The testing schedule is so regimented that players know they will not be required to offer a urine sample on those days.

headline: Defending School Report Cards, Over a Chorus of Boos
text: The architect of the city’s new system that assigns grades to public schools faced fierce criticism yesterday at a hearing before the City Council’s Education Committee, whose members blasted the evaluations as unfair, reductive and a maze of statistics.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Citigroup Deliberating on Choice for Top Job
text: Citigroup’s board was locked in debate over its new leader yesterday, with no clear consensus over who would be tapped.

headline: Another Study Finds Heart Risks in a Diabetes Drug
text: An independent analysis of thousands of older people with diabetes found that those treated with the widely used drug Avandia had significantly elevated risks of heart attack and death.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the conviction of a Canadian pig farmer in the deaths of six women in Vancouver misstated the neighborhood from which they and other women who worked as prostitutes had vanished over a 19-year period. It is the Downtown Eastside, not the Lower Eastside. (Go to Article)

headline: week’s notables
text: PLAYER In Spain, reports that Barcelona will sell Ronaldinho during the January transfer period were dismissed by the club’s president, Joan Laporta. “We are not going to sell Ronaldinho,” he told the news media before Sunday’s 2-1 win over Deportivo la Coruña. “We are not in contact with Chelsea, Milan or any other team.”

headline: In New Ad, Romney Attacks Huckabee on Immigration
text: Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign plans to begin running a negative television advertisement today in Iowa highlighting Mike Huckabee’s record on immigration, escalating the warfare between the two Republican candidates as they scramble for support in the nation’s first nominating state.

headline: The Claim: Don't Eat the Mistletoe. It Can Be Deadly
text: THE FACTS

headline: Dmitri A. Medvedev: Young Technocrat of the Post-Communist Era
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 10  Dmitri A. Medvedev’s quick ascent owes much to Vladimir V. Putin, the man who endorsed him as his successor on Monday. Critics dismiss Mr. Medvedev as a colorless bureaucrat who got lucky, saying he was chosen by Mr. Putin as a man easily manipulated so Mr. Putin can remain a power behind the throne.

headline: Fin Whale at Feeding Time: Dive Deep, Stop Short, Open Wide
text: The word “big” doesn’t do justice to whales. Humpback whales can weigh up to 40 tons. Fin whales have been known to reach 80 tons. Blue whales, the biggest animals to have ever lived, reach 160 tons  the same mass as about 2,000 grown men or 5 million grown mice.

headline: Danny Newman, 88, Musical Publicity Expert, Is Dead
text: Danny Newman, longtime director of press and public relations at Lyric Opera of Chicago and an influential thinker on the art of selling classical music to the public, died on Dec. 1 at his home in Lincolnwood, Ill. He was 88.

headline: Troubled Citigroup Names Pandit as Chief Executive
text: Citigroup, the country’s largest bank and one of the biggest casualties of the turmoil in the credit markets, appointed Vikram S. Pandit as its chief executive today.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about Rudolph W. Giuliani’s tenure as the United States attorney in Manhattan referred incorrectly in some editions to the United States attorney general in 1987, who was then Mr. Giuliani’s boss. He is Edwin Meese III, not Edward.

headline: Emergency Antidote, Direct to Addicts
text: Among the growing numbers of researchers and public health officials advocating a daring new strategy to put an injectable antidote for heroin overdoses directly into the hands of addicts, few have the credibility of Mark Kinzly.

headline: Attacks in Baghdad Kill 9 and Damage a Refinery
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 10  A spate of bomb, rocket and mortar attacks rocked areas of Baghdad on Monday, killing at least nine people and exploding part of a major oil refinery, sending up a thick column of smoke that dominated the city’s skyline for much of the day.

headline: Lining Up Bobby Bowden’s Successor
text: Jimbo Fisher will succeed Bobby Bowden as Florida State’s next coach  someday. Bowden, who has the most victories in major college football, has agreed to a deal for next season, his 33rd, with options to stay longer. But T. K. Wetherell, the university president, designated Fisher, the offensive coordinator, as “head-coach-in-waiting,” then skipped out of a somewhat unusual news conference without answering questions about the contracts, which are not yet completed.

headline: Death at the Omaha Mall: Focus on the Weapon
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Music Director for Vienna Opera
text: The Austrian conductor Franz Welser-Möst, below, signed on as music director of the Vienna Opera, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Welser-Möst, 46, music director of the Cleveland Orchestra and the Zurich Opera, will succeed Seiji Ozawa for five years, beginning on Sept. 1, 2010, according to the Austrian Federation of National Theaters.

headline: Deloitte Agrees to Pay $1 Million Fine
text: Deloitte & Touche, one of the Big Four accounting firms, agreed yesterday to pay $1 million to settle accusations that it had botched an audit of a pharmaceutical company by entrusting it to a partner it knew to be a poor auditor.

headline: Senate Will Consider More Restrictive Rules on Mortgages
text: Christopher J. Dodd, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, will introduce a bill today that would impose new regulations on mortgage brokers and investment banks and restrict certain aggressive lending practices, Congressional aides said yesterday.

headline: Measures Considered to Curtail Fan Behavior
text: Three weeks after Richard J. Codey, the president of the New Jersey Senate, condemned a ritual of harassment at Gate D of Giants Stadium during halftime of Jets games, he offered stadium security a vote of confidence, even though the abuse has not been stopped.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
