text: An obituary yesterday about Richard Nolte, a diplomat and geographer, misstated the number of his surviving grandchildren. There are 10, not 9.

headline: Prosecutor Says Serbia Blocked Arrests in Killings
text: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 10  The chief prosecutor of the international war crimes court for the former Yugoslavia accused Serbia on Monday of blocking the arrests of the two suspected leaders of a violent campaign of ethnic expulsions and killings, including the 1995 massacre of Muslims in the Bosnian enclave of Srebrenica.

headline: Fed Cuts Rate a Quarter Point; Stocks Dive
text: The Federal Reserve cut a key short-term interest rate today by a quarter of a percentage point, to 4.25 percent, signaling its concern that the credit crisis might be gradually damaging the broader economy beyond housing.

headline: China and U.S. in Food Safety Accord
text: BEIJING, Dec. 11  China and the United States, seeking to ease the furor over the safety of food exports, signed an agreement today calling for a greater United States role in certifying and inspecting Chinese food exports, including an increased presence of American officials at Chinese production plants.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the National Briefing column on Friday about a decision by Cardinal Roger M. Mahony not to file a police report after he was assaulted misstated his title. He is the archbishop of Los Angeles, not the bishop.

headline: Tough, Rewarding Days Caring for Four Children
text: Patricia Velasco was having a tough day. It was a Tuesday, but it could have been any day of the week.

headline: Memo Pad
text: MAXJET HALTS TRADING Holding tickets or planning travel on MaxJet? The airline says it continues to accept bookings and has no plans to change its schedule after temporarily suspending trading in its shares in London on Friday. The two-year-old all business-class carrier is reported to be seeking new financing. Like all airlines, MaxJet is struggling with soaring fuel costs. Based at Washington Dulles International Airport, MaxJet is one of four international discount all business-class discount airlines to start up in the last two years. It flies from New York, Las Vegas and Los Angeles to London Stansted Airport. In a note to investors yesterday, Douglas McNeill of Blue Oar Securities in London said MaxJet was in trouble partly because “punctuality statistics and anecdotal evidence suggest that customer service is well short of the required level.” Meanwhile, British Air said it planned to start new all premium-class service in May between various European cities and cities in the United States, using 757 aircraft configured with business-class and premium-economy seats only.

headline: Mortgage Crisis Forces the Closing of a Fund
text: Losses on investments weakened by the deepening housing crisis have forced Bank of America to close a multibillion-dollar high-yield fund, the largest of its kind, after wealthy investors withdrew billions of dollars in assets.

headline: The Eyes of an Artist (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Democrats Postpone Vote on Domestic Spending
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 

headline: Poll Finds G.O.P. Field Isn’t Touching Voters
text: Three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Republican voters across the country appear uninspired by their field of presidential candidates, with a vast majority saying they have not made a final decision about whom to support, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: A 17-Year-Old Legal Case and a $5.4 Million Fine Shadow D’Amato’s Hometown
text: ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Dec. 6  Most people here in the Long Island village where Alfonse M. D’Amato grew up do not even know about the $5.4 million fine in a federal civil rights case that has been hanging over their heads for 10 years. Those who do know about it seem unconcerned, as if the flood of tax bills that the judgment represents  more than $1,000 for every man, woman and child in a community of two- and three-job families  were safely contained behind some invisible levee.

headline: Putin Backs Deputy Prime Minister as Successor
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 10  President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday endorsed as his successor Dmitri A. Medvedev, a protégé with no background in the state security services and virtually no power base in the Kremlin.

headline: Winning When They Shouldn't
text: The Boston Celtics already have the look. They have championship talent, in the franchise players Kevin Garnett, Ray Allen and Paul Pierce, and a cornucopia of effective role players. They flexed their muscles at the start of the season and showed the N.B.A. they were a team to be reckoned with.

headline: U.S. Panel Cuts Jail Time for Crimes Tied to Crack Cocaine
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The United States Sentencing Commission voted unanimously today to lighten punishments retroactively for crimes related to crack cocaine, a decision that could affect some 19,500 federal inmates.

headline: Israelis Brief Top U.S. Official on Iran
text: JERUSALEM, Dec. 10  Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made an unusual visit to Israel and got a polite earful on Monday about Israel’s gloomy assessment of Iran’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: Risk Taking Is in His Genes
text: KYOTO, Japan  Inspiration can appear in unexpected places. Dr. Shinya Yamanaka found it while looking through a microscope at a friend’s fertility clinic.

headline: European Automakers Likely to Build Plants in United States
text: DETROIT, Dec. 10  The dollar’s falling value is making European automakers eager to build more vehicles in the United States, even as American car companies continue to shift production to other, lower-cost countries.

headline: In Midwest Duck Blinds, Visions of Global Warming
text: RICH HILL, Mo.  After 32 years of hunting ducks here in the wetlands of west-central Missouri, Chuck Geier knows when temperatures will drop and waters will freeze. That means he also knows when the birds will fly and hunting will be best.

headline: Equity Firm Makes $1 Billion Investment in MBIA
text: MBIA, the nation’s largest bond insurer, said yesterday that it would receive a $1 billion investment from the private equity firm Warburg Pincus to shore up its finances and safeguard its top-flight credit rating.

headline: Destroyed: The C.I.A. Torture Tapes
text: To the Editor:

headline: When a Big Tip Turns Into Big Trouble
text: IN my job, I travel about 200,000 miles a year. After a while every city starts to look alike. But I can always tell what part of the world I’m in by its drivers. Growing up in Boston, I figured I could handle any type of problem the gods of driving threw at me. I met my match in Singapore, a place known for its law-abiding citizens.

headline: Lost Prokofiev Scoregets a Second Life
text: An unfinished Prokofiev score, written for a film that was never made and all but forgotten for 70 years, will be the music for a ballet to be performed by the Royal Ballet in the spring at Covent Garden in London in a production featuring Carlos Acosta, Zenaida Yanovsky and Alina Cojocaru, The Times of London reported. Said to be reminiscent of Prokofiev’s “Romeo and Juliet” and his Fifth Symphony, the score was completed by Michael Berkeley, a British composer. It was discovered by Kim Brandstrup, a Danish choreographer in London, who said he encountered a reference to it in a Prokofiev biography and unearthed a photocopy in the department of music at Goldsmiths, University of London. He proposed to the Royal Ballet that it be turned into a dance piece, and Monica Mason, director of the company, suggested that Mr. Berkeley, as he put it, arrange and elaborate the score. The score was commissioned in 1936 for “The Queen of Spades,” to be directed by Mikhail Romm, but when the production was called off, the music was left in a fragmentary state.

headline: Militant Attacks in North Africa
text: Here is a chronology of militant activity in the Maghreb region of North Africa over the past year, including attacks in Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia, as compiled by Reuters.

headline: Dozens Die as Migrant Boat Sinks in Aegean
text: At least 51 would-be migrants drowned trying to cross from Turkey to Greece and the European Union when their boat sank in rough weather early Sunday, officials said. The boat was carrying about 70 Palestinians, Iraqis and Somalians when it sank off Seferihisar, in the Aegean province of Izmir, said Orhan Sefik Guldibi, a local official. The boat’s origin was unclear. Rescuers saved six people. The death toll was expected to rise.

headline: Black Given Prison Term Over Fraud
text: CHICAGO, Dec. 10  In the months since his convictions in July on fraud and obstruction of justice charges, Conrad M. Black, the fallen press baron who once presided over the world’s third-largest newspaper empire, was not above poking fun at himself as he waited to see how long he would spend in prison.

headline: Oprah Movie Takes on Football
text: Football lifted CBS and NBC into first place in the ratings on Sunday, while ABC remained competitive, thanks to its made-for-television movie “Oprah Winfrey Presents: Mitch Albom’s ‘For One More Day.’” Benefiting from an overrun of its afternoon football broadcast, CBS attracted the most viewers over all, averaging more than 24 million during the first half of the 7 p.m. hour, Nielsen estimated. Directly after the game, CBS remained No. 1 with “60 Minutes” (15.9 million), although the network’s ratings slipped as the night wore on, with “The Amazing Race” (11.9 million), followed by “Cold Case” (11.2 million) and then, finally, “Shark” (9 million). NBC, meanwhile, with its live “Sunday Night Football” coverage, finished third over all in total viewers but ahead of CBS in a close race for first among adults 18 to 49. ABC ranked third in that demographic, buoyed by “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (12.8 million) but also benefiting from “For One More Day,” which averaged 12.5 million viewers from 9 to 11 while finishing second only to football in its time slot in the 18 to 49 set. Fox was fourth for the night with a lineup mostly of repeats.

headline: Inflation Picks Up in China; Trade Gap Grows
text: HONG KONG, Dec. 11  Inflation accelerated further in China last month, government statisticians announced today, as rising costs for food and fuel together with government currency policies are sending prices up briskly across Asia.

headline: Mayo Clinic Study Links Anemia Drugs to Leukemia Risk
text: Anemia drugs from Amgen and Johnson & Johnson may raise the risk that patients with a bone marrow disease will later develop leukemia, according to an analysis of 30 years of patient records.

headline: Following a Mosaic Path to Chart a Neighborhood’s History
text: When Jim Power created his first mosaic on a lamppost on Astor Pace in 1987, a concrete band shell still stood inside Tompkins Square Park, admission to the CBGB club cost $5, and about the same amount could buy a night’s lodging in the Bowery.

headline: From Iran’s Fiery Leader, a Slightly Tamer Blog
text: TEHRAN, Dec. 10  Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, president of Iran, is not the first name that comes to mind when thinking of net surfers and instant messages. Yet, it turns out, the man is a blogger.

headline: As a Nation Was Born, They Wrote and Wrote
text: He was her “Lysander,” after the Spartan hero. She was his “Diana,” after the Roman goddess of the moon. She called him “My Dearest Friend.” He called her “Miss Adorable” and his “Heroine,” who sustained “with so much Fortitude, the Shocks and Terrors of the Times.”

headline: Central U.S. Reeling From Ice Storms
text: Ice, sleet and freezing rain beset much of the central part of the United States today, causing deaths in traffic accidents on slippery roads and cutting power to hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses.

headline: Flu Shots for Children Grow Near in New Jersey
text: TRENTON, Dec. 10  Despite opposition from numerous parents and children’s rights advocates, a public health advisory panel voted on Monday to require all children in New Jersey who attend preschool or are in day care to get annual flu vaccinations.

headline: The Giants May Win, but They Don’t Dazzle
text: The Giants are rounding into a playoff team, in the standings and in their personality. At 9-4, they can clinch a postseason spot by defeating the Washington Redskins on Sunday night, although they are likely to clinch one even if they do not win another game.

headline: Bloodshed in ’02 Shadows Indian Politician in Race That Tests Nationalist Party
text: AHMEDABAD, India  Five years after more than 1,000 people, most of them Muslims, were killed as riots swept through the Indian state of Gujarat, the man censured by the courts for failing to stop the violence is in a tight race to keep his job as the state’s chief minister.

headline: Drugs Pass Review
text: Nexium and Prilosec, AstraZeneca’s top-selling acid-reflux drugs, do not increase heart risks, regulators concluded after a six-month review.

headline: Black Is Sentenced to 6 1/2 Years in Prison
text: CHICAGO, Dec. 10  Conrad M. Black, the flamboyant former press baron, will spend more than six years behind bars for fleecing shareholders of Hollinger International out of millions of dollars, a judge decided today.

headline: Unhappy Investors Send Shares Lower
text: Stocks fell sharply and Treasuries rallied this afternoon after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates less than some investors were hoping for and indicated that it would be measured in its response to the tighter credit market.

headline: No Videos as Patriots Set Sights on the Jets
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 10  Now, let’s go back to the videotape.

headline: A New Leader Guides His Fledgling Group
text: A change in leadership is cause for nervous anticipation at any institution, and the New York Youth Symphony is no exception. The orchestra opened its 45th season on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall with a concert conducted by Ryan McAdams, its newly appointed music director.

headline: Ways to Cut City Traffic? Well, Maybe
text: You wouldn’t be able to hail a cab in Manhattan below 86th Street, where cabs would be allowed to pick up passengers only at taxi stands scattered throughout the area.

headline: Pakistan’s News Media No Longer Silent, but Musharraf Has Muted His Critics
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 10  Nearly all private television channels blacked out last month by President Pervez Musharraf’s emergency decree are back on the air. But the country’s once-thriving television news media remain largely muzzled by sweeping new restrictions that journalists and Western diplomats say stifle criticism of the government.

headline: Insights: Anorexia May Be Tied to Hormones in Womb
text: Anorexia is 10 times as common in women as in men, and a new study suggests that female sex hormones in the womb may play a part.

headline: The Gene That Tells Planaria Worms Which End Is Up
text: The flatworms known as planaria have long amazed scientists with their capacity for regeneration. Cut off the head end of one, and it regrows a head. Cut off the tail end, and it regrows a tail. As little as one three-hundredths of a worm can regenerate a complete organism.

headline: A Network for Blacks With Sense of Mission
text: SILVER SPRING, Md.  Fortified by caffeine and good will, the volunteer construction crew at Love Fellowship Tabernacle in Brooklyn worked long hours to transform a dingy storage area into the Kingdom Cafe. The hammering and plastering created a restaurant and gathering spot for young people at this Pentecostal church in the struggling East New York neighborhood. As for the lights and camera, they were there for “Divine Restoration,” a TV One program that finds black churches needing a makeover and turns the process into television.

headline: Mediator to Enter Talks With Drivers of Wheelchair Vans
text: A federal mediator will arbitrate talks between four companies that provide 8,000 daily van rides for disabled and frail passengers in New York City and the union that represents their drivers.

headline: The Postwar Election
text: The 2008 presidential election has fundamentally shifted, but it hasn’t been because of events in Iowa and New Hampshire. It’s because of events everywhere else.

headline: War vs. Terrorism Debate in Embassy Bomb Appeal
text: The national debate over Guantánamo and the way the government has pursued its fight against terrorism since the 9/11 attacks was a presence yesterday as a federal appeals court in Manhattan considered the cases of three operatives of Al Qaeda convicted in the last major terrorism trial in the United States before 9/11.

headline: Counting Calories, but Not to Shed Pounds
text: We stood in front of the freezer case at the grocery store, my 16-year-old daughter, Kitty, and I. It was late, and I was tired, but we had come out for a few items that couldn’t wait until morning. One of them was ice cream.

headline: Mr. Johnson’s Unused Authority
text: When President Bush plucked him from civil service obscurity in 2005 to run the Environmental Protection Agency, Stephen Johnson probably never imagined that he would someday find himself at the center of the policy struggle over global warming. But that is where he is now, courtesy of the Supreme Court’s ruling in March that greenhouse gases could be regulated under the Clean Air Act, a law administered by the E.P.A. Unfortunately, Mr. Johnson and the agency have not done anything meaningful since.

headline: UBS Records a Big Write-Down and Sells a Stake
text: FRANKFURT, Dec. 10  UBS became the latest Western bank to seek a financial lifeline from the cash-rich East on Monday, selling a more than 10 percent stake to investors from Singapore and the Middle East, as it wrote down a further $10 billion in the value of its mortgage-backed assets.

headline: Canada: Ottawa Mayor Charged
text: The police filed criminal charges against Mayor Larry O’Brien of Ottawa. Mr. O’Brien, a multimillionaire, is accused of offering an opponent cash and help with a federal appointment if he dropped out of the 2006 election. Legal scholars said Mr. O’Brien appeared to be the first mayor in modern Canadian history to face criminal charges related to his office.

headline: Police Tie Colorado Church Shootings to One Gunman
text: COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 10  Two deadly church shootings in Colorado over the weekend, 12 hours apart in different cities, were committed by the same man, though his motives remain unclear, the police said Monday.

headline: How a Higher Fare Affects Riders’ Choices: Not Much
text: As it sometimes does to commemorate the holiday season, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is getting ready to vote on a slate of fare increases.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Walter Mosley’s Three-Book Deal

headline: Bloomberg Travels to the Old World in Search of New Ideas
text: The last time a New York City mayor went to Beijing, nearly 28 years ago, he came back aglow with an idea that proved to be a bust almost as fast as you could say Deng Xiaoping. With the present mayor now making the rounds in China, who knows what we can expect?

headline: An Effort for Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Restores Sentencing Powers of Federal Judges
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Supreme Court today restored federal judges to their traditional central role in criminal sentencing.

headline: For a Few Dollars More, Dining Improves on Longer Flights
text: Now that the airlines have had a few years of experience selling food in the coach cabin instead of including it in the price of a ticket, they are applying the lessons they have learned to a new round of “buy on board” options.

headline: Australia Shocked by Case of Raped Indigenous Girl
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 11  Australia has been rocked by the case of a 10-year-old indigenous girl who was gang raped in her home community, and the revelation that her nine rapists had not been given prison sentences, in part because the judge found that the victim “probably agreed” to have sex.

headline: U.S. to Limit Flights at Kennedy
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Transportation Department plans to announce next week that it will impose limits on the number of flights landing and taking off at Kennedy International Airport in an effort to ease congestion and delays, according to officials involved in the deliberations.

headline: Voyager 2 Continues Its Trek
text: Nearly eight billion miles away, the Voyager 2 spacecraft has passed through a sonic boom of solar wind particles in the outer part of the solar system, NASA scientists said. On Aug. 30, the craft detected the speed of charged particles from the Sun passing it abruptly slowing from 700,000 miles per hour to 350,000 miles per hour. Over the next two days, the spacecraft passed through the boundary four more times as the solar system’s “termination shock” bubble expanded and contracted. Voyager 2’s twin, Voyager 1, passed through the boundary three years ago, in the opposite hemisphere and about a billion miles farther from the Sun. The new data confirm a squashed shape for the magnetic bubble enveloping the solar system, which has been pushed inward in the southern hemisphere. Both spacecraft will eventually exit the solar system, perhaps as soon as 7 to 10 years from now.

headline: Children Hurt in Pakistan Bombing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 10  A suicide bomb attack on a military truck carrying schoolchildren outside a Pakistani Air Force base in northwestern Pakistan wounded five children and two adults early on Monday, military officials said. The attack came a day after a suicide bombing in northwestern Pakistan killed six civilians and a police officer.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the merger of the video game developer Activision with the Vivendi Games unit of Vivendi Universal referred incorrectly to one of Activision’s game franchises. It develops games based on the Spider-Man movies, not the Superman movies.

headline: Somalia: Islamists Take Town
text: Bule Burte, a strategic town in central Somalia, has fallen out of government hands, residents said, and a militia allied to the Islamist movement is in control. The militia forced out government troops after a clan-related dispute. Somalia’s Islamist movement was defeated a year ago by Ethiopian troops but has been making a resurgence recently. Somalia’s 72-year-old president, Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, left a hospital in Kenya on Sunday for treatment in London.

headline: A Battle Fought in the Factories
text: WEIFANG, China, Dec. 8  When the aging state-owned Weifang East Steel Pipe factory here in China’s northern coastal plains fell into insolvency a few years ago, unpaid workers at first responded by blocking the factory gates and marching angrily on a nearby municipal building.

headline: A Satirical Spin on Stereotypes, at Home, Abroad and on Broadway
text: Form follows function so closely that it trips itself up in “Yellow Face,” David Henry Hwang’s lively, messy and provocative cultural self-portrait of a play. This exploration of one man’s personal and social identity crisis, which opened last night at the Public Theater, suffers from its own artistic identity crisis.

headline: New Jersey Moves to Abolish Death Penalty
text: TRENTON, Dec. 10  The New Jersey Senate voted Monday to make the state the first in the country to repeal the death penalty since the United States Supreme Court allowed executions to resume in 1976 and established the nation’s current system of capital punishment.

headline: Paris Flocks to a Cunningham Revival: Works That Remain Fresh
text: PARIS, Dec. 10  Among the American cultural phenomena that the French have taken to their collective heart (le jazz hot, le film noir, etc.), surely nothing is more surprising than the success of the choreographer Merce Cunningham over several decades. His company visits Paris more often than any other city in the world, gives more performances here than anywhere else and tours extensively around the French provinces. In his home city, New York, empty seats are not unusual; in London it is only occasionally impossible to obtain a ticket for a Cunningham performance.

headline: One ‘Family Man’ vs. Another
text: This television advertisement for Mitt Romney, his first that directly takes on a Republican rival  in this case, Mike Huckabee  will start running in Iowa on Tuesday.

headline: Arsenal, the One in Argentina, Wins a Title
text: Arsenal has finally won a major continental competition. No, not that Arsenal, the fabled Gunners who call north London home. But Arsenal de Sarandí of Avellaneda, Argentina.

headline: Britain: ‘Missing’ Man’s Wife Charged
text: John Darwin, the 57-year-old man who walked into a London police station this month claiming amnesia, more than five years after he was presumed to have drowned in a kayaking accident in the North Sea, appeared in court on fraud charges and was remanded into custody. The charges involved obtaining an insurance payout by faking his death and obtaining a British passport in an assumed name. At the court in Hartlepool, his wife, Anne, 55, was charged separately with two counts of deception involving more than $330,000 in insurance claims. She flew back to Britain on Sunday after leaving the couple’s hideaway apartment in Panama. Before her arrest at Manchester Airport, she gave The Daily Mail a tearful account of their secret life. She said that her husband went missing after talking of clearing heavy debts by faking his death and that she believed him dead until he reappeared at their home 11 months after his smashed kayak was found on a beach near Hartlepool. She said she then joined him in an elaborate scam, rejoining him at home on the day she persuaded an inquest to declare him formally dead. “You tell one lie and you had to tell another one to cover up for the first one, and it all just snowballed,” she said.

headline: Canadian Exchanges Plan to Merge
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 10  A proposed merger announced Monday between the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Montreal Exchange, valued at $1.3 billion, was quickly questioned by a large institutional investor in Quebec.

headline: Choreographers Stretch Visions in and Out of the Box
text: Showcases can be deadly, but the selection of choreographers for the NuDance Festival on Saturday night at Theater of the Riverside Church was unusually good. The artists came from a wide range of backgrounds, including Broadway, mainstream modern dance and hip-hop. Nearly everyone had something distinctively personal to say, for the most part stylistically. The festival, a platform for new and midcareer artists, summoned memories of the theater’s history as a major presenter of dance.

headline: Patterns: Parkinson’s Raises Risk of Depression in Relatives
text: First-degree relatives  parents, siblings and children  of people with Parkinson’s disease are about 50 percent more likely than relatives of healthy people to suffer depression or anxiety, a new study reports.

headline: Germany: Broadcaster Stake Sold
text: Axel Springer, the European newspaper publisher, agreed to sell its 12 percent stake in the broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media to the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Permira Advisers for 509.4 million euros ($749.5 million). Kohlberg Kravis, based in New York, and Permira, based in London, are paying an average of 19.40 euros a share for the Springer stake. The two companies agreed last December to acquire 50.5 percent of ProSiebenSat.1 for 3.1 billion euros. Axel Springer is based in Hamburg, Germany.

headline: Commuter Jet and Boeing 747 in Near Miss
text: A 37-seat commuter jet arriving at Kennedy Airport nearly collided with a Boeing 747 cargo jet on Sunday afternoon when the Boeing, which was supposed to land on a perpendicular runway, failed to do so and continued across the smaller jet’s path, controllers at the airport’s tower said yesterday.

headline: Still Fighting Cancer, Yow Is Back on the Court
text: RALEIGH, N.C.  The hair that fell out during chemotherapy treatments has grown back and now Kay Yow has a short gray look as she coaches the North Carolina State women’s basketball team.

headline: A Place to Play With Your Old Friends
text: The holidays are a time for nostalgia. For film buffs that inevitably means “It’s a Wonderful Life.” For romantics that may mean reminiscing about an old flame. For a gamer, that could mean a wistful recollection of that time when your mastery of Centipede made you the king of the arcade or the winter of 1982 when your skills at Pitfall! on your buddy’s faux-wood-paneled Atari 2600 made you the lord of the shag-carpeted living room.

headline: New Jersey Nears Repeal of Death Penalty
text: TRENTON, Dec. 10  The New Jersey Senate voted Monday to make the state the first in the country to repeal the death penalty since 1976, when the United States Supreme Court set guidelines for the nation’s current system of capital punishment.

headline: Nationals Replace Schneider With Lo Duca
text: Catcher Paul Lo Duca may want to find out if Brian Schneider left any shin guards or chest protectors behind with the Washington Nationals. Ditto for Schneider with Lo Duca and the Mets.

headline: Excerpts From an Interview With Dmitri A. Medvedev
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 10  Last month, First Deputy Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev, who was endorsed today by President Vladimir V. Putin to be Russia’s next president, met with foreign journalists. Here are excerpts from his comments during the meeting, as translated by The New York Times:

headline: Starting the Peace Process
text: Israelis and Palestinians are supposed to begin serious negotiations tomorrow after last month’s long-on-optics, short-on-specifics Annapolis peace meeting. Despite all the smiles and handshakes, both sides went home and fell back into some familiar, counterproductive patterns.

headline: Hong Kong Exchange Looks to Trade Smog Rights
text: HONG KONG, Dec. 11  As this city struggles under a daily cloud of noxious fumes from local traffic and nearby factories in mainland China, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange is considering using its financial muscle as part of a solution.

headline: For Tortured Russian Poet, a Life of Drama and Despair
text: The Russian poet Marina Tsvetayeva endured and indulged in a life of high drama. One of her young daughters died of starvation during the famine that followed the Russian Revolution. A lover of both men and women, she followed her White Russian husband into exile in Europe, then returned after he was accused of changing sides and spying for the Soviets. Impoverished and spied on by Soviet secret agents, she hanged herself in 1941.

headline: Stop Stalling on Judicial Raises
text: New York was once a national leader in judicial compensation. Now, it ranks 49th among the 50 states when salaries are adjusted for the cost of living, and the last pay increase was in 1999.

headline: Gazans’ Passage to Mecca Seen as an Insult to Abbas
text: JERUSALEM, Dec. 10  What appeared to have been a decision by Egypt and Saudi Arabia to cooperate with Hamas rather than with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, in allowing 2,000 people to leave Gaza last week for a pilgrimage to Mecca is causing friction in Palestinian, Israeli and Western circles.

headline: Always On
text: Q. Many devices that are “always on” while seemingly “off” draw power so that they can spring into action on demand. How much electricity does a television, for example, use when plugged in but not turned on?

headline: Drivers and Autopilots (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Divided, France Welcomes and Condemns Qaddafi
text: PARIS, Dec. 10  Redemption, at last, seems to have come for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 5-9 with 1,133 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,028 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Ask.com Puts a Bet on Privacy
text: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 10  Will privacy sell?

headline: Bush Adviser Is Seen as Force in Spending Impasse
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  Ed Gillespie made a name for himself in 1994 as a sharp-tongued pitchman for the Contract With America, the conservative Republican manifesto that catapulted his boss, Dick Armey, to power. But when Republicans shut down the government in a spending clash with President Bill Clinton, Mr. Gillespie warned it was the wrong battle to pick.

headline: An 8-Second Ride Lures Sponsors Beyond the Rodeo
text: JUSTIN McBRIDE and Adriano Moraes are hardly household names, but advertisers are betting that these bull riders  who compete for prize money by trying to stay on a bucking bull for eight seconds  could represent the next big thing in sports sponsorship.

headline: Stanton Wheeler, 77, a Yale Law Professor, Dies
text: Stanton Wheeler, a professor at Yale Law School who made notable studies of white-collar crime, prison systems and the way judges think but who was not a lawyer, died on Friday in New Haven. He was 77 and lived in Branford, Conn.

headline: El Salvador: Iraq Mission Renewed
text: President Elías Antonio Saca said El Salvador would send a 10th contingent of 280 soldiers to Iraq next year to help with aid and reconstruction efforts there, according to The Associated Press. El Salvador, which has had troops in Iraq since 2003, is the only country in Latin America that has maintained such a deployment.

headline: When Employees Sue
text: Yes, it is a cliché. And no, the boss does not always act as if it were true, but employees really can be a company’s most important asset.

headline: In Duck Blinds, Visions of Global Warming
text: RICH HILL, Mo.  After 32 years of hunting ducks in the wetlands of Missouri, Chuck Geier knows when temperatures will drop and waters will freeze. That means he also knows when the birds will fly and hunting will be best.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The About New York column in some editions on Saturday, about the ways that digital technology has transformed crime investigations, gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the given name of a man who used an MP3 player to secretly record his interrogation by a city police officer after a shooting in the Bronx in 2005. He is Erik Crespo, not Eric.

headline: Jailed Rapist Confesses to Murders 30 Years Ago
text: CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo., Dec. 10  A convicted rapist who has been in and out of prisons for decades has confessed to nine murders, including those of five women that terrorized this city along the Mississippi 30 years ago.

headline: Caution: Art Afoot
text: LONDON, Dec. 8  As contemporary art often does, the giant crack in the floor at the Tate Modern here inspires different responses from different people.

headline: Another Movement of Musical Diplomacy
text: If North Korea keeps its promises, potentially millions of its isolated, tightly controlled citizens are likely to hear their national anthem played on the radio by the New York Philharmonic. And then they will hear “The Star-Spangled Banner,” a quintessential American symbol, in a place long subjected to anti-American propaganda.

headline: Foreign Aid Strategies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Freelancers Walk Out at MTV Networks
text: Scores of workers from MTV Networks walked off the job yesterday afternoon, filling the sidewalk outside the headquarters of its corporate parent, Viacom, to protest recent changes in benefits.

headline: OSHA Investigates Ballet Dancers Fall
text: The Atlanta Ballet is under investigation by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration of the United States Department of Labor after a 17-year-old dancer wearing a panda costume fell about 12 feet into the orchestra pit last week during a performance of “The Nutcracker” at the Fox Theater in Atlanta, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported. The dancer, Leah Boresow, a high school senior, plunged into the empty orchestra pit and suffered serious injuries. She underwent spinal surgery on Wednesday and was reported to be in critical but stable condition at the Atlanta Medical Center, the Atlanta Ballet said in a statement. Andre Richards, director of the Atlanta West Office of OSHA, said, “Anytime we see a high-profile situation such as that, normally what we do is initiate an inspection.” He added, “We will probably take a look at the costume to see what level of vision that person had.” He said a week or two might pass before the inspector’s report would be available and any citations might be issued. Jeff Al-Mashat, a spokesman for the ballet, said precautions would be taken to keep the panda dancers safe for the remaining run of the ballet, continuing through Dec. 29. The Journal-Constitution reported that two days before her fall, Ms. Boresow told friends at Chattahoochee High School that she was concerned that she might fall off the stage because of the costume, which offered limited sight through a hole in the nose of the panda head.

headline: Scientists Blend Materials to Create Oil-Repellent Surfaces
text: Water has many remarkable properties, not the least of which is its high surface tension. That makes water-repellent materials fairly common. The surface tension makes water bead up.

headline: The Soul of a New Vaccine
text: ROCKVILLE, Md.  The sign on the wall reads “Emergency Response Procedures for a Mosquito Release.”

headline: From a Japanese Satellite, Here Comes the Sun
text: Telescopes aboard the Hinode satellite, launched by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency in September 2006, have been returning some of their first results, featured in the current issue of Science. Left, a photo in visible light shows threadlike features in a prominence on the Sun's surface. Right, an image of Mercury in transit across the disk of the Sun.

headline: Gas Terminal Proposed Off New Jersey
text: Exxon Mobil said today that it plans to build a $1 billion floating natural-gas terminal about 20 miles off the New Jersey coast, a move it thinks could help deflect potential opposition because of the project’s distance from shore.

headline: Another Loss, but a New Scapegoat: The Fans
text: They played a meaningful fourth quarter at Madison Square Garden on Monday, and given the current ill state of affairs, this counted as progress.

headline: Killer Who Escaped From Mental Hospital Commits Suicide After Recapture
text: A mentally disturbed killer who escaped from a troubled New Jersey psychiatric hospital on Sunday and was captured hours later killed himself early yesterday, while he was supposed to be under the supervision of the hospital’s staff, state officials said.

headline: Taliban Loses Grip on Last Major Town
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Dec. 10  Afghan and NATO troops retook the town of Musa Qala in southern Afghanistan on Monday, forcing the Taliban to withdraw from the only sizable town they hold in the country, Afghan and NATO officials said. There was no clear picture of casualties, but the Taliban and civilians said there had been heavy bombardment overnight.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the conviction of a Canadian pig farmer in the deaths of six women in Vancouver misstated the neighborhood from which they and other women who worked as prostitutes had vanished over a 19-year period. It is the Downtown Eastside, not the Lower Eastside.

headline: Onscreen Villain Makes Doctors Wince
text: The most horrifying moment in the new movie “Awake” occurs 34 minutes into the film, when the protagonist (Hayden Christensen) feels the scalpel cutting into his chest. As his surgeon (Terrence Howard) deepens the incision, the audience can hear the patient’s screams of agony, while the characters onscreen see only a man lying on an operating table, seemingly unconscious.

headline: Text of Federal Reserve Statement
text: Here is the text of the statement from the Federal Reserve’s policy-setting committee, announcing a quarter-point reduction in benchmark interest rates.

headline: Concert Dates
text: The seventh annual Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival will take place from June 12 through 15 on its usual site, a 700-acre farm in Manchester, Tenn., 60 miles southeast of Nashville. ... Bruce Springsteen and his E Street Band will promote his new album, “Magic,” in concerts on July 27, 28 and 31 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., Reuters reported. Tickets go on sale on Dec. 15.

headline: Worker Who Fell 47 Stories Still Critical
text: The window washer who survived a 47-story plunge when his scaffold collapsed on Friday remained in critical condition yesterday as relatives gathered to mourn his younger brother, who was working with him and died in the fall.

headline: U.S. Joins Overseas Adoption Overhaul Plan
text: The United States, the world leader in international adoptions, will join more than 70 nations committed to standardizing policies, procedures and safeguards to reduce corruption in the largely unregulated adoption marketplace.

headline: Rising Food and Fuel Costs Spur Inflation in China
text: HONG KONG, Dec. 11  Inflation accelerated further in China last month, government statisticians announced on Tuesday, as rising costs for food and fuel are now sending prices up briskly across Asia.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review on Saturday about a concert version of Philip Glass’s “Einstein on the Beach,” at Carnegie Hall, misdentified the tenor saxophone soloist in the “Building/Train” section. It was Andrew Sterman  not David Crowell, another saxophonist who performed in the concert.

headline: 2 Singapore Funds Invest and Recruit Talent Abroad
text: SINGAPORE, Dec. 10  From its birth in 1981 with just two employees, the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation has become one of the world’s largest sovereign funds, managing more than $100 billion in assets, with 900 employees in eight offices around the world. It is larger even than Temasek Holdings, the government’s better-known fund.

headline: Rehab Plan Announced for N.F.L.’s Ex-Players
text: The National Football League and the players union announced a program yesterday that will pay part or all of the costs for joint-replacement surgery for former players.

headline: Walter Mosleys Three-Book Deal
text: The novelist Walter Mosley has signed a three-book deal with Riverhead Books, a unit of Penguin Group, to publish a literary novel and two books in a new mystery series featuring Leonid McGill, an African-American detective in New York City who first appeared in a short story included in “Best American Mystery Stories of 2006.” In an interview Mr. Mosley, right, said that the new character “couldn’t get more different from Easy Rawlins if you tried.” (He was referring to the detective who has appeared in 11 of his 27 books.) The new series, Mr. Mosley said, would be “very noir and contemporary and New York.” He has already completed the literary novel “Last Days of Ptolemy Grey,” about the relationship between an old African-American man with dementia and a 17-year-old girl. Sean McDonald, executive editor at Riverhead, acquired world rights to the three books from Gloria Loomis, Mr. Mosley’s agent. The first book in the new mystery series will be published in 2009.

headline: Bodies Twisting Into Pretzels, and Human Stacking Blocks
text: The New Shanghai Circus has a neat trick of cutting the music during its most astonishing feats, so that the soundtrack becomes the “oohs,” “ahs” and “Oh, my Gods!” from the stunned audience. At least that was how it went on a Sunday afternoon at the family-oriented New Victory Theater, where the company is performing.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,725,844.05

headline: Michael Shaheen Jr., Top Justice Dept. Official, Dies at 67
text: Michael E. Shaheen Jr., who spent 22 years as head of the Justice Department’s internal investigations office, sometimes issuing rebukes of perceived ethical lapses by the nation’s highest officials, died Nov. 29 at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 67.

headline: Justices Restore Judges’ Control Over Sentencing
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  The Supreme Court on Monday restored federal judges to their traditional central role in criminal sentencing.

headline: Defendant’s Son on Stand in Killing of L.I. Teenager
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Dec. 10  A young man at the center of a racially charged manslaughter case on Long Island took the stand Monday in Suffolk County Criminal Court here and told a jury that on Aug. 9, 2006, a group of white teenagers screeched up to his house and screamed profanities and anti-black epithets.

headline: Given the Latitude to Show Leniency, Judges May Not
text: It is one thing to have power, and another to use it.

headline: A Lesson to Be Learned, and Degrees to Be Earned
text: In Harlem yesterday, a long way from a federal courthouse in Richmond, Va., the news on Michael Vick reached a former N.F.L. wide receiver named Duke Fergerson, who immediately did the depressing math.

headline: Roles Swap in Argentina’s Palace as First Lady Takes Over
text: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10  Néstor Kirchner, Argentina’s most popular president in decades, draped the light-blue-and-white sash over the shoulder of his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, on Monday, officially passing power to the first woman to be elected Argentina’s leader in its 191-year history.

headline: When Removing One Predator Harms the Prey
text: The predator-prey relationship is simple, right? If a predator is around, that is bad for the prey, and if the predator is removed, that is good for the prey.

headline: Office-Building Workers Threaten to Strike on New Year’s Day
text: With the city’s office-building market booming year after year, the janitors, doormen and elevator operators who keep those buildings running want their share.

headline: Cuba: U.N. Rights Pacts to Be Signed
text: Foreign Minister Felipe Pérez Roque said Cuba would sign the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, in force since 1976. Yesterday was International Human Rights Day, which he said Cuba celebrated “holding its head high,” according to Agence France-Presse. In a nearby Havana square, government supporters were shoving and shouting at about a dozen dissidents who had held a protest calling for improved human rights on the island.

headline: Vick Receives 23 Months and a Lecture
text: RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 10  Michael Vick, the former Atlanta Falcons star who has traded his No. 7 jersey for a black-and-white-striped jail uniform, stood expressionless in a federal courtroom Monday and apologized to the court and his family for his involvement in a dogfighting ring. But for the judge about to decide Vick’s fate, those words were not enough.

headline: Garden Settles Harassment Case for $11.5 Million
text: Three days before a federal judge was to hear testimony on Anucha Browne Sanders’s claim for compensatory damages against Madison Square Garden, the parties settled the sexual harassment case yesterday and ended all appeals.

headline: In the Crowded Sky, Change Is Approaching
text: IT’S a challenging time to be writing about air travel. It’s an even more challenging time to be reading about it.

headline: An Ancient Medicine (Enjoy in Moderation)
text: Every year, the average American adult drinks the equivalent of 38 six-packs of beer, a dozen bottles of wine and two quarts of distilled spirits like gin, rum, single malt Scotch, or vodka that aspires to single malt status through the addition of flavors normally associated with yogurt or bubble bath.

headline: China: An Oil Deal With Iran
text: The China Petrochemical Corporation, known as Sinopec, signed a $2 billion agreement to develop Iran’s Yadavaran oil field. The field would produce 85,000 barrels a day in four years and an additional 100,000 barrels a day three years after that, China’s official Xinhua news agency reported, citing the Iranian oil minister, Gholam Hossein Nozari, above.

headline: C.I.A. Chief Says Others Decided Fate of Video
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, distanced himself today from the decision to record and subsequently destroy hundreds of hours of video footage taken during the interrogations of senior Al Qaeda captives.

headline: Harvard to Aid Students High in Middle Class
text: BOSTON, Dec. 10  Harvard University announced on Monday that it would significantly increase the financial aid it offered to middle-class and upper-middle-class students, seeking to allay concerns that elite colleges are becoming too expensive for even relatively well-off families.

headline: David H. Shepard, 84, Dies; Optical Reader Inventor
text: David H. Shepard, who in his attic invented one of the first machines that could read, and then, to facilitate its interpreting of credit-card receipts, came up with the near-rectilinear font still used for the cards’ numbers, died on Nov. 24 in San Diego. He was 84.

headline: Disabled, and Waiting for Justice
text: We know what is behind President Bush’s sudden enthusiasm for fiscal discipline after years of running up deficits and debt: political posturing, just in time for the 2008 election. But one should not forget the damage that his administration has also inflicted by shortchanging important domestic programs in favor of tax cuts for the wealthy and his never-ending Iraq war.

headline: Mental Reserves Keep Brains Agile
text: My husband, at 74, is the baby of his bridge group, which includes a woman of 85 and a man of 89. This challenging game demands an excellent memory (for bids, cards played, rules and so on) and an ability to think strategically and read subtle psychological cues. Never having had a head for cards, I continue to be amazed by the mental agility of these septua- and octogenarians.

headline: Living With Perfection (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Selection Spurred Recent Evolution, Researchers Say
text: Researchers analyzing variation in the human genome have concluded that human evolution accelerated enormously in the last 40,000 years under the force of natural selection.

headline: Disputed in Iraq, Blackwater Now Splits California Town
text: POTRERO, Calif.  The scandal in Iraq involving Blackwater, the private security firm, is a world away from this tiny town near the Mexican border. But five members of the community’s planning group are expected to lose their posts on Tuesday for approving a Blackwater training camp on an old chicken farm here.

headline: Making Art Onstage Near Art on the Walls
text: Choreographers are enamored of museums and art galleries, and while such envy can seem regressive, their outlook is certainly understandable. It’s about wealth and sustainability, two obvious qualities dance will probably never achieve. Money is always in short supply, and there’s no such thing as sustainability in dance; that elusiveness is what makes it so fascinating.

headline: Cures for Forgetfulness (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gore Urges Bold Moves in Nobel Speech
text: OSLO, Dec. 10  He has said it again and again, with increasing urgency, to anyone who will listen. And on Monday, former Vice President Al Gore used the occasion of his 2007 Nobel Peace Prize lecture here to tell the world in powerful, stark language: Climate change is a “real, rising, imminent and universal” threat to the future of the Earth.

headline: After 8 Years in Limbo, Frustrated Kosovo Awaits Its Future
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Dec. 10  As the deadline for a negotiated agreement on Kosovo’s future expired Monday without a settlement, several thousand protesters took to the streets of this war-ravaged capital, waving Albanian and American flags and chanting, “Independence now!”

headline: Monday Injury Roundup: Wounded Chargers
text: * The Chargers were particularly banged up on Sunday. Linebacker Shawne Merriman (sprained knee) and fullback Lorenzo Neal (broken leg) will miss at least Sunday’s game against Detroit. Quarterback Philip Rivers also has a sprained knee and his status for Sunday is uncertain.

headline: 'La Virgin de Guadalupe, Dios Inantzin'
text: Images from the Latino Theater Company's production.

headline: $1.6 Million Homes
text: Properties on the market in California, Tennessee and New Mexico.

headline: MBIA’s Capital Move May Force Rival to Do the Same
text: MBIA‘s decision to raise up to $1 billion in new capital and set aside at least $500 million to cover expected mortgage-related losses puts pressure on rival bond insurers to do the same, analysts said on Monday.

headline: Insitu Flies Off With $25 Million
text: An unmanned aircraft system developer, Insitu, is flying high with another $25 million in Series D venture capital funding. Battery Ventures led the insider round, with contributions from Second Avenue Partners and Pteranodon Ventures.

headline: Phoenix Equity Packs Off Radley and Banks
text: Just in time for the Christmas retail season, a London buyout shop, Phoenix Equity Partners, has sold its women’s handbag and branded luggage business, Radley + Company, and its fashion retail chain, Bank Stores Holdings for a combined 149.5 million pounds ($303.6 million).

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Sells Argillon for $314 Million
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Monday to sell a German catalysts and ceramic materials producer, Argillon to a British catalysts and ceramic materials group, Johnson Matthey for 214 million euros ($314 million), marking a final exit from a group of companies it bought from Siemens in 2002.

headline: Employees Sue Bank of Nova Scotia in Overtime Dispute
text: The Bank of Nova Scotia is the latest bank to be targeted by a lawsuit that alleges that bank employees have been discouraged from claiming over time pay for extra work.

headline: EdgeCast Teams Up With Disney for $6 Million
text: A rich media content delivery network, EdgeCast Networks, announced the closing of a $6 million Series B financing on Monday. But what may be more important to the company is that the capital comes from Steamboat Ventures, the venture capital arm of Walt Disney, and a strong potential network partner.

headline: Canada’s Agrium to Raise $1.25 Billon in Offering
text: A Canadian fertilizer and seed producer, Agrium, will raise $1.25 billion in an equity financing to support the company’s $2.65 billion takeover of UAP Holding.

headline: ‘Keep Santa Fat!’
text: As if he doesn’t have enough to occupy him, Santa is a multi-purpose pawn in a PR war. He’s the focus of a slick petition campaign against the food police’s attack on his girth. The “fat Santa” backers say their campaign will help America’s Second Harvest:

headline: Libya Touts Its Own Sovereign Wealth Fund
text: It looks like Libya is gearing up to join the sovereign wealth party sweeping Asia and the Middle East.

headline: STMicro to Snap Up Genesis for $336 Million
text: STMicroelectronics, Europe’s largest semiconductor maker, said Tuesday that it would acquire a video-chip maker, Genesis Microchip, for $336 million.

headline: ArcelorMittal Buys Argentina’s Largest Steel Distributor
text: The steelmaker ArcelorMittal added another purchase to its South American buying spree on Tuesday, acquiring Argentina’s largest steel distributor M.T. Majdalani.

headline: Reckitt Coughs Up $2.3 Billion for Adams Respiratory
text: Britain’s Reckitt Benckiser, the world’s largest household products manufacturer, agreed Monday to buy a cough and congestion medicine group, Adams Respiratory Therapeutics, for $60 a share, or $2.3 billion,

headline: Are You a Grinch or a Giver?
text: It’s that time of year when friends and family take part in that annual holiday ritual — debating the merits of the gift exchange.

headline: Quebec Pension Fund Questions Exchange Merger
text: A proposed merger announced Monday between the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange and the Montreal Exchange, valued at $1.3 billion, was quickly questioned by a large institutional investor in Quebec.

headline: Venture Cash Puts L.A. in Party Mood
text: With high-tech-focused venture capital pouring into Southern California, the party scene is apparently heating up among the region’s entrepreneurs. Late last year, the region bypassed New England to rank second in the United States — after Silicon Valley — for tech investment.

headline: Greenlight Capital Has No Plans for I.P.O.
text: Greenlight Capital‘s president, David Einhorn, said at a conference Monday that his hedge-fund firm had no plans to seek capital from outside investors, as some of its peers have done.

headline: Consortium Pulls Plug on Nufarm Deal
text: A Chinese-led consortium that includes the buyout giant the Blackstone Group has withdrawn from the bidding for an Australian crop chemical company, Nufarm, as a result of time constraints, despite winning exclusive access to the company’s books.

headline: British Hedge Fund Posts 41% Return, Report Says
text: Sloane Robinson, a British hedge fund manager, has emerged as one of the top performers in Europe this year with its oldest fund generating a return of more than 40 percent, according to Financial News.

headline: NetSuite Begins Public Stock Offering With a Dutch Auction
text: NetSuite on Monday said it has begun the auction portion of its initial public offering, giving individual investors rather than underwriters the opportunity to set its opening stock price.

headline: Lacoste Parent Makes Hostile Bid for Gant
text: Maus Frères, Switzerland’s fourth largest clothes retailer and the owner of the Lacoste brand, began a hostile 5.2 billion Swedish kroner ($813 million) takeover bid on Tuesday for Gant, a Swedish clothes retailer with more than 300 stores around the world.

headline: Mortgage Crisis Forces BofA Fund to Close
text: Losses on investments weakened by the deepening housing crisis have forced the Bank of America to close a multibillion-dollar high-yield fund, the largest of its kind, after wealthy investors withdrew billions of dollars in assets.

headline: Xstrata Said to Court Suitors
text: Xstrata, the world’s sixth-largest mining company, is open to discussions with potential suitors, including Vale of Brazil and Anglo American, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Cardtronics Cuts Shares and Price in Initial Offering
text: Cardtronics, an operator of automated teller machines, cut the size of its initial public offering and lowered the estimated price range of the shares, a regulatory filing showed.

headline: Washington Mutual Cutting Dividend and Jobs
text: Washington Mutual, one of the country’s largest lenders, said Monday that it would exit the subprime lending business, cut its dividend and eliminate 3,150 jobs.

headline: Sears Gets a Look at Restoration’s Books
text: Sears Holdings can examine Restoration Hardware‘s confidential financial data after agreeing not to solicit investors to sell their Restoration shares before a deadline for bids expires Thursday.

headline: Black Sentenced to 6 and 1/2 Years in Prison
text: In the months since his convictions in July on fraud and obstruction of justice charges, Conrad M. Black, the fallen press baron who once presided over the world’s third-largest newspaper empire, was not above poking fun at himself as he waited to see how long he would spend in prison.

headline: 2 Singapore Funds Invest and Recruit Talent Abroad
text: From its birth in 1981 with just two employees, the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation has become one of the world’s largest sovereign funds, managing more than $100 billion in assets, with 900 employees in eight offices around the world. It is larger even than Temasek Holdings, the government’s better-known fund.

headline: RAB Capital Warns Investors on Profits
text: RAB Capital, the British hedge fund and the second-largest shareholder in Northern Rock, let its shareholders know that it might not best last year’s results because of November’s market problems.

headline: ‘Axis of Eh?’
text: More “late night” jokes from readers:

headline: Absolut Parent to Be Sold Next Year, Sweden Says
text: The maker of Absolut vodka, Vin & Sprit will be sold next year via auction, the Swedish government said on Tuesday, and could fetch $6 billion to $7 billion in what would be the country’s biggest privatization ever.

headline: The Dangers of Generalizing About the Generations
text: When I wrote last week’s post What the Gen Y Worker Wants, I expected to get a lot more criticism than I did for making generalizations about different demographic groups. I got some. I also got criticism for even suggesting that it is a strong job market. One commenter, who identified himself as a “business professor at a mid-range college,” questioned the very idea students feel they have a lot of choices in today’s job market by saying that most of his students “really just want to get a job so they can start paying for their crushing student loans.”

headline: TPG’s Bonderman, Still Reluctant to Go Public
text: The Blackstone Group has done it. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has filed to do it. And the Carlyle Group is expected to do it.

headline: Rio Tells BHP to Put Up or Shut Up
text: The Rio Tinto Group, the mining company, said Tuesday that it had asked British regulators to force its competitor BHP Billiton to turn its $139 billion takeover proposal into a formal bid or to drop the offer.

headline: For the Moment | The Costume Institute’s Harold Koda and Andrew Bolton
text: Bolton, left, and Koda(Karen Willis)

headline: Speech by Dmitri A. Medvedev
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 11 – Following is the text of the address today by Dmitri A. Medvedev, in which he announced that he intended to nominate President Vladimir V. Putin to be prime minister after the next presidential election, as translated by The New York Times.

headline: Energy, an Ingredient in Local Food and Global Food
text: When I find time to read instead of report and write, I’m usually catching up on the fine work of my colleagues and other journalists days behind the datelines. As an editor for The Times once said, you can either write for the paper or read it, but you can’t do a good job of both.

headline: FFSA prize ceremony – and a homecoming for Bourdais
text: There has been a lot of coverage in the English language of the Autosport awards last weekend, and rightly so. But an exotic alternative – if you live on the continent and dislike taking the Eurostar – was the ceremony last night for the French automobile racing federation (the Federation Francaise du Sport Automobile, or FFSA). It took place in the plush 18th Century concert hall called the Casino de Paris, and was attended by hundreds of people, including racers and team members from every level in France from go-karting up to Formula One.

headline: The Early Word: Storming Iowa
text: DES MOINES — We’re using split-screens today, one watching an ice storm as it moves its way through the Midwest and possibly complicates the travel plans of candidates, and the other attuned to the presidential campaign as it pops up and down on the television during the early morning news here. The Republican candidates are beginning to return here in preparation for their debate on Wednesday; the Democrats’ turn comes on Thursday — and it’s the last debate in this state before the Jan. 3 caucuses.

headline: Choice Picks
text: The nominations for the Critics’ Choice Award — the annual bonbons bestowed by the Broadcast Film Critics — were announced this morning. The by-now usual suspects make an appearance, although Amy Adams of “Enchanted,” the much attended but little recognized fairy tale, gets some love as well.

headline: Don’t Like Congestion Pricing? Consider These Alternatives
text: In a front-page article, William Neuman examines some of the more unusual ideas being considered by the state commission studying how to mitigate traffic congestion in Manhattan. The ideas include banning the hailing of cabs in Manhattan below 86th Street, and instead installing taxi stands where cabs would be allowed to pick up passengers only at these stands scattered throughout the area; imposing license-plate rationing, under which, say, drivers with a license plate ending in 5 would be prohibited from entering the busiest parts of Manhattan on the 5th, the 15th or the 25th of every month; and significantly raising the cost of street parking, which could cost as much as parking in a garage.

headline: In Papers, Russia’s 2008 Campaign Is Already Over
text: The Russian presidential campaign has ended before it began. That seems to be the dominant opinion of the Russian news media, a day after President Vladimir Putin endorsed the candidacy of his slight, soft-spoken protégé, Dmitri Medvedev, to succeed him in the country’s top office.

headline: No Pain, No Gain
text: “A leader of the CIA team that captured the first major Al Qaeda figure, Abu Zubaydah, says subjecting him to waterboarding was torture but necessary,” reports ABC News, in a pretty substantial scoop. “In the first public comment by any CIA officer involved in handling high-value al Qaeda targets, John Kiriakou, now retired, said the technique broke Zubaydah in less than 35 seconds.”

headline: Fine Print | Richard Avedon Monograph
text: Bob Dylan, 1965, and Avedon in a 1980 self-portrait.

headline: Defending the Honor of the Globes
text: Out here in the kudosphere, we like to have it both ways. We pay slavish attention to the Golden Globes, teasing apart their nominations, which will be out this Thursday, for any hint of heat or light. But at the same time, the Globes become a piñata, whacked over and over for alleged hackery and excessive fanboy tendencies.

headline: The First Orders Arrive for Chocolate Beta Bars
text: Wired co-founder Louis Rossetto‘s new chocolate company, TCHO, started filling local orders for its “beta bars” today, and dozens of people from the San Francisco Bay Area placed orders for hundreds of them.

headline: No Accounting for Taste
text: Speaking of snot-nose critics, Richard Corliss does some deprogramming after the New York Film Critics Circle and wonders why those smartypants always gotta be difficult when it comes to handing out hardware. Movies that won over critics and fans alike, like Judd Apatow’s “Knocked Up” and “Superbad,” get bupkes, while “There Will Be Blood” is showered with praise. No wonder the Oscars are posting rugged audience numbers, he says:

headline: The Bagger’s Unholy Love Child
text: The Bagger has to admit to having a soft spot for The Reeler, Stu VanAirsdale’s whip-smart, towel-snap of an NYC film site. Sure, there are days when it can read like you got trapped on a small boat with the all-knowing grad student from hell, but he and his gang know their stuff and strut it. Nothing is sacred and all cows are in danger. The Bagger, incidentally, has been hailed as the Father of the Reeler, but his paternity has not entitled him to much consideration.

headline: Red Bulls Closing In on New Coach
text: Nothing is set, but the Red Bulls moved a step closer to hiring a new coach when Juan Carlos Osorio, the favored replacement for Bruce Arena, resigned as coach of the Chicago Fire.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “There was nothing too exciting this time. Rex Reed made a vomiting noise the first time there was a vote for Francis Coppola’s ‘Youth Without Youth,’ which prompted NYFCC chief Stephen Whitty to quip, ‘And a special award to Rex for sitting through it.’” — Jeffrey Wells on the New York critics’ award discussion.

headline: Banks and Buyout Firms, Together Again
text: Way back in 2004, there was lots of angst on Wall Street about the potential conflicts between private equity funds and investment banks. Many firms, including Morgan Stanley and J.P. Morgan Chase, decided the best strategy to ease clients’ concerns was to cut their buyout arms loose.

headline: This Just In
text: The firestorm of results from various critics’ covens will barely abate and then it will be time to punch in on Golden Globe nominations. Being on Oscar patrol is like being part of a national political campaign; incremental data comes in day after day and is beaten to a pulp by far too many prognosticators. But when it is all done, what pops out is a best picture, not a leader of the free world.

headline: Pavano, New Agent Says, May Stay With Yankees
text: Tom O’Connell has been an agent for 10 years, and he represents about 60 baseball players, mostly in the minor leagues. He may have just met his toughest challenge.

headline: Mets Happy With Pitching Staff
text: The Mets have done nothing so far this off-season to bolster their starting pitching staff, which appears to need help. And that situation may not change.

headline: Iowa Campaigns Fall Victim to Storm
text: IOWA CITY – ­ It is looking like a snow day on the campaign trail in Iowa.

headline: The Surprising Success of an Ultra-Cheap Car
text: PARIS — Every morning my quiet neighborhood in Paris springs to life. And I jump for cover.

headline: Ask About New York’s Ethnic Neighborhoods
text: Joseph Berger, an education and regional columnist for The New York Times, is taking questions from City Room readers this week about New York City’s ethnic and immigrant neighborhoods.

headline: Strikers Picket ‘The View’
text: Striking members of the Writers Guild of America East picketed outside of the ABC Daytime studios on the Upper West Side of Manhattan today beginning at 9:15 a.m. (almost an hour earlier than most days) in order to catch audience members who were arriving to see the popular morning talk show “The View.”

headline: On Bonuses, Banks Face a Balancing Act
text: For an object lesson in the dilemma facing investment banks these days, consider Cowen Group. Late Monday, the boutique investment bank said it had decided to raise the amount of its revenue set aside for compensation and benefits to 65 percent from 60 percent. On Tuesday, Cowen’s stock slumped more than 10 percent.

headline: Tuesday Kickoff: Seminoles Plan for Post-Bowden Era
text: Bobby Bowden gave his support to naming the Florida State offensive coordinator Jimbo Fisher his successor-in-waiting, which will help smooth the Seminoles’ eventual transition to the post-Bowden era, writes Steve Ellis of the Tallahassee Democrat. David Whitley of the Orlando Sentinel writes that the move should help Florida State begin to attract high-profile recruits again.

headline: Dozens Killed in Algerian Bombings
text: Two car bombs exploded in quick succession near United Nations offices and an Algerian government building.

headline: Make Your Own Ringtones (Even With Copyrighted Songs)
text: Too many start-up ideas are rather boring combinations of trendy concepts — say, a social network for hedge fund mangers. But I ran into one today that seems interesting; it’s something like YouTube for ringtones. The site, which officially launches Tuesday, is called Cellware, and it was founded by John Ferber, who started Advertising.com with his brother Scott.

headline: Universal’s Imeem Deal May Unlock More Free Music
text: Universal Music Group’s announcement on Monday that it would license its catalog to Imeem, a rapidly growing social networking site, may well be a key milestone in the development of digital music. Universal had been the last holdout among major labels in supporting Imeem, which offers users what no other site has before: they can choose as many songs as they want to listen to on their computers — streaming, not downloading — without paying anything for the privilege. The music is paid for by the advertising on the site.

headline: To Life for Death & Co.
text: The web site Eater.com reported this week that Death & Co., a popular East Village cocktail lounge, was in trouble and had closed temporarily, though it’s expected to reopen in less than a week. There are apparently mistakes and problems with its liquor license. And it’s long faced some community opposition.

headline: Ne-Yo, The Goo Goo Dolls and, Oh, Yes, Barack
text: When the doors of the Gibson Amphitheatre in Hollywood, Calif., opened last night, 4,500 Barack Obama supporters and volunteers surged down the tiered aisles to their seats.

headline: Former Interrogator Enters Waterboarding Fray
text: UpdatedThe latest scandal swirling around the Central Intelligence Agency features videotapes and the senior officials who decided to destroy them (a group that a New York Times report today says included lawyers at the agency’s clandestine wing).

headline: Sign of the Strike: Jan. Press Tour Canceled
text: The Television Critics Association’s January press tour has officially been canceled, the group’s president informed members in a letter Monday night.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: Alison Smale, the IHT's managing editor, discusses events in the  world this week.

headline: There Will Be, and There Was, Blood
text: “There Will Be Blood” premiered last night in New York at the Ziegfeld, and there was a pre-screening reception at the Brasserie 8 1/2, to which the Baguette snuck in. Daniel Day-Lewis, the film’s star, was dressed in a tartan suit and looked like a country squire. His wife, Rebecca Miller, wore her hair in punk pigtails.

headline: Luxe In Translation | Russian
text: T presents a series of “essential” foreign phrases. This lesson is for light-packing travelers who find themselves in Moscow this winter. Buying a coat takes time so it’s wise to request some nosh while you deliberate at the trendy Denis Simachev Bar and Boutique where furs and authentic Russian pickles are both on offer.

headline: Flights of Fancy?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Battle Ships | The New Queen Victoria Versus the Queen Mary 2
text: The Queen Victoria (Steve Dunlop)

headline: Corporate ‘Bots
text: Turns out that the Bagger’s critical colleagues at the House of Many Doors are hired for their ability to manufacture prose in support of the broad corporate agenda. In an interview with Big Media Vandal, critic Armond White tells it like it is, or at least in a way that allows him to keep dissonance at bay.

headline: Tuesday’s Links: A Long Day for the Falcons
text: What have football fans done to deserve the Monday night games we have received this season? Did ESPN and the N.F.L. think when they scheduled last night’s Saints-Falcons game that the biggest storyline would be in a courtroom in Richmond, Va., more than 500 miles from the Georgia Dome? That turned out to be fortunate because it was something to talk about as New Orleans rolled, 34-14. Still, Dom Bonvissuto of SI.com gleaned a few things from the game, like how the Saints don’t need Reggie Bush and how Chris Redman is not the answer for the Falcons either.

headline: Turning a Funnel Into a Rabbit Hole
text: The IFC blog said that the throwdown between “There Will Be Blood” and “No Country” might come down to which one stars the more luxuriant moustache. And they spill a big ol‘ can of adjectives on the way:

headline: Fighting a Drought on the Island
text: Let’s see, Christie Brinkley proclaimed that she is an Islander. And Kevin Connolly carried the team crest into battle as a producer in episodes of “Entourage.”

headline: A Different American Education
text: In 1948, Sayyid Qutb began his unhappy education in the United States. He arrived at a hinge moment in the evolution of American power, the dizzying, go-go, post-World War II days. Modernity — in the form of rising affluence, movies and sexually liberated women — hit Qutb in the face, and the sheer godlessness of the place overwhelmed him. He came on a scholarship to study at the Colorado State College of Education in Greeley, but during his two years there he also traveled to New York and California, the coastal pillars of American dynamism and technological progress. By the time he left in 1950 to return to Egypt, he had had his fill of American depravity — and had concluded that “Islam and modernity were completely incompatible.” He was brimming with rage.

headline: No End. No Matter.
text: Critics have been lavish in their praise of “There Will Be Blood,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s reinvention of the Western, and the New Yorker’s David Denby is no exception. Like many of his peers, Mr. Denby goes over the top and stays there in counting the ways in which the movie succeeds:

headline: Overstock Tumbles
text: If you’re a retailer, Christmas is when you clean up. If not, you may need a new business model.

headline: Huckabee’s Pushback on Immigration
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — ­With Mike Huckabee’s record on immigration now the subject of negative television ads in Iowa, the candidate today embraced the endorsement of one of the most outspoken anti-immigration crusaders of recent times.

headline: Betting on the Next Wall Street C.E.O. Exit
text: As Citigroup prepares to name its new chief executive as soon as Tuesday, we’re reminded of all the dethronings on Wall Street this year. From Citi to Merrill Lynch to UBS, top banks facing billions of dollars in mortgage-related losses have dumped their chief executives.

headline: The Lending Crisis as Crack Epidemic
text: The mortgage lending crisis “is the most serious problem that has faced this country since crack cocaine,” the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, told a group of about 60 residents of the Canarsie neighborhood Monday night.

headline: Why Broadcasters Should Be Thankful for DVRs
text: Much of the recent ratings attention has been directly at the continuing erosion of viewers from the five broadcast networks. In the November sweeps, CBS, NBC, ABC, and the CW were all down compared with the prior year. (Fox posted slight gains.)

headline: Giuliani Now Says He Would Have Deported Illegal Immigrants
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who said as mayor of New York that he welcomed hard-working undocumented immigrants, is being quoted in a new book as saying that he would have liked to deport all 400,000 illegal immigrants from New York but had to bow to reality.

headline: The Rights of Baby Boys
text: Circumcision is the most common surgical procedure performed in the United States. But does it violate the human rights of baby boys?

headline: Shearman & Sterling Names New Partners
text: Shearman & Sterling, the New York-based law firm, said Tuesday it named 13 associates and counsel to the partnership.

headline: Dana Installs Big Auto Names for New Board
text: From DealBook’s colleague Micheline Maynard:

headline: The Winter Weather in Katmandu
text: I’m planning to go to Katmandu by January 15th. Is that a good time to go? What about the weather in that season?

headline: Remembering Mayor La Guardia’s Legacy
text: Fiorello H. La Guardia was born 125 years ago today, on Dec. 11, 1882, on the East Side of Manhattan. His father, who was a lapsed Catholic, and his mother, who was Jewish, were immigrants from Italy, but La Guardia became Episcopalian.

headline: An Early Heisman List for 2008
text: Now that the college football world has cleared out of New York City, is it too early to take a peek at who might win the 2008 Heisman Trophy?
