Awards like the Heisman are crazy to handicap, especially if the 2008 season plays out in any way like the 2007 season did. (Remember, Tim Tebow is most likely a smiling bridesmaid if Dennis Dixon doesn’t rip up his knee.) Without further ado, here’s one chump’s opinion of the top-10 candidates for 2008. Not that I have to ask, but feel free to question my intelligence in the comments section.

headline: Dear Mr. Edwards: Define “Beginning”
text: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa –­ Speaking at a town hall event here Monday night, John Edwards said that he has been aggressive about ending the war in Iraq “from the very beginning.”

headline: December Surprise: Tropical Storm Olga
text: [UPDATED. The storm became Tropical Storm Olga yesterday.]It’s not unheard of to have tropical storm activity in December, but it’s unusual enough to warrant including a note from my colleague John Schwartz who, like me, spends part of his time tracking and writing about weather-related disasters. (John divided his time between New York and New Orleans for so long I thought he’d been cloned.)

headline: Obama Gets Shea-Porter Endorsement
text: DES MOINES — Senator Barack Obama received a key New Hampshire endorsement today, collecting the support of Representative Carol Shea-Porter.

headline: Turning Homosexuality On and Off
text: What if you could take a drug that would quickly alter your sexual orientation from straight to gay, or vice versa?

headline: Citi Names Pandit as C.E.O., Bischoff as Chairman
text: Citigroup, the country’s largest bank and one of the biggest casualties of the turmoil in the credit markets, named Vikram S. Pandit as its chief executive Tuesday.

headline: Fútbol, Not Lucha Libre
text: The Mexican Soccer Federation came down harshly on Club Correcaminos UAT for a melee following Saturday’s second-division promotion semifinal against Dorados de Sinaloa, suspending the team’s assistant coach six months for beating up the Dorados coach.

headline: The Stealth Candidates
text: While most commentary on the new CNN presidential poll focuses on Mike Huckabee’s poor showing against the major Democratic candidates, the Opinionator is struck by the good news the figures hold for two candidates who’ve been on the outside looking in of late:

headline: Convergence Dreamers
text: When I first started blogging a couple of years ago (as Screens), and I thought I’d review ‘‘Brokeback Mountain’’ mash-ups as long as I could, I created a folder for documents and random ideas. It’s called ‘‘Internet television.’’ I vaguely thought that was the phrase for videos that floated around the Web.

headline: Box? We Don’t Need No Box
text: The FX cable network has never been shy about proclaiming how its series defy the conventions of television genres like sitcoms, medical dramas, police procedurals, legal dramas and reality shows. Now the network’s first big brand-image campaign is taking the same tack.

text: Nouvel’s guest lounge for the Cartier Foundation at Art Basel Miami Beach.

headline: How to Not Save a Lot of Money on Car Insurance
text: Teenagers everywhere: Break every rule of car insurance thriftiness and you might just give your mother the most flabbergasting phone call of her life. From the Edmonton Journal:

text: One of the new commercials from a campaign for the FX cable network, which carries the theme "There is no box."

text: The limited-edition Richard Phillips/Jimmy Choo clutch.

headline: Basel Player | Jürgen Mayer H.

headline: New Report Fuels Congestion Pricing Debate
text: Proponents of congestion pricing are trumpeting the findings in a new report released today by the city’s Independent Budget Office, which found that the drivers who would be affected by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s much-debated congestion pricing proposal mostly come from outside the city and on average have substantially higher incomes than other motorists.

headline: What Next for Citi’s Financial Supermarket?
text: “Simplfying the company’s organizational structure.”

headline: Auld Bounces Back With the Bruins
text: That’s life (that’s life), That’s what all the people say: “You’re ridin’ high in April, Shot down in May.”

headline: Hank Azaria on His ‘Simpsons’ Voices
text: Here are clips from “LateNet With Ray Ellin,” featuring Hank Azaria on the origins of some of his many “Simpsons” voices. First, Milhouse’s father and Chief Wiggum:

headline: Council Says Many Elderly Worry About Having Enough Food
text: The City Council issued a report today arguing that many residents above age 60 skip meals, go hungry or worry about how they are going to feed themselves. The report recommends expanding the number of senior centers that serve breakfast; allowing them to serve a second free meal; increasing financing so they can stay open seven days a week; and expanding the availability of home-delivered meals.

headline: But the Guy at the Bottom of the Basement Stairs Is Still There!
text: From I Used To Believe, a Web site for childhood beliefs:

headline: Bali Update: ‘Non Paper’ a Nonstarter for U.S.
text: It has taken me years to get comfortable with some of the terms thrown around during international treaty negotiations. One phrase that still jars is “non paper.” This is text that doesn’t exist, but does exist, that is designed as a starting point for discussions leading toward formal language in a final document, but doesn’t bind anyone to anything.

headline: A Gift for Romney
text: Mitt Romney may be having a rough couple of weeks, but today he received a good piece of news, in the form of an endorsement from The National Review, which has these words for him:

headline: Battle Shaping Up for Upstate Senate Seat
text: Senator James W. Wright, an upstate Republican, is planning to leave the State Senate by the end of the year to join Mercury Public Affairs, the political consulting company.

headline: When Big Blue Got a Glimpse of the Future
text: Theodore Holm Nelson, the sociologist and philosopher who coined the term “hypertext” and who is something of an Internet Don Quixote, has had a tremendous influence on the computing world.

headline: Huckabee Catches Feller’s Pitch
text: VAN MATER, IOWA – Gov. Huckabee stopped briefly today at the Bob Feller Museum here, located in this hamlet comprised of two intersecting streets in the middle of a corn field, to accept the endorsement of Mr. Feller, 88, an Iowa native and Hall of Fame former Cleveland Indians pitcher, and to talk about his life as a rather ambivalent sports fan.

headline: CBS Takes Monday Night
text: A two-hour edition of “Deal or No Deal” put NBC on top of the ratings for much of Monday night, but a low-rated episode of “Journeyman” at 10 p.m. meant the network earned a second place finish overall.

headline: How MTV Milks It
text: Some television producers would say that the process of turning a simple television episode into an event — drawn out over days or weeks, with online tie-ins — is a bona fide art form.

headline: We Knew Him When…
text: The excitement over Mike Huckabee’s rise in the polls reminded me of a column Nick wrote almost two years ago about the former Arkansas governor. The column had nothing to do with winning the presidency; it was about losing weight. After being told that he had obesity-related diabetes in 2003, the governor changed his diet, began running and lost 110 pounds. Here’s what Nick wrote:

headline: Bill Me Later Is Getting Big Now
text: UPDATE: In response to questions by readers, I’ve inserted a bit more explanation of how Bill Me Later works.UPDATE 2:This still seems to be generating a lot of questions. Please post any questions you have in the comments, and I’ll send them to Bill Me Later and post the responses.

headline: Have Pillow, Will Fight Hipsters
text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: The Animated Life: White Out
text: A visual paean to the magic of snow, by artist Jeff Scher with music by Shay Lynch. Part of Sightlines, an Op-Ed visual series.

headline: Watch Out for Confidence Schemes, Officials Warn
text: It’s that time of the year again in New York: snowflakes drifting, chestnuts roasting, con artists conning.

headline: The Lotts, Lobbying and Domain Name Defense
text: A report confirming an online union between Senator Trent Lott and former Senator John Breaux — breauxlott.com — raised questions because Mr. Lott is not allowed to join the lobbyist ranks for some time and has played down the prospect.

headline: Coffee, Tea or Whine?
text: At the turn of the last century, while working a flight from New York to Miami, I pushed the meal cart up the aisle and stopped to serve the first row of main-cabin passengers. Instead of cheese omelets with hash brown potatoes or Special K cereal and a banana, as had been our custom, the cart was loaded with bagels. I served one to a female passenger who looked up at me in disbelief. “Is that all?” she cried. “Is this breakfast?”

headline: Voices From 5th Avenue
text: A weak dollar draws shoppers across the Atlantic.

headline: Will the Supreme Court Decide the 2008 Election?
text: In 2000, the Supreme Court decided that George W. Bush was the winner. In 2008, the court may once again have something to say about the election — but this time, it may do it before the votes are even cast.

headline: Council Backs Landmark Status for Domino Plant
text: The Domino Sugar plant refinery, comprising three conjoined structures at the center of the storied waterfront factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is once and for all a New York City landmark.At its meeting this afternoon, the City Council voted unanimously to approve the designation granted by the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission on Sept. 25.

headline: Maybe Speed-Dating Will Help
text: In “Why I Will Never Have a Girlfriend,” a young scholar does a statistical analysis of the earth’s population and concludes there are 18,726 smart, beautiful, eligible women suitable for him. But that’s not good news:

headline: Nonprofits and Businesses Form New Alliance
text: A newly formed group — of 60 or so organizations in all the states — is pushing presidential candidates and others onto new policy tracks.

headline: Falcons’ Long Day Enters Day 2 as Petrino Quits
text: Falcons Coach Bobby Petrino resigned after less than one season to take over at the University of Arkansas.

headline: Biden’s No-Frills Ad
text: Democrat Joe Biden, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, talks up his extensive political experience in his latest TV spot while acknowledging that the word “experience” is too much of a campaign catchphrase. (And one that’s been bandied about a bit among some high-profile Democratic rivals.)

headline: ‘White Out’
text: Snow is particularly joyful in how it transforms everything it covers.

headline: Naughty Santa Reveals All
text: Perhaps you missed it, but Saturday marked the 10th annual New York City SantaCon. On a single day each December, an informal, secretive, debauched and merry band of people dressed up as Santa Claus converge on the city for drinking and celebration. As the event’s not-safe-for-work-or-small-children Web site makes clear, the event has some strict rules. The organizers are anonymous. (“Who’s in charge? Santa.”) Press inquiries are not welcome.

headline: Chocolate Ganache
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a simple, sophisticated  dessert.

headline: A Snow Day in the Caucus Homestretch
text: After an ice storm hit Iowa, Mitt Romney was the only presidential candidate able to keep campaigning.

headline: Barry Smith on Gazprom, St. Petersburg and Why Phoenix Is a Mess
text: Here are more excerpts from the interview SKA St. Petersburg coach Barry Smith gave the Russian TV network Sportelekanal. The interview was published Monday on the network’s Web site. The Buffalo-born Smith has SKA in second place, so far the best performance in the club’s 61-year history.

headline: Afghan Children, Hidden Suffering
text: U.S. Army medics act like a pediatric team in Taliban strongholds of Afghanistan, treating horrific illnesses and suffering among children.

headline: Rangers’ Avery Returns to Practice
text: Less than two weeks after surgery to his left wrist, Rangers forward Sean Avery rejoined his team at practice on Tuesday, a return that could be heard as well as seen.

headline: CBS Logo Display
text: A new motion-activated billboard in the 14th Street-Union Square subway station flashes the CBS logo over passers-by.

headline: It’s getting darker
text: Recession talk increases. Dick Berner of Morgan Stanley tends to be cautiously optimistic; when he says

headline: The Funny Side of Global Warming (No Kidding)
text: In the 20 years I’ve been covering global warming, it’s been hard to find a lot of laughs. There have been a few moments — like when I was standing too close to an open-water gap in the floating sea ice at the North Pole, until a bearlike Russian camp worker pulled me back, explaining in broken English that a tourist had fallen into the 14,300-foot-deep, 28-degree water that way the year before. That’s about as funny as it gets on my beat. I snapped the picture above as he was rushing over toward me.

headline: Weekly Wrap: Orton, Hill and Collins Make It 59 Quarterbacks
text: The Fifth Down’s contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

headline: Suspicions in U.S. That China Has Put Ban on Hollywood Films
text: SHANGHAI  China has stopped granting permission for American films to be shown in its theaters in an apparent trade dispute with the United States, according to several Hollywood executives and United States government officials.

headline: Bucking for Their Eight Seconds of Fame
text: Carl François tossed a kiss into a crowd of urban cowboys gathered round a bullring on Monday night.

headline: Footnote
text: The cast of the all-black Broadway revival of “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” was announced on Tuesday. The play will star Terrence Howard as well as Phylicia Rashad, Anika Noni Rose and James Earl Jones. Debbie Allen is directing the production, which is to begin performances at the Broadhurst on Feb. 12.

headline: In Special Education Cases, City Is Fighting Harder Before Paying for Private School
text: New York City, at the suggestion of private consultants, is significantly ramping up its effort to challenge cases in which it pays for private school tuition of children with disabilities whose parents say they are ill-served by the public schools.

headline: So Little Time, So Many Charities to Feed
text: WHEN casting about for ways to spend on others at this time of year, people whose hearts are as big as their appetites turn to food-related charities. But figuring out where to direct help can be complex, especially in an era when tens of thousands of such programs exist.

headline: Wary of Protests, Exxon Plans Natural Gas Terminal in the Atlantic
text: Exxon Mobil said Tuesday that it would like to build a $1 billion floating terminal for liquefied natural gas about 20 miles off the coast of New Jersey, a move meant to deflect safety and environmental concerns about proximity to populated areas.

headline: Cocaine Caused Singers Death
text: An accidental cocaine overdose caused the death of Kevin DuBrow, below, lead singer for Quiet Riot, a heavy metal band popular in the 1980s, The Associated Press reported. The announcement was made by Samantha Charles, a spokeswoman for the Clark County, Nev., coroner, after toxicology results were received on Monday. Mr. DuBrow was 52 when he was found dead in his home in Las Vegas last month.

headline: My Roommate Is My Enemy, Though We Do Like to Sing
text: A musical comedy about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict sounds more like a punch line than like a pleasant night at the theater. (What yuks!) But the creators of “West Bank, UK,” Oren Safdie (book) and Ronnie Cohen (music and lyrics), do an excellent job of avoiding the most obvious pitfalls  partisanship, preachiness and political naïveté  even if they get bogged down in allegory.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Tuesday about Arsenal de Sarandí’s championship last week in the Copa Sudaméricana misidentified the team it defeated for the title. It was Club América, not Chivas of Guadalajara. (Arsenal defeated Chivas in the quarterfinals.)

headline: Rape of Girl, 15, Exposes Abuses in Brazil Prison System
text: BRASÍLIA  The police jail at Abaetetuba could not be torn down soon enough for Márcia Soares, a lawyer and federal human rights official here. To her, the jail has come to symbolize everything that is wrong with Brazil’s efforts to safeguard women and children from violence.

headline: President Pick Would Name Putin Premier
text: MOSCOW  The longtime aide tapped by Vladimir V. Putin to be his successor as president of Russia declared Tuesday that he wanted Mr. Putin to be his prime minister, offering the clearest indication yet of how Mr. Putin plans to maintain firm control over the Kremlin after his term ends next spring.

headline: White House Is Confident of Broad Support on Iran
text: WASHINGTON  A week after American intelligence agencies reported that Iran halted work on a covert nuclear weapons program in 2003, the Bush administration expressed confidence on Tuesday that it had rallied international support to intensify diplomatic and economic pressure on Iran’s government.

headline: Texas: Two Boys Are Charged
text: Two boys ages 11 and 14 have been charged with trying to rape a 60-year-old woman in her Austin home. The boys wore bandanas when they broke through a window in July, and one tried to sexually assault the woman but stopped when her heart device was set off, the police said. They were charged with burglary with intent to commit sexual assault. Detective Scott Stanfield said the attack was deemed premeditated because the boys had a “rape kit” that included items to restrain the victim.

headline: Fed Leads Drive to Strengthen Bank System
text: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe announced on Wednesday the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

headline: British Library Buys Pinter Papers
text: The British Library has bought the papers of Harold Pinter, the 2005 Nobel laureate in literature, for $2.3 million, Reuters reported. The collection of Mr. Pinter, below, includes letters from Samuel Beckett and the poet Philip Larkin. It comprises more than 150 boxes of manuscripts, scrapbooks, letters, photographs, programs and e-mail messages, as well as a draft of an unpublished memoir of his youth, “The Queen of All the Fairies.” Jamie Andrews, head of modern literary manuscripts at the library, said, “This is a wonderful collection that sheds new light on each stage of Harold Pinter’s unparalleled career over the past 50 years.” A small temporary exhibition, “His Own Domain: Harold Pinter, a Life in Theater,” will be presented at the British Library from Jan. 11 to April 13.

headline: Bush Vetoes Children’s Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush vetoed a children’s health measure on Wednesday afternoon, effectively killing Democrats’ hopes of expanding a popular government program aimed at providing insurance to children in lower-income and middle-income families.

headline: Inflation Picks Up in China; Trade Gap Grows
text: HONG KONG  Inflation accelerated in China last month, government statisticians announced Tuesday, as rising costs for food and fuel together with government currency policies are sending prices up briskly across Asia.

headline: Yahoo Deal Adds Content From CNBC
text: Yahoo Finance, the most popular business news Web site, will begin distributing content from the business news channel CNBC on Wednesday.

headline: Israeli Forces Move Into Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli troops accompanied by about a dozen tanks moved into southern Gaza on Tuesday, a day before Israelis and Palestinians were due to hold their first talks on a comprehensive peace following the American-led conference in Annapolis, Md.

headline: Veto of Energy Measure Is Raised as a Possibility
text: WASHINGTON  The White House has raised last-minute concerns over regulation of automobile emissions and fuel economy that aides said Tuesday could lead to a presidential veto of the energy bill now before Congress.

headline: Shares Fall on a Rate Cut Considered a Disappointment to Fed Watchers
text: In the last couple of weeks, Wall Street grew hopeful that the Federal Reserve was poised to ease the tight credit market with an aggressive intervention. Tuesday, investors reacted as if policy makers had trampled on those expectations.

headline: Who’ll Get to Start Is Anyone’s Guess
text: It has been the year of the backup quarterback and at least three more will get a chance this week. Fifty-six quarterbacks have made starts this season, including the newcomers Brock Berlin (Rams) and Chris Redman (Falcons) in Week 14. Kyle Orton, who has not thrown a regular-season pass since 2005, has already been announced as the Bears’ starter for Monday night’s game against the Vikings. Shaun Hill appears to be the last man standing for the 49ers, and Todd Collins, No. 15 at right, will get the start for the Redskins in place of the injured Jason Campbell. San Francisco and Chicago will become the sixth and seventh teams to use three starting quarterbacks this season.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Jeopardy!’ Host Has Heart Attack

headline: C.I.A. Director Speaks to Senate Committee
text: WASHINGTON  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, distanced himself on Tuesday from the decision to record and subsequently destroy hundreds of hours of video taken during the interrogations of senior Qaeda captives.

headline: An Island in the Hudson, Plundered in Search of Indian Artifacts
text: MAGDALEN ISLAND, N.Y.  For more than 3,000 years, this alluring isle of stone in the Hudson River north of present-day Kingston has beckoned strangers. Over the millennia, Indians stopped at its graywacke shores  and at least one was laid to rest here. They took shelter in a west-facing sandstone rock shelter. They pulled mounds of shellfish from the river. And they shaped countless arrowheads in the high, flat belly of the island before setting out to hunt or fight.

headline: Another Study Finds Heart Risks in a Diabetes Drug
text: An independent analysis of thousands of older people with diabetes found that those treated with the widely used drug Avandia had significantly elevated risks of heart attack and death.

headline: Putting Stadium Site to Full-Time Use
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  On a recent Sunday afternoon outside Gillette Stadium, home of the undefeated New England Patriots football team, the parking lot was jammed with so many cars that attendants wearing fluorescent vests were on hand to direct traffic.

headline: Immigration Moves to Front and Center of G.O.P. Race
text: Mike Huckabee wrote a book this year in which he lamented the “seething anger” surrounding the immigration debate, advocated giving illegal immigrants a path to citizenship and concluded that in the debate “some of the rage is fueled by prejudice.”

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,740,154.05

headline: Betting That a Suburb Wants a Taste of the City
text: NAPERVILLE, Ill.  One of the Chicago area’s richest men, John P. Calamos Sr. of Calamos Investments, is making an ambitious attempt to gain a foothold in the world of commercial real estate by building a 1.2-million-square-foot development in this western suburb of Chicago.

headline: The Uptowning of the Lower East Side
text: SOMETIMES life happens in reverse. At least it did for Neil Ferguson, a chef whose move to his current restaurant from his previous one seems like some sort of cosmic snafu, like a perversion of the correct chronology.

headline: Trial of Cholesterol Drug Gets House Scrutiny
text: A Congressional committee is investigating Merck and Schering-Plough for their handling of a critical clinical trial of Zetia, their blockbuster cholesterol-lowering drug.

headline: Venezuela and Guyana to Improve Alerts After Border Incursion
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Guyana and Venezuela agreed on Tuesday to establish ways to prevent Venezuelan military activities in Guyanese territory, after reports that Venezuelan soldiers had entered Guyana in November and destroyed two gold-mining dredges.

headline: Recipe: Foie Gras With Baked Quince
text: 1 tablespoon Champagne vinegar

headline: Glide, Swoosh, Splat: Mexico Tries Out an Ice-Skating Rink
text: MEXICO CITY  Ice-skating ranks low on the list of sports in Mexico, somewhere far below bullfighting and slightly above croquet. So it was with some bemusement, wonder and trepidation that residents of this capital have been flocking this month to an enormous ice rink that Mayor Marcelo Ebrard has constructed in the historic central square.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Recipe: Kumquat-Clementine Cordial
text: Time: 10 minutes, plus one week’s macerating

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Agence France-Presse report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the next music director of the Vienna Opera, Franz Welser-Möst, misstated the most recent action with regard to his appointment. He signed his contract on Sunday; he was not named to the post (that occurred in June). The report also misidentified the man Mr. Welser-Möst is succeeding. He is Seiji Ozawa, not Ioan Holender. (Mr. Holender, the general director of the opera, will be succeeded by Dominique Meyer.)

headline: Nets Dangle $10 Ticket Lure, but Fans Don’t Bite
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Four young men formed a line at the turnstiles inside the Izod Center about two hours before the Nets’ game Tuesday night against the Los Angeles Clippers.

headline: Support for the Arts in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Politics, Putin-Style
text: The Soviet-style guessing game over Russia’s presidential succession seemed all but decided this week when President Vladimir Putin endorsed the candidacy of his loyal protégé, Dmitri Medvedev, and then Mr. Medvedev announced that, once elected, he would appoint Mr. Putin to be his prime minister.

headline: Calendar
text: Holiday Markets

headline: At the Heart of Truffles, Adaptable Ganache
text: IF the word “ganache” intimidates you, you are not alone. Maybe if the stuff were called “basic, simple and entirely superior chocolate sauce,” more people would make it.

headline: China Agrees to Post U.S. Safety Officials in Its Food Factories
text: XIANGHE, China  China and the United States, seeking to ease the furor over the safety of food exports, signed an agreement Tuesday calling for a greater American role in certifying and inspecting Chinese food products, including an increased presence of American officials at Chinese production plants.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about a 100-year-old Zen master in New Mexico misspelled the name for a Zen meditation hall. It is zendo, not zenda.

headline: Twin Bombs Kill Dozens in Algiers
text: ALGIERS  Twin car bombs near United Nations offices and an Algerian government building killed dozens of people Tuesday in what may have been the deadliest attack here in more than a decade.

headline: Surveillance Court Declines to Release Secret Opinions
text: WASHINGTON  In a rare publicly issued opinion, the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court said Tuesday that it would not release documents related to the National Security Agency’s program of wiretapping without warrants.

headline: System ‘Failed’ Young Rape Victim
text: Heads began to roll as outrage and disbelief continued to spread across Australia over the decision of a local judge, Sarah Bradley, left, to allow nine Aborigines who pleaded guilty to the gang rape of a 10-year-old Aboriginal girl last year to walk free from a court in Queensland. Officials acknowledged that girl had been raped before, in 2002, when she was 7, by several juveniles who did not face court, in the Aboriginal community of Aurukun, where she lived. She was then sent to live with a non-indigenous foster family in Cairns before being returned to Aurukun in April 2006, where she was gang-raped a second time. One welfare officer responsible for sending the girl back has been fired and two others have been suspended, said the Queensland premier, Anna Maria Bligh. “The system clearly failed this little girl,” she said. Local reports said the state had asked the prosecutor in the gang rape case to stand aside after a court transcript disclosed that he had characterized it as “consensual sex.” Calls grew for the removal of Judge Bradley, who said the girl had “probably agreed” to sex. The girl, now 12, is with another foster care family.

headline: Recent Arrival at Citi Now Runs It
text: Vikram S. Pandit joined Citigroup six months ago to oversee one part of the giant bank. Now, he confronts a far more daunting task: shoring up the entire company, which has been pummeled by the mortgage crisis and the recent turmoil in the credit markets.

headline: Credit Crisis Prompts Fed to Roll Back Rates Again
text: The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark short-term interest rate Tuesday by a quarter of a percentage point, to 4.25 percent, and suggested that it would lower rates again if the credit crisis continued to damage not just housing, but the rest of the economy as well.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A jazz entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about the Jim Hall Trio, at the Village Vanguard this week through Sunday, misidentified the sidemen who are playing with him. The bassist and drummer are Scott Colley and Lewis Nash  not Steve LaSpina and Terry Clarke, who also play with Mr. Hall.

headline: In India, a Rare School Shooting Leaves 14-Year-Old Dead
text: NEW DELHI  A simmering feud among a group of eighth graders exploded Tuesday in an upscale suburb south of this capital city in a rare school shooting that killed one student.

headline: Colorado: Gunman Killed Himself
text: The gunman who killed four people in two church-related attacks on Sunday committed suicide after being shot “multiple times” by a volunteer security guard at a church in Colorado Springs, the El Paso County coroner said. The man, Matthew Murray, 24, was confronted by the guard, Jeanne Assam, a former police officer and member of the New Life Church, as he entered the building. He fired a single bullet into himself as he lay wounded, the corner said. Mr. Murray killed two people early Sunday at a missionary training center near Denver and had just killed two teenage sisters in the parking lot at New Life, about 12 hours later, before facing Ms. Assam.

headline: New Jersey to Reconsider Paid Leaves
text: WOODBRIDGE, N.J.  Bowing to pressure from business leaders in New Jersey, Gov. Jon S. Corzine and the state’s top two legislators promised on Tuesday to scale back to 6 weeks from 10 a proposal that would give employees the right to take paid family leave to care for a newborn or a sick relative.

headline: After a Window Washer’s 47-Floor Plunge, the Big Question Is: How Did He Survive?
text: A 29-year-old man plunges 17 stories in the atrium of a hotel in Minneapolis, landing on an overhang.

headline: Wait Until 2010, Nets Say of New Brooklyn Arena
text: The Nets, who had hoped to move into a new arena near downtown Brooklyn in time for the 2009-10 season, have acknowledged that construction will not be finished until sometime in 2010.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about the mental reserves that might help ward off symptoms of dementia, misstated the name of the medical center with which two researchers who study the issue are affiliated. Dr. Nikolaos Scarmeas and Yaakov Stern are at Columbia University Medical Center, not Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. (The name was changed in 2003.)

headline: Thomas’s Courtside Monologue Was Search for Sixth Man
text: Mara Altschuler’s courtside tickets to Knicks games have been in her family for more than 40 years, offering her a ringside seat to listen in on coaches from Red Holzman, Hubie Brown and Don Nelson to Rick Pitino, Pat Riley and Larry Brown.

headline: S.E.C. Planning to Delay Accounting Rules for Small Companies
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to delay for another year the requirement that small companies report on the state of their internal financial controls, the agency’s chairman, Christopher Cox, is expected to tell lawmakers on Wednesday.

headline: First Israeli Resolution Accepted
text: A committee of the General Assembly for the first time passed an Israeli resolution, one dealing not with the Middle East conflict but proposing that developed countries make their agricultural know-how more available. The measure attracted 118 votes, and Dan Gillerman, the Israeli ambassador, said, “It is not easy for Israel to garner so many votes, to have its resolution and its point of view adopted, but today it happened.”

headline: A Las Vegas Gym Faces a ‘Ladies’ Night’ Bias Case
text: LAS VEGAS  During a tour of a Las Vegas Athletic Club gym, a prospective member, Todd Phillips, was struck by the fact that his wife was offered a cheaper sign-up rate than he was and that there was a special workout area for women.

headline: The Led List
text: The set for Monday’s Led Zeppelin reunion:

headline: Guatemala: U.S. Adoptions to Go Through
text: Lawmakers endorsed an overhaul of the country’s adoption system, ending what critics called a largely unregulated business in which poor mothers were paid to turn over their children to American couples. The new law, pushed by the United States government, allows thousands of pending adoptions, most to Americans, to proceed. Guatemala sends more adopted children to the United States than any other country except China; this year it has sent 4,700. The new law also creates a government authority to handle future adoptions, bringing Guatemala in line with the Hague Convention on Intercountry Adoption and wresting the system away from lawyers who charge as much as $30,000 per child.

headline: Steroid Report Expected to Cite About 50 Players
text: The headquarters for George J. Mitchell’s investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball has been the DLA Piper law offices in Midtown Manhattan, right next to Rockefeller Center and only blocks from the Park Avenue offices of Major League Baseball. On Tuesday, as Mitchell’s 20-month investigation drew to a conclusion, it was Major League Baseball that was on the move, as officials from the sport went to the DLA Piper offices to get a look at the report.

headline: Checks and Balances for Our Spies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Well column in Science Times on Dec. 4, about Heather Kuzmich, a former contestant on “America’s Next Top Model” who has Asperger’s Syndrome, misidentified the city in which she got lost in one episode. It was Shanghai, not Beijing.

headline: Weapons of War at the Mall and Church
text: Barely touched on in the coverage of the two latest gun rampages is how the disturbed shooters could so easily obtain assault rifles  weapons designed for waging war. In separate random massacres, eight people were slain at an Omaha shopping mall last Wednesday and four were more shot dead Sunday at two Colorado churches. The Omaha killer took his stepfather’s rapid-fire rifle from a closet to pick off Christmas shoppers. In Colorado, the gunman, leaving behind an Internet screed referenced to the 1999 Columbine massacre, was equipped with two assault rifles, three handguns and 1,000 rounds of ammunition.

headline: Bill and Hillary Clinton’s Pitch in Iowa: ‘I Love the ’90s’
text: Grinnell, Iowa

headline: Honors for Woods
text: Tiger Woods swept the three biggest annual awards for the seventh time. He received the Jack Nicklaus Trophy for player of the year, the Arnold Palmer award for leading the money list ($10.8 million) and the Byron Nelson award for lowest-scoring average (67.79). Jay Haas was voted Champions Tour player of the year, and Nick Flanagan won the Nationwide award. The other PGA Tour awards went to Steve Stricker, the first player to win comeback player of the year in consecutive seasons, and Brandt Snedeker, who was the rookie of the year.

headline: Some Used Football Helmets Under Scrutiny
text: More than 200,000 amateur football players in the United States wore used helmets this fall that were returned to the field without proper testing, and the F.B.I. is investigating.

headline: Bubbly Enthusiasm, Personified
text: THE name’s Champagne. Rosé Champagne.

headline: At Bronx Court, Elevator Woes Slow Justice
text: There are many longstanding, seemingly intractable shortcomings in the city’s family court system that might delay a parent in getting a child back from foster care: unprepared lawyers, overcrowded dockets and long waiting lists for drug treatment and mental health services.

headline: For a Single Mother, Mr. Claus Is Mr. Right
text: In “The Perfect Holiday” Nancy (Gabrielle Union), a divorced mother of two boys and a girl, glumly faces Christmas in New Jersey without a man in her life. Rubbing salt in her wounds is her ex-husband, J-Jizzy (Charlie Murphy), a preening rap star with whom she is locked in a custody battle. Swathed in chinchilla, he is stymied on his current project, a Christmas album that includes gems like “I Love the Ho Ho Hos.”

headline: Text of the Fed Statement
text: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to lower interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point:

headline: Recent Arrival at Citi Now Runs It
text: Vikram S. Pandit joined Citigroup six months ago to oversee one part of the giant bank. Now, he confronts a far more daunting task: shoring up the entire company, which has been pummeled by the mortgage crisis and the recent turmoil in the credit markets.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Deaths From Icy Weather Rise to 20 in Central States
text: CHICAGO  A surge of moist and shallow arctic air swept through the central Plains states and Midwest on Tuesday, dropping freezing rain and snow. The storm knocked out power to hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses, closed schools and compounded the hazardous conditions that have left at least 20 people dead since the weekend.

headline: Humane Society Traces Expensive Pups to Pet Mills
text: LOS ANGELES  A pet store in the Bel-Air neighborhood deceived customers, including Hollywood celebrities, about the origin of their puppies, many of which come from unlicensed pet mills, according to a Humane Society of the United States investigation released Tuesday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Tuesday about the Giants’ development into a solid, if unspectacular, team misstated their potential for playing at home in the postseason. They could do so if they are the top wild-card team in the National Football Conference championship game and face the second wild-card team; they would not necessarily play all of their postseason games on the road.

headline: Rare Look Inside Baghdad Museum
text: BAGHDAD  For a few brief hours Tuesday, three dozen spectators  journalists, local politicians and their guards  gathered at the National Museum of Iraq here, their voices echoing through its vast, darkened halls. It was one of the few times outsiders had been allowed inside since Baghdad fell, looters stripped the galleries of some 15,000 Mesopotamian artifacts, and the museum became a wrenching symbol of the losses of the war.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An Associated Press report in the N.B.A. roundup in some editions on Friday about the Knicks’ status as the league’s most valuable franchise misstated a Forbes magazine assessment of the club’s worth. It is $608 million, not $604 million.

headline: A New Chapter in the Tale of the ‘Dinnertime Bandit’
text: STAMFORD, Conn.  The “dinnertime bandit” shuffled in just before lunch.

headline: Stop! In the Name of ‘Liebestod’: Wagner Meets Pop
text: “Shoppa loppa shoop shoop. He’s sure the boy for me.” Funny, it doesn’t sound much like Wagner, does it?

headline: Strike Touches a Ritual for Wooing
text: UNLESS something happens quickly to restart stalled talks between entertainment producers and the Writers Guild of America, one of the oldest rituals of the television business, the May network upfront presentation, is likely to fold its tent, possibly forever.

headline: Seeking Leaders, U.S. Companies Think Globally
text: The corner offices of corporate America are increasingly being filled from every corner of the world.

headline: From China, Only in a Bottle, a Berry With an Alluring Name
text: YUMBERRY sounds more like the creation of an advertising agency than of nature  like Cherry Garcia or Juicy Fruit. But while the name was dreamed up a few years ago to help sell the fruit’s juice, which is just now appearing in stores around the country, the fruit has been grown for 2,000 years in China. It’s so popular there that about twice as many acres are devoted to growing it as the number devoted to apple orchards in the United States.

headline: C.I.A. Chief Admits Failure to Inform Congress
text: WASHINGTON  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, acknowledged Wednesday that the C.I.A. had failed to keep members of Congress fully informed of the facts that the agency had videotaped the interrogations of Al Qaeda detainees and destroyed the tapes three years later.

headline: The Eccentricities of Iowa
text: Come caucus night in Iowa, some unknown number of voters will show up in their neighbor’s living room, or in a church basement, a VFW hall or a school auditorium to show support for a candidate. On their way in, they might stop and let one of the 160 entrance poll takers who work for the television networks and the Associated Press know who they are going to support and why. But once they get inside  especially if they are at a Democratic party event where people have to publicly state their preference  they could be persuaded to change their mind. If their first choice candidate doesn’t get 15 percent of the vote, they will have to change their mind.

headline: Canadian Government Seeks to Reopen Medical Reactor
text: OTTAWA  Overriding the safety concerns of its regulator, the Canadian government is rushing through legislation to reopen a nuclear reactor that produces most of the world’s supply of an important diagnostic isotope.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,878 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: Petrino Quits the Falcons to Coach the Razorbacks
text: A miserable year for the Atlanta Falcons took a stunning turn Tuesday night with the resignation of Coach Bobby Petrino, who left Louisville less than a year ago to take what he called the best job in the N.F.L.

headline: A Film Producer Guided More by His Heart Than by His Calculator
text: LOS ANGELES  “Talk to Me,” a sharp-tongued urban bio-pic, fell on deaf ears at the box office. The British farce “Death at a Funeral” staggered through American theaters. “Lars and the Real Girl,” that love story involving a life-size sex doll? Let’s just say it, um, deflated on arrival.

headline: Sounds of the New, Arrayed to Enliven a Nordic Night
text: Composers from the north put their exports in the hands of Americans on Monday night. Speculum Musicae, the New York new-music group, played pieces by the Finnish composers Kaija Saariaho and Magnus Lindberg, and by two Danes, Bent Sorensen and Poul Ruders. The small auditorium in the basement of Scandinavia House on Park Avenue was as appropriate a place as any.

headline: The Capital of Slumping Home Sales
text: Just south of Los Angeles, there is a small city called Paramount where houses have all but stopped selling.

headline: Bankers Face Grim Truth: Worst Is Yet to Come
text: AS the credit crisis sweeps wildly through Wall Street, major investment banks face a grim truth about their already-slumping profits: the worst is yet to come.

headline: Dinner Theater Served With Odd Conversations
text: It’s not easy, on a Saturday night in this maddening city, to feel that you have landed exactly where you want to be, and even, perhaps, where you need to be. But “No Dice,” performed by the Nature Theater of Oklahoma and commissioned by Soho Rep, is that rare, wondrous type of theatrical sustenance: You leave blissful and sated, yet wanting more.

headline: Student Lender to Stop Using College and Team Names in Marketing
text: A student lender that paid students as much as $50 for referring classmates for loans and paid dozens of universities to use the institutions’ names, athletic team names, logos and mascots on advertising material sent to student borrowers has agreed to stop these marketing tactics, the New York attorney general announced Tuesday.

headline: Trial Witness Said to Cast Doubt on Part of Testimony
text: A principal witness in the stock-options backdating trial that ended in a conviction of Gregory L. Reyes, the chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems Inc., has told associates her testimony may have been untrue, according to court documents.

headline: Judge Backs California Rules on Greenhouse Gases
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge in Sacramento on Wednesday upheld a California law regulating greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks, another in a string of legal defeats for the auto industry this year.

headline: Welless Kane Oscar No Rosebud
text: The Oscar statue awarded to Orson Welles for the best original screenplay of 1941 for “Citizen Kane,” left, did not attract a bidder and failed to sell on Tuesday at auction at Sotheby’s in New York, Bloomberg News reported. The Academy Award statue, its finish worn from years of handling, had been expected to fetch $800,000 to $1.2 million for its seller, the Dax Foundation, a Los Angeles charity that had planned to use the proceeds for philanthropy. However, a 1940 copy of Welles’s 156-page script for “Citizen Kane,” carrying a presale estimate of $120,000, sold for $97,000, including fees, to an unidentified telephone bidder. The seller was a private collector whom the auction house declined to identify. Welles co-wrote, directed and starred in “Citizen Kane,” his first film, and was also nominated for Academy Awards for best director and best actor in the title role. He won only the prize for screenwriting, which he shared with Herman L. Mankiewicz. In 1982 Sotheby’s sold Rosebud, the sled that figured significantly in the story, for $60,000.

headline: What You Get for ...$1.6 Million
text: Gatlinburg, Tenn.

headline: Rights Group Says Egypt Used Torture in Terror Case
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An American human rights group issued a report on Tuesday accusing the Egyptian government of using torture and false confessions in a recent high-profile terrorism case.

headline: Remaking The Journal
text: In the last few months, Rupert Murdoch has moved into an office at Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal. He has pushed the paper’s editors for shorter articles and more hard news. He has personally wooed reporters he wants to keep out of his competitors’ hands.

headline: Mexico: Cannibal Suspect Found Hanged
text: A 38-year-old man accused of killing a girlfriend and eating parts of her body was found dead in his cell in Mexico City, apparently a suicide, prison officials said. Guards found the man, José Luis Calva Zepeda, hanging by his belt. He was arrested in October when the police discovered the dismembered body of his girlfriend in his apartment and human flesh in a frying pan.

headline: Rangers and Knicks Share Owner, but Little Else
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The two teams in the Madison Square Garden empire practice perhaps 100 yards apart, their locker rooms separated by a long hallway. Some days, like Tuesday, they each practice at the Madison Square Garden Training Center, and they eat in a common lunch room.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on Tuesday about the role of lawyers at the Central Intelligence Agency in approving the 2005 destruction of hundreds of hours of interrogation videotapes gave an incomplete name in some editions for the former chief of the agency’s clandestine branch, who has been described by intelligence officials as having authorized the destruction of the tapes. He is Jose A. Rodriguez Jr. (Go to Article)

headline: White House Seeks Change in Mileage Measure
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The White House has raised last-minute concerns over regulation of automobile emissions and fuel economy that aides said could lead to a presidential veto of the energy bill now before Congress.

headline: Retroactively, Panel Reduces Drug Sentences
text: WASHINGTON  The agency that sets guidelines for federal prison sentences voted unanimously on Tuesday to lighten punishments retroactively for some crimes related to crack cocaine, a decision that could eventually affect about 19,500 inmates and mean freedom for some within months.

headline: Hoboken’s Rebirth Fuels School Aid Formula Fight
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.  In the early 1970s, Hoboken was so broken down that some residents feared for their lives. Crime and arson were rampant, and those who could afford to fled to neighboring towns like Secaucus.

headline: High Stakes for Poker as a Learning Tool
text: Not so long ago, poker was just a game. A few years back it emerged as a fad. Then, largely because of television, it morphed into a national phenomenon, if not an industry.

headline: Small Businesses Oppose Mandated Health Benefits
text: The small business lobbying group that had a big part in derailing Hillary Rodham Clinton’s effort to overhaul health care in the early 1990’s has staked out its position for the 2008 political season.

headline: 4 Killed in New Jersey Fire
text: UNION, N.J.  A ferocious fire swept through a two-story house in New Jersey early Wednesday morning, killing four people from three generations of a family, including a 14-year-old girl, her parents, and her grandmother, the authorities and neighbors said.

headline: DNA Pioneer’s Genome Blurs Race Lines
text: Now, this is awkward.

headline: Pavano, New Agent Says, May Stay With Yankees
text: Tom O’Connell has been an agent for 10 years, and he represents about 60 baseball players, mostly in the minor leagues. He may have just met his toughest challenge.

headline: S.E.C. Fraud Suit Names San Diego Auditor
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil fraud complaint against the former auditor of San Diego on Monday, a rare step reflecting the agency’s concern about the quality of the information that governments provide to municipal bond markets.

headline: Pairings
text: THE extra-fruity richness of rosé Champagne, whether a mere whisper or a shout, gives the wine what it takes to accompany meaty dishes, from first-course beef carpaccios and plates of prosciutto to roast veal and game birds. And the fizz and lively acidity make it a good partner for fatty foods, which is why I love it with foie gras, especially when seared and nicely burnished.

headline: Call to Arms to Retain Name at a Garden State Rest Stop
text: Molly Pitcher is in trouble, boys and girls. This documented American hero, who replaced her wounded husband during the battle of Monmouth in 1778, just might be banished from the New Jersey Turnpike in another outbreak of the naming-rights blight.

headline: Health Care Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Monday about the Browns’ 24-18 victory over the Jets referred incorrectly in some copies to a tight end for Cleveland. He is Steve Heiden, not Eric.

headline: Letters
text: Farewell, Entree

headline: Chandler’s Greatest Mystery: His Life
text: Few writers own a city as completely as Raymond Chandler owns Los Angeles. Seen through the eyes of Philip Marlowe, his existentialist detective, its bungalows, courtyard apartment buildings and sunlit anomie cast a spell that acts on his legions of fans like a potent drug. They cannot get enough.

headline: Hand-Pulled Noodles, Hold the Noir
text: WHEN I ate at Food Shing on a blustery night last winter, a Hong Kong action movie played on a television set wedged above the door. On it, men in black suits with steely glares and strong chins deployed gruesome acrobatics to beat the living daylights out of each other in a parking lot.

headline: Deadlock Stymies Global Climate Talks
Report Finds Better Scores in New Crop of Teachers
text: Teaching is attracting better-qualified people than it did just a few years ago, according to a report released Tuesday by the Educational Testing Service.

headline: 7 Troopers Suspended in Sex Assault Inquiry
text: TRENTON  Seven New Jersey state troopers were suspended on Tuesday in connection with an investigation into a young woman’s report that she had been sexually assaulted.

headline: Maine’s Babies to Get a Jump on College Tab
text: BOSTON  Starting in 2009, every child born in Maine will be eligible for $500 toward college from the fortune of a shoe magnate who died there last month.

headline: The Songs Remain the Same, Just Played a Little Slower
text: LONDON  Some rock bands accelerate their tempos when they perform their old songs decades after the fact. Playing fast is a kind of armor: a refutation of the plain reality of aging  all that unregainable enthusiasm and lost muscle mass  and a hard block against a band’s lessened cultural importance.

headline: Living Large and Robustly With Schumann and Ravel
text: Chu-Fang Huang has done well on the piano competition circuit, and it’s easy to see why. At Zankel Hall on Monday evening, she demonstrated a steely technique and a huge, powerful sound of the sort usually associated with burly Russian players, although Ms. Huang is fairly petite and was trained in China and the United States. The only teachers listed in her program biography, Claude Frank and Robert McDonald, are gentler, more subtle players than she is.

headline: Losing Weight in the Gulf
text: Manama, Bahrain

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on Tuesday about the role of lawyers at the Central Intelligence Agency in approving the 2005 destruction of hundreds of hours of interrogation videotapes gave an incomplete name in some editions for the former chief of the agency’s clandestine branch, who has been described by intelligence officials as having authorized the destruction of the tapes. He is Jose A. Rodriguez Jr.

headline: Dreamliner Is Expected to Meet Its Revised 2008 Deadline
text: Boeing said on Tuesday that it was on track to deliver the first 787 Dreamliner at the end of next year after improving supply-chain problems that had led to a six-month delay in its original production schedule.

headline: Broaden a Cook’s Culinary Horizons 11 Ways
text: IT would take a bolder deconstruction specialist than me to detect any grand meaning in the past year’s cookbooks. All I can say about the 11 notable titles selected here is that in my opinion they represent an argument against the frequently heard claim that cookbooks are being dumbed down.

headline: Made for Washington, Given to Lafayette, a Medal Sells for $5.3 Million
text: A gold medal that was created for George Washington and presented to the Marquis de Lafayette was auctioned at Sotheby’s in Manhattan on Tuesday for a record $5.3 million, and will remain in France after residing there for 183 years.

headline: New Math in 30 Seconds: Change Plus Experience Equals Biden
text: This advertisement will be the third that Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign has run in Iowa. The 30-second television commercial is to start appearing statewide on Wednesday.

headline: Former Iranian President Publicly Assails Ahmadinejad
text: TEHRAN  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s policies were attacked Tuesday at Tehran’s major university in an unusual speech by his predecessor, who warned that political suppression, questionable economic policies and defiance on the nuclear issue were leading Iranians in the wrong direction.

headline: Why Pregnant Women Don’t Tip Over
text: Pregnant women do not tip over, and researchers say an evolutionary curve has a lot to do with the reason why.

headline: Guadalupe Spreads Her Theatrical Wings
text: LOS ANGELES  Andrea García Soto, who sings in the choir, was recently found to have breast cancer, so she prayed for her own health. Guillermo García, a dancer, has a terminally ill sister, so he danced to stop her suffering. His wife, Nellie García, another singer in the choir, was simply thankful for past blessings, so she sang to show devotion.

headline: Regular Freight Rail Service Starts Between 2 Koreas
text: DORASAN STATION, South Korea  For President Roh Moo-hyun, who steps down in February and is barred from running for another term, the journey on Tuesday of a 12-car South Korean freight train across the world’s most heavily fortified border on Tuesday was one of the last hurrahs of his reconciliation policy with the Communist North.

headline: Climate Change in ’08
text: To the Editor:

headline: Liberty University Pledges ‘Good Clean Fun’ at New Sports Park
text: Students at Liberty University, founded in 1971 by the televangelist Jerry Falwell, are not allowed to watch R-rated movies, drink alcohol or dance. But soon their campus in Lynchburg, Va., may feature downhill mountain-biking trails, zip-lines and year-round skiing and snowboarding slopes.

headline: Maryland: Teacher Dies From Staph Infection
text: A public school in Montgomery County is taking steps to protect students against a drug-resistant form of staph infection after a special education teacher died of complications from the bacterium. The teacher, Merry King, had worked at Herbert Hoover Middle School in Potomac for two of the past three years. Ms. King’s classroom was sanitized as a precaution after she died Sunday. A Montgomery County schools spokeswoman said communal areas at the school would also be sanitized with a bleach solution. Ms. King had been absent from the school since Nov. 30 and had been hospitalized since early last week.

headline: Thomas Responds but Has No Answers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  His back to the wall, his personal space consumed by cameras and microphones, Isiah Thomas breathed deep and dutifully navigated a dozen questions over 11 minutes Tuesday afternoon. The session was not as strenuous as it might sound.

headline: Chief Says G.E. Profit Will Grow 10% or More
text: To hear Jeffrey R. Immelt, General Electric’s chief executive, tell it, his company is having a great 2007 and faces a very nice 2008.

headline: Debates Persist Over Subsidies for Immigrant College Students
text: Go to college, we urge our children. College is the new high school, and without an undergraduate degree, they will be doomed to low-earning, second-rate lives.

headline: Many Still Without Power After Storm
text: Hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses in the nation’s midsection remained without electricity on Wednesday after being hit by an ice storm that pulled down power lines, cracked tree limbs and closed schools, highways and airports.

headline: South Africa Grows Up
text: Johannesburg

headline: N.F.L. and Players Union Agree to Alter Disability Plan
text: The National Football League and the N.F.L. Players Association, which have been criticized by some former players for their treatment of retired and disabled players, are changing the disability plan with the hope it will streamline the process for players seeking disability payments.

headline: Agreement With China to Regulate Some Drugs
text: BEIJING  American and Chinese regulators signed an agreement Tuesday to strengthen regulation of drugs and medical devices exported to the United States. But the accord covers only a tiny fraction of the pharmaceutical ingredients being marketed worldwide by thousands of unlicensed chemical companies.

headline: Feeling Heat, Clinton Tries Iowa Up Close
text: DES MOINES  Ten months ago, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton went to East High School here on her first trip to Iowa as a presidential candidate and laid out a case for her candidacy to a cheering crowd in a packed gymnasium.

headline: Peru’s Ex-President Gets 6 Years for Illicit Search
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  The Supreme Court of Peru sentenced former President Alberto K. Fujimori on Tuesday to six years in prison for ordering an illegal search as his government was collapsing in 2000, the first prison sentence for Mr. Fujimori as he stands trial on various other charges, including murder and forced disappearance.

headline: For Casino Owner, Winning a License Was Not a Matter of Luck
text: PITTSBURGH  Don H. Barden could have scheduled the groundbreaking for his $450 million casino on his 64th birthday, Dec. 20, if he wanted. After all, he owns what is projected to be the most lucrative of Pennsylvania’s 14 slots casino licenses.

headline: On Taliban Turf, Long Lines of Ailing Children
text: KARAWADDIN, Afghanistan  The Afghan boy crouched near a wall in this remote village, where the Taliban’s strength has prevented the government from providing services. His eyes were coated by an opaque yellow sheath.

headline: Thomas P. Whitney, Solzhenitsyn Translator, Dies at 90
text: Thomas P. Whitney, a former diplomat and writer on Russian affairs who was best known for translating the work of the dissident writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn into English, died on Dec. 2 in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Failing Health Does Not Derail an Indomitable Spirit
text: Yessina Rodriguez’s life is at a standstill.

headline: Mars Rover Finding Suggests Once Habitable Environment
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The lame wheel on the NASA Mars rover Spirit has proved an invaluable science tool, turning up evidence of a once habitable environment, scientists said Monday.

headline: Justice in Sentencing
text: With a pair of 7-2 rulings this week, the Supreme Court struck a blow for basic fairness and judicial independence. The court restored a vital measure of discretion to federal trial judges to impose sentences based on their assessment of a particular crime and defendant rather than being forced to adhere to overarching guidelines.

headline: A Sprawling Novel’s Turn as an Epic Opera: 52 Soloists and 1 Horse
text: The Metropolitan Opera’s production of “War and Peace,” Prokofiev’s epic masterpiece, was a milestone for the company when it was introduced in 2002. A co-production with the Kirov Opera of St. Petersburg, the staging involved 52 soloists singing 68 roles, not to mention 118 choristers, 41 dancers, 227 supernumeraries and 1,200 costumes. It was also a personal milestone for Valery Gergiev, who spearheaded the production and conducted the enormous score, nearly four hours long, with utter authority.

headline: The Dream Is Dead
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Journeyman Scuttles NBCs Night
text: A two-hour edition of “Deal or No Deal” put NBC on top of the ratings for much of Monday night, but a low-rated episode of “Journeyman” at 10 p.m. meant the network earned a second-place finish over all. CBS ranked first for the night, thanks largely to “CSI: Miami,” the night’s top rated show, which dominated the 10 p.m. hour with 14.1 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. By comparison, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” averaged 12.7 million while leading the 8-to-10 p.m. time slots. “Journeyman,” however, drew just 5.6 million. CBS remained solidly in second place earlier in the night even though its 9 p.m. comedies were in repeat. CBS’s 8 p.m. comedies, “How I Met Your Mother” (8.4 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (7.5 million), finished roughly even with ABC’s special in the hour, “I Want a Dog for Christmas, Charlie Brown!” (7.8 million). ABC tied Fox for third over all, getting little help in the ratings from “October Road” at 10 (5.2 million) or from its 9 p.m. comedies, “Samantha Who?” (6.7 million) followed by “Notes From the Underbelly” (4.6 million).

headline: House Votes to Raise Pilot Retirement Age
text: The House voted unanimously to extend the retirement age for commercial pilots to 65, changing a 1960 Federal Aviation Administration regulation forcing pilots to leave the cockpit at age 60. The bill, if approved by the Senate, would put the retirement age in line with international standards. The International Civil Aviation Organization adopted a retirement age of 65 in November 2006. The House measure would require pilots ages 60 and above to have a medical certificate renewed every six months and to take a flight test known as a line check every six months.

headline: Stolen Statues Anger Indonesian Lawmaker
text: More than 100 ancient artifacts, including ancestral statues, have been stolen from Central Sulawesi province in Indonesia and are being sold at galleries on Bali, an Indonesian legislator said on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported. “These various artifacts have been stolen from the Lore Lindu plateau since 2000, and we have seen ourselves about 100 of them being offered for sale in galleries in Bali,” said Asmir Podungge, a lawmaker from the Poso district. “They were sold at high prices, including one stone ancestor statue known as Batu Nongko, which is said to have been sold for five billion rupiah,” or $537,000. Mr. Podungge said that the district parliament had alerted the local authorities but that “they seemed to not be too excited about this.” The Lore Lindu plateau holds many megalithic remains, including huge boulders carved into ancestral figures, stone burial jars, plates and game boards, whose origins remain unclear. Mr. Podungge’s complaints followed the arrest of four people on Java, Indonesia’s main island, in connection with the theft of five ancient statues from a museum in the historic city of Surakarta. A routine inspection of the Radya Pustaka museum found that the works had been stolen and replaced by fakes. The police found them in the home of a prominent businessman in Jakarta.

headline: Jeopardy! Host Has Heart Attack
text: Alex Trebek, right, the host of “Jeopardy!,” has had a minor heart attack. The show’s Web site, jeopardy.com, said Mr. Trebek was “resting comfortably in a Los Angeles hospital, and he will be back in the studio for the next scheduled tapings in January.” Mr. Trebek became the host of “Jeopardy!” in 1984, when he replaced Art Fleming, and has won two Emmy Awards for his role.

headline: Ground Zero Hunt for Remains Is Mostly Done
text: An expanded search for human remains begun last year at ground zero is largely completed, according to a memorandum sent to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday and ushering in a new phase of operations.

headline: Martha Stewart Living to Curtail Its Blueprint Magazine
text: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia will stop publishing Blueprint magazine on a stand-alone basis after the January-February issue.

headline: A Prisoner of Fear Holes Up With His Fuzzy Friends
text: Robert Zukerman gives an impeccable performance in the title role of “The Puppetmaster of Lodz” at the ArcLight Theater, but you still leave wondering whether this 24-year-old work by the Romanian playwright Gilles Ségal would have been better as a shorter one-act.

headline: On a Maltese Island, Bargain Vacation Rentals
text: Bert and Kathi Childers of Dallas first visited Gozo in 2002 on a two-week package tour they had taken from Hamburg with a couple of German friends. Something about the island struck a chord and they decided to stay on for another two weeks.

headline: After Arrests, Drug Evidence Goes Missing
text: One day last December, a Brooklyn prosecutor called the Police Department laboratory to check on a test of drugs that had been seized six weeks earlier.

headline: Giving Testimony on the Horror That Was Nanking
text: “Nanking” is a swift, incisive documentary about one of the lesser-known horrors of the 20th century: the 1937 Japanese invasion of the Chinese city now called Nanjing, where more than 200,000 civilians and prisoners of war were slaughtered in a matter of weeks. The capital of the Republic of China at the start of World War II and the headquarters of the Chiang Kai-shek government, this attractive, cosmopolitan city of parks and thoroughfares was largely destroyed in what is known as the rape of Nanking.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on Monday about the impact of Western creditor lawsuits on the Congo Republic and other heavily indebted developing countries in Africa misstated the size of the Congo Republic’s debt as of December 2004. It was $8.5 billion, not $8.5 million.

headline: Better Leaders for Africa
text: To the Editor:

headline: Haste Makes Cordial
text: IN a more organized alternative reality that I do not inhabit, I would have thought about the holidays in August. Surrounded by ripe seasonal fruit, I could have turned it into delightful elixirs  nectarine wine, raspberry ratafia  to distribute to my nearest and dearest come December and bring joy to their world.

headline: Muscle Flexing in Senate: G.O.P. Defends Strategy
text: WASHINGTON Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, operates with near-robotic efficiency when it comes to negotiating budget figures in public, consistently refusing to answer questions that would ever commit him to a specific number at the bargaining table.

headline: Food Stuff
text: Fresh From the Farm, California Caviar

headline: Philharmonic Gets a Taste of Pyongyang Diplomacy
text: It was one of the more unusual moments on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall: North Korea’s highest-ranking diplomat in the United States stood next to the podium on Tuesday and welcomed the musicians of the New York Philharmonic to his country.

headline: Fund for N.F.L. Retirees in Need of Help Is Gaining Support
text: MINNEAPOLIS  An initiative begun by Kansas City Chiefs offensive lineman Kyle Turley, who hopes to persuade N.F.L. players to donate part of their Dec. 23 game paychecks to an organization assisting retired players in need, continued to gain steam Tuesday.

headline: Penthouse Buys Group of Social-Networking Sites
text: While the influx of free and low-cost video has hurt the sale of pornographic videos, the chief executive of the Penthouse Media Group remains so bullish on the sex-related entertainment industry that he is investing $500 million in a group of social networking sites.

headline: Recipe: Chocolate Truffles
text: Time: 30 minutes, plus at least one hour’s chilling

headline: Checkpoint: Huckabee on AIDS and Iran
text: In recent days, Mike Huckabee, a Republican presidential candidate, has mischaracterized his record and past statements on two subjects: one relating to the federal government’s response to the AIDS crisis in the 1990s and another about his lack of knowledge of a report finding that Iran had halted its nuclear weapons program in 2003.

headline: Yahoo Deal Adds Content From CNBC
text: Yahoo Finance, the most popular business news Web site, will begin distributing content from the business news channel CNBC on Wednesday.

headline: Wednesday’s Links: An Empty Nest in Atlanta
text: Bobby Petrino quit Tuesday as the Falcons’ head coach and, honestly, who can blame him? Well, for starters, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution’s Jeff Schulz can. John Czarnecki at Foxsports.com says Petrino would never have lasted in Atlanta and, with Petrino leaving the Falcons with a 3-10 record after their 34-14 loss to the Saints on Monday night, it makes you wonder why N.F.L. teams consider hiring college coaches in the first place. What do the Falcons do now? Exactly what everyone does when a coaching job comes open: Call Bill Cowher. …As a side note, early in that Monday night loss, Falcons receiver Roddy White scored a touchdown. White, who is having his best pro season without the disgraced quarterback Michael Vick, then lifted up his jersey to reveal a homemade T-shirt with the words, “Free Mike Vick.”

headline: World Club Top 10: Flight of the Red Wings, Roar of the Bears
text: Detroit’s seven-game winning streak has lifted the Red Wings to the No. 3 slot in the World Top 10. The Motor City side are the only dominant club in the N.H.L., which so far this season has seen unusual parity. (Only 12 standings points separate the overall 3rd-place team from 30th going into Tuesday’s games.) But with this latest streak, the Wings threaten to open up a lead as intimidating as Salavat’s in the Russian Superliga.

headline: Republican Presidential Debate
text: Following is a transcript of the Republican presidential debate in Johnston, Iowa, as provided by the Federal News Service.

headline: For the Moment | The Costume Institute’s Harold Koda and Andrew Bolton
text: Bolton, left, and Koda(Karen Willis)

headline: Staying Alive
text: A night out with Brian Bergdoll, a John Travolta impersonator.

headline: The Huckabee Factor
text: Mike Huckabee walked into the lobby of the Des Moines Marriott at 5:30 a.m. on Dec. 3, deposited an armful of dirty laundry at the desk and checked to make sure he was being credited with Marriott Rewards points toward his next stay. Then, accompanied by his wife, Janet, his daughter, Sarah, and his press secretary, Alice Stewart — who doubles as his Boston Marathon trainer — he walked into the dark, freezing morning, climbed into a waiting S.U.V. and headed for Central College in Pella, Iowa.

headline: Interactive Resort Guides
text: Looking for a skiing getaway? New interactive resort guides from The Times point out the best parts of the slopes, plus provide insider tips and recommendations for lodging and dining. Learn about the best spots in Aspen, Colo., Park City, Utah, Hunter, New York, and other hot locations around the country. New destinations are added weekly.

headline: Elliott Carter at 99
text: Now here’s a way to celebrate your birthday: Gather hundreds of affectionate fans in a theater, sit as they watch a rare performance of your only opera and bathe in their applause.So it was for the Elliott Carter, who turned 99 on Tuesday and is one of the most eminent living composers. He was attending the final showing in a run of his opera “What Next?” The work, a sort of musical “Waiting for Godot” with six singers, was being staged for the first time in New York, Mr. Carter’s city of origin and his home for many years.The opera is just 40 minutes long, and occupied the second half of the program, which took place at the Miller Theater. The first half consisted of Carter chamber works, ranging from an unaccompanied violin solo to a six-member ensemble.At intermission, a stream of people came up to Mr. Carter, who was seated in an aisle seat in the third row. Many wished him a happy birthday. He signed a compact disc of his music. He accepted an organic chocolate bar from a female admirer, and took a bite. He greeted each person amiably, sometimes leaning forward to hear better.Seated around him were his friends and supporters in the music world, including the bass clarinetist Virgil Blackwell, a musical collaborator and close friend. Charles Rosen, the pianist and scholar who recently wrote about his connection to Mr. Carter in The New York Times, was there. So were other musical satraps, including Joseph Polisi, the president of the Juilliard School, and Ara Guzelimian, the school’s dean and a former administrator of Carnegie Hall.After the opera performance, the cast took its bows in a row on the stage. The conductor, Jeffrey Milarsky, a busy specialist in contemporary music, was up there too. Then he gestured for the audience to rise, which it did, and the whole house began singing “Happy Birthday” to Mr. Carter, who approached the stage, turned and waved to the audience and clapped one hand against the other, which was holding a cane. He had a big smile on his face. Many people cheered.

headline: Clinton’s ‘Gore Moment’
text: The big question you hear right now if you cover politics for a living — and thus no one thinks you’re really good for talking about more interesting things, like, say, the celebrity version of “The Apprentice” — is just what’s happening to Hillary Rodham Clinton. A month ago Washington had moved on to speculating about her running mate (my guess if she wins Iowa: Tom Vilsack); now she’s in a three-way tie in Iowa and losing her lead in New Hampshire faster than Mitt Romney changes positions. Is she seriously in danger of coming undone? Is she still in command of the race? There is an appropriately Clintonian way to answer these questions, which is yes to both.The first presidential campaign I covered was Bill Bradley’s 2000 run against Al Gore. (I met my wife on that campaign, so it wasn’t a total loss.) People forget this now, but there was a moment, at about this time in 1999, when Mr. Bradley came stunningly close to stealing the Democratic nomination. Mr. Gore was a sitting vice president, with all of the institutional support in the party, as well as the labor unions and the interest groups and the big-money bundlers and the bulletproof limo and, of course, the prosperity and relative peace of the Clinton years at his back. And yet here was Mr. Bradley, three years removed from his last public office, surging to a lead in New Hampshire and gaining so much ground in Iowa, a state in which he hadn’t even planned to compete, that his campaign decided to send dozens of staff there. (It was, in retrospect, a huge tactical blunder, but Iowa is like that, tantalizingly within reach one minute and 56,000 square miles of pure quicksand the next.) In those tense weeks, you could almost hear the monstrous machinery of the Democratic establishment squeak as it teetered away from Gore.

headline: Flying Solo
text: I saw my first iPod vending machine a little over a year ago at Atlanta’s Hartsfield-Jackson Airport. It looked pretty much like a vending machine from which you buy Skittles and Doritos, except boxier and you stick in your credit card and out comes a $250 iPod. I’ve since seen a few more of these at other airports. I’ve never seen anyone actually buy anything from them, but I often see people gathered around them, the looks on their faces saying, well, here’s more evidence that America has finally gone off the rails.

headline: Huckabee Apologizes to Romney Over Mormon Comments
text: JOHNSTON, Iowa — In the jammed spin room here after the Republican debate, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee told CNN that he had apologized to Mitt Romney and told him that Mormonism (Mr. Romney’s religion) should not be part of the campaign. (This tidbit thanks to Mark Halperin and The Page. ) “I am being much more cautious now,” Mr. Huckabee said, repeating something he’d mentioned during the debate here about how his words were reverberating more as he gained prominence in the polls.Mr. Huckabee has been taking heat within the last day for remarks he made in a magazine article for The Times, in which he asked whether Mormons believe that Jesus and Satan arebrothers.
