headline: Immelt: Television Networks Must Change
text: Add Jeffrey Immelt to the chorus of voices who are questioning the fundamental business model of network television.

headline: Quotation From Chairman Mao: Play Ball
text: The members of the United States U-23 men’s national team are hardly walking around Changsha, China, toting copies of Mao’s “Little Red Book.” That said, the team will be playing a game in the city where Mao Zedong, the leader of the People’s Republic of China from 1949 until his death in 1976, began his political career.

headline: Bebo Copies Facebook, Which Invites Others to Do the Same
text: When last we looked at the world of “platforms” that let developers write applications for social networks, Google had announced its OpenSocial standard, backed by MySpace, LinkedIn and others. This was meant to counter the activity on Facebook, which had generated a lot of applications with its own platform introduced in August.

headline: Admit It, Globie
text: The Bagger thinks confession is good for the soul, and not bad for the blog either, so he will admit a few fantasy scenarios for Thursday morning’s Golden Globe nominations, which will unfold here and elsewhere in almost real time. The Bagger has fingies crossed that Frank Langella gets a best actor, drama, nod for “Starting Out in the Evening.” Philip Seymour Hoffman gets a best actor, comedy or musical, nom for “Charlie Wilson’s War.” And “Once,” a movie about how music is forged in the spaces between people, gets best picture nomination, musical or comedy. A nerd can dream, no? What do you hope/wish/root for?

headline: Spitzer Shores Up Pension Rules
text: With the New York attorney general conducting a sprawling investigation of the state pension fund, the Spitzer administration sought to shore up Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli’s efforts to improve oversight and internal controls over the $154 billion fund.Under a new regulation issued by the insurance commission — which has special jurisdiction over the comptroller’s office — a new audit committee will be created to review internal and external audits as well as a new actuarial committee to review the assumptions used to calculate the benefits payments the fund will make in the future.

headline: Amtrak Settlement: Faster Ride to Albany?
text: The State Department of Transportation today settled a longstanding lawsuit with Amtrak over a never-completed project to bring high-speed rail to the Albany-New York run. And though the settlement will not itself bring the project to fruition, it may open the door to significant capital and track improvements that could bring down times on the train ride deeply familiar to, among others, Albany lawmakers from downstate districts, who take the train twice a week during much of the year.

headline: Bloggingheads: Saleable Candidates
text:
Bloggers Matthew Yglesias, left, and Ross Douthat, both of the Atlantic, discuss which party's presidential candidates will make for more effective ads.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Just a Few Debate Leftovers
text: DES MOINES — Well, we’d have to agree with our colleague Katharine Q. Seelye that not much news was made here today during the debate among the Republican candidates.

headline: “Afternoons with Worsom”
A Life Less Dolce
text: Italians, despite their claim to have mastered the art of living, report themselves to be the least happy people in Western Europe.

headline: Edwards Takes Aim at Republicans
text: GRINNELL, Iowa – Maybe it was the buzz around the Republican debate today, or a new CNN poll that showed John Edwards beating all of the top Republican contenders in a hypothetical presidential election.

headline: "The Harry Situation"
text: A make-believe TV show rolls its credits.

headline: Clip From "The Harry Situation"
text: A make-believe show stages an accident.

headline: Privacy Groups Question F.T.C. Chairwoman’s DoubleClick Ties
text: Two privacy groups filed a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission today asking the commission’s chairwoman, Deborah Platt Majoras, to recuse herself from the commission’s review of Google’s merger with DoubleClick.

headline: Clinton May End Relationship With Burkle Firm
text: Former President Bill Clinton is in negotiations to sever his relationship with the Yucaipa Funds, a privately held California investment firm headed by Ronald W. Burkle, according to two people familiar with the discussions.

headline: A Fee Jackpot in Cannery Casino Deal
text: As Australia’s Crown hopes to reap rewards from its $1.8 billion acquisition of Cannery Casino Resorts, so too do the advisers on the gambling deal.

headline: UrbanEye: Lucian Freud at MoMA
text: An installation featuring the etchings of celebrated British painter Lucian Freud opens at the Museum of Modern Art.  Melena Ryzik of The Times reports.

headline: Hot ‘Lanta
text: Gary Roberts can still fight and Mark Recchi, at 39, can still score. In his first game wearing a baby blue Thrashers jersey, Recchi, claimed on re-entry waivers from Pittsburgh last week, scored twice Wednesday in a 5-3 Atlanta loss to the Bruins. Recchi scored on the power play and then at even strength, playing wth Slava Kozlov and Eric Perrin. He logged 17:08, including 2:51 on the power play.

headline: Reading Room
text: Somehow, around 5 tonight, I ended up on Fifth Avenue, in the thick of holiday shoppers. I saw a man carrying a large cream Jimmy Choo bag, his fingertips lightly extended as though it were a basket of eggs; whatever was in the box, it had cost him enough to feel proud and, I suppose, pleased with himself. All those crisp, pleated shopping bags and the sense of having bought something special for someone, or at least having made a decision—it throbbed along the avenue. I was armed myself, with a large silvery white book, appropriately called “Be Dazzled! Norman Hartnell.” The 268-page book (Pointed Leaf Press) had come into my office, among others, and as I cracked it open, out came, it seemed, the froth of the British Empire. It’s a stunning book, full of information and surprise. Bill Cunningham, as cheery as Santa Claus, stopped by my desk and immediately took notice. “He was at his best for the Queen Mother,” Billy said of Hartnell, who began making clothes in the 1920s and died in 1979 (with few material possessions, apparently).

headline: Pakistan's Silent Majority
text: Writer David Rohde and photographer Thomas Munita report from rural Pakistan, where President Pervez Musharraf claims to be widely supported.

headline: The Comic Who Shook Italy
text: Stand-up comic turned blogger Beppe Grillo is building the first populist political movement seen in Italy for decades.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: Alison Smale, the IHT's managing editor, discusses events in the  world this week.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: The Man From Target
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Dec. 13 column.

headline: Arctic Update: Resilient Bears, Shrinking Ice
text: The warming Arctic is again making news, with a heap of findings unveiled at the fall meeting of the American Geophysical Union in San Francisco. There’s new evidence that polar bears have squeaked through past Arctic warm spells. And there are fresh findings on why the sea ice around the North Pole has seen dramatic summer retreats lately. That’s a subject dear to my heart ever since I got to spend three days with a climate team near the North Pole.Bear Facts[UPDATED below, 12/13]The BBC reported Monday on the discovery in Norway’s Svalbard archipelago of a polar bear jawbone that appears to be at least 110,000 years old. This is significant because it could confirm genetic hints that the species has lived through at least a couple of protracted warm spells in which Arctic temperatures were likely several degrees warmer than at present. (Polar bear remains are rare because they spend so much time patrolling far from land.) The bone was discovered by Olafur Ingolfsson of the University of Iceland.

headline: Manhattan: Strike Vote by Building Workers
text: Several thousand janitors, doormen and other employees who help clean and operate New York City’s office buildings voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to authorize a strike on Jan. 1 if the city’s real estate industry does not grant them the substantial raise their union is seeking. Mike Fishman, the union’s president, said that a large raise was warranted because office rents in Manhattan have jumped by more than 25 percent in the past year. Negotiators for the building owners say that the workers are already the nation’s highest paid and that the industry could be hurt by the shaky economy.

headline: A Great Pretender in Great Demand
text: Well, you can tell by the way Brian Bergdoll walks, he’s a woman’s man, no time to talk. Also, in this particular instance, he was very late.

headline: Survey Points to Tensions Among Chief Minorities
text: Distrust and racial tension among Hispanics, Asians and blacks in the United States are pressing concerns for all three groups, a new national poll conducted in English, Spanish and five Asian languages has found.

headline: Who Invited the Dog?
text: IT was a dark and stormy night  actually four stormy nights  when Jayme Otto, 31, and her husband, Ryan Otto, 33, drove 1,200 miles from their home in Boulder, Colo., to her parents’ house in Cleveland for Christmas.

headline: Blue Dog Democrats Try to Keep Pay-as-You-Go Promise
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Dennis Moore of Kansas held up a photo of his eight grandchildren on Wednesday and promised not to saddle them with any more debt.

headline: Central Bankers to Lend Billions in Credit Crisis
text: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe on Wednesday announced the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

headline: Focus of Climate Talks Shifts to Helping Poor Countries Cope
text: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  With little progress on the primary goal of United Nations climate talks here  preventing further climate change  a secondary quest to help poor countries cope with the effects of a warming world has now become a central theme of the gathering.

headline: Cane Hobbles CBS
text: Back-to-back episodes of “Cane,” with Jimmy Smits, below, dragged CBS down to a fourth-place finish in the ratings on Tuesday among adults 18 to 49. NBC led the night over all, thanks mainly to its weight-loss competition, “The Biggest Loser,” which delivered the night’s best results in that demographic and 9.8 million total viewers, Nielsen estimated. NBC also got a boost at 8 from “Deal or No Deal” (11.3 million), although CBS’s “NCIS” rerun led that time slot with the largest audience (11.8 million). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers, but fourth in the 18-to-49 set, as its two episodes of “Cane” at 9 (8 million) and 10 (7.8 million) continued to fare poorly in that age group. ABC was third over all, leading the 10 p.m. hour with “Boston Legal” (9 million). In the 8 p.m. hour, ABC broadcast two animated specials, an encore showing of “Shrek the Halls” (10 million) followed by “A Winnie the Pooh Christmas” (8.5 million). Repeats on Fox put that network in fourth place in total viewers, but second in the 18-to-49 group.

headline: Extra Spacewalk for Astronauts on Space Station
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  American astronauts aboard the International Space Station said Thursday that they will perform an extra spacewalk next week to examine a malfunctioning joint that turns a set of solar power panels.

headline: Groban No. 1 for Third Week
text: Josh Groban has tied Elvis Presley for the most consecutive weeks on the top of the Billboard chart for a Christmas album. His “Noël” (Reprise) is at No. 1 for the third week in a row, selling 581,000 copies in the week that ended on Sunday, an 8 percent increase over the previous week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Total sales for “Noël” are 2.1 million. The only new album in the Top 10 this week is “Audio Day Dream” (Arista) by the “American Idol” runner-up Blake Lewis, which opens at No. 10 with 98,000 sales. Otherwise, the Top 10 is a slight reshuffling of familiar recent hits: Alicia Keys is No. 2, the Eagles No. 3, the compilation “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 26 is No. 4, “Hannah Montana 2/Meet Miley Cyrus” (Disney) is No. 5, the “High School Musical 2” soundtrack is No. 6, Carrie Underwood No. 7, Garth Brooks No. 8 and Taylor Swift No. 9.

headline: Freddie Fields, Hollywood Talent Agent, Dies at 84
text: Freddie Fields, a retired Hollywood producer, studio executive and agent who helped found Creative Management Associates, one of the industry’s most influential talent agencies in the 1960s and early ’70s, died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 84.

headline: 3 Big Banks See No Relief as Write-Offs Mount Up
text: The Bank of America Corporation, the Wachovia Corporation and PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected, the latest indication that the credit markets are not returning to normal.

headline: As Woods Enters Prime, Time Is on His Side
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  The face of the man is still boyish, unlined and smooth, with no hints of age around the eyes or cruelty at the corners of the mouth. The famous smile is quick and ready to light up any room. On this day, as with most, it is a room with a view  of the golden foothills of the Santa Monica Mountains, dotted with mansions above the impossibly manicured Sherwood Country Club, where Tiger Woods will end his 2007 season this week by playing host to the Target World Challenge.

headline: Parasites in Fish Farms Threaten Salmon, Researchers Say
text: Parasites that breed in fish farms kill so many juvenile wild salmon that they threaten the survival of fish populations in some rivers and streams, Canadian researchers are reporting.

headline: Swiss Parliament Deals Setback to Leader of Far-Right Party
text: GENEVA  Less than two months after the controversial justice minister, Christoph Blocher, led the far-right Swiss People’s Party to a comfortable election victory, parliamentarians ejected him from the Federal Council, which runs the government by consensus.

headline: Birthday Greetings for Elliott Carter at 99
text: Now here’s a way to celebrate your birthday: Gather hundreds of affectionate fans in a theater, sit as they watch a rare performance of your only opera, and bathe in their applause. So it was for the composer Elliott Carter right, who turned 99 on Tuesday. He was attending the final showing in a run of his opera, “What Next?,” at the Miller Theater. The work was being staged for the first time in New York. The first half of the concert consisted of chamber music by Mr. Carter, followed by the opera after the intermission. During the break a stream of people came up to him. Many wished him a happy birthday. He signed a CD of his music. He accepted an organic chocolate bar from a female admirer, and took a bite. After the opera performance and bows by the cast members, they joined with the audience in round of “Happy Birthday.”

headline: Kasparov Says He Was Forced to End Bid for Presidency
text: MOSCOW  Garry Kasparov, the opposition leader and former chess champion, said Wednesday that he had been forced to withdraw his candidacy for president of Russia because his political movement had been unable to rent a hall in Moscow for a nominating convention, a requirement under Russian law.

headline: Rosanne Cash Is Recovering
text: The singer and songwriter Rosanne Cash was reported to be recovering at her New York home after brain surgery last month at New York-Presbyterian Hospital to correct what was called a rare but benign condition. Her record label, Manhattan Records, deemed the surgery successful. It added that Ms. Cash, 52, a Grammy Award winner and the eldest of the five children of Johnny Cash, is expected to resume recording her debut album for Manhattan in the spring. She also plans live performances and a book to be published by Viking early in 2009.

headline: Carried Away With Imitation Luxury
text: “LOOK sharp!” Waving a passer-by to his cart at Madison Avenue and 67th Street, Omar, the vendor, pointed to the logo on one of his most popular items, a canvas tote bag patterned in a familiar-looking interlocking chevron. “This one is the wrong writing,” he murmured.

headline: For Los Angeles Museum, a ‘Transformative’ Gift of Modernists
text: LOS ANGELES  The Los Angeles County Museum of Art announced Wednesday that it had been promised a gift of 130 mostly Modernist works, including 20 by Picasso, a group of 21 watercolors and paintings by Paul Klee and Wassily Kandinsky and sculptures by Alberto Giacometti. The museum described the gift as a “transformative addition” to its collection that “in many cases represents Lacma’s first major work by that artist.”

headline: Canada: Mounties Urged to Restrict Taser Use
text: In a report, the watchdog commission that oversees the Royal Canadian Mounted Police recommended that Taser stun guns be used only on people who are “combative or posing a risk of death or grievous bodily harm,” much like a conventional firearm rather than a nightstick or pepper spray. The report was ordered by the government after a confused and angry Polish immigrant, Robert Dziekanski, left, died at the airport in Vancouver after being stunned at least twice by Mounties. The report found that Tasers were increasingly being used against people who were merely resistant rather than dangerous.

headline: Express Track to a Fare Increase
text: Next week, the board of the state Metropolitan Transportation Authority is scheduled to vote on raising tolls and fares for mass transit. But the real decision seems to have been made already. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who wants the increase and approves the appointments of board members, won the support of Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who controls 4 of the board’s 14 members. It is unlikely that the board, really independent in name only, would defy them.

headline: Many Paths but One Goal
text: JUST as varieties of yoga exist, so do styles of facial acupuncture, each with a different emphasis.

headline: A Chapter of ‘Jackass’ as Web Test
text: LOS ANGELES  Paramount Pictures is lurching onto the Web with its “Jackass” franchise, with what it says will be the first studio-backed feature film to have its premiere online. And the studio hopes the result will be considerably more pleasurable than the old MTV show’s trademark shot to the groin  perhaps by paving the way for more profit-making Web-only material.

headline: Postpartum Impression
text: PARIS

headline: Smithsonian Money Woes
text: Addressing maintenance and security expenses at the Smithsonian, representatives of that institution and the Government Accountability Office testified before a Senate committee Wednesday about its financial challenges. The government estimated that the Smithsonian would have $2.5 billion in unmet maintenance and security needs through 2013, including deferred projects. That amount did not account for structural problems at its 1881 flagship Arts and Industries building, which has been closed and empty since January 2004. Cristián Samper, above, acting secretary of the Smithsonian, said $100 million is needed to repair the roof and other parts of that building, while another $100 million is needed to update and maintain its collection. Further, he said, about $400 million is needed for the planned National Museum of African American History and Culture. Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California and chairwoman of the Senate committee, said she and appropriations subcommittees are working toward creating a $45 million public and private matching program for maintenance and revitalization projects at the Smithsonian. If established, the fund would appropriate $15 million in matching federal money once the Smithsonian raises $30 million in private funds.

headline: Fame’s Demands, and the Flights of Fancy to Escape
text: Alvin Ailey had a love-hate relationship with fame. He began his career in dance as a take-charge young artist whose performing and fledgling choreography were fueled more by apparent self-confidence than by deep knowledge of the art form. He had started under the tutelage of Lester Horton, a charismatic dance mentor in Los Angeles, where Ailey grew up. But Horton died, in 1953, too soon to give the would-be dancer much sense of continuity and tradition. Ailey left for New York in 1954 and never stopped, achieving what passes for acclaim in the humble world of dance. That was a burden he both accepted and felt oppressed by. And he eventually identified with artists for whom fame became notoriety.

headline: Drive Maker in China to Be Sold to Iomega
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Iomega, an American distributor of computer data storage equipment, said Wednesday that it was entering into a complex $310 million deal to acquire ExcelStor, a Chinese contract maker of disk drives.

headline: Little Headway With China on Finance
text: XIANGHE  China and the United States ended three days of intense economic talks on Thursday with new accords on food safety, energy and environmental cooperation but making what Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. conceded was only modest progress in opening China’s financial markets.

headline: Fever Promotes Assistant
text: The Indiana Fever hired the assistant Lin Dunn to replace Coach Brian Winters on Wednesday. Dunn, who spent four seasons as a Fever assistant coach, succeeds Winters, who was 78-58 in four seasons and guided the W.N.B.A. team to three playoff appearances. Winters was let go in October with a year left on his contract. Dunn will be the Fever’s fourth coach in their eight-year history. Dunn went 33-63 as the coach and general manager of the expansion Seattle Storm from 1999-2002. With the Storm, she drafted Lauren Jackson, the eventual league most valuable player, and Sue Bird.

headline: Determining Whether a Turbine Will Work
text: BEFORE buying a wind turbine, a homeowner should learn how much electricity he uses (utility companies can provide a usage history), and assess local wind speeds.

headline: An Appeal for Calm After Suicide Bombings in Algeria
text: ALGIERS  A day after suicide terror attacks rocked Algeria’s capital, the country’s foreign minister urged calm on Wednesday, saying that the bombings did not portend civil war.

headline: Lawyer Who Showed Producer Around Wants a Cut From ‘The Sopranos’
text: TRENTON  It is a tale of influence, of promises, favors and made men, not unlike an episode of “The Sopranos.”

headline: A Voice to Guide You on the Road
text: G.P.S. didn’t always stand for Global Positioning System, you know.

headline: Power Loss From Storm Is Lingering
text: Hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses in the nation’s midsection remained without electricity on Wednesday after being hit by an ice storm that pulled down power lines, cracked tree limbs and closed schools, highways and airports.

headline: China: Retail Sales Show Big Jump
text: China’s retail sales increased at the quickest rate in at least eight years on rising incomes, helping government efforts to curb the economy’s dependence on exports and investment to achieve growth. Sales climbed 18.8 percent, to 810.5 billion yuan ($110 billion), in November from a year earlier, the statistics bureau said, after rising 18.1 percent in October. That was the biggest gain since 1999, according to Bloomberg data.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Birthday Greetings for Elliott Carter at 99

headline: Adult Contemporary’s Darling Shows Off His Range
text: It’s easy to like the trumpeter Chris Botti. It’s easy not to like him, too. Since the release of his first solo album in 1995, Mr. Botti has burnished an image of pensive romance, achieving stardom in the realm of adult-contemporary pop. His faintly jazz-inflected style  traceable to the Miles Davis of late-1950s vintage, around “Porgy and Bess” and “Kind of Blue”  luxuriates in melody and mood. He’s Sting-endorsed and Oprah-approved, with brooding looks that any camera seems to love.

headline: Australia: Casino Chain Expands in Las Vegas
text: Australia’s largest casino company, Crown Ltd., said it agreed to buy Cannery Casino Resorts for $1.75 billion, expanding its business in Las Vegas. Cannery Casino, which is privately held, operates three Las Vegas casinos, including the Cannery Casino and Hotel and the Nevada Palace casino, and the Meadows Racetrack and Casino south of Pittsburgh. This month, Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd. split into separate listed companies, Crown and Consolidated Media Holdings Ltd. A private company led by James D. Packer, above, Consolidated Press Holdings Ltd., owns 38 percent of Crown’s stock.

headline: Durant: A Sweet Tooth and a Sweet Jumper
text: During the final minute of Seattle’s 117-110 victory over the Knicks Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, the Seattle rookie Kevin Durant had the ball with a 4-point lead and drove the lane against two defenders to try to secure the victory.

headline: Baseball Braces for Steroid Report From Mitchell
text: George J. Mitchell’s report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, to be unveiled Thursday afternoon, will be highly critical of the commissioner’s office and the players’ union for tolerating the presence of drugs throughout years of abuse, a person who has read the closely guarded report said Wednesday.

headline: Still Life With Parties and Hedge Funds
text: Miami Beach

headline: Selected Studies: Infertility in Women
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Britain: Microsoft Buys Map Service
text: Microsoft said it had agreed to acquire MultiMap, an online map service based in London, in an attempt to compete more effectively with the search services of Google and to collect more revenue from online and mobile advertising. The MultiMap Web site aids consumers in finding elusive addresses throughout Europe and the United States and in much of the rest of the world. It also offers services for business customers, allowing them to include maps on their Web sites. The acquisition, for an undisclosed amount, is part of a race by Microsoft and its competitors online to further develop their digital mapping abilities.

headline: Hungry Caterpillar in the Florida Keys
text: LIKE the butterfly-to-be in his most famous book, “The Very Hungry Caterpillar,” Eric Carle is changing.

headline: At a Yiddish Cabaret, Hope, Despair and Song
text: Across an emotional spectrum from saucy irreverence, high spirits and nostalgia to the bitterest despair and back to hope, “Kleynkunst!” revisits the little-known but vibrant Yiddish cabaret that flourished in Warsaw from the early 1920s until it disappeared by Nazi design in the ghetto of that city, where Jews in 1928 constituted 30 percent of the population.

headline: Mideast Teams Begin Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli and Palestinian negotiators on Wednesday held their first meeting in what was supposed to begin a final peace process as envisioned by the American-sponsored conference in Annapolis, Md., last month, but the talks were marred by conflicting agendas and overshadowed by a sharp escalation of hostilities in and around the Gaza Strip.

headline: Crossover Dreams: Turning Free Web Work Into Real Book Sales
text: Three years ago “Diary of a Wimpy Kid,” a children’s novel illustrated with cartoons, was published online, where anyone could read it free. To this day anyone still can, at Funbrain.com, an educational Web site.

headline: Teenage Birth Rates
text: To the Editor:

headline: C.I.A. Chief Cites Agency Lapse on Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, acknowledged on Wednesday that the C.I.A. had failed to keep members of Congress fully informed that the agency had videotaped the interrogations of suspected operatives of Al Qaeda and destroyed the tapes three years later.

headline: U.S. Links Smuggled Cash to Venezuela
text: BUENOS AIRES - A Miami man who brought $800,000 in a suitcase into Argentina was trying to deliver a campaign contribution from the Venezuelan government to the Argentine presidential candidate Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, American prosecutors said Wednesday.

headline: Charity’s Share From Shopping Raises Concern
text: Shopping has become virtuous, especially at this time of year. Buy a “Better World” scarf at American Eagle Outfitters, and the retailer says $10 of the $19.95 price will go to one of three charities. Buy or lease a BMW this month, and participating dealers say they will give $25 to the Make-A-Wish Foundation.

headline: A Flock of Shows, Touched by Faith
text: It is almost certainly true that no person, regardless of religious commitment, has ever taken to the freeways with a bumper sticker that reads, “Who took Christ out of the Christmas special?”

headline: At Sallie Mae, a Rejection and a Downward Forecast
text: The parent company of Sallie Mae, the student lender, cut its profit forecast for 2008 on Wednesday and said that its offer to strike a new deal with a group of investors had been rejected.

headline: Shareholders Back Dow Jones Sale
text: Rupert Murdoch won control on Thursday of a long-coveted prize, The Wall Street Journal, one of the world’s most-respected and powerful newspapers, when shareholders of The Journal’s publisher, Dow Jones & Company, gave their blessing to a takeover by Mr. Murdoch’s global media empire, the News Corporation.

headline: G.O.P. Debate Sheds Little New Light
text: The last Republican presidential debate before the Iowa caucuses, a sleepy affair, was nearly over on Wednesday when one of the less-known candidates, Representative Tom Tancredo, decided to launch an attack on one of the leading candidates. “I have to say it, because you’re leading the pack now, and congratulations to you, governor ...” he began.

headline: Media Analyst Takes Post at Time Warner
text: Time Warner has quietly hired a prominent media analyst as it reshuffles its executive ranks in the weeks before Jeffrey L. Bewkes takes over as chief executive from Richard D. Parsons.

headline: Short, Unhappy Union of Petrino and Falcons Reaches a Bitter End
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  A copy of the letter Bobby Petrino left for his players informing them he was resigning as the Atlanta Falcons’ head coach was lying on the carpet of the locker room late Wednesday. It was crumpled as if it had been thrown to the floor in disgust.

headline: Performing Arts Library Awarded Major Grant
text: A $1 million grant has been awarded to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts by the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. The grant, beginning on Feb. 1 and continuing until Jan. 31, 2010, will enable the library to record about 25 live jazz, contemporary dance and theater performances, as well as about 45 histories with personalities related to those performances. In addition, the library will preserve 70 hours of oral histories concerning the life and work of the dancer and choreographer Martha Graham (1894-1991). These tapes, housed in the library, were described as being extremely fragile and deteriorating.

headline: Federal Judge Upholds Law on Emissions in California
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge in Sacramento on Wednesday upheld a California law regulating greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks, another in a string of legal defeats for the auto industry this year.

headline: How to Thaw an iPhone
text: Q. When my iPhone locks up, is there any way to get out of the situation besides powering it off and on again?

headline: A Source Takes the Day Off as the Heat Builds
text: Kirk Radomski had the day off Wednesday. Radomski’s black chair inside the office of Pro Touch Detail Center in St. James, N.Y., was empty. Vinny Greco, Radomski’s business partner, stressed that Radomski’s absence had nothing to do with the impending release of George J. Mitchell’s steroid report Thursday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A television review in Weekend on Nov. 30 about “Tin Man,” a mini-series on the Sci Fi Channel based on “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz” by L. Frank Baum, referred imprecisely to an interpretation of Baum’s having Dorothy wear silver shoes on the yellow-brick road. While the juxtaposition of the colors has been seen by some as indicating Mr. Baum’s support for the monetary system of bimetallism, he is not known to have advocated that system.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A theater review on Tuesday about “Yellow Face” by David Henry Hwang, at the Public Theater, misidentified the nationality of the actor Jonathan Pryce, whose starring role as a Eurasian in the New York production of “Miss Saigon” was criticized by Mr. Hwang. (The dispute is used as the taking-off point for “Yellow Face.”) Mr. Pryce is Welsh, not English.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Plumeria in Winter

headline: Canada Acts to Reopen Reactor Producing Medical Isotope
text: OTTAWA  Overriding the safety concerns of its regulator, the Canadian government is rushing through legislation to reopen a nuclear reactor that produces most of the world’s supply of a medically important diagnostic isotope.

headline: Rockland County Family Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
text: After 18 years of selling investments in a fictitious Brazilian gold mining operation and using the Internet to sell wholesale merchandise they never delivered, a Rockland County family of five pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges of defrauding victims across the nation and in Europe of millions of dollars, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Winter Storm Blows Into Northeast
text: The Northeast hunkered down as the first major winter storm of the season descended on the area, bringing visions of snow plows and shovels and the possibility of having to make alternate plans for the children if school is canceled on Friday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Sunday about ethnic tensions in northern Iraq’s oil-rich city of Kirkuk over its uncertain political future misstated the capital of neighboring Turkey, which opposes a desire by Iraqi Kurds to control Kirkuk and wants to safeguard Kirkuk’s Turkmen minority. It is Ankara, not Istanbul. The article also misidentified the area of Turkey where most of its ethnic Kurdish population lives. It is the southeast, not northeast. And the article misstated the ethnic background of Tahsin Kahya, a member of the Kirkuk Provincial Council, who said that a constitutional referendum on Kirkuk’s future, which is supposed to be held before Dec. 31, should be delayed for years. He is a Turkmen, not an Arab. (Go to Article)

headline: Writers Guild Grants a Waiver
text: What would screen actors be without screenwriters? Rather than let the world learn the answer, the striking Writers Guild of America granted a waiver to let the Screen Actors Guild hire a writer to provide material for the 14th annual SAG Awards in Los Angeles on Jan. 27, Reuters reported. Nominations are to be announced on Dec. 20. The guild, on strike since Nov. 5, also granted waivers for the recent Kennedy Center Honors in Washington and a charity event on the Paramount lot in Hollywood.

headline: An Inspiring Life, Built on a History of Pain
text: Diana Martin says she has lived through so much drama that she could write a book. Themes would include abandonment, loss of a son, the murder of her one true love and perseverance through years of difficulty.

headline: A Holiday Helper for the Computer Savvy
text: Are you the computer-savvy member of your family, the one who goes home for the holidays only to find yourself in front of multiple computers, trouble-shooting instead of celebrating?

headline: A Little Silver Is as Good as Gold
text: ON Oct. 22, Alaska Airlines flight 345 from San Francisco to Portland, Ore., was a sea of shell-pink T-shirts and plum-colored sweatshirts, worn by rows of stiff-legged participants from the Nike women’s marathon and half-marathon. Around each finisher’s neck was a dainty Tiffany sterling silver pendant. In the first row of coach, one woman told her seatmate in hushed tones that she had spotted a woman in first class wearing pendants from all four years of the race (one is pictured at left).

headline: Florida Court Rejects Claim, a Boon for Morgan Stanley
text: The Florida Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected an appeal by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, who asked the court to restore a $1.58 billion verdict against the investment bank Morgan Stanley.

headline: A Beloved Spanish Gypsy Returns to France’s Arms
text: PARIS  Although the Paris Opera is the place where Romantic ballets like “La Sylphide” (1832) and “Giselle” (1841) had their world premieres, it isn’t where they survived. When Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes brought “Giselle” to Paris in 1910, the French had to be reminded that this ballet was a chunk of their own cultural history.

headline: You Won’t Find Me in My Office, I’m Working
text: IF you’re looking for Bryan Judkins, you won’t find him at his desk. “I use it as a coat rack,” he said of his work space at Young & Laramore, an advertising agency in Indianapolis, where he is the associate creative director. “People see my coat and know I’m in the building.”

headline: A Monster and Fireworks Let You Know Someone Nearby Is Using a Cellphone
text: In a twist on the Webkinz model  pairing a password-tagged toy with an online world  Moshi Monsters (www.moshimonsters.com) are a family of six monsters that live in a light-up cellphone charm and, virtually, in an online home you create.

headline: Hold the Chemicals, Bring on the Needles
text: JANE BECKER, a composer and solo pianist, celebrated her 50th birthday at the dermatologist, paying $1,500 for shots of Restylane and Botox. But three months later, their wrinkle-smoothing effects wore off. So, she turned to a less-artificial youth tonic: facial acupuncture.

headline: Tolerable Wearable Artwork
text: IS there any expression in fine jewelry more noxious-sounding than a necklace or bracelet that is described as “wearable art”?

headline: The Best Doctors: The Elusive Best Standard
text: To the Editor:

headline: Markets Still Uneasy After Loan Plan
text: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe on Wednesday announced the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

headline: On Central Park Benches, Inscriptions Remember the Dead and Celebrate Life
text: In this city, known for its writers, even Central Park’s benches have stories to tell. From marriage proposals and deaths to cast members celebrating a Broadway success, each adopted bench is maintained for life and engraved with a personal message. “Michelle, will you marry me? Love, John,” reads a brass plaque on a bench near the zoo. She said yes.

headline: Looking Through Lens of Time, Mangini Did the Right Thing
text: Hempstead, N.Y.

headline: U.S. Presses China on Economic Issues
text: XINGHE, China  A delegation of senior American economic officials led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. churned through a long day of meetings Wednesday with their Chinese counterparts, picking and poking at many economic issues but encountering arguments from the Chinese on several fronts.

headline: Small Businesses Oppose Mandates for Health Plans
text: The small-business lobbying group that had a big role in derailing Hillary Rodham Clinton’s effort to overhaul health care in the early 1990s has staked out its position for the 2008 political season.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about long delays in the resolution of Social Security disability claims misspelled the surname of the legislative director of the National Council for Social Security Management Associations, who commented on the delays. He is Rick Warsinskey, not Warsinsky. The article also misidentified the North Carolina city in which Walter Patterson, a disability lawyer, has his practice. It is Statesville, not Charlotte.

headline: After Clashes, Fear of War on Congo’s Edge
text: SAKE, Congo  A major confrontation between the Congolese Army and a renegade general is plunging the country back toward war, threatening to undermine the fledgling democratic state and set off a new regional conflict on a scale not seen here in years.

headline: Buying Postage From Your Desk
text: Buying Postage From Your Desk

headline: Traffic Panel Keeps East River Bridge Tolls on Table
text: The chairman of the state commission studying ways to reduce traffic in Manhattan is increasingly pushing a measure certain to prompt opposition in the rest of the city: charging tolls on the four East River Bridges.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Sunday about ethnic tensions in northern Iraq’s oil-rich city of Kirkuk over its uncertain political future misstated the capital of neighboring Turkey, which opposes a desire by Iraqi Kurds to control Kirkuk and wants to safeguard Kirkuk’s Turkmen minority. It is Ankara, not Istanbul. The article also misidentified the area of Turkey where most of its ethnic Kurdish population lives. It is the southeast, not northeast. And the article misstated the ethnic background of Tahsin Kahya, a member of the Kirkuk Provincial Council, who said that a constitutional referendum on Kirkuk’s future, which is supposed to be held before Dec. 31, should be delayed for years. He is a Turkmen, not an Arab.

headline: After Eulogies, Years of Litigation for Police Widow
text: When Officer John M. Kelly crashed his police car during a chase on Staten Island in 2000, thousands of officers attended his funeral, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared: “John Kelly is a hero. Nobody can take that away.”

headline: ESPN Will Take on Army With Its Own High School Game
text: On Jan. 5, two high school postseason games will be played, each intended to show off a passel of future college football stars. NBC will broadcast the U.S. Army All-American Bowl at 1 p.m., to be followed an hour later by the Under Armour High School All-American Game on ABC.

headline: Lawyer Says Confession in Linda Stein Homicide Was Coerced
text: The woman accused of killing Linda S. Stein, the punk rock manager turned Fifth Avenue real estate broker, was coerced into confessing and should be released on bail, her lawyer told a judge on Wednesday at a hearing that ended with an angry confrontation between the families of the defendant and the victim.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the sentencing of Conrad M. Black, the former media mogul who was convicted of fraud, misspelled the name of the town where he bought his first newspaper. It is Sherbrooke, Quebec  not Sherbooke. The article also misstated, in some editions, the proximity of the federal prison camp at Eglin Air Force Base, where Mr. Black is likely to serve his sentence, to his Palm Beach, Fla., home. It is 500 miles away, it is not “near.”

headline: The E-Mail Fix at 10,000 Feet
text: Q. Do any airlines offer wireless broadband Internet connections?

headline: Hong Kong Leader Presses China for Vote
text: HONG KONG  Facing widespread demands from the public for full democracy to be introduced within five years, the Hong Kong government urged the Chinese government on Wednesday to set a firm timetable for direct elections for the region’s leader and legislature.

headline: The Hague: General Who Besieged Sarajevo Gets 33 Years
text: The International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia sentenced Dragomir Milosevic, left, a former Bosnian-Serb general, to 33 years in prison. He ordered the relentless shelling and sniper campaign that wounded and killed thousands of civilians in the besieged Bosnian capital, Sarejevo, for 15 months in 1994 and 1995. “There was no safe place in Sarajevo,” said the presiding judge, Patrick Robinson. “One could be killed and injured anywhere and anytime.”

headline: The Other ‘Atonement’ Love Story
text: ONIBURY, England

headline: Countrywide Subpoenaed by Illinois
text: The Illinois attorney general is investigating the home loan unit of Countrywide Financial as part of the state’s expanding inquiry into dubious lending practices that have trapped borrowers in high-cost mortgages they can no longer afford.

headline: Shootings Test Limits of New Self-Defense Law
text: PASADENA, Tex.  Joe Horn’s home was his castle, but what about his neighbor’s home?

headline: Jurors Deadlock on 6 of 7 in Sears Plot
text: MIAMI  One of seven indigent men accused of plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago as part of an Islamic jihad was acquitted on Thursday, but a mistrial was declared against the other six after the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked.

headline: Ike Turner, Musician and Songwriter in Duo With Tina Turner, Dies at 76
text: Ike Turner, the R&B musician, songwriter, bandleader, producer, talent scout and ex-husband of Tina Turner, died on Wednesday at his home in San Marcos, Calif., a San Diego suburb. He was 76.

headline: Senate Approves Energy Bill Without Tax Increase
text: WASHINGTON  Pared-down energy legislation cleared the Senate by a wide margin on Thursday evening after the oil industry and utilities succeeded in stripping out provisions that would have cost them billions of dollars.

headline: China: High-Rise Fire Kills 21
text: Twenty-one people were killed in a fire that tore through a 28-story apartment building in eastern Wenzhou. The Xinhua news agency said more than 200 firefighters battled the fire for three hours. About 200 residents were rescued or evacuated, it said. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

headline: Bangladesh: Sundarbans Devastated by November Cyclone
text: Unesco said that the cyclone that struck southern Bangladesh last month and killed 3,000 people also destroyed 40 percent of the Sundarbans, one of the world’s largest mangrove forests and a World Heritage site. The Sundarbans, on the delta of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and Meghna Rivers, is home to several endangered species, including the Bengal tiger, and is a source of livelihood for hundreds of thousands of people who subsist on fishing and shrimping. Unesco estimated that regeneration of the Sundarbans ecosystem would take 10 to 15 years.

headline: Final Debate Before Iowa Caucuses Shows Uncertainty at Top of Republican Field
text: The last Republican presidential debate before the Iowa caucuses, a sleepy affair, was nearly over on Wednesday when one of the less-known candidates, Representative Tom Tancredo, decided to mount an attack on one of the leading candidates.

headline: A Universe of Gadget Advice
text: BUYING a book online is easy, but buying electronics can be intimidating. Is it a good gift? Are you getting the right model? Are you getting a good deal, or getting taken?

headline: MTV to Let Freelancers Stay on Its Insurance
text: Acknowledging the concerns of hundreds of freelance workers, MTV Networks on Wednesday reversed some of the cuts it had intended to make to benefits packages.

headline: Gene Therapy, Revisited
text: In decisions followed closely by experts in performance-enhancing drugs, the Food and Drug Administration and the National Institutes of Health both ruled in the past two weeks that the death of an Illinois woman receiving gene therapy to treat her rheumatoid arthritis was not related to the therapy itself. The woman had developed a life-threatening infection that the regulators decided was due to other drugs she was taking.

headline: Italy Struggles Under Truck Strike
text: ROME  Gasoline became nearly impossible to find and supermarket shelves grew barer on Wednesday, the third day of a nationwide strike of heavy trucks in Italy that threatens deep paralysis by its planned end on Friday.

headline: Unearthing a Spy Who Couldn’t Keep Up With a Cop
text: “Watchman” represents a road not taken by Ian Rankin, the immensely popular Scottish mystery writer. This book, first published in Britain in 1988 but only now arriving in the United States, was the second crime novel written by an author who, whether or not he knew it at the time, was in search of an enduring antihero. If he had clung to the main character in “Watchman,” Mr. Rankin might have devoted two decades to the cloak-and-dagger adventures of a mildly James Bondian figure named Miles Flint.

headline: What to Ask About Infertility
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about the presidential race in California, incorrectly described the vessel that spilled 58,000 gallons of oil in San Francisco Bay on Nov. 7. It was a container ship, not a tanker.

headline: Lennon’s Hair Fetches Thousands
text: A lock of John Lennon’s hair attracted a winning bid of $48,000 on Wednesday at an auction in Worthing, England, The Associated Press reported. Carrying a presale estimate of $4,000 to $6,000, the hair, inside an autographed copy of Lennon’s book “A Spaniard in the Works,” above, went to an unidentified telephone bidder at a sale of Beatles memorabilia. “It’s astonishing that there is still so much interest in the Beatles, and the sale goes to prove that John Lennon is still an icon,” said Francesca Collin, a spokeswoman for the auction house, Gorringes. Lennon gave the hair and the book to Betty Glasow, the Beatles’ hairdresser in their heyday, who offered those items and others for sale. Nick Muston, a director of Gorringes, said Ms. Glasow decided to sell the material because she wanted fans to have it.

headline: Bomb Kills Lebanese General Who Battled Militants
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A powerful car bomb killed one of Lebanon’s top generals and his bodyguard in a suburb of Beirut on Wednesday, striking an unexpected blow at the country’s most widely respected institution and further undermining Lebanon’s precarious stability.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How much patterned wallpaper is too much?

headline: The N.F.L.’s Not-So-Perfect Season
text: Here's the conundrum for the National Football League: Two teams are on the brink of perfection -- the Patriots, as they march toward 19-0, and the Dolphins and their diametrically opposed slog to 0-16.

headline: Groups Refile Suit Over Immigration Law
text: Civil rights groups filed a new federal lawsuit challenging an Arizona law that would cancel the business licenses of employers found guilty of hiring illegal immigrants more than once in three years. An earlier suit by the groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union, was dismissed on Friday by Judge Neil V. Wake of Federal District Court, who said they had sued the wrong government officials. The groups said they expected the new lawsuit would address the judge’s concerns. The law is to take effect Jan. 1.

headline: Three Blasts Kill at Least 27 in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  At least 27 people died and 150 were wounded Wednesday when three car bombs ripped through a southern Iraqi city where the local authorities had recently taken over security responsibility from the British military and rival Shiite groups had been battling for control of oil and power.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, the On Education column on Wednesday, about the debate over allowing illegal immigrants to pay in-state tuition at public universities, referred incompletely to the legal status of Ysaira Paulino, an immigrant from the Dominican Republic. Although she indeed overstayed her visa when she was enrolled at the City College of New York, she now has a work permit, and has a petition pending to become a permanent resident.

headline: A Shameful Presidential Threat
text: The Senate should ignore an incredibly mischievous last-minute veto threat from the White House and vote resoundingly in favor of an energy bill that could come before it as early as today. The bill represents a historic opportunity to ease America’s dependence on foreign oil and to take steps in the battle against global warming, and its passage would send a message to the worlds’ negotiators in Bali that Washington is at last getting serious about climate change.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Giving Names to Souls Forgotten No Longer
text: THIELLS, N.Y.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,879 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: Knicks, Still Falling Apart, Lose to a Rebuilding Team
text: Kevin Durant has phenomenal talent, very little experience and not much help in the lineup that surrounds him. But it does not take much to beat the Knicks, and Durant’s considerable skills  combined with a former Knick’s heady play  was enough to send the Knicks to another humiliating defeat.

headline: Turning Points on the Road to Conception
text: Dr. Zev Rosenwaks is director of The Center for Reproductive Medicine and Infertility at New York-Presbyterian Hospital.

headline: Racing to Beat the Maternal Clock
text: In the nearly 30 years since Louise Brown made history as the first test-tube baby, more than one million infants have been conceived by means of in vitro fertilization. Assisted reproductive technologies continue to advance, but increasingly they are pushing against one of nature’s great barriers to fertility: maternal age.

headline: Cheers in Newark for a Housing Project’s Downfall
text: NEWARK  A green-spangled marching band shimmied and lunged to a crash of cymbals. Inside a giant tent, a five-piece band serenaded the crowd, which was dining on a Southern-style catered lunch. Save for the overcast skies, it was a glorious day for the destruction of a building.

headline: In a Funk, Italy Sings an Aria of Disappointment
text: ROME  All the world loves Italy because it is old but still glamorous. Because it eats and drinks well but is rarely fat or drunk. Because it is the place in a hyper-regulated Europe where people still debate with perfect intelligence what, really, the red in a stoplight might mean.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about an imprisoned rapist who confessed to nine decades-old murders in Missouri, Illinois and Kentucky, misstated the age of one victim in some editions. Deborah Sheppard was 23 at the time of her murder, not 21.

headline: New York Frees Oldest Inmate
text: Charles E. Friedgood, who at 89 had been the oldest inmate in a New York State prison, was released on Tuesday and granted permission to live with a sister in Florida, where a daughter also lives, the State Parole Board said on Wednesday.

headline: Men in Pelts (but Not Too Many Pelts)
text: FIVE years ago, Spencer Levy would have recoiled from the thought of wearing fur. But last year, Mr. Levy, a real estate broker in New York, spotted a Juicy Couture hoodie lined with rabbit (his wife, Michelle Wohlers, works in sales for the line) and, just like that, he changed his tune.

headline: How Dyslexics Think
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jets and Patriots Say It’s Just a Game. It’s Not.
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  The latest twist in the feud between the Jets and the New England Patriots involves another video camera. The Jets insist the latest installment in their bitter rivalry filled with spies, lies and alibis differs from the Spygate saga.

headline: Spines, Made Extra Curvy for Women
text: Pregnant women do not tip over, and the reason has a lot to do with an evolutionary curve, researchers say.

headline: Increases in Education Aid Range From 2 to 20 Percent Under Corzine Plan
text: Each of New Jersey’s 615 school districts would receive 2 percent to 20 percent more in state aid next year under a new financing formula officially unveiled by Gov. Jon S. Corzine on Wednesday, nearly two weeks after parts of the proposal were revealed by state lawmakers and state education officials.

headline: The Tax Debate That Isn’t
text: If there’s one issue on which Republican presidential hopefuls should feel vulnerable, it’s taxes. The Bush tax cuts, more than any other policy, are crippling the government financially.

headline: Secular Europe’s Merits
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland

headline: U.S. and Chinese Officials Duel on Economic Issues
text: XINGHE, China  A delegation of senior American economic officials led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. churned through a long day of meetings Wednesday with their Chinese counterparts, picking and poking at many economic issues while encountering arguments from the Chinese on several fronts.

headline: Most Want Musharraf to Quit, Poll Shows
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The first comprehensive public opinion poll conducted in Pakistan since President Pervez Musharraf declared a state of emergency last month has found that 67 percent of Pakistanis want him to resign immediately and that 70 percent say his government does not deserve re-election.

headline: Come Back, Barney, Come Back
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush may call the shots around the White House. But now there is video proof that his dog Barney doesn’t listen to him.

headline: India, a Stirring Giant, Is the New Place to See and Be Seen
text: NEW DELHI  If it’s Monday, it must be Romania  and Finland and Minnesota.

headline: A Close Call on the Way to a Trophy
text: The Herman Trophy is awarded to the winner of the most master points at the Fall North American Championships, which ended 11 days ago in San Francisco. The winner was Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif., with 375.28 points. He finished second in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, but the diagramed deal occurred during the Edgar Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs, in which he finished 14th with his wife, JoAnna Stansby, who was on the winning Venice Cup team in Shanghai in October.

headline: California: Board Members Recalled Over Blackwater Plan
text: Residents of Potrero, a rural community in east San Diego County, voted to oust five members of the town’s planning board who endorsed a bid by Blackwater Worldwide to build a training camp. Three of the board’s nine members have already been removed because Blackwater opponents revealed that they had been improperly appointed. Election officials counted the recall ballots Tuesday night, said Deborah Seiler, registrar of voters for San Diego County. The five board members elected to fill the seats of the recalled board members oppose Blackwater’s development of an 824-acre tract of land near Potrero, close to the Mexican border, people on both sides of the debate said.

headline: Flu Vaccinations: Protect Our Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Warehouse Workers Quit in Immigration Inquiry
text: Fresh Direct, the online grocery delivery operation that caters to affluent and overworked New Yorkers, lost dozens of employees this week after federal immigration officials notified the company that its employee records were under investigation.

headline: Racing to Be in Step With the Green Movement
text: OF all the ways manufacturers are rushing to jump onto the “environmentally friendly” bandwagon, inserting a biodegradable midsole into an otherwise everlasting running shoe seems like a fairly minuscule step.

headline: The Rangers’ Normally Stingy Defense Rests
text: WASHINGTON  The Rangers’ wild 5-4 overtime loss Wednesday night to the Capitals would have been stunning even if the Rangers had not beaten the Devils, 1-0, three days earlier.

headline: Will 2008 Be a Postwar Election?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shares Hold on to Part of Early Gains
text: Shares rose on Wednesday, led by technology and energy stocks, in another volatile day on Wall Street.

headline: Deal Governing Development in the Catskills Does Not End a Battle
text: HIGHMOUNT, N.Y.  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his environmental team appeared to have won a big victory in September by brokering a deal to reduce the size of a proposed Catskill Mountains megaresort while protecting 1,200 acres of woodland from development.

headline: Airline Trade Group Predicts a Further Drop in Profit Next Year
text: Soaring fuel prices and slowing economic growth are likely to wipe out much of the airline industry’s profits next year, despite steady increases in global demand for air travel, the International Air Transport Association, a leading trade group, said Wednesday.

headline: Giants Counting on Jacobs to Get a Grip
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The glummest face in the winning locker room last Sunday belonged to Brandon Jacobs. He had started against the Philadelphia Eagles after missing the previous two games with a strained hamstring. He ran the ball 22 times for 70 yards and caught 3 passes. The Giants won.

headline: Manhattan: School Official Charged
text: An employee of the city’s Department of Education was charged on Wednesday with taking cash bribes from at least five school bus companies in exchange for giving them advance notice about city inspections and for granting them favorable bus routes. In a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the employee, Geoffrey Berger, a borough supervisor in charge of city school bus routes in Westchester County and the Bronx, was charged with taking thousands of dollars of bribes for at least five years. The charges against him arose from a federal investigation into Mafia influence over the city school bus drivers’ union, Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union.

headline: With Writers Out, Directors Offer Their Own Talks
text: LOS ANGELES  Movie and television directors said Thursday that they were prepared to begin bargaining toward a new contract with production companies after the New Year holiday, a move that could realign Hollywood’s troubled labor front.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Silver Anniversary in the Round

headline: Democrats to Spend Bush’s Limit Their Way
text: WASHINGTON  Stymied by Republican opposition to their spending proposals, Congressional Democrats said on Wednesday that they would finance the federal government at roughly the amount insisted on by President Bush but shift more money to their favored causes.

headline: Shift Away From Ad-Free Has a Price
text: WHEN children log onto Webkinz.com, the popular virtual world for children who buy Webkinz stuffed animals, they can send messages to their friends, decorate their virtual rooms and take trivia quizzes.

headline: Albany: Nominee for Waterfront Commissioner
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has nominated Ronald Goldstock to be New York State’s commissioner on the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, a bistate agency that certifies dockworkers and polices the waterfront. Mr. Goldstock previously worked as managing director at Kroll Associates, a private security firm, and was director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force for more than 13 years. If approved by the State Senate, Mr. Goldstock would succeed Michael C. Axelrod. On Oct. 15, Mr. Spitzer issued an executive order instructing the state’s inspector general, Kristine Hamann, to look at “allegations of misfeasance and nonfeasance by personnel of the Waterfront Commission, including allegations of misconduct, conflicts of interest, abuse and waste.”

headline: Mexico: Counterfeit Million Seized
text: The authorities said that federal agents raided a house in Tonalá, a suburb of Guadalajara, this week and seized more than $1.1 million in counterfeit $100 bills. Twelve people were arrested. The investigation that led to the raid also involved the United States Secret Service and was begun in 2005 after millions of counterfeit $100 bills started showing up in southern California.

headline: Tip of the Week: Online Meeting Planners
text: The Meeting Planner link on the World Time Server site (www.worldtimeserver.com) lets you pick a date and add in the locations of all the participants from around the globe so you can narrow down a time that works for everyone. (It is useful for online game players, too.)

headline: Get Them Hooked and They’ll Reel Themselves In
text: “ARE your arms tired yet?”

headline: Fire Ravages a Historic Block in New Haven and Displaces at Least 100
text: NEW HAVEN  A three-alarm fire ripped through a historic block near the New Haven Green early Wednesday, closing a section of downtown and displacing at least 100 residents before it was contained, the authorities said.

headline: Who’s Imitating Whom?
text: VISITORS loitering along the palm-lined streets of Miami Beach during Art Basel last week appeared to pattern themselves after the most disparate of fashion role models. Some chose to emulate the dissolute preppiness of Wes Anderson, the film director, while others aped the calculated depravity of the photographer Terry Richardson. A few even managed to fuse the styles of both, combining the supersize, mauve-tinted eyewear and stubble affected by Mr. Richardson (and certain 1970s pornographers) with canvas sneakers or white bucks, trim bow ties and seersucker.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $2,831,660.89

headline: Ted Corbitt, a Pioneer in American Distance Running, Dies at 88
text: Ted Corbitt, who began running as a child on his father’s cotton farm in South Carolina and virtually never stopped, becoming a pioneer of ultramarathon running in the United States, died Wednesday in Houston. He was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: In Twilight of Life, a Former Moonshiner Finds Mercy
text: Daniel Freeman was getting old, he was out of work and poverty was pressing in. Before his life ended, he wanted to clear his name of a 1963 conviction for a liquor-law felony.

headline: The ‘Hallelujah’ Chorus Continues Its Attraction
text: Religious art operates under the principle that God wants the best. St. Thomas Church does its best to oblige. Its “Messiah” performances are near the top of New York’s many Christmas attractions. Handel’s beloved oratorio returned to St. Thomas on Tuesday evening and will repeat Thursday.

headline: New Yorkers Are in a Fiery State of Mind
text: These are red-pepper days in New York. Not red-letter but red-pepper, as in the bright hieroglyphics that pop up automatically when an e-mail gets way too salty.

headline: Fury Rising Over Lenience in Gang Rape of Aboriginal Girl, 10
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Mounting anger over the handling of the gang rape of a 10-year-old indigenous girl has pushed the plight of Australia’s Aboriginal minority to the top of the country’s political agenda, leaving the new government of Prime Minister Kevin Rudd scrambling for solutions to one of the country’s most intractable problems.

headline: An Enthusiast Entrepreneur Kicks Off a T-Shirt Business
From a Critic of Tribunals to Top Judge
text: Back in 2002, a master’s degree candidate at the Naval War College wrote a paper on the Bush administration’s plan to use military commissions to try Guantánamo suspects, concluding that “even a good military tribunal is a bad idea.”

headline: Britain: Unemployment Is Down
text: Unemployment in Britain declined to 3.2 percent in November, the lowest level since 1975, as the strength of the economy encouraged companies to take on more workers. Claims for unemployment benefits dropped 11,100 from October, to 813,000, according to the Office for National Statistics. Average earnings including bonuses rose at an annual rate of 4 percent in the three months through October, down from 4.1 percent in the three months through September, the statistics office said. With bonuses excluded, wage growth slowed to 3.6 percent from 3.7 percent in the third quarter.

headline: Dubai Court Sentences Two in Rape
text: A Dubai court sentenced two men on Wednesday to 15 years in prison for the rape of a French-Swiss teenager whose case became a rallying point for critics of the way the United Arab Emirates treats victims of sexual assault.

headline: National Finals Rodeo Adds Bucks to the Bucking
text: LAS VEGAS  Nascar’s drivers have long distanced themselves from their sports’ moonshine-running past, and millionaire Major League Baseball players compete in cathedrals that bear little resemblance to their game’s origins in dusty sandlots. In rodeo, the sport of America’s original extreme athletes, not a whole lot has changed.

headline: Patients Wonder Whether to Replace a Wire That Might Fail
text: MORRISTOWN, N.J.  For one heart patient, there will be no more agonizing over whether the implanted device meant to save his life might kill him instead.

headline: Immigration, and Its Politics, Shake Rural Iowa
text: STORM LAKE, Iowa  Along the main thoroughfare of this small meatpacking town, the transformation of a single shop, once known as the Ken-A-Bob restaurant, tells the story of the town itself.

headline: The Man From Target
text: Huckabee! Huckabee! The man of the hour! What is it that voters love so much about this guy? Is it a hitherto inchoate yearning for a president who knows less about international affairs than they do? Hope that a man who can lose 100 pounds could also get rid of the federal deficit?

headline: Officials See No Public Health Threat in Shortage of a Meningitis Vaccine
text: A developing shortage of vaccine against childhood meningitis is expected to inconvenience some pediatricians and parents, but should not become a public health threat, officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.

headline: Marit Allen, Costume Designer for Movies, Dies at 66
text: Marit Allen, a British fashion writer and editor in the miniskirted 1960s who went on to design costumes for film characters as varied as the frumpy cross-dresser in “Mrs. Doubtfire,” the cowboys of “Brokeback Mountain” and the purple stretch-panted creature in “Hulk,” died on Nov. 26 in Australia. She was 66 and lived in London.

headline: Blaze Kills Four in a Much-Loved Family in New Jersey
text: UNION, N.J.  Whether holding summer parties, playing host at events for their daughter’s swim team or welcoming fellow Filipino immigrants to New Jersey, Edgardo and Digna Aguas had an address that was familiar to nearly everyone in their wide social circle.

headline: Russia Tells Britain to Shut Cultural Offices
text: Russia’s Foreign Ministry ordered Britain to close the cultural offices of the British Council outside of Moscow by Jan. 1, saying it had repeatedly broken tax laws as well as the Vienna Convention by operating out of British consulates. Britain said it would ignore the order, which it considers a violation of international law. The countries have been embroiled in a dispute over Russia’s refusal to hand over Andrei K. Lugovoi, the former K.G.B. official accused of fatally poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko in London last year with a radioactive isotope. In July, Britain expelled four Russian diplomats, setting off a tit-for-tat response in Moscow.

headline: Manhattan: Fire Inspection Report
text: Response times have not increased since the Fire Department adopted new rules last month requiring fire companies to devote an additional three hours each week to the inspection of high-rise buildings under construction and demolition, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta, said at a City Council hearing on Wednesday. The companies now dedicate nine hours a week to inspections. Between Nov. 5 and Dec. 11, firefighters inspected 97 percent of the 468 such high-rise buildings. The average response time for citywide emergencies stood at 4 minutes 46 seconds last month  5 seconds less than in November 2006 and 13 seconds less than in November 2005, Mr. Scoppetta said.

headline: Aiming to Translate Politics Into Hope for Palestinians
text: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  Tony Blair had that practiced politician’s half grin, his eyes in semi-focus, as the Palestinian minister of tourism, Khouloud Daibes, showed him around a display of Palestinian products at the Chamber of Commerce here Tuesday night. Mr. Blair, the former British prime minister and now the Western envoy for Palestinian development, posed for photos with businessmen and praised the quality of the local marble tiles.

headline: Homespun Electricity, From the Wind
text: WHEN Rena Wilson Jones and her husband, Drew, were building a house 10 years ago in a subdivision near the edge of Urbana, Ill., they knew the property was likely to be windy, bordered as it was by open fields to the north and west. But they did not realize how fierce the winds would be until construction of their house was under way. In the decade that followed, the wind drove Ms. Wilson Jones crazy from November through April, she said, whipping across her yard and making it difficult to work in the garden. At times, it was hard to walk outside.

headline: Uncloaking the Plight of an Aging Woman
text: You have to hand it to Judith Malina. At 81 the co-founder of the Living Theater is still dancing around the stage, taking off her clothes, doing her best to shake up the world. She is a sympathetic match for the 88-year-old Doris Lessing, who made the invisibility of aging women a major theme decades before talk-show guests started chatting about hot flashes. In “Maudie and Jane,” based on a Lessing novel, Ms. Malina makes the dirty, aged Maudie defiantly visible and strangely charming.

headline: Biogen Takes Itself Off the Block After Failing to Sell High, and Shares Plunge 28%
text: Big pharmaceutical companies may be desperate for new products, but they apparently are not ready to obtain them at any price.

headline: Wake Up to Birds or Music or Pictures of a Favorite Pal
text: It’s nice to wake up to the sound of twittering birds, but in many places that experience is hard to come by in December.

headline: Clinton Aide Sees Problem for Obama
text: DES MOINES  A top adviser to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that Senator Barack Obama’s admission of illegal drug use as a young man could threaten his electability and be seized on by Republicans if he won the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: C.I.A. Agents Sense Shifting Support for Methods
text: WASHINGTON  For six years, Central Intelligence Agency officers have worried that someday the tide of post-Sept. 11 opinion would turn, and their harsh treatment of prisoners from Al Qaeda would be subjected to hostile scrutiny and possible criminal prosecution.

headline: Contempt Vote in Panel for Bush Aides
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate Judiciary Committee voted on Thursday to hold a present and a former aide to President Bush in contempt of Congress, but it is by no means clear that they will be dragged before the lawmakers anytime soon.

headline: Congressman Says Google Is Resisting Deal Inquiry
text: Representative Joe Barton of Texas said on Wednesday that Google had rebuffed requests by his staff for a meeting as part of an investigation into the company’s $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick.

headline: Animal Instincts Most Costly
text: THOUGH it seems impossibly abstract from the vantage point of Madison Avenue, armed conflicts are taking place between powerful aggressors and their enemies across the globe. The fighting seems unimaginable, light-years away.

headline: A Phone’s Makeover Goes Beyond Cosmetics
text: On the face of it, the differences between Samsung’s popular BlackJack smartphone and the upgraded BlackJack II are superficial. The screen is bigger, the numeric keys embedded in the qwerty keyboard are positioned closer together and the unit is slightly heavier. There are additional keys for quick access to the Internet, e-mail, online video and the camera.

headline: Work Believed a Gauguin Turns Out to Be a Forgery
text: When “The Faun,” a stoneware sculpture, was bought by the Art Institute of Chicago a decade ago, it was hailed as one of the museum’s most important acquisitions in 20 years.

headline: Lehman Earnings Fall, but Not as Much as Expected
text: Lehman Brothers, one of a handful of Wall Street banks to avoid large losses related to subprime mortgages, reported better than expected earnings for the fourth quarter, on the back of two one-time gains and in spite of a month  November  that Lehman executives called “the worst single month in the credit markets, ever.”

headline: Foundation Testing Potential of Philanthropy via Internet
text: The Case Foundation is embarking on an effort to test the potential of citizen-led philanthropy via the Internet.

headline: A World Consumed by Guilt
text: LET us set aside the clichés about green fashion, ye cynical Kermits, and presume that everyone is now on board with saving the world by doing our holiday shopping at Barneys, where even the window displays promote eco-friendly clothing.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: President Vetoes Second Measure to Expand Children’s Health Program
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush vetoed another children’s health bill on Wednesday, effectively killing Democrats’ hopes of expanding a popular government program aimed at providing insurance to youngsters in lower- and middle-income families.

headline: Movement With Mystery and Efficient Athleticism
text: Many dancers have walked slowly across many stages, their faces bathed in a slanting light, their eyes focused on a middle distance. The viewer’s imagination rushes toward whatever unseen entity the dancer approaches: a lover, an uncertain future, death.

headline: Special Session in Albany, Where Gridlock Never Left
text: ALBANY  The State Senate plans to return here Thursday for a special session, but it appears that lawmakers will accomplish little. Senate Republicans have been negotiating with Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Assembly Democrats over largely the same set of issues for more than six months, but have yet to achieve much in the way of results.

headline: WPP Says, ‘Veni, Invidi, Vici’
text: Madison Avenue is growing increasingly excited that new technologies will help advertisers aim commercials at television viewers more precisely. A deal being made by the WPP Group, the giant advertising company, underscores that ardor.

headline: Great Open Spaces in Washington
text: The most sobering part of Wednesday night’s Rangers-Capitals game had nothing to do with the game — a 5-4 overtime victory by Washington, which was wildly entertaining unless you are a big fan of goalies — but the lack of people watching in Washington’s Verizon Center.

headline: Golden Globe Nominees
text: Images of this year’s Golden Globe nominees, including  “Atonement,” “Sweeney Todd” and “Michael Clayton.”

headline: The Democratic Debate
text: Following is a transcript of the Democratic presidential debate in Johnston, Iowa, as provided by the Federal News Service.

headline: List of Golden Globe Nominees and Winners
