text: Motion picture and television nominees and winners for the 65th annual Golden Globe Awards.

headline: A New Online Leader
text: Mike Huckabee had the most-visited campaign Web site among presidential candidates during the first week of December, a first for his site. This spike in online traffic conincides with Mr. Huckabee’s recent rise in the polls and increased visibility in the news. Mr. Huckabee and Representative Ron Paul of Texas, whose supporters on the Internet have propelled his campaign forward, lead the more well-known candidates in visits to their sites. “This election has a lot of big brand names running, so Americans may feel like they know them already and instead are going online to learn more about these other candidates such as Mike Huckabee and Ron Paul as reflected in our data,” said Matt Tatham of Hitwise, a firm that tracks online traffic.

headline: G.P.S. Comparison Chart
Scent Notes | Gucci by Gucci
text: When Gucci decided to create its latest fragrance, the house’s artistic director, Frida Giannini, set herself quite a task: to create the perfume equivalent of a Niketown flagship, huge and impressive and filled to the brim with everything a fan could possibly dream of asking from a brand. It would distill the essence of Gucci — the label’s unrestrained luxury, its blatant carnality, so free of French hauteur, so Italian in its joyful, slightly bad-taste abandon. The name said it all: Gucci by Gucci. Given the amount the house had riding on it, to report that the perfume, which came out in November, succeeds in virtually every way is not merely a relief. It is a pleasure.

headline: Dress Codes | Men in Fur
text: Men have been responding enthusiasticly to this winter’s influx of fur.

headline: World Must Cope With Bloggers’ Union Strike
text: No more pointless, self-absorbed meanderings on the web — Now the “bloggers’ union” is out on strike:

headline: Shot to the Groin Goes Straight to the Web
text: First there was straight to cable. Then straight to video. Now “Jackass,” straight to the Web. Paramount Pictures is lurching onto the Internet with its “Jackass” franchise, with what it says will be the first studio-backed feature film to have its premiere online. Read more …

headline: Rubik’s Cubism
text: For folks with an awful lot of time on their hands:

headline: The Sound of One Warm Hand Clapping
text: One Cold Hand is “a site for the collection and hopeful reunion of Pittsburgh’s dropped gloves.” Now, how about umbrellas? Socks?

headline: Eco-Shopping
text: Eco-shopping to save the land, but is it all truly green?

headline: In Its Race Against Google, Microsoft Buys MultiMap
text: Microsoft said it had agreed to acquire MultiMap, an online map service based in London, in an attempt to compete more effectively with the search services of Google and to collect more revenue from online and mobile advertising.

headline: Preparing for Change, Time Warner Hires Media Analyst
text: Time Warner has quietly hired a prominent media analyst as it reshuffles its executive ranks in the weeks before Jeffrey L. Bewkes takes over as chief executive from Richard D. Parsons.

headline: A.M.D. to Write Down an Acquisition
text: The chip maker Advanced Micro Devices said Wednesday that it planned to take a material write-down of the value of its 2006 acquisition of ATI Technologies, a costly bet made to compete better in the market for graphics semiconductors.

headline: China’s Great Wall Sells Drive Maker to Iomega
text: Iomega, an American distributor of computer data storage equipment, said Wednesday that it was entering into a complex $310 million deal to acquire ExcelStor, a Chinese contract maker of disk drives.

headline: Congressman Says Google Is Resisting Deal Inquiry
text: Representative Joe Barton of Texas said on Wednesday that Google had rebuffed requests by his staff for a meeting as part of an investigation into the company’s $3.1 billion acquisition of DoubleClick.

headline: Elan Shares Drop on Biogen’s decision to Go It Alone
text: The decision by Biogen Idec, the pharmaceutical company, to take down its for-sale sign not only wiped $6 billion off its own value but hit shares of its partner Elan as well.

headline: ArcelorMittal Moves to Take Control of Chinese Steelmaker
text: ArcelorMittal said Thursday it had signed an agreement with the China Oriental Group‘s controlling shareholders to raise its stake in the company to 73.13 percent from 28 percent, in a deal that would make it the first foreign company to take control of a Chinese steelmaker.

headline: Zell Hopes to Close Tribune Deal Next Week
text: Samuel Zell, the real-estate magnate, hopes that the $8.2 billion deal he’s leading to take Tribune private will close Dec. 20.

headline: Airline Industry’s Weak Outlook May Increase Pressure to Merge
text: A grim report from the airline industry’s leading trade group may force some carriers to pick up the consolidation flag.

headline: A Divided Italian Governement Postpones Alitalia Decision
text: Alitalia on Thursday put off a decision to pick a buyer until next week after the Italian government failed to choose its preferred bidder for the ailing carrier.

headline: WestLB Seeks Merger with Helaba
text: The owners of WestLB, a German bank that has been battered by a trading scandal and turmoil in the mortgage markets in the United States, said on Wednesday they would seek merger talks with a publicly-owned counterpart, Helaba.

headline: Eton Park Buys Stake in $20 Billion Indian Mutual Fund
text: Eton Park Capital Management , a hedge fund founded by Eric Mindich, a former partner at Goldman Sachs, has agreed to buy a 5 percent stake in Reliance Capital Asset Management, in a deal that for the first time puts a value on India’s largest mutual fund.

headline: Biogen Shares Plummet as No Buyer Surfaces
text: Big pharmaceutical companies may be desperate for new products, but they apparently are not ready to obtain them at any price.

headline: Countrywide Subpoenaed by Illinois
text: The Illinois attorney general is investigating the home loan unit of Countrywide Financial as part of the state’s expanding inquiry into lending practices that have trapped borrowers in high-cost mortgages they can no longer afford.

headline: Hedge-Fund-Happy Firm Takes Stake in BlueMountain
text: BlueMountain Capital Management sold an undisclosed stake in itself to an asset manager, Affiliated Manager Group, according to a press release.

headline: Shareholders Back Dow Jones Sale
text: Rupert Murdoch won his long-coveted prize Thursday when shareholders of Dow Jones & Company gave their blessing to a takeover by Mr. Murdoch’s global media empire, the News Corporation.

headline: Citigroup’s Pandit Remains Elusive About Asset Sales
text: As DealBook noted earlier this week, now that Citigroup has announced its new chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, attention is increasingly turning to the question of whether he will break-up the financial behemoth.

headline: Kraft to Issue $3 Billion of Notes
text: Kraft Foods, the food conglomerate whose brands include Ritz crackers and Velveeta cheese, said in a regulatory filing Wednesday it expects to issue $3 billion of notes.

headline: Endeavor Sews Up American Apparel Deal
text: The chief executive of Endeavor Acquisition, the special-purpose acquisition company that agreed to buy American Apparel earlier this year, no doubt breathed a sigh of relief Wednesday as the company closed on the deal just three days before its drop-dead date of Dec. 15.

headline: Keeping Score in Wall Street’s C.E.O. Shuffle
text: Merrill Lynch and Citigroup have both put new chiefs at the helm and they considered many of the same candidates in the search process. David Weidner, writing in a commentary on MarketWatch, notes the stark contrast between the two choices — John Thain and Vikram Pandit, respectively — and suggests Mr. Thain has the most to lose by far.

headline: Hedge Fund Minnows Swim to Bigger Lakes
text: Two deals where smaller hedge funds have agreed to fold their operations into those of bigger rivals highlight how the going has gotten tough for the relative minnows of the industry, Breakingviews says.

headline: Central Bankers to Lend Billions in Credit Crisis
text: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe on Wednesday announced the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

headline: Digital Domain Files for I.P.O. to Compete With Pixar
text: Digital Domain, a special effects firm, wants to raise about $100 million in an initial public offering to pay off debt and maybe produce films, apparently in an attempt to compete with DreamWorks Animation and Walt Disney‘s Pixar Animation, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: 3 Big Banks See No Relief as Write-Offs Mount
text: Bank of America, Wachovia and the PNC Financial Services Group said on Wednesday that losses tied to bad debt would be worse than expected, the latest indication that the credit markets are not returning to normal.

headline: Biographies of Five Voices From ‘In Our Own Words: Portraits of  Brooklyn’s Vietnam Veterans’
text: Anthony Wallace

headline: Resources for Job-Seeking Veterans
text: If there is one category of workers who need all the help they can get, it’s veterans. That is why I was so pleased to hear about the Creating Futures Program started by CompTIA, a trade association for the technology industry. The program trains people for civilian work in technology. Users can log onto the program from anywhere in the world, as long as they can get to a computer with Internet access. Given that technology is one of the one of the sectors the Labor Department predicts will see the greatest growth in the next 10 years, this seems to be a good matchup between an industry needing people and people in need of job training. The program is free to applicants and sponsored by Ricoh.

headline: Carlyle-Backed China Pacific Insurance Eyes $4 Billion I.P.O.
text: The China Pacific Insurance (Group), the nation’s third-largest insurer, may raise as much as 30 billion yuan ($4.07 billion) in the biggest initial public offering ever by a Chinese insurer.

headline: WPP Leads Invidi’s $25 Million Round
text: Invidi Technologies, an advertising technology company, said on Thursday it raised $25 million in its latest round of funding, led by the advertising holding company WPP Group.

headline: HSBC May Extend Deadline for $6.3 Billion Korea Exchange
text: The Korea Exchange Bank‘s chief executive, Richard Wacker, said HSBC Holdings may extend an April deadline for buying his company.

headline: Lone Star to Sell Tokyo Star Stake for $1.7 Billion, Report Says
text: The private equity firm Lone Star Funds will sell its 68 percent stake in Tokyo Star Bank of Japan for as much as $1.7 billion to a private equity fund, Advantage Partners, Reuters reported.

headline: Fundamental Applied Biology Nabs $21 Million
text: Fundamental Applied Biology has raised $21 million in a second funding round.

headline: Snow and Sleet Expected Today
text: The National Weather Service issued a winter weather advisory for the metropolitan region at 4:23 a.m. and a hazardous weather alert at 5:32 a.m. for New York City and much of Long Island and northern New Jersey. The weather service predicts with 100 percent certainty the arrival of snow, sleet and rain today, probably starting around 9 a.m.

headline: Dow Forms Joint Venture with Kuwait for $9.5 Billion
text: Dow Chemical, the largest American chemical maker, said Petrochemical Industries of Kuwait agreed to pay $9.5 billion to form a joint venture producing plastics and chemicals.

headline: Northern Rock Rescue Effort Looks Shaky
text: Efforts to rescue Northern Rock, the struggling British lender, appear to be faltering amid a slew of bad news.

headline: Perelman’s Appeal in Morgan Stanley Suit Is Rejected
text: The Florida Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected an appeal by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, who had asked the court to restore a $1.58 billion verdict against the investment bank Morgan Stanley.

headline: ‘Ol’ Glue Eyes’
text: More “late night” jokes from readers (send via the comment link below):

headline: Lehman’s 4th-Quarter Profit Falls but Beats Expectations
text: Lehman Brothers reported a decline in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, the first sign of the toll that subprime mortgages will take on investment banks for the quarter. But the firm still managed to beat analysts’ expectations.

headline: Are Tolls on the East River Bridges Politically Feasible?
text: The chairman of the state commission studying ways to reduce traffic in Manhattan is increasingly pushing a measure certain to prompt opposition in the rest of the city: charging tolls on the four East River bridges. As William Neuman reports today, such tolls would likely be part of a scaled-back congestion pricing scheme, in which the northern boundary of the zone in which traffic fees would be charged would be set at 60th Street rather than 86th Street.

headline: Iberdrola Renovables Completes $6 Billion I.P.O.
text: Shares of Iberdrola Renovables, an owner of wind-driven power plants, were modestly lower in early trading in Madrid after its $6 billion initial public offering priced at the low end of the expected range.

headline: Quote: Ought We to Forgive Ike Turner?
text: “Ought we to forgive Ike Turner?,” Farah Jasmine Griffin wrote in a New York Times profile in 2001. “The question isn’t whether Mr. Turner owes us an apology; he owes that to Ms. Turner. And only she can truly forgive him.”

headline: Federal Agents Subpoena Sharpton’s Group and Four Associates
text: Updated 11:22 a.m. | The Rev. Al Sharpton today adamantly denied any wrongdoing relating to the financing of his 2004 presidential campaign, while accusing federal investigators of being politically motivated and trying to stir up a media spectacle by delivering subpoenas to four associates of Mr. Sharpton’s early Wednesday morning.

headline: The Early Word: Another Day, Another Debate
text: DES MOINES — Today’s debate among the Democratic candidates comes as the tight race among the top three candidates in the party’s field has drawn a lot of interest in this state and elsewhere. For the Democrats, what happens here obviously will have a rippling effect through the early nominating states.

headline: Golden Globes Announced
text: Best Motion Picture — Drama

headline: Iowa Forecast: Democrats on Ice
text: Countdown: 21 days until Caucus Day. Eleven shopping days left until Christmas.

headline: Clinton’s Caucus Crunch
text: There are a number of reasons why Hillary Rodham Clinton has had trouble mastering the intricacies of how the Iowa caucus system works, starting with the fact that her husband – Bill Clinton – never competed in any competitive Iowa caucuses when he ran for president in 1992 and 1996. But here’s an arguably even more significant one: Mrs. Clinton’s generally very seasoned core of senior advisers back in Virginia is devoid of people who have actually run an Iowa caucus before.

headline: Techno Claus
text: David Pogue offers gift ideas for gadget lovers, just in time for the holidays.

headline: Playing the Christmas Card
text: Congress got in the the holiday spirit yesterday, and the right-wingers are taking down names. “Democrats who supported a House resolution to honor Ramadan voted against a similar resolution to honor Christmas and Christianity last night,” writes Amanda Carpenter at Town Hall. “18 Democrats voted ‘nay’ or ‘present’ on a resolution to ‘recognize the importance of Christmas and the Christian faith.’ An eagle-eyed Republican House staffer points out that those same members, with one exception, voted to ‘recognize the commencement of Ramadan,’ a Muslim religious observance in October.”

headline: NBC Scraps ‘Journeyman’
text: On Tuesday, one day after “Journeyman” posted its lowest rating of the fall, NBC opted not to order a full season of freshman series before the renewal window closed.

headline: Next Move by Stringer Could Decide Others’ Fate
text: Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, has more than a couple New York City politicians on pins and needles these days.

headline: Get Squeamish?
text: I hope you’ve finished eating your cereal this morning, because this story mixes two words that really should never be mixed: milk and pus.

headline: A Quick Trip Round the Globes
text: Entrail readers and other soothsayers circled Beverly Hills this morning, as the Golden Globes announced its nominations. Both “Charlie Wilson’s War” and “Atonement” picked up multiple nods. And in an unusual move, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association spread the love, citing seven films, as opposed to the usual five, in the best picture category.

headline: Blackstone Raises $1.3 Billion Debt Fund
text: The Blackstone Group said Thursday that it had closed a $1.3 billion fund to find gems amid the detritus of the debt markets.

headline: Creating a Better Playground
text: If you want your child to be more active, try throwing him a ball.

headline: Garbage In, Museum Out?
text: New York City has museums dedicated to police officers, firefighters, public transit, skyscrapers — and even sex. But what about trash?

headline: On Bonus Expenses, Lehman Holds the Line
text: After getting tripped up by the mortgage mess, some Wall Street firms have decided to earmark a larger portion of their revenue for employee bonuses this year — a move that shareholders don’t always appreciate.

headline: Red Kite Fund Said to Lose 22 Percent in November
text: Red Kite Metals, a hedge fund that posted a gain of 188 percent last year, lost about 22 percent last month as copper prices fell, Bloomberg News reported Thursday citing two unnamed investors in the fund.

headline: Pressing Murdoch on The Journal’s Climate Views
text: David Sassoon, an environmental blogger, has posted a provocative open letter to Rupert Murdoch, the head of News Corporation and soon-to-be owner of The Wall Street Journal, asking him to “green” the paper’s opinions on global warming just as he has pledged to zero out carbon dioxide emissions from his media empire.

headline: Prince Sells in Aspen
text: Hala Ranch

headline: The Youngest Nominee
text: “I’m too excited,” Saoirse Ronan told the Baguette over the phone. The 13 year old had just received a best supporting actress nomination from the Golden Globes for her role as a jealous sister in “Atonement.”

headline: Mayor Leaves China After an Exchange of Ideas
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wrapped up a three-day trip to China on Wednesday before embarking to Bali today for a United Nations conference on global warming. As part of his whirlwind itinerary in Beijing and Shanghai, he met with Cheng Siwei, vice chairman of the National People’s Congress; Guo Jinlong, the recently appointed acting mayor of Beijing, who played a pivotal role in building a railroad to the Tibetan plateau; Yu Zhengsheng, who was recently promoted to the top Communist Party post in Shanghai; and Han Zheng, the youngest mayor Shanghai has had in half a century.

headline: ‘The Office’, ‘Dexter’ Up for WGA Awards
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Deal Me In
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Youth With Youth
text: “Atonement,” which had the biggest day on the board with seven nominations, represents something of a youth brigade. Its director, Joe Wright, is 36, it has two young co-stars in Ms. Knightley, 22, and James McAvoy, 28, and the even younger Saoirse Ronan, who received a nomination in the supporting category for dramas.

headline: Word-of-the-Year Ritual Pauses for Puzzlement
text: One of these words is not like the others:

headline: Carrión to Run for Comptroller in 2009
text: Adolfo Carrión Jr., the Bronx borough president, ended speculation about his political aspirations by announcing this morning that he will run for comptroller in 2009, rather than for mayor, as he had long planned.

headline: Christmas and Disco? It’s a Crisco Party!
text: From the news in Thursday’s Times that impersonators rake it in this time of year:

headline: A Globe Nomination for a Globe-Shaped Person
text: Helena Bonham Carter, who got a Globes nomination for her performance in “Sweeney Todd,” was delighted by the news, she told the Baguette, but a little distracted by the fact that she is about to give birth.

headline: Lucky Number Seven
text: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association broke tradition by naming seven films in the best drama category. Call them the magnificent seven or the jury-rigged baker’s half-dozen: “American Gangster,” “Atonement,” Eastern Promises,” “The Great Debaters,” “Michael Clayton,” “No Country for Old Men” and “There Will Be Blood.”

headline: Clinton Ad: Dorothy Speaks

When the Bagger, who is ancient and dessicated, suggested to the young sprite Ellen Page that it seemed weird that she, the screenwriter Diablo Cody and the director Jason Reitman, all 30 or under, where able to come up with something as remarkably wise as “Juno,” she said, “I think that’s pretty ageist of you, actually.”

headline: Huckabee’s Compassionate Conservatism
text: The cover of the Times Magazine this Sunday is a profile of Mike Huckabee by Zev Chafets, a writer whose work I’ve always liked. It’s a great portrait, rendered skeptically but without cynicism, and I highly recommend it. What’s occurred to me as I’ve read stories about Mr. Huckabee over these last few months — I’ve not yet met him — is that you can already see how, should he manage to win the nomination, he would deftly steer himself back toward the political center in time for the convention. The outlines of the post-primary Huckabee storyline have already emerged: he raised some taxes over his own party’s objections, he refused to deny scholarships to illegal immigrants (a decision he has refused to back away from “even if it costs me he election”), he came off as too liberal and secular for a lot of his fellow Baptist preachers. These lines from the Huckabee resume have earned him the scorn of some Republican interest groups, most notably the anti-tax Club for Growth, whose idea of state government consists of a couple of prisons and a paving machine, but they would serve him nicely in a general election, where independent voters might shrink from electing another rigid conservative. Campaign reporters always line up to write stories like this, not because they care about making the Mike Huckabees of the world seem kind and gentle, which he may well be, but because we in the media are trained to look for the contradiction of stereotypes — and no one is more gleefully stereotyped in America than the religious conservative. Thus we in the media have historically embraced the story of the Republican governor who, it turns out, isn’t as much of a crazy conservative as you might think. Hey, look, the Tin Man has a heart! George W. Bush was a “compassionate conservative” who worked amiably across the aisle with Democrats. Mitt Romney passed a landmark, bipartisan bill to provide healthcare. Even Ronald Reagan enacted a huge tax increase while governor of California. And so on.

That wasn’t surprising, perhaps, given the league’s much deeper public relations crisis today: the release of a report by the former Senator George J. Mitchell about steroids use in baseball.

So for half a second I was delighted to see a post on DSL Reports that Sprint was eliminating such mumbo jumbo as the “Federal Programs Cost Recovery Fees.”

headline: Will That Be Skim in Your CAFE?
text: The Senate and White House are fussing over the enforcement details of the latest energy bill, which passed the House last week. The bill aims to raise the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards to 35 miles a gallon by 2020. Meanwhile, and despite a veto threat from the White House, automakers are also warming to the heightened standards. The trouble is, despite their stated purpose of reducing America’s energy consumption, CAFE standards are a poor method of achieving that goal.

headline: Vintage Ike Turner
text: Ike Turner died Wednesday at 76. Mostly he will be remembered as the violent, abusive husband of Tina Turner. But it should not be forgotten that he was an idiosyncratic, influential musician whose fundamental contributions to rock-and-roll would probably never have been noticed had it not been for the eventual pop success of Ike and Tina Turner.

headline: Vegansexuality
text: Forget homo-, bi- or even metro-: the latest prefix in sexuality is vegan-, as in “vegansexual.” In a survey of vegan and vegetarians (most women), the questions ranged from attitudes about eating meat to to wearing possum fur to, yes, “cruelty-free sex” — that is, “rejecting meat eaters as intimate partners.” Some of the survey respondents volunteered their reluctance to kiss meat eaters. “I couldn’t think of kissing lips that allow dead animal pieces to pass between them,” a 49-year-old vegan woman said. For some, the resistance is the squeamishness factor. “Nonvegetarian bodies smell different to me,” a 41-year-old vegan woman said. “They are, after all, literally sustained through carcasses — the murdered flesh of others.” Read more in the Times Magazine …

headline: Holier Than They
text: For years, the left – and moderates – permitted the right to frame itself as the sole custodian of “family values” in the United States. It was only when vast numbers of American families woke up to the fact that they were not being valued at all – that, in fact, they were being fleeced – that non-conservatives shook themselves into a sentient state and began to talk about replacing empty words with substantive promises about health care, child care and college aid.

text: NASA officials scrambled this year to decide how to handle the legal and public relations fallout surrounding Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, an astronaut who drove from Texas to Florida to confront a romantic rival, according to e-mail messages released Wednesday by the space agency.
