text: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

headline: Warm and Fuzzy | Todd St. John’s Holiday Video
text: In case you missed it: In celebration of the season, T commissioned several artists to create short films on the theme of “giving.” The first to arrive is “Circle Squared” by Todd St. John, a designer and animator whose studio and workshop in New York is called HunterGatherer. Other films in the Giving series — by Andy Spade and the Neistat Brothers — will be posted soon.

headline: We’re Booked
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Luxe in Translation | French
text: T presents a series of “essential” foreign phrases. This lesson is for worn-out lady travelers who find themselves on the rue St. Honoré, Paris’s high-end boutique drag. The glistening new spa by haute shirtmaker Anne Fontaine has a textile-themed “weaving” massage in which the rubdown, incorporating bamboo rods, mimics the motion of a shuttle across a loom.

headline: Checkmated by Putin
text: As a chess master, Garry Kasparov has few equals. But when it comes to Russian politics, President Vladimir Putin dominates the playing board.

headline: Worker Injured in Crane Accident Downtown
text: Updated, 4:40 p.m. | A man was injured around 10:50 a.m. today after a crane dropped its load onto an office trailer at the site where Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, is erecting a large skyscraper, across from the ground zero. The man was taken to St. Vincent’s Hospital in Manhattan and was reported to be in critical condition.

headline: Democrats Eye ‘Freedom’s Watch’
text: In his Web column today, Carl Hulse writes that Democrats were pleased with how much they forced the Republicans to spend on a recent special election. But to their dismay, a well-bankrolled, Republican-leaning outside group weighed in on the race. Freedom’s Watch, an organization with deep pockets guided by former White House spokesman Ari Fleischer, injected itself for the first time in a House contest. Go to column

headline: Blood Simple?
text: Ever wonder what the old game of Mousetrap might look like if the relevant game piece was blood instead of a steel marble? BroadwayWorld’s got the answer. (Thanks to swag-loving Hollywood Elsewhere for the tip.)

headline: I Went Back to My City, and My City Was Gone.
text: As Will Smith gets ready to stride out into a devastated New York in “I Am Legend,” the Vulture blog at New York magazine reviews the cinematic depictions of Gotham’s destruction. The Day After is always just around the corner in that little island off the coast of America.

headline: Knocked Out
text: Dave Karger at EW does a bright, acute deconstruction of yesterday’s somewhat bewildering results, highlighting the borderline freakish omission of “Knocked Up,” one of the best reviewed, best attended comedies of the year.

headline: Clinton Laughs Off Idea of ‘Downward Spiral’
text: JOHNSTON, Iowa — While announcing the endorsement of Congressman Leonard Boswell and a 99-county blitz across this state that begins this weekend, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday dismissed reports that her campaign would undergo a shakeup or that it was in trouble here.

headline: Huckabee’s Breakdown in Communications
text: DES MOINES — The Huckabee campaign was crippled for about 24 hours by a massive e-mail breakdown that began just after Wednesday’s Republican debate and stymied its communications just as media attention on it crescendoed.

headline: Euronet Gets an Earful on MoneyGram Offer
text: MoneyGram International is not alone in being skeptical about Euronet Worldwide‘s unsolicited $1.65 billion takeover bid. Euronet’s own shareholders seem to be pessimistic about the deal, and so is Tony Wible, an analyst at Citigroup.

headline: Crime Is Down, but Brooklyn Talks It Up
text: Statistics can be tricky things. Recently some of us at the City section were talking about a Times article by Al Baker detailing how remarkably low crime numbers have fallen in the city. Around the same time, though, we had heard from some Brooklyn residents that they were increasingly nervous lately about street crime. We also got a news release from Anthony Herbert, a candidate for the State Senate in next year’s elections, about a group he is forming called the Downtown Brooklyn Safety Task force, to deal with what he says is an increase in robberies and muggings in the neighborhoods around Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Eight Years of Aging on Video
text: What does growing older look like?

headline: Media Mania for a ‘Front-Page Thought’ on Climate
text: Roger A. Pielke Jr., a political scientist at the University of Colorado, has a question about media coverage of research linking hurricanes and global warming, and I have a possible answer. Here’s his question, posted today on his blog, Prometheus:

headline: A Talk With Bahman Ghobadi
text: This interview is part of Link TV's world cinema series, CINEMONDO, and can be seen in its entirety at the link below.

headline: Now That That’s Done, Pitchers and Catchers Report in…
text: John Thorn, a sports historian, is author of “Total Baseball: The Official Encyclopedia of Major League Baseball” and “The Hidden Game of Baseball,” among other books.

headline: Friday Kickoff: The Armanti Edwards Bandwagon
text: Pete Thamel is not the only person who thinks Appalachian State quarterback Armanti Edwards could be a Heisman contender next season. SI.com’s Stewart Mandel writes that Edwards could garner some attention next season if he continues to play the way he has. Appalachian State seeks its third consecutive national championship when it faces Delaware tonight in the Football Championship Subdivision title game.

headline: Bloomberg Defends Pay Raises for City Hall Aides
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg — who wrapped up a five-day visit to Asia today after speaking at a United Nations climate change summit in Bali, Indonesia — was asked about a front-page article in The Times that described significant salary increases that top aides to the mayor have received.

headline: Hooray for Pandit
text: It’s nice to see Citigroup’s stock up today, even after it was downgraded by Moody’s.

headline: The Most Joyous Seven Minutes of Hockey Ever?
text: Below, an amazing document of communion between hockey fans and players. It was recorded last Friday night in Martin, Slovakia, when perennial minnows MHC Martin beat HC Kosice in the Slovakian Extraliga and reached second place at the start of the two-week December break. After the game highlights, watch the unbelievable send-off the 4,000 fans at the Martin Winter Stadium give their players, and how much fun the players have giving back the love. It may be seven of the most amazing minutes of hockey footage you’ve ever seen.

headline: McNamee Then and Now
text: In 2000, the same year the Mitchell report says Brian McNamee was injecting Roger Clemens with testosterone and human growth hormone, the former Yankees strength coach wrote in the New York Times that, “The suggestion that steroids are the answer to the increased strength, recovery from injury and the improved performances of today’s players is just wrong.”

headline: The Meaning of Mandates
text: The sharpest attacks in the Democratic campaign thus far — and the ones that have provoked the most emotion in partisan blogs and columns — involve, oddly enough, health-care mandates. Even when I mentioned the other day on the blog that I was thinking of delving into mandates this week, I got a flood of passionate e-mails from very smart people on the subject, trying to sway me one way or the other. This tells me two things: one, I need to change my e-mail address, and two, the fight about mandates is about something deeper than mandates.

headline: Disney Takes 'Pirates' Online
text: Disney promotes an interactive 'Pirates of the Caribbean'

headline: A Floating Apparition in Buttermilk Channel
text: Of a winter’s day, when its white hull seems suspended between silvery bars of harbor sky and the Buttermilk Channel, the motor vessel Islander even looks like an apparition.“Woods Hole,” it says on the hull. As in Massachusetts. And the island it was built to serve is Martha’s Vineyard. Yet the 57-year-old ferryboat is here in New York, tied up at Yankee Pier on Governors Island, where Brooklyn can see it and Manhattan cannot.

headline: ‘A Wild Pitch That Beans Mitchell’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send ’em via the comment link below):

headline: Under the Skin
text: The last two weeks inside this electronic Reading Room have been unexpectedly cozy — thanks mostly to Jennifer Schuessler, who must have felt as if she were herding cats while synthesizing the comments of her free-ranging colleagues.

headline: Of Orwell, Wikipedia and Guantánamo Bay
text: Winston Smith, the protagonist in George Orwell’s “1984,” worked at a government job he hated, rewriting history to conform to current propaganda imperatives. This week, a group called Wikileaks asserted that the United States military appeared to have a Winston Smith of its own at the Guantánamo Bay naval base, mucking about with the way Wikipedia and news sites portray the base and, curiously, posting odd assertions about Fidel Castro.

headline: TV Talk-Show Hosts Eye January Return?
text: Reuters reports:

headline: The Week in Comments: ‘Efficient, Relatively Eco-Friendly’
text: Monday, Dec. 10

headline: Understanding The Writers’ Complaint To The Labor Board
text: Almost one week after negotiations broke down between the writers’ guild and the studios’ alliance, the feud deepened on Thursday with the filing of an unfair labor practices complaint with the National Labor Relations Board.

headline: Of Taxes, Hostages and Henry Kravis
text: When a proposal on “carried interest” was zapped from a federal tax bill last week, The New York Post proclaimed, “Score one for the barbarians.” The barbarians in question were the private equity firms who lobbied mightily to kill the provision, which would have more than doubled the tax rate that fund managers pay on a big part of their income.

headline: Bali Deal: Negotiators Agree to Negotiate
text: UPDATED 12/14, 4:00 p.m. New York time:

headline: The Blimp Is Up
text: Moving right ahead, although a little off schedule, the Ron Paul blimp launched early Friday morning from the Airship Management Hanger in Elizabeth City, N.C.

headline: ‘Kid Nation’ Makes Little Racket, After All
text: CBS’s controversial reality series “Kid Nation” went out with a whimper on Wednesday, with a fourth-place finish in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic.

headline: Answers About New York’s Ethnic Neighborhoods, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of answers from Joseph Berger, an education and regional columnist for The New York Times, who took questions this week from City Room readers about New York City’s ethnic and immigrant neighborhoods.

headline: Gotta Find a Wii
text: Sleeping bag. Check.

headline: F.T.C. Chair to Remain on Google Review
text: The head of the Federal Trade Commission said Friday she will not remove herself from an antitrust review of Google‘s purchase of online advertising company DoubleClick, rebuffing requests from privacy groups opposed to the transaction.

headline: A G.O.P. Heavyweight for Huckabee
text: “Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee scored a major victory Thursday when he secured the support of prominent G.O.P. insider Ed Rollins, who will serve as national chairman of Huckabee’s campaign,” reports The Hill.

headline: Ratings Redux: ‘Deal’ Pulls NBC Into Tie
text: NBC and CBS shared the lead on Wednesday in the night’s ratings, with NBC benefiting from yet another two-hour block of “Deal or No Deal” and CBS from its popular crime shows, “Criminal Minds” and “CSI: NY.”

headline: Hey, Taxi! Do You Take Credit Cards?
text: Credit card machines have now been installed in about half the city’s nearly 13,100 yellow cabs; all taxis are scheduled to have them by Jan. 31. From time to time, we have heard complaints about drivers refusing to take credit cards, or claiming that the machines were broken (some readers have posted complaints here on City Room). So the Metro Section decided to investigate. We sent out five reporters with instructions to try 20 trips each. They fanned out in Manhattan, boarded cabs and asked cabbies the question, “I’ve only got a credit card, is that O.K.?”

headline: Ratings: In Land Of Reruns, CBS Is King
text: Facing mostly repeat competition on Thursday, new episodes of CBS’s regular line-up dominated the night’s ratings, leading every hour of prime time by a wide margin. CBS’s “CSI” at 9 p.m. delivered the night’s largest audience with 19.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. No show on any other network garnered even half that many viewers.

headline: Teammates Commend Coles for Courage
text: Jets receiver Laveranues Coles answered questions at the podium after the team’s loss last Sunday to the Browns. After he finished, Coles needed to lean on a media-relations staffer to get down three steps.

headline: Talking to Mitchell Not Worth It for Schilling
text: Curt Schilling of the Boston Red Sox acknowledged on Friday that he had declined former Senator George J. Mitchell’s request to be interviewed as part of Major League Baseball’s investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Jack Bauer: Pizza Delivery Guy
text: Whether you need a “24” fix or a pizza with all the fixin’s, try these:

headline: Sex Ring in Minneapolis Lured Queens Women
text: Advertisements in Chinese newspapers in New York and other American cities promised women jobs as domestics or as masseuses in Minneapolis. But when the women — Chinese and Korean, many of them here illegally, with few skills and possibly no other job prospects — arrived in Minneapolis, they learned that the jobs were actually in the sex trade, according to the police there.

headline: Speaking English, Staten Island-Style
text: It turns out that people on the south shore of Staten Island do not just have some specialized vocabulary words. There is even a distinct south shore Staten Island accent that can be heard in the speech of those who have lived in the area for a few generations, according to a linguist who grew up there.

headline: Why Amazon Should Buy eBay
text: UPDATE: I posted two follow ups to this post. One is on the consumer frustration with eBay. The other is about the disillusionment of its sellers.

headline: Friday’s Bunker: Making the System Work for You
text: You have to have a game plan is you want to do hockey right.

headline: ’08 Hopefuls Pressed on Foreign Aid
text: One voice is O.K., but a choir of voices is a heck of a lot louder. At least that’s the message of a new $1.8 million nationwide TV ad campaign designed to mobilize citizens to demand that their favorite presidential candidates increase foreign aid if elected.

headline: School’s Out
text: Thanks to our commentators, and our loyal readers, for their company on this two-week voyage through “The Education of Henry Adams.” It’s been full of unexpected detours and rewarding tangents. I’m still not sure I truly understand the dynamic theory of history, but it’s been a thrill to be schooled a bit in the authentic ways of Washington by those who genuinely know.

headline: Google’s Advertising Black Box Becomes Just a Bit Translucent
text: Google these days is constantly tweaking all aspects of its many services. One of these changes jumped out at me as a sign of a shift in strategy. It is testing a system that will let Web site owners who sell advertising through Google’s AdSense system to review and reject advertisements they don’t find appropriate.

headline: Sallie Mae Executive Chairman to Resume C.E.O. Role
text: Sallie Mae, the giant student lender whose $25 billion buyout is all but dead, said after the market closed on Friday that its executive chairman would again take up the role of chief executive.

headline: Ask Ming Hung Wong a Question
text: Welcome back to our expert roundtable discussion of China’s environmental crisis. To ask a question or make a comment on the issues raised by the eighth article in the series on the problems caused by China’s booming aquaculture industry, write to us using the comments box below.

headline: 2007, Year of the Proposed Ban
text: What we’re reading elsewhere…

headline: Life by WindLight
text: On The Medium, we’re resolving in 2008 to spend more time with our freaky friends who have forsaken good old Real Life for good new Second Life.

headline: ‘Thug Snacks’? This Councilman Won’t Bite
text: Remember Cocaine, the highly caffeinated soft drink whose name was changed after a storm of negative publicity?

headline: Show of Hands: Was This a Defining Moment?
text: When Fred Thompson refused to answer a question during Wednesday’s debate about whether climate change was real and caused by human activity, we thought it livened up a rather dull affair but hardly considered it a “defining moment.”

headline: Rollins Joins Huckabee Campaign
text: CONCORD, N.H. — Mike Huckabee announced Friday that the G.O.P. political strategist Ed Rollins, who helped craft the party’s appeal to working class Democrats during the Reagan years, would assume the role of Mr. Huckabee’s national campaign chairman.

headline: M.T.A. Expands Service on No. 7 and L Lines
text: Certain Queens and Brooklyn commuters can rejoice. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced this afternoon that service will expand on the No. 7 and L subway lines next week.

headline: ABC Announces New Year Line-Up (And Prays)
text: ABC will roll out a series of scripted and unscripted shows this winter, with the premiere of “Cashmere Mafia” and new episodes of “Lost” in January and the return of “Dancing With the Stars” and “The Bachelor” in March.

headline: Strike: When Will The Late-Night Hosts Return?
text: The strike-sidelined stars of late-night may return to television just in time for January’s primary election season.

headline: Touring the House
text: After a week of showing family, plumbers, contractors and other workers the house, we have become professional tour guides. So I am going to try to give you, the readers, a virtual tour. You’ll see where the windows are and how the bathrooms are shaping up, and I hope you’ll get a better sense of how spacious the rooms are and their orientation.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 14
text: Here is a slide show of 11 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include SantaCon, the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “War and Peace” and the Frank Viola Homing Pigeon Club on Stillwell Avenue in Coney Island.

headline: Giuliani: ‘Tested. Ready. Now.’
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani never gave a formal announcement speech when he began running for president. Now, after a rocky month, he is planning to give an address in Tampa on Saturday where he will lay out his vision of a Giuliani presidency.

headline: Week 15 Fantasy Football Picks
text: Rats!

headline: An Armed Resistance
text: Guerrillas from a separatist movement and the Ethiopian government are fighting for control of the Ogaden region, whose residents are starting to flee.

headline: Nitkowski Is Glad He Said No to Steroids
text: C.J. Nitkowski was a free agent after the 2001 season, and the drug culture in baseball was rampant. C.J. was interested in taking steroids, and he asked his friend Brian McNamee for his opinion.

headline: Kevin Bacon Has Landed
text: DES MOINES — Kevin Bacon is next up in the line of stars rotating through Iowa for John Edwards. Already, the actor has set hearts a-fluttering.

headline: Saturday Matchup: Bengals at 49ers
text: The first Saturday night game of the year (8 p.m., NFL Network) is a matchup between two of the most disappointing teams of the season, teams whose players have had more fight among themselves than against opponents.

headline: Back in the Air
text: Kite-flying was banned in Afghanistan during Taliban rule, but it is again out in the open, over the hills of Kabul.

headline: The Friendliest Country, and the Unfriendliest Skies
text: Most visitors to the Unites States will tell you that service in American restaurants and hotels is generally as friendly and as unpretentious as you will find anywhere. I know that because I grew up in England, where every waiter in a rundown cafe greeted me as I were a summons to the police and every worker in an upscale place as if I were a fly that had landed on the duck à l’orange. In Japan, where I now live, service in even a convenience store is efficient, quick and impeccably polite, but you won’t get the genuine laughs or banter that you often find in even a bank in New York. Democracy finds its vindication, I often think, in the cheerful, ungrudging attention you get across what is perhaps the world’s most open nation.

headline: A Lasso for Listeners: Part Oslo, Part Oklahoma
text: Rune Grammofon, an independent record label based in Oslo, traffics in music of unconventional detail and assiduous design. Its stable of artists, almost exclusively Norwegian, includes electronic programmers, jazz-tangential confabs and some curiously captivating vocalists. What they seem to have in common, besides the endorsement of Rune Kristoffersen, the label’s founder and operator, is an ethos of attraction. However opaque or experimental their music becomes, they want to draw you in.

headline: 7 Killed by Bomb Blasts in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  A rash of bomb blasts and ambushes across Baghdad left seven people dead on Saturday, including three members of American-backed security patrols that were trying to rout insurgents. The attacks came as people across the country were deep in preparations for the holy Muslim holiday of Eid ul-Adha, which follows the annual Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca and begins on Wednesday.

headline: Sticker Shock a Hazard, Even When the Artists Are Only Potential Stars
text: I PLOTTED my executive pursuit of starting a contemporary art collection from a supercaffeinated base camp in the Empire Diner at 10th Avenue and West 22nd Street in Manhattan. It was dark and early on a wintery Thursday morning. The sky outside the diner’s Art Deco-style windows looked like an ominous gray abstraction. But my guide, Simon Watson, a 52-year-old art consultant with close-cropped silver hair and indigo clothes, was in a sunny mood.

headline: A Little Here, a Little There and It’s Gone
text: WHERE does the money go? As I tallied up our family’s income and expenses for the year, I was baffled.

headline: Britain Overtakes U.S. as Top World Bank Donor
text: BERLIN  The World Bank, overcoming misgivings about its direction and leadership, said Friday that it had raised $25.1 billion in aid for the world’s poorest countries, a record sum that includes donations by China and Egypt, nations that were once recipients of such aid.

headline: Piggybacking on Buybacks
text: SOMETIMES the simplest investing strategies are also the best.

headline: Retirement at RBS
text: RBS Greenwich Capital Markets, the American securities unit of Royal Bank of Scotland, said its chief executive, Jay Levine, would leave in March. He is retiring because the subsidiary, based in Greenwich, Conn., will be reorganizing as a result of Royal Bank’s purchase of ABN Amro Holding. “It was really something Jay wasn’t interested in,” a company spokesman, Peter Ward, said. “He really wanted to get to a smaller, more entrepreneurial endeavor.”

headline: Criticism of Curry Comes From a Big Fan
text: CHICAGO  Eddy Curry came home Friday, only to find humiliation instead of hugs, indignities instead of affection. The ball was still on the rack when it all began. Matters only got worse when the game started.

headline: Algeria: U.N. Death Toll Raised to 17
text: The United Nations confirmed that 17 of its staff members died in the bombing of two of its buildings in Algiers on Tuesday, which the government said killed 37 people. Marie Okabe, a spokeswoman for Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, said the earlier toll of 11 dead had risen after more bodies were dug out from the rubble. The United Nations said that all but three of the dead  a Dane, a Filipino and a Senegalese  were thought to be Algerians.

headline: Paid in Dollars, Some Americans Are Struggling in Europe
text: PARIS  Erica Nevins’s faith in the dollar was shaken the moment she pressed a crumpled $1 bill into the hand of a little girl begging for money on the streets of Marrakesh, Morocco.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about billionaires who push for social change in poorer countries misspelled the surname of one such entrepreneur. He is Warren E. Buffett, not Buffet.

headline: Iconoclasm and a Hint of Stalin’s Heavy Hand
text: Shostakovich wrote his D minor Cello Sonata in 1934 as the terrible Soviet purges of the next five years were about to begin. Its Bolshevik-friendly tone represents a U-turn from the in-your-face iconoclasm of “The Nose” in 1928 or the seedy verismo of another, just-finished opera, “Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk,” soon to receive its famous pan from the Soviet Union’s critic in chief. Indeed, a bit of Stalin seems to hover behind the sonata’s sweetly singing melodies and frantic, dancelike energies, Shostakovich’s unique voice notwithstanding.

headline: Gazans Rally on Hamas Anniversary
text: GAZA  About 200,000 Gazans rallied in support of Hamas on Saturday, the 20th anniversary of its founding.

headline: Politeness of China Talks Can’t Disguise the Discord
text: BEIJING  In three days of talks on economic issues this week, a half-dozen Bush administration cabinet members and their aides sat in rows of tables facing their Chinese counterparts in an ornate conference room. The talk was polite, the atmosphere convivial and the pledges of cooperation profuse.

headline: The Condition of Faith vs. State in America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about a visit to Bethlehem by Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain and now an international envoy for Palestinian development, described incompletely Israel’s policy about the presence of its citizens in the West Bank. While Israeli citizens cannot freely visit Palestinian towns there, tens of thousands of Israelis do live in settlements in the territory.

headline: Adding to the List of Worries, Signs That Inflation Is Bubbling Up
text: Economists and central bankers have worried for months that soaring food and energy costs could lead to higher inflation, but investors had shrugged off those concerns, preferring to focus on the slowdown in growth.

headline: Ethiopians Said to Push Civilians Into Rebel War
A Star Who Plays Second Fiddle to Music
text: When a star pianist comes into a huge hall wearing a three-piece orange suit, “self-effacing” is not the description that comes to mind. But when Yefim Bronfman lumbered into Grand Central Terminal in October for a free morning concert to benefit the Food Bank for New York City wearing the organization’s colors, he presented a contradictory image: that of a virtuoso making a striking public entrance and that of someone who would have preferred not to be drawing so much attention to himself.

headline: Building a Greener Cardboard Box
text: AMERICANS are using more cardboard in different ways each year. But tree replanting and technological advances in making cardboard are easing the environmental impact, says Patrick J. Moore, chairman and chief executive of the Smurfit-Stone Container Corporation, the largest maker of paper-based packaging products, with $7.2 billion in sales in 2006. Mr. Moore, who is based in St. Louis, says recycling programs are also improving the environmental impact of all the packaging that Americans consume. Here are excerpts from a conversation:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about plans by the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay requiring small companies to adhere to some auditing requirements under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act left the incorrect impression that the S.E.C. chairman, Christopher Cox, was leaving the door open for an indefinite stay of the requirements. As the article noted, testimony prepared for Mr. Cox to deliver to a Congressional panel did not explicitly say that he wanted the commission to require small companies to obey the law after the delay. His testimony, however, did include a reference to a time “when, eventually, smaller public companies do come into full compliance” with the law.

headline: California: Guilty Pleas in Attack Plot
text: Two men accused of plotting in prison to attack military sites, synagogues and other targets pleaded guilty to conspiring to wage war against the United States. The men, Kevin James, 31, and Levar H. Washington, 28, pleaded guilty to seditious conspiracy charges. Mr. Washington also pleaded guilty to using a firearm to further that conspiracy. The authorities say Mr. James, Mr. Washington and two others were part of a California prison gang cell of radical Muslims. The police said they uncovered the plot in July 2005 while investigating gas station robberies that they say were committed to finance the attacks.

headline: Prosecutor in DeLay Case Says He Won’t Seek Re-election Next Year
text: HOUSTON  Ronnie Earle, the long-serving Texas district attorney who has been leading the criminal prosecution of the former House majority leader, Tom DeLay, said Friday that he would not seek a ninth four-year term next year. Instead, he said, he may run for governor in 2010.

headline: Pass Is No Help for Declarer, but One Club Gives the Clue
text: Bridge is a bidder’s game, or so the modern mantra goes. But overbidders ignore one reality: If you make a bid and become a defender, you have given declarer extra  often vital  information in the quest for his contract.

headline: The Cabby Takes Plastic, or at Least Is Supposed To
text: More than half the city’s yellow cabs are now fitted with devices to accept credit cards for payment. Drivers fought the credit card plan with an unexpected fury  and it was at least partly responsible for their decision to go on strike twice.

headline: Cautiously, Big Labels Confront the Mixtape
text: LOS ANGELES  Early this year, DJ Drama, a mixtape producer who made his name spotlighting new rap talents on his own line of compilation CDs, found himself in a Georgia jail cell after being arrested on charges of racketeering in connection with his recordings. This week, less than a year after authorities raided his studio, and with the case still pending, he found himself in a more agreeable setting: the Billboard album chart.

headline: A New Emphasis for the Ministry: Management Skills
text: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.  For the last four years, Wendy Samuels has worked in a remote village in Jamaica for Mustard Seed Communities, a Roman Catholic nonprofit group that helps disabled children.

headline: Robert Kulicke, 83, Artist and Frame Maker, Is Dead
text: Robert M. Kulicke, a painter, goldsmith, teacher, businessman and designer who changed the look of postwar art by modernizing frame design, died on Friday in Valley Cottage, N.Y. He was 83 and had lived in Manhattan until about 18 months ago.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Weekend Explorer column on Friday, about the Upper East Side, referred imprecisely to the architectural style of the mansion Andrew Carnegie built at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 91st Street and of the town house Woody Allen bought on East 70th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues. They were built after the death of the last King George of Britain in 1830, and thus are Georgian style, not Georgian. The column also misstated the year Carnegie moved into the mansion. It was 1902, not 1901.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A subheading in the NYC column on Friday, about the absence of urban and suburban issues as a topic in the Democratic and Republican presidential debates, referred incorrectly to the type of community that is home to more than 80 percent of the nation’s population. That proportion lives in metropolitan areas, which include cities and suburbs; the 80 percent figure does not represent urban dwellers only. (About 50 percent of the population is in the suburbs and 30 percent in cities.)

headline: Some Charges Dropped Against Former Curator
text: Two years into her criminal trial on charges of conspiracy to acquire looted artifacts, Marion True, a former curator for the J. Paul Getty Museum in California, was dealt a break Friday when lawyers for the Italian state and the region of Sicily dropped civil charges against her regarding 40 artifacts the museum has returned to Italy. Civil claims involving some other artifacts the museum has not returned are still pending against Ms. True, said Maurizio Fiorilli, the lawyer representing the Italian state, at a hearing in Rome. The dismissal of the claims involving the objects was required under an accord between the Getty and Italy signed in September. All of the 40 objects except for a renowned statue of Aphrodite have been returned. They are to go on view next week at the Quirinale, the presidential palace, along with artifacts returned by other American museums and dealers. The Aphrodite is to be handed over in 2010.

headline: Going Out, Gervais Picks Bang Over Whimper
text: LOS ANGELES  Ricky Gervais says he decided to make an 80-minute finale to his HBO series “Extras” because he had a few things left to say about the wages of fame, and the people who pay them.

headline: Report Says That the Rich Are Getting Richer Faster, Much Faster
text: The increase in incomes of the top 1 percent of Americans from 2003 to 2005 exceeded the total income of the poorest 20 percent of Americans, data in a new report by the Congressional Budget Office shows.

headline: Hamas Arrests Aide to Palestinian Prime Minister
text: JERUSALEM  The Hamas police in Gaza arrested an aide to the Ramallah-based Palestinian prime minister on Friday and held him for questioning, a Hamas spokesman said.

headline: Delay Is Sought by Justice Dept. on C.I.A. Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department asked the House Intelligence Committee on Friday to postpone its investigation into the destruction of videotapes by the Central Intelligence Agency in 2005, saying the Congressional inquiry presented “significant risks” to its own preliminary investigation into the matter.

headline: The Enemy at the Gates of Going Undefeated
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  He has been the feared nemesis in the hoodie for so long, with a career wound tightly around his poisoned relationship with the Jets, that it is difficult to pinpoint exactly how Bill Belichick’s image crossed the Rubicon from envied champion to football villain.

headline: Campaigns Woo 3 Iowans for Paper’s Endorsement
text: DES MOINES  The other day, as his sport utility vehicle idled outside, former President Bill Clinton held forth on a sofa in the publisher’s suite at The Des Moines Register, explaining why he believed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton should win the newspaper’s coveted endorsement.

headline: Player Cooperated, and His Name Was Left Out of Report
text: One active major league player was able to keep his name out of the former Senator George J. Mitchell’s report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, even though Mitchell had evidence that he bought them, Mitchell said in an interview Friday.

headline: In Two Nights of Mixed Choreography, a Dancer’s Star Remains a Constant
text: In 1962, Alvin Ailey choreographed “Reflections in D” to Duke Ellington’s music as a vehicle for himself. At only three minutes, it was meant as a transition dance, allowing time for other dancers to change their costumes between pieces. But innocent tasks can produce enlightening results, as this work proves. Clifton Brown, making his debut in the solo on Wednesday night at City Center, dived inside the music, providing voluminous breadth to his curving arms as he fluidly moved from one grounded position to the next.

headline: Siemens Reverses Decision
text: Siemens, the German engineering giant, revoked the appointment of a finance executive on suspicion that he might have links to a bribery investigation facing the company. Siemens announced a week ago that the executive, Hannes Apitzsch, would become chief financial officer of its industry sector. That sector is a recently created grouping of business lines including automation machinery, building technologies and light bulbs.

headline: Plant Will Tour,but Not With Zeppelin
text: Robert Plant will tour with Alison Krauss, dashing the hopes of those who expected Led Zeppelin to mount a reunion tour, BBC News reported. Ms. Krauss and Mr. Plant, above, who released the album “Raising Sand” in October, will perform across Europe in May and are expected to come to the United States in the summer. Tickets for the tour, which begins in Birmingham, are now on sale. Led Zeppelin, with Mr. Plant as lead singer, played its first concert in 19 years in London on Monday, sparking rumors of a tour.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary of the musician Ike Turner, using information provided by Getty Images, misstated the date of the photograph of Ike and Tina Turner. While Getty says it does not know the precise date of the picture, it says that it is from 1970 or later, not “around 1960” and thus not from the early days of the Ike and Tina Turner Revue.

headline: In Kansas, Top Official Announces Resignation
text: Kansas’ attorney general said Friday that he would resign, less than a week after admitting to an affair with a former employee who says the attorney general also sought information from her about a political rival.

headline: An Opera, Unloved by Its Creator, Finds Some Devoted Friends Onstage
text: A few years after the 1844 premiere of “I Due Foscari,” one of his early (and now seldom heard) operas, Verdi disparaged it as a deadly bore. This gloomy three-act work is certainly dark but not dull, especially given the emotive performances by the soloists when Eve Queler conducted the Opera Orchestra of New York and the New York Choral Ensemble in a concert performance at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

headline: New York State Theater to Close for Repairs in 2008
text: The New York State Theater will go dark during New York City Opera’s 2008-9 season so that it can be renovated, the opera said Friday in a joint announcement with New York City Ballet, which shares the stage. But construction will be periodically suspended so that the ballet can proceed with its lucrative holiday “Nutcracker” and then its winter and spring seasons.

headline: Investors Sell on Inflation Data
text: Stocks fell Friday after accelerating inflation spurred concern that higher prices will curb consumer spending and give the Federal Reserve less leeway to cut interest rates.

headline: Estranged Londoners, Waist-Deep in Trouble
text: “Flood,” in which London is largely underwater for four hours, is the kind of disaster movie that when you meet an estranged father and son early on, you know that they will have a wet scene of redemption and reunion by the last act.

headline: McQuarters Not Fazed by Threat of Harsh Weather
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A northeaster is predicted to pound Giants Stadium this weekend, and R. W. McQuarters would seem to be facing the trickiest challenge of any Giants player on Sunday night against the Redskins. One of his jobs is to catch wind-blown punts.

headline: Staff Reductions at Nbc News and CBS
text: NBC is replacing the senior producer in charge of the newly created fourth hour of “Today” as part of a staff reduction at the network’s news division. Amy Rosenblum, who joined NBC News after a long stint as executive producer on the syndicated talk show “Maury,” with Maury Povich, will be leaving “Today,” where she has worked for two years. “Today,” the most successful news program on television, this week celebrated its 12th year of winning every week in the morning news competition. Ms. Rosenblum was one of about 15 news employees who will be leaving NBC News, either through buyouts or layoffs. NBC executives said that the reductions were limited and that the news division had added staff members in other areas, such as its education initiatives. But money was a factor in the reductions. Many of those leaving were long-time staff members at high salaries. CBS also announced staff reductions Friday, all at its interactive division, including some news employees. CBS executives would not provide a number but said it would likely be fewer than 20 people.

headline: Musharraf Lifts State of Emergency in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Pervez Musharraf lifted the six-week-old state of emergency and restored the Constitution on Saturday, after passing a flurry of constitutional amendments and decrees to ensure his recent actions would not be challenged by any court.

headline: With Color and Panache, Afghans Fight a Different Kind of War
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The kites appear suddenly, whimsical flashes of color that kick above the beige landscape here of relentless dust and desperation.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a hearing on a claim by death row inmates in Connecticut that the state’s death penalty discriminates against minorities misstated the timing of the last execution in the state. Michael Ross, a serial killer, was executed by lethal injection in May 2005; it has not in fact been “decades” since the state executed anyone. (Go to Article)

headline: Letterman Pursuing a Deal With Writers
text: In what may be the first break in the Hollywood writers' strike, David Letterman is pursuing a deal with the Writers Guild of America that would allow his late-night show on CBS to return to the air in early January with the usual complement of material from his writers, even if the strike is still continuing.

headline: Wikipedia Competitor Being Tested by Google
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google is testing a new Web service intended to become a repository of knowledge from experts on various topics, one that could turn into a competitor to Wikipedia and other sites.

headline: North Korea Replies to Bush With an Offer and a Condition
text: WASHINGTON  Responding to a recent letter from President Bush, North Korea agreed on Friday to follow through on its pledge to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula, provided the United States reciprocates by normalizing relations between the countries.

headline: Ground Zero Health Program Hits a Setback in Washington
text: The future of a national program to provide medical treatment to ground zero workers outside the metropolitan area is in doubt after the federal government abruptly halted the search for a contractor to process medical reimbursements.

headline: Strike Ends in Russia
text: The Ford Motor Company and a union representing part of its Russian employees agreed to end a strike that was corroding Ford’s profit in one of Europe’s hottest markets. Already, two-thirds of Ford’s assembly line employees at a plant in Vsevolozhsk, outside St. Petersburg, had broken ranks with the union and returned to work since the strike began Nov. 22. On Friday, the remaining union employees also agreed to return beginning with the late shift on Sunday, though negotiations on salaries and benefits in the 2008 contract continue, according to a statement from Ford. Russia, awash in oil money, is projected to surpass Germany as the largest car market in Europe by the end of the decade.

headline: Working on a Degree, and Trying to Learn From Mistakes
text: When he found himself in jail at 18, Jonathan Rosario knew it was time to turn his life around.

headline: ABC’s ‘Lost’ Is to Return, and ‘Grey’s’ Will Move
text: LOS ANGELES  ABC announced on Friday that it would increase the reality programming on its schedule by more than 50 percent, beginning next month. The shake-up of the network’s ratings-leading prime-time schedule is a result of the extended writers’ strike.

headline: Iowa’s Student Vote
text: College students are legally entitled to vote where they attend school. That makes perfect sense given that they often live in their college communities for four years or more and become eligible to vote for the first time while living there. But not everyone likes this arrangement, and political operatives often try to suppress the student vote. We recently got a glimpse of this process in Iowa, where the presidential caucuses are just weeks away.

headline: Senegal Bars a Singer
text: Senegal has barred the reggae star Tiken Jah Fakoly from entering the country after he criticized President Abdoulaye Wade, Agence France-Presse reported. The singer, who is from the Ivory Coast, criticized Mr. Wade during a news conference and afterward at a concert on Wednesday, urging the president to leave office for the good of his country. Senegal’s interior ministry said Thursday evening that Mr. Fakoly was “persona non grata in Senegal” for his “insolent and discourteous” remarks and would be barred from entering the country. The singer had been in Senegal for the International Hip-Hop Awards in Dakar. The independent Senegalese newspaper Sud Quotidien said he was a “victim of state xenophobia.” Last month the Senegalese government faced protests that were seen as the country’s most violent since the late 1980s.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Book Seller Is a Buyer

headline: Project Enlists Computers to Help Fight Wildfires
text: FRASER, Colo.  Nobody on Michael E. Hutt’s team has illusions that wildfire can be tamed. The blazes in Southern California in October were lesson enough for that.

headline: Giuliani, Very Open? There’s Always a First Time
text: A few years back, a man named Russell Harding held a City Hall patronage job that came with a government credit card, which he used to steal more than $250,000.

headline: Woods Shows Off His Skills, but Not as a Host
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  Tiger Woods’s contract to play host to the Target World Challenge clearly contains no clause obligating him to be nice to his 15 invited guests  at least not during play. Because on a perfect day for scoring at Sherwood Country Club on Friday, six golfers shot a 67 only to discover that their rounds of five under par were only good enough to put them five shots further behind their genial host.

headline: Musharraf’s Rural Support Seems Less Than He Claims
text: BADAR RANJHA, Pakistan  In an interview last month, President Pervez Musharraf challenged Western journalists to journey to rural Pakistan to gauge public opinion. The mood of voters could be best gauged in the villages of Punjab, he said, the densely populated eastern province that holds 55 percent of the country’s population.

headline: Huckabee Faces Old Queries in New Spotlight
text: When Mike Huckabee became lieutenant governor of Arkansas in 1993, he complained of being burdened by college tuition bills for his son, the expenses of two residences  one in Texarkana and the other in Little Rock  and the cost of commuting between the two.

headline: Arizona: Suspect in Killings Sentenced
text: A man accused of being the Phoenix Baseline Killer was sentenced to 438 years in prison for the sexual assaults of two sisters. The man, Mark Goudeau, 43, a former construction worker, still faces trial in the killings of eight women and a man in 2005 and 2006. He has pleaded not guilty. Mr. Goudeau was convicted in September on charges of raping one woman and sexually attacking another as they walked home from a park. During the two-month trial, both sisters identified Mr. Goudeau as their attacker, and DNA evidence also linked him to the rape.

headline: Book Seller Is a Buyer
text: A book of fairy tales handwritten and illustrated by J. K. Rowling sold for nearly $4 million at Sotheby’s auction house in London on Thursday. One day later, the identity of the winning bidder was revealed: Amazon.com. The company now owns one of seven copies of “The Tales of Beedle the Bard,” which is hand-bound in leather with silver mounts, The Associated Press reported. Proceeds from the sale will benefit the Children’s Voice, an organization that campaigns for children’s rights in Europe founded in 2005 by Ms. Rowling and Baroness Nicholson, a member of Britain’s House of Lords. Amazon has posted photographs of the book and says it will review the tales on its site. The company has also created a discussion board to answer questions about the book’s contents. Craig Berman, a spokesman for Amazon, said the company plans to put the book on a tour of libraries and schools. Ms. Rowling wrote the Beedle tales after finishing the Harry Potter series. She said the other six copies of the book had been given to people who were closely connected to the creation of the series.

headline: Static on the Dream Phone
text: SEBASTOPOL, Calif.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Thursday about a collective malaise in Italy misspelled the name of the city where Beppe Grillo, a performer who has given voice to the country’s mood, was shown preparing for a performance. It is Novara, not Novarra.

headline: Warning for Drug
text: The European health regulator said Pfizer’s Champix, a stop-smoking aid, should carry a warning about the risk of suicide attempts among patients. In urging the warning, the regulator, the European Medicines Agency, followed the lead of American health officials who said last month doctors should monitor patients for mood shifts and patients should tell their doctors of changes.

headline: Senate Passes Bill Easing Home Loan Rules
text: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  The Senate passed legislation on Friday that would make more Federal Housing Administration loans available to subprime borrowers facing foreclosure.

headline: Villone Allegations Difficult to Process
text: One of the joys of being a beat writer is the downtime in the clubhouse when you really get to know the players. No tape recorders, no notebooks, just talk. You learn things this way, and develop trust, but you also simply enjoy the company of certain guys as people.

headline: The Mac Crowd Mourns
text: IN part because CompUSA has been a large seller of Macs, the news last week that the electronics retailer plans to close its remaining stores early next year has drawn lots of attention online, much of it presented in an elegiac tone.

headline: Separatists in Philippines Agree to Reconcile
text: MANILA  Two rival Islamic separatist groups in the Philippines have agreed to reconcile by September, a pledge that has raised hopes here that the insurgency in the south of the country where the separatists have been fighting for self-determination since the 1970s might finally come to an end, officials said Friday.

headline: Schwarzenegger to Declare an Emergency Over Budget
text: LOS ANGELES  With several costly policy problems awaiting a legislative repair, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Friday that the state’s budget deficit had grown to between $10 billion and $14 billion and that he would call for a state of fiscal emergency next month.

headline: Bolivians Now Hear Ominous Tones in the Calls to Arms
text: SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia  “Against narco-communism,” reads one line of graffiti in this city in the lowlands of Bolivia. “To arms, Cruceños,” reads another, calling on residents to fight the government of President Evo Morales, who put the armed forces on alert this week as four eastern provinces move toward greater autonomy.

headline: Taxi TV, Brisk as the Traffic You’re Stuck In
text: Where once there was only peeling vinyl, printed fare rates and the cabdriver’s ceaseless cellphone chatter, there is now a television screen.

headline: Happy Hour With the Centaur Lady
text: You have to feel favorably disposed toward Andrew Dinwiddie and Jeff Larson, the curators of the well-liked Catch performance series. Not only do they make the safety announcements themselves (“the exits are, um, over there”), they are also endearingly enthusiastic about their offerings. And they managed to get Singha beer as a sponsor for Catch 27, a mini-festival that features a bunch of talented artists over two weekends at Performance Space 122.

headline: Anglican Archbishop Faults Factions
text: The archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, sent a lengthy letter to the members of his warring Anglican Communion on Friday, saying that both sides had violated the Communion’s boundaries and put the church in crisis.

headline: Ethanol’s Issue: Getting Acquainted With Drivers
text: LIMA, Ohio  If America’s great ethanol fuel experiment is ever going to work, Bill Timmermeister will be among the first to know.

headline: In China, Farming Fish in Toxic Waters
text: FUQING, China  Here in southern China, beneath the looming mountains of Fujian Province, lie dozens of enormous ponds filled with murky brown water and teeming with eels, shrimp and tilapia, much of it destined for markets in Japan and the West.

headline: Capitol Pas de Deux: One Party Leads, and the Other ...
text: WASHINGTON  When Republicans had the House majority, party leaders used to game out tactics that they thought the Democrats might use to gum up the legislative works. To their surprise, one of them recounted recently, they always came up with more devious ideas than anything the Democrats actually tried.

headline: Several Children Are Injured When Their Van Collides With a City Bus in Queens
text: A private van that the police said was illegally carrying a group of young children to school collided with a city bus in Queens on Friday, critically injuring a 9-year-old girl and sending six other children to hospitals.

headline: Buying Into Lloyd’s
text: Japan’s largest insurer, Millea Holdings , said its Tokio Marine and Nichido Fire Insurance unit would buy Kiln Ltd. for £442.2 million ($902 million) to gain a seat at Lloyd’s of London.

headline: Ohio Elections Official Calls Machines Flawed
text: CINCINNATI  All five voting systems used in Ohio, a state whose electoral votes narrowly swung two elections toward President Bush, have critical flaws that could undermine the integrity of the 2008 general election, a report commissioned by the state’s top elections official has found.

headline: Let Baseball Players Police Themselves
text: Kennesaw, Ga.

headline: A Baseball Lover, Key to Tarnishing a Yankee Era
text: Brian McNamee is a former New York City police officer from Queens who has cherished the game of baseball since he was a youngster in the Rockaways and who twice found himself in the employ of the Yankees. But today he stands as the man who delivered a rattling blow to the team by linking two famous Yankees  Roger Clemens and Andy Pettitte  to the use of illegal, performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Report to Urge Sweeping Change for SUNY System
text: Warning that New York has “slipped in stature” and that its once-powerful position in national research has “faded,” a commission set up by Gov. Eliot Spitzer is recommending that the state free its public colleges and universities to raise tuition without the Legislature’s approval and to charge different prices from campus to campus.

headline: Barack’s Blast From the Past
text: There are lots of different ways for a presidential candidate to deal with the question of drug use. You can admit it, deny it or say you didn’t inhale. That last one, I think we can agree, is a choice we won’t be seeing again any time real soon.

headline: Huckabee Camp Shifts Focus for New Hampshire
text: CONCORD, N.H.  Mike Huckabee, who surged in Iowa polls with an appeal to religious and social conservatives, returned Friday to New Hampshire, where he is still an also-ran for the Republican presidential nomination, and opened a newly focused campaign for the votes of working people and economic conservatives.

headline: Onstage and Off, a Group Inspired by Rivalries, Loves and Triumphs
text: “I get asked the same question over and over, which is to talk about the Steppenwolf aesthetic,” said Anna D. Shapiro, director of the Steppenwolf Theater Company’s production of “August: Osage County,” now playing at the Imperial Theater on Broadway.

headline: A Sale for Boeing
text: The Boeing Company said AWAS, an airplane leasing company in Ireland, has ordered 31 of its single-aisle 737-800 jets. While specific deal terms were not disclosed, Boeing said the order was worth $2.3 billion at list prices, although airlines typically negotiate discounts. AWAS owns and manages 315 airplanes.

headline: Small Shops See Smallness as Their Big Selling Point
text: Predictions of a weak holiday shopping season have led the big department stores to slash prices and stretch their advertising budgets. But most small retailers, which cannot afford either the price cuts or the expensive advertising, are doing something else this year: making a virtue of their size.

headline: Advocate Sentenced in Lobbying Probe
text: A Republican environmental advocate who arranged the lobbyist Jack Abramoff’s entree to the Interior Department was sentenced to two months in a halfway house and four years of probation. The activist, Italia Federici, who pleaded guilty in June to tax evasion and obstructing a Senate investigation, was spared prison only because she has become a key witness in the Justice Department’s continuing corruption investigation. Ms. Federici has admitted acting as a link between Mr. Abramoff and J. Steven Griles, the former deputy Interior Department secretary who for five years was her boyfriend. Mr. Griles provided Mr. Abramoff with advice and internal information, sometimes directly and sometimes through Ms. Federici.

headline: On Retainer in Pakistan, to Ease Military Rulers’ Path
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan

headline: Resignation at Credit Suisse
text: The United States head of asset management at Credit Suisse, Keith Schappert, left the company, the bank said. “He has resigned,” a spokeswoman, Suzanne Fleming, said. She declined to comment on whether a successor was being considered.

headline: Illinois: Security at Nuclear Plants
text: The Exelon Corporation said it would replace the Wackenhut Corporation with an in-house security force at its 10 nuclear power plants after the discovery about two months ago that guards at a Pennsylvania plant were sleeping on the job. Exelon, based in Chicago, said it was acting even though a review of security at its other plants found “no significant deficiencies.” The change is to be made by July. Exelon has 17 reactors at 10 plants, including in Illinois, Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Officials at Wackenhut have characterized the apparent lapses as “an anomaly.”

headline: Lost the Battle,won the War
text: He may not have won “American Idol,” but Chris Daughtry is king of the album charts this year, according to Billboard magazine, The Associated Press reported. His band, Daughtry, sold 3.2 million copies of its self-titled debut, making it the most popular album of the year. The group was followed by Akon, whose “Konvicted” sold 2.7 million; “The Dutchess,” by Fergie, which sold 2.4 million; the “Hannah Montana” soundtrack, with 2.5 million copies sold; and 2005’s “American Idol” star Carrie Underwood, whose “Some Hearts” sold 2.3 million. Beyoncé’s “Irreplaceable” was the No. 1 single of the year, followed by Rihanna’s “Umbrella.” The top tour of the year, Billboard said, was that of the Police, whose reunion concerts took in at least $212 million.

headline: In a Familiar Spot, Wake Forest Makes Up for a Loss
text: CARY, N.C.  Without a traditional national power in this year’s men’s College Cup, and with three of the top four seeds already ousted, the N.C.A.A. soccer championship offered only one guarantee.

headline: I Am Not a Health Reform
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Arizona: Three Bodies Found in S.U.V.
text: Three bodies were found in a sport utility vehicle in Phoenix, and the police are investigating the case as homicide. An officer who thought the Ford Explorer looked suspicious found the bodies in the back of the vehicle, which had been parked in front of an apartment complex, Sgt. Andy Hill said.

headline: Steroid Era Is No Longer Only About Bonds
text: A day after issuing his strongly worded report on steroid use in Major League Baseball, George J. Mitchell sat in the conference room of his Manhattan office discussing the public reaction.

headline: Dean Says Firing Came After Query on Finances
text: The dean of the highly ranked medical school at the University of California, San Francisco, was fired this week, and he suggested on Friday that the move came as a result of questions he had raised about the institution’s financial accounting.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a hearing on a claim by death row inmates in Connecticut that the state’s death penalty discriminates against minorities misstated the timing of the last execution in the state. Michael Ross, a serial killer, was executed by lethal injection in May 2005; it has not in fact been “decades” since the state executed anyone.

headline: Money Goes Far in New York, if You’re European
text: Margaret Dragonette arrived in New York last week  three nieces, a cousin and loads of empty luggage in tow. By the time Ms. Dragonette, an administrative assistant for a nonprofit in Liverpool, was heading home, her group had filled six large suitcases and five carry-on bags. The bags were so stuffed with Juicy Couture T-shirts, Guess watches and Croc sandals that her nieces would have to wear the Ugg boots she was giving them for Christmas on the plane.

headline: Justice Attempts to Clear His Name
text: When wildfires devastated Southern California in October, David Justice was one of hundreds to lose a home. He did manage to save his World Series rings from Atlanta and the Yankees, reminders of a 14-year career punctuated by postseason highlights.

headline: One Player Who Spoke With Mitchell Wonders Why So Few Others Did
text: Toronto Blue Jays designated hitter Frank Thomas was surprised when he discovered that several major league players had declined to meet with George J. Mitchell for his investigation into the use of performance-enhancing substances in baseball. So Thomas made sure that Mitchell would not pitch a shutout.

headline: 7-Ton Load Falls Near Ground Zero
text: Seven tons of metal studs that were being hoisted by crane at the new Goldman Sachs office tower near ground zero plummeted to the ground on Friday when a nylon sling failed, seriously injuring an architect who was in a construction trailer that was crushed.

headline: Scientists Move Closer to Reliable H.G.H. Test
text: Shipments of human growth hormone arrived at players’ doorsteps by mail and by package couriers. They were purchased via the Internet, through antiaging centers and through dealers like Kirk Radomski, a former Mets clubhouse attendant who sold it more than any other illegal substance he supplied to his Major League Baseball clients.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,948,500.89

headline: Sallie Mae Chairman Made Chief
text: Sallie Mae, the giant student lender whose $25 billion buyout has run aground, said on Friday that its executive chairman would again take up the role of chief executive.

headline: Nets Have the Knack for Beating Cleveland
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets have done at least one thing well during this disappointing season: beat Cleveland.

headline: Balancing the Somber and the Sparkling
text: Conductors must devote a lot of thought to their debut programs with major orchestras, and the works they choose say a lot about them before they conduct the first note. Andrey Boreyko, a Russian conductor who directs orchestras in Hamburg, Germany, and Bern, Switzerland, made his New York Philharmonic debut on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall with a program that proclaimed him to be deadly serious but also to have a light-spirited side.

headline: Some Familiar Support on the Run to the Wire
text: The Des Moines Register has a 20-year history of issuing endorsements for presidential candidates running in the Iowa caucuses. And while the effect of those endorsements is hard to gauge, it is nonetheless true that in all but one instance, the candidates who have received them went on to either win the caucuses or finish a strong second.

headline: Jury Rules One Way, Judge Another in Mob Killing
text: The pizza man was charged with hiring assassins to kill a Genovese crime family associate. The evidence was robust. The baker was charged with helping him. The evidence was less robust.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Class Acts: Paris Ballet Student Exhibitions
text: PARIS  No ballet company or ballet school is older than that of the Paris Opera. The two are intimately linked. Former company dancers have often become teachers at the school; its current director is Élisabeth Platel, an eminent ballerina of the 1980s and ’90s. Many students appear beside the adult dancers in the company’s productions at both the Palais Garnier (as in the current “Paquita”) and the Bastille (as in “Casse-Noisette”).

headline: Forecast for the Jets Is Full of Snow and the Patriots
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  When Darrelle Revis played for the University of Pittsburgh, the Panthers traveled to the winter wonderland of West Virginia.

headline: In Export-Import Data, More Signs of a Slowdown
text: AMERICAN consumers may finally be showing some restraint. At least that is the indication from the trade figures released this week, which provide another indication of a slowing economy.

headline: Clinton Advises, ‘Stay Tuned,’ Despite Campaign’s Recent Rough Weeks
text: DES MOINES  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday would not rule out running campaign advertisements that criticized her opponents by name, telling journalists to “stay tuned” to what her campaign had planned.

headline: Bird in the Brush
text: In 2004, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service decided that it did not need to list the sage grouse  whose habitat and diet are defined by sagebrush  as threatened or endangered. Ranchers, developers and the petroleum industry all breathed a sigh of relief. Now, Federal District Judge B. Lynn Winmill has ordered the Fish and Wildlife Service to review its conclusions about the sage grouse. We hope that the agency will remember that its responsibility is to reach an impartial decision based on the “best science”  something it forgot the first time around.

headline: Climate Treaty Deal Seems Close, but Is Elusive
text: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  The world’s countries, trying to wrap up two weeks of intense and at times emotional talks here on a two-year timetable for reviving an ailing, aging climate treaty, appeared close to a final agreement on Saturday but divisions remained.

headline: Huckabee Strikes at ‘Arrogant’ Bush Foreign Policy
text: TAMPA, Fla.  As Rudolph W. Giuliani tried to refocus his presidential campaign with a rare formal address here Saturday, Mike Huckabee gave the first detailed look at his foreign policy, sharply criticizing what he called the “Bush administration’s arrogant bunker mentality.”

headline: A Long Time Coming
text: It took 31 years, but the moral bankruptcy, social imbalance, legal impracticality and ultimate futility of the death penalty has finally penetrated the consciences of lawmakers in one of the 37 states that arrogates to itself the right to execute human beings.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the abuse of women in Brazil’s prison system described incorrectly the origin of a study about the subject. It was a report to the Organization of American States by a group of private organizations in São Paulo that formed the Study and Working Group on Women in Prison that led to increasing public and government attention to the problem. It was not a study commissioned by the government.

headline: Hirotaka Ono, Auto Executive, Is Dead at 52
text: Hirotaka Ono, a senior operating officer at the Suzuki Motor Corporation who was considered a possible successor to his father-in-law, Osamu Suzuki, as chairman, died Wednesday. He was 52.

headline: In a Mess, Yes, but She’s Got a Plan

headline: Up With the New
text: Facing mostly repeat competition, new episodes of CBS’s regular lineup dominated Thursday night, leading every hour of prime time. CBS’s “CSI” at 9 p.m. delivered the night’s largest audience (19.8 million), Nielsen estimated. No other network show got even half that many. Leading the 8 p.m. hour, CBS’s “Survivor: China” attracted 14.5 million viewers. At 10, CBS’s “Without a Trace” (15.1 million) was well ahead of ABC’s “Private Practice” rerun (4.8 million) and the last hour of NBC’s “Saturday Night Live” Christmas special encore, which averaged 5.7 million viewers from 9:30 to 11. Fox ranked No. 2 in total viewers thanks to “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” at 8 (9 million), followed by “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” at 9 (7.5 million). NBC edged past Fox for second place among adults 18 to 49. ABC was fourth over all.

headline: On Trial, L.I. Man Recalls ‘Lynch Mob’
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The black man accused of shooting a white teenager last year in a racially charged manslaughter case on Long Island took the stand here on Friday in Suffolk County Criminal Court.

headline: The Court That May Not Be Heard
text: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, the special court that reviews government requests for warrants to spy on suspected foreign agents in the United States, seems to have forgotten that its job is to ensure that the government is accountable for following the law  not to help the Bush administration keep its secrets.

headline: Corrections

headline: Trump v. Scotland, Rd. IV

A week after Scottish lawmakers took the unusual step of agreeing to review the plan, the Aberdeenshire council voted to support Trump’s project, which has already been rejected by the council’s oversight committee.

text: I had a feeling Brian Burke had a trick up his sleeve. By standing pat on D, he was adding Schneider to the deep blueline corps — Scott Niedermayer, Chris Pronger, Beauchemin, O’Donnell — that won the Cup.

headline: Body Wash
text: What dirty deed has besmirched the squeaky-clean word soap? Long bathed in smiles after being showered with praise, the word that was coined a millennium ago as the Old English sape and was long associated with a state next to godliness now seems barred from the language.
