headline: Questions Linger About Why N.F.L. Destroyed Patriots’ Tapes
text: The N.F.L. reacted swiftly to the spying scandal in September. Commissioner Roger Goodell promised on national television that there would be a full investigation of the New England Patriots’ covert filming of Jets defensive signals. He ordered the Patriots to send any videotapes filmed in violation of N.F.L. rules to the league office.

headline: Valdosta State Wins Title
text: Michael Terry scored a touchdown with 22 seconds left and Valdosta State beat Northwest Missouri State, 25-20, for the N.C.A.A. Division II championship in Florence, Ala. Terry’s 1-yard touchdown run capped an eight-play, 37-yard drive fueled by Willie Copeland’s four straight completions for 27 yards. Valdosta (13-1) overcame a 14-3 halftime deficit in dropping Northwest Missouri to 12-2.

headline: Cartoons, ‘Cholera’ and Subversive Remix
text: David Shrigley’s Worried Noodles

headline: Looking Past the Pictures
text: THE top-floor rental where Vince Collura and Gina Asaro-Collura lived for four years in Peter Cooper Village in Lower Manhattan felt so palatial they called it the penthouse. “It was the hugest one-bedroom ever,” and had an East River view, Mrs. Asaro-Collura said.

headline: Burned Bungalows, and an Iffy Market
text: RESIDENTS of the bungalow district of Brighton Beach, a 10-block stretch of wooden single-family houses in Brooklyn that stand cheek-by-jowl along narrow lanes, are accustomed to feeling embattled. Since the late 1990s, developers have been snapping up these bungalows, which are half a mile from the ocean, and replacing them with beige concrete apartment buildings.

headline: Life of Roses? No, but She’s Doing Fine
text: MARY J. BLIGE was in black and bling when she stepped into Legacy Recording Studios on the West Side of Manhattan to videotape a Yahoo Webcast. Her black knee-high Yves Saint Laurent boots had five-inch heels, leading up to black pants, a ribbed black Michael Kors top and a black cap; her Hermès belt had gleaming metal studs and her hoop earrings glittered with diamonds. After the band’s equipment was set up, she started to run through “Just Fine,” the first single from her new album, “Growing Pains” (Geffen). Ms. Blige looked into the camera as she delivered its spoken intro and about 20 seconds of a verse, then waved the band to a stop. “I’m ready,” she said. “Rehearsal over. No more rehearsing. Now we’re ready to do it for real.”

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Comedy

headline: The Newest Mandarins
text: Lei Bo is a philosophy graduate student in China whose faith is in history, and by habit he considers the world using the thousands of classical passages that live in his head. Three years ago he was studying in an empty room in the School of Management at his university in Beijing when students began to amble in for their class on Sun Tzu’s “Art of War,” a work from either the fifth or the fourth century B.C. Lei Bo decided to stay. He had taken two courses on “The Art of War” in the philosophy and the literature departments, and was curious to see how students in business and management might approach the same subject. The discussion that day was on the five attributes of a military commander. Sun Tzu said in the first chapter of the book, “An able commander is wise (zhi), trustworthy (xin), humane (ren), courageous (yong) and believes in strict discipline (yan).”

headline: When Lily Left Us: Tough to the End
text: ONE of the running gags passed from one smirking generation to another around my big extended family was that our seemingly mild-mannered mother was one tough cookie to have outlasted our less-than-mild, often unmannered father. After his death at 93 she called herself, without a hint of irony, the Last Man Standing.

headline: Frustration With Charities and U.N. in Congo
text: GOMA, Congo  Frustration at the United Nations peacekeeping force and the dozens of aid organizations working in North Kivu Province, in eastern Congo, is rising as violence increases, the number of displaced people here creeps toward one million, and the pace of assistance lags, especially to those fleeing the fighting in the past few weeks.

headline: A Semi-Nude Minor? In The Times?
text: IN an otherwise depressed newspaper world, where revenues are stagnant and layoffs and buyouts are frequent, T, the fashion magazine of The New York Times, is a spectacular success. T, published 15 times a year, is a glossy, unabashed tribute to the good life, as defined in its pages by Hästens mattress and box spring sets starting at $4,475, Swiss “coffee centers” topping $3,600, and a Roger Vivier satin clutch with silver sequins going for $15,000.

headline: Remember the Milkman? In Some Places, He’s Back
text: STEPHANIE MONAHAN fondly recalls having milk delivered to her front door by the local milkman when she was a young girl growing up on the outskirts of Boston. So, a few months ago, when she saw an old-fashioned milk truck chugging up the hill of her new neighborhood in Milton, Mass., she chased after it to find out if it made home deliveries.

headline: Jennifer Kunin, Sidney Reitzfeld
text: Jennifer L. Kunin and Sidney P. Reitzfeld are to be married Sunday at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Lisa J. Grushcow is to officiate.

headline: Philharmonic Gets Its Music Man
text: GENERALLY, the path for a conductor goes like this: start with a small local orchestra, maybe take an assistant conductor’s job at a bigger one, make a mark at a summer festival, hope to break into the top rank at a Philadelphia Orchestra or Berlin Philharmonic.

headline: Not if Exports Save Us
text: LOOKING only at standard macroeconomic statistics, you would think the economy was in very good shape. Gross domestic product has grown at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the last six months, well above the historical average. The price index for personal consumption expenditures, excluding the volatile food and energy components, rose at a 1.6 percent annual rate over the same period, well below the historical average.

headline: It Was a Very Organic Year
text: LOOKING back at the restaurants I reviewed this past year in the eastern part of Connecticut (including New Haven and Hartford Counties), I remember many that I would enjoy eating at again. Too many to revisit here. So I have limited my choices to those that are representative of a culinary trend, offer especially good value for the money or have a very distinctive style.

headline: First the Wedding, Then the Real Show and Razzle-Dazzle Begins
text: THE beachside fireworks display had begun to wind down at Lulu de Kwiatkowski’s and Alfredo Gilardini’s wedding reception on Nov. 10 in the Bahamas when suddenly whistles began to blow and drums began beating. As their 160 guests looked on, a junkanoo, a traditional Bahamian Mardi Gras-style band with 30 men and women in colorful traditional costume, wound its way from the beach toward those assembled at the Lyford Cay Club.

headline: Letters to the Editor: Where Did Service Go?
text: To the Editor: Thank you for Aboard Planes, Class Conflict; (Nov. 25) on the woes of travelers in economy class. We don’t expect elaborate meals or lay-down seats, and I don’t think most expect gracious service. But travelers do have a right to expect attentive treatment, space that permits medically sound space and movement, adequate and clean bathrooms and like “amenities.” Many wags have noted that the absence of food service represents an improvement, so that’s not the issue.

headline: Special District Elections Raise Concerns
text: VOTERS went to the polls Tuesday to cast ballots in 154 special taxing districts on Long Island that approve budgets that total hundreds of millions of dollars for services like firefighting, water, sanitation and parks.

headline: Climate Plan Looks Beyond Bush’s Tenure
text: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  The world’s faltering effort to cut greenhouse gas emissions got a new lease on life on Saturday, as delegates from 187 countries agreed to negotiate a new accord over the next two years  pushing the crucial debates about United States participation into the administration of a new American president.

headline: Rebecca Strauss, Benjamin Handler
text: Rebecca Ilse Strauss, the daughter of Nancy B. Strauss and Albrecht B. Strauss of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Joseph Handler, the son of Leslie Handler and Dr. Martin Handler of Kings Point, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Strassfeld officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in New York.

headline: A Local Son (and Chef) Livens His Hometown
text: YOU know the story: local boy leaves town, makes good and, in this case, brings back to his undernourished neighborhood the culinary riches of the wider world. That’s the story of Peter Xavier Kelly, who, after six years of planning and an investment of several million dollars, has brought his latest triumph, the impressive X2O Xaviars on the Hudson, home to Yonkers.

headline: Those Summer Nights
text: It’s the summer of 1981, a mere week before Diana Spencer and Prince Charles are to be married. Lara, just turned 17, is embarking on a trip from London to Tuscany with her scholarly, travel-phobic father, Lambert, whom she has seen only sporadically since her early childhood. They are off to stay with one of Lambert’s oldest friends. The expectation is obvious: this girl will come to know her elusive father; she will break out from her troubled, tentative girlhood and become a confident woman. Will she find a fairy-tale love as well? While Esther Freud’s sixth novel, “Love Falls,” follows this all-too-familiar arc, her depiction of Lara is so charming and observant, her writing so dynamic, that all the clichés of a youthful summer of self-discovery are transcended.

headline: Plenty of Blame for Afghanistan
text: It was not a pretty sight: Defense Secretary Robert Gates, last week, accusing NATO allies of not doing nearly enough in Afghanistan. But beyond the finger-pointing, there is a much more serious issue. Unless the United States and Europe come up with a better strategy  and invest more money, attention and troops  the “good war” will go irretrievably bad.

headline: Laura Gilman, Donald Springer
text: Laura Dwyer Gilman and Donald Scott Springer were married Saturday evening at the Surrey Hotel in Manhattan. Harold Silverman, a retired State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, officiated.

headline: Snowstorms Delay Air Travel
text: Snow overnight gave way to rain on Sunday in the New York City area, even as much of the Northeast was hit by snowstorms that delayed air travel and caused traffic accidents.

text: With all the infinity pools and wet bars around, it was only a matter of time before an infinity bar was conceived and installed. And now it has  at the Grace Bay Club in the Turks and Caicos.

text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Ask the Hofstra senior Antoine Agudio why he works so hard, and he says it is because he is lazy.

headline: Correction: A New Kind of Diva
text: An article on Dec. 2 about the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko misidentified an opera in which she is scheduled to perform in 2012. It is “Manon,” by Massenet, not “Manon Lescaut,” by Puccini.

headline: Don’t Go Near Those Shark Clichés
text: Over the last three seasons, the San Jose Sharks have appeared in seven playoff rounds  more than any other team. But the 17-year-old team with the snazzy teal jerseys has never appeared in the fourth and final round, the one in which the Stanley Cup is won or lost.

headline: Bookshelf
text: THE NUTCRACKER DOLL. Written and illustrated by Mary Newell DePalma. Arthur A. Levine/Scholastic. $16.99. (Ages 4 to 8)

headline: A Feast for the Eyes
text: The mystique surrounding today’s Lower East Side art stars doesn’t include how well they eat. Nor does it promote the image of a cozy holiday dinner. But on a late-fall afternoon, downtown notables gathered for the First Postapocalyptic Christmas Dinner at the Chinatown loft of Agathe Snow. As prepared by Snow and her kitchen collaborators, the artists Marianne Vitale and Anne Apparu  together known as the catering-as-performance company Chop Shop  the rambling feast was somewhere between Judy Chicago and Judy Rodgers.

headline: Today, Would Tartuffe Have His Own Show?
text: The period that tends to be forgotten when we look at period drama is our own. We’re well aware, for example, that “Julius Caesar” is about Elizabethan England as well as ancient Rome. And if the director happens to set the play in Fascist Italy, that adds yet another historical layer to the proceedings.

headline: A Rebate From Harvard?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Connecticut’s Poor
text: Connecticut is a wonderful place to live  for those fortunate enough to make a living wage. Ask Debbie Kievits, 46, of Norwich. She is well-known for her selfless community activism, but a year ago, rheumatoid arthritis made it impossible for her to hold a job. She spent her savings supporting her family. Now she and her two teenage children make ends meet with the help of friends and fund-raisers while Ms. Kievits waits to qualify for Social Security disability payments.

headline: No Child Left Behind? Say It in Spanish
text: AS school enrollment for Hispanic children declines in New York City and in other urban areas around the metropolitan region, school districts in dozens of outlying suburbs are adding seats and bilingual programs to address a sharp increase in the number of Hispanic students whose parents are immigrants.

But she helps her father, a varlet, tend the lord’s dogs, and fleas are one of the occupational hazards. So she prays for relief:

headline: Obama Showing New Confidence With Iowa Sprint
text: WATERLOO, Iowa  Senator Barack Obama is seeking to capitalize on a moment of opportunity in the weeks before the Iowa caucuses to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s long dominance of the Democratic field, and in doing so, he now faces intensified questions about his vulnerabilities in a general election.

headline: Our Decrepit Food Factories
text: The word “sustainability” has gotten such a workout lately that the whole concept is in danger of floating away on a sea of inoffensiveness. Everybody, it seems, is for it whatever “it” means. On a recent visit to a land-grant university’s spanking-new sustainability institute, I asked my host how many of the school’s faculty members were involved. She beamed: When letters went out asking who on campus was doing research that might fit under that rubric, virtually everyone replied in the affirmative. What a nice surprise, she suggested. But really, what soul working in agricultural science today (or for that matter in any other field of endeavor) would stand up and be counted as against sustainability? When pesticide makers and genetic engineers cloak themselves in the term, you have to wonder if we haven’t succeeded in defining sustainability down, to paraphrase the late Senator Moynihan, and if it will soon possess all the conceptual force of a word like “natural” or “green” or “nice.”

headline: Independent Streak
text: After enjoying one of the most celebrated careers in Hollywood, you’ve decided to go the art-house route and make “Youth Without Youth,” a Romanian fable about an age-defying linguist and his lover who is reincarnated as a seventh-century Indian. Is the film intended for a mass audience? No, not at all.

headline: Nobody Knows the Tribbles He’s Seen
text: BY any reasonable definition David Gerrold is a major figure in science fiction. He has published some 50 books and won many of his genre’s highest awards, including the Hugo and the Nebula. John Cusack and Amanda Peet starred in “Martian Child,” which was inspired by his novella “The Martian Child” and opened last month.

headline: Jennifer Leach, Jeffrey English
text: Jennifer Leach, the daughter of Jacqueline Leach and Wilson S. Leach of New Canaan, Conn., was married there Saturday to Jeffrey R. English, the son of Roberta English of Summit, N.J., and Bruce English of Brooklyn. The Rev. Harold E. Masback III performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of New Canaan.

headline: The Ghosts of Clinton Street
text: NORA GERAGHTY and Dan Kahn moved into the four-story brick house on Clinton Street in the summer of 2001, a week after graduating from college. By day, their life resembled that of any young couple in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn: coffee from a patisserie on Court Street and commutes on the F train to entry-level jobs in Manhattan.

headline: In Co-ops, ‘Equality’ Can Be a Bit Elastic
text: NEW YORK’S Business Corporation Law requires that shareholders who own the same class of stock be treated the same, and in a co-op, this usually means that monthly maintenance and special assessments must be calculated on a per-share basis.

headline: In the Courtyard of Miracles and Wonders
text: ON a cold Saturday night last fall, two of my closest friends and I ate dinner and watched a movie in an old town house on West 11th Street. While I was there, I had an experience I had been wanting for more than 25 years.

headline: She Reigns as Bloomberg, but Briefly
text: The week began as usual, with a flurry of announcements from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. There was the ribbon-cutting, the notice urging parents to register their children for prekindergarten, the statement in support of a transit fare increase.

headline: Wilson Ahead by a Shot
text: Oliver Wilson of England shot a five-under-par 67 and led by one stroke after three rounds of the South African Open. Wilson was at four-under 212 heading into the final round, with the halfway leader, James Kingston, in second place. Garth Mulroy was two shots back after a 64, the day’s best round. Greg Norman shot a 72 and was at 217. The defending champion, Ernie Els, was at 224.

headline: Blast Kills Five at Headquarters of Kabul Police
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A vehicle packed with rockets exploded across the street from the Kabul police headquarters on Saturday, killing five civilians and wounding at least 24 others, Afghan officials said. Three policemen were among the wounded.

headline: Refining the Turf and Adding Surf
text: THIS has been a year of change for Tellers, which opened in Islip in 1999. A new executive chef, Alan Kwan, came on board in March; he had worked at a number of well-regarded West Coast places, including Restaurant Gary Danko in San Francisco.

headline: Bond Failures Laid to Tax-Weary Voters
text: TAX-FATIGUED voters said no last week to $189 million in school construction proposals on bond issues throughout the state. While 8 of 14 school districts approved bonds, less than half the $347 million sought by school boards and administrators was approved by voters.

headline: Russia’s Knockoff Democracy
text: MOSCOW

headline: Quotas Draw Fire Over Black Sea Bass, Scup and Fluke
text: LOOMING congressional mandates have federal regulators proposing cutbacks to the 2008 catch of three popular fish species, including summer flounder, prompting complaints from fishermen that the quotas hurt more than they help.

headline: Playing for Time
text: Playing for Time

headline: Still Choosing the Mailbox Over the In-Box
text: This Monday is set to be the busiest day of the year for mail, so take pity on your harried and hunched-over postal carrier. On this day, 275 million first-class cards and letters are expected to be mailed, according to the United States Postal Service. Over the entire holiday season, from Thanksgiving to Christmas, about 20 billion cards, letters, packages and other pieces of mail (especially catalogs) will be mailed, the Postal Service projects.

headline: Colleen Weis and Martin Laiks
text: Colleen Ross Weis and Martin Scott Laiks are to be married on Sunday at the Pierre Hotel in New York. Rabbi David L. Silverman officiated, and Rabbi Arthur Schneier took part in the ceremony.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: The Governor’s Nose Dive
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s polls are looking like a downhill skier’s delight and a politician’s nightmare. Each new survey puts his popularity at a lower point than the one before, with his foes rejoicing as the man once thought most likely to reform Albany skids publicly into failure.

headline: Unfold and Ride
text: BOOMING auto sales threaten to jam the streets of Asian cities, which are already packed with bicycles and scooters. To help solve the problem, a group at M.I.T. was asked to find a solution. It designed a folding electric scooter that can be placed throughout cities for rental, much like the bicycle rental system in some European cities.

headline: Amanda Perwin, Seth Cassel
text: Amanda Julia Perwin, the daughter of Jean Perwin and Joel S. Perwin of Miami Beach, was married Saturday evening to Seth Ian Cassel, a son of Mindy Cassel and James Cassel of Miami. Rabbi Gary Glickstein officiated at the Ritz-Carlton, South Beach.

headline: Let the ‘Starchitects’ Work All the Angles
text: IT’S hard to pinpoint when the “starchitect” became an object of ridicule. The term is a favorite of churlish commentators, who use it to mock architects whose increasingly flamboyant buildings, in their minds, are more about fashion and money than function.

headline: CARDINALS AT SAINTS
text: CARDINALS AT SAINTS

headline: Penske Can Swap Owner Points
text: Nascar has approved Penske Racing’s request to transfer owner points to Sam Hornish Jr. from Kurt Busch, a move that locks Hornish, a three-time IndyCar Series champion, into the first five Nascar races of next season. Hornish, a former Indianapolis 500 winner, is leaving the IndyCar Series for Nascar next season.

headline: Ask First, Tear Down Later
text: IF you are interested in buying a house that is ripe for a teardown, here are five factors to consider:

headline: Stephanie Lehman, Eric Schutzer
text: Stephanie Fran Lehman and Eric Phillip Schutzer were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Michael Stanger at the St. Regis in New York.

headline: The Facts Say No
text: EVER since the pioneering work “Measuring Business Cycles” by Wesley Mitchell and Arthur Burns was published in 1946, the question of whether the United States economy is in a recession has been answered with opinions.

headline: Buccaneers Follow Garcia’s Lead to the Top
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Jeff Garcia again finds himself wrapped in adversity, something he considers as comfortable as a pass pocket lined with goose feathers.

headline: Brooklyn Woman, 35, Is Fatally Shot
text: A 35-year-old Brooklyn woman who was shot and killed during a gunfight between two men on Saturday evening might have been a bystander, the police said.

headline: Often a Swan, Rarely a Queen
text: SHE (more rarely, he) is the most talented student in the local dance school. Her legs are long, her feet arched; her neck looks suitable for a potential swan. Her teacher encourages her parents to have her audition for the School of American Ballet, or the Royal Ballet School, or the Paris Opera Ballet School. There are hundreds of children at the audition, but she gets in.

headline: Letters to the Editor: Greater Strife in Oaxaca
text: To the Editor: Regarding 36 Hours in Oaxaca, Mexico; (Nov. 25): Beth Greenfield writes, “Although it’s known as a hotbed for social justice rallies (including a large-scale teachers’ strike in 2006), the city’s infectious zeal goes far beyond the political.” This characterization underrepresents the political reality of Oaxaca, and tourists should know this when they decide to travel.

headline: Waltrip Hires New Crew Chiefs
text: Michael Waltrip Racing has hired three new crew chiefs, including Ryan Pemberton, who left Dale Earnhardt Inc. earlier this week. Pemberton will be the crew chief for David Reutimann. Waltrip had a rough first season as a team owner, with his three cars struggling to make races.

headline: Letters: Death in the Family
text: In his opening paragraph, Daniel Bergner (Dec. 2) describes Booth Gardner walking along the beach, his grandchildren exploring the water’s edge. Gardner says, “I can’t see where anybody benefits by my hanging around.”

headline: Pettitte Admits He Used H.G.H. ‘for Two Days’
text: Two days after being implicated in the use of human growth hormone in George J. Mitchell’s report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, Yankees pitcher Andy Pettitte acknowledged Saturday that he had tried the substance.

headline: Noted
text: To the Editor:

headline: Southern California Art? Look It Up
text: IN Los Angeles, Lyn Kienholz is known within the art world as a hostess extraordinaire. Since 1974, the year after her divorce from the Pop sculptor Ed Kienholz, she has entertained and connected countless California painters, sculptors, writers, politicians, and museum curators at her home in the Hollywood Hills.

headline: H (as in Humming) Street
text: IT’S been almost 40 years since riots ripped through Washington in the wake of Martin Luther King Jr.’s assassination, and few areas were hit harder than the H Street Northeast corridor. Running from just north of Union Station toward the Anacostia River, H Street never fully recovered, even as other riot-scarred neighborhoods began picking up in the 1990s.

headline: Glory of Cars, Even Parking
text: A book can make an appreciated and lasting gift. Here are some possiblities, all related to automobiles in some way but most of them of interest to the general reader, not just to car buffs. CHARLES McEWEN

headline: Russia Helps Its Muslims Take the Journey to Mecca
text: MOSCOW  Gulsine K. Fatakhudinova, a 56-year-old Tatar Muslim, came lugging suitcases to pray at the lime-green mosque in central Moscow  one of dozens of people who arrived one recent day bundled in the weighty coats, fur hats and other winter garb they would soon cast off, at least temporarily.

headline: The Stranded Elf of Second Avenue
text: IT has long been an immutable fact of New York life that the holiday season begins with the arrival of the Christmas trees  and the French Canadians who sell them. Each neighborhood has its own familiar team, which appears year after year on Dec. 1, when New Yorkers discover heretofore hidden reserves of small-town bonhomie and offer showers, food and other niceties.

headline: Lisa Goldstein, Jeffrey Manheim
text: Lisa Ellen Goldstein, a daughter of Fredda and Edward Goldstein of New York, is to be married Sunday to Jeffrey Ira Manheim, a son of Barbara and Michael Manheim of Lake Worth, Fla. Rabbi Israel C. Stein is to officiate at the Westin Diplomat in Hollywood, Fla.

headline: It’s Too Late for Later
text: Bali, Indonesia

headline: 36 Hours in New Orleans
text: WHAT other city, after being half-drowned and left to starve, foiled by bureaucracy and attacked by the auto-immune disease of rampant crime, could stagger to its feet to welcome visitors with a platter of oysters on the half shell and a rousing brass band? What place, barely two years after Hurricane Katrina, could provide streetcar rides and impromptu parades, riverboat calliopes and sidewalk tap dancers? When chroniclers look back, the city's ability to be itself — a place that embraces sorrow and joy with equal gusto — in this hardest of times will become part of its legend.

headline: One Billionaire’s Home, Countless Stares
text: GREENWICH

headline: Gone Wild and Gone All Wrong
text: Reno, Nev.

headline: Near Perfection for Penn State
text: Penn State played near-perfect volleyball in its N.C.A.A. run, winning its second national title while dropping only two games in six tournament matches. The scrappy Nittany Lions even found a way to stun top-seeded Stanford Saturday night in Sacramento, getting 26 kills from Megan Hodge and 19 from Nicole Fawcett against the same university they beat for their first title in 1999.Fawcett served on match point and Penn State capped its 26th straight victory on another powerful kill by Hodge, the tournament’s most valuable player, winning by 30-25, 30-26, 23-30, 19-30, 15-8 exactly three months to the day after losing a five-game thriller to the Cardinal  the last defeat for the Nittany Lions.

headline: So How Do We Get to Berkeley? Spend Big on SUNY, Panel Says
text: AMHERST, N.Y.  John B. Simpson, the president of the State University at Buffalo, incessantly buttonholes people to assert that the way to remake western New York is to remake his university, one of the state university system’s four research centers.

headline: Planetary Politics
text: Have the worlds of science fiction and presidential politics ever been more closely aligned than they were in 2007? This was the year when Rudolph Giuliani told a young questioner on the campaign trail that “we’ll be prepared” if the United States is attacked by aliens from another planet; when Dennis Kucinich blithely confessed during a Democratic debate that he’d seen a U.F.O.; and when Mitt Romney revealed in an interview that L. Ron Hubbard’s “Battlefield Earth” was one of his favorite novels.

text: DARDENNE PRAIRIE, Mo.

text: Though he was at first shocked by the suggested elimination of “The Ballad of Sweeney Todd,” Stephen Sondheim said that when he put on his “movie-buff hat,” he “completely agreed.”

text: The deluge of bright red handbags, purses and knapsacks seen around the city has more to do with fall fashions than with the Christmas season. The nail-polish-red theme is intensified when matching gloves, coats and scarves are worn.

headline: Court Inquiry on Tape Case Is Opposed
text: The Justice Department has urged a federal judge not to hold a hearing on the Central Intelligence Agency’s destruction of videotaped interrogations of two suspected Al Qaeda operatives, saying a judicial inquiry “is both unnecessary and potentially disruptive.”

text: USED to be, you’d be hung from the yardarm for mutiny at sea. Now, it seems, some rebellions may get you a refund.

headline: Business and Friends
text: While negotiating the sale of his share of a small shawarma restaurant to a friend of his, my husband learned that a famous shawarma chain is opening a branch near the restaurant. He fears that if he tells the friend, he will back out of the deal. It feels wrong to withhold this information. Must he tell?  Wendy Schor-Haim, Tel Aviv

headline: Cheating Matters (Sometimes)
text: AH, yes, the outrage of the baseball fan. The list of former and current players alleged to have used steroids and other illegal, performance-enhancing substances made public this week by George Mitchell has catalyzed it: Cheaters! Cheaters! How dare they undermine the great national pastime with their greed; their self-aggrandizement; their lack of respect for the game and its history, for the fans and their reverence of the record book, for fair play.

headline: Tango in the Clutches of Buenos Aires
text: CAROLINA SOLER describes tango as a mirror of “the seduction, sadness, passion, strength and weakness of Buenos Aires.” Youthful exuberance also counts for a lot, as her company, Estampas Porteñas, made clear in the fall of 2006, when it made its New York debut at Town Hall.

text: Tarrytown

headline: As China Goes, So Goes Global Warming
text: GIVEN the accelerated melting these days in Greenland, it’s probably no longer appropriate to use the adjective “glacial” to describe treaty negotiations aimed at curbing dangerous human interference with the climate.

headline: At the Paper Mill, a Mr. Fix-It With a Plan
text: MILLBURN

headline: You Can Almost Hear It Pop
text: THE American economy is slipping into its second post-bubble recession in seven years. Just as the bursting of the dot-com bubble led to a downturn in 2001 and ’02, the simultaneous popping of the housing and credit bubbles is doing the same right now.

headline: In Seattle, a Fugue for Orchestra and Rancor
text: SEATTLE

headline: Sale Talk Swirls Around Dolphins
text: Miami Dolphins owner Wayne Huizenga said he is “not actively looking to sell” the team despite frustration over a winless season, but he has confirmed talking with potential buyers since April. Huizenga issued a statement Saturday in response to reports he is discussing the sale of his franchise and Dolphin Stadium to two real estate developers.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: THE VOYAGE THAT NEVER ENDS: Fictions, Poems, Fragments, Letters, by Malcolm Lowry. Edited by Michael Hofmann. (New York Review, $27.95.) A cache of false starts and oddments, but it provides a remarkably full portrait of Lowry the man.

headline: Paperback Row
text: WHAT TERRORISTS WANT: Understanding the Enemy, Containing the Threat, by Louise Richardson. (Random House, $15.95.) Richardson, a Harvard scholar, views Al Qaeda in the context of other terrorist organizations and finds that it is neither unique in its organization nor unprecedented in its reach. Terrorist movements require alienated individuals, a complicit community and a legitimizing ideology, Richardson argues; their troops are motivated by a desire for revenge, renown and reaction from the enemy. The Bush administration has given Al Qaeda the great renown and huge reaction it desires. A successful campaign against terrorism, like those in Peru, Turkey and Britain, she says, requires an effort led by police intelligence units and other arms of the states to isolate the terrorists by empowering nonviolent moderates. Our reviewer, Martin Walker, called the book an “overdue and essential primer on terrorism and how to tackle it.”

headline: Reefer Madness in Iowa
text: With the Iowa campaign in wild flux  and in the case of Hillary, acid reflux  The Des Moines Register decides to hold a tie-breaking debate with the two Democratic front-runners.

headline: They’re Not Asking, ‘Christina Who?’
text: Los Angeles

headline: Corrections: Area Code, Sweet Area Code
text: An article on Feb. 19, 2006, about people who relocate to Washington, D.C., and keep their hometown cellphone area codes for a sense of regional identity, misspelled the given name of a California woman with a 714 area code who works for a San Francisco congressman. She is Puja Patel, not Punja. (Ms. Patel pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Dec. 7.)

headline: An Understudy Helped Make the Dolphins 17-0
text: MIAMI  A harried television producer perused her notes last Thursday morning and glanced up at Earl Morrall, who was in town for a long-planned reunion with other members of the undefeated 1972 Dolphins.

headline: Retailers Face an Ominous Holiday Sign
text: Sales of women’s clothing, a traditional pillar of the holiday shopping season, are unusually weak so far this year, according to a major credit card company, an ominous sign for the retail industry.

headline: Staying Home
text: It’s New Year’s Eve a few years back: candles are lighted in Emily’s “cozy one-bedroom” apartment, iTunes shifts seamlessly from the Magnetic Fields to Maria Callas to Nina Simone, and although we love to look out her second-story windows at the packs of people clamoring between bars and parties, and although we half-made plans to go to bars and parties ourselves, there’s no way we’re going out. The abortion is scheduled for two days from now, and we’re holing up.

headline: Most Work to Resume at Goldman Site
text: Most construction work can resume at the new headquarters of Goldman Sachs near ground zero, an official in the Department of Buildings said Saturday, a day after an architect was critically injured in an accident there.

headline: Back From the Edge, and Living His Life Note by Note
text: “Becoming a composer totally surprised me,” said Gerald Busby. He sat on his sofa, which doubles as his bed, in his studio apartment at the Chelsea Hotel, with his upright piano and artwork that friends and colleagues have given him over the years. His sheet music was in stacks along the walls.

headline: Never Mind What’s in Them, Bags Are the Fashion
text: A team of designers at Saks Fifth Avenue envisioned “a piece of modern art” and hired a renowned graphic artist to create it. Their counterparts at Lord & Taylor demanded five prototypes, even traveling to a Korean factory to oversee manufacturing.

headline: Here Comes the Bride
text: Joe McGinniss’s new book, about the November 2003 murder of a Hong Kong-based investment banker named Robert Kissel, expands his true-crime oeuvre from bloody trilogy to bloody quartet. “Never Enough” begins with a cluster of hard-boiled clichés that create a cartoonish first impression. Kissel’s father “played to win” but “knew how to catch flies with honey.” Kissel’s own “killer instinct slumbered” during high school in New Jersey; he would gaze across the Hudson at the Manhattan skyline like a “kid with his face pressed against the glass of the candy store window.” Meanwhile “it was her way or the highway” for Nancy Keeshin, the selfish woman Kissel would marry. New York City is “the land of hopes and dreams, the fast track, the big league.”

headline: Wait Till Next Year
text: ALTHOUGH many people consider a two-quarter downturn of gross domestic product to be a recession, the designation of recessions is done by the business-cycle dating committee of my organization, the National Bureau of Economic Research.

headline: Where the Flophouse Once Ruled, a Call to Go Slow
text: DAVID MULKINS, a history teacher at the High School of Art and Design, became a community activist because he couldn’t sleep at night. Mr. Mulkins was so annoyed by the racket outside his apartment on East Fifth Street near the Bowery that he started attending meetings in hope of curbing the incessant noise from the bars that increasingly define his neighborhood.

headline: Nation’s ‘First Suburb’ Aims to Be Most ‘Green’
text: IT was last spring, during a dinner conversation with a friend about global warming, Thomas R. Suozzi said, that he got the idea to develop the nation’s first “green” suburb in Nassau County.

headline: A Zoo Explorer Starring in His Own Series
text: BRIDGEPORT

headline: Carroll College Takes N.A.I.A. Title
text: Gabe Le ran for 116 yards and 2 touchdowns to help Carroll College of Montana beat the defending champion Sioux Falls, 17-9, in Savannah, Tenn., for Carroll’s fifth N.A.I.A. title in the last six years.

headline: With Woods in Front, Opponents Face Long Odds in Final Round
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  Some things in sports are almost impossible to overcome: there is Tom Brady with a 14-point lead in the fourth quarter or Roger Federer with match point in a tie breaker or even Jimmie Johnson in the Nextel Cup.

headline: Inside the List
text: McGINNISS’S CAMPAIGN: Joe McGinniss, whose new true-crime book, “Never Enough,” is reviewed in this issue by Bob Shacochis, made his first appearance on the Times best-seller list in 1969, when he was 26. The book was “The Selling of the President 1968,” a new kind of campaign reportage  McGinniss spent more time with the TV production men around Richard Nixon than with the candidate himself. “The Selling of the President 1968” hit No. 1 and spent 31 weeks on the list; overnight, it made Theodore White’s “Making of the President” campaign books seem wan and dated. In the Book Review, Marvin Kitman wrote about McGinniss: “His book is a 60-second commercial compared to Theodore White’s 90-minute special on the same subject, yet far more entertaining.” “The Selling of the President 1968” was the first of many of McGinniss’s books to appear on the Times best-seller list  including “Fatal Vision” (1983), “Blind Faith” (1989) and “The Last Brother” (1993), a biography of Ted Kennedy. His two most recent books, however, did not appear here.

headline: British Hand Over Basra to Iraqis
text: BAGHDAD  British forces handed over control of Basra Province to Iraq’s government on Sunday, giving up military control of the final region under their supervision after four and a half years.

headline: Are We in a Recession?
text: Six experts assess the current state and forecast the future direction of the American economy.

headline: Crime Is Low, but Fear Knows No Numbers
text: JOSÉ SANTIAGO, 39, has been around Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, ever since he was a child and started spending summers in the neighborhood with his father, a building superintendent who worked there. Mr. Santiago is a building superintendent himself now, living and working just down the street from where his father lived and worked.

headline: The Views From the Back of the Plane
text: The cover article in the Nov. 25 issue of the Travel section, “Class Conflict,” by Michelle Higgins, the Practical Traveler columnist, prompted an unusually large response from readers, including 298 comments posted on our Web site. Here is a sampling.  The Editors.

headline: Rodriguez Keeps Quiet on Michigan Job
text: West Virginia Coach Rich Rodriguez refused to discuss Michigan’s vacant coaching job at a news conference. Rodriguez said at the opening of a previously scheduled news conference on No. 11 West Virginia’s trip to the Fiesta Bowl that he would only talk about preparations to face No. 3 Oklahoma.Sporting News Radio reported Friday, citing unidentified sources, that Rodriguez and his agent were in Toledo, Ohio, meeting with Michigan Athletic Director Bill Martin and the university president, Mary Sue Coleman.

headline: Extreme Sports Vault Onto the Big Screen
text: THE new documentary “Steep” takes viewers where only the most extreme athlete has dared to go: alongside skiers as an avalanche, which looks more like a river, nearly carries them away; watching another skier narrowly slicing his way through backcountry trees as if he’d sneaked onto a Christmas tree farm; in a helicopter as it approaches a snow-glazed mountain when one of the skiers deposited on it zips down an almost vertical slope.

headline: In Campus Shadow, Ohio State Closes In on a National Title

headline: For Republicans, Falling in Love Is Hard to Do

But from Ronald Reagan to George W. Bush to Dwight Eisenhower, Republicans voters have displayed a zeal for their candidates that Democrats could only envy.

headline: Hey, Where’s Scrooge? Oh, It’s a Different Dickens
text: Don’t be fooled by the familiar dramatis personae: the regretful old man haunted by memories, the ghost of times past with the power to erase his bitter legacy, and the poor but loving family gathered in anticipation of a meager Christmas celebration. Charles Dickens may be the author of the uplifting little fable being presented by the Two River Theater Company as its family-friendly holiday show, but the work in question is not “A Christmas Carol.”

headline: Air Rights, Swapped for Schools
