headline: Russert to Romney: Are You A Flip-Flopper?
text: Mitt Romney endured withering questioning about his shifting positions and tone on a range of issues in his first appearance on “Meet the Press” this morning but perhaps the most memorable moment came when Mr. Romney grew unusually emotional while responding to a question about the Mormon Church’s decision to finally grant full rights to blacks in 1978.

headline: Edwards Sticks to the Positive
text: John Edwards appeared on Sunday political talk shows this morning and put forth a consistently positive demeanor, declining easy opportunities to hammer his Democratic opponents.

headline: Breaking News (O.K., Not Really): Pats Fans Loathe Mangini
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Braving the snow-rain mixture blown sideways by the wind, I made my way down the stands toward the Jets’ sideline to take an informal Eric Mangini public opinion poll. Not surprisingly, the folks in the front row were not big Mangini fans.

headline: Illness, Sloppiness Prompt Rangers Lineup Shuffle
text: Whether the flu bug or their mid-December playing funk is causing more woes among the Rangers, it was clear before Sunday’s game against Phoenix at Madison Square Garden that Rangers Coach Tom Renney was in no mood to sit around and wait for either to simply pass.

headline: Crossing Party Lines, Lieberman to Endorse McCain
text: Senator Joseph Lieberman, the Connecticut independent who was the Democratic nominee for vice president in 2000, plans to endorse Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, for president tomorrow, according to both Democrats and Republicans knowledgeable about the move.

headline: Clinton Endorsed by Bob Kerrey
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa –- One of Bill Clinton’s political headaches during his 1992 campaign and his first years as president was Bob Kerrey, the Democratic senator and Vietnam veteran from Nebraska, who also ran for the 1992 nomination and was a tough critic of some of Mr. Clinton’s personal and policy choices.

headline: Clinton Hits Iowa With New Energy
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa – A couple of quick observations from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s first “Every County Counts” tour of Iowa, which will have her and her surrogates campaigning in all 99 counties of Iowa over the next five days.

headline: Candidates Feeling the Pressure, and Showing It
text: You can tell when time is getting short in the nominating season. Tempers get short, too, personal attacks increase and, of course, the candidates start looking drawn and a bit grayer around the edges.

headline: Giants’ Bubble Not Burst, but Flattened
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In what the Giants hope is not a bit of foreshadowing, the practice bubble adjacent to Giants Stadium — the white one easily visible for a couple of miles away and from passing planes overhead — collapsed under the weight of the team’s expectations.

headline: Two Aesthetics
text: I spent the month of November in New York, and for part of that time I hung out at the Museum of Television and Radio (now the Paley Center for Media), doing research for a book I’m writing on the ’60s TV show “The Fugitive.” When I wasn’t reading reviews and cover stories in old issues of TV guide, I was going to galleries, listening to concerts and seeking out movies that would probably not make it up to Delaware County. The movie I found was “Starting Out in the Evening,” described in the reviews as a “small film,” which means not only that there are no special effects, but that almost nothing happens (a point of criticism on the part of some reviewers).

headline: A Context for Those Complaints
text: After five-plus years of fielding air travel questions from the general public, I’ve pretty much heard it all. Certain subjects I expected to be popular — questions about the use of cell phones during flight, for instance — and I continue to be amazed at the number of fliers petrified by turbulence. But more than anything else, I have learned to never, ever underestimate how much people simply hate to fly.

headline: News Headlines
text: A roundup of stories from the world of real estate:

headline: Michigan Gets Its Man
text: Michigan’s long football nightmare is over. The Wolverines have hired West Virginia’s Rich Rodriguez, a move that brings to a close a drawn-out search that included Les Miles and Greg Schiano both deciding against coming to Ann Arbor.

headline: No Long-Term Contract Extension for the Bunker
text: Mike Richards probably has every hockey commentator wishing that they had spent more time learning how to play the game than collecting cards or setting up a hockey bunker.

headline: Following Death of Mother, Tyree Heads to Florida
text: The mother of Giants receiver David Tyree died of a heart attack Saturday night. Tyree was at the team hotel when his wife, Leilah, came to tell him about the sudden death of his mother, Thelma Tyree.

headline: Polling the Youth Factor
text: Taking a cue from Howard Dean’s 2004 campaign, many of this year’s candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination are courting the younger set.

headline: Reinventing the Revolution
text: Updated | 12:30 a.m. The revolution, it seems, will be televised. Or at least streamed live over the Web.

headline: Who’s on the List, Mr. Edwards?
text: OTTUMWA, Iowa — How confident is John Edwards about winning the Democratic presidential nomination? Well, consider this: Mr. Edwards, speaking at a forum in this small Iowa community, said that he has already begun thinking about who he would want as a running-mate. Maybe even more than just thinking about it.

headline: The Forgotten Soldiers
text: Four decades after the C.I.A. hired thousands of warriors to fight in the Vietnam War, men who say they are veterans of that operation are still hunted by their government.

headline: Who’s Advertising on the Tube
text: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, ran campaign advertisements on television more frequently than any other candidate through mid-November, according to the television tracking company Nielsen. He ran his first TV advertisement in February and mounted the costliest early advertising push in a presidential campaign. His rivals Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mike Huckabee began running television advertisements in November. The leading Democrats have stepped up their TV campaigns since October, running nearly as many advertisements as Mr. Romney.

headline: Even Iowa Voters Get a Holiday Break
text: In the well-tested playbook for presidential campaigns, there is no entry for this question: How do you keep momentum alive during the holidays without alienating — or annoying — voters?

headline: Dubai Rx : Conduit for Fake Drugs
text: Massive free trade zones like those in Dubai are being used by counterfeiters to smuggle fake drugs from China to Europe and the United States.

headline: Are There ‘We Can’t Score’ Shots?
text: First of all, the Rangers’ latest debacle raises the annual flu shot debate, as in, why did Henrik Lundqvist not get one?

headline: Man Faces Federal Charges in a Sex Ring in Minnesota
text: MINNEAPOLIS  A man suspected of luring 100 Asian women into a sex ring here has been charged in federal court with transporting women across state lines to engage in prostitution.

headline: Leadership Battle Grips South Africa’s Dominant Party
text: POLOKWANE, South Africa  In South Africa, the African National Congress is the unchallenged political machine, the party’s leader is its kingmaker and the conference to select that person, which began Sunday, is not unlike an American presidential primary.

headline: Pakistan Says Terrorism Suspect Has Escaped
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A man who was arrested in Pakistan last year on suspicion of plotting to blow up trans-Atlantic airplanes, and who faced extradition to Britain in another case, escaped from his guards Saturday after a court hearing here, officials said Sunday.

headline: A Quicker Resort This Year to Deep Discounting
text: KMART made a generation of bargain hunters react like starving dogs to a ringing bell. Now Internet companies want to bring the blue-light special to the cellphone  only this time, the bells are text messages telling shoppers that Valentino clutches, Christian Dior sunglasses and other luxury items are selling at more than 50 percent off.

headline: Commercials Bask in a Show’s Glow
text: As everyone knows, advertisers pay for time on television shows according to the number of viewers. But they should care about more than ratings, according to data newly released by the Nielsen Company, the audience measurement firm; it also matters how much the viewers like the show.

headline: Kosovo Struggles to Forge an Identity
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo  When Kosovo recently held a contest to design a flag, the organizers insisted that it reflect the multiethnic population, shunning the nationalist symbols of the past.

headline: Arsenal Edges Chelsea
text: William Gallas headed in a corner from Cesc Fabregas during injury time in the first half and Arsenal beat Chelsea for the first time in three years, 1-0. The victory kept Arsenal atop the Premier League standings with 40 points, ahead of United with 39 and Chelsea with 34.

headline: Disappointments on Climate
text: A week that could have brought important progress on climate change ended in disappointment.

headline: A Jilted Mentor’s Small Measure of Revenge
text: Foxborough, Mass.

headline: No Stranger to Trouble, Artest Finds a New Perspective
text: Ron Artest and the Sacramento Kings were greeted by a cold, pelting sleet when they arrived in Philadelphia on Thursday afternoon.

headline: A Multi-Voiced Warbler With an Electric Ukulele
text: Nellie McKay, 25, may be the sole member of her generation  musician or not  to cherish the sustained, warbling soprano style that was once a staple of Hollywood and Broadway musicals. It was one of the voices she deployed on Saturday night at the Concert Hall at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, singing the 1930s standard “Prisoner of Love.” At various times she also had a sultry jazz croon, a singer-songwriter’s naturalism, a crisp operetta declamation and a rapper’s fast rhymes. And she sang “Don’t Fence Me In” with an electric ukulele, then got the audience to whistle along with her.

headline: A Warning From Behind the Curtain
text: The Golden Globe nominations were announced on Thursday, glimmering tributes to the likes of Tom Hanks, Denzel Washington and Cate Blanchett. But on the same day, all that glitters in Hollywood was buried beneath a blizzard of arcane initials.

headline: Working Hard to Give Others a Better Beginning
text: PHILADELPHIA  Lorenzo Compton did not have a promising start. His parents kicked him out at 17 for refusing to obey, he dropped out of the 12th grade when he got a girl pregnant, he served almost two years for drug dealing and he carries a bullet in his thigh.

headline: Disabled Need Help Now, Not Later
text: To the Editor:

headline: Don’t Stand a Ghost of a Chance With You
text: It’s too bad that “Paranormal State,” a new series on A&E, is unlikely to find a mass audience, because the parodies it would inspire on shows like “Saturday Night Live,” if it had the requisite level of public recognition, would be delicious.

headline: In ’08 Race, the Other Clinton Steps Up Publicly
text: DUNLAP, Iowa  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign advisers laid out their new political strategy in a private conference call with allies last Tuesday, Bill Clinton was not on the line. He did not need to be. The message being delivered was his.

headline: Retailers Face an Ominous Holiday Sign
text: Sales of women’s clothing, a traditional pillar of the holiday shopping season, are unusually bleak so far this year, according to a major credit card company, an ominous sign for the retail industry.

headline: Suspect in Bomb Plot Escapes in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A man who was arrested in Pakistan last year on suspicion of plotting to blow up trans-Atlantic airplanes and who faced extradition to Britain in another case, escaped from his guards Saturday after a court hearing here, officials said Sunday.

headline: A Focused, Slimmer Marbury Returns
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  With a heavy heart and a lighter frame, Stephon Marbury returned to work Sunday.

headline: Country Music Is Still Calling
text: With 2,054 radio stations, country music dominates the airwaves in the United States, Reuters reported. The total, reported by M Street, which tracks radio statistics, was an increase of five from a year earlier but 450 fewer than a decade ago. News-talk stations, which have swelled by nearly 500 in the last 10 years, totaled 2,026, an increase of 18 from 2006. Among stations with music-driven formats, country was followed by contemporary Christian stations (numbering 920); Spanish (917); adult contemporary (666); and Top 40 (495). The number of contemporary Christian and Spanish language stations increased in the last year, while adult contemporary remained flat, and Top 40 declined by 15.

headline: Kyrgyzstan Leader’s Party Wins in Landslide
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The party of the president of Kyrgyzstan, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, stormed to an overwhelming victory in early parliamentary elections Sunday, preliminary results announced on Monday showed. But opposition candidates have already accused the government of rigging the voting and warned of further instability.

headline: Counterfeit Drugs’ Path Eased by Free Trade Zones
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Along a seemingly endless row of identical gray warehouses, a lone guard stands watch over a shuttered storage area with a peeling green and yellow sign: Euro Gulf Trading.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Scrambling to Cope With Rise of Huckabee
text: This article was reported by Michael Cooper, Michael Luo, Marc Santora and Paul Vitello and written by Mr. Cooper.

headline: Police in Iran Shut 24 Internet Cafes
text: TEHRAN (Reuters)  The Iranian police have closed down 24 Internet cafes and other coffee shops in as many hours, detaining 23 people, as part of a broad crackdown on immoral behavior, official news media said Sunday.

headline: Chance for Victory Slips Through Fingertips
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  So, which was the worst incomplete pass by the Giants during their miserable 22-10 loss to the Washington Redskins on Sunday night in the cold and bitter winds of Giants Stadium?

headline: Once Broke, GameStop Moves Up to S.&P. 500
text: Just over a decade ago, the company now known as GameStop was bankrupt, and analysts in the video game industry predicted that people would buy games online rather than in its mall stores.

headline: Dolphins Celebrate Their 1972 Season by Winning First Game
text: MIAMI  The Miami Dolphins commemorated the anniversary of their 1972 perfect season Sunday, in a season that has been anything but perfect. And for long stretches of the game against the Baltimore Ravens, it seemed as if Larry Csonka, Nick Buoniconti and Bob Griese, ensconced in a luxury box with their Hall of Fame blazers, would have given the Dolphins a better shot at avoiding a perfectly awful 0-16 season than anybody the Dolphins had on the field.

headline: 300 Inmates Break Out of Indian Jail
text: NEW DELHI  In the epicenter of the Maoist rebellion in central India, 300 prisoners who were apparently led by Maoists broke out of jail on Sunday evening, the police said.

headline: A Year for Quick Hits and Fast Flops as Campaigns Broke New Ground
text: THEY say the older you get, the faster the years seem to go by. But you could be the president of the “Gossip Girl” fan club or the newest cast member of “High School Musical 3” and still believe that time’s flight is on fast-forward.

headline: In Northeast, a Storm of Inconvenience
text: Barrages of snow, sleet and wind-driven rain delivered a wintry blow across the New York region and the Northeast on Sunday. It delayed air travelers, caused minor traffic accidents, washed out a million weekend plans and frustrated all but the most hardy mall crawlers and Christmas shoppers.

headline: Big Table Fantasies
text: Broadly speaking, the serious contenders for the Democratic nomination are offering similar policy proposals  the dispute over health care mandates notwithstanding. But there are large differences among the candidates in their beliefs about what it will take to turn a progressive agenda into reality.

headline: Palestinian Rocket Injures Child in an Israeli Kibbutz
text: JERUSALEM  A rocket fired at Israel on Sunday afternoon by Palestinian militants from Gaza landed near a house in Kibbutz Zikim, lightly wounding an Israeli toddler inside, an army spokesman said.

headline: A Pro Athlete With Spare Millions? Lenny Dykstra Has Your Magazine
text: Lenny Dykstra had a busy last week. He was named in the Mitchell report into performance enhancing drugs in baseball as someone who received steroids. He was also helping to start a magazine.

headline: Turkey Bombs Kurdish Militants in Northern Iraq
text: ISTANBUL  Turkey’s military said it bombed Kurdish militant targets in northern Iraq before dawn on Sunday, as part of an American-sanctioned effort to weaken the Kurdish guerrilla group that hides there. An Iraqi official said one woman had been killed.

headline: Leno and O’Brien to Resume Their Shows
text: NBC officially announced yesterday that its two late-night stars, Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien, will return to the air on Jan. 2 even if the strike against networks and studios by entertainment writers is not resolved by then.

headline: Ingersoll to Buy Climate Control Maker
text: Ingersoll-Rand, the industrial conglomerate, agreed on Monday to buy Trane, the air-conditioning company that is the successor to American Standard, for $10.1 billion.

headline: Two Wins in 24 Hours for Paerson
text: The Olympic slalom champion Anja Paerson won a women’s World Cup super-G in Switzerland on Sunday for her second victory in 24 hours.Paerson finished the Corviglia course in 1 minute 15.06 seconds to edge Canada’s Emily Brydon by 0.04. Renate Goetschl was third.“It’s just amazing,” Paerson said. “Yesterday, I was just thinking about getting across the finish line because this is such a tough super-G course.”Julia Mancuso lost half a second in the final interval but still posted the top American result, tying for 10th with Canada’s Britt Janyk in 1:15.57.

headline: A Lesson From New Jersey
text: For years people of color who traveled New Jersey’s highways knew that they were at a higher risk of being pulled over by state troopers. In 1998, this shameful policy of racial profiling was revealed  but only after troopers fired 11 shots into a van carrying black and Latino men  and New Jersey’s state police were placed under federal oversight. Now a special advisory committee to Gov. Jon Corzine has concluded, persuasively, that the State Police have changed their ways, and the governor has asked for an end to federal monitoring.

headline: On Facebook, Scholars Link Up With Data
text: Each day about 1,700 juniors at an East Coast college log on to Facebook.com to accumulate “friends,” compare movie preferences, share videos and exchange cybercocktails and kisses. Unwittingly, these students have become the subjects of academic research.

headline: Telecom Industry Wins a Round on Eavesdropping
text: WASHINGTON  Telecommunications companies won a skirmish in the Senate on Monday as a bill to protect them from lawsuits for cooperating with the Bush administration’s eavesdropping programs easily overcame a procedural hurdle.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
For Giants, Shockey Is Biggest Loss
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Faced with a big halftime deficit against the Redskins in September, the Giants mounted a stirring comeback to help reverse their season.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: A Woman in Control Sings Soul, Classically
text: The huge sign behind the Nokia Theater stage displayed the name of the radio station  98.7 KISS-FM  and also its slogan: “The Best Variety of Old School and Today’s R&B.” The occasion was the Kiss Holiday Concert on Friday night, and the star was a doubly appropriate singer.

headline: A New Look at a Caravaggio
text: Bought last year for $103,000, and now believed to be worth $100 million, a painting newly authenticated as a Caravaggio has gone on public display for the first time, at the Museo Regionale Conte Agostino Pepoli in Trapani, Sicily, Agence France-Presse reported. The painting is “The Card Sharps,” an early version of a 1594 work by the Italian Baroque master that is on display at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. The painting on display in Sicily was declared a Caravaggio after the British art collector and historian Denis Mahon, 97, bought it at a Sotheby’s auction.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: EARNINGS REPORTS The big Wall Street banks will continue to report their fourth-quarter results, with Goldman Sachs on Tuesday, Morgan Stanley on Wednesday and Bear Stearns on Thursday.

headline: Candidates Collect Endorsements in Final Days in Iowa
text: DES MOINES  The Democratic presidential candidates pressed across Iowa on Sunday as they began to make their closing arguments to voters before the holidays, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton clearly buoyed by her endorsement Sunday from The Des Moines Register.

headline: N.Y. Couple Convicted in Slave Case
text: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  The so-called Muttontown Slave Trial has involved a wild barrage of testimony by two Indonesian domestic workers employed  and according to prosecutors, enslaved and tortured for years  by an affluent Long Island couple. The verdict on Monday made for no less of a wild scene.

headline: New CDs
text: LUPE FIASCO “The Cool” (Atlantic)

headline: Death Penalty Repealed in New Jersey
text: TRENTON  Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed into law a measure repealing New Jersey’s death penalty on Monday, making the state the first in a generation to abolish capital punishment.

headline: Old U.S. Allies, Still Hiding in Laos
text: VIENTIANE PROVINCE, Laos  They call themselves America’s forgotten soldiers.

headline: Huckabee Draws Support of Home-School Families
text: DES MOINES  Christine and Chuck Hurley have raised and home-schooled their 10 children here, and five of those children will be eligible to vote in the Iowa caucus on Jan. 3.

headline: Duck Beware: A Hungry Wolf Prowls a Miniature World
text: “Peter and the Wolf,” Prokofiev’s 1936 musical fable about a plucky boy who resourcefully captures a fierce predator, might seem too slight to be called a masterpiece. But what other term applies to a piece of such seemingly effortless invention, or one that so readily appeals to listeners of any generation? The work’s narrative, also written by Prokofiev, has been delivered by all manner of celebrity storytellers, from Boris Karloff and John Gielgud to Captain Kangaroo and Dame Edna.

headline: What Next, Having the Office Christmas Party at Home?
text: For years, equipment once normally found only in the office has been migrating into the home, from answering machines and water coolers to laser printers and PCs. Now, in a quirky new campaign, Microsoft is hoping to sell America on the idea of bringing servers in-house.

headline: United Tops Liverpool
text: Manchester United extended its six-year unbeaten streak at Anfield by defeating Liverpool, 1-0, in an English Premier League match. Carlos Tevez’s goal in the 43rd minute off a corner from Wayne Rooney also sent Liverpool to its second consecutive league defeat after an unbeaten start.

headline: The Italian Malaise
text: To the Editor:

headline: German Skater Sets World Record
text: The German speedskater Jenny Wolf broke her world record in the women’s 100 meters with a time of 10.22 seconds at a World Cup race in Erfurt, Germany. That broke the mark of 10.28 she set in Calgary, Alberta, on March 4. Xing Aihua of China was second in 10.59, followed by Judith Hesse of Germany in 10.62.

headline: In a Battle for the Gold Cup, a Slam Opportunity Missed
text: The premier bridge event in Britain is the Gold Cup. The final, played on Dec. 9 at the Peebles Hydro Hotel in Scotland, was won by Alexander Allfrey, David Bakhshi, Andrew Robson and Tony Forrester. Their opponents  Paul Bowyer, Duncan Happer, Ben Green, Jim Mason, Dick Pathan and Nick Stevens  conceded defeat after 48 of the 64 scheduled boards, down 126 international match points to 28.

headline: For Recipients of Medicare, the Hard Sell
text: COLUMBUS, Miss.  Dorothy K. Barksdale, a 70-year-old seamstress, vividly remembers the day an insurance agent visited her home and signed her up for a private Medicare health plan.

headline: Sorenstam Repeats in Dubai
text: Annika Sorenstam of Sweden shot a two-under-par 70 Sunday to win the Dubai Ladies Masters by two strokes and collect her first victory since she won here in 2006.“I am so happy to have finally won again,” said Sorenstam, who finished at 10-under 278 at the season-ending tournament of the Ladies European Tour. The third-round leader, Iben Tinning of Denmark, had a double bogey at the last hole and finished with a 73, tying for second with Laura Davies of England, who shot a 72.

headline: The Early Years of Rock, Later Than Previously Thought
text: Any documentary series about the history of rock music that manages to get through its first show without mention of Elvis Presley, Buddy Holly or Chuck Berry, and only a passing reference to the Beatles  well, you have to admire its assertiveness.

headline: A Tale of Two Nutcrackers, With More Than a Chunnel Between Them
text: One of the refreshing things about the original 1892 “Nutcracker” is that, unlike most narrative ballets, it isn’t a love story. But that hasn’t stopped theorists, directors and choreographers from deciding that the scenario Marius Petipa drew up in 1891 for Tchaikovsky to set to music and what remains of the choreography created by Lev Ivanov (when Petipa fell ill) would all be improved by turning it into, yes, another love story.

headline: Greenspan Urges U.S. to Help Those Facing Foreclosure
text: Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Sunday that the government should provide direct financial assistance to homeowners who are threatened by foreclosure in the worsening credit crisis.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Dave Barber, senior vice president for newspaper relations at Parade, New York, part of Advance Publications, will now lead the newspaper relations group. He assumes duties from Lamar Graham, general manager, who was recently promoted to executive editor.

headline: A Surreal State
text: BRUSSELS

headline: Used to Taking Charge, but Finding Herself in Need
text: Armed only with a stick, Eilene Rockette stood outside wearing rain boots, a sweatshirt and sweat pants while being drenched by what felt like buckets of water. She yelled to others peering out from their apartments to help her clear debris that had clogged several drains on the street.

headline: Tweaking a Definitive Moment in History
text: CHICAGO  John Adams’s “Doctor Atomic” enjoyed a major success during its premiere production two years ago at the San Francisco Opera. Yet even among the work’s champions, the consensus was that this ambitious opera  about the physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, who presided over the Manhattan Project to build the first atomic bombs  needed some tweaking.

headline: Faster Chips Are Leaving Programmers in Their Dust
text: REDMOND, Wash.  When he was chief executive of Intel in the 1990s, Andrew S. Grove would often talk about the “software spiral”  the interplay between ever-faster microprocessor chips and software that required ever more computing power.

headline: Election in South Korea Is Missing Its Suspense
text: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea’s presidential elections have tended to be bruising, down-to-the-wire contests that exposed voters’ ideological schisms and raw emotions over the country’s tortured relations with North Korea and the United States.

headline: Talk of an Exit, but Not From Morgenthau
text: Last year, Robert M. Morgenthau presided over an office with roughly 96,000 cases, 500 assistant district attorneys, and some of the most high-profile trials in the nation, and he is on track to do the same this year.

headline: Diane Wood Middlebrook, Biographer, Dies at 68
text: Diane Wood Middlebrook, a biographer, poet and critic known for her best-selling, controversial life of the poet Anne Sexton, died on Saturday in San Francisco. She was 68.

headline: McCain Seeks to Capitalize on New Endorsements
text: CONCORD, N.H.  Senator John McCain, seeking to capitalize on a string of highly sought newspaper endorsements, is making an aggressive push to attract independent voters, who helped drive his victory here eight years ago.

headline: Celine Dion, She Went On and On
text: LAS VEGAS  For the final performance of “A New Day,” Celine Dion’s show at Caesars Palace here last weekend, M J Wylie, 49, a health-care consultant from Denver, decided to go formal. She wore a floor-length black gown and a sparkly white shawl; around her neck was a silver pendant in the shape of the show’s first logo, an elongated figure of a woman. Inside her $3,400 Judith Leiber clutch, bought at the gift shop adjacent to the theater and also bedazzled with the logo, were several autographed photos of Ms. Dion with Ms. Wylie. It was an undeniably elegant ensemble; the only problem, Ms. Wylie said, was that her dress hid her commemorative “New Day” tattoo.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,882 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

headline: Inmates Chip Away Jail’s Walls and Leap From Roof to Freedom
text: Jose Espinosa and Otis Blunt hail from different towns and very likely were strangers until they wound up in the same jail, a drab building of sealed windows rising 14 stories behind the courthouse in downtown Elizabeth, N.J.

headline: At Web Site for Journalists, Criticism of a Campaign Article Becomes a Melee
text: A usual round of media self-criticism turned into a schoolyard brawl last week, as editors, reporters and bloggers traded insults over a front-page article in The Washington Post, all at the very online water cooler where they usually get their news about the industry.

headline: Managing a Post-Feb. 5 Campaign
text: COLFAX, Iowa – For most of the year, two working assumptions have guided the strategic decisions of the major presidential campaigns. The first was that a Republican and Democratic nominee would for all and intents purposes be known after Feb. 5, when there are primaries and caucuses in more than 20 states. The second was that there will only – as the line goes – be three tickets out of Iowa; just three candidates from each party would survive the caucuses here on Jan. 3 and move on to New Hampshire, with the rest of the field being eliminated.

headline: Group to Ask for Expanded Inquiry of the Power Markets
text: Customers are paying “unjust and unreasonable rates” for electricity because wholesale markets favor large generating companies, according to a broad coalition of industrial, governmental and consumer groups that says it will ask the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to expand its investigation into the marketing of power.

headline: Gretzky’s Presence, Even as a Coach, Stops the Rangers Cold
text: As Wayne Gretzky looked around Madison Square Garden on Sunday night at the end of the Phoenix Coyotes’ 5-1 victory over the Rangers, he let himself soak in the atmosphere he remembered so fondly as a player. He was battling the flu, laboring to walk and struggling to talk, but he left the rink with a smile.

headline: Facebook, the Place People Go to Meet Other Scrabble Players
text: Like most fanatical Scrabble players, devotees of Scrabulous, a Scrabble-like application on Facebook, hate to be interrupted. So players are breathing easier since an upgrade last week intended to ensure that matches load more quickly.

headline: Case Lays Bare the Media’s Reliance on Iraqi Journalists
text: Bilal Hussein, an Iraqi photographer who had a hand in The Associated Press’s 2005 Pulitzer Prize for photography before being jailed without charges by the United States military, finally had a day in court last week. But his story, which highlights the unprecedented role that Iraqis are playing in news coverage of the war, is really just beginning.

headline: Changing Courses at the Food Network
text: You can find chef Emeril Lagasse’s name and face all over a dozen cookbooks, 10 restaurants, lines of pots and pans, knives, Wedgwood dishes, spices, salad dressings and pasta sauces, and even a deep fryer.

headline: ‘I Am Legend’ Has a Healthy Start
text: “I Am Legend” (distributed by Warner Brothers), starring Will Smith, right, in a postapocalyptic vision of a zombie-infested Manhattan, hauled in an estimated $76.5 million in its debut to capture first place in the weekend box-office rankings compiled by the tracking company Media by Numbers. Second place went to another newcomer, “Alvin and the Chipmunks” (Fox), a resurrection of the musical-cartoon franchise, which took in $45 million. Dropping to third place from second last week, the fantasy “The Golden Compass” (New Line) had $9 million in sales. “Enchanted,” Disney’s revisionist fairy tale, took in $6 million, bringing its total gross to $92.2 million in its fourth week in release, and the Coen brothers’ latter-day western, “No Country for Old Men” (Miramax), finished fifth, with $3 million in its sixth weekend.

headline: Vexing Questions of Jewish Identity
text: “Are you Jewish?” is a question often lobbed at Jamie Kastner, a Toronto filmmaker and writer. Why do you want to know?, he asks in a film that flings the question back as he moves around the globe  New York, London, Jerusalem, Paris, Berlin  to engage a widely varied cast of characters about the meanings of Jewishness. With the deliberately provocative and potentially offensive title “Kike Like Me,” his documentary is to have its television premiere in this country Monday night at 10 on the Sundance Channel.

headline: Advertising Accounts
text: Heineken USA, White Plains, named Wieden & Kennedy, Portland, Ore., to create English-language campaigns for its Heineken and Heineken Premium Light beer brands, which had been handled by Berlin Cameron United, New York, part of the United unit of the WPP Group. Spending was estimated at more than $100 million. The Vidal Partnership, New York, continues to create Spanish-language campaigns.

headline: A Young Shepherd’s Ageless Trek
text: Few composers in the 20th century devoted more time and craft to opera than Gian Carlo Menotti, who died in February at 95. Yet from a sizable body of work that includes two Pulitzer Prize-winning works (“The Consul” and “The Saint of Bleecker Street”), only one of Menotti’s operas can truly be said to have achieved lasting popularity: “Amahl and the Night Visitors,” a brief, modest work created for NBC television and first performed in a live broadcast on Christmas Eve in 1951.

headline: Facing a Challenge, a Tar Heel Responds
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  After two seasons in which Danny Green made only modest contributions, North Carolina Coach Roy Williams figured Green was capable of more. So he challenged Green and told him it was time for him to become a key figure for the Tar Heels.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Fun on the Ice in Mexico
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rare U.S. Victory in Cross-Country
text: Kikkan Randall became the first United States woman and the second American to win a World Cup cross-country race when she defeated the world sprint champion Astrid Jacobsen of Norway in the final meters of a 1.2-kilometer freestyle race in Demino, Russia.Randall is the first American to win a World Cup cross-country race since Bill Koch in 1983. She finished in 2:48.7  seven-tenths of a second ahead of Jacobsen.

headline: South African Prevails at South African Open
text: James Kingston shot a one-under 71 to beat Oliver Wilson by one stroke at the South African Open on Sunday.Kingston, of South Africa, finished at four-under 284 as darkness set in after an earlier rain delay at the Pearl Valley Golf Estates course in Paarl. Greg Norman shot a 71 and finished tied for seventh. Ernie Els had a 69 to finish in a tie for 16th with Retief Goosen, who shot a 75.

headline: Woods Adds Another Victory to a Season Full of Triumphs
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  In a near-perfect ending to a spectacular 2007 season, Tiger Woods tied up a lot of loose ends Sunday in the Target World Challenge at Sherwood Country Club. With a final-round 68 for a 72-hole total of 22-under-par 266 that was not quite as easy as it looked, he beat Zach Johnson by seven strokes, Jim Furyk by eight and the rest of the field by a mile.

headline: A Book Signing With the Author a World Away
text: Many people know that Conrad M. Black, the media baron who was sentenced last week to six and a half years in prison, is also a serious author, with weighty biographies of Richard M. Nixon and Franklin D. Roosevelt under his belt.

headline: You Can Go Home Again, but You’ll Pay the Consequences
text: First of all, it really is that good. You would expect it to have shrunk over the years, the way buildings that loomed large in your childhood seem smaller when you revisit them. But as the first-rate revival that opened Sunday night at the Cort Theater makes electrifyingly clear, “The Homecoming” is every bit as big as its reputation.

headline: Alex Trebek Leaves Hospital
text: Alex Trebek, below, the host of “Jeopardy!,” has been released from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles where he was treated after suffering what was described as a minor heart attack last Monday. He plans to spend the holidays at home and has promised to return to the studio on Jan. 14 to tape the quiz show’s “Teen Tournament.” In a statement relayed by the show’s publicity representative, Jeff Ritter, Mr. Trebek, 67, said, “I’m truly overwhelmed by the great show of support and compassion expressed in the past few days to me, my family and my co-workers.”

headline: Crossing Europe, Packing Menace, Sex and Secrets
text: Darcy Arlen, straight out of Indian Bend, Ohio, is taking a six-week European tour courtesy of her parents, who gave her the trip to celebrate her high school graduation. As Craig Holden’s “Matala” begins to spread its dark wings, Darcy is an accident waiting to happen, despite her squeaky-clean schedule full of museums, opera, architecture and ruins.

headline: She Aided Victims of Shootings, and She Became One
text: It was about 5:30 p.m. when, while taking her 9-year-old son to a Saturday evening swimming practice in Brooklyn, Carol Simon-Hayes realized she had forgotten something at her apartment. She left her son, Kieron, with friends at a gas station and approached her building, just down the block on Eastern Parkway.

headline: Democrats, Staying Within Spending Limit, Draft Budget with Domestic Emphasis
text: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats on Sunday readied a $516 billion budget that grudgingly sought to meet President Bush’s overall spending target while shifting money into domestic Democratic priorities like health care and education.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘I Am Legend’ Has a Healthy Start

headline: Michigan Hires Rodriguez as Coach
text: The University of Michigan will introduce Rich Rodriguez as its coach Monday, ending an awkward monthlong search with the hiring of one of college football’s most respected offensive minds.

headline: Whittling Away, but Leaving a Gap
text: There was an avalanche of sentencing news last week. The Supreme Court gave trial judges more power to show mercy, the United States Sentencing Commission gave almost 20,000 prisoners doing time on crack cocaine charges a good shot at early release, and even President Bush commuted a crack sentence.

headline: Boycotted Radio Host Remains Unbowed
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The humbling of Don Imus last spring over his remarks about the Rutgers women’s basketball team has done nothing to quiet Michael Savage, a radio host with a far bigger following and far more checkered track record.

headline: Wake Forest Gets Title Satisfaction While Ohio State Can’t Find Any
text: CARY, N.C.  Zack Schilawski grew up in this small bedroom community outside Raleigh, playing youth league soccer and occasionally getting a chance to watch college and professional teams compete at SAS Soccer Park.

headline: Chilling Day a Challenge for Player and Fan Alike
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  When it snows or rains or the wind blows furiously, sensitive sports like baseball, golf and tennis yield to the elements and wait for another hour or another day. Football keeps going, as the New England Patriots and the Jets did on this dreadful Sunday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report on Tuesday in the women’s college basketball roundup in some editions about Rutgers’s 56-51 victory over California misspelled, in some copies, the given name of the Scarlet Knights’ player who performed well despite taking intravenous fluids before the game because of an illness. She is Kia Vaughn, not Kim. (Go to Article)

headline: After 100 Years, Caruso and Melba Sing Again
text: A century after they were sealed, two urns containing 24 discs representing the best of French and Italian opera, as sung by artists like Nellie Melba and Enrico Caruso, will be put on display on Wednesday by the Paris Opera and the French National Library, Agence France-Presse reported. During 2008 the recordings, which feature works by Bizet, Gounod, Donizetti and Rossini, will be extracted from their protective covering, and EMI, the successor to Gramophone, which donated the discs, will issue them on CD. The records were sealed on Dec. 24, 1907, in a solemn ceremony in the basement of the Palais Garnier opera house in Paris as a gift from Alfred Clark, the head of Gramophone in France. He stipulated that they remain unopened for 100 years, “so men of that epoch can hear what the leading voices of our time sounded like.” The urns were exhumed in 1989 and entrusted to the library for safekeeping. Because of danger from the asbestos used to protect the records, the urns will not be opened when they are displayed this week.

headline: The World Is Flat, and Chocolatiers Want to Coat It
text: ZURICH  When the cold winter wind blows off Lake Zurich, the people who live around this sprawling factory, a 10-minute ride from the center of town, can smell the chocolate in the air. It is especially pungent this time of the year, when the factories are humming to meet holiday demand, the chocolate-maker’s bonanza.

headline: Niemeyer Plans Cultural Center in Spain
text: Leaders of seven major cultural institutions, including Lincoln Center, gathered over the weekend in Avilés in northwest Spain, where the Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer, left, who turned 100 on Saturday, is designing a center for them, Agence France-Presse reported. March is the anticipated start date for construction of the Niemeyer Cultural Center, featuring a 1,000-seat auditorium, a 43,000-square-foot gallery and a multiplex movie theater to be shared by the seven institutions. Besides Lincoln Center, the principal participants in the weekend discussion of new ways to work together were the Sydney Opera House, the Barbican Center of London, the Hong Kong Cultural Center, the Pompidou Center of Paris, the Alexandria Library of Egypt and the Tokyo International Forum.

headline: Tough Love, Conveyed With Nails and a Cross
text: In one of the strangest scenes from “Hard as Nails,” a documentary that will be shown Monday night on HBO, an unordained Roman Catholic minister named Justin Fatica stands before a teenager and shouts, “Jesus loves you!” as an assistant slams a metal folding chair against the minister’s back. And that is not even the most painful scene in this intimate and disturbing film.

headline: The Office I Left Giuliani
text: ON “Meet the Press” a week ago, Rudolph W. Giuliani attempted to deflect criticism of his close relationship with his former police commissioner, Bernard Kerik, by saying that his misjudgment of Mr. Kerik had to be weighed against his other accomplishments. “How can I not have pretty good judgment about the people who work for me and not been able to turn around the United States attorney’s office?” he asked. But Mr. Giuliani’s claim to have turned around the Manhattan United States attorney’s office is not only untrue, it is an insult to the outstanding men and women who have served in that office over the last 50 years.

headline: Flawed Media Plan
text: Decades ago, when most Americans relied on just a few news outlets, it made sense to bar companies from owning a newspaper and a broadcaster in the same city and limit the number of TV stations a single company could own. That was the best way to ensure that Americans had many different sources of information and the diversity of views needed for a healthy democracy.

headline: M.T.A. Rapid Response Plan for Elevators and Escalators
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to spend $1.3 million to hook up more than 300 elevators and escalators in the subways to a computerized monitoring system that would allow it to respond more quickly to breakdowns. The plan is to be submitted this week to the authority’s board for consideration.

headline: Holidays Find Loan Crisis Spreading to Businesses and Neighbors
text: Marcia is not in the holiday mood this year. She is not putting any Santas, reindeer or lights outside her house. She is probably not going to have many presents inside. There will be no home improvements anywhere. The fact is, she does not know how long she can even call the place hers.

headline: Precursor to Defeat: Bubble Deflates
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In what the Giants had hoped would not be foreshadowing for their game Sunday night against the Redskins or for their fortunes for the rest of the season, the practice bubble next to Giants Stadium collapsed during the ice and wind storm that struck the area early Sunday.

headline: Patriots Undefeated and the Jets Have New Intrigue
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Patriots linebacker Junior Seau peeled himself off Chad Pennington as time expired, celebrating his sack by raising his arms and pointing toward the cloudy sky. Few in Gillette Stadium noticed the celebration.

headline: Footnotes
text: Renzo Piano has been named the winner of the American Institute of Architects’ 2008 Gold Medal, the organization’s highest honor. He will receive the award at its gala on Feb. 22 at the National Building Museum in Washington. Mr. Piano designed the New York Times building in Manhattan. ... The Lilly Foundation is donating $44 million to the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music for the construction of a state-of-the-art studio building. The gift is the largest ever received by the university to support the arts. ... In ceremonies at the Royal Academy of Music in London last week Queen Elizabeth II presented the composer Judith Weir with the Queen’s Medal for Music for 2007. The award, established in 2005, is intended to raise the general profile of music in Britain.

headline: For Pop Stars, a Day to Pledge Fidelity to Radio
text: Radio stations must miss the days when they were the primary gatekeepers for pop stardom. MTV sandbagged them in the 1980s, and then along came the Internet.

headline: An Iran Gig for Chris de Burgh?
text: The Irish singer Chris de Burgh, below, best known for his hit “The Lady in Red,” is to perform in Iran in the summer with the Iranian rock band Arian, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the band’s manager. Arian is a founder of modern Iranian pop and the first group in the Islamic republic to receive an official permit to perform. Mr. de Burgh’s appearance, which has not been confirmed by his Web site (cdeb.com), would be the first by a major Western pop star in Iran since the 1979 Islamic revolution, which regarded rock music as decadent.

headline: Orioles Speak Up Against Mitchell Report
text: The Baltimore Orioles broke ranks with the other 29 major league clubs and Commissioner Bud Selig by issuing a statement late Saturday night that strongly questioned George J. Mitchell’s report on the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball.

headline: Killed in a Duel, Then Lost in the Earth
text: NASHVILLE  On Saturday morning, cars jammed the street outside James and Laura Jane Bowen’s home. Friends chatted in the yard, hands around coffee cups.

headline: Ingersoll to Buy Climate Control Maker
text: Ingersoll Rand, the industrial conglomerate, said Monday it would buy Trane, the air conditioning company that is the successor to American Standard, for $10.1 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Russian Bobsled Is Fastest in World Cup Race
text: Alexandr Zubkov of Russia drove his sled to victory in the four-man World Cup bobsled race, a year and a day after crashing on the course at the Olympic Sports Complex in Lake Placid, N.Y.His two-run time of 1 minute 48.79 seconds was 0.05 seconds faster than the American sled piloted by Steven Holcomb of Park City, Utah, who leads the standings with 660 points. Pierre Lueders of Canada, winner of the two-man race Saturday, was third.

headline: Britain Hands Over Control of Basra Province to Iraq
A Familiar Editor for Gawker
text: Nick Denton, the entrepreneur who has built Gawker Media into a formidable blog brand, said two weeks ago that he wanted the new editor of his flagship site, Gawker.com, to oversee its evolution toward a more traditional news operation.

headline: Finn Is Fastest; Ligety Fifth
text: Kalle Palander of Finland got his third career giant slalom victory on the Gran Risa course in Alta Badia, Italy, and the American Ted Ligety skied the fastest second run to finish fifth.Palander led the first run and his two-run combined time of 2:30.92 was enough to hold off Austria’s Benjamin Raich, the Olympic giant slalom champion, by 0.42 seconds.Ligety, who leads the giant slalom standings, was penalized by the International Ski Federation for showing up four minutes late to Saturday’s public draw. By rule, he was forced to start 46th instead of within the top 15 and was fined $867. (AP)

headline: The Election Watchdogs Going Missing
text: The Senate is ducking its responsibility to keep the Federal Election Commission stocked with qualified appointees to police the already booming election season. If a nasty partisan standoff is not soon resolved, the six-member regulatory panel could be left with just two commissioners remaining and unable to work. This is a ridiculous prospect  and an invitation to even more scheming and corner-cutting  in what is sure to be a multibillion-dollar campaign.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report on Tuesday in the women’s college basketball roundup in some editions about Rutgers’s 56-51 victory over California misspelled, in some copies, the given name of the Scarlet Knights’ player who performed well despite taking intravenous fluids before the game because of an illness. She is Kia Vaughn, not Kim.

headline: Real Estate Executive With Hand in Trump Projects Rose From Tangled Past
text: It is a classic tale of reinvention, American style.

headline: Philippine Talks Stall as Separatists Accuse Government of Changing Agreement
text: MANILA  Negotiations between the Philippine government and Islamic separatists suffered a serious setback over the weekend after the insurgents accused the government of unilaterally changing the essence of the draft of an agreement on ancestral homelands.

headline: Putin Opens Mecca Path for Muslims
text: MOSCOW  Gulsine K. Fatakhudinova, a 56-year-old Tatar Muslim, came lugging suitcases to pray at the lime-green mosque in central Moscow  one of dozens of people who arrived one recent day bundled in the weighty coats, fur hats and other winter garb they would soon cast off, at least temporarily.

headline: Updating a Classic, or Is It a Hoax?
text: A very odd book, or rather a set of 50 books, has appeared for sale on eBay. They are “My 61 Memorable Games,” by Bobby Fischer. According to the listing, Fischer has updated his book, “My 60 Memorable Games,” which he published in 1969, and is selling this set and another set of 50 as a “special edition, first print run.” The bidding was up to $3,050, as of early Monday morning. One of the odd quirks of the sale is that the buyer has to take the whole set, not just one book.

headline: All the World’s Hockey Rinks, Just a Mouse Click Away
text: Now you can see an aerial view of every hockey arena on the planet, or at least more than 1,100 of them, thanks to a French fan’s labor of love and the amazing powers of Google Earth. Want to zero in on the home ice of the Seibu Prince Rabbits, the Dubai Mighty Camels or the Lake Erie Monsters? Of course you do.

text: German state lender KfW could lose more than 5 billion euros ($7.3 billion) due to its participation in the bailout of German bank IKB, the head of KfW, Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier, told the Sueddeutsche Zeitung daily.

headline: Ireland’s FBD Holdings Said to Be Target of $1.45 Billion Bid
text: A European financial institution is set to make a 1 billion euro ($1.45 billion) takeover bid for Irish insurer FBD Holdings, The Sunday Business Post newspaper reported.

headline: Third Avenue Re-opens International Fund
text: Third Avenue Management, the money manager founded by value investor Martin J. Whitman, will reopen its $2.3 billion international fund to investors because the U.S. subprime crisis lowered prices and created buying opportunities.

headline: 3i Takes Inspicio in $626 Million Deal
text: 3i Group agreed Friday to buy British testing and inspection services group Inspicio, valuing the company at about 310 million pounds ($626 million), including debt and options.

headline: ABN Amro to Take Australia’s Monash Private
text: ABN Amro Capital Management, the Sydney-based private equity arm of Dutch bank ABN Amro said Friday that it would acquire Monash IVF, the Australian university spin-out that pioneered the test-tube baby, in a 200 million Australian dollar ($176 million) buyout.

headline: Will Regulators Put a Crimp in Convergence?
text: A prevalent perception in the capital markets is that the once generally respected demarcation between hedge funds and private equity funds is disappearing, as private equity and hedge fund structures and investment approaches continue to converge.

headline: Do Buyout-Backed I.P.O.’s Outperform the Market?
text: Initial public offerings by private equity-backed companies in Britain and Germany outperformed the stock market and other I.P.O.’s, according to two academic studies.

headline: Bidders Line Up to Roll Dice on Tropicana Casino
text: At least a half-dozen potential buyers have contacted New Jersey state casino regulators about buying the Tropicana Casino & Resort, and a sale could take place within weeks, the head of the state Casino Control Commission said Friday.

headline: Aon Sells 2 Insurance Units for $2.75 Billion
text: Aon, one of the world’s largest insurance brokers, said on Monday it has agreed to sell two units for about $2.75 billion and will use the proceeds to buy back shares.

headline: 2 Alitalia Bidders Outline Turnaround Plans
text: Air One, one of the finalists to buy Alitalia, said its recovery plan for the Italian carrier includes a complete renewal of the fleet, new destinations in China and the Americas, and an international partner.

headline: Google Executive to Become an Angel
text: Chris Sacca, the head of special initiatives at Google who led the company’s efforts to open up the wireless spectrum to more competition, is leaving Google to invest in early-stage technology companies.

headline: Oracle Bid Adds New Element to BEA Backdating Suit
text: What does BEA Systems‘s rejection of Oracle‘s takeover bid have to do with backdated stock options?

headline: More CRM Software Deals in 2008?

headline: Quick, Call Tech Support for the S.E.C.
text: It’s no secret that the Securities and Exchange Commission is terrifically understaffed and wildly underfunded compared with the populous and wealthy Wall Street world it is supposed to police, says The New York Times’ Gretchen Morgenson.

headline: G.E. Sells $100 Million Stake in Genpact
text: General Electric, as part of its regular review of its portfolios, agreed to sell $100 million of Genpact shares in a private deal, the companies said late on Friday.

headline: HSBC Boosted by $1.5 Billion Taiwan Deal
text: HSBC, Europe’s biggest bank, said on Monday it expected to remain profitable in Taiwan in 2008, as its acquisition of a local rival will help it access more clients in Asia’s third-largest wealth management market.

headline: Dealmakers Say Goodbye to a Once-Hot Market
text: After notching a record $2.7 trillion of mergers and acquisitions worldwide in the first half of 2007, cooler heads — or at sentiments — are now prevailing.

headline: Ingersoll in $10 Billion Deal for Trane
text: Ingersoll Rand, the industrial conglomerate, said Monday it would buy Trane, the air conditioning company that is the successor to American Standard, for $10.1 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Tudor Fund Hit With $1 Billion in Withdrawals
text: Tudor Investment clients pulled more than $1 billion from its Raptor hedge fund after manager James Pallotta lost 8.5 percent this year, mostly on U.S. equities, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Memsic Flat in Debut
text: Shares of Memsic, a maker of sensors used to add touch, pedometer, or light-show functions to mobile phones, edged up 20 cents, or 2 percent, to $10.20 in the company’s debut on the Nasdaq Global Market Friday afternoon.

headline: Gant Investors Said to Reject Maus Bid
text: Owners representing more than 55 percent of shares in Swedish clothing retailer Gant have rejected a bid from Lacoste-brand owner Maus Freres, shareholder Ricon SGPS said on Monday.

headline: Australian Councils May Sue Lehman Over C.D.O.’s
text: Lehman Brothers faces the threat of legal action by municipal councils in Australia over the sale of high-risk collateralized debt obligations by the Wall Street bank’s local subsidiary, Grange Securities, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Related Gets $1.4 Billion From Investor Group
text: Related Companies, the New York real estate developer, said Monday it would receive $1.4 billion in equity and debt investments from a group including Goldman Sachs, Michael Dell’s MSD Capital and Mubadala Development, an affiliate of an investment firm owned by Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Waiting for a New US Policy
text: In the end, the conflict that dominated the Bali climate talks was not between developed countries and developing nations. It was the U.S. against the rest of the world. The U.S., which opposes carbon limits and generally refuses monitoring of its climate control actions, almost managed to jettison an agreement hammered out in a 2 week conference attended by 11,000 delegates from 200 nations. (see my analysis and commentaries)

headline: Strike Ends Most Scripted TV Work
text: “Production on all but two of the last few scripted prime-time television shows shooting in Los Angeles ground to a halt on Friday as a crippling strike by Hollywood writers neared the end of its sixth week, an industry group said,” Reuters reports.

headline: Mastering the Out-of-Office Message
text: After last week’s post about time management tricks, I wanted to e-mail Merlin Mann, whose “inbox zero” video I linked to, telling him about the blog post. I don’t know Mr. Mann, but I’ve long admired his blog, 43Folders, and lately I have become a bit of a zealot about his “in box zero” concept of e-mail management. When I got to his site, it was easy enough to e-mail him since his site is well organized and there is a clear “about” page that leads you to a page with information about him. But when I got to that page, I learned that he isn’t reading e-mails at the moment because he is on paternity leave until the end of December.

headline: Loews Sets Spinoff of Lorillard Unit
text: Loews Corporation, the diversified conglomerate, said Monday that its board of directors approved a plan to spin off Lorillard, the cigarette maker, as a separately traded company.

headline: Spoiler Alert
text: An empty Manhattan? Turns out “I Am Legend” is a total fantasy. The head’s up about Popular Mechanics’s deconstruction comes courtesy of Cinematical.

headline: War Is Not the Answer
text: Will “Charlie Wilson’s War” dodge the bullets that have laid low all the battle-weary film fare this year? “There’s a possibility that this movie does absolutely nothing,” Tom Hanks, who produces and stars, admitted. But CWW is using guerrilla tactics to fight from the hills. It’s funny, for one thing.

headline: The Early Word: Endorsement Time
text: It’s endorsement time, with several of the candidates on Monday announcing prominent (and sometimes curious) backers as they head into the final stretches for the Iowa and New Hampshire contests.

headline: Embarrassment of Riches
text: Depending on where you live — the Bagger is Jersey proud — this was an exquisite weekend for movies. In the white trash ville gorgeous suburban redoubt where the Bagger lives, the local theaters were jammed with excellence. The arty cinema in town was showing “Atonement,” “I’m Not There,” “No Country For Old Men,” “Starting Out in the Evening” and “Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead.”

text: National Oilwell Varco, a maker of oil and gas drilling equipment, said Monday it will acquire Grant Prideco for about $7.4 billion in cash and stock, creating a new company with an estimated market value of $32 billion.

headline: Fox: Every Work Stoppage Has A Silver Lining

text: Shares of Trane streaked higher Monday on news that the air-conditioner maker would sell itself to Ingersoll Rand for $10 billion. But on Friday, it was Trane’s options that were on a tear.

headline: Update: Talk Off | Airports
text: Last week, in The Moment’s Talk Off column, Nathan Lump, the magazine’s Travel Editor, battled the Travel Features Editor Jeffries Blackerby over the merits of airports. Readers voted by leaving comments. The results: Nathan, who argued the affirmative position, won the Talk Off with approximately 75 percent of the votes. (Note: Though the margin of victory was decisive, the real winner of the Talk Off might have been erik, who posted this brilliant comment: “You should make a movie starring Hugh Grant as a disheveled Prime Minister who comes up with an Iraq exit strategy at Heathrow. And Emma Thompson will cry and someone will sing a really good version of that Mariah Christmas song.”)

headline: Managing a Post-Feb. 5 Campaign
text: In his column today, Adam Nagourney writes that “as campaigns try to keep up with this fast-paced, multi-layered campaign, there is growing sense among Republicans that for their contest at least — and perhaps for Democrats — Feb. 5 may not be the end of the line. And at the same time, Democrats are looking at a scenario where only two of their candidates emerge out of this state.” Go to Column

text: Countdown: Seventeen days until Caucus Day. Seven shopping days until Christmas.

headline: Of Humans, Oil, and Whales
text: Our endless quest for that wondrous liquid fossil fuel, oil, is expanding toward the ends of the Earth as higher prices justify more extreme extraction efforts. Jad Mouawad, my friend and colleague covering the global oil industry, ventured to frigid Barrow, Alaska, recently to write about the Royal Dutch Shell’s planned exploration push offshore into the Arctic Ocean, and the implications for the whale-hunting Inupiat natives of Barrow.

headline: On the Road: Clinton Backers ‘Not on a Suicide Mission’

headline: Monday Kickoff: From Morgantown to Ann Arbor
text: Now that Rich Rodriguez has been introduced as Michigan’s new head coach, let’s take a look at the various ways in which his move is being viewed. SI.com’s Stewart Mandel calls it “college football’s most significant hire since Florida landed Urban Meyer.” Bob Wojnowski of the Detroit News writes that hiring Rodriguez was “the aggressive, innovative move Michigan had to make.” Jim Carty of the Ann Arbor News says the hire is a “home run” for Athletic Director Bill Martin. The folks at MGoBlog.com seem pretty satisfied with the move as well.

headline: The Giant Rat of Sumatra, Alive and Well
text: When the human imagination wants to conjure up a fantastical beast for its own entertainment, it often follows the simple but effective recipe of taking a familiar critter and exaggerating it to colossal or minuscule size. Enormous “this-es” and tiny “thats” populate classical myths and campfire stories, high-flown allegorical novels and bait-shop lies about the one that got — well, you know.

headline: Twit-ter
text: George Clooney “thinks that, provided he does films which are politically committed, he’s allowed to do Ocean’s 11, 12, and 13,” says public intellectual Rupert Everett, in an interview with The Independent. “But the Ocean’s movies are a cancer to world culture. They’re destroying us.”

headline: Hating on the Haters
text: The Film Experience has had enough with the treatment of Nicole Kidman as some kind of satin piñata. So what if “Compass” and “Margot” underwhelmed? This girl can still move units.

headline: El Diablo
text: A while back, the Bagger’s alter ego did a profile of Diablo Cody and found out that, apart from having written a smashing screenplay, Ms. Cody’s unprintably named blog from her stripper days was a revelation — smart, edgy, with unexpected riffs that tied together figures from Russian historical novels and the twerps on sniffer’s row. The same can’t yet be said for her new column in EW, but keep an eye on it. Maybe when she gets a moment between projects, she’ll start connecting.

headline: Get Serious
text: Peter Bart, the editor in chief of Variety, examines the malaise afflicting so-called serious films and finds that the solution on the business side may lie in international markets, where adults actually want to see films intended for grown-ups.

headline: The Depth of eBay’s Problems 1: Disappointed Buyers
text: I wrote a post Friday with the thought that Amazon should buy eBay, and readers nearly revolted at the idea. The outpouring of rage at eBay was of the sort we don’t see here for anything other than cellphone companies. The company is clearly getting hit by both buyers and sellers. I’ll write a post shortly on the frustrations of merchants on eBay.(UPDATE: That post is here.) Below is a sampling of the complaints from Bits readers.

headline: Menus As Literature
text: The wordiness of some menus reflects an intense focus on ingredients. The chef wants you to know exactly what he or she is putting in a dish, and that knowledge can definitely be helpful. You may be able to predict better how the dish will taste. You may be able to predict better whether you’ll enjoy it.

headline: The Softer Side of Clinton
text: JOHNSTON, Iowa — Imagine Hillary Rodham in the sixth grade, wearing thick glasses that she hated. But she was hoping cute boys at school would notice her. So occasionally, she would take off those glasses.

headline: 2007: Who Is the Bank of the Year?
text: This has been a defining year for investment banks, whose fortunes — and in some cases, chief executives — were made or lost according to how well they weathered the mortgage debacle.

headline: Emeril Goes, but Flay and Ray Stay
text: If the Food Network transforms a chef into a star, should the network reap the broader financial rewards of the chef’s brand name?

headline: Reruns? Let’s Just Call Them ‘Classics’
text: While David Letterman’s production company attempts to secure an agreement with the Writers Guild of America, repeats of “The Late Show with David Letterman” and “The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson” continue on CBS. This week the network is taking a page from NBC and Comedy Central and scheduling a theme week of classic episodes.

headline: Q & A Excerpts: George J. Mitchell
text: Friday, the day after George J. Mitchell released his 409-page report on the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, Duff Wilson, William C. Rhoden and I sat down with Mitchell in a conference room at the law offices of DLA Piper.

headline: If You’re Middle Class, Please Stand Up
text: John Edwards remains very much in contention in Iowa and in the race for the Democratic nomination, and over the weekend the Edwards camp unveiled a new TV ad titled, “Fight.” In it, Mr. Edwards looks into the camera and declares war on inequality. “The moral test of our generation is whether we’re going to allow this broken system to go on without a fight or take on corporate greed and stand up for the middle class and American jobs before it’s too late,” he says. “Saving the middle class is going to be an epic battle, and that’s a fight I was born for.”

headline: I.I.H.F. President: Both N.H.L. and N.H.L.P.A. Should Adjust Transfer Agreement
text: The International Ice Hockey Federation released an interview with its president, René Fasel, to clarify its positions on the reopening of the N.H.L.-I.I.H.F. player transfer agreement. Fasel reiterates the European position we noted earlier: an end to N.H.L. clubs’ warehousing of European players in the minor leagues; an earlier transfer deadline than June 15 for N.H.L. transfers; and a way to deal with the plummeting value of the U.S. dollar against European currencies.

headline: Take Me Out of the Ballgame?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: About This Blog
text: It’s hard to believe, but this is my 250th post on Paper Cuts.

headline: Citi’s New Administrative Chief: The Internal Memo
text: When Vikram S. Pandit took the reins of Citigroup last week, many wondered if he would begin a Morgan Stanley-ization of the firm. Mr. Pandit has already remade Citi’s capital markets group in Morgan Stanley’s image and acquired a private equity firm stocked with executives from his old firm.

headline: Sipping kosher mulled wine inside an architectural gem
text: The market is housed inside Daniel Libeskind”s new addition

headline: Clinton’s Concerns on Caucuses
text: JOHNSTON, Iowa – No presidential candidate who knows what’s good for him (or her) would dare to criticize the Iowa caucus process too harshly. But Hillary Rodham Clinton edged up to the line this morning, for understandable reasons.

headline: Does Mallett Fit Into Rodriguez’s Plan?
text: The big buzz of in the aftermath of Rich Rodriguez’s hiring at Michigan surrounded the reaction of the country’s No. 1 recruit, Terrelle Pryor. “Add Michigan to my list,” he declared to rivals.com. For those unfamiliar with Pryor, check out some of his YouTube clips.

headline: An (Un)easy Guide to Holiday Tipping
text: How much holiday money should a New Yorker give to the doorman, superintendent, concierge or porter? How about your letter carrier, housekeeper, parking-lot attendant and newspaper distributor? Or your child’s schoolteacher? And how should you deliver it? In a box in the building lobby? In a hand-delivered envelope? In the mail?

headline: Putting a Price on the Drudge Report
text: The Drudge Report isn’t for sale — at least, not that we know of. But that didn’t stop Duff McDonald, writing in the latest issue of Portfolio magazine, from playfully speculating about the value of Matt Drudge’s Web site, a gossipy gathering of links, news and scoops that has been around for more than a decade and can still make waves in Washington.

headline: Sharpton and Bill Clinton, Together in S.C.
text: Update | 6:10 p.m. The event has been canceled.

headline: Clinton on 'Today'
text: David Gregory interviews Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Video: NBC News)

headline: Leno and Conan Back — But Funny?
text: NBC said today that Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien will return to the air on Jan. 2 even if the strike against networks and studios by entertainment writers is not resolved by then.

headline: Hopeful Signs for Smaller Deals in 2008
text: The merger world isn’t what it used to be. Multibillion-dollar deals dropped off noticeably in the second half of 2007, in large part because leveraged buyout firms were kept at bay by the choppy credit markets.

headline: Leno and O’Brien Explain Decisions To Return January 2
text: “NBC officially announced today that its two late-night stars, Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien, will return to the air on Jan. 2 even if the strike against networks and studios by entertainment writers is not resolved by then,” Bill Carter reports.

headline: Iowa’s First Lady Endorses Edwards
text: DES MOINES ­– On the evening of Nov. 30, at a holiday party for Gov. Chet Culver of Iowa, John Edwards stood in a darkened ballroom in front of chattering and oblivious partygoers eating ribs and drinking beer.

headline: Options for Carpeting
text: I am someone who can get tan in the rain — literally. I have done it on more than one occasion.

headline: Giuliani Says He’s in to Win N.H.
text: DURHAM, N.H. — Rudolph W. Giuliani may have scaled back his television advertising here in New Hampshire after it failed to lift his standing in the polls, but he told a town-hall-style meeting here Monday that he is competing to win in the primary, and boasted that he will campaign here again next fall (presumably as the nominee).

headline: Nostalgic Rides Around New York: Have a Listen (‘Screech!’)
text: December is nostalgia month for the city’s transportation aficionados, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is breaking out vintage subway cars and buses for passenger use.Old New York City Transit buses are running on the crosstown routes of M34, M42, and M50 in Manhattan from 7:30 to 10:30 a.m. and from 3 to 6 p.m. And on Sundays in December, subway cars from the 1930s to the 1970s will operate on the V(intage?) line between Queens Plaza and Second Avenue on Sundays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (The traditional vintage subway program, which is not for normal passenger use, has been questioned for its fiscal appropriateness.)

headline: The McCain-Lieberman Show
text: HILLSBOROUGH, N.H. — As Senator John McCain sat on the back his campaign bus just after the sun rose this morning, flanked by his old friends former Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, and Senator Joseph Lieberman, today’s endorsement made perfect sense.

headline: I Put the ‘DU’ in a Not-so-Dumb Idea for Baseball
text: The release of the Mitchell report last week dealt Major League Baseball and its fans a serious blow. But rather than wax nostalgic for the good old days when the worst thing a player put into his body before the game was a pint of bourbon, we need to get aggressive and move forward. To use a sports metaphor, “We cannot stop steroids; we can only hope to contain them.”

headline: ‘Survivor’ Boosts CBS, But for How Long?
text: Todd Herzog, a 22-year-old flight attendant from Utah, became the latest champion of the “Survivor” series on Sunday, as the final episode of the show’s 15th edition gave CBS a modest boost in the ratings. Attracting 15.1 million viewers from 8 p.m. to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, the “Survivor: China” finale garnered slightly better ratings than the show’s average this season and matched the ratings for its September premiere, which had been one of the series’ lowest-rated debuts.

headline: A Big Debut for Goldman’s New Fund?
text: Despite the notorious blowups of several hedge funds at Goldman Sachs this summer, it seems investors remain bullish on the investment bank’s prowess.

headline: Dodd Delegates
text: A part of the New Hampshire primary process is the   selection of the delegates by each Democratic campaign.

headline: Navel Gazing | T’s Paolo Roversi Kerfuffle
text: (Paolo Roversi)

headline: The Films of St. Clair Bourne
text: St. Clair Bourne talks about his career as a documentary filmmaker during an interview in June 2006.
