headline: Giants’ Playoff Scenarios Updated
text: Fresh from the National Football League, here is what has to happen for the Giants (9-5) to make the playoffs as a wild-card team. The surest route, of course, would be for the Giants to beat either the Bills in Buffalo on Sunday, or — and this would be interesting, wouldn’t it? — the Patriots on Saturday, Dec. 29, at Giants Stadium.

headline: No ‘Yes’ Men, Obama Says
text: STORM LAKE, Iowa – Even though many Iowa voters appear to be undecided in their decision for president, one question keeps coming up again and again for candidates in the waning days of the caucus campaign: Who would you select for your vice president?

headline: Not the Lawyer of the Year: Alberto Gonzales
text: When the American Bar Association’s ABA Journal named former Attorney General Alberto Gonzales “Lawyer of the Year” last week, it came in for a flood of criticism.

headline: Campus Voices: Devoted Dodd Delegates
text: On Saturday, two students from Harvard’s Institute of Politics, who are spending a considerable amount of time in New Hampshire as part of an academic project on the state’s primary, watched a candidate’s caucus as possible convention delegates were selected.

headline: The Depth of eBay’s Problems 2: Angry Sellers
text: Here’s another angle on what’s wrong at eBay: Sellers increasingly find eBay’s fees to be too expensive and are becoming successful at finding buyers on Amazon.com or on their own sites. I wrote Friday about why Amazon should buy eBay. And I posted this morning about the torrent of angry comments we got about eBay, mainly from buyers.

headline: Now Booking | Easter Island
text: A guest room at the Posada de Mike Rapu.

headline: Relief and Dismay in Saudi Rape-Victim Case
text: Advisors to King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia may have thought that pardoning “the girl from Qatif” would quiet critics at home and abroad who were outraged by the way she was treated by the fundamentalist-Islamic Saudi justice system. But from many quarters, the pardon, reported in a Saudi newspaper on Monday, seems to be renewing the criticism and calls for reform.

headline: Be Bloomin’ Witty
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions at right.

headline: New Life for ‘Quarterlife’
text: NBC has announced a premiere date for the Web-to-television series “Quarterlife.” The first of six episodes will debut on Feb. 18 at 9 p.m., after the premiere of the reality show “Baby Borrowers.”

headline: Simon Apologizes, Takes Leave of Absence From Islanders
text: While awaiting word of his punishment from the N.H.L. for Saturday night’s incident with Pittsburgh’s Jarkko Ruutu, Islanders forward Chris Simon has been granted a leave of absence from the team.

headline: The Next Hoover
text: Is President Bush’s economic policy worse than his foreign policy? Joseph Stiglitz, the Columbia economist who served as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton from 1995 to 1997, evidently thinks so. Stiglitz has an essay in the December issue of Vanity Fair that begins:

headline: A Break for Simon, but Not the Pundits
text: The Islanders have announced that Chris Simon will be taking a break from the team, but a few writers were asking before the announcement that the NHL make any break permanent.

headline: New Romney Ad: ‘Judgment’
text: Mitt Romney is set to begin a new line of attack on his rival Mike Huckabee in Iowa tomorrow with a new ad, this one highlighting the number of clemencies he granted and criticizing him for reducing penalties for manufacturing of methamphetamines.

headline: Indian Company Poised to Buy Jaguar and Land Rover
text: Over the weekend, the Times of London reported that Tata Motors, an Indian automobile company, had emerged as the frontrunner in the Jaguar and Land Rover sweepstakes.

headline: Sexicon
text: The stunningly odd and hugely popular Marina speaks in a voice that sounds so much like voice-recognition technology that I swear there’s some machinema appeal to her whole gig.

headline: Kaka and Marta Crowned
text: A day after helping AC Milan defeat Boca Juniors 4-2 in Yokohama, Japan, for the Club World Cup, Kaka was named FIFA World Player of the Year.

headline: Dinner Plans
text: "Home for the Holidays," in which the Neistat Brothers prepare to entertain. And succeed.

headline: Ovechkin Night in the Bunker
text: Alex Ovechkin was worth all the late nights spent watching tapes of the World Junior Championship in North Dakota a few years back. And the Washington Capitals probably felt they had found their way back to the adults’ table when they drafted Ovechkin in 2004.

headline: Clergy Urge Ceasefire on Immigration
text: As we reported last week, Republican candidate Mitt Romney is running negative TV ads in Iowa that portray Mike Huckabee as soft on immigration.

headline: The Sun’s Long-Lost Twin Gets A Name (Or Two)
text: The judges in the Solar-Twin Naming Contest have decided on a winner — and more.

headline: That’s a Whole Lot of Birds
text: What we’re reading elsewhere…

headline: Beyond Sheep-Throwing: Rhapsody on Facebook
text: Rhapsody, the music service, just introduced its Facebook application. It’s easy to skip past this, because everybody has a Facebook app these days. But it’s worth a look because the experience shows that an application on Facebook can have much more usefulness than Zombies and SuperPoke.

headline: The Regulars Return for the Usual, No Longer on Second Avenue
text: The clear matzo ball soup was the same, the blue and brown tile floors were the same, even the hustling waitresses were the same. The waitresses recognized their old customers of the Second Avenue Deli and the old Second Avenue Deli customers recognized them back — even though they had reconvened one mile north and were no longer on Second Avenue. Instead, now they were on East 33rd Street, between a nail salon and a body hair threading place on the south side of the street between Lexington and Third Avenues.

headline: Will Hillary Clinton Be Stampeded by the ‘Herding’ Effect?
text: Many voices have been raised — including this Editorial Page’s — against the presidential primary calendar, which gives states like Iowa and New Hampshire an undeservedly outsized role in selecting the nominees.

headline: Where Should Airport Security Begin?
text: At least some, if not most, security experts maintain that a repeat of 9/11 is impossible. I am not among them.

headline: Bloggingheads: Beating the G.O.P.
text:
Mark Schmitt (l) of the New America Foundation and Matthew Continetti of the Weekly Standard debate whether Hillary Rodham Clinton or Barack Obama is more electable.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Bulgaria Top Performer
text: In a report sure to fuel debate, Bulgaria is listed as the top performing market in the latest Knight Frank Global Price Index. Bulgaria’s prices jumped 30.6 percent in the quarter ended in September, despite “numerous concerns over the level of oversupply” in resort areas, the property company says.

headline: Romney Again Seeks Huckabee Apology
text: LONDONDERRY, N.H. – At a campaign stop here on Monday, Mitt Romney continued his blunt criticism of his Republican rival Mike Huckabee, renewing a call for Mr. Huckabee to apologize for characterizing the Bush administration’s foreign policy as “arrogant.”

headline: A Hurdle for Matching Money
text: More than any other candidate, John Edwards has used ActBlue.com, the liberal fund-raising Web site, to solicit donations — $4.4 million so far. But on Friday, the Federal Election Commission ruled against a request from Mr. Edwards that money raised through ActBlue be used to qualify for federal matching funds.

headline: Bloomberg’s World Stage
text: The Bloomberg-for-president buzz machine seems to have shifted into overdrive recently, with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg traveling the world, acting like a statesman and injecting himself into the political debate.

headline: Kerrey Tries to Explain Obama ‘Muslim’ Remarks
text: Yet another day, yet another Clinton campaign surrogate explaining remarks made about one of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s top rivals, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: ‘The Fertility Diet': Help or Hype?
text: A new book from Harvard researchers called “The Fertility Diet” is certain to offer hope to the six million couples in the United States alone who are struggling with infertility. Unfortunately, it isn’t going to help most of them.

headline: The Story of Westbrook’s Non-Touchdown
text: Several readers have commented on The Fifth Down on Brian Westbrook’s unselfishness in sliding down at the 1 rather than scoring a touchdown in the final minutes against the Cowboys on Sunday. In the full story of the play, Westbrook does not even take credit for the idea. Westbrook told reporters that right tackle Jon Runyan had suggested the tactic right before the play. Runyan emphasized the point during the play as well.

headline: Thompson Starts His Bus Tour in Iowa
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa – Fred D. Thompson kicked off his bus tour of Iowa on Monday night in this town on the bank of the Mississippi River, and he seemed to have taken to heart the wide criticism of his low-key efforts at campaigning.

headline: Scientific Breakthrough: How to Wash Your Hands
text: For my Findings column, I put in a day of field work in New York with Donald Norman, the author of the classic “The Design of Everyday Things” and a new book, “The Design of Future Things.” I had a fine time being enlightened by the great expert on gadgets gone bad as he analyzed gear at places like Hammacher Schlemmer and Best Buy (my ulterior motive was to get advice on what to buy my dad for Christmas).

headline: Striking Hollywood Writers Deny Globes
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Leno’s Producer: “It’s Going To Be Hard”
text: Bill Carter summarizes Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien’s decisions to return on Jan. 2:

headline: Home Prices in South Korea Stalling at a High Point
text: SEOUL  In 30 years as a real estate broker, Chung Doo-hyun says, he has never seen a market behave the way South Korea’s is.

headline: Loews to Spin Off Lorillard Tobacco
text: In a move that would finally separate the Loews Corporation from the tobacco business, the company said on Monday that it planned to divest its interest in Lorillard Tobacco, the cigarette company that makes Kent, Newport, Maverick and True.

headline: For Romney, a Course Set Long Ago
text: WASHINGTON  George Romney had big ideas for his youngest child.

headline: Seeking $30 Million to Renovate, Church Finds Help in Neighbors
text: Foiled long ago in its plan to raise money by replacing its landmark community house with a 59-story office tower, St. Bartholomew’s Episcopal Church on Park Avenue is now passing the plate among the very neighbors whose views would have been sliced by the skyscraper.

headline: Doggedly Persistent, Untying Medicare Knots for the Elderly
text: The client, a retired fabric cutter who looks older than his 66 years, slumps into a chair and empties a shopping bag stuffed with unopened envelopes, prescription slips and sheaves of official nasty-grams onto the counselor’s desk.

headline: Investigation of Spitzer Heats Up
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration has received a second subpoena from the Albany County district attorney, P. David Soares, reflecting what appears to be a more aggressive approach in his investigation of the administration.

headline: Spitzer Urges Financing of Proposals for SUNY
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer said on Monday that despite the state’s budget difficulties, it must find money to invest in at least some of the proposals outlined by his higher education commission, though he stopped short of saying which recommendations he would embrace in his budget.

headline: A Midnight Service Helps African Immigrants Combat Demons
text: WASHINGTON  At an hour when most people here are sleeping or sinning, the worshipers of the Spiritual Warfare ministry gather in the cold sanctuary of a neighborhood church to battle evil.

headline: 64 Journalists Killed Worldwide in 2007, the Most Since ’94
text: More journalists have been killed worldwide in 2007 than in any year since 1994, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists, an independent group that promotes press freedom and defends the rights of journalists.

headline: Jets’ Coaches Cooked Up Surprises for Patriots
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.,  The Jets drew up a game plan for the New England Patriots as if they were mad scientists. On offense, they installed an option package using receiver Brad Smith at quarterback. On defense, they used down linemen as if playing musical chairs  sometimes three, sometimes two, sometimes one, with several players rotating in and out.

headline: Persevering Despite Muggers and a Nighttime Commute
text: To get to her night-shift factory job, Laura Pinto, 67, leaves her Bronx apartment and shuffles five blocks to the Grand Concourse, where she boards a No. 1 bus. She takes it to 205th Street, gingerly disembarks, walks two crosstown blocks and gets on another, the No. 20, which takes her to Yonkers. For the two-and-a-half-hour trip, Ms. Pinto chooses from one of seven canes and walkers of varying height and durability, making her selection according to what is hurting most.

headline: England Introduces New Coach
text: Fabio is the given name of the new coach of the English national team, and he is Italian. Not that there is anything wrong with that.

headline: Venezuelans Tried to Bribe Miami Man, U.S. Says
text: MIAMI  First came allegations of death threats and offers of financial support from Venezuela’s national oil company. Then on Monday, a new allegation: an attempt to bribe Guido Antonini Wilson, the man at the center of the international firestorm over a cash-stuffed suitcase.

headline: NASA Seeks Solutions for Technical Problems
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  NASA spent Tuesday troubleshooting problems in space and on the ground, with astronauts examining malfunctioning joints on the International Space Station and with engineers testing fuel tank sensors aboard the shuttle Atlantis sitting on its launch pad.

headline: Evidence in Hollywood Wiretapping Case Is Questioned
text: LOS ANGELES  Lawyers for defendants in the Anthony Pellicano wiretapping case argued in federal court here on Monday that evidence seized from the Hollywood private detective’s offices had been improperly obtained and should be tossed out.

headline: Troubled Manhattan Commercial College to Close
text: Interboro Institute, the fast-growing two-year commercial college in New York City that ran into problems with state regulators two years ago, will close on Friday because it cannot raise the money it needs to meet stiffer state requirements, according to a statement from its parent company on Monday.

headline: More Hiring and Advertising Ahead for Paul Campaign as the Donations Pour In
text: Flush with cash after another record fund-raising event, the campaign of Ron Paul said Monday that it was hiring more staff members, expanding its ground operations in early primary states, planning more advertising and looking ahead to competing in the contests on Feb. 5.

headline: 12 Killed in Pakistan Bombing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Twelve soldiers were killed Monday when a suicide bomber detonated explosives near a sports field used by the Pakistani Army in Kohat, a garrison town in North-West Frontier Province, military officials said. Four other soldiers were wounded in the attack.

headline: Saudi King Pardons Rape Victim Sentenced to Be Lashed, Saudi Paper Reports
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  King Abdullah has pardoned a woman who was sentenced to 200 lashes after pressing charges against seven men who raped her, a Saudi newspaper reported Monday.

headline: Public Land in Nevada
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Type of Coal Plant Moves Ahead, Haltingly
text: WASHINGTON  The nation’s leading effort to build a coal-fired electric plant that will capture and store its carbon emissions will take a shaky step forward on Tuesday, when the consortium building it announces a location for the $1.5 billion plant.

headline: Gays Living in Shadows of New Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  In a city and country where outsiders are viewed with deep suspicion and attracting attention can imperil one’s life, Mohammed could never blend in, even if he wanted to.

headline: 3 Apes Capering and a Juggler A-Leaping
text: “Area 51,” a new dance by Yvonne Meier and Aki Sasamoto, was a wittily imaginative exploration of how much can be communicated almost entirely by movement. The 50-minute piece ran out of steam about two-thirds of the way through, but until then, it was delicious.

headline: Healing: In I.C.U., Lack of Sleep Can Hurt Recovery
text: Patients in intensive care units are so busy being poked, prodded, jabbed and medicated that they rarely have time for something known to promote healing: sleep.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Blueprints column in Sunday Business this week, on the Square Feet page, was omitted in some editions. The column is available at nytimes.com/realestate/commercial.

headline: A Lawsuit Will Determine the Fate of 2 Picassos
text: You might begin by picturing a spring day in Berlin, two months after the rise of Adolf Hitler. It is late March 1933, and a man has called upon an art transporter, Gustav Knauer, to hire him for a job.

headline: With Regrets, New Orleans Is Left Behind
text: LAKE CHARLES, La.  With resignation, anger or stoicism, thousands of former New Orleanians forced out by Hurricane Katrina are settling in across the Gulf Coast, breaking their ties with the damaged city for which they still yearn.

headline: San Francisco’s Mayor Proposes Fee on Sales of Sugary Soft Drinks
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In a move he says is necessary to trim the city’s waistline, the decidedly slim mayor of San Francisco, Gavin Newsom, has proposed charging big stores a fee when they sell sugar-sweet soda.

headline: A Comet Is Missing, So Spacecraft Will Go to NASA’s Next Choice
text: In business, repurposing is all the rage. Take a product or service intended for one purpose and have it do something else.

headline: Singing Her Way From Obscurity to Fame on the Internet
text: Cinderella is alive and well and living on Staten Island.

headline: Some Old (Very Old) Christmas Favorites
text: Given the vast repertory composed to celebrate Christmas, it’s mystifying that such a tiny slice of it is heard year after year. Most ensembles stick to traditional carols, Handel’s “Messiah” or a few relevant Baroque works. But Christmas is also a time when early music specialists like Frederick Renz and his Early Music New York are in their element. Mr. Renz has always taken the view that forgotten favorites of Christmas past  long past  are worth revisiting, and he invariably assembles engaging, well-researched programs that lift the holiday out of the modern hyper-commercial world.

headline: Hazards: Football Head Injuries, Not So Cut and Dried
text: Those bone-jarring collisions on the football field that make fans wince and players tumble like rag dolls may not always be the real ones to worry about.

headline: Laws of Nature, Source Unknown
text: “Gravity,” goes the slogan on posters and bumper stickers. “It isn’t just a good idea. It’s the law.”

headline: Dancers Bring New Life to Scores Banned by Nazis
text: Much of the history of dance lies in the history of music. Now and again something happens to make us reconsider that history. One such event occurred over the weekend when, in a brilliantly enterprising program at the Juilliard School, the conductor James Conlon, the Juilliard Orchestra and Juilliard Dance presented three world premieres choreographed to long-forgotten scores, written from 1911 to 1935 by German composers whose work the Nazis had banned.

headline: Iraq Leaders Denounce Bombings by Turkey
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi leaders criticized Turkey on Monday for bombing Kurdish militants in northern Iraq with airstrikes that they said had left at least one woman dead.

headline: Keeper of an Unlikely Trove, Gutenberg to Warhol
text: NEWARK  It is difficult to say which is more surprising: that the Newark Public Library owns prints by Picasso and Rauschenberg, a page of the Gutenberg Bible and a 1493 printed tome known as the Nuremberg Chronicle, or that William J. Dane, a dapper, refreshingly irreverent art scholar from New Hampshire, has been tending to this astounding collection for six decades.

headline: As Ethanol Takes Its First Steps, Congress Proposes a Giant Leap
text: Congress is on the verge of writing into law one of the most ambitious dictates ever issued to American business: to create, from scratch, a huge new industry capable of converting agricultural wastes and other plant material into automotive fuel.

headline: Sequoyah High’s Success Energizes Tribe
text: TAHLEQUAH, Okla.  If not for basketball, Angel Goodrich and her school, Sequoyah High, would be as easy to overlook as the dusty farming towns that freckle northeast Oklahoma. Goodrich, a shy sliver of a guard, is the face of the Lady Indians, who are the three-time defending state champions in their classification and a rising force on the national scene.

headline: $7.4 Billion Pledged for Palestinians
text: PARIS  Eighty-seven countries and international organizations pledged $7.4 billion in aid to the Palestinians on Monday, in the most ambitious fund-raising effort in more than a decade to help Palestinians create a viable, peaceful and secure state of their own.

headline: Weak Eyes, Strong Eyes
text: Q. Most people I know believe that it’s better to order weaker glasses than were prescribed because the correct prescription weakens your eyes even more and results in your needing a stronger prescription down the line. Is that true?

headline: Lawyer in Pornography Case Is Spared Jail
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Heaping blame on a church in Greenwich for trying to hide the fact that its longtime musical director had child pornography on a computer, a senior federal judge on Monday sentenced a lawyer who took part in the cover-up to home confinement for six months.

headline: Long Island Couple Convicted of Enslaving 2 Domestic Workers for Years
text: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  The so-called Muttontown slave trial involved a wild barrage of testimony by two Indonesian domestic workers who were employed  and, prosecutors say, enslaved and tortured for years  by a well-to-do couple on Long Island. And the verdict Monday morning made for no less wild a scene.

headline: Iowa’s Undemocratic Caucuses
text: Des Moines

headline: The Hoops Star, the Movie Star and the Size 22 Feet
text: HAVING played professional basketball for 14 years in the National Basketball Association, I’ve spent a great deal of time on airplanes over the last three decades.

headline: Memo Pad
text: CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY AIR TRAVEL About the same number of people as last year, 47 million passengers, are expected to travel on domestic airlines during this Christmas holiday period, the Air Transport Association says. The four busiest air travel days in the period, which began last Thursday and continues through Jan 2, are expected to be, in decreasing order, Jan. 2, Dec. 21, Dec. 27, and Dec. 26. The least busy travel days are expected to be Christmas Day and Dec. 24, the airline trade group said.

headline: Secret War in the Skies Over Korea
text: The Korean War has been called “the forgotten war,” and “Missing in MIG Alley,” on PBS on Tuesday night, illustrates a little-known chapter. It describes the rivalry in the sky between two types of fighter jets then on the cutting edge of military aviation: the Soviet MIG-15, used by the North Koreans, and the F-86 Sabre, flown by the Americans and the British.

headline: Amid Strike, 2 NBC Hosts Will Return to the Air
text: NBC announced on Monday that its two late-night stars, Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien, would return on Jan. 2 even if the strike against networks and studios by writers was not resolved.

headline: Higher Wages at Harvard
text: To the Editor:

headline: Goldman Beats 4th Quarter Estimates
text: Goldman Sachs topped estimates for fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, rounding out another record year despite the turbulence in the financial markets.

headline: New Police Radio System in New York State Draws Scrutiny
text: A $2 billion emergency radio network intended to connect all emergency agencies and local police and fire departments in New York State has failed its first major test, prompting concerns from some state officials and causing the state’s second largest city, Buffalo, to opt out of the system.

headline: A Grandfather’s Suicide Bombing Puzzles Algerians
text: ALGIERS  As a suicide bomber, Rabah Bechla was most unusual. But the story of Mr. Bechla, a 63-year-old grandfather of seven who rammed an explosives-packed truck into a United Nations office here on Dec. 11, killing at least 17 people, is in many ways the story of Algeria itself.

headline: San Francisco Opera, Coming to Theaters
text: It’s an arms race out there in opera land.

headline: Chamber Works Conclude a Pianist’s Busy Weekend
text: A musician learning solo repertory might spend many hours perfecting a single phrase and years honing an interpretation. Chamber music needs similar dedication, and as in any burgeoning relationship, new musical partners need time to discover each other’s quirks.

headline: Signs of TB in Ancient Skull Support Theory on Vitamin D
text: In the disease-scarred bones of a Homo erectus from Turkey, scientists have found evidence of a peril that human ancestors encountered in their migrations out of Africa: tuberculosis.

headline: Tests Negative on L.I. Man Whose Relatives Had Avian Flu
text: Avian flu in Pakistan nearly touched the United States this month when a 38-year-old Nassau County resident returned from visiting family members who were later confirmed to be part of Pakistan’s first cluster of human infections.

headline: Newborn Found in Queens Trash Bin
text: A newborn girl was found Monday night  one of the coldest nights so far this year  in a commercial trash bin in Queens, the police said. She was wrapped in a blanket and stuffed in a paper bag.

headline: A Clearer Muddy Story: Fast-Flowing Water Can Form Deposits
text: Much of the earth is little more than glorified mud. That is, something like two-thirds of the sedimentary rock at or near the earth’s surface is mudstone, shale or other rock formed by the deposition of clays and other fine particles.

headline: Airlines to Use Courts to Thwart a Movement
text: DOMESTIC airlines are not happy about a New York State law, the first of its kind, that will require airlines to provide certain services to passengers who sit for three hours or more on airplanes stuck on the tarmac.

headline: For Sports Fans, a Season of Foul Play
text: The sports world is giving New Yorkers more than their usual quotient of agita, and that includes people who think a full-court press is a legal maneuver and a hat trick part of David Copperfield’s act.

headline: A New Deal to Develop Ground Zero
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to approve a deal Tuesday that would bring an international shopping center operator back to ground zero to help build retail space in the buildings and tunnels under construction on the 16-acre site.

headline: Week’s Best
text: PLAYER Paolo Maldini, 39, who won his third FIFA Club World Cup with A.C. Milan on Sunday in a 4-2 victory against Boca Juniors in Japan, said he would retire at the end of the Italian season in June. Maldini, who has played for Milan since the 1984-85 season, has won many major titles with the club, including seven Serie A titles and five European Champions League titles.

headline: House Passes Sprawling Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON  The House approved a sprawling $516 billion budget bill Monday night in an effort to end a spending standoff with President Bush and free money that federal agencies have been awaiting since Oct. 1.

headline: Putin Agrees to Be Protégé’s Prime Minister
text: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin formally declared Monday that he intended to become prime minister next year, all but ensuring his dominance of the Russian government even after his term ends.

headline: Bank Robbed Twice, Maybe by Same Man
text: A man who robbed a bank in Brooklyn on Monday morning may have not only returned to the scene of the crime, but he may also have robbed it again.

headline: Brought on by Darkness, Disorder Needs Light
text: In a few days, the winter solstice will plunge us into the longest and darkest night of the year. Is it any surprise that we humans respond with a holiday season of relentless cheer and partying?

headline: Start-Up Sells Solar Panels at Lower-Than-Usual Cost
text: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Nanosolar, a heavily financed Silicon Valley start-up whose backers include Google’s co-founders, plans to announce Tuesday that it has begun selling its innovative solar panels, which are made using a technique that is being held out as the future of solar power manufacturing.

headline: Rethinking Afghanistan: Were We Sidetracked in Iraq?
text: To the Editor:

headline: F.C.C. Eases Media Ownership Rule
text: WASHINGTON  By the narrowest of margins, the Federal Communications Commission adopted proposals by its chairman to tighten the reins on the cable television industry while loosening 32-year-old restrictions that have prevented a company from owning both a newspaper and a television or radio station in the same city.

headline: Iran Receives Nuclear Fuel in Blow to U.S.
text: WASHINGTON  The United States lost a long battle when Russia, as it announced on Monday, delivered nuclear fuel to an Iranian power plant that is at the center of an international dispute over its nuclear program. Iran, for its part, confirmed on Monday plans to build a second such plant.

headline: Bus and Subway Service Improvements Planned
text: To sweeten the pill of a proposed fare increase, New York City Transit said on Monday that it was planning a series of subway and bus service improvements that would go into effect in the second half of next year.

headline: Kyrgyzstan: On the Path to a One-Party State
text: With 95 percent of the ballots counted, the Ak Zhol party of President Kurmanbek Bakiyev had captured 49 percent of the votes in the parliamentary elections on Sunday, while the second-place finisher, the opposition party Ata Meken, had 9 percent. But under Kyrgyzstan’s election rules, parties must surmount two electoral barriers in order to enter Parliament: support from 5 percent of the country’s 2.7 million registered voters, and 0.5 percent of the total electorate in each of the country’s nine voting regions. As of Monday, just one party of the 12 running had qualified for any seats in Parliament  the president’s.

headline: Holiday Specials
text: For anyone who has to travel for work while everyone else is celebrating the holiday season, there is a silver lining: hotels that cater to business travelers are charging deeply discounted rates.

headline: The Mourning After
text: London

headline: Ingersoll to Buy Climate Control Maker
text: Ingersoll-Rand, the industrial conglomerate, agreed on Monday to buy Trane, the air-conditioning company that is the successor to American Standard, for $10.1 billion.

headline: The Claim: A Little Alcohol Can Help You Beat a Cold
text: THE FACTS

headline: Petrino’s Departure Is Particularly Disturbing
text: The last several months have seen a brutal assault on our faith in the redemptive power of sport. Michael Vick. Marion Jones. Madison Square Garden. The Tour de France. Last week, the Mitchell report named names and soiled reputations.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING | MIDDLE EAST; Lebanon: Presidential Vote Postponed Again
text: The Syrian-backed opposition boycotted a vote to elect a new president, delaying Parliament’s decision for the ninth time. The election is now scheduled for Saturday. The presidency has been vacant since Nov. 23.

headline: Teenage Risks, and How to Avoid Them
text: Last January in Freehold Township, N.J., a car driven by a 17-year-old high school student, with two fellow students as passengers, passed a car being driven by another teenager at 70 miles an hour in a 50-mile zone. The passing vehicle crashed into an oncoming van. Three boys and the 68-year-old van driver were killed.

headline: New Paths to Stem Cells (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Scholastic Plans to Put Its Branding Iron on a Successor to Harry Potter
text: With the Harry Potter series now completed, Scholastic, the United States publisher of those wildly successful books by J. K. Rowling, is moving forward with what it hopes will be its follow-up blockbuster series.

headline: Bernstein Returns in the Form of Festival
text: Leonard Bernstein, once a prominent presence on New York's music scene in the era of student protest, black-and-white television and classical music's cultural relevance, will once again loom large in the city.

headline: Democrats Delay a Vote on Immunity for Wiretaps
text: WASHINGTON  In a setback for the White House, Senate Democrats on Monday put off until at least next month any decision on whether to give legal protection to the phone carriers that helped with the National Security Agency’s eavesdropping program.

headline: Housing Starts Decline 3.7%
text: The housing market, in its deepest rut since the early 1990s, showed little sign of stabilization in November, and economists expect conditions to worsen in the near term.

headline: Knicks’ Ugly Night Capped by Coach’s Frank Words
text: Isiah Thomas seemingly has a built-in mute button that self-activates every time he feels the impulse to blast his players. The device either went dead or shorted out Monday night after Thomas again watched his team collapse.

headline: Britain: Data on Would-Be Drivers Lost in U.S.
text: The transport minister, Ruth Kelly, left, told Parliament that personal information on three million candidates for British driver’s licenses was missing after an Iowa subsidiary of the government contractor for the written part of the learner’s permit test mislaid a computer hard drive. No financial information was among the details. The disclosure was the latest in a series of blunders involving data submitted to government departments, including the loss in the mail in October of two computer disks carrying confidential data, including bank details, on 25 million people in families receiving government child benefits. Banks have found no evidence of fraud from that loss, according to the finance minister, Alistair Darling. Ms. Kelly said that the drivers’ data had been specially formatted for the Iowa subsidiary of Pearson Driving Assessments Ltd., a contractor of the Driving Standards Agency, and that it was not “readily usable” by outsiders.

headline: Coughlin Tells Giants It Is Time to Refocus
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tom Coughlin’s face is so telling that it may as well be made of neon. Coughlin, the Giants’ coach, does not mask his emotions well, and usually does not care to. In that way, he is a refreshing presence in an N.F.L. coaching fraternity increasingly adept at providing bland answers and calculated personas.

headline: Going Public Caps Dream for a Maker of Software
text: SAN MATEO, Calif.  If the initial public offering for NetSuite shares goes as planned later this week, Evan Goldberg will have come a long way from the overcrowded Silicon Valley apartment that served as the company’s first office nearly 10 years ago.

headline: Bold Escape Not First Try for Inmate
text: ELIZABETH, N.J.  There was a gnawing familiarity to the daring weekend escape of two inmates from the most secure part of the Union County jail.

headline: Fashion and Faith Meet, on Foreheads of the Pious
text: CAIRO  There is a strong undercurrent of competition in Egypt these days, an unstated contest among people eager to prove just how religious they are. The field of battle is the street and the focus tends to be on appearance, as opposed to conviction.

headline: A Recruit for Tintin
text: Andy Serkis, who provided the human expression and movements for the computer-generated characters in two Peter Jackson projects  he was Gollum in the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy and the giant ape in “King Kong”  will reunite with Mr. Jackson in the DreamWorks trilogy “Tintin,” Reuters reported. Although DreamWorks offered no confirmation, it was believed that Mr. Serkis, above, will play Captain Haddock, a temperamental seafarer, in the adaptation of the comic strip created by Hergé (1907-83) and dealing with the adventures of the young reporter Tintin. Steven Spielberg and Mr. Jackson will each direct one film; the third director is to be determined.

headline: A True Outsider Joins Michigan’s Ranks
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  So much for the idea that only a Michigan man can coach at the University of Michigan.

headline: Corzine Signs Bill Ending Executions, Then Commutes Sentences of Eight
text: TRENTON  Few other issues have prompted the kind of intensity and conviction that Gov. Jon S. Corzine shows when he talks about preventing even one more execution.

headline: California Moves Closer to Expanding Health Care
text: SACRAMENTO  California moved significantly closer to enacting a broad expansion of health insurance coverage on Monday when the Democratic-controlled Assembly passed legislation that has the backing of the Republican governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger.

headline: St.Clair Bourne, Filmmaker, Dies at 64
text: St.Clair Bourne, a documentary filmmaker who recorded American black culture, produced portraits of eminent African-Americans and, in one stark film, drew a parallel between the civil rights movement and the “troubles” in Northern Ireland, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 64 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: Belgium: Loser to Lead Interim Government
text: After a meeting with King Albert II, Guy Verhofstadt, left, the liberal ousted by voters in June, accepted the job of forming and leading an interim government because of the ”gravity of the situation in which our country finds itself.” But he said he did not want to remain in power beyond March. Mr. Verhofstadt, who had been prime minister since 1999, conceded defeat after the June election but has stayed on because the conservatives who won proved unable to form a coalition. But he has lacked power to act on major issues, and on Saturday thousands of union members marched through Brussels to protest the half-year political impasse and rising fuel and food prices. At the heart of the deadlock are disputes among parties from Dutch-speaking Flanders and the French-speaking area, Wallonia. Those tensions engulfed even the country’s annual beauty pageant on Saturday, when the new Miss Belgium, Alizée Poulicek, a blond 20-year-old from the French-speaking part of the country, was booed when she disclosed that she could not speak Dutch. The contest was held in Antwerp, a stronghold of Flemish nationalism, before an audience of 3,500. Ms. Poulicek, who besides French speaks English and Czech, told the Flemish television broadcaster VRT that she would try to learn more Dutch.

headline: The Second Avenue Deli, Now in Midtown, Reopens
text: The clear matzo ball soup was the same, the blue and brown tile floors were the same, even much of the kitchen staff was the same.

headline: Survivor Lifts CBS
text: Todd Herzog, above, a 22-year-old flight attendant from Utah, became the latest champion of the “Survivor” series on Sunday as the final episode of the show’s 15th edition gave CBS a modest boost in the ratings. Attracting 15.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., the “Survivor: China” finale achieved ratings slightly better than the show’s average this season, Nielsen estimated. Compared with last fall’s “Cook Islands” finale, however, Sunday’s finale was down more than 10 percent among adults 18 to 49. CBS averaged the most viewers for the night, although the network did rank second at 10 with its “Survivor: China” reunion special (12.2 million), which trailed NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” coverage. NBC and Fox shared second place for the night, but Fox led over all among the 18-to-49 set, largely because of an overrun of its afternoon football coverage, which delivered more than 21 million viewers as prime time began at 7 p.m. A new episode of “The Simpsons” (10.1 million) also put Fox on top at 8 p.m. among adults 18 to 49. ABC was fourth for the night with a lineup of repeats after “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (11.8 million).

headline: Food and Fuel Compete for Land
text: Shopping at a Whole Foods Market in suburban Chicago, Meredith Estes said food prices have jumped so much she has resorted to coupons. Charles T. Rodgers Jr., an Arkansas cattle rancher, said normal feed rations so expensive and scarce he is scrambling for alternatives. In Oregon, Jack Joyce, the owner of Rogue Ales, said the cost of barley malt has soared 88 percent this year.

headline: Boy, 9, Dies in Staten Island House Fire
text: A 9-year-old Staten Island boy died Monday after a fire raced through his family’s home in Prince’s Bay, despite desperate rescue attempts by his father, firefighters and several neighbors.

headline: The Obama-Clinton Issue
text: Hillary Clinton has been a much better senator than Barack Obama. She has been a serious, substantive lawmaker who has worked effectively across party lines. Obama has some accomplishments under his belt, but many of his colleagues believe that he has not bothered to master the intricacies of legislation or the maze of Senate rules. He talks about independence, but he has never quite bucked liberal orthodoxy or party discipline.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Zoologist Gives a Voice to Big Cats in the Wilderness
text: Among zoologists, Alan Rabinowitz is known as the Indiana Jones of wildlife conservation. But he is actually more the Dag Hammarskjold of biology.

headline: California Moves Toward Universal Health Care
text: SACRAMENTO  California moved significantly closer to enacting a broad expansion of health insurance coverage Monday when the Democratic-controlled Assembly passed legislation that has the backing of the Republican governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger.

headline: Wanted: A Defender of the Census
text: At a confirmation hearing this afternoon, senators will question Steve H. Murdock, President Bush’s nominee to be the next director of the Census Bureau. Mr. Murdock, the official state demographer of Texas, has impressive academic and professional credentials and a reputation for integrity and objectivity. What the senators will most need to figure out is if Mr. Murdock also has the political fortitude for the job.

headline: White House Visitor Logs Are Public, Judge Rules
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled Monday that White House visitor logs were public records and ordered the Bush administration to stop withholding them from scrutiny by outside groups.

headline: Darwin’s Era, Modern Themes: Science, Faith and Publication
text: Given the furor he feared it would unleash, it is not surprising that Charles Darwin sat on his “great idea,” refusing to publish “The Origin of Species” until 1859, more than 20 years after he first devised the theory of evolution.

headline: Insouciance Recaptured
text: Isabelle Dinoire, the Frenchwoman who received the world’s first partial face transplant, regained nearly full use of her facial muscles within 18 months and is “satisfied with the aesthetic result,” according to her surgeon.

headline: South Africa: Two-Man Fight on for Tuesday
text: Delegates of the governing African National Congress scheduled the election of party president for Tuesday, ending two days of partisan warfare between supporters of the only candidates to be voted on, Thabo Mbeki, the current party leader and president of the country, and his onetime government deputy, Jacob Zuma. The delegates at the party conference in Polokwane nominated the two and scheduled the vote after agreeing on restrictions on the balloting, including a ban on electronic voting. Mr. Zuma’s supporters argued that anything but ballots counted by hand would open the bitterly fought election to fraud. Mr. Mbeki, who is seeking a third term as the party’s president, appears to trail Mr. Zuma.

headline: Senior Executive of Fidelity to Lead Morgan Stanley Unit
text: Morgan Stanley said on Monday that it had hired a senior executive from Fidelity Investments to lead its retail brokerage division. The executive, Ellyn A. McColgan, will take over from James P. Gorman, the former Merrill Lynch executive who currently heads the retail unit.

headline: New DVDs
text: TWO-LANE BLACKTOP

headline: Fair Pay for Judges
text: The rancid political quagmire that is Albany these days produced a rare breakthrough last week on a matter of great importance to New York’s justice system  a pay raise for judges. There is at last a chance that the state’s woefully underpaid judiciary will get a raise this year. But that will require Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, to step up and make it happen.

headline: Footnotes
text: La Scala’s opening night performance of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde,” directed by Patrice Chéreau and led by Daniel Barenboim, will be shown at theaters across the United States and abroad by Emerging Pictures, beginning on Jan. 27 at Symphony Space. ... Mamie Gummer, Kristine Nielsen, Benjamin Walker, Rosie Benton and Derek Cecil have joined Laura Linney and Ben Daniels in the cast of the Roundabout Theater Company production of “Les Liaisons Dangereuses,” beginning previews on April 11 at the American Airlines Theater. ... Ann Hampton Callaway will appear Tuesday night through Monday in her new holiday show at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola.

headline: A Spotlight on Anesthesia (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: BioShock Triumphs at TV Video Game Awards
text: BioShock, the moody, elegant adventure from Take-Two, continued its romp through the year-end video game awards season on Monday as it took the top prize in the awards presented by the G4 television network.

headline: Patterns: In the Upper Great Plains, Lower Mortality Rates
text: Minnesota is to die for  unless you are in a hurry to expire.

headline: Obama and Edwards Engage, Gently, on Special Interests
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa  Senator Barack Obama and former Senator John Edwards, two Democratic presidential candidates courting many of the same undecided Iowa voters, added to their efforts Monday to distinguish between each other on the issue of reducing special-interest influence in Washington.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,883 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: WORLD BRIEFING | EUROPE; Greece: Labor Minister Fired
text: The government appointed a new labor and welfare minister after dismissing her predecessor over the weekend after a series of scandals that included an accusation that he illegally employed foreign workers. Fanni Palli-Petralia, a former tourism minister, replaces Vassilis Magginas, who held the post for just seven months. He had been under attack over the government’s plan to overhaul the troubled social security system. Unions have been staging strikes in opposition to the plan.

headline: Iran Suggests It Is Building 2nd Nuclear Plant
text: TEHRAN, Dec. 17  Iran confirmed Monday that it had received the first fuel shipment for its nuclear power plant at Bushehr, but also indicated for the first time that it was building a second nuclear power plant.

headline: After Latest Incident, Isles’ Simon to Get Help
text: SYOSSET, N.Y.  A black stocking cap pulled low on his shaved head, the troubled Islanders forward Chris Simon silently walked out of the team’s practice facility Monday. It is uncertain when  or even if  Simon will return to the team.

headline: In a Thickly Textured Maelstrom, Nothing’s Left to Chance
text: Dillinger Escape Plan’s music is arranged down to the millisecond and always has been. But watching its shows is like cranking the handle on a jack-in-the-box. You know what’s coming, but you’re startled anyway, and then you do it again.

headline: Rayovac Batteries in a Partnership With the World of Disney Characters
text: BEWARE, Energizer bunny, wherever you are. Some familiar Disney characters are leading an assault by a rival brand on the battery market.

headline: A Big Gift for the Met: The Arbus Archives
text: Two years ago gallerygoers had a chance to discover the personal side of Diane Arbus in a retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In addition to the portraits that made her famous  powerfully unsettling photographs of dwarfs, transvestites and everyday people  the Met filled librarylike rooms with her photographic equipment, pages from her diaries, books from her home and studio and family pictures.

headline: Questions on Illegal Immigrants Lead to Raid on Nonprofit’s Office
text: NEW HAVEN  As Connecticut grapples with the remnants of a weekend storm and shivers in sub-freezing temperatures, a nonprofit group that helps many poor residents pay their heating bills is reeling after federal agents raided its offices on Thursday.

headline: Tinsley Is More Careful Since Escaping Attack
text: Indiana Pacers guard Jamaal Tinsley knows he is a lucky man. He knows that only a few inches separated him from a terrible fate. Less than two weeks after the former Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor was shot and killed by an intruder in his home, Tinsley’s car was sprayed with bullets from an assault rifle outside an Indianapolis hotel.

headline: Overhaul Proposed in Accounting Standards Board
text: The Financial Accounting Foundation, the body that decides who will set accounting rules in the United States, plans on Tuesday to propose an overhaul aimed at enabling the Financial Accounting Standards Board to act faster while increasing the power of its chairman, Robert H. Herz.

headline: Real-Life Superheroes to a Bunch of Comics Geeks
text: At a recent performance of “Comic Book Club,” a weekly stage talk show at the People’s Improv Theater in Chelsea, an audience member declined to give his name. “I have family and friends,” he explained. “I’m a closeted geek.”

headline: 31 Accused in Florida of Falsifying Home Loans
text: MIAMI  Federal prosecutors on Monday announced the indictment of 31 people in connection with a mortgage fraud scheme involving at least 28 properties in South Florida and fraudulent loans totaling more than $14.2 million.

headline: Reggae Honors for Marley Family
text: Dead more than 26 years, Bob Marley still casts a spell, topping Billboard’s year-end ranking of top reggae albums, Reuters reported. Not only did he occupy the first, ninth and tenth places, but his sons, Stephen and Damian Marley, have captured the No. 2 and No. 3 positions on the chart. The senior Marley took first place with “Forever Bob Marley” (Madacy Special Products/Madacy), above, a collection of songs from his pre-Island Records days; and Bob Marley & the Wailers had the No. 9 and No. 10 best sellers with “Africa United: The Singles Collection” (Tuff Gong/Island/UMe/IDJMG) and “Gold” (Tuff Gong/Island/Chronicles/UMe). Stephen Marley finished just behind his father with “Mind Control” (Ghetto Youths/Tuff Gong/Universal Republic/ URMG), followed by Damian Marley with “Welcome to Jamrock” on the same label. The brothers also took third and fourth place on Billboard’s year-end list of top reggae artists, headed for the second consecutive year by Matisyahu, a New Yorker who attracts fans with his mix of hip-hop and reggae and lyrics about his Hasidic Jewish background.

headline: The Cruelty in Bull Riding
text: To the Editor:

headline: House Passes Sweeping Energy Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Legislation that will slowly but fundamentally change the cars Americans drive, the fuel they burn, the way they light their homes and the price they pay for food cleared the House on Tuesday by a large margin. President Bush said he would sign the hard-fought energy bill on Wednesday.

headline: Romney Takes On a Rising Huckabee, Comparing Records
text: This television advertisement for Mitt Romney, his second going after his Republican rival Mike Huckabee, will start running in Iowa on Tuesday.

headline: E.C.B. Makes $500 Billion Infusion
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank on Tuesday pumped 348 billion euros ($500 billion) into the financial system, easing conditions in credit markets grappling with both a global lending squeeze linked to the United States housing downturn and traditional year-end demands for cash.

headline: Campaign Song 2008? Strike Up the Broadband
text: Already, the influence of the Internet and new media has been felt on the national political scene  from the success of Barack Obama in raising large amounts of money from small donors over the Web, to the George Allen “Macaca” clip posted on YouTube, which played a key role in his losing his Senate seat in 2006, thereby helping turn over control of the Senate to the Democrats. In his lively new book, “The First Campaign: Globalization, the Web and the Race for the White House,” Garrett M. Graff  the founding editor of the blog FishbowlDC.com and editor at large of Washingtonian magazine  asks how the technology that is transforming the global economy is going to affect the “first campaign of the new age.”

headline: Mitchell Report Revealed Little Original Work
text: Roger Clemens is the highlight of the Mitchell report, but the most glaring aspect of the deficient report, to this reader, is how poor a job Mitchell and his investigators did investigating the use of steroids in baseball during the last decade or two.

headline: India’s Automaker of Many Faces May Land Jaguar
text: The luxury brand Jaguar is poised to join Tata Motors, a widely diverse Indian auto company that makes tractor-trailers, full-size S.U.V.’s and the world’s cheapest car.

headline: Straussian Summit Meeting of Sopranos
text: CHICAGO  Every new production of Strauss’s “Frau Ohne Schatten” is a newsworthy event. Of all the Strauss operas, this fantastical, strange and humane fairy tale, first presented in Vienna in 1919, is the longest, the most musically elaborate, the most philosophically resonant and the most daunting to stage.

headline: British Writers Campaign for Literacy
text: More than 500 authors, including Ian Rankin, Nick Hornby, Jackie Collins and Andrew Motion, Britain’s poet laureate, have appealed to Prime Minister Gordon Brown to confront childhood illiteracy, the BBC reported. Their letter, citing official statistics showing that one-fifth of 11-year-olds leaving primary school are unable to read to the minimum standard for their age group, called for reading to be taught for an hour a day and added that “no child should be left behind.” Delivered to Downing Street by some of the 545 signatories, the letter said in part: “As authors, we are deeply concerned at the low levels of childhood literacy across Britain. In a complex world, reading has become increasingly important  if not crucial.” A government spokesman said there was a commitment to bring a “sharper focus” to the basics of reading.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Judge Orders Hearing on C.I.A. Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Tuesday ordered a hearing into whether the Central Intelligence Agency’s destruction of interrogation videotapes in 2005 violated his order that summer to preserve evidence in a lawsuit brought on behalf of 16 prisoners held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Cosmic Clash
text: Astronomers have released an image of what looks like galactic warfare. In a symphony of X-rays (purple), radio waves (blue) and starlight (red), the composite image shows a jet of energy shooting out of a galaxy and hitting its neighbor to the right before splattering into intergalactic space.

headline: Trainer’s Steroid Testimony Followed Deal With Prosecutors
text: Brian McNamee, the former Yankees strength coach who says he injected pitcher Roger Clemens with steroids and human growth hormone, signed a proffer agreement with federal prosecutors last summer, McNamee’s lawyer said Monday.

headline: New Fraud Inquiry May Complicate South Korean Election
text: SEOUL, South Korea  What had appeared to be a one-horse race for the presidential election in South Korea turned less predictable on Monday when Parliament voted to open an independent investigation into accusations of fraud against Lee Myung-bak, the front-runner and candidate of the opposition Grand National Party.

headline: Princeton Student Admits Faking Attack
text: A Princeton University junior who claimed to have been beaten by two men in black ski caps for his conservative views admitted on Monday that he made up the attack, according to Princeton Township police officials.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Sunday about Bush administration concern over the prospect of failure in the war against the Taliban and Al Qaeda in Afghanistan misidentified, in some copies, the soldiers shown on a recent search for weapons near the Afghan village of Espondi. They were Afghan soldiers, not members of the 82nd Airborne Division. (Go to Article)

headline: Israeli Airstrike Kills a Top Militant in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  An Israeli airstrike on Monday night killed a senior Islamic Jihad commander and his aide as they drove in a car through northern Gaza City, according to Islamic Jihad radio and the Israeli Army.

headline: After Legal Odyssey, Homecoming Show for Looted Antiquities
text: ROME  In Greek, the word nostos means homecoming; the plural is nostoi. Hence the title of an exhibition that Italy has organized to trumpet the return of dozens of ancient artifacts that until recently adorned showcases in American museums and private galleries.

headline: Statement Hints at Castro’s Retirement
text: MEXICO CITY  Fidel Castro indicated Monday in a statement read on state television that he was willing to hand over the reins of Cuba’s government to a younger generation of leaders. But his statement remained silent on whether he was speaking hypothetically or had a transition plan in mind.

headline: Real Winter
text: When the snow stopped falling here in the Northeast, it was like looking out upon a collective memory of winters past  farther past than last winter, that is, when crocuses were pushing out of the earth in early January. It was hardly a surprising storm, yet it demonstrated how easily our idea of normal can be subverted. We are every bit as mercurial as the weather itself.

headline: McCain Senses Momentum Is Starting to Help Him
text: CONCORD, N.H.  Seeking to capitalize on a series of highly sought newspaper endorsements, Senator John McCain is strongly pushing to attract independent voters who helped drive his victory here eight years ago.

headline: First Litmus Test on Drug Involvement for Clemens
text: It will be more than five years until Hall of Fame voters weigh in on whether accusations of steroid use have tainted Roger Clemens’s career. But Clemens will get an early referendum on where he stands from six high school coaches in Texas.

headline: Blazing Arizona
text: On Jan. 1, Arizona intends to become the first state to try to muscle its way out of its immigration problems on its own. That is when, barring a last-minute setback in court, it is to begin enforcing a new state law that harshly punishes businesses that knowingly hire undocumented immigrants. It is a two-strike law, suspending a business’s license on the first offense and revoking it on the second. It is the strictest workplace-enforcement law in the country.

headline: English Arts Council Gives and Takes
text: Nearly 200 arts organizations across England are being informed that beginning in April they will no longer receive financing from Arts Council England as it imposes its biggest cuts since its establishment 50 years ago, The Guardian of London reported on Monday. But of the 990 organizations that receive money from the $2 billion available to the council, three-quarters will receive increases to match or exceed inflation, and about 80 groups are being added to the roster of recipients. The Royal Opera House and the Royal Shakespeare Company will receive increases to match inflation. Among those told to expect an end to financing are two chamber orchestras, the City of London Sinfonia and the London Mozart Players. The Pop-Up Theater company for children, based in London and in business for more than 25 years, has been told that it is likely to lose its $392,000 grant. Admitting that the holiday-season timing was bad, the Arts Council said “tough decisions” had to be made. Louise Wylie, its spokeswoman, said the criteria for financing included breadth of audience and excellence of work. Peter Hewitt, the chief executive of the Arts Council, told Arts Industry magazine, “Yes, some organizations will be unhappy with our decisions, but the majority will have a stronger, better future.” Organizations facing reduction or withdrawal of their grants have an opportunity to appeal.

headline: Growing Pains: Many Parents Fail to See Obesity in Children
text: When researchers from the University of Michigan surveyed more than 2,000 parents about their children’s health, they heard some good news. Despite the growing obesity problem, many of these parents could report that their sons and daughters, at least, were “about the right weight.”

headline: Floyd Red Crow Westerman, 71, an Actor, Is Dead
text: Floyd Red Crow Westerman, who used his talents as an actor, singer and songwriter to advance the cause of Native American rights and become one of the more famous Indian faces, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 71.

headline: World Food Supply Is Shrinking, U.N. Agency Warns

text: Loews‘ plan to exit the cigarette business by spinning off its Lorillard Tobacco unit pleased but did not entirely surprise investors since Loews, a diversified conglomerate which was built by the brothers Laurence and Preston Robert Tisch, and is now run by Laurence’s son James, has been divesting itself of its stake in Lorillard over the years. The Tisch family continues to control Loews.

headline: Seeking Ideas for Gift Giving Fatigue
text: A few weeks ago, my cousin sent me an e-mail saying she was in the midst of a moratorium on shopping. Then last week, she e-mailed me a video made by international sustainability expert, Ann Leonard called “The Story of Stuff,” which provides some of the reasons (environmental sustainability, wastefulness, exploitation of low-wage workers to name just a few), for her anti-consumption stance. I watched the video this morning and while I’m not sure I can go cold turkey on all shopping, I do expect that I will be thinking twice about how much stuff I can really acquire and whether there are gifts I can give to others that won’t contribute to the piles of clutter so many of us are surrounded by these days.

headline: Tuesday’s Links: Vikings in Hunt, Bears in Hibernation

The Vikings, who have teams breathing down their necks in the N.F.C. wild-card race, rallied for their fifth straight victory, beating the Bears by 20-13. The loss eliminated the Bears from playoff contention, continuing the strange trend of Super Bowl teams not making the playoffs the following season.

headline: New Year’s Eve and Beyond in New York
text: My wife and I are making our first visit to NY to celebrate my 60th birthday. We arrive on New Year’s Eve afternoon from England and will be staying for 7 days. Obviously, we will read guide books and will make some of the usual main tourist visits but I am wondering if there are any “off the beaten track” places that you would recommend. headline: Do His Doctors Know?
text: WATERLOO, Iowa — Bill Clinton and Magic Johnson were about half an hour late to their rally here at the Boys & Girls Club, and Mr. Clinton just explained why.

headline: Revealing Sources | London’s Top Ornament Shops
text: (Coppi Barbieri)

headline: Keeping Students Away from the Polls
text: The campaigns of fear and intimidation that once kept black voters from casting ballots didn’t end when Congress passed the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Candidates Rockin’ the Gadgets
text: The candidates shared their favorite electronic gadgets with The Associated Press. From their responses, it’s evident that these are all people constantly on the move.

headline: Object-Oriented Objects at N.Y.U.
text: Yesterday I met Momo. It was about a foot tall, pear shaped, and wearing a woolly ski mask over its cardboard frame. As I carried it around a crowded room it kept leaning to point east. It was telling me the direction to Tompkins Square Park. Under its fuzzy skin was a G.P.S. navigation system and various motors.

headline: Beware the Fixed-Gear Bike-Riding Salmon From New Jersey
text: What we’re reading elsewhere…

headline: Ethanol and the Energy Bill
text: The House just passed the latest and not-so-greatest version of the energy bill, which passed in the Senate last week after some major revisions; the President is expected to sign on Wednesday. So far, much of the talk has centered on the higher fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks. But lost in the dialogue are measures to increase ethanol production by a huge amount.

headline: Tyco, Redux
text: Talk about rolling the dice.

headline: Dumbo Is Now Protected as a Historic District
text: Like SoHo and TriBeCa before it, Dumbo has now made its way from neighborhood acronym to historic treasure. Dumbo — the name once stood for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass but now hardly requires an explanation — was designated New York City’s 90th historic district by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. (The first historic district, designated in 1965, was Brooklyn Heights.)The new historic district is bounded by John Street to the north, York Street to the south, Main Street to the west and Bridge Street to the east, and includes 91 buildings that reflect the industrial heritage of the Brooklyn waterfront.

headline: Good News (And a New Voice) For NBC
text: “NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams” was the top-rated evening newscast last week, beating ABC’s “World News With Charles Gibson” by nearly half a million viewers, Nielsen Media Research reported.

headline: Guards Shoot Dog at Baghdad Bureau
text: Investigators from the State Department have made two visits to The New York Times’s news bureau in Baghdad as they look into the shooting of one of the bureau’s dogs by Blackwater bodyguards last week.

headline: D.C.’s Latest Verb: To Be Larry Craiged
text: Washington, D.C. likes its eponyms — taking the names of people in the news and giving them to something larger. And Washington being Washington, it’s often something negative.

headline: Chris Simon and a Rude Awakening in the Bunker
text: The morning ritual, for the most part, is the same. I wake up around 5:30, check on the coffee pot and then check again to make certain I am awake.

headline: The Candidates on Climate Change
text: Wonder where Rudolph W. Giuliani stands on global warming? Need to know how John Edwards feels about emissions caps? Curious about Hillary Rodham Clinton and climate change?

headline: Achatz Is Cancer Free
text: It was stunning to hear this summer that Grant Achatz of Alinea in Chicago, one of the most acclaimed chefs in the country, had cancer of the mouth. Today, in a statement released by his publicist, he had better news:

headline: Red Bulls Get Their Man
text: Juan Carlos Osorio said Tuesday he had landed his dream job. The New York Red Bulls said they have landed their dream coach. But as so many others have found, the mystical force that seems to surround the MetroStars/Red Bulls has often turned those dreams into night terrors.

headline: Aiming to Put More Carts and Better Food on the Streets
text: Adhering to the philosophy that an apple a day may help keep the doctor away, city officials are trying to increase the availability of fresh fruits and vegetables in poor and minority neighborhoods through a sharp increase in vending carts, which they hope will combat the city’s obesity epidemic.The proposal, introduced by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, calls for 1,500 new permits for fruit and vegetable carts in neighborhoods where consumption of fruits and vegetables is low. Currently, fewer than 10 percent of the 4,100 mobile food carts serve fruits and vegetables. (About half serve processed foods like kabobs and gyros, while most of the remaining serve things like coffee and pretzels.)

headline: France’s New Old Way of Limiting CO2
text: PARIS — France has come up with an ingenious way to get consumers to buy more fuel-efficient cars: by giving a rebate to high-mileage cars and charging a surtax on gas hogs. The system is called a “bonus-malus” approach, such as exists in auto insurance. Translated from the Latin, it is a Peter-Paul approach, in which the state robs Peter of 2,600 euros ($3,800) when he buys a Porsche Cayenne Turbo and pays Paul 700 euros ($1,025) when he buys a Mini Cooper D.

headline: Rangers-Pens Pregame: For Jagr, a New Center and New Teeth
text: Among the new things you will see in the Rangers’ game tonight against the Penguins: a new set of front teeth for Jaromir Jagr, who had them knocked out (again) against Phoenix. He smiled to show them off outside the locker room at Madison Square Garden before the game when asked if he had been to the dentist. “They love me there,” he said.

headline: Smoking May Be Hazardous to Your Bar
text: When the undercover investigator walked into the Hill Tap Tavern in Elmhurst, Queens, on Monday, he saw a customer smoking at the bar, according to his report. What happened next left the bar owner facing a charge that could put him in prison for up to seven years.

headline: Diane Arbus: Same Photos, Different Frame
text: The sprawling sorority of sexy, groovy, broad-minded photographers who make their names taking pictures of fat, old, garish and parochial people is … annoying.

headline: Bonfire of the Vanities
text: What happens when a labor union comes between an industry’s collective ego and the ultimate gratification? We’re about to find out. The Bagger is betting it won’t be pretty. (Maybe the writers should give the Oscars a pass, but insist it be one long infomercial about the value of scripted excellence.)

headline: Lens: World Express
text: Follow New York Times staff photographer Todd Heisler as he photographs the diverse communities along the No. 7 train in Queens.

headline: Not Your Mom’s Apple Pie Chart
text: When nearly 1,100 people responded to “Which Came First,” I decided to provide a statistical analysis of the various attempts to order the Fenton photographs. Perhaps something could be learned from such an analysis.

headline: Conflict in Congo
text: The surrender of four members of the Rwandan-led Hutu militia brings into focus how complex the situation in Congo has become.

headline: John Edwards's Iowa Closing Argument
text: Iowa will be a make-or-break state for John Edwards, more so than for any other candidate. He is trying to close strong, the way he did in 2004.

headline: The People Inside Google’s Black Box
text: UPDATE: Google called to clarify this post. Google uses this network of people to test proposed search formulas. But it largely doesn’t use humans to evaluate specific sites or results. See this post for details.

headline: Mike Huckabee: 'What Really Matters'
text: Mike Huckabee's new ad.

headline: Predicting the house price fall
text: Aha. I ran across an old Calculated Risk post that tells us what we’re in for.

headline: Black Cake: A History
text: For Caribbean-born New Yorkers and their children, black cake evokes nostalgia for the islands, where the baking was a solemn ritual at Christmastime.

headline: Gadgets With the Blind in Mind
text: I was on NPR’s “Talk of the Nation” the other day, suggesting holiday tech gifts and taking calls from listeners.

headline: Laboring for Union Support
text: Eager to show that their candidate has strong labor support, officials with the Hillary Clinton campaign said that she would receive the endorsement of the nationwide painters’ union on Wednesday.

headline: A Great Sendoff for 2007
text: I don’t know how you all feel this holiday season, but I must say the spirit hasn’t gripped me yet. Maybe that’s because I’m trying to get as much work done as I can so I can enjoy a couple of weeks of vacation, which means, by the way, that I’m going to take a brief hiatus from The Pour. So, have a great holiday and a happy New Year, and I’ll see you sooner than you know in 2008.

headline: Colonial, Gecina in Merger Talks
text: Spanish real estate giant Inmobiliaria Colonial is in discussions to merge with Gecina, the French property company.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Stump Speech
text: FORT DODGE, Iowa — Well, former president Bill Clinton was more than an hour late for this event, held at the Fort Dodge Opera House, where perhaps 200 people or more had waited so long that they ordered pizza. They had expected him before dinner but he didn’t arrive until about 7:30.

headline: Always a Good Sign for the Rangers: Jagr Is Smiling
text: And it is not just because of his new teeth.

headline: On the Road: Flying Romney Air
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Too bad we don’t get frequent flier miles.

headline: Banks Study Bailing Out Struggling Bond Insurer
text: Officials from Merrill Lynch, Bear Stearns and other major banks are in talks to bail out a struggling bond insurance company that has guaranteed $26 billion in mortgage securities, according to two people briefed on the situation, because the insurer’s woes could force the banks to take on billions in losses they had insured against.

headline: Housing Starts Decline 3.7%
text: The housing market, in its deepest rut since the early 1990s, showed little sign of climbing out in November, and economists said that they expected conditions to worsen in the near term.

headline: S.&P. Cuts Rating on Bond Insurer
text: Citing deepening problems in the mortgage market, Standard & Poor’s cut the rating of one troubled bond insurer Wednesday and assigned a negative outlook to ratings of four other companies that guarantee debts tied to home loans.

headline: New Prime Minister for Ukraine
text: MOSCOW  Yulia Tymoshenko, the former opposition politician who helped lead the peaceful street protests that overturned a rigged presidential election three years ago, was approved by Parliament as Ukraine’s new prime minister.

headline: Poland: Online Auction Trader Sold
text: The South African media group Naspers agreed to acquire Tradus, which operates the largest online auction trader in Poland, for £946 million, or $1.9 billion, adding to its Internet businesses in emerging markets like Eastern Europe. The deal extends Naspers’s reach as it seeks to diversify its revenue, largely dependent on newspapers and magazines. Tradus, based in London, has online auction businesses in Eastern Europe, specifically in the Czech Republic, Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia  and beyond, to Ukraine and Russia.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel to Return to Air Without Writers
text: The comedian Jimmy Kimmel will resume his late-night show on ABC on Jan. 2, the network said Tuesday.

headline: 75 Years Later, Survivor Helps Commemorate Ukrainian Famine
text: Seventy-five years ago, in a small village in eastern Ukraine, Daria Schulha Kira recalls huddling with her three siblings as Communist Party officials ransacked their home looking for grain. “Your government needs your food,” she remembers the armed men shouting. “Then they took iron bars and poked in the walls and the floors looking for anything they could find.”

headline: Living to 100, and Looking Back on a Legacy of New York Jazz
text: Lawrence Lucie no longer has the jet-black hair, the stylish suits or the dexterity that made him one of the pre-eminent rhythm guitarists in the jazz world. But he can still draw a crowd.

headline: Clemens Strongly Denies Allegations by His Ex-Trainer
text: Roger Clemens unleashed the equivalent of a verbal fastball Tuesday, forcefully denying the allegations that Brian McNamee, his former personal trainer, made about his using steroids and human growth hormone.

headline: Students Step Out to Brahms Flourishes
text: Three duos performed Brahms at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday night. All were beneficiaries of weeklong workshops and master classes led by Emanuel Ax, David Zinman and Richard Stoltzman. Brahms’s linkage of piano to either violin, cello or clarinet was the subject matter.

headline: A Goofy Scheme to Get the Girl
text: The Hungarian cartoon feature “The District!” is a last-minute shoo-in for the title of 2007’s most original animated film, no small triumph in a year that also included the releases of “Persepolis,” “Ratatouille,” “Beowulf” and “Paprika.”

headline: Reid’s Relationship With Bush Enters Deep Freeze
text: WASHINGTON  Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, has called President Bush a loser and a liar and has referred to him derisively as King George. Mr. Reid has also apologized  but only, he likes to point out, for the “loser” line.

headline: In Marseille, Rap Helps Keep the Peace
text: MARSEILLE, France  The other day, a dozen or so teenage rappers in baggy jeans and hoodies gathered outside a community arts center called Le Mille-Pattes in Noailles, a poor immigrant neighborhood here, hard by the Old Port.

headline: Frank Morgan, Master of Bebop Sax, Dies at 73
text: Frank Morgan, a jazz saxophonist whose promising career was derailed by drug problems in the 1950s but whose triumphant comeback 30 years later led to an unexpected taste of midlife stardom, died on Friday in Minneapolis. He was 73.

headline: Israel’s Dilemma in Response to Rockets
text: JERUSALEM  In a concerted effort to suppress rocket fire from Gaza, Israeli forces killed at least 10 Palestinian militants, eight of them from Islamic Jihad, in 24 hours on Monday and Tuesday.

headline: Turkey Arrests Kurdish Leader
text: ISTANBUL  Turkish military authorities arrested the leader of the country’s Kurdish political party on Tuesday, saying he had illegally avoided military service. The arrest capped weeks of attempts to shut down the party, and his supporters said it was political.

headline: Morgenthau Says Rumors of His Quitting Are False
text: Robert M. Morgenthau, facing a swirl of rumors that he was retiring after 33 years as Manhattan district attorney, met with reporters on Tuesday and said the speculation was untrue.

headline: Bush Signs Broad Energy Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Legislation that will slowly but fundamentally change the cars Americans drive, the fuel they burn, the way they light their homes and the price they pay for food was signed by President Bush Wednesday after having been adopted by the House on Tuesday by a large margin.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: Zuma Is Chosen to Lead A.N.C.
