text: POLOKWANE, South Africa  The African National Congress chose the Zulu politician Jacob G. Zuma as its new leader on Tuesday, handing South Africa’s president, Thabo Mbeki, a resounding defeat.

headline: Cafe’s Growth Is Promising, but There’s That Lack of a Stove
text: This is the second in a series of three articles about start-ups and their founders’ hopes for the year ahead. The first appeared last week. This column will return to all three after six months, and again after one year, to compare their achievements with their original goals.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Lawyer for Refco Charged in Fraud
text: Federal prosecutors charged the former outside counsel for the bankrupt commodities brokerage firm Refco on Tuesday with fraud tied to the eventual collapse of the commodities and futures brokerage.

headline: The Big Day Nears: What Should Iowa’s Role Be?
text: To the Editor:

headline: University Lectures Are Going Global
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Walter H. G. Lewin, 71, a physics professor, has long had a cult following at M.I.T. And he has now emerged as an international Internet guru, thanks to the global classroom the institute created to spread knowledge through cyberspace.

headline: Election Ban on Sharif Is Upheld
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan’s election commission has upheld an earlier ruling barring the former prime minister Nawaz Sharif from running in general elections scheduled for next month.

headline: Strong Turnout for Fed Auction
text: The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that it collected bids from 93 financial institutions on $20 billion in loans in its first auction of short-term credit, a strong turnout that suggests banks may be more inclined to borrow from the Fed under the new auction-based system.

headline: Deliveryman for Restaurant Slain in a Yonkers Stairwell
text: YONKERS  When their daughter was born seven months ago, Martin Perez and his girlfriend, Elizabeth Aponte, decided they would work opposite shifts so that one of them would always be available to care for her  an arrangement much like the one Mr. Perez’s parents had after they moved their family here from the Dominican Republic in 1989.

headline: Golden Globes and Oscars Are Drawn Into Strike
text: LOS ANGELES  The red carpet is beginning to look a lot like scorched earth.

headline: Pension Fund Shortages Create Hard Choices
text: Almost half of the states have been underfunding their retirement plans for public workers and may have to choose in the years ahead between their pension obligations and other public programs, according to a comprehensive study to be released to the public on Wednesday.

headline: High Noon in New Orleans: The Bulldozers Are Ready
text: Ever since it took over the public housing projects of New Orleans more than a decade ago, the Department of Housing and Urban Development has been itching to tear them down.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: REVISITS

headline: Congress Votes to Spare Millions From Alternative Tax
text: WASHINGTON--Congress gave final approval on Wednesday to a plan that will spare millions of middle-class taxpayers from paying higher taxes in the coming months. The White House welcomed the development and said President Bush would sign the bill.

headline: U.S. Acts to Ease Crunch at New York-Area Airports
text: HERNDON, Va.  Travelers going through Kennedy and Newark Liberty airports next summer may find somewhat fewer flights at the hours they most want to travel, but they are far more likely to leave on time or arrive in time to make connections, federal transportation officials said Wednesday.

headline: Terrorism Damage Bill Is Passed by House
text: The House approved a government insurance program on Tuesday that commits Washington to paying for most of the damage in the event of a terrorist attack in the next seven years. The vote was 360 to 53.

headline: Bail Is Denied in 5th Ave. Killing
text: A state judge on Tuesday denied bail for Natavia S. Lowery, a personal assistant accused of killing her boss, Linda Stein, a real estate broker and former punk rock manager, in Ms. Stein’s Fifth Avenue apartment in October.

headline: Resolving Crisis in Congo Hinges on Foreign Forces
text: RUTSHURU, Congo  Word spread quickly of the surrender of four Interahamwe, members of the Hutu fearsome youth militia that carried out the Rwandan genocide in 1994 and has been hiding in the eastern Congo jungles since. A crowd of people in their Sunday best soon gathered to gawk at the young men as they marched through town.

headline: As Campaign Season Nears, Spitzer Seeks New Help and Eyes Republican Seats
text: ALBANY  As he revs up his political operation for the coming year, Gov. Eliot Spitzer may bring aboard a prominent financier and Democratic donor to help expand the governor’s relationships with business and labor groups, a person close to Mr. Spitzer said on Tuesday.

headline: Report Finds U.S. Agencies Distracted by Focus on Cuba
text: Catching Americans who travel illegally to Cuba or who purchase cigars, rum or other products from the island may be distracting some American government agencies from higher-priority missions like fighting terrorism and combating narcotics trafficking, a government audit to be released Wednesday says.

headline: Judge May Not Step in to Halt Arizona Law
text: LOS ANGELES  The legal effort to block what is widely considered the nation’s toughest law against employers who hire illegal immigrants may be headed for a setback in Arizona after a federal judge said Tuesday that he was not inclined to stop the law from going into effect Jan. 1.

headline: For NASA, Repair Work on Ground and in Space
text: WASHINGTON  NASA spent Tuesday troubleshooting problems in space and on the ground, with astronauts examining malfunctioning joints on the International Space Station and engineers testing fuel tank sensors aboard the shuttle Atlantis as it sits on its launching pad.

headline: Bronx Woman, 25, and Daughter, 6, Are Found Dead at Home
text: A 25-year-old woman and her 6-year-old daughter were found dead in their Bronx apartment Tuesday after friends and relatives grew worried that the girl had not shown up at school and the woman had not arrived for work.

headline: Picture of Secret Detentions Emerges in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan’s military and intelligence agencies, apparently trying to avoid acknowledging an elaborate secret detention system, have quietly set free nearly 100 men suspected of links to terrorism, few of whom were charged, human rights groups and lawyers here say.

headline: G.M. to Start Another Round of Buyouts and Seek Cheaper Labor
text: DETROIT  General Motors said Tuesday that it would begin another round of buyout offers that would allow it to begin hiring new workers for significantly less pay.

headline: Silver Lake Partners to Buy a Quarter of Research Firm
text: Silver Lake Partners has agreed to acquire a quarter of the Gerson Lehrman Group, the upstart Wall Street research firm that has come under scrutiny from regulators, according to people involved in the negotiations.

headline: Flights of Pianistic Fantasy, Not for the Fainthearted
text: One of the most formidable performances of 2007 in New York came in February when the pianist Yefim Bronfman played the premiere of Esa-Pekka Salonen’s Piano Concerto with the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Salonen, who conducted the performance, was late in finishing the work, an exuberantly modernist riff on Rachmaninoff-style late Romanticism. The piano part is astoundingly difficult. Yet Mr. Bronfman, who had fewer than five weeks to learn it, played with commanding virtuosity.

headline: Seminary’s Renovation Juggles the Old, the New and the Financial
text: The General Theological Seminary in Chelsea has been on the same site in Manhattan for almost two centuries, and this is both a blessing and a burden.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Amy Winehouse Is Arrested in London

headline: It’s Just Fine to Drink and Read
text: BEEP, beep, beep, beep: it’s the truck backing up with this year’s crop of wine books for the holidays. Make no mistake, reading is the next best thing to drinking for the wine lover, and much more practical on subways, buses and trains.

headline: Betting on the Patriots Isn’t the Lock of the Year
text: None of them wear a headset or pore over game film. Their defensive schemes are better suited for an abacus than a computer. Las Vegas oddsmakers, however, have done something that none of the N.F.L’s. brightest offensive and defensive coordinators have done this season: beat the New England Patriots.

headline: Huckabee Now a Candidate With Something to Lose
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mike Huckabee was taking a vigorous morning run on a hotel treadmill on Saturday, avoiding the trail outside. “Too much snow out there,” said Mr. Huckabee, a former Arkansas governor, explaining his wariness of the slick roads and blocked pathways of New Hampshire. He worried, he said, about getting sideswiped or “hitting some patch of black ice and getting hurt.”

headline: Busy Bank Robber at Fulton Mall Was Too Predictable, Police Say
text: For Orlando Taylor, a 26-year-old Brooklyn man who apparently had a strange attraction to a couple of bank branches at the bustling Fulton Mall, three times was a charm. So was the fourth time. But according to the police, when he returned on Tuesday to commit a fifth robbery in five days, his luck ran out.

headline: McCain Sees a Need for Mortgage Aid
text: SALEM, N.H.  Reacting to voters’ concerns about the economy, Senator John McCain said Tuesday that he would consider greater intervention by the federal government to limit the fallout of the mortgage crisis if current measures fail.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING | THE AMERICAS; Brazil: Santa Comes Under Fire
text: Suspected drug traffickers shot at a helicopter carrying a Santa Claus to a Rio de Janeiro slum to distribute toys. No one was hurt, although two shots hit the copter. It returned to its base, and the Santa took a car to complete his mission. According to the police, the gunmen apparently mistook the helicopter and its passenger as a police operation.

headline: Canada: Core Inflation Rate Falls
text: Cheaper new cars, a result of the surging Canadian dollar, lowered Canada’s core inflation rate last month, Statistics Canada reported. The core portion of the country’s consumer price index, which excludes volatile items like gasoline and mortgage interest, was 1.6 percent in November, compared with 1.8 percent in October. The agency attributed that unexpected decline to a 3.9 percent drop in new car prices and lease rates. Canada’s overall inflation rate grew slightly in November to 2.5 percent, compared with 2.4 percent in October. Much of that was attributed to a 17.6 percent increase in gasoline prices.

headline: Baseball, Money and Steroids: What Are Our Values?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pink Slip for Thomas? Fan Says Sign Right Here
text: While the Knicks have cracked down recently on hecklers and holders of opinionated signs inside Madison Square Garden, they probably cannot influence a demonstration outside the building that will urge the dismissal of Isiah Thomas, the team’s coach and president.

headline: System to Track Cloned Animals Is Planned
text: Responding to concerns in the food industry, companies developing cloned livestock have come up with a system to track the animals as they move through farms and slaughterhouses.

headline: Economics: The Year in Books, 2007
text: In my column this week, I call “Overtreated,” by Shannon Brownlee, the book of the year in economics. The column also mentions a few other books from 2007: “The Age of Turbulence,” by Alan Greenspan; “Falling Behind,” by Robert H. Frank; “Supercapitalism,” by Robert Reich; and “The Bottom Billion,” by Paul Collier.

headline: Russia and Poland to Discuss U.S. Missile Shield
text: BERLIN  Signaling a thaw in relations that had chilled under the previous Polish government, Russia and Poland said Tuesday that they would hold consultations over plans by the United States to deploy elements of a missile-defense system in Eastern Europe.

headline: Insurers Seek Bigger Reach in Coverage
text: Acknowledging that too many people simply cannot obtain health insurance on their own, the insurance industry plans on Wednesday to propose a series of steps the companies say would let more individuals, even those who have health problems, obtain coverage.

headline: Former Yankees Traveling Secretary Pleads Guilty in Tax Case
text: The Yankees formally fired David Szen, their former traveling secretary, on Tuesday after Szen pleaded guilty in United States District Court to filing a false federal income tax return.

headline: Economy Key in South Korea Election
text: SEOUL, South Korea  As South Koreans headed to the polls for their country’s presidential election on Wednesday, voters appeared ready to choose Lee Myung-bak, a pro-business candidate identified with the nation’s economic growth but bedeviled by corruption charges.

headline: Justice Nominee Questioned on Waterboarding
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush’s nominee to be the second-ranking official at the Justice Department refused to say on Wednesday whether he considered the interrogation technique known as waterboarding to be “torture,” from a legal standpoint.

headline: No. 1 Book, and It Offers Solutions
text: In 1967, Jack Wennberg, a young medical researcher at Johns Hopkins, moved his family to a farmhouse in northern Vermont.

headline: Economy Looms Over South Korea Election
text: SEOUL, South Korea  As South Koreans headed to the polls for their country's presidential election on Wednesday, voters appeared ready to choose Lee Myung-bak, a pro-business candidate identified with the nation’s economic growth but bedeviled by corruption charges.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An illustration with the Mind column in Science Times on Tuesday, about seasonal affective disorder, carried an incorrect credit. The artist was Ward Schumaker, not Vivienne Flesher.

headline: In Christmas-Greeting Style, Huckabee Makes Appeal to Voters
text: This commercial by Mike Huckabee is being shown in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina.

headline: At 71, Physics Professor Is a Web Star
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Walter H. G. Lewin, 71, a physics professor, has long had a cult following at M.I.T. And he has now emerged as an international Internet guru, thanks to the global classroom the institute created to spread knowledge through cyberspace.

headline: The Second Amendment Means ...?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Joel Dorn, Record Producer, Dies at 65
text: Joel Dorn, who, having achieved his adolescent ambition of becoming a producer for Atlantic Records, went on to influence the shape of pop music in the work of artists like Roberta Flack, Bette Midler and the Neville Brothers, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 65.

headline: Bush Approves Army Reorganization
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush has approved what officials are describing as the most significant reorganization of American ground forces since World War II, signing off on a plan that will keep more troops than previously envisioned in Europe and add large numbers of soldiers to bases in Colorado, Georgia and Texas, Army officials said Wednesday.

headline: Master of ‘Rings’ to Tackle ‘Hobbit’
text: LOS ANGELES  Goblins, trolls and dragons were a breeze compared with the caustic clash of egos that kept “The Hobbit” in Hollywood limbo for years. But a settlement announced on Tuesday between Peter Jackson and New Line Cinema holds the promise that peace will break out in Middle Earth and that fans could see the first of two resulting movies by December 2010.

headline: Laugh at the Web Clips, Then Buy the Gel
text: ADVERTISING about advertising has long been a popular ploy on Madison Avenue. So, too, has the idea of ads that parody other ads. Now, with the increasing interest among marketers in embedding brands in entertainment programming, a viral campaign is arriving that spoofs the concept  while at the same time, of course, playing up the product.

headline: It’s Edwards the Fighter in the Iowa Homestretch
text: OTTUMWA, Iowa  More than 150 Iowans were rustling in their chairs at a community college here the other night, waiting for John Edwards. Mr. Edwards’s bus was parked and running outside the door, but it was nearly 45 minutes before he finally made his characteristically late entrance.

headline: What You Get for ... $4 Million
text: Miami

headline: Cereal as a Metaphor for Capitalism
text: A business course on cutthroat capitalism disguised as a slacker comedy: That’s the kindest way to describe Michael Lehmann’s “Flakes,” a movie that shares the smug, hipper-than-thou sensibility of its sour protagonist, Neal Downs (Aaron Stanford).

headline: A Crisis Long Foretold
text: A truism of crisis management is that most seemingly out-of-the-blue disasters could have been prevented if someone had paid attention.

headline: Goldman’s Record Year Ends With Modest Gain
text: Goldman Sachs did it again. Now the question is whether the Wall Street bank can do it again and again.

headline: Union Leader Is Accused of Extortion
text: The former president of a New York area Teamsters local was arrested on Tuesday on charges that he forced his union members to do work for him personally, including building a new roof on his country home, squiring his daughter to her yoga class and setting up a Christmas tree at his Manhattan apartment.

headline: Mixing a Rare Verdi With a Difficult Babbitt
text: “I don’t know whether the quartet is beautiful or ugly,” Verdi said after the premiere of his String Quartet in E minor in 1873. He wrote the piece to pass the time when a production of “Aida” was postponed after the lead soprano fell ill, and he continued to worry about its worth for several years.

headline: From That Trip to the Forest, Here’s the Cake
text: Posters for the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of “Hansel and Gretel” show the children in the witch’s house as Hansel gorges on a hunk of chocolate cake. When the opera opens on Monday, and for all of its nine performances through the end of January, Alice Coote, who portrays Hansel, will be indulging in a seriously delectable treat.

headline: Trial in Slaying of L.I. Man Turns on Reaction to Threat
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  “I did what I had to do; you might as well put the cuffs on me now.”

headline: Opening of Memorial for Sept. 11 Is Postponed
text: For years, under Gov. George E. Pataki, state officials told the public that the World Trade Center memorial would open Sept. 11, 2009, the eighth anniversary of the attack.

headline: Executions in U.S. Decline to 13-Year Low, Study Finds
text: The number of executions in the United States has declined to a 13-year low, according to a study by a research group that has been critical of the way the death penalty is applied.

headline: E.P.A. Denies California Emission’s Waiver
text: DETROIT — The Bush administration said Wednesday night that it would deny California's bid to set stricter vehicle emissions standards than federal law required as part of the state's efforts to fight climate change.

headline: A Fruitcake Soaked in Tropical Sun
text: WHEN a man in a hairnet beckons, who can resist?

headline: ‘Alarming Alliance’ of Mafia and Street Gang Is Broken Up
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  State authorities on Tuesday broke up what Attorney General Anne Milgram said was an “alarming alliance” between the Luchese crime family and the Bloods street gang to supply drugs and cellphones to gang members inside a New Jersey prison.

headline: Bush Lawyers Discussed Fate of Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  At least four top White House lawyers took part in discussions with the Central Intelligence Agency between 2003 and 2005 about whether to destroy videotapes showing the secret interrogations of two operatives from Al Qaeda, according to current and former administration and intelligence officials.

headline: Sprint Nextel Hires a Chief From Its Spinoff
text: The Sprint Nextel Corporation, the cellphone company that lost more than a million customers in the last five quarters, named Daniel R. Hesse as chief executive on Tuesday, succeeding Gary D. Forsee, who was ousted two months ago.

headline: F.C.C. Reshapes Rules Limiting Media Industry
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission approved two new rules on Tuesday that are likely to reshape the nation’s media landscape by setting new parameters for the size and scope of the largest news and cable companies.

headline: Comfort in Layers of Chocolate
text: MY parents love to tell the story of me and the bowl of schlag (whipped cream) at Demel coffeehouse in Vienna. I was a toddler, the tale goes, held in my mother’s arms in front of the pastry counter, when I pitched myself forward, diving into a bowl of said schlag. I made it up to my wrists before being caught, but after licking the white fluff from my fingers, I apparently spent the rest of the day ecstatic.

headline: This Time, Sarkozy Embraces Attention to His Private Life
text: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy told journalists he did not mind media reports about his love life, one day after reports of his romance with a former supermodel, Carla Bruni, surfaced in the French press.

headline: Beneath the Roar of Times Square, an Old, Familiar Rhythm Returns
text: All of a sudden, on his way to Brooklyn one recent evening, Victor Miranda decided to change trains at 42nd Street, instead of 14th.

headline: Fehr and Selig to Begin Talks on Mitchell Report
text: Donald Fehr, the head of the baseball players union, and Commissioner Bud Selig have agreed to discuss recommendations from the Mitchell report, a move that could lead to a third reopening of the collective bargaining agreement since 2005 in an ongoing bid to crack down on the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Senate Adds $70 Billion for Wars in Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted Tuesday night to approve a sweeping year-end budget package after adding $70 billion for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan over the objections of Democrats who have been stymied all year in their efforts to change the course of the conflict in Iraq.

headline: For Now, U.S. Won’t Cap Flights Per Hour at J.F.K.
text: WASHINGTON  The United States transportation secretary will announce on Wednesday that her department has negotiated an agreement with the airlines to ease congestion at Kennedy International Airport next summer by shifting some flights to less busy times, according to government officials and industry executives.

headline: The Vatican’s Relative Truth
text: POPE BENEDICT XVI has offered a couple of recent previews of what’s likely to be his core message to the United Nations next April, the projected highlight of his first visit to the United States. Last Tuesday, the pontiff released the text of his annual statement for the Vatican’s World Day of Peace, raising typical papal concerns like poverty and disarmament, but also a defense of the family based on heterosexual marriage and, in the section reflecting Benedict’s budding environmentalism, a reminder of human supremacy over the animal kingdom.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING | EUROPE; Ukraine: Ex-Premier Makes Comeback
text: Yulia Tymoshenko, who helped lead the street protests that overturned a rigged presidential election three years ago, was narrowly approved by Parliament to be prime minister. She held the same post in 2005 before a falling-out with President Viktor A. Yushchenko, with whom she has reconciled.

headline: Rice Visits Iraq Amid Strain With Turkey
text: BAGHDAD  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made an unannounced visit to Iraq on Tuesday, visiting the oil-rich city of Kirkuk and then Baghdad, as tensions mounted along the country’s mountainous border with Turkey.

headline: When a Universe Reels, a Baryshnikov May Fall
text: Mikhail Baryshnikov, who defied gravity as a ballet dancer, is gravity’s slave in “Beckett Shorts,” which opened on Tuesday night at the New York Theater Workshop. Mr. Baryshnikov enters falling in the opening segment of this 70-minute compilation of four brief plays by Samuel Beckett. And for the rest of the show you can feel good old physics tugging at feet that once took flight like no one else’s.

headline: A Producer of Movies to Try Hand at Games
text: The Hollywood producer Jerry Bruckheimer, whose movies and television shows are so replete with car chases and fast action that critics say they look like video games, is finally lending his expertise to that medium.

headline: What Was That All About?
text: Bali, Indonesia

headline: Osorio Leaves Fire to Coach Red Bulls
text: Juan Carlos Osorio said he had landed his dream job. The New York Red Bulls said they had landed their dream coach. As many others have found, the mystical force that seems to surround the MetroStars/Red Bulls has often turned those dreams into night terrors.

headline: Thomas Sticks With Knicks Team He Criticized
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Isiah Thomas the point guard was a fierce competitor who drove his teams to titles and glory. Isiah Thomas the team executive is a manic day trader who pounces on every chance to stockpile talent. Isiah Thomas the coach is a frustrated, tortured soul who cannot find players as intense as he was, and is now openly wondering why.

headline: Recipe: Royal Fans
text: 2 cups sifted cake flour

headline: In Reversal, Fed Approves Plan to Curb Risky Lending
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, acknowledging that home mortgage lenders aggressively sold deceptive loans to borrowers who had little chance of repaying them, proposed a broad set of restrictions Tuesday on exotic mortgages and high-cost loans for people with weak credit.

headline: Too Costly for Even the Well-to-Do
text: Harvard’s new financial aid policy is the boldest move yet to mitigate the soaring costs of a college education. Most previous efforts to make higher education affordable have focused, as they should, on helping low-income students. Now Harvard will also provide generous aid to students whose annual family incomes reach as high as $180,000. It is a welcome move, but also a disturbing admission that the priciest colleges are now beyond the reach of even many upper-middle-class families.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the House’s passage of a budget bill misstated the amount approved for two programs. The legislation provides $602 million, not billion, for agricultural drought relief; and $195 million, not billion, for repair of the collapsed highway bridge in Minneapolis.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the House’s passage of a budget bill misstated the amount approved for two programs. The legislation provides $602 million, not billion, for agricultural drought relief; and $195 million, not billion, for repair of the collapsed highway bridge in Minneapolis. (Go to Article)

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Dec. 11 about the effort to develop a malaria vaccine using live mosquito parasites misstated the timing of research into the mosquito genome. It was decoded in 2002, along with that of the parasite that causes malaria  not “in the ’80s.”

headline: Cinephiles, Pack Your Bags. An Uncut Version Awaits.
text: SHANGHAI  For weeks now, the ranks of Chinese visitors to Hong Kong have swelled with a brand-new category of tourists: moviegoers.

headline: Laura Huxley, Her Husband’s Biographer, Dies at 96
text: Laura Archera Huxley, a writer who was best known for her memoir of her years with her husband, the novelist Aldous Huxley, died on Thursday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 96.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
The Gifts of Bach’s Melodic Generosity
text: For more than a decade the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has greeted each holiday season with performances of Bach’s six “Brandenburg” Concertos in a single sitting. It has become a staple, selling out year after year. When David Finckel and Wu Han, the society’s current artistic directors, inherited the tradition last year, they built a winter Baroque Festival around the “Brandenburg” concerts, a venture repeated this year.

headline: Bush to Visit Middle East in January
text: WASHINGTON  The White House confirmed on Tuesday President Bush’s plans to visit Israel and the West Bank next month, as well as other Middle East destinations, as he works to nudge peace talks forward.

headline: Down Payment on Mideast Peace
text: The political and territorial challenges facing Israeli and Palestinian peace negotiators are formidable and familiar. The economic obstacles to the creation of a viable Palestinian state are also formidable, but easier to make a dent in  if all the donors who claim to care about the Palestinians and peace live up to their promises.

headline: Meat to Wrap the Mind Around
text: IN September, when Sasha Wizansky and Amy Standen published the inaugural issue of Meatpaper, a slender magazine that is, according to the cover, “Your Journal of Meat Culture,” they weren’t entirely surprised that both omnivores and vegetarians responded enthusiastically.

headline: Green Light for Institute on Creation in Texas
text: HOUSTON  A Texas higher education panel has recommended allowing a Bible-based group called the Institute for Creation Research to offer online master’s degrees in science education.

headline: House, 314-100, Passes Broad Energy Bill; Bush Plans to Sign It
text: WASHINGTON  Legislation that will slowly but significantly change the cars Americans drive, the fuel they burn, the way they light their homes and the price they pay for food cleared the House on Tuesday by a large margin. President Bush said he would sign it on Wednesday.

headline: At End of Her Mother’s Life, Finding Unconditional Love
text: The beatings started when her father left.

headline: 101 Simple Appetizers in 20 Minutes or Less
text: YOU want good food at a holiday cocktail party and you want to impress people? You don’t want a caterer, you refuse to heat up frozen food, and you want to show that your expertise extends beyond buying perfectly ripe hunks of cheese and juicy olives? Then think about doing some cooking.

headline: Detroit Revival Vies With Industry’s Decline
text: DETROIT  For decades, city leaders and local business executives here have been predicting an imminent revival of their desolate downtown. For all their cheerleading, though, nothing much changed.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING | THE AMERICAS; Canada: New Mad Cow Case
text: Mad cow disease has been confirmed in a 13-year-old beef cow from Alberta, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency said. No part of the cow entered the human or animal food or feed chain, it said. The cow was born after restrictions on feed were put in place. It is the 11th case of the disease since 2003.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,884 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: After Delay, Clinton Embarks on a Likability Tour
text: DES MOINES  The tableau was classic Clinton: Bill Clinton chatting with African-American cashiers and baggers at a grocery store here Tuesday, telling them how wonderful Hillary Rodham Clinton was, while she waited quietly for him to finish so they could dazzle more voters.

headline: A Pushcart Vendor Defies a City, With Persistence and Hot Dogs
text: Out in front of the crowded entrance to the Metropolitan Museum of Art is one of the more lucrative spots in Manhattan to sell hot dogs. It is so good, in fact, that one of the largest pushcart vending companies in New York City pays $574,000 a year to the city for the right to place two hot dog carts there.

headline: In the Kitchen of Long Ago, With Grandma
text: THE daughter of an interfaith marriage, I chose Judaism, but Christmas cookies chose me.

headline: This Magna Carta to Remain in U.S.
text: The man who just paid $21.3 million for a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta, the English document that helped establish the rights of man and lay the framework for the Constitution, says he wants to keep the copy on display in the United States.

headline: Bad Bill Now, Bad Bill Later
text: While trying to do the wrong thing  shove a bad bill on electronic spying through the Senate  Majority Leader Harry Reid ended up doing the country a favor. He put off the vote until January. It was the right move, but senators who care about national security and the Constitution will have to be careful not to be stampeded into supporting what will still be a bad bill next year.

headline: Concerns Grow Over Work of Official in California
text: LOS ANGELES  Chriss W. Street was called a hero in 1994, when he sounded the alarm on high-risk investments in the Orange County portfolio and predicted the county’s $1.7 billion bankruptcy filing.

headline: Manhattan Market Dips, but Parts Remain Rarefied
text: Once part of the sprawling Nabisco cookie complex, the eight-story red-brick building at 450 West 15th Street, just east of 10th Avenue in the meatpacking district of Manhattan, is the epitome of understated warehouse chic, with polished concrete floors and century-old brick walls and frosted windows.

headline: Magna Carta Copy Sold
text: A 710-year-old copy of the declaration of human rights known as the Magna Carta  the version that became part of English law  was auctioned Tuesday for $21.3 million, a Sotheby’s spokeswoman said.

headline: Tribune Chief to Step Down After Sale
text: Dennis J. FitzSimons will step down as chairman and chief executive of Tribune Company as soon as an $8.2 billion takeover deal is completed, the company announced Wednesday.

headline: 205 Schools Accept Plan for Bonus Pay
text: New York City officials released the names of 205 public schools where teachers have chosen to take part in a new bonus program based largely on improving test scores.

headline: Nets Force a Long Shot That Costs Them the Game
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When everything is going right for the Nets, they seal every route to the basket and force opponents to shoot from outside. Long shots can carom hard off the rim, and the Nets can collect the ball and speed the other way.

headline: In France, Swapping a Pied-à-Terre for a Château
text: LIMÈSY, France

headline: Romney Refocuses on His Business Experience
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H.  Mitt Romney was recounting to his audience here a political fable of sorts, about how he never expected to get into politics after spending his life in business. The moral is one he has been telling again and again in his final sprint before the first votes are cast.

headline: Holiday Cheer (and Calories)
text: Dinella Ascenso teaches her students at the High School of Food and Finance in Manhattan how to make holiday-season biscotti. At the Anderson School, also in Manhattan, first graders were asked to bring in foods that their families serve during the holidays. The results included challah and gingerbread cookies. Jordyn Peques and Naqueilla Paul were among the children who sampled the treats.

headline: ‘Juiced’ Ghostwriter: I Told You So
text: Whatever else its eventual impact, the Mitchell report last week immediately recasts the importance of the small library of books documenting  and in some cases, shaping  baseball’s steroid era.

headline: Bush Lawyers Discussed Fate of C.I.A.Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  At least four top White House lawyers took part in discussions with the Central Intelligence Agency between 2003 and 2005 about whether to destroy videotapes showing the secret interrogations of two operatives from Al Qaeda, according to current and former administration and intelligence officials.

headline: Child Health Plan to Be Expanded
text: TRENTON (AP)  Under an agreement to be unveiled on Wednesday, New Jersey will offer low-cost health coverage for the children of families who lack insurance but who earn too much for government help.

headline: Douglas Kneeland, Former Reporter for The New York Times, Dies at 78
text: Douglas E. Kneeland, a former reporter for The New York Times who covered some of the major stories of the 1960s and ’70s and later became a high-level editor at The Chicago Tribune, died on Saturday in Lincoln, Me., the town in which he was born and to which he returned in retirement. He was 78.

headline: Recipe: Black Forest Cake
text: Adapted from Johnny Iuzzini, Jean Georges

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the laws of physics and nature misstated the time in which Plato was forming his idea of a higher realm of ideal forms. It was in the fourth century B.C.; it was not “a few hundred years” after the fifth century B.C., when the Greek mathematician and philosopher Pythagoras and his followers proclaimed that nature was numbers.

headline: Newborn Pulled From Trash in Stable Condition Next Day
text: A newborn girl who was found crying in a commercial trash bin in Queens on Monday night was in stable condition Tuesday in the intensive care unit at Elmhurst Hospital Center, where the staff has unofficially named her Christina because she was found around Christmas, a doctor said.

headline: E.C.B. Makes $500 Billion Infusion
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank on Tuesday pumped 348 billion euros ($500 billion) into the financial system, easing conditions in credit markets grappling with a global lending squeeze linked to the United States housing downturn and traditional year-end demands for cash.

headline: How a Middle School Can Be ‘Dangerous’ and Still Get an A
text: When Shawn Carson taught last year at a middle school named the South Bronx Academy for Applied Media, he entered his room on many days to find a message from his students on the blackboard. In graphic and vulgar language, as he recalled in a recent interview, it described him committing a homosexual act.

headline: Some Dirty Little Detours on the Road to Shangri-La
text: Somewhere out there, right now, everyone’s dream vacation awaits. It is a collective dream, created by travel journalists who describe, in a cascade of clichés and superlatives, a world of white-sand beaches, quaint villages and smiling locals eager to share their secret knowledge. It is a world in which all places, regardless of location, history or culture, embody a “bewitching blend of the ancient and modern.”

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell Stake to China Amid Loss
text: Morgan Stanley posted its first quarterly loss ever on Wednesday after taking an additional $5.7 billion write-down related to subprime mortgages. The investment bank said it would sell a $5 billion stake to the China Investment Corporation, that country’s sovereign wealth fund, to shore up its capital.

headline: Pentagon Says Services in Iraq Are Stagnant
text: WASHINGTON  Despite a significant reduction in violence in Iraq over the past three months, the Iraqi government has made little headway in improving the delivery of electricity, health care and other essential services, a new Pentagon report said Tuesday.

headline: F.S.U. to Bar as Many as 25 Players From Bowl
text: There had been hope in the Florida Panhandle the last few years that Bobby Bowden would rally Florida State to its former prominence before he retired.

headline: Colorado Decertifies Machines for Voting
text: DENVER  Thousands of Colorado’s electronic voting machines do not work properly and have been decertified, according to a review by the Colorado secretary of state that has left elections officials scrambling to find viable machines in time for local and Congressional primary elections in August and the presidential election in November.

headline: United Nations: Assembly Calls for Freeze on Death Penalty
text: In a vote that made for unusual alliances, the General Assembly passed, 104 to 54 with 29 abstentions, a nonbinding resolution calling for a moratorium on the death penalty. Among the countries joining the United States in opposition to the European-led measure were Iran, Myanmar, North Korea, Sudan and Zimbabwe. Opponents argued that the resolution undermined their national sovereignty. Two similar moves in the 1990s failed, and Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said the new vote was “evidence of a trend toward ultimately abolishing the death penalty.”

headline: Machismo, Down to the Studs
text: ON today’s voluble, provenance-obsessed menus, it’s not uncommon to be told what breed of cattle your beef comes from or where it was raised.

headline: Illinois Town Chosen as Site for New Type of Coal Plant
text: WASHINGTON  An industry consortium planning a coal plant that will capture its carbon dioxide and pump it underground selected a site near Mattoon, Ill., on Tuesday for the $1.5 billion project. A second site in Illinois and two in Texas had been considered..

headline: Baseball Union Agrees to Discuss Report
text: The baseball players’ union has agreed to discuss the findings in the report from former Senator George J. Mitchell on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, the union and the commissioner’s office said Tuesday afternoon.

headline: New Business Helps Oracle to a Strong Quarter
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Second-quarter revenue at the Oracle Corporation, the business software company, soundly surpassed Wall Street’s projections on Wednesday as the company reported a sharp rise in new software licenses.

headline: Joseph Henderson, an Early Jung Disciple, Dies at 104
text: Dr. Joseph L. Henderson, a psychoanalyst and author who was an early practitioner of methods developed by Carl Jung to explore cultural influences on the unconscious mind, died on Nov. 17 in Greenbrae, Calif., outside San Francisco. He was 104.

headline: Verdi’s Swedish Monarch Is Returned to His Native Land
text: Political relevance, mother’s milk for opera in the 21st century, was poison for Italian composers like Verdi. “Un Ballo in Maschera” broadly re-enacts the assassination of the Swedish king Gustav III in 1792. Neapolitan censors in the 1850s, edgy on the subject of regicide, said no to it and also to an alternative setting by Verdi’s librettist Antonio Somma, one that would have had Renato, Riccardo and Ulrica cavorting improbably in the drawing rooms of Boston and enlisting conspirators from colonial legislatures.

headline: Credit Is Passed Around in Complete Rangers Victory
text: After they had seemingly dug themselves out of a midseason funk with a victory over Pittsburgh that was impressive on many fronts Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers passed credit around their locker room as if it were a puck in a power-play drill.

headline: Rush to Judgment
text: One of my male colleagues was explaining why men age better than women.

headline: Met Has New Rival in Operas at Movies
text: It’s an arms race out there in opera land.

headline: Kyrgyz Vote Law Voided
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  The Supreme Court struck down a contentious election law on Tuesday that had appeared to guarantee all seats in Parliament to the Ak Zhol Party of President Kurmanbek Bakiyev.

headline: Hands Across Iowa for Thompson
text: Fred D. Thompson’s “hands down” moment in the Des Moines Register Republican debate last week is still resonating throughout his campaign, and keeps popping up on his bus tour this week.

headline: Name a Patriot, and He’s Probably Scored
text: Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic contributed to this notebook.

headline: Wednesday’s Links: Playoff Picture Almost Ready for Framing
text: ‘Tis the season — when your boss at the newspaper tells you not to use cliches like that. And when the last remaining pieces of the N.F.L.’s playoff tournament are falling into place. For one thing, the Patriots have wrapped up home-field advantage, but is that really going to help them? The N.F.C.’s division titles are locked up, but four teams (Giants, Vikings, Redskins and Saints) remain in the running for the two wild-card spots. The Vikings (8-6) are the team with the hot hand. They have won five in a row (and have the tie breaker over the 9-5 Giants, if it should come to that.) There is less suspense in the A.F.C., where four teams (Steelers, Jaguars, Browns and Titans) are vying for three spots. Incredibly, the Chargers (9-5), who started the season 1-4, have already clinched a spot and it’s the Steelers (9-5) who might have to win out to make the playoffs.

headline: For the Moment | Party politics in L.A.
text: Franklin Getchell

headline: Bangkok Christmas gift ideas, part one
text: Last-minute Christmas shoppers in Bangkok can pick up beautiful silk scarves, home-made jewelry, mulberry-paper greeting cards, cutlery, artisanal soaps, lotions, locally grown tea and coffee, pottery, and lots more handicrafts at the Ambassador Hotel (Sukhumvit Soi 11) on Saturday, Dec 22. The craft fair, which runs from 10am to 2pm, works on the fair-trade concept, only selling things made by Thai artisans; 70 percent of sales revenue goes directly to the people who made the handicrafts.

headline: Bangkok Christmas gift ideas, part two
text: A half-dozen vineyards have started up in Thailand in recent years, part of the global trend to make wine at non-traditional latitudes. Most of the Thai wine, to be honest, is plonk. But one exception is Chateau de Loei, located on a plateau near the border with Laos. Their best wines are not bargains – upwards of $20 – but they’re very drinkable.

headline: ‘Homo Politicus’
text: Status

headline: It Costs $574,000 To Vend Hot Dogs on New York Streets
text: But a onetime “Pushcart King” is fighting back on behalf of Vietnam vets. Read more.

headline: They’re Not All iPols
text: Find out on The Caucus if Senator John McCain grooves on an eight-track tape player (ooh, that’s cold — and also not true):

headline: ‘But Professor, Why a Duck?’
text: On campus, life imitates the Marx Brothers college farce “Horsefeathers” in the form of Walter H. G. Lewin, 71, a physics professor with a cult following at M.I.T. who has now emerged as an international Internet guru:

headline: Can We Talk?
text: Graphic found here.

headline: Harmony Gold Sells $252 Milion in Assets
text: Harmony Gold Mining, Africa’s third-largest gold producer, agreed to form a venture and sell a stake in assets including its Cooke uranium ore dump in South Africa to Pamodzi Resources Fund for $252 million.

headline: Level 3 Sells Ad Unit to DG FastChannel
text: Level 3 Communications on Wednesday said it will sell the advertising distribution business of Vyvx to DG FastChannel. Vyvx is a wholly owned subsidiary of Level 3. Under the terms of the deal, Level 3 will receive $129 million payable in cash.

headline: Deutsche Bank Settles Enron Claims
text: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay creditors of Enron, the energy trading company, $25 million to settle a lawsuit related to transactions between the companies, Enron said on Tuesday.

headline: Lawyer for Refco Charged in Fraud
text: Federal prosecutors charged the former outside counsel for the bankrupt commodities brokerage firm Refco on Tuesday with fraud tied to the eventual collapse of the commodities and futures brokerage.

headline: Accel-KKR Boost Stake in Software Vendor
text: Accel-KKR said Tuesday that it boosted its stake in iTradeNetwork, a vendor of software for food suppliers, by buying out founding shareholders in a deal of undisclosed size.

headline: E.C.B. Makes $500 Billion Infusion
text: The European Central Bank on Tuesday pumped 348 billion euros ($500 billion) into the financial system, easing conditions in credit markets grappling with a global lending squeeze linked to the United States housing downturn and traditional year-end demands for cash.

headline: F.C.C. Reshapes Rules Limiting Media Industry
text: The Federal Communications Commission approved two new rules on Tuesday that are likely to reshape the nation’s media landscape by setting new parameters for the size and scope of the largest news and cable companies.

headline: Paul Allen to Bid in Spectrum Auction
text: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen has applied to bid in an upcoming U.S. auction of coveted wireless airwaves, according to auction documents released late Tuesday.

headline: SFR May Dial Up $7.2 Billion Deal for Neuf Cegetel
text: Vivendi‘s SFR wireless phone unit is in talks with the other main shareholder in Neuf Cegetel in what investors said could be a 5 billion euro ($7.2 billion) purchase of the second-largest fixed-line phone company in France.

headline: Applied Precision Cancels I.P.O., Sells Unit
text: Seventeen months after filing for an initial stock offering that it never completed, Applied Precision said it had dropped its I.P.O. plans and has sold its semiconductor test-instrumentation business to Rudolph Technologies.

headline: Opponents Of Google’s DoubleClick Deal Threaten Lawsuit
text: A coalition opposing Google‘s $3.1 billion merger with DoubleClick renewed charges of conflicts and threatened possible legal action over a decision by a regulatory chairman not to recuse herself from reviewing the merger.

headline: Crunch Time for Tribune Buyout
text: Tribune executives were sweating out aggressive last-minute questioning Tuesday from bankers reluctant to fund the final portion of a debt-laden $8.2 billion deal to take the company private with Chicago billionaire Samuel Zell, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Milestone Postpones I.P.O.
text: Milestone AV Technologies postponed plans on Tuesday for an initial public offering because of unfavorable market conditions, an underwriter said.

headline: Cardiac Dimensions Raises $35.5 Million
text: Cardiac Dimensions said Tuesday that it has raised $35.5 million in venture capital financing, money it will use for clinical trials for a device that repairs the mitral valve in patients suffering from congestive heart failure.

headline: Ustream Takes $2 Million in Angel Round
text: Internet broadcast start-up Ustream.TV said Tuesday that it completed a $2 million angel round and that former Democratic presidential candidate Wesley Clark joined its board.

headline: Harbinger Takes Stake in Media General
text: Distressed and special situations hedge fund firm Harbinger Capital Partners has taken a stake in a struggling media company with a warning to management that it may clean shop.

headline: Peltz Has Another Bone to Pick With Cadbury
text: Shares in Cadbury Schweppes rose on Tuesday as Nelson Peltz, the activist shareholder, urged a faster rate of change as he warned the British company’s sweets and drinks units may become takeover targets.

headline: The Year in Technology M&A
text: Microsoft, Oracle, I.B.M. and a host of private equity firms helped drive technology mergers and acquisitions to a fourth consecutive record year in 2007. The introduction to The 451 Group’s Technology M&A Outlook report lists the year’s significant deals, identifies M&A drivers and looks at the outlook for 2008.

headline: Eton Park Bulks Up Goodyear Stake
text: Hedge fund Eton Park Capital Management has raised its stake in Goodyear Tire & Rubber to 7.7 percent.

headline: Cerberus’s Feinberg Testifies in United Rentals Trial
text: Stephen Feinberg, the famously reclusive founder of hedge fund and private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, faced a grilling Tuesday over his decision to pull out of the $7 billion takeover of United Rentals during the first day of trial in the court battle.

headline: Banks Study Rescue of Bond Insurer ACA
text: Officials from Merrill Lynch, Bear Stearns and other major banks are in talks to bail out a struggling bond insurance company that has guaranteed $26 billion in mortgage securities, according to The New York Times, because the insurer’s woes could force the banks to take on billions in losses they had insured against.

headline: Cobham Buys BAE Surveillance Unit for $240 Million
text: British aerospace company Cobham said it had agreed to buy BAE Systems‘s Pennsylvania-based Surveillance and Attack business unit for $240 million.

headline: Are Wall Street Analysts Worth Their Salt?
text: Maybe Wall Street analysts are more honest and less compromised than they were pre-Sarbanes-Oxley, but recent events show that they’re still awful at their most important job: predicting bad news, writes Fortune’s Geoff Colvin.

headline: Credit Crunch Crimps Manhattan Office Deals
text: Once part of the sprawling Nabisco cookie complex, the eight-story red-brick building at 450 East 15th Street, just east of 10th Avenue in the meatpacking district of Manhattan, is the epitome of understated warehouse chic, with polished concrete floors and century-old brick walls and frosted windows.

headline: NetSuite Boost Price Range Again
text: NetSuite‘s hotly anticipated initial public offering just keeps getting hotter.

headline: How Long Can Goldman Keep It Up?
text: Goldman Sachs did it again. Now the question is whether the Wall Street bank can do it again and again.

headline: Morgan Stanley Posts Loss, Sells Stake to China
text: Morgan Stanley posted a fourth-quarter loss, its first-ever quarterly loss, after taking an additional $5.7 billion write-down related to subprime mortgages. The investment bank said it would sell a $5 billion stake to the China Investment Corporation, that country’s sovereign wealth fund, to shore up its capital.

headline: Silver Lake to Take Stake in Gerson Lehrman
text: Silver Lake Partners has agreed to acquire a quarter of the Gerson Lehrman Group, the upstart Wall Street research firm that has come under scrutiny from regulators, according to The New York Times.

headline: Manager of Failed Bear Funds Leaves Firm
text: Ralph Cioffi, the manager of Bear Stearns hedge funds that invested in subprime mortgages, has left the firm as U.S. prosecutors investigate whether he withdrew money from two funds before they collapsed in July, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Rubenstein Buys Copy of Magna Carta
text: David M. Rubenstein, chief of the private equity firm Carlyle Group, did some serious holiday shopping on Tuesday — but he won’t be taking his purchase, a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta, home with him. Though Mr. Rubenstein won the auction for the document with a $19 million bid ($21.3 million with fees and commissions), he told reporters he was just a “temporary custodian” of the historic piece of parchment, which David Redden, Sotheby’s vice chairman, called “the most important document in the world, the birth certificate of freedom.”

headline: A Spout and a River of Blood
text: Every year, the Bagger develops an awards season crush. This time around he’s got one on SpoutBlog, which never fails to freak out and amaze him when he gives it a click. Take, for instance, what the blog sees as the scariest thing about “Sweeney.”

headline: The Early Word: Looking for Magic in Iowa
text: In these final stages of the campaigns in Iowa, some of the candidates have retooled their styles and their speeches on the stump. The Times’s Adam Nagourney examines John Edwards’s closing argument to Iowa’s caucusgoers, voters who know him well.

headline: Food Stuff
text: Second Avenue Deli, Now Farther North

headline: Pulling Back the Curtain on the Scene
text: David Hudson at GreenCineDaily, who loves movies and all the writing about movies, has come to realize that “The Lives of Others,” the drama about the last days of East Germany, is fatally flawed. He ought to know because, it turns out, Mr. Hudson lives in Berlin. And the Bagger thought covering movies from Jersey was tough.

headline: The Vulture Has Landed
text: Who can make jokes about bongs and erections seem tenderhearted?

headline: From Here to Eternity
text: Tom O’Neil of The Envelope tells The Associated Press that the writers’ strike during awards season may reveal a dark industry secret: “We may finally find out how vapid and empty these stars really are.”

headline: The Bummer Oscars
text: Remember the post-9/11 Oscars, when the gowns, the glitter and the gaiety seemed a little beside the point? Salon does, and though Los Angeles is not reeling from a terrorist outrage, it is going to be a bit weird for the place to get its party on, given the pall hanging over the town, which seems to part only for verbal flamethrowing.

headline: A New Agreement to Reduce Congestion at J.F.K.
text: The United States transportation secretary will announce an agreement with the airlines to ease congestion at Kennedy International Airport next summer by shifting some flights to less busy times, Matthew L. Wald reports. As a result, the department will not, at least for now, order a reduction in the number of flights per hour at Kennedy, and will not immediately issue rules to carry out a more controversial tactic — auctioning off landing slots — to reduce the number of flights to Kennedy.

headline: Interesting Obama history
text: I’ve been alerted to an interesting Boston Globe article about Barack Obama’s role, when he was in the Illinois legislature, in the attempt to get the state committed to universal health care. It turns out that the story very much prefigures the debates we’re having right now.

headline: Q and A: Peter Hoffman
text: For several decades now the chef Peter Hoffman has been a fixture of the downtown dining scene, and he championed a farm-fresh, seasonal approach to cooking and menus before it was a gospel as widely preached —- and a religion as enthusiastically practiced —- as it is today.

headline: Iowa Forecast: A Foggy Day in Cedar Rapids
text: Countdown: 15 days until Caucus Day. Five shopping days until Christmas. (The Forecast feels a little panicky about that, especially since campaign travel does not usually include shopping.)

headline: Wednesday Kickoff: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
text: These coaches have been going about this whole quitting thing all wrong. Spencer Hall, who is the mind behind Every Day Should Be Saturday, uses his Sporting News column as a forum to dispense educational information about how to correctly leave a coaching job.

headline: Morgan Investment Marks Shift for China Fund
text: From Keith Bradsher, DealBook’s colleague in Hong Kong:

headline: In Iowa, It Ain’t Over …
text: Most political prognosticators have reduced the Iowa caucuses to a two-person field in both parties: Hillary Clinton vs. Barack Obama and Mike Huckabee vs. Mitt Romney. But The Des Moines Register’s David Yepsen says it’s a mistake to write off John Edwards and Fred Thompson.

headline: The (Energy) Future Is Not Now
text: The FutureGen Alliance — a partnership of coal producers and users and government — yesterday announced the Illinois site of what would be America’s first utility-scale zero-emissions coal-powered electrical plant. The plant will also, in theory, produce a stream of pure hydrogen fuel and a stream of carbon dioxide in a form ready to pump into the earth for long-term storage so it doesn’t heat the climate.

headline: Fire in a White House Office Building
text: The Lede is following the fire at the Eisenhower Executive Office Building in Washington with frequent updates during the day, in chronological order — scroll to the bottom of the post for the latest additions.

headline: N.H. Forecast: Winter Sports
text: With a little less than three weeks left until the first in the nation New Hampshire primary be sure to check The Caucus in the morning for an update on all the happenings in the Granite State.

headline: Board Approves Subway and Bus Fare Increase
text: Updated, 4:13 p.m. | After an unusually vigorous and spirited debate, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted at 10:50 a.m. today to raise fares on subways, buses and commuter railroads and tolls on bridges and tunnels.

headline: The Hallmark Campaign
text: Now Rudolph W. Giuliani’s political ads are getting into the Christmas spirit, just like Mike Huckabee.

headline: Oh, That Crazy Wife of Mine
text: The big news from Iowa Monday was that Mari Culver has endorsed John Edwards. This carries some weight, because Mrs. Culver is married to the state’s Democratic governor, Chet Culver, and her father-in-law is John Culver, the former senator. (John Culver also co-wrote a terrific biography of Henry Wallace, which I highly recommend for history or agriculture buffs, but that’s beside the point.)

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Jack Pendarvis
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

headline: Palm Gives Sinking Feeling to Elevation Partners
text: It has only been two months, but Elevation Partners‘ investment in Palm has been anything but uplifting so far. Elevation, a private equity firm whose founders include rock star Bono, invested $325 million in Palm in a deal that closed Oct. 24. Since then, Palm’s stock has lost nearly half of its value, after adjusting for a special dividend it paid out to shareholders.

headline: There’s No Place Like Home
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Making Hospitals Pay for Their Mistakes
text: In most businesses, customers don’t pay for a vendor’s mistakes. But when hospitals make errors, they charge patients additional money to fix the problem.

headline: TCI Starts Proxy Fight at CSX
text: Two activist hedge funds took another shot at CSX on Wednesday as they named an alternate slate of directors, in the first sign that they will wage a proxy fight.

headline: Holiday Gifts | Editor’s Wish List (Day Two)
text: At this time of year, fashion magazine editors may have it worse than the general population. Every day we find ourselves surrounded by beautiful objects — falling in love is an occupational hazard. Which is why, come holiday time, making a list is almost impossible. Where do we start? This week several T editors share their material desires. Friends and family: take note! (Yesterday’s gift list can be found here.)

headline: Do You Know the Words to the Edwards Fight Song?
text: DES MOINES — Campaigns use music at rallies for two purposes. The first is to pump up the crowd, with exciting anthematic music designed to stir the soul and get the adrenaline flowing. (That, by the way, is the real reason U2 exists).

headline: Richardson Ad: Back to Iraq
text: The Democrats might differ subtly on health care, immigration and education, but Bill Richardson wants voters to remember he’s all alone on one issue: Iraq.

headline: ‘The Same Colorist as Paulie Walnuts’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send them via the comment link below):

headline: At Morgan Stanley, Succession Still in Question
text: John Mack is giving up his bonus in 2007. Will the chief of Morgan Stanley need to give up his job as well?

headline: Will Letterman Return On Jan. 2 Too?
text: Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien of NBC and Jimmy Kimmel of ABC will return to their respective broadcasts on Jan. 2, without writers. David Letterman and Craig Ferguson of CBS want to return the same day ­ but with writers.

headline: Peace in Our Time
text: Warrior Ant Press makes a modest proposal:

headline: Go Big or Stay Home
text: David Poland writes in his blog that for the striking writers, the middle way is fraught with peril.

headline: Exegesis Is Not on the List
text: NOTE: The Screen Actors Guild nominations have been announced. Here is a full list.

headline: Question Marks Over the Awards Shows
text: The Writers Guild of America’s decision to block writers from working on the Golden Globes and block the Academy Awards’ producers from using historical film clips could hurt the two television networks — NBC and ABC, respectively — that are set to broadcast the award shows early next year.

headline: Obama Family Sends Christmas Cheer
text: OK, so to recap: When it comes to Christmas ads, Rudy Giuliani has Santa Claus on his side, and Mike Huckabee urges everyone to remember the birth of Jesus. But Barack Obama’s holiday greeting has a sugarplum cuteness factor that just might outweigh the other two — his adorable little girls.

headline: The Energy Bill: A Hero and a Villain
text: President Bush has just signed into law an energy bill that could have been even better but still remains an impressive achievement. The long struggle to produce that bill yielded the usual quotient of heroes and villains, but two deserve special mention:

headline: Famous in a Small Town
text: One of the eeriest photography books of 2007 has got to be Brian Howell’s “Fame Us: Celebrity Impersonators and the Cult(ure) of Fame,” published by Arsenal Pulp Press.

headline: Simon’s Suspension: 30 Games
text: Headlines on various newspaper Web sites say Chris Simon has received the longest penalty in National Hockey League history. The articles say the length of the suspension for intent to injure by using your skate on a player’s leg is 30 games. What are we seeing that the NHL is not?

headline: Imagining Super Taxis of the Future
text: A hypercharged MetroCard that could be used on both taxis and subways? Taxi fares subsidized by advertising? G.P.S.-mapping of empty taxis available for download? Group cab rides from Shea Stadium? Late-night buses replaced by taxis? A one-passenger cab?

headline: Nine Strikes and He’s Out?
text: The verdict is in: Chris Simon of the Islanders has been suspended for 30 games for his skate stomp of Jarkko Ruutu’s foot. This is the longest suspension in league history, longer even than the 25 games Simon received for a two-handed slash to the chin of the Rangers’ Ryan Hollweg last season. It was Simon’s eighth suspension in all.

headline: Off-Field News Disheartening; Rivalries Exciting
text: A survey of soccer Web sites this morning yields an eclectic mix of news, and the off-the-field stuff is quite disheartening:

headline: NASL Jerseys Never Go Out of Style
text: One of the more enlightened things the Cosmos of the old North American Soccer League did in the 1980s was issue players snazzy Ellesse bathrobes in the team’s blue and yellow colors. The reason: Because a growing number of female reporters demanded (and deserved) entry into the team’s locker room and the Cosmos were not about to alienate anyone.

headline: Mets Sign Reliever Wise
text: Although their primary off-season goal of acquiring a front-line starter remains unfulfilled, the Mets are trying to offset those troubles by bolstering their bullpen. On Tuesday, they signed Matt Wise, a right-handed reliever who pitched last season for the Milwaukee Brewers, to a one-year contract.

headline: An Odd Couple: Kissinger and McCain
text: BOSTON — The setting of Senator John McCain’s event here was replete with imagery meant to play into his strengths.

headline: S&P Cuts Rating on Bond Insurer ACA
text: Citing deepening problems in the mortgage market, Standard & Poor’s on Wednesday cut the rating of one troubled bond insurer, ACA Financial, and assigned a negative outlook to ratings of four other companies that guarantee debts tied to home loans.

headline: Al Lord Finds: You Can’t Go Home Again
text: Al Lord is in his second term as chief executive of Sallie Mae, having had to return to the helm thanks to the credit crunch killing the takeover deal (at $60 a share) that would have left him set for life.

headline: Man of the year
text: All I know about Time’s Man of the Year is that there was a flap in Russia over an alleged resemblance between the president and Dobby the house elf from Harry Potter.

headline: Bitten by Blackstone, China Wants Interest This Time
text: Is China getting more savvy with its Wall Street deals?

headline: Romney Ad Shows His Human Side
text: Mitt Romney is out with his ad that will be up in Iowa and New Hampshire into Christmas week, one that pulls off a twofer — showcasing his executive experience while also offering a glimpse of his humanity.

headline: Does This Bus Go to the Future?
text: Daimler Buses North America announced on Monday that the New York Metropolitan Transit Authority has ordered 850 diesel-electric hybrid Orion VII Next Generation buses. The M.T.A. first announced its intent to order new buses in October, pending approval of the agency’s board. The order will increase the number of M.T.A. hybrid-electric buses to nearly 1,700, the largest fleet of hybrid-electrics in the world.

headline: Ratings Win for ‘Biggest Loser’
text: After losing 164 pounds — nearly half his body weight — 40-year-old Bill Germanakos became the fourth winner of “The Biggest Loser” on Tuesday, as the show’s season finale helped NBC eke out a first place finish in the ratings for the night.

headline: Clintons Cling to the 1990s
text: INDEPENDENCE, Iowa – For all of the recent stories about Bill Clinton, and for all of his punchy remarks that can steal the spotlight from his wife, it’s worth noting that the Clinton campaign continues to highlight him as a big asset, and has been running toward – not away from – memories of the Clinton administration.

headline: CNN’s Obama/Osama Habit
text: Inside the pressure-cooker that is live television, the name Barack Obama apparently becomes tricky.

headline: Romney Plays Down Expectations
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa—Knowing politics is invariably about beating or not beating expectations, Mitt Romney made a point of claiming he was 22 points down to Mike Huckabee in Iowa four different times to reporters here on Wednesday.

headline: Edwards Subtly Jabs at Rivals
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. –­ John Edwards started off a news conference on Wednesday by counterattacking what he called a “veiled reference” made about him by Senator Hillary Clinton.
