headline: Pondering the Pool
text: One of the issues Paul and I worked on while we were in Florida — but didn’t resolve — was the pool. The question is, what kind of pool?

headline: Mutlu yillar, or why Santa is strolling the streets of Istanbul
text: A street vendor in Istanbul selling New Year goodies. “Mutlu yillar” means happy New Year. (AP)

headline: Obama Hears Middle-Class Concerns in N.H.
text: CONCORD, N.H. — With tears in her eyes, Sandra Burt, who lives with her husband in a double-wide mobile home here and said she can barely afford the medication she needs every month, sat across a table from Senator Barack Obama and asked him what he could do to help.

headline: Clinton Vows Regular Pullout of Brigades
text: ELKADER, Iowa – Iraq doesn’t come up on the presidential campaign trail as much as it once did, but Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was asked here Wednesday afternoon when she would “bring the boys home” – and gave a blunter and less conditional answer than usual.

headline: Wednesday in the Bunker: Looking Forward
text: After all that has happened on Wednesday, I’m trying to take the long view about hockey and the bunker.

headline: Design Team Picked for Governors Island Park
text: A team of five design companies was chosen today to design the transformation of Governors Island from an abandoned military base into a 90-acre open space at the heart of New York Harbor. The new parkland will include a two-mile promenade on the water’s edge, a 40-acre park occupying the southern half of the island and improvements in the historic military district that makes up the northern half of the island and includes structures built as early as 1810.

headline: Clinton’s Holiday Ad: Wrapping It Up
text: Scissors snipping shiny wrapping paper, a fancy ribbon ready to be tied in a bow, “Carol of the Bells” chiming in the background… is it a Martha Stewart ad?

headline: The Leadership Divide
text: Since a lot of you have asked how the recent Clinton-Obama feud is playing out on the ground here in Iowa, let me offer one more post on the subject before moving on to other things.

headline: How Much to Go to the Trees?
text: A holiday film by Partners & Spade.

headline: The Bride Wore Two-Ply
text: With the expectations and costs of weddings skyrocketing these days, both richer and poorer couples find with debt do they start.The Vows column can often feel like the adult version of My Super Sweet Sixteen. Then again, couples can buck the trend and go to Cheap Chic Weddings, a Web site that aggregates money-saving tips on catering, gowns, wedding music, flowers, among other things.

headline: Media Frenzy 101: A Kid-TV Star, Pregnant at 16
text: Celebrity misadventures rarely interest The Lede very much, not least because so many other news outlets just can’t seem to resist masticating each one to a glutinous pulp. Why dive into the Dumpster after them?

headline: Why Hand Washing May Be Your Best Medicine
text: Everyone knows hand washing is important. But a new study shows how washing your hands often, and at the right time, can have a big impact on your family’s risk for getting sick.

headline: Vote Ends Strike of Van Service for Disabled
text: Members of Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union voted this afternoon to ratify a contract settlement, ending a 10-day strike that inconvenienced about 9,000 wheelchair users and other people with disabilities who depend on Access-a-Ride, a government-financed van services to get around.About 1,500 drivers and mechanics began their strike on Monday morning, shutting down operations at Atlantic Paratrans, the Maggies Paratransit Corporation, MV Transportation and the Transit Facility Management Corporation. The four companies operate about half of the approximately 20,500 rides provided each average weekday under the paratransit program, which runs door-to-door van service for eligible residents who cannot use regular public transit.

headline: Oh, Lord: Sallie Mae’s Conference Call
text: Albert L. Lord may have just learned a nearly $3 billion lesson.

headline: Edwards’s Somber Holiday Message
text: John Edwards appeals to the generosity of Americans in his holiday TV ad, set to appear in Iowa and New Hampshire beginning Sunday.

headline: Unknown housing territory
text: I’m still trying to work out the implications of this, but some thoughts about the size of the bubble: at an aggregate level, the housing bubble looks like something we’ve seen before. The rise in the price-rental ratio was somewhat larger than the rise that took place in Los Angeles in the late 1980s, but in the same general ballpark.

headline: A Kid-TV Star, Pregnant at 16
text: The Lede blog writes about Jamie Lynn Spears — younger sister of Britney, star of the hit Nickelodeon TV series “Zoey 101″ and now, at 16, a mother to be — and her television persona:

headline: Politics in South Korea
text: The victory of Lee Myung-bak, a pro-business candidate dogged by corruption allegations, puts South Korea's conservative party back in power.

headline: A $300 Speeding Ticket? Just Kidding!
text: The Associated Press reports that police officers in Rancho Cordova, Calif., a suburb of Sacramento, plan to pull drivers over during the holidays to give them — not tickets or warnings, but $5 Starbucks gift certificates, as rewards for good driving.

headline: Talk Off | Shoulder Pads
Paul Allen and Echostar Line Up for Spectrum Auction
text: The Federal Communications Commission has released the list of 266 bidders for its big auction of wireless spectrum that starts next month. There are a few surprises: Echostar, the satellite TV company, and Paul Allen’s Vulcan group are among those registered to bid. (A Vulcan spokesman declined to comment. Echostar hasn’t yet returned a call.)

headline: The Safety Hazard on Your Lap
text: [Correction Appended]

headline: The Web Is Overrun With Elves
text: Add another entry to the list of massively popular, rapidly spreading and slightly bizarre viral Web phenomena: OfficeMax’s ElfYourself.com.

headline: Movie Minutes: Charlie Wilson's War
text: A. O. Scott reviews "Charlie Wilson's War," a new film starring Tom Hanks and based on a true story of a congressman who helped to end the Cold War.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Sweeney Todd'
text: A.O. Scott reviews Tim Burton's latest, an adaptation of Stephen Sondheim's musical about a vengeful barber, starring Johnny Depp.

headline: City Council Approves Columbia Expansion Plan
text: After an unusually lengthy debate, the New York City Council cleared the way for a 17-acre campus expansion by Columbia University, the largest in its history. The 35 to 5 vote, with 6 members abstaining, followed a hectic day of committee meetings and was the final significant step in a rezoning process that pitted the university and its supporters against a coalition that included the local community board and some property owners and residents.

headline: Over?
text: The rapid transit from design boutique to catalog to that's-so-last-year.

headline: Iron Mike Is on a Roll
text: Mike Keenan, the guy who guided the Rangers to the Cup that may have to stand for this generation, has just completed one of the most successful road swings in N.H.L. history with his Calgary Flames.

headline: Quotes of the Year
text: The 10 most memorable quotes of 2007, according to Fred R. Shapiro, editor of the Yale Book of Quotations:

headline: About my son
text: This is pretty funny. There’s a rumor spreading that my son works for the Hillary campaign.

headline: Citi Lays Off 30 C.D.O. Bankers: The Internal Memo
text: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague

headline: Strike News: Shifting New Shows
text: Underscoring the topsy-turvy nature of the network’s strike schedules, ABC and NBC made tweaks to two midseason show premieres on Wednesday.

headline: Little Shop of…
text: Thursday’s paper has a story about Pantone’s choosing Blue Iris as its color for 2008. The reporting did yield a certain symmetry: Raf Simons’ dresses and pantsuits in Yves Klein blue for Jil Sander’s fall 2007; a super cool and curvy sofa by Zaha Hadid in a similar hue, and those blossomy colors in the spring 2008 Balenciaga show. Of course that only proves that Pantone is on the curve, and not ahead of it, and I recognize the pure publicity value of “naming” a color from the 21st century palette. As if.

headline: Alzheimer's: The Rarest Gene
text: One family's deadly struggle with early-onset Alzheimer's has given scientists a window into the disease and its genetic origins.

headline: Viacom Dumps DoubleClick for Microsoft
text: Microsoft and Viacom today  announced a multiyear content and advertising partnership. Under the deal, Microsoft will become the exclusive seller of remnant display ads on Viacom’s Web sites. (“Remnant” refers to ad space that Viacom cannot sell through its own sales force.) In addition, Microsoft will use technology from aQuantive, which it recently bought, to serve ads on Viacom’s Web sites; it will buy ads on Viacom’s online and broadcast networks; and it will license Viacom content, on a nonexclusive basis, for use on outlets like MSN and the Xbox 360.

headline: Alzheimer’s: Quest for Understanding
text: Fritzie Hess is determined to help scientists understand Alzheimer's.  She lost her father to it and cares for a sister who has advanced dementia.

headline: Google: There’s Nobody in Our Black Box. Yet.
text: My post Tuesday about the role of humans in Google’s search results misinterpreted a comment by Peter Norvig, Google’s head of research. In an interview with Technology Review, Mr. Norvig talked about how the search engine has a vast network of part-time employees evaluating how good its results are. As I read the interview, I incorrectly thought he was saying that human ratings were fed into Google’s algorithms and used, alongside PageRank and other quantitative measures of pages, to determine the order in which sites are listed in response to a given query.

headline: E.P.A. to States: CO2 Is Not Your Problem
text: An unbending reality in Washington is that when someone has to release news that’s likely to generate criticism, it comes after hours. So one can assume the Bush administration was bracing for incoming fire when the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Stephen L. Johnson, scheduled a phone briefing for 6:30 tonight.

headline: Obama: Stop Chinese Toy Imports
text: CONCORD, N.H. — At a campaign stop here on Wednesday, presidential candidate Barack Obama took a hard line on the import of toys from China, saying that he now favors an outright ban.

headline: Opening the German-Polish Border
text: Security and control at the once-contentious border between Germany and Poland ease further, but divisions remain.

headline: Notes From Down Under
Bloggingheads: Waterboarding
text:
Paul Glastris of the Washington Monthly and Byron York of National Review debate the usefulness of harsh interrogation techniques.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Romney’s Holiday Party Draws a Crowd
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Take that Mike Huckabee.

headline: Newly Released
text: Anyone looking through publishers’ catalogs might be convinced that the book industry has dispensed with December, as many companies go straight from the blockbusters of November to the take-a-chance books of January. Still, a small group of authors (including a Nobel Prize winner and a couple of perennial best-seller writers) dare to hit the shelves this month. In a couple of cases the books listed below aren’t officially published until January, but they’ll be in the stores before the new year.

headline: E.P.A. Says 17 States Can’t Set Emission Rules
text: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday denied California and 16 other states the right to set their own standards for carbon dioxide emissions from automobiles.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Indoor Water Garden

headline: 2 Young Hedge-Fund Veterans Stir Up the World of Philanthropy
text: As hedge-fund analysts, Holden Karnofsky and Elie Hassenfeld made six-figure incomes deciding which companies to invest in. Now they are doing the same thing with charities, for a lot less pay.

headline: A Field Guide to the Rituals and Foibles of the Wild Potomac Man
text: “Homo Politicus” ought to be a solemn book, but it reeks of unseemly glee. Although Dana Milbank, The Washington Post’s “Washington Sketch” columnist, has collected a rich compendium of astoundingly ill-advised acts and statements on the parts of public officials, he fails to register the threat posed by such ineptitude. Instead he treats greed, egomania, ruthlessness, corruption, stupidity and extreme feats of partisanship lightly. (From the office of Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma: “Mars Has Global Warming Despite Absence of S.U.V.s.”) It’s as if he thinks these things are funny.

headline: Inquiry Focuses on Marine in Death of Iraqi Officer
text: BAGHDAD  A United States marine is at the center of an American military investigation into the death of an Iraqi policeman on Monday from what appears to have been a knife fight between the men at a base jointly manned by American and Iraqi forces in Anbar Province, a military spokesman said.

headline: Gems in the Back of a Closet
text: To ordinary people, the end of the year brings holiday gatherings, gift-giving and New Year’s resolutions. To a technology critic, though, the year’s end also brings a sobering realization: no matter how hard you try, no matter how many columns and blog entries you write, you can’t review everything.

headline: In New Jersey, a Health Plan to Cover Uninsured Children
text: WOODBRIDGE, N.J.  Moving New Jersey closer to universal health care coverage, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Wednesday that the state had reached an agreement with Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield allowing working- and middle-class families to obtain health insurance for children at drastically reduced rates.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on June 30, 2000, about Tobin Rote, a championship quarterback for the Detroit Lions in the 1950s, misstated his full name, referred incorrectly to a relative in the list of survivors and omitted the names of two others. He was Tobin Cornelius Rote Sr.  not Jr.

headline: Jamie Lynn Spearsis Pregnant at 16
text: Jamie Lynn Spears, right, the 16-year-old star of the popular Nickelodeon series “Zoey 101” and the sister of the troubled singer Britney Spears, 26, said she was 12 weeks pregnant by her boyfriend, Casey Aldridge, The Associated Press reported. “It was a shock for both of us, so unexpected,” Jamie Lynn told OK! magazine. “I was in complete shock, and so was he.” Her mother, Lynne Spears, said: “I didn’t believe it because Jamie Lynn’s always been so conscientious. She’s never late for curfew. I was in shock. I mean, this is my 16-year-old baby.” Jamie Lynn said she planned to rear the baby in her home state, Louisiana, “so it can have a normal family life.” In a statement, Nickelodeon said: “We respect Jamie Lynn’s decision to take responsibility in this sensitive and personal situation.” The third season of “Zoey 101” ends on Jan. 4. Filming of the fourth season, beginning in February, has been completed.

headline: Officers Charged in Cocaine Disappearance
text: Two city police officers were arraigned Wednesday on charges of misconduct and falsifying records in connection with the disappearance of 11 bags of cocaine.

headline: An Encore for Gypsy
text: Well, they had the hopes and the rhythm and the girl to go with ’em, but they needed the time and place. And, after much considering and calculating, they’ve got those, too. A revival of “Gypsy,” based on the production that was part of the summer’s City Center Encores! series and starred Patti LuPone, Boyd Gaines and Laura Benanti, is to begin previews on March 3 at the St. James Theater on Broadway. The opening is March 27. The three headliners are coming with the show, and further casting is to be announced.

headline: France Convicts 5 Former Guantánamo Inmates
text: PARIS (AP)  A court convicted five former inmates of the American detention center at Guantánamo Bay on Wednesday on terrorism-related charges, but did not send any of them back to prison in France. A sixth man was acquitted.

headline: Charter Schools Outshine Others as They Receive Their First Report Cards
text: Education officials, acting under the city’s new system of accountability, released report cards on Wednesday for several charter schools, with the majority receiving A’s and B’s, but one school in Queens getting an F.

headline: Columbia’s Historic Atom Smasher Is Now Destined for the Junk Heap
text: Columbia University has decided to junk a 70-year-old atom smasher that is the nation’s oldest artifact of the nuclear era, ending weeks of internal debate and lobbying over its fate.

headline: Simplify the Controllers, and Everyone’s a Video Gamer
text: Pass a traditional video game controller to someone older than 50, and you are likely to get a look of bewilderment. That’s one reason Nintendo’s Wii controller  modeled after the familiar TV remote  has mass appeal, even in places like retirement homes. As the battle for the living-room screen escalates, there are signs that Sony and Microsoft are seeing the importance of simplified controls as well.

headline: Bond Insurer Cut to Junk; Negative Outlook for 4 More
text: Citing deepening problems in the mortgage market, Standard & Poor’s cut the rating of one troubled bond insurer on Wednesday and assigned a negative outlook to four other companies that guarantee debts linked to home loans.

headline: Art Show Imperiled
text: A major exhibition of art from Russia, scheduled to be shown next month at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, may not go on after Russian authorities again expressed fears that the paintings could be seized to satisfy private legal claims while in Britain, The Associated Press reported. The British cultural agency said it had assured Russia that the works to be displayed in “From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925” were protected under British law and would not be seized. But Zinaida Bonami, deputy director of the Pushkin Fine Arts Museum in Moscow, said the Russian federal cultural agency notified the Pushkin, the State Hermitage Museum, the Russian Museum and the Tretyakov Gallery on Tuesday that it would not issue an export license for the art, including works by Matisse and van Gogh. No specific British claims against the paintings were mentioned. Some of the paintings have rarely been seen outside Russia. A Russian cultural official said that a final decision on lending the paintings would be made on Thursday.

headline: $9.4 Billion Write-Down at Morgan Stanley
text: Morgan Stanley reported the first quarterly loss in its 72-year history Wednesday, heightening fears that the financial toll would keep mounting from the fast-spreading crisis in the subprime mortgage market.

headline: Already Got the iPhone? How About Making It Hands-Free?
text: What could you give to someone who already has an iPhone? One possibility is the Vibe Duo headset from V-Moda. It’s one of the first iPhone accessories that works both as a hands-free device for the phone and as a two-speaker headset for audio.

headline: Pete Rose’s Lesson for Roger Clemens
text: If, as it seems, Roger Clemens is following a script, expect him to write a book in 2022. Following the lead of a venerable leader, Pete Rose, Clemens will admit in the book that he used steroids when he played baseball, just as Brian McNamee told George J. Mitchell that Clemens did.

headline: New Subway Math May Bring Windfall of Spare Change to Transit System
text: Beginning in March, many subway and bus riders will have to learn a new math  and it could leave them scratching their heads. Or gnashing their teeth.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $3,163,562

headline: Foundation Hopes to Lure Top Students to Teaching
text: Taking the prestigious Rhodes Scholarships as a model, the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation in Princeton is creating a fellowship program that it hopes will lure top students into teaching and transform teacher education in the United States.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Today’s HDTV, or Next Year’s?
text: BUYERS of consumer electronics are haunted by one question: Should I buy now or wait for new features, better performance and lower prices?

headline: Mighty Canadians and a Book About Them
text: Two bridge books have received more press than any others this year. This is especially surprising for one of them, “The Backwash Squeeze & Other Improbable Feats” by Edward McPherson (HarperCollins), because it contains no deals. It is the story of the author’s quest to learn our game.

headline: Congress Averts Higher Tax Bill for Middle Class
text: WASHINGTON  Congress on Wednesday gave final approval to a plan that will spare millions of middle-class taxpayers higher tax bills for 2007. The White House welcomed the development and said President Bush would sign the bill.

headline: The Fed’s Empty Gun
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama’s Vote in Illinois Was Often Just ‘Present’
text: In 1999, Barack Obama was faced with a difficult vote in the Illinois legislature  to support a bill that would let some juveniles be tried as adults, a position that risked drawing fire from African-Americans, or to oppose it, possibly undermining his image as a tough-on-crime moderate.

headline: A Holiday Political Quiz
text: Five days to Christmas and two weeks to Iowa.

headline: Central Asia on Front Line in Energy Battle
text: BUKHARA, Uzbekistan  In the scrub brush desert south of this ancient Silk Road town, the natural gas wellheads are built on modest concrete platforms about the size of basketball courts. Because the gas is naturally pressurized, pumps are not needed to bring it to the surface. Pipes simply kiss the ground and gas pours through them.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article last Thursday about a major confrontation between the Congolese Army and a renegade general that is increasing the risk of war in Congo and threatening to undermine the fledgling democratic state misidentified the country’s first democratically chosen government. It was the one that took power at independence in 1960; it is not the current government, in office for a year.

headline: Grobans Christmas Grows Merrier
text: Breaking Elvis Presley’s record for the most consecutive weeks at No. 1 for a Christmas album, Josh Groban, above right, saw his “Noël” (Reprise) hold the top spot on the Billboard chart for the fourth week in a row. With 669,000 sales for the week that ended on Sunday, “Noël,” helped by Mr. Groban’s performance last month on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” also inched past the “High School Musical 2” soundtrack (Disney) to become the best-selling album of the year so far, with a total of 2.77 million copies sold, Nielsen SoundScan reported. (“High School Musical 2,” which sold 178,000 copies last week to reach No. 6, is right behind with 2.7 million, and two sales weeks remain for 2007.) With almost no new releases in stores, the rest of the Top 10 is little changed from last week. Alicia Keys holds at No. 2, the Eagles at No. 3 and “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 26 at No. 4. Mannheim Steamroller’s Christmas Song” (American Gramaphone) rose six spots to No. 5, Miley Cyrus is No. 7; Taylor Swift, No. 8; Carrie Underwood, No. 9; and Garth Brooks, No. 10.

headline: President Approves Realignment of the Army
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush has approved what officials are describing as the most significant realignment of the Army since World War II, signing off on a plan that will keep more troops than previously envisioned in Europe and add large numbers of soldiers to bases in Colorado, Georgia and Texas, Army officials said Wednesday.

headline: Mukasey Signals He’ll Be a Strong Bush Advocate
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey has signaled in his first weeks on the job that he intends to be a forceful advocate for some of President Bush’s most controversial antiterrorism policies, even if that means angering Congressional leaders who hoped that he would instead focus on repairing the strained relationship between the Justice Department and Capitol Hill.

headline: As Voting Nears, Romney Shifts Political Narrative
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H.  Mitt Romney was recounting to his audience here a political fable of sorts, about how he had never expected to get into politics after spending his life in business. The moral is one he has been telling again and again in his final sprint before the first votes of the 2008 presidential campaign are cast.

headline: Statistics on Children in Newark: Grim, With a Ray of Hope
text: NEWARK  The numbers bear out the conventional wisdom that growing up in New Jersey’s largest city can be rough. Each week, the authorities remove an average of 33 children from their homes because of abuse and neglect. Every month, about 150 teenagers are infected with a sexually transmitted disease. One-third of all children here live in poverty.

headline: G.M. Said to Be Selling a Truck Unit
text: DETROIT  Navistar International, an Illinois-based maker of trucks and diesel engines, is expected to announce Thursday that it is buying General Motors’ medium-duty truck business, according to people with direct knowledge of the discussions.

headline: The Green House as Classroom
text: WHEN the actors Alysia Reiner and David Alan Basche embarked on a renovation of their four-story, 5,000-square-foot row house in Harlem two years ago, they did not intend for it to become a show house. But a chance meeting with Michela O’Connor Abrams, the president and publisher of Dwell Magazine, led to a Web chronicle of the job on dwell.com, and turned the renovation into a marketing vehicle for manufacturers of environmentally conscious products and a chance for the couple to evangelize on green building.

headline: Britain Detains 3 Men Freed by U.S.
text: LONDON  Three former British residents who were held for more than four years in the Guantánamo Bay detention center arrived Wednesday at Luton, outside London, aboard a jet chartered by the government and were turned over to the police.

headline: Chinese Anti-Corruption Site Crashes
text: SHANGHAI  A Web site created by China’s anti-corruption bureau crashed after it began operating on Tuesday, overwhelmed by traffic from people wishing to file complaints, according to the Beijing Youth Daily newspaper.

headline: Bush Deflects Questions on C.I.A. Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush deflected questions on Thursday about the destruction of C.I.A. interrogation tapes, saying that he will withhold comment until investigations into the affair are complete.

headline: Lost and Found in London
text: To the Editor:

headline: Denmark: Christmas-Tree Growers Face Cartel Charges
text: The state prosecutor for serious economic crimes charged the Danish Christmas Tree Growers Association with price fixing. “The association has been charged with instructing its members over a four-year period what prices they should charge for their Christmas trees,” he said. Denmark exports about 10 million trees a year. Prices for Nordmann firs, coveted for their soft, long-lasting needles, rose 25 percent this season.

headline: A Cosmopolitan Cubist With a Wandering Eye
text: Charles G. Shaw (1892-1974) belongs to a generation of abstract painters who remain for the most part stubbornly lost. Active in the interwar period, they organized themselves into the American Abstract Artists when abstraction was viewed as un-American and then were largely swept aside by Abstract Expressionism.

headline: Guilty Plea From Ex-HealthSouth Exec
text: A former HealthSouth executive, Malcolm E. McVay, pleaded guilty Wednesday to making illegally structured bank deposits 10 months after being resentenced to probation for his role in the company’s $2.7 billion fraud.

headline: China: Complainers Crash Anti-Graft Web Site
text: A Web site created by China’s anti-corruption bureau crashed after it began operating on Tuesday, overwhelmed by traffic from people trying to file complaints, The Beijing Youth Daily reported. When the site, which is operated by the National Bureau of Corruption Prevention, reappeared online Wednesday, it contained more than 250 complaints, including several claims of official corruption.

headline: Corrections
text: The subheading with a front-page headline on Wednesday for an article about discussions between four top White House lawyers and the Central Intelligence Agency over whether to destroy videotapes showing secret interrogations of members of Al Qaeda referred imprecisely to the White House’s position thus far on the matter. While Bush administration officials have acknowledged some discussions leading up to the destruction of the tapes in November 2005, as the article noted, the White House itself has not officially said anything on the subject, so its role was not “wider than it said.” (A related article appears today on Page A6.) (Go to Article)

headline: Let Freedom Remain, Says Financier Who Bought Copy of Magna Carta
text: The man who paid $21.3 million for a 710-year-old copy of the Magna Carta, which laid the framework for the United States Constitution and is one of the most prized historic documents in the world, says he wants to keep the copy on display in the United States.

headline: Facing Treacherous Streets With Limited Mobility
text: “You just have to be careful,” said Jeffrey Watler, wearing a winter coat over the collared shirt required by his employer, a messenger service. Knapsack on his back, he threaded his way through pedestrians, bike messengers and dogs on the way to his next pickup near Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Leave Him in or Take Him Out? Coaches Ponder Clemens as a Speaker
text: In normal times, decisions undertaken by the Texas High School Baseball Coaches Association are not of much concern outside Texas. The seven members on the association’s executive board plan all-star games and the group’s yearly convention and help oversee the state playoffs.

headline: Japan: U.S. Pushes to Halt Humpback Whale Hunt
text: The United States is pushing Japan to suspend its hunt of humpback whales, and the American ambassador to Tokyo said an agreement to stop it may have already been reached. Japan dispatched its whaling fleet to the southern Pacific last month in the first major hunt of the endangered species since the 1960s.

headline: Portugal Polishes Its Image as the ‘West Coast of Europe’
text: FOR Portugal, the signing in Lisbon last week of a treaty to overhaul the governance of the European Union was a “tipping point,” said Manuel Pinho, Portugal’s minister for the economy and innovation.

headline: A Landscape’s Isolation Is Turned Into a Virtue
text: The winning design for a 40-acre park that would unfold across the southern half of Governors Island is not the kind of grand public-works project the city once championed. But in an age when developers regularly usurp the government’s planning role, it reflects the kind of imaginative, civic-minded thinking that can restore our faith in city and state leaders.

headline: Hopes Dim for U.N. Solution for Kosovo
text: UNITED NATIONS  The Security Council signaled Wednesday that it would not be able to resolve the status of Kosovo, the breakaway Serbian province, and that a solution would have to come from outside the United Nations.

headline: Winehouse Free on Bail
text: The British singer Amy Winehouse was released on bail after her arrest in an investigation into perverting the course of justice, Reuters reported. The police in London said on Wednesday that Ms. Winehouse, 24, was to return to a police station in March pending further inquiries. Her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, has been in custody for several weeks on charges of trying to pervert the course of justice in relation to an assault case.

headline: Bolivia’s Leader Says States’ Dispute Can Be Resolved
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia  At 6 a.m. in this city 11,900 feet above sea level, the corridors of the presidential palace are bitingly cold. Aides huddle in overcoats near space heaters. Soldiers clasping rifles with bayonets stand guard with chattering teeth.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.  What is the best way to clean a granite countertop?

headline: 21st-Century Justice
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Piano and Strings Make Room for the Horn
text: Chamber Music at the Y devoted its Tuesday evening concert at the 92nd Street Y (and a repeat on Wednesday) to works by Schumann and Brahms, with two well-known scores set beside two that usually slip below the radar.

headline: Ransom-Note Ads About Children’s Health Are Canceled
text: The Child Study Center at New York University said on Wednesday that it would halt an advertising campaign aimed at raising awareness of children’s mental and neurological disorders after the effort drew a strongly negative reaction.

headline: Congress Is Still Pursuing Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON  It has a been a difficult few years for earmarks, the pet spending projects that lawmakers pursue in Congress. They have been linked to felony cases, blamed for the national debt, stripped from the budget, exposed to public scrutiny and subjected to ridicule. Yet earmarks and the lawmakers who love them will not be denied.

headline: C.I.A. to Cooperate With House on Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has agreed to make documents related to the destruction of interrogation videotapes available to the House Intelligence Committee and to allow the agency’s top lawyer, John A. Rizzo, to testify about the matter, Congressional and intelligence officials said Wednesday.

headline: The Islanders’ Simon Is Banished 30 Games
text: Nine months ago, the N.H.L. handed down a 25-game suspension, its longest for an on-ice incident. The recipient was Chris Simon.

headline: Hitting the Bottom, the Bottom Hits Back
text: In this damp weather, it’s not hard to tell when the fans grab their clumpy jackets and head for the exits. The fans actually departed Madison Square Garden Wednesday night because the Knicks were winning by 19 points with 8 minutes 50 seconds left.

headline: Missing in a Snowy Forest for Days, a Family Is Safe
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A man and his three children who disappeared in the snowy woods last weekend were found shivering, but alive, by rescuers on Wednesday, in a three-day saga that began with a hunt for a Christmas tree and ended with what rescuers called a Christmas miracle.

headline: Illinois: Man Admits Ninth Killing, Police Say
text: The authorities named a ninth victim of a man who had previously confessed to killing eight women from 1977 to 1982. Police officials in Paducah, Ky., said the man, Timothy W. Krajcir, 63, had admitted to the 1979 kidnapping and murder of Joyce Tharp, 29. Earlier this month, officials announced that Mr. Krajcir, who has been imprisoned since 1983, had confessed to the killings of five women in Missouri, two in Illinois and one in Pennsylvania. Sexual assault accompanied many of the killings. Mr. Krajcir, who has yet to be charged in three of the killings, awaits extradition from Illinois to Missouri, where he faces multiple life sentences.

headline: A Bigger Screen for the Gamer With High-Definition Needs
text: While it is nice to have a big-screen HDTV in the living room, these behemoths are not intended to keep up with high-end game consoles and PCs. Now, however, there’s the Sharp Aquos LC-32GP3U, a high-definition television created especially for gamers.

headline: Ways to Lead: Reach Out, or Confront?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wouldn’t You Know It, the Knicks Win
text: In the wake of protests and chants, taunts and insults  all aimed at a team and a coach that has pushed its fans to the point of insanity  the Knicks found a new way to torture their critics Wednesday. They won, big.

headline: After Chief Holds a Chat, Sallie Mae Stock Plunges
text: You known the conference call is going badly when the chief executive tells shareholders they will have to walk through a metal detector the next time they meet.

headline: G.M. Selling a Truck Business to Navistar
text: DETROIT  General Motors said Thursday that it had agreed to sell its medium-duty truck business to Navistar International, an Illinois-based maker of trucks and diesel engines.

headline: Giants Look to Rookies to Fill Shockey’s Void
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Kevin Boss has been called the un-Jeremy Shockey. Even Boss struggles to build a list of similarities between the two.

headline: Washington: Lawyers Can Take a Number
text: A Web site that rates lawyers the way Zagat rates restaurants, by number, is protected by the First Amendment, a federal judge in Seattle ruled Tuesday. Saying the ratings assigned by the Web site, Avvo, are opinions rather than facts, the judge, Robert S. Lasnik of Federal District Court, dismissed a lawsuit brought by two disgruntled lawyers, John Henry Browne and Alan J. Wenokur, who claimed their low rankings had cost them clients and money. “Rather than seeing the Avvo ratings for what they are  ‘that and $1.50 will get you a ride on Seattle’s new South Lake Union Streetcar’  plaintiffs Brown and Wenokur want to make a federal case out of the number assigned to them,” Judge Lasnik wrote.

headline: The Evolution of a Man Called ‘Bulldozer’
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The man chosen as South Korea’s next president in Wednesday’s election owes much of his victory to a wildly successful project he completed as this city’s mayor: the restoration in 2005 of a paved-over, four-mile stream in downtown Seoul, over which an ugly highway had been built during the growth-at-all-cost 1970s.

headline: Late Shows to Return, but Who’ll Be Talking?
text: LOS ANGELES  The late-night talk show hosts are returning. But the stars are not yet ready to come out for them.

headline: Lieberman as the Eccentric Uncle in a Democratic Family Feud
text: Given the surfeit of circus rings engaged under the political big top, there are only so many acts that can get much attention.

headline: Bear Stearns Loss Presages More Turmoil
text: Bear Stearns reported its first quarterly loss ever in its eight-decade history on Thursday, stung by the mortgage crisis that has swept markets across the globe.

headline: Jury Rejects Man’s Bid for Share of ‘Sopranos’
text: TRENTON  A jury in federal court here found the writer and producer David Chase, much like Tony Soprano, the character he created, to be a man of influence who could grant valuable favors.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Wheelchair Van Operators End Strike
text: A 10-day strike that inconvenienced about 9,000 wheelchair users and other people with disabilities who depend on Access-a-Ride, a government-financed van service, ended on Wednesday when members of Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union voted to ratify a contract settlement.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Ian Hunter, at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, misidentified the bass player in his Rant Band. He is Paul Page  not Graham Maby, who has played with Mr. Hunter.

headline: Refugees Risk Coming Home to an Unready Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  The widow Hashim crossed the border into Iraq from Syria at dusk last month, heading homeward as the sun set behind her and the sky ahead grew dark.

headline: The Civilized World Finds a Refuge
text: I DON’T know about you, but I don’t get the holiday blues anymore. That syndrome seems like a quaint, forgettable rash compared with my now-annual The World Is Headed for Disaster winter panic, which is caused by exposure to extreme weather changes, scary news reports and unrelentingly cheery holiday excess.

headline: Backing Up Master Mixes
text: Q. Is it possible to back up an iTunes playlist?

headline: Nanotechnology Companies Planning to Sell Shares
text: NANOTECHNOLOGY companies, nurtured on billions of dollars in government grants and venture investments through most of this decade, are getting ready to go public.

headline: Slowing the Rise in Health Costs
text: With the disjointed American health care system in perpetual crisis, it is essential to find ways to slow the relentless rise in costs, without jeopardizing the quality of care. There is no single solution. But a broad range of reforms could combine to produce worthwhile savings.

headline: Plaintiff Drops Suit Against Leonard Lauder
text: A grandson of a Viennese woman who disappeared in the Holocaust has dropped his lawsuit in Manhattan Federal Court demanding the return of a Gustav Klimt painting from the private collection of Leonard A. Lauder, the cosmetics magnate. The lawsuit was abandoned because of conflicting evidence, said E. Randol Schoenberg, a lawyer for the plaintiff. In a statement Mr. Lauder said: “We are pleased that the case has been withdrawn. It confirms what we’ve always asserted, that there is no evidence to support the claim.” The plaintiff, Georges Jorisch, 79, had charged that the painting was owned by his grandmother Amalie Redlich, who disappeared after she was deported by the Nazis to the Lodz ghetto in Poland in 1941. The signed oil painting, “Blooming Meadow” (1906), was purchased by Mr. Lauder in 1983 from the art dealer Serge Sabarsky.

headline: Paying Homage to Visions of Bowl Games Gone By
text: It is nearly time to break out the Barcalounger, football fans. Bowl season kicks off this week, setting off an indulgence of 32 televised games in 20 days featuring teams and players you have scarcely heard of and may never hear from again.

headline: Bank of Japan Holds Its Key Rate Steady
text: TOKYO (Bloomberg News)  The Bank of Japan kept interest rates steady on Thursday in its first unanimous decision since June, after a drop in business confidence signaled that companies were bracing for slower growth.

headline: A Pause From Death
text: The United Nations General Assembly voted on Tuesday for a global moratorium on the death penalty. The resolution was nonbinding; its symbolic weight made barely a ripple in the news ocean of the United States, where governments’ right to kill a killer is enshrined in law and custom.

headline: A Centennial Face-Lift for a Beaux-Arts Gem
text: About four years ago, Paul LeClerc, president of the New York Public Library, began noticing the streaks blackening the marble facade of the Beaux-Arts main building when he walked into work each day.

headline: Pantone's Color of the Year Is...
text: AT least one color authority, Pantone, has taken the plunge and announced its favorite color for 2008. To be sure, this news doesn’t seem as delectable as People’s Sexiest Man Alive or as snugly affirming as Time’s Person of the Year. You probably did not even know that chili pepper red was the color for 2007.

headline: A Tradition Lives: A Home Away From Home
text: MINNEAPOLIS  James Sheppard of the Minnesota Wild can afford his own apartment or home and enjoy an expensive dinner at any restaurant in the Twin Cities. So why is he living in a basement in suburban St. Paul?

headline: Hasidic Rabbi and Assistant Are Arrested in Tax Scheme
text: The grand rabbi of Spinka, a Brooklyn-based Hasidic sect, was arrested Wednesday with his executive assistant in Los Angeles on charges that they arranged and profited from inflated charitable donations that saved the donors millions of dollars in federal income taxes.

headline: Brown’s British Blues
text: LONDON

headline: Florida State Investigation Threatens Bowden’s Mark
text: Florida State Coach Bobby Bowden finished the regular season with the most career victories in major college football, but there are no guarantees he will start next season as the leader.

headline: Campbell Soup Sells Godiva
text: The Campbell Soup Company agreed on Thursday to sell its Godiva Chocolatier unit to Yildiz Holding of Turkey for $850 million.

headline: Columbia Expansion Gets Green Light
text: The New York City Council cleared the way Wednesday for the largest expansion in the history of Columbia University. The university plans a $7 billion project over the next 25 years that will transform a section of Upper Manhattan now dominated by warehouses and auto body shops into a campus with glass-walled high-rise buildings, tree-lined thoroughfares and student dormitories.

headline: Man and Woman, Hot and Acting Hotter
text: “She has that thing that all Latin American ballerinas have,” the Russian ballerina Alexandra Danilova is reputed to have said of a dancer to a critic friend. “Hmm, I can’t think of the word ...” The critic suggested, “Temperament?” Danilova replied at once: “No. Bitchiness.”

headline: No Password Needed, Just Look Your Best
text: In a twist on the old RCA advertisement showing a dog listening to its master’s voice coming from a phonograph, Asus has created a laptop that uses its camera to scrutinize the user and, if the master’s face is familiar, lets the person log on without a password.

headline: Conservative Wins Vote in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Lee Myung-bak, a conservative politician famous for his success in business but dogged by questions about his character, swept to a huge victory on Wednesday in a presidential election dominated by economic concerns.

headline: My Spooler Isn’t Spooling
text: Q. I keep getting error messages about my “spooler” when I try to print documents from my Windows Vista-operated computer. What does this mean, and what can I do to fix it?

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Jamie Lynn Spears

headline: Hell on Wheels
text: Aboard Seven Seas Mariner,

headline: The Online Gold Standard
text: CLACK, clack, clack. That’s the sound of fingers tapping, as holiday shoppers forsake their Excel spreadsheets and arid texts for the heady allure of the Web. Judging by holiday purchases, online buying sprees are turning even the most solemn of sobersides into saucer-eyed children mesmerized by glitter and gilt.

headline: Putting Very Little Weight in Calorie Counting Methods
text: THE Spinning class at our local gym was winding down. People were wiping off their bikes, gathering their towels and water bottles, and walking out the door when a woman shouted to the instructor, “How many calories did we burn?”

headline: 18 Arraigned in Partnership Between Gang and Mob
text: MORRISTOWN, N.J.  It was a mob scene.

headline: Religious Leaders Call for Talks With Iran
text: More than 60 Christian, Jewish and Muslim leaders have signed a call to the American government and the religious authorities in Iran to open direct negotiations and stop planning for war. The statement, “A Pax on Both Our Houses” (“pax” is Latin for “peace”) says the war in Iraq demonstrates how war wastes lives and resources, and violates human rights. The statement was released Wednesday in Des Moines, to remind the presidential candidates and reporters now crisscrossing Iowa that many religious constituencies are still focused on foreign policy, organizers said. The full text of the statement is available on interfaithpeacecommittee.org.

headline: U.S. to Cap Flights at Kennedy at Peak Times, but Its Daily Totals May Increase
text: HERNDON, Va.  Travelers going through Kennedy and Newark Liberty Airports next summer may find somewhat fewer flights at the hours they most want to travel, but are far more likely to leave on time or arrive in time to make connections, federal transportation officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Behind That Merry Sweater: Some Holly, Jolly R & D
text: AND the cat came back, but it was not the very next day. It was not even the next year, because that would have been tacky.

headline: Survivor Is Poised to Lead South Africa
text: POLOKWANE, South Africa  When Jacob Gedleyihlekisa Zuma, the man who is likely to be South Africa’s next president, was 21 years old, South Africa’s apartheid government condemned him to 10 years imprisonment on Robben Island, in a cell not far from that of Nelson Mandela.

headline: Outside the Garden, an Eight-Foot Pink Slip for Thomas Seeks Change
text: Outside Madison Square Garden on Wednesday morning, on the busy city sidewalk, there stood a Salvation Army group singing Christmas carols.

headline: Corrections: A World Consumed by Guilt
text: Two picture credits last Thursday with an article about the benefits of eco-conscious shopping were reversed in some copies. Tony Cenicola photographed the organic cotton jeans on the first page and the patchwork dress with the continuation of the article; Lars Klove photographed all the other items.

headline: Oracle Beats Wall Street’s Expectations for Quarter
text: The Oracle Corporation, the business software company, reported a sharp rise in new licenses on Wednesday, soundly beating Wall Street’s projections for the second quarter.

headline: Organ-Driven, With Unexpected Stops
text: The promise of Crescent Boogaloo, a small coterie of all-stars at the Jazz Standard, announces itself up front. There’s a lot of room for overlap between the more groove-oriented music of New Orleans (a k a the Crescent City) and the New York-based, 1960s-vintage Latin-soul hybrid known as boogaloo (or bugalú). Put those two styles in contact, with the right ambassadors, and you might have something special.

headline: Bring on the Virtual Chestnuts for a Downloadable Yuletide Hearth
text: In 1966, WPIX in New York broadcast a video loop of a burning Yule log on Christmas Eve, creating a tradition that has stood the test of time and, it seems, technical advances. In 2007, we have iYule, a 30-minute downloadable video of a burning Yule log for cellphones, computers and HDTVs.

headline: Belgium Sets Interim Government
text: BRUSSELS  An interim government was formed Wednesday in Belgium, led by a man who lost the last elections and who had planned to leave Belgian politics.

headline: A Heavy Crown in the 400-Year-Old Future
text: With its caffeinated, urgent productions, you might be excused for thinking that the Red Bull Theater was named after the energy drink instead of a Jacobean era theater. The director Jesse Berger spilled buckets of blood in the Red Bull’s well-reviewed 2005 version of “The Revenger’s Tragedy,” and its sleek, erotic new revival is, in its own way, just as over the top.

headline: Love That Book? Then Set It Free
text: THE mission began at dusk, in a light rain. I carried the package under my arm, hoping not to attract attention. As my husband and I approached the target  a large hospital  from the south, I whispered, “Try to look normal.”

headline: Hedge Funds Propose CSX Directors, Starting Proxy Battle
text: An activist hedge fund that has feuded with the railroad operator CSX over its strategy proposed a slate of five alternate directors on Wednesday, beginning a proxy fight.

headline: Tom B. Murphy, a Longtime Power in Georgia, Dies at 83
text: ATLANTA  Tom B. Murphy, a colorful and commanding legislator who ruled the House of Representatives in Georgia when Democrats were at the height of their power in the state, died Monday at his home in Bremen, Ga., where he lived all his life. He was 83.

headline: Jack Zander, Animator of Early TV Commercials, Dies at 99
text: Jack Zander, a master animator who 60 years ago was among the first to apply his art to a brand-new form of communication  the television commercial  died on Monday at his home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 99.

headline: Disney Wonders if a Mermaid Can Follow a Trail Blazed by a Lion
text: What could have been a debacle became one of the savviest moves in recent Broadway history: Take a hugely successful animated movie and pair it with a director who has a serious non-Broadway pedigree. The result, “The Lion King,” under Julie Taymor’s direction, was a critical and commercial smash, changing the dynamics of Broadway and remaking Disney Theatrical Productions, the little corporate experiment that put the show together.

headline: Opinions Wanted (Really)
text: HOW wrong can you be?

headline: Tribune Chief to Step Down as Newspaper Chain Goes Private
text: A day before an $8.2 billion deal is expected to take the Tribune Company private, Dennis J. FitzSimons said Wednesday that he would step down as chairman and chief executive as soon as the transaction was done, clearing the way for the real estate billionaire Samuel Zell to assume control.

headline: Pearly Wisdom
text: STICK WITH SOFT BRISTLES Hard bristles damage teeth and gums unless they’re used very carefully. Dentists universally recommend using a soft-bristle brush, said Dr. Howard S. Glazer, a former president of the Academy of General Dentistry, an organization devoted to advocacy and continuing education.

headline: Corrections
text: The subheading with a front-page headline on Wednesday for an article about discussions between four top White House lawyers and the Central Intelligence Agency over whether to destroy videotapes showing secret interrogations of members of Al Qaeda referred imprecisely to the White House’s position thus far on the matter. While Bush administration officials have acknowledged some discussions leading up to the destruction of the tapes in November 2005, as the article noted, the White House itself has not officially said anything on the subject, so its role was not “wider than it said.” (A related article appears today on Page A6.)

headline: Charges of Price Fixing on European Christmas Trees
text: PARIS  The state prosecutor for serious economic crimes charged the Christmas Tree Growers Association with anticompetitive price fixing and said he would bring the growers to court in the spring.

headline: For Turkey and U.S., a Delicate Issue of Cooperation in Combating Militant Kurds
text: WASHINGTON  Turkey provided the United States with ample warning that it was making an incursion into Iraq this week, officials from the State and Defense Departments said Wednesday.

headline: Driver Is Fatally Stabbed in Brooklyn
text: A driver was stabbed and killed Wednesday night while sitting in a parked sport utility vehicle in Brooklyn, the police said.

headline: Loss Is NBCs Gain
text: After losing 164 pounds, Bill Germanakos, below, on Tuesday won “The Biggest Loser,” as the show’s season finale helped NBC eke out a first-place finish in the ratings. Nielsen estimated that 11.4 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m., putting the finale ahead of its competition among adults 18 to 49 and delivering NBC’s best ratings in the slot in 11 months. CBS won the 8 p.m. hour with an “NCIS” rerun (13 million), which outperformed NBC’s “Clash of the Choirs” (7.7 million) and ABC’s “Duel,” which averaged 7.3 million, from 8 to 9:30. New episodes of “The Unit” at 9 (10.8 million) and “Cane” at 10 (7.2 million) put CBS in a tie for first with NBC in total viewers, but third among adults 18 to 49. Fox ranked second on that demographic with repeats. ABC was fourth over all.

headline: Qaddafi Plays Paris and Madrid
text: For 34 years, Libya’s leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was not invited to Paris. By the time he left last weekend, it was clear why. Having waited so long, Colonel Qaddafi seemed determined to spare no offense.

headline: Is This a Toothbrush or a Drill Sergeant?
text: HONESTLY, how hard can it be? We’ve been doing it twice a day since kindergarten. But still we can’t get it right.

headline: Just a Simple Cab Ride
text: To the Editor:

headline: Israelis Cool to an Offer From Hamas on a Truce
text: JERUSALEM  Officials in the Israeli prime minister’s office reacted coolly on Wednesday to an indirect approach by the Hamas leader in Gaza offering talks on a truce.

headline: In Charity and Politics, Clinton Donors Overlap
text: This article is by Don Van Natta Jr., Jo Becker and Mike McIntire.

headline: A Shanghai Auntie Mame
text: SHANGHAI

headline: Judge Frees Imam to Fight Deportation
text: YORK, Pa.  An immigration judge here released an Islamic leader from Pittsburgh on $5,000 bond on Wednesday while he fights an effort to deport him to Turkey after having lived in the United States for 19 years.

headline: Flash in the Can: Designs Soon Forgotten
text: AS 2007 draws to close, let us gather up the year’s trends  its baroque mirrors, its wall decals of stags, skulls and robins, its lacquered Chinese Chippendale-style chairs  and inspect them for staying power.

headline: A Compromise on Use of Avastin to Treat Eye Disease
text: Genentech, the biotechnology company, appears to have resolved a dispute with ophthalmologists that will allow its drug Avastin to continue to be used to treat eye diseases, boths sides announced on Thursday.

headline: Obama and Clinton Touch on International Matters
text: ELKADER, Iowa  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama waded into international concerns Wednesday, with Mrs. Clinton being less conditional that nearly all American troops in Iraq could be withdrawn “certainly within a year” if she were elected president, and Mr. Obama calling for banning toy imports from China.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: New York Introspective

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Id al-Adha, the Muslim Feast of the Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Silicon Valley Shaped by Technology and Traffic
text: ALVISO, Calif.  Palo Alto Networks is a high-tech start-up with ample financing and ambitious plans. But despite its name, the company has no offices in Palo Alto, Silicon Valley’s unofficial capital.

headline: Producers Charged
text: Two Hollywood producers were charged in Los Angeles with bribing a Thai government official to get contracts to run the Bangkok International Film Festival. Federal agents on Tuesday arrested Gerald Green, whose film credits include this year’s “Rescue Dawn,” shot largely in Thailand, and his wife, Patricia T. Green, who was a producer of “The New Swiss Family Robinson.” Prosecutors said the two paid the governor of the Tourism Authority of Thailand, who was also the president of the festival, more than $1.7 million to obtain contracts worth more than $10 million between 2003 and 2007. The governor during that period, whom prosecutors did not name, was Juthamas Siriwan. Investigators said the governor had authority to approve contracts up to a given amount, and that the Greens set up shell companies to get contracts that didn’t exceed that amount. Authorities said the Greens passed bribes to the governor through her daughter and other intermediaries. Prosecutors also said that the Greens tried to concoct a cover story for the payments after a July raid of their offices by the F.B.I. The Thai government this year stripped the tourism agency of control over the festival.

headline: U.S. Investigating Marine in Iraqi Policeman’s Death
text: BAGHDAD  A United States marine is at the center of an American military investigation into the death on Monday of an Iraqi policeman from what appears to have been a knife fight between the men at a base jointly staffed by American and Iraqi forces in Anbar Province, a military spokesman said.

headline: Nissan and Chrysler Discussing a Pact
text: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan’s third-largest carmaker, is in talks with Chrysler on a possible manufacturing agreement, the chief executive of Nissan, Carlos Ghosn, said on Wednesday.

headline: I Love Paris, Postpartum
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fire Breaks Out on White House Grounds
text: WASHINGTON  A two-alarm fire broke out on the White House grounds Wednesday morning, sending 1,000 federal workers scurrying for safety and damaging Vice President Dick Cheney’s ceremonial suite in the historic Eisenhower Executive Office Building across the street from the West Wing.

headline: 93 Banks Place Bids to Borrow From Fed
text: The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it had collected bids from 93 financial institutions in its first auction of short-term credit, a turnout that suggested banks might be more inclined to borrow from the Fed under its auction-based system.

headline: Charges of Price Fixing on European Christmas Trees
text: PARIS  The state prosecutor for serious economic crimes charged the Christmas Tree Growers Association with anticompetitive price fixing and said he would bring the growers to court in the spring.

headline: O’Neal’s Role Shrinks as Burdens Grow
text: MIAMI  Shaquille O’Neal emerged from the locker room Tuesday afternoon after practice wearing a white tank top and black sweat pants, looking much like a stripped-down version of his flamboyant self.

headline: Steelers at Rams
text: Steelers at Rams

headline: Europe Proposes Binding Limits on Auto Emissions
text: PARIS  European Union officials told leading automakers on Wednesday to make deep cuts in tailpipe emissions of the cars they produce or face fines that could reach billions of euros.

headline: Corrections: Who Invited the Dog?
text: An article last Thursday about people whose pets become difficult houseguests misstated the surname of a woman who took her dog to a meeting at the home of a former boss, and misstated her current profession. She is Rosi Kerr, not Kerry, and she works in sales for an energy company; she is not an energy consultant.

headline: An Idea Whose Time Should Be Past
text: The mandatory sentencing craze that began in the 1970s was a public-policy disaster. It drove up inmate populations and corrections costs and forced the states to choose between building prisons and building schools or funding medical care for the indigent. It filled the prisons to bursting with nonviolent drug offenders who would have been more cheaply and more appropriately dealt with through treatment. It tied the hands of judges and ruined countless young lives by mandating lengthy prison terms in cases where leniency was warranted. It undermined confidence in the fairness of the justice system by singling out poor and minority offenders while largely exempting the white and wealthy.

headline: He Needs Socks. He Wants This.
text: IF you are stuck trying to find the perfect gift for someone special, the easiest thing (and often the nicest) is a simple upgrade. Replace the stainless with sterling. The gigabytes with terabytes. The 18-year-old with 30-year-old. (That’s Scotch, not a paramour.)

headline: Some Lawyers Seek Changes in Vioxx Settlement
text: Several plaintiffs’ lawyers have asked the federal judge overseeing the $4.85 billion Vioxx settlement to give them the freedom to keep some of their clients outside the settlement while still allowing other clients to accept it.

headline: Tip of the Week: Weather Alerts
text: The Weather Channel offers free updates by e-mail or text message to your mobile phone. Click the Alerts link at www.weather.com to get started. The AccuWeather site (accuweather.com) has its own detailed e-mail alerts; click the Products & Services link and choose Email Alerts in the Consumer section.

headline: Thompson Picks Up the Pace Across Iowa
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  At a campaign event here on Wednesday, a supporter of Fred D. Thompson started to ask a question, but didn’t get very far.

headline: Once Volatile, Crossing Is Opening With a Whisper
text: SLUBICE, Poland  As of 12:01 a.m. on Friday, the border between Poland and Germany, one of the most violently contested frontiers on earth, is being thrown open. Yet, for the most part, the barriers are coming down more with a whimper than a bang.

headline: On the Ground, in the Wild, a Path to Inner Peace
text: Reisterstown, Md.

headline: Astronaut’s Mother Is Killed by Freight Train
text: WASHINGTON  The mother of a veteran NASA astronaut who is now on board the International Space Station died Wednesday when her car was struck by a freight train in a Chicago suburb, the police said.

headline: Park Plan Is Chosen for Governors Island
text: More than 10 years after the Coast Guard left Governors Island in New York Harbor, a team of architects has been selected to design a grandly whimsical green 40-acre park on its southern half that public officials hope will ultimately attract commercial development.

headline: Giuliani Has Decided to Zag While the Other Candidates Zig
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Mitt Romney, Mike Huckabee and Fred D. Thompson all stumped in Iowa on Wednesday, 15 days before its caucuses. Senator John McCain campaigned in New Hampshire, 20 days before its primary.

headline: Parcells Decides to Return, but Heads Farther South
text: When Wednesday began, it seemed nearly certain that Bill Parcells would take on his latest reclamation project and become the executive in charge of rebuilding the Atlanta Falcons. Parcells was even quoted in multiple news media outlets saying he was pretty sure he would take the job as the Falcons’ vice president for football operations. He had already agreed to a deal in principle.

headline: Brooklyn Sweep Shows Local Focus in Fight on Labor Violations
text: On a Brooklyn street cluttered with dollar stores and cuchifrito stands, New York State’s labor commissioner announced on Wednesday a stepped-up enforcement effort against neighborhood businesses that violate the state’s wage and hour laws.

headline: Giuliani Released From Hospital After Treatment
text: ST. LOUIS  Rudolph W. Giuliani was released from a hospital here Thursday afternoon after coming down with what his Republican presidential campaign described as “flu-like symptoms” that led him to turn around his airplane in mid-air Wednesday night.

headline: Grade-School Memories at Heart of Mail-Threat Case
text: STAMFORD, Conn.  The letters that began arriving at a woman’s childhood home in Bridgeport, Conn., in May 2006 were as macabre as they were childish looking. One had a tombstone with her name on it and a drawing of a heart with a bite taken from it. Another had stick figures of grade-school children, a severed head and the warning “Prepare yourself.” The police traced the letters to an address in Minnesota, where they found tragedy waiting to happen.

headline: Mangini Says Clemens Will Start if Healthy
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Kellen Clemens spent most of the first half-hour of the Jets’ practice Wednesday with his hands jammed into a green warmer cinched around his middle, silently watching Chad Pennington throw one pass after another.

headline: Marley Is Dead, Killed in a Nuclear War
text: HAS there ever been a holiday yarn as ubiquitous as Dickens’s “Christmas Carol”? Whether filmed in black and white or color, played straight or set to music, starring Alastair Sim or Mr. Magoo, this quintessential Christmas story is inescapable this season.

headline: Man Is Charged in Stabbing of Two
text: A family acquaintance has been charged with two counts of murder in the stabbing deaths of a 25-year-old woman and her 6-year-old daughter, whose bodies were found in their Bronx apartment on Tuesday, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: Fighting It Out on the Battlefield and on the Court
text: If there is one thing we learn in science fiction, it is that humans are about the gutsiest species in the known universe. When every other world has been wiped out by alien invaders, it is always Earth that, despite its backward technology, manages to hold on.

headline: Treasury Dept. Declines to Press China on Yuan
text: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)  The Treasury Department declined again Wednesday to designate China as a currency manipulator, despite the increasing pressure from Congress.

headline: It’s Not Just ‘Ayes’ and ‘Nays’: Obama’s Votes in Illinois Echo
text: In 1999, Barack Obama was faced with a difficult vote in the Illinois legislature  to support a bill that would let some juveniles be tried as adults, a position that risked drawing fire from African-Americans, or to oppose it, possibly undermining his image as a tough-on-crime moderate.

headline: Peoples Choice Awards Get Strike Makeover
text: Producers of the People’s Choice Awards “said on Wednesday the upcoming show will be presented in a new prerecorded ‘magazine’-style format because of the Hollywood writers strike,” Reuters reports.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: A Holiday Political Quiz
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Dec. 20 column.

headline: On His Blog, Schilling Has Words for Clemens
text: Boston’s Curt Schilling, one never afraid to speak his mind, has given his take on Roger Clemens, Barry Bonds, George J. Mitchell and many of the players in Mitchell’s report.

headline: What Do You Believe?
text: After the Mitchell Report’s release, a handful of players named in the report have admitted using performance enhancing substances once or twice. Roger Clemens, meanwhile, has denied using any steroids and human growth hormone. Do you believe these statements made by the players?

headline: Thursday’s Links: Blaming Jessica Simpson, Among Others
text: There’s something in the air every December in the N.F.L., and it’s not just playoff talk or calls for Matt Millen to be fired. It’s blame. Sometimes it is being assigned, sometimes it is being accepted, but as three-quarters of the league’s teams prepare to watch the playoffs instead of participating in them, it’s about time fans in every city figure out whose fault it is.

headline: For the Moment | “Whatever,” whenever in L.A.
text: Franklin Getchell

headline: Guilty Plea From Ex-HealthSouth Exec
text: A former HealthSouth executive, Malcolm E. McVay, pleaded guilty Wednesday to making illegally structured bank deposits 10 months after being resentenced to probation for his role in the company’s $2.7 billion fraud.

headline: Ex-Refco Executive Pleads Guilty
text: A former senior executive at Refco pleaded guilty on Wednesday to fraud charges for his role in the collapse of the futures and commodities broker.

headline: Nanotechnology Companies Eye Public Markets
text: Nanotechnology companies, nurtured on billions of dollars in government grants and venture investments through most of this decade, are getting ready to go public.

headline: F.C.C. Approves $16.4 Billion Buyout of Intelsat
text: The Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday approved the $16.4 billion buyout of satellite company Intelsat a group led by a London private equity firm, BC Partners.

headline: First Reserve Plunks Down $1.8 Billion for Abbot
text: First Reserve, the biggest private-equity investor specializing in the energy industry, agreed to buy Scottish oil drilling services company Abbot Group for $1.8 billion.

text: Akela Pharma said on Thursday it would not go ahead with its U.S. public offering, citing unfavorable market conditions for small and micro-cap companies.

headline: Peltz Said to Take Stake in Cheesecake Factory
text: Despite his apparent distaste for fruity pebbles, activist investor Nelson Peltz does seem to have a sweet tooth. Following his efforts to break-up soft-drink maker and confectioner Cadbury Schweppes, Mr. Peltz is now reportedly eyeing a big slice of  The Cheesecake Factory, the casual dining chain known for the eponymous dessert.

headline: Hell on Wheels
text: From a rant against wheeled luggage on Thursday’s Op-Ed Page:

headline: 3Guppies Loses Key Backer
text: The heavily funded Seattle mobile services company 3Guppies has lost the support of its primary venture backer, forcing it to cut a significant portion of its staff.
