text: From the Institute for Policy Innovation, which lobbies for lower taxes:

headline: ‘A Maxim Security Prison’
BSkyB Should Trim ITV Stake, Watchdog Finds
text: BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster controlled by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, should cut its stake in broadcaster ITV to below 7.5 percent because it reduces competition in the TV market and works against the public interest, the British Competition Commission said Thursday.

headline: SFR Rings Up $2.95 Billion Deal for Neuf Cegetel
text: French mobile operator SFR has agreed to buy Neuf Cegetel for around 2.05 billion euros ($2.95 billion) to bolster its investment capacity in high technology, notably fiber optics.

headline: The Year’s Most Laughable Political Antics
text: The late-night comedians may have made an early exit from the scene, but fortunately there was no shortage of political punch lines in 2007. From tapping toes and UFO encounters to prostitution scandals and $400 haircuts, it was a year in which politicians did their best to satirize themselves. As a salute to our nation’s fine public servants, here’s a look back at the year’s most memorable feats and foibles. The envelopes, please.

headline: Euronext to Launch Private Equity Index
text: Euronext, the European stock exchange grouping of NYSE Euronext, plans to launch a private equity index early next year, to be published alongside its market benchmarks, a senior exchange official said Wednesday.

headline: Stem-Cell Institute Gives Private Firms Access to Its Cash
text: Although companies now have a chance for the first time in the California stem-cell institute’s three-year history to apply for a slice of its $3 billion pot, they may wind up having to share some of their revenue and research.

headline: Apollo-Backed Paper Company Seeks Listing
text: Verso Paper, which Apollo Management bought from International Paper last year for $1.4 billion, filed with regulators Thursday to raise as much as $345 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Umbro Shareholder Gives Nike Bid a Boost
text: Shares of Umbro, the seller of soccer-related goods, rose Wednesday after a major shareholder said he may support Nike‘s 285 million pound ($569 million) bid for the company.

headline: Britian’s Biffa Opens Books to Buyout Shops
text: Biffa, a British landfill operator and trash collector, said Wednesday that it’s prepared to accept a proposed 1.22 billion-pound ($2.46 billion) takeover from Montagu Private Equity and HgCapital.

headline: 93 Banks Place Bids to Borrow From Fed
text: The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it had collected bids from 93 financial institutions in its first auction of short-term credit, a turnout that suggested banks might be more inclined to borrow from the Fed under its auction-based system.

headline: Barclays Sues Bear Stearns in Fund Collapse
text: Barclays Bank accused Bear Stearns on Wednesday of loading one of its hedge funds with about $500 million in troubled assets just weeks before it and another Bear Stearns fund collapsed.

headline: Blackstone Said to Plan Big Debt Offering for Hilton
text: The Blackstone Group is planning a $9 billion commercial mortgage-backed securities offering backed by Hilton Hotels next quarter, according to a Credit Suisse research note.

headline: Scent Notes | J’adore by Dior
text: A perfume’s becoming a wild financial success seems to engender the assumption that it is inferior. This is snobbery.

headline: Goldman, Morgan, Lehman Said to Vie for Daito Trust
text: Investment banks Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers are among the bidders for a stake in Japanese house builder Daito Trust Construction, which may lead to a multibillion-dollar buyout, Reuters reported.

headline: Tribune Chief to Step Down as Newspaper Chain Goes Private
text: A day before an $8.2 billion deal is expected to take Tribune private, Dennis J. FitzSimons said Wednesday that he would step down as chairman and chief executive as soon as the transaction was done, clearing the way for the real estate billionaire Samuel Zell to assume control of the media conglomerate.

headline: 2 Young Hedge-Fund Veterans Shake Up Philanthropy
text: As hedge-fund analysts, Holden Karnofsky and Elie Hassenfeld made six-figure incomes deciding which companies to invest in. Now they are doing the same thing with charities, for a lot less pay.

headline: Nissan Talks to Chrysler About Production Agreement
text: Nissan Motor, Japan’s third-largest carmaker, is in talks with Chrysler on a possible manufacturing agreement, Nissan’s chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, said.

headline: Eaton Bulks Up with Moeller, Phoenixtec Deals
text: Eaton, the world’s second-largest maker of hydraulic equipment, will buy Moeller Group of Germany and Phoenixtec Power Company of Taiwan for about $2.8 billion as revenue growth in the United States slows.

headline: Southwest Airlines Prepares for Consolidation
text: Southwest Airlines chief executive Gary Kelly doesn’t have any offers out to buy another airline, but he expects Southwest to jump in when the consolidation fun begins.

headline: Employers Behaving Well
text: How do you know if a company you want to work for, or are already working for, is doing good things in the world? Here are a couple of new resources:

headline: The Microclusters of Silicon Valley
text: Silicon Valley, the wellspring of the digital technologies fueling globalization, is itself a collection of remarkably local clusters based on industry niches, skills, school ties, traffic patterns, ethnic groups and even weekend sports teams, The New York Times says.

headline: NetSuite Prices I.P.O. at $26 Per Share
text: Business software isn’t the most glamorous of businesses, and December isn’t the greatest time for initial public offerings — but none of that seemed to matter to NetSuite.

headline: G.M. Said to Be Selling Truck Unit to Navistar
text: Navistar International, an Illinois-based maker of trucks and diesel engines, is expected to announce Thursday that it is buying General Motors‘ medium-duty truck business, according to The New York Times.

headline: John Mack in the Hot Seat
text: Morgan Stanley portrayed Wednesday’s decision to take a $5 billion infusion from China as a strategic move, and not a desperate act. Still, the announcement came as the firm reported the first quarterly loss in its 72-year history and as a joke about foreign investments was making the rounds on trading floors: “Shanghai, Dubai, Mumbai or goodbye.”

headline: Bear Stearns Reports First-Ever Quarterly Loss
text: Bear Stearns reported a steep loss for its fourth quarter, its first ever in its eight-decade history, as the investment bank was stung by the mortgage crisis that has swept markets across the globe.

headline: A Little Saggage for Baggage
text: Nothing like some data points to break through the strike-born gloom here at Bagger H.Q. At 9:00 a.m. E.S.T., the Screen Actors Guild will announce their nominees for the SAG Awards, which will give the Bagger and all his ninny friends a lot to chew on. For example:

headline: SAG Crudités
text: If you want to snack on something nutritious while awaiting the SAG announcements, head over to Awards Daily for some prefatory analytics. Among other insights/guesses, Sasha Stone, veteran awards seer, thinks that Daniel Day Lewis will get a nomination for “There Will Be Blood,” and that he will likely go the distance and win all the best actor marbles at the Oscars. She also makes a pretty educated guess at the best ensemble performance nominees, which is SAG-speak for best picture:

headline: The Early Word: Tancredo to Withdraw
text: After months of single-digit polling, Tom Tancredo, the Republican candidate who campaigned largely on an anti-immigration platform, will drop out of the presidential race during a news conference in Des Moines later today. The Denver Post examines the Colorado congressman’s decision.

headline: The Neediest Cases | Fighting Cancer, but Not Alone
text: Elida Fernández, 53, is being treated for breast cancer. The Neediest Cases Fund helped to pay $500 towards the monthly cost of her medication.

headline: Elizabeth II Outlives Victoria Today
text: Long live the Queen, indeed. Just past teatime in London today (or about 10 a.m. Eastern time), Elizabeth II will become the oldest monarch in Britain’s history, surpassing Victoria, who was 81 years, 7 months and 29 days old when she died in 1901.

headline: N.H. Forecast: Endorsement Season
text: Countdown: 19 days until the primary.

headline: How to Restore a Century-Old Marble Exterior
text: The New York Public Library intends to announce today a three-year restoration of the facade, stairs and plaza of its main building that is to be completed in time for the building’s centennial in 2011. Already some of the building is shrouded with netting; the first scaffolding is to appear in February on the Bryant Park side of the building, which is now known as the Humanities and Social Sciences Library.

headline: SAGS Rock This Way
text: The SAGS are in and “Hairspray” and “3:10 to Yuma” both get into the ensemble category. “There Will Be Blood” and “Sweeney Todd” don’t make the cut. Read more on the Bagger’s take on the nominations and how SAG tends to go its own way.

headline: Kerrey Apologizes to Obama
text: DES MOINES – Former Senator Bob Kerrey has apologized to Senator Barack Obama, praising his judgment and experience to serve as president. He said he did not intend to offend Mr. Obama or contribute to misinformation about his family’s Muslim heritage.

headline: Circle Your Calendars

Is there anyone who actually thinks Simon will be — or should be — in uniform that night? Anyone? I’m not talking about the severity of the punishment here. How could he possibly help the Islanders?

headline: Holiday Gifts| Editor’s List (Day Three, Part One)
text: At this time of year, fashion magazine editors may have it worse than the general population. Every day we find ourselves surrounded by beautiful objects — falling in love is an occupational hazard. Which is why, come holiday time, making a list is almost impossible. Where do we start? This week several T editors share their material desires. Friends and family: take note! (Gift lists from earlier this week can be found here.)

headline: Driving Tips From 68 Degrees North
text: During my first few weeks in New York, the most striking surprise was that my New York friends, when emerging from the subway, always knew which direction was downtown. As if possessing the magnetic receptors of migratory birds, they’d stalk off in the correct direction without even a momentary pause at the top of the entrance stairs. This, it seemed to me, was the cultural inheritance of the native New Yorker.

headline: Sick to Your Stomach? You’re Not Alone
text: Cases of norovirus — commonly known as the stomach flu — have spiked in recent weeks, the city’s Health Department announced this morning. Emergency room visits for vomiting and diarrhea — the virus’s most common symptoms — have jumped to 500 a day from 300 a day in November.

headline: Thursday Kickoff: Radio Free Charleston
text: It wasn’t exactly Lenny Bruce or George Carlin’s “Seven Words You Can Never Say on Television” routine, but a Charleston, W. Va., radio personality known as Coach Kidd finds himself on the sidelines following his extravagant support of Rich Rodriguez’s decision to head to Michigan. It seems that Kidd, a Michigan native, has been proclaiming that Rodriguez’s move can only help the Wolverines. Things went a little too far in the mind of the station and many of Kidd’s listeners when he played the Michigan fight song for the fourth time. “He just kept playing it over and over again,” the station’s program manager told Justin D. Anderson of the Charleston Daily Mail.

headline: Oddly Enough
text: Folks who tuned into the SAG awards and saw “3:10 to Yuma” and “Into the Wild” in the ensemble category might wonder what gives. But the actors have always gone their own way. Last year, they — and almost nobody else — gave “Bobby” a nod. And the year before, “Hustle and Flow” made their idiosyncratically named best picture list.

headline: Citadel Not in Talks for BofA’s Prime Broker Unit, Report Says

headline: Thursday Matchup: Steelers at Rams
text: Pittsburgh (9-5) has a short week to deal with a disappointing loss to Jacksonville on Sunday. The Steelers suddenly find their division lead in jeopardy and are in a fight for playoff positioning. A game against St. Louis (3-11) would seem to be a nice break after tough losses to the Patriots and the Jaguars. But the Steelers’ other three losses were on the road: to Arizona, Denver and the Jets, which all have losing records. Before allowing 117 yards to the Jets’ Thomas Jones in Week 11, the Steelers had not allowed a 100-yard rusher in two years. But they allowed 147 yards to Fred Taylor last week as the Jaguars rushed for 224, and the Rams’ Steven Jackson is coming off his best game of the season, with 143 yards against the Packers. This is the first time the Rams have played host to the Steelers since moving to St. Louis in 1995.

headline: Stick Thin | A Look Book Makeover
text: First she made bodysuits chic. Now Donna Karan is taking aim at portable USB drives… T’s fashion editors were momentarily baffled this week when a chrome and rubber memory stick arrived in the mail from Donna Karan’s publicists. Turns out it’s a digital look book — a high-tech iteration of the runway-fashion flipbook that designers send to editors. The Donna PR team hails its gizmo as a paperless ecological breakthrough. All I know is it saves fashion assistants (like me) the hassle of Web surfing for digital images and alphabetizing the books. Like a good DVD, there’s even bonus material: there are detail images, still lifes of shoes (love that) and even back-stage footage from the Spring ’08 show. Next season, I’m hoping Donna will invent clothes that steam themselves.

headline: A YIMBY Crowd Rallies on the Lower East Side
text: It’s not every day that a community rallies in support of a chain store. But that is what a group of Lower East Side and Chinatown residents did today, in support of the Pathmark at 227 Cherry Street. Call them YIMBY’s. Yes in my backyard.Of course, they are opposed to something — namely, the possibility that the supermarket will be sold for $250 million to make way for luxury condos. About 100 demonstrators armed with petitions gathered at the store, holding signs that read “Stop Gentrification!” and chanting, “$250 million for condos we can’t live in, that’s crazy!”

headline: Is Information Overload a $650 Billion Drag on the Economy?

headline: Turn-Ons Include Museums and Gmail. Turn-Offs Are Liars.
text: It was a quixotic open casting call made via e-mail: Have your moving silhouette, iPod-ad-style, be immortalized as part of an exhibition on online dating for the Museum of Modern Art in February. R.S.V.P. to a gmail address, then show up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with props for banal everyday activities like brushing your teeth, drinking water or reading a book. The filming of some 1,000 silhouettes images began today and continues Friday.The project, called “I Want You to Want Me” (not, apparently, named after the 1977 song by Cheap Trick), is a creation of Jonathan Harris and Sep Kamvar. The pair combined art, emotion and statistical combing of the Internet in their last project, “We Feel Fine,” which crawled blogs and online postings and aggregated statements about people’s emotional states. The new project is one of a handful commissioned by MoMA to be part of the “Design and the Elastic Mind” exhibition, an exploration of how disruptive technology has been incorporated into everyday lives. The show will be on view from Feb. 24 to May 12.

headline: Who Is Really Hurt by Apple Rumor Site’s Closure?

headline: Marketing Disorder

text: The most anticipated arrival in Buffalo on Sunday is not the Giants’, but Kevin Everett’s. headline: P.P.S. Take Tissues to This Weepy About a Romance Tested by Death
text: It would be easy to dismiss “P.S. I Love You,” about the agonies visited on a young married couple, as the big-screen equivalent of a paperback romance. Certainly the refined critical mind understands that this is the kind of artful emotion machine that the movies have been making since the very first tear slid down an actress’s face, the droplet seen  and experienced  around the world by audiences who answered that bead of dew with a grateful flood of their own. Cry us a river, Mary Pickford!

headline: Britain: 3 From Guanánamo Freed in London
text: Three former British residents who were held for more than four years at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and detained on their return to Britain on Wednesday, were reunited with their families. Two, Omar Deghayes, a Libyan, and Jamil el-Banna, a Palestinian, are wanted by the Spanish authorities in connection with terror-related offenses. They were ordered freed on bail. The third man, Adbenour Samuer, an Algerian, was released without any charges.

headline: To Our Health, in the New Year
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend last Friday about Ian Hunter, at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, misidentified the bass player performing with him there. He was Paul Page, not Graham Maby. A correction in this space on Thursday misstated Mr. Maby’s association with the band. While he did not play at the Music Hall, he is still a member of Mr. Hunter’s Rant Band.

headline: ‘M’ Is for the Mania, Manipulation and Magic
text: When Susanna Sonnenberg was 10 years old, her mother bought her a copy of Penthouse magazine and told her to read one of the letters aloud.

headline: New Guard Arrives at Tribune, a Developer Who Speaks His Mind
text: On Thursday, after completing an $8.2 billion deal that turned the Tribune Company into a privately held operation, Samuel Zell made himself chief executive, announced a new set of directors and managers, and declared that the troubled company would look to raise revenue more than cut spending.

headline: With 5 Goals From Gaborik, the Wild Defeats the Rangers
text: ST. PAUL, Minn.,  Henrik Lundqvist’s answers seemed to take him in circles when he tried to explain this strange night for the Rangers. Which was odder: Marian Gaborik’s five goals or the two unsportsmanlike conduct penalties taken by the Rangers in their 6-3 loss to Minnesota?

headline: Yielding to Youth’s Fierce Enthusiasms
text: Deciphering what Ensemble ACJW means goes a long way to explaining what it does. To Academy, Carnegie Hall, the Juilliard School and the Weill Music Institute might have been added the New York City Department of Education, but after a while acronyms get out of hand.

headline: Bid for Home as Synagogue Meets Hurdle in Connecticut
text: LITCHFIELD, Conn.  For an Orthodox Jewish organization seeking permission to renovate a historical Victorian home into what would be the first synagogue in this quaint New England town, it is back to the drawing board  and, perhaps, to the local courthouse.

headline: House Panel Subpoenas C.I.A. Official Over Destroyed Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  The House Intelligence Committee subpoenaed the former chief of the Central Intelligence Agency’s clandestine service on Thursday to testify about his role in the destruction of videotapes documenting the interrogation of two suspected operatives of Al Qaeda.

headline: Marbury Takes Another Leave of Absence From Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The morning after the Knicks played their best game of the season  and without Stephon Marbury  Marbury left the team again.

headline: Some Lawyers Seek Changes in Vioxx Settlement
text: Several plaintiffs’ lawyers have asked the federal judge overseeing the $4.85 billion Vioxx settlement to give them the freedom to keep some of their clients outside the settlement while allowing other clients to accept it.

headline: In Witness Killing, Prosecutors Point to a Lawyer
text: NEWARK  For prosecutors in New Jersey, much about the 2004 murder of Deshawn McCray was all too familiar: Yet another key witness in a major drug case had been shot dead before he could testify in court.

headline: Shut Out in Kyrgyzstan Elections, Opposition Party Vows Protests
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Leaders of this former Soviet republic’s main opposition party vowed nationwide protests Thursday after government officials announced final election results that excluded the party from Parliament.

headline: Racing Around the Globe, Solving a History Mystery
text: The hyperactive sequel “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” sends its archaeologist hero, Ben Franklin Gates (Nicolas Cage, flexing his deadpan), on a globetrotting quest that might have been devised after a long night of Wikipedia surfing.

headline: Despite ‘High Note,’ Bush Scolds Congress as Wasteful
text: WASHINGTON  Having beaten back most of the Democrats’ legislative initiatives, President Bush chided Congress on Thursday for wasteful spending and announced that his budget director would seek ways to reverse some of the thousands of spending projects attached to a huge spending bill.

headline: Islamic Scholar’s Suit for a Visa Is Rejected
text: Saying the government had acted properly and for “bona fide” reasons, a federal judge threw out a lawsuit on Thursday that was brought last year by an Islamic scholar who claimed that a portion of the Patriot Act had been used to deny him a work visa to enter the United States.

headline: The Year of Puncturing Wall Street Orthodoxy
text: NEVER in the history of Wall Street have so many who are so senior fallen so fast.

headline: Orphanages Stunt Mental Growth, a Study Finds
text: Psychologists have long believed that growing up in an institution like an orphanage stunts children’s mental development but have never had direct evidence to back it up.

headline: Time on Your Hands? Curl Up With a Series
text: It is not merely the season for giving, is it? It is the season of diversion, distraction, avoidance: the season of running away from old aunts, small children, sweaters with snowmen and overcooked meats. It is, in other words, the time to hide out with long-form narrative television (and yes, to hand it out, too). The first seasons of NBC’s “Friday Night Lights” and Showtime’s “Dexter,” two of the best dramatic series currently on television, came out on DVD in recent months. So too the fourth season of “The Wire,” HBO’s sublime epic of urban realism, which begins its fifth and final chapter on Jan. 6 (so you’ll want to catch up). Herewith are more of the best series, mini-series and specials to come out on DVD this year:

headline: Giuliani Treated for Flu Symptoms
text: ST. LOUIS  Rudolph W. Giuliani was admitted to the hospital in St. Louis late Wednesday with flu-like symptoms but was expected to leave the hospital and fly to New York later Thursday after doctors said they found nothing of concern, his campaign said.

headline: The Artesana Rosewood Residences and Lodge Kura Hulanda & Beach Club
text: The Artesana Rosewood Residences

headline: U.S. Investigates Chocolate Makers
text: A month after Canadian officials confirmed a wide-ranging investigation of price fixing in the chocolate industry, several chocolate makers said Thursday that they had learned United States government investigators were looking into pricing practices.

headline: Rodriguez Fires Assistants
text: Rich Rodriguez fired Michigan’s assistants Thursday, his second day as an employee of the university. Lloyd Carr, who is retiring, will coach Michigan on Jan. 1 against Florida in the Capital One Bowl.

headline: Art in Review
text: JASON RHOADES

headline: Apple Rumor Site to Shut Down in Settlement
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple on Thursday put to rest the last of a series of lawsuits it brought in a losing and costly effort to put a stop to Web leaks about its product plans.

headline: Changes à la Russe: Vladimir Putin and Echoes From the Past
text: There are chilling echoes of the Soviet past in Russia’s current political game: President Vladimir Putin’s secretive style; his K.G.B. background; the enormous, autocratic power he wields; and if there’s a power struggle going on in the Kremlin (Mr. Putin’s term ends early next year), no outsider has been let in on it.

headline: Schneider Sees No Problem Fitting in With the Mets
text: Consider Brian Schneider’s two-night visit to New York a success. Schneider, the Mets’ new catcher, and his wife, Jordan, realized that they might prefer to live in Manhattan and not in a leafy suburb.

headline: Not a Jolly Season for 2 Top Bankers
text: James E. Cayne and John J. Mack have a lot in common. The chiefs of both Bear Stearns and Morgan Stanley have presided over announcements of steep losses this week and have forgone bonuses.

headline: Bomber Hits a Gathering of Civilians and G.I.’s
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-packed vest amid a group of civilians and American soldiers northeast of Baghdad on Thursday, killing several people.

headline: Italy: Prodi Faces Down 2 Confidence Votes
text: Prime Minister Romano Prodi survived his 29th confidence vote in 19 months to pass a portion of the 2008 budget. The Senate voted 163 to 156 to approve a section of the bill. Earlier, he won a separate confidence vote on another part. One more ballot to complete passage is set for Friday. Confidence votes, which stake the government’s survival on the outcome, were needed to force dissenting allies to support the bill.

headline: Japan’s First Encounter With Westerners
text: NAMBAN ART:

headline: With Vigor Once Again, Only a Little Bit Different
text: If you walked past Carnegie Hall early this week, you would have seen posters announcing performances of Handel’s “Messiah” on either side of the main entrance. One advertised the annual reading by the Oratorio Society of New York, on Tuesday evening. The other was for the version by the highly regarded Musica Sacra on Wednesday and Friday. Both listed the same conductor, Kent Tritle.

headline: Plan on Airline Emissions Hints at U.S.-Europe Rift
text: European Union governments have scaled back a proposed law that would regulate emissions from any airline with takeoffs or landings in Europe. But on Thursday, the ministers still agreed within five years to adopt measures likely to intensify a battle with the United States over global environmental regulation.

headline: Deck the Parks
text: “NATIONAL parks are the best idea we ever had,” Wallace Stegner wrote. And what’s great in the summer can be glorious in December, when snowflakes float down into the Grand Canyon and mounds of stark white ice slow the waterfalls of Yosemite Valley.

headline: A World Away, Healing From an Attack
text: When American soldiers arrived in Baghdad in April 2003, Uday Hattem met them on the street. “Because at the beginning it was everything normal,” he said. “We talk with them; they are not afraid.”

headline: Once More Diving Into the Vaults, and Surfacing With Cinematic Pearls
text: It’s been a good year for old-movie buffs. The DVD industry continued to mature in 2007; diminishing returns on newly produced films led both the big studios and the boutique labels back to the archives. Rapid advances in digital restoration techniques and a concerted attempt to return to original release material produced some amazingly handsome new versions of familiar films (“The Jazz Singer,” “Nosferatu”), as well as neglected gems (“Killer of Sheep,” “True Heart Susie”).

headline: There Is No Rewriting Baseball’s Stained History
text: When Curt Schilling was invited by George J. Mitchell to help in the former senator’s investigation of baseball’s performance-enhancement epidemic, Schilling politely declined. He said, in effect, that he didn’t know anything.

headline: Qaeda Deputy to Take Queries
text: BAGHDAD  Arabic-language Web sites have begun publishing invitations purportedly issued by Al Qaeda for questions to be submitted to an “open interview” with Osama bin Laden’s deputy, Ayman al-Zawahri.

headline: Indictments Stir Plot in the Case of the Cash-Filled Bag
text: MIAMI  A federal grand jury here indicted four Venezuelans and one Uruguayan on Thursday on charges of illegally operating as agents of the Venezuelan government in covering up a scheme to deliver $800,000 in a cash-filled suitcase to the campaign of Argentina’s new president.

headline: Big Bond Insurer Discovers That Layers of Risk Do Not Create a Cushion
text: For an obscure corner of the financial market, the bond guarantors have caused quite a stir this week.

headline: Top-Level Play From a Midmajor Star
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  Jason Thompson says the right things. He explains that his priority is finishing his senior season at Rider and helping his team earn a postseason berth. But he does not hide the fact that the N.B.A. is never far from his mind, which is not hard to understand. He is close to making it happen, taking the improbable leap to the N.B.A. after being an undersized and overlooked high school player who wound up at a midmajor college.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Slavery’s Place in the Capitol
text: The Capitol’s mammoth new visitors’ center is a work in progress bedeviled by cost overruns and mounting delay. The $621 million project is not expected to be ready for tourists until next fall. But the House and Senate have set an encouraging standard, emphasizing the center’s educational mission by naming the main welcoming chamber Emancipation Hall. This honors long-forgotten African-American slaves forced to help build the original Capitol in the 18th and 19th centuries.

headline: Officer Is Indicted in Fiancée’s Slaying
text: A New York City police officer who has been on suspension since his fiancée, a fellow officer, was found shot to death in the couple’s Long Island home was indicted Thursday in the case, according to the Suffolk County district attorney’s office.

headline: Panel Has Not Decided Whether Players Will Testify
text: The chairman of a House oversight committee has not decided whether to call baseball players to testify at a Jan. 15 hearing on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, his chief of staff said Thursday, contradicting a statement by the ranking minority member that the panel had decided not to call players.

headline: Time Warner Rejects an Arbitration Offer to Carry the NFL Network
text: Time Warner on Thursday rejected an offer by the N.F.L. to submit to “baseball-style arbitration” to resolve the impasse that has kept the cable operator from carrying the NFL Network.

headline: New York Law on Stranded Passengers’ Rights Is Upheld
text: In a victory for air travelers, a federal judge in Albany upheld on Thursday a state law that would penalize airlines that fail to provide adequate services to passengers trapped on the tarmac for more than three hours.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about the selection of Jacob Zuma as the new leader of South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, gave the incorrect age in some copies in describing when he was sent to prison by the former apartheid government. He was 21, not 24. (Go to Article)

headline: Jury in Shooting of L.I. Teenager Queries Judge
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  The jury in the trial of a black man accused of fatally shooting a white teenager did not reach a verdict during its second day of deliberation on Thursday, and instead asked for clarification of the law and transcripts of crucial testimony.

headline: Sarkozy in Rome: Affairs of State and the Heart
text: ROME  Affairs of state and more personal ones mixed to bring Italy and France a little closer as President Nicolas Sarkozy of France arrived here on Thursday for his first official visit. For the official part, Mr. Sarkozy, a Roman Catholic but twice divorced, met with Pope Benedict XVI and with Italian and Spanish leaders.

headline: Westchester Lawyer Charged in Wife’s 2006 Shooting Death
text: Almost from the start 13 months ago, the police regarded Carlos Perez-Olivo’s story as “unusual.”

headline: Whistle-Blower Is Awarded $1.6 Million
text: A former drug sales representative who became a whistle-blower has been awarded $1.6 million for bringing a drug marketing fraud to light, despite efforts by the Justice Department to prevent his receiving the money.

headline: Family Ties Get Tighter as the Jets’ Revis Settles In
text: WESTBURY, N.Y.  Here in his two-story condominium, the one with hardwood floors and leather couches and a huge flat-screen television, Darrelle Revis is everywhere at once.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Britain: Long Lives the Queen
text: Queen Elizabeth II became Britain’s oldest-ever monarch, reaching a new milestone in a job she has held for more than a half century. Elizabeth, 81, passed the mark set by her great-great-grandmother Queen Victoria. Victoria was born on May 24, 1819, and lived for 81 years and 243 days. Buckingham Palace, calculating longevity down to the hour, said Elizabeth moved past her predecessor about 5 p.m. There would be no special events to celebrate the occasion, and the queen spent the day working quietly at home on royal paperwork.

headline: Belgium Arrests 14 in Plan to Free Bomb Plotter
text: BRUSSELS  The Belgian authorities detained 14 people they described as Islamic extremists on Friday, saying they planned to use explosives to free a Qaeda sympathizer jailed for plotting an attack on an American air base. They said raids in 15 locations, mostly in Brussels, had turned up explosives and arms.

headline: Prosecutor Asks to Be Removed From Trooper Sex Assault Case
text: TRENTON  The New Jersey attorney general said on Thursday that the prosecutor investigating accusations by a college student that she was sexually assaulted by state troopers asked to be removed from the case because of comments he made to a newspaper.

headline: Rescue Recess
text: To the Editor:

headline: Judge Refuses to Order Hearing on C.I.A. Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Friday declined to rule immediately on a request to compel the government to explain in detail the destruction of C.I.A. videotapes showing the harsh interrogation of two suspected Al Qaeda operatives.

headline: Democracy in Ecuador
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Orleans Council Votes for Demolition of Housing
text: NEW ORLEANS  After protesters clashed violently with the police inside and outside the New Orleans City Council chambers on Thursday, the Council voted unanimously to allow the federal government to demolish 4,500 apartments in the four biggest public housing projects here.

headline: Ailey Family Celebrates One of Its Own
text: Dance companies like to refer to themselves as families. The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater actually seems to fit the description, with dancers staying on in administrative capacities long after retiring from the stage. Ailey, who died in 1989, inspired unusual loyalty and affection partly, I suspect, because of his own endearing humanity and self-doubt.

headline: Cactus Makes Perfect
text: Heat-seeking golfers who favor Scottsdale, Ariz., will encounter a curious phenomenon this winter: What's old is new. November witnessed extreme makeovers applied to two of the Sonoran Desert's "must-play" destinations, Troon North and the TPC Scottsdale. Troon North's tweaks are the more subtle. Its Saguaro-laced Monument and Pinnacle courses have been rated as Arizona's top two public-access tracks for than 10 years, but the layout routed players in confusing directions. After much soul-searching, Troon Golf executives split up the vaunted Monument layout, pairing its old back nine with the old back nine of the Pinnacle to form a "new" Pinnacle course. The "new" Monument course comprises the old front nines. Original designer Tom Weiskopf resurfaced the greens and reworked the bunkers to achieve a consistent look throughout. The result is better flow. Gone are the "Where-in-the-world-am-I-going" cart rides that slowed up play considerably. Monument is the more spectacular of the two, with gigantic rocks and elevation changes at every turn, but Pinnacle is tougher -- and, in a rarity for the desert, is a walkable course, even if its ninth hole doesn't return to the clubhouse.

headline: Arrogance and Warming
text: The Bush administration’s decision to deny California permission to regulate and reduce global warming emissions from cars and trucks is an indefensible act of executive arrogance that can only be explained as the product of ideological blindness and as a political payoff to the automobile industry.

headline: Scientists Weigh Stem Cells’ Role as Cancer Cause
text: Within the next few months, researchers at three medical centers expect to start the first test in patients of one of the most promising  and contentious  ideas about the cause and treatment of cancer.

headline: China Grabs West’s Smoke-Spewing Factories
text: HANDAN, China  When residents of this northern Chinese city hang their clothes out to dry, the black fallout from nearby Handan Iron and Steel often sends them back to the wash.

headline: Consumer Spending and Inflation Up
text: Inflation grew in November at its fastest pace in two years, as sky-high oil prices pushed up the costs of other products, the Commerce Department said on Friday.

headline: Talk About Slippery Slopes
text: One of the daredevils in “Steep,” a documentary about extreme skiing, insists he is not hooked on the adrenaline rush of this death-defying sport. His denial is hard to believe.

headline: In Race for Comptroller, Some Are Looking Ahead
text: The job comes with a $176,000 salary, a $76 million budget, a $112 billion pension fund to invest and a staff of 700. There are rarely controversial decisions to make or angry constituents to deal with. And it’s a nifty platform from which to run for another office.

headline: Iraq Bomber Aimed at Alcohol Sellers
text: BAGHDAD  Blood and ouzo mingled on the sidewalk outside a shattered Baghdad liquor store on Thursday after three people were killed in a car bombing directed at alcohol sellers in one of Baghdad’s most heavily protected areas.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $3,183,702

headline: Doctor May Testify if Bonds Goes to Trial
text: Federal prosecutors will probably call a former doctor for Barry Bonds as a witness if Bonds’s perjury and obstruction of justice case goes to trial, according to court documents made public Thursday.

headline: Bill Strauss, Parodist of Public Figures, Dies at 60
text: Bill Strauss, a founder of the singing satirical troupe Capitol Steps, whose response to any political disaster of the last quarter-century was to find out whether it rhymed with anything, died Tuesday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 60.

headline: Election 2013 (or Later): Debates Already in Swing
text: The future is uncertain for Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens. Bonds could end up in prison if he is found guilty of felony charges of perjury or obstruction of justice for lying to a grand jury about using steroids. Clemens could be called to testify before Congress next month to answer questions about his alleged steroid use.

headline: TV’s Perfect Girl Is Pregnant; Real Families Talk
text: CONCORD, Mass.  Talk about teachable moments.

headline: What Do You Believe?
text: After the Mitchell Report’s release, a handful of players named in the report have admitted using performance enhancing substances once or twice. Roger Clemens, meanwhile, has denied using any steroids and human growth hormone. Do you believe these statements made by the players?

headline: The Old South, Down to the Colonnaded Verandas
text: ON a warm spring day in 1986, Steve and Marianne Harrison took up the invitation to visit a friend who had just moved from Connecticut to a drowsy little town in the South Carolina Lowcountry. The couple were complete Manhattan fashion obsessives: Mr. Harrison was an executive with Anne Klein, and his wife a partner in Smith-Kollmar, a successful knitwear maker. When he considers that they had never even been to Charleston or Savannah, much less tiny Beaufort, Mr. Harrison concedes that their next decision was perhaps a bit rash.

headline: Site of Shootings Reopens With Tears and Applause
text: OMAHA  It was all quiet except for the sound of muffled crying when the security gate rose Thursday morning at the reopening of the Von Maur department store here, the site of a shooting rampage that left nine people dead just over two weeks ago.

headline: Drug Maker and Eye Doctors Settle Dispute Over Avastin
text: Genentech appears to have resolved a dispute with ophthalmologists that will allow the company’s drug Avastin to continue to be used to treat eye diseases, both sides announced on Thursday.

headline: Study Quantifies Orphanage Link to I.Q.
text: Psychologists have long believed that growing up in an institution like an orphanage stunts children’s mental development but have never had direct evidence to back it up.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: A Picasso Is Stolen

headline: Kyrgyzstan: On Top of Old Santa
text: The authorities say they plan to name one of the country’s snowy peaks Mount Santa Claus. Why such an honor from the predominantly Muslim and former Soviet land? “We want to develop tourism, and Santa Claus is an ideal brand to help us do this,” said Nurhon Tadzhibayeva, a tourism official.

headline: Share Of Curlin Is Sold
text: The ownership of the Breeders’ Cup Classic winner Curlin has changed again. Jess Jackson bought out another partner and now has an 80 percent interest in Curlin, a 3-year-old colt. Jackson, who owns Stonestreet Stables, bought out the investment banker George Bolton. Jackson’s spokesman Kevin McGee would not provide details. Curlin is the favorite to be named Horse of the Year in 2007.

headline: Economy Enjoyed a Summer Sprint, but Mortgage Crisis Expected to Slow Pace in Final Quarter
text: WASHINGTON (AP)  The economy sprinted ahead at its fastest pace in four years during the summer, but it is expected to limp through the final three months of this year as housing and credit problems weigh on individuals and businesses alike.

headline: Behind the Music, This Time for Laughs
text: “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story” has a good beat and you can dance to it, though mostly you’ll probably just tap your foot. It’s a cleverly packaged story about a patently phony musician  er, John C. Reilly is Dewey Cox  who conquers the nation’s eardrums with a song in his heart, a guitar in his hands and a million clichés in his DNA. He’s a tuneful pastiche: a little bit country, a little bit rock ’n’ roll, topped off with a pinch of Ray Charles, a dash of Buddy Holly and a whole mess of Johnny Cash as filtered through Joaquin Phoenix’s impersonation and mischievously repurposed through the Judd Apatow laugh factory.

headline: Pakistan: Lawyers’ Leader Rearrested
text: Pakistani officials rearrested Aitzaz Ahsan, the leader of Pakistan’s lawyers movement, just 18 hours after granting him a three-day release from detention as a good-will gesture for the Id al-Adha holiday. He was arrested just outside the capital, Islamabad, according his wife. Mr. Ahsan; the dismissed chief justice of the Supreme Court, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry; and several other dismissed justices have been jailed or placed under house arrest since President Pervez Musharraf declared a state of emergency last month, suspended the Constitution and appointed a new Supreme Court. The lawyers movement is a driving force of the opposition against Mr. Musharraf.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about the selection of Jacob Zuma as the new leader of South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, gave the incorrect age in some copies in describing when he was sent to prison by the former apartheid government. He was 21, not 24.

headline: To Dismay of Inspectors, Prowling Cats Keep Rodents on the Run at City Delis
text: Across the city, delis and bodegas are a familiar and vital part of the streetscape, modest places where customers can pick up necessities, a container of milk, a can of soup, a loaf of bread.

headline: Ship That Spilled Oil Leaves Bay Area
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The Chinese container ship that hit the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge on Nov. 7, spilling 58,000 gallons of fuel, was cleared to leave United States waters on Thursday and resume maritime commerce.

headline: Frosty the Cyclist
text: Even in cold weather, pedaling up a hill will make you steamy. That changes quickly on descent -- making dressing for cold-weather cycling quite tricky. "If you don't have one component right, it just doesn't work," says Brandon Dwight, the co-owner of Boulder Cycle Sport in Colorado and a competitive cyclist since 1993.

headline: Three Tar Heels Attacked
text: The authorities have charged two women and a man with a weekend attack on three North Carolina football players, which police said was motivated by robbery and included the sexual assault of at least two players. The police said the players were attacked early Sunday at their off-campus apartment.

headline: Finding the Hard and Frozen Stuff
text: When the conditions are just right, the Sierra backcountry has hundreds of mountain lakes to skate on, and "our loose confederation of mountain skaters had gone in search of perfect ice," David Page writes for The Times. With the weather teetering above freezing, many of the lakes remained open water, but that didn't stop the pursuit.

headline: Jack Linkletter, Second-Generation TV Host, Dies at 70
text: Jack Linkletter, who followed his father, Art Linkletter, into broadcasting, serving as the host of several television shows in the late 1950s and 1960s, died on Tuesday at his home in Cloverdale, Calif. He was 70.

headline: For Clinton Campaign, Different Strategies at Play
text: DES MOINES  Faced with a question, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton often begins her answers with a single word: “Well.” (As in, “Well, I’ve spent 35 years of my life...”) It’s hard to tell if it’s a verbal tic; a one-syllable pause as she prepares a response; or a Midwesternism that has survived Wellesley, Yale, Arkansas, Washington, and New York.

headline: Top Bush Terrorism Adviser Is Leaving Unscathed
text: WASHINGTON  For more than four years Frances Fragos Townsend, President Bush’s departing chief terrorism adviser, has worked at the center of contentious anti-terrorism programs, but unlike other battle-scarred West Wing colleagues she is departing with barely a scratch.

headline: Huckabee, Back in Iowa, Brings Christmas Message
text: DIKE, Iowa  He came to town this week dressed in a dark pinstriped suit and cowboy boots, advocating lower taxes, death to the Internal Revenue Service and restoration of the words “Merry Christmas” and “Jesus Christ” to the American lexicon.
