text: THEATER

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Id al-Adha, the Muslim Feast of the Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: India Overturns Law Banning Women Bartenders
text: NEW DELHI  Yet another British-era law has been toppled like a drunk from a bar stool, in a change that gives women the freedom to make a living mixing the perfect cosmopolitan.

headline: Despite Earlier Defiance, Holdouts in Columbia’s Expansion Zone Are Down to 3
text: When Columbia University began buying property north of its Morningside Heights campus for its planned expansion a few years ago, a group of longtime business owners formed an alliance and pledged never to sell.

headline: City Urged to Restore Stop on Extension of No. 7 Train
text: Two years after the Far West Side was rezoned for large-scale development, a growing number of elected officials, environmentalists and community groups are questioning the city’s and state’s plans for the area.

headline: In High Country California, Seeking Ice Instead of Snow
text: WE drove up into the High Sierra at first light, on roads that by the end of the day would be open only to travelers on cross-country skis or snowshoes. The National Weather Service had issued a winter storm watch; up to two feet of snow was predicted. It was the first big storm of winter, and when it hit, another season of skating mountain lakes would come to a muffled end.

headline: Never Mind the Map: Sometimes New York City Is More of an Idea
text: Oh, say can you see? With its red and black stripes and black stars on a green field, David Hammons’s beautiful “African-American Flag” hangs high over the central exhibition space of “New York States of Mind” at the Queens Museum of Art.

headline: With Little Time Left, Trenton Lawmakers Weigh New Formula for School Financing
text: TRENTON  Less than three weeks before the end of the legislative session, state lawmakers began circulating a bill on Thursday that would overhaul the formula New Jersey uses to finance its public schools.

headline: To Keep Doors Open, St. Bart’s Opens Its Arms
text: THE Rev. William McDonald Tully, with his bald head bare and his clerical shirt and collar camouflaged by that urban essential, a V-neck sweater in black cashmere, is loping down the center aisle of St. Bartholomew’s Episcopal Church, the gently decaying Park Avenue landmark where he has served as rector, and as a bit of a secular entrepreneur, since 1994.

headline: Mel Cheren, 74, an Entrepreneur of Disco, Dies
text: Mel Cheren, an innovative record executive who helped start the Paradise Garage, a cavernous focal point of the downtown Manhattan gay disco scene in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Dec. 7 in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: New Fund to Help Charities Add Efficiency by Growth
text: A New York foundation that focuses largely on opportunities for low-income youths is creating a fund to help charities become bigger and more efficient.

headline: For a Top-Tier University, There’s Now Room to Get Even Better
text: As Columbia University officials doggedly pursued their plan to acquire 17 acres a few blocks north of their main campus in Manhattan, they often pulled out a chart showing their pint-size 36-acre campus stacked up against those of competitors like Harvard, Princeton and Yale, whose campuses are measured in the hundreds of acres.

headline: Stewart and Colbert to Return Without Writers
text: Comedy Central’s pair of popular news satirists, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert, will return to their television shows on Jan. 7, two months after production was suspended because of a writers’ strike.

headline: No Forfeits, Bowden Says
text: Coach Bobby Bowden said he did not think Florida State would have to forfeit games for using ineligible players this season. “We didn’t know anyone was ineligible,” he said Thursday. Bowden has 373 career victories, the most in major college football history. About two dozen Florida State players have been suspended for the Music City Bowl against Kentucky for cheating on an online exam.

headline: Refocusing, Campbell Sells Godiva
text: The Campbell Soup Company agreed on Thursday to sell its Godiva Chocolatier unit to Yildiz Holding of Turkey for $850 million.

headline: New York Condos Lure Deal-Seeking Europeans
text: The sidewalks of Manhattan are crammed this month with European tourists on shopping sprees, picking up gifts that cost far less in the United States than they do at home because of the weak dollar. But they are not just crowding into boutiques and department stores. Some are also shopping for condominiums.

headline: For a Stealthy Transit Fare Increase, Listless Boos and Shows of Regret
text: The fate of subway and bus riders  a polite way to say higher fares  was sealed on Wednesday in a well-lighted but thoroughly soulless boardroom of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: Missing From Mitchell Report, Sosa Is Included in Grimsley Affidavit
text: The Department of Justice unsealed two affidavits by a federal agent concerning people involved with performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, identifying seven more current or former major and minor league players, including the home run slugger Sammy Sosa, who may have used the drugs.

headline: A Serious Run at the Playoffs Brings Out the Vikings’ Humorous Side
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Something about winning brings out the amateur comedian in everybody, even a deadly serious coach like Brad Childress of the Minnesota Vikings.

headline: Matisse, Drawing in Three Dimensions
text: In 1899, at a time when his paintings were showing lots of rebellious talent but not much clear direction, Henri Matisse began attending classes in clay modeling and sculpture. Assigned to copy one of the sculptural masterpieces in the Louvre, he selected “Jaguar Devouring a Hare,” a violently precise work by Antoine-Louis Barye.

headline: Microwave Greatness
text: Despite their first home loss of the season Wednesday night, the Boston Celtics' reversal is practically unrivaled in American sports. When something so dramatic happens, it is an immutable law of American sports media that no superlative is quite superlative enough. With a 20-3 record, the Celtics aren't just a great turnaround story, they're The Best Team Of Modern Times. Until they aren't.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about changes in the credit ratings of bond guarantors misidentified a company assigned a negative outlook by Standard & Poor’s. It is XL Capital Assurance, not XL Capital Ltd.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about charter schools that received their grades under New York City’s new report card system misstated the number of charters that were graded. It was 14 out of 60  not 13.

headline: Personal Touch for Richardson in Envoy Role
text: In 1998, Bill Richardson, then the United States ambassador to the United Nations, flew to Japan in search of backing for potential military strikes in Iraq.

headline: Los Angeles Police Told to Disclose Their Finances
text: LOS ANGELES  Officers of the Los Angeles Police Department’s gang unit and narcotics unit will be required to disclose an array of personal financial information to the department under a new anticorruption policy.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: France: Housing Aide Out Over Cheap Home
text: Jean-Paul Bolufer, the chief of staff in the Housing Ministry, was ordered to step down for enjoying a subsidized 2,000-square-foot Left Bank apartment at a quarter of the market rent. The scandal came as the ministry faced pressure over high rents and homelessness.

headline: Top Concert Promoter Sets Up a Challenge to Ticketmaster
text: In a bid to consolidate its hold on live-music fans, the concert giant Live Nation said on Thursday that it would acquire the software and services to ramp up its ticket-selling operation, potentially positioning the company to compete directly with its longtime contractor, Ticketmaster.

headline: China and India in First War Games
text: China and India began a weeklong joint military exercise in China’s southwestern Yunnan Province. The drills, which involve about 100 soldiers from each side, are intended at strengthening cooperation on anti-terrorism, according to China Daily. China and India fought a brief border war in 1962 and have been unable to resolve a related territorial dispute through negotiations.

headline: Sierra Leone: Blast in Capital Kills 17
text: A huge explosion in the center of the capital, Freetown, killed at least 17 people and wounded many more, according to witnesses and rescue officials. Officials said that the blast, which occurred on a busy street in a main shopping district of Freetown as crowds thronged to shop for Christmas, was most likely caused by a gas leak. Sierra Leone’s infrastructure remains badly dilapidated from a decade-long civil war that ended in 2002.

headline: Violent Protest Over Housing in New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS  After protesters clashed violently with the police inside and outside the New Orleans City Council chambers on Thursday, the council voted unanimously to allow the federal government to demolish 4,500 apartments in the four biggest public housing projects in the city.

headline: Gone for the Holidays, but Leaving a Light on (Got It, Mr. President?)
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate seemed to wrap up its last business of the year on Wednesday night. But anyone listening carefully to the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, would have heard him laying out plans for the Senate to work through the holidays  sort of.

headline: 50 Killed in Pakistan Bombing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan -- A suicide attacker detonated a powerful bomb inside a crowded mosque in northwestern Pakistan Friday morning, killing as many as 50 men and wounding 80 as they prayed to mark the Muslim holiday of Id al-Adha, Pakistan's former interior minister said.

headline: Stocks Soar on Merrill Report and Economic Data
text: Stock markets surged on Friday as reports of talks on an investment in Merrill Lynch and a strong report on consumer spending lifted investors’ spirits heading into the holiday weekend.

headline: Man Sought for Questioning in Killing
text: The police identified a Brooklyn man on Thursday that they are seeking for questioning in the Dec. 15 death of Carol Simon-Hayes, who was shot as she walked to the entrance of her Crown Heights apartment building.

headline: Searching Across the Border
text: SOUTH of the border? How about north? Second-home shoppers who want something more exotic than their friends’ mountain bungalows and beach condos have two easy options: Mexico and Canada.

headline: Giants Stay Relaxed Despite the Stakes
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The temperature was in the 40s, the field was bathed in sunshine, the wind was barely blowing and Giants Coach Tom Coughlin was happy. Preparations for a big game were going smoothly  maybe even better.

headline: Newly Elected South Korean Forecasts Chill With North
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean president-elect, Lee Myung-bak, who said during his campaign that he intended to get tough with North Korea, declared Thursday that he would not hesitate to criticize its authoritarian government.

headline: Epiphanies in a Medieval Courtyard
text: THE first thing I see every morning is the Cloisters tower, gray and severe, perfectly framed by the living room window of my apartment. The Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum’s medieval outpost, is about a quarter-mile to the south, on a hill a little higher than the one my building is on, near the stony tip of northern Manhattan. In between is a valley of rooftops, garages and streets. Above, open sky, clouds, the moon, stars.

headline: Tyson Finds a Label for Its Antibiotic-Free (Well, Almost) Chicken
text: Tyson Foods ran into an unusual snag after it introduced a marketing campaign to promote its “raised without antibiotics” chicken. The Department of Agriculture initially approved the label, but later said it had made a mistake.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the social networking of technology start-ups in California misidentified the location of the part of Sand Hill Road where Silicon Valley venture capital firms are concentrated. It is in Menlo Park, not Palo Alto.

headline: Whistler Blackcomb
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Musical Greetings That Swing Angelically
text: The pop-jazz singer Ann Hampton Callaway possesses what I think of as a quintessential Christmas voice. Sweet and pure, with a fluty upper register, her sound transports you to an ethereal realm where the air is thin and clear, and moonlight lends the snow on the earth below a bluish tint.

headline: Mint to Add 6 Nonstates to State Quarters Lineup
text: Americans who are unsure where the Northern Mariana Islands lie, or just what Guam is famous for, may find answers in their pocket change by the end of 2009.

headline: Gold in the Ivory Tower
text: THE separation of the wealthiest from the rest of the country is alarming. But it would be even more alarming if we recognized that income isn’t the only measure of wealth. Health and education are forms of wealth, too, essential to happiness and a strong society. Yet in the discussion of America’s growing wealth gap, they too often go unnoticed.

headline: Cubans Still Waiting for Castro
text: CIENFUEGOS, Cuba  The speculation was that he would be here, that Fidel Castro was ready to leave his hospital bed after 17 months of convalescence and that he would come to inaugurate a revamped Soviet-era oil refinery that he had been saying for years was a key to Cuba’s energy future.

headline: Class-Action Cases Rise, Fueled by Subprime Troubles
text: The subprime mess is turning out to be a boon for class-action lawyers.

headline: Man Cleared in 1998 Northern Ireland Blast
text: LONDON  A judge in Belfast on Thursday cleared Sean Hoey, a 38-year-old electrician, of murder and all other charges stemming from the car bombing in 1998 that killed 29 people and wounded more than 200 in the Northern Ireland town of Omagh.

headline: Smoothing Bumps for Boomers
text: IT was at the top of a trail called Hanging Tree that the fear set in. And at the crest of a steep, mogul-filled and tree-strewn trail, it’s all about the fear, isn’t it? This was near the top of Aspen Mountain last winter, and at moments like these  surveying a no-nonsense double-black-diamond run  the mind will race.

headline: F.T.C. Approves DoubleClick Deal
text: THE Federal Trade Commission said Thursday that it had cleared Google’s proposed merger with DoubleClick, the digital marketing company, saying that the deal was “unlikely to substantially lessen competition” in the Internet advertising realm.

headline: Out of Uncertainty, a Coach Brings Success
text: Bill Lynch’s cellphone buzzed early one morning in June at the Indiana University football complex. It was the daughter of his good friend, Indiana Coach Terry Hoeppner, calling to tell Lynch that her father had died that morning after an 18-month fight with brain cancer.

headline: U.N. Body Plans to End Investigation of Contracts
text: UNITED NATIONS  The General Assembly is preparing to put an early end to an in-house panel that has exposed more than $600 million in tainted United Nations contracts and is currently investigating an additional $1 billion in suspect agreements.

headline: Russia Signs Deal for Gas Pipeline Along Caspian Sea
text: Desperate to meet growing domestic and European demand, Russia signed a deal Thursday with the Central Asian republics of Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan to build a natural gas pipeline along the Caspian Sea, a move that analysts said could strengthen Russia’s monopoly on energy exports from the region.

headline: Solving the Mortgage Crisis May Require a Guardian Angel
text: I knew it was the Christmas season. There on television was Henry F. Potter, the mean banker, quizzing Pa Bailey, the idealist from the building and loan society.

headline: Musical Greetings That Swing Angelically
text: The pop-jazz singer Ann Hampton Callaway possesses what I think of as a quintessential Christmas voice. Sweet and pure, with a fluty upper register, her sound transports you to an ethereal realm where the air is thin and clear, and moonlight lends the snow on the earth below a bluish tint.

headline: Decongesting the Skies
text: The Bush administration’s remedy for the nation’s overcrowded skies, months in the making, correctly zeros in on the New York area where steady and sometimes monumental delays have created flying misery across the nation. The short-term solution includes caps on hourly traffic, which should help. But Washington also needs to aggressively pursue longer-term solutions, chief among them cutting-edge air traffic control systems and relieving congestion on runways and taxiways.

headline: Visions of Sugar Plums
text: On Wednesday evening at the New York State Theater, George Balanchine’s production of “The Nutcracker” achieved its 2,000th performance by New York City Ballet. After a perfectly straightforward account of the first act, the second one became a special event. The three principal dance roles  the Sugar Plum Fairy, her Cavalier and the Dewdrop Fairy  were performed in multiple castings. One Sugar Plum ballerina (Maria Kowroski) danced the character’s solo; later another (Wendy Whelan) danced her adagio; then three (Darci Kistler, Yvonne Borree and Abi Stafford) shared the stage in its coda, of whom one (Ms. Kistler, who was dancing lead “Nutcracker” roles in her 1980 debut season) took charge of the end of the ballet.

headline: Treasures From Afghanistan to Tour the United States
text: A traveling exhibition of some 200 artworks from the National Museum of Afghanistan in Kabul will begin a 17-month tour in the United States in May, making its first stop at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article and a picture caption on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about the office market in Manhattan misstated the address of the Milk Studios Building, which recently sold for more than $160 million. It is at 450 West 15th Street, not East 15th Street.

headline: Murder Most Musical
text: Tim Burton makes fantasy movies. Stephen Sondheim writes musicals. It is hard to think of two more optimistic genres of popular art, or of two popular artists who have so systematically subverted that optimism. Mr. Sondheim has always gravitated toward the dissonance lurking in hummable tunes, and has threaded his song-and-dance spectaculars with subtexts of anxiety and alienation. Mr. Burton, for his part, dwells most naturally (if somewhat uneasily) in the realms of the gothic and the grotesque, turning comic books and children’s tales into scary, nightmarish shadow plays.

headline: Handel’s Holiday Hit, Tactfully Modern
text: For a week or two in mid-December, Handel’s oratorio “Messiah” is performed somewhere in New York almost every day. As holiday traditions go, this has certainly proved to be among the more durable. The New York Philharmonic threw its collective hat into the overcrowded ring just a few years ago, offering performances played by an instrumental complement scaled down to the proportions of a Baroque ensemble.

headline:
Helping Police Officers
Understand the Autistic
text: BRICK TOWNSHIP, N.J.  An autistic boy is discovered standing in the middle of a busy road, on his way to the beach. A young girl with autism outsmarts a number of locks, leaves the house before her mother wakes up and is found, naked but alive, in a neighbor’s pool.

headline: Albany Adds 60 Schools to City List of Failures
text: Sixty New York City elementary and middle schools have been newly identified as failing under the federal No Child Left Behind law, according to a list released on Thursday by the State Education Department, which also showed that the number of failing schools was rising in both the city and the state.

headline: India: Premier Asks States to Fight Maoists
text: With ill-equipped and short-staffed local police forces unable to handle an increasingly well-organized Maoist insurgency in central India, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh urged state governments to establish special police forces to take on the guerrillas. Mr. Singh was speaking to a conference on internal security in the capital, New Delhi, four days after Maoists led a jailbreak that freed 300 prisoners from a local jail in Chhattisgarh, the epicenter of the conflict. Mr. Singh, who has called the Maoist rebellion the most significant internal security challenge to the country, acknowledged that a lack of opportunity in some of India’s poorest hinterlands had provided “a fertile ground for extremist ideologies to flourish,” but also said that insecurity had hindered economic expansion in those very areas.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Blindly Into the Bubble
text: When announcing Japan’s surrender in 1945, Emperor Hirohito famously explained his decision as follows: “The war situation has developed not necessarily to Japan’s advantage.”

headline: Data About Zetia Risks Was Not Fully Revealed
text: New evidence shows that the drug makers Merck and Schering-Plough have conducted several studies of their popular cholesterol medicine Zetia that raise questions about its risks to the liver, but the companies have never published those results.

headline: With Detroit Downbeat on 2008, Its Suppliers Are Singing the Blues
text: CARMAKERS expect 2008 to be challenging, at best, but hundreds of automotive parts suppliers are anticipating the year ahead to be one of the ugliest ever.

headline: In Bhutan, Sacred Sights Amid the Clouds
text: “Traveling many years, I have not yet seen a place as peaceful as Bhutan, or a place affecting such peacefulness within myself,” the photographer Kenro Izu writes. “If there is a place indeed named Utopia, this place may come the closest to it.” Mr. Izu has been taking photographs of sacred places since the late 1970s, but Bhutan, a Buddhist country of about 670,000 people nestled in the Himalayas, has become his personal Shangri-La.

headline: I.R.S. Says Bill Would Aid Tax Fraud in Virgin Islands
text: The Internal Revenue Service has criticized proposed legislation that would scale back audits of wealthy taxpayers in the United States Virgin Islands, saying that the bill would “significantly affect” the agency’s efforts to combat offshore tax fraud.

headline: Sallie Mae Delays Stock Repurchase
text: The parent of Sallie Mae, which for years profited from placing large bets on its own stock going up, now faces a possible loss of more than $1 billion as the bet has gone drastically wrong. On Thursday it negotiated a two-month delay in the deadline for coming up with the money.

headline: Good-Time Charlie’s Foreign Affairs
text: Most of the recent films we’ve seen about the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq remind us what a drag those conflicts are, which may be why so few of us have bothered to go see them. Of course all wars are terrible, but good movies have a way of mitigating that dreary fact even as they acknowledge it. Take the cold war: a “long twilight struggle” (as John F. Kennedy put it) that brought the world to the brink of annihilation and provided a persistent source of tension, anxiety and dread for hundreds of millions of people around the world. Horrible, to be sure. But also kind of a blast.

headline: Penn State Players Charged
text: Felony assault charges were refiled against two Penn State football players, two weeks after a judge dismissed the same charges at a preliminary hearing. Defensive tackle Chris Baker and linebacker Navorro Bowman were charged Wednesday with being part of a group of people that beat a man Oct. 7. Centre County District Attorney Michael Madeira said District Judge Carmine Prestia erred when he dropped the charges.

headline: Study Shows Marathons Aren’t Likely to Kill You
text: Worried about dropping dead if you run a marathon? Researchers in Canada say you can put your mind at ease. The risk of dying on a marathon course is twice as high if you drive it than if you run it, they find.

headline: Denial of State Emissions Plan Was Foreshadowed
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration’s decision to deny California the right to regulate greenhouse gases from vehicles exploded like a grenade here and in California. But it was hiding in plain sight for weeks.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Small Town Cheers Huckabee’s Embrace of Faith
text: DIKE, Iowa  He came to town this week dressed in a dark pinstriped suit and cowboy boots, advocating lower taxes, death to the Internal Revenue Service and restoration of the words “Merry Christmas” and “Jesus Christ” to the American lexicon.

headline: Oil-for-Food Case Opens in Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Six Australian businessmen face the possibility of millions of dollars in fines in a new civil case connected with huge bribes paid to the government of Saddam Hussein.

headline: On the Water, Away From the Tracks
text: STAND on the banks of the Hudson River and it is easy to envision Henry Hudson and his crew sailing its waters for the first time; the battles and gunfire of the Revolutionary War; and Thomas Cole, along with the rest of the Hudson River School painters, easels nearby and paintbrushes in hand. New York state history doesn’t get a lot more palpable than this.

headline: FedEx Earnings Fall; High Fuel Costs Blamed
text: MEMPHIS (AP)  The package courier FedEx reported on Thursday that its second-quarter profit fell 6 percent from a year ago, largely because of high fuel costs, lower demand for freight shipments and a sluggish American economy.

headline: Court Voids Conviction in 1988 Murders
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.  A state appellate court overturned on Friday the convictions of a Long Island man who has been imprisoned for 17 years for the grisly 1988 murders of his parents.

headline: A Revisionist Tale: Why a Poor China Seems Richer
text: HONG KONG  Should China be treated differently because it may not be so rich after all? That is one of the central questions raised by new calculations from the World Bank that suggest the Chinese economy may not be as large as previously thought.

headline: Australia Suit Over Wheat for Iraq
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Six Australian businessmen face the possibility of millions of dollars in fines in a new civil case connected with huge bribes paid to the government of Saddam Hussein.

headline: Film Listings
text: MOVIES

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Hamas Fighter Killed in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  A Hamas fighter was shot to death on Friday in Gaza near the border with Israel, but the Israeli army said it had nothing to do with it.

headline: One Blast Furnace, Two Steel Towns
text: The mass shift of polluting industries from West to East has blighted China's economic rise, while giving the West cleaner air and water.

headline: Early Friday Injury Update: Steelers Lose Parker
text: Steelers running back Willie Parker, the N.F.L’s leading rusher, broke his right leg in the first quarter Thursday night against the Rams. Pittsburgh snapped a two-game losing streak, winning by 41-24, and received a strong game from Parker’s replacement, Najeh Davenport. But this was against a 3-12 team. How will Parker’s injury affect the Steelers in the playoffs?

headline: Sid the Fighting Kid
text: A goal, two assists and his first N.H.L. fight added up to a Gordie for Sidney Crosby in Boston on Thursday. Tom Fitzgerald, the Penguins’ director of player development, said between periods on NESN that Pittsburgh brass cringed when they saw the franchise throw down against the Bruins’ Andrew Ference. What if he were to break a hand on a helmet? But behold, those soft hands in action:

headline: Hat Trick + 2 for Gaborik
text: There are nights when everything seems to find the back of the net. But it certainly helps when you’re as fast and skilled as the Wild’s Marian Gaborik.

headline: For the Moment | Yearn, Hollywood, yearn!
text: Franklin Getchell

headline: Potential Change for a Crucial Habitat
text: Environmentalists are thinking ahead to the effect of tourists and investors on Cuba, which is a landscape of important habitats.

headline: Think About Climate Change on the Beach This Week
text: My column this week is on small island states and why they have taken the lead in issues related to climate change. I’m talking about places like the Maldives, the Seychelles, and Caribbean Islands — which will literally be swallowed up by 1.5 meters of sea level rise. Aggressive action on climate change is a matter of survival for them.

headline: City Officials Aren’t LOL About Cats
text: Bodega owners like ’em for their rodent kill power, but cats are not a health inspector’s best friend:

headline: 'An Ordinary Spy'
The Week Ahead: Dec. 23-29
text: Film

headline: Stewart and Colbert to Return, Sans Writers
text: Comedy Central’s pair of popular news satirists will return to their television shows on Jan. 7, a day before the first in a series of pivotal primary election nights. But with guests staying away because of the writers’ strike, who are they — not to mention Letterman, Leno and Conan — going to get to talk to them? Read more …

headline: M&A Deals Hit Record $1.57 Trillion in 2007
text: Despite a sharp decline in dealmaking at mid-year, merger volume in 2007 hit a record $1.57 trillion in the United States, up 5.5 percent from the previous year, according to research firm Thomson Financial. But, for the first time in five years, U.S. lagged deal-making in Europe, where mergers totaled $1.78 trillion.

headline: SunTrust Bails Out 2 Funds
text: SunTrust Banks, the large regional bank, said Thursday that it would take up to $400 million in fourth-quarter pretax write-downs, mainly from a bailout of two money market funds.

headline: Royal Philips to Buy Respironics or $5.2 Billion
text: Royal Philips Electronics, the world’s largest manufacturer of patient-monitoring systems, agreed to buy Respironics, which makes medical devices, for 3.6 billion euros ($5.2 billion) in what Bloomberg News called its biggest acquisition ever.

headline: Mayer Brown to Merge With Hong Kong Firm
text: Mayer Brown, the Chicago-based law firm, announced Friday that it will join forces with Johnson, Stokes & Master of Hong Kong in a deal that will dramatically expand its Asian presence.

headline: Arcapita Snaps Up Storage Company Pods
text: Arcapita, an investment firm owned by Arcapita Bank of Bahrain, said Thursday it purchased Pods, a moving and storage container company, for $430 million.

headline: Kyte Flies Off With $15 Million
text: Kyte, a mobile social-networking start-up, said Thursday it got $15 million in funding from Spanish carrier Telefonica, Japan’s NTT DoCoMo, and Nokia Growth Partners.

headline: Basell Closes Lyondell Chemical Deal
text: Basell, the Dutch chemical and plastics maker, completed its acquisition of Houston-based  Lyondell Chemical, creating the world’s third-largest independent chemical company.

headline: Subprime Troubles Fuel Class-Action Suits
text: The subprime mess is turning out to be a boon for class-action lawyers.

headline: UBS Hires Head of Global Investment Solutions
text: UBS‘s global asset management group has hired Curt Custard, previously the global head of multi-asset solutions at  Schroders, to run its global investment solutions business unit. The unit’s previous head had resigned.

headline: Got Him Right in the Chess
text: Found here.

headline: G.E. and Allied Launch Buyout Loan Fund
text: GE Commercial Finance and Allied Capital, seeking to fill a gap left by troubled investment banks, have formed a $3.6 billion fund to finance private equity deals. The fund will finance commitments up to $500 million for borrowers across a range of industries, including healthcare, media, energy, aerospace, business services and transportation.

headline: GainSpain Closes $20 Million Round
text: GainSpan, which focuses on Wi-Fi sensor network technology, said it completed a $20 million second round of funding led by Opus Capital.

headline: Ex-Merrill Executives Seek Delay in Enron-Related Trial
text: Three former Merrill Lynch executives scheduled to be tried a second time on charges of participating in an alleged sham deal with Enron want a judge to postpone the January trial so they can resume efforts to settle the matter.

headline: A Matchmaker for Hedge Funds and Investors
text: Hedge fund managers and institutional investors are hooking up on the Internet.

headline: Counter-Narrative
text: Of course, all serious movie fans have heard the tender-hearted tale of the wise-beyond-her-years 16 year old who became pregnant, but remained steadfast even as those around her looked askance.

headline: Bonus Dispute Lands Fund in Receivership
text: Southway Partners, a Minnesota hedge fund firm, has been put into receivership by a judge who was angered by the refusal of the firm’s principals to pay $1.83 million in bonuses owed to a former portfolio manager.

headline: Fewer Births, Fewer Deaths for 2007
text: Fewer hedge funds are opening, and fewer are closing, as the hedge fund industry is set for multi-year lows in both categories in 2007.

headline: Michigan Court Seeks to Halt Manor Care Buyout
text: Carlyle Group‘s $4.9 billion buyout of Manor Care, the largest nursing-home chain in the United States, cleared a hurdle in West Virginia, where regulators on Thursday lifted a suspension of their approval, but hit a snag in Michigan, where a court issued a temporary restraining order seeking to halt the deal.

headline: Vimpel Dials Up $4.3 Billion Telecom Deal
text: Vimpel Communications, Russia’s second-largest mobile operator, said Friday it agreed to buy Golden Telecom for about $4.3 billion. Under the deal, which had been widely expected, Vimpelcom will pay $105 for each Golden Telecom share, a 5 percent premium to its closing price Thursday.

headline: NetSuite Shares Surge in Debut
text: Fears that NetSuite‘s decision to use a Dutch auction to launch its initial public offering would keep the business software maker’s stock from popping in its debut appear to have been unfounded.

headline: Feeling Guru-vy
text: The Bagger is not proud of the fact that he finds the Gurus of Gold, at Movie City News, riveting. He is going to meetings and leaning hard on a power greater than himself to overcome his obsession with what is, after all, a meaningless grid of movie awards persiflage.

headline: Senior Executive Is Leaving Cisco Systems
text: Cisco Systems‘ chief development officer, Charles H. Giancarlo, widely seen as a top candidate for chief executive, announced on Thursday that he was quitting the company, leaving the race for leadership wide open.

headline: MBIA Shares Fall as Risk Cushion Unravels
text: It’s been a rough week for MBIA.

headline: Packaged Goods
text: The Vulture explores the re-occurring role this year of some dude named Wang, among his many aliases. Some readers may find this link to be of dubious taste, but then, so is the Bagger.

headline: Another Vampire Heard From
text: A. O. Scott goes bloody bonkers for “Sweeney,” saying that it is both a horror flick and a musical and concludes both are exquisite: “It is cruel in its effects and radical in its misanthropy, expressing a breathtakingly, rigorously pessimistic view of human nature. It is also something close to a masterpiece, a work of extreme — I am tempted to say evil — genius.”

headline: New Guard Arrives at Tribune
text: On Thursday, after completing an $8.2 billion deal that turned Tribune into a privately held operation, Samuel Zell made himself chief executive, announced a new set of directors and managers, and declared that the troubled company would look to raise revenue more than cut spending.

headline: Sallie Mae Delays Stock Repurchase
text: The parent of Sallie Mae, which for years profited from placing large bets on its own stock going up, now faces a possible loss of more than $1 billion as the bet has gone drastically wrong. On Thursday it negotiated a two-month delay in the deadline for coming up with the money.

headline: ‘Zoey Can’t Say No-ey’
text: So now it seems the TV comics are saying as one: “Writers? We don’ need no steenking writers!” So show them what they’ll be missing. Send your “late night” jokes via the comment link below. Some fresh reader comedy:

headline: The Year of Puncturing Wall Street Orthodoxy
text: Never in the history of Wall Street have so many who are so senior fallen so fast.

headline: Why Europeans Are Buying Manhattan Condos
text: Taking advantage of the weak dollar, foreign tourists are keeping brokers busy with their eagerness to buy Manhattan apartments, which many see as investments, according to a front-page article by Christine Haughney, who also reports that “Manhattan brokers are waking before dawn to talk by phone with European buyers about amenities and closing costs and working late advising foreign buyers in town on the best places to shop for gadgets and clothes.”

headline: Friday’s Links: Pricey Rice Cookers, Free Rice, and a Slash Career
text: 1. While I was posting about some of the reasons people aren’t doing traditional shopping this year, Laura Vanderkam was positing on The Huffington Post that shoppers, particularly women, are captivated by high-priced domestic items like an $883 rice cooker because women’s changing roles at work and home have elevated cooking and other domestic projects from chore to a means of self-expression. It’s an interesting argument.

headline: Not a Jolly Season for 2 Top Bankers
text: James E. Cayne and John J. Mack have a lot in common. The chiefs of both Bear Stearns and Morgan Stanley have presided over announcements of steep losses this week and have forgone bonuses.

headline: The Early Word: Huckabee Scoffs at ‘Christophobia’
text: The candidates will be dashing around this weekend — mostly in Iowa and New Hampshire — in a last-minute push before the short holiday respite they’ve promised voters (and us). Their schedules have been jammed with events, voters have been waiting and waiting for the candidates to show up as their itineraries and the weather prompt delays.

headline: Merrill Said to Consider $5 Billion Infusion
text: Another day, another report of a banking deal by a sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Obama Practices Snowball Pitch
text: EXETER, N.H. — After waving to a crowd and departing a cafe here Thursday, Senator Barack Obama turned suddenly and whipped a snowball in the direction of his spokesman, Robert Gibbs, who was standing next to a snow bank about 15 feet away. “It just disintegrated,” Mr. Gibbs declared mockingly of his boss’ close-range snowball.

headline: Obama’s ‘One Thing’
text: EXETER, N.H. — For the second day in a row, the Obama campaign gathered a small group of voters on Thursday to meet with the presidential candidate in an “informal” setting — informal that is if these local residents didn’t mind the bright television lights and a couple dozen reporters listening to their every word.

headline: N.H. Forecast: Ski Poles and a New Poll

headline: The Climate Message — What Works?
text: Thursday’s post on Senator Inhofe’s latest attempt to fight big cuts in greenhouse gases generated a lot of comments from people trying new ways of describing the climate challenge that are both accurate and effective.

headline: Suicide Attack in Pakistan
text: A suicide attacker detonated a bomb inside a mosque as people celebrated a major holiday with a former interior minister.

headline: McCain Shares P.O.W. Christmas Story
text: John McCain’s holiday television spot, in which he combines one of his prisoner of war stories with overt religious imagery, is more inner reflection than outward vote-for-me pitch.

headline: F1 news round up
text: As we move into the festive season – which will be followed very quickly afterwards by all sorts of car launches and other distractions – I figured I would do another little roundup of things that appeal to me from around the web. I am doing this in order to refrain from talking politics, and so that I do not have to file this post under the politics category.

headline: Rudy’s Rope-a-Dope
text: Remember Rudy? The Atlantic’s Marc Ambinder says that “despite the downside risk, the Giuliani campaign is comfortable with Mike Huckabee’s rise.” Despite Giuliani’s falling numbers in several national polls, he remains “in a position to exit February 5 with the most delegates,” Ambinder says. “For now.”

headline: Stray Questions for: Natasha Wimmer
text: Natasha Wimmer’s translations include “The Savage Detectives,” by Roberto Bolaño, as well as books by writers including Mario Vargas Llosa and Laura Restrepo.

headline: The Problem With Chocolate
text: Most people have heard that chocolate is good for you. But now, the medical journal Lancet is bursting the chocolate bubble.

headline: Biden Ad Lends Mystical Quality to Caucus
text: It has falling snow, gentle music and a mention of “a time of possibilities,” but Joe Biden’s latest television ad is definitely not about Christmas. It’s about that other holiday coming up, the one where only one candidate will get to celebrate — Iowa caucus night.

headline: Due in January: Mars in the Corner Pocket
text: Scientists are growing more excited about the possibility of witnessing, for the first time, a celestial pool shot that would do Fast Eddie Felsen proud: An asteroid they first spotted last month may slam into Mars on Jan. 30.

headline: One Equity to Sell Quintiles Stake to Bain, TPG
text: Update: Bain and TPG announced they will acquire One Equity’s stake in Quintiles for an undisclosed amount. The deal is expected to close next month, and the company will incur no new debt from the sale.

headline: A Subway Worker’s Legacy, in Art Form
text: Writing about Marvin Franklin, the artist whose work is on view at the New York Transit Museum from this week through March, it feels natural to focus on the details of his premature and unsettling death — Mr. Franklin was a 55-year-old subway track worker who was killed by a train in March – and on the profound effect that his passing has had on the friends and family he left behind. (A subsequent review found numerous safety lapses and prompted the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to order a series of reforms.)

headline: Iowa Forecast: The Downward Slide

headline: Friday Kickoff: Do the Bruins Like Bellotti?
text: There seems to be plenty of action surrounding the U.C.L.A. coaching search. On Thursday, Norm Chow removed himself from consideration and Rick Neuheisel spoke about the violations that took place when he was the coach of Colorado. Meanwhile, the Bruins spoke with Oregon Coach Mike Bellotti, who, according to a report in the Los Angeles Daily News by Brian Dohn, is now the leading candidate for the job. Bellotti is expected to make a decision within 72 hours.

headline: Alterna-Oscars
text: The Bagger is celebrating the holidays somewhere in Minnesota, but he’ll be back in his Jersey bunker in a few days. Meanwhile, if readers have any ideas about what the Oscars should do if the strike isn’t settled, please figure it out among yourselves in comments. The Bagger needs help on this one.

headline: The Avenger
text: Perez Hilton — the maverick gossip artist whose snark-off video channel was dropped and resumed in two and a half days by the capricious dictator YouTube — retaliated by trustbusting, that is, posting video to his own site! Choquant.

headline: Pressure Mounts as FreshDirect Turmoil Rises; Union Vote Fails

text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Trade trends
text: I’m working on a Brookings Paper updating work on the effects of trade on income distribution. And I thought I’d share a fairly striking picture. This chart shows US imports of manufactured goods from advanced countries and developing countries, measured as a percentage of US GDP. We used to say that imports from low-wage developing countries couldn’t have that large an effect on wages here, because they were small compared with the economy. Well, you can’t say that anymore.

headline: Strike News: Oh, The Pickets Outside Are Frightful…
text: Writers Guild of America members are getting a holiday break from the picket lines.

headline: This Wouldn’t Happen If Donald Trump Were President
text: First “The Celebrity Apprentice” was scheduled to debut Jan. 3. Then NBC moved the reality series to Jan. 10. Now the network has moved it back to Jan. 3. The reversal came after ABC moved the last new episode of “Grey’s Anatomy” from Jan. 3 to Jan. 10, “in part to avoid interruptions from coverage of the Iowa Caucus that night,” Broadcasting & Cable reports.

headline: Update: Talk Off | Shoulder Pads
text: Earlier this week, in The Moment’s Talk Off column, Courtney Weinblatt, the magazine’s fashion assistant, battled the design market editor Andreas Kokkino over the merits of shoulder pads. Readers voted by leaving comments. The results: Courtney, who argued the negative position, won the Talk Off with approximately 53 percent of the votes. Just one vote separated the victor from her adversary — that’s not much padding — but Courtney wouldn’t have it any other way.

headline: Iowa’s Conservatives, Unbound
text: What’s happening in Iowa at this moment strikes me as very portentous for the Republican Party. In order to understand why, I think you need to take a quick tour of the history of the modern conservative movement, or at least one version of it.

headline: What Downturn? On Wall St., Bonus Pool Is Up
text: It’s been a year that many Wall Street firms would just as soon forget. In many cases, the firms’ earnings fell to decade-lows, and their shareholders, who suffered their worst losses since 2002, were justifiably disenchanted.

headline: A Republican Crows in Brooklyn
text: To hear Craig A. Eaton tell it, this is the best time to be a Republican in Brooklyn. Mr. Eaton, the newly elected chairman of the Brooklyn Republican Party, said that his goal is to breathe new life into a party operation that, even he admits, was on life support.

headline: Obama Waylaid by Weather; Iowa Events Canceled
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa – Generally, there are few political advantages to being a one-state presidential candidate. Today, however, might be an exception.

headline: Friday’s Links: About that N.F.L. Revenue …
text: The argument for the construction of publicly-funded sports facilities has always been the amount of money that sports teams generate for the local economy, but according to The South Florida Business Journal, Florida’s hunters and fishermen contribute more money to the economy yearly than the Jaguars, the Dolphins and the Buccaneers combined. The hunting and fishing crew contributes even more than the Disney theme parks.

headline: A Letter From the Italian Interior Minister
text: [ Giuliano Amato, the Minister of the Interior of Italy, wrote to The New York Times in response to a Dec. 13 article by Ian Fisher, the paper’s Rome correspondent, entitled “In a Funk, Italy Sings an Aria of Disappointment.” His letter is below. Mr. Fisher discussed the reaction to his article in Italy with The Lede. ]

headline: A Times Article Throws Italy Into a Tizzy
text: Ian Fisher, the Rome correspondent of The New York Times, wrote an article about a souring national mood in Italy that appeared on the front page of the paper last Thursday, Dec. 13, under the headline, “In a Funk, Italy Sings an Aria of Disappointment.” The article also appeared in The Times’s sister paper, The International Herald Tribune, which circulates in Italy.

headline: A Big Bet on Kayak for Travel Search
text: Mike Moritz of Sequoia Capital and some other prominent venture capitalists are making a big bet on Kayak, the travel search engine, to challenge Expedia and the other online travel agencies. Kayak has raised a huge $196 million round of financing and is buying SideStep, a rival travel search firm, for $193 million.

headline: For Clinton Campaign, Different Strategies at Play
text: In his Web column today, Patrick Healy writes about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “Likeability Tour” across Iowa and the different strategies the campaign is employing in the final days before the caucuses. Go to Column.

headline: Water Taxi to Skip East River Route for 4 Months
text: As of Jan. 1, the New York Water Taxi is suspending its ferry service on the East River route serving points in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan for four months, citing a combination of rising fuel costs and the low ridership during the winter season. While the company’s tourist service has been profitable, ferry companies have long struggled with the economics of ferry service. It will reopen in May.Fuel costs have doubled in 2007 alone, said Tom Fox, the president of New York Water Taxi. Even so, the company’s East River route broke even for the first time in 2007 during the fall, spring and summer seasons. But ridership declines by about 30 percent in the winter because of a fall in tourism, and the commuters are not profitable.

headline: What’s the Best Buyout of 2007?
text: Forget your holiday plans for a minute and think back. Way back. All the way to June.

headline: “Disparities”

headline: When Your Doctor Is on the Gift List
text: A friend of mine recently told me she was buying a gift for her therapist. I was surprised, as I’ve never given a gift to any of my doctors. But her therapist is someone she sees often, and a gift during the holidays felt appropriate, she said.

headline: Carlyle Closes Deal for Nursing Home Operator
text: The Carlyle Group closed its $4.9 billion acquisition of Manor Care, the nursing home operator, on Friday after a Michigan court lifted its temporary order against the deal.

headline: Drugs and Today’s Wall Street
text: The image of a drug-fueled Wall Street is often seen as a stereotype from the 1980s, when cocaine and heroin were common as after-hours entertainment and even sweeteners for business deals.

headline: Amid Questions, Bruno Ends Ties With Investment Company

Bruno, has severed his ties with a Connecticut investment company, a move that came just weeks after The New York Times reported that the company was managing tens of millions of dollars for union locals in and around Mr. Bruno’s district, northeast of Albany.

headline: Life Without FreshDirect
text: My stockpiles were depleted. There were no cans of tomatoes and chicken broth tucked under the metal kitchen shelves. There no bottles of seltzer and beer in the hidey hole between the sink and the fridge. Supplies of canned salmon, beans, flour, cornmeal, ketchup and squeeze containers of Fox’s U-Bet syrup were dangerously low.

headline: The Most Fabulous Views of Manhattan . . .
text: Governors Island, which lies about 800 yards south of Manhattan’s tip, is one of the best and most underused pieces of real estate in the New York City area — maybe the entire nation.

headline: And more trade charting
text: A bit more on trade — hey, I’m getting to share some preliminary research in real time! In a previous post I showed the dramatic growth in imports of manufactured goods from developing countries as a % of GDP. (No, services outsourcing isn’t included.) It won’t surprise you to learn that this is almost entirely a story about Mexico and, mainly, China. This chart only shows imports of manufactures from developing countries, as a % of GDP.

headline: Fantasy Start-Bench Week 16: Birthday Edition
text: I turned 40 yesterday. And you know what? I couldn’t care less. Forty seems to be a good age so far. My back doesn’t ache any more than usual after shoveling mounds of snow. I’m not sprouting any new gray hairs other than those already there because of Selvin Young vs. Travis Henry stress. And I’m not freaking out midlife crisis-style by ditching my wife for Jamie Lynn Spears and/or buying a Corvette.

text: This is a quick update to note that Japan has temporarily halted plans to kill up to 50 humpback whales as part of its annual harvest of hundreds of whales from several species in Antarctic waters.

text: CORALVILLE – In every speech, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee repeats a core cluster of aphorisms that summarize his politics, but there is almost always a new one that pops up, sort of like a try-out on a team.

headline: In N.H., Clinton Cites Bipartisan Work

text: Raila Odinga is the leader of Kenya's opposition party, and according to recent polls, he may win the election for president on Dec. 27.

headline: Rite Aid May Double Down on East Coast, Analyst Says
text: Shares of Rite Aid rebounded by more than 6 percent on Friday after UBS analyst Neil Currie raised his rating on the company to “buy” from “neutral.” But Mr. Currie, who predicted that Rite Aid will sell its nearly 900 stores on the West Coast and make a tidy profit in the process, hedged his bet: “[W]e feel it is time to change our rating to a buy, albeit a risky one at that,” he noted.

headline: The Baghdad Awakening
text: The "Awakening" movement, administered by the American military, has given local Iraqis, almost exclusively Sunni Arabs, a role in policing their neighborhoods.

headline: Saturday Matchup: Cowboys at Panthers
text: Dallas (12-2) is coming off a surprising loss to Philadelphia, and Carolina (6-8) is coming off a surprising victory over Seattle. The spotlight will be squarely on the quarterbacks. More specifically, the spotlight will be on Tony Romo’s thumb. His thumb injury clearly affected him against the Eagles. He completed only 13 of 36 passes and threw three interceptions. His 22.2 passer rating was the worst of his career. On Saturday (8:15 p.m., NFL Network), Romo returns to the site of his first N.F.L. start, Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, N.C., where he rallied the Cowboys with a 25-point fourth quarter last season.

headline: Edwards’s Character Witnesses
text: NEVADA, Iowa – John Edwards has been circling Iowa this week making his “closing arguments” to Iowa voters, and sure enough, his town hall events have had the feel of packed courtrooms full of undecided jurors.

headline: Three-Dot Lounge Lizards
text: Islanders Coach Ted Nolan’s oldest son, Brandon Nolan, was brought up by the Carolina Hurricanes to replace Justin Williams, who tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee during the first period of the Hurricanes’ 5-4 loss at Florida on Thursday. Williams will have surgery that will keep him out for four to six months. Before the injury, he’d played in 205 games straight back to 2004. The Canes will miss Williams, an off-the radar consistent scorer.…There’s a great long list here of all the players who have scored five goals in a game. Marian Gaborik did it for the first time Thursday. Wayne Gretzkyscored five-in-one four times, the first two times in the same year (1981).…

headline: Records Kept Secret Pending Appeal
text: A federal judge agreed to let the Bush administration keep secret the lists of visitors to the White House until an appeals court decided whether the documents were public records. The judge, Royce C. Lamberth of Federal District Court, granted the White House request five days after ordering the Secret Service to turn over the records to a liberal watchdog group that sought them under the Freedom of Information Act. The logs, being sought by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, relate to White House visits regarding nine conservative religious commentators, including James Dobson, Gary Bauer and the Rev. Jerry Falwell.

headline: Iraqi Shiite Wants to Limit Sunni Patrols
text: BAGHDAD  The leader of Iraq’s largest Shiite political party said Friday that the neighborhood patrols credited with calming many Sunni areas must submit to government authority and include a broader sectarian mix.

headline: Fliers Fed Up? Airline Employees Feel the Same
text: And you thought the passengers were mad.

headline: For Small Animals, a Fleck Is a Lot
text: When Heidi L. Hoefer, a veterinarian who specializes in treating small exotic pets like birds and rabbits, used to practice in New York, “a week didn’t go by that we didn’t have a case of lead poisoning in small birds,” she said.

headline: Thrill of Victory Doesn’t Last for Knicks

headline: Hunting Expands. So Does Camouflage. Can You See a Pattern Here?
text: Sitting in his 15-foot-high treestand in the woods of central Missouri in early November, Morgan Burch pulled off an impressive bow-hunter’s double, shooting a wild turkey and an 8-point whitetail buck in the waning light of a Saturday evening. Of course, he was clad head to toe in his camouflage choice of the day: Seclusion 3D, a pattern of limbs and leaves for deciduous forests.

headline: Footnotes
text: Lou Reed, below, will serve as the keynote speaker for the annual South by Southwest Music Conference in Austin, Tex., on March 13, Reuters reported. The composer Steve Reich and the Sonic Youth frontman Thurston Moore will also speak at the conference. ... R. Kelly avoided having his bond revoked on Friday in his child pornography case, but Cook County Judge Vincent Gaughan admonished him for missing a court hearing earlier in the week, and ordered him to cancel a Jan. 13 concert to ensure that he makes a Jan. 14 court date, The Associated Press reported. The judge also set a May 9 trial date.

headline: Everyday Items, Complex Chemistry
text: Holiday shoppers this season may still worry if the toys they buy contain lead after more than 10 million children’s products were recalled this year for that reason.

headline: More Juice, Less Punch
text: FOR those of us who love baseball, this has been a hard time. The Mitchell report named many players past and present it said used steroids and human growth hormone, and the news media had a field day focusing on the lying, the cheating and the betrayal of the game and its fans. Yet no one has asked a fundamental question: Do performance-enhancing drugs improve performance in professional baseball?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Dec. 10 about a single mother in the Bronx who had trouble finding work and received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to pay her rent misspelled her given name. She is Idelle Doulin, not Adelle.

headline: A Request for Clemency Leads to a Political Issue for Huckabee
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  It took a jury less than 15 minutes to convict Eugene Fields of driving while intoxicated, his fourth such conviction in less than five years. Mr. Fields, whose pickup crashed after he drank 12 beers, received the maximum sentence, six years in prison.

headline: Mbeki Plans to Stay in Office
text: PRETORIA, South Africa  South Africa’s president, Thabo Mbeki, said Friday that he intended to remain in office until his term ended in early 2009, despite being ousted as leader of the African National Congress earlier this week by his rival and most likely successor, Jacob G. Zuma.

headline: Groceries on the Computer, and Immigrants in the Cold
text: For New Yorkers who crave onion-rosemary marmalade with their crostini, loathe the narrow aisles of the nearest supermarket or simply have no time to shop, Fresh Direct has been like a high-tech fantasy come true. With the touch of a computer mouse, it conjures up fresh, sophisticated groceries at the customer’s doorstep.

headline: Nightmare Before Christmas
text: Christmastime is bonus time on Wall Street, and the Gucci set has been blessed with another record harvest.

headline: Holiday on Tuesday: Christmas
text: NEW YORK

headline: Do-It-Yourself Music Stardom
text: THE former Talking Head, David Byrne, interviewed Thom Yorke of Radiohead for Wired about Radiohead’s online-album experiment. Interestingly, though, a companion piece by Mr. Byrne, about how artists should navigate the troubled and chaotic music industry, is getting the most attention (wired.com).

headline: When Playing the Wrong Card Achieves the Right Result
text: As we all know, defense is the hardest part of our game. And for this column, I am assuming that the only goal is to break the contract. It is not a pair event or board-a-match teams, when stopping overtricks can be so important.

headline: Repeats Rule
text: Two reruns of “CSI” and an en core of “Without a Trace” pushed CBS into first place over all in the ratings on Thursday night. Nielsen estimated that “CSI” at 8 earned 9.1 million viewers, and another “CSI” at 9 drew 11.3 million viewers; 11.5 million watched “Without a Trace” at 10. No other show delivered a double-digit audience. Fox’s lineup of “Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?” at 8 (7.6 million) and “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” at 9 (7.2 million) ranked second for the night. NBC was third with the finale of its weeklong “Clash of the Choirs,” which averaged 8.1 million viewers from 8 to 10. ABC ranked fourth.

headline: Back Talk on Pretending to Be Busy, or Infallible
text: SOMETIMES I am tempted to take the e-mail address off the bottom of this column, especially when a subject really riles up readers and I get messages that cannot be printed in a family newspaper.

headline: Emerald City of Giving Does Exist
text: My philanthropic tour of Minneapolis began on the banks of the Mississippi River, where the Great Northern Railroad once transported flour from the giant mills of General Mills and Pillsbury. The Great Northern is long gone  merged into the Burlington Northern almost 40 years ago, and though the mills are still standing, they have long since been converted to other uses, as General Mills moved to the suburbs, and, in time, acquired its rival Pillsbury.

headline: BMW Plans Thousands of Layoffs
text: FRANKFURT  The German luxury carmaker BMW, facing rising costs and resurgent competition from rivals like Mercedes, plans to dismiss several thousand workers, its first significant layoffs in at least a decade, the company said Friday.

headline: Enshrining the Presidential Sax
text: President Bill Clinton, below, has donated the saxophone he played at his inauguration to the American Jazz Museum, The Associated Press reported. The museum is part of the historic 18th and Vine district in Kansas City, Mo., where musicians often play into the early morning at an old union hall called the Mutual Musicians Foundation. “Though he may have been unable to hang in a jam session at the Mutual Musicians Foundation, he is the only leader of the free world to be a jazz musician, and I know he would have loved the chance to sit in on a set,” the Rev. Emanuel Cleaver, a Democratic congressman of Missouri, said in announcing the donation.

headline: A License for Local Reporting
text: JOURNALISTS are instinctively libertarian, at least when it comes to journalism. We like the conversation about journalism and the federal government to begin and end with a robust defense of the First Amendment. That’s why journalists have not been leading participants in the debate over the Federal Communications Commission’s regulation of broadcasting, even though the future of our profession and its public mission is at stake.

headline: Milestone in Death Penalty Fight, but Still a Way to Go
text: Mario Marazziti’s name appeared in this column on Dec. 23, 2000, almost exactly seven years ago. An Italian journalist and spokesman for the Community of Sant’Egidio, a Roman Catholic movement of lay people known for its efforts on behalf of the poor and peacemaking, he had been bustling around holiday-happy Manhattan.

headline: Japan: It’s O.K. to Fire on Godzilla, Official Says
text: The minister of defense caused a media squall after joking about invasions by space aliens and movie monsters. Responding to a question at a news conference, the minister, Shigeru Ishiba, told reporters that he was studying whether the nation’s pacifist Constitution would limit a military response to an attack by space aliens. “There are no grounds to deny that there are unidentified flying objects and some life forms that control them,” Mr. Ishiba said, smiling at first, but then delivering a straight-faced explanation. “If Godzilla attacked, that would probably be a natural disaster relief operation,” making military action legally permissible, he said. The comments came days after Japan’s chief cabinet secretary, Nobutaka Machimura, who is the government’s top spokesman, professed belief in U.F.O.’s.

headline: For Pet Owners, Too, Toys a Reason for Concern
text: When Lane Nemeth, who founded Discovery Toys in 1978 and sold the company to Avon two decades later, decided to start a pet products company a few years ago, one of the first things she did was to look for regulations about how to manufacture pet toys safely.

headline: From Undercover to Between Covers
text: Joseph Weisberg looks about how you would expect a Brooklyn dad and schoolteacher to look, with a bald head, white-flecked beard and baggy leather jacket. So on a recent frigid night, when he ambled down a Park Slope street and surreptitiously passed off a plastic container from a gumball machine to a reporter, nobody noticed.

headline: Belgium Holds 14 in Plot to Free Qaeda Supporter
text: BRUSSELS  The Belgian authorities detained 14 people they described as Islamic extremists on Friday, saying they planned to use explosives to free a supporter of Al Qaeda in prison for plotting an attack on an air base. They said raids in 15 locations, mostly in Brussels, had turned up explosives and arms.

headline: Kentucky: Louisville Smoking Ban Is Struck Down
text: A circuit judge struck down a citywide smoking ban in Louisville, saying that an exemption for Churchill Downs was unconstitutional and that the entire ordinance, therefore, was illegal. “Only after voting that Churchill Downs would keep its exemption did the Council pass the smoke-free law,” Judge Steven Ryan wrote. “The converse of this fact is that the Council would not have passed a smoke-free law devoid of said exemption.” A group of business owners, the Metro Louisville Hospitality Coalition, sued to overturn the ban.

headline: Bush’s Chief Terrorism Adviser Is Leaving, Unscathed
text: WASHINGTON  For more than four years, Frances Fragos Townsend, President Bush’s departing chief terrorism adviser, has worked at the center of contentious antiterrorism programs, but unlike other battle-scarred West Wing colleagues, she is leaving with barely a scratch.

headline: Arrest Provides Some Solace to Slain Deliveryman’s Family
text: As a slain deliveryman from Yonkers was buried on Friday, family members and friends took solace in the quick arrest of a suspect in the killing.

headline: Rice Has Sharp Words for Taiwan, as Gates Does for China
text: WASHINGTON  Senior administration officials sharply criticized China and Taiwan on Friday, saying they were inflaming tensions with each other and with the United States.

headline: Pair of Meditations, Mystical and Rambunctious
text: Late Thursday afternoon, as a steady stream of holiday shoppers, tourists and people leaving offices bustled past St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue, inside the church almost every pew was filled to capacity for a choral program and organ concert.

headline: Hijacking Comes to Little When Robbers Can’t Get the Cargo Out
text: It began as a brazen robbery and kidnapping in Hells Kitchen on the West Side, as men with guns and a phony police badge hijacked a FedEx tractor-trailer loaded with holiday gifts.

headline: Judge Supports Arizona Law on Immigrants
text: A new Arizona law considered among the nation’s toughest against employers who hire illegal immigrants will go into effect on Jan. 1 after federal judges on Friday refused to block it.

headline: Under Pressure, Japan Delays Plan to Hunt the Humpback
text: Japan, under pressure from the United States and Australia, is delaying plans to kill 50 humpback whales as part of its already contentious annual whale harvest in waters near Antarctica.

headline: Information Con Game
text: The very title of a now 41-year-old law  the Freedom of Information Act  sounds naïve in today’s Washington, where government secrecy has become an even higher and darker art under the Bush administration.

headline: Truce Reached in Fight Over Chinese Beverage Company
text: SHANGHAI  After months of legal skirmishes and name-calling over who controls Wahaha, one of China’s biggest beverage makers, Groupe Danone of France and the Wahaha Group of China have agreed to return to “peace talks.”

headline: Jets’ Statement on Their Treatment of Concussions
text: With any injury, player safety is our foremost concern. Our approach to treating concussions is conservative and involves a team of specialists including a neurologist, neuropsychologist, and neuroradiologist. No player has been allowed to return to a game unless he is entirely without symptoms; has normal mental status testing; and has a normal neurological examination. Most recently any player who has loss of consciousness is not allowed to return to play regardless of symptoms, results of mental status testing or neurological examination. Medical staff and coaches continue to follow the player through the game and if the status of the player changes, he is removed. Players are expected and encouraged to report their symptoms, both on the day of the game and thereafter. However, in-game decisions are only one component of the process.

headline: Celebrity Architects
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spitzer Pardons Ex-Convict to Spare Him Deportation
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced the pardon on Friday of a 54-year-old Brooklyn man convicted of robbery 16 years ago, saying the pardon would spare the man from being deported to Jamaica.

headline: Cowboys at Panthers
text: 8:15 p.m., NFL Network

headline: Charming and Aloof, Huckabee Changed State
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  In more than a decade of presiding over this state, Mike Huckabee produced a legacy like few other Republican governors in the South, surprising even liberal Democrats with his willingness to upend some of Arkansas’s more parochial traditions.

headline: Awakening Councils by Region
text: At the heart of the American military’s counterinsurgency campaign  and a large part of its success  has been the expansion of the Awakening Councils, groups of Sunnis, some of them former militants themselves, who have bonded together to fight the most violent of the Sunni insurgents.

headline: The State of Iraq: An Update
text: AS 2007 comes to close, how should we understand the situation in Iraq? Are we witnessing the greatest American military comeback late in a war since Sherman’s march to the sea in 1864? Or is Iraq still a weakly governed and very violent place where sectarian reconciliation is starkly absent?

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about two Hollywood producers accused of bribing a Thai official to get contracts to run the Bangkok International Film Festival misidentified the Patricia Green who was arrested with her husband, Gerald. She is Patricia T. Green  not Patricia M. Green, a writer and producer, whose television credits include “Chicago Hope,” “China Beach” and “L.A. Law.” (Go to Article)

headline: News Mixed, but Stocks Still Manage Strong Rally
text: Stock markets surged Friday on reports of a possible foreign investment in Merrill Lynch and an uptick in consumer spending.

headline: Goldman Is Buying Stake in a Troubled Student-Loan Company
text: Goldman Sachs on Friday agreed to buy a $260.5 million stake in the First Marblehead Corporation, shoring up the troubled student-loan company and sending its stock soaring.

headline: Punitive Arizona
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vermont Rejects Sale of Verizon Lines
text: MONTPELIER, Vt. (AP)  Vermont regulators on Friday rejected a $2.7 billion plan by FairPoint Communications to buy Verizon’s landlines in northern New England.

headline: No Joke, Bulb Change Is Challenge for U.S.
text: The new energy bill signed this week makes it official. When 2012 hits, stores can no longer sell the cheap but inefficient incandescent light bulbs that are fixtures in most homes.

headline: Frank Capra Jr., Movie and TV Producer, Dies at 73
text: Frank Capra Jr., who never wanted to go into his father’s business but found in the end he could not resist its pull, died on Wednesday in Philadelphia. He was 73 and lived in Wilmington, N.C.

headline: Saudi Arabia: Officials Say They Foiled Plot Against Holy Sites
text: The police arrested a group of men planning to attack holy sites around Mecca during the hajj, the annual Muslim pilgrimage, the Interior Ministry said. “The group was arrested three days before the hajj season,” said Mansour al-Turki, a spokesman for the ministry. Nearly three million pilgrims went to Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which concluded this week with a final visit to Mecca after days of rituals in the surrounding hills. The minister gave no further details on the number or identity of those arrested, but the Saudi-owned satellite television station Al Arabiya described them as Saudis.

headline: Makeover Scrambles City Opera Schedule
text: When the New York State Theater closes next year for renovations, the homeless New York City Opera will probably put on four stripped-down productions at other locations, possibly Carnegie Hall, the Beacon Theater and other Lincoln Center halls, company officials said on Friday.

headline: What's Offline: Buy Little, Waste Less
text: A GROUP of environmentally concerned friends in San Francisco got together on Jan. 1, 2006, and decided to “flee the consumer grid,” vowing not to buy anything new for at least the next 12 months.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about an exhibition at the Seattle Art Museum, “Japan Envisions the West: 16th- to 19th-century Japanese Art From the Kobe City Museum,” at one point misspelled the name for Japanese art made in the late 16th and early 17th centuries under the influence of contact with the Spanish and Portuguese. As noted in the headline and elsewhere in the column, it is Namban, not Nambam.

headline: Triumph for an Inmate, and a Persistent Investigator
text: Hours after learning that Martin H. Tankleff’s conviction for the 1988 murders of his parents had been overturned, Jay Salpeter, a former New York City homicide detective whose work was crucial in winning a new trial for a man imprisoned half his life, was about as ecstatic as a hard-boiled private eye ever gets.

headline: A Buyout for Manager of Drug Trials
text: The private equity arm of JPMorgan Chase, One Equity Partners, agreed on Friday to sell its stake in Quintiles Transnational, a big manager of clinical drug trials, to the company’s chief executive and other buyout firms.

headline: Giuliani, on the Mend, Slows Campaign Pace
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani scaled back his weekend schedule in New Hampshire on Friday as he recovered from the illness that led him to be hospitalized overnight this week for what his aides called “flulike symptoms.”

headline: I.R.S. Bars Investment Strategy Used to Sidestep Rule on Losses
text: The Internal Revenue Service has banned a year-end investment strategy used to get around the so-called wash sale rules on harvesting tax losses.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Dec. 10 about a single mother in the Bronx who had trouble finding work and received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to pay her rent misspelled her given name. She is Idelle Doulin, not Adelle.

headline: The Price of Food Safety
text: Americans can be forgiven for wondering if anything these days is safe to eat. Recent food scares have involved such all-American staples as spinach, peanut butter and hamburger meat. A stomach-churning article in The New York Times recently made it clear that some imported seafood, the stuff that is supposed to be good for the heart, can be heavy with pesticides, veterinary antibiotics and other unhealthy extras.

headline: Russia to Lend Art
text: One day after announcing that it was canceling plans to lend paintings from its museums to a major exhibition in London, Russia reversed itself after the British government moved up the date on which legislation protecting art from seizure in lawsuits would become effective, The Associated Press reported. The exhibition, “From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925,” was scheduled to open at the Royal Academy on Jan. 26. But Moscow refused to lend major French and Russian paintings out of concern that they might be held. (Above, Kuzma Petrov Vodkin’s 1912 work “Bathing of a Red Horse.”) Among the paintings to be shown were prominent Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works, which descendants of some Russian collectors claim were taken by the new government after the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. James Purnell, head of the British Culture Department, said on Thursday that Britain would move up, to early January from late February, the effective date of a provision in legislation that bars the seizure of art lent on a government-to-government basis. Natalia Uvarova, a spokeswoman for Russia’s federal culture agency, said that her office would issue licenses for the paintings only after the law takes effect, which means that the Russian works, now in Dusseldorf, Germany, will return to Moscow instead of continuing on to London, she said. It was up to the organizers of the London exhibition, Ms. Uvarova added, to decide whether the paintings could be shipped quickly enough for the show to open as scheduled on Jan. 26.

headline: Romney Learns That ‘Facts Are Stubborn Things’
text: FORT DODGE, Iowa  There was the period last spring when Mitt Romney claimed while campaigning in Iowa and New Hampshire that he had been a hunter “pretty much all my life,” only to have to admit later he had seriously hunted on only two occasions.

headline: Accused Doctor Gets His Visa Back
text: An Indian doctor once accused of involvement with terrorist bombers in Britain was given back his Australian visa, in the latest chapter in a case that has embarrassed the police, prosecutors and the government. The high court in Melbourne rejected an appeal by Kevin Andrews, the former immigration minister, to stop the reinstatement of the visa for the doctor, Mohammed Haneef. Dr. Haneef’s lawyer, Peter Russo, said his client wanted to return to his old job as a hospital registrar. Dr. Haneef was arrested on July 2 in Brisbane, two days after a distant cousin, Kafeel Ahmed, had crashed a burning Jeep Cherokee into the main terminal at Glasgow’s international airport. Prosecutors said Mr. Ahmed, who later died of burns, had also helped plant two car bombs in central London. On July 27, the charge against Dr. Haneef was dropped, and Australia’s chief prosecutor admitted that prosecutors had made erroneous statements in court.

headline: Alan Wagner, 76, First President of the Disney Channel, Is Dead
