text: Alan Wagner, a former CBS programming executive who became the first president of the Disney Channel, died on Tuesday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 76.

headline: Fernandez and Rose Jr. Are Linked to Radomski
text: A chubby left-handed pitcher with an awkward delivery and the son of a banned baseball legend became the last two players of note linked to Kirk Radomski, a former Mets clubhouse attendant who provided dozens of major league players with performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: The High Cost of Education
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rookie Helps Isles Hold Off Penguins
text: PITTSBURGH (AP)  Blake Comeau scored his first career goal to give the Islanders the lead midway through the third period Friday night, Trent Hunter added a goal 37 seconds later and the Islanders shook off a recent slump to beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 4-2.

headline: In Trade Ruling, Antigua Wins a Right to Piracy
text: PARIS  In an unusual ruling on Friday at the World Trade Organization, the Caribbean nation of Antigua won the right to violate copyright protections on goods like films and music from the United States  an award worth up to $21 million  as part of a dispute between the countries over online gambling.

headline: Pennington and Coles Share a Bond That Extends Beyond the Field
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  The quarterback grew up in Knoxville, Tenn., the son of a high school football coach. He speaks carefully and evenly. A mop of sandy brown hair flows from underneath his baseball cap.

headline: Weakening Pakistan
text: Pakistan’s president, Pervez Musharraf, insists his outrageous power grabs are aimed at stabilizing and protecting his country. His authoritarian maneuvers only weaken the country’s already feeble political institutions and fuel more political turmoil.

headline: Peters Is Making a Name for Himself
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  At 6 feet 4 inches and 340 pounds, Jason Peters would seem to be a hard guy not to notice, particularly for N.F.L. coaches. After all, he ran the 40-yard dash in 4.94 seconds, blazing fast for a man his size.

headline: In Racially Charged Manslaughter Trial, Jury Sends Messages of Discord
text: The Long Island jury hearing the manslaughter trial of a black man charged with shooting a white teenager last year sent the judge several notes on Friday, saying it was “hopelessly deadlocked” and asking to hear the jurors’ oath again because “some jurors aren’t interpreting the law as stated in our directions.”

headline: Bonds Will Keep Lawyers, Despite Potential Conflicts
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A soft-spoken Barry Bonds told a federal judge Friday that he wanted to keep his legal team intact despite a potential conflict of interest.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Israel: Army Denies Role in Hamas Death
text: A 17-year-old Hamas fighter was shot to death in Gaza near the border with Israel, but the Israeli Army denied that it had anything to do with it. Hamas said the fighter, identified as Awad al-Foujom, died in a gun battle with Israeli forces. Nearly 20 Palestinian fighters have been killed this week, most of them from Islamic Jihad. Near Nablus, in the occupied West Bank, a Palestinian was stopped at the Hawara checkpoint trying to smuggle a mortar shell; the previous day, another Palestinian tried to stab an Israeli soldier there, the army said.

headline: From an Asylum, Dark Tidings of Hope
text: The Italian avant-gardist Dario D’Ambrosi has been establishing a new downtown theater holiday tradition: Christmas in the madhouse.

headline: A Life of Helping Becomes One in Need of Help
text: This was life, until Susan Barron crossed Second Avenue on a Saturday morning two and a half months ago: an apartment on the East Side of Manhattan, where she has lived for decades. A fat Scottish terrier that she doted on. A psychology practice treating people with physical disabilities, offering “scholarships” to patients who could not pay full fees.

headline: Jailed 17 Years, Long Island Man Gets Second Trial
text: A state appeals court on Friday overturned the conviction of a Long Island man imprisoned 17 years for the grisly murders of his parents in 1988. The decision cited the “cumulative effect” of new witnesses and extensive new evidence that have emerged in recent years, pointing to other suspects as the real killers.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Dec. 5 about the distinctions between Iran’s civilian and military nuclear programs referred incorrectly to an assessment in the new United States national intelligence estimate that Tehran’s nuclear program is now entirely civilian in nature. The document says that American intelligence agencies have moderate  not high  confidence in that judgment.

headline: China Less Willing to Be America’s Piggy Bank
text: For the last three years, China has been the financier that kept the American government well funded. In 2004, it bought a fifth of the Treasury securities issued, a proportion that rose to 30 percent in 2005 and to 36 percent in 2006.

headline: As Cars Hit More Animals on Roads, Toll Rises
text: BOZEMAN, Mont.  On a dark highway near Anchorage, Specialist Steven Cavanaugh of the Army, who had survived 300 missions in Iraq, was critically injured in December when his vehicle hit a moose. Specialist Cavanaugh died Dec. 6.

headline: Sex Education Works
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clinton Sums It Up for Viewers in 2 States
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, began running the following new 30-second advertisement in New Hampshire on Thursday and in Iowa on Friday.

headline: Bail Is Set at $1 Million for Husband in Slaying
text: WHITE PLAINS  Shortly after a county court judge set bail at $1 million for a disbarred Chappaqua lawyer charged with murdering his wife, the Westchester County district attorney asserted on Friday that the defendant, Carlos Perez-Olivo, pulled their car over on a darkened road 13 months ago and “shot his wife once in the back of the head.”

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $3,664,828

headline: Scholars and the Military Share a Foxhole, Uneasily
text: The United States military is frequently criticized for not doing enough to reduce civilian casualties or to stabilize the places it is fighting to protect. Yet what happens when the outside experts who can offer such advice are condemned for doing exactly that?

headline: Illinois: Governor’s Chief Fund-Raiser Pleads Not Guilty
text: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich’s chief campaign fund-raiser pleaded not guilty to tax charges and must get treatment for his gambling problem to remain free on bond. The fund-raiser, Christopher Kelly, a roofing contractor, is accused of using his company’s money to pay gambling debts to Las Vegas casinos and Chicago-area bookmakers and of misinforming the Internal Revenue Service about that and other reported misspending, according to the indictment. Mr. Kelly is a friend of Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat, and was once his point man on Illinois gambling issues, but he was not on the governor’s staff.

headline: China and Taiwan Draw Fire From Washington
text: WASHINGTON  Senior Bush administration officials on Friday sharply criticized both China and Taiwan for unnecessarily inflaming tensions between each other and with the United States.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Takes Its Makeup Magic to the Met, With Scary Results
text: Louis Zakarian is a makeup artist and Philip Langridge is an opera singer who have pretty much the same equipment where they have been doing their work: monster-size ovens and professional-grade KitchenAid mixers.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the acquittal of a suspect in a bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, in 1998, misstated the position of the Irish Republican Army about a peace agreement that year. It did not oppose the agreement. It was the Real I.R.A., a dissident group suspected in the bombing, that opposed it.

headline: Bomber Kills 48 in Mosque in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide attacker detonated a powerful bomb inside a crowded mosque in northwestern Pakistan on Friday, killing 48 people and wounding 100 as they celebrated one of Islam’s major holidays with the country’s former interior minister, state-run media reported.

headline: Borat R.I.P.
text: Sacha Baron Cohen is retiring Borat Sagdiyev, the clueless Kazakh journalist, as well as another of his alter egos, the aspiring rapper Ali G, The Daily Telegraph reported. Mr. Baron Cohen, who is currently playing a singing barber in Tim Burton’s “Sweeney Todd,” starred last year in the movie “Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan.” He first introduced the character on “Da Ali G Show,” a television show that was carried on HBO in the United States.

headline: Georgia: Slain Marine’s Dog Adopted by His Family
text: A military dog wounded in Iraq in the same rocket attack that killed its marine handler was adopted by the slain marine’s family. The family of the marine, Cpl. Dustin Lee, planned to take home the bomb-sniffing dog, an 8-year-old German shepherd named Lex who was granted early retirement. “Nobody can do anything to replace the void in this family,” said Col. Christian Haliday, commander of the Marine Corps Logistics Base in Albany, where Corporal Lee and Lex were assigned. “We hope Lex can bring a small piece of his spirit and help maintain his memory.” Corporal Lee, 20, was killed and Lex was wounded on March 21 in Anbar Province. Corporal Lee’s mother, Rachael, said she believed that her son’s spirit would live on through the dog because of their close bond and because they were together during the final moments of her son’s life. “It was blood on blood,” she said. ”We can’t get Dustin back, but we have Lex.”

headline: Bruno Quits Job at Financial Firm Where Unions Were Investors
text: ALBANY  Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, has resigned from his job at a financial firm three weeks after it was revealed that the firm manages tens of millions of dollars for labor unions in and around his district.

headline: The Recalls’ Aftershocks
text: Wondering what happened to all the lead-tainted products that have been recalled recently?

headline: Compact for SUNY System
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Facts Are Stubborn,’ Romney Once Said, and He Should Know
text: FORT DODGE, Iowa  There was the period last spring when Mitt Romney claimed while campaigning in Iowa and New Hampshire that he had been a hunter “pretty much all my life,” only to have to admit later that he had seriously hunted only on two occasions.

headline: Officer Pleads Not Guilty in Killing of His Fiancée, Also an Officer
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Officer Alexis Chaparro of the New York Police Department was arraigned Friday on a second-degree murder charge in the shooting death of his fiancée, Officer Sonia Garcia.

headline: Anti-Musharraf Lawyer Is Suddenly Freed, Then Abruptly Arrested Again
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  For 24 hours on Friday, the leader of Pakistan’s lawyers movement was a free man.

headline: Budget Cuts Will Mean Layoffs at Fermilab
text: The Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, the nation’s premier center for plumbing the mysteries of the universe in the tiniest bits of matter, is planning to lay off more than 10 percent of its employees in the coming months, the result of impending budget cuts mandated by the spending bill passed by Congress this week.

headline: Iran Wins in Court
text: Iran won a court ruling on Friday in its bid to force an art dealer in London to return 18 ancient artifacts it charges were stolen from the country’s tombs, The Associated Press reported. The Court of Appeal, overruling a lower court, reinstated Iran’s suit to reclaim the artifacts. Iran says the jars, bowls and cups, which date from 3000 B.C., come from sites in the Halil Rud valley, where many tombs were emptied illegally from 2000 to 2004. The dealer, Fayez Barakat, owner of the Barakat Gallery, said he had bought the works in Europe for about $500,000. In March the Iranian government asked London’s High Court to order the return of the items, arguing that the gallery had no title to them, since there was no way that their unknown finder could have had lawful title. Previously, a High Court justice had dismissed the case, saying Iran had not proved its ownership of the artifacts and that Iranian law was unenforceable in the English courts.

headline: Ike Turner Is Eulogized as Misunderstood
text: GARDENA, Calif.  Even in death, Ike Turner commanded center stage.

headline: 9/11 Panel Study Finds That C.I.A. Withheld Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  A review of classified documents by former members of the Sept. 11 commission shows that the panel made repeated and detailed requests to the Central Intelligence Agency in 2003 and 2004 for documents and other information about the interrogation of operatives of Al Qaeda, and were told by a top C.I.A. official that the agency had “produced or made available for review” everything that had been requested.

headline: A Tortured Voice of a Lost Russian Generation
text: MOSCOW

headline: Big Fund to Prop Up Securities Is Scrapped
text: Some of the country’s biggest banks have pulled the plug on a plan backed by the Treasury Department to rescue troubled investment vehicles that were leveled by the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Pakistan’s Detainees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review on Thursday about Crescent Boogaloo, at the Jazz Standard, misidentified the composer of “Simone,” a song that was performed. He is Frank Foster  not Dr. Lonnie Smith, the organist in Crescent Boogaloo.

headline: At Heinz, Hoping to Leave a Legacy of Product Safety
text: FOR wary consumers, 2007 may well be remembered as the year of the recall. Toys may have grabbed the spotlight, but pet food and food for humans ran a close second. One company  the Topps Meat Company in Elizabeth, N.J.  recalled more than 21 million pounds of frozen hamburger because of potential E. coli contamination. The company closed on Oct. 5 and declared bankruptcy late last month.

headline: Insight From the Inside on Hip-Hop
text: Full Circle’s “Innaviews,” performed on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop, is more of a Valentine’s Day show than a Christmastime event. On one level the piece celebrates the loving, enduring relationship of Gabriel Dionisio and Anita Garcia, the husband-and-wife team who founded the hip-hop dance collective Full Circle in 1996 and still direct it. Known professionally as Rokafella (Ms. Garcia) and Kwikstep (Mr. Dionisio), the two are breakdance stars in their own right. They are also funny and very, very smart.

headline: Apartment Is Robbed at Gunpoint
text: Two men posing as deliverymen entered a building on the Upper West Side on Friday and robbed the occupants of an apartment at gunpoint, the police said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report from The Associated Press in the men’s college basketball roundup in some editions on Friday about Long Island University’s 67-62 victory against St. Peter’s misstated the teams’ records and the length of Long Island’s winning streak. Long Island is 8-3, not 9-3, and has won four games in a row, not five. St. Peter’s is 3-6, not 3-7.

headline: Dream Turns Nightmare: Milwaukee Police Officer to Be Deported
text: MILWAUKEE  Growing up here, Oscar Ayala-Cornejo recalls, he played chess and devoured comics, hung out at the mall and joined the Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps. After high school, he realized a childhood dream, joining the Milwaukee Police Department.

headline: United Rentals Loses Bid to Make Suitor Complete Buyout
text: In a victory for Cerberus Capital Management, a Delaware judge on Friday ruled against the United Rentals petition to force the private equity firm to complete its $4 billion buyout.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about the political disillusionment of Rabah Bechla, one of two suicide bombers who struck Algiers on Dec. 11, misstated the reason elections were held in 1991 when Mr. Bechla voted for the Islamist Salvation Front, which would have won if the army had not intervened to cancel the result. The elections were for parliament, not for the presidency.

headline: Rove Reaps His Reward
text: Karl Rove, President Bush’s former deputy White House chief of staff and chief political strategist, has sold his memoirs to Threshold Editions, the conservative imprint of Simon & Schuster that has had a No. 1 New York Times best seller with “An Inconvenient Book,” by the conservative radio and television talk show host Glenn Beck. Mr. Rove chose Threshold, whose editor-in-chief, Mary Matalin, is a longtime friend, after an auction that started with nine bidders and ended with two Simon & Schuster imprints: Threshold and Free Press. The lawyers Robert Barnett and Michael O’Connor negotiated the seven-figure deal on behalf of Mr. Rove. In a statement Mr. Rove said he would write about his role in President Bush’s “consequential and contentious” administration. “The book will be a candid, careful look at how he got there and what his administration did once in office,” he said. In a telephone interview Ms. Matalin said that she believed that Mr. Rove, given his insider knowledge and his interests, would produce a unique memoir. “He’s a policy wonk, he’s a history buff, he’s a reader, he’s an accessible intellectual,” she said. “So you bring those things together, and I’ve read every political book out there, and there’s nothing close to what he’s going to be able to put together.”

headline: No Immediate Ruling on Judicial Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge said Friday that he would not rule immediately on whether to hold a judicial inquiry into the destruction of C.I.A. videotapes that showed the harsh interrogation of two suspected operatives of Al Qaeda.

headline: Officer Hinders State Inquiry Into Waterfront Commission
text: An investigation by the New York State Office of the Inspector General into potential corruption at a bistate waterfront crime-fighting agency has hit a snag because one of the subpoenaed officers has refused to testify.

headline: Cuban Refinery Inaugurated, With Chávez in Spotlight
text: CIENFUEGOS, Cuba  The speculation was that he would be here, that Fidel Castro was ready to leave his hospital bed after 17 months of convalescence and that he would come to inaugurate a revamped Soviet-era oil refinery that he had been saying for years was a key to Cuba’s energy future.

headline: 10 Survive Plane Crash
text: A DC-3 aircraft chartered by the National Science Foundation crashed while taking off from a remote research site in West Antarctica. Although the plane was heavily damaged, none of the 10 people on board were injured, the agency said. The crash occurred near Mount Patterson, where researchers are deploying G.P.S. units and other sensors to obtain data on changes in Antarctic ice sheets. A foundation spokesman said the six passengers and four crew members were flown out on another aircraft. The site is about 550 miles from the main American research and logistical hub at McMurdo.

headline: Learning to Overcome What Life Throws at Them
text: “This one,” Jermaine McKenzie said, pointing to a cauliflower-shaped scar on his right cheek, “I fell when I was 2.”

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about two Hollywood producers accused of bribing a Thai official to get contracts to run the Bangkok International Film Festival misidentified the Patricia Green who was arrested with her husband, Gerald. She is Patricia T. Green  not Patricia M. Green, a writer and producer, whose television credits include “Chicago Hope,” “China Beach” and “L.A. Law.”

headline: Mars Shot Is Put Off for 2 Years, NASA Says
text: WASHINGTON  NASA has delayed the launching of a mission to Mars by two years, to 2013, because of an undisclosed conflict of interest involved in one of two final proposals, officials said Friday.

headline: Britain: Police Suspend a DNA Testing Method
text: The Association of Chief Police Officers of England, Wales and Northern Ireland said it was suspending the use of a form of DNA testing criticized by a judge who acquitted the only person charged with murder in Northern Ireland’s deadliest terrorist attack. Detectives used the technique to link Sean Hoey to the attack, a 1998 bombing that killed 29 people in the town of Omagh. But a judge acquitted Hoey this week, saying he was not satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt of the evidence’s integrity. The technique, known as low copy DNA profiling, can capture the genetic profile of a suspect from samples so small they can be invisible to the naked eye  sometimes drawing DNA from a tiny number of human cells, according to Britain’s Forensic Science Service.

headline: Arabella Spencer-Churchill Dies at 58; Rebel Broke Family Mold
text: LONDON  Arabella Spencer-Churchill, a granddaughter of Britain’s wartime prime minister whose unconventional enthusiasms included a role as co-founder of the Glastonbury rock festival, died Friday at her home there, in England’s rolling West Country. She was 58.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Russia to Lend Art

headline: In Helicopter or Hummer, Kenya Contender Dazzles
text: SUSWA, Kenya  At the sound of the copter blades, a thousand Masai tribesmen crane their necks upward.

headline: A Brisk Business in Selling Hope by the Wick
text: Hispanics have long lighted them for loved ones and for luck. But devotional candles are increasingly kindled by anyone with a wish or a prayer, and as a result, they are now a lucrative and growing niche in the $2 billion candle market in the United States.

headline: It’s Time Manning Plays His Hand
text: Giants fans cannot hate Eli Manning.

headline: Changing the Face of Hockey
text: As a teenager in Chicago, Gerald Coleman decided he wanted to play hockey for a living. He let nothing stand in his way.

headline: House Tour Sheds Light on Life in Old Rome
text: ROME  Buried for many centuries, two patrician villas unearthed here recently have been brought to life through an on-site multimedia reconstruction that plunges the spectator into the heart of ancient Roman life.

headline: For Jets, Silence on Concussions Signals Unease
text: Laveranues Coles is equal parts receiver and raconteur, the New York Jets player who talks when no one else will. But upon hearing one subject  concussions, specifically the two he has sustained in the past year  he immediately lost his smile, and looked around the locker room to see who might be listening.

headline: Buy This Sweater, Save a Seal
text: This is the time of year in which wants and needs come into collision, when we’re encouraged to go ahead and indulge ourselves and others. But those powerful psychic forces compete with the other urge of the holiday season  to give to charities, whether out of guilt or benevolence. Thank goodness, then, that there’s a way to do both. It’s called embedded giving, and it means that you never have to choose between that expensive watch and making a worthy donation.

headline: One Killed and Two Injured in Bronx Shooting
text: A man fatally shot a woman he had been dating in the Bronx early Friday morning, then shot her new companion, critically injuring him, and another man, the police said.

headline: Boys’ Kidnapper Gets 170 Years More
text: ST. LOUIS  A man who is already serving 74 life sentences in state prison for kidnapping two boys and holding one of them for four years was sentenced Friday to 170 years in federal prison.

headline: Now on Sale: The Discards of Investors
text: ONE less festive sign of the holiday season is the magnification of losses in some of the worst-performing stocks. Shareholders often sell these poor performers before the year is out to reduce the tax they owe on gains made on sales of investments that turned out better.

headline: 1 vs. 2
text: We don’t really get this in North America, where our pro leagues are chopped up into different little divisions and have elaborately unbalanced schedules. But euro hockey fans and soccer fans everywhere know about those special nights when No. 1 in the league plays No. 2.

headline: No More Dates In Datelines
text: The New York Times took another step – a small and unannounced one – into the Internet age last week by eliminating dates from datelines.

headline: Getting the Vote Out in Kirkuk
text: Some Kurds say they were pushed to move back to Kirkuk to ensure a high turnout for a referendum whose deadline is about to pass.

headline: Dubai Rx : Conduit for Fake Drugs
text: Massive free trade zones like those in Dubai are being used by counterfeiters to smuggle fake drugs from China to Europe and the United States.

headline: Kenya's Presidential Elections
text: Raila Odinga is the leader of Kenya's opposition party, and according to recent polls, he may win the election for president on Dec. 27.

headline: Opening the German-Polish Border
text: Security and control at the once-contentious border between Germany and Poland ease further, but divisions remain.

headline: Iowa Forecast: Apple’s Eye
text: Countdown: Twelve days until Caucus Day. Three shopping days until Christmas. Happy birthday, Paul D. Wolfowitz.

headline: ‘CSI,’ ‘Without A Trace’ Win Thursday
text: Two reruns of “CSI” and an encore of “Without a Trace” pushed CBS into first place over all in the ratings on Thursday night.

headline: The Early Word: Momentum
text: As Libby Copeland of The Washington Post muses on that “Silly Putty for political consultants”: momentum, The Times’s Long Run series focuses today on the man who seems to be profiting most from his right now, whatever it is. Adam Nossiter and David Barstow on Mike Huckabee as governor of Arkansas:

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Artists Only
text: About a year ago, a college senior and Facebook veteran taught me how to share intimate information on social networks. His first rule was ironclad: “You gotta be transparent about your love life.”

headline: Happy Holidays | Video Greetings From Andy Spade
text: In celebration of the season, T commissioned several artists to create short films on the theme of “giving.” The final video to arrive is “How Much to Go to the trees?” Story by Andy Spade, the founder of the Jack Spade men’s line; directed by Red Bucket Films.

headline: Borgetti to M.L.S.? Ah, Not So Fast
text: The on-again, off-again pursuit of the Mexican striker Jared Borgetti by Major League Soccer was apparently on again … until it was off again.

headline: N.H. Forecast: A Day for Hot Chocolate
text: Countdown: 17 days until the primary.

headline: Final Poli-Book Best Seller List for 2007
text: Our final best seller list for political books this year may provide some last-minute gift ideas for those of you with shopping still left to do.

headline: Hoover’s Letter to Truman’s Special Consultant
text: From the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (Hoover) to the President's Special Consultant (Sidney Souers, former Director of Central Intelligence)

headline: Obama Faults Edwards on Independent Ads
text: OSKALOOSA, Iowa – Senator Barack Obama called on his rival, John Edwards, to distance himself from outside groups that are gearing up to run television ads to promote his candidacy, saying here today: “You can’t just talk the talk.”

headline: Would It Kill You to Raise Fuel Standards?
text: The year was about to end without a front-running entry on my list of Most Idiotic Press Releases of the Year. But suddenly a clear winner emerged, a Dec. 14 howler from the Competitive Enterprise Institute. It is entitled, “Senate’s New Auto Fuel Standards Will Cost Lives.”

headline: The Anbar Awakening
text: The Sunni Awakening has helped calm one of the most violent provinces of Iraq. But it faces an uncertain future.

headline: Talking Heads Not Talking Climate
text: The League of Conservation Voters generated quite a bit of buzz on environmental (and journalism) blogs this week after it launched a new campaign pressing America’s most-watched political reporters to bring up global warming more often on all those influential Sunday talk shows. The group reviewed videotape of more than 120 interviews of presidential contenders by Chris Wallace, Tim Russert, George Stephanopoulos, Wolf Blitzer and Bob Schieffer this year.

headline: Answers from Yu Jie
text: Today we have answers to reader questions from Yu Jie, following the ninth article in the series on the the transfer of heavy industry to China from the West. Yu Jie is China Program Advisor for the Heinrich Böll Foundation in Beijing.

headline: Visions of health care
text: I have to get into the habit of reading the new CBO director’s blog — really important stuff. Anyway, Peter Orszag alerts us to a new study on the VA system, which confirms the system’s amazing performance — high and rising quality (I’m sure someone will chime in with a horror story, but you can find those in any system), delivered relatively cheaply.

headline: Letters: The Readers Speak
text: Re “A Semi-Nude Minor? In The Times?” (Dec. 16): While I can appreciate the fact that T magazine might not have been the most appropriate venue for this photo editorial, it is interesting to see how it has been perceived by so many people.It is also fascinating that people think that they have the right to judge so severely and with such vengeance.Perhaps these are the same people who would not enter an art museum unless the statues were covered in drapes. In Europe, the pictures in question would never elicit the least bit of controversy.There is nothing “minor” about Ali. She is an old soul who is an extremely intelligent, focused, disciplined, responsible young lady. She is as beautiful on the inside as she is on the outside. While she is a few months shy of her 18th birthday, she is more mature than most adults twice her age.She has had the good fortune to work with some of the world’s best-known photographers over the past two years, including Paolo Roversi. He is an icon in the fashion industry. While I am with Ali every step of the way, it is not up to me to choose which photographs are to be published. I do not have control over that decision-making process. That said, there is nothing remotely sexual or pornographic about the pictures in the T. In my eyes, they portray a sense of innocence and beauty.To those who have responded to your column by criticizing my daughter and me so vehemently: Please understand that I have my viewpoint, and you have yours. It is unacceptable for you to demand that we think exactly alike, and it is unconscionable that you feel the need to judge or attack while expressing your views. After all, we come from totally different backgrounds and perspectives and are each entitled to our opinions.Art and beauty are in the eye of the beholder. If you don’t like what you see, keep in mind that no one is forcing you to look. MaryAnn MichaelColleyville, Tex., Dec. 19, 2007 ● On the one hand, you’re right. I don’t read T. On the other hand, now that you bring it up, those photos of that 17-year-old model are not fit for a newspaper with general circulation.Exposing as much as possible of a minor’s body for commercial gain (but without getting arrested) is immoral, no matter how artful the photography.The Times can find some other way to sell its paper than exploiting even a willing minor whose parents care more about her career than about the character of our culture.J. Christy WarehamNewark, N.Y., Dec. 16, 2007 “ ● Jim Schachter, a deputy editor of The New York Times Magazine, justifies his decision to expose a youngster’s breast in a fashion spread by blurring the line separating commercial images from “art.”He acknowledges that “sexually charged” images sell products, so does he really suffer under the same illusion as the mother of the 17-year-old model, who found the layout to be “very artistic in nature”? Have we become so cynical that the currency of a young body can be peddled as “art” even in the most commercial of contexts?Rebecca ReichmannRancho Santa Fe, Calif., Dec. 17, 2007 ● I guess I am glad I never buy the Sunday Times. It’s not so much that I disapprove of the T magazine section (I’ve never seen it, I think), but that I would resent paying for it and disposing of it greenly.I do buy and read the daily Times every day, and subscribe to the Book Review. Much of the reason I don’t buy the Sunday Times is that there is so much in it I really have no interest in.Emily Ann SchmalzerBrentwood, N.H., Dec. 17, 2007 ● Ordinarily I automatically dump T in the T-rash without even opening it, along with other glossy ads for things I’ll never need or want. But your column prodded me to have a look online at the 17-year-old model posing semi-nude.What a disappointment! She’s no Lolita, just an underweight kid posing in a grown-up’s overpriced duds. And that barely perceptible bare breast was so badly out of focus that it registered zero on both the photographic and sexuality meters.The only astonishing thing about the photos was the revelation that a $3,890 Galliano taffeta coat could be worn, as the caption states, as a skirt.No, these photos didn’t register as pornographic nor tawdry — nor even edgy. Aaron EpsteinWashington, Dec. 16, 2007 ● Can fashion photographs be “art”? The word was used by many cited in your column.I have just viewed the photos of Ali Michael. I find an unmistakable reference to Degas’ sculpture of the 14-year-old dancer in the focused photo with a taffeta coat: the tied hair, the arms straight behind the back, the use of material in an original way, not to mention the insecurity of youth bravely confronting the hostilities of the world, including that of sexual exploitation.The great difference for these two models is, of course, exposure. Degas’ model posed in private; the resulting sculpture became the vehicle of expression.Ms. Michael is viewed by millions and is herself, to a far greater extent, the vehicle of expression. Her body has, in a sense, been designed to meet certain criteria of the modeling circuit, achieving that white, emaciated, vulnerable look.My concern for Ms. Michael is that the look of breakable china may go deeper than art or artifice.John DannAmherst, Mass., Dec. 17, 2007The writer is a painter and sculptor. ● Gee whiz, the Gray Lady is getting frisky. The soul-searching regarding this issue stands in stark (sorry) contrast to the Mapplethorpe uproar several years ago.At that time, Cincinnati decided that his work would shock and offend the good citizens of Cincinnati. The Times scolded the Queen City for its provincial prudery, in articles and editorials. It’s art, not porn, it proclaimed.Maybe yes, maybe no — either way, has The Times yet published even one of the “offending” photos? I haven’t seen one.Yes, of course, there are certain standards and unwritten laws (mostly involving advertising revenue) that must be considered — or are there?Give us a break. The Times is way ahead of the field in bowdlerizing words and images, while preaching open-mindedness to the benighted citizenry. Lionel LibsonCamden, Me., Dec. 16, 2007 ● The bright line T magazine needs to find is not is not one that “separates sexually charged images of men and women just short of 18 from art,” as Jim Schachter, a deputy editor of the Magazine says, it is the bright line that separates pornography from child pornography. If the model is, or looks, under-age, The Times should do itself and the world a favor. Hire a grown-up. Then readers can decide for themselves whether it is too nasty to have in the house, and editors can decide whether it is too nasty to have in The New York Times.Kathleen A. PoolPortland, Ore., Dec. 16, 2007 ● The photographs are neither sexy nor tawdry. The model is indeed showing a lot of skin, but she is much too skinny.Yale RichmondWashington, Dec. 17, 2007 ● You are a brave man. In today’s culture, you could be accused of censorship, prudery, proselytizing … a whole host of rocks could be thrown your way. And probably will be. I hope you can duck.The quest for material gain should never intrude on values. Keep explaining this to Jim Schachter, Bill Keller and all those at The Times who don’t seem to understand this.Bill FabrizioEast Atlantic Beach, N.Y., Dec. 17, 2007 ● Your column was much ado about nothing. After refreshing my memory with the pictures, I found the offending photo to be so indistinct as to be inoffensive and meaningless.The real issue was the exploitation of a minor in a semi-nude picture. This is the issue that you should have focused upon, not the poor-quality picture.Michael HermanNew York, Dec. 16, 2007 ● The Times risks losing its reputation by daring to see how far it can go in prurient appeal. If T magazine leads the way, can we expect its standards will show up in news sections? (News could serve up photos of the yearly naked run of students at Tufts, pictures of a bare breast at the Super Bowl halftime show.)If there are going to be double standards for sections of the paper, perhaps subscribers should be allowed to opt out of receiving T.S. E. SoderlindShort Hills, N.J., Dec. 16, 2007 ● I fear your column only stokes the fires of censorship by suggesting that art photography in The Times should be held to a different standard for good taste than that appearing in a specialist publication like V simply because The Times is sold to those who don’t seek or expect to find such images in their daily newspaper.This notion perpetuates America’s puritanical neurosis about the portrayal of the human form in any medium.While I found T’s photos (and most fashion or lifestyle photography today) to be silly, incomprehensible and pointless, I have no objection to it being offered up to those readers and advertisers willing to pay the big bucks to keep The Times and the industry for luxury products afloat.It would be far more objectionable for The Times to censor creative people who are exploring the edge of good taste to avoid offending a moralistic minority. Those people have nothing better to do than tell everyone else how to live their lives, and they won’t be satisfied no matter what you do.Whether the subject is fashion photography or news reportage, most thinking people can decide for themselves what content they want to see in their daily reading. P. Douglas FolkPhoenix, Dec. 16, 2007 ● The Holiday 2007 T magazine was very disturbing to me. After glancing through it and seeing the article with the young teenager, I was disconcerted by what I considered a step beyond art, pushing the images to a questionable level of good taste.Frankly, the entire issue left a stressed-out, overly commercial, lacking-in-substance impression. If I wished to read this type of magazine, I would buy it. Unfortunately, the past and present issue of T land in my waste basket often with but a glance.It is very revealing when the top editors have become inured to what that “edge” means to those of us who are not Seventh Avenue-hardened. The cult of the skinny anorexic models has gone too far. If you’ve ever known a young person who suffers this life-threatening state, it is neither attractive nor appealing.Ruth Mary PollackGuilford, Conn., Dec. 16, 2007 ● While neither tawdry or pornographic, as you say, the pictures you refer to probably startled quite a few readers, coming as they did in their Sunday morning paper.I do question the contention that content in T pushes limits that the regular paper does not. I recall seeing a photograph accompanying a review of the play “Lulu” in the Nov. 29 Arts pages. The picture was a highly sexualized young lady (probably not a teen, though, and I recognize that this likely changes the conversation), sitting with her legs spread around a seated man whose pants are around his ankles.I don’t point this out to criticize any of the pictures I’ve seen in The Times. I am far more inclined to take umbrage at a smug-looking Dick Cheney on Page 1 than any mildly erotic image within separate sections of the paper. I only wish to demonstrate that this sort of eroticism may be more prevalent in your paper than you might think. Ralph W. SiddallDes Moines, Dec. 16, 2007 ● My children are children no longer. I am more liberal than most, with a particularly strong perspective on censorship, but it is neither the parent nor the political animal in me that is concerned to see these pictures in a Times publication.No matter how seriously editors make decisions when skating the edge of child pornography, they are already over the edge in my book.The Times’s willingness to exploit this edge pushes me toward The Wall Street Journal. It’s easier to sort out that publication’s bias than to trust a company that would skim this edge. By sexualizing childhood for the sake of sales, The Times positions itself among a new batch of competitors.Longtime readers want The Times to move with the times, but this move reads as a sign that the Times may be morphing into something unrecognizable to this reader.Pamela MilesNew York, Dec. 16, 2007 ● I looked at the pictures on the Web site. Although, as Ali Michael’s mother said, she may be “very modest,” her garb and poses cross my line of what we used to call decency.My mother always demanded of me and my siblings that we do nothing in public that we would not do at home. That’s my line, and in my opinion, Ms. Michael crossed it.The Times should not have printed the pictures, regardless of the age of the model.Bill AbbottSaratoga, Calif., Dec. 17, 2007 ● That glossy magazine The Times throws at us 15 times a year is not part of the “culture.” That’s just an excuse to make more money for The Times.What happened to the wonderful magazine The Times used to give us at holiday time, showing New Yorkers and visitors the maps of the city and where each great holiday happening would be?Get back to basics and stop the stupid designer nonsense I throw in the garbage. And no more of these “culture” excuses.Estelle BrunoWest Sayville, N.Y., Dec. 16, 2007 ● Had I been a responsible editor asked to decide on those photographs, I would have nixed them. But not so much for the sexual suggestiveness as to avoid rewarding the physical child abuse of which they appear to be incontrovertible proof.As my wife instantly observed when I sought her opinion, that poor girl looks starved. The only visible curve on her is the profile of her breast. If she’s not anorexic or bulemic, then she is suffering from something else that also needs urgent medical attention.Isn’t the “fashion” industry belatedly recognizing this problem? Should The Times, or any newspaper, be part of the solution instead of the problem?Martin A. DyckmanWaynesville, N.C., Dec. 16, 2007 ● Those critics have too much time and too little do. Pornography is in the mind of the beholder. They must have filthy minds.Peter J. PeiranoRidgewood, N.J., Dec. 17, 2007●●Re “If It’s Fit to Blog, Is It Fit to Print?” (Dec. 9):It may have been the correct decision to keep from the printed version of The Times the quote from the book by Scott McClellan, the former White House press secretary, that suggested President Bush had lied to him since Mr. McClellan had already said to Larry King on CNN that he didn’t think Mr. Bush had knowingly pressed him to divulge false information.All the fuss over Mr. Bush seems to have eclipsed the fact that Mr. McClellan’s statement also included Vice President Dick Cheney, Andrew Card, Karl Rove and Scooter Libby.They were not similarly excused by Mr. McClellan on “Larry King Live.” How about mentioning that in the printed version of The New York Times? And how about a follow-up investigation of the fabulating four by Times reporters?James D. PoissonWakefield, R.I., Dec. 9, 2007 ● Your analysis of the excerpt from Scott McClellan’s not-yet-released book about the leak that led to Scooter Libby’s conviction raised compelling journalistic issues. But it glossed right over the substantive issue, arguing that the president may not have been one of the five who knew that Mr. McClellan was being asked to lie to the public and that therefore the leak story didn’t go to print.Wouldn’t the story of the president and his press secretary being lied to by Karl Rove, Scooter Libby, Vice President Dick Cheney and the president’s own chief of staff be front-page news?Mary E. FellowsPortland, Ore., Dec. 10, 2007●I have written in before to complain about The Times Magazine’s use of veryyoung-looking models. This may be the first actual breast, but spreadsfeaturing heavily made-up girls who look 12 or 14, sprawled in provocative,slutty poses are a standard feature of T ­ thumb through some back issues.I’m a Times subscriber in Tucson, and from here, obviously, the standardsof the New York fashion world (not to say the fashions themselves) arefairly incomprehensible. I take The Times to feel as if I know what’sreally going on, and despite some disappointments in the tone andindependence of the coverage, I love the paper and depend upon it. But thisold-hippie, staunchly anticensorship liberal is honestly shocked by theeditors’ lack of attention to the demi-child-porn in some of your fashionlayouts.If the Times lets fashion photographers, under-age models and their stagemothers decide what’s within the bounds of good taste, readers willcontinue to complain and editors will continue to have to explain howimages to delight pedophiles got into their newspaper.Renee DowningTucson, Dec. 16, 2007

headline: Personnel File: Garcia Returns to Haunt 49ers
text: During his time as the quarterback in San Francisco, Jeff Garcia set about writing his name into the record books of the 49ers, a team that has featured Y. A. Tittle, John Brodie, Joe Montana and Steve Young. In 2000, Garcia set team records for completions (355) and passing yards (4,278) in a season, and his 32 touchdown passes in 2001 were the third most in team history.

headline: Week 16 In Preview: Another Day, Another Way to Win
text: The Vikings are riding a five-game winning streak, during which they have won in ways great and small. They beat Oakland with trick plays and the running of Chester Taylor. They pounced on turnovers to rout the Giants and the 49ers. They dominated the Lions. They rallied in the fourth quarter against the Bears. They have won with Adrian Peterson out for two games and running for 100 yards in only one of the other three.

headline: College Basketball: Top of the Heap
text: The rankings will tell you that North Carolina is the No. 1 men’s basketball team in the country. (The R.P.I., for the record, will tell you that it is Vanderbilt.) But after No. 2 Memphis dismantled No. 4 Georgetown on Saturday, it is fairly obvious that the Tigers (10-0) will be the favorite to win the national title.

headline: Clinton Returns the Fire
text: MILFORD, N.H. – Senate Hillary Rodham Clinton hit back Saturday afternoon against Senator Barack Obama’s contention that he had more support than she did from foreign policy advisers from Bill Clinton’s administration.

headline: Ambrose Bierce’s “Devil’s Dictionary”
text: From the “i” entries in “The Devil’s Dictionary” by Ambrose Bierce (1911):

headline: Huckabee Uses Vets for a Critique
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa – On Saturday afternoon, Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas and Republican presidential candidate, spoke movingly of a soldier recently returned from Iraq. The young man, he said, had been awarded the Bronze Star, and wanted to become a policeman. But an incident in which he shot a friend with a B.B. gun when he was 13 was still on his record, and he needed a pardon from his governor to enter the police academy.

headline: The “Blog” of “Unnecessary” Quotation Marks
text: This site reaffirms Dave Barry’s insight that many folk’s cant do “punctuation”:

headline: In Other Words, Just Fly Away
text: An irate passenger has his jets cooled by an airline agent:

headline: Holiday Gifts | Editor’s List (Day Six)
text: Over the past few days, the T staff have shared their material desires. Friends and family: take note! (Gift lists from earlier in the week can be found here.)

headline: The Anbar Awakening
text: The Sunni Awakening has helped calm one of the most violent provinces of Iraq. But it faces an uncertain future.

headline: Edwards: No Support for Outside Ads
text: CORALVILLE – Under pressure from Senator Barack Obama, John Edwards said on Saturday that he is asking outside groups that circumvent campaign finance regulations not to run television ads on his behalf in Iowa.

headline: ‘Hey, Don’t Look at Me’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send them via the comment link below):

headline: Inequality denial
text: Well, there they go again. The Economist has a piece asserting, as a critique of Conscience of a Liberal, that rising income inequality hasn’t translated into a big rise in social inequality. It’s actually an argument I take on explicitly in Chapter 12 . But The Economist nonetheless rounds up the usual suspects.

headline: New Obama Ad on Trade Enforcement
text: Striking a populist tone echoing that of rival John Edwards, Senator Barack Obama is out with a new ad that highlights his position on trade enforcement.

headline: World of Wonders
text: At a meeting back in the 1930s, a professor of aerodynamics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology named Ed Warner was told that Pan Am was developing a new 39-seat airplane. Warner scoffed at the idea, and scrawled some mathematical equations on a blackboard to show that it couldn’t be done. “There,” he said, “that proves it.”

headline: Educating Okposo and Saturday Night in the Bunker
text: Kyle Okposo is preparing to represent the United States at the World Junior Championship tournament in the Czech Republic, the Islanders’ Garth Snow is looking for scoring help and the Minnesota Golden Gophers are turning to anyone they can find, if only to say, “We were robbed.”

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Dec. 23
text: The networks’ early gifts to you are several high-profile interviews on Sunday morning.

headline: Ehlvest Wins Marshall Chess Club Championship
College Basketball: No Gators Walking Through That Door
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — While listening to Florida Coach Billy Donovan after his team got trounced Saturday by Ohio State, 62-49, I couldn’t help but think he was going to channel his old mentor Rick Pitino. As he refused to use his team’s inexperience as an excuse, I could almost hear that famous Pitino line while he was coach of the Boston Celtics: “Larry Bird is not walking through that door, fans. Kevin McHale is not walking through that door. Robert Parish is not walking through that door. If you expect them to walk through that door, they’re going to be gray and old.”

headline: Christmas Flourishes, in a Trim Green Stillness
text: CULVER CITY, Calif.  Around the country, this is the season when cemeteries become homes for many families’ second Christmas tree, where devotion meets tinsel, “Let It Snow” garden ornaments and the occasional Santa swizzle stick.

headline: Goes With the Job
text: An A.P. English teacher at a public school, I am inundated with requests for college recommendations. To write and send one takes about two hours. I do at least 25 a year and cannot decline such requests. It’s killing me! Would it be unethical to charge a fee to the parents of these students akin to that charged by outside SAT tutors?  Name Withheld, Brooklyn

headline: Oysters, Ideal for the Palate
text: IN a season awash with fruitcake and candy canes, nothing revives a weary palate better than a tangy fresh oyster. In December they’re at their best, and tradition invites them to the table. I was 9 or 10 when I ate my first raw oyster, a little Olympia, just shucked, extended in my father’s big hand and swallowed with great reluctance on a tidal flat in Puget Sound in Washington. It was delicious.

headline: Space to Nurture Obsessions
text: ALTHOUGH Robyn Sklaren and Brian Fountain’s kitchen is spotless, with nice new cabinets and countertops, it has the sad air of neglect. On a recent Sunday morning, no smells of brunch or even boxed doughnuts wafted from the space.

headline: Treating Mom to Art, Opera and Lots of Chiles
text: FOR almost 200 years, Santa Fe has been a site of pilgrimage. Every Good Friday since the early 18th century, believers have marched by foot, away from the center of town, with its Romanesque cathedral and rounded stucco buildings the color of roasted corn, toward El Santuario de Chimayo, the Lourdes of the Southwest, in the high-desert hills some 28 miles north. It’s a marathon of the devout, who reach the holy finish line wearing anything from hiking gear to their Sunday best.

headline: Technology Leads a Comeback for Shares
text: The stock market surged last week on robust earnings from technology companies, a strong report on consumer spending and optimism about the Federal Reserve’s efforts to inject cash into the credit markets.

headline: A Place Just Like Every Other Place. Only Not.
text: LAUREL, Md.

headline: Seen It Once? That’s Just the Start
text: NEXT month Dance Theater Workshop is remounting Miguel Gutierrez’s enthralling “Everyone,” seen at the Henry Street Settlement in March. Go, then go back: “Everyone” should be absorbed multiple times. But the chance to see it even twice is a luxury. Though recent initiatives at Dance Theater Workshop and elsewhere suggest that the tide is turning, contemporary dances still die quick, quiet deaths far too often.

headline: Season’s End in Sight, Jets Have a Lot Left to Play For
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Eight days and two games remain in a Jets season most often described as lost or miserable. Their record resides near the bottom of the N.F.L. standings, 3 wins and 11 losses. They stopped thinking about the playoffs months ago.

headline: The Caviar Lesson
text: MY mother was one of five sisters who came to the United States in the 1930s from Budapest. Her sisters called her Koldus Grofne, which means Beggar Countess. The phrase sounds better in Hungarian, but the meaning is clear in both languages: My mother had royal tastes without the money to back it up.

headline: With Airwaves Under Assault, Radio Stations Raise the Alarm
text: ON Monday night at 10:27, listeners to the Newark-based jazz station WBGO could hear the legendary Red Norvo plunking away at the final bars of “Have You Met Miss Jones?” The station’s signal, at 88.3 FM, blankets the city from Tottenville at the southern tip of Staten Island to Riverdale in the north Bronx.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are (Stuffed)
text: DOWNTOWN bistros seem finally to be paying tribute to the ’90s  the 1890s, that is  by covering their walls with a Victorian curio cabinet’s worth of antlers, skulls and nests. But it’s the stuffed animals in a growing number of New York hot spots that most recall the era of pith-helmet safaris.

headline: One Character at a Time
text: IT would be nice to believe that words are exact, like neat little keys that fit into locks and open doors. But words are picklocks at best. And they become even less precise when discussing ethnicity, as is clear in David Henry Hwang’s new play, “Yellow Face,” at the Public Theater.

headline: Attractive and Accessible, but Is That All There Is?
text: Ornamental art is hard to resist. But you have to, for behind the casual facade of easy decoration is a theory of art’s purpose that shuns complexity, even snubs its nose at it. It is a theory that says looking good is sufficient.

headline: What We Talk About When We Talk About Art
text: WHEN it comes to fashionably obtuse language, the art world is one of the leading offenders. Academic pretensions flash through like brush fire, without a drop of cold water splashed their way.

headline: JETS  at TITANS
text: JETS

headline: Party Backing Ousted Thai Leader Wins
text: BANGKOK  A party that supports former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra won Thailand’s parliamentary election on Sunday, defeating a party backed by the generals who ousted him in a coup 15 months ago.

headline: Give a Property Tax Break to Older Volunteers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: When the Bullies Turned Faceless
text: An article last Sunday about the suicide of Megan Meier, who was the target of a hoax on MySpace, referred incorrectly to statements made by Lori Drew, a neighbor, through her lawyer. She has denied creating the MySpace page used in the hoax and has denied knowledge of the final messages, which are a suspected cause of Ms. Meier’s suicide; she has not denied knowing about the ongoing hoax.

headline: Turkey Bombs Kurds in Iraq; 2 Sides Differ on Casualties
text: ISTANBUL  In its third large cross-border attack into Iraq within a week, Turkey said Saturday that its warplanes had killed hundreds of separatist Kurdish rebels.

headline: Letters
text: SEATTLE SYMPHONY

headline: Young Fans Stick by Knicks, and Vice Versa
text: Good things came in small packages last Monday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: In the Jungles of Laos, the Aftermath of an Old War
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Television Screen, Sliced Ever Thinner
text: IMAGINE a television set so thin that you could roll it up and carry it in your briefcase. It’s not as far off as you might think.

headline: Can There Be Too Many Tourists? In Tuscany, Maybe
text: PLANS to bring the historic Italian city of Siena into the jet age with the expansion of its small airport are being contested by an embattled group of citizens who say that Siena is doing fine, just as it is.

headline: In a Sometimes Ignored Neighborhood, First-Class Dreams
text: GLENDALE has long struggled for postal recognition.

headline: Needing No Weatherman
text: In his memoir “Dog Heart,” the South African writer, painter and longtime anti-apartheid activist Breyten Breytenbach told the story of a grandfather who spent his days in a pepper tree, staring off into the distance; young Breyten took him his morning mug of coffee, and everyone in the family pretended it was normal for someone to perch on a branch 10 feet off the ground. Finally, though, the father became concerned for Grandpa’s safety and had the tree chopped down; within a week, the old man was dead. The moral is clear: take away a person’s roots and you take away his life.

headline: Another Day, Another Way to Win
text: The Vikings are riding a five-game winning streak, during which they have won in ways great and small. They beat Oakland with trick plays and the running of Chester Taylor. They pounced on turnovers to rout the Giants and the 49ers. They dominated the Lions. They rallied in the fourth quarter against the Bears. They have won with Adrian Peterson out for two games and running for 100 yards in only one of the other three.

headline: Celebrating the Intangibles Money Can’t Buy
text: WITH Wall Street shaky but art prices sky-high, even the art world’s professional boosters started sounding moral about art and money in 2007, as if opportunistically positioning themselves for a fall. Too late. By now everyone knows that art is business, the art world a public relations machine. The sheer bulk of hyped product made the past season look not eclectic and textured but sleek and flat.

headline: An Appreciation of ‘The Hunt’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Merriman Expected to Return
text: The Pro Bowl linebacker Shawne Merriman, who missed last week’s game with a sprained left knee, appears ready to start for San Diego on Monday night, when the Chargers play host to the Denver Broncos.“I’ve been doing pretty much everything the whole week,” Merriman said Saturday after practice. “I feel good, I’m moving around good and I’m expecting to play.”Merriman’s one concession to his injury will be a knee brace. “Sometimes it hampers my change of direction and it prevents me from doing certain things,” he said.

headline: Letters
text: Brought to You By . . .

headline: Correction: Calendar of Events, Long Island
text: A picture caption on Dec. 9 about the musical “Annie” at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts in Brookville misstated the surname of the actor shown playing Daddy Warbucks. It is Barton, not Baron.

headline: Hoover Planned Mass Jailing in 1950
text: A newly declassified document shows that J. Edgar Hoover, the longtime director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, had a plan to suspend habeas corpus and imprison some 12,000 Americans he suspected of disloyalty.

headline: Porsche and VW: One Happy Family?
text: STUTTGART, Germany

headline: Make Legislators Earn Their Raises (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tension Looms on Thai Election Day
text: BANGKOK  As promised, the generals who seized power 15 months ago in a coup are holding an election on Sunday to hand Thailand back to a civilian government.

headline: Man Convicted for Shooting Teenager
text: A Suffolk County jury on Saturday night found a black man guilty of manslaughter for shooting of an unarmed white teenager outside the man’s house last year, ending a racially charged trial.

headline: Putting on the White Tie and Gown
text: ON a chilly Sunday in Vienna, the famous Café Bräunerhof had closed for the night, but up the block, close to the Hofburg palace, the lights at the Tanzschule Elmayer were blazing. It was November, and the ball season was drawing near. No one in this city wanted to be caught, come January, unable to dance.

headline: Supporting Cast Teaches Bryant to Appreciate Los Angeles
text: Seven months ago, Kobe Bryant’s powerful hands were outstretched and cocked, poised to slam the figurative big red button that would blow up the Los Angeles Lakers, end an era and reorder the N.B.A. universe. Last week, those capable hands were flinging passes to Andrew Bynum, clasping the shoulders of Jordan Farmar, diagramming sets to Vladimir Radmanovic and holding up the foundation of the franchise that Bryant so badly wanted to leave.

headline: Egyptian Guard Killed in Clash With Smugglers at Israeli Border
text: JERUSALEM  An Egyptian border guard was shot dead on Friday night in a clash in the Sinai Desert with Egyptian smugglers escorting African migrants to the Israeli border, according to news agency reports. An African migrant from another group was wounded early Saturday when Egyptian border guards opened fire to try to stop them, the reports said.

headline: Hotels Discover the Brooklyn Vibe
text: THE surge of hotel development in New York City over the last two years is starting to appear a bit “frothy” to some industry watchers.

headline: The Gift
text: W HEN a friend told me my mother was giving me a gift, my first instinct was to belt the guy. It’s a good thing I’ve never belted anybody. Still, what kind of gift is the chance to stand around helplessly while your mother dies? I chalked up my friend’s comment to one man’s attempt at pseudo-spiritual spin. He meant well.

headline: A Circle of Faith Grows in Unexpected Ways
text: LARCHMONT, N.Y.

headline: Two Punks Go Into a Bar
text: IN London during the late 1970s, Mick Jones, the lead guitarist for the Clash, and Tony James, the bassist of Generation X, were pre-eminent rulers of punk, slag-off sultans whose riotous antics won legions of followers.

headline: Sailing Toward Paradise
text: THERE are few places on the planet more appropriate to contemplate a sea journey than at the Miraflores Locks, on the western end of the Panama Canal. It is a balmy March evening, and the red tropical sun hangs low over the jungle-covered hills. At eye level a container ship slides silently by, seeming close enough to touch. The size of a lengthwise Chrysler Building and stacked high with multicolored metal boxes, it slips into the lock, and great steel gates swing closed as the 65,000-ton ship is lowered in its final stage from Lake Gatún. The lower gates open like the doors of a cathedral, and the enormous vessel is pulled forward by tow lines. It fires up its engines and churns toward the Pacific.

headline: Artists Only
text: About a year ago, a college senior and Facebook veteran taught me how to share intimate information on social networks. His first rule was ironclad: “You gotta be transparent about your love life.”

headline: Chile’s Rising Waters and Frozen Avocados
text: Santiago, Chile

headline: Sylvan Fox, 79, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Journalist, Dies
text: Sylvan Fox, the first “rewrite man” to be singled out for a Pulitzer Prize, died on Saturday at New York University Medical Center. Mr. Fox, who also worked as a reporter and editor for The New York Times, was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Going, Going, Back Again
text: IF you thought that those grand apartments at the sold-out 15 Central Park West were gone forever, think again.

headline: Ordinary Misfits
text: The mark of greatness in golf is the ability to play long ball and sink a chip shot. Apply the same measures to writing, and you begin to get a sense of Michel Faber’s talents. In his novel “The Crimson Petal and the White” (2002), Faber, who was born in the Netherlands and now lives in Scotland, delivered an 800-plus-page panorama worthy of Trollope or Dickens. Following a collection of novellas, he is back with “Vanilla Bright Like Eminem,” a set of 16 stylish, harrowing stories that get off to running starts and have concise, cut-to-the-chase precision. Does Faber write poetry too? If so, I want to read it.

headline: As I Was Saying Before I Left Office
text: DES MOINES, Iowa

headline: $840 a Seat? Sure. It’s a Slam Dunk.
text: WORKERS last week rushed to install new risers and seating at the County Center in White Plains in time for a basketball slam-dunk competition scheduled for Thursday.

headline: A Substitute Helps Arsenal Increase Its Lead in England
text: The substitute Nicklas Bendtner scored moments after entering the game Saturday as Arsenal beat Tottenham, 2-1, to continue its success against its north London rival in the English Premier League.

headline: Does Low Cost Mean High Risk?
text: IN the wake of September’s crash in Phuket of a jet from One-Two-Go Airlines, a Thai low-cost carrier, some aviation experts expressed shock that the plane had even tried to land. Shortly before the jet came down, other aircraft landing on the Thai island had warned traffic controllers of dangerously wet and windy conditions, and the One-Two-Go pilots could have canceled their landing. They didn’t, and more than 80 passengers were killed when the jet skidded beyond the runway and burst into flames.

headline: Ripping Out and Remodeling; for Her, a Tool Belt’s Not a Prop
text: MILLER PLACE

headline: Letters: Stereo Sanctuaries
text: In his book “Where Men Hide,” James B. Twitchell further explores what Virginia Heffernan touched on in her article: what “man caves” represent and how consumerism has hastened the disappearance of gendered spaces (The Medium, Dec. 9). While traditionally the idea was for men to have sacred, no-girls-allowed rooms that might be about collecting, hunting, woodworking or other hobbies, it has now become more about sitting/being entertained/buying  and the guys aren’t necessarily averse to letting the women in their lives help design the space (and occasionally hang out there, too). Anthropological consideration of such spaces serves as a fascinating lens through which to observe gender relations, in what feels like a major cultural shift of our time.

headline: Gators Lose and Face Long Road Back to Top
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  The people who run Value City Arena tried to create some excitement for Ohio State’s game Saturday against Florida. They pumped the “Jock Jams” soundtrack into the arena speakers and handed out white towels in an attempt to whip the crowd into a frenzy.

headline: 10 Years Later, Chiapas Massacre Still Haunts Mexico
text: ACTEAL, Mexico  It was 10 years ago that gunmen crept down the hillside into the center of this impoverished Indian village in Chiapas State. By the time they fled hours later, the attackers had littered the ground with bullet casings and killed 45 innocent people, including 21 women and 15 children.

headline: The Human Stain
text: You don’t have to spend all day poring through fashion magazines to see that red lipstick is having a moment. Certainly, reds tend to reappear on makeup counters during the holiday season, but vibrant crimsons are on the face of every fashion-conscious starlet facing a flash right now, as well on the spring runways, a season usually reserved for soft pinks and nudes. Red lips, according to the beauty industry’s party line, are “classic,” “pretty” and “universally wearable.” But such claims merely gloss the surface.

headline: Tatsuzo Shimaoka, 88, Master of Pottery, Is Dead
text: Tatsuzo Shimaoka, a potter who was designated a “living national treasure” in Japan for his mastery of his craft, died on Dec. 11 in Mashiko, Japan, where he had maintained a studio since 1953. He was 88.

headline: For Those Who Text and Drive, You Can Stop Now
text: CAN technology solve problems that technology has created? Consider my dismay recently as I spied a driver on the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut weaving in and out of his lane because he was tapping out messages on his BlackBerry.

headline: A Young Teacher’s Year of Mop-Ups and Cinderella
text: IT was my first year of teaching, and the reality of my new job was setting in. At 8:30 in the morning I was bent over, scrubbing the linoleum floor. My stomach churned as I cleaned up regurgitated Lucky Charms, the green and pink marshmallows working against me.

headline: Training for a New Life Through a New Trade
text: THEY’RE building new kitchen cabinets  and, they hope, new lives.

headline: Tommy Byrne, 87, a Former Yankee Pitcher, Dies
text: Tommy Byrne, the longtime Yankees left-hander who was named the American League’s comeback player of the year in 1955 and often seemed on the verge of a brilliant career only to be plagued by wildness, died Thursday at his home in Wake Forest, N.C. He was 87.

headline: Counties Face Sluggish Sales Tax Revenues
text: WITH sales tax receipts slipping below estimates and with budget surpluses shrinking, sales tax dependent Nassau and Suffolk Counties are trying to adjust to tighter times without raising property taxes.

headline: Need a ‘Taxi’ in Tokyo? Just Flash a Card
text: New flashcards made by a Princeton, N.J., company, Lingolook (www.lingolook.net), hope to do away with the panic of flipping through guidebooks to find the phrase for “Where’s the airport?”

headline: Does Yankees’ Steroid Use Taint Torre?
text: Joe Torre was not mentioned in the Mitchell report. There was no reason he should have been. But the report raises a question about Torre indirectly, as it does directly about Roger Clemens and Barry Bonds and their chances for election to the Hall of Fame.

headline: Talking Politics, Drawing Viewers
text: AS television viewers paid increasing attention this year to the presidential race, they often sought out more politically opinionated talk, at least on cable.

headline: A Cafe Ahead of the Pack
text: Food courts and fast food are still standard fare in shopping malls, but sometimes an oasis appears in the culinary desert. At Saks Fifth Avenue in the Walt Whitman Mall, you can turn left past the Burberry handbags to find Cirella’s at Saks Fifth Avenue, a stylish cafe in a nook beside the accessories department. Here, the typical shopper’s lunch has been given an upgrade.

headline: I’m a Believer
text: In the parable of the lost sheep, in the Gospel of Luke, Jesus says there shall be more joy in heaven over “one sinner that repenteth” than over 99 just persons who need no repentance. Never mind heaven: check out the joy on the Internet. In 2001, rumors started to hit the blogosphere that Antony Flew, a British philosopher born in 1923, had found God after six decades of atheism. At first Flew denied the reports. But in May 2004 he told a conference in New York that he had indeed changed his mind and become a believer. A flurry of online pundits debated the meaning of this shocking conversion.

headline: Reena Mehta and Dashiell Flynn
text: Reena Mehta, a daughter of Manjula Mehta and Dr. Jagat S. Mehta of Pittsford, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Dashiell Deben Flynn, the son of Daphne Makinson of Washington and John Flynn of Montpelier, Vt. Patricia Gahagan, a justice of the peace in Woodbury, Vt., will officiate at her home. On Nov. 16, Pandit Surendra B. Joshi, a Hindu priest, performed a Hindu ceremony at the Jag Mandir Palace in Udaipur, India.

headline: Belgium Frees 14 Held as Plot Suspects
text: BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP)  A judge on Saturday released 14 men who had been accused of plotting to break a suspected supporter of Al Qaeda out of prison here, saying there was too little evidence to hold them.

headline: Residents Speak Against Proposed University
text: Mount Pleasant

headline: Down Sybarites’ Alley
text: PARISIANS don’t go window shopping. Rather, when the weekend arrives, the masses stroll past the boutiques and, as they put it, “faire du lèche-vitrine” (go window licking).

headline: A Dramatic Comeback for the Play
text: THIS was the year that the play stood up for itself, reminding us that it can go places inaccessible to other art forms. Perhaps it took the surprisingly successful marathon that was Tom Stoppard’s three-part “Coast of Utopia,” which began in 2006, to reorient New York theatergoers to the pleasures of bona fide drama.

headline: A Tree Dies in Norway
text: Early in THE REDBREAST (Harper/HarperCollins, $24.95), an elegant and complex thriller by the Norwegian musician, economist and crime writer Jo Nesbo, an old man who has just received a death sentence from his doctor goes into the palace gardens in Oslo and kills an ancient oak tree. “Yes!” you think. “What a terrible act, but what wonderful symbolism!” And you’ll be amazed when, hundreds of pages later, the real reason for the aboricide is revealed, along with the answers to other seemingly minor mysteries (including the significance of the title) that figure in the novel’s ingenious design.

headline: Another Look at Teardowns
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Goldman Chief’s Bonus
text: The Goldman Sachs Group awarded its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, a record $67.9 million bonus in 2007, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Hannah Grossman, Daniel Singerman
text: Hannah Felicia Grossman and Daniel Micah Singerman are to be married on Sunday evening at the Hotel duPont, in Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Michael Beals is to officiate.

headline: Protecting a $155 Billion Pot
text: New York’s comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, one of the most powerful people in the state, was chosen by his friends in the State Assembly over more qualified contenders. Nevertheless, Mr. DiNapoli has worked hard to make up for the way he was chosen, devoting his first year in office to reforming his own job in ways that serve the public interest.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: SIR GAWAIN AND THE GREEN KNIGHT: A New Verse Translation, by Simon Armitage. (Norton, $25.95.) One of the eerie, exuberant joys of Middle English poetry, in an alliterative rendering that captures the original’s drive, dialect and landscape.

headline: Erica Smolow, Scott Koenig
text: Erica Fran Smolow, the daughter of Rhoda F. Smolow and Dr. Craig R. Smolow of Great Neck, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Scott Jonathan Koenig, the son of Madeleine Koenig and Dr. David Koenig of North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Howard A. Stecker performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y., with Cantor Joel Caplan taking part.

headline: Prima Performances From the Familiar, and Not
text: THIS year certain dancers have come to loom large in my mind, dancers whose names I was not aware of having heard when it began. Two of them dance lead roles with New York City Ballet: Ashley Bouder and Teresa Reichlen. Ms. Bouder, dark and  by City Ballet standards  short, scorches her way into steps and onto the music with a high-definition clarity scarcely seen since the prime of Merrill Ashley in the 1980s. Ms. Reichlen, fair and unusually tall, seems lyrical, windblown, even when dancing in the high-wire rhythmic complexities of the “Agon” pas de trois or amid the Wrens’ comedy in “Union Jack.”

headline: Letters: The 53 Places to Go in 2008
text: RESPONSIBLE TRAVEL

headline: The El, With Bells
text: FROM the elevated tracks of the No. 7 train as it pushes northeast through Queens, Christmas comes in flickers of light, quick daubs of color in the darkness. These moments of brightness, strung up along balconies and porches and visible as the train clatters through the night along Queens Boulevard and Roosevelt Avenue, offer an invitation to wonder who lives in the houses and apartments below.

headline: The Exchange: Kindness for Rudeness
text: DURING my junior year abroad, I lived with other American students in a suburban house outside Cork, Ireland. I was a skinny, eye-rolling 21-year-old with literary pretensions. I thought I was too good to hang out with my housemates, who were all chubby girls from Midwestern colleges.

headline: Navigating a Tricky Year, Hands On
text: FOR years, one of the fiercest arguments in the investment business has been over whether it pays to bet on actively managed mutual funds or to sit back and go with low-cost funds that replicate the performance of market benchmarks like the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index.

headline: Holiday Jeers
text: Holiday Jeers

headline: Up Front
text: This week, Matt Weiland reviews “Psychogeography,” Will Self’s essays about eccentric voyages on foot, with illustrations by Ralph Steadman. While Weiland has never hoofed it from Battersea Park to Heathrow and then from J.F.K. to the Lower East Side, as Self once did, his recent move back to New York after four years in London has given him some perspective on comparative urban rambling.

headline: Ruling Lets Firms Bar Union E-mail
text: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that employers have the right to prohibit workers from using the company’s e-mail system to send out union-related messages, a decision that could hamper communications between labor unions and their membership.

headline: All the Little Gifts
text: Sea Cliff

headline: Where Historic Town Houses Still Hold Court
text: IT was around 1900 that 78th Street from Fifth Avenue to Madison began to make the transition from rows of brownstones to individualized town houses. Apartment buildings never invaded the block, as they eventually did most others, and their absence leaves a street unusually rich in the details of private house architecture.

headline: Nurturing a Goal With Abundant Hope
text: Stephanie Womble’s apartment is packed with Christmas cheer. Lights are strung through the living room, the tree plays carols, and the walls and doors are covered in wrapping paper.

headline: Farm Evolves From One Generation to Next
text: Belvidere

headline: Correction: From Russia With Luxe
text: An article on Dec. 9 about Moscow as a new luxury destination misstated the cost of a ticket on the city’s metro system in United States currency. The ticket, at 17 rubles, is about 70 cents, at the exchange rate of 25 rubles to the dollar; it is not 7 cents. A picture caption also misidentified the location of a Rolex billboard. It is in the plaza leading to Red Square; it is not in Red Square.
