headline: In Kentucky’s Teeth, Toll of Poverty and Neglect
text: BARBOURVILLE, Ky.  In the 18 years he has been visiting nursing homes, seeing patients in his private practice and, more recently, driving his mobile dental clinic through Appalachian hills and hollows, Dr. Edwin E. Smith has seen the extremes of neglect.

headline: Alternative Tax Folly
text: Congress has passed and President Bush is sure to sign into law a bill that will spare some 23 million Americans from having to pay the alternative minimum tax next April. Mr. Bush and the bill’s Congressional supporters are right when they say the new law will provide much-needed shelter from a tax that was never supposed to apply to this many Americans.

headline: ’Tis the Season
text: Much as I love “A Christmas Carol,” I don’t believe Charles Dickens really did justice to the nature of his hero, Ebenezer Scrooge. If Dickens hadn’t been such a sucker for personal redemption, he might have let us see how perceptive the old Scrooge really was  the one who savors all the ironies of Christmas. How else, after a night of ghostly trauma, could he have remembered there were two prize turkeys in the poulterer’s window at the corner in the next street but one?

headline: Oscar Peterson, Virtuoso of Jazz, Dies at 82
text: Oscar Peterson, whose dazzling piano playing made him one of the most popular jazz artists in history, died Sunday night at his home in Mississauga, Ontario, outside Toronto. He was 82.

headline: I Hear America Dancing, and the Sound Is Just Like Tap Shoes
text: Stereotypes get a bad name, but our poor brains couldn’t function without them. Americans look toward Europe and see weariness and cynicism bent under the weight of history. Europeans see America’s vision of personal reinvention and hope and find a culture of naïveté.

headline: Broken Polls
text: Election officials hate to admit how vulnerable their voting systems are to errors and vote theft. The Ohio and Colorado secretaries of state, however, have recently spoken openly about the weaknesses of the voting machines used in their states  and are pushing to get them fixed. Election officials in other states, whose voting machines have similar vulnerabilities, should follow Ohio’s and Colorado’s lead.

headline: School for Liars Teaches the Dishonesty of Truth and the Truth About Dishonesty
text: Much of Jesse Ball’s delicious first novel, “Samedi the Deafness,” takes place in an inventive institution called a verisylum, an asylum for chronic liars (conveniently located near Washington). And while the Samedi part of the title becomes lucid early on, the deafness isn’t explained until Page 254. That’s fair warning: Readers who long for instant clarity will be frustrated. But anyone with a taste for the elusive will find that this smart, audacious work becomes as gripping as a good thriller, which it partially resembles.

headline: Falling Short of Professional Standards
text: Will American doctors be a help or a hindrance in efforts to raise the quality and cost-effectiveness of the nation’s health care system? A new, worrisome survey raises doubts about physicians’ willingness to meet their medical and societal responsibilities.

text: The Baltimore Sun is taking the unusual step of placing responsibility for its opinion pages with its top news editor.

headline: Vikings Fail to Clinch, Leaving Their Fate in Redskins’ Hands
text: The Washington Redskins shut down Adrian Peterson and set up two early touchdowns with interceptions, taking control of their playoff fate with a 32-21 victory over the Minnesota Vikings on Sunday night.

headline: In Search of Her Inner Kangaroo Suit
text: As soon as Eve Best walks into a cafe or bar, she is received like the patron saint of the service industry, with waiters flocking to her like sparrows to St. Francis. She is either a very good tipper, a fierce hangout loyalist or simply that darn charismatic.

headline: Michael Kidd, Choreographer, Dies
text: Michael Kidd, the award-winning choreographer of exuberant dance numbers for Broadway shows like “Finian’s Rainbow,” “Guys and Dolls”‘ and “Can-Can” and Hollywood musicals like “The Band Wagon” and “Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,” died Sunday night at his home in Los Angeles.

headline: Monday’s Matchup
text: Regular watchers of “Monday Night Football” have grown familiar with the Broncos, who will be featured on the broadcast for the third time this season. Their previous two games were among their best in a disappointing season. But unlike the first two games, this one is on the road, where Denver is 2-5. Worse for the Broncos and their 29th-ranked run defense, the Chargers’ running game is on a roll. After a slow start, LaDainian Tomlinson is in position to win his second rushing title. The Chargers had 274 rushing yards last week against Detroit. Denver gave up 214 rushing yards to San Diego in a 41-3 loss in Week 5. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

headline: The Day’s Best
text: Fred Taylor, left, scored on a 62-yard run on the Jaguars’ first play in a 49-11 win over the Raiders. He finished with 111 yards on 7 carries before he was pulled by Coach Jack Del Rio.

text: London

headline: Oprah Puts Her Brand on the Line
text: Last week, Denzel Washington and Harvey Weinstein were hosts for the New York premiere of “The Great Debaters” at the Ziegfeld Theater in Manhattan. Set to go into wide release on Christmas Day, “The Great Debaters” traces the mostly true story of the debate team of tiny Wiley College. It was led by a charismatic professor named Melvin B. Tolson, played by Mr. Washington, who also directed the film.

headline: Long Season Takes One More Stumble Toward the Finish
text: NASHVILLE  Chad Pennington drew a deep breath and walked slowly off the field. He wanted to soak in the emotions of starting another football game near the end of the most turbulent of seasons, in his home state, with friends and family in the stands.

headline: The Top Player in This League? It May Be the Sports Reporter
text: A few teams are rich and getting richer, hunting more avidly than ever for talent, raiding the less-endowed leagues, poaching free agents and bidding the prices of star players to unheard-of heights.

headline: Dueling Bills in the Fight Over Housing
text: A bill recently proposed in the City Council and known as Introduction 627 has been heralded by many tenants and housing advocates as a measure that would provide long-overdue protections to renters. It would, for the first time, give tenants the right to sue their landlords in Housing Court for harassing them by making threats, disrupting services or using other tactics to force them out.

headline: Notable Scenes From the YouTube Election
text: Before we zoom past the 2007 portion of this longest campaign in modern history, let’s pause and give a nod to some of the year’s more memorable moments.

headline: Senator Awaiting Records of Ministries’ Finances
text: Six weeks after Senator Charles E. Grassley asked six well-known evangelistic ministries to provide information on how they spent donors’ money, only two have complied.

headline: Out for the Season, Coles Ponders the Future
text: NASHVILLE  Laveranues Coles wore his usual postgame outfit in the Jets’ locker room: diamond studs the size of nickels, a fur coat, a fedora and a tie.

headline: Can NBC Do for ‘Quarterlife’ What YouTube Could Not?
text: Scripts by Marshall Herskovitz, the Emmy award-winning writer and producer, have drawn millions of viewers to movie theaters and television sets over the past two decades.

headline: Searching for Friends, Spitzer Warms to Lobbyists
text: Earlier this year, aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer began planning a lavish December fund-raiser on Manhattan’s West Side, hoping to cap Mr. Spitzer’s bruising first year in office with a show of political support and financial strength. To drum up contributions, they made an aggressive pitch to a group that Mr. Spitzer is not usually associated with: the state’s top lobbyists.

headline: A Rabbi of His Time, With a Charisma That Transcends It
text: In 1965, after walking in the Selma-to-Montgomery civil-rights march with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel was at the Montgomery, Ala., airport, trying to find something to eat. A surly woman behind the snack-bar counter glared at Heschel  his yarmulke and white beard making him look like an ancient Hebrew prophet  and mockingly proclaimed: “Well, I’ll be damned. My mother always told me there was a Santa Claus, and I didn’t believe her, until now.” She told Heschel that there was no food to be had.

headline: Blog, Blug. To the Writer Doris Lessing, It’s Whatever.
text: Doris Lessing will never be confused with the Internet’s exhibitionist personality Tila Tequila, but winning the Nobel Prize in Literature in October helped Ms. Lessing’s status on MySpace. What once was 125 friends before the announcement from the Nobel committee has now topped 350 friends.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: MARKETS The New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq will close at 1 p.m. Monday and will be closed Tuesday, Christmas Day. Many markets outside the United States will be closed on Wednesday as well.

headline: In Wake of Recent Manpower Loss, FreshDirect Workers Vote ‘No Union’
text: The low-wage warehouse workers at FreshDirect, the online grocery delivery service, voted overwhelmingly against union representation this weekend, according to the company and the two unions vying to represent the workers.

headline: Little Love Among Matchmakers
text: THE world of Internet dating can be a cold, unforgiving place, particularly when it comes to the fight for customers.

headline: Nepal to End Its Monarchy in a Deal With Ex-Rebels
text: KATMANDU, Nepal (Reuters)  Nepal’s government agreed Sunday to abolish the centuries-old monarchy in a political deal with Maoist former rebels, but the decision will go into effect only after next year’s elections, party officials said.

headline: After Tense Trial, a Tribute in Rubber and Smoke
text: PORT JEFFERSON STATION, N.Y.  Minutes after Daniel John Cicciaro’s young body was lowered into the ground last year, his friends revved up their gleaming sports cars and peeled out past the mourners, leaving long lines of burnt rubber on the cemetery blacktop.

headline: Austrian Fails to Get Record Win
text: Thomas Morgenstern of Austria failed to win a record seventh consecutive event in World Cup ski jumping after finishing third in Engelberg, Switzerland.Morgenstern, the Olympic champion, was beaten by Andreas Kuettel of Switzerland, who won with jumps of 411 feet 9 inches and 446-3 in the large hill for 252.7 points.Austria’s Gregor Schlierenzauer was second with 248.9 points after jumps of 408-6 and 446-3.Morgenstern was third with 408-6 and 442-11 for 246.6 points.Going into the meet, he had become the first skier to post five consecutive victories to start a season.Morgenstern leads the World Cup standings with 660 points.

headline: Saban Not Injured in Accident
text: Alabama Coach Nick Saban’s car struck a downed tree this weekend, but he and his wife were not injured in the one-vehicle accident. The Tuscaloosa police said Saban and his wife, Terry, were driving near the entrance of their neighborhood when their car hit the tree. A police spokesman, Capt. Greg Kosloff, said officers arrived on the scene Saturday night and a report was filled out.

headline: Quoted in the News? Post a Comment, Please
text: THE days when the journalist had the last say about a subject are long gone. This thought is usually expressed by repeating  and then dismissing as outdated  the words of A. J. Liebling: “Freedom of the press is guaranteed only to those who own one.”

headline: Turkey Bombs Kurdish Rebels in Iraq for 2nd Day, Kurds Say
text: BAGHDAD  Turkish jets bombed separatist Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq for the second day in a row, Kurdish security officials said Sunday, although there was no immediate confirmation from the Turkish military.

headline: Italy’s Man From God
text: Charming Italians who parlay supposed Vatican ties into financial gain are nothing new. When I was a correspondent in Italy in the 1980s, Roberto Calvi played that game. He ended up hanging from Blackfriars Bridge in London.

headline: With Nod to Holidays, Candidates Keep a Vigorous Pace Before the Break
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  If there were any doubts how competitive the presidential race remained, fresh proof could be found Sunday in the itineraries of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, who risked testing the holiday patience of voters as they campaigned across the state before suspending politicking for a Christmas break.

headline: Tomato Pickers’ Wages Fight Faces Obstacles
text: IMMOKALEE, Fla.  In a colorful, often clamorous pressure campaign that has relied on support from college campuses and church groups, a group of farmworkers has persuaded McDonald’s and Taco Bell to have their tomato suppliers pay their pickers more.

headline: Uzbekistan Is Expected to Re-elect Its President
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  Voters in Uzbekistan went to the polls on Sunday in a presidential contest that is widely accepted as a foregone conclusion but that casts doubt on the country’s long-term stability.

headline: Invitation to an Experiment
text: One drawback of newspaper bridge columns is that readers can immediately see all 52 cards in the diagram and will be influenced by noting where the key cards are lying. Today we are trying an experiment to see if we can circumnavigate this snag.

headline: Rob Reiner Gambles on Oldsters
text: LOS ANGELES  Rob Reiner decided he wanted to direct “The Bucket List” after reading just 10 pages into the screenplay, when a character is asked what he’s doing in a hospital bed and matter-of-factly answers, “Oh, fighting for my life  you?”

headline: Israel Angers Palestinians With Housing Plan
text: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel on Sunday rejected overtures by Hamas, the militant Islamic group that rules Gaza, for discussions about a temporary cease-fire.

headline: Hey, Scholar, Leave the Kids Alone!
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Candidate’s Life ... and Wrinkles?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Phillies Sign Taguchi
text: Outfielder So Taguchi, who hit .290 for St. Louis last season, signed a one-year contract with Philadelphia on Sunday.The 38-year-old Taguchi led all National League pinch-hitters with a .406 (13 for 32) batting average.Taguchi played all three outfield positions for the Cardinals in 2007, starting 41 times in center field, 21 times in left field and twice in right.“Taguchi gives our team more defensive versatility in the outfield,” the Phillies assistant general manager Ruben Amaro Jr. said in a statement. “And he has proven over his career that he can get key hits in big situations.”As a member of the World Series champion Cardinals in 2006, Taguchi hit .400 with two homers and four runs batted in in the playoffs. He started three of the five World Series games.

headline: If You Want to Get an Arena Full of Girls Screaming, Play Mean Guy (or Nice Guy)
text: Bow Wow wanted an arena full of screaming teenagers (and screaming future teenagers) to know that a mere five-figure fee wouldn’t stop him from giving them a show to remember. “They said it’s a $10,000 fine if I go over,” he shouted, on Friday night. “But I said, ‘The hell with the money!’ ” And so the show went on.

headline: A Party Where Hope Eclipses Stress of the Season
text: Usually the youngsters who participate in the Shorefront YM-YWHA-sponsored afterschool program in Brighton Beach are getting homework help or playing in the gym after classes. But on a recent Friday, it was time to celebrate the holidays.

headline: What to Do With Taboo News When Teenagers Are Your Readers
text: Most celebrity news outlets did not hesitate to pounce on the news that Jamie Lynn Spears, the 16-year-old star of “Zoey 101” on Nickelodeon and younger sister of Britney, is pregnant. OK! magazine was first to print the news, which was quickly picked up  and milked  by just about everyone else.

headline: ‘Ode to Joy,’ Followed by Chaos and Despair
text: London

headline: The Worst Courts for Businesses? It’s a Matter of Opinion
text: As it has every year for six years now, the American Tort Reform Association released its list of “judicial hellholes” last week. South Florida took the top spot, followed by parts of Texas; Cook County, Ill.; West Virginia; Clark County, Nev.; and Atlantic County, N.J.

headline: Bryant Reaches Milestone as Lakers Beat Knicks
text: Kobe Bryant made history, re-energized Madison Square Garden and pretty much wrecked the Knicks on Sunday afternoon, in a performance that was occasionally effortless and always entertaining.

headline: Georgia School Melds a World of Differences
text: DECATUR, Ga.  Parents at an elementary school here gathered last Thursday afternoon with a holiday mission: to prepare boxes of food for needy families fleeing some of the world’s most horrific civil wars.

headline: Yonkers Man Is Mourned After Killing in Harlem
text: Detectives in Manhattan are looking for a gunman who shot and killed a Yonkers man early Sunday morning while he sat in his car at a traffic light.

headline: Rudolph W. Giuliani: In His Own Words
text: Following is how former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York concluded a town-hall-style meeting on Saturday in Hopkinton, N.H., as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times:

headline: Clemens Releases Video Denying Use of Drugs
text: Roger Clemens continued his campaign to fight allegations that he used performance-enhancing drugs, releasing a video Sunday in which he said he had never used steroids or human growth hormone.

headline: In Iran, Search for American Yields Little
text: TEHRAN  The wife of a former F.B.I. agent who has been missing since March 8 and was last known to have been on a Persian Gulf island that belongs to Iran left the country on Sunday morning after unsuccessfully seeking clues to her husband’s whereabouts.

headline: Girl Power Is in Full Force Online
text: Teenage girls are more likely than boys to have engaged in creating most kinds of online content, according to a new report by the Pew Internet & American Life Project. They are more likely to have created a blog, more likely to have joined a social-networking site like Facebook and more likely to post pictures online. The study used telephone interviews with a nationally representative sample of 935 Americans age 12 to 17.

headline: Struggling Rangers Can’t Stop Senators
text: Over the last 21 days, the Rangers have bounced between emotional extremes. They started December with a rare, resounding road victory at Ottawa that seemed to announce their arrival as an elite team, only to immediately head into a downward spiral that continued in Sunday’s 3-1 loss to that same Ottawa team.

headline: Strike Means Fewer Places for Stars to Pitch Movies
text: LOS ANGELES  When Jay Leno, David Letterman and Conan O’Brien return to the air in early January, it may already be too late for Hollywood studios.

headline: For Happiness, Go to the Birds; for Truth, Try the Cats
text: Thank goodness for cats, especially those with cameos in art made for children. As in life, these unsentimental creatures tend to put in perspective the more outlandish desires of their human owners.

headline: ‘Fire Isiah’? Not Everyone Is in Agreement
text: The Knicks were barely two quarters into their game against the Los Angeles Lakers when Derek Peterson stood up and  practically in my ear  shouted “Fire Isiah.”

headline: U.S. Officials See Waste in Billions Sent to Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  After the United States has spent more than $5 billion in a largely failed effort to bolster the Pakistani military effort against Al Qaeda and the Taliban, some American officials now acknowledge that there were too few controls over the money. The strategy to improve the Pakistani military, they said, needs to be completely revamped.

headline: On Wall Street, Merrill  Leads the Markets Higher
text: Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm, threw a party for investors Monday, but it could not get in the door.

headline: Saudi Police Arrest 28 in Foiled Plot During Hajj
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The number of men arrested late last week in a suspected plot to attack Muslim holy sites around Mecca and Medina during the hajj, the annual Muslim pilgrimage, was put at 28 in a statement issued Sunday by the Saudi Interior Ministry.

headline: Santa Is Packing More Sofas and Less Jewelry
text: FORGET about strings of pearls, dive watches or flower baskets. This could be the year of Barcaloungers and blenders.

headline: The Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Aiming for Films of High Quality and Low Ecological Damage
text: Paramount Vantage, formerly known as Paramount Classics, is the “low-budget, high-quality” division of Paramount Pictures, says Georgia Kacandes, its executive vice president for physical and postproduction. It is also, apparently, the low-emissions, high-minded division of Paramount.

text: Julio Bocca Retires

headline: With L.I. Murder Conviction Voided, the Same Old Question: Who Did It?
text: The same questions asked nearly two decades ago when Arlene and Seymour Tankleff were slashed and bludgeoned in their waterfront home on Long Island are being asked anew today:

headline: State of the Unions
text: Once upon a time, back when America had a strong middle class, it also had a strong union movement.

headline: Madrid Tops Barcelona
text: Real Madrid won, 1-0, at archrival Barcelona to extend its lead in Spanish soccer’s Primera Liga to 7 points.Madrid midfielder Julio Baptista’s 36th-minute goal separated the teams in front of a crowd of 98,000 at the Camp Nou, where Barcelona had won its previous 11 matches this season.“We are playing in a style that allows us to win matches,” Real Madrid Coach Bernd Schuster said in comments posted on his team’s Web site. “We are in a great position right now, but titles are won at the end of the campaign.”Defending champion Madrid enters the midseason break with 41 points from 17 matches. Barcelona has 34 points, with Espanyol a point further back. Villarreal has 32 points and Atletico Madrid 31 points. Espanyol won, 2-1, at Atletico, and Villarreal was held to a 1-1 home draw by Recreativo Huelva.

headline: Browns Lose, Then the Titans Rub It In
text: CINCINNATI  Because Cleveland bungled both early and late and lost, 19-14, to the Cincinnati Bengals on Sunday in the cold and wind of Paul Brown Stadium, the Browns needed help to clinch a playoff berth for the first time since the 2002 season.

headline: E-Greetings Gain Ground at Businesses This Season
text: Have you sent out your holiday cards this year? What about your e-cards?

headline: New England Is Celebrating Season Filled With Snow
text: BOSTON  After an absence, a white Christmas will be a reality and not a dream this year in northern New England, elating skiers and people whose livelihood depends on snow.

headline: Serbia Enlisting Some Unlikely Faces
text: BELGRADE, Serbia  As the dispute over Kosovo’s future nears a climax, the Serbian government has enlisted the support of some the world’s best known statesmen  all of them dead.

headline: Hindu Radical Is Re-elected in India
text: NEW DELHI  He has been likened to the Emperor Nero, who fiddled while Rome burned. He has been denied entry into the United States for violations of religious freedom, yet praised as a business-friendly politician who has allowed private industry to flourish in his state.

headline: At Canarsie High, Now Marked for Closing, Loyalty Prevails
text: They came despite the snow and slush, most straight from work, some after multiple bus trips, demanding to know whether anything could be done to save Canarsie High School.

headline: Douglas Morgan, a Collector of Typefaces, Dies at 75
text: Douglas O. Morgan, a publisher whose extensive collection of rare 19th-century wood type letterforms helped start a graphic design revival, died Dec. 10 at his home in Essex, N.Y. He was 75.

headline: Giants Slog Their Way to Playoffs
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  The rain had turned to snow, and the day had turned to night as the Giants glided through the stadium tunnel toward the locker room, their uniforms soaked and their smiles frozen.

headline: Keep Those Tie-Breaker Rules Handy
text: It turns out that next week will not just be about the Patriots’ pursuit of perfection. After the Browns and the Vikings failed to clinch playoff spots Sunday, Week 17 will now feature several games with potential playoff implications. There are two berths left — the No. 6 spot in each conference — and five teams vying for them. Here are the details:

headline: The West: Still Best
text: The way the NHL schedule has been set up the last three years, the Eastern and Western Conferences are almost like separate leagues that play only a handful of interlocking games. That arrangement will change next year. Nevertheless, this season the Western Conference has been clearly better in interleague, er, interconference play.

headline: For the Moment | Majed Al-Sabah
text: Sheikh Majed Al-Sabah, this week’s guest blogger on The Moment, is fashion royalty. Not only is Majed, as he is better known, a member of Kuwaiti royal family (his father is the first cousin of the emir of Kuwait; his mother is the emir’s sister), but he is a retail visionary, whose Villa Moda store in Kuwait is the crown jewel in a luxury company that now spans five countries in the region. These days, Majed is a front-row fixture at the fashion shows, but as he recalls in his first post, there was a time when he was lucky to have standing room tickets.

text: From a reminiscence on hideous Christmas presents:

headline: The 12 Days of Christmas Cutbacks
text: Funny Christmas card found here.
