text: From the auto section:

headline: 25 to Watch at the World Juniors
text: A year ago, Canada won its third straight gold medal at the World Junior Championship. Before they got to the gold-medal game, they had to get through the United States team in a lengthy shootout. After you watch the video above, you’ll understand why Jonathan Toews, Peter Mueller and Jack Johnson are having such a big impact in the N.H.L. this season.

headline: Cheer Up. Christmas Could Be Worse.
text: We might have had to endure Christmas pudding on top of fruitcake, but we were saved by pumpkin pie. From an Op-Ed contributor:

headline: ‘Meathead’ Joins AARP
text: From “This Is Spinal Tap” to “This Is MRI”: After a few flops and a political detour, Rob Reiner returns with “The Bucket List,” which stars Jack Nicholson and Morgan Freeman, about old guys dying of cancer. Read more …

headline: Regrets, You’ve Had a Few
They’re Not the Eggmen
text: The tooth will set you free, to be funny: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Vermont Reject FairPoint’s $2.7 Billon Bid for Verizon Lines
text: Vermont regulators on Friday rejected a $2.7 billion plan by FairPoint Communications to buy Verizon‘s landlines in northern New England.

headline: Atlantic Bridge Locates Exit for GloNav
text: European venture firm Atlantic Bridge Ventures will have some extra money for Christmas shopping as it notched its second exit of the year, selling portfolio company GloNav to chipmaker NXP Semiconductors for $110 million.

headline: News Corp. Sells Fox Stations to Oak Hill
text: The News Corporation said it would sell eight of its owned-and-operated Fox network affiliated television stations to private equity investment firm Oak Hill Capital Partners for about $1.1 billion in cash.

headline: ArcelorMittal Inks 2 Deals
text: ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steelmaker, announced on Monday two deals, including one in Europe and at least its third in South America this month.

headline: Dell Buys Britain’s Networked Storage
text: Dell, the computer maker, said Friday it agreed to buy The Networked Storage Company, a privately held data-storage consulting firm based in the United Kingdom. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Much Riding on Vietcombank I.P.O.
text: The long-awaited and oft-delayed initial public offering of Vietnam’s largest state-owned bank is finally under way. The deal for Vietcombank is expected to raise $600 million – or more than the entire market capitalization of the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange just two years ago.

headline: Lilliputian Systems Fattens Its Pot With $18 Million
text: Lilliputian Systems, a notoriously secretive company developing matchbook-sized fuel cells, has landed $18 million in new funding, according to recent documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: York Pushes for FNX Sale, but Analysts Seem Skeptical
text: York Capital Management, a New York-based hedge fund, is pushing for the sale of Toronto’s FNX Mining, amid unprecedented wave of mergers and takeovers in the sector. York, which owns nearly 20 percent of FNX’s shares, has now hired investment bankers to find a buyer for the nickel and copper miner.

headline: Linn Drills Down Deal for Lamamco Assets
text: Linn Energy, the Houston-based energy company that doubled its reserves this year by the purchase of Dominion Resources‘s gas deposits, will buy unspecified oil and gas assets from Lamamco Drilling for $552 million.

headline: Montreal Exchange Ups Stake in Boston Options Exchange
text: Takeover target the Montreal Exchange will become the majority owner of the Boston Options Exchange, in a $52.5 million cash deal announced Friday.

headline: Alitalia Recommends Air France Bid
text: Alitalia recommended Friday that Air France-KLM, the world’s largest airline, should buy the Italian state’s controlling stake in the carrier.

headline: Shari Redstone Named Chair of Midway Games
text: While it remains unknown whether Shari Redstone will succeed her father, Sumner Redstone, as chairman of Viacom and CBS, she is stepping up at Chicago-based Midway Games, the struggling video-game publisher he controls.

headline: 2 Former Merrill Executives Face Enron Retrial Next Month
text: Two of three former Merrill Lynch executives will be retried as scheduled next month on fraud and conspiracy charges linked to a 1999 deal with Enron, but the third will go it alone at a later date, a federal judge ruled Friday.

headline: Rusal Launches Bid to Become World’s Largest Aluminum Miner
text: Rusal, a Russian miner controlled by billionaire Oleg Deripaska, agreed Friday to buy a 25 percent stake, worth about $13 billion, in OJSC MMC Norilsk Nickel and launch a takeover of the business that would create the world’s largest aluminum miner.

headline: Banks’ Big Fund to Prop Up Securities Is Scrapped
text: Some of the country’s biggest banks have pulled the plug on a plan backed by the Treasury Department to rescue troubled investment vehicles that were leveled by the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Porsche and VW: One Happy Family?
text: Porsche‘s takeover of Volkswagen – which began with a surprise 20 percent investment in 2005 and is likely to be completed with a majority stake next year – has inspired all sorts of bromides in the German news media: a David-and-Goliath tale, an audacious power play, a collision of mass and class.

headline: Marsh C.E.O.’s Exit Spurs Sale Chatter
text: Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance broker, said on Friday that it would replace its embattled chief executive, Michael G. Cherkasky, after a year of disappointing results. (Read the internal memorandums at Fortune’s Web site.)

headline: K.K.R. Launches $1.2 Billion Bid for U.K. Software Maker
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Friday unveiled a 593 million pound ($1.2 billion) offer for British human resources software maker Northgate Information Solutions despite recent concerns about its debt.

headline: Goldman Buys Stake in Troubled First Marblehead
text: Goldman Sachs on Friday agreed to buy a $260.5 million stake in First Marblehead, shoring up the troubled student-loan company and sending its stock soaring.

headline: Was Kleiner’s Thumb Less Green in 2007?
text: For Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, one of the leading investors in green tech and a partner with Al Gore, it hasn’t exactly been a completely smooth year, CNet News.com says.

headline: UBS Faces Scrutiny Over Write-Downs
text: Switzerland’s banking regulator will investigate how UBS ran up losses in the credit crisis requiring billions of dollars of writedowns, a spokesman for the body was quoted as saying on Sunday.

headline: Hedge Funds Take Stock of Bank Exposure
text: Hedge funds are scrutinizing their levels of exposure to bank defaults, in a telling reversal of conventional risk management concerns, according to a report in The Financial Times.

headline: Tattered Standard of Duty on Wall Street?
text: In his latest column in The New York Times, Ben Stein, the lawyer, actor and economist, takes another shot at Goldman Sachs for “betraying” its clients’ trust.

headline: Goldman Said to Top M&A League Tables
text: Wall Street powerhouse Goldman Sachs has done it again.

headline: G.E. to Buy Several Merrill Financing Businesses
text: Merrill Lynch, in an effort to raise cash amid mounting mortgage losses, agreed Monday to sell the majority of its capital finance business to General Electric for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Visa Debut Looms Large in 2008
text: Analysts predict that next year’s initial public offerings will include a steady stream of activity, including credit card issuer Visa‘s $10 billion I.P.O., Reuters reported.

headline: Me Blackberry, You iChat
text: People used to hand you a business card and announce their preferred method of communication. They’d say things like this: “The card has my e-mail, but I am much better by phone” or “Even though the office number is there, I really only respond by cell, so let me write it down.”

headline: The Early Word: Christmas Break
text: It’s questionable whether the candidates really will be taking a holiday respite this close to the Iowa caucuses, or if their Christmases will be full of behind-the-scenes strategy sessions. Democrats and Republicans alike tried to shake as many hands as possible, the last day before the brief break. The Times’s Jeff Zeleny writes that Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton hit the trail especially hard.

headline: A Presidential Science Debate?
text: If the 2008 presidential candidates are forced, kicking and screaming, to debate science, what questions should they be asked?

headline: The Ralph-Rudy Reference
text: A note on Ralph and Rudy:

headline: United Rentals Concedes Defeat in Cerberus Battle
text: United Rentals said on Monday that it will not appeal a Delaware judge’s ruling Friday that Cerberus Capital Management cannot be forced to complete its $4 billion buyout of the rental equipment operator.

headline: Obama goes Harry and Louise
text: A friend sends me this:

headline: Talking to Kids About Santa…and Everything Else
text: Raising a child means having a lot of difficult conversations. And this time of year, one of the toughest involves Santa Claus.

headline: Monday Kickoff: Bo Knows Two Jobs
text: Can Bo Pelini concentrate on stopping Ohio State’s offense as defensive coordinator of L.S.U. while also preparing to restore Nebraska’s tradition as the program’s new head coach? Cory McCartney of SI.com reports on the challenges Pelini is facing while he momentarily works two jobs.

headline: Merrill to Receive $6.2 Billion Capital Injection
text: Merrill Lynch said Monday it will take $6.2 billion in investments from the Singapore government and a mutual fund manager to shore up its capital base, as many analysts expect the investment bank to announce a second consecutive quarterly loss next month.

headline: Harrah’s Says Buyout Has Regulatory Clearances
text: Almost exactly a year after shareholders approved its $17 billion going-private transaction, Harrah’s Entertainment said Monday that it has received all the necessary regulatory approvals to complete the deal. Monday’s announcement sets the stage for the largest casino operator in the world to delist from the New York Stock Exchange and come under the control of Texas Pacific Group and Apollo Management, two private equity firms.

headline: Unofficial Candidate Carols
text: Here at The Caucus, we like holiday carols as much as the next person, but we like politics even more. That’s why we want to pass along a few, let’s say, alternate holiday songs about the candidates that we found online.

headline: Seeking Suggestions, and Offering Season’s Greetings
text: As 2007 draws to a close, so does the second month of Dot Earth. This 100th post is two things — a season’s greeting and a call for suggestions (more on the suggestions below).

headline: News Corporation Sells 8 TV Stations
text: Bloomberg News reports:

headline: For Capital, Merrill Looks East and West
text: The major source of Merrill Lynch‘s $6.2 billion cash infusion, announced Monday, was fairly unsurprising: Singapore. It is just the latest Asian country to invest in a troubled financial firm, following China’s decision to pour $5 billion into Morgan Stanley.

headline: While Visions of Fascism Danced in His Head
text: Ron Paul took a bit of heat the other day when he intimated that Mike Huckabee’s maybe-that’s-a-cross-maybe-it-isn’t Christmas ad had a whiff of fascism to it.

headline: Christmas, Asian Style
Ackman Raises Stake in Target
text: William Ackman may have taken a hit with his investment in Target, but it appears he’s raising his bets on the retailer.

headline: Oy, Kos
text: Markos writes:

headline: Smoke-Free French Cafes
text: France's coming ban on smoking in cafes suggests a slowly changing way of life -- and not everyone is happy about it.

headline: Silliest Argument, Hands Down
text: Christmas is here, and in the spirit of the season, I’m trying awfully hard to be charitable. But then I see Fred D. Thompson driving around Iowa in a newly-painted bus advertising his “The Clear Conservative Choice: Hands Down!” tour, and my charity flees faster, as Fred himself might put it, than a whitetail buck at an NRA convention.

headline: Diego Rivera in Mexico City
text: Images from a series of exhibitions celebrating the artist.

headline: 'Bindi the Jungle Girl'
text: Bindi Irwin, 9, whose father, Steve Irwin, was killed last year, is moving to claim his mantle with a TV show on Discovery Kids.

headline: Another Lump of Coal for Katie
text: Only one evening newscast, ABC’s “World News With Charles Gibson,” added viewers in 2007, Jacques Steinberg reports in a year-end television news review.

headline: MaxJet Files for Bankruptcy, Stranding Passengers
text: Maxjet Airways said on Monday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection, taking what the all-business class airline called a “drastic measure” because of soaring fuel prices and the deteriorating credit market.

headline: Bobsledding Toward 2008
text: Thanks to everyone for the lively and informative discussion about stores, especially to Llooped for the mention of the Louis stores in Tokyo, as well as the Prada shop (a favorite of mine for its landscape connections), and to Javiello for Moss (true, true), and Jennevive for the San Fran update. And, Georgianna, I couldn’t agree with you more about Kiliwatch in Paris. I first saw the name in a Paris Vogue caption and then went to investigate. The place is always mobbed with people (a good sign) and I often find oddball T-shirts and great jeans (for pretty good prices, I might add).

headline: Monday’s Links: Cleveland Loses Ugly
text: In a game that was anything but pretty, the Bengals played the role of spoiler during the Browns’ inspiring season. The Columbus Dispatch provides a slideshow of the game, which was more about who made fewer mistakes than who actually played better. Despite the ugly loss, Mary Kay Cabot of The Cleveland Plain-Dealer writes that Browns tight end Kellen Winslow is sure his team is superior to the Titans and should be in the playoffs.

headline: Morning Paper: ‘Couch Crunch,’ Time Warner Options, ‘Sopranos’ Ending
text: — With the late-night shows sidelined by the writers’ strike for another week, Hollywood publicists who have “long regarded late-night television as one of the most important marketing tools” for new movies are suffering from the “couch crunch,” Brooks Barnes reports in today’s Times. Morning shows and daytime talk shows have taken on even more importance.

headline: Unfit to serve
text: That’s me I’m talking about.

headline: An Och-Ziff Underwriter Shows Wariness of Stock
text: A Citigroup analyst left a lump of coal for Och-Ziff Capital Management, the hedge fund that went public last month. The analyst, Prashant Bhatia, began covering the fund with a “hold” rating, writing in his research note that Och-Ziff might be facing headwinds for the forseeable future.

headline: LVMH Closes Deal to Buy Les Echos
text: French luxury goods company LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton said Monday it had concluded a deal with Britain-based media group Pearson to buy France’s leading financial newspaper Les Echos.

headline: Ratings: Gambling and Sports Top Godliness
text: The finale of ABC’s week-long series “Duel” earned a disappointing 6.1 million viewers on Sunday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, and ABC ranked third for the night in the ratings. “Duel” was a game show that asked contestants trivia questions and gave them poker-style chips with which to bet on the certainty of their answers.

headline: Questions We Thought, But Didn’t Ask, in 2007
text: If the local cable company’s customer service phone help line always has “longer than expected” hold times, when does it ever have “shorter than expected” hold times?

headline: A Few More Questions
text: 1) Are we about to enter 2008: “The year of the in-flight fistfight caused when the person next to you spends four hours from San Francisco to New York talking loudly on the cellphone about his/her dating habits/pet’s grooming needs/excitement over the availability of airplane WiFi?”(We are open to a shorter title).(1b) Have I had my last peaceful nap on an airplane?

headline: Atomic Wedgie: Better to Watch Than Receive
text: FremantleMedia, the production company behind “The Price Is Right” and the British version of “American Idol,” wants to cash in on recent interest in Web-to-television programming deals.

headline: Notable Scenes From the YouTube Election
text: In her Web column today, Katharine Q. Seelye creates a personal Top 10 list of the most indelible images from a year that developed its own political video idiom, including the “1984” mash-up, the crush on Obama and more.

headline: Raising the Roof
text: So if Santa were to pay our house a visit tonight, he wouldn’t find much of interest, except the newly completed roof. Only trouble is, you can’t see the roof in the photo, which was taken from the street.

headline: An Unusual Friendship
text: Despite a significant language barrier, Soung Oo and Dante forged a best friendship.

headline: More Questions We Thought, But Didn’t Ask, in 2007
text: Are we living in a Google World, where everything is free thanks to the advertising that can be generated by people using the Google tools?

headline: The Greatest Christmas Present: An Easy Flight
text: In terms of air travel, right now, Christmas Day, is the calm eye of the holiday travel storm. Almost everyone who hoped to get away has left the airport by today. And everyone who hopes to get back will probably wait to travel tomorrow.

headline: Justifiable Waterboarding?
text: “No one should be prosecuted for waterboarding Abu Zubaydah,” insists Mark Bowden, the “Black Hawk Down” author, in the Philadelphia Inquirer.

headline: North Pole Listing
text: “Sumptuous villa” in icy paradise. Includes private pool, Swedish sauna, large workshop and panic room. Great investment opportunity. Plenty of room for support elves. View the full listing here.

headline: No Easy Button for Roberts
text: There’s an Easy Button on the desk of St. John’s Coach Norm Roberts. It’s a gag playing off those Staples commercials, where the Easy Button is pressed and office supplies –- or whatever one needs –- magically appear.

headline: News Unlikely to Fill TV Strike Holes
text: News programming has proved to be unpopular on network television, even as the writers’ strike creates holes in prime time schedules, the Associated Press reports:

headline: In Chinatown, a Church Speaks in Several Languages, but With One Strong Voice
text: At the church, pots of red and white poinsettias were carefully arranged for midnight Mass. With the funeral service for an 82-year-old Irish-American parishioner completed in the morning, the Italian-American priest spent part of his afternoon on Monday reviewing his homily, to be delivered in Cantonese and English. A sign announcing a Christmas Eve vigil for Fujianese immigrants was taped to the window.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Tuesday about a lawsuit over two Picassos at the Guggenheim Museum and the Museum of Modern Art once owned by Paul von Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, scion of a wealthy Jewish family of philanthropists and financiers, included an erroneous spelling from MoMA for the maiden name of Mendelssohn-Bartholdy’s second wife, to whom he gave his art collection, and misspelled her married name after a subsequent marriage. She was Elsa Lucy Emmy Lolo von Lavergne-Peguilhen, not Lavergue-Peguilhen, and later became the Countess von Kesselstatt, not Kesselstat.

headline: The Lure of Treatments Science Has Dismissed
text: The ailing millions who spend their money on unorthodox medical treatments may differ in their preferences for powders vs. needles vs. the sound of cracking bones, but they do share a single mantra: “I don’t care what the studies say; it works for me.”

headline: WNET Adds Indie Films on Saturday Nights
text: For years WNET, Channel 13, in New York has broadcast back-to-back classic movies on Saturday nights, drawing some of its largest audiences of the week. Beginning on Jan. 5, this public television station will drop the second classic film and add independent and short films to the lineup, turning its movie night into an interactive experience catering to filmmakers and those who like to discuss what they have watched.

headline: Jay-Z to Quit His Day Job as President of Def Jam
text: After an unusual three-year turn in the corporate suite, Jay-Z, the rap superstar, said Monday that he would step down from his post as president of Def Jam Recordings, one of the world’s best-known record labels.

headline: Markets Up After a Deal by Merrill
text: Shares rose on Monday after a billion-dollar investment deal between Merrill Lynch and the Singapore government raised hopes that wealthy foreign investors would come to the rescue of America’s ailing investment firms.

headline: Telling It Like It Is to the N.F.L. and Cable TV
text: Hello again, everyone, this is Howard Cosell, speaking of the NFL Network  and of Saturday night’s New England-Giants game in the swampland that is the New Jersey Meadowlands.

headline: Oscar Peterson, 82, Jazz’s Piano Virtuoso, Dies
text: Oscar Peterson, whose dazzling piano playing made him one of the most popular jazz artists in history, died on Sunday night at his home in Mississauga, Ontario, outside Toronto. He was 82.

headline: Italian Cement Maker Spurns Mafia
text: ROME (Bloomberg News)  Italcementi S.p.A., Italy’s biggest cement company, plans to suspend its Sicilian operations as a protest against extortion payments to the Mafia.

headline: When Private Struggles Become Public Displays
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  “I’m taking up valuable space and worthy subsidies to keep me alive. So why don’t I just pass it off to someone else and just exterminate my life?”

headline: Georgia School as a Laboratory for Getting Along
text: DECATUR, Ga.  Parents at an elementary school here gathered last Thursday afternoon with a holiday mission: to prepare boxes of food for needy families fleeing some of the world’s horrific civil wars.

headline: Giving Felons a Future
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ghost of East Village Past Shows Up for Christmas
text: As the spreading infestation of skyscrapers cast long shadows over the East Village, an ember of a vanishing sensibility burned bright Saturday at P.S. 122: “500 Clown Christmas,” from a Chicago troupe combining music, clowning and acrobatics, was in raucous motion.

headline: Wyeth Hit by Generic Competition and Regulatory Setback
text: Shares in Wyeth fell sharply on Monday after its heartburn medicine attracted generic competition and American regulators delayed its experimental drug for preventing bone loss.

headline: Cancer Returns, and the Bills Pile Up
text: Elida Fernández, 53, is spending her first Christmas away from the Dominican Republic, her homeland. Unfortunately, this holiday season is not a joyous one for her, nor for her daughter Judy Gabot, 30, who is working two jobs in an effort to keep her mother alive.

headline: Ruling Against Defense in Wiretapping Case
text: A federal judge on Friday rejected a flurry of motions by lawyers for the private investigator Anthony Pellicano, below, and his co-defendants in the long-running Hollywood wiretapping and racketeering case. With a trial set for Feb. 27, defense lawyers have questioned the F.B.I.’s search warrants, seeking to suppress evidence, including audio recordings seized from Mr. Pellicano’s Sunset Strip office, and to have the case dismissed on grounds of government misconduct. A lawyer for Terry Christensen, the lead partner of a major entertainment law firm, asked Judge Dale S. Fischer of United States District Court to toss out audio recordings of Mr. Christensen discussing wiretaps with Mr. Pellicano, arguing that the electronic folder containing the recordings had an innocuous title and thus investigators should never have opened it. But the judge rejected that and every other argument made by the defense, writing in one of several rulings that “There is no merit to the motions.”

headline: The Order of the Universe (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Birthing: Elective Caesareans Tied to Breathing Problems
text: Babies delivered by elective Caesarean sections are significantly more likely to have respiratory problems than those delivered vaginally or by emergency surgery, a new study finds.

headline: At Christmas, Iraqi Christians Ask for Forgiveness, and for Peace
text: BAGHDAD  Inside the beige church guarded by the men with the AK-47s, a choir sang Christmas songs in Arabic. An old woman in black closed her eyes while a girl in a cherry-red dress, with tights and shoes to match, craned her neck toward rows of empty pews near the back.

headline: The Sidney Awards
text: Every year, The Sidney Awards go to the authors of the best magazine essays, and every year the psychic costs grow worse. The Sidneys have become so prestigious and life-altering that the winners know that everything they produce hereafter will be anticlimactic. Some crack up  F. Scott Fitzgerald style  others simply endure a long, slow slide from the summit back to obscurity.

headline: In This Economy, the Loser Is ...
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Happy Holiday Greeting From Ma’am
text: LONDON  Seventy-five years ago, courtesy of what he referred to as “the marvels of modern science,” King George V became the first British monarch to broadcast a message to his subjects at Christmastime via the radio.

headline: N.C. State Guard Out for Season
text: North Carolina State point guard Farnold Degand is out for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee. Degand, a sophomore, had started all 10 games for the Wolfpack (7-3) this season and was averaging 6.9 points, 3.2 rebounds and 28.6 minutes. He led the Wolfpack in assists and 3-point shooting.

headline: Officials Falling Behind on Mortgage Fraud Cases
text: The number of mortgage fraud cases has grown so fast that government agencies that investigate and prosecute them cannot keep up, lenders and law enforcement officials have said.

headline: When the Senses Become Confused
text: One morning seven years ago, Sherrilyn Roush woke to discover that the left side of her body had gone numb.

headline: Curry and Randolph May Be One Big Man Too Many
text: Nate Robinson had seen enough, and he wanted out  away from the chaos, the congestion and the cameras. His locker stall, squeezed between those of Eddy Curry and Zach Randolph, was prime territory for reporters staking out the Knicks’ burly big men. The nightly swarm had become intolerable.

headline: The Giants May Rest, but the Debate Will Not
text: Tom Coughlin suspected he would face some tough questions this week. Had his Giants lost to the Bills on Sunday, they would have been desperately preparing for a game on Saturday night against the undefeated Patriots, perhaps needing a victory for a playoff berth, with the accompanying anxious speculation over their coach’s fate.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Statues of Hindu God Stolen

headline: Football Leads the Night
text: “Sunday Night Football” lifted NBC into first place on Sunday, followed by CBS, which benefited from an overrun of its own football coverage into the 7 p.m. hour. Directly after football, CBS’s “60 Minutes” and then “The Amazing Race” delivered approximately 12.8 million and 8.3 million viewers, respectively, Nielsen estimated. Later in the night, CBS’s two-hour special, “In God’s Name,” drew just 3.8 million viewers. ABC ranked third, as the finale of its week-long series “Duel” earned a disappointing 6.1 million viewers. After “Duel” at 8, ABC’s broadcast of the movie “The Santa Clause II” averaged 8.7 million viewers from 9 to 11. Just 4.6 million tuned in to Fox for “Spiderman II” from 7:30 to 9. Fox finished fourth over all.

headline: Uconn Women Back at No. 1
text: After an absence of nearly four years, the Connecticut women’s basketball team is back at No. 1 in the rankings. The Huskies received 49 of the 50 first-place votes in the Associated Press poll after being No. 2 all season. Tennessee had been No. 1 since the preseason poll, but lost to Stanford, 73-69, in overtime Saturday night.The Lady Vols fell to No. 3. Stanford received the other first-place vote, moving to No. 2 from No. 5.Connecticut last held the top spot Feb. 23, 2004. The time away from the top ranking was the longest drought in Coach Geno Auriemma’s career, since Connecticut first reached No. 1 on Jan. 17, 1995. Connecticut has now held the top spot 95 times. Only Tennessee has held it more. The Huskies (9-0) have been winning by an average of 40 points this season.

headline: Fearsome Nessie Started Out as a Good Egg and Playmate
text: Many lonely children yearn for a pet to call their own. In “The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep,” based on a novel by Dick King-Smith, a boy, Angus (Alex Etel), finds not only that, but a best friend as well, after the mysterious egg he stumbles across hatches a creature unlike any he’s ever seen. Adorable and full of mischief, his new companion, Crusoe, who looks something like a cross between a dinosaur and a snail, immediately adds spice to his drab life.

headline: A Life Turning Around
text: At just 17, Jay supports himself by working two jobs. He tries to keep his little brothers out of trouble, and he calls his mother “my first love.” To protect him, we cannot tell you his last name, because when he was 12, he yielded to heavy recruitment and joined a gang in the rough section of Brooklyn where he grew up. Today, Jay is working and studying as hard as he can to build a full, new life. The gang has not forgiven him for leaving.

headline: Regional Carrier Sold
text: Air France-KLM Group, the world’s largest airline, agreed to buy the regional carrier VLM Airlines to expand its business travel to London. Air France is buying the airline from Panta Holdings.

headline: Singapore: Temasek Raises Stake
text: Temasek Holdings, the biggest shareholder in Standard Chartered, increased its stake in the British bank to 18 percent, increasing the financial services investments in its $100 billion portfolio. Temasek bought 12 million shares of Standard Chartered, raising its holding by one percentage point, the bank said in a filing. Standard Chartered gets most of its profit from Asia and spent more than $2.7 billion since 2006 on acquisitions, including Hsinchu International Bank in Taiwan and Union Bank Ltd. in Pakistan. The shares purchased by Temasek, worth £220 million ($436 million), lift the total holding to 253.7 million shares.

headline: Sharks Forward Arrested
text: San Jose forward Ryane Clowe was arrested early Monday morning on suspicion of drunken driving in Los Gatos, Calif. Clowe, who has been out of the lineup after having knee surgery, is the second Sharks player in two seasons to be arrested on that charge, despite a policy to reimburse Sharks players or staff members for a taxi or car service if they need transportation.

headline: Conserving Cuba, After the Embargo
text: Through accidents of geography and history, Cuba is a priceless ecological resource. That is why many scientists are so worried about what will become of it after Fidel Castro and his associates leave power and, as is widely anticipated, the American government relaxes or ends its trade embargo.

headline: Jets’ Answers Are Familiar Refrain After Latest Loss
text: At the beginning of Coach Eric Mangini’s conference call Monday, every sentence came out twice. This was not because Mangini used his pet phrases  “collective effort” and “each season is different” and “we don’t discuss injuries”  but because of an echo on the phone line.

headline: Switzerland: UBS Examined
text: The country’s banking regulator is planning to find out how UBS racked up $10 billion in write-downs related to the subprime lending problems in the United States. “We have to look how the situation got so far” into a loss, a spokesman for the Federal Banking Commission, Alain Bichsel, said. “It’s our job.” On Dec. 10, UBS announced the largest subprime write-downs by any European bank and said it would raise $16.8 billion to improve its financial strength. Mr. Bichsel said that the bank’s response to the losses was “very good” and that UBS would not face an “investigation in the legal sense.” There is no evidence of any wrongdoing by UBS, Europe’s largest bank by assets, he added. A spokesman for UBS, Serge Steiner, declined to comment.

headline: Hurting U.S. Research Labs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thai Party Says It Can Form Coalition
text: BANGKOK  A party that backs former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra said Monday that it had made alliances with enough other parties following parliamentary elections Sunday to form a coalition government.

headline: Merrill Lynch Sells Stake to Singapore Firm
text: Merrill Lynch became the latest Wall Street bank to grab a financial lifeline from a foreign government, agreeing on Monday to sell $5 billion of new stock to an investor from Singapore and a smaller stake to a domestic firm, as the fallout from mortgage mess continues to spread.

headline: Tolling Against Executions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Food Scarcity and H.I.V. Interwoven in Uganda
text: MBARARA, Uganda  At the AIDS clinic here, the stories are brutal. A young cattle herder, infected with H.I.V. along with his wife, tells me that all four of their children died before turning 3.

headline: Wallace, Fan of Clemens, Becomes His Questioner
text: Mike Wallace has been a correspondent for CBS’s “60 Minutes” for the past four decades and more recently has taken on a reduced role, with the weekly news show now describing him as a correspondent emeritus.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about Jacob Zuma, the man who is considered likely to be South Africa’s next president, described the country’s political system incorrectly in some editions. It is a democracy dominated by one party, not a “one-party democracy.”

headline: Uzbekistan: Leader Wins New Term
text: Islam A. Karimov won a third seven-year term as president with 88 percent of the vote in weekend voting, Uzbek election officials said. The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said that the contest failed to give the population a true choice and noted that all three of Mr. Karimov’s opponents publicly endorsed him. Mr. Karimov has led the ex-Soviet state of 28 million people since 1989. He was technically barred from seeking another term under the Constitution, but election officials dealt with the issue by simply ignoring it, or by contending that the country’s various referendums  the last in 2002 extending the presidential term to seven years from five  left Mr. Karimov with a clean slate.

headline: Restructuring Aims to Give Canada’s Debt Market a $33 Billion Lift
text: OTTAWA  A tentative restructuring agreement should unlock a $33 billion portion of Canada’s debt market that has been frozen since August, its chief architect said on Monday.

headline: Israel Won’t Prosecute for Use of Cluster Bombs in Lebanon
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli military prosecutors announced Monday that they would not press charges over the army’s use of cluster bombs during the war against Hezbollah guerrillas in Lebanon, actions that had been widely criticized by human rights organizations.

headline: Britain: A Drop in Home Prices
text: Home prices in Britain fell the most in three years in December, and the threat of more declines may cause the property market to seize up in 2008, said Hometrack Ltd., a London-based research group. The average cost of a home in England and Wales slipped for a third month, dropping 0.3 percent to £175,200 ($348,350). “The second half of the year has seen a major reversal in confidence,” Richard Donnell, director for research at Hometrack, said in a statement. “Just as the financial markets have faced a liquidity squeeze, so the housing market is in danger of facing its own liquidity squeeze.” Prices increased 3 percent from a year earlier, the least in 18 months, Hometrack said.

headline: ‘Better Arrests’ in New York Decoy Program After Officers Receive More Training
text: Earlier this year, prosecutors in Manhattan and the Bronx grew concerned over some arrests stemming from the Police Department’s Operation Lucky Bag, in which an undercover officer leaves an item in the subway to see if someone will take it.

headline: A Master of Motion Learns Lessons of Inspired Immobility
text: In the last of the four one-act plays by Samuel Beckett currently at New York Theater Workshop, Mikhail Baryshnikov sits on an iron bed in a tatty red plaid bathrobe for 17 minutes, not moving or speaking, as a voice recites the thoughts that relentlessly taunt him. A close-up of his face is projected on a giant scrim, shrinking the already intimate space between the audience and the man.

headline: For Christmas Joy, a Cure?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Dec. 11 about the effort to develop a malaria vaccine using live, weakened parasites grown in mosquitoes misstated the role of Dr. Ruth S. Nussenzweig in earlier discoveries leading to the vaccine. Along with Dr. Jerome Vanderberg and other scientists, Dr. Nussenzweig was a co-author of a 1967 paper showing that the vaccine worked in mice; she was not a co-author of several papers from the 1970s showing that the concept worked in humans.

headline: Whatever Game’s Integrity, Fans Show Up
text: Major League Baseball has always had its doomsayers. Well, maybe not always, but certainly in the past several decades. For one reason or another, baseball has been a dying sport. Except it has never died. And it’s not about to die now because of the Mitchell report.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Saturday about Barry Bonds’s desire to keep his legal team intact for his perjury and obstruction of justice case despite potential conflicts of interest referred incorrectly to the professional relationship between his lead lawyer, Allen Ruby, and a surgeon for Mr. Bonds who could be called to testify. Mr. Ruby was a lawyer for the surgeon, Dr. Arthur Ting, for a month in 2005  not when Dr. Ting testified a year later before a federal grand jury hearing evidence against Mr. Bonds.

headline: A Threat So Big, Academics Try Collaboration
text: It is a basic tenet of university research: Economists conduct joint studies, chemists join forces in the laboratory, political scientists share ideas about other cultures  but rarely do the researchers cross disciplinary lines.

headline: Broadway Hit Captures Era, and Saves a Tailor
text: The bolts of cloth on display in the quiet showroom of Saint Laurie Merchant Tailors whisper the tones of serious business  dark blues, every shade of gray and brown, subtle stripes and plaids. You have to venture back into the adjoining suit factory to see the fabrics that scream “Showtime!”

headline: Fishing and Floating in Costa Rica
text: UPALA, Costa Rica  In Costa Rica, there are fishermen, and then there are members of the Club Nacional de Pesca.

headline: Surf’s Up, and So Is the Crime Rate on Baja’s Beaches
text: ROSARITO, Mexico  Surfers talk endlessly about waves  their size, their intensity, their roll. And crime waves are no exception.

headline: Recent Entries From Our Blogs
text: Dot Earth

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in The Arts on Monday with the continuation of a music column about national music identity and the annual Christmas show at Radio City Music Hall misidentified the scene for which some Rockettes were shown preparing backstage at Radio City. It was the Dance of the Toy Soldiers  not the “Nutcracker” scene, which does not include the Rockettes.

headline: Parents Defend School’s Use of Shock Therapy
text: Nearly a year ago, New York made plans to ban the use of electric shocks as a punishment for bad behavior, a therapy used at a Massachusetts school where New York State had long sent some of its most challenging special education students.

headline: A New Sensation in Iraq: Motor Scooters
text: BAGHDAD  Violence may be down in Iraq, but road rage is up.

headline: Price Range for Morgan Stock
text: SHANGHAI  Morgan Stanley, the investment bank, and the Chinese government said Monday that the bank had determined the range of prices to be used when China’s international investment fund converts $5 billion in securities into Morgan Stanley stock.

headline: Leading the Charge to Inspire Underdogs
text: Its steadfast humanity, its literacy, its passionate belief in education, its faith that history teaches invaluable lessons and its strong, emotionally grounded performances: There are enough things to admire about “The Great Debaters,” the heavily fictionalized true story of The Little Debate Team That Could, that your impulse is to forgive the movie its shortcomings.

headline: Mission to a Distant Comet (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Christmas Morning Comes
text: This is a simple holiday. Ask any child, or, better yet, ask yourself what you recall from your own childhood Christmases. Presents, yes, and shopping and decorations and the return of familiar songs and the smells of baking and perhaps the cadence of a few verses from the early chapters of Matthew and Luke.

headline: St. Nick in the Big City
text: ST. NICHOLAS was a super-saint with an immense cult for most of the Christian past. There may be more icons surviving for Nicholas alone than for all the other saints of Christendom put together. So what happened to him? Where’s the fourth-century Anatolian bishop who presided over gift-giving to poor children? And how did we get the new icon of mass consumerism in his place?

headline: In San Francisco, It’s Work to Find Toys
text: SAN FRANCISCO  This is the city of lost toy stores.

headline: To Provide Quality Music Education Now, Schools Could Learn From the Past
text: School’s out for the holidays, and it’s probably the last thing on anyone’s mind. But in the marginalized world of music education, a good deal of serious thinking needs to be done. Now that Charles Dickens’s Christmas ghosts have made their rounds for the year, perhaps they might be enlisted to provide perspective and encourage some soul-searching.

headline: On the Ground and in the Water, Tracing a Giant Wave’s Path
text: TEMPE, Ariz.  Next to the office of Harindra Joseph S. Fernando at Arizona State University is a 107-foot-long wave tank that can mimic oceanic motions.

headline: Footnotes
text: WKCR (89.9 FM and wkcr.org) began its annual Bach Festival on Monday morning. From Christmas Eve through New Year’s Day, the station dedicates its broadcast hours to the music and influence of Johann Sebastian Bach. ... For the second year running, “Songs From the Labyrinth,” a collection of lute songs by John Dowland performed by Sting, was the best-selling classical music album of the year, Billboard reported.

headline: Democrats Try to Rein In Fees on Consulting
text: It was the spring of 2004, and Senator John Kerry had just secured the Democratic presidential nomination. But as huge sums of money began pouring into his campaign, his top strategists had more on their minds than just getting ready for a tough race against President Bush.

headline: A Question of Blame When Societies Fall
text: As I pulled out of Tucson listening to an audiobook of Jared Diamond’s “Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed,” the first of a procession of blue-and-yellow billboards pointed the way to Arizona’s strangest roadside attraction, “The Thing?”

headline: It’s Downhill for Sleds, Lamentably
text: These are desperate times for sledding and its urban fans.

headline: Rivera, Fridamania’s Other Half, Gets His Due
text: MEXICO CITY  It’s easy to forget that at the height of Diego Rivera’s fame, in the 1920s and ’30s, he had star power. A Communist who painted murals for the great capitalists of his day, he offered an epic view of history and a cosmic vision of human potential. But in the last few decades here, his reputation has been vastly eclipsed by Fridamania, the cult status of his third wife, Frida Kahlo.

headline: The Silent Scream
text: Q. My dog is bothered by a sound my espresso machine makes that I cannot hear. And then there is that cellphone ring tone that kids can hear but older people cannot. Can your hearing be harmed by a loud, high-frequency noise you cannot hear?

headline: Zap! Make the Interview Part Jig, Part Bullfight
text: In journalism’s grocery store, the interview is found not among the staples but with the produce. It has a short shelf life. It wilts. What the politician, the police chief and the porn star have to say, even if startling, rarely startles for more than a week or so.

headline: District Trying to Forge a New Identity
text: A train thundered across the Manhattan Bridge, high above the wind-swept streets of Dumbo, where two young graphic designers were trundling a hotel-style luggage cart, loaded with laundry bags and cardboard boxes, toward their building.

headline: Louisville Center Healing Fast
text: The injured Louisville center David Padgett has been cleared to work out and could be back when the Cardinals face West Virginia next month, Coach Rick Pitino said Monday. Padgett, a fifth-year senior who fractured his right knee Nov. 18, was expected to miss up to 10 weeks and possibly the entire season.

headline: For the Lost and Stranded, Help From a Smiling Face
text: ONE of those long faces at the airport last week belonged to me. After my Continental flight from Tucson arrived late in Houston, I double-timed it across two terminals to make my connection.

headline: Giants Should Dream Big and Play for an Upset
text: Tom Coughlin can play it good and safe Saturday night, treat the last game of December like the first week of August. He can be the pragmatic professional, the staunch football conservative, deploy his starters for a series or two and give them the rest of a well-deserved game off.

headline: Court Ruling on Protests Curbs Malls in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The California Supreme Court ruled Monday that privately owned shopping malls cannot stop protesters from demonstrating there to urge a boycott of one of the tenants.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the selection of a new leader by the Liberal Democrats in Britain misstated the span over which the country’s two main parties have dominated the government. Since 1922  not 1992  every British election has been won by either Labor or the Conservatives. (Go to Article)

headline: Two Shot, One Fatally, at a Party in Bronx
text: Five people were killed in four separate shootings in the Bronx and Brooklyn on Monday, the police said.

headline: African Players Choose Club or Country
text: Every two years, as the start of the African Cup of Nations tournament approaches, coaches and club officials throughout Europe whine, gnash their teeth and lament the departure of their African players.

headline: Rhode Island Men Return to Poll
text: Rhode Island made it into the Associated Press men’s college basketball poll for the first time in nine years, entering at No. 25 after the program’s best start since the 1991-92 season. The Rams (11-1) were last ranked briefly in November 1998.For the fourth consecutive week, North Carolina, Memphis and Kansas were the top three teams in the rankings. Losses last week by No. 4 Texas, No. 5 Georgetown and No. 6 Duke moved Washington State (11-0) up three spots to No. 4, the highest ranking in team history.

headline: Brain Cells, Doing Their Job With Some Neighborly Help
text: A region deep in the brain called the hippocampus tracks, sorts and stores the onslaught of information pouring through the senses every waking minute. A large question in neuroscience is one a kindergartner would ask: How?

headline: Arecibo Radio Telescope Is Back in Business After 6-Month Spruce-Up
text: Its future may be uncertain, but if the Arecibo radio telescope in Puerto Rico is headed into mothballs it will go there with a fresh coat of paint.

headline: Sleep’s Restorative Value (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Albany G.O.P. Plans Inquiry on Reports of Purged E-Mail by the Administration
text: The State Senate investigations committee will hold hearings next month as part of an inquiry into claims that the Spitzer administration has been deleting electronic records, including e-mail messages, the committee’s chairman said Monday.

headline: Spread of Mumps Is Feared After Maine Reports Cases
text: BOSTON  State health officials across New England are on alert after dozens of cases of mumps have been confirmed or suspected in Maine.

headline: Pope Makes Appeal to Protect the Environment
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI reinforced the Vatican’s growing concern with protecting the environment in the traditional midnight Christmas Mass on Tuesday, bemoaning an “ill-treated world” in a homily given to thousands of pilgrims here in the seat of the world’s billion Roman Catholics.

headline: Insights: Clinical Trials May Not Represent Population
text: The randomized clinical trial, widely considered the most reliable biomedical research method, can have significant drawbacks, a new study suggests, because patients included may not be representative of the broader population.

headline: Professor Cites Bible in Faulting Tax Policies
text: At a time when some voters are asking how the religious views of candidates will shape their policies, a professor’s discovery of how little tax the biggest landowners in her state paid to finance the government has prompted some other legal scholars to scour religious texts to explore the moral basis of tax and spending policies.

headline: The Right Answer in New Orleans
text: New Orleans will never recover economically unless it attracts a work force large enough to drive the industries upon which the city has historically depended for its livelihood. Low-wage workers, in particular, are unlikely to return until the tens of thousands of rental houses and apartments that were destroyed by Hurricanes Rita and Katrina are replaced. To secure its economic future, the region needs an aggressive, farsighted plan for rebuilding the rental housing stock and creating more affordable housing.

headline: Michigan State Players Ineligible
text: Defensive end Jonal Saint-Dic and linebacker SirDarean Adams, both seniors, are among five Michigan State players who will sit out the Champs Sports Bowl on Friday against No. 14 Boston College because of academic or other violations.The Spartans said Monday that Saint-Dic was academically ineligible, along with wide receiver and return specialist Terry Love, wide receiver/cornerback T. J. Williams and offensive guard Abre Leggins. Adams violated unspecified team rules.

headline: Birds, Bugs Named as Steroid Users!
text: I am a baseball fan of the most fitful and narrow-minded sort. I love the Yankees, but really only when they’re winning, I hate the Red Sox, especially when they’re winning, and the other teams, as far as I’m concerned, can all go take a whiff.

headline: In a Flat World, a Rebel With a Cause
text: “Persepolis” is a simple story told by simple means. Like Marjane Satrapi’s book, on which it is based, the film, directed by Ms. Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, consists essentially of a series of monochrome drawings, their bold black lines washed with nuances of gray. The pictures are arranged into the chronicle of a young girl’s coming of age in difficult times, a tale that unfolds with such grace, intelligence and charm that you almost take the wondrous aspects of its execution for granted.

headline: Giving Till It Hurts
text: The public has rightly shown its empathy with wounded and troubled war veterans, contributing hundreds of millions of dollars to private charities that claim to have the veterans’ best interests at heart. A new study details rampant abuses of the money flow.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Critics’ Choice column on Monday, about new CDs, misspelled part of the title of the new CD by the German band Einstürzende Neubauten. It is “Alles Wieder Offen,” not Weider.

headline: Two Venerable Lighthouses Compete for One Genuine Lens
text: ROCHESTER  In the evening, the Rev. Thomas H. Wheeland likes to retreat to the back porch of his rectory at Holy Cross Church and look out onto Lake Ontario, illuminated by a wide beam of light from a neighboring lighthouse.

headline: A TV Doctor Who Travels Into Trouble
text: MY television series and work with various humanitarian organizations takes me to some of the world’s most remote and hazardous locations.

headline: States’ Widening of Health Care Hits Roadblocks
text: SACRAMENTO  A year that began with great ambition for major expansions of health insurance here and in other state capitals is ending with considerable uncertainty, as a second wave of change runs headlong into a darkening economy and political divisions over how to apportion the cost.

headline: On the Same Wavelength With the Doctor
text: My friend’s grandmother-in-law, at 94, has refused her son’s pleas to make a routine doctor visit. “‘Why should I go to the doctor?’” my friend recalled her exclaiming. “‘They don’t know anything anymore. You used to go to one doctor and he told you what was wrong and what to do about it. Now all the doctor does is draw vials of blood, order tests, and then tell you to go to another doctor.’”

headline: United Rentals Will Not Appeal Ruling
text: United Rentals said Monday that it would not appeal a Delaware judge’s ruling Friday that the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management cannot be forced to complete its $4 billion buyout of the rental equipment operator.

headline: Uzbekistan Re-elects Its President
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  President Islam A. Karimov of Uzbekistan won 88.1 percent of votes in the presidential election Sunday, according to preliminary results released on Monday by the country’s Central Election Commission.

headline: Researchers Find Animal That Links Whales to Land
text: Scientists who study evolution have long known that whales must have had ancestors that lived on land. Some characteristics were dead giveaways, most notably the fact that they are air-breathers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Hard Nut Cleans Up
text: Ovation TV’s Battle of the Nutcrackers has produced a winner. “The Hard Nut,” Mark Morris’s version of the classic Tchaikovsky ballet, received the most votes in online viewer polling. Ovation will replay all four versions of “The Nutcracker” featured in the competition in a Christmas-day marathon beginning at 8 a.m. Eastern time. In addition to “The Hard Nut,” there will be a filmed version of George Balanchine’s “Nutcracker,” featuring dancers from the New York City Ballet; a performance of “The Nutcracker” by the Bolshoi Ballet; and “Matthew Bourne’s ‘Nutcracker!’”

headline: Lost Star Goes to Jail
text: Michelle Rodriguez, the former star of “Lost,” will be spending the holidays in jail, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Rodriguez, below, reported to a Los Angeles County jail on Sunday to begin a six-month sentence for failing to complete community service and alcohol monitoring as part of her probation from a drunken driving incident, authorities said. She was booked into the Century Regional Detention Facility on Thursday, the same jail where Paris Hilton served much of her sentence earlier this year. Ms. Rodriguez received the sentence in October after she admitted violating her probation by failing to provide proof of community service and by drinking alcohol while wearing a monitoring device. She was on three years’ probation after pleading no contest to a hit-and-run, driving on a suspended license and drunken driving in connection with two incidents in Hollywood in 2003.

headline: Treatments: Talking Out the Choices for Breast Cancer Surgery
text: Two-thirds of general surgeons fail to mention the possibility of breast reconstruction before their patients choose between mastectomy and breast-conserving surgery, researchers have found. When that talk does occur, it sharply increases a woman’s willingness to consider mastectomy.

headline: Even Top Performers Have Flaws, and That Might Be a Good Thing
text: Don’t tell the piano teacher, but practice doesn’t really make perfect. A virtuoso musician may seem to nail every note, but actually there are tiny variations in even the most skilled performance.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $3,742,926

headline: The Comeback Kid
text: St. John’s forward Rob Thomas scored his first college basket last week. It came nearly 5,000 miles away, in an empty gymnasium during a Red Storm loss at a tournament in Hawaii.

headline: Memo Pad
text: HOLIDAY TRAVEL More than 65 million Americans will travel 50 miles or more from home during the Christmas-New Year’s holiday period, about the same as last year, AAA says. The automobile club said that that gas prices and air fares would be “well above last year’s levels.” Domestic air fares are averaging more than 15 percent higher than fares at the same time last year, and gas prices are up an average of 70 cents a gallon. Rates at midlevel hotels are 4 percent higher than they were at Christmas last year and 9 percent higher than at New Year’s. But average car-rental rates are 4 percent lower this Christmas and are expected to be 13 percent lower for New Year’s, AAA said.

headline: Doubts Engulf an American Aid Plan for Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Weeks before it is to begin, an ambitious American aid plan to counter militancy in Pakistan’s tribal areas is threatened by important unresolved questions about who will monitor the money and whether it could fall into the wrong hands, according to American and Pakistani officials and analysts familiar with the plan.

headline: On Ukrainian Screens, Say It in Ukrainian
text: A Ukrainian court on Monday banned the screening or distribution of all foreign films that are not dubbed or subtitled in Ukrainian, Agence France-Presse reported. The constitutional court said foreign films could not be distributed or shown if “they are not dubbed or post-synchronized or do not have the captioning data in the state language.” The move follows a campaign calling for a boycott of foreign films dubbed into Russian or carrying Russian subtitles. Ukraine, a former Soviet republic with 47 million inhabitants, is split over the language issue. In a poll released on Monday about 42 percent of 1,800 respondents said Ukrainian should be the sole state language; 30 percent said Russian should be granted the same status.

headline: Juror in Long Island Killing Says He Was Pressured Into a Guilty Verdict
text: At 8 p.m. on Saturday, a jury deciding the racially charged manslaughter case of a black man who shot a white teenager last year was still “hopelessly deadlocked,” to use the term the jurors used earlier in a note to the judge.

headline: Hazards: More Transfusions Mean More Risk for Women
text: Women are more likely than men to die after heart surgery, and one reason may be the use of a common medical procedure: blood transfusions.

headline: Election Rules Complicate Kenya Race
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The fate of Kenya’s hotly contested presidential election could come down to a single slum.

headline: The Claim: Calories From Alcohol Go to Your Midsection
text: THE FACTS

headline: Snowstorm Sweeps Across the Midwest, Killing 19
text: CHICAGO  Ice storms, then a thick layer of snow and finally a raging, blinding wind paralyzed parts of the nation’s middle section over the weekend, stranding holiday travelers in roadside motels and shelters and leaving at least 19 people dead.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about a public offering by the software company NetSuite misstated its losses in the first nine months of 2006 and the year its chief executive joined the company. The losses were $26.9 million, not $27.6 million, and Zachary Nelson joined the company in 2002, not 2000. The article also misstated the company’s plans for some proceeds of the offering. NetSuite said it would retire the outstanding balance on an $8 million secured line of credit, not start paying it down.

headline: U.S. Doubts Kurds’ Claims of New Attack by Turkey
text: BAGHDAD  American military officials in Iraq said Monday that they had no operational reports that Turkey bombed northern Iraq on Sunday, contrary to Kurdish claims of Turkish airstrikes that day.

headline: New DVDs
text: WALT DISNEY TREASURES

headline: A Partridge, a Pear Tree, a Price Tag That Grows
text: Maids a-milking finally received a raise this year and gold prices jumped, a combination that made it more costly than ever to bestow the elaborate set of gifts from the classic holiday carol “The 12 Days of Christmas.”

headline: Teens and Decision Making (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the selection of a new leader by the Liberal Democrats in Britain misstated the span over which the country’s two main parties have dominated the government. Since 1922  not 1992  every British election has been won by either Labor or the Conservatives.

headline: Michael Kidd, Choreographer, Is Dead
text: Michael Kidd, the award-winning choreographer of exuberant dance numbers for Broadway shows like “Finian’s Rainbow” and “Guys and Dolls” and Hollywood musicals including “The Band Wagon” and “Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,” died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles.

headline: For Geezers Gone Wild, Too Little, Too Late
text: “The Bucket List” operates on the hope that two beloved stars rubbing their signature screen personas together can spark warm, fuzzy box office magic. I wouldn’t count on it. Stars or no, it is an open question whether audiences will flock to a preposterous, putatively heartwarming buddy comedy about two men diagnosed with terminal cancer living it up in their final months.

headline: When Faith and Work Are at Odds
text: Being away from family is an everyday occupational hazard for business travelers, but trips that mean missing a holiday at home  by design or by delay  are all the more vexing.

headline: Very | Julia Dunstall
text: (Billy Farrell/PatrickMcMullan.com)

headline: World Club Top 10: The Team in the Oldest Rink
text: It’s Christmas, and to hockey’s credit, there isn’t a game scheduled in a top league anywhere in the world. Which doesn’t stop us from compiling this week’s top 10, and behold, there in the east … a new No. 2 team: venerable Slovan Bratislava.

headline: Photographing Rockwell
text: Images from the works of Norman Rockwell and Kevin Rivoli.

headline: Tuesday’s Links: Chargers Put the ‘D’ in Denver
text: After a one-week reprieve, “Monday Night Football” was back to being a snoozer. The Chargers, determined to secure the No. 3 spot in the A.F.C., played inspired defense in a 23-3 victory over the Denver Broncos, their fifth win in a row. Playing only one half, LaDainian Tomlinson had his fourth straight 100-yard game and took over as the N.F.L.’s rushing leader (watch his highlights here).

headline: For the Moment | MTV Arabia
text: Sheikh Majed Al-Sabah, this week’s guest blogger on The Moment, is fashion royalty. Not only is Majed, as he is better known, a member of Kuwaiti royal family (his father is the first cousin of the emir of Kuwait; his mother is the emir’s sister), but he is a retail visionary, whose Villa Moda store in Kuwait is the crown jewel in a luxury company that now spans five countries in the region. In today’s post, he looks at the commodification of youth culture in the Arab-speaking world.

headline: Iowa Stocking Stuffers
text: Here’s what the Edwards campaign wants for Christmas:

headline: A New Topic for Debate
text: A group of scientists is making an unusual foray into presidential politics, calling on the candidates, Republican and Democratic, to hold at least one debate focusing on the environment, medicine and health, technology policy and other science-related subjects.

headline: The Box
text: HE couldn't move — he couldn't turn. He was awake but his feet were stuck. Something at the end of the bed was holding down the duvet, making it heavy.

headline: Myrrh
text: Now the water in the saucepan was off the boil my mother would turn, spluttering, from the can of kaolin she was about to apply to a boil on the back of my neck to clean

headline: Christmas Specials Include 24 Hours of ‘Miracle On 34th Street’

headline: The Letter Writer
text: G. P. Sawant, a professional letter writer in Mumbai, is a winner and loser due to globalization.

headline: From Around New York, Symbols of the Season
text: East Side: Dozens of little angels got their wings as costumed cherubs "flying" in procession at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, at East 90th Street and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. The children presented two Christmas Eve performances on Monday as part of the church's annual Family Christmas Pageant, re-enacting the Christmas story through scriptures and familiar carols.

headline: Oscar Niemeyer
text: Images of the architect's works.

headline: Hockey al Fresco
text: The forecast for New Year’s Day in Buffalo calls for “rain/snow showers” with a high of 36 F. Forget about Sidney Crosby, the first star of the N.H.L.’s Winter Classic between the Penguins and Sabres will be the weather forecaster.

headline: Buffett to Buy Marmon From Pritzker Family
text: Warren E. Buffett agreed on Tuesday to buy a 60 percent stake in Marmon Holdings, the industrial holding firm owned by the wealthy Pritzker family, for $4.5 billion with the goal of eventually owning the entire firm.

headline: Readers’ Questions: Alzheimer’s Disease
text: Five million Americans are living with Alzheimer’s disease, and at least 66,000 die of it every year, making Alzheimer’s the nation’s sixth leading cause of death. By 2050, as many as 16 million Americans may be afflicted, yet, as the Times reports, researchers have been unable to find even modestly effective treatments.

headline: USA-Kazakhstan at the World Juniors, LIVE. (Sort of.)
text: Wednesday at 10 a.m. Eastern time, the Times hockey blog will try its best to bring you a live description of the Team USA’s opening match at the World Junior Championship. The technical obstacles are many — the game will not be televised anywhere on the planet, and there will be no live English-language description of the play from anyone, though USA Hockey says there will be a live audiocast on its web site, which you can find here.

headline: They’re on to us!
text: Here:

headline: Fine Print | Poolside With Slim Aarons
text: Globalization may have been the buzzword of the nineties, but for a select few, the world was a very small place several decades earlier. Poolside With Slim Aarons (Abrams) gives a voyeuristic peek into the lives of the jet-lagged jet-set at play, in the days before budget airlines and package holidays. C.Z. Guest, Lilly Pulitzer, Peter Beard and Cheryl Tiegs make suntanned appearances, but the real stars are the locations: private summer residences in Palm Beach, Porto Ercole, Puerto Vallarta, Monaco, and Costa Smeralda, as well as famous hotels like Acapulco’s Las Brisas and La Concha, the Hotel du Cap in Antibes and Villa d’Este on Lake Como.

headline: Weekly Wrap: Facing Manning, and the Other Guy
text: Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic contributed to this notebook.

headline: 2007: Let’s Eat, Not Fuss
text: AS 2007 drew to a close and I ricocheted around the city to sample the latest crop of restaurants, I was struck by how seldom I found myself in stylish showpieces beseeching rapt attention, how often I visited humbler, more peculiar haunts. That’s where the buzz was. Much of the talent, too.

headline: Rich Get Richer, as Bergtraum Adds Transfers
text: Over the last decade, as Murry Bergtraum High of Manhattan dominated the Public Schools Athletic League in girls’ basketball, its rivals eagerly waited for its reign to end.

headline: Qantas Polishes Outlook as Industry Retrenches
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Just months ago, Geoff Dixon, the chief executive of Qantas Airways, was battling to restore his reputation after supporting a failed private equity bid for the airline.

headline: Will Smith Says He Was Misunderstood
text: Calling it “an awful and disgusting lie,” Will Smith, above, said through his publicist that he is angry with a newspaper reporter’s interpretation of comments he made about Hitler, The Associated Press reported. In an article published Saturday in The Daily Record, in Scotland, Mr. Smith was quoted as saying: “Even Hitler didn’t wake up going, ‘Let me do the most evil thing I can do today.’ I think he woke up in the morning and using a twisted, backwards logic, he set out to do what he thought was good.” The quotation was preceded by the reporter’s observation, “Remarkably, Will believes everyone is basically good.” On Monday the Jewish Defense League denounced the reported comment and urged movie theaters to stop showing “I Am Legend,” in which Mr. Smith stars. In his publicist’s statement, the actor said: “I am incensed and infuriated to have to respond to such a ludicrous misinterpretation. Adolf Hitler was a vile, heinous vicious killer responsible for one of the greatest acts of evil committed on this planet.”

headline: John A. Garraty, Historian and Trailblazing Biographer, Dies at 87
text: Prof. John A. Garraty, a historian who wrestled into print the gargantuan reference work American National Biography, which in 24 volumes and 20 million words tells the story of the United States through the life histories of thousands of its citizens, died last Wednesday at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y. He was 87.

headline: Brooklyn Man Is Killed in a Fast-Moving Fire
text: A 56-year-old man who neighbors said had been a heavy smoker died in a fire at his apartment in Brooklyn that might have been started by a lighted cigarette, the authorities said.

headline: Rash of Shootings, Some Fatal, From Brooklyn to the Bronx
text: Two teenagers who were fatally shot on a Brooklyn street on Monday were identified by the police Tuesday as the authorities investigated several shootings around the city. The teenagers, Robert Grant, 19, and Oliver Maitland, 16, were each shot in the head in front of a brownstone in the Fort Greene section, the police said.

text: The stretch of Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan used to be the homely cousin to the two strong shopping avenues that flank it: Broadway and Columbus Avenue.

text: A One-Size-Fits-All Solution, by Michael S. Barr, Sendhil Mullainathan and Eldar Shafir

headline: Frozen Rates, Falling Prices
text: Darien, Conn.

headline: Even if His Own Work Isn’t Broken, a Brazilian Architect Fixes It
text: What to do with our aging architectural heroes? What if their genius deteriorates and they begin tinkering with their own masterpieces?

headline: Turkey Says 150 Killed in Strikes on Rebel Kurds
text: ISTANBUL  Two Turkish airstrikes on Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq hit more than 200 targets and killed more than 150 rebels, the Turkish Army said Tuesday.

headline: Disease Brings Drastic Changes to Patients, and Stress to Family Members
text: Family members are sometimes shocked and mortified to hear a relative with Alzheimer’s disease blurt out uncharacteristic, awful remarks  swear words, racial slurs, bitter complaints about a spouse. Many cannot help wondering if the disease has peeled back inhibitions to expose an ugly side that the patient was repressing all along. Was he or she a closet bigot, unhappily married, pleasant on the outside but hostile underneath? Or should the harsh words be dismissed as random sparks from sick and dying brain cells?

headline: An American Primitive, Forged in a Crucible of Blood and Oil
text: “There Will Be Blood,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s epic American nightmare, arrives belching fire and brimstone and damnation to Hell. Set against the backdrop of the Southern California oil boom of the late-19th and early-20th centuries, it tells a story of greed and envy of biblical proportions  reverberating with Old Testament sound and fury and New Testament evangelicalism  which Mr. Anderson has mined from Upton Sinclair’s 1927 novel “Oil!” There is no God but money in this oil-rich desert and his messenger is Daniel Plainview, a petroleum speculator played by a monstrous and shattering Daniel Day-Lewis.

headline: Buffett Strikes a Deal With the Pritzker Family
text: Berkshire Hathaway, the firm controlled by Warren E. Buffett, said Tuesday that it would pay $4.5 billion for a controlling stake in Marmon Holdings, an industrial conglomerate owned by the Pritzker family, the prominent Chicago business dynasty.

headline: Gum That Won’t Stick to Shoes? It’s in the Works
text: BRISTOL, England  Terence Cosgrove, an unassuming professor in this western English town, imagined a world where chewing gum did not stick to sidewalks and shoes, theater seats or hair.

headline: Turkey Says Its Raids in Iraq Killed 150 Rebels
text: ISTANBUL  Turkish airstrikes on Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq have killed more than 150 rebels and hit more than 200 targets in recent days, the Turkish military said Tuesday, countering Kurdish claims that only a handful of people were killed in the attacks.

headline: The Ink Fades on a Profession as India Modernizes
text: MUMBAI, India  G. P. Sawant never charged the prostitutes for his letter-writing services.

headline: The Original Subprime Crisis

headline: Fighting Cancer Imperils a Family’s Togetherness
text: It’s hard to imagine now, but not long ago, Maurice Haines was a very large man.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 25 Near Refinery in Northern Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  At least 25 people were killed when a suicide bomber rammed his truck into a line of Iraqis waiting for cooking gas near a checkpoint outside the Baiji oil refinery in northern Iraq, the police said Tuesday.

headline: A Day for Peace (and Quiet) on the Ferry
text: Christmas is about families and friends reuniting, and there are few better facilitators of those reunions than the Staten Island Ferry, a lifeline for those who live in the city’s least accessible borough.

headline: Holiday Spending Is Weak, as Retailers Expected
text: American consumers, uneasy about the economy and unimpressed by the merchandise in stores, delivered the bleak holiday shopping season retailers had expected, if not feared, according to one early but influential projection.

headline: The Grinch Steals It
text: “Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas” was the top-grossing show on Broadway for the week ending Dec. 16, the most recent week for which figures were available, according to the League of American Theaters and Producers. The musical, whose limited-engagement run at the St. James Theater ends on Jan. 6, took in $1.57 million  down slightly from nearly $1.7 million for the same week last year, but still enough to qualify “The Grinch” (with Patrick Page, right, in the title role) as Broadway’s top earner for the week. “Wicked” was a close second, with a weekly gross of nearly $1.45 million, followed by “Jersey Boys” at $1.26 million, “The Lion King” at $1.12 million and “The Little Mermaid,” at $1.02 million. But it was a blue Christmas at the Cort Theater, where the critically acclaimed play “The Homecoming,” by Harold Pinter, earned just $165,000 and saw an attendance rate of less than 40 percent.

headline: Clemens Will Talk to Reporters
text: The lead attorney for Roger Clemens said Tuesday night that he and other attorneys working for his firm have begun their own investigation into allegations that link Clemens to the use of steroids and human growth hormone.

headline: Impressive Transformations
text: These older restaurants reviewed in 2007 made notable changes:

headline: Here, Kiddie, Kiddie: A Witch Is Cooking Up a Treat
text: Children were everywhere at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday afternoon for a special Christmas Eve matinee, the premiere of a new production of Engelbert Humperdinck’s “Hansel and Gretel.” As patrons entered the house, some children scurried up and down the stairs of the grand promenade, while others peered over the rim of the orchestra pit to watch the musicians warm up. As the house lights dimmed, and the Met’s low-hanging crystal chandeliers ascended to the ceiling, impressionable children applauded. Indeed, applause broke out all through the performance, especially when the plucky Hansel and Gretel pushed the glutinous Witch into the oven during the final scene.

headline: When Both Parents Suffer Dementia, Children Suspect It Is Also in Their Future
text: “I’ve seen a number of adult children that have not one but two parents with dementia,” said Dr. Daniel I. Kaufer, a neurologist and director of the memory disorders program at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. “It’s like the perfect storm of dementia care.”

headline: A Gambling-Fueled Boom Adds to a Church’s Bane
text: MACAO  At morning Mass in St. Anthony’s Church on Sunday, Lancelot Rodrigues, an 84-year-old Roman Catholic priest, can name just about every member of the congregation in the sparsely populated pews listening to his sermon in Portuguese. He keeps the service short, to about 30 minutes. He knows from years of practice that brevity brings better crowds.

headline: $23.88 Million Tax? That’s Life, Not Luxury, for Yankees
