headline: In the Absence of a Gene That Says ‘Yes’ or ‘No,’ the Value of One That Says ‘Maybe’ Is Questioned
text: Genes play a role in Alzheimer’s disease, but in most cases the role is not fully understood. In some rare forms of the disease, which start early in life, in the 40s or even younger, single genes have been identified that make Alzheimer’s inevitable. In affected families, genetic tests can predict who will become demented.

headline: A Jury Awards Millions to Toby Keiths Family
text: An Oklahoma jury has awarded the country singer Toby Keith, right, his mother and his siblings $2.8 million in damages in the death of Mr. Keith’s father, H. K. Covel, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Covel was killed in 2001 when his truck crossed a highway median and was struck by a charter bus operated by Rodríguez Transportes of Tulsa. Mr. Covel’s family initially suspected that Mr. Covel had lost control of his truck as a result of a seizure or some other attack. They later learned that another vehicle had bumped the truck into the bus’s lane. The verdict, which was returned last week, attributed the accident to the bus’s faulty brakes, which the company knew were in need of repairs, said the family’s lawyer, Greg Dixon.

headline: Home Prices Fall for 10th Straight Month
text: The decline in home prices accelerated and spread to more regions of the country in October, according to a series of private indexes released Wednesday.

headline: Israel and Egypt Spar Over Weapons Smuggling

headline: By Holding to Form, Texas Takes Execution Lead
text: This year’s death-penalty bombshells  a federal moratorium, a state abolition and the smallest number of executions in more than a decade  have masked what may be the most significant and lasting development. For the first time in the modern history of the death penalty, more than 60 percent of all American executions took place in Texas.

headline: A Celebration of the New Year Ushers in a Bit of Japan
text: SINCE Mariko Hashimoto arrived from Kyushu in 1987, she has adapted to daily life in New York. She uses broccoli rabe instead of aka takana (spicy mustard greens), shops in the Caribbean markets of her Washington Heights neighborhood for batatas rather than Japanese satsumaimo (yellow sweet potatoes), and has learned to love the local mofongo, the Dominican version of mashed plantains with lots of garlic.

headline: Jenny Holzer Makes Light of Poems and Beats Swords Into Paintings

headline: A One-Size-Fits-All Solution
text: WHILE the causes of the mortgage crisis are myriad, a central problem was that many borrowers took out loans that they did not understand and could not afford. Brokers and lenders offered loans that looked much less expensive than they really were, because of low initial monthly payments and hidden, costly features.

headline: The Résumé Factor: Those 2 Terms as First Lady
text: As first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton jaw-boned the authoritarian president of Uzbekistan to leave his car and shake hands with people. She argued with the Czech prime minister about democracy. She cajoled Roman Catholic and Protestant women to talk to one another in Northern Ireland. She traveled to 79 countries in total, little of it leisure; one meeting with mutilated Rwandan refugees so unsettled her that she threw up afterward.

headline: The 10 Best New Restaurants

headline: Pairings
text: AFTER a recent trip to Paris, I was haunted by a dish I had at Toustem, Hélène Darroze’s new Left Bank bistro. Snails in snail butter tucked into little brioche buns were irresistible, mainly because of the garlicky snail butter soaking into the bread.

headline: Happiness for Sale
text: If money can’t buy true love, at least it can pay for a nice dinner out. But what about happiness? In an editorial observer last month, I noted that many scholars studying happiness agree that it cannot: growing incomes don’t make happiness grow. Now there is some evidence that this time-honored conclusion could be wrong. Recent analyses of polling data on life satisfaction across the world suggest that countries may indeed become happier as they grow richer.

headline: Weighing Expansion as More Top Students Clamor at Ivy Gates
text: In the mid-1960s, when William R. Fitzsimmons was a student at Harvard, the college took in a freshman class of roughly 1,550, including students at Radcliffe, which it would eventually absorb. In the four decades since, the population of the United States has ballooned by two-thirds, applications to Harvard have tripled and Mr. Fitzsimmons has ascended to the job of dean of admissions and financial aid at Harvard, but this year’s freshman class is only about 125 students larger than when he was a student.

And let us not forget grandma, who holds long conversations with her cow and once met a 1,000-year-old cobra with a ruby in its forehead and a mustache on its albino face.

headline: Engaging a Distant Teenager With Extended Hours
text: THE PROBLEM When Andrew Coburn, a teacher at the Met High Schools in Providence, R.I., met his new ninth grader, a Cambodian immigrant, she spoke fluent English but read at a third-grade level. Her slender frame seemed to radiate depression. School, Mr. Coburn thought, seemed a place she wanted to get away from as soon as she could. Even if she lasted for four years of high school, she would have nine years of academic ground to cover. But first the teacher needed to get her to stay in school.

headline: The Work Remaining

Many people at the center of the scandal have fled Washington, and new laws and rules have been put in place making it harder to use prosecutors’ offices to win elections. Much, however, remains to be done, starting with a full investigation into the misconduct that may have occurred  something the American people have been denied.

headline: Little Tramps Mansion
text: The Swiss mansion where Charlie Chaplin spent his last 24 years is to become a museum dedicated to his life and the history of cinema, Agence France-Presse reported. The colonnaded Manoir de Ban, above, in Corsier-sur-Vevey, is set in a large wooded park, with views of Lake Geneva and the Alps. Under an agreement between the museum’s foundation and a group of investors from Luxembourg, the house will be turned into a museum at a projected cost of $30 million. The former staff quarters will become a 200-seat cinema, and the vaulted cellars will be transformed into a “Hollywood street,” complete with street lamps, from the 1920s. Until last year the home was occupied by Chaplin’s descendants. “Regularly people used to ring at the door to ask to visit,” recalled Michael Chaplin, one of Chaplin’s sons, who settled there with five of his seven children. “They came from China, Latin America, Africa.” The museum is scheduled to open at the end of 2009. Closer to home New York Chaplin-lovers can enjoy a new 35-millimeter print of “City Lights,” his 1931 classic, which opened yesterday at the Film Forum on West Houston Street in the South Village and runs through Jan. 1.

If they should lose to the no-doubt-resting-their-starters Cowboys, the Vikings and the Saints are standing by, ready for their close-up. headline: For the Moment | Who You Calling ‘Emerging’?
text: Sheikh Majed Al-Sabah, this week’s guest blogger on The Moment, is fashion royalty. Not only is Majed, as he is better known, a member of Kuwaiti royal family (his father is the first cousin of the emir of Kuwait; his mother is the emir’s sister), but he is a retail visionary, whose Villa Moda store in Kuwait is the crown jewel in a luxury company that now spans five countries in the region. headline: Does Too Much Green Lead to “Greenflation”?
text: It’s been a year of remarkable progress on climate change. Just about everyone, it seems, understands the link between carbon dioxide and global warming. headline: Should an Overdue Library Book Affect Your Credit Rating?
text: The Queens Library, the nation’s largest public library system in circulation, hired a collection agency 11 years ago to pursue late fines and track down missing materials. Anne Barnard and Jo Craven McGinty tally the results so far: $11.4 million in revenue, nearly half of that in fines. Borrowers who fail to return materials can be referred to a collection agency, then to a credit bureau — and have their credit scores damaged as a result.

headline: Wednesday Kickoff: Boosters for Rodriguez
text: The Wizard of Odds has highlighted an interesting story regarding the soap opera surrounding Rich Rodriguez’s departure from West Virginia. Last week, John Pruett, a sports columnist for The Huntsville Times in Alabama wrote a column that basically said boosters should not be a part of the hiring process for a coach. Pruett later received a call from Ken Kendrick, the managing general partner of the Arizona Diamondbacks and a prominent West Virginia graduate and booster. Kendrick was extremely critical of the Mountaineers’ athletic department, saying that incompetence and stonewalling had led to Rodriguez’s departure, not greed on Rodriguez’s account.

headline: Joe Biden, Briefly
text: One day last week, I drove down to Indianola, Iowa, to see Mitt Romney speak at a country club, then headed two and half hours northeast to the little town of Tipton, where Hillary Rodham Clinton held forth at the fairgrounds. Then I got back into car and drove north, toward Cedar Rapids, where I knew a lot of my colleagues would be going that evening for an appearance by Mike Huckabee. By then, though, I decided I’d seen enough standard campaign rallies for one day, so I turned right off Route 30, instead, and set a course for Marion, where the Nash family was throwing a house party for Joseph Biden.

headline: On Our Own Ignorance (and That of Many Others)

Bush is the most admired man and Sen. Hillary Clinton the most admired woman in Gallup’s annual survey. But neither winner had a very decisive win this year, with former President Bill Clinton nearly tying Bush and Hillary Clinton barely topping talk-show host Oprah Winfrey. headline: The N.H.L. Gets the Holiday Break Right, and Now Resumes…
text: As nice as it would have been to have a hockey game to watch the last two days, I like that the N.H.L. goes dark for two days over Christmas. My sentiments are less for the players — who are compensated well enough that holiday work is hardly too much to ask — but for the people who work in arenas across the country for more meager salaries. A few years ago, I covered an N.F.L. game on Christmas (in Detroit, no less) and watched as hundreds of folks directed cars in the frigid parking lot and pulled hot dogs from boilers and thought, this is so not a good way to make them spend a holiday.

headline: Editors’ Note: The Ron Paul Vid-Lash
text: A post in The Medium that appeared on Monday about the Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul and his purported adoption by white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups contained several errors. Stormfront, which describes itself as a “white nationalist” Internet community, did not give money to Ron Paul’s presidential campaign; according to Jesse Benton, a spokesman for Paul’s campaign, it was Don Black, the founder of Stormfront, who donated $500 to Paul. The original post also repeated a string of assertions by Bill White, the commander of the American National Socialist Workers Party, including the allegation that Paul meets regularly “with members of the Stormfront set, American Renaissance, the Institute for Historic Review and others” at a restaurant in Arlington, Va. Paul never attended these dinners, according to Benton, who also says that Paul has never knowingly met Bill White. Norman Singleton, a congressional aide in Paul’s office, says that he met Bill White at a dinner gathering of conservatives several years ago, after which Singleton expressed his indignation at the views espoused by White to the organizer of the dinner. The original post should not have been published with these unverified assertions and without any response from Paul.

headline: The Insider’s Outsider
text: Those of us who have been toiling in the salt mines of publishing for longer than we care to remember tend to lose sight of the fact that we weren’t always the ultimate insiders. headline: A Colony With a Conscience
text: THREE hundred and fifty years ago today, religious freedom was born on this continent. Yes, 350 years. Religious tolerance did not begin with the Bill of Rights or with Jefferson’s Virginia Statute of Religious Freedom in 1786. With due respect to Roger Williams and his early experiment with “liberty of conscience” in Rhode Island, this republic really owes its enduring strength to a fragile, scorched and little-known document that was signed by some 30 ordinary citizens on Dec. 27, 1657.

headline: Juliette Binoche in Iran
text: The French actress Juliette Binoche is visiting Iran in conjunction with her appearance in a new film by the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the INSA news agency. “When you work with someone, you have to know them,” said Ms. Binoche, above, who won the Academy Award for best supporting actress for her performance in the 1996 film “The English Patient.” Mr. Kiarostami won the 1997 Palme d’Or at Cannes for “A Taste of Cherry.” In his new film, “The Certified Copy,” being made in Italy, Ms. Binoche portrays a gallery owner enjoying a brief encounter with a British writer. “Iranians have come to the West for years,” Ms. Binoche said. “It’s about time Westerners came to Iran and got to know it.”

headline: Egypt and Israel Meet Over Arms Smuggling
text: Israel’s defense minister, Ehud Barak, met President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, amid tension over weapons smuggling from Egypt into Gaza. Earlier in the day, Egypt’s foreign minister, Ahmed Aboul Gheit, had complained about “the Israeli lobby’s efforts to harm Egypt’s interests with the Congress,” referring to moves to make some American military aid to Egypt conditional on its taking steps to stop the smuggling and protect human rights. After the meeting, Mr. Barak said, “Whenever we have points of dispute, we will discuss them through face-to-face dialogue in good faith.”

text: WASHINGTON (AP)  MF Global, the futures and options brokerage firm, agreed Wednesday to pay more than $77 million to settle federal charges that it had failed to watch over a hedge fund charged with fraud more than two years ago.

headline: G. P. Sippy, Indian Filmmaker Whose ‘Sholay’ Was a Bollywood Hit, Dies at 93
text: The Indian filmmaker and director G. P. Sippy, whose 1975 blockbuster “Sholay” (“Embers”) remains the most famous Hindi movie and the biggest commercial success for Bollywood, died on Tuesday in Mumbai. He was 93.

text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan and President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan signaled an improvement in relations between their countries after an unusually cordial meeting here on Wednesday and called for greater cooperation in fighting terrorism.

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: Kazakhstan: Airline Buys Jetliners
text: Air Astana, a venture between the Kazakh government and BAE Systems, agreed to buy nine Airbus and Boeing jetliners to help meet surging travel demand in Kazakhstan. The six Airbus A320s and three Boeing 787-8s have a combined catalog price of $950 million, Air Astana said in an e-mailed statement. Deliveries will start in 2012, it said.

headline: Bigger Stake in Pharmion
text: The investor Steven A. Cohen reported Wednesday that he had increased his stake in the Pharmion Corporation, a pharmaceutical company based in Boulder, Colo., to 7.1 percent, from 5.1 percent.

headline: French Aid Workers Get 8 Years Hard Labor
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Six French aid workers were found guilty on Wednesday by a court in Chad and sentenced to eight years of hard labor for trying to take to Europe 103 children who they claimed were orphans of the conflict in Darfur.

headline: Outlook Improves for Russian Art Show
text: Russia’s culture minister, speaking after reading a draft of a proposed British law to confer immunity on some contested works of art, expressed optimism that an exhibition of 120 French and Russian paintings lent by four Russian museums would proceed as planned next month in London, Agence France-Presse reported. The minister, Mikhail Shvydkoi, told the Itar-Tass news service, “I received a draft of the law from Britain, which gives a significantly greater chance for a positive resolution of the question and the holding of the exhibition.” Moscow had threatened to cancel the show, “From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925,” scheduled to begin on Jan. 26 at the Royal Academy of Art, unless the art could be safeguarded from lawsuits by descendants of some Russian collectors contending that the works were confiscated by the new government after the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. Britain then promised to accelerate passage of legislation offering guarantees. “The law offers the possibility to enter into serious negotiations on sending the exhibition to London,” Mr. Shvydkoi said. The art is now on view in Düsseldorf, Germany.

headline: Recline in an Easy Chair and Play Your Favorite Game, No Wires Dangling in the Way
text: Mention the name Phantom to any gamer and expect to hear a snicker of derision. The company, founded in 2002, once promised and never delivered a much-ridiculed game console that would download games from the Internet. Chastened, the company has returned with something less ambitious: a wireless keyboard and mouse kit for media and game PCs.

headline: Egypt and Israel Discuss Arms Smuggling

headline: Did Art Thieves Try, Try Again?
text: The police say that they suspect that the thieves who stole Picasso’s “Portrait of Suzanne Bloch” and Candido Portinari’s “Coffee Worker,” above, from the São Paulo Museum of Art last week are the same men who tried to break in at least twice previously, Bloomberg News reported. On Oct. 29 intruders overpowered two security guards, who did not have keys to the section of the museum where paintings are displayed. On Dec. 17 security guards chased away two people who were using a blowtorch to try to cut through a back door. The second incident was not reported to the police. Last week’s theft, carried out in three minutes, has led to calls for the Brazilian government to take control of the museum, which lacks an alarm system and where the collection, valued at more than $1 billion, is uninsured. The stolen Picasso is said to be valued at $50 million. “It’s appalling that anyone with half a brain would be able to walk into one of Latin America’s most important museums and steal a Picasso,” said Jones Bergamin, who runs the auction house Art Bourse in Rio de Janeiro. “The guardians of art in Brazil nearly invited these thieves to rob them.” Jose do Nascimento Jr., director of museums at the Institute of Heritage and National Arts in Brazil, said the country had the world’s fourth-highest number of art thefts, after the United States, France and Iraq.

headline: 4 Sunni Allies of U.S. Killed in Iraq

The violence, which started Monday with a dispute over public Christmas decorations, left at least 10 churches burned or vandalized. On Tuesday evening, a member of a Hindu nationalist group that has campaigned against conversions to Christianity was stoned to death.

headline: Protection for Endangered Whistle-Blowers
text: Congress is finally ready to stand up to the Bush administration and for those courageous federal workers who dare to reveal waste and abuse in government. The Senate has passed strong reforms to the 1989 whistle-blower protection law, counteracting the gag orders, retaliatory investigations and other harassments that have become shamefully standard practice during the last seven years.

text: The body of a man was found Wednesday on a handball court in a Queens park, where he was pronounced dead from what appeared to be stab wounds, the police said.

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: Nigeria: Pfizer Fights Jailings
text: Pfizer said it would fight a Nigerian court order that could jail three employees who had failed to appear at a trial over whether the company had improperly tested an experimental drug on Nigerian children. The employees did not receive summonses to appear at last month’s trial, Pfizer said. The state of Kano is demanding $2.75 billion from Pfizer, which it says used an untested meningitis drug in a 1996 outbreak. Pfizer has said its use of the drug obeyed government rules and saved lives.

headline: Some Orders That the Boss Should Heed
text: NEW YEAR’S resolutions tend to be discarded like old Christmas trees, and often just as quickly. But blaming ourselves for being weak only masks a larger problem. We don’t go to the gym or get home in time for dinner with the family because our lives contain too much stress and not enough time, and we, the workers of the world, cannot unilaterally change that.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Tuesday about the choreographer Michael Kidd misstated, in some copies, the year that he was given a special Academy Award. It was 1997, not 1996.

headline: Throwing the Book at Them
text: It turns out the library can do more than just shush you. If you accumulate enough unpaid late fees, some New York libraries are ready to hit you where it really hurts: your credit score. They have reported millions of dollars in such bad debts. Most people make good before their creditworthiness is damaged. But there is something chilling in this kind of threat from a library.

headline: Wonderful Life but So-So Ratings
text: Few tuned in for prime-time television programming over the Christmas holiday, and those who did were not necessarily interested in traditional holiday fare. Nielsen estimated that NBC led Tuesday night’s ratings with a special two-hour edition of “Deal or No Deal,” which averaged 9.8 million viewers from 8 to 10, but the network’s Christmas Eve broadcast of the classic 1946 film “It’s a Wonderful Life” fell just short of its competitors (4.5 million), giving NBC a second-place finish on Monday night in a tie with CBS among adults 18 to 49. CBS broadcast repeats of its regular Monday- and Tuesday-night lineups, leading on Monday in total viewers but trailing well behind on Tuesday. ABC got a lift from the computer-animated 2005 film “Madagascar” (4.8 million), which helped it eke out a victory on Monday with the 18-to-49 set. On Tuesday ABC’s broadcast of the 2003 movie “Pirates of the Caribbean” (5.5 million) put the network in a virtual tie for second with Fox’s lineup of reruns.

headline: Giuliani’s Doctor Says Tests Reveal ‘Very Good Health’
text: LARGO, Fla.  A week after a severe headache landed Rudolph W. Giuliani in a St. Louis hospital, the Giuliani campaign on Wednesday released the first statement from one of his doctors, who pronounced him “in very good health.”

headline: Hunt for Suspects in Mauritania Killing
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Law enforcement officials in Mali, Mauritania and Senegal were searching on Wednesday for three men linked to a North African affiliate of Al Qaeda and suspected of killing four French tourists in a Christmas Eve attack.

headline: 6 in Family Are Found Slain in Home Outside Seattle
text: SEATTLE  Six people were found shot to death at a home in a rural part of King County on Wednesday, and investigators arrested two people they said were responsible for the killings, law enforcement officials said. The victims included two children.

headline: North Korea: Hint at Slowing Disabling
text: North Korea indicated it would slow down the dismantling of its nuclear weapons program because of what it said was a delay in the delivery of energy aid it was promised as a reward under an international deal. The United States, China, Japan, Russia and South Korea had set a year-end deadline for the disabling.

headline: Bulldog With Attitude Has Big Freshman Year
text: ATHENS, Ga.  Georgia tailback Knowshon Moreno crashed into the line, and tempers flared.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An architecture column on Wednesday about Oscar Niemeyer and the impact his new work is having on some of his earlier work in Brasília, where he has created several masterpieces, misstated the name of a major roadway and open space in the city. It is the Monumental Axis, not the Ceremonial Axis. The column also misidentified the area where Brasília was built. It was a savanna, not a jungle.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about Broadway box office grosses for the week ending Dec. 16 referred incompletely to the gross for “The Homecoming,” at the Cort Theater. Although the play grossed just $165,679 and saw an attendance rate of less than 40 percent, it was in previews until Dec. 16. (In the week ending Dec. 23 its gross increased nearly 50 percent, to $247,572, and attendance was just over 50 percent of capacity, an increase of 30 percent over the previous week. )

headline: Lottery Numbers
Has Vitamin A. Needs a Martini.
text: SEVERAL cultures clash at the intersection of Broadway and Columbus in San Francisco’s North Beach. Right behind beatnik Mecca  the City Lights bookstore and the Vesuvio cafe  is Chinatown, authentic down to the hanging smoked ducks and unmistakable fish-feather-ginseng smell. Up Columbus Avenue, Italian restaurants beloved exclusively by tourists are forever dying and being born.

headline: Ruling Allows Wider Investment Options for Bloomberg and His Foundation
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, seeking to bolster his charitable giving, has reached a new agreement with the City Conflicts of Interest Board that will allow him to move his money into more aggressive investments, including hedge funds and publicly traded stocks.

headline: Feinsteins New Venture
text: Michael Feinstein is establishing an outpost in London. Mr. Feinstein, the singer, pianist and impresario of the Manhattan supper club Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, has entered into an arrangement to take cabaret artists to the 450-seat Shaw Theater in London under the name Feinstein’s at the Shaw. Mr. Feinstein will inaugurate the series himself, with a show called “An American in London,” from Jan. 6 through Jan. 11. On his Web site, michaelfeinstein.com, he wrote on Wednesday: “The vision for the Shaw will be similar to its New York counterpart and will present many of the multigenerational artists who are best appreciated in a more intimate theatrical setting, but it will also have a more Eurocentric flavor. We plan to present a Songwriters’ series, a Legends series and evenings of special tributes that will run the gamut of all different types of good music.” The theater is part of the Novotel London St. Pancras Hotel on Euston Road, next to the British Library and the St. Pancras train station.

headline: Tiger on the Loose: Can It Happen Here?
text: New Yorkers have plenty of reasons to be on edge when walking the streets, from armed thugs to reckless taxi drivers to aggressive hawkers.

headline: Fastest-Growing States Show Slower Expansion
text: The bursting housing bubble squelched expansion in some of the nation’s fastest-growing states in the year that ended July 1, according to an analysis of census figures released Wednesday.

headline: Fountain of Youth? Go Wash Your Face
text: IN my job as this newspaper’s resident beauty skeptic, I receive a lot of books about longevity with preposterous titles like “Stop Aging, Start Living,” “The New Anti-Aging Revolution: Stopping the Clock” and “The Science of Staying Young.”

headline: More NetSuite Sold
text: The software maker NetSuite and its investors have sold an additional 930,000 shares. The stock, which had risen 49 percent since going public Dec. 20, fell 6.6 percent on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Ruling Backs Benefit Cut at 65 in Retiree Plans
text: WASHINGTON  The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Wednesday that employers could reduce or eliminate health benefits for retirees when they turn 65 and become eligible for Medicare.

headline: Turkish Jets Strike Kurdish Rebels
text: ISTANBUL  Turkish warplanes attacked Kurdish rebel camps in northern Iraq on Wednesday, the Turkish military said, acknowledging its second cross-border airstrike this week and its third in recent days.

headline: Bush Condemns Assassination
text: CRAWFORD, Tex.  President Bush on Thursday condemned the assassination of Pakistan’s opposition leader, Benazir Bhutto, a killing that left in ruins the delicate diplomatic effort his administration had pursued for the last year to reconcile that country’s deeply divided political factions.

headline: Thomas Morgan, a Journalist and Activist, Dies at 56
text: Thomas Morgan III, a former reporter and editor at The New York Times who was a president of the National Association of Black Journalists, died on Monday in Southampton, Mass. He was 56 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: Bridging 2 Marriages and 4 Decades, a Large, Close-Knit Brood
text: Before Senator John McCain steps in front of an audience at a presidential debate, his daughter Meghan makes sure his nose is properly powdered. And from the campaign bus, Ms. McCain blogs about New Hampshire through the prism of politics and fashion (“I helped Dad pick out some swank Timberland boots.”)

headline: Shifting Coupons, From Clip and Save to Point and Click
text: COUPON lovers, take heart. The era of waiting, scissors in hand, for the Sunday newspaper circular is over.

headline: Therapists Are Leashed, but Affection Is Unbridled
text: With a jingle of tags and bells, Harley, Dolly, Feather and Bailey trot past a bank of poinsettias and into the Clove Lakes Health Care and Rehabilitation Center, a nursing home on Staten Island. The lobby erupts, as if rock stars just walked in.

headline: Belichick Puts Pads Away in Short Week for Patriots
text: From the files of intriguing coaching decisions, we have the New England Patriots.

headline: Beckett’s Bow to Ballet: A Dramatist With the Precision of a Choreographer
text: Anyone who sees Mikhail Baryshnikov in “Beckett Shorts,” the set of four brief plays by Samuel Beckett at the New York Theater Workshop, must reflect on how far this former ballet luminary has come from his training in Leningrad and his roles in the 19th-century classics. He is best known now as a star of the TV series “Sex and the City,” and the distance between that and “Beckett Shorts” is virtually as far. Part of his virtuosity has always dwelt in his need to elude definition or pigeonholing. His whole career has kept people asking, “Who is he really?”  which must be what he wants.

headline: It’s All About the Monroes
text: The United States Mint has announced the designs for the next four coins in its decade-long series of one-dollar coins featuring American presidents. James Monroe, the fifth president, will appear on Feb. 14, followed at three month intervals by John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson and Martin Van Buren. The Mint is also redoubling its efforts to get the public to use more of the dollar coins, which are the same size and color as the Sacagawea dollars first issued in 2000. A test program in the Washington, D.C., area is trying to encourage businesses to use more of the coins and is gathering feedback about why they might be resisting. The Mint turned out 800 million presidential $1 coins in 2007.

headline: Human Rights Activist, Jailed in Iran, Is Transferred to Hospital
text: TEHRAN  A prominent human rights activist who has been jailed since October was transferred to a hospital Wednesday, according to his wife and the news agency ISNA.

headline: Let Online Poker Continue

headline: New Jersey Requires H.I.V. Test in Pregnancy

headline: A Winter’s Tale, Told in Handy Tools
text: IT is always good to be prepared for a new season. Now that winter is here, a shovel that can be used to clear the walk without risking back injury, retrofitted stair treads that automatically melt snow and ice, and an inflatable castle for children to play in are all worth having on hand.

headline: Appeals Court Reinstates Patent Suit Against Google
text: Google must face a Wisconsin company’s lawsuit over a toolbar feature that generates Web links from search data, a federal appeals court decided in a ruling posted on Wednesday.

headline: Use a Paper Clip On Stuck Discs
text: Q. I have a DVD stuck in my computer’s drive. It will not eject using traditional methods, so how can I get it out of there?

headline: A Legacy of Audacity Is Granted an Encore
text: In his later years the flinty American composer Ralph Shapey, who died in 2002 at 81, would rail against the conservatism of the mainstream classical music scene in America. In fist-shaking defiance he wrote formidable, complex and ingenious works. And if people resisted, that was their problem.

headline: A Small Label Printer for Stickers on the Spot
text: For those who are still creating paper trails in the digital age, a new miniprinter might help. The Brother QL-570 Label Printer, due early next month for $99, pops out a wide variety of peel-and-stick labels with your own text and graphics.

headline: Tyson Rewards Top Executives After Return to Profit
text: Tyson Foods, the largest United States meat producer, increased the compensation of its chief executive, Richard L. Bond, fivefold and quadrupled the pay of its former chief, John H. Tyson, as the company returned to profit after a 2006 loss.

headline: Not a Ringing Endorsement
text: More than 500 e-mail messages, a couple of dozen phone calls and at least a handful of reader threats to cancel subscriptions have poured in since the editorial board of The Concord Monitor ran its scathing anti-endorsement of Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Both Jagr and Power Play Score Twice for the Rangers
text: The Rangers created plenty of fireworks in Wednesday’s 4-2 victory over Carolina  some good, some ugly  and generally turned an otherwise mild rivalry with the Hurricanes into a combustible night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.  Where can I find an old-fashioned radiator humidifier?

headline: A Woman of Ambition, Neither Hero Nor Villain
text: The writer of contemporary history is like the man with his nose pressed against the mirror trying to see his whole body, Arnold Toynbee cautioned. Yet whatever their limitations, books about prominent sitting officials are irresistible, partly driven by an insatiable public appetite for gossip about public figures and an interest in understanding and judging them.

headline: Documents of Library in Boston to Go on Web
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The historical record of the United States government will soon be more accessible.

headline: France: Vivendi to Buy Sports Concern
text: Canal Plus, Vivendi’s pay-television unit, said it had agreed to buy Occade Sport, an organizer of sporting events. Canal Plus will acquire all of Occade Sport’s shares from Gones & Sports by the end of February, Vivendi said. Financial details were not disclosed.

headline: Extra Points
text: Kansas City cornerback Ty Law told reporters on a conference call that when he played under Eric Mangini in New England, he knew Mangini would one day become a head coach. Law added that the Patriots used to jokingly call Mangini Mini-Me in reference to his relationship with his former mentor, Patriots Coach Bill Belichick.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Rapper Fails to Appear

headline: Pistons Hit the Nets With Their Best Shot, and the Nets Fall
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets have enough talent to match one surge by an elite opponent such as the Detroit Pistons, but not two. Detroit kept pounding away at the Nets on Wednesday, like the surf battering a flimsy pier, and the Nets crumbled.

headline: McCain Campaigns in Iowa, Energized by New Hampshire
text: URBANDALE, Iowa  Senator John McCain kicked off his first full day of a brief campaign swing through Iowa on Thursday, hoping his ascendancy in recent polls in New Hampshire would help propel him in Iowa, where he has struggled and spent little money.

headline: High Schools Try Teamwork to Put Trainers on Site

headline: Long Before Video Cameras, a French Artist Brought Motion to His Images
text: Ah, boredom, the curse of the rich and idle in 18th-century France. So how did the aristocrats while away their leisure time on dreary winter days?

headline: The Pogies: Envelope, Please
text: Good evening, and welcome to the third annual Pogie awards! Let’s hear it for Rico and the band!

headline: Mrs. Clinton’s Gender Pitch
text: In her recent campaigning, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been toning down her gender-based appeal as she emphasizes strength and experience. But now she is making a direct pitch to young women in a new online essay for Glamour magazine’s Web site (www.glamour.com) in its political space, “Glamocracy.”

headline: Edwards Campaign May Have Expected Union Group Plan
text: DES MOINES  In the final days before the Iowa caucuses on Jan. 3, John Edwards has stepped up his criticism of outside organizations that spend money to influence elections, repeatedly disavowing a labor group that is blanketing Iowa with commercials supporting his candidacy.

headline: The $50 Ticket: A Lottery Boon Raises Concern
text: With the popularity of traditional lotteries waning across the country, many states are turning to instant games priced at $20, $30 and as high as $50 to lure new players and raise revenue.

headline: City Is Doubling Police Program to Reduce Crime
text: Every new police officer in New York City will be sent onto the streets of some of the city’s toughest neighborhoods as part of a broad anticrime operation that the authorities say has helped produce historic drops in crime, the city announced on Wednesday.

headline: State Without Pity
text: It is a shameful distinction, but Texas is the undisputed capital of capital punishment. At a time when the rest of the country is having serious doubts about the death penalty, more than 60 percent of all American executions this year took place in Texas. That gaping disparity provides further evidence that Texas’s governor, Legislature, courts and voters should reassess their addiction to executions.

headline: In Their Own Words
text: Former Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, speaking Wednesday in Conway, N.H.

headline: Russia: Another Candidate Exits
text: Boris Y. Nemtsov, a leader of the Union of Right Forces, a mainstream liberal party, pulled out of the March presidential election, asserting that improper pressure by the Kremlin had turned the campaign into a farce. Mr. Nemtsov, left, a first deputy prime minister under President Boris N. Yeltsin, called on opposition parties to unite around a single candidate to oppose the favorite, Dmitri A. Medvedev, a longtime aide to President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Offering Enlightenment, or Just a Little Peace
text: Room 315, the Rose Main Reading Room of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, has a loyal cast of repeat visitors. The regulars have their own reasons for being there: a love of words, a desire for serenity amid the din of the city, a place they can use as their office for school work or research.

headline: Tip of the Week: Increasing the Speed of a Vista-Operated PC
text: If you have a spare U.S.B. flash drive with at least 256 megabytes of free space on it, you can use it to give your Windows Vista-operated PC an extra cache of memory to help increase speed, using the Windows ReadyBoost feature. Just plug the drive into a U.S.B. 2.0 port, and if it is fast enough to work with ReadyBoost, the system will prompt you to set it up. You do not have to erase any existing files on the drive and can indicate how much space you want to use for storage. The feature also works with Secure Digital cards. Full instructions for using ReadyBoost are at http://snipurl.com/1vmik.

headline: Clemens’s Legal Team Adds Private Investigators
text: Roger Clemens’s lawyer has hired private investigators to try to challenge the credibility of Brian McNamee, the trainer who told federal agents and former Senator George J. Mitchell that he had injected Clemens with steroids and human growth hormone, a lawyer familiar with the matter said Wednesday.

headline: A Global Trek to Poor Nations, From Poorer Ones
text: JUAN GÓMEZ, Dominican Republic  The scrap-wood shanties on a muddy hillside are a poor man’s promised land.

headline: Garden Settles a Lawsuit Filed by a Former Rangers Cheerleader
text: Rather than defend itself against sexual harassment again, Madison Square Garden on Wednesday settled a lawsuit filed three years ago by the former captain of the Rangers’ cheerleading squad, the Rangers City Skaters.

headline: Holiday Cheer Gives Way to Final Primary Push in Iowa
text: DES MOINES  After a 48-hour lull for Christmas, the Democratic and Republican presidential campaigns roared back to life on Wednesday with a barrage of new advertisements, closing campaign arguments and more than a few attacks as they girded for the eight days leading to the first vote of 2008 here.

headline: Knicks’ Lineup Gets New Look, but the Result Is the Same
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Changes swept through the Knicks’ locker room Wednesday night, though it was hard to discern just who got the worst of it and whether it was all worthwhile.

headline: 2 Newark Bouncers Shot, One Fatally, After Dispute at Club
text: NEWARK  Two men who worked as bouncers at a bar here were shot early Wednesday, one of them fatally, by a man they had turned away from the club earlier that night, the police said.

headline: Based on a True Story
text: LOS ANGELES  At home, in gang territory near the 10 freeway, Malcolm Mays, 17, sleeps on the faded carpet of his grandmother’s living room.

headline: Lots of Home Work
text: ONCE their eyes adjusted to the dim interior of the house that would be theirs, Marcel and Sherrie Deans marveled at the architectural details they could make out amid the dust-covered desks and armchairs and piles of books.

headline: China Offers Production Guidelines for Seafood
text: SHANGHAI  Responding to growing concerns about the quality and safety of its seafood, China said this week that it would introduce production standards, including several measures intended to improve product safety and guard against the use of illegal veterinary drugs.

headline: New Law Allows Needle Exchanges in Washington
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush signed legislation on Wednesday lifting a ban that for nearly a decade has prevented city officials here from using local tax money for needle exchange programs.

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: China: Cellphone Upgrade Approved
text: China’s government approved a plan to build an improved wireless broadband cellphone network to elevate the country’s competitiveness with homegrown technology. The plan is “a major thrust in the future of China’s information technology,” China’s State Council said, but it did not provide details.

headline: Las Vegas Wins Big
text: The sparkling gambling palaces that line the Las Vegas Strip are intended to disconnect visitors from the realities of ordinary life.

headline: In Their Own Words

text: To the Editor:

headline: China: I.B.M. License for Chip Maker
text: I.B.M. licensed technology used in making computer chips for mobile devices and consumer electronics to a chip company in China, the companies said. The Chinese company, Semiconductor Manufacturing International of Shanghai, bought the license. The buyers will use it to expand offerings for mobile devices.

headline: Jurors’ Regrets May Be Used in Appeal of L.I. Conviction
text: Lawyers for a black Long Island man convicted of manslaughter in the shooting death of a white teenager said on Wednesday that in filing their appeal, they planned to use doubts about the verdict raised by two jurors.

headline: Fuel for Bushehr
text: President Bush is not eager to pick another fight with the Russians. So he did the diplomatic thing last week and said that it is good that Russia finally delivered fuel for Iran’s Russian-built nuclear power reactor at Bushehr. Don’t believe it.

headline: Kenyans in Vote in Test of Democracy
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The lines started to form at dawn on Thursday and some were literally miles long.

headline: Spiritual Journey Guides an Imposing Jets Tackle
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Before he embarked on a two-year mission for the Mormon Church, Sione Pouha heard all the horror stories. Friends told him to expect more than a few doors slammed in his face.

headline: Private Place for Smokers, on the Web
text: PARIS  Only the select few can enter the online preserve of Altadis, the European tobacco giant. Inside, visitors find a parallel universe where willowy models strut down the runway with cigarettes hanging from their pouty lips, and celebrities like Bob Dylan, Clint Eastwood and Brad Pitt flaunt smoking as the ultimate symbol of chic rebellion.

headline: California: Part of San Francisco Health Plan Struck Down
text: A federal judge has struck down a key provision of a new San Francisco program to provide basic health care for uninsured residents. The city was set to begin requiring employers with more than 20 workers to start subsidizing the health plan on Jan. 2. But the judge, Jeffrey Wright of Federal District Court, ruled that the mandate would violate a 1974 federal law designed to prevent inconsistencies in the coverage afforded employees who work for the same company but live in different jurisdictions.

headline: Japan Textbooks to Restore Reference to Wartime Suicides
text: TOKYO  Japan’s Education Ministry announced Wednesday that it would partly reinstate references in textbooks to the military’s role in forcing civilians to commit mass suicide during the Battle of Okinawa in the final months of World War II.

headline: Rapper Fails to Appear for Arraignment
text: The rapper Yung Joc was designated a fugitive after he failed to appear on Wednesday for arraignment in Cleveland on a felony charge of carrying a concealed weapon, The Associated Press reported, citing a prosecutor. Yung Joc, right, whose real name is Jasiel Robinson, was accused of trying to take a loaded semiautomatic handgun onto a Delta Air Lines flight on Sunday at Cleveland Hopkins International Airport. An assistant Cuyahoga County prosecutor, Gayle Williams, said that Mr. Robinson was considered a fugitive and that she planned to seek a warrant for him. His lawyer, Stanley Jackson Jr., was apologetic and said Mr. Robinson, 27, of Atlanta, was out of town attending to family and personal obligations. Mr. Robinson was arrested at an airport security checkpoint, where the police said they found the gun and ammunition in his carry-on bag. He told them he did not know the weapon was there. Mr. Jackson said Mr. Robinson maintained his innocence. He was released on Monday on $50,000 bond, but on Wednesday Municipal Judge Michael John Ryan doubled the bail to $100,000.

headline: Danger Is Part of Race’s Allure
text: With 49 deaths in 29 years, the annual Dakar Rally off-road race has been panned by the Vatican newspaper as “the bloody race of irresponsibility.”

headline: Nepal: 50 Missing in Icy River
text: Policemen, soldiers and villagers searched the icy Bheri River for more than 50 people believed missing after a steel footbridge collapsed on Tuesday. At least 16 people were confirmed dead.

headline: The Experience of Surround-Sound Speakers at Home, but Without All That Surround
text: Home theater surround-sound setups use five speakers to emulate the movie-hall experience  a pair front and back, and one speaker in the center. But if you can’t wire and hang such a system, there is a workaround: Single-enclosure sound bars for mounting under flat-panel TV screens.

headline: Promising Dystrophy Drug Clears Early Test
text: Researchers in the Netherlands have developed a drug that may eventually be used to treat children with a severe and fatal type of muscular dystrophy.

headline: The Year That Yelled ‘Notice Me’
text: FASHION historians may someday reflect on 2007 and overlook the significance of its finer moments: the ascension of a new generation of design talent, the influential Poiret show at the Costume Institute, the retirement of Valentino, to give but a few examples. Those scholars may conclude instead that this was the year in which designers finally succumbed to the baser desires of an overheated celebrity culture, in which the only thing that matters is fame and the only means to succeed is by screaming, “Look at me!”

headline: You Must Remember This
text: IT was a year of miraculous events. President Bush invited Al Gore to the Oval Office for a friendly chat about global warming. France elected a president who likes and admires Americans. Eliot Spitzer discovered the virtue of humility. In mid-rant, Hugo Chávez was finally told to shut up. The cute little Canadian dollar  the “loonie”  became worth more than a greenback.

headline: Afghanistan to Expel 2 Officials
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two senior political officers working for the European Union and the United Nations assistance mission in Afghanistan will leave the country as ordered by the Afghan government after discussions on Wednesday failed to resolve a dispute over whether the two had held talks with the Taliban, according to a United Nations spokesman.

headline: Spectacle on 34th Street
text: GRIPPED by last-minute holiday fever, shoppers thronged Macy’s on the weekend before Christmas, pouncing on the announcement that the store would stay open around the clock. Visitors, and even a few rebellious staffers, were tricked out for the occasion like 24 Hour Party People. Tweaking a store tradition that asks employees to dress in black, Jose Benavidez brightened up his uniform with a fuchsia scarf he had bought on the street. His colleague, JJ Martin, patrolled the makeup counter wearing fingerless gloves, a studded cuff and a generous daub of lip gloss. Plaid caps and Peruvian knitwear were de rigueur. But one dapper gent broke with form by flaunting a rep tie and a rakish beret. “I dress this way every day of my life,” he said. “I’m a fashion designer in my heart.”

text: Previously recorded: $3,742,926

headline: It’s a Case. No, It’s a Battery. No, It’s Both for iPhones.
text: With more cellphones doing triple duty as media players, movie viewers and photo albums, expect to see more products like the mophie Juice Pack.

headline: Tankleff Freed After Posting Bail
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  After being imprisoned nearly half his life for the murders of his parents, crimes he insists he did not commit, Martin H. Tankleff walked free on Thursday after a bail hearing here.

headline: San Francisco Police Look for Clues Indicating How Tiger in Fatal Attack Escaped
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Now considered a crime scene, the San Francisco Zoo was closed to visitors on Wednesday as police investigators swept the grounds searching for evidence to explain how a Siberian tiger escaped its open-air grotto on Tuesday, killing one young man and seriously injuring two others.

headline: Introducing the Ivanka
text: LOOKING almost demure in a tailored gray coat, Ivanka Trump stepped onto a makeshift stage to greet the construction crew at Trump SoHo, a new condominium and hotel in downtown Manhattan. The occasion, a topping-off party to celebrate the project’s near completion, was raucous.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article by The Associated Press on Saturday about convictions in the October 2006 killing of the former heavyweight boxing champion Trevor Berbick misidentified the location where his body was found. It was in the parish of Portland, Jamaica  not in Portland, Ore. (The article carried a dateline of Kingston, Jamaica.)

headline: New Orleans Housing
text: To the Editor:

headline: 25 Years Later, an Arrest in a New Jersey Killing
text: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J.  For the past quarter-century, George J. Carty III has lived a decidedly low-key life. He moved from his childhood home here in South Jersey to West Virginia, where he graduated from medical school. He married. He moved again, this time to Ohio, for a medical internship.

headline: Sallie Mae to Sell Stock to Pay Off a Failed Bet
text: Sallie Mae, the troubled student loan giant, said Wednesday that it would raise $2.5 billion by selling stock in the public market and would use most of the money to pay off a disastrous bet that the company made on its common stock price.

headline: Major Retailers Feel the Squeeze From Consumers
text: As the nation’s merchants began poring  or weeping  over holiday sales receipts Wednesday, a surprising pattern emerged: even brands that for years have inspired the undying devotion of shoppers felt the pinch of tightening wallets.

headline: Maryland Insurance Regulator Takes Control of ACA Unit
text: The ACA Financial Guaranty Corporation, the troubled bond insurance firm, has entered into a consent agreement giving the Maryland Insurance Administration significant control over management of the company, the firm disclosed in a filing Wednesday.

headline: A Chorus of Dog Whisperers
text: WHEN Doug Finley of Sparta, N.J., contemplated leaving commercial photography two years ago, he considered the standard advice given to those at a professional crossroads: do what you love.

headline: Marketing Décor for a Conflicted Era
text: THERE was a time when American Leather, an upscale furniture manufacturer based in Dallas, had a few easy-to-describe product lines. Its “traditional” couches and chairs appealed to the mature consumer with an established home, according to Jennifer Green, a spokeswoman for the company, while its “contemporary” furnishings spoke to a younger and trendier buyer. For everyone else, there were the pieces in somewhat generic, enduring styles, “like what you’d see at Crate & Barrel,” she said.

headline: Indonesia: Landslides Bury Dozens
text: Landslides from heavy downpours across the island of Java left at least 78 people dead or missing, most of them killed in a single landslide in the Karanganyar district that buried a late-night dinner party, a rescue official said. The victims had just cleaned up a mud-covered home. ”They were having dinner together when they were hit by another landslide,” the official said. “At least 61 people were buried.” In the nearby Wonogiri district, 17 people were feared dead when landslides hit their homes after a half-day of nonstop rain.

headline: Chip Makers Delay a Merger of Their Memory Divisions
text: STMicroelectronics and Intel announced a delay Wednesday in the merger of their unprofitable memory units and said banks would commit less start-up financing to the venture than previously announced.

headline: After a Quick Goodbye, a Brief Reunion
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  It was like old times for Herman Edwards at practice Wednesday, seeing Chris Baker’s No. 86 lined up at tight end and Justin McCareins’s No. 81 sprinting down the sideline.

headline: In a Strategy of Yesteryear, a Lesson for Players of Today
text: It is interesting to compare expert-level bridge today with, say, 40 years ago. How would you think it varies?

headline: Winning Thai Party, Backer of Ousted Prime Minister, Sets Governing Coalition
text: BANGKOK  The winning party in Thailand’s general election said Wednesday that it had agreed with coalition partners to form a government but would wait until official election results were released on Jan. 3 before providing details.

headline: Photographs, Art and Lessons, Taken From a Life Cut Short
text: In the summer of 1993 Dan Eldon, a 22-year-old photographer for Reuters, was making his way through the streets of Mogadishu to the suspected headquarters of a Somali warlord where scores of people had just been killed in a bombing by United Nations forces. There, amid the rubble, he and three other journalists were set upon by an enraged mob and stoned to death.

headline: Leap Wireless Restates Results for Last 3 Years
text: Leap Wireless International, the operator of the Cricket and Jump pay-as-you-go mobile phone services, restated more than three years of financial results Wednesday.

headline: Judge Hands I.R.S. Victory in Tax Shelter
text: A civil court has ruled that a popular tax-avoidance scheme known as Son of Boss was abusive and any deductions claimed for it were invalid, an important victory for the Internal Revenue Service in its battle against questionable tax shelters sold to wealthy individuals.

headline: China to Levy Tariffs on Some Exported Steel Products
text: China, which makes one-third of the world’s steel, said Wednesday that it would introduce export tariffs on some steel products and increase rates on other items to rein in a record trade surplus and cut energy consumption and pollution.

headline: Liberal Quits Race Against Medvedev
text: The liberal opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov pulled out of the March presidential election in Russia, asserting that improper pressure by the Kremlin had turned the campaign into a farce. Mr. Nemtsov, a head of the Union of Right Forces, called on opposition parties to unite around a single candidate to oppose the favorite, Dmitri A. Medvedev, a longtime aide to President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Beyond Conspiracy, Progress
text: On the outskirts of Kandahar in Southern Afghanistan, there’s a junkyard of the Soviet empire. It’s filled with the hulls of T-55 and T-62 tanks and the tubes of multiple rocket launchers. Some of the tanks are intact. I guess high-explosive, antitank missiles penetrated the turrets and coated the interior of the steel shells with blood.

headline: Patriots-Giants Game Now on NBC and CBS
text: The Patriots-Giants game, which was to be broadcast Saturday night to less than half the country by the NFL Network, will be available to fans throughout the nation under an agreement reached Wednesday by NBC and CBS to simulcast it.

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: Mexico: Trade Deficit Declines
text: Mexico reported a smaller-than-expected trade deficit for November after oil exports rose sharply. The deficit narrowed to $760 million from $1.65 billion in October, the finance ministry said. Economists expected a gap of $1.39 billion. Mexican oil export revenue rose 69 percent last month to $4.89 billion, the ministry said. Nonoil exports grew 8.7 percent to $19.5 billion. Total imports rose 12 percent to $25.18 billion.

headline: Extra Points
text: Linebacker Kawika Mitchell, who had two sacks, a forced fumble and an interception return for a touchdown in Sunday’s victory against the Bills, was named the National Football Conference’s defensive player of the week. ... Running back Ahmad Bradshaw (bruised calf), who had 151 rushing yards on Sunday, did not practice. ... A scoring change on a fumble against the Bills subtracted 2 yards from the Giants’ total of 291 rushing yards, which had been the most for the team since 1959. The revised total of 289 yards tied a team standard from 1985.

headline: Clean vs. Illegal: Orr’s Hit Deconstructed
text: When Rangers forward Colton Orr hit Carolina center Matt Cullen with an open-ice blow in the second period of Wednesday night’s game at Madison Square Garden, it took several views of the replay to even form an opinion on whether the hit was dirty or clean. And people will walk away with different views, no matter how many times they see it. On the ice, the referees initially indicated to Rangers captains that there would be no penalty, but conferred and gave Orr a five-minute major for interference and a game misconduct.

headline: Notable Deaths of 2007
text: Norman Mailer, Luciano Pavarotti, Ingmar Bergman, Liz Claiborne, Beverly Sills, Oscar Peterson, Boris Yeltsin, Lady Bird Johnson: They were just some of the notable figures of our time who passed from the scene in 2007. The Times here remembers them and others in a slide show and a month-by-month list with links to each of their obituaries.

headline: For the Moment | The Sands of Time
text: Sheikh Majed Al-Sabah, this week’s guest blogger on The Moment, is fashion royalty. Not only is Majed, as he is better known, a member of Kuwaiti royal family (his father is the first cousin of the emir of Kuwait; his mother is the emir’s sister), but he is a retail visionary, whose Villa Moda store in Kuwait is the crown jewel in a luxury company that now spans five countries in the region. In today’s post, Majed shows how luxury in the Middle East is a nebulous concept that extends beyond the shopping mall.The nomadic Arabs called “The Bedouins” were pastoralists who moved their herds from place to place in search of water, securing spots throughout the Arabian Peninsula. They lived in small, tightly-knit hereditary tribes. They were known for their hospitality, pride, courage and endurance. Their precarious, wandering existence demanded these traits, given that they had to tend to their sheep, camels and goats, as well having to protect their extended family and honored tribal rules. They lived in Sadu tents made out of camel wool, which the Bedouin women wove, and they survived on the livestock and the dairy products they carried with them.

headline: Battle of the Aliquippa Cornerbacks
text: When the Jets are host to Kansas City on Sunday, the rookie cornerback Darrelle Revis will look toward the Chiefs’ sideline and see a familiar face from his hometown.

headline: An Iranian Clothing Designer
text: Simin Ghodstinat creates elegant clothing for wealthy Iranian women while staying within strictly enforced boundaries of propriety.

headline: The Early Word: Obama’s Foreign Policy Nod
text: Congressman William Delahunt of Massachusetts, a leading Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, is set to endorse Barack Obama today. He told the Boston Globe he was impressed with Mr. Obama’s willingness to talk with America’s enemies and with his original opposition to the Iraq war.

headline: Further Winter Driving Tips, This Time From All Over

headline: Giuliani Ad Invokes 9/11
text: Santa Claus is gone from Rudolph W. Giuliani’s latest television ad, and the smoldering ruins of the World Trade Center site after the Sept. 11 attacks are in. The ad will begin airing Friday in Florida and New Hampshire and nationally on Fox News.

headline: How Low Can the Murder Rate Go?
text: New York City is headed toward having fewer than 500 homicides this year, by far the lowest number in a 12-month period since reliable Police Department statistics became available in 1963, when there were 548 killings. In a front-page article, Al Baker reports that crime in almost every major category declined again this year, with violence down in the schools and on the subways.

headline: Strike Makes Networks Rethink Programming
text: “Now in its seventh week, the Writers Guild of America walkout has forced producers to reconsider how shows are developed, the type of shows produced and how they’re sold to advertisers,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Iowa Forecast: One Week to Go
text: Caucus Countdown: Seven action-packed days until Caucus Day.

headline: Should Small Businesses Blog?
text: Today’s Shifting Careers column in the print edition of The Times is about what kinds of small businesses can benefit from blogs. You can read the column here.

headline: Wii Video Workouts Don’t Beat Real Sports
text: Children who play sports video games on the Nintendo Wii burn more calories than they would playing regular video games, but not as many than if they played the actual sports, a new study shows.

headline: Thursday Kickoff: Is Something Happening Here, Mr. Jones?
text: Central Michigan may have lost to Purdue in a wild Motor City Bowl last night, but ESPN’s Joe Schad is reporting that Coach Butch Jones is flying to Morgantown today for a second interview for the West Virginia job. Jones is a former Mountaineers assistant.

headline: New Year’s: It’s Treadmill Time
text: Resolutions are all well and good, but consult your doctor before starting any exercise routine …

headline: Oh, the Hill-a-rity
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign is having a Hill-uva time trying to make every possible Hill-arious play on the name “Hillary,” come Hill or high water.

headline: Please Silence Your Cell Phone
text: URBANDALE, Iowa — John McCain offered what appeared to be a lesson in cell-phone manners this morning to Rudolph W. Giuliani, a rival for the Republican presidential nomination. The setting was at Elks Hall here, where he was addressing a very crowded room of people when – his cell phone went off. He barely stopped.

headline: Readers Respond to the Debate Over Responsible Downloading

headline: Anguish in Brooklyn Over Bhutto Assassination
text: It was only minutes after the gunshots that killed Benazir Bhutto rang out on a street in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, that word of the assassination began to spread through the quiet blocks of Midwood, a Brooklyn neighborhood with a significant Pakistani population.From house to house, corner to corner, the news circulated through streets where Urdu signs hang in storefront windows and bakeries serve sweet Pakistani cakes. Some people called relatives in Karachi or Islamabad to hear firsthand reports of civil disturbances that followed the assassination. Others gathered in Pakistani restaurants to watch news broadcasts that showed the turbulence.

headline: The Uninvited Guest
text: I set to work last night at 11 p.m. — I’m a perennially early sleeper — with my lunch happily digested a few minutes before. I still had five solid hours before I’d get sleepy, I knew (I tend to go to bed every evening at around 9 p.m.); and with everyone around me asleep, or on their way to dreams, I felt I had the whole world to myself. It’s become the shadow present that gives itself to me every holiday season — or at least the challenge that I, like many of us, have to try to turn into a blessing.

headline: Where Every Day Is New Year’s Eve
text: NEW Year’s Eve is a big night at Caesars Pocono Palace in Marshalls Creek, Pa. Women in gowns and cocktail dresses and men in jackets and ties glide through the lobby, which is made up like a winter wonderland with glittering cotton snow and Styrofoam penguins. They laugh at the comics and clap and dance to the band. They wear leis and party hats. If this year is like every other, the place will be packed.

headline: Amazing Race Through Partytown
text: NEW Year’s Eve in New York is for tourists. It’s impossible to get a cab, the trains are even more crowded and unreliable than usual, and they’re far likelier to be filled with unwholesome substances and drunks. All the good parties/restaurants/shows are incredibly expensive or booked months in advance. And in the city that never sleeps, any evening that peaks at midnight is bound to be a letdown.

headline: Military Paper Challenges Defense Dept.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Dec. 12 about the announcement of a trip by the New York Philharmonic to North Korea in February referred imprecisely to a work by the composer John Adams that was alluded to by Zarin Mehta, the orchestra’s president, when he commented on the program for the concert in North Korea. While some themes in the work, “The Chairman Dances,” are also heard in Mr. Adams’s opera “Nixon in China,” it is not an excerpt from the opera.

headline: Malaysia: Hindu Loses Bid to Block Son’s Conversion
text: Malaysia’s highest court rejected a Hindu woman’s plea to stop her Muslim-convert husband from changing their 4-year-old son’s religion to Islam, in a case that has raised more concerns over minority rights. The couple, who are seeking a divorce, are ethnic Indians. The court ruled a child could be converted to Islam with the consent of one parent. The ruling means the woman could lose custody, as Malaysia’s Islamic courts will not give custody to a non-Muslim parent.

headline: Officials Cite Confessions in Killings of 6

headline: After Half a Lifetime in Prison, an Inmate Is Free for Now
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  After being imprisoned nearly half his life for the murders of his parents  crimes he insists he did not commit  Martin H. Tankleff shed his shackles Thursday and celebrated at a victory party with family, friends and other supporters.

headline: Correction: Accessorizing a Catskills Farmhouse With a Past

headline: Pakistanis Bury Bhutto and Brace for More Turmoil
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Hundreds of thousands of distraught Pakistanis gathered Friday to bury Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister assassinated a day earlier at an election rally, while violence flared across the country, leaving at least 10 dead. The government ordered paramilitary forces in Ms. Bhutto's southern home province of Sindh to shoot rioters on sight.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Dec. 13 about a collective malaise in Italy misspelled the surname of a columnist for Corriere della Sera, a leading Italian newspaper, who commented that many people feel helpless about the country’s problems. The columnist is Beppe Severgnini, not Severnigni. The article also referred imprecisely to the 102 cabinet ministerial appointments made by Prime Minister Romano Prodi last year. While that number was a record and reflected the unwieldy nature of Mr. Prodi’s nine-party coalition, as the article noted, the 102 appointments included deputy ministers, not just cabinet ministers.

Smart, ambitious and resilient, she endured her father’s execution and her own imprisonment at the hands of a military dictator to become the country’s  and the Muslim world’s  first female leader.

headline: Ashcan Views of New Yorkers, Warts, High Spirits and All
text: The painters of the Ashcan School just wanted to have fun. They chronicled the lives of poor city dwellers, but they were neither social critics nor reformers. Robert Henri, George Luks, John Sloan and other early-20th-century American realists identified with the group were high-spirited fellows who prided themselves on fielding a baseball team that regularly defeated those of the National Academy of Design and the Art Students League. They liked to dine in fancy restaurants and hang out at McSorley’s, the men’s-only tavern on East Seventh Street. They enjoyed the theater, the circus and trips to Coney Island. No Puritan crusaders, they were manly epicureans, and their virile hero was Teddy Roosevelt.

headline: Custom Models That Fit All Needs
text: WORKING from his solar- and wind-powered workshop near Telluride, Colo., Pete Wagner has been turning out custom-built skis since last year. headline: Sci-Fi Dream Turns World’s Worst Nightmare
text: In “Destination Unknown,” an Agatha Christie thriller published in 1954, two women sit knitting in an English hotel, discussing the latest terror weapon of the nuclear age, the cobalt bomb. “I do think all these atom bombs are very wrong,” one of the women says. “And cobalt  such a lovely color in one’s paint box and I used it a lot as a child; the worst of all, I understand nobody can survive.”

headline: Atlantis Launching Delayed Again
text: The next flight of the space shuttle Atlantis, already delayed until Jan. 10, will be further delayed to replace a socket in the electrical system on the external fuel tank. In the countdown on Dec. 6, the original launching date, sensors designed to ensure that the main engines shut down at the proper time during launching malfunctioned. Engineers think the problem is in the part of the socket on the outside of the tank and can be repaired on the launching pad by soldering electrical connections. If a more major repair is required, the Atlantis would have to be rolled back to its hangar, lengthening the delay.

headline: Needling More Than the Feminist Consciousness
text: In the ’70s, artists who swapped their paintbrushes for a needle and thread were making a feminist statement. Today, as both men and women fill galleries with crocheted sculpture and stitched canvases, the gesture isn’t quite so specific. Some contemporary artists gravitate to the retro-kitsch factor; others seize on the exacting technique, or the association with sweatshop labor, or a personal memory of Aunt Gladys’s afghans.

headline: Just Possibly the Best Place for Doing Nothing
text: IT’S tempting to think of the Lower Keys, a roughly 36-mile stretch of Florida islands between Marathon and Key West, as something of a lonesome no-man’s land.

headline: Salvaging U.S. Diplomacy Amid Division
text: WASHINGTON  The assassination of Benazir Bhutto on Thursday left in ruins the delicate diplomatic effort the Bush administration had pursued in the past year to reconcile Pakistan’s deeply divided political factions. Now it is scrambling to sort through ever more limited options, as American influence on Pakistan’s internal affairs continues to decline.

headline: With Role Diminishing, Curry Shows Confusion
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  After one of the most miserable nights of his career, Eddy Curry’s body language after practice Thursday conveyed what a lost soul he seems to have become. As sweat fell from his face, he showed little emotion as he spoke to the news media in soft tones. He offered short answers, his words dripping with frustration.

headline: After Benazir Bhutto
text: Benazir Bhutto was a flawed and undeniably courageous leader. Her return to Pakistan two months ago raised hopes that her country might find its way toward democracy and stability. Her assassination on Thursday is yet one more horrifying reminder of how far Pakistan is from both  and how close it is to the brink.

headline: Rangers’ Avery Enjoys Stirring Things Up
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers forward Sean Avery hardly considers a game in Toronto a homecoming. Avery grew up in Pickering, Ontario, on Toronto’s outskirts, but he harbors little love for what he left behind.

headline: Bhutto Is Buried as Pakistan Reels
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The body of Benazir Bhutto was laid to rest in her ancestral village, as violence erupted in cities across Pakistan on Friday, a day after the former prime minister was assassinated at an election campaign rally.

headline: Indiana: Sentence in 2006 Sniper Shootings
text: A teenager who pleaded guilty to killing one man and wounding another in a series of 2006 Indiana highway sniper shootings was sentenced Thursday to 42 years in prison. Defense lawyers tried to portray the defendant, Zachariah Blanton, 18, as troubled and the victim of teasing, but the judge said his emotional problems were no excuse for killing someone he had never met. Prosecutors said Mr. Blanton fired his hunting rifle into Interstate 65 traffic on July 23, 2006, from an overpass about 60 miles south of Indianapolis, killing Jerry L. Ross, 40, of New Albany. An Iowa man traveling in a pickup truck was injured. Mr. Blanton pleaded guilty this month to voluntary manslaughter with a deadly weapon and criminal recklessness.
