headline: The Sidney Awards II
text: Several months ago, Christopher Hitchens was sent an article about a young soldier, Mark Jennings Daily, who had been killed in Iraq. Daily was improbably all-American  born on the Fourth of July, an honors graduate from U.C.L.A., strikingly handsome. He’d been a Democrat with reservations about the war. But, “somewhere along the way, he changed his mind,” the article said. “Writings by author and commentator Christopher Hitchens on the moral case for war deeply influenced him.”

headline: Son Accused of Killing Officer in Their Home
text: An off-duty police officer who was a popular public figure in Piscataway, N.J., was shot and killed in his house on Thursday by his teenage son, who shot himself in the arm to cover up his act, prosecutors said.

headline: Amazon to Sell Warner Music Minus Copy Protection
text: LOS ANGELES  In the recording industry’s latest move away from its reliance on digital locks to reduce piracy, the Warner Music Group said on Thursday that it would sell songs and albums without anticopying software through Amazon’s fledgling digital music service.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about corporate philanthropy in Minneapolis-St. Paul, misstated the names of two organizations involved in charitable work in the area. They are the Minnesota Council on Foundations, not the Minneapolis Council on Foundations, and Twin Cities Rise, not Twin Cities Rising. The column also referred incorrectly to financing of a pedestrian bridge over an interstate highway. The bridge  the Irene Hixon Whitney Bridge, which crosses I-94 to connect the Walker Art Center to the city’s park system  was built with donations from the Whitney family and others. Dayton-Hudson, a predecessor to the Target Corporation, did not build the bridge.

headline: A Year of Books Worth Curling Up With
text: Full-time book critics approach recreational reading with a head start. We’re already reading for pleasure. We are immersed in books we find appealing, since the nearly 300 books chosen for the daily reviews in The New York Times have been culled from tens of thousands of volumes published each year. Some are chosen for their self-evident importance. Some are terrific sleepers. Even if a book’s foremost quality is its awfulness, a review in these pages means there’s something about it that one of us found noteworthy.

headline: Sri Lanka: Labor Minister Attacks TV Station
text: The labor minister, Mervyn Silva, and his bodyguards rampaged through a television station in Colombo and assaulted its news director for not broadcasting one of his speeches before employees fought back and took them hostage, officials and witnesses said. “This is not the first time Minister Silva did this,” said Sunanda Deshapriya, an official with a local media rights group. The station’s staff chased the attackers into an office and refused to let them out for three hours as soldiers and policemen gathered outside. The standoff was broadcast live by the station. Mr. Silva was eventually freed after issuing a public apology. He left the office escorted by the police amid hoots and jeers from station employees. Television showed him covered in red ink. He was admitted to a hospital with what was described as a minor head injury.

headline: Office-Building Workers Again Threaten a Strike
text: The union representing 26,000 janitors, doormen and other workers at 1,000 Manhattan office buildings renewed its threats to strike on New Year’s Day after a negotiating session ended with little progress on Thursday.

headline: Herman Rose, 98, Painter of Cityscapes, Is Dead
text: Herman Rose, a New York painter who was particularly admired for his cityscapes, died on Dec. 4 at his home in New York. He was 98.

headline: Hard at Work on New Year’s Eve
text: WHEN Chris Rock walks out in front of some 20,000 people on Monday night at Madison Square Garden to celebrate both New Year’s Eve and the kickoff of his six-month international “No Apologies” tour, no one will be surprised when he gets his first laugh. He is, after all, Chris Rock, and if he is not the funniest man alive, then the other guy is doing a good job of hiding.

headline: Firsthand Experience of Rape, and Resiliency
text: FOR more than half of her life, rape has never been far from the thoughts of Susan Xenarios.

headline: Girl, 3, Burned in Brooklyn Blaze
text: Firefighters crawled beneath flames to pull a critically burned 3-year-old girl from a house fire in Brooklyn on Thursday night, the Fire Department said.

headline: McCain Talks of Pakistan in Swing Through Iowa
text: URBANDALE, Iowa  Senator John McCain of Arizona kicked off his first full day of a brief campaign swing through Iowa on Thursday, hoping his ascendancy in recent polls in New Hampshire would help propel him in Iowa, where he has struggled and spent little money.

headline: Friend Says Rendezvous in Queens Led to Death
text: A Queens man whose body was found stabbed and beaten on a Little Neck handball court had left his nearby apartment the night before intending to meet a woman for a date but never returned home, according to one of his roommates.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Meet to Ease Tensions
text: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Olmert, met here on Thursday to try to dispel the tensions of recent days, and they recommitted themselves to refrain from acts that would prejudice a final peace treaty while they try to negotiate one, officials from both sides said.

headline: Marbury’s Future Becomes Clouded by 3 Small Words
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  During an innocuous session with the news media after Thursday’s practice, Isiah Thomas fielded what seemed like an endless stream of questions about his revamped starting lineup, the unthinkably poor play of Eddy Curry and the team’s latest miserable defeat.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: The Ghost Down the Hall Is Scary in Spanish, Too
text: “The Orphanage,” a diverting, overwrought ghost story from Spain, relies on basic and durable horror movie techniques. Give a competent director a gliding camera, creepy music and a dim hallway lined with doors, and a decent scare is likely to follow. No matter how many times you have seen similar tricks, the sudden apparition of a child at the end of that hall  especially a child in a weird, anachronistic costume  is likely to make you jump a little in your seat. So when a distraught Laura (Belén Rueda) stumbles down the corridor and comes face to face with a boy whose shorts and knee socks are accessorized by a burlap sack covering his face, you are likely to be nearly as terrified as she is.

headline: Two Regions, Two Loyalties and Two Extremes
text: Somewhere in Connecticut, at the border separating sports fans that prefer their teams from the north and those who swing to the south, they are counting down to Saturday night with bated breath and with disparate agendas from opposite sides of the great emotional divide.

headline: Essence Editor Is Leaving Magazine
text: Susan L. Taylor, the longtime editor and driving force behind Essence, the magazine aimed at black women, is leaving the publication after 37 years to devote more time to an organization she founded to help troubled children.

headline: Michigan: Ruling on Licenses for Immigrants
text: Illegal immigrants are ineligible for driver’s licenses, Michigan’s attorney general said in an opinion that affects one of the few states that have been granting licenses to such immigrants. The opinion by the attorney general, Mike Cox, is binding on state agencies and officers unless reversed by the courts. Michigan law prohibits the secretary of state from issuing a driver’s license to a nonresident. Mr. Cox, a Republican, said it would be inconsistent with federal law to regard an illegal immigrant as a permanent resident.

headline: Threat in Maine, the Whitest State, Shakes Local N.A.A.C.P.
text: BANGOR, Me.  In October, the N.A.A.C.P. chapter for northern Maine got shocking news. A man from a nearby town had threatened to shoot “any and all black persons” attending the group’s meetings at an old stone church here, and state prosecutors were worried enough to seek a restraining order.

headline: Russia Denies It Will Sell Iran Air Defense System
text: MOSCOW  A Russian government agency disputed reports that it had signed a contract to sell a sophisticated air-defense system to Iran, saying it had no such plans.

headline: Searching for a Caretaker
text: ASK owners of second homes, and they’ll have at least one story of heartbreak about hiring the wrong person to watch over their house while they’re away. The maid who never showed up, the next-door neighbor who forgot to turn on the humidistat, the service that didn’t live up to its references.

headline: New-Home Sales Hit 12-Year Low in November
text: Sales of new homes hit a 12-year low in November, falling short of even the most skeptical Wall Street estimates.

headline: For Bozeman, Road to Redemption Winds Slowly
text: BALTIMORE  It was the final day of classes at Morgan State before Christmas. At basketball practice, the mood was at once light and serious. Coach Todd Bozeman was in full throat, funny, profane, vigorous. He seemed to talk to everyone at once. “That’s why I call you Jughead,” he said to one confused player. And to the staffer who forgot to turn on the shot clock, “That’s what you get for going to public school.”

headline: Car Bomber Kills 8 at Baghdad Market
text: BAGHDAD  A car bomber killed 8 people and injured 66 in Baghdad on Friday, timing the blast to catch people emerging from prayers on the Muslim holy day and setting off the explosives directly under a mural celebrating doves of peace.

headline: Wild Revelry Is So Last Year
text: IF all goes according to plan, the shiny ball will drop at midnight on New Year’s Eve in Times Square, to the tooting of horns and the wild screams of the jubilant throng. As usual I’ll be there.

headline: Aetna to End Payment for a Drug in Colonoscopies
text: Aetna, one of the nation’s largest private health plan managers, is the latest insurer to clamp down on the use of a powerful anesthetic during an increasingly common form of colon cancer screening.

headline: Clocking the Candidates
text: IN the history of the televised republic, there have never been as many presidential campaign debates in a non-election year as there were in 2007.

headline: Not Up on British Slang, Dear? You May Be Bovvered
text: In Britain the sketch comedian Catherine Tate is more than famous. Tony Blair made a cameo on her show when he was prime minister. At a 2005 awards performance she asked Queen Elizabeth II, who was in the audience, “Is one bovvered?” This was from her best-known character, a feckless teenager who deals with humiliation by saying sarcastically, “Am I bovvered?” (i.e., bothered). Everybody, including the queen, got it.

headline: Influence of Mayor’s Departing Deputy Is Seen in His Successor
text: In a move that underscores the mayoral aide Daniel L. Doctoroff’s continued influence over city development, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday named Robert C. Lieber, a key lieutenant of Mr. Doctoroff’s, to succeed him as deputy mayor for economic development.

headline: Credit Crisis? Just Wait for a Replay
text: What if it’s not just subprime?

headline: A Post-Google Fraternity of Investors
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Chris Sacca had a plum job as the Wi-Fi guru at Google. But with his stock options fully vested, he left the Internet search company this month for a new career as a venture capitalist.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the digitizing of government documents misstated the background of Pierre Omidyar, whose Omidyar Network is helping to finance the project. He is the sole founder of eBay, not “one of the founders.”

headline: Chewing Gum, Plaster Bellies and Other Sculptural Byways
text: The history of art is always growing, but this year has brought some especially outstanding expansions. New York has been the beneficiary of two large exhibitions of Latin American modernism, a revelatory presentation of early Modernist photography from Central Europe and a survey of the paintings of Richard Pousette-Dart, an artist previously lost in the gap between Abstract Expressionism and Minimalism.

headline: Way Down in Harmony, With Mythic Blues Again
text: “Honeydripper,” John Sayles’s shambling fusion of pop mythology and social mosaic, imagines the world-changing moment, around 1950, in the rural South when a blues guitarist first plugged in his ax and rocked the joint.

headline: When ‘Home for the Holidays’ Involves Two Homes
text: THE white-on-green names slip past the car on my habitual route from Boston to my family holidays in Canada. Lee and Concord in New Hampshire. White River Junction, Burlington and Swanton in Vermont. The Quebec farm towns of Philipsburg and Iberville. Then I reach Pont Champlain, the bridge spanning the St. Lawrence, and see the searchlight on the Place Ville-Marie building sweeping the skies over Montreal.

headline: China Moves to Improve Quality of Its Seafood
text: SHANGHAI  Responding to growing global concerns about the quality and safety of its seafood, China said this week that it would introduce an array of production standards to improve safety and guard against the use of illegal veterinary drugs.

headline: In Fatal Blast in Midtown, Inquiry Blames Pipe Blockage
text: The deadly steam pipe explosion that shook Midtown Manhattan on July 18 was caused by a combination of heavy rainfall, leaks in underground water and sewer pipes and debris that clogged two critical devices designed to let water out of the steam main, according to an extensive investigation whose findings Consolidated Edison released on Thursday.

headline: Time’s Up
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: James DeAngelis, Last of Yale’s Ironmen, Dies at 97
text: James DeAngelis, a son of immigrants who became a Yale football celebrity and who was the last survivor of its famed 1934 lineup of Ironmen, died Wednesday in Wallingford, Conn. He was 97.

headline: Under Attack, Drug Maker Turned to Giuliani for Help
text: In western Virginia, far from the limelight, United States Attorney John L. Brownlee found himself on the telephone last year with a political and legal superstar, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: Correction: The Old South, Down to the Colonnaded Verandas
text: The Havens column on Dec. 21 about Beaufort, S.C., misstated the name of a restaurant overlooking a waterfront park. It is Panini’s Café, not Panera.

headline: Apple Making Deals for Web Video Rentals
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple’s sputtering efforts to be a major purveyor of video downloads may get a boost in 2008 from an agreement with 20th Century Fox for digital movie rentals.

headline: The Spirit Moved Them
text: WHEN he was a sophomore at Santa Fe Community College in Gainesville, Fla., Martin Birrittella experienced something that changed how he would spend his free time for the rest of his life  and possibly longer.

headline: Postcard Perfect
text: Don: It snows almost every day here and when we look out the windows, the conifers are draped in white, and it seems as if we’ve walked into a postcard. From the great room with its huge fireplace, we will often see elk grazing.

headline: Pleasure Without Guilt: Green Hotels With Comfort
text: “HEY there’s no schwag!” my wife, Nina, exclaimed from the bathroom of our room at the Gaia Napa Valley Hotel.

headline: Preventing AIDS Prevention
text: Congress and President Bush have done the right thing, lifting a disastrous nine-year ban that prevented Washington from using locally raised tax dollars on needle-exchange programs that help fight the spread of AIDS. Unfortunately, that still leaves in force an even broader and more damaging law that prohibits the use of federal funds for needle-exchange programs in the United States or abroad.

headline: U.S. Troops Kill 11 Shiite Militiamen
text: BAGHDAD  American soldiers raided a neighborhood in the southern Iraqi city of Kut early Thursday morning, killing 11 members of the Mahdi Army, the militia loyal to the anti-American Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, the American military and witnesses said.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Egypt to Copyright Landmarks

headline: Kukuiula

headline: Bush to Veto Pentagon Funds Over Iraq Provision
text: CRAWFORD, Tex.  President Bush will veto a huge Defense Department bill because of concerns by the Iraqi government that Iraqi assets in American banks could be vulnerable to claims from victims of Saddam Hussein, the White House said Friday in Texas.

headline: Obama Aide Ties Pakistan to Iraq War
text: DES MOINES  The chief strategist of Senator Barack Obama’s campaign said Thursday that the assassination of the Pakistani opposition leader Benazir Bhutto “underscores the case for judgment” when voters begin to select their presidential candidates next week.

headline: Seeing Vulnerability in N.F.C. Foes, Giants Are Confident
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  All anyone wants to talk about is the Patriots, and the chatter shrouds a quiet and cool confidence among the Giants about the larger world beyond.

headline: New Zealand Builds a Nest Big Enough to Save Kiwis
text: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand  In the thousand or so years since humans discovered the remote islands that make up New Zealand, three-quarters of the indigenous bird species have been driven to extinction, and until recently, it looked as if the kiwi could follow.

text: GERT AND UWE TOBIAS

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Miracle on 32nd Street
text: After more than a decade of dreaming, it may still take a miracle to build a new Pennsylvania Station in New York City. The odds would increase if Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s development team presented their proposal to the public as soon as possible. Then everyone  especially the people who use the station  could push to make this much-needed project happen.

headline: Bhutto Assassination Ignites Disarray
text: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  Benazir Bhutto, the Pakistani opposition leader and twice-serving prime minister, was assassinated Thursday evening as she left a political rally here, a scene of fiery carnage that plunged Pakistan deeper into political turmoil and ignited widespread violence by her enraged supporters.

headline: Letterman Makes Deal With Writers
text: David Letterman has secured a deal with the striking Writers Guild of America that will allow him to resume his late-night show on CBS next Wednesday with his team of writers on board, executives of several late-night shows said today.

headline: Art Deco Vases With a Couture Past
text: Some have it; others don’t.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Dec. 17 about the radio host Michael Savage and a call for advertisers to boycott his program because of remarks he made about Muslims referred incorrectly to a telephone call he took in 2003 in which he said he hoped the caller, who had identified himself as gay, would die of AIDS. The call was made to the television show Mr. Savage had on MSNBC; it was not made to his radio show.

headline: Starting Anew at 54, and Expecting the Best to Happen
text: “Haaaaaaa.” Angela Wahls Conteh inhaled deeply, then exhaled, “Shoooo.” She loosened up her 5-foot-5 frame by rotating her head, then her arms.

headline: The Noble, Gentle Swan Is Anything but, to Some
text: NEW HAVEN  Known for gliding along local waterways with statuesque grace, the mute swan is rarely thought of as an environmental hazard.

headline: The Early Filer Gets a Late Refund
text: Some very early tax filers will have to wait until February to get their tax refunds because of Congress’s late fix to the alternative minimum tax, the Internal Revenue Service said. Congress put a one-year freeze on growth of the A.M.T. last week. But that means the I.R.S. will not be able to start processing five related forms until February, delaying potential refunds for those people until then. Last year, three million to four million people filed in January using those forms, it said.

headline: Trouble With Trade
text: While the United States has long imported oil and other raw materials from the third world, we used to import manufactured goods mainly from other rich countries like Canada, European nations and Japan.

headline: Familiar Threats Constrict Press Freedom in Algeria
text: ALGIERS  At the height of Algeria’s civil war in the 1990s, Chawki Amari never slept in the same apartment two nights in a row. Like many journalists, he was caught between Islamic militants who threatened to take his life and a military-backed government that threatened to take his freedom.

headline: Benazir Bhutto, 54, Who Weathered Pakistan’s Political Storm for 3 Decades, Dies
text: Benazir Bhutto, who was assassinated at age 54 on Thursday in the Pakistani city of Rawalpindi, spent three decades navigating the turbulent and often violent world of Pakistani politics, becoming in 1988 the first woman to be democratically elected to lead a modern Muslim country.

headline: Musharraf’s Political Future Appears Troubled
text: Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto’s death raises the specter of prolonged political conflict between Pakistan’s president, Pervez Musharraf, and the country’s opposition, according to Pakistani and American analysts. How he handles the next several days could determine whether nationwide antigovernment protests erupt.

headline: Entertainer and Fighter Is Clemens’s Lead Lawyer
text: Rusty Hardin, the Houston lawyer hired by Roger Clemens to defend him from claims he used performance-enhancing drugs, is a star of the Texas bar, a charmer of juries and journalists and a lawyer whose preparation and aggressive tactics draw in celebrity clients and often send them home with their names cleared.

headline: In With the New, Kicking Out the Jams
text: GENE BERTONCINI

headline: Brooklyn Man Fatally Stabs Roommate, Who Was His Sister’s Companion, the Police Say
text: A man whose sister said he had been suffering from mental problems in recent months fatally stabbed his roommate with a kitchen knife on Wednesday night in their Brooklyn apartment, the police said Thursday.

headline: Discover Tries Nurturing Parents
text: IN a bet that managing your finances is like raising your child  trying, but rewarding  the Discover credit card has a new marketing partnership with Parents magazine, the nation’s most popular glossy about the world’s most demanding job.

headline: Albuquerque Has Renewal of Attacks on Abortion
text: A rash of attacks on abortion and family planning clinics has struck Albuquerque this month, the first such violence there in nearly a decade.

headline: Visions of a People in Motion
text: Jacob Lawrence painted “The Migration of the Negro,” 60 small pictures in tempera on hardboard panels, in what seems like a flash. The series was completed in 1941, after about a year of work in a cold-water studio at 33 West 125th Street in Harlem. Lawrence was 24. With its visual tact and deep emotion, it was instantly recognized as a tour de force, a new American epic. It made his career.

headline: Pursuing a Cross-Country Dream
text: For elite American cross-country skiers, winter trails have always seemed to stretch to a horizon that was seldom attained.

headline: Nigeria’s Corruption Fighter Reassigned
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Nigeria’s top anticorruption official, whose investigations have ensnared some of the country’s wealthiest politicians, is being sent to a year-long course at a remote training institute, according to senior law enforcement officials, provoking criticism from many who described the move as an attempt to sideline him.

headline: Punch Line on T-Shirts Not Meant to Be Joke
text: For the Yankees fan who has everything  most important, a sense of humor  there is still time for a late gift.

headline: A Humbling Lesson in Cable Reality
text: The N.F.L. is learning how much easier it is to sell TV rights to networks than it is to operate its own cable network. The league decades ago mastered the art of juggling networks to yield maximum cash, and its 32 teams now share $3.7 billion a year in TV money, including DirecTV’s cash for the satellite-delivered NFL Sunday Ticket package.

text: For centuries France has drawn artists seeking inspiration and the warmth of ateliers, spare retreats of timbered beams and sloping ceilings, weak light and high romance. Think Van Gogh, Utrillo and Picasso to name a few.

text: All of the presidential hopefuls yesterday expressed their reactions to the assassination of Pakistani opposition leader Benazir Bhutto. But they also used the moment to emphasize their own crisis preparedness and experience as talk on the trail shifted back, at least momentarily, to foreign policy.

headline: The U.N.’s Comic Invention
text: “He has fought against foes ranging from the Green Goblin to Doctor Octopus, but Spider-Man now faces an even more formidable challenge: improving the battered image of the United Nations,” reports the Financial Times.

headline: Steam Pipe Explosion Is Blamed on Confluence of Events

headline: Iowa Forecast: Back on the Bus
text: Caucus Countdown: We can’t believe it, but only six days until Caucus Day.

headline: New Ads: Romney Attacks McCain; McCain Touts Support
text: Mitt Romney, waging a two-front battle to stave off challengers in both New Hampshire and Iowa, unleashed a television advertisement critical of Senator John McCain on Friday.

headline: LIVE at the WJC: USA-Switzerland
text: But not on this blog. Instead, you can read a live English-language minute-by-minute description of the Americans’ second match at the World Junior Championship by someone who is actually seeing the game, and here is the link at the Czech site onlajny.cz.

headline: Without Correspondents In Pakistan, TV Networks Rely on Producers and Part-Timers
text: Of the U.S. television networks, only ABC and CNN had full-time personnel in Pakistan when the former Pakistan prime minister Benazir Bhutto was assassinated on Thursday.

headline: Friday Kickoff: An Ugly Divorce
text: The sudden breakup of the West Virginia-Rich Rodriguez union continues to get uglier and uglier. Now it‘s headed to court. Greg Moore of the Charleston Gazette reports that the university is suing in order to secure a $4 million buyout from Rodriguez for breaking his contract to go to Michigan.

headline: Tragic by Design: Greatest Car Styling Blunders
text: In 1980, a woman I knew in Detroit reported her Ford Pinto stolen. Her insurance company turned down her claim for reimbursement of its value on what I considered novel grounds: No one would steal a car that ugly. That turned out to be a smart call by her insurance adjuster. She later confessed that she and some friends had pushed it into the Detroit River. (At least in a watery grave, it was no longer a danger to explode.) I guess in Detroit, the car theft capital of the world, the insurance industry is savvy enough to know what is worth stealing, and what is not.

headline: Screwing In Light Bulbs, With Pride, on the Brooklyn Bridge
text: When I told a friend I was writing about one of the guys who maintains the light bulbs on the Brooklyn Bridge, he replied, “Oh, like the Gay Talese story about the guy who runs the Times Square news ticker?” That article carried no byline and was published on the editorial page on Nov. 2, 1953, so I hadn’t read it, but it offers an interesting lesson: for so many city icons that you imagine have always been the way they are, there is somebody behind the scenes keeping them going.

headline: Housing: How far is down?
text: More bad housing news this morning. The question remains, how far is down?

headline: Fast Food 101
text: Schools around the country are focusing on serving more healthful food to students to combat childhood obesity. But what about the food served near the schools?

headline: A Banquet of Words
text: The ever-growing number of information-hungry gastronomes in this country, which the writer David Kamp rather cunningly named “The United States of Arugula” in a 2006 book, is evident in the detailed descriptions of dishes on restaurant menus, in the popularity of food-oriented shows on television.

headline: A River Does Not Run Through It
text: I’m still trying to get used to blogging, and the part that’s most difficult is knowing that sometimes I’ll just be flat wrong. At the magazine, we have a team of outstanding fact-checkers and a ton of time (and, even then, small mistakes happen); with the blog, it’s often just my memory and me. The cool thing is that you have instantaneous feedback from readers who keep you honest, and that was the case yesterday, when a few commenters pointed out—rather gently, I thought—that Arkansas is not in fact between the Mississippi and the Missouri rivers. Bodies of water are always the clues that doom me in the Sunday crossword puzzle, so I should have known enough to consult a map. Anyway, my sincere thanks for pointing out the error.

headline: Feresten Returns To Fox Sketch Show
text: After a two-month pause because of the writers’ strike, Fox will begin taping episodes of the Saturday night series “Talkshow with Spike Feresten” early next month.

headline: Meet and Run

headline: Romney Begins Final Iowa Push
text: LE MARS, Iowa — Mitt Romney began his final push in Iowa this morning with his wife, Ann, prominently by his side and a trimmed down stump speech heavy on the themes of family and his image as a turnaround artist capable of changing Washington.

headline: Are “Green” Tax Breaks a Boon for Car Makers Like Fiat?
text: Interesting news from Italy today. The government said it would extend tax breaks on new, less polluting cars. That immediately sent up the share price of Fiat, Italy’s biggest car maker.

headline: A Fifth Grader’s Review of Wii Table Tennis
text: I was thinking about the Hollywood writers’ strike the other day, and envying the time off those screenwriters are getting. And then it hit me: what if I staged a tiny, one-day writer strike of my own?

headline: Bloomberg for President?
text: As the candidates slog through the snow and chicken dinners of Iowa and New Hampshire, Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York, a self-made billionaire, has inspired speculation that he could be a late, self-financed entry.

headline: New Thompson Ad: The Iowa Message
text: Republican candidate Fred D. Thompson makes his case for why he’s the hands-down most conservative, “Reaganesque” choice for Iowa caucus-goers in a new TV spot.

text: ABC is teasing the fourth season of the deserted island drama “Lost” with cinematic recaps of thefirst three seasons and dramatic glimpses at coming episodes of the series, which has its season premiere Jan. 31.

text: It occurs to me that some readers might want to know a bit more about the history behind what I’m saying currently on trade.

text: There were cardboard boxes of income tax records, mortgage papers, photographs that elicited gloomy memories and plastic cases filled with old-fashioned floppy disks — the kind that might have been used with some of the first personal computers on the market.

headline: ‘CSI’ No. 1 On A Repetitive Thursday
text: Reruns of its popular procedurals put CBS on top of the ratings on Thursday, a night of mostly repeats and relatively small network television audiences. “CSI” at 9 p.m. delivered the most viewers overall, 10.8 million, according to Nielsen’s estimates. It was followed close behind by “Without a Trace” at 10 (10.5 million) and “CSI: NY” at 8 (9.6 million).

text: Ahmad Fadam is an employee of The New York Times and a sculptor.

headline: Can You Spot the Fake One?
text: In the movies, homes often come with secret staircases or bookcases that revolve — when you pull just the right tome — and lead to hidden rooms.

text: Mitt Romney is out on Friday with his third television ad attacking his Republican rival Mike Huckabee in Iowa, this time hitting him on the full range of issues Mr. Romney has been bringing up on the stump about his opponent — immigration, crime, foreign policy and spending.

headline: Earth-shattering?

headline: Tea for Two at The Peninsula
text: I’ve heard that the practice of serving a proper, formal English high tea is held more tightly by certain segments of Hong Kong society than by most segments of London society. (I’m not entirely sure of this, but dissenters from the U.K. are welcome to lob angry emails in my direction).

headline: If She Had Been President …
text: In her latest campaign move, Hillary Rodham Clinton takes on a more powerful opponent than her Democratic rivals John Edwards and Barack Obama: President Bush. Her new TV ad asks, “What if we had a different president this year?”

headline: Q&A: Pakistan After Bhutto

headline: A Word (or Two) From Junya
text: Yesterday, I hung out for a good portion of the day at Comme des Garcons, talking to folks. Despite the impression of surprise and playfulness left by the Comme des Garcons shops, which are designed by Rei Kawakubo and Toshiaki Oshiba (a collaboration that goes back more than 30 years), the headquarters are a no-frills, no-nonsense workspace: cutting tables, mannequins, offices, what you might expect. Tao Kurihara is warm, thoughtful, slightly impish and easy to talk to. She is no pushover, I felt. Tao giggled with something like alarm when I casually asked what she’s planning for her fall show. Such information is a secret at Comme des Garcons; nobody knows what the different studios are working on until their respective shows, in Paris, and everybody at CdG respects that.

headline: More Questions for the Smithsonian
text: W. Richard West Jr., below, the founding director of the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian, spent a quarter of a million dollars of institution money on transportation and hotels over four years, the Smithsonian confirmed on Friday. The money was spent on more than 500 days of travel between 2003 and 2007. The dozens of trips, first reported in The Washington Post on Friday, took him to Europe, New Zealand, Indonesia, Singapore and a number of other destinations for speaking engagements, work for other nonprofit organizations and fund-raisers. Linda St. John, a Smithsonian spokeswoman, said that all Mr. West’s travel was approved. “He brought in $51 million in fund-raising” during that period, she said. “While it may seem shocking that he spent $250,000 on travel, realize what the trade-off is and what he gave to the Smithsonian and Native Americans." Mr. West, in a telephone interview, said, “The fact is that the strategic aims of the Museum of the American Indian required that I had these connections to the international community." Mr. West, 64, a lawyer and historian who is a citizen of the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes, oversaw the opening of the museum on the National Mall in 2004, as well as the creation of the George Gustav Heye Center for the museum in New York and the Cultural Resources Center in Suitland, Md. He recently retired as director, but remains on the payroll until the end of the year. Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, chairwoman of the Senate Rules and Administration Committee, said she had asked for an accounting of Mr. West’s activities from the Smithsonian’s board of regents, as well as from the Government Accountability Office. Smithsonian officials have been under scrutiny since spending abuses by the institution’s secretary, Lawrence M. Small, came to light this year. Mr. Small resigned in March; Sheila Burke, his deputy, did so in September.

headline: Aztec Pyramid Found
text: Archaeologists have discovered the ruins of an 800-year-old Aztec pyramid in the heart of Mexico City that could prove that the city is at least a century older than previously thought, Reuters reported. Mexican archaeologists found the ruins, which are about 36 feet high, in the central Tlatelolco area, once a religious and political center for the Aztec elite. Since the discovery of another pyramid at the site 15 years ago, historians have thought Tlatelolco was founded by the Aztecs in 1325, the same year as the nearby twin city of Tenochtitlan, the capital of their empire, which the Spanish razed in 1521. The pyramid, found last month, may have been built as early as 1100, signaling that the Aztecs began to develop their civilization in central Mexico earlier than believed. “The timeline is going to need to be revised," the archaeologist Patricia Ledesma said. In August archaeologists in the city’s Iztapalapa district unearthed what they say may be the main pyramid of Tenochtitlan.

headline: Edwards Evokes Nation at Risk; McCain and Romney Wage Ad War
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa  With the skirmishing between the campaigns of John Edwards and Senator Barack Obama intensifying, Mr. Edwards on Friday tried to distinguish himself from his Democratic rivals, saying he has “what it takes in here for the battle” with corporate interests.

headline: Bhuttos Last Book
text: HarperCollins Publishers is rushing out a book by Benazir Bhutto, the assassinated Pakistani leader, Publishers Weekly reported. Andrew Wylie, the agent for the deal, said the manuscript, “Reconciliation: Islam, Democracy and the West,” originally scheduled for spring publication, was “completed only a week ago." HarperCollins does not yet have a firm release date, but will publish the book “as soon as possible," said Tim Duggan, the company’s executive editor. The book, written with Mark Siegel, a Washington lobbyist who was a friend and consultant of Bhutto’s, details her “vision for how to bridge the political and cultural gap between the Islamic world” and the West, Mr. Duggan said.

That makes it perfect for Snoop Dogg, the quick-witted rapper who is always game for a stunt or a catchphrase. Steadying my foam-splattered hand, I surveyed the 27 empty flutes arranged in neat rows on the kitchen table. I filled three of the flutes, and placed them on a slightly tarnished silver tray. Then I hid bottle No. 1 in a cardboard box on the floor, and carried the tray of frothing flutes into the living room.

headline: Bhutto’s Rival Seeks Alliance Against Musharraf

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A brief film review in Weekend on Dec. 14 about “The Singing Revolution,” a documentary about Estonia’s struggle to end Soviet occupation, misidentified the site of the Estonian song festival. It is in Tallinn, the capital  not Tartu, where some festivals were held in the 19th century. The review also referred incorrectly to the songs performed at the festival that are shown in the film. They were written by composers; they are not folk songs.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on Tuesday about a legal dispute over a New York State ban on the use of electroshock therapy on children with severe behavioral problems misstated, in some editions, the amount of electric charge used at a Massachusetts school where New York sends some of its special education students. It ranges from 15 to 45 milliamperes, or thousandths of an ampere  not 15 to 45 amperes.

headline: Top Cop
text: Reruns put CBS on top of a Thursday night that consisted mostly of repeats. “CSI" at 9 delivered the most viewers, 10.8 million, Nielsen estimated. It was preceded by "CSI: NY" at 8 (9.6 million), and followed by "Without a Trace" at 10 (10.5 million). Fox ranked second for the night, drawing an average of 6.2 million viewers with the movie "Ice Age" from 8 to 10. ABC finished third and NBC fourth.

headline: Iran: Russia Denies Planning Missile System
text: A Russian government agency disputed reports that it had signed a contract to sell a sophisticated air-defense system to Iran, saying it had no such plans. This week, the Iranian defense minister, Mostafa Mohammad Najar, said that a contact had been signed and that Russia would equip Iran with S-300 missiles, which are used to shoot down planes and missiles. In a statement posted on its Web site, the Russian agency, the Federal Military and Technical Cooperation Service, flatly denied the Iranian claim. “The issue of supplying Iran with S-300 anti-aircraft missile systems, raised by mass media, is not on the agenda, is not being considered and is not being discussed with the Iranian side at the moment,” the statement said.

headline: Beijing’s Olympic Quest: Turn Smoggy Sky Blue

headline: Time and the Dictator

A few months ago, an Indonesian court ordered Time magazine to pay the former dictator a judgment now valued at about $111 million in a libel case. The verdict, which Time is challenging, should not be allowed to stand.

headline: Ruling on Nazi Art
text: A federal judge has ruled that a painting held by a German baroness belongs to the estate of a Jewish art dealer who was forced by the Nazis to auction it, The Associated Press reported. Chief Judge Mary M. Lisi of United States District Court for Rhode Island on Thursday ordered Maria-Luise Bissonnette to turn over “Girl From the Sabiner Mountains," above, to representatives of the estate of Max Stern, who died in 1987, stating that his “relinquishment of his property” was clearly “anything but voluntary." Both sides say that the painting, which has not been authenticated, is by Franz Xaver Winterhalter, a 19th-century artist famous for his portraits of European nobility. One appraiser for Ms. Bissonnette estimated its value at up to $94,000. Mr. Stern inherited his family’s art gallery in Düsseldorf, Germany, in 1934, but three years later the Nazis forced him to auction its contents because he was Jewish. He later fled to Canada, where he became a prominent art dealer and worked to reclaim his lost paintings. Ms. Bissonnette’s stepfather, Karl Wilharm, a member of the Nazi Party, purchased the painting at the auction; Ms. Bissonnette, who resettled in Rhode Island, inherited it. Mr. Stern left his estate to the McGill and Concordia Universities in Montreal and Hebrew University in Jerusalem, which have continued his work in trying to find his paintings, hundreds of which are still missing. Ms. Bissonnette has said that she and her family did nothing wrong. “I have the receipt,” she said earlier. “My father paid for it."

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about Rudolph W. Giuliani’s most detailed account yet of the health scare that led to his recent hospitalization referred incorrectly to the date that Senator Paul E. Tsongas, a 1992 presidential candidate, died of cancer. Had Mr. Tsongas been elected president, his death on Jan. 18, 1997, would have been two days before the end of his first term  not two days before the beginning of his term in 1993. (The error also appeared on Nov. 24, 2000, in an article about Dick Cheney’s heart attack and the health of presidential candidates.)

headline: Week 17 in Preview: Redskins Control Their Playoff Destiny
text: The Washington Redskins can earn a playoff berth by beating the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday. But like several other matchups on the final day of the regular season, the outcome will hinge as much on who does not play as on who does.The Cowboys (13-2) clinched home field in the National Football Conference playoffs last Sunday. They have little to gain by going all out against Washington (8-7) and will probably limit the risk to injured players like Tony Romo (thumb).One player who will not be taking part is Terrell Owens, who sustained a high ankle sprain last week. Owens scored all four touchdowns in the Cowboys’ Week 11 victory against the Redskins (highlights here), taking advantage of a secondary weakened by the absence of safety Sean Taylor. Taylor, who missed the game with a knee injury, was shot and killed a week later. His death, and a season-ending injury to quarterback Jason Campbell, might have led the Redskins to pack it in.Instead, they won three in a row. Now, buoyed by the steady play of Todd Collins, who has not thrown an interception, and Clinton Portis, who has 376 yards from scrimmage in the last three games, the Redskins control their playoff destiny.“I don’t know of a team — I haven’t been a part of one — that’s overcome this much,” Coach Joe Gibbs told reporters. “It’s almost like they’re going to overcome whatever’s out there.”

headline: A Clicker Is Born
text: U.S. patent 2,817,025 was issued almost exactly 50 years ago to a slight, soft-spoken Austrian immigrant who worked in the industrial labs of the Zenith corporation on the West Side of Chicago. Robert Adler was an accomplished physicist who adored nature, books and classical music. He didn’t watch much television, but he was nevertheless a genius at improving its gadgetry. His 1957 patent described something called a “new and improved remote control system.” Five drawings laid out an architecture for the kind of innovation that would become increasingly common as the century wore on: a media technology that appeared simple, and that promised to make life better for consumers, and that hid its complexity under the guise of compact physical elegance.

headline: A Happy Accident, Carefully Planned
text: GENIUS in photography often means a knack for being in the right place at the right time. For the commercial photographer and train buff O. Winston Link (1914-2001), that was Staunton, Va., in 1955. Having traveled there on assignment from his home in New York to photograph window air-conditioners for Westinghouse, he took a side trip to nearby Waynesboro, a stop on the last large steam-powered railroad in America, the Norfolk & Western. Over the next five years, until the railroad completed its conversion to diesel-powered engines, Link made more than 20 trips to Virginia, West Virginia, North Carolina and Maryland, producing more than 2,400 images of Norfolk & Western trains, stations and related sites.

headline: Scottish League Player Dies

He was carried off on a stretcher and taken to a hospital. The Motherwell club chairman, Bill Dickie, said that O’Donnell had a seizure, but did not elaborate. He said there would be an autopsy.The teams completed the game, apparently unaware of O’Donnell’s condition. Motherwell won, 5-3.

headline: The Combatant
text: ONE DAY IN EARLY JANUARY 1963, David Halberstam, portable typewriter in hand, appeared at the ground-floor apartment I was renting on a side street in Saigon. The front room served as an office. I slept in the second room at the back. I was the correspondent for United Press International, and David was in Vietnam for The New York Times. It was typical of the man that he did not ask, “May I join you?” Although wire-service reporters and daily-newspaper journalists often teamed up overseas, he simply assumed he would be welcome and set his typewriter down on the other side of the table I used as a desk. That day was the beginning of a partnership and, in later years after our assignments in Vietnam were over, a friendship that was to endure until he was killed in a car crash in California last April.

headline: Hugh Massingberd, 60, Laureate for the Departed, Dies
text: Hugh Massingberd, a celebrated former obituaries editor of The Daily Telegraph of London who made a once-dreary page required reading by speaking frankly, wittily and often gleefully ill of the dead, became the recipient of his own services after dying in West London on Christmas Day. He was 60 and lived in London.

headline: Powerful Attractions
text: IN THE SUMMER OF 1997, a friend and I rented a house in a small village on the Greek island of Sifnos. One afternoon there was a knock at the door; we opened it to find a tall, plump woman wearing velvet bedroom slippers, a flowing calico frock and an old straw hat slightly askew. At the front of the hat was a roughly frayed hole, like an exit wound left by a stray bullet. Though in her late 60s and a touch rustic, the woman was strikingly pretty. She introduced herself as Jeannie Campbell and told us she had been sent to check on us by a mutual friend. We invited her in for tea. Seeing a manuscript on the kitchen table, she said, “Is someone writing a book?” I said I was. She studied the title, and said: “Oh. Lillian Hellman. My ex-husband was a good friend of hers.” Gingerly, I asked the obvious question. She sipped her tea and said, “Norman Mailer.”

headline: Forgotten Step Toward Freedom
text: WE Americans live in a society awash in historical celebrations. The last few years have witnessed commemorations of the bicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase (2003) and the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II (2005). Looming on the horizon are the bicentennial of Abraham Lincoln’s birth (2009) and the sesquicentennial of the outbreak of the Civil War (2011). But one significant milestone has gone strangely unnoticed: the 200th anniversary of Jan. 1, 1808, when the importation of slaves into the United States was prohibited.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: As an Age Recedes, a Craftsman Soldiers On
text: WITH small but energetic steps, Walter Schnerb turned from a cutting machine to his desk, a page from a score of the Puccini opera “La Fanciulla del West” in his hand. Using his index finger, he reached inside a small blue glue pot, then swiftly stuck a thin strip of paper over a ripped edge of the page to repair it.

headline: Drawn to an Island Life, and Seeing the Cost in Every Price Tag
text: MONA AND BARRY ROSENTHAL remember the precise moment they decided to move from Canton, Mass., south of Boston, to Martha’s Vineyard, six miles off the southern tip of Cape Cod.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The World of Tomorrow
text: ON Jan. 1, 1908  New Year’s Day one century ago  The New York World greeted readers with a stirring rumination about the past and future of America. The title of the article was simply “1808  1908  2008.” The World began by marveling at how far America had come since 1808, then turned to the question of the future: “What will the year 2008 bring us? What marvels of development await the youth of tomorrow?”

headline: How to Lose Your Job on Your Own Time
text: WERE Henry Ford brought back to life today, he would most likely be delighted by the Internet: the uninhibited way many people express themselves on the Web makes it easy to supervise the private lives of employees.

headline: Reflections on Light Under Winter’s Spell
text: IT’S like anything else  when you have enough you don’t give it a second thought, but when you crave it, it stays on your mind. So it is with winter light. In these last months, as the wide shaft of light that falls across the kitchen floor has dwindled to a sliver on the table, I find myself searching out the light, cataloging its various sources, then itemizing their deficits.

headline: Luxury Deregulation: Determining Income
text: Q We live in a rent-stabilized apartment. By 2010, the rent will exceed $2,000 a month. (In January, when our renewal lease goes into effect, the rent will be $1,980.)

headline: For a People in Pain, a Reason to Dance
text: THE first guests arrived at 10 p.m., knowing they would dance until nearly dawn. The sari-like Sudanese dress of the women  called a tob in Arabic  stood out among the dark suits of the men, and guests shouted to hear one another over the noise of the band.

headline: Effort to Block California Anti-Bias Bill
text: LOS ANGELES  Conservative groups in California are gathering signatures to try to block an anti-discrimination bill because it includes language that would extend protection to public-school students based on their sexual orientation and gender identity.

headline: A Strategy Up Their Sleeves
text: WHEN he hits the blackjack tables at the Foxwoods casino in eastern Connecticut, Mr. S is no longer a construction worker in his 20s laboring for a weekly paycheck. Dressed casually and acting as if he couldn’t care less what anyone thinks, he plays the part of a pushy rich kid who has no problem making bets that often exceed $1,000 a hand.

headline: So Many Crimes, and Reasons to Not Cooperate
text: CAMDEN, N.J.  When her 16-year-old son was shot dead on a street corner here in June, Rosalynn Glasco became the latest mother left to search for justice in a world without witnesses  where the stigma of being seen as a snitch or the fear of retaliation prevents many from testifying about even the worst crimes.

headline: Grace After the Fall
text: Viewed now, three decades later, when the sight of a violent hit in the National Football League is an every-Sunday occurrence, the play seems almost routine: a wide receiver for the New England Patriots reaches for a pass. His defender, gathering speed, takes aim at his human target. As the ball sails harmlessly away, the defender slams into the helpless receiver’s lowered head, with pulverizing force.

headline: How Sushi Chased Beef Wellington
text: CHIPOTLE, huitlacoche, galangal, Kaffir lime, cilantro aioli, ciabata, chimichurri, bok choy, arugula, tat soi, yuzu, mesclun, panna cotta, ponzu, lemon grass  these and dozens of other words were mostly unknown 30 years ago when I began reviewing restaurants for the Connecticut section of this newspaper.

headline: Orders From on High? That’s So Yesterday
text: GARY HAMEL’S latest book, “The Future of Management” (Harvard Business School, $26.95), comes at a time when American companies face a new avalanche of competition from China and India, as well as entrenched competition from Japan and Western Europe. Mr. Hamel, a co-founder of the Management Innovation Lab, offers a way for business leaders to face this onslaught through what he calls “the technology of management.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: HENRY JAMES: The Mature Master, by Sheldon M. Novick. (Random House, $35.) Striving to supplant the common view of James as “a passive, fearful man,” Novick paints him as a gregarious, sometimes heroic, often troubled citizen of the world.

headline: In Bhutto Stronghold, Sharif Seeks a Political Alliance Against Musharraf

headline: Texas Freshman Cleared to Play
text: The Texas freshman Gary Johnson, sidelined this season because of an unspecified heart condition, can play his first game Jan. 2 against Texas Christian.Johnson was “cleared to participate in all physical activity at the University of Texas,” the trainer Fred Burnett said in a statement Saturday.Johnson, a 6-foot-7 forward who was the Longhorns’ top recruit, has been monitored for the past six months by Dr. James Willerson, president-elect of the Texas Heart Institute and president of the university’s Health Science Center in Houston. University officials released no other details on his condition, which was diagnosed in May.Texas (11-2) lost to Wisconsin, 67-66, on Saturday.

headline: An Asian Hub in the Making
text: IMAGINE a city with Venice’s canals, New York’s Central Park and the broad tree-lined boulevards of Paris. And how about the colorful shopping bazaar of Marrakesh, Morocco; the pocket gardens of Savannah, Ga.; and an opera house like the one in Sydney, Australia? Throw in a world-class hospital, convention center and schools, and a sustainable design, and you might think you’re lost in a SimCity video game.

headline: Immigration Is Defying Easy Answers
text: New immigration and the political reaction against it are nearly as old as the United States itself. Yet the immigration surge of the last decade has awakened tensions of unexpected intensity that have pervaded the presidential campaigns of both parties and stirred voter anger across the country.

He had written “The Final Problem,” the story in which Sherlock Holmes takes a fatal plunge while grappling with the villainous Professor Moriarty, and was pleased to have freed himself  and his readers  to concentrate on his weightier, more serious work. That was the idea, anyway.

More recently, however, the agency added an unlikely item to the catalog of potential threats to postal workers: people who want to get their mail.

headline: A Hilton in the News (and It’s Not Paris)

The huge charitable gift includes $1.2 billion from the recent sale of the Hilton Hotels Corporation and from the coming sale of Harrah’s Entertainment, the casino company.

headline: A Neurotic’s Neurotic
text: GIVEN THAT WORDS are the bread and butter of psychoanalytic work, it would seem strange on the face of it that very few practitioners have written elegant or even lucid prose. Indeed, they amount to no more than a handful: Freud himself; his daughter, Anna; the British analyst D. W. Winnicott; the much-neglected Leslie Farber; Robert Stoller; Irvin Yalom; Adam Phillips. The field, suffering as it does from an inferiority complex about its relevance to the larger culture, has immured itself behind the high walls of jargon  terms like “introjective identification,” “countercathexis” and “unintegrated superego nuclei.” This emphasis on opacity is in part an effort to preserve psychoanalysis’s waning mystique. Paradoxically, it also underscores the discipline’s attempt to validate its much-disputed conjectures about human behavior by appropriating the clinical vocabulary of hard science. Yet for those of us who remain interested in what the talking cure may have to offer (the number dwindles almost daily), the lack of an accessible dialogue between clergy and laity remains a woeful reality.

headline: United States Wins Hopman Opener
text: Meghann Shaughnessy, filling in for Serena Williams, was a winner in her match, then Mardy Fish clinched a victory for the United States over India in the opening round of the mixed-teams Hopman Cup in Perth, Australia. Shaughnessy won the last five games to defeat Sania Mirza, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3. Fish secured the victory with a 6-2, 6-4 win over Rohan Bopanna. Mirza and Bopanna won the mixed doubles, 6-4, 6-4.Williams, recovering from a knee injury, was expected to arrive in Perth in time for the United States’ match Monday against the Czech Republic.

headline: Deacons Rally to Defeat Huskies in Meineke Car Care Bowl

headline: Mom vs. the World
text: DURING A WARM MONTH IN 1952, the work crews clearing land for new homes in East St. Louis, Ill., were approached by a pregnant housewife from a neighboring street who asked if she might borrow some of their heavy equipment. Gloria Connors already had one son, and with another boy on the way, she wanted to build a tennis court on her property. People in East St. Louis didn’t have tennis courts in their backyards. It was, that second son, Jimmy Connors, told me, “the other side,” a blue-collar town of stockyards, factories and railroad tracks across the Mississippi River from St. Louis, but Gloria had been an accomplished professional who had played well at the U.S. national championships at Forest Hills in the 1940s and once reportedly thrashed the youthful Olympian Babe Didrikson in a challenge match, and she already had a feeling about her sport and Jimmy. The construction men obliged her with their graders and steamrollers; Gloria laid out the court and then took up her garden tools. “She made everything possible for me,” Connors says. He feels that way because Jimmy Connors, one of the finest, fiercest tennis players ever, is the only leading man to have been coached throughout his career by a woman  a mother so dedicated that she was preparing to teach him even before he was born.

headline: She Was Supposed to Be Dead
text: When Kate Webb reported from the battlefields of Cambodia, she kept her chestnut hair cropped G.I.-short and wore jeans and loose shirts to obscure her breasts. This was 1971. Only a handful of women were full-time correspondents in Vietnam, and even fewer women roughed the front lines next door in Cambodia, where military officers believed foreign women were, at best, a distraction. At worst, they were bad luck.

headline: Hot Properties
text: “God makes stars,” the pioneering movie producer Samuel Goldwyn once said. “It’s up to producers to find them.” In this era of D.I.Y. stardom, you don’t need God or Goldwyn to grab your 15 minutes; you need only a Webcam and the minor technological wherewithal to upload your own fabulousness. Information dissemination is cheap thanks to the Internet, and now so is fame, which has become the virtual-reality birthright of every Tom, Dick and Lonelygirl15 itching to go viral. In the new global meritocracy, anyone can be a star.

headline: Innovative Minds Don’t Think Alike
text: IT’S a pickle of a paradox: As our knowledge and expertise increase, our creativity and ability to innovate tend to taper off. Why? Because the walls of the proverbial box in which we think are thickening along with our experience.

text: AIR travel is likely to be even more miserable in 2008 than it was this year, with growing delays, fewer choices, higher fares, dirtier airplanes and grouchier flight crews.

headline: Correction: A City of Legend Embarks on a New Journey
text: Because of an editing error, the Next Stop article on Dec. 16 about Alexandria misstated the action taken by Egypt that led to the Suez Crisis of 1956. Egypt nationalized the canal; it did not privatize it. The article also misstated the location of Fort Qaitbay. It is at the western  not eastern  end of the Corniche, the road along the Mediterranean.

headline: All the Profitable Horses
text: THE threat by Mayor Michael Bloomberg last month to close the city’s more than 60 Off-Track Betting parlors was an insincere and petulant negotiating ploy rather than a realistic proposal. Perhaps his raising the topic, however, will finally prompt some overdue reform of New York’s dysfunctional OTB system, which is a national embarrassment and a model of inefficiency.

headline: The Poles Get Cold Feet
text: Poland’s new government is right to be taking a skeptical second look at the Bush administration’s proposal to station 10 interceptor missiles there as part of a European-based missile-defense system. The pragmatic conservatives voted into power in October want to make sure that the project offers real security benefits to Poland that outweigh its potential diplomatic costs.

text: In a sports year unlike any other, 2007 too often meant scandal and sadness rather than success.

headline: Mr. Reassurance
text: During the war years of the ’40s, the uncomplicatedness of certain actors made them useful. Nobody wanted to watch a neurotic or a sexual malingerer at the heart of a flag-waver. Barry Nelson, 23 years old and blessed with a three-dimensional Archie comic of a face, got the money lines in the 1943 movie “The Human Comedy”: “I guess you don’t really understand your country until it’s in trouble,” he says, sitting in a movie theater with a couple of other G.I.’s. They’re watching a newsreel in which a literally waving flag is superimposed onto the face of F.D.R. “All the rest of the time you take it for granted. Like your family.” Sitting near Barry Nelson, a startlingly young-looking Robert Mitchum seems as if he can’t wait to lead the postwar charge that would soon land the neurotics and the malingerers in the power seats. By the time the second wave of that charge hit  with the advent of Brando, Clift and Dean  Barry Nelson’s regular-guy persona was no longer so useful in Hollywood.

headline: Democrats on Ice
text: NOTHING in the neat sitting room in the apartment overlooking Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem where Mona Sutphen and Clyde Williams live indicates the couple’s true passion in life. The room is minimally furnished, with little more than a sofa, a dining table, and a few books stacked in a corner.

headline: Paperback Row
text: DRAGON SEA: A True Tale of Treasure, Archeology, and Greed Off the Coast of Vietnam, by Frank Pope. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) Pope had worked on underwater expeditions all over the world when he agreed to manage an attempt to raise the Hoi An, a pottery-laden junk that sank off the coast of Vietnam in the mid-15th century. In this engaging account, he describes the conflict between his mentor, a marine archaeologist committed to using precise methods in the recovery and in contributing to the historical record, and the Malaysian businessman who financed the expedition and wanted to cut corners and make money. He also describes saturation diving, which requires crew members to remain pressurized for two months. Pope does a “crack job of blending storms and tension, regional history” and the “gruff cast of characters,” our reviewer, Holly Morris, said.

headline: Literary Life
text: Madeleine Stern was a renowned antiquarian book dealer, but her most important discovery was not a book at all. It was a series of lurid stories, all published in gaudy popular journals, all written under a pseudonym, all by New England’s fresh and hearty Louisa May Alcott.

text: COALINGA, Calif.  When any of the 5,300 inmates at Pleasant Valley State Prison begin coughing and running a fever, doctors do not think flu, bronchitis or even the common cold.

text: FIRST the housing market soured, then consumer spending. Traders may get an indication on Friday that another shoe is dropping when the latest details of employment conditions are announced.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘The History of the Snowman’
text: A review on Dec. 2 about “The History of the Snowman,” by Bob Eckstein, misstated the name of a cartoon cited in the book and misspelled the surname of the painter and graphic artist who drew it. The cartoon is “Snowman,” not “The Snowman”; it was drawn by Frank Frazetta, not Franzetta.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Dec. 2 in T: Holiday magazine about wealthy Russian women who collect art misspelled the Russian word for mansion. It is osobnyak, not obsonyak (hence, these collectors hang their art in their McOsobnyaks, not McObsonyaks).

headline: Unveiled
text: The “Arabian Nights” event given by the designer Marc Jacobs at the Rainbow Room on Dec. 12 was the office party of the year. Many costumes reflected the fantasy drawings of the fashion artist Antonio Lopez in the 1985 book “Antonio’s Tales From the Thousand and One Nights.” Top left, an image from the book’s cover.

headline: Not in My Tropical Backyard
text: ON Dec. 13, after four months of lawsuits, protests and politics, the Hawaii Superferry finally started service between Honolulu and Maui. The 350-foot catamaran, which can accommodate 866 passengers and 286 cars, promises to revolutionize travel between the islands by allowing people to travel with their cars and possessions, instead of people flying and cars traveling  empty  on barges.

headline: The Kitchen God’s Life
text: Can any room claim to be the warmest in the house? Living rooms have once again become formal, pristine, empty spaces, like the parlors reserved in the 1900s for “company.” Bedrooms  well, look at the divorce rates, still high no matter how you run the numbers. Dining rooms? They’re dwindling in square footage  who sets a proper table these days and then washes and irons the linen? Dens? They’ve become media rooms where Mom, Dad and kiddos No. 1 and No. 2 plug into their iPods, Xboxes, Macs and movies in companionably self-absorbed isolation. Libraries? See Dens, above. What other rooms have lost in area and panache, however, the kitchen has gained. It’s practically an axiom that the kitchen has become the most favored room in the house, but as in those popularity contests we grudgingly endured during high school, the winner never turns out to be the warmest bulb. Just the best looking.

headline: A Dirtier (and Funnier) Shade of Clean
text: IN the name of physical comedy Lucille Ball got her head stuck in a loving cup on “I Love Lucy,” Mary Tyler Moore wedged her big toe in a bathtub faucet on “The Dick Van Dyke Show,” and Marlo Thomas lodged her own disobedient digit in a bowling ball on “That Girl.” But those classic sitcom episodes don’t prepare a fellow for the sight of Gary Lockwood with his mouth stuck on a doorknob.

headline: Cars Rock, but Stickers May Shock
text: MY list of favorite automobiles this year is, I think, a reflection of America: there’s a growing class of millionaires at the top, a widening blue-collar class at the low end, and a middle class that is rapidly disappearing.

text: Don Renzulli, the N.H.L. executive in charge of staging the league’s first outdoor game in the United States, sounded supremely confident.

headline: Giant Rises, and Shines
text: WE may look back on 2007 as the year public opinion shifted toward greener cars and trucks, a result of heightened concern about climate change and oil imports, coupled with high gas prices and a shift away from truckish S.U.V.’s. Interestingly, though, this wasn’t a year when a lot of notable green cars came to market.

headline: Fans and Grills Are Fired Up for History
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The luckiest Patriots fan in Germany purchased tickets for their final regular-season game in July.

headline: The Shrinking Market Is Changing the Face of Hip-Hop
text: UNTIL a few weeks ago it seemed like one of the few happy stories to emerge from an otherwise difficult year in hip-hop. UGK, the Port Arthur, Tex., duo that influenced a generation of Southern rappers, returned after a five-year hiatus. They came back bearing a sublime single, “Int’l Players Anthem (I Choose You).” And they came back bearing a great double album, “Underground Kingz” (Jive/Zomba), which made its debut atop Billboard’s album chart.

headline: Sweden Ends Canada’s Streak
text: Tobias Forsberg scored with seven seconds left Saturday to give Sweden a 4-3 victory over Canada in a world junior championship game in Pardubice, Czech Republic. The victory ended a 20-game winning streak in the world junior tournament for Canada, the three-time defending champion.In Liberec, the United States improved to 3-0 in Group B when Tyler Ruegsegger, James vanRiemsdyk and Mike Carman scored in a 3-2 victory over Russia. In other games, the Czech Republic beat Slovakia, 5-2, and Finland defeated Kazakhstan, 5-0.

text: NEW YORK

headline: A New Luxury Hotel Opens in Singapore
text: Last week, the St. Regis Singapore became “the first new internationally branded luxury hotel to open in Singapore in 11 years,” according to its general manager, Yngvar Stray. The 20-story hotel, the first property in Southeast Asia for St. Regis Hotels and Resorts, is in the uptown Orchard Road shopping and embassy district. It adjoins the St. Regis Residences, which are still under construction.

headline: Bridget Grabish, Joseph Shanley
text: Bridget Nolan Grabish, a daughter of Beatrice V. Grabish and Stanley J. Grabish of North Wales, Pa., was married Friday to Joseph Patrick Shanley, a son of Laura K. Shanley and Gerald E. Shanley III of New York. Msgr. John J. Grabish, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph’s Church in Philadelphia.

headline: Yemen’s Exotic Secrets
text: ON my first morning in Sana, the capital of Yemen, the call to prayer didn’t just rouse me from sleep, it rattled the window panes, seemed to shake the foundation of my hotel, and spread from minaret to minaret as if the entire Old City was an enormous echo chamber. The scratchy invocations thundered on for so long I wondered whether it was even worth attempting to sleep again.

headline: A Patience to Listen, Alive and Well
text: REPORTS about the diminishing relevance of classical music to new generations of Americans addled by pop culture keep coming. Yet in my experience classical music seems in the midst of an unmistakable rebound. Most of the concerts and operas I attended this year drew large, eager and appreciative audiences.

headline: Manisha Shetty and Sameer Gulati
text: Manisha Shyla Shetty and Sameer Gulati are to be married Sunday at Rudraksha, a cultural center in Bangalore, India. Lata Sharma, a Hindu priestess, is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Jolting Joe
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Spy in the Gray Flannel Suit
text: In the first third of this beautiful new novel, we follow young Mark Ruttenberg, an ordinary spy, through the final stages of his training in Virginia and his initial posting overseas. The book is fiction packaged as mock memoir, the story told in Ruttenberg’s distinctive voice: operationally plain, detailed but distanced, present but not always there. The voice is born of the case reports officers like Ruttenberg must generate to document their every move. He describes the traffic on the sidewalks, the buildings and the weather, the e-mail messages and the meetings. As a C/O, or case officer, Ruttenberg is trained to scan the streets behind his car for potential tails, and the faces at a party for potential recruits (known as “developmentals”). Restlessly and endlessly he scans. Slowly  indeed, it feels almost accidental  his scan begins to register not just the tactical facts of tail or no tail, but also the poverty and misery of his fellow man in the unnamed police state where he serves. He begins to track his own reactions and attractions. Bit by bit, a queasy truth takes hold. The book, though serious and strong, is not a novel in the normal sense. It is, rather, itself an act of espionage, the collected field reports of Ruttenberg meticulously spying on himself.

headline: Here Come the Losers, Two by Two
text: Calabasas, Calif.

headline: Alison Cannata and John Hendele IV
text: Alison Beth Cannata, the daughter of Carolyn Cannata and Gregory J. Cannata of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., is to be married Sunday afternoon to John Martin Hendele IV, a son of Rachelle Hendele and Mr. Hendele III of Chicago. Rabbi Edward Schecter is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: The Southern Strategist
text: In the small Southern town that produced Harry Dent, the future Nixon White House political aide, Dent’s great-uncle John (The Baptist) Prickett edited the newspaper. One day, an outraged reader called Prickett a “Republican S.O.B.” Prickett, who like everyone else in South Carolina was a Democrat, laid him flat with a punch. The baffled reader, upon recovering, asked what was the matter with calling him an S.O.B. “But you called me a Republican S.O.B.,” Prickett answered  and thereby hangs the tale of why Harry Shuler Dent is such an important figure in American history. He was the behind-the-scenes player who did the most to turn the South from a region that despised Republicans into a Republican bastion.

headline: The Communicators
text: THERE IS, IN THE END, no telling what tales they had to tell, the two greatest nonhuman linguists of our day: Washoe, the sign-language-wielding chimpanzee with an intense footwear fetish; and Alex, the wildly outspoken parrot, an African gray known to regularly order about his human researchers and to purposely give them the wrong answers to their questions just to alleviate his boredom. After all, we only ever gave them our own words to work with.

headline: Local Militants in Pakistan Add to Qaeda Threat
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Qaeda network accused by Pakistan’s government of killing the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto is increasingly made up not of foreign fighters but of homegrown Pakistani militants bent on destabilizing the country, analysts and security officials here say.

text: Newark

headline: Two Steps Greener, One Back
text: IN normal times, designers and engineers gather in studios and conference rooms to set the course for how cars will look and function. In 2007, though, the decisions with the greatest effect may have been those made inside courtrooms and government agencies.

headline: Ginger Buzz
text: IT is the time of year when sweet things come a-creeping. Fruitcakes, I mean. Gingerbread houses. Funny little cookies. Cards from distant relations emblazoned with photographs of children dressed in sweaters, and sometimes-tragic dogs dressed in sweaters. That sort of thing.

headline: Red, White or Green?
text: Waccabuc, N.Y.

headline: The Hard Sell
text: The books a child sneaks off his parents’ bookshelves and surreptitiously reads ought to be sex books. “Lady Chatterley’s Lover” and “Memoirs of Hecate County” scandalized and educated earlier generations. The volume I made off with was a 75-cent paperback of “The Hidden Persuaders” by Vance Packard. It did scandalize me, completely. But it did so by exposing the secret world of advertising and brands. Published in 1957, it is now enjoying its 50th anniversary and a new edition from Ig Publishing, with an introduction by Mark Crispin Miller. I remember my own edition as small enough to hide  not that I really needed to  but packed with dynamite. It had a lurid cover illustration showing a barbed fishhook buried in a gleaming apple. Packard’s book reached into the darkest corners, not of sensuality, which I was sure I knew all about from television, but of the cynical selling in the commercials that ran between the shows.

headline: Cashing Out of New York City
text: THERE is a well-worn path between New York City and the surrounding suburbs. Over the years, many New Yorkers have made the move, looking for safer streets, better schools, bigger houses and more room to grow. Now another group is making the trek, and the reason is more squarely focused on money.

headline: Paterno Has Last Laugh Against Texas A&M
text: SAN ANTONIO  When a Texas A&M male yell leader created a stir by yelling at a pep rally Thursday that Joe Paterno was on his death bed and needed a coffin, Paterno coyly shrugged off the comments.

headline: The Blush of the New
text: Thomas Mann was an archmodernist, and this was his favorite story: One day, Gustave Flaubert was out walking with his sister. Ferociously antibourgeois, Flaubert lived alone, unconsoled and unencumbered by marriage or family. His novels mocked and maligned the French middle class, ironizing it into oblivion. He was a great frequenter of brothels and had fornicated his way through Paris and Cairo. And yet here he was out for a stroll, suddenly stopping in his tracks before a small house surrounded by a white picket fence.

text: There is a 26,000-acre national park on the edge of New York City, its nearest point less than an hour from Times Square. But not many New Yorkers know it is there. Though about two million people visit parts of it every year, the park is forlorn and in need of help  from the federal government, from Albany and from the city.

text: The union representing 26,000 janitors, doormen and other workers at more than 1,000 New York City office buildings reached a tentative four-year contract with building owners on Saturday, averting a strike threatened for Tuesday.

text: BAGHDAD  The top American military commander in Iraq said Saturday that violent attacks in the country had fallen by 60 percent since June, but cautioned that security gains were “tenuous” and “fragile,” requiring political and economic progress to cement them.
