text: YOU made plans for New Year’s Eve in New York long ago, but unless you’re headed straight from Times Square to La Guardia Airport, you’ll also be here on New Year’s Day, one of the deadest days of the frigid New York winter. Streets are empty, many businesses are closed, most natives are holed up in warmer climes like (a) Jamaica or (b) under the covers nursing a hangover.

text: Shore Line East train service expanded in the 1990s to coax commuters east of New Haven out of their cars. To a large degree, the trains, which are operated by Amtrak through an agreement with the state, have succeeded; they offer eastern Connecticut residents an inexpensive connection to Metro North trains in New Haven, easing traffic on Interstate 95. So for many, Shore Line East takes the headaches out of getting to work.

text: MY Chinese friend Yuzhi invited herself over for a serious talk. Her English is poor, and she struggled to convey her message, but she was concerned: she had noticed I was lonely.

headline: Plays Well With Others
text: GOOD acting is not contagious, as far as I know. But a visitor sampling the best of Broadway over the holiday season might almost imagine it is, and that it has swept through the city like a virulent flu, infecting people in packs. Everywhere you look, a particular kind of theatrical magic is taking place, as ensemble performances of a rare order are glowing brightly on stages across the theater district.

headline: These Bonds May Shine (Despite Your Tax Bracket)
text: BACK in the days before heavily leveraged hedge funds and rampant trading of derivatives, the rules for investing in municipal bonds were fairly simple: Consider them only if your high tax bracket has pushed their taxable-equivalent yields higher than those of Treasuries. And beware of buying individual munis, which were expensive to trade and required credit analysis homework.

text: In a television interview a few months after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Vice President Dick Cheney described a sense of obligation he shared with President Bush. The two men wanted, Mr. Cheney said, “to pass on our offices in better shape than we found them to our successors.”

headline: Turning an Evaluation Into More Pay

headline: 36 Hours in Sarasota, Fla.
text: SET on a sparkling bay, behind a necklace of sandy barrier islands, the resort town of Sarasota was pioneered in the Roaring Twenties by the immensely wealthy John and Mable Ringling of circus fame. The couple didn’t come to get away from the clowns and freaks; they brought the entire circus with them to pass the winter in warmth and style. To this day, this scrubbed, suntanned and artsy little town offers just enough of a city vibe to sustain great food and a little night life. Plus, the circus still comes down in the winter.

headline: The Anthropological Psychologist
text: I wish I’d known the work of Dr. Marian Radke-Yarrow when I was pregnant. I remember more than a few close friends asking me if I worried about the particular packet of DNA I was passing on. I was concerned about the depression that ran in my gene pool, but I also worried about things that were more nurture than nature, like having a child who bears the weight of her mother’s mood. I felt almost old-fashioned, because while even the most sophisticated scientists doff their hats to nurture, they, like the rest of us, seem to have come to the conclusion that nature rules the roost, and that roost is ringed with neurons.

headline: Correction: Seeing the Summer Olympics, but Not Beijing
text: The Heads Up column on Dec. 16, about the Summer Olympics equestrian events in Hong Kong, referred incompletely to the purchase of tickets. Although Hong Kong residents can indeed buy tickets for those events through China Travel Service (www.ctshk.com), United States residents must buy them through CoSport (www.cosport.com), the official United States ticket agency for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games.

headline: China Detains Dissident, Citing Subversion
text: BEIJING  The authorities have detained a prominent Chinese human rights advocate on suspicion of subversion, escalating a crackdown on dissent during the West’s holiday season.

headline: Heil Woodrow!
text: Coming of age in the 1960s, I heard the word “fascist” all the time. College presidents were fascists, Vietnam War supporters were fascists, policemen who tangled with protesters were fascists, on and on. To some, the word smacked of Hitler and genocide. To others, it meant the oppression of the masses by the privileged few. But one point was crystal clear: the word belonged to those on the political left. It was their verbal weapon, and they used it every chance they got.

headline: Letters: Desperately Seeking a Kidney
text: As a recent recipient of a live-donor kidney, I can say that Sally Satel’s article (Dec. 16) helped me explain to my extended family most of what I experienced (short of Satel’s online relationship with the retiree from Canada) during the three years of dialysis waiting for a transplant. And the difficult time I’m currently having expressing my appreciation to my donor, while not feeling that we need to be life-long best friends. Thank you.

headline: The Binocular Brigade
text: River Vale

headline: Second String
text: In his fourth decade as a Rolling Stone, Ron Wood is still “the new boy”  as close as anyone alive to the band’s surviving core, but never an equal member. As he puts it in “Ronnie,” his entertaining memoir of a career divided between rocking and painting, he is the “little brother” and “sparring partner” to Keith Richards, which leaves his insider’s perspective something of an outsider’s tale. He’s up there all right, a jolly passenger on the Stones’ superstar ride, but he never conveys a substantial sense of steering the ship, or even of being certain where it’s headed. (Since Mick Jagger abandoned his autobiography, that view will have to wait for Keith’s in 2010.)

headline: How a ‘Wisp of a Girl’ Conquered Pakistan
text: London

headline: Queen of the Separates
text: Pants, shirt, jacket. No big deal  now. But back in the early 1970s, before Liz Claiborne became a household name, that outfit was not much of an option for women. Out in the world, you wore a dress or a skirt with a matching jacket. At home, you wore slacks or a housedress. You could be dressed up or dressed down, in other words, but “separates,” as the fashion industry calls the way women now dress, had yet to become a phenomenon. Until Liz.

headline: Invisible Blogger
text: The sidewalks of Harlem’s main thoroughfares are wide and inviting, and in the 1960s the kids playing “boxball” shared the asphalt squares with some of the greatest orators in creation. The most famous spot for speechifying was the “Speakers’ Corner” outside Lewis Michaux’s bookstore on 125th Street, where Malcolm X delivered his lectures on race and politics. On weekends or after work, fathers took their boys down to the corners in Harlem to watch any number of would-be firebrands engaged in emotional debate over Vietnam or the state of race relations or Bobby Kennedy’s political future.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Aldous Huxley: Selected Letters’
text: A review on Dec. 2 about “Aldous Huxley: Selected Letters,” edited by James Sexton, misstated the time by which Huxley “was dabbling in Scientology.” It was 1950, not the end of World War II. (Only in 1950 did L. Ron Hubbard publicly introduce the principles of Dianetics, which were later expanded into the basis for Scientology.)

headline: Out of Darkness, New Life
text: KIRALY STREET in Budapest has staked claim to the title of hip new spot with its restaurants and fine boutiques, but there’s more to the city’s once-gritty District VII than this one storied stretch. Cafes, bars, nightclubs and fashionable stores have sprung up throughout the dark lanes of the old Jewish Quarter, whose history and recent rise to trendiness evoke comparisons to the Lower East Side of New York.

headline: Anxious? You Should Be. It’s Good for Business.
text: ANXIETY is usually something people want to avoid. The dictionary defines it as “a state of being uneasy, apprehensive or worried about what may happen.” People who experience too much anxiety may find themselves on a therapist’s couch, and doctors prescribe pills to keep this feeling away.

headline: Traveling the Globe on a Single Ticket
text: A trip around the world is no easy feat. Neither is booking the ticket.

headline: Learning to Move Under the Sea, on Wheels
text: UNDERWATER ballet is an art form perhaps best left to the imagination. Immersion makes a body feel graceful, but what with problems of buoyancy, hydrodynamics and air supply, the choreographic possibilities are slender. Small wonder that the maritime ballets of the masters  August Bournonville’s “Napoli,” Frederick Ashton’s “Ondine,” George Balanchine’s “Ballo della Regina”  work their magic on a dry stage, by suggestion.

headline: Food Edenist
text: Those of us who were new recruits to America’s food revolution of the 1960s and ’70s were shocked when our leaders got hit by friendly fire. It was 1977 when Karen Hess and her husband, John, hurled “The Taste of America” at us with the gleeful abandon of characters in “The Monkey Wrench Gang.” The fighting Hesses declared war not just on the entire food industry and industrialism in general, which was fine, but also on us “foodies,” as we were beginning to call ourselves, which was not fine. For a decade we’d been rejoicing in the liberation of the American palate, and here we were, shot down from within our ranks. We felt betrayed.

headline: The Free Market: A False Idol After All?
text: FOR more than a quarter-century, the dominant idea guiding economic policy in the United States and much of the globe has been that the market is unfailingly wise. So wise that the proper role for government is to steer clear and not mess with the gusher of wealth that will flow, trickling down to the every level of society, if only the market is left to do its magic.

headline: A Haven for Children at Court
text: White Plains

headline: Ravens Put Heap on Injured Reserve
text: Todd Heap, a two-time Pro Bowl tight end, was placed on injured reserve by the Ravens on Saturday. Plagued by a nagging hamstring injury, Heap played in only six games, recording 23 catches for 239 yards and a touchdown.

headline: A Car Dealer’s Daughter
text: I’M the older of two girls. When I was really young, maybe about 5, my sister, who was about 2, had a series of medical emergencies. She was sick a lot. My mother would say to me, “Susie is sick today, so you need to be a big girl.”

headline: Friday Night Lights and Property Taxes

headline: The Lives They Lived
text: Welcome to the 14th annual Lives They Lived issue. On the last Sunday of each year, we fill these pages with stories of all kinds of people who have died during the last 12 months. It is a daunting task: this newspaper alone published more than 1,000 obituaries, and those only touch on the vast number of notable deaths. In putting together this issue, we shy away from any attempt at being definitive; instead we embrace idiosyncrasy, storytelling and the interests and passions of our editors and writers. This year brought the deaths of many giants of politics and culture, from Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. to Luciano Pavarotti, from Brooke Astor to Ike Turner, from Lady Bird Johnson to Jack Valenti. But we present some of the lesser-known lives: Harry Dent, who quietly consolidated the South for the Republican Party; Andrée de Jongh, who, at 24, courageously escorted more than 100 soldiers and civilians out of Nazi-occupied Belgium to safety; Gloria Connors, who taught her son Jimmy how to be an unrelenting champion; Ernest Withers, who, as a black photographer, was able to document the civil rights movement from inside. Their stories and those of the two dozen others presented here create a collage of lives well lived.

headline: Amateur Night? Not for These Bands
text: AMONG the familiar tenets of successful musicians  play loud, live fast, blame the bad stuff on the drummer  there’s one that is rarely heard beyond the tour bus.

text: THE Indiana Children’s Wish Fund, which grants wishes to children and teenagers with life-threatening illnesses, got an early Christmas gift nine days ago. Morgan Keegan, a brokerage firm in Memphis, made an undisclosed payment to the charity to settle an arbitration claim; the Wish Fund said it had lost $48,000 in a mutual fund from Morgan Keegan that had invested heavily in dicey mortgage securities.

headline: This Land Is Newark’s Land
text: In the coming weeks, Newark will begin selling off a new batch of city-owned lots to private developers at market prices. Conspicuous by their absence in this process are the phrases “sweetheart deals” and “politically connected cronies.”

headline: Tali Sedgwick, Adam Walden
text: Tali Sirena Sedgwick and Adam Ross Walden were married at the New York City Municipal Building in Manhattan on Thursday. Soraida Burgos, a staff member in the city clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Another Little Italy, With Scant Parking to Match
text: IF it hadn’t been for the biting northeastern wind the other day, you might have thought La Casa del Caffe in Morris Park in the Bronx was actually in Italy instead.

headline: Forgotten, Yes. But Happy Birthday Anyway
text: I SUPPOSE I already knew that it was a little perverse to be setting off in search of one of history’s losers. But even the French seemed to think it was odd. Georges-Louis Leclerc? The Comte de Buffon? I e-mailed well in advance to the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, the natural history museum in Paris that Buffon largely founded. But the press office there seemed barely to have heard of the man. Like everybody else in the biological world, they were perhaps too busy celebrating the tercentennial of the great Swedish botanist Carolus Linnaeus, who was Buffon’s archenemy.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘The Boys From Dolores’
text: A review on Dec. 9 about “The Boys From Dolores: Fidel Castro’s Schoolmates From Revolution to Exile,” by Patrick Symmes, referred incorrectly to the Colegio de Dolores, the elite Jesuit-run prep school Castro attended in the late 1930s and early ’40s; it was not also a “military” school. The review also referred imprecisely to other private schools around the world that were bastions of their colonial societies. Though they tended to be authoritarian, to have close ties with the colonial establishment and to exhibit varying degrees of military-associated features, they were not necessarily military schools.

headline: Mr. Murdoch Builds His Dream House
text: USUALLY, the apartments of the rich are very private, their marble floors and high ceilings hidden from view. But the renovations of Rupert Murdoch’s triplex at 834 Fifth Avenue are so expansive that they are visible from the street.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE UNWRAPPING: So what did you get for Christmas, book-wise? Inside the List asked a few best-selling novelists what they planned to give this season. Ken Follet replied: “I will give ‘The Bad Girl,’ by Mario Vargas Llosa, to someone I am attracted to, because it is sexy, romantic and sad.” Jan Karon said she is giving “the exquisitely witty and wise ‘Uncommon Reader,’ by Alan Bennett.” Sue Grafton laughed and said, “Other than my own?” She went on: “It would have to be ‘Vogue Knitting: The Ultimate Knitting Book.’ I’m really into knitting, and so is my friend. It’s this beautiful glossy book with all kinds of beautiful illustrations and all sorts of information about the process and art of knitting.” James Patterson told us: “I am absolutely devoted to giving my son books for Christmas. This year he will be receiving ‘To Kill a Mockingbird.’” Mitch Albom said he’s giving “Tony Bennett in the Studio: A Life of Art and Music,” by Tony Bennett with Robert Sullivan. “Tony is a national treasure, and my friend, and giving this book is like giving an autobiography, a record collection and a tabletop art gallery all at once.” Dean Koontz said: “I am giving two-book sets of ‘A History of the English-Speaking Peoples Since 1900,’ by Andrew Roberts, and ‘Lone Survivor,’ by Marcus Luttrell with Patrick Robinson. In vigorous, pellucid prose, Roberts writes history with attitude and well-argued conviction. Luttrell and the Navy Seals of whom he writes are the embodiments of the ideals and the valor central to the culture chronicled in Roberts’s work.” And Nicholas Sparks told us: “I’m giving ‘The Afghan Campaign,’ by Steven Pressfield, to half a dozen people, and certainly to those who loved Pressfield’s earlier novel ‘Gates of Fire.’ It’s a marvelous story, wondrously told, a novel that keeps the pages turning, the readers guessing, and makes one feel as if they, too, were in the army, marching with Alexander the Great.”

headline: Strong Opinions
text: “Diary of a Bad Year” is not the first among J. M. Coetzee works of fiction to force readers to consider the friable boundary between fiction and nonfiction. “Elizabeth Costello” reveals its eponymous heroine, a literary celebrity, through a series of lectures given by Costello, their content familiar from essays published previously  by J. M. Coetzee. Thus instructed to conflate Costello with her creator, Coetzee’s readers encounter her again, in his following novel, “Slow Man,” which finds Costello taking up residence in the home of the protagonist, Paul Rayment, as he examines his life in the wake of a crippling accident. “Like it or not, I will be with you a while yet,” Costello informs her reluctant host. She’s brought a “hefty typescript” with her, and it appears she is the author of Paul’s fate, nudging him toward fulfillment. Or is she a product of his imagination? Certain of Costello’s exasperated comments to Paul  “I did not ask for you”  imply she has no more control over their peculiar pairing than does he. “Diary of a Bad Year” forgoes the conceit of a perfunctorily named and differentiated alter ego by following the late career of Señor C, who, like Coetzee, is a South African writer transplanted to Australia and the author of a novel titled “Waiting for the Barbarians.”

headline: Nature as the Palette of the Soul
text: For those who know what to look for, American art history contains all kinds of surprises. One of them is Christopher Pearse Cranch (1813-1892), a poet, author and landscape painter of talent who has spent much of the past century in obscurity.

headline: Film
text: AMERICANS stayed away from movies about the war in Iraq, but that war didn’t stay away from either us or the big screen. If anything, the war has been relentlessly present this film year, in the oil that gushes like blood in “There Will Be Blood” and the blood that gushes like oil in “Sweeney Todd.” These films do not have to be about Iraq, consciously or not, to speak to the times and the raw fear, wrath, greed, madness and thirst for vengeance that helped spur the country into this war. The war is in these films and us both.

headline: Venus’s Navel: Tortellini Lessons at the Source

headline: Subtly Terrifying, Just Like Real Life
text: A LOT of movie comedies are described as horrible. And plenty of horror films make people laugh. Faced with excruciatingly gory, sadistic or otherwise twisted imagery, an audience invariably giggles, prompted by nerves, revulsion or embarrassment.

headline: The Guardians
text: They came from different Americas only to find themselves together, as soldiers will do, in a strange land. Yance Tell Gray, 26, grew up on a ranch in Ismay, Mont., and could ride and rope and brand while he was still a child. Gray was so eager to join the Army that he signed up while still in high school; his parents had to sign a waiver. Omar Mora, 28, came to the United States from Ecuador as a 2-year-old and grew up in La Marque, near Houston. He was working as a stock boy in Lowe’s home-improvement store when, in 2004, he decided to enlist. He still had only a green card.

headline: Letters: Not Dialects
text: To the Editor: I would like to point out that in the article "In Tikal, Temples in the Mist" (Dec. 16) about Tikal, the ancient Mayan site in Guatemala, the author perhaps unknowingly erred when he referred to Guatemala’s “dialects.” This is how they are commonly referred to in Spanish, as implicit claims that these are dialects of Spanish.

headline: C. Vivian Stringer
text: C. Vivian Stringer knew a few things about grace in the face of ugliness long before the radio host Don Imus disrupted her life.

headline: Selections From Opinion Online
text: Jet Lagged  If you take to the air to celebrate the holidays  I just flew from Japan to California to spend the season with my mother  jet lag is going to be the uninvited Scrooge at the dinner table. It’s always there, this shadowy specter with mangled syllables and crossing eyes, and it’s likely to make you kiss Uncle Bud on the lips and give Aunt Irma a hunting knife for Christmas. You’re not really responsible for what you do in its thrall, but if you’re looking for a “trip” or a “foreign influence,” look no further than this creature inside you that just tempted me to sign up for a prepaid cremation and to be moved by a letter that, a week from now, I’d hardly notice.

headline: The Liberated Chef
text: The men who ruled the world in the late 1950s, or at least six of the men who ruled publishing, rejected Peg Bracken’s manuscript, “The I Hate to Cook Book.” It would never sell, they told her, because “women regard cooking as sacred.” It took a female editor at Harcourt Brace to look at the hundreds of easy-to-follow recipes wittily pitched at the indentured housewife and say, “Hallelujah!” Since its publication in 1960, Bracken’s iconic book, which celebrated the speedy virtues of canned cream-of-mushroom soup and chicken bouillon cubes, has sold more than three million copies. That helped lift her spirits, her daughter, Jo Bracken, said, about her $338 advance.

headline: Dial-Tone Phreak
text: Someday there will be no need of the dial tone, and for a few of us it will be as if the voice of God has gone dead. That reassuring voice that will speak to anyone who knows how to listen: like God, it exists everywhere and yet only in your cupped ear, even if you’re a small blind boy with a reputed 172 I.Q. whose parents are fighting late at night.

headline: To Botch a Forecast, Rely on Past Experience
The Face of War
text: Until Susan Sontag disavowed some of her more arch anxieties in “Regarding the Pain of Others,” intellectual debate over the depiction of atrocities was mostly a chronicle of aesthetic alarmism. Walter Benjamin’s notion that photography creates “a new reality in the face of which no one can take responsibility for personal decisions” turned out to be fairly silly. John Berger’s idea that overexposure to violent images leads us into unconscionable passivity is demonstrably untrue. (Vide Vietnam.) Terrain that has tripped up such great critical minds is not to be entered incautiously.

headline: A Perfect Match

Among their usual culprits: television in general and in particular game shows, perhaps the strongest a posteriori evidence that Americans’ brains were getting flabby on cultural junk food.

headline: Up Front
text: On our cover this week, Kathryn Harrison reviews J. M. Coetzee’s latest novel, “Diary of a Bad Year.” A frequent contributor to the Book Review, Harrison has been closely following Coetzee’s career ever since she read “The Life and Times of Michael K,” which remains a favorite. Coetzee, she wrote in an e-mail message, “is never sentimental, and he pushes his characters right up against the problem of mortality and the inescapable cruelty of life. It’s not so much that he doesn’t spare the reader from pain as that he doesn’t spare himself. And then there’s the writing, which is clean and stark, beautiful as the desert is beautiful, an ecosystem in which nothing is wasted. Coetzee understands that a writer’s restraint is the catalyst for a reader’s emotional response, and his sentences feel less written than rendered, subjected to a heat or pressure that removes all but the essential.”

headline: His View From the Bridge
text: BECAUSE Ben Cipriano is a wisecracking kind of guy, maybe it’s best to begin his story in the form of a joke: How many electricians does it take to screw in all the light bulbs on the Brooklyn Bridge? The answer is six. Not much of a punch line, but it has the advantage of being factually correct. Their names are Jerry, Tommy, Richie, Mike and Bobby, plus Mr. Cipriano, the boss, who has been climbing bridge cables for more than 20 years and does not plan to stop any time soon.

headline: Letters: The Huckabee Factor
text: In his illuminating article, Zev Chafets (Dec. 16) ends with a discussion of Mike Huckabee’s possible interest in second place on the Republican ticket. He quotes the Republican consultant Mike Murphy as saying “vice presidents become presidents.” In fact, since Martin Van Buren succeeded Andrew Jackson to the presidency in 1837 no sitting vice president was elected to the presidency until the election of George H. W. Bush in 1988. Recently, except for Bush 41, all sitting vice presidents running for the presidency  Nixon, Humphrey, Mondale and Gore  have been defeated.

headline: Record-Setting Night, Perfect Finish for Patriots
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The New England Patriots’ season began here with a scandal and, of course, a victory. This alarmed me. Not because I wanted them singing a say yes to drugs song. But wasn’t this a little young to start the indoctrination?

headline: A Tyrant With a Focus on Love’s Uncertainty
text: IN “The 13th Letter,” Otto Preminger’s 1951 remake of the Henri-Georges Clouzot film “Le Corbeau,” a village doctor (Charles Boyer) lectures a younger colleague (Michael Rennie) on human nature.

headline: The Eye on the Prize
text: Ernest C. Withers had not been a Memphis police officer very long when he saw the limits of his power. In 1948, he became one of the first nine black police officers hired by the city. They were allowed uniforms, patrol cars and guns, but they were barred from patrolling white neighborhoods or arresting white people. Their job was to keep the peace in black Memphis, particularly inside the thriving and jiving Club Ebony, Club Paradise, Club Handy, Currie’s Club Tropicana and other night spots. The gatekeepers of the white supremacist code wanted to confine, contain and keep the police officers where all black Southerners were expected to stay: in their place, isolated and invisible.

headline: 76ers Trade Korver
text: The Philadelphia 76ers acquired guard Gordan Giricek and a first-round draft pick from the Utah Jazz for guard Kyle Korver on Saturday.The 6-foot-5 Giricek averaged 4.3 points in 22 games for the Jazz this season and has career average of 9.8 in six seasons.“We are excited about acquiring a player of Gordan’s ability, as well as an additional asset in the form of a first-round draft pick,” 76ers General Manager Ed Stefanski said. “This move will provide us with increased salary-cap flexibility this off-season and also allows us to continue our evaluation and development of the young talent we have on this team.”Korver averaged 10 points in 25 games with the 76ers and was their top 3-point threat. In four seasons with Philadelphia, Korver averaged 10.5 points and shot 42 percent.“I want to thank Kyle for the positive impact he has made on this team and the city of Philadelphia through his play on the court and, even more importantly, his philanthropic efforts off of it,” Stefanski said.

headline: Immigration and the Candidates
text: Even by the low standards of presidential campaigns, the issue of immigration has been badly served in the 2008 race. Candidates  and by this we mean the Republicans, mostly  have been striking poses and offering prescriptions that sound tough but will solve nothing. They have distorted or disowned their pasts and attacked one another ferociously, but over appearances, not ideas  over who can claim to be the authentic scourge of illegal immigrants, and who is the Lou-Dobbs-Come-Lately.

headline: Memories of a Venerable Showcase
text: FROM dance enclaves in the Bronx to roving, artist-run collectives, showcases for “emerging choreographers”  that fuzzy, mutable category  are a dime a dozen these days. But this week one of the pioneers, the Fresh Tracks series at Dance Theater Workshop in Chelsea, reaches an important milestone: 500 artists presented, counting a few double appearances.

headline: A Day of Free Lessons in Playing in the Snow
text: Winter Trails 2008 is a program that invites children and adults to break out of their holiday stupor and get out for free lessons in cross-country skiing and/or snowshoeing.

headline: ‘An Ordinary Spy’

headline: ‘The Geography of Bliss’
text: My bags were packed and my provisions loaded. I was ready for adventure. And so, on a late summer afternoon, I dragged my reluctant friend Drew off to explore new worlds and, I hoped, to ﬁ nd some happiness along the way. I’ve always believed that happiness is just around the corner. The trick is ﬁnding the right corner.

headline: ‘The Long Embrace’
text: In March of 1986 I began reading the collected letters of Raymond Chandler. I was at the time living in an apartment on Carondelet Street in an older part of Los Angeles where Chandler himself had once lived. My neighbors were mostly elderly people who had lived in my building for many years and with whom I had very little contact, except for one old woman who occupied the apartment above me. I had once kicked her little dog when it attempted to bite me as I came up the front steps, and for this she took to tormenting me whenever she could. She would rise early and shuffle past my bedroom window in her heavy leather slippers, speaking baby talk to her small dog or singing loudly, making as much noise as possible in order to interrupt my sleep. She broke flowers off their stems, left bits of paper scattered in my garden. Sometimes when my husband and I returned home, she would be waiting for us and lean out her window and call out in a high, shrill voice, "It's the intelligentsia — the intelligentsia has returned!" She divided the word intelligentsia into separate syllables, flinging each one down at us as we hurried to open our door. Only in L.A., I thought, could someone make this word sound like a term of such utter derision.

headline: Meet the New Huck
text: Former Governor Mike Huckabee of Arkansas unveiled a pugnacious new stump speech on Saturday, tearing into the credibility of rival Mitt Romney, the Bush administration’s handling of the war, and “east coast establishment Republicans” in general.

text: Now that U.C.L.A. has hired Rick Neuheisel, it has to deal with the questions about his past. The Los Angeles Times’ Bill Plaschke writes that the future of the Bruins’ program depends on Neuheisel being honest when he says he’s learned from past mistakes.

headline: Immigration Exhibit in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — Immigration is a hot button issue at the Iowa caucuses and an exhibit at the Des Moines Art Center, the city’s elegant Richard Meier-designed museum, provides plenty of political satire for thought. Entitled “Borderlandia,” the 70-piece exhibit explores the cultural and political divisions between Mexico and the United States – with a healthy dose of criticism of the current anti-immigration movement.

text: NEW ORLEANS — Colt Brennan readily acknowledged earlier this week that he could help his draft status immensely with a solid performance in the Sugar Bowl. Right now, the N.F.L. draft guru Gil Brandt said that Brennan projected as a solid second rounder. Wherever he goes, Brennan is probably the most intriguing quarterback in this year’s draft.

headline: Putting Dodd on the Map
text: One of the Harvard students involved in the Campus Voices project at the Institute of Politics there traveled to Iowa this weekend from her home in Omaha during the holiday break. She caught up with Democratic Senator Chris Dodd’s campaign as he talked to patrons at a diner, and she delved into the differences between caucusing and a primary. The students have been largely following events leading up to the New Hampshire primary.

text: The forecast for Sunday’s Jets-Chiefs game calls for rain and possibly sleet or snow. No matter how the weather turns out, Giants Stadium will remain dry. The Jets announced before the game that alcohol would not be served at the stadium.

headline: Will More Eyes Make Us Safer?
text: You know the old saw – “there are three kinds of lies: lies, damn lies and statistics.” The quip was brought to mind when I glanced at the year-end Department of Homeland Security fact sheet touting what it’s done to make us safer. Among the featured items was “increasing by more than 175 percent the number of personnel trained in techniques to identify high-risk passengers in airports.”

headline: Rangers vs. Canada
text: Thanks to a quirk in the Rangers’ schedule, Sean Avery’s Canadian-baiting came at a rather appropriate time, with the Rangers in the middle of playing every Canadian team in a span of seven games. It started with Ottawa’s visit to Madison Square Garden last Sunday, continued in Toronto on Saturday, Montreal visiting the Garden tonight, then a three-game swing through Calgary, Vancouver and Edmonton this week.

headline: Playoff Possibilities: Who’s No. 6?
text: UPDATE, 11:20 p.m.: The Tennessee Titans, despite losing quarterback Vince Young to an injury in the third quarter, defeated the Indianapolis Colts, 16-10, to clinch the sixth and final playoff spot in the A.F.C. Naturally, in a season of backup quarterbacks, Kerry Collins led the Titans on the tying and winning drives in the third and fourth quarters. (Kerry Collins is no relation to Todd Collins, the backup quarterback who led Washington to a playoff-clinching win earlier Sunday.) The Titans will face the third-seeded San Diego Chargers next Sunday afternoon.

headline: Pakistan’s Zapruder Film Surfaces
text: Britain’s Channel 4 News has broadcast new video of the attack on Benazir Bhutto “apparently contradicting the official version of events, which insists that Benazir Bhutto was not shot.” The Channel 4 report, by correspondent Jonathan Rugman, argues forcefully that Ms. Bhutto was shot by an assassin, who is clearly visible in the new video, moments before a suicide bomber detonated an explosive device beside the vehicle she was standing in.

text: The most fiercely fought election in Kenya's history has pitched one of the most stable nations in Africa toward chaos.

headline: U.S. Experts Criticize Bhutto Post-Mortem
text: Leading American experts in forensic pathology this weekend deplored the failure of Pakistani officials to order an autopsy of Benazir Bhutto, saying that the standard medical procedure was a crucial part of any credible investigation of a murder.

headline: American Edged in Combined
text: Magnus Moan of Norway won a Nordic combined World Cup event in Oberhof, Germany, edging Bill Demong of the United States by one-tenth of a second in a photo finish. Moan finished the 15-kilometer cross-country race in 40 minutes 8.8 seconds.

headline: On America’s Watch
text: In recent years, Pakistan has been the home of banks that wired money for the 9/11 plot, been the chief source of illicit nuclear proliferation, offered a tribal-area haven for planners of worldwide terrorism, abetted the reconstitution of the Taliban and educated many a suicide bomber in Islamic religious schools.

headline: Mediators Receive Role in Oscar Dispute
text: A judge has ordered mediation in a lawsuit brought by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to bar the public sale of two Oscars awarded to the silent-film star Mary Pickford (1892-1979) and one presented to her husband Buddy Rogers (1904-99), The Associated Press reported. The defendant is Rogers’s second wife, Beverly Rogers. The academy argues that under its bylaws, it gets the first chance to buy the Oscars, for $10 each. If mediation fails, the dispute is scheduled to go to trial next year.

headline: Robin Williams to Be Letterman Guest
text: In the first competitive move in what may become a booking blitz, David Letterman has booked Robin Williams as the first guest on his late-night show when he returns to the air Wednesday night.

headline: No Accident Charge Against Brandy
text: Citing insufficient evidence, prosecutors in Los Angeles have decided not to charge the Grammy Award-winning singer and actress Brandy, below, in connection with a car crash in December 2006 that killed a 38-year-old woman, Reuters reported. The police had recommended that Brandy, 28, whose real name is Brandy Norwood, be charged with vehicular manslaughter in the accident, involving four vehicles. A lawyer for Ms. Norwood, who starred in the television comedy “Moesha,” said she was “extremely pleased” at the prosecutors’ conclusion. Relatives of the dead woman, Awatef Aboudihaj, have filed a $50 million wrongful-death lawsuit against Ms. Norwood.

headline: Radio’s Challenge: Counting the Young
text: As radio moves away from an outdated system of audience measurement, it is facing the same problem that confronts other media: figuring out how many young people are listening or watching is maddeningly difficult.

headline: Macs, PCs and Music Downloads
text: Macintosh owners are far more likely than PC owners to have recently paid for a music download, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm. In the third quarter of 2007, exactly half of Mac owners paid to download music at least once, while only 16 percent of PC owners did. The data was derived from an online panel of 4,915 people and weighted to reflect the United States’ online population.

headline: Seminoles Meet Kentucky After Facing a Scandal
text: It almost sounds like a joke. Florida State’s football team will be short-handed and vulnerable in the Music City Bowl against Kentucky on Monday because the Seminoles will be missing players who were suspended for cheating on, of all things, a music test.

headline: In Prison, Toddlers Serve Time With Mom
text: MEXICO CITY  Beyond the high concrete walls and menacing guard towers of the Santa Martha Acatitla prison, past the barbed wire, past the iron gates, past the armed guards in black commando garb, sits a nursery school with brightly painted walls, piles of toys and a jungle gym.

headline: A Guide to Embracing Life as a Single (Without the Resignation, That Is)
text: For some singles at New Year’s Eve soirees tonight, the minutes leading up to midnight will be agonizing as they ponder whom they’ll be standing next to at the pucker-up moment.

headline: Dance Film Wins Baghdad Festival
text: The French short film “La Danse, l’Art de la Rencontre” (“Dance and the Art of Encounters”) won first prize at the first Baghdad international film festival held in the Iraqi capital since 2005, Agence France-Presse reported. Directed by Domenica Hervieu, the documentary is a poetic exploration of the world of dance. Tight security surrounded the festival, held at the Palestine Hotel, where 63 films from around the world were screened.

headline: Web Playgrounds of the Very Young
text: LOS ANGELES  Forget Second Life. The real virtual world gold rush centers on the grammar-school set.

headline: Markets Close Lower to End the Year
text: In what was perhaps a fitting finish to an underwhelming year, the stock market closed down modestly on Monday.

headline: After the Pain of a Son’s Death, a Shared Mission in Politics
text: In an instant, a world in which everything seemed right suddenly seemed all wrong. John and Elizabeth Edwards’s 16-year-old son, Wade, their first-born, was dead, with nothing to blame but the gust of wind that had flipped his car off a wide-open road.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Friday for Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister of Pakistan, incorrectly described her children. She had one son, Bilawal, and two daughters, Bakhtwar and Aseefa, not two sons and one daughter. It included the wrong year for the death of her brother Shahnawaz. It was in 1985, not 1995. It also gave the incorrect name for the entity that broadcast an interview about the sale of Pakistan’s nuclear technology to other states. It was the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, not Company.

headline: Saying He Pulled Negative Ad, Huckabee Shows It
text: DES MOINES  In an act of political jujitsu, Mike Huckabee has halted a negative ad that he was about to broadcast on television Monday against his Republican rival, Mitt Romney. But while claiming the moral high ground, he proceeded to show the ad to a roomful of reporters, photographers and television cameras who are repeating his anti-Romney message for free while Mr. Huckabee declares that his hands are clean.

headline: Curry Doesn’t Start, and It Doesn’t Help
text: Whether slumped at his locker in a dress shirt and tie, or slumped on the bench in his blue warm-ups, Eddy Curry presented an apt portrait Sunday of all that has gone horribly wrong for the Knicks.

headline: Democrats Try Various Styles, and Pronouns
text: DES MOINES  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s appearances are not billed as anything so conventional as mere “rallies” or “town meetings” or “speeches.”

headline: New Year’s Eve
text: At midnight tonight, the horses on this farm will age a year. That is the custom  every horse has the same birthday, Jan. 1. Like all things calendrical, this is a human convention. When it comes to equine conventions, I know enough to notice some of the simpler forms of precedence: who goes first through a gate, who gets to the grain feeder ahead of the others. But I can report that the horses make no fuss about their common birthday or the coming of the new year. Tonight, like any other, they will be standing, dozing on their feet, ears tipping back and forth at the slightest of sounds.

headline: The Going Got Tough, So Jones Got Going
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Thomas Jones had yardage to gain and a game to win. He was not worried about what would happen to him or the Jets after they played the Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday. He was not thinking about Darren McFadden, either.

headline: What if Iowa Settles Nothing for Democrats?
text: DES MOINES  Iowa is packed with presidential candidates and hundreds of campaign aides, advisers and contributors. Twenty-five hundred representatives of news organizations have been granted credentials to cover the caucuses on Thursday night, twice as many as in 2004. Rarely has a political event been so intensely anticipated as a decisive moment, at least on the Democratic side.

headline: Youthful Holiday for Strings, With André Watts on Piano
text: The second half of December seems to be the time when classical music’s old pros go away and the young and aspiring take over. In recent weeks at Carnegie Hall the pianist Emanuel Ax and several colleagues taught students how to play Brahms duo-sonatas, and Ensemble ACJW, consisting of postgraduate instrumentalists halfway between further education and careers, has given concerts.

headline: In the DVD War Over High Definition, Most Buyers Are Sitting It Out
text: What if nobody wins the high-definition DVD format wars? That increasingly looks to be the situation for the next-generation DVD technology, which is available to consumers in two incompatible formats.

headline: British Queen Honors Minogue and McKellen
text: The pop singer Kylie Minogue and the actor Ian McKellen were among the names on the traditional New Year’s honors list issued by Queen Elizabeth II, according to Reuters and the BBC. Ms. Minogue, who returned to the stage late last year after surgery and chemotherapy for breast cancer, becomes an officer of the Order of the British Empire. Mr. McKellen, a Shakespearean actor perhaps best known for his portrayal of the wizard Gandalf in the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy, was made a Companion of Honor, restricted to 65 members. Among others on the honors list were the Jethro Tull frontman Ian Anderson, the actors Richard Griffiths and Julie Walters, the novelist and playwright Hanif Kureishi and Nicholas Kenyon, managing director of the Barbican Center and former director of the BBC Proms. The list was the first to be recommended to the queen by Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

headline: New Questions Arise in Killing of Ex-Premier
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  New details of Benazir Bhutto’s final moments, including indications that her doctors felt pressured to conform to government accounts of her death, fueled the arguments over her assassination on Sunday and added to the pressure on Pakistan’s leaders to accept an international inquiry.

headline: Naked or in a Wolf Suit, Sex in Its Many Guises
text: “Everyone wants to read about sex!” Lucia Perillo writes in her essay in “Do Me,” an eclectic literary anthology dedicated to sex in all its glorious  and not so glorious  iterations.

headline: The Great Divide
text: Yesterday The Times published a highly informative chart laying out the positions of the presidential candidates on major issues. It was, I’d argue, a useful reality check for those who believe that the next president can somehow usher in a new era of bipartisan cooperation.

headline: To Mark 100 New Years, a Much Brighter Ball
text: It was not always a midnight kaleidoscope of roaring multitudes and a 1,200-pound sphere clad in Waterford crystal, with 30,000 watts of light-emitting diodes to dazzle America. A century ago Monday, the first New Year’s ball descended in Times Square and a tradition was born, with modest crowds cheering a five-foot iron globe studded with 216 electric lamps.

headline: U.N. Force Takes Control in Darfur
text: The United Nations officially began a new peacekeeping effort on Monday in the Darfur region of western Sudan in a ceremony that transferred power from the African Union. The Sudanese government had spent months resisting admission of the international force.

text: This television advertisement for Mitt Romney, his third aiming at Mike Huckabee, is running in Iowa.

headline: Markets End Lower to End the Year
text: In what was perhaps a fitting finish to an underwhelming year, the stock market closed down modestly on Monday.

headline: Orphans Who Thrived
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turmoil Grows in Kenya, With More Than 100 Dead
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The post-election turbulence continued to spread in Kenya on Monday as a curfew was imposed in Kisumu, the nation’s third-largest city; ethnic fighting intensified; and more than 100 people were killed.

headline: In His Own Magazine, an Editor Puts Himself Into an Elite Group
text: Talk about prestigious and prominent bylines: the table of contents of one new publication includes Thucydides, Shakespeare, Tolstoy, Osama bin Laden, Pope Urban II, Lenin ...and Lewis H. Lapham.

headline: Spain Snaps Up Follett Novel
text: Who may be bigger in Spain than J. K. Rowling? None other than Ken Follett, best known for his thrillers. About 525,000 copies of the Spanish translation of his new historical novel, “World Without End,” sold out within hours of being put on sale on Friday, Agence France-Presse reported. The daily newspaper El Mundo said Mondadori, the publisher, had ordered a rush reprint of 175,000. The publisher said that the single-day sales were unsurpassed, even by Ms. Rowling’s “Harry Potter” books. The publisher said that “The Pillars of the Earth,” a 1989 prequel to “World Without End,” had sold 5.5 million copies as the novel most read by Spaniards in the last 20 years.

headline: When the Germans, and Rockets, Came to Town
text: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  In 1950, this cotton market town in northern Alabama lost a bid for a military aviation project that would have revived its mothballed arsenal. The consolation prize was dubious: 118 German rocket scientists who had surrendered to the Americans during World War II, led by a man  a crackpot, evidently  who claimed humans could visit the moon.

headline: Tear Gas Not Fog? Oops!
text: Releasing tear gas instead of fog as planned, a Berlin theater sent its audience fleeing from a performance based on the 1928 German children’s book “Emil and the Detectives,” Agence France-Presse reported. The mistake took place on Saturday afternoon at the Volksbühne theater in central Berlin, where about 100 people were watching the show. Several had to be treated for eye problems.

headline: Learning From Experience
text: To the Editor:

headline: Davenport Takes Tuneup
text: Lindsay Davenport got off to a good start in her first tuneup event for the Australian Open, beating Laura Granville, 6-2, 6-3, on Monday in the first round of the ASB Women’s Classic in Auckland, New Zealand. Davenport, 31, won in 66 minutes. The Australian Open will be her first Grand Slam event in more than a year.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For New Year’s Eve in Iowa, Restrained Revelry
In Restless Pursuit of Craigslist’s Success
text: MICROSOFT tried. Google tried. Now it’s eBay’s turn to see if it can dethrone the Web’s most spectacularly successful underdog, Craigslist.

headline: The Office Pool, 2008
text: Washington

headline: What’s That Catchy Tune? A Song for Car Insurance Makes the Charts
text: It would be unremarkable that the song “From Where You Are” by Jason Wade, a singer in the band Lifehouse, had cracked the Billboard top 100 list  except that it was written for an Allstate commercial.

headline: Elections Face Possible Delay as Pakistani Tensions Grow
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  The most experienced opposition politician in Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, upped the ante in the coming confrontation with the ruling party on Monday, calling for President Pervez Musharraf’s immediate resignation and the formation of a government of national consensus.

headline: About That Peace Process
text: It didn’t take long for the glow of the Annapolis peace conference to wear off. Israelis and Palestinians have quickly fallen back into predictable destructive patterns. Arab countries have not done anywhere near enough to support the negotiations. Even the United States is behind on its pledges: because of bureaucratic wrangling and Israeli doubts, it has yet to establish a promised “mechanism” to monitor the two sides’ behavior and pressure them into meeting their commitments.

headline: Jihadists in Jails Win Leverage Over Their Keepers
text: CASABLANCA, Morocco  Ahmed Rafiki sprawled on the makeshift couch in his cell, a fresh red henna dye in his long hair and beard.

headline: 'National Treasure' Remains a Gold Mine
text: “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” (distributed by Disney) dominated North American box offices for a second consecutive weekend, holding the No. 1 ranking by taking in an estimated $35.6 million at 3,832 theaters for a two-week total of $124 million. “Alvin and the Chipmunks” (Fox), starring Jason Lee as the surrogate father of the animated musical ’munks, clambered up the ladder to second place from third last week on a gross of $30 million at 3,484 theaters, bringing its three-week total to $142.3 million, according to the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers. Although “I Am Legend” (Warner Brothers), with Will Smith, dropped to third place from second, it attracted $27.5 million at 3,636 theaters to push its three-week total to $194.6 million. “Charlie Wilson’s War” (Universal), starring Tom Hanks as a conniving congressman, held on to fourth place, with $11.7 million at 2,575 theaters. Fox Searchlight’s well-received “Juno,” with $10.3 million from 998 theaters, finished fifth. On a per-screen basis, Paul Thomas Anderson’s “There Will Be Blood” (Paramount Vantage), starring Daniel Day-Lewis as a monstrous oilman, was the weekend’s winner, averaging $92,763 on each of two screens.

headline: From the Kaplan Regional, a Plan-the-Defense Exercise

The first events were held Wednesday, when the winners of the top bracket in the Knockout Teams were Ruth Stober of Great Neck, N.Y.; Steven Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y.; Julian Heicklen of Teaneck, N.J.; and Brett Kunin of West Orange, N.J. headline: Attack on 2 Israeli Settlers Rattles Peace Negotiations

headline: Low Murder Rate Brings New York Back to ’63
text: It was a year of trauma for the nation, and of foreboding for New York City. In 1963, the year that John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, New Yorkers were feeling strains in the urban fabric: Affluent families fled to the suburbs, job losses mounted among old-line manufacturers, and 548 people were killed.

headline: Stray Bullet Kills Woman in New Jersey
text: A woman in Irvington, N.J., was killed instantly on Saturday night when a stray bullet pierced the wall of her bedroom and struck her in the head, the authorities and relatives said.

headline: Stiegler Injured in Crash
text: Resi Stiegler of the United States, a slalom specialist, will be sidelined two months after a crash Friday during the first run of a World Cup giant slalom in Lienz, Austria. Stiegler, 22, sustained a broken left forearm and right shinbone and torn knee ligaments. She will have surgery.

headline: Successor to Lott Is Chosen
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Roger Wicker, a conservative Republican from northern Mississippi, was named on Monday to the United States Senate seat just vacated by Trent Lott, setting off a political battle in Mississippi that could have an impact in Washington.

headline: Children Contest James Brown Will
text: Five of James Brown’s children are seeking to invalidate his will on grounds that former advisers seeking to profit unduly influenced Brown, below, to create charitable trusts, The Associated Press reported, citing court documents. The children of Brown, the soul singer, were largely excluded from the financial part of the will, which left the bulk of Brown’s money to trusts to educate his grandchildren and needy youngsters. Five of the Brown children are challenging the will in Aiken County Probate Court in South Carolina. One of the former advisers, Albert H.  Dallas, denied the accusations and called efforts to void the will “an act of desperation.” One grandchild whose tuition would be paid by trusts created under the will accused his relatives of trying to break the charities to get the money. Most of Brown’s estate, including his home in Beech Island, S.C., and rights to his image, name and music, would go to the James Brown “I Feel Good” Trust for the education of needy children in South Carolina and Georgia, as well as to a family trust to educate Brown’s grandchildren younger than 35. He died at 73 on Christmas Day 2006.

headline: Three Men Are Killed in Brooklyn Gunfire
text: Three men were killed in separate shootings in Brooklyn on Sunday night.

headline: Awkward Encounters in the Hollywood Trenches
text: LOS ANGELES  A dozen striking screenwriters gathered in the bar at the Hotel Bel Air not long ago to decompress after another day on the picket line. Less than 10 feet away sat another strike-weary pair: Peter Chernin, president of the News Corporation, and Barry Meyer, chief executive of Warner Brothers.

headline: St. Pierre Rolls
text: Georges St.-Pierre overwhelmed Matt Hughes and won by a verbal tap-out in the second round to take the interim welterweight title Saturday night at UFC 79 in Las Vegas.

headline: Looking at America
text: There are too many moments these days when we cannot recognize our country. Sunday was one of them, as we read the account in The Times of how men in some of the most trusted posts in the nation plotted to cover up the torture of prisoners by Central Intelligence Agency interrogators by destroying videotapes of their sickening behavior. It was impossible to see the founding principles of the greatest democracy in the contempt these men and their bosses showed for the Constitution, the rule of law and human decency.

headline: Opposition Parties Vow to Proceed With Jan. 8 Election
text: NAUDERO, Pakistan  Three days after the violent killing of its leader, Benazir Bhutto, Pakistan’s largest political party on Sunday picked her 19-year-old son to succeed her as chairman and vowed to forge ahead with elections next week, immediately creating a new quandary for the government about whether to delay the vote.

headline: As Ailing Son Declines, a Mother Keeps the Faith
text: The hiss of an electric respirator fills Dorian Reyes’s room. He is tethered to three other machines: one monitors his heart rate, one keeps his failing lungs clear and another delivers liquid food intravenously. With them he has vital signs; without them he will die.

headline: Schumer Visits Troops in Iraq on New Year’s Eve

headline: Heras Reportedly Ends Pro Career

headline: Fatal Crash Ends Serbian 'Big Brother'
text: The death of three former contestants in an automobile accident on Saturday night brought a sudden cancellation of the Serbian version of the “Big Brother” reality show, Agence France-Presse reported on Sunday, citing the producer and broadcaster. After the fatal crash near Belgrade , the remaining seven housemates were taken from the home that is the setting for the show and told the news off-camera. The contest was to have ended on Jan. 5.

Vodafone and Orange, two other British mobile phone companies, have been talking about a similar deal since February.

headline: Here’s to the Non-Working Vacation
text: For a time, I went on a lot of short vacations, always remaining plugged in. I never fell behind on work, and for that reason, it was easier to catch up when I got home. I also never got very far from New York, which meant that I stopped feeling like a traveler, by which I mean someone who knows what is going on in other countries. But I like being a traveler. So it didn’t feel good not to be one. Lots of independent workers, especially those who work online, live like this.

headline: Clinton Joins Fight Over Fighting Special Interests
text: KEOKUK, Iowa – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the Obama-Edwards fray over fighting special interests on Monday afternoon, arguing that her rivals should stop “jumping up and down” and instead devise a strategy to pass health insurance and energy reforms over the objections of drug, health, and oil companies.

headline: Whose Interests Are Special?
text: Barack Obama has always excited big Labor and other Democratic constituencies, even if they weren’t necessarily ready to endorse him for the presidency. Now, though, as Mr. Obama goes all out to undermine a surging John Edwards in the final days before the Iowa caucuses, that cordial relationship is being put to the test. Mr. Obama has essentially charged that Mr. Edwards is a hypocrite because, while Mr. Edwards has said he favors banning unregulated campaign money from outside groups, his campaign is getting millions of dollars worth of assistance from outside contributors — namely unions. What’s remarkable about this line of attack is that, while Mr. Obama is aiming squarely at Mr. Edwards, he also risks alienating some of the most powerful interest groups in Democratic Washington. In case you haven’t been paying attention, here’s what’s going on: several state chapters of the mighty Service Employees International Union have endorsed Mr. Edwards and set up an independent entity — the kind of so-called 527 that Edwards himself has decried in the past — to run ads on his behalf. They even hired his 2004 campaign manager, Nick Baldick, to oversee the operation. (The state and municipal workers union and Emily’s List are also in Iowa, dropping a lot of cash in support of Hillary Clinton.) Mr. Obama, the only one of the three leading candidates who hasn’t received a big union endorsement, has repeatedly called on Mr. Edwards to ask his labor friends to stand down. Mr. Edwards has responded by saying that he still opposes such groups in theory, but that he isn’t involved in the union effort and is powerless to control it.

headline: Could These Sound Bites Come Back to Bite?
text: KEOKUK, Iowa – There are usually a dozen television cameras and DV cameras recording Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign events, and one wonders if some of her remarks – taken out of context – could end up in a Republican attack ad someday.

headline: Across the World in 36 Hours
text: As I was recently reminded, there is no day of the year better for flying than Christmas Day. The roads are relatively clear, even in Los Angeles, and the planes are seldom full. Those unfortunates on duty in the airport and the skies join with those eccentrics who choose to take to the air in place of family festivities and make the terminal itself, the jet, a site for celebration. One year, on Christmas Day, a British Airways gate agent gave me, and even the friend who came to see me off, a free pass to the First Class lounge and an invitation to go wild. Few immigrations officers or security personnel (other than sniffer dogs) want to be cast as Scrooge, and gifts acquire a special meaning when they come from strangers.

headline: Robin Williams to Be Letterman Guest
text: “David Letterman has booked Robin Williams as the first guest on his late-night show when he returns to the air Wednesday night,” Bill Carter reports.

text: 2007 was the year of “Mad Men” — and “A Shot at Love with Tila Tequila.” It was the year of “The War” — and “Cavemen.” Television critics across the country have released their 2007 year-in-review lists, and while many of the picks are just common sense — did any list forget “The Sopranos?” — they paint a picture of a creative, confusing year.

headline: Welcome to the Big Time, Kid
text: DES MOINES — Sydney Rieckhoff, at nine years old a true cub reporter, has learned a big lesson about the media world she had thought she wanted to join.

headline: Bloggingheads: Party Realignments
text:
Robert Wright (l), author of "The Moral Animal," and Mickey Kaus of Slate's Kausfiles discuss how a reshuffling of coalitions could change the Democratic and Republican Parties.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Edwardses Take On Michelle Obama
text: EMMETSBURG, Iowa – It was the Edwardses versus Michelle Obama on the campaign trail today.

headline: A New Museum in Trajan’s Market
text: This fall, an ancient architectural gem called Trajan’s Market (Mercati Di Traiano), re-opened after a two year renovation. Unearthed from Rome’s hills only during the Mussolini era (1920s-30s) there is no proof that the structure ever actually functioned as a market. No matter.

headline: No Mail today, or Tomorrow or Ever
text: “Hey, Johnny, where are we going to put the mailbox?”

headline: Romney to Huckabee Supporter: Pizza?
text: INDEPENDENCE, Iowa—The Romney-Huckabee spat is starting to take on an aspect of the bizarre, even if it is great political theater.

headline: Blog Talk: Why Iowa?
text: O.K., so every political junkie is incorporating words like “caucus,” “Yepsen” and “Keokuk” into their vocabularies this week. But judging by the outspoken voices in the blogosphere, many of those folks aren’t too pleased about paying so much attention to Iowa.Readers here at The Caucus have been voicing their opinions after reading Adam Nagourney’s “On the Campaign” column, where our national political correspondent analyzed this question: “What if Iowa settles nothing for the Democrats?” Our readers, however, seemed more interested in why rural, racially homogeneous Iowa should even be in a position to make such decisions.

headline: Dreaming of Riding Weather to Come
text: A motorcycle show in Manhattan at the end of December is bound to be a flop, right? Well, judging by the crowd of riders lined up at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center last Friday, that would be a bad assumption.

headline: John McCain Writes for Glamour
text: Now that the year’s end is only hours away, we can pretty safely say this is one of the weirdest bylines we’ve seen all year: Senator John McCain for Glamour.

headline: Presbyterian’s Rocky Division I Road
text: The kind of season Presbyterian College is having in its first year of Division I basketball has been hard for even the coach’s wife to believe.
